reviews.review: A must see. We visited the Hermitage with our Road Scholar tour. Being on a schedule, our RS guide was able to provide a comprehensive tour and explanation of the highlights of this fabulous collection of art. If you're doing this on your own, you could easily spend a few days here. Housed in a separate building across the square, is the equally wonderful Impressionists collection which has a tremendous number of works by Picasso, Matisse, and others.Only negative was the understaffed main cafe in the Hermitage where it took seemingly forever to get through line to choose a salad or sandwich. I think the smaller "internet cafe" had the same offerings and has quicker service.

SHAMELESSLY OPULENT...Helped Bring on the Revolution!. The VAST sums of money spent on the Winter Palace and the Hermitage were deliberately designed to flaunt the wealth of the Romanov tsars: In doing so the grand rooms of the five linked by bridges buildings were filled with almost obscene amounts of treasures - mostly imported from Europe.Highlights must include the parquet floors, the chandeliers, amber, mirrors and furniture with pride of place going to the Renaissance paintings that included two da Vincis and 20 Rembrandts.Our three hour tour covered only a few of the 150 or so rooms and, amazingly, what we saw was the reconstructed version after the major fire in 1873 had destroyed so much of the vast interior. Clever Communists had saved the Hermitage from destruction during the Revolution and have since helped turn it into one of the biggest and richest tourist centres in the world..

Magnificent. Gold Gold all Around.. Splendor and Grandeur. The art and objects are impressive. The display of Silver, Carpets, Antiques and Art is awesome. Take the 600 Rouble Ticket and the Audio Guide.. Tickets available on Vending Machines too at the entrance so no lines for tickets. Just tender exact amount. Like 1200 ( 1000 + 100 + 100 ) for two people.Dont buy tickets for students/child below 18 years. Carry either a photocopy of the Passport or the Original.. There is a separate counter for issuance of tickets for such Free Tickets in the Building.

A wonder of art. My first time to St Petersburg and the must see Hermitage. It is so large and right now so much art is being moved about and into new and interim facilities that a guide is a good investment. Much of what we wanted to see had moved across the square and we would have not found it.The museum offers a behind the scenes tour, I would skip it. I have done this in other museums and it was great. Here it 25 minutes away and most of the really interesting stuff is in gas sealed rooms with solid doors so you see some minor items.

Worthwhile visit . Really enjoyable visit. No chance of seeing everything without sore feet but very enjoyable. No real queues and plenty to see. The enormity of the building impressive even before you start. Lovely cake at the cafes!

Amazing - a "must see". Plan to spend a day here. See all the big things - like the gold peacock clock, but allow yourself the time to linger over the paintings, the inlaid furniture, the fine carvings. It is well described in tourist guides.
Must see. Stunning architecture and interiors. Huge amount of unique exhibits, impossible to see everything in details in one day. Can rent audio guide supporting many languages.

Impossible Dream - Awake to Beauty beyond comprehension. So many reviews. Is it possible to provide a more compelling review. We visited with a private guide and gained entrance through the rear door, therefore no waiting. The guide knew of our interest in the hereditary succession of czars and rulers, so we spent a great deal of time with the portraits. This enabled a better understanding of the successions and the brutality of some of the czars in getting rid of opponents. But surely that was common in the times of royalty in any fiefdom. The guide then took us to the masterpieces of the museum, including the gold peacock and an overview of the famous paintings. To think that two Leonardo Da Vinci paintings are exhibited is quite astounding, with the Louvre in Paris, being the only other public museum to have more than one LDV.We were totally exhausted after three hours and could no longer absorb any more of the beauty and majesty of the museumJust looking at the floors, ceilings, walls, and lighting was enough to gauge the enormous cost and effort in building such an edifice.A must visit for any visitor to Russia, and I would add, it should be a must for anyone's bucket list.

Simply Stunning. The Hermitage is well known for it's massive collection of artworks which are mind blowing but the buildings themselves deserve special mention. In fact I enjoyed the structure as much or more than the art itself. Definitely spend several hours there preferably with a group for early (or after hour) admission to avoid the crowds. Prebooked tickets will avoid hours waiting in line especially in summer.
One of the 3 best museums of the world. The coleccion its impresive and the plaza outside its full of joy and a beautiful view of the enormous palace and the arc in front.

Overwhelming & Dazzling. Given the enormous amount of damage sustained during numerous wars and conflicts, this magnificent building and all it's artwork is a testament to a resilient city and a proud people to rebuild it. Tickets are timed but I doubt it would make much of a difference when you went, I suspect it's always crowded. The shear enormity of the collection is staggering, it's one of the worlds best museums for a good reason. We spent 6 hours and could have spent 6 days.

Very good and very bad. The Hermitage is one of a kind, stunning, remarkable. spectacular. And, it was so wildly overcrowded, I would have walked out if I had not had my own personal guide. Imagine those palatial, over-decorated rooms you see in the pictures with 1500 people crowded in and more arriving every minute. This was like a super-gigantic NYC subway car at rush hour. Honestly, no kidding, this is NOT a place for claustrophobes. I made a choice in advance that I am so glad I did. I hired a guide for me alone. I debated about the group guide for a mere six people. But it was money well-spent to have my own personal guide. Truly, would you go into the jungle without a guide? It was like that. She knew where a place to sit was, a window to cool off next to, in the oppressive heat of bodies crammed together, which cloak room was fastest. Now she knew a lot about the art, too, but OMG so much of being there was about navigating through the crush. She even got me into a room with fewer (I said fewer, not few) people and you can look at a superb Lucas Cranach while you are there. Btw, she also did the lining up for tickets and so on, but I'm not even counting that. I went on a Tuesday, not too early, but before noon. I asked if there were ever a less crowded time, heavy snow, January, midweek?The answer was no, definitely not. This was standard. I paid $100. for the guide and she was worth every cent.

Spectacular but very crowded. Must admit I was more taken with the building, floors, ceilings, etc than the artwork contained within. Really annoyed by "bloody tourists" who insist on taking selfies with a Da Vinci or a Van Gogh

Superlatives are not enough!. Do your own research & decide your priorities; you must or you will go nuts; it is simply overwhelming to see anything in depth & even attempt to get an overview both. We had a tour guide (note:not a DOCENT) who led a "speed-date" overview with occasional stops to soak in the grandeur of rooms and the masters (Rembrandt & Rennaisance). Across the palace square is the museum which houses the Impressionists & post-Impressionists (only recently opened). BTW; the architecture inside this building is modern & eclectic with clean WC!Despite the crowds, everything seemed reasonable & orderly.

just millions of masterpieces in the masterpiece. What you can say about the largest museum in Russia and the pearl in the museums' collection all over the world. Hermitage is a truly masterpiece. There are so many unique exhibits there, so you won't have enough time ever to see them all properly, even if you go (like me) there almost every week. The most important for me there,that's not just a museum with priceless art pieces, that was a Winter Palace for Russians Emperors. The whole neighborhood awakens in you Imperial spirit. If you don't have much time, just try to go through and see the interiors and the most outstanding masterpieces and don't forget to have a look to the ceilings and flooring, as both sometimes not less incredible than art and sculpture. If you want to see unique incredible art and how people lived time ago with great sense of taste, you must visit Hermitage... Actually you just must anyway :)

Just fantastic. We pre-booked tickets to avoid the queues and walked straight in which was excellent. There is so much to explore here that you want to allow plenty of time.The architecture is just as inspiring as the displays. We didn't take a guide as we only had 3.5 hours to get around and that was not long enough. It was a very long walk and totally worth it, if you get the chance to see it all then do. I am going back in December to see the other half!!!The displays are over 3 floors, there are lifts at different points in the building though central stairs were magnificent to walk up. It can get very busy any noisy with the groups however there are so many rooms you should be able to work around them. There is a late night on Wednesday's that is supposed to be quieterThe cloakroom was a bit of a melee and the staff not particularly helpful especially not in English, so if you can avoid taking extra bags or coats then you can avoid the cloakroom.This was ranked in the top 10 museums in the world by National Geographic and I totally agree!

Amazing place but Overwhelming. This visit was astonishing. The buildings themselves were magnificent with seemingly endless gilded decoration. We were in a group with a wonderfully knowledgeable guide for which we were grateful, but it was very crowded and actually you do not get to spend a lot of time in any rooms. The two Leonardo's were sublime little paintings and you can really look at them quite close. But in all you would need days to see anything in real depth. The impressionist collection is now held in another building within General Staff Headquarters across the Palace Square but we ran out of energy to take this on. Leaving and Getting your coats and bags can be a bun fight as numerous groups seem to do so at once. You have to see these buildings and maybe concentrate on just some of the art work.

Amazing. This place is wonderful. So much to see. Make sure you try and see your personal interests early as it's so easy to run out of time. out guide made an amusing comment regarding the KGB Babuschkas in every room. would be lovely if they smiled occasionally!

Fascinating Museum - gold and diamond rooms. This museum has basically EVERYTHING...so one needs to plan the visit carefully. We found a one day visit sufficient. The Gold room includes gold artifacts presented to the Tzar and family by visitors so the collection includes artifacts from ancient Egypt - on, but not personal artifact belonging to the Tzar family. The diamond room, on the other hand, presents personal artifacts belonging to the Tzar family. We took and English which was breathtaking. Our guide spoke superb English, was fluent and knowledgeable. Highly recommended!

So amazing, we visited there three times!. The Old Masters are fabulous. Go in the morning to avoid crowds. We were awe-struck by the impressionist paintings in the building across the palace square. Again, go early. Eat first because you cannot get back in if you leave, and there is no cafe within the ticketed area.

So much more than you can imagine.....must see. Be prepared to walk a lot....there is so much to see in the Hermitage and one day is not enough. You can do the quick stop tour, but even that was 3 hours for us as part of another tour. Lots of art work displayed in the museum...so plan carefully so you dont miss out on the major attractions. I would recommend going on a tour as they have planned times and they will narrate thru the tour. .

Strong Positives, Strong Negatives. Pro: 1) Advance ticket purchase and side entry worked perfectly. No queues, no delays. 2) Opulent interiors and a few pieces of interesting artwork. 3) Very good audio guide.Con: 1) Pickpockets 2) Rude, unhelpful staff, 3) Massive crowds - came in waves though, so there were quiet times to view rooms and displays. There was only one cruise ship in port and I can only guess what it's like when there are more.

Art work that can only be seen at museum.. Well worth going! Great, but go with a guide or go early. Long lines and very crowded in the summer. A guide can maneuver you to your interested works. It is a very large museum and and one could spend several days looking so plan your trip based on what you want to see.
SO much to see pace yourself. A must see and worth seeing with a guide to get a good understanding of everything. Also, October is a great month to visit

Hermitage museum in st petersburg. Amazing is an understatement for such a gem of a museum. The palace elegance was just jaw- dropping. Many paintings by masters also there. I particularly liked rembrandt's painting of the prodigal son
#1 in St. Petersburg. Of course this is must for visit. Once (or twice) in lifetime experience. Buy your tickets beforehand. Lots of rushing Chinese.

Spoilt by crowds . So sad to mark this amazing place so lowly but the crowd control needs serious work. You cannot possibly enjoy the incredible works of art with the masses of tour groups jammed in.Very disappointing

Amazing, but HUGE crowds. This is one of the most amazing places to see over 3 million exhibits and of course the actual building is amazing also. However I can't describe how busy and crowded the place was. It was literally shoulder to shoulder and mainly large groups of noisy chinese tourists. I have never thought of travelling to Russia in the winter, however I think this would be the only time you could visit this attraction and actually breath!

A must. Included in our 2 day Alla Tours Faberge Museum shore excursion ex Cruise terminal. Very beautiful but very busy. With a small group (16) we got to see a lot. Not to be missed. best with a guide who can explain so many things.

Awesome. Be mindful, we were on a tour and our time in each area was limited. LOTS of people everywhere we toured, and we were told,"this is slow time!" Choose your travel time carefully. It seems we never had enough time in each place, but did get the highlights.
amazing. talk to the hotel concierge and ask for a private tour option - totally worth the money. Otherwise you will be lost and miss out on something

What a world of wonders. Well, to summarize the state of the Museum in one sentence, I can say " If you spend one minute in front of one Exhibit, it would take at least three years to complete the lot". What a world of wonders, vast in size, originality and rarity in exhibits, it is very cheap to see them in here when you compare with other museums. This is a must once in a life time affair if do not have plenty of time in your hand. If you do have time at least a week is a fair time to spend to see all the buildings.

two days tour. As a part of a cruise in Baltic capitals we spent twoi days in st. Petersburg.We took a two days guided tour by a private company with Hebrew talking guidesOf course it is a too short tour but it was well organised an included most popular sites of the town.The giuide LEONID LANDA (e-mail:landa-l@mail.ru mobile: +7 905 202 84 49 ) is a lecturer in university and has very large and profound knowledge on history,economy,geography and many other fields.Since he spent his chikdhood in Israel he is aware of Israeli mentality which help him to make an interesting tour for Hebrew speaking people .

Impressive but not interactive. We found the Hermitage to be a magnificent building but the inside to be a bit of a let down, as we have come to expect in other museums around the world more interaction with the exhibits with not much in English and unable to decipher Russian.
must seen. Huge and impressive like every thing in Russia. The palace itself worth the visit! Pay attention to get lost in the museum

Great!. The Eremitage is not only great in dimension, but offers great insights in art, too. We spent a long, but happy day in the Eremitage starting with the winter palace, listening to the audioguide and enjoying both the impressive buildings as well as the art shown.After the Eremitage we went to the Administrator's building and spent another hour there.The only "disappointment" was the guided visit to the diamond room. While done with great enthusiasm abd knowledge, we felt the one hour (plus) tour was too long for what is shown. We prefered the Faberge museum not far from Newski prospekt.
A marvelous place. It's hard to describe without ruin for others just i'll say it's realy worth seeing. With all his different types of room grom archeology to russian art to french

spectacular inside and out. never seen such a wonderful collection of treasures under the one roof, comparable to the louvre. worth every minute of your time. the building itself is worth seeing. great location a real beauty

Absolutely brilliant. There are the great museums of the world and then there is the Hermitage, one of the oldest museums, and arguably the best, in the world. The museum was founded by Catherine the Great in 1764. Its collection comprises over 3 million items, only a small percentage of which are on display. I spent around 3 hours visiting the museum with no hope of seeing even what was exhibited. I got a good feel of the splendour that existed at the time of Catherine and a very strong desire to return to St Petersburg. We studied a guide before our visit and decided to view the "Russian Culture" exhibitions, as we have previously visited the British Museum (3) and the Louvre (2). We also viewed the "Palace Interiors" and much art displayed on the 1st floor. A visit to the Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace is a must when visiting St Petersburg, preferably spread over 2 days, if you can.

Unbelievable collection. We came on a tour with an highly educated guide and a small party. The collection is vast and varied, being amassed after the revolution from both the royal palaces and those of the nobility, particularly Peter and Catherine.The artwork was breathtaking, from Rembrandt to Reuben's and personally I enjoyed that the most. But there are treasures for all. From gilt decorated desks to priceless clocks.Just be prepared to walk long distances and jostle with other tourists.

Worth for the time and money. Beautiful even day time or night time, even outside or inside. I enjoyed every second spending. Really recommend to visit on Wed and Fri that it's open until 20:00. Please don't miss.

Should be a bucket list to do thing. Where to begin? First of all, we spent four amazing hours exploring it and managed to see some 20% of it, barely scratching the surface of the magnificence that is the Hermitage. Tickets can be purchased at the automated machines located in the inner courtyard, right before the "individual entrance" sign. That means no cue!! After purchase, pass to the right of the gigantic cue waiting to buy a ticket and enter, strolling :) Get a book guide or audio and a free map of the place, we kinda got lost a few times. The palace itself is a wonder beyond comparison, the Louvres being a pale shadow, both in elegance and richness. If you're an art fan, they have dedicated section and hallways split by school (French, Flemish and so on). If you're into archaeology and history like myself, head to the ground floor section on Roman, Greek, Assyrian, pre-Roman, Egyptian - it's amazing. Top floor house some Japanese, Indian relics as well. We followed a book guide and went through some must see rooms, ballrooms, the church!, apartments, library, the malachite room (wow), Alexander's hall and so on, i can write a book on this. Pay attention to the thrones rooms (there are two), the general first floor architecture and elegance, and forget about time. I think anyone who hasn't seen this wonder should make it a priority. Oh, and there is that golden mechanical peacock clock that gets everybody gapping in awe.

Winter Palace. Another Bargain, but beware if not Russian your ticket price is 2x's that of Citizens... the Palace is enormous and each room decorated with full royal splendor. One would say that the Czars were definitely resting in luxury.

A visit by an Independant Traveller. I arranged a guided tour through Marina Wilson Private Tours.Excellent highly knowledgeable guide named Irene. Was pleased to be able to stay till 9pm but after four hours one has information overload. This destination is a must see for anyone visiting St Petersburg
Wow place . The smell of history the beautiful structure the elegance the peace no words can describe this beautiful place. Really amazing.
Amazing.. Fully came up to all expectations.Mix of historical artefacts,history and art,all housed in magnificent buildings.A must to visit.
Surprising . You need a day to really appreciate the exhibits and artwork on display. Our time was limited but throughly enjoyed what we did get to see on our brief tour.

Best Museum. This is a large museum. The best museum in Russia. The art work was amazing. I also enjoyed the Egyptian exhibit as well. There are cafes available as well. Several gift shops too. It will take several hours to really see everything this museum had to offer. A definite when in St Petersburg.

In a word, WOW☺. The full name is State Hermitage Museum, and consists of six buildings in the main museum complex: Winter Palace, Small/Old/New Hermitage, and Hermitage Theatre. All are open to the public, but foreign visitors pay substantially more than nationals. Entrance is, however, free the first Thursday of each month. The museum complex is closed Mondays. The main museum, Hermitage, is one of the largest and oldest in the world, founded in 1764 by Catherine the Great as a private museum, which has been open to the public since 1852—a century before my birth.☺ Some sources cite Hermitage as the world’s second largest. With the world’s largest collection of paintings, Hermitage has more than 3 million objects. It’s said that if you spend three minutes admiring each object, you’d be here for 14 years! Classical and Egyptian antiquities, jewelry, prehistoric art, exquisite porcelain, and sculptures populate rooms with 25-foot ceilings. Each room is dedicated to regions of art, such as paintings by Dutch masters, Italian/Greek sculptures, and an amazing coin collection that dates to the crusades and medieval times. There’s far too much in this must-see museum to describe in a brief review, so I recommend visiting the museum’s website and find the ‘360 degree’ feature. This allows anyone at no cost to view individual rooms—without people gawking at these exquisite art objects. The only detraction I found was the hordes of people, as seen in some of the accompanying photos. I recommend a guided tour and arriving as soon as it opens. First visit the main Hermitage building, then Winter Palace, which has fewer visitors in the afternoon. A full day can be spent in each. Day? Make that a week!

Too much but cool. Probably it's the biggest museum in Russia. Its history is very impressive and great. Wonderful, royal, huge, breathtaking. it's a day excursion after which it's better to relax to digest all information you'll get. Really impressive and big. Maybe too big.

Very crowded even though it was the end of the tourist season. We visited with a tour guide (headsets) who really knew her stuff, so we were skillfully navigated around the crowds. But it was still very busy. My favourite exhibit was the mechanical bird; shame it wasn't operating, just a video.. There are just so many works of art in the Winter Palaces it could take you weeks to just walk past every one. A guide will ensure you at least see all the great works. If you are determined to go alone there are maps available. You will have to check in your coat and bag in the chaotic cloakrooms. Well worth a visit.

One of the best museum of the world . Don't miss it, together with Louvre they are by far the best museum of the world ... amazing building, fantastic collections . I was there several times and saw always different collections ... impressionists, deutsch paintings, classic Italian ... and of course many art objects coming from Czar personal collection ... I was every time going with guide that can help you to focus of specific period or type of art. You can find always guide available ready to go with you in private tout for few roubles, right after tickets they should be there proposing their service, and I always had good guides.Additionally the museum is in contant reform bringing back the brightness of this palace ... a must go

Best display of Art from all over the world.. Amazing to see so many Rembrandt van Rijn paintings in a gallary.Absolutely breath taking the wealth and collections on display.Our recent visit was a high-lite of our Holiday.Worth a visit and every penny!
2nd Museum of the world. it's very big. you should stay there one day, just for fast-visiting!enjoy paintings, ancient things and so on...don't forget to buy a guide book of museum in exit

Amazing Russian History. We went there before the official opening time to pass the long queues with tour company arranging it all, The Hermitage Museum is so large so beautiful you could spend years there and still not see every thing.

Visiting on the Free Day. I was lucky enough to be in St. Petersburg for the first Thursday of the month when the museum is free. I was told the free day is usually a mad house, especially in the busy, summer months but also that the crowds start to die down in October when I was there. I debated just paying to go on a different day since I don't do well with crowds but I ultimately decided to brave the crowds and get there early. The courtyard opened at 10am and the museum opened at 10:30am. I was in line at 9:40 and I was towards the front. I had my free ticket, coat checked, and was in the museum by 10:41. I happened to see the line outside around noon and it was insane... winding through the plaza. So if you decide to go on a free day, definitely make sure to get there early! From June to September I'd probably consider going on a different day.The museum is spectacular and particularly so because it's a palace. I did visit Tsarskoye Selo but if you don't have enough time for that day trip then the Hermitage itself is a nice palace experience. Do note that there is a separate second building, the General Staff Building, that houses the Hermitage's contemporary and 19th-20th century collection including Monet, Manet, Van Gogh, Degas, Picasso, Matisse, etc. It's the large yellow curved building across from the palace. There weren't many people inside so I imagine not many people knew about it. However, if you like impressionist or post-impressionist art, don't miss it.

A must see . The Hermitage Museum is one of the worlds largest museum with over 3 million works of art. From the minute you walk into the court yard you are in awe of how beautiful and big it actually is. To think this museum was meant for Catherine the Great and the mice's eyes only. Plan to spend a few hours here walking through the 5 building. This is a must see.

Even for the non artsies. I appreciate art but am not a fanatic by any means - but the range of items in this world renowned museum is enough for anyone to find items to appreciate. We had a tour here as part of our cruise but then stayed on after our bus left which everyone later wished they had done as they had no time to wander. Watch for pickpockets though in the cloak area - one of our tour party lost his wallet immediately.

Huge, with something for everybody, but very busy. A superb very varied collection housed in stunning buildings. However, be prepared for significant crowds, whose manners and ability to queue and take turns, are diametrically opposed to those of the English !! Although there are a number of information desks, not many are staffed, and those that are have are virtually all staffed by ladies who only speak Russian. We had a particular problem trying to obtain additional tickets for the diamond exhibition, constantly being told to apply online, when they were only available at the main ticket desk.

See it if you can. If you weren't interested in Russian and European history before, visit this amazing place and you will suddenly be researching so much. How did they have so much money to build such a wonderfully ornate and lavish palace; who really lived among such opulence...so much gold and so many works of art that in the end we were strolling past Rembrandts and Vermeers with hardly a backwards glance! We went at the end of the season in early October and it was perfect, no queues at the ticket office and could avoid the odd large Chinese tour party. Not sure what it would be like in late July though.

A must see for any Art lover.. This museum, former winter palace, is second to the Louvre in Paris with the most extensive art collections in the world. A must see for any art lover. Beautiful architecture, and great assortment of art. I liked the Art Nouveau collection, the Egyptain collection, the Medieval relics, and the Impressionism and Post Impressionism collection.

Hours and Hours of Joy. This is a wonderful museum in St Petersburg. The moment you walk into the museum and walk up the staircase you are in another world! Good idea to get a guide if you only have limited time as they will tell you all the very interesting history. There are Rembrandts and a couple of paintings by Leonardo da Vinci, Rubens and many more ....

Overwhelming ..................... Maybe it was out tour guide "Natasha" while extremely knowledgeable on EVERY piece of art work inside the Hermitage 3 1/2 hours of art history is more than anyone can begin to understand and or absorb - room after room - the Hermitage contains 300,000 pieces of art work - Natasha missed telling us about 3 of them. Wish I could recall just a little of what all she had to say.A tour of this museum is not for the slightly disabled - lots of steps and hall ways. There is a metal detector - just in case you have a pace maker etc. For the TRUE ART LOVER - what a treasure of master pieces from the world over....for the not so art lover - well 3 1/2 hours was more than plenty of time .....
Checking out the museum!. So good, very busy but understandable with how much their is too see. Recommended for anyone who has time to check it out!

A labyrinth worth exploring. By tickets from the ticket machines or online to avoid the long lines. Get a free map of the place.This is a collection of five buildings and it is said if you spend 8 hours a day just looking at each exhibit for one minute, you'll need 15 years to finish viewing them all, so it's important to be selective!The map didn't really help as directions weren't clear enough, thankfully lots of seats for tired feet offered much-needed respite. There were also enough toilets, cloakrooms and cafes for taking breaks.Definitely worth a visit, just be prepared for hordes of noisy tourists photo-bombing you, also be prepared to spend at least a day in this amazing place.

BEAUTIFUL ART & ARCHITECTURE. My place was definitely the highlight of my SPB tour here! The architecture was tremendous and the the paintings were beautiful! I took way too much photos of the architecture! Too think of the immense amount of talent and patience that people had back in the days is moving! Unfortunately, we were not able to spend that much time here as we were only here for a day (as part of a cruise stop).

An absolute must see. Cannot be missed. One of the most beautiful days of my life, well - two days! We had to come back the next day as we didn't have time to see everything on the first day. So many magnificent pieces of art but what struck me the most is the interior of every room - all so unique and wonderful. The gift shop has many many excellent books and no tacky souvenirs.
Worth the Entrance fee. You will spend hours and hours at this place. There are a lot of things to see. Don't miss the show of the Moving Golden Peacock/Owl/Rooster in one of the wings.

Never enough time!. Went with group and audiovox devices (essential for listening to guides). This is must see museum. Allow a full day. Wear comfy shoes. Gift shop has high quality souvenirs-hard to find in this city.
Fabulous. Been 2 days to the Hermitage, wanted to go again, it is Fabulous! Both the architecture of the buildings and the expositions are amazing

SPB tour of State Hermitage and Museums. Extraordinary experience with our SPB guide Nikolas. This building is opulent from start to finish. He got us in before the huge crowds and we had the chance to enjoy these buildings. We still marvel at the wealth of these places. Gold everywhere and such fine furnishings. To be seen to be believed!

Do Not Miss. I ran out of adjectives on my visit. Every new room we went into - and there was so many - were more fantastic than the previous! My husband & I are not "museum" fans usually, but loved this! Do not miss it!

A visual treat. We concentrated on the Hermitage's French impressionist art - a beautiful collection... Then we roamed the building and spent time admiring the architecture and colors of the rooms in the Palace. It's a visual treat.
We were told that if you spent 10 seconds in front of each painting it would take you 8 years to see it all.

Stunning Hermitage Museum. This you can't miss on a visit to St. Petersburg. You will need a full day here and go before the cruise ships arrive with the tourists. The staircase is splendid and leads you to the hundreds of rooms with the many displays exhibits, paintings, etc. I love the room with peacock clock. the hallways the ceiling, the architecture is magnificent. From the square outside you are overwhelmed with splendour

Once a Week Only. The Peacock Clock automaton is a must within a must. Now reopened but missed it this time, as it was under Restoration. It only happens once a week at a specific time to preserve it (used to be at 7pm on Tuesdays. or was is Wednesdays? when saw it in Oct. 2014). Worth inquiring to pick your day of visit in order to see this beautiful clock adorned with mechanical birds, originally purchased by Catherine The Great, in action. We were lucky in 2014 as we did not know about it. Before leaving the museum, we decided to enjoy one last time the gorgeous golden pavilion with garden, which hosts this beautiful piece, and walked into a crowd starting to assemble. We admired this remarkable machinery at work--one of these moments when one is filled with wonder at the incredible artistry and mechanical genius. I was curious about the "competition" with the Louvre. Hermitage is one of the most beautiful museums in the world indeed, but with its unbeatable collection and stunning modern entrance through the glass pyramid, the Louvre remains the greatest.

Magnificent!. If you don't see anything else in St. Petersburg, make sure you see the Hermitage. Definitely a bucket list item. Not just an art museum, a stunning palace and piece of world history. Avoid the crowds by going off season (if you can), or invest in a private guide and VIP entry to skip the sometimes 2 hour lines to get in during summer.

Malachite and Lapis. It is difficult not to give this place a really good rating. It is simply a huge collection of all things wonderful. A feast for your eyes, wherever you keenly look ……or simply just happen to see. Absurd to think you can adsorb it all in one visit.Today it was impossible for me not to be overwhelmed with the craftsmanship of all the inlays; all the incredible inlayed wooden floors, wall panels and furniture. But, I was constantly distracted by the concentration of lapis and malachite columns, tables and vases of such depth and vibrancy of color, and how those little pieces of raw material can be honed and polish and assembled into amazing decorative pieces of such grand scale.So much to see, so little time.

A must see in St Petersburg. The Hermitage is simply beautiful. A must see. The winter palace is gorgeous. Expositions are well kept and beautifully displayed. You would need at least 2 days to adequately cover it.

Beautiful. This museum is just beautiful... absolutely everything about it is gorgeous. The collection is very interesting and they keep everything in great condition, the place is very clean considering thousands of people walk in everyday. Only bad thing I can say is some of the staff aren't friendly at all, one of the security guards at the entrance was rather rude and unfriendly, that didn't ruin the day... we really enjoyed everything we saw in here. It's also nice everything else you can do near this museum, be patient the lines can be slow.

Wow. Went on a group tour with our cruise ship. We had been told that it could be busy. Our tour had a timed entrance. We went in and there were very few people around. What a wonderful building and amazing art. Many WOW moments. In one room there was a choir singing, wonderful!

OMG.... Amazing . The hermitage is the most beautiful place to see... full of the most precious heritage from arround the world. Lots of the painting. .. jewelry. ... gold.... memorials.... states. ... from diamond room to the ball room to the chambers full of history and rich heritage. We had the chance to visit the diamond room with our guide Julia (very knowledgeable tour .... not to miss) than we had our time to see almost all of the museum. Than we had our second tour to the gold room with our guide Anna (very knowledgeable tour... not to miss).The hermitage is soooo big you need more than 6 hours to cover it all.Fees: general entry was 600 rub. Diamond room fees was 300 rub.Gold room fees was 300 rub. You can have some pictures from the inside.

All you expect and more!. Knowing that this is considered together with El Prado and the Louvre on the three top art museums in the World won't prepare you for the experience. Just walking the four buildings that comprise the museum will take you more than a day. If you want to admire selected paintings, schedule a week. I recommend you take a 5 hour private tour of the highlights and then return to enjoy your favorites. I particularly enjoyed their collection of Spanish and Dutch masters and their Impressionists and post Impressionists paintings (located in the Administration Building across the plaza.) This museum by itself, is worth the trip to Saint Petersburg.
An absolute highlight of a visit to St. Petersburg. The "grandeur" of the palace and the collection is overwhelming and beautiful . Take your time because it's a gigantic musuem !

Its a must see place in St.Petersburg. if you are in St.Petersburg take at least 1 day and walk around take a look at this great collection of art. You will have a desire to come back. This is one of the best if not the best museums of the world, and I believe it has larger European art collection than Louvre

Massive. The Hermitage museum is amazing - so much to see. The museum is also free for students, so well worth it if you have a student card. If you don't want to spend the entire day wandering around a museum, I recommend getting a tour guide, otherwise, there is so much to see and the maps are pretty informative on what is in each section so if you get sick of paintings you can move on. The museum can be rather daunting due to it's size, so make sure you eat before, as the café is rather overpriced inside the museum.
Must Do. This is a place where you really need to spend a large amount of time. One day is simply not enough. It is on my list to re-visit.
Great collection. An amazing museum, the interior of the museum is almost as beautiful as the art collection. Obviously a must see, very crowded though.

World Class museum. Try to make it at least a whole day.. We were fortunate to gave 9 days in St Peterburg and went to the Hermitage 3 times. We had a private guide who took us around for over 6 hours and showed us the highlights of this vast museum..which is really in 4 separate attached palaces. He was a great docent sharing his knowledge of the art. I don't really see how an individual by themself could possibly take it all in. We saw many large tour groups who had 20-40 people trying hear what their guides were saying. We went a second time paying $300 each for the tour of the diamond room and the good rooms. These are very limited tours, but to say it was overwhelming is to put it mildly. My advice here is to only do the diamond room (it has a lot of gold tin it). The gold room is more of a history of the Russian people thru the gold jewelry they created over the centuries. It was also overwhelming..but after 45 intense minutes with the diamonds, we had a hard time focusing for another 45 minutes with the gold. You cannot move thru these rooms at your own pace. You have an English speaking guide and a Russuan guide and the whole tour was the Russian speaking and then the English speaker translating. We felt rushed..but it was so worth it.After this tour we were already in the Hermitage so our guide took us to see the Rembrandts. We returned to the museum on Sunday night to see the ballet Swan Lake in Catherine's theatre. Very nice performance. Try to stay in St Petersburg for several days and especially spend a whole day at the Hermitage with a private guide. You will learn so much if you do it this way.
STP CITY TOUR. The museum is very huge.. nice and history. A lot's of group are queing and make sure you do not bring any big bag ( need to put in at loaker room). Come visit in the early morning.
Classy and worth seeing in ST petersburg. It´s worth going there when you´re in St Petersburg. It´s filled with history and gives a bigger understanding of Russia and all it´s history.

Stunning - An absolute must do. This is an experience not to be missed whether you are an art lover or not. The Palace is spectacular and the collections breathtaking. I do recommend you go with a guide to get the full history of this wonderful place.

Possibly the Finest Art Museum in the World. This is another St Petersburg attraction where we were well aware that crowds and lines would be a problem so we booked a private tour with local Alla tours and had a no wait no line entry. Our guide also managed the speed of our tour to let pushy loud groups past and keep us in a fairly quiet relaxed window. This is a little more expensive but again is well worth it to maximize your museum time. Our guide also said the collection is so big that if you spent just 30 seconds looking at each exhibit it would take 15 years to see the museum so accept that you're not going to see everything. There is a very nice multi floor museum plan map that you can get in several languages that can assist you in seeing what collections are a priority for you. In our case our guide took us directly to what we wanted to see. Shortly after Catherine the Great had her husband killed and took power she began to rapidly advance Russia. Other European capitals had centuries of head start in collecting state art collections. If Russia was to be a great empire it was great to win battles, extend territory and sign treaties. But she would need great palaces, culture and art to be like other European capitals. There was no time to pick individual paintings so she bought every collection available and now here they are for us to see. This is one of the finest art museums in the world and if you want to maximize your museum time I strongly recommend a private tour operator like Alla tours.

Night time tour was fun!. Got to go on a night time private tour. Was very nice to be able to come here when nobody else is around. Got to spend lots of time and was able to look at a lot of the artifacts on display. Truly was an interesting place.

Awe inspiring. We were lucky enough to to have a local guide as part of a small group tour as she pointed out all the main exhibits. You could easily spend the whole day or just keep coming back over several days - there is so much to see. Didn't have time to go to the new art museum - next time!

Absolutely Grand. The Hermitage Museum is an absolutely grand place to visit in St. Petersburg. It is a museum of art and culture and is over 200 hundred years old. It was Catherine the Great who started the museum in the 18th century. Her collection is impressive. She had over four thousand paintings, and a great collection of coins, medals, books, furniture, mirrors, vases, ceramic items and drawings etc. The Hermitage Museum is located along Palace Embankment.There is so much to see – that it will probably take you more than one visit to see everything. The museum items are actually housed in six beautiful buildings. Our guide said that there were over three million items in the museum. This museum is extremely popular – and so you have to get used to the crowds. I would recommend that you go in a group – as groups have priority and are allowed entry earlier than the official opening time.There is a grand staircase that leads up to the upper floor. As you climb up, you will be amazed by the ornate decorations. Each room seemed even more grandiose than the previous one. I was amazed by everything I saw. There was a lot of prehistoric art. There was also art from Italy, Holland, UK, Egypt, Germany, France, Switzerland, Russia, Spain etc. There were Impressionist paintings too. Catherine’s rooms were simply stunning in every respect. They were awesome. The opening hours are 10.30 am to 18.00. On Wednesdays and Fridays the museum closes at 9pm. Entrance fees for each adult is 600 Rubles (equivalent to GBP 7.50 Aug 2016). School children, students and pensioners pay half. There is free entry to all on the first Thursday of every month.Photography is allowed - but you cannot use the flash.You should plan to spend an entire day in The Hermitage. You will love it.

One of the greatest Museums in the world. Differently from other great museums, where the objects are by far the main attraction, it is the Winter Palace that dominates the experience of visiting this amazing collection. In some of the rooms you can easily imagine grand balls, state receptions, intrigues, etc.. The collection is world class in almost every aspect it covers. Be prepared to share this wonderful experience with hordes of other visitors. You can only hope that they get something out of it, as much as you will.Plan your visit in advance using the helpful virtual visit in the website, and do not even think that you can see it all in a day or two. Buy tickets on the web to avoid very long lines at ticket office. Two days consecutive ticket is a good option for most people.

This museum is famous for a reason. Hermitage museum is huge. In order to see the most important things (without a guide) you need 4 hours. In order to see the whole thing then you need 8 hours!As a result, you need to have a plan of what to see before your visit. My itinerary was the following (numbers correlate to rooms):198-->189, 333-->327, 204-->229-->254-->244 (with all the intermediate rooms you will come across inbetween), 109-->128Actually you can witness the whole european history in this museum and with only 600 rubles. You may buy an e-ticket but the price is double (plus it is in USD!).After entering the museum you can have for free a map of the museum (available in many languages)

Too big to be true!. It's the biggest museum I've ever been to, I spent 9 hours in it and felt like I was gonna die from tiredness! The Museum and Palace were beautiful, huge and full of arts. If you wanna enjoy ALL of arts and exhibitions inside, I recommend you to spend 2-3 days in this museum so you can slowly appreciate them. BUT if you have only one day or half day in this HUGE museum, I recommend you to take a look at the information about all exhibitions and choose what you REALLY want to see, then go for it. You can also use the ticket for Hermitage to enter the General Staff Building at the opposite side of the square for free. The art and exhibition there were quite modern and easier to understand, and I enjoyed it more than in Hermitage. Tips: Book the ticket via the internet before hand so you don't have to wait in line for the ticket in front of the museum. And book it in the Russian Page not the English one because the ticket will be cheaper!! Ask the staff at the hostel or hotel to help you deal with this!

great and very nice pics, long time spent here. WOW it is just such wonderful, museum, plan on spending a very long time in here, from the lines to the tour inside, of course impossible to see everything in one day it reminded me of the Louvre, where you simply cannot take so much in in such a short time... hpurs just fly by and there is still more and more to see...beware of the pickpocket mayhem they really are everywhere even inside the museum... i was warned many times and I was careful but then I did see these guys trying to get into some tourists bags a couple of times... right in front of us... both times They failed cause once the guy's bag had a zipper or was closed somehow so they didnt get anything and the second time the lady had some sort of scarf tied around the bag so it made it difficult to reach the inside... anyway they are so fast when they try to get in your bag I just couldnt believe it when I saw it ...and they they are gone just like that dissapear between the crowd in seconds....and they look like another tourist too... so not so easy to spot them. the souvenir store is worth a visit too. many simple inexpensive little souvenirs to take home If you want to remember the trip, and sure you will!

Absolutely must see!. The Gem of Museums in Russia - wonderful! Watch out for pickpockets - the desperadoes know visitors have money and credit cards! Despite all the cameras watching tourists for vandals, the pickpockets appear invisible!

Crazy beautiful!. WOW, OMG and are you kidding me! Fabulous and unbelievable are not overused to describe this museum. Just go! I would recommend the early or small tour group, worth the price. The Nazis left Moscow and SPB destroyed after the war. The Russian government and the public have done a gargantuan job of restoring this palace to pristine condition. It took decades and it was worth the time, money and effort. It's mind boggling how the Tsars lived.

Must see in St Petersburg. Fabulous collection and terrific reconstruction. Also new art museum is wonderful--impressionists. The gold work and other work in rebuilding is great. There is so much to see. You need good guide which we had from SPB tours and you need a guide book to help you remember what you have seen. Plus do so research before hand.

World Class. This is one of the world's great museums and you don't want to skip this when visiting the city. Since it is world famous you can expect a lot of people. You will need to check coats, backpacks, umbrellas, water bottles, etc in the cloakroom before entering so best to not bring unnecessary items. Photos are ok, without flash. The museum is full of priceless objects, and the buildings themselves are architectural treasures as well. Don't expect to see everything. They told us that if someone wants to see every item on display they could only pause a few moments, and then it would still take years. This place is huge, so figure out ahead what you want to see and spend as much time as you can. But don't be disappointed that you don't get it all.

Hermitage. We were not specially waiting to see this museum and we only went there because all churches are locked in Wednesdays. But we were really surprised with all it had to offer and specially the ornamented roofs in each room. Fantastic!

Spectacular. Incredible collection - impossible to take in much in one visit. Very crowded and lines for everything. A guide or audio-tour is smart but doesn't expose you to much more than high-lights. Allow yourself a couple visits. Research before visiting if it's important to see particular items.Coat check is frequently required. No charge but scarily crowded and time consuming. Interior photography allowed (no flash). Don't touch the rope barriers in the palace rooms - they will set off an alarm - mild but disconcerting.

Stunning. Amazing museum, beautiful building, fabulous visit spoilt only by the hoards of Chinese visitors who have no manners, no concept of personal space and just barge in front of everyone with no respect to take their turn!
Student. As student you don't need to pay for the museum. But you can't change from building one hour before closing time because the cash desk is already closed.
Unbelievable!!. The City of St. Petersburg, Unicef and the Russian authorities should be proud!! The collections are from all over the world and all the Masters are represented. Another MUST SEE!
Magnificent grandeur. Lots of wow factors in this vast building and is best seen with a tour guide as the building so extensive. The magnificence has to be seen to be believed.
Beautiful museum!. One of the most beautiful musea I have never visited. You need more then one day to see it all. Definitely worth the visit!
riggers and the white rabbit. this is an absolutly breath taking place this rooms are unbelieveable each one surpasses the last from floor to ceiling

must see one of the world grandest museums !!!!!. I went to the "hermitage" without an advance online reservation. in the courtyard there are machines where you can buy the ticket . a combined ticket to the hermitage and the annex across the street is around 9$. there is a huge line to get in but I found out that there are side entrances where you go in with no line and surprisingly few people notice it and use it !! the museum is huge and has 3 millions items . I am most interested in paintings, Russians and Europeans and skipped other sections due to time concerns . I did of course the royal rooms and the hall where the provisional government was arrested by lenin in 1917 .I have been to the museum 24 years ago and its my second time and I love it !!! you can not visit st Petersburg without visiting it !!! a must must see !!!!!!!!!!

Huge and filled with treasures. Plenty to see in the Hermitage. Get a good guide book, so you know what you want to see and where to find it otherwise you will be wandering for hours. It is everything they say it is.

A Must See in St Petersburg. This tour was fantastic even though we only had a few hours to view. You could take a week to view all the fine works of art and experience the history. We truly enjoyed the museum
Interesting. Very interesting,but also very crowded,you have to be aware of pickpockets,but all in worth seeing,some of the rooms are beautiful and also the artwork

One of the best museums you will ever visit. If you love art and baroque architecture, you will be in awe of the Hermitage from the moment you enter and see the main (Jordan) staircase. Not only is the art collection amazing, so is the building and galleries themselves because this once was a functioning palace that served as the imperial residence. The Pavilion Hall with the peacock clock was my favourite. Our afternoon tour only covered a small portion of the museum, you literally need weeks to cover it properly. We came back to the Hermitage Theatre that same night to watch the ballet which was magnificent. Do not miss this gem of a place if you plan a trip to Saint Petersburg.
Best Museum I have ever visited. Its not just wants displayed in the Museum its the winter palace of the Romanov Tsar dynasty. The palace decorations are mind boggling.

A must visit. One of the most amazing places I've ever been to, shouting art, history, culture and luxury..Definitely not a place you can cover over one visit, especially if you wanna stop and appreciate the never ending pieces of art around you.IMPORTANT: count for the waiting time on the queue for tickets, we went twice, one time we've spent over 3 hours... by the time we got in we were already tired and late..

Opulent palace, very busy place so be patient. Opulence is an understatement. The guilding, carvings, wood floors, antiquities are absolutely amazing. Mind you, most of St. Petersburg royal homes are of this quality which is why this city is such an amazingly beautiful city. Well worth the visit but skads of visitors, particularly tour groups. Groups go through with private microphones though so we did not find the noise level too much. The grounds are fantastic.

Amazing a must. Fantastic soo much art which cannot be seen outside of this museum. Very busy lots of other admirers of art. On top of that the palace in which the art is displayed adds to the beautiful art.

Beautiful inside and out. The Hermitage museum is both magnificent in the art collection as it is in the architecture of the palace itself. I highly recommend that you higher a private guide as they will be able to take you to the important paintings and guide you easily through the museum. This place is so large you will be overwhelmed without a guide!

Great Building with 3rd Class Art. I have wanted to visit the Hermitage for years. I had heard it was comparable to the Louve in Paris or Prada in Madrid. So my wife and I took a River Cruse from St Petersburg to Moscow. First of all this was in August and maybe the AC was not working but it was very crowded and "warm". The building itself was very nice but it had been built as a residence and had no natural flow. Therefor you were forced to fight you way into a room and try to view the displays and then fight your way back through the same small door. To get to Russia you have to have a visa and to get a visa you have to get background check by Russia. It cost my wife and me $500 each to get the visa after filling out a 6 page form. Russia knows more about me now than the FBI. I mentioned this to our guide and she said the US does the same to Russians wanting to visit America. One of her questions on the US form was "Have you engaged in prostitution within the last 10 years?"

Top of the Line museum & palace.. Visited this amazing place with a tour, which is the way to do it -- tours can get in an hour early if prearranged before general public is admitted. Allow 2-4 hours for a quick tour, or all day if you want to read all the description plates. A guide can show you the highligts, reveal the history, and get you to the right displays. Many WC's on premise, a sitting area in the entrance lobby for 50+ people for those needing a break. If you go past 10:30 am, be prepared for long lines for entrance, and masses of people on the inside. I entered on a Sunday and plenty of locals visit as well. Plan this event carefully and allow time for history & culture to grow upon you. One of St. Petersburg's top places!

So much to see, so little time. One must not miss the Hermitage Museum on your Baltic Sea trip. Our travel guide Maria with TJ Travel did an outstanding job of showing us all of the highlights. This museum would be impossible to tour independently due to the vast amount of art. Yet Maria gave us a wonderful overview of the Museum taking us through the maze of artisans to view the more famous ones. One must not miss the Museum, the only one like it in the world. Dick and Brenda Young

Absolutely an amazing experience!. This is one of those amazing experiences....the buildings themselves are impressive, stunning floors, ceilings, staircases and doors.....and then there is the amazing contents of priceless art and artifacts....a must see when in this beautiful city. We bought a two day ticket online and in advance....definitely better than queuing up, but be warned the two days must be done consecutively and there are no pass outs given. You can however move from one building to the other....but only once per day. This is quite restrictive as you cannot take food or water into the buildings (must be left in a locker inside the entrance after going through the security check). There is a coffee shop/café inside but you may be a long way from this facility depending on where you are and who really wants to spend their time in this amazing place sitting drinking coffee?! Suggest having a break when moving from the Winter Palace to the General Staff Building. Our favourite section was probably The Impressionists located in the General Staff Building across the square.....they don't seem to be as strict there about water (keep it discreetly in a large handbag) and nowhere near the number of visitors....perhaps people don't know about it! Make sure you take your camera, photos are fine, just no flash, which is very fair. It is quite warm inside....wear layers so you don't feel uncomfortable.....you can't go outside and back in. Considering the number of visitors, the toilet facilities are few and far between, with long queues...even the men had to line up! One final tip...suggest you buy two separate day entry tickets and have a day or two break in between to give your senses a break, it really was quite overwhelming as there are just so many amazing sights to take in....absolutely incredible!

A vast collection of arts that would take weeks to see. Hermitage is a vast museum and it has a vast collection. As you enter you eyes are treated to a rich architectural details favored by Catherine the Great. I don't know why she is called Great. To my mind someone who kills her husband and builds a glitzy palace full of bling at the expense of people is not Great! Anyway that is what you will see as you enter. You will see a marvelous world of gilded walls and halls. Inside the collection is vast. Italian masters, French masters and Russian modernists: they are all there. The trouble is that this museum is too crowded. There are so many groups coming in that you cannot stand before a painting for 5 minutes before you get pushed out by a group or a guide. I kept trying but gave up after a struggle for 3 hours. If you really want to see the paintings do inquire for a quiet time. But then you must speak Russian to find out!

Lots of walking and stairs but worth it. I think I was more intrigued by the palace itself than the items on exhibit, That is not to say that the Hermitage doesn't have stunning exhibits. We were told that only 5% of the collection is on display at any time and this museum encompasses 4 very large buildings. To say the collection is varied is an understatement. There is something for everyone to love here. It is stunning, amazing, intriguing and overwhelming,
Must see the Amber room. This is a must see when in St Petersburg, Russia. The Museum and its history is most important to see, but the art that was collected by Catherine the Great is there as well.

Nice and nicer. Got there on a rainy day, the line to the tickets was long. Fortunately the self service ticket machine did work and we passed the line in an instant. In side you are not allowed to visit with back bags so what stored them in an automatic free locker (again, no line there).Place is beautiful, every other room is a WOW.Had a wonderful three hours .
WONDERFUL. Great museum and palace, you need several days to see the whole thing, but go even for a few hours, see the rooms and as many galleries as you can

Must spend a day here!. I arrived in the museum at noon, thinking only spending 2 hours there, but ending up with staying there for 4 hours!! So many collections and treasures, full of histories and stories. The museum was a palace itself, so in addition to the invaluable artworks and historical objects, the rooms are worth visiting...and taking lots of photos!!It's a magnificent museum, and definitely worth taking your time to visit!

What lovely architecture !!. You will fall in love with the architectural beauty of this place. The barouq style design of this place. The extensive use of white and gold and the statues. They all will mesmerize you. Be thr once you are in St. Petersburg.

Epic Collections of Arts & Architecture . We were visiting this Museum as a part of the group tour. With a local guide, walking us through the highlights in two hours. Then on our own for another two hours. Just not enough time to be awe in every corner of this massive palace.This museum needs another three full days to a week to wonder on our own time. This museum puts the Paris Louvre to shame. A must do !!! Wear comfortable shoes. Go early.

An amazing experience. There are not enough words in my vocabulary to adequately describe the Hermitage. It is simply amazing and a must see for any visitor to St. Petersburg. The real problem is that there is not enough time, even with a 3 or 4 hour tour. The place is huge and treasures are beyond belief.

Overwhelming but necessary. Much bigger than I expected! We spent a few hours there but were only able to see a fraction. Particularly enjoyed the ancient mummy, the old armoury and the paintings. It can get very busy so get a guide rather than trying to do it alone. Well worth a visit but wear comfy shoes!

Must visit . ...while in St Petersburg. But make sure you will reserve the whole day for it. It's huge and needs time to discover all the beauty and art it hides inside itself. I would suggest to buy tickets in advance (there is internet option I believe), because in the time of high season the line can take a while. If you don't have the whole day, then make a tour on the second floor.

Incredible. I visited the museum on a tour of the city for five hours. We had a guide and I would strongly recommend that you not visit the attraction on your own. This was my favourite museum I have ever been to in my life. I recommend it most highly.

Huuge museum . The museum is one of the biggest museums that I've ever been to. It has everything related to art. I recommend everyone who goes there to have either a map or a tour guide since if u enter by urself without knowing where to go u'll end up getting lost. All the pieces are wonderful but so similar to each other. A person should be very advanced in art to be able appreciate it. It's deformed a place to be.

An Absolute Must!. You cannot miss this attraction when you visit St Petersburg. The wealth and power Russian Tsars had in the past is really beyond imagination! We did queue for a while (30-45mins) to get tickets so you might want to consider getting the tickets in advance. But definitely a must visit! The palace itself is so so luxurious. Can't believe a commoner like myself can get to see it. Plan at least half a day to visit!!

wonderful! not to be missed. Lots of things to see so buy a two-day entrance ticke and a private guide.Be there early so that not many visitors are there and you can walk around easily. the museum cafeteria is not bad if you are going to spend the whole day and need a break

Tour of the Hermitage . Well obviously it's mind blowing! I'm a history buff and this was amazing for me. From the staircase to the throne - wow!Just be prepared. It's a lot of walking and a lot of stairs. There are cafes on the ground level and by the end you'll need to visit - you're not allowed bottles of water on your way round and you'll be thirsty! There aren't really enough loos and there are always queues. Just be prepared.

Amazing place and breathtaking exhibition. Even if you have very limited time as we had, do yourself a favor and visit the Hermitage for at least 2-3 hours. It's a gorgeous palace with amazing masterpieces. They have kiosks where you can buy tickets with credit cards without the enormous lines. If you have kids with you, after obtaining adult tickets at such a kiosk, go straight to the entrance where you'll get free admission tickets for children. Make sure to bring their documents to confirm age or student status. As for the inside of the museum, the entrance and closest/main rooms are usually very crowded. However, many outermost rooms have very few people in them, while keeping the artistic values of closer rooms.

A must do. One visit isn't enough. Neither is two or three. This place is enormous so try to look it up first so you know what you want to see. I had a guide for half a day and it was well worth it as she knew her way around so,I didn't waste time. I went back two days later and spent a few more hours looking at other things. This is one of the greatest museums in the world and with such a rich history behind it. Make the effort to,go, and try to spend more time there. I recommend having a guide, but if not, at least buy tickets on line to avoid the interminable queue, and you get to,use a side entrance with a very short waiting time. This ticket also gives you 10% discount in th gift shop at this entrance only.
Spectacular. Within the stunning Winter palace this enormous priceless collection of millons of items has to be seen to be believed.You can easily spend more than half a day here and it is crowded.

Great.. Was on a tour so ended up going through it a little too fast in most places and a little too slow in a few others. But an amazing collection of diverse artifacts from across Europe and Egypt. Beautiful building and interior. Be ready to stand in line and don't bring big bags or coats as you have to check them.

WOW. This museum is amazing , there is something different to see around every corner and in every room.I would suggest you try to book into the "gold room tour", it is well worth the visit.They say if you spent one minute to look at every exhibit in the museum it would take 11 years to see everything...and I would believe it.So don't expect to see everything, plan your visit and be prepared to walk a lot and go up and down many staircases.It is like something you have never seen before and a place that you certainly could visit on more than one occasion.

Visit the home of The Tsars. A huge Place set on the Banks of the River. Get there early before the Chinese invasion.Good to view the palace where the Romanovs controlled Russia. Huge rooms and furniture and paintings
A must see. If time allows suggest you go twice or more so that you can see things in more depth and that YOU want to see rather than the things you guide wants you to!

Gold, gold and more gold. We went on a night tour organised by the cruise ship, Holland America.There were a few tours but it was not that crowded. We were able to go through the place at a pleasant pace and could see anything on displayed with clear view.My first impression was GOLD, gold was almost everywhere. However, there were many great art works: paintings, sculptures and precious gemstones made into tables and vases. The tour guide said you need to spend 10 years to go through all the objects displayed in the Hermitage but there were more in storage.When you are in St Petersburg, go to visit the Hermitage, preferably at night. Also, wifi was free for 15mins, very good speed, log back in for another 15mins when you're kicked out, they didn't check if you've already logged in before.

wow, just wow. This is one big, big museum. The parts showing russian history was not really interesting and also hard to follow due to that most information on there was only in Russian. In the part showing the art it was much better. If you visit Saint Petersburg you of course must visit this place. I would advice to take a guided tour, without it you might walk around randomly for hours and hours :)

Don't visit in peak season if you don't like crowds. We visited in September and it was still busy, our guide told us it is manic in July and August!!! The layout and maps provided by the Hermitage leave somewhat to be desired. Having said that the content sof the museum have to be seen to be believed, so much so that there is too much to see in one holiday. Plan what you want to see and try and stick to it, yes you'll have to go back but that's a good thing. Be sure to pre book your tickets on line and collect them from the Hermitage shop, queuing for entry otherwise can be a nightmare.

Must see!. One of my highlights in Russia. Beautiful palace and collection of art. The place is massive and you literally spend a week walking around and discovering new parts. Must see when visiting St Petersburg as a tourist.

If you can a MUST see!!!. One of the world's wonders.Truly stunning atr by world masters and more.It's hugh so a lot of time is needed...see the Gold Room as a sepereat tour.Suggest a private Russian guide

Astonishing Museum. This museum is truly incredible and compares very favourably with other great museums such as the Louvre. Historically similar to the Louvre, once a palace, now a museum, it amazes me that the buildings and a large proportion of the works of art displayed were once a private collection visible only to the privileged few and their guests. There is everything here from old masters to ancient artifacts through numerous statues, jewelry items, clothing, incredible polished stone vases, curios - you name it, the Hermitage has it! Don't miss the incredible gold peacock clock acquired by Catherine the Great - extravagent to say the least. To cap it all off the entire collection is housed in some of the architecturally and decoratively finest rooms I have ever seen. Any serious fan of museums should strive to visit the Hermitage at least once. Spectacular, like many of the other major sites in and around St Petersburg.

Really great museum.. But around it - hell. A lot of unlicensed guides and salesman (caviar and heats) but police don't do anything with this because of corruption system. A lot of people not depend of the day of your visit..(
Amazing. Be sure to allow a few days to see the Hermitage. There are too many treasures to view in one day (and too many people to dodge to see them)

AMAZING. This is one amazing place to visit....walks your legs off there is so much to see. An absolute must is to visit this place. We were lucky visiting with a cruise and even more lucky we visited on a Monday which is the day it is closed, but they opened especially for the cruise tours ( and there were a lot) it was still really busy but we any other time it is rally really busy. The Grandeur of the place is to be seen to be believed and the paintings and sculptures awesome. We were told by our Guide who was brilliant to stand in front of everything on display for 2 minutes each...paintings sculptures etc it would take 7 years to get around the place..it is so big. but well worth the visit.
Beautiful Museum. Give yourself more than 1 day to visit this museum and surrounding Winter Palace area. It is well worth a visit.

A marvel you must visit at least once in your life. I have seen almost all the great museums in the world but I must say I have never been as impressed as I was when I saw the Hermitage. Going up the Jordan staircase is a breathtaking experience. and everything that you can see inside from pictures to a marvellous movable clock that is composed of a pheasant, a cock, an owl , a dragonfly and other animals.You can admire magnificent decorations of walls and ceilings and vases of semi precios stones.

So many things from cultures little seen. Aside from the astounding number of old masters' works the items from Central Asia and Siberia were wonderful. The furnishings and room decorations were staggeringly opulent. Be prepared to spend a lot of time studying the map to decide where you want to visit. There is not a 'companion' restroom but there is one inside the ladies' room.

Amazing building packed with art. Book this well in advance and arrange a local guide, who will show you all the things you like in a small group....we were only 4 people...and she was conversant with every foreign artist's work we saw

Beautiful palace. The Hermitage is one of most famous museums in the world. The palace itself is very beautiful. The withe stairway after the entrance is magnificent. Some of the rooms are a delight to see. The works of art inside are world famous. There is always a line to enter that can take up to 2 hours.

Too many beautiful artifacts and art to see in a short visit. ....but the place is so huge that it would be physically difficult to have a much longer visit. Don't miss it if you get the chance. Try to go when it's not so crowded - we went in September, which was not bad.

Amazing. Wow. The sheer number of pieces of art on show is spectacular. The set up ans flow of the museum is well done and is quite cheap to visit.Its said if you want to look at each piece in the museum for a minute each, it would take you 3 years to go through it. The Winter Palace has over 400 rooms, and with the Hermitage buildings, there are over 1,000.I recommend to go with a guide though as they will be able to explain the history behind everything and show you the important pieces. And yes, all the gold colours in the museums is guildes gold... all of it. Go check it out.

How to fill a day - or a week. Imagine the V&A, the British Museum and the National Gallery all under one roof and you're some way to understanding the Hermitage Museum. We walked 8 km on our visit and there was still much more to see.The exhibits are well-displayed and the actual rooms are works of art in themselves. Inevitably there are certain areas which become very crowded but it is worth persevering in order to see the items on display. The variety of works of art was amazing, ranging from Erté to Egyptian mummies, from mechanical clocks to Rembrandt - it's all there.

Hermitage overwhelms you with beauty. Toured the most magnificent palace, home of Catherine the Great. The palace is overwhelmingly grand, every room beautiful. The artwork collection from the time of her reign that was collected, painted, and presented throughout are beyond words. I learned most of the art refracts a period in Catherine's lifetime, such as her marriage to Peter the Grest, her successful battle over the Turks, her educating go young women, and so so much more. She truly brought culture to a very cold dark Russia. The museum is definitely a must see.

Stunning - opulent - incredible. What a wonderful experience - a vast number of amazing works in a fabulous place. An absolute must but it is busy. It would have been nice to take more time over our visit but the compensation was a concert with the St Petersburg Philharmonic to round off our evening. (I think this may have been put on for our cruise ship visit)

So many amazing pieces or art to see... so little time!. The Hermitage is a MUST see when you visit St Petersburg. Not only is the Hermitage a beautiful building, it houses an amazing collection of art: painting, sculptures, art objects, ... it's an art lover's play garden! If you don't have more than one day to visit the Hermitage, I recommend the audio tour to visit the Hermitage itself (the Winter Palace) and choose the sections you really want to see (the art itself) very carefully. Because before you know it, hours have passed.Buy your ticket at the ticket vending machines right behind the Hermitage entrance. Don't wait in line to buy your ticket inside, you will lose precious time :-)The museum can be very busy, especially at the major art objects such as "Madonna With Child" (Da Vinci) and the Rembrandt section.
