I heard it's really quiet in January, but I don't think many of us will travel to Russia in January. Enjoy it and take time to see as much as you can!
Great place to visit. Full of Russian historic treasures. I recommend fast pass to avoid very long queue. The weather in july was very nice to visit st petersburg in general

Lot to see but needs Translations. The Eremitage and Winterpalais is a must see in St.Petersburg. You can spend hours in the rooms and miss one or almost get lost. It is a great place and we enjoyed it. The only big minus is the missing translations. every exhibit is in Russia with Russian letters. As one of the most popular places in Russia I expect some English guys! The rooms signs are written in English but that's it. And you don't find English speaking staff.

Huge Museum. Hard to believe that this museum was the private art collection of an individual. Must see, though I would recommend hiring a guide as it is easy to get lost in the maze of corridors and rooms in this huge and magnificent building.

Book a guide to enhance your visit. We took Trip Advisor advice and booked a private guide through our hotel concierge (2 days before our visit). We were awarded with a terrific guide, Nadia, who helped us navigate through this mind blowing museum and palace. Worth the visit, our teens survived...but be warned we couldn't get them to visit other museums after so choose the ones YOU want to see prior to bringing them along. If you have teen sons, include the armory, visit the mechanical display and the one of a kind archeological relics from Siberia (mummy and permafrost preserved items) to keep their attention. The stories of the paintings and the visits to the palace rooms with the chandeliers and Russian gold details were a draw as well. A guide helps you jump the lines and is well worth the investment...especially maneuvering around the cruise tours. Enjoy!

Stunning, hot, and crowded. Because we used a tour company (Ulko Tours), we were able to skip the lengthy lines and start our guided tour right away, and having a guide is a must. Because of the large number of people visiting each day, you can't linger for long before being edged along to the next room. Amazing building and art, but on a crowded July day, the place felt like a sauna and we all lost interest after an hour or so. Definitely worth a visit but be prepared to bump and grind with thousands of other sweaty tourists.
Unequaled!. Thanks to booking our tickets from home, we didn't have to queue for hours. We took an audioguide for the residential part and chose to "just" see the impressionists - well worth it!
Astonishing. Beautiful palace and marvelous collection of artworks and architecture. you can experience the "past".

Ruined by an uncontrolled mob. Local say goes in Spring, fall or winter if you want to enjoy a trip to this world famous museum. They are right. After struggling up the Jordan staircase and through three room I left. Hot and tired from being jostled by the crowd of tourists and frustrated by not being able to see anything.

Too big. Avoid the lines and buy the tickets in the automatic machines. Too much people, too much tours. The rooms and very beautiful and it has a lot to show. Unfortunately you don't have the time to see it all, so i advise you to plan the visit and what you want to see. You can buy the tickets in the automatic machines that are in the left and right after the main entrance. The ticket gives you access to the Hermitage, General Staff, Menshikov Palace and the old Winter Palace. Don't go to the last one because there is nothing to see there. Travel light and comfortable because there is a lot to walk in the Hermitage.
Three days in St Petersburg.. This is an amazing museum. Hard to believe that it was originally someone's "home". You could spend a year here and not see everything.

35 kms of art in 5 buildings. Absolutely amazing museum and gallery with art by da Vinci, Reubens, Titian and so many others. Lots of sculptures and other artworks. We went on an organised tour and walked straight in however we saw what looked like 3 hour long queues for those who just walked up. So book a tour.You won't see it all- it would take years.Very highly recommended .

Worthwhile but needs to be organised differently. As one of the most famous art galleries in the world I expected it to be more organised. We arrived as a pre-booked group but had to wait nearly an hour to get in because it was so disorganised. It was pouring with rain and there is no space outside to stand under shelter.Once inside it is a fascinating place, both the building and its history as well as the art collection. It is advisable to have a good guide.
Must see!. Beautiful palace and gorgeous inside. Great to see DaVinci and Rembrandt paintings. This was part of our SPB tour and we had early entrance. So glad as the lines outside were huge!

Magnificent !!!!. On my 'bucket list ' and the main reason to visit St Petersburg, even stayed in the State Hermitage Official Museum Hotel.Had already bought tickets on the Hermitage Internet site, and although we had to queue to get into the cloakroom and security, was well worth it as the queue to buy tickets was very long. Our ticket was a 'combined ticket ' that also allowed us into the new home of the 19th Century Impressionist and post Impressionist into 20th century, it is in the General Staff building across from the Hermitage, and into The Winter Palace.Spent a couple of hours in the main Hermitage building viewing room upon room of golden chandeliered magnificence, one of the highlights was the Peacock Clock . We then decided to go to see the Impressionist Paintings in the General Staff building, a warning if you want to purchase things from the Museum shop , do it before you leave as you cannot get back in, although there is a smaller shop in the other building. The collection takes up 2 floors of the building, and allowed you to see artwork that previously you had only ever seen in books. After a visit to the shop, we went in search of the Winter Palace exhibition, to say we were very 'underwelmed ' is an understatement. We thought we were going to see more of the magnificent Winter Palace rooms, but in fact it was just a small exhibition that took about 10 minutes to see!!!!!!Overall a very pleasant but also tiring day which is a must for any visitor to St Petersburg.

Easy Entry to this Glorious Palace Museum. This is the Hermitage, a Museum-Palace complex with vast marvelous collection of artworks and glorious palatial architecture. You can't expect to see all. Plan your visit and what you wanted to see. Museum staff are helpful to show you where to find it. Its a must for any St. Petersburg visit. Its tourist season and people come in groups, like an invasion! Buy tickets online, there will be a separate entrance for online ticket holders. A 2 days access is slightly cost more, but its great.
The legend. It is an amazing museum with so many different arts, antiques and statues. History from all over the world and a lot of turists.

Beyond Superlatives: One of the Greatest Palaces and Museums in the World. The Hermitage is without dispute one of the top art museums in the world. If you are in St. Petersburg, you are likely to see it either for the art, because it was the tsars’ Winter Palace, or both.Let’s start with the art. This collection is enormous. You cannot possibly see everything. It’s probably close to impossible even to see just the very most famous paintings in a single visit. The best of these, perhaps, are the extensive Rembrandts. You can also see countless other old master works, including two pieces by Leonardo da Vinci.Incidentally, the outstanding Impressionist collection has been moved to the newly acquired and renovated space across the square in the old General Staff building (that’s the large yellow neoclassical structure just opposite the Hermitage on the square). It’s worth a visit in its own right, but we won’t review it here.You will also want to come here to view the incredible palace and some of its contents. The main hallway is huge and grand. There are many rooms that are incredibly ornate and in some cases feel like everything is made of gold. This was among the most opulent palaces in the world.One thing you will not want to miss is the so-called peacock clock, which almost defies description. Everything about the clock is mechanical and much of it moves naturally and not at all like, say, a cuckoo clock. The clock itself is housed in a large glass display and is covered in gold. They can’t run it all the time, but there is an excellent HD video showing the peacock fluidly turning its head, and various other creatures depicted moving around as well.We would strongly recommend getting a guide, at least for your first visit. Why? Well, first of all, doing so will get you an early entrance. We were in some rooms we had almost to ourselves in the early morning, but were absolutely packed with tourists by 11. Many of the tourists arrive in large groups, swamping some of the most famous attractions in particular. In the case of the two Leonardo paintings, for example, the room almost deteriorated into a line of Asian tourists lining up and taking selfies in quick succession. That left little availability just to enjoy the pieces for their intrinsic worth.You might also want a guide because this museum is absolutely huge, with literally millions of pieces of art. The Romanovs were fabulously wealthy monarchs, and spent liberally on art over the course of centuries so what is here is among the very best in the world. We spend a lot of time on line (the museum’s website is replete with good images), but having a guide helped us enormously. In some cases the great artwork is so plentiful that it’s possible to “lose” even the greatest pieces among many hung on the enormous palace walls.You can check the website to find pieces that suit your own taste, but among the hundreds of paintings that any art museum would leap at are:-Paintings by Fra Angelico, including Madonna and Child with Four angels-Leonardo’s Madonna with flower and the Benois Madonna-Raphael: The Conetabile Madonna and The Holy Family-Titian: Numerous paintings, including The Flight Into Egypt and Portrait of a Young Woman and the incomparable Danae-Caravaggio: The Lute Player-Holbein-Lucas Cranach the Elder (the lovely Virgin and Child Under the Apple Tree)-Velazquez: Boy with a Dog-Murillo: The Walpole Immaculate Conception-Many, many Rubens paintings, including “Bacchus”-Snyders: Fish Stall/Market. You’ll also want to hunt for the comical “bird concert”, which is one of many Dutch masters hung 3-high in an enormous gallery-Some of Rembrandt’s best pieces, including the Sacrifice of Isaac, Danae (vandalized by mad man, but partly restored), and Descent from the CrossJan Steen ( in particular the comical Revelers)-Watteau (multiple paintings)-Boucher-Gainsborough-Eugene DelacroixThe Hermitage is one of the world’s top attractions and should definitely be on your list.
Marvellous building and collection. Marvellous collection of paintings. Very beautiful building and interior. One drawback... Too many people inside. This somewhat spoils the experience a (tiny) bit

Avoid the Lines. We went with TJ Travel, so we got early entry into the Hermitage. The line to get in however was massive. I have never seen a line that long for any museum or tourist attraction. Inside it's very impressive. I'm not a huge fan of museums, but this had some interesting pieces. The large green vase that you will see had to be brought in prior to putting up one of the walls, which we found very interesting. If I was going without a tour group, I would book my tickets prior.

Very interesting historical place. I visited in August this magnificent place. My kids were very impressed. We Wales for over 3 hours and we're not able to finish. Very interesting historical and cultural place.

Lots to see but overcrowded . The Hermitage has an amazing collection. You could probably spend a week there and still not see everything. It's difficult to enjoy it however because it is so incredibly crowded. You have to fight your way to see the most popular pieces like the Rembrandts. If you want a more relaxed experience, go off season. Our guide said it's very quiet in the winter.

Beauty overload.. Try to get an English-speaking guide if visiting The Hermitage. Not only will they explain what you see, but will help negotiate rules etc. as not everyone speaks English. The treasures must be seen to be believed.

Long long lines. The Hermitage is a enormous and classical structure That encompresses classical european art as well russian art and antiques from the nobles. However....Book a guided tour. Not only you can enjoy that huge maze but the lines are virtually 0. I wasted 2h of my Day at the line.
Interesting - Very Busy. Loved walking round this place - the opulence is amazing. Book a ticket online and avoid the ques. Gets very, very busy so come early to avoid the crowds

Vast array of art & artefacts. They need more signs for tourists though. Once you get inside the Hermitage it is very impressive. There are several large ornate rooms and a multitude of art and artefacts. It is possible to obtain an audio guide and a floor plan to help you plan a route. There are a huge amount of visitors so it can be congested at the entrance, exit, cloakrooms and cafés but in the rooms it is fine. One very big annoyance was the lack of staff or information regarding the ticket queues outside The Hermitage. We joined a long queue for the ticket office and wasted 2 hours standing in it. The line was for people wishing to buy discounted tickets there are ticket machines in the square where you can buy your ticket. 600ru is the full price and you can purchase from these machinesIf we knew that we would have only needed to wait a short while to buy the tickets. I imagine lots of other people were in the big queue thinking it was the only option. A sign explaining ticket options and queuing options would help a lot.

Never Enough Time....!. What a great museum! Only had time to visit one wing of one section (3 hours)! So many great things to see/experience! Do not miss it; even if you have only limited time. Lines can be long so arrive early or book a tour as they get priority entrance.
Amazoo!. Depending on when you go.. be prepared to stand in long queues to go in...but it's worth it! Also wear flat or comfortable shoes because its a very big place.

Worth the time, effort and energy to battle the crowds. The exterior might be enough to see, its massiveness most impressive. And then there is the inside. Be prepared for wait in line and for a crush of people in the beginning. View the beginning in fast forward and once into the museum/palace can slow down and enjoy the sights and take photos. You could easily spend all day here, but that might be art overload. We allowed 4 hours, hit the highlights and feel like we saw it all.

Beautiful . The Hermitage opened early for the cruise ship tours and we were able to enjoy this masterpiece of architecture and its exquisite works of art without the long waits and crowds. And our local guide was so knowledgable about the art and history.
Russian heritage. Be there early in order to have time to visite everything. There is a lot of history about the Russian culture and the Romanov family. Must to do.

Overwhelming architecture and art collection. This is a must to visit. Overwhelming collection of art. In total over 3 million pieces. The buildings and the different rooms are magnificent. Breathtaking.
Wonderful and very intetesting. Great museum und very rich collection. Very interesting and pleasant. The impressionnist collection is wonderful.
Winter Palace. Rivals Versailles in France for beauty and opulence. Try to go early in the morning to avoid large crowds. The Hermitage is one of the finest art museums I have ever seen.

Treasury of world's best art. Hermitage is one of the oldest and largest museums of art, craft and culture in the world. Founded by Catherine the Great, today it consists of Small Hermitage, The Great Old Hermitage, The New Hermitage, The Winter Palace (all 4 are inner connected), The Hermitage Theatre, The General Staff Building, The Menshikov’s palace, Peter’s Cabin, Porcelain Museum and The Storage center. They say it takes 15 years to review the whole collection if one spends more than 1 minute admiring every piece (plus travel time and lunch breaks as art watching always makes me hungry). I advise to purchase 2-days ticket online (soft copy is enough) which allow you to skip a massively annoying line and to sneak through a special entrance, otherwise the wait is loooooong.

QUEUE, QUEUE, QUEUE. Probably the worst experience I've ever had in hundreds of museums. If you haven't booked online in advance don't bother. There are lots of other things to do in St Petersburg. I queued in four different queues fit nearly three hours before getting in.

A must visit . A must visit place if you visit St Petersburg. The huge place and beautiful art work just takes the breath away. It is a huge one and would take a lot of time to see the rooms and art work. Nevertheless a place to visit.

Spectacular!. The State Hermitage Museum is a museum of art and culture in Saint Petersburg, one of the largest and oldest museums in the world. Catherine the Great found it in 1764. The Museum has opened to public since 1852. It has over 3 million collections including the largest compilation of paintings in the world. The Museum Complex has six historic buildings, embracing the prominent Winter Palace, the former residence of Russian emperors. The architecture, massiveness of the buildings and vast collections are truly impressive! It should have 6 stars!

Unimaginable. We had the opportunity to see the Hermitage and Winter Palace in the evening. We were on a cruise ship and they have arranged tours in the evening for just cruise ship passengers to tour between the hours of 7:30-9:30. So 72 passengers from our ship accompanied a tour guide (required, with no visa, your tour guide is your visa). We learned much about the winter palace, like which columns were real and which were made of papier mache. Lots of information on the Tsars and Catherine the Great. We made our way to the art galleries and saw about 20 of hundreds. Largest was the Rembrandt. There was a gallery of Little Dutch Men or not Rembrandt. Some Titian, two Divincis. Especially interesting were the mini mosaics on columns, vases and tables. There was a room from the Vatican and a marvelous floor mosaic that Catherine the Great had copied, that are no longer publicly viewed because they are part of the Popes private residence. So the restrooms are old, old you can not throw your toilet paper in the commode and flush it down. But everything else is really beautiful. If you can take advantage of this tour be warned nothing else is open and you only see what the tour guide likes, so no Faberge egg, and the communists sold many wonderful things to get cash. Oh, and people will waste time taking selfies of themselves with the art (no flash allowed).

A wonderful visit. What a visit. Great place to be in & appreciate the grandeur of the Czars, the wealth they possessed, the beauty of the hundreds of exhibits spread over the huge museum. A must see for any tourist to the Russian Federation, it rivals the "Louvre" in sheer spectacle.

Overwhelming collection, beauty ... and crowds in August. We visited the Hermitage with our tour company, and although it is possible to do it on one's own, I am glad we had a guide to run interference and, indeed, "guide" us through the labyrinth of rooms. We were there for four hours, which gave us a taste of the variety of items in the immense collection. Having first been on such a tour, it is more likely---if you have time---that you can stay on or return on your own and head straight to the collections that are of greatest interest to you.Be prepared: long lines in August for entry, although one can purchase tickets online and go in through another entrance. No water allowed, which makes several hours inside quite difficult.Of course we are all there to see the collections of paintings, carvings, and exquisite ornaments. But also the structure itself is a work of art, with inlaid wood flooring, every door decorated elaborately, frescoes on nearly every ceiling, stunning columns in galleries, and jaw-dropping gilt work in ballrooms and other grand rooms. Some great views of the Neva River from the hallways that connect the Old and New Hermitages.Seeing an item up close or taking a picture is a challenge, with all the tourists jammed into each room. Save yourself frustration and buy a book in the gift store or on the street outside (which will contain photos of noteworthy Old Masters and Da Vinci's paintings, modern artworks, as well as some of the objects and rooms considered most noteworthy); just glory in the beauty and snap a photo of something that catches your fancy. For me the latter was delicate glass goblets and small mosaics. Glad I snapped the photos because they do not appear in the book, and they pleased me very much.
Only Aa bit dear. We were there as part of a cruise excursion so only had the opportunity to see a fifth of the museum. What we did see was wonderful.

Makes the British Museum and Smithsonian look sick. Unbelievable collection of art, costume, carriage, jewelry, etc, etc. My favorite item in the exhibit is the Faberge egg with a golden wind up model of the Trans Siberia express in it.

Crowds Ruin The Hermitage Museum. A Baltic cruise included St. Petersburg. There were at least 7 huge cruise ships docked in the harbor - which means thousands of tourists competing for excursions. Our trip to the Hermitage Museum was long and tedious. Gridlock is the word for Russian traffic. Once there, the museum rooms were so crowded that it was not possible to look at anything except from a distance. Our tour guide herded us through the rooms, not even stopping to point out wonders of the art world. Overall, St. Petersburg was a huge disappointment. A four-hour tour involved 3 hours stuck in traffic! Although the Hermitage is fabulous, try to go sometime when you can actually look at something. Look for a private tour!!!!

One of the most beautiful museum in the world. Great art exhibitions, beautiful rooms wonderful art shows. Watch out for the waiting queue. It may take an hour or more. Lack of air in some rooms due to large group of tourists in organized tours. Avoid being stuck in between. Don't miss it even if you are in st. Petersburg for one day.

What a museum!. St. Petersburg's most popular visitor attraction, and one of the world's largest and most prestigious museums, the Hermitage is a must-see for all first-time travelers to the city. With over 3 million items in its collection, it also definitely rewards repeat visits, and new-comers can only hope to get a brief taste of the riches on offer here, from Impressionist masterpieces to fascinating Oriental treasures.I know some local St Petersburg's citizens who live there for ages, but still there are many exhibits they have missed.
Our second visit. The sense of the imperialism of czarist Russia permeates this place. Also the feeling of sadness when one thinks of the fate of the last czar and his family.

Hot and crowded . You can't came to st. Petersburg and not visit the museum. It's like going to the beach without a towel. But. Be prepare, like you are other tourists who believe it's a must. And in a hot day it's a furnace. Well now you will have to make up your mind. And if you come from the Big apple go to the national art museum it's cool, great and you can walk and enjoy. Believe me I have been in both.

The best museum I've ever visited. Coming from London we have some fantastic museums, all free by the way, and I've visited many others on my travels. The Hermitage though is the best I've been to. It's not just the art though; you've got to be impressed by the Rembrandts etc. It's the grandeur of the rooms in the building. A couple defied belief. The gold on the walls, the paintings on the ceiling, the architecture. Stunning. We aren't art experts but the exhibits on display are astonishing. The museum does get very busy, tour guides with their followers are everywhere so it is hard to fully explore so try to get into the museum ahead of the cruise tours!

Very interesting, massive art display, winter palace very impressive. A very big day, with far too much art to properly appreciate in one trip. I strongly recommend a tour in order to maximise the visit.Winter palace was an incredible sight, huge rooms of ridiculous decadence. The actual Hermitage museum was incredible, continuing the theme of decadence. Taking a tour allows an early entry before the crowds, which is a big reason to consider it - by about lunch time the museum was absolutely packed, especially around the Da Vincis and other famous pieces. A tour also skips the massive queue which extends across the entire square.

A year wouldn't be enough time to visit. So glad we had guides (Dancing Bear Tours) as Kate led us to the highlights. We spend 3 hours there and obviously that's not enough time but we did get a feel for the building and the art. Just absolutely amazing. No matter when you arrive there will be crowds and lines. Definitely go with a guide.

My enthusiasm was tempered by all the crowds!. The Hermitage is an amazing place. It is a feast for the eyes and as a result, is an emotional experience. I felt so overwhelmed by the gold leaf, the bright royal embience and the grandness of the palace.The museum is tremendous. To see Rembrandts, Van Dykes, and many other classic artists together in one place was exquisite!The only negative was the crowds. We were there in the morning and even then, the crowds of tourists were building. By the time we left in late morning (about 11AM) the crowds were so large and the museum was so crowded that it was impossible to get out without elbowing your way through a thick wall of people moving against you. It was like swimming upstream against a heavy current!This is a great place to visit, but do so with an organized tour that can get you in early in the day. It will then be an excited experience worth the effort.
State of the art . This is real example of the grandeur of the Russian Architecture. It's a huge and looks amazing.Extremely photogenic place with a huge history behind it.

5 star attraction and mandatory for art lovers everywhere. This is a place that requires multiple visits but with today's tour crowds and limited time on a tour bus, you must savor every second on the property. There is so much to see that having a private tour is the best option. The tour groups route you through many of the room highlights, but if you want to see a specific area; you will need to time to navigate to the building.I was in the Hermitage on a very hot summer day and first thing in the morning. The museum does not have any air conditioning. Please dress for a heat wave because the air circulation inside is not refreshing or pleasant.

Amacing place. So beautiful places with art traces. Guided tour is useful to take from somewhere, because the place is huge and without guides You'll have to waite really long time before getting in.The place is quite warm, dont put on warm clothes and it is not allowed to take drinking bottles with You. Enjoy the glory and history!

Still can't comprehend the size and splendour of this place. We spent the full day in the Hermitage. Such marvellous collection! It is little wonder that the entire place was jam packed from start to finish. There is no air conditioning, so leave your jackets and sweaters in the check-in luggage. Although backpacks aren't allowed, you can bring a plastic bag in for water and snack supplies. There are two cafes where you can take a breather from time to time, but be forewarned it is hella busy.
Very interesting museum. Is definitely place I would recommend to visit. It is a large place so make sure you have comfy shoes on. But definitely worth it!

Worth the wait. Very crowded. This experience demands your patience, but if you can embrace this, you'll enjoy all the beautiful art, furniture, exhibitions and architecture. The new modern wing across the square is definitely worth it - a lot less crowded and some real art treasures on display. The cafe here is really nice too!

Not to be missed, butv one visit is not enough. As soon as you tell people you've been to St Petersburg, their first question is not: was it cold? (which it wasn't) but: did you visit The Hermitage?Being part of an organised group, there was no question of our not visiting the number one tourist attraction in this lovely city. Other tourists had the same idea, and that was the first problem, that it was too crowded. Every room we entered, we had to wait at the door, until it cleared, but by then our very well-informed guide, who was speaking to our group through ear-pieces, had usually moved on into the next room, and was describing some other art or artefact we hadn't yet reached. This must happen all the time, and it is very frustrating.The Hermitage houses many of Russia's finest art treasures, but there are far too many paintings, sculptures, statues and other works of art for them to have justice done to them in a three-hour visit. Instead, the lover of art needs to return there several times. Having said that, I would not feel that I had properly been to St Petersburg without this valuable and important visit.

Mind-Blowing!. When I tell you that this museum is mind blowing – believe me. First of all, it is enormous. We were told that if you stood in front of each piece of art for a half minute, it would take you 9 years to see everything and it is not all on display. Is that not incredible? The Hermitage is made up of five historical buildings and houses one of the finest art collections in the world. What you will not see here is Russian Art. You must go to the State Russian Museum to see that. The museum was founded in 1764 by Catherine the Great as a private exhibition hall; it opened to the public in 1852. Always expanding, the museum’s holdings include 3 million items, including the largest collection of paintings in the world. Some highlights not to be missed include the following: Main Staircase, Malachite Room, Peter’s Room, Armory Hall, Golden Boudoir Room, Giant Statues of Atlantes, Giant Jasper Vase, Leonardo da Vinci Room, Peacock Clock, plus the many galleries filled with paintings. We were fortunate to have a private guide with SPB Tours take us thru the museum. We were able to go to the front of the line and go right in. Our guide was an art history major who really knew her art. She was able to tell us about each and everything that we were interested in. I like Egyptian art, so she took us to see the Egyptian collection. This is truly an exceptional museum – not for the faint of heart – try to decide what you really want to see – there is no way you could ever see it all on one visit. Admission Fee – Wheelchair accessible.

Enormous. And wonderful.. Firstly - definitely buy tickets online first. Make sure you go to the entrance for people with internet tickets/vouchers (when facing the Palace, to the right). Secondly - we saw some massive queues in the mornings so decided to go in the afternoon and there was no queue at all for internet tickets. It's the side entrance though (Small Hermitage, I think it's called) so you have to go back through the building to the Palace itself if that's what you're aiming for. It's not exactly clearly marked and the lady at the information desk wasn't exactly helpful.So get a map/floorplan and check which rooms/areas you want to visit. You can wander around freely, of course, but the place is absolutely enormous so if there are specific things you want to see then best to make a plan. Some rooms were packed with tour groups so we had to wait our turn to see the famous pieces (and encountered some VERY pushy tourists as well - be warned!)The Winter Palace is stunning and is a 'must see', but don't forget the General Staff building with the impressionists/post-impressionists. Amazing collection and a lovely modern building, calm and relaxing. Don't expect to be able to see the whole place! It's too big. :)
Must visit. So many things to see and quite big. Ventilation is not that good so in hot weather its difficult to be inside for long time.
Amazing place!. I had the chance to make a photoshoot in some of its rooms, it is breath taking! A must-see if you visit St. Petersburg
Tour. Not to be missed. Can be tiring but well worth it if visiting St Petersburg. Lived up to our expectations-and more
Russian history. Hermitage musium is not just a place to visit. It is a summary of Russian history gathered together. You see wonderful architectral masterpiece decorated by ancient scents.

How to get in without losing temper. I read quite a few reviews about buying tickets online to avoid a queue before I went. The information in English on the Ermitage website is incorrect, so here is the truth :) 1. Buy ticket online, do not print it, but save it in your phone.2. Go to the second entrance, when facing the palace, it is on the right, but not the guarded street, the next one to the right, under the bridge.3. Be there at least 10:15 am to get inside by 11, the is also a queue (all people with vouchers). Stand in the queue and wait till 10:30, thats where the wooden doors will open (no sooner).4. You pass the security control (like at the airport, bags separately), it is rather quick.5. Go to the right to the cloakroom, put your things there, believe me, it s worth it.6. Go to the other side of the hall, check the bar code from your voucher directly to the terminal and don t forget to grab a map. (there is no need to have ID cards or have it printed, only if you need a free (student) ticket).7. Enjoy!

You need to see to believe. Tip: there is a lift from the ground floor to the first floor to the right of the great staircase! If you want to save your legs use it. The museum also scans bags for water so leave bottles in a coach/behind. Expect to experience rush hour on the tube/metro in a busy city. Be realistic about what you want to get from a visit. In my view either go for particular artists or styles or just immerse yourself in the glorious decorations on the walls, the floor, the ceilings and the amazing doors. The popular paintings get surrounded by people taking pictures of themselves by the painting which isn't really what an exhibition is intended to engender in its visitors.

Wow. Amazing place can't take it all in,you walk round each room in amazement .the ceiling and floors are a work of art as well as the pictures. This was part of our tour with Maxibalti Tours so we had a guide who explained and guided us through the museum.

Huge!. Too much to see, I think you really need a few days just here. Wouldn't even contemplate it without a guide. Gorgeous building and gorgeous art. The scale of the buildings is so hard to believe

Astounding museum. The hermit Tosh may be the world's single greatest museum experience. It doesn't have quite the art collection of the British Museum or the Louvre, but the palace itself has so many astounding rooms and displays and decorative art objects that the whole effect beats any other museum I have ever visited. The only downside is that it is very crowded in August vacation time with numerous tour groups rushing through on preset tours.If you don't have a guide, the audio tours are well worth the investment. Even if you think you know about the paintings and artists, the audio guide gives an excellent explanation of what the different rooms were used for. It's advisable to try and plan your route along the lines that the museum suggests. Otherwise you were up to miss a room you really wanted to see.Trying to see both the classical art exhibits with Rembrandt and da Vinci and Raphael and the impressionist collection the same day is probably too much.We did the Winter Palace the first day and then went to the general staff headquarters building which has been converted to a very impressive Museum of modern Art on the second day. That was an effective plan.

Incredible!. You cannot leave St. Petersburg without a visit to the State Hermitage and Winter Place. Our trip was organized by our cruise line so we did not need to stand in line to purchase tickets. We actually were able to get into the museum an hour before the public opening hours, so we were able to experience it for about an hour without the huge crowds that eventually made it into all corners of the beautiful palace. The museum is massive. We spent about 3 hours there, but could easily have spent an additional 3 hours. The rooms are gorgeous, as is all the precious artwork. My favorite room was the room with the gold peacock clock; white and gold everywhere! A tour of St. Petersburg's palaces and churches will highlight how much the Russian aristocracy loved gold! Take time to look at the beautiful inlaid floors. In one room the ceiling matches the design on the floor. Do not miss this spectacular museum.

The Louvre of St. Petersburg. Our guide told us that if we were to look at everything in the Hermitage for 30 seconds it would take us three years to see it all. It was amazing. Leonardo Da Vinci, Raphael, Michelangelo and thousands of other artists' works are represented here along with much history of palaces of the Tsars. The Hermitage does not house Russian art as it is in the State Russian Museum, but it is worth every second you can spend there. There is a line and we went with a group. You would need some sort of guide or guidebook to get the most out of your visit.

Astounding. Although I expected the museum's collection to be wonderful, I was unprepared for the museum. The rooms were works of art with walls, ceilings, and floors of remarkable beauty. Outstanding

Plan ahead and be realistic about how much you can see in the time you have. We only had a half day here which is nowhere near enough time - frankly you could spent months in this place and still not see everything. We got in without having to queue (timing is everything!) but within no time, the museum was heaving. It is definitely worth buying tickets online or hiring a guide who can get the tickets without having to queue. Failing that, start at the Impressionist & Post-Impressionist collection across the square and buy your tickets there as the queue will be shorter or buy tickets from the machines rather than queuing for the ticket office.. I would have thought that the Impressionist stuff would attract big crowds but it doesn't seem to do so - although I did hear some people with a guide complaining when they discovered they would not be seeing the Impressionists on their tour - as the collection moved a couple of years ago a bit of prior investigation would have revealed this to them. We had worked out a selection of things we wanted to see in the main building in addition to walking through the palace which is itself absolutely stunning. You have to be selective and we know we will be coming back so didn't feel the temptation to try to cram in too much. It is worth noting that whilst some areas of the museum bear a distinct resemblance to Victoria Station on the London underground at 5.30pm, other areas were very quiet. It gets quieter after lunch.The museum provides a guide of highlights and needless to say these areas are exceptionally busy with the exception of the Cranach paintings which are no longer located where they are shown on the plan - they have moved to the third floor where the Impressionist collection used to be until they were moved to the General Staff building elsewhere in the Palace complex. This change obviously flummoxed most people - we had to ask several of the generally non-English speaking attendants before we tracked them down and we were alone in the room. The beautiful da Vinci paintings, meanwhile, were surrounded by what can only be described as a rugby scrum - a couple of Japanese tour groups arrived at the same time and at one point the Russian matriarch guarding the room had to drag two brawling men apart. All they wanted to do was photograph the two star paintings - not look at them or appreciate them. It is unfortunate that people behaving in this way (and I am sure it is not just the Japanese) ruin it for everyone. We retreated and returned later on our way out when the crowds were still there but at least they weren't fighting over photo-taking positions! The Rembrandts were crowded out too but the impressive paintings by Frans Hals close by were neglected. The Peacock clock is absolutely amazing, much larger than I expected, and sitting in an amazing Baroque room. The decor is completely over the top throughout the palace with gold leaf & marble everywhere - it could be tacky but the sheer opulence & grandeur just takes your breath away.Overall, even though it will in all likelihood be very busy, this is something not to miss. Plan ahead and be realistic about what you can achieve in the time you have.

Interesting but select carefully what you see. A huge palace museum. Book online or at the tourist entrance automatic machine to avoid the long lines. Impossible to see in a day or even a week so select carefully. I strongly recommend the modern section.

STUNNING COLLECTION. What a place ,the shear grandure and greatess of the building is somthing ,but the immense collection of artworks is somthing else.If you go make sure you have plenty of time to look around..

State Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace. A must to see, stunningly beautiful outside and inside, we spent 6 hours there and easily have gone back for the next couple of days, no English signs, we had our own private guide which had our tickets in advance so we were able to go straight in, the queues are very long.There is so much to see, we wanted to see the Pazyryk Rug and artifacts which were on display in the basement which was so interesting, a shame as not many people were aware of these different exhibitions, our guide had to ask so many people before hand as it wasn't well known where exactly it was! Certainly worth finding. Plenty of cafe's and souvenir shops fairly expensive and again not much in English . We will certainly visit again.

Wonder of the World. One of the wonders of the world. Take at least 2 days to see "something", because 2 days are nowhere near what is needed to see it completely and in a good way. Still a great museum, a wonder under every aspect!
Amazing. A must visit when visiting saint petersburg, it's collection of different paintings, and other artifacs will leave you speachless.

Unbelievable museum. This is unbelievably huge museum with collection of painting, sculpture and antique more than ten thousands. You wouldn't finish it even in one week. The waiting line is very long, therefore to visit this museum it is better to hire guide who also buy ticket museum with skip the waiting line. Our guide, Anya is so expertise in the museum collection and she picked only best treasures which for us is enough. A must visit with guide in SPB.

Hermitage Museum. Try to be at the museum before it opens. While you will not be the first inside you will be there before the tour groups descend. There is amazing art on display, with impressive ceilings, floors and walls. The Golden Peacock, chandeliers, items under glass, relief work on the upper sections of some walls and paintings by loads of artists will occupy at least four hours of your time. If you have not been called to your bus by then keep going as legend has it that there are twenty-six kilometres of art to inspect.
Awesome - everything I expected and more . But be sure and buy your ticket on the Internet or get it from your hotel because the queue trot the ticket office was enormous.
a must see. this is a must see but the crowds are so bad.If possible get a special early AM tour at 9 as hordes enter at 1030

Impressive museum for which you can avoid the queue!. It will require hours or day to visit it at your own pace if you want to see each room in details.If you want to gain time book your ticket online and it took us 5 min to enter and you have special entry to have your ticket printed!! Outside people was queuing outside the palace and inside. Better to keep the time for the visit...You can also upload an app to replace the audioguide. This was not working well for us but it is worth to try...

Beautiful, don't get lost . Only visited the outside as was here for a short time. Can highly recommend visiting here on your trip, absolute must see. Others on our cruise who went inside said it was a must see though the guides went too fast and people got lost

Tips to avoid lines and crowds. We found the interior to be incredibly gaudy, but that was to be expected and many will love the over-the-top rich style. The collection is enormous of course and there is something for everyone. Don't forget there is a second, separate building on the other side of palace square. When facing the Winter Palace turn around and cross the square to the big yellow building - the entrance is under the second balcony from the left, to the left of the arch. There you will find the wonderful impressionist and more modern collections (start on the 4th floor).Tips:Buy an online ticket and you can use a special entrance - head right of the Winter Palace to the corner of the square and it is signposted.If you don't have an online ticket, go to the yellow building mentioned above and buy your ticket there (either in-person or from a ticket machine). The line will be way shorter. You can use the same ticket for both buildings, and skip the long ticket lines.Weds and Fri are open until 21:00 - a good time to visit is on those evenings to miss the biggest crowds.

Hermitage Palace Square Building. On a private tour through Viking Ocean Cruise, our group was admitted about 45 minutes early to this part of the museum. This was exceptionally lucky because in the summer the lines are incredibly long. There are amazing numbers of Masterpieces in this museum and we were just able to see the highlights with our fantastic guide- 3 hours of walking so be prepared. Even the interior of the building is a masterpiece. Grab a Museum Plan in English for an overview of the "best of" each floor. Don't try to do this on your own- our guide had the quickest way to each masterpiece and none of the descriptions are in English.Our one regret is that we did not have time to see the Faberge eggs which are in another building.Good cafe and numerous gift shops.

Stunning. It is very special when you have the opportunity to see something that you have heard of all your life. We were so fortunate in being able to spend the whole day at the Hermitage with our tour company SPB Tours. Many St. Petersburg tours only allow you one or two hours. Not only that, they arranged for early entry 1 1/2 hours before it opened to the public so we were able to see it relatively uncrowded. The buildings are as stunning as the treasures thay contain. Don't forget to check out the beautiful wood inlay floors as you are going through. I think I could spend many more days at the Hermitage and still not see everything..
Wonderful!. Great for people who love art! need to visit more than once. so crowded but full of exciting. the out side view is also great.

Be aware of Impressionist new location . A quick note to warn everyone that the museum is now permanently displaying its Impressionist and Post-Impressionist fabulous collections (from Matisse to Denis to Picasso and Kandinsky) in the flat building across the big square from the Winter Palace. Worth starting with this part. Much fewer visitors when we were there (esp. on Wednesdays and Fridays after 5pm, open until 8pm).

It's Grand!. The Hermitage is a must visit in St. P. We entered quickly with a tour, but the summer crowd is crazy! My favorite room is Rembrandt's, but there are many treasures to see. Do some research in advance and plan your visit so that you see what you want in what time you have. You could spend days there.

AMAZING!!!. The sheer size of this museum (5 + buildings joined together) gives you a small insight as to what to expect. You must take a guided tour otherwise you could wonder around in this museum for years and still not see everything. Our guide was wonderful and she took us to all the relevant and major pieces by the known legends and then showed us wonderful pieces from less know artists or told us of the incredible stories around the pieces. We spent 4 hours and that was a quick trip to inspect the must see pieces. Also, if you get a guided tour you can enter 1.5 hours before the public enters so there is not as many people about - trust me, once entry was open to the public - the place was very crowded.

Seriously Impressive. Apparently if you spend 2 minutes in front of each art piece, you'll be here for 3 years. So if you're into art it's pretty amazing. But I'd also recommend that you pay attention to the rooms and the furniture, also very cool. I was a particular fan of Catherine the Greats room and garden.

Gold room tour. Did not give this enough time - it was huge and well worth the trip! Taking the gold room tour took almost 2 hours but was fantastic. We had a very knowledgeable guide with excellent softly spoken English who took her time to explain everything and took questions at anytime throughout the tour. Would definitely recommend.

Hermitage etc. We were very lucky to be with our guide, because we got preferential entry. An incredible collection of paintings, sculptures and works of art. Amazing to see original Da Vincis, Raphaels and a Michelangelo sculpture
We found doing this tour with TJ Travel they only use small groups so you get priority entry.. What a magnificent building & a must see for any holiday. This will leave you with life time memories.

Breathtaking. This museum defies description! We only had a half day trip which allowed us to get a feel for the place. To fully appreciate the museum would take days. It takes some time for the reality of where you are to sink in - home of the Tsars, site of the start of the Soviet era. And in the presence of works of the great artists such as Leonardo David Vinci, Michaelangelo, Titian and so many others. If ever in St Petersburg, this is a MUST visit.

Amazing collection. The Hermitage collection would take ten years to see all the pieces. There are over three million items inside. From the ambassadors stairway to the field Marshall hall to the emblem hall and on into the great throne room is a dizzying array of artwork collected by the monarchy. In recent years the collection of the display has been expanded into the staff headquarters across the square. This collection is the impressionists and the modernists.It is well worth several hours visit at a leisurely pace. We had a local guide who pointed out the most important pieces and the history behind them.

Fit for Kings. If you have time to visit one museum, it would have to be the Winter Palace. The collection of art there is extensive and truly amazing. Russian tzars have been collecting paintings for centuries. They don’t have much in terms of furniture to show the way the palace was set up for receptions and celebrations. It really is an art museum. The palace is extensive and consists of several buildings. To get a true idea for the wonders it has, you may need to spend more than one day there. It is a good idea to get a tour guide, who would be able to provide historic background and tell anecdotes about the palace.

Glamour and history in one one package. The architecture of the place alone is worth seeing. Definitely a must see in the city. Do buy your tickets in the ticket machines rather than queuing hours for the ticket office.
Worth it!. Very beautiful and full of beautiful structures to feast your eyes on. They also allow you to take pictures. Make sure you have good walking shoes for your trip to tour Russia!

Incredible. The place was magnificent. There is so much to see and the opulence of the palace is incredible. you would need several hours just to look at all the artwork and the various buildings. If possible I would do a private tour. Some of the tours from the cruise ships would not give you enough time to see the place ,it is very busy ,very crowded so you have to spend your time wisely there.

Overwhelming. This museum is the former palace and home to rulers of Russia and it houses many art treasures including an extensive display of Renaissance painters. The art work and architectural detail is overwhelming throughout the museum. Best visited over a two day (or more) period of time otherwise it is hard to take it all in.

You'll need more time!. There is so much to see that you will need to allow lots of time. Part of the collection that we wanted to see was in another building that we didn't have time to see. Even the time allowed was not enough to see the entire Hermitage. There are many works by the great masters that have to be seen and contemplated, but again, you need time. I was greatly impressed! It was very crowded when we were there. I would recommend a visit when it was spring or fall. It was very hot, and I wondered how the paintings would survive the heat, the sunshine, the humidity, and (the cold).

What a dream place! . This is one of the most impressive buildings you will ever see , there is so many details so much to see that one day is not enough. All the art in there , the paintings and everything about this place is a wonder. From your very first step in there to the end of your journey you will feel as you travelled to another time! A great experience!!

Vast collection of Italian art works. Majestic elegance, this winter palace decor combines elements of the Renaissance, Classical and Moorish styles. It's 18th century peacock clock is one of the highlights of this museum.

Get your timing right. Spectacular and enormous and so many people.First of all buy your ticket on line, it does avoid the main que.Secondly the main museum opens until 9pm two nights a week and the masses disappear around 5/6pm.Thirdly, if you can, buy the two consecutive day ticket and plan.We arrived about 4pm and it was elbows everywhere, we had the Mexican tour, the Chinese, the French..and that was just on the staircase! it's like the UN in there and chaos. You can't get near, let alone spend anytime at the top exhibits.About 5pm crowds started to thin and by 6.30 it was fantastic, we went back and revisited several parts again, what a difference. It is a stunning museum.Ok it was July and peak tourist month. Went to the art collection first, separate building, which was not particularly crowded, the tour buses and cruise ships focus on the main building so you get to wander around at leisure and there is a lot of really great stuff. Mistake we made, hindsight is wonderful, was going into the main building too early.Summary though is it's a must see if your in St Petersburg, just be prepared.

A lifetime is not enough. You can't have enough time for the Hermitage. The breadth and quality of art is breathtaking. Tours will give you a flavor of what's available but will be unsatisfying to anyone who wants to savor the artistic genius on display. If a tour is your only option try to go with a small group as you have a better chance of getting in before the crowds. Generally the ship sponsored tours are large and late to the Hermitage and despite what they tell you getting a visa from a reputable tour company is simple (30 seconds with SPB tours) and part of the tour price.

Cannot be missed. This is what everyone raves about and indeed it is spectacular in terms of quality and size. The restoration work has been magnificent and I would have liked much more info about this aspect - there are lots of photos but many lack a translation. I note there are many magnificent European paintings, da Vinci, Rembrandt in particular. There are Egyptian artefacts and you drown in gold. This was our third great palace and I must admit a bit of disappointment that there was little that was "Russian". That may well say more about em than the Hermitage!

If you like crowds, you'll love the Hermatage. The Hermitage is possibly the world's largest art museum. It is the #1 attraction in St. Petersburg for good reason. Not only does it have Rembrants and DeVinci's but shows Russian history and art as well. The Hermitage is four buildings, three facing the river. Plan a visit of several hours. We got lost trying to rush on a compressed tour schedule. At one point, other tours vacated our area and we were able to take good photos. But generally it's crowded all the time with tourists competing for space andgluide descriptions. Take your patience along.

A must see, but takes a bit of planning. Amazing collection of art housed in architecturally astounding buildings, a must see for every visitor. Getting in can be difficult; if going in high season the easiest/fastest was seems to be waiting until about noon, walking straight in the main gates and going to the ticket machines just inside. Getting tickets here allows you to bypass the very long lines waiting to buy tickets (not many ppl seem to know this). Second best choice is to get online tickets and arrive at approx the same time. Worst choices are to get in line early (at 8am) to wait for the doors to open and then get in line to buy tickets inside the museum OR to get online tickets and join the mega line in the morning, waiting to exchange them for real tickets. Also, look into what artwork is where and make a plan ahead of time. The 'map'/'plan' then give is not that helpful. Take a handfan, it's hot in the summer!

Just go!. Stunning - amazing -all of those words! What opulence! Even just the decoration! Look at the floors, ceilings and doors as well as the art works!
BUT go early and take a fan!

Wow! . The building is so beautiful there is almost no need for art. The artwork is amazing. I recommend going with a guide, as they help you get in and navigate around.
We went in early August. It was very crowded. I think fall might be better.
A must see!

Buy tickets online!. Buy tickets online and enter on the side of the palace rather than the front gate. I probably saved one hour this way and enjoyed the museum before it got too crowded. Beautiful collection and well maintained.

Hermitage & Gold Room shore excursion. Visited from cruise ship arrived 9:15am already some ques. Public state rooms less crowded than late morning. Our trip included the Gold Room, which was full of intricate gold decorative objects, most centuaries old. With our guide having to translate for the in-room Russian guide we spent about an hour in the room. Viewing was good in the illuminated cabinets and only our group was in the room. However we would not view this room again as when we returned to the paintings room it was packed (apx 11:00am).In the gallery rooms we could only glimpse the artwork due to the throngs of visitors. Indeed we felt at times it was unsafe, particularly squeesing through doorways and on stairways.Never the less it was one of the highlights of our trip rouund the Baltic.

Very popular. Find time to yourself, visited with a tour group which rushed around to the important displays in the limited time we had, l couldn't get near exhibits until the group had moved on and l had lost understanding of guides explanation and detail, decided to wander and take in obscure and wonderful displays away from crowds until our time was up
Worth to visit. Beautiful than I think before. Worth to visit as number one. 2 days is better than one day if you have enough time to be in SpB.

Go to the second building before it's discovered. You can't go to St. Petersburg without going to the Hermitage. It houses an amazing art collection. 3 things. 1st. buy tickets online to avoid long lines to get in. 2nd. Do the visit in 2 days if you can swing it. You can buy tickets for consecutive days at a somewhat discounted price. 3rd. Be sure not to miss the 19th and 20th century european art collection. They are in a separate building across the square. The best part....the tour groups haven't gotten this building on their itineraries yet so you can stroll through wide open galleries and actually look at the art without having to elbow someone in the neck to see what you want to see.

The Greatest of Them All. Worth all the fame it has!! The museum is huge and indescribable work of art. We puts together Versailles and the Louvre in some way, because it takes you to the palace and at the same time through a huge collection of masterpieces. I really recommend you not doing in summer since the place gets really crowded and it gets hard to see some paintings because of the endless excursions in the place. TIP: the general staff building is new and holds the impressionists collections. If you want to buy the ticket with less line, you can go there and them use the same ticket to the winter palace.
Visiting the Hermitage. The Hermitage is a wonderful art gallery that has been restored to its original splendor, and that splendor was unbelievable. A must see in St Petersburg - don't miss it.

Excellent building including grounds. Spent the day there with a tour group, very impressed with the palace. The gardens were wonderful. The fountains started at 10.00am. Get there early as the crowds get large and becomes difficult to walk around all the rooms. Take a walk towards the sea, the views are great. Plenty of shade in the garden if it is hot. Not very many shops selling water and food. Also very difficult to find toilets, not very well sign posted.
Amazing..... The glory of Soviet era is depicted in gold.Place is kept very clean and very well managed.You cannot miss when you visit SPB.

Wow!. Wow! Amazing on so many levels. More Rembrandts than I have seen anywhere else. The Ambassador's Staircase on entering the winter palace sets the tone. The big problem is us, the tourists. Too many and this spoils the experience for all. Still if you go to St Petersburg and do not see this set of buildings, why did you go? Some amazing detail. Much design is european but much materials and craftsmanship is Russian. Magnificent.
Huge. This is by far the biggest museum I have ever visited ! the paintings and sculptures are fabulous ! a big recommandation to all !
Huge crowds but worth it. Awesome. What a place! Obviously a world class attraction. Don't miss it. Probably a good idea to get there early in the day to avoid the crowds.
The louvre of the north. A wonderful example of wealth, power, and the evidence of soviet policies are all around.wish the original amber room was there

Absolutely Magnificent. Overwhelming experience. We were on a Princess Cruise and booked a 2 day St Petersburg Tour with all the trimmings. We were the first tour group in, an hour and a half before the general public so we had plenty of time and no crowds. The place was simply more than we ever expected, the art works, display spaces and the general condition of the exhibits and rooms were first class. The Russians must be congratulated on the way they have looked after the place.

How to avoid the 4 hour queues!. I've been working at the Hermitage this summer, and it has pained me to see that everyday people queue for up to hours to see the exhibits. Please please please buy your tickets online, or at the machines outside the entrance! The museum is definitely worth it. If you are interested in the interiors, classical art, or ancient art then go into the Winter Palace, however if you're more interested in modern, impressionist or surrealist art you'll want to go to the other part of the Hermitage which has great works in the General Staff building which is the huge white semi circular building opposite the winter place.

Beautiful But Very Hot and Crowded. The Hermitage museum is part of the winter palace complex and it is huge. Our guide told us that to visit and really explore each of the rooms would take 7 years. The collection of artwork is unbelievable. There are only 10 Leonardo da Vinci paintings left in the world and the Hermitage has 2 of them. We went with a tour-which is recommended but it was still an exhausting experience due to the crowds and the lack of air conditioning. Ideally I think it should be tackled over 2-3 days with rest breaks in between. But even if you have only a few hours, do not miss it.
Splendid St Petersburg . Excellent, clearly demonstrated a vast working knowledge of highlights and history of each area visited.
Worth the trip, the expenses and the lines. Buy your ticket on-line beforehand and skip the lines. I can't believe people don't do this. Wonderful, over the top and decadent.

Plan your visit!. We visited twice in our visit to St Petersburg. The first was an experience from hell, by the second we'd sussed it out!We attempted to use a student card to get in free ( being mature students on an art course). Make sure if you do, that it has a date. If you are a mature student they don't understand the concept!  This involved the long queue. Over an hour. It's not worth it. Then we joined a group that whistled through rooms past paintings by artists you'd waited years to see. It was hot. Pause to look and you're lost. Rembrandt's and Leonardo's are surrounded by folk who just want a selfie.   Second  attempt was far better.  Buy a tickets for 600 R from kiosks in courtyard. Online gives no advantage but costs $16. Then you're straight in. Plan what interests you before you go, and don't forget Impressionists are now across the road in the yellow General Staff building. Hermitage has an excellent website. You can plan your trip, putting what you want to see on a map with directions   Or just write down key room numbers and pick up a plan. The room attendants are helpful even if it involves sign language. Don't miss the Raphael corridors copied by Catherine the Great from Rome. Look out for paintings she bought from the Walpole collection, including a questionable Leonardo nude. Look out for special exhibitions. On the top floor there's currently  Cranach and back on display is 'Van Der Weyden's St Luke painting the Virgin' , (over?) cleaned but still fantastic.  And if it all gets too much get out and pop across to the General Staff building which contains magnificent Monet's and Matiste's and empty cafes.

Have to visit when in St Petersburg. The Hermitage Museum is a must to visit, you will be blown away by all the different rooms and decor and architecture. Also pieces by Ranbrandt and Michel Angelo are on display.

BE AWARE !. You must be going there to check out this page so I wont repeat what's already been said.It is a must see in a lifetime but it can be chaos on legs!Check out contributor moreglob,absolutely spot on.Dont go there on your own be part of an organised tour.They let you in first (upto 10-30)before the queues become enormous outside.I have now decided I never want to see another European palace again! And its a wonder the revolution didn't start earlier! Hope you like glitz and gold!Good luck, enjoy.

Hermitage Museum not to be missed!. There is something for everyone at the Hermitage, from royal artworks to Egyptian artifacts and Grecian antiquities - you need to spend at least an entire day here if not two to see everything, Well worth the ticket price and as the museum was designed to house artworks it is very well laid out but it pays to pre-book tickets/tour and get there early to avoid the queues. The building itself is a treasure with a magnificent staircase and surrounds. Also, in addition other ad hoc exhibitions are on show and for my visit this included the Byzantine and antique toy displays. Fabulous and enjoyed every minute.

See the treasures of the Russia. see the fine art the collection of gold and Jewels that go back centuries. it is massive and can not be fully appreciated in one day. like the Louvre you need time to really see the whole museum

Both a Five Star Location and maybe a 2-3 star visit. The Hermitage is spectacular - 5 buildings with a collection that contains almost all the varieties of art and 3,000,000 items. Not all on view of course but those that are are displayed in beautiful surroundings. The Winter Palace is opulent almost beyond description. That is the five star piece. But the day we were there 8 cruise ships were in the harbor (and I was on one of them so can't complain) and the crowds at the Hermitage were similar to the NY subway at rush hour. Tour groups are let in an hour early and it's really crowded then but when it is opened to everyone you can barely walk through the rooms catching at best a glimpse of the art work. And because you have to carry your passport at all times and because they are having a big problem with pickpockets we had a couple very nervous tour guides. So glad I went but disappointed that I wasn't able to see more of the gorgeous artwork in this fabulous museum.

Worth every penny of your admission ticket. Even if empty, the Hermitage is a majestic place to visit. Nevertheless this huge museum does require a strategy how to explore it and what you would like to see as it can be overwhelming. Our favourites - the Russian Rooms, Jordan Staircase and Peacock Clock.

Amazing!!!. Simply the best museum ever, what a collection, what a place, does not matter the sort of art you like, paintings, sculptures, ancient, old, contemporaneous, out of any scale you might consider!!!

Not Overrated!. Required visit for all first time visitors to St. Petersburg, I'd heard so much....seen so many photos....watched the movie Russian Ark, yet still I was awed by this amazing museum. Definitely not overrated, words and photos are insufficient. You simply MUST visit.The works of art showcased are true treasures, but it would take multiple visits to truly appreciate the Masters here. The sheer opulence of the rooms themselves is overwhelming. I attempted to take photos to capture "some" of their essence, but that really is impossible--a photo only records a fragment.Many reviews focus on the overcrowded galleries and oppressive throngs, but I didn't mind this -- even on the day we visited, which happened to be "free admission" for the public (first Thursday of the month). Standing outside in an enormous queue would have tried your patience, but getting inside as the doors first open (after cruise ship groups) allowed us to move around relatively freely. The museum is so massive that you really can maneuver and enjoy the wonder of the rooms.
Amazing!. Everything that has been said about the Hermitage is true. The impressionist collection at the Staff Building was beyond world class.

A must see!. Wow! Just wow! Spectacular museum and palace. We took a guided tour of this place. The architecture and interior decor is amazing! The artwork and sculptures housed here are great as well. Our tour guide was so knowledgeable. Very impressed with the Hermitage. A must see on your visit to St Petersburg.

Well worth a visit BUT BE WELL PREPARED. An amazing place with plenty to see. You will find information on this all over the internet if you want some background information on it before you go. This is more to inform you of what to expect on entering the museum ... A couple of things to keep in mind... Try to get an early entry time (not later than 10am if possible) with a good guide, a good guide can evade a lot of the crowds coming behind. Don't underestimate how big the crowd becomes as the morning goes on. DONT bring bags, umbrellas or coats, even a rain mack with you. You will have to check them into cloakrooms on entering. You will be given a tag to claim them on leaving...leaving is absolute mayhem, no system at all at the cloakrooms, hundreds of people pushing and shoving you out of the way, only 1 lady per section trying to retrieve belongings. Took me 20 minutes to get my fold up rain gear back and we were early leavers. The queues outside were enormous and go on all day. I was there in July, maybe it is not so crazy at a different time of the year. It was well worth the visit but Once was enough for me. There is no control over the numbers they allow in and the place becomes a sea of bodies.

So much to see, so little time…. The Hermitage is one of the largest and oldest museums in the world dating back to 1764 during the reign of Catherine the Great. We were fortunate to begin our tour before the doors were opened to the public which allowed us time to visit the interior rooms with less crowds and more opportunities for better photos. The museum has in excess of 3,000,000 items however only a small portion is available to the public. The public is permitted to visit the Winter Palace, the Small Hermitage, Old Hermitage, the New Hermitage and the Hermitage Theatre. Before entering the complex you will see the Palace Square with a dominating 2 mile long building. It is now the General Staff building.Once you enter the courtyard, the beauty of the blue, white and gold façade of the Winter Palace dazzles you. We spent 4-1/2 hours at the Hermitage Museum and could not begin to do justice seeing all that it has to offer. Highlights of our visit were: the Palace Square, Winter Palace, Jordan Staircase, the Peacock Clock, Golden Drawing Room, Rembrandt’s Return of the Prodigal Son and so many more. If you plan on going, you surely will not be disappointed. For us, we hope to have another opportunity to visit St. Petersburg and pick up where we left off today!

Russian History . This is one of the most amazing museum i have ever visited. It has been constructed in levels and different rooms have different historical value. It is said to be 10 kms long and i was not able to compete it in one day. A true art lover will definitely take a week to complete this tour. Must visit.

hunt for the gems that are not on the guided tours. I strongly advise you to visit this museum on your own or with a private guide. We spent 7 hours !!! and will gladly return for a second visit.There are a lot (mostly ?) groups and guided tours : you can see it before some of the highlights of the museum, and then we found absolute gems that we had all for ourselves : for ex. 3 very good works of Breughel the Elder, masterpieces, absolute masterpieces (yes I am from Belgium), so do your homework, especially if you have a limited amount of time. Prepare the visit and make a list of items you absolutely want to see. Going to "your" highlights do enjoy this wonderful amazing place.During our visit we accidentally stumbled on the temporary exhibition (upper floor) of Cranach, ah what a wonderful day we spent in this wonderful place
great. its a great museum, with so many things to see. very organized, you can buy tickets in an office inside the museum or in outside it special machines.

Hugh collections of art works, spectacular palaces. Very crowded in July.. Plan ahead if you are visiting in July. Get your ticket from their official website, enter through a side door. There is a cafe inside, we end up spending the whole day there. There are many tour groups and rude tourists. A lot of them don't seem to respect the rules, take pics when it is not appropriate. They touch everything when they are not supposed to. The AC can be minimal in rooms that are full of people. It is a must visit in St. Petersburg.
One of the best and biggest museums of the world. Yes, it is one of the best and biggest museums of the world and this is a very good reason someone to visit it
Simply Awesome. Perhaps the primo museum in the world. Endless treasures paintings sculptures fabulous rooms too much to try to describe. Stunning on every level.

A fabulous Museum to visit!. This museum is a great representation of how the leaders of this country lived in their golden era. There is so much art to look at that it will take you many days to finish if you want to see everything. What a fabulous lifestyle in contrast with the life of the common people.

Wow!. An amazing museum in terms of the displays, the variety of exhibits and the building itself. You could easily spend all day here and still not see everything! We did a tour so saw the highlights in 2 hours which was very good.

Unsurpassed beauty and oppressisive crowds. The art in the museum is second to none and the buildings and their decoration is even grander than the art. But the crowds must be among the worst in the world. We had a tour booked so we got early admission but as far as I could tell that just meant earlier crowds. There is not a second of time or an inch of space to relax and enjoy your surroundings. Guides kept herding us along like cattle. A Davinci here, Matisse's The Danec there, an impossibly beautiful throne room there. But I'm not saying don't go. Of course you must go. There is no denying it is one of the most fabulous palaces and museums in the world. Just be prepared for the crowds. Maybe do your homework before you go because if you think there's time or space to read the little description beside the painting, forget about it.

DenRus Private Tour. We really enjoyed our DenRus tour of St. Petersburg, Russia, and especially our tour of the Hermitage, on July 19th. Our guide, Kyrill, spoke English fluently, was an outstanding guide and was very knowledgeable regarding the works of art that we especially wanted to see. We would highly recommend booking a private tour with DenRus on any trip to St. Petersburg. Not only was our DenRus tour far superior to any of the excursions arranged by Oceania Cruise ship Marina and its tour service GoNext, it was also a better value.Dick Carroll & Anne BrookesHouston, Texas

Overwhelming in a good way. This is a location that has more in it that one can take it in one visit. But tickets in advance of your visit to skip the line. No flash photography but unfortunately a lot of visitors ignore this and the guards do not enforce it as they should. Incredible collections on display and the restoration is amazing.

One of Best Museums in the World. There is no doubt this is an absolutely fantastic museum filled with a variety of 'curiosities'. It is huge. This is the second biggest museum in the world in terms of art gallery space, second to the Louvre. Over 2.2million pieces means it would take 5-8 years to see it all. The old museum and the winter palace were my favourite, with art and exhibits in regal surroundings. But a guide is a must to ensure that you see the best bits. We were part of a tour and had a wonderful lady lead the way. But be warned, no a/c so can get hot and clammy in summer and no cafes or food inside. Go early and hook up with a tour company who are able to get early access before the general public are allowed in at 1030. But this is a St Petersburg must see.

Top museum but overcrowded in summer. A lot has been written about this fabulous museum. No words can truly describe its wealth.One comment - why not extend the working hours during the peak season? This could probably bring the pressure down somewhat.

Be Prepared to Fight the Crowds. The Hermitage is a must see experience for the architecture as much as the collection. DaVinci, van Rijn, etc. Almost 3 million objects.
