You are reminded that the buildings (there are four palaces joined as one museum) were designed as residences. Since designed as four palaces, not a museum, the circulation is impossible. You would be better served by hiring a private guide and laying out what you want to see beforehand. Don't be fooled by early entry group tours. There are dozens of them. Try the late afternoon.

A must must see - you can spend days here. The place is huge and well decorated. There are so many items displayed that you can shoot hundreds of photos and you should take the photos so that you can remember what you have seen. If there is one thing I want to see in St Petersburg again and that would be the Hermitage Museum. The photos tell the reason. But if you do go, try to get a guide that can cut through the long line up, don't want to stand in the line up waiting and waiting.
One of the finest museams and art galleries in the world. The Hermitage is fantastic. The art work and sculptures are incredible. You may want to buy entrance tickets in advance to avoid the lines.

A quiet hidden corner of wonder. Away from the crowds and lines, a trip to the basement of the main building reveals a magnificent collection of early indigenous Siberian art. Including a Scythian burial site (burrow) these artifacts rival anything I've seen at the museums on the west coast of North America. It's a quiet respite from the crowds above. If you venture to the impressionist collection don't miss Van Gogh's "the Bush" a personal favorite.
Massive art collection!. Thanks to our tour guide Julia from Alla tours, we managed to get through the museum in 2 hours with 9 kids while seeing art work from Rembrandt, Da Vinci, and many others.

Super. Split the visit in a few days it's overwhelming. First thursday of each month is free entrance.
Students go in for free, but make Sure your student card says student on it.

It takes more than just one day to see it. First piece of advice - do not line up for a ticket, the lines can stretch for miles. Either pre-book your ticket on line or use the following trick: When you approach the building from the front, follow the signs for the on-line ticket holders. This will take you off to the right and through a side gate to a separate entrance. Just before you get to that entrance, under a portico are two ticket machines where you can use your credit card to purchase tickets. No-one knows they are there as I only ever saw one person using them. It spits out your ticket which you then take into the nearby entrance and scan through the turnstiles and you are in, while the other 2,000 people still wait patiently in the line for the ticket office.If you have booked on-line, then use that same entrance I have just directed you to but take your email confirmation up to the desk, where they will issue you with a physical ticket to scan at the turnstiles next to them.There are maps available in most languages and you are going to need one or you will get lost.There are 400 separate galleries spread over 3 floors and several buildings. Remember that this is the largest museum in the world so my suggestion is to go first to the café and over a coffee or a snack from their amazing selection of delicious items, sit down with your map and plan your route in order to see as much as you can.If you are there on Wednesday, not only does the Museum stay open longer (until 9pm) but the famous Peacock Clock is wound up at 7pm on Wednesdays to do it's thing. This is the only time you can see it operating, but be warned, there is seating in the hall where it is for only about 6 people, and if you don't get there at least a half hour early, you won't get anywhere near it to see it work.There are too many fabulous items in the Hermitage to list - download the ap and you can get a virtual tour - but don't neglect the State Rooms. The grand staircase is a wonder, and these rooms formed the Winter Palace of the Czars and are magnificent in themselves.Photography throughout the Museum is permitted so go for it.If you want something from the Museum Shop - my daughter wanted a special "Hermitage" teddy bear - best to look at the start of your visit then leave it to "on the way out" - even though the Museum shut at 9pm, the shop shut at 6pm.This building and this collection is unsurpassed - take several days to do it, or work out what you want to see beforehand and target those areas using your map.
This is another "must see" in St Petersburg.. I would say that it is advisable to allow at least 4 hours to visit this incredible Palace - museum. Some of the rooms are breath-taking!

It's difficult to comprehend how big this Museum is !!! . Picked up by the excellent tour company Alla Tours , from the cruise terminal who had an appt for 10.00 , guess what @ 10 .10 we are climbing the grand staircase . Soooooo much to see & observe , very busy in July .It is one of the five largest art museum in the world , with five buildings , you could spend days , weeks , truly magnificent .

Make sure you go to the theasury :). Museum itself is amazing and worth visiting, you should be prepared for at least one hour of waiting for a ticket. So I wouldn't suggest you this, unless you are a student, because it is possible to get a discount. There are machines for buying tickets, be sure to use those. For 300 rb you can visit the Diamond and Gold rooms, and it is totally worth it, because it is one hour of guided tour and many interesting items are on display. The rooms of museum are beautiful, but you can read about that elsewhere, plan to spend at least 4-5 hours inside.

World class. Just came back from 4 hours at the Hermitage and Winter Palace. Fabulous, extensive art collection on display. Could spend days here soaking up all of the art. Building has been beautifully restored and is absolutely magnificent.

Amazing Arcetecture . The Hermitage is definitely worth a visit, even if you are not particularly into art museums. The Hermitage is housed in the winter palace and extensively fills many parts of the palace. Not only is the art interesting, but so is the architecture and room decoration. We ordered tickets online but had difficulty finding the proper que to get in...a number of misleading signs. Online tickets really are a much qiicker way to get in. Once in you can take flashless photos without purchasing a photo pass (no one hassled us at all). The crowds can be rather thick, especially at the popular and we'll known pieces (Rembrandt, da Vinci, Michelangelo, etc). I doubt any time of day is best to see these. I particularly enjoyed the lower level showcasing Greek art as the rooms were beautiful and there were few tourists.The moderns (Picasso, Monet, etc.). Are no longer housed in the main building. Rather, you have to go to the General Staff building. This was well worth it as there are a number of Monet and other modern masters.Most name plates have English, as well as a few longer information signs. We had some information on key pieces in a guidebook and got along fine. If you really like to know more than the title and artist you will want an audio guide or tour.We were in no rush and walked through the vast majority of rooms. This took us about 6 hours. It would be difficult to see much in less than 2 hours, especially when getting in and fighting crowds.
Excellent!!!. What an amazing Museum/Palace!Over 3,000,000 pieces of art an history!Andy the rooms are worth the visit. They are out of this world.

Fabulous . This is a must on a visit to St Petersburg. This will be at least a day to look round as there is do much to look at. The palace itself is a breathtaking the rooms they have kept to show you what it was like originally was fantastic. I would recommend you buy your tickets on line as this will save you queuing as there is a fast track system fir pre-booked tickets.
Wow. Fantastic jewel of the olden age and the legacy of the historic tsars. Over 3 million of beautiful paintings of the past famous artists are being displayed.

WOW- incredibly impressive- definitely a top 5 museum. The Hermitage Museum is a most impressive place, composed of 5 very large buildings, containing over three million objects- our guide told us it would take 11 years to see it all if you spend only one minute at each. The oldest building was home to the imperial family, the others housed their art collection, they all are now brimming with incredible works from great European artists.The buildings are incredibly crowded thronging with tourists for all over the world. If one waits in line, it could be hours of waiting before one can enter.There are great paintings from famous artists, the most impressive being the Rembrandt's. The sculptures are magnificent, the armory room very impressive ma she Egyptology section almost as good as the British museum.Be prepared for lots of walking and heat can be daunting. It's all well worth it!!!

State hermitage museum . Awesome! Need to have loads of time to see this wonderful place. Although our group with Alla Tours, we had early entry into the museum, it was still very crowded. But once inside our guide was able to give us wealth of information, and did not feel rushed. Ideal for solo travellers who could spend lot more time in this beautiful place.

in one word: overwhelming in size and contents. Officially named the State Hermitage Museum, this is probably the most visited site seeing event in St. Petersburg. And it is well worth the visit, though one should schedule at least one full day for a visit. You should also be prepared for large tour groups milling around in most of the exhibition holds and in front of toilets, which offer plenty of opportunities for pickpockets: be aware.The Museum comprises five buildings all connected and accessible with your admission ticket with the exception of the Winter Palace of Peter the First. The entrance to all is in the main winter Palace, the largest building of the complex located close to the Neva river and the Dvortsovyy Most bridge and street. The group tours enter on the river side, while the individuals use the inside entrance from the court yard. For all those who have their own transportation I would suggest leaving the car at the hotel, and taking a taxi rather than exposing oneself to the stress of finding a parking spot.Since you are dealing with two or three big buildings involving lots of stairs, very comfortable shoes are recommended; as a matter of fact, the guide brochure offered by the Museum requests that you do not wear high heels. I would also recommend, that you take some time before rushing into the Museum’s exhibits, and decide what exhibitions you want to see the most. The information plan is very well organized and colour coded, allowing you to prioritize your wishes. It an enables you as well to find the shortest way from point A to point B.The staff is quite helpful though not always willing to offer information in English. Therefore a few Russian words might help to break the ice and show your willingness and accepting the mother tongue. All of a sudden you will find that the English or German or whatever will be offered as their alternative language.We found the toilets quite clean and the coffee shop on the main floor of the main building offering reasonable food options at reasonable prices. All floors are accessible to handicapped people including those in wheelchairs, though at times reaching ones’ destination might be labourious.A definite must in St. Petersburg.

Bring own headphones to share audio guide . 1. Free entry for students (any nationality), so bring your Id. I forgot my student Id but showed them my health insurance card. Apparently they don't notice and just check the "valid until" date. 2. Audio guide is held like a phone. No provided head phones, although there is a possibility to stick in headphones. We recommend to bring you own, then you can even share an audio guide. 500 rubles and passport deposit. No students discount here. The audio guide only tells you about certain paintings and rooms though, not everything. Of course the most famous ones are covered. 3. If you don't want to spend ALL day here, we recommend to come here in the evening (open till 9pm on wed and fri). There won't be a queue. Although the queue in the morning moves relatively fast. 4. We read somewhere that the Peacock clock strikes at full hours. We were there at 7pm. But nothing happend. We asked someone why it's not happening and what we understood is that it only strikes on Wednesdays.

World famous art collection and palace interiors. You will experience an extensive art collection second only to the Louvre in Paris. Buy tickets on the internet to avoid long lines.You will benefit from the works of all world famous artists.You need time. If possible, use more than one day in the museum because it can be difficult to digest all impressions in one day.

the best of st. petersburg. by far, in my opinion, this is the best attraction the city of st. petersburg can offer.a fabulous place by all counts. big and huge compleax.a very big courtyard in front. the hermitage museum is superb.one of the greatest in the world. definitely at par with Louvre in Paris.the whole complex have six buidings and the museum itself can not be seen in one day. it needs at least two visits to fully appreciate its exhibits.

Lots to see. There is obviously lots to see here (way more than we could take in on our short visit) so we focused on the palace rooms. Those rooms were impressive and our private guide did a great job of explaining the history. The main disappointment is that the museum pieces are sometimes not well presented and the buildings are poorly maintained.

Where did all these people come from. The crowds are beyond belief although the museum is extraordinary. We felt there was much we didn't see because they take all the tours through the same rooms. It is also a little discouraging to know all of this was re-built after wwii. I wouldn't miss it, but in some ways its disappointing.

Phenomenal!. Not to be missed when visiting St Petersburg. Unfortunately EVERYONE else is also visiting, either get there early or be part of a small tour group that can skip the lines and get one in some of the lesser visited rooms. All the Impressionists are now to the east in a beautiful newly renovated building without the crowds.

A wonderful Palace that is truly magnificent. Yes a place where you can imagine the feeling of being a royal. From the jewels to just about every room. We had a guided tour and it made the difference. I would go back

Outstanding collection of art. The museum is huge, the building itself is very beautiful and is worth to look at. The collection of paintings and sculptures from different cultures and centuries is impressive. Especially I liked the old Byzantium. One day is not enough to see and enjoy everything.

An Unbelivable Treasuretrove of Art. This Museum is fantastic. The building is magnificent but the artworks it contains are beyond belief. We were told that to spend just one minute looking at every art treasure would take you over eight months! A place not to be missed when visiting St Peterburg.

WONDERFUL - but avoid the crowds and get there early, and try to visit off-season.. Firstly, arrange your visit outside of high season. In high season the crush of mainly Chinese and Japanese tour groups all competing to take photos of the de Vinci’s and Rembrandt’s is a nightmare – luckily for the Rembrandt’s there is a room full of them, and they don’t have a clue what they are looking at, so they just take a few photos of the first one and leave the rest alone - thankfully. They should have a separate room with pictures of Mickey Mouse and Homer Simpson, tell them they are da Vinci’s and Rembrandts, and they wouldn’t be any the wiser. Either way, don’t come here expecting the opportunity to quietly sit and admire a da Vinci – because you won’t. Luckily I never rated da Vinci’s paintings (sculpture a different matter) – the Mona Lisa doesn’t look like she wears an enigmatic smile, in my opinion she looks like a constipated granny.Also make sure that you arrive before opening time (before 1030am) and have correct denomination of notes below 1000 Rubles so that you can use the ticket machines (they take 100 to 500 Ruble notes only, and the price pp is 600 Rubles), rather than queue for 100m with the crowds.The art work. Be selective, as there is so much to see. We whizzed through and still spent 3 hours inside and missed the entire downstairs, including the Egyptian room. I skimmed through the French section (I never rated French art – too overdramatic and all show – typical) and the English section (there are only a couple of landscapes worth seeing, and they are mainly poor portraits of Russian nabobs.) The English section doesn’t even have any dogs playing poker! Big disappointment.But the Flemish and Dutch art is wonderful, and the tapestries following from climbing up the main staircase are also wonderful. Take your time with the Rembrandt’s – you will never see such a collection, not even in Holland (although The Nightwatch is in Amsterdam and is probably my favourite painting.)The state rooms are beautiful. Being a geologist I can only stand in amazement at the malachite, rhodonite, porphyry (less so) and, most beautiful of all, the Lapiz tables, urns and other furnishings.I didn’t make note of all the room names, but the red-flock-wall-papered throne room puts the best of British pubs to shame, and the golden columned (ball?-)room is beyond imagination.Summary: visit out of season and early to try avoid the crowds; use the ticket machines; spend time on the Rembrandt’s and, I suppose if you like them, the da Vinci’s and other paintings; and be prepared to spend a whole day inside, because if you really want to do the place justice, then you will need that long! Oh – and the audio guide is worth the money.

So much to see. Had to go there as it is a very famous museum. So much to see. Handy that it is on the hop on hop off bus route. Hint is buy tickets online and you can just exchange them when you get there. It avoids the queues. The entrance on the side closest to the canal is where the tourist groups enter, chose the other one on the square.

Impressive exhibitions, well-presented. This is one of the very interesting museums to visit in Russia and worldwide. Many of its exhibitions are unique and very valuable. Yet, one may have two legit reservations: (1) The very important ancient Greek pieces we were told remain hidden in storage (lack of funds?), and (2) museum's policy that groups are given priority over individual visitors, which means that individuals have to wait much-much longer. This is unfair !

Don't miss it. The must do place to visit in SPB. I'm not an art lover, and their sure is plenty of it here but I thoroughly enjoyed my visit. Seeing some of the old masters work was great and interesting even for a heathen like me. The highlight for me though was the splendour and opulence of the interior. Some of the rooms are just stunningly beautiful and artifacts are jaw droppingly gorgeous. The place is huge, so plan your trip wisely and take a break in the cafe to recharge your batteries.

Hermitage with a 3 year old. This is our second visit. The first time we were in May and this time in July. Both times we had great experiences, but in July it was very crowded. We hired a private guide which made a big difference and pleasant experience. We definitely need to come back in Winter.

A truly great Museum. As others have said this is truly one of the great museums. Opulence simply doesn't describe it. The sheer scale and volume of contents meant that we only had time to see the highlights on our tour, but it was simply wonderful. Our guide managed to steer us clear of the majority of the crowds even though it was July and absolutely heaving with tourists. Any visit to the Hermitage is an unforgettable experience.
Wessam Mohamed . Breath taking. A museum with the rich collections of the Romanovs. Royal luxury. The golden peecock is a must see

A Must. One of the best Museums in the world for sure. Please see it. There is entry fee for locals and tourists ( different) and also for videos etc..... but its huge and there is a map of the Hermitage which will guide you to various rooms and opulence. The place is priceless and right on the water-front. At the end treat yourself to a dessert from outside.

Massive museum in a massive palace. I understand Hermitage to be 2nd largest museum after Louvre. It is not possible to see it in a day. With the crowds & tour groups it is very difficult to see anything. Do not try to tour with another person--split up & reconnect periodically. The art is overwhelming. The architecture is over the top.

You would think it was their first day- unorganised. This was my second time at the museum. This time I came during tourist season, so there was a lot more people. The first day, my brother and I stood in a line that did not move for 15 minutes, and we were about 100 meters from the door. We left. The second day, he was determined to see it, so we got there at 10:30 in the morning. After being in line for one hour, we were almost halfway up to the door. There are these announcements made that are almost inaudible and you cannot hear them very well over the wind and talking. I told my brother, "It sounds like they are saying something about ticket machines." There were about 5 machines near the back of the line that look like ATM's, but since I live in Russia, I am accustomed to seeing KACCA or Tickets at places that sell tickets. These machines were not marked in any way. I told my brother to hold our place in line, and I walked back to look at the machines. Sure enough, they sold tickets, and you could by pass the two hour line and walk straight into the museum. Why they do not have these ticket machines marked is beyond me, but what a waste of valuable time! Just think, the first day, we LEFT. Perhaps we would have never come back! They need to get their outside signage updated to fit the expectations of tourists. It is a pretty simple thing to know where to buy tickets! Come on Hermitage! How long have you been open?!? Also, since the lines are so long, they should put a shelter for people to stand under. I would NEVER stay in that line if it was raining- which it does almost 6 out of 7 days there.

Wonderful but too much to see as part of a 2-day tour. It was beautiful but there is such a lot to see that you can't do it justice with a 2 hour tour. Also our organized tour didn't go the the part we would have liked to see, which was the Impressionists which was in another building.

Hermitage museum . It is a must see. Rich with valuables and history. Every corner has a stunning masterpiece The marble decorations, tables and vases are impressive. You can not visit Saint Peterborough without visiting this museum. For those who can not walk for long there are wheelchairs as you will have to stop by each piece for sometime to look at the wonderful details.

Incredible History on Display. A must-visit in St. Petersburg. The interior is stunning and the museum is a maze of rooms...many, many rooms. Easy to spend a few hours visiting each room. I had a private tour guide who was able to take me through Russian history. Palace Square outside of the museum is a wonderful location to take photos and take in the moment.

Opulence and art everywereh - a top museum in the world.. Easily one of the top museums in the world! Overflowing with art, treasures, artifacts, and opulence. Minimum of 2.5 hours, easily 4-5 hours. Easy to get separated from your party in there. Terrific view along the river as well. For sure go with a tour guide or use an audio tour.

MUST SEE!!!!. This museum/palace is astonishing. Every floor, wall ceiling is masterfully done. It would truly take someone days and days to walk through and truly appreciate this gem. I can not say enough of the awe inspiriting feeling you get when viewing this museum and palace.
Unforgettable. One of the richest museums in the world! Fantastic collection of every kind of art - an absolute must see!
Wow. If this is how the Tsars and Tsarinas lived, I can see why there was a revolution. Our mouths were agape throughout the visit

Lost in Arts. Even when we are not seriously into arts, culture and history, this museum is so fantastic to let go when in St. Petersburg. It's one of the world's top few museums (together with Paris' Louvre) with over 3 million finest collections from ancient to modern artworks. It's amazing to see up close paintings by legendary artists such as Leonardo da Vinci, Rembrandt, Van Gogh, C'ezanne, etc. We ended up spending almost the whole day here and were able to see only a small part (visit was a few years back in July).

A truly outstanding palace and museum. To do the Hermitage full justice you need several days. It's not just the art and treasures that are stunning, the building itself has so many stunningly attractive rooms. However the crowds and the queues are equally overwhelming. Some tips: 1. Buy your ticket on-line. The ticket tells you about a side entrance. When we entered there was absolutely no queue while others stood waiting elsewhere in their hundreds!2. Buy the ticket on the Russian website. It's identical to the English one but oddly tickets are half the price. Irena Domingo has a blog that tells you how to do this.3. Go on Wednesday or Friday evening when it's open till 9pm - the rooms are much quieter after 6pm.4. Allow plenty of time!5. Get an audioguide. The English tour doesn't happen that often and you'll just be stuck in a group without having a chance to pause and look more closely.6. Ask when the Peacock Clock operates. We were lucky enough to catch it at 7pm - a unique show.7. Don't be put off by the café reviews - it's quite OK and anyway you're not allowed to bring food or drink in.

Very Impressive. If you are visiting St Petersburg The Winter Palace is a must see! The architecture and interior is absolutely stunning. The whole building is full of so much history and famous artwork. The only down side was that it was very busy when we visited, other than that I would highly recommend going!

The biggest disappointment of my holiday. I loved the Peacock Clock; Nicolas II's library was evocative; the Treasury (one could go in as part of a pre-booked group) had a lot of interest. However, the main art collection was a big disappointment. It did not live up to the hype. Many of the famous pictures allegedly by great names were actually "attributed to" and not of the calibre you might see in the Louvre or the Galleria Borghese for example. I think the most interesting collection was the 19th century aristocratic portraits by Christina Robertson which were brilliant. It is worth mentioning that the loos are good and the catering very well priced.
Magnificent place!. I spent about 5 hours and I haven't finished my excursion. Would love to come and finish it) Or maybe I'd like to stay and live there) Lol

Best museum ever!. If you want learn history, let visit this museum! You will learn a lot, directly. The collection is very complete, the palace is unique and the information is very helpful. My son, 9 yo, get enjoy to watching the collection, especially the painting.

Overcrowded . If you are in St petersburg you must go there. Just try to avoid the crowds if you can. Buy the tickets in advance online, it will save you hours of queuing. Two days a week the museum is open until 9pm. I guess there will be less groups in the evening. Our visit was kind of ruined by hundreds of people streaming up an down the aisles. It was literally impossible to take a couple of minutes to take a look at anything. But, as I said before, it's a must-see and the palace is quite stunning. If you want to see real artworks, go to the gallery staff building just in front of the Winter Palace. No crowds, air-conditioning and real masterpieces.

Very good museum. . Very very good museum. Everything was great. We were 2 adults. I highly recommend to take a guidance, because the entry to the museum is very hard without a guidance. Without a guidance, you will stande very long time to buy a ticket.

The breadth of the collection is staggering ★ ★ ★ ★ ★. This museum and palace deserves its exceptional reputation, I was blown away!17th Century Flemish painting? Medieval Italian armour? A Petrine baroque 'chat room'? Chandeliers the size of caravans? Highly elaborate solid silver salt cellars and inkwells? I could go on and on and on.....what an incredible collection of art, artifacts and interiors in a building oozing with history.Not to be missed, magnificent!

Amazing!. Wonderful collection. Plan lots of time if you can. We were only able to see some of the highlights but, you were able to get close to Rembrandt's, DaVinci's etc. The locals get a discount if they wait in line for tickets on the day of the visit. Try to avoid waiting in that line.

Great Museum but very crowded. What a shame the customer experience for this wonderful museum is so poor. Long queues to get in could be alleviated but having longer opening hours. The museum doesn't open until 10:30 am and by then everyone is queuing up to enter. Upon entry you need to queue again for the cloakrooms as you cannot take bags or coats inside-althoguh we did see some people with these in the museum-not sure how that happened. You cannot return to the cloakroom unless exiting the museum, and then you would need to buy a new ticket to get in. So make sure you have everything you need with you when you leave the cloakroom. However you can't take a waterbottle or snack into the museum By lunch time we could see the queue to enter was enormous-through the courtyard and all around the square, What these poor folk standing in the rain didn't realise was that the ticket office was closed for lunch. Really? Who treats customers like that? Most of the tourists inside the museum were in groups and frequently blocked the flow around the museum. The whole experience was like trying to view fine art on a crowded commuter train. Fantastic building though! very ornate richly decorated walls and ceilings.

Stunning. Absolutely a must see if you are in Saint Petersburg. Amazing!just be careful to keep your personal belongings in frontof you. Pickpockets will try to steal from you while you are taking photos and admiring everything.

Magnificent!. Our visit was part of a tour from our cruise ship but the couple of hours we spent in the Hermitage really blew us away. Our guide was particularly knowledgeable so we didn't waste any time. The collection of art is amazing and the lavishness of the rooms, breath taking. This alone has encouraged us to consider taking a holiday to this wonderful city.

Huge, come early in the morning. Art here is a must for anyone who loves art. On the practical note. It gets so crowded by guided tours from cruise ships as the day advances that some rooms become impossible to pass, with 50 people in front of each painting clicking their smartphones instead of looking at the painting itself. Sad really when you think about it.

A Marathon of Beautiful Art Works. A Baltic cruise is not complete without a visit to The Hermitage State Art Museum of St Petersburg where Catherine the Great's magnificent art collections are housed in glorious state rooms. The opulence and scale of wealth is astounding- no wonder the peasants revolted.It is advised that you need to be prepared for a great deal of walking both inside and outdoors and this is the case. It can be very hot and crowded in the state rooms with up to 17000 visitors each day in peak season. Security requests that no water bottles be taken in so make sure you're well fed and hydrated and then feast your eyes on fabulous gilded and chandeliered state rooms with Delft tiled storage heaters in each corner, see artefacts of the most decorative order, stunning parquetry floors, frescoed walls and art works beautifully curated. In The Hermitage you can come closer to a Da Vinci or Rembrandt that in almost any other art gallery in the world. This visit will become an everlasting memory.

Remarkable!. Unquestionably, one of the finest museums in the world. Works by Renoir, Degas, Monet, Van Gogh, Da Vinci, and Rembrandt...to name a few. Not only is the art remarkable, but the palace is grand and stunning. We were on a private tour that started at 9:00 am...1 1/2 hours before it opens to the public. I'd highly recommend trying to hook the same as the lines and droves of people were insane.

the must visit place in Piter. If you visited Piter without visiting State Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace, then you saw half of it, definitely. This is the must see museum, located in the center of city. The best time to visit is weekday (Mon-Fri) morning, 10 AM.

Worthy of it's World famous renoun. This museum is a must for any one visiting St Petersburgh, we could certainly have spent 2-3 days just in this 1 museum. The details and exhibits are fantastic, Make sure you see the Gold Peacock Clock which stands in it's own glass case. Groups have a separate entrance from walk in visitors which helps speed up entry, but be prepared for scanner security and note that you are not allowed to take large bags in.
Museums. Just mind boggling, give yourself time, you need LOTS of time. maybe even if you do not wish to be rushed, give yourself a couple of days
Wow! Impressive!. Again use SPB tours to get you in and around this place. Our guide got us in front of the line and showed us the museum's premier pieces.
was great. Was nice and it was really a experience. July And August is probably the best time there for visiting St. Petersburg

Hermitage Museum. The Museum building interior has rooms where the decor is as good as the exhibits. It was crowded but not so much that I couldn't see what I wanted.I visited on a cool day but as others have said it may well get hot in there in warmer weather. If you have a large coat on you might be asked/told to put it in the cloakroom.Gold leaf in abundance, quite a sight. Yes it is often raining in St Petersburg but the Hermitage alone makes it worth it... let alone visiting the Church on Spilled Blood.. oh my...

Amazing that's All. Did you know that if you stood in front of every exhibit for 8 seconds, it would take nine years to see them all at the Hermitage. It is very crowded during the day but cruise ships offer a night tour also where the crowds are not there. The exhibits of art and the famous works of artists are truly amazing.It is just mind boggling, the wealth that is on display. It would be best to try and pick a time early in the day to beat the crowds but best also with a good tour company such as SPB.

Incredible palace and the collection is stunning. This stunning building houses an extensive art collection. It's a briskly paced tour, but using Best Guides to arrange a private tour guide helped our small group navigate without much headache on a very busy day in peak season. This is no gallery to sit and ponder the work, as the crowds require you to keep moving fairly quickly, but we were able to view, hear about, and even photograph a nice range of beautiful works while touring this important piece of St. Petersburg's history.

Which is more amazing - the building or the art?. Went to The Hermitage on a crowded Saturday afternoon with 3 tired kids in July with a tour group - typically a recipe for disaster. But it is so diverse and beautiful, (and such an amazing history) that you had to be inspired. The building and its rooms are as gorgeous and important as the art. Unfortunately we only had 2 hours, but I would love to go back in and soak it all in under more leisurely conditions.

Breath taking. We had a tour guide for our trip who rushed through a bit quick but after a while I just strolled at my own pace to take in the breath taking art on show ,from the building to the sculptures , to the art work , still speechless about the trip . Very calm place and busy so make a 2-3 day free time to have any chance of looking around and seeing some of many famous pieces .

Beautiful, but so big you cannot possibly see it all. We were fortunate to be able to visit on an "off" day. Only tours were being let in. We were with a group of 16 so we treated well. Even so it was pretty crowded. The content of the museum is astounding. Be prepared for a long stay and still only being able to see a part of it. It has to be a must see if you are in the area.

Beautiful experience. Loved the place. I recommend to buy tickets online before visiting the place. It will enable you to skip the lines.Also if you have the chance to book a guide, do so. Or plan your trip before. I think on the website of the museum you can plan the trip. The place is sooooo big. So not planning in advance will have you wonder around not fully understanding what you see. Also because we did not plan so great i think we missed some essential elements in our visit

Stunningly Beautiful!. St. Petersburg has been on my Bucket List and my primary target was The Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace. (All part of the same complex.) It did not disappoint. I went to Russia as part of a cruise of the Baltics that had 3 days in Peter (as the locals call it.) As an art buff, I read and heard from other visitors that their biggest regret was that they were limited to 2-3 hours in the museum and didn't get to see the Impressionist works. After checking comments on Trip Advisor, we selected a local tour group so we could see more than the ship excursions were offering and spent about 8 hours in the Palace over 2 of the 3 days we were in port. Our guide (Marina with Inside Tours) was very knowledgable and we covered everything I wanted to see, from the Treasury Rooms to the Old Masters, Impressionists, Peacock Clock and more. The palace itself is stunning. Some popular works were hard to see with the crowds, such as Leonardo's Madonna and Child with Goldfinch, but be patient and you'll finally get to the front. Our first day was a Tuesday and Marina said it was the busiest day there because it was closed on Mondays and Catherine's Palace in Pushkin was closed Tuesdays, so everyone hits The Hermitage Tuesday. If you can go, do but get tickets prior to the visit, particularly to the Treasury Rooms as they are on a strict schedule. Exhausting, but well worth it.

Great museum, very busy!. Fantastic collection of art, obviously. Peacock clock a highlight for us non-art experts, but every painting a masterpiece.Queues are unbelievable, to the point my wife felt guilty when we wafted past with our pre-bought ones (we stayed at the state hermitage hotel, where they have a kiosk). Lifts for pushchair and baby change. Café was overcrowded, so plan on eating elsewhere.

the best. To save time, buy electronic tickets and use the separate (side) entrance for visitors with electronic tickets; the line to buy tickets at the museum is gigantic.if your time is limited, plan your visit ahead of time! The rooms in the museum are numbered, but somehow not always in a sequence that you would expect. Don't be afraid to ask the curators - they are extremely nice, knowledgeable and eager to help, although English is sometimes a problem... We concentrated on Italian, Spanish, French art (main building, 2nd floor) and also went to see the post/impressionists & other contemporary paintings which were recently relocated to a separate (impressively renovated) building, across from the main building. It took us from 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. and we still didn't see enough. On Wednesdays the museum is open till 9 p.m. It's amazing the stuff that they have!

Amazing place. Went to the Hermitage when in St Petersburg on a cruise. What an impressive place, with a glimpse of how Russia was before the revolution. The opulence explains in some way why it happened. Lots of paintings and gold leaf. Impressive.

Beautiful building but way, way, overcrowded!. Visited The Hermitage as part of a cruise excursion. Like many of the palaces in St.Petersburg the building was architecturally wonderful but be prepared for a fight to get inside. The queues were very long and as we went through the entrance we had another group literally try and physically push there way past us. It all got very messy. Once inside the volume of visitors made it impossible to relax and enjoy the stunning interior and art work. There were so many people crammed inside that it made the visit uncomfortable.If you can get in early then I suspect you will avoid this kind of chaos but be prepared for a busy visit. That being said it is a wonderful palace and one of those visits you need to do when visiting this great city. Just plan your timing.

A must if you visit St. petersburg. I visited while on a cruise in June 2016. I decided to join the Cruise Line tour as I knew that we would be allowed in at 9am , well before the crowds were allowed to enter. WOW...what an impressive museum. There is so much to see that it's best to concentrate on the most popular areas . Our group had such a knowledgable guide that she made the visit so much more interesting than if you would do this tour on your own. I am so glad I chose this tour as the whole experience was amazing. You go from one awe inspiring room to another and the number of masterpieces in the Hermitage is absolutely mind boggling. Do not miss this place.

Stunning architecture. Wonderful palace with amazing interior! Literary the most beautiful museum of the world. Worth seeing! Small piece of advice - If you want to visit it, buy the tickets online from the official website, than you can go in without waiting at all. The normal line would take you at least 3 hours.
Great visit. We went twice, great visit but tooooo much to see and a bit too much gold for my taste.Many visitors, very busy, but a lot to see.

Buy online ticket or on the maschine next to online ticket entry. I wasn't amazed about Hermitage but I enjoyed some exhibition rooms.However, I would definetely suggest to buy online tickets on homepage or maschine next to e-ticket entry. You will avoid huge lines to ticket office and can even save 2 hours standing in a line. When we went out from Hermitage, there were no one standing at the e-ticket entry comparing to main entrance where line was almost 500 m!!

Great history . A visit to the hermitage is a must while in St Petersburg. Get the tickets on the internet, then you save time in the large queues. There are a lot of groups specifically in the summer months with all the ships coming to in.This is a place to visit year round.

Good Museum but very crowded. There were lots of people visiting this museum when we were there and the queuing detracted quite a bit from the enjoyment of the visit. This museum is similar to, but not as extensive nor as accessible, as the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam.

Great Visit. Go as early as you can maybe with a group tour with early access. this place well you could visit for days but we had three hours there with an excellent guide another great experience and a must in St. P

Chaos amidst beauty. A great museum rebuilt almost entirely. Its popularity is making a decent tour of the museum quite difficult. It is overrun by tour groups and I am not sure why guiding is allowed inside the museum which makes it more complicated. I would suggest to visit in the late afternoon when the lines are less ( snap of the lines attached ) and you can do a focussed visit. The audioguide is not the best but it touches the let highlights.
Exhibits,beautiful and in plenty. World's largest museum and most attractive place.You can spend 3/4 days easily looking at the beautiful paintings .The dancing ,golden Peacock is amazing.

Go Early and Enjoy Longer. Definitely leave a full day for this, if you go early, you can also avoid the crowds. I heavily recommend using the ticket machines rather than waiting in the queue to buy tickets. Also, if there is more than one of you, you should get one person to queue for security while the other is buying tickets otherwise you will have to wait twice.If you buy the tickets using the machines in the courtyard, you can go directly inside to the security queue. Hermitage is worth every penny you pay for it. Also, save some time to the General Staff Building across the Palace Square, which has an impeccable collection of impressionist painters.
Must see if you are fan of art. this museum offers to see you all culture antic collocation , not only European but collection from most part of the world

Go early. This is the reason I came to Russia and I don't regret it. It may not be the Louvre in Paris but it's the next best thing. You don't have to be a Russian history major to enjoy the place. My only suggestion is to get a half day or full day tour by one of the more reputable tour companies. The place is just too big and they will swing you through the important exhibits. Let me caution you about Russian taxi drivers. They will take advantage of you whenever they can. Negotiate the price in advance and don't fall for their line that it's all set by the meter!! And if you're going to the Russian ballet that night, make sure you have arranged in advance for your taxi driver to pick you up.

Very good for a rainy day. As it was raining the whole time we were in St. Petersburg we spent a lot of time in Hermitage. It has many famous paintings and historic things. It reminded me a lot of Louvre but was smaller from my point of view and each room was splendid - historic. We were tyired after the visti but glad we went.

Badly organized, lacks any greatness. I visited the Hermitage and I am pretty disappointed. This place, despite supposedly being the jewel of Russia and the most talked about thing since sliced bread is badly over hyped. I love museums, I love history, I love architecture. This is possibly the most poorly designed museum I have ever been in. I am almost sure that if I had 3 weeks here in some sort of important position, I could design the inside so that it is not confusing and doesn't take away from the experience. When you are inside, nothing is clear, you don't know which way to go, there is hardly any information on any of the works and its like a stadium at halftime inside. I understand this is Russia so I do not expect nor was I expecting all the information in the world, however more information could of easily been produced in English about the artworks, time periods, etc. There is more I can say but no need for me to say it. However, had I known previously what I know now, I would not have wasted 600 rubles or my time on this place.
A must. This may be one the best in the world. You could spend years to visit it all. Take a tour or you'll be waiting long hours in line to get in.

Super, Stunning, Phenomenal!. What more can be said than what hasn’t been said already. This museum is one of the most amazing places that we have ever visited. It was founded in 1764 by Catherine the Great with the main complex made up of 6 buildings, 5 being open to the public. The Hermitage is one of the largest and oldest in the world with over 3 million works of art.I highly recommend going as part of an organized tour as this will get you into the group entrance instead of the main entrance where the line was at least 2 football field lengths (maybe more see photo attached) long. Our guide surveyed us before going in and was able to get us to the things that we wanted to see and most popular pieces in our half day visit. You could probably spend weeks here and still not see everything. The complex in itself is incredible. Photography is allowed but with no flash. The admission fee was around 300 rubles or $10.00 us. Tour companies will mark this fee up with the inclusion of a tourguide.

The Hermitage is one of the three top sites to visit in the world. t is hard to imagine the opulence and grandeur of the hermitage - and the definitive styles of Elizabeth and Catherine. The number of master artists displayed is unlike any in the world. Be sure to also visit the new contemporary wing
4 of 5. ...because it is SO crowded without air conditioning. The artifacts inside are truly impressive and numerous. It makes it clear why the peasants revolted.
Breathtaking. The collection of priceless art here is overwhelming. If you are not on a guided tour, prepare your visit well by deciding which parts you want to see

Crowded. This is a must see. The history is amazing and the palace is awesome. There are a lot of rooms to get through, you stay within the roped areas, if you venture off the path they have ladies that will police each room. It takes a while to get thru the whole palace. The crowds are just awful. The people are pushy and rude, they will bump you without a second though and not apologize. I am not used to that were I come from. I would like to go back on a off peak time.

Russian big treasure. Every time I visit Saint Petersburg, I go to the Hermitage.. and every time it's a new experience full of information, cultural dose, dazel and a big need to drown in history and books.

Wonderful maze. Massive museum and the layout is a maze! Don't really like museums, but definitely found this interesting. It was eye opening and quite educational. So many beautiful monuments and statues :).

Spectacular. Visited from a cruise. Very busy, was advised best time to visit is October. Still worth visiting especially with a guide who points out all interesting facts. If going without a guide you can take a lot longer to take it all in.

Impressive. Is a place you shouldn't miss. Very beautiful and makes you dream how was life there before it turned into a museum. Many interesting things to see, art from different places and times. Rooms are really impressive as so are some of the paintings and sculptures. You need at least a hole day to see it all but if you can, try to go twice, it worths.

One of the finest museums in the world. So there will be 100,000 people there with you but the Hermitage certainly has to rank among the very best museums in the world. The collection of art is stunning, and the rooms that were used by the czars are just absolutely fabulous. The only problem is you should allocate multiple days to make a significant dent into seeing all of the museum. It is certainly one of the best. You can't come to St. Petersburg and not see the Hermitage

A must visit. An excellent choice for those interested in art. This is a huge museum that requires a lot of walking. It is preferable to go with a tour guide to explain the history behind every room and picture. The walls, the chandeliers and the paintings are very interesting

Even better the second time. We had visited Hermitage two years back. The first time it was overwhelming with too many things to take in. This time we did not necessarily see too many newer things but could relate to them better. Hermitage will be amazing no matter how many times you go there.

Magnificent Palace and art Collection. You will have to queue to get in here, but well worth it. As well as the actual palace the works of art cover every era and every part of the world, plus there were well-preserved relics from the Egyptian, Greek and Roman periods. Fascinating place, though you will only see a fraction of it in one visit.

Opulent and enormous - several hours needed. If you are an art buff you will probably need to visit this twice. The rooms are breathtaking in their opulence - lots of gold gilt, chandeliers etc. The building is enormous and it's impossible to visit every room so you need a good book to direct you to the highlights. Having your own visa helps with entry as you don't have to get in the awfully long guided tour queues - you buy your ticket at a machine and go straight in. It's definitely worth visiting.

Palatial....majestic....pick a trite superlative, it'll be right. Exceptional museum, truly matches up with the worlds best. Range of art is breath taking - be aware that the Rembrandt section in particular is crowded and not well temperature controlled. Tour groups make things a little like Pamplona running with the bulls but in this case best to stand your ground. Definitely best to buy tickets online and use the side entrance to skip the line

Living History..A MUST. Years and years of history is placed in this awesome inspiring brilliant structure. This is a must see, do and experience trip that any person cannot but stand in astonishment to the richness of history present before their eyes. We have been told that should you stand for 30 sec in front of every piece inside the museum then you need around 10 years to see all the museum. This definitely would make the museum so popular that most of the times it is super overcrowded.
Amazing. Everything I expected and more. Just fabulous. Too much to take in so a good guide is essential to ensure you see the most interesting objects.

Amazing Hermitage . Loved our visit to the Hermitage. Our tour guide Anna from Anastasia travel was an expert on the history of the Hermitage. One of our comrades had a wheelchair and Anna was especially helpful guiding us with her.

Hermitage, all that we heard it would be.. It would be impossible to not give one of the best museums in the world, a positive review. Pictures, statues, frescoes on and on, and many of them done by the masters, of irreplacible quality and value not able to be determined. Negatives, people people people, everywhere. I didn't expect a command visit, but it took my wife 20 minutes to get to the coat check area and back. The exhibits were spectacular, but so were the crowds. We did not visit the Post Impressionists area, and the people in our tour group who did said it was not to be missed, but we had fought the crowds and lost, long enough for that day.

Have an early entry ticket by booking a tour. We were on a Baltic cruise and booked a 2 day tour with Alla Tours (see my review). This enabled us to have an early entry ticket. Our Russian guide knew how busy the Museum is. So many reviews detail this magnificent building with ornate and opulent interior rooms. This venue is a must see. You are allowed to take photos, but no flash.The Russian stewards in a lot of the rooms were rather stern and eagle eyed, but they deal with thousands of visitors a day. There is a lot of rooms and only a limited amount of people allowed in each one. Be prepared for lots of queuing and standing around in hot rooms. It is worth the wait.Top tip, especially for ladies. The bathrooms are in the main reception area. It's the only one available for several hours
One of the greatest museums in the world. Definitely a must when visiting st. Petersburg. Amazing collection and designed rooms. Not only for art lovers but for everyone!

The Museum is huge but we didn't see much. The hermitage is a huge Museum and so is the line to get inside. We purchased tickets in the internet and thus avoided the line by entering through the very small line just at the right of the huge one. Another way for individuals to avoid the line is to purchase the tickets in the machines in the yard ( there are one in each side), the museum was very crowded, so crowded that we couldn't enjoy the art as we usually do. also significant portion of the pictures are non interesting portraits. the pictures by the west European painters were much more interesting, but it took a while until we found them. it may be wise to take a guide, we didn't.
State Hermitage Museum. big, grand wonderful museum. great Rembrandt room. really crowded and very long lines to enter, unless you get early admission from a guided tour.

Must see. Must see in St. petersburg - come early (15 minutes before opening) and buy your tickets at one of the ticket machines - this way you avoid the long lines, keep enough Roubles in Cash some of the machines didn't accept credit cards...

More than a museum visit . Entering the Ermitage for the first time is an experience you will remember for life... if you only think that 11 years are not enough to visit all... I appreciated the entire journey we made!!!
Awe inspiring. The life of the wealthy is certainly on display here. They have done a wonderful job of collecting items to display from around the country.

Over the Top Amazing!!!!. Went to the Hermitage Museum on the second day of our 2 days in port in St. Petersburg. Had a private tour guide with SPB tours and well worth it. The lines to get into the museum in June are crazy with all of the tourists, especially since this is one of the top attractions in the world!Amazing, amazing collection of gold/jewels/artwork including paintings and sculptures/throne room, etc.Crowds/Crowds/Crowds! Gold/Gold/Gold! Didn't know there was that much 24 carat gold leaf in the world, let alone in one building. Worth every minute of the experience. A don't miss museum in Russia.

In tourist season...book the tickets in advance. We bought the tickets in advance and that spared us from a long time in queue. As audio guide we used the application published by the museum, and chose the 2.99 € 1-hour visit. The app took some time to get used to but once we learnt it...it proved to be very useful. After the tour we simply chose to see the works of our favourite artists on our own. I would especially recommend to see the Rembrandt room. With the same ticket you get admission to the General Staff building that includes a superb collection of works painted by Matisse.

Amazing building, oh yeah and it's full with priceless art. To be honest I mainly came here for the ceilings. The interior decor is epic! To get into the hermitage either buy your ticket online if you have a printer. Or, if your like me who doesn't carry a printer whilst travelling and can't speak Russian to ask, I went to Menshikov Palace which is over the bridge when they first opened then went to the hermitage and went to the side entrance. No queue! Was in by 12pm whilst others were still queuing to get in the door.

Stunning!. Absolutely stunning inside and a great place to visit if you like art galleries. We visited with a tour guide who was extremely informative and interesting. Definitely worth a visit if you are in the city.
Hermitage in 4 hours. So much to see & take in the centre is very much larger than you think and by using a private tour we beat the crowds at early doors fantastic paintings and culture.

Russia . The Hermitage was amazing. We went with a private guide. I am not sure we would have enjoyed it as much on our own. It is massive and not much English. We also did the gold and diamond rooms. They needed you have special times for visits. Distances from one to the other are great.

State Hermitage Museum. The place is enormous. The collection of art and artifacts overwhelms you. You could do a separate tour marveling at just the architecture and construction of the palace. The crowds are usually fierce, so try to be part of a tour group that has early admission before the doors open to the masses. Also, there is no air conditioning and the top floor can get pretty warm. We toured the palace for about two hours . . . about all we could handle before museum overload kicked in. But it would take more hours and days to do it justice.

Priceless art and artifacts just inches away. We hired a private guide for our tour of the Hermitage who took us in before the doors were open to the huge lines outside. This made our experience extraordinary. We were absolutely blown away by the numbers of pieces and the expanse of the museum. The Italian collection alone rivals the Uffizi in Italy and you can literally walk right up to most pieces with no barricades. Another surprise was all the ancient Egyptian and Roman artifacts, amazing Hellenic pots and even a mummy.

Historic site that you easily can follow with audiguide on your smarthphone. Buy the ticket online (more expensive that onsite) but you will skip a few hours line. Also the audioguide that you can download on your smartphone is highly recommendable. Enjoy a great site with a lot of history on russian empire.
hermitage museum. By going to these places, in addition to visiting its beautiful monuments. You can also visit two of the great Leonardo da Vinci

Cruise shore visit. Wow an impressive museum for sure but for some I guess it could be painting overload, yes loads of high end paintings here from all the great masters Well worth a visit but be ready to queue for entrance although the line shrinks at a reasonable pace

Massive and Magnificent. A lot has been written about the Hermitage and so I shall not repeat the usual array of superlatives.However the following are a few essential points.1. Buy the tickets online and save time. You may spend at least an hour in the ticket queue2. Your online tickets should be exchanged for real tickets before the entry.3. Choose what u want to cover before hand.4. Try to divide your trip into two days.5. Take a tour guide if you are short of time but if possible do it slowly at a leusurely pace using the audioguide.6. If you are an art lover you are in heaven. However part of the heaven has moved across the square to the Staff gallery. This is the one with the Impressionists, the post impressionists and the Picassos. You can enter this with the same ticket. Try to set aside atleast a couple of hours for that.7. In the main museum, there is a dizzying collection of Rembrandts and Reubens along wirh some Da Vincis and an incredible work by Michelangelo8. Not too many eating options exist except for a well stacked cafe on the ground floor.9. Enjoy the Hermitage
Could visit many times and still not see it all. If you can manage it, visit early or in a tour with special admission on a closed day. There is so much to see, minimal crowds are a necessity.
amazing collection. The art collection are truly stunning, the buildings themselves are beautiful, but the museum is very crowded and there are insufficient toilet facilities.
Beautiful and Big!. The day we visited it was very hot and inside there is really no AC or air flow so we did not visit as much as we had hoped to.

Beautiful . One of the nicest museums. Very busy full of Tour groups and very warm inside, but everything is worth it. Tip is to buy tickets in the machines on the side and take a side entrance saves tons of time

Biggest museum I've ever seen . This is the biggest museum I've ever seen in the world, collections from everywhere in the world, Europe, Asia, egyptian ancient history, middle east, India. We booked online to avoid waiting in long queues, better to wear comfortable shoes as museum needs at least 5 hours walking continously to finish, if you like to read everything for each item so you need 2 or 3 days. The museum provides lockers for bags and hangers for jackets so you can put and start your tour, guides available and there are cafes inside to rest.

Worth the wait (but, wow, the crowds). If you visit this attraction during the tourist season (and without a guided tour that provides for special entry), be prepared for lots of waiting. It's a fantastic, world-level attraction, however.

Vast and Impressive. This is a "must see" attraction. It is vast and dripping in gold, precious stones and artworks. Impossible to see it all in one lifetime, let's hope re-incarnation is a reality as I am definitely coming back as often as possible to see it all.

Gorgeous. Aside from housing works from many great artists, the structure alone is breathtaking. From the moment you traverse up the grand staircase and wind your way through all the exhibits. Do not miss the peacock clock, that is a stunning work of art.
Amazing place. Visited as part of a tour but feel that it would be better to do it as a full morning or afternoon tour as there is so much to see and can get very crowded

Amazing place! . We visited this palace the las day in Saint Petersburg. If I knew it was so big I would visited it the first day. The place is so big that you might need more than 2 days if you want to see it all. It is a bit overwhelming, once inside there are so many rooms that you don't know where to go. Every room has a different decoration. I highly recommend!!

Best seen with a good guide. There are thousands of magnificent items to be seen in the amazing museum so do yourself a favour and go with a guide to ensure you see the masterpieces as well as their own favourite pieces.

Majestic, Expansive, Beautiful - Tiring. No words can describe the vastness and the majesty of the Hermitage. Its big, it has an extensive collection of art from all over the world. The building in itself is already a masterpiece.Its a must-see when you are in Saint Petersburg. Just some tips:Make sure you book your ticket vouchers online. It will make you save tons of time and avoid waiting in line for tickets (which will take hours). It will cost a little more, but will give you huge amount of convenience.Wear comfortable shoes. Walking through the museum is a physical task. Make sure to be ready for serious amount of walking! Went on a summer and it was packed! The locals I talked to said that winter time is the best time to visit the museum, as there are very few tourists (but you get to experience the infamous SPB winter).If you do not have a lot of time, i suggest you visit the Russian Art collection, and the art from Siberia and Central Asia, exhibits you might probably only see in the Hermutage. There are pieces worth visiting (Like a Cezanne, a Picasso and Athena's head in the Greek Collection), but other exhibits you can see similar things on other museums.The building has different gallieries, designed with different themes (and jewels), i love the Malachite room personally. Most definitely you should also und your "personal favortie room"!

Magnificent Museum . As advertised. Wonderful and extensive tour of one of the world's great museums. Five buildings of history, conjoined to make a continuous tour of several hours, yet Natasha, our TJ Travel guide made it fascinating, wouldn't pas this one up but don't do it without a knowledgeable guide.

Amazing museum. This museum was amazing and you could spend weeks just going through everything. It was VERY crowded and the people working the museum were not very nice. The sheer magnitude of opulent collecting and spending by the Czar's and their families at a time when the people were suffering was something that the whole family decided was very sad and you could understand why people were so driven to revolt.

great art collection ...if you can see it. The Hermitage and Winter Palace is a must for most travellers to St Petersburg. The art collection alone is worth the trip with an amazing collection of Old Masters in an opulent building that almost exceeds opulence. The problem is that is so crowded that you will struggle to see much. Try and go on your own and you will face a wait of at least an hour and it rain quite a lot in this city. Go with a tour and you will reduce the wait but will end up being taken through at a brisk pace battling with wave after wave of other tourists all following their guides. Yes you should visit but don't bother during the summer months unless you are made of sterner stuff than our family

First look when you arrive shows the grandness of this Palace.. We entered through the group designated entrance. It took about an hour wait in the rain. When we got close to the door a lot of people were coming out and going in at the same time which caused some problems. Just couldn't understand why the same door was used as an exit and entrance.After that our tour leader took control and aided by a communication system to each of our group we were fascinated by the history and collections on display.Coming off a cruise ship we had only 4 to 5 hours time so I will definitely be going back one day. Tired legs but very happy to have touched the grandness of this Palace.

Use the ticket vending machines!. I felt sorry for all the people who stayed in the queue for 2 hours under the rain, while the machines just did the job without any queue.I went mostly to visit the palace and I was not disappointed. Just amazing, don’t miss it. Unfortunately the huge crowd spoils a lot of the experience. Of course a top collection of old paintings, personally I preferred the collection at the General Staff Building, more modern.

Only Egypt hall was interesting for me. Too many paintings of the same period of time from different countries. I was bored after 20 minutes walking thru. But interiors of the palace are really great!

Its Breathtaking. This incredible Palace with its fantastic collection of paintings and artworks is huge and will take up most of your day. If only they had organised the movement of visitors in a single direction it would have avoided the chaos of tourists coming from every direction. However, there is no mistake that the Hermitage is magnificent and worth a visit

absolutely incredible museum . great museum for the historian of Russian history and art...so much to see throughout this museum that you would need more than a day to see it all...every room you step in is filled with amazing opulence...it's a must see! one truly would need to wear appropriate walking shoes.

Avoid free 1st thursday. We purchased tickets ahead of time online and found it a great time saver with a separate entrance,coat check.Exceptional collection of art and architecture.We purchased the two day pass and due to our own scheduling conflict were compelled to go on the first thursday of the month (Free entrance day) the crowding and tour grouping was intense. Glad we had the other day to compare it to.

One of the World's Best. Everything in the Hermitage is outstanding. It is one of the world's best art collections housed in one of the world's most impressive Palaces. You can't hope to see it all in one visit. I recommend going with a tour group, as small a group as you can manage. Groups can pre-book a set entry time and avoid the long line ups faced by independent visitors AND that entry time can give earlier access than independent visitors can get. If you come to St. Petersburg on a cruise, you may be able to book a tour that visits in the evening and I was told this was a more relaxed way to see the Hermitage though I did not do this. Wear good walking shoes and be prepared for stairs, congestion and line-ups inside the buildings. Also be prepared to be amazed!

Hermitage on foot. We celebrated July first on a TJ travel tour with guide and information provider Natasha. If we knew nothing beforehand about St Petersburg, we certainly do now with 2 full days. Hermitage museum is fascinating and the history sublime. Later in the day, we were entertained with a canal boat tour which passed by the Hermitage and it's five separate buildings. To think we had just walked through all of them made us tired looking at it.

Not worth a long wait- rain or shine . I would recommend to prebook your tickets in advance. This is an all day event, if your on cruises, this is not a half day tour, the line is always long and it raining, it's worst than I've ever experience. The artifacts are nice but the palace is not the original so a lot of it is overly re-duplicated. You don't need a guide to come here. Best is to hire a personal driver to tour St. Pete, cheaper and you willsee more stuff.
wow. must visit place in st Petersburg, will be full in tourist season, good for photo shot, we love Russian the way they maintain they history

Truly spectacular. This really is the museum equivalent of the Grand Canyon! It is so vast that you can only get a flavour of what is there, but as a non-museum person, I found the pace of the tour and scope just right. We went with Alla Tours which we booked online in the UK.The wealth of the Russian Czars was mind blowing, and their art and antiquity collections must be unparalleled in the world.I suspect that nowhere else will compare in the future!

You can see why there was a revolution. This is an amazing museum. So many riches. Excellent paintings, statues and a wide variety of other artifacts. But so much wealth...Be prepared for a very long wait at the entrance (unless you have prepaid for your tickets and have a pushy tour guide), and a long wait to check your bags/coats. The Hermitage was quite crowded, with way too many people taking selfies and posing for photos and being herded around in large groups, but there is a lot to see so it was worth putting up with all that.We were on a private tour which made all the difference.

Excellent!. Do not miss this attraction, you will not be disappointed. The place is exquisite, absolutely gorgeous, and lots to take in. Make sure your camera/cell phone battery is fully charged because you will take and be allowed to take lots of photos.

fabulous. This is a n amazing place. But it is packed. We used a tour guide and that helped, without a guide who buys tickets ahead and can guide you around the high lights you would face long lines. I gather visiting in winter is better if you want to see artworks. in summer we were told the worst day to visit is Tuesday. We visited in July, on a wednesday, there were still a lot of people, but our guide felt it was comparatively empty
Everything in St. Petersburg is 5 stars. This was the first place we visited and it didn't disappoint. Beautiful architecture, lots of gilding, wonderful art and wheelchair accessible.

Most amazing Palace and Museum. A Must-see in this city with so much history and incredible display of collections and ornate rooms showin the wealth and power of the imperial family. Crowds though make it necessary to get a private guide who all use earphones and microphones in order to communicate with their groups. A guide can also arrange to get the first hour of the museum to avoid the huge crowds by 10am, I have never seen a museum with wall to wall people like this before.

You may catch flies, your mouth is always hanging open in awe!. If you ever make it to St Petersburg don't leave the Hermitage off your list. Go with a tour because you get in before the museum opens and you do avoid some of the crowds. It is hard to believe that there is so many beautiful things in one place. A don't miss attraction!
Just go. If you're in Petersburg and you don't go here (and have never gone), you've wasted a trip. Try to allocate at least 4-6 hours for the trip.
We loved this museum. This is one of the most incredible museums I have visited in Russia and anywhere in the world. A profusion of amazing paintings...

Main attraction. Be ready for long lines but well worth it.Get a guide if you can so at to negotiate the queues.Wonderful Rembrandt collection.The museum is overwhelming so you need someone's of guide you.It is closed on Monday so plan your trip accordingly.
Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace. This museum is amazing. So many exhibits and the history that it has is incredible. I definitely would visit this place again.

Amazing Art Collection. The Hermitage Museum has an amazing collection of work. Room after room of famous paintings, sculptures, etc. It is worth having a guide take you through because the museum is huge and it would take you years to see everything. So, let your guide point out the highlights or let them know exactly what you want to see so they can take you on some short cuts. The winter palace is also nice to visit, but we had visited Catherine's palace the day before so the winter palace was unimpressive after Catherines. Unfortunately the day we visited the Hermitage, there were 5 cruise ships in port and the crowds were insane. I've never seen crowds anywhere in the world as bad as what we experienced in the Hermitage the day we were there. We arrived relatively early and didn't have to wait in line too long, but once in the museum and palace looking out into the square, the line was huge, stretching throughout the square. If in St. Petersburg, the Hermitage should be on the top of your sightseeing list despite any crowds.

A whole life is too short for Hermitage . We went on a Sunday morning afraid of the long queues, but surprisingly we bought the ticketts in less the 20 min. The english speaking tours are not well organised, so You can not take all the available tours in one day. Everything else You must see for yourself. The museum does not work on Mondays.

superb!!. love the way the Russians have restored everything to its old splendid...its like seeing a history class... beyond imagination...and the size of this museum is huge ..we could only cover 1/100 of it i am sure in 3 hours!!!!!

Jaw dropping architecture and collections of art. The Hermitage may be the cream of the cream of art museums in the world since the buildings themselves are works of art and vessels of Russian history. The collection of art and artifacts is overwhelming. We spent three hours as part of an organized tour with SPB and we got to see an enormous collection but we know we probably only scratched the surface. The museum becomes increasingly crowded as the day goes on and the staff does a great job of crowd control, but some suggestions for maximizing your experience are contract with an organized tour group and be sure your tour guide is knowledgeable about the museum and its art and history and knows how to navigate the enormous space. If you choose to go independently, the line tends to go around the block and, in my opinion, spending two hours or more on line is a waste of time.

be amazed. Please give yourself plenty of time to explore this museum minimum of 4 hours. Plan what you want to see and plan your route. So much fantastic art, china and of course the rooms of the imperial family . This is my top attraction in the city

WOW, but long waits.. What a fantastic place to visit, we went on a rainy day and went in as sooned as it opened, ( highly recommend ). The crowds were already building up outside with long ques. BUT when you enter you have to put your coats in a cloakroom ? why i dont know, more long ques. All the waiting is well worth the delights you are about to see, the architecture is stunning where ever you go, and the Art work is simply amazing and plenty of it. We were on a cruise tour so only had a short 2-30 hour visit, you really need a lot longer to appreciate what you see. But as the morning wore on the place gets more and more packed and its hard to get around and see it all with so many wanting photo's etc. But the whole experience was stunning and for me and the wife well worth the hassell. The exit from the museum was more like a rugby scrum with people wanting to get there coats and people wanting to leave there coats getting hot and bothered. There is a small toilet also in the cloakroom and to be honest it was chaos. Expect long ques and waiting around but really enjoy what is on offer, it is fabulous.

Crowded and rushed. A great place although I am not sure who designed the tours. It is like an archive and you need a guide to take you around for specific pieces. Very much like the louvre the only difference here you have no English signs or signs at all. We spend 2 1/2 hours and enjoyed what we can see. I wish they organize the place better. But it is the band that attracts. One advise about tickets there are machines for credit card use at the entrance and on the side of the museum that for unclear reason no one uses. it took me 2 minutes to get our tickets and get in while all the masses are in line... Again, the lack of signs is a major problem.
