A Great Museum. My wife and I toured the Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg in May 2016. What a fabulous place. The name "hermitage" means "a place of solitude." The Hermitage is located in the Winter Palace of Empress Elizabeth Petrova and the palace was greatly expanded by Empress Catherine the Great and she began collecting the artistic treasures that were the beginning of the Hermitage. The Hermitage is one of the greatest museums in the world and easily rivals the Louvre in Paris. The collections are extensive and are magnificent. The rooms of the palace of the Romanov tsars are also restored. The palace was restored to its former glory which was destroyed by the Nazis during WWII during the 911 day siege of St. Petersburg. Most of the collections (two train loads) were moved deeper into Russia when the Germans attacked Russia and thus were preserved. The rest of the collections were stored in the cellars and thus protected from shelling. The Russians also captured a lot of art that the Nazis took during the war and placed it in the Hermitage. In touring the palace with its beautiful rooms, much of the art collection is also viewed. The collection is vast with many magnificent paintings and sculpture. Works by Leonardo da Vinci, Madonna with a Flower, the Little Madonna and the Benois Madonna, are on display. Paintings include Gainsborough's The Lady in Blue, Gros's Napoleon on the Bridge at Arcola (a different-looking Napoleon), Delacroix, Titian's Danae and The Repentant Mary Magdalene, Caravaggio's The Lute Player, Ruben's The Union of Earth and Water and Perseus and Andromeda, Rembrandts, El Grecos and many others. Sculptures include Canova's The Three Graces (a beautiful white-marble group), the Dionysis Hall filled with Roman and Greek statues as is the Jupiter Hall, and many other sculptures that are simply exquisite. In one of the palace rooms there is a huge shiny brass clock called the Peacock clock which was made in England in the 18th century and has many intricate works. There is a huge Peacock standing on a brass tree trunk with a large brass rooster below the Peacock and a metal owl in a brass cage containing several bells that ring when struck. On the hour the Peacock comes alive and spreads its HUGE brass tail, while the rooster crows and the bells are chimed. It is truly a wonder and I had never seen anything like it before. There are many rooms within the palace but the ones I thought were wonderful were (1) the Raphael Loggias, copies of the loggia in the Vatican, (2) the Jordan staircase in white marble and gold trim, (3) the Hall of Peter the Great with a inlaid parquet floor that is simply outstanding and awe inspiring, (4) the Gallery of 1812 with many portraits of Romanov generals, and (5) the huge St. George Hall, a throne room of white Carrara marble with a large throne decorated with the Romanov crown and the Russian double eagles (as are the gold chandeliers in the room). Many of the rooms in the palace have beautiful inlaid parquet floors or mosiac floors. The great Impressionist paintings are now located in the General Staff Building across the great plaza and these should not be missed. There are exquisite paintings by Pissaro (The Boulevard Montarte), Renoir, Monet, Cezanne, Vincent van Gogh, Gaughan, Signac, Rousseau, Picasso (several including The Absinthe Drinker), Matisse, Vlaminck, Dufy, Kandinsky and others. Many of these Impressionist paintings I had never seen before not even in books. Since we only had a morning and part of an afternoon, we simply did not have time to sit an marvel and the beautiful artwork. We had also opted for the private access tour on which we were taken by bus to another neighborhood in St. Petersburg to huge buildings where other Hermitage treasures were stored including furniture, clothing of the tsars and empresses (including Catherine the Great's green military-style outfit that we saw her wearing in a portrait of her on her horse), tents from rulers of the middle east, and a huge room of carriages of the tsars including coronation carriages. On the whole, I like the private access tour but I would have appreciated more time in the General Staff Building.  I recommend that you reserve two whole days for touring the Hermitage so you are not rushed and so that you don't become burned out and overwhelmed by seeing so much great art in a short period of time.

I recon it is better/grandier than Louvere. Recommended to hire local guide or go as a part of the group.
Magnificent in every respect, however extremely busy place.

Book tickets in advance. We booked our tickets online before we left we were so glad we did as the queues were enormous. When we arrived they closed the ticket office as the museum was at capacity, but online ticket purchasers were still able to enter. You take your print out to a booth at the front and they give you a ticket. Don't join the main queue! Alternatively there are credit card ticket machines near the front entrance which have no queues. Once you are inside the hermitage it doesn't feel crowded and the treasures are unbelievable, we have visited many many museums and have never seen such a collection. Try and plan your must see areas before you go or you will see too much to really appreciate it.

Stunning!. This enormous museum is amazing. You can walk for hours and still only see a fraction of it. It is always crowded. However, it is so worth the effort. You will be stunned by the overwhelming opulence and beauty. Words don't do it justice!

Great museum. We arrive moments before opening. They let me go first with my daughters and wonderful tour guide Tatiana. Since I ride a scooter I had to go through the accessible way and toilet. Every thing was accessible and I enjoyed every part of this wonderful place

Amazing. So much to see! Brilliant rooms and architecture, views and paintings from the masters. Surprisingly airy when we went though can get very busy. Security takes time and timed entry in place. Views from the concourse and across the water are impressive as well.

Amazing museum-complex; a must see in St. Petersburg. Your holiday in St. Petersburg would not be complete without a visit to the Hermitage, one of the largest and oldest museum collections in the world. Since it is the peak tourist season during summer, do expect long queues and big crowds when you visit. We started off our tour of the Hermitage from the Winter Palace, which has a really impressive white-and-gold grand double staircase that is bound to leave a memorable impression. The Hermitage museum-complex consists of five different buildings, the Winter Palace, the Hermitage Theatre, the Small Hermitage, the Old Hermitage and the New Hermitage. The highlight of the Hermitage buildings are the art pieces, and the various rooms usually have a theme, e.g. Rembrandt, or art from the Italian Renaissance period etc. The Winter Palace showcases more of the grandiose palace rooms to give you an idea of what the lives of the Russian Tsars were like in the past. Because the museum-complex is so vast, it is impossible to see the entire collection in one visit; so you might wish to consider keeping two days if you have the luxury of time in St. Petersburg. Or, if you have only an afternoon to spare like I did, you could zoom in on the more renowned pieces by celebrated artists like Michelangelo, Raphael and Rembrandt. There’s also the Peacock Clock in the Small Hermitage that’s really cool as well; it looks nothing like one but it actually is clock that still functions today.

Amazing...just be prepared for the masses!. Of course this was to be a highlight of my trip to St. Petersburg and it was. I had a guided tour, which was good, but we only saw a small fraction of what is available to see. What a shame. But we did see the highlights. I knew it would be busy but I had no idea of what the crowds would be like.Next time I would plan to purchase a 2-day pass and the audio guide and do it on my own time so if I would get lost in this enormous museum it wouldn't matter!I had to pay extra to see the "Modern" Impressionist and post-impressionist paintings in another building but it was well worth it. Could have spent a day in this part alone. Unbelievable collection of VanGogh, Monet, Manet, Matisse, Picasso, etc.
Unmissable. One of the finest buildings in the world. Enormous so decide what you want to see first. Definitely get tickets online first to save queues.
You MUST visit here. An insight into the opulence and sophistication of Russian aristocracy. If at all possible, take a private guide, who's knowledge and enthusiasm only enhances the experience.

Absolutely amazing!. No preparation or review of the Hermitage ahead of time would ever have prepared us for such an absolutely amazing visit. Every room, every angle, every nook held something unique to see. Our pictures are terrific (even without flash), The Hermitage is a must see!!!

Amazing!. This is a great rainy day activity as it is huge! I would also recommend getting a tour so you can fully understand and appreciate the palace. I took a gazillion pictures but I can't get them to load and it doesn't really do the place justice. Everything is grand and larger than life. Just a heads up it is packed on Tuesdays because it is closed on Monday. Also, get there early to as it gets jam packed.

Busy and there is far too much to appreciate.. Our guide said that we walked about 2.5 miles and we barely saw a quarter of what is available. Visitors tend to go in groups wearing head sets with a lead guide giving a commentary. What you see depends on the guide and how busy the place is. There is so much to see and after a while there is too much to take in, the architecture and the exhibits and the related history. You must have a guide to explain it all. Our guide avoided the crowds but that may have been at the expense of seeing important things. I suspect that you could go regularly for a week and still not see everything, let alone appreciate it.

Impressive!. The Museum should be visited by any art lover. It is worth the visit and the time spent there. We used a whole day to go through and still we could not make it by the end of the day. It is imperial, impressive, exquisite and refinate. There are precious masterpieces and copies of famous paintings and sculptures. For some art lovers, the Museum represents a dream come true.

Inspirational. This is a fantastic venue for art lovers and the buildings are also awesome. It is very large and difficult to get round it all and therefore a guide is best to cover your areas of interest.It is very crowded and gets hot later in the day with all the people in the building and it is best to make an early start.
Private guided tour Tailored Tours. Excellent handling our group of 8 through tremendous crowds and giving us best photo opportunities possible besides great history and information.

Early entry for best resulst. Our tour involved turning up at the entrance at 09.00 well before the usual public opening time. Basically we had the whole of the museum to ourselves apart from the staff.It was excellent and wonderful to see the interior of the rooms without being surrounded by other people. This is a must if you want to see the Hermitage at its best. The photos I took of the grand entrance staircase minus any other people are the best I took all week I was in Russia. To admire the many paintings from afar often in the right settings also needs very few people around.A visit to the Hermitage in St Petersburg is not to be missed but book an early tour or you will find yourselves queuing for ages.

Magnificently ornate in every way!. Go early and avoid the queues. Entrance inside is along a corridor which leads to a staircase which in turn opens out to reveal a grand double-staircase with beautiful bright, white and gold decor. And that's just the beginning of the story! It's said that you need 63 years to see everything in this museum, but even allowing 2-3 hours you see plenty that will stick in your minds for years!

Must visit . Amazing place. Fortunately we had a private guide and didnt have to follow a tour group. You need to allow several hours for a visit. Amazing rooms in the Winter Palace and a huge art collection

2 days would be almost enough. This museum is on par with any other major site of its type - art from all over the world including dutch, French, modern masters. WOW. Big crowds were a little annoying and we ran out of steam way before we ran out of museum. In a whole day I think we covered about 1/10 of it, and we had a private guide.

A Must See. Every visit to St Petersburg, Russia should include this museum. From the beautiful green exterior walls to the lovely paintings and sculptures on the walls, this is a coll place. Even my teenagers enjoyed themselves. Located right on the main river.

An absolute must-visit.. You cannot visit St Petersburg with visiting this incredible collection. The buildings making up the complex are astounding and the exhibits extraordinary in their richness and diversity.
It's said that it will take 8 years to see everything, spending only 1 minute at each exhibit.

get your own guide. there is a wealth of architectural and artistic detail inside the Hermitage. try and spend at least 3 hours, and get your own knowledgeable guide to explain both the building and the treasures. tour groups just flash through the museum and don't get time to drink it in. get to the basement if at all possible to see the exhibition from the Pazyryk burial site in Siberia.

Awesome. There are no adjectives to describe adequately this beautiful complex and the collection inside. A must see that should be on everyones bucket list.Do with a private guide to have the best experience.

Must see if you are in St. Petersburg. Only after seeing the Palace will you have some ideas of how powerful Peter the Great was and how powerful was the Russian back in the 18 centry. Choose SPB Tour if you don't have one

Consider your timing and tickets.... I won't go on about the actual museum. It houses all the amazing things you can read about elsewhere.BUT...I think depending on cruise ships in port and other factors, it can be an absolute mad house. I was so thankful to have a tour guide who got us in quickly. The line to get in had no end and it was raining. The insides were also packed to the gills and seeing things was just frustrating in the end so we left without seeing about half of it. Lots of pushy tour groups vying for a close-up of just about everything. I recoiled in horror at seeing how close some folks got to the Da Vinci paintings in there. One slip and....Plan ahead, get tickets ahead of time and if you can, go with no cruise ships in port!

Great. Experience for fans of paintings.... Visited the world renown museum , Hermitage set amongst a spectacular city scape bordered by the Palace square , Neva river and local streets.Set inside a spectacular building it self worthy of being a museum alone , ornate stair wells and rooms as far as one can walk in five hits us containing some of the world most cherished creations.Truely a treat for lovers of fine art , it was really a treasure to say I have been. Cost approx 800roubles to enter , suggest not waiting in line but to use the electronic ticketing boxes immediately to your left or right after entering the gates. Try to get there early as the place is a major tourist attraction and can be rather congested.

Awesome!!!!. If you wanted to see what the word museum is, you will need to visit Hermitage. Simply amazing, grandiose and beautiful. The museum displays what Ancient Russia was all about, art from Italy, Spain and Holland...If you can manage with your Russian (language) there is a section for the kids, where they give them a map, questions and they will need to find the answers to the Qs while visiting the museum. A very smart way to get the kids enjoy the museum while learning about the Russian history.

THE PLACE TO SEE. This is one of the greatest museums in the world. The art work alone is worth the visit. The place is huge. I would recommend between 2 to 3 hours to visit. There is food available to purchase. We hired a local guide. This I would recommend. Our guide got us in without waiting in long lines. We visited the museum in July. This. Is the busiest time of the year and 30,000 people visited the museum the day we visited. However, it is worth seeing.

Hire a private guide or a small group tour and pay extra to go early in the morning. A lot to see and take in at the hermitage. Must have a guide so if time is limited you get at least the highlights. We also enjoyed going across the square to the newest addition to the hermitage now housing the Impressionists exhibition. We had a guide with a very small group that got us in several hours prior to public opening. Well worth the extra money. Queues when we left were miles long. And the place was starting to get packed.

Fantastic but overcrowded. In order to avoid long queues either print your ticket on line or pre-arrange visit with one of reputable tours ( we did with Ulko tour). The place is overwhelming, beautiful and full of unbelievable splendour and incredible art collection. We did only see the highlights as one would need several days to see the entire museum.

Worth waiting in line - but you don't have to.. Even if this museum were empty, exploring the magnificent halls of the Winter Palace would be worth the price of admission. After waiting in line for about an hour, we realized that tickets can be purchased from machines just inside the gate. Only wait in line if you want a tour.

Buy your ticket online!!! You will thank me later :-D. We bought our ticket online which was a huge advantage when we arrived and saw the massive queue to the cashier outside. With online vouchers you can skip the hours waiting and go in on the right side of the building under the arcades. Great experience, i would recommend to have a big meal before because its sooo big, you wil walk a lot and the cafes inside are also packed. You can easily spend 5 hours there.
Simply amazing!. Book your tour through a private operator and you will get priority entrance before it's open. There will still be lots of people, but not as much as when it's open.

Amazing. Beautiful palace with a lot of history and art - golden columns and doors, enormous crystal chandeliers, amazing floors and even greater ceilings...with incredible collection of art which will leave you totally speechless...

Print your tickets online!. Great museum, well worth the visit! Love the lavish decor. We were able to bypass a crazy line by printing our tickets in advance. It didn't open until 10am and the line was already almost to the street at opening. Spent about 3 hours here, very crowded but beautiful.

Marvelous palace and museum. We were in awe of its grandeur almost immediately by walking up Ambassador’s Staircase right after entrance. The historical imperial rooms were so grand and the arts collection was equally spectacular. We were here with TJ Travel for about 2 hours only, too rushed a visit but we were still able to see plenty, thanks to our tour guide. We walked through Field Marshall Room, Memorial Hall of the Peter the Great, Armorial Hall, War Gallery of 1812, St. George Hall, Pavilion Hall (Peacock Clock). Then, we saw the art works by Leonardo da Vince (Benois Madonna, Litta Madonna, see contrast of the style), Titian (Danae), Raphal (Conestabile Madonna, and replica of Vatican Loggia), Michelangelo (Crouching Boy), Canova (The Three Graces), and Rembrandt (another Danae, The Prodigal Son) etc. Due to the time constraint, we didn’t visit the General Staff building for its modern impressionist collection. The museum is the third largest after Louvre and NY MET with ~3 million collections. My advice is to get an Hermitage guidebook at the museum or any gift shop to make your visit more memorable. The museum was very crowded, so you better off enjoy photos in the guidebook. If you come on your own, you can find self walking tour info in Rick Steves tour book and saint-petersbrug.com or familiarize yourself with a virtual tour at hermitagemuseum.org. With limited on what we could see, we nevertheless left very impressed.The name "Hermitage" (French, "abode of a hermit") just makes it even more contrasting.

The Hermitage. Plan on spending the day here. This museum is comprised of a thousand rooms. Many of the Masters have art shown on these walls. There is an audio tour that you can rent that will explain the rooms and the art work.

Beautiful museum. Enjoyed the Hermitage, the buildings alone are worth the visit. Get your tickets on line before visiting this way you avoid the ticket purchase lines. By having your internet tickets you enter from a side door. There were no lines and the whole process took only a few minutes. Once we were inside the museum we could see people lined up for hours waiting to get in. The museum was crowded, but it was also a rainy day. Give yourself a full day to visit and or you can purchase a two day ticket. Do not miss the Winter Palace, the interior is stunning!

Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace. This city centre set of interconnected buildings is one of the must-see and must-visit places in St Petersburg. With fabulous architecture and a truly vast collection of paintings, sculptures and other important works, this is definitely somewhere to visit when in the city.

Thoughts. Here are my practical observations. If you buy your ticket on line you will pay a lot more (I paid $17.95 per adult) but the line is much shorter. there is a kiosk selling tickets by the 'internet' entrance. Those tickets were 600 rubles each. After you go through the 'Internet' entrance (to the right of the main entrance, down the alley between the green and cream colored buildings) you will be able to check your bags and coats for free. It's a good idea to drop off anything you don't want to carry around for hours. But remember you will not have access to the bags until you leave.Use the bathrooms since the ones inside are not as nice and are spread out/ difficult to navigate to.If you have children in your group you will need to get a free ticket at the counter before you go through the turn style.If you have checked your bags pay attention to the halls you walk through (Egyptian) so you can find your way back.It's ok to go through without a tour guide, guide book, audio guide or app on your phone. It's ok to just walk around and look at stuff. If your family is like mine, they'll be happier if they can just walk around and look at some things without knowing the history and detailed explanations or the artistic significance of The works for they see. It's ok to just enjoy it on your own terms. If you're an art liver and history buff we would love a tour.My daughter enjoyed finding the dogs in art work. You can tell which things are famous by where all the tour groups stop and take pictures.Your ticket is also good for the General Staff building across the square (the long yellow building). This is where the Impressionists are kept. I will write a separate review. You should make sure to go.While in the Hermitage pick one work of art you really like. Sit and look at it for 10-15 minutes. Look at it from all angles. Take a picture (no flash). Take a selfie. Buy a postcard later if one is available. Make sure to find out the artist and year. Take a picture of the sign if you might forget.Later when your snobby friends talk about a "must see" work of art (that you didn't see) you can talk in great detail about your favorite work of art and ask if they saw it.There is no way to see it all.

Book your ticket online!. Went there twice: first time after an hour of waiting in freezing wind and rain gave up, came back next day with e-tickets ( don't have to print it). Everything went smoothly with e-tickets, no line whatsoever by 11am.

Just WOW.. Coming into the first hall... It was gold... Ok. Fancy. Then 40 minutes down the hallways.. MORE GOLD. I thought my eyesight was gone. It was really refreshing to see Chinese influence on Russian culture in the wardrobe room and the Ruby glazed room was absolutely stunning. Was lucky enough to have arranged a private escort into the country through the Disney cruise. Wonderful!

Great to see but very tiring. We went on a port excursion to the Hermitage. There were 7 ships in port and I think they were all there that day. Wall to wall people and not all courteous. If you're older like we are,very few places to sit down and it is 3 or 4 buildings of rooms. The art is fabulous and we're happy we saw it but might be better to go on your own and could choose what you want to see. We're glad we went but it was a very strenuous day.

Biggest museum . It's one of the biggest museums. You can't be in all rooms during one day. It's chic, bright, expensive palace. Rooms are very big and includes lot of fantastic and famous works of art. You can find even Rafael, Leonardo Da Vinci, Michaelangelo...

Overwhelming. We were lucky to go there early with the tour we booked from our Disney cruise.We went from the door by the water.When we finished our visit, the palace started to be really crowded with visitors.This palace left me speechless.Here is a small sample of the photos that I took there.

Highlight of our cruise. One word - WOW! The Czars never saw a piece of art that they didn't want..and they amassed an amazing collection, all housed in a magnificent former palace. The building itself is as impressive as the art.We had a semi-private guide who knew just how to maneuver us around the tremendous crowds and got us up close to all the masterpieces. It was a rainy, cool day, and I cannot imagine how uncomfortable it could be in that poorly ventilated place on a hot day. The Nazis plundered this city and the Soviets destroyed so much art and beauty during their rule, that it is so fortunate that this site and its collections still exist. You can spend days here.

Five Buildings in one - all amazing. As with any of the worlds great museums it takes a lifetime to see everything. Decide what you want to see and if pennies (euros, rubles) allow have a guided tour of pre selected highlights. We did and saw some wonderful things.

Spectacular, but crowded.. The Hermitage and Winter Palace are not to be missed. The size and grandeur is unique. Unfortunately you will find it crowded; so much so that you will not be able to linger more than a minute at any exhibit. Think in terms of hurting cattle. Get tickets in advance or though a service as the ticket lines can be very, very long.

Best museum in the world!. The winter palace is incredible! 200 Rembrandt's along with 3 million other items! You could literally spend days here so do allot at least a couple hours time. Treasures in every room - a feast for the eyes. Do tour it with a Guide - so much history
A Marvellous place. Great place to visit. A highlight of my trip in St Petersburg. One of the top museums in the world. A must go place in one's life.

Wow factor museum. Because of Russian visa requirements, it was essential to book shore excursions via the ship.This tour is a must, allowing early entry and relaxed viewing before the hordes arrive.Three hour queues are common at peak times.This is undoubtedly the best museum I have ever seen, the wow factor increasing with every minute.Our excellent Russian tour guide had calculated that if you spent fifteen seconds at every display, and allowed time to eat and sleep, it would take sixteen years to see it all!I can believe it.A must.The gold and diamond rooms are separate trips which we didn't have time to see unfortunately, next time maybe.
Huge and beautiful. They say it would take years to see everything in the Heritage and I believe it. We saw just a small sample and it is well worth the visit. Very grumpy staff.

Outstanding, if you go to Russia you must see the Hermitage. A must see in St Petersburg, beautiful building and especially Leonardo's works are amazing. As it is quite a large museum it is a good idea to take an audio guide so you can see the important rooms and you can take your time to listen to the description as some of the inscriptions are only in Russian, sometimes the museum can get really full and with all the tours it is hard to move around without getting pushed out of the way, therefore try going in the afternoons. The ticket is only valid for one day and it is impossible to see the Hermitage in just one day so they should consider making tickets valid for longer.

Better than Verauilles. My wife and I just spent 2 days visiting the Hermitage and it is amazing. Versailles pales into insignificance by comparison. You could spend almost a day, without looking at a single exhibit, just walking from room to room looking at the walls, floors and especially the ceilings. Once you start checking out the exhibits, if you read all the available information, you could easily be there a week. I would heartily recommend buying your own ticket ( much less expensive from the machine by the 'Internet voucher' door than online) than going with a guided tour because on those you are whisked through at great pace with no time to study anything as you are constantly trying to keep pace with your guide.

excellent visit. it's a very large palace & the most opulent rooms were those of the royal family. May be better to buy tickets online & also once you exit , you can't enter again so plan for 3/4 hours inside!

Gold, gold, gold. It took us more than an hour to get in, but was definetely worth waiting. Unfortunately tourists from Far East are not as friendly as Westerners. They push you in the crowd and try to take a picture of almost everything. Nevertheless, huge collection of art should be seen.

Buy online. There are two long lines at the hermitage, one outside and one inside the courtyard. If you buy your ticket online you only have to go to the online ticket booth Inside the courtyard. The online ticket line is usually only 10 people long :) They exchange your printed ticket from online for a real ticket which you use to walk straight to the right of the inner courtyard line. It took us a total of ten minutes to get in while done of the folks stood out in the rain for hours.
Museum . It's a very good museum. The life of great Katrina in st. Petersburg. Not too big but you walk back along part of history . Nice garden, nice historical building.

Above average art, but INSANITY in the number of visitors and no A/C. This should be a more exciting place to visit, due to the spectacular art, but I found that I didn't really enjoy my time here. You can see rare da Vinci paintings, a Michelangelo sculpture, Rembrandts, and so much more...but the place is swamped with an unmanageable number of visitors. Fire code in the United States would never in a million years allow this place to keep functioning this way. When you first go in the main hallway and go up the main set of stairs, it feels like you're on the verge of a trampling. It gets better, especially if you are there to see all sorts of different artistic works, and not just the really famous stuff. I actually heard someone walk up to a Rembrandt asking, "Is this the famous one?" before taking out his cell phone to take a photo. It's great that people are interested in seeing art, if even for the celebrity of it all, but it's difficult to appreciate art when you're being rushed along so the next group of people can snap a pic to use in their online posts. Another oddity is the fact that there is no air conditioning in 95% of this place. And it gets very warm with all the bodies in there. Not to mention, muggy, since it's often overcast or raining in St. Petersburg. We wondered if it wouldn't damage the art, since every other major museum I know checks for temp and humidity on the hour in their galleries. It was a bit bizarre, even with windows cracked open to try to alleviate some of the heat...which meant more moisture comes in. Anyway, I digress. We would suggest that the Hermitage do what the British Library and the British Museum have done: take your masterpieces that the vast majority of people most care about and put them on the nearest floor, in a sort of best-of-the-best area. That way, they could eliminate people having to wander all over kingdom come to find a few pieces of art and art lovers who are interested in seeing the other stuff don't have to deal with as many crowds. Like other people suggest, you can buy your tickets from eight electronic kiosks in the courtyard (four on each side - go to the right side where nobody notices they are and there probably won't be a line at all) rather than wait in the huge line. A big bonus is that they sometimes stop selling tickets to the people waiting in line due to being overcrowded inside...they didn't seem to stop sales at the kiosks, though, so after we bought our tickets, we walked to the front of the line, showed them our tickets and walked right in. Coat check is free. You can probably find lists of their artworks available on their website, so I won't cover any of that here. Bring a fan.

Incredible!. With approximately 3 MILLION items, all I can say about the Hermitage is WOW!! Unfortunately, you could easily spend one full week exploring this museum, so you come away with an incredible desire to return and a feeling of disappointment that your time there was too brief! The artwork is amazing. There are even two paintings by Da Vinci and a sculpture by Michelangelo! There is an extensive collection of French impressionists and Dutch artists including several paintings by Rembrandt. Not too mention all the Egyptian, Greek,and Roman artifacts. This is easily one of the finest museums in the world and not to be missed!

Wow wow wow. We are not big museum goers but I would happily keep coming back to this gem. Probably the best museum we have ever been to. The art collection is mind boggling and the rooms themselves are mind blowing.
A must do!

Almost overwhelming with beauty.. They really knew how to build and finish a beautiful palace! More than enough history to go around. You need a guide for this place as there is not enough time of you had to stop and figure out what everything is . Well worth the price of admission and the crowds. Take pictures where they let you which is only outside, if I remember correctly. Take it all in and be amazed at this beautiful place.
yet amothwer wonder. this is so large and has so many rooms that it would take a week just tom walk round. just so much top see. a must if you are in this city0.

Crowded but extremely beautiful. The most amazing place you'll visit. The Winter Palace is a major part of the Hermitage Museum so you get to see amazing art as well as an incredible building where the Tsars used to live and the October 1917 revolution took place. The rooms are stunning and so is much of the art work.Be warned, it gets really crowded. We luckily didn't have to queue to get in... the lines are long... as we were on a self-organised trip. We still got bumped by lots of ill-mannered tourists who have no idea how to queue or walk without avoiding people. Go and see this place and you'll understand! It's overcrowded but well worth the visit.

Divinely beautiful. Don't go looking for Faberge eggs at the Hermitage. It has everything else, golden columns & balconies, exotic chandeliers, best parquet floors anywhere in the world and some sculptures and nice paintings. Definitely will change your opinion of Soviet Russia.
Beautiful. Went here for private night time tour and symphony. Truly amazing, the beauty and history is overwhelming and it was one of my favorite things to do whilst we were in Russia.

WOW!!!. A definite must if in St Petersberg. The Hermitage is enormous and would take years to get around it all! Our guide had planned our visit well, having identified key areas / items of interest and made sure we covered as much as possible. The winter palace is awesome. Again we were so glad of a superb guide and would say to make the most of such a visit a guide is necessary.

Ho Hum. If you want to see Russian and Soviet art, this is for you. The bleakness of the Soviet era is manifest in the 20th Century selections. If you don't have much time in SPB, then choose another attraction. After having been to the Prado, Louvre, and other museums, it seemed to lack variety and energy. There were some lovely medieval and Renaissance pieces in the room with the church art.

Mind blowing. This was the most amazing place we have been to. It is hard to know where to begin. Was it the architecture, the faberge collection (there was an exhibition at the time), the artefacts from the time it was a palace, the stunning priceless artwork...?! It was exquisite. We spent 5-6 hours there which was simply not enough. We had a private guide and this is probably the way to best approach it.

Fantastic museum terrible access. Let's start with the access the queues are horrendous and once you get in you have to queue for the clock room. The main clock room holds 3000 coats. The process of getting in, especially if waiting in the rain, which was the situation when we visited results in frayed tempers and aggressive behaviour which we experienced. The museum holds fantastic paintings and artefacts. We booked to visit the gold room in our tour which was spectacular. The only downside of the gold room was that the tour guide was a member of the museum team and did not speak English. This resulted in our tour guide translating everything that was said, which was not ideal and like being in a time delay. The tours around the museum are closely timed and you have yo keep walking either in some areas no stopping yo take photos. Would thoroughly recommend the museum if visiting the city but patients us required to overcome the queues

"Amazing". The Hermitage Museum is a must. The area is very pleasant, nice cafes, restaurants, bars. You should find the time during the trip to St Petersburg to spend half day visiting the Museum. Focus in Rembrandt room in the Hermitage Museum.

Fabulous works of art. This is a must see place but my advice is book a private tour. The place is heaving with thousands of tourists. Although we were on a cruise we booked a private tour of st Petersburg with Alla tours before leaving uk. Our guide Slav was fantastic. He knew all the best ways around the museum so that we could back double if need be. If you don't care for artefacts or paintings, still go for the opulence of each room

Can not be done in one day. The entrance is reasonable, possibly contributing to the overcrowding. Several tour groups jostle for position and those not in a group seems to be shunted to the side. The solution was to make our own small group and march to the items we wanted to see. But you can not do this in a day, it is way too comprehensive. Read up. Plan your trip. Excecute. And then enjoy what you see en route. The extra exhibitions are also worthwhile, we did the gold room. Unique.

Diverse and Fascinating. The collections of art and history that are displayed here are amazing. The actual architecture and decoration from the time of royal residence are breathtaking. If you have the time, plan to spend a whole day just here. If you only have a few hours, it is still worth it. Make sure you don't miss the DaVinci and Michelangelo works.

Overwhelming!. Like the Louvre, to get the best out of the Hermitage you need to plan your visit carefully. The summertime queues are lonnngggg! Be prepared to wait for an hour to get in, even if you're with a pre-booked tour group.Once inside, it can be pretty manic, especially around the most famous exhibits. If you want some quality time to appreciate key pieces, arrive early, perhaps a make a number of short morning visits, or better still brave the cold and visit off-season. Otherwise be prepared to jostle for position for your turn to get 10 secs in front of a Da Vinci. If a single visit is all you can do and you're tight on time, a tour guide may be best as they know the quick routes through the main exhibits. If you're going it alone, get a on-line guide beforehand and plan the route out. The building interiors themselves are worth the visit, so make time to look up and around.After a couple of hours of jostling, you're ready to get out for some fresh air!

best palace in the world bar non and that includes Hampton Court, Buckingham & Windsor !. Finally got to St Petersburg after not being able to queue long enough to get a visa 4 times. This city is amazing. I am going to go back as there is so much to see in the Winter Palace alone ! I have never seen so much gold in my life and it is everywhere internally and externally ! We were able to get into the palace early and avoid queues and sharing a room with any body else although that changed after 10:30. The palace offers unparalleled craftsmanship, artwork and space like no other. It was one incredible space after another

A must see place in St. Petersburg. This palace is highly recommended to visit for all people coming to St. Petersburg. This place is special and unique. You will learn a lot about the epoch and the life of people living in it.

Amazing. Amazing museum! I thought about downgrading to 4 stars because of the crowds but that really isn't the museums fault. Surprised that many people stand in a very long line to buy tickets from a counter but ticket machines are fairly empty. Once you have a ticket entrance is fairly quick, but crowds are very big especially due to large groups of guided tours. We did a tour with an audio guide app on our iPhone that stated 1 hour... It took us a little over two hours, but was very satisfied with what we saw.

Monumental building, less impressive exhibits. This place is indeed overwhelming but the best exhibit by far is the building itself with the amazing rooms, hallways and decorations. Having spent 2 exhaustive days exploring the museum, I can honestly say that the art collection is not that impressive (certainly not at the level of Louvre, el Prado, National Gallery etc.)The Gold and Diamond Rooms (additional fees) are massive tourist traps that are definitely not worth the time unless you don't have anything else to do (which is almost impossible in St. Petersburg).

Incredible.... Very long queue, ribbon on Square. Buy your ticket advanced. Morning begins! Inability to see everything. Wonderful everything. I was impressed. But a lot of people, not tire of the sights but also crowds.If you want to see everything, you have to return. Maybe in winter they are fewer...

Lovely place but busy. This is lovely museum and you will need a lot of time to visit the place.the big downside is the amount of people coupled to the fact that it is very hot.we only had 1.5 hours so it was whirlwind tour but beautiful rooms ceiling and floors.try to go early or out of season

amazing!!!. the queue is insane! You can stand for hours in the queue until you finally get into the museum. It is confusing, desorganised, there is no clear info, employees do not speak good english. The tkt cannot be bought in advance and it's valid on the date of purchase, meaning, you better arrive early in the morning. You can escape the caos of the queues by buying your tkt online or hiring a guide as there are different queues for those tkts. Once you manage to get into the museum, you will be sure that everything was worthy! The museum is fantastic! The building itself is already an attraction.

An amazing palace. You could spend days exploring this museum. Arrive early as the crowds are large and the museum does not have A/C. It gets very warm inside as you tour the various rooms. Recommend a tour guide that supply headsets so you learn all the history within each room.

A lot portraits, a copy of Louvre. The Hermitage museum is a definite "must visit" place in St. Petersburg. Very Europium, very many portraits. Bigger than Louvre, but the paintings are not that well placed. A lot disappear in the direct light of the day (windows) and to even see what's on the paintings you have to find an angle where it isn't light blinded.  There are a lot worse to see paintings and a lot Romanov history.

To be visisted with a guided private tour. We had the chance to visit this museum with a private guide. It is obviously rather expensive but so worth the money and the time. The guide will pick up for you various precious rooms and paintings for which you would probably losse a lot of time and energy if you had to do it on your own.
Breathtaking. I would highly recommend a guide otherwise you could end up wasting a lot of time in this vast place!

Hermitage. One could spend weeks in this cultural heaven. The building, itself, is a work of art. Our guide was able to highlight specific pieces of art and provide extensive background on that which we were viewing. Having headphones to hear her remarks made the visit even more special.

Expansive, world class art museum. One could spend days at the Hermitage. Recommend touring with a guide to hit the high points before getting worn out. Beautiful venue with impressive collection of European artists.

Stunning Museum and Palace and A Must See.. Booked a tour of Museum with SPS Tours as part of a 2 day St. Petersburg tour, early admittance before official opening times and spent a couple of hours going through a small amount of the exhibits and getting a flavour of this wonderful and breath-taking palace. Guide warned in advance about pick pockets which was so helpful and necessary. Loved the paintings and the palace and was amazed on leaving at the crowds and queues which our guide explained were up to 3-4 hours long. This is one which is better organised in advanced to get the best of.

Packed but Magnificent. Went here on the tour. Mind you that our guide even mentioned that we are going in an hour early from the general opening time. But there were already several lines from other "tours" also going in. It took about 30 minutes for our group to go in. My tour was mostly narrated by the guide, went to several of the more famous and popular rooms. You have to pretty much elbow your way just to see the rembrants, michaelangelo and other famous painters. Our tour spent about 3.5 hours there and we probably only saw the tip of what Hermitage has to offer. But you do see the grandeur of the palace. It seems by the time we got out it was more people waiting outside and inline to get in.Warning: a lot of hawkers selling souvenirs outside and pickpockets. Actually saw one hawker trying to occupy the tourists' attention while there was a pickpocket person behind them.

Be prepared to walk and walk and walk. This is a must see in St Petersburg but be sure to wear your walking shoes and tank top. It's extremely HOT inside the buildings and the tons of people don't help either. Cameras without flash are allowed in most rooms. Limited places to sit. No food or drink. Small bags only. The rooms and rooms of beautiful art, paintings, antiques, vases etc. We went on a guided tour which is highly recommended so you use your time wisely. Even guided and quickly moving we still spent 2-hours. You can easily spend all day - so much too see and the crowds of people.

incredible. If you have got to St Petersburg then you could hardly not do this museum and winter palace. However allow for some time, a good morning as its enormous and there is a lot too see. I would highly recommend a guide, as they know their way around, as its very easy to get lost and with the crowds you could easily miss something amazing!

Unique!!. For me, this museum is the most amazing I have ever seen. I have never seen so many great masters under one roof. I have to say, I have been here twice. The first time was in November and we had the place to ourselves and saw much more, and this time. A wet July day with a great guide but the place was packed and we couldn't have done it on our own but it meant there was no time to see the Impressionists for example. The building itself is jaw dropping when you add the contents ... If you only seeone place in St Petersburg, this should be it!

There is So Much to See it is Unreal. It is a Must to get there EARLY and it is Mobbed by Midday. We spent a Day there and did not even see the Tip of the Iceberg and I would recommend you do your homework first so you see the critical things that really interest you. I am sure you could spend a week there and still not see it All - Just Mind Blowing

Stunnjng place. You have no chance of seeing this place in a week let alone a day so plan what you would be most interested in ahead of time to make the most of your visit. PICK POCKETS ARE RIFE. Our guide identified several and warned us, they abused her for watching them and telling us. It's a real shame that the security don't stop them going in they must recognise them. Security are only interested in the property and not their visitors.

State Hermitage Museum visit. Well as recommended we arrived early and at that time the queues were manageable.On reflection though we wished we had booked online and then you could more or less walk straight through to the front of the queue.We actually spent five hours in here so that gives you an indication as to how much we enjoyed the visit. I would say first of all ignore the irritation of the organised cruise tours who obviously think that their visit is more important than everyone else's!This place is spectacular from the minute you walk though the entrance gates there is so much to see and enjoy and as a bonus the exhibitions are housed in some spectacular buildings. Many of your major artists are here such as Gainsborough, Rembrant, Reynolds etc etc. Plus we even found work from Joseph Wright a local artist for us coming from Derbyshire! There were lots of early statues and artwork and once you have started in the exhibitions before you realise it you will have spent many hours of enjoyment walking around the various floors of sites to see.

Just about worth the scrum. We visited on a very wet and windy day, and the crowd physically struggled, with pushing and shoving and outbursts, to get in through the small entrance and out of the weather. Once in you are obliged to check in your coat and/or bags, so you face another chaotic struggle. The palace rooms are wonderful but don't assume you are here for the art, which you might glimpse metres away among the selfie-takers.

Winter palace is just amazing, don't miss it.. We hired a guide and didn't have to queue. It saved time and we got full attention from her and avoided the crowds. The place is stunning in interior and arts. No money saved when decorating and getting arts and paintings. You can spend at least one day if you are on a good shape but 3 hours was well enough. But what ever you do, go there. It's fantastic and we were happy to bypass the queues.

jaw dropping. this must be one of the most beautiful, rich and important museums of the world, rankig up with the Louvre, the Metropolitan NY and the British museum. it's art collection is Incomprehensible: it contains more than 3 millions works of art! it's humanly impossible to grasp the whole collection, but even the little you see in a regular - minimum half a day visit, is enough to awe-strike you. there are rooms full of Rembrandt,and rooms full of Caravaggio... gold gilded rooms, the Russian Tzsar's staterooms, crown room, throne room (the museum is located in the former winter palace of the emperors of Russia). and it goes on and on...
Without peer. There are no words to describe the Hermitage which do it justice. It is simply a 'must-see' and glorious

Nice but insanely crowded. We visited the Hermitage mid-week on a rainy day (which seemed the norm during a week in St. Petersburg). While the museum is impressive and has wonderful exhibits and pieces, the crowd and lack of efficient crowd control killed the experience.Long lines and people pushing to get through gets tiring. I suggest going as soon as they're open (or beforehand and stand in line), as by 11 on the day we visited they closed the entrance for a few hours as they were at capacity. When leaving we saw the line extend into the middle of the square; not worth waiting that long in our opinion.If you haven't seen any of the other palaces or museums in Russia, then it's worth it. We really enjoyed visiting the quieter parts of the museum (top floor).

Russia at its best, but beware. This museum was included as part of a Viking cruise from Moscow to St. Petersburg. It is magnificent, overwhelming and every superlative you can think of. On the downside, the crowds are oppressive and, despite multiple warnings from our guides, one of our party managed to lose his wallet to a pickpocket. That was despite being in a subgroup of thirty or so. It's probably a case for a money belt being worn under all your outer clothing. It's not convenient but it should preserve your valuables.Refreshments are available (and you'll need them - this tour can be quite exhausting) but there seems to be just one person serving the hordes. Be prepared for a longish wait and nowhere to sit. However, it's a small price to pay to visit one of the best museums in the world.

A Must See in St. Petersburg. We didn't have a great desire to see The Hermitage Museum as all reports indicated that it was just a huge art gallery with room after room of paintings. As we are not avid art lovers the idea did not appeal, but as it is on the agenda of most tours we did not have a lot of choice!How wrong we were. Our guide Tanya, from Guide Guru, quickly evaluated our interests as being more about architecture and interiors than art, and very efficiently moved us through more of the glorious Winter Palace rooms and just some of the more important parts of the art museum. The experience was truly amazing and we were very appreciative of our guide taking the trouble to accommodate our interests.

Not to be missed St. Petersburg. Booking anything can be daunting in St. Petersburg. I've been to the Louvre many times and The Hermitage blows it away in beauty, art and history. Definitely book advanced tickets through a tour group that will get you in early to beat the crowds. Another useful bit of information is the museum is open until 21:00 (9p.m.) on Friday evenings. I got our tour company to do a private tour for my family of 6 on Friday evening. There was hardly anyone there. We got to see so much more and our photo ops without all the crowds were amazing. We did the night tour and then the 2-hour regular tour with our main tour group the next day and got to see completely different rooms. It was a wonderful opportunity!

one of the best museums. First, this place hosts 30,000 visitors in July so be prepared for the crowds. However it's a museum not to be missed. One can see pieces of art by famous and less famous artists from all epochs. Da Vinci, Picasso, Matisse , Rodin , Gauguin, el Greco, and I am sure I forgot so many others...The settings in the Romanov mansion are just right for that, and in addition to art one can also get a feel of the extravagant life that the royal family led, and one can also understand why the revolution took place.So much history and art in this fantastic place
Wonder - World . I have been to many palaces in Asia and Europe, and I have never seen such glorious beauty of art and architecture. I have no any words to describe, just go, see and get blessed!!!

Get off the tour trail. Don't take the tours which seemed to me to be simply stating the obvious, but stroll around the quieter rooms where the hordes don't seem to go. The quality of the exhibits is second to none, we spent the whole day gazing open mouthed at architecture and artefacts.

Must see. This place is absolutely amazing. A must see if you visit St. Petersburg. Reserve at least 3-4 hours. Lines can be long. I would recommend to hire a professional guide who can skip the lines. Well worth the money, around $15/hour.

Awesome. No need to comment on this extraordinary palace and gallery. The buildings are as awesome as the art works on display, and it is probably a must for any traveler to visit SPB. It might be useful to note, however, that, unless you love standing in line for hours, you should order your ticket online or use one of the ticket vending machines at the right side of the courtyard, right next to the big entry portal. Tickets there cost a few cents more, but otherwise you'll never get a chance to jump the line
Great & Grand collection. One would need 2 years to see it all !!! Richly ornate, tons of history to unfold, second to the Lourve in Paris, breathtaking opulence, wonderful collection !!!

Plenty to see in one day. If you start early enough you can see all the museums in one day.
Must see in St Petersburgh.
Food not too badly priced. We in May did not have major problems with queues.

It was okay. We went here on a Friday. We got there about 10:15 and there was already a bit of a line . Fortunately we bought tickets online and printed them which helps to avoid standing in line to purchase. There was a 2 hour wait to purchase tickets by early afternoon. The real problem was the very, very crowded exhibits. There were also many people with long Selfie sticks in the way. It was hard to stand back and enjoy the art fur to the incredible masses of people. Coat check was required but free. Toilets were free. The physical beauty of the building was the best part of this museum. Also, beware of pickpockets on the public transport areas surrounding the Hermitage.
Purchase e-ticket. If you are in SPb in rainy days, better to buy. E-ticket on their website. You can use extra entrance with no que. If you see que to main entrance, you understand.

Get early access tickets. The lines are huge!. We had a two day private tour with SPB, highly recommend them. They got us in prior to the general opening to the public. It is a must see in St Petersburg, go early so much too see. It is a vast museum lots to learn and take in. Beware there are pick pockets looking for easy opportunities. You will need to check your bags.

10am. Best advice you will receive!Purchase your tickets online and print them out ahead of time. Don't go on the first Thursday of the month, that day is free and it will be mobbed.When you see the, yes mile long line of people, walk past all of them and there is a second aisle/roped off entrance to the left or right of the entrance (this is on the curved staircase plaza side not river) that is just beside the long lines. Once inside if it has been raining you will likely have umbrellas/jackets, you will have to check those to your left. Depending on the madness of the main hall there is another entrance in the 1400 or less small coat check. If you can and its not crazy rain, leave everything at the hotel you can and don't check anything as that is as much a hassle as getting in.To give you an idea, we waited in line to get in for about ten minutes with pre purchased tickets, the long line is roughly 3 hours. There are essentially no signs though directing you, so go straight to the front and you'll see the secondary ropedLanes.Good luck, it's with every effort!!!!
French Impressionism a Must!. The French Impressionism collection is spectacular! Make the extra time to go see it - it is in a separate area from the main Hermitage Museum.

Must visit. If you are interested in art plan several visits. One is definitely not enough.You can buy tickets on-line, but pay attention to tha fact that you have to use all the tickets on the voucher on the same day. For different days you need separate vouchers
Best Museum!. This is a fine museum! Best collection of art I've seen. Get your tickets in advance though. Long lines to get in if you have not purchased tickets in advance.

Packed to the gunnels with treasure. It's simply got it all. Everything about the Hermitage is grand. I love the building, the situation, the history, the gold leaf AND they even have done paintings. You name it.... it's there.

You Can't Miss This Museum in St. Petersburg. You can spend the whole day touring this museum and palace. If you're a history buff and/or a photographer, this is a must see place to visit. I suggest you hire a private tour guide who knows Russian history and the museum well.

My Second Favorite Sight in St Petersburg. This was my second time here. We were on an arranged tour which got into the palace before it opened to the general public. Our guide was well trained and explained in detail a lot of the rooms we saw....it was however....just the right amount of information. There are palaces and museums throughout the world but I don't think any can be as magnificent as this place. The size and contents and room decorations are just dazzling. We were a group of 16 which ranged in age from 8 to 80 and everyone seemed happy at the end of the tour!

History Comes Alive. A must see in this historic city. Today, a magnificent world-class art museum. Yesterday, the seat of a government overthrown in a massive, eathshaking revolution. We enjoyed both. The splendor of renown artists, dazzling mosaics, and famous statues. I sat for a few moments and imagined the Bolsheviks, alerted by shots from the battleship Aurora on the Neva River, storming the palace and ousting the provisional Kerensky government. You can see pictures, but the Hermitage is many times more grandeur in real life.

Can be done without a tour or guide. With limited time in St. P and with 2 teenage kids, we knew we had to approach the Hermitage with a plan. First off, we found the things we really wanted to see: Imperial apartment, Russian portraits, St. George's Hall, Great Church, peacock clock, Rembrandt room, Knight's hall, Da Vinci. All of these being on the same floor was nice. I had a map of the floor and circled and wrote in what I wanted to see. As you walk in each room, look for the room number above one of the doors. This will help guide you around.  TIPS:Buy tickets online-even if you read there won't be a line or you can use the kiosks, this took the guess work out and you knew you were ready for entry.Download the free APP-very helpfulIt's crowded & rooms can get hot-especially the Rembrandt roomThere are a few seats in many rooms-kids found them...Use the bag check for big backpacks. Carry water bottle & snack in your smaller bag. Know there are tours & individuals who will likely cut you off, take up entire viewing space, walk right in front when you thought you were the front row, elbow to get in front, etc. Be prepared to jostle right back or you might not get a peek.We saw what we wanted in about 3 hours. We had lunch at a close pizza place, and then we went to the General Staff Building to see the Impressionists. (separate review) But, suffice it to say, Staff Building was not crowded and definitely worth your time.

Tooo crowded. Staying in line for hours. People get aggressive. Wait again at the garderobe. Too many people in there.nimpossible to enjoy. The new part with the impessionists in the other palast is highly recommended.

State Hermitage: Great but crowded. Fantastic museum. Combination of a former palace and very large museum. Comparable to the Louvre or British Museum by its size and number and quality of displays.The Impressionist collection in the annex across the square is one of the best in the world. It is also less visited in a completely renovated setting. Worth the trip to St Petersburg on its own.Queues to get for the main museum are colossal. Count in excess of one hour even at the opening. Try and use a group tour or get your hotel to book for you in advance. Inside is extremely crowded as well.The impressionists are accessible virtually without queue... Try that at the musee d'Orsay in Paris...
2 hours is not enough. If you enjoy art, amazing decor, and massive sturctures, this place will privide it all but you will need a good five days to see it all and really take it in.
Amazing. Going on a day normally closed with a tour group is the way to go. We got right in and was not crowded. Beautiful art and history.

Great Mirror. Hermitage is a great and world class Mirror in which you could see any kind of art that you like ,any sign of civilizition that you search.Dont miss it.Arrange enough time and care about high temprature inside

Overwhelming and amazing!. You could spend four days at the Hermitage and you'd probably only see half of its collection. Truly one of the largest in the world, the building in which all of this amazing art is housed is awesome to see in and of itself.

Hermatige hits the Heights. one of the great cultural attractions of the world,the Hermatige continues to reveal itssecrets each time we visit.on this occasion we concentrated on the old masters and some contempory works.this is an exibition that contains the most sought after art ever assembled under one roof.to gain the maximum enjoyment from your visit,try an arrange a private guide to walk you through the palace and its many rooms.arrive early,ahead of the crowds,preferably in spring or autumn.wear comfortable walking shoes,switch off your phone and lose yourself in presence of genuis.don't attempt to cover it all in one visit.pace youself over two days or so,and save something for next time.

Magnificent!. A must if visiting St. Petersburg. We booked a guided tour with our cruise ship and it was fabulous. The museum is closed to the public on Mondays but open for organised tours such as ours so it was easy to walk round and view everything. The grand ballroom of the winter palace is fantastic with beautiful chandeliers, acres of gold leaf and beautiful ceilings and floors. Most of the rooms are like this but vary in size. The museum is really interesting housing paintings done by famous artists, furniture, artefacts and lots more interesting things. Definitely a must if visiting this beautiful city.
Stunning. We got to see this amazing place. This was my no.1 on my list for St Petersburg and it didn't disappoint. We got through early due to TJ Travel Tours. A must see.

Overwhelming. This place is unreal, you could spend days going through and still feel like you've only scratched the surface. I came with a tour group, and I recommend a guide to help you find the key highlights. I will definitely return some day, this is a gem that will always have something new to explore. You should plan at least a half day.

Great Palace; try avoid the queue by booking through the internet. Great palace; the interior decoration is definitely worth the visit. To avoid queueing up early in the morning for the ticket, one could book ticket through the museum webpage where you can pay by credit card and get entrance voucher where you can gain access to the Hermitage through separate entrance.BUT beware of very professional organised thieves who 'work' their ways inside the museum. They very professional, working as partners, deploying common 'gypsy tricks' which one commonly encounter in Paris or Rome. They distract your attention and your valuable will disappear in seconds.

Leave plenty of time to visit this amazing palace. This is a massive, wondrous place to visit. You will need a map or if on a tour then stick to your tour leader or you will get lost. Every room is amazing and the art work is prolific. Even if you spent only 1 minute looking at each work of art, they say it would take you a number of years to get through the museum. We only had the morning to take it all in, as we were on a tour, there just was not enough time allotted for us to appreciate this palace and museum, and all it has stood for in the history of St Petersburg and Russia.

Very stately museum. Best museum by far as to the collections of arts, sculptures and paintings. We were awed the moment we got in. I think I can stay in this place a whole month and still won't get to finish seeing all the things I want to See.
art lovers: make your choice. pick your rooms or art period because they have a loooootdo not forget to look at the building/rooms and try to forget the chinese tourists
Crowded and hot. The museum was crowded and hot.There is no supervision on the number of visitors simultaneously inside the museum, making it difficult to view and enjoying a visit there

Incredible beauty. The Hermitage, or Winter Palace, is an enormous palace filled with some of the world's finest European art. It can be crowded, but just looking at the building is amazing. We only saw a small amount of the immense collection in 1.5 hours, but it was about all we could take in. Be sure to see the peacock clock and the mosaic tables.

Impressive. A visit to the Hermitage is a must when visiting Saint Petersburg.It comprises 4 palaces, the Winter palace ,SmallHermitage, Old Hermitage and New Hermitage. We visited the museum as part of our SPB tour and enjoyed the visit very much.
Fantastic and interesting . Very interesting, well worth a visit. Highlight of our trip to this unique cruise destination. Arrive early as it gets very busy but well organised.

One Cannot die without seeing this museum. This is likely the biggest and best museum in the world. Unless you're particularly undaunted. it's not possible to see it all. So pick and chose and be happy. That's what we did and we were happy.
Museum tour. Could have used more time here but we had a full day of sightseeing. Fabulous selection of paintings by the masters!

Pick and choose from a wealth of wonders. We spent six hours in the Hermitage ... it was nothing like enough. In fact six days would probably only scratch the surface. We last visited more than 40 years ago when Petersburg was Leningrad and we, as students, were closely supervised. The supervision is still a problem. Visiting during a cruise, the only way we were allowed off ship was as a group ... unless we cared to organise individual visas. So the speed of the trip was reflected in a largish group. On the up side this meant we were able to enter the museum at any earlier time than allowed by general admissions. We had a tour of one of the gold rooms, too. Both these seemed only to be available as a group. The gold was fabulous and its history haunting. Even with the early admission the rooms seemed very busy. Our highlight trip then went through the five buildings which make up the Hermitage. We went nowhere near the modern paintings in the General Staff Building. Since the Impressionists were at the heart of our previous visit this became a necessary evil. Many works left a lasting memory: Michaelangelo's Crouching Boy; the 1812 Gallery; the Grand Church; the Pavilion Hall with its mighty mosaic and Peacock Clock by James Cox. The tiny Head of an Old Man by Rubens stopped me for longer than it should and I nearly lost the rest of the party. It was intriguing, too, to see pictures last viewed in Norfolk at Houghton Hall. For a brief period many of the works sold from that collection to Catherine the Great were allowed back to Britain for the Houghton Revisited exhibition.  As with our previous visit, I did find that a number of paintings were hung facing the light. In sunshine this made it difficult to view them in their full glory. My advice with the Hermitage and limited time is to study the museum's website and plan a route to see just what you want to, Along the way you will pass Rembrandts, Van Dykes, Raphaels and da Vincis. It will be up to your schedule to decide for how long you stop and stare.

Winter Palace/ Hermitage Museum. Found the whole experience very pleasurable, we had a 2 day ticket, what was good about this place compared to the Catherine and Peterhof, is that one could take one's time and see things again and again. The vasteness of the palace meant that there was always something new to see. In the General Staff Building, the Impressionist paintings were particularly appealing with all the masters of the genre being represented, Monet, Renoir, Degas, Picasso etc. On the ground floor there was a famous painting of the young Bonaparte in Italy. Of all the places I went to, the Winter Palace and its accompanying buildings was the best value for 800 Roubles on a 2 days ticket.

Fantastic Museum. My English is not good enough to explain how beautiful this Museum is.Only what I must say is that one wisitors ever wisits St Perburg can't leave City without wisiting that magnifisant Museum.Don't be that person and don't miss wisiting Hermitage.My advice is don't do that without good guide.We do that with Pauline, excellent guide.At your request I can give you her contact.Have a nice time there. Enjoy!

Lots to see - but plan your day!. You can walk around the Hermitage for days, weeks, or months without seeing everything. My reccomendation is to make a clear strategy upfront of the "must see" and take it from there. Amazing art, historic items and something for everyone. Reccomend to pre-pay for tickets to avvoid a line.

Number one in S. Petersburg!. The winter palace has no rival in Russia. Is increadibly beautiful and all the art collections are simply amazing. I suggest to plan your trip to the museum with the free oficial app.

Don't bother. If you think you are visiting a museum of great pieces of art you will discover most are 2nd rate and certainly not worth the effort of dealing with crowds and crowds of very rude people. There is no way you can stand back and admire anything as people jostle each other to get to the front. As for the wait to get inside - ridiculous. Save your energy for the truly great art works of this world in Paris, Rome and London where equally large crowds behave appropriately and give you space to enjoy the material on display. This place does not even rate the score I have given! The rudeness of the staff in the cloakrooms has to be seen to be believed although the I did have some sympathy for them with far too many customers to deal with.

Wow ! Definitely can't miss this!. We were in St. Petersburg from a cruise ship. This was the last stop before returning to the port. It was a long day filled with rain. Be prepared to wait a rather long time to get inside the Hermitage- and once inside it is chock full of people. It was extremely busy ! This is also considered the Winter Palace. There are 5 different buildings joined together that makeup the museum. It is filled with beautiful architecture and an impressive collection of over 3000 items. We were hurried through the visit as we were on a tour and we spent nearly an hour waiting in line to get in. But even though we were on a short trip through it was worth seeing. Make sure to look up at the elaborate ceilings. Photography is allowed except for flash. And there is a lengthy security clearance to get into the actual museum once you are in. Do not bring backpacks or any other type of large bag. You will have to check your coats (especially if wet) in the cloak room which adds to time at the back end to get your belongings back. It's definitely a must see and better if you allow more time to leisurely go through.

The Riches of Russia. An amazing collection of collections from all around the world in the most striking building - the Winter Palace. The length of queue changes from day to day but can be avoided by buying an advance ticket. See any hotel concierge even if your not staying there.
The most beautiful place. This is the most wonderful museum. The Winter Palace is breath-taking and the artworks are rare. We also saw a ballett performance and it was absolutely wonderful.

Wow. We went to there With Friend's, even Not enough for one day to visit.. each will be monthly on the first Thursday of free very well going on because it's free 10.30 in opening our trip it took 7 hours all every trace of fans remained Everyone must surely visit Palace of getting separate tickets to the museum part with. It's really amazing a Palace...
Stunning but oh so busy. Holidaying in high season. Absolutely packed and 200 metre line to get in. Need to plan your visit carefully and do some research about exactly what you want to see!

Overwhelming experience!. The five buildings of the Hermitage Museum, including the Winter Palace has to be the highlight of any visit to St Petersburg. The decor of the Palace has to be seen to be believed with the grandest examples of every type of architectural feature while to collections in the rest of the museum are absolutely unique.
Everlasting Hermitage by the Neva. A beautiful site from across the river and more beautiful inside in the gilded and mirrored halls and its collection of art treasures.
Must see!!. This museum is amazing! So much to see and is a must if you are visiting St Petersburg. We went with a private guide so no standing in that gigantic line!

Outstanding artwork but extremely crowded. Wonderfull collection of art, beautifully displayed especially the large halls and the private chapel of the tsar, but mobbed with people. Better to visit with a group and not in the summer.

As the director says...... ....probably not the first museum in the world but certainly not the second one. Impressive exhibition, wonderful , superb paintings, get lost in the different rooms named after the nationality of the artists. A magnificent experience, saw Versailles, El Prado. Louvre and others but the combination of art and opulence in the site is unbeatable. Perfectly kept and wonderfully displayed. No barriers between yourself and the artworks, another unicity of this lovely palace
Artwork and history galore.. This is a huge museum, no way to see it all, but we loved it. We did have our own tour guide who was outstanding which I'm sure helped.

Beautiful museum. I visited the Hermitage during my second day in St. Petersburg.One of the greatest museums in the world; before leaving we prepared a path to avoid seeing a lot of uninteresting rooms for us.You can stay there for a whole day and perhaps it would not be enough to see all the rooms.I recommend buying the tickets online ($ 16 for each, instead of 7/8 euro you buy the ticket directly to the museum) in order to avoid at least an hour of tail.The visit to the Hermitage is mandatory!

Awesome experience. We had an absolutely awesome experience at the Hermitage. It is a vast place. It is beautiful. The building itself is a vast complex and really a work of art on its own merits. The objects inside are truly magnificent and one cannot help but be in awe of all of this. Absolutely breathtaking.

Stunning. Awesome wealth, glitter, treasures and building. You will need a very experienced guide to take you through. There are millions of treasures to see. The art work of da Vinci Goya Rembrandt etc. amazing rooms with chandeliers ,gold and parquet floors. Buy a guide book to remind you of each room visited. We heard accapella singers in one of rooms...a real treat. It's tiring and frustrating try ing to see small art work. (Pickpockets again!)The peacock clock is fantastic. An amazing visit but you need weeks. However a rush round on a tour gives you a flavour of the amazing museum.

Too much for one day.. Where do you start with this place, it's huge and there is just so much to see you can't do it justice in one day. So many different parts that have been added and all filled with items from the most famous artists, sculptures and craftsmen from all over the world. Just the building would be enough to see let alone the millions of exhibits, stunning.
