A must see in St Petersburg. We were in a tour from our cruise. We got there early, but it was still very crowded and hot - no A/C. We were herded through and didn't get much time to enjoy an of the art. That said, you should visit the hermitage if you are in St. Petersburg.

INCREDIBLE!! MUST SEE!. You must see this museum when you are in St. Petersburg. I was shocked at how nice the outside and interior architecture was . . . work of art in themselves. Add the artwork and sculptures and you have one of the nicest museums in the world! MUST SEE!!!
A not to be missed highlight of St. Petersberg. It is hard to take in there is so much to see. Very crowded but definitely worth a visit. Wheelchair accessible washroom near entrance.

You'd need a year to visit this properly. Two different places connected to each other. The Winter Palace is full of wonderful rooms each opulently decorated. Do look out for the Peacock Clock (photo 6) it is mechanical and quite stunning. The Hermitage is of note because of its artworks, magnificent but VERY crowded, that's the only drawback. Wonderful.

Great, absolutely fantastic. This is obviously a must see when in St Petersberg. The only issue is the crowds.Fortunately we were on a tour from a cruise ship, which meant that we entered the museum over an hour prior to teh general public, even then we still had to queue outside for a while.Once inside for the first hour or so the crowds were not too bad but once the general public cam ein the place was swarming with people. BUT, the museum is very large and you can visit other locations within, where most folks do not go and still see some great works of art.The most impressive aspect of the museum has to be the architecture, this is a wonderful building, the work that went into building it, and keeping it in such fantastic condition. Fortunately you can take pictures, to capture memories. ,

Another iconic visit with great displays. I know that the source of many of the Hermitage's treasures is suspect, but it is a great pleasure to see so many classic paintings and statues. My only regret is that, even after two trips to St Petersburg, I have seen so little of the overall collection.

Extensive Repository of Art and Artifacts. As is often the case with massive museums comprised of many buildings, it may be important to come with a guide, as we did. How else will you know where to enter and what to see in what order? How else will you easily get into the Treasury Room, which requires a special arrangement and a specially trained lecturer, even if you come with your own guide?But if you do come on your own be sure to purchase your ticket online. This will prevent you from waiting on a long queue in order to be admitted. (I don't believe that the price is any different.) Once you have your ticket, lines are short or non-existent. But know this, online tickets are only admitted through a special entrance on the side of the museum (not joking, as this museum has many entrances, which results in a great deal of confusion for visitors).Next, be sure to STUDY the layout of the museum. You can do this online or even through various smart phone applications. Try to prioritize your interests among the many subject areas from Russian treasures to Greek Sculpture to Western European Art of earlier centuries to French Impressionism. And do make an appointment to see the Treasury Room, which is similar in nature to the Green Vault in Dresden, if you've ever been there. Amazingly fine treasures were given to the Czar by subjects of his expansive country (a country so large that its boundary touches upon other empires such as China, Turkistan, Iran, etc.). Were these subjects who provided such treasures paying homage or were they providing fealty in order to ask for favors? A good read of Tolstoy's novella, "Hadjii Murat," will help you to understand how such a collection might have been formed.Western Art in the museum covers paintings from the Netherlands, from Italy, from France, and from Great Britain. Rembrandt is given particular emphasis in this collection, but, alas, there is not one Pieter Breugel, the Elder, and few El Grecos or Abstract Expressionists. As expansive as it is, this is not a perfectly balanced and curated collection. 20th Century European Art is in a completely different building where you are admitted by the same ticket but must cross a very large central courtyard to get there. In winter, you will need to dress in your outerwear, even if for only 5 minutes.Bathrooms are a bit sparse. Food is served in one central area, but for all I know there are other locations I never saw. Do not expect a full meal, only a sandwich or pastry and a drink. Since there is so much to see, it might be cost and time-effective to eat a hearty breakfast beforehand and then a large dinner once the museum closes. We decided to return for another half day visit, but alas there is no half-day admission price. If you purchase your ticket on your own, however (which we did not), you can get a two-day value ticket that saves a good deal of money.One final word of warning, beware of the men outside selling guide books. Two of them "bumped" into my wife and pick-pocketed her wallet! An unusual occurrence? Hardly, as we had been warned by our guide to be careful. But these guys are pros. Perhaps it's a good idea should you have two credit cards with you to keep each in a separate place. Anyway, this is one thing that is unlikely to happen visiting the Metropolitan Museum in New York or the Kunsthistoriches in Vienna. They have THAT on the Hermitage.
Engineer. Best museum in europe worth to visit if you are in Saint petersburg. Visit all areas and enjoy your stay.

You need days in here to do it justice. We were on an organised tour, and only had 3 hours here, and we didnt even scratch the surface of the vast collection. Although we did see many of the highlights, we missed so much... Our guide was fantastic, somehow managing to get to the front of queues, and save loads of time waiting. The place does get rather full when cruise ships are in port, so be aware of that, and many of then are just so intent in taking photos of every single item.... But even if , like us, you only have a few hours, its a must. There are toilets at the entrance, ladies may have a 20 min wait, and also some at the exit.

Have everything. The Ermitage offers something for everyone, either you are intersted in the old Egypt or the famous painter like Rembrands and Da Vinci. You can easily get lost here for a whole day (or two for that matter). It is highly reccomended to pre-book tickets priro to your visit, as this will save you for a lot of waiting.

Vast museum with so much history.. We were on a two day trip with TJ travel I would suggest that you have a tour guide to explain what you are looking at where ever you go . This place is vast with a series of rooms. To try and understand the history as you don't have everything in English you need the guide.

The building is the star. Yes its a museum/art gallery. Personally I don't think its got the best collection of the grand masters. What it has got is the building itself. Some of the rooms are stunning (in between the tour groups) Don't bother hanging around the peacock clock, it only goes off once a week.Note your ticket gets you entry to the general staff gallery across the square, this is where the impressionist exhibition is held.
Super Museum!. One of the best museums I have visited. The museum has a very complete collection of a wide variety of objects and art. The museum as a palace is also great.

Fabulous collection in a beautiful venue!. Too many great items to list! Be sure to make a plan of what you want to see, the website is awesome to see your choices. The Museum was quite crowded when we were there and quite hot...be sure to wear layers. I was only disappointed in the tour groups being very disrespectful and pushing their way to the front of everything. Many of the people just snapped photos without even looking at the art. The museum should consider better crowd control. Use patience and well worth a visit.

Invasion of Tourists. We had a tour arranged through Oceania Cruise lines. As with many of the tours, the broken English of the tour guides was a bummer. But what was intolerable was the mass of humanity that was syphoned through the palace, numbering in the tens of thousands per day!. You shuffle along trying to understand your guide and are grateful when the tour has ended. The Winter Place and the Summer place were similar. If you can arrange a private tour, DO IT.
Very rich museum. . Never visit St.Petersburg without visiting the Ermitage. One of the richest museum I ever visited. Could be easily compares to the Louvre in Paris.

Baltic cruise. Try to visit in the cooler months,as peak season is horrific! Besides the crowds inside this absolutely beautiful and amazing place, you need to deal with heat as there is no air conditioning due to the fragility of the items on display! Also if you want to truly enjoy your viewing experience you need to be not rushed, this is not possible in peak seasons unless you are fortunate enough to have a viewing when it closes to the masses & is open only to groups such as cruise ships on private tours. Even then you would require dozens of visits as this museum houses no less than 2million pieces in 7 or 8 different buildings, the Russians don't mum about!

Get there early to avoid crowds. It's open to tour groups from 0900 and the general public from 1030. Some of the best works are behind glass which isn't perfectly non-reflective. If you go exploring by yourself, you certainly need a map as it is a labyrinth and very easy to get yourself lost.
world class. this is a truly world class museum.Do not niss if you are visiting this city.Again it gets crowded so plan and time your trip
soooo grate. It takes about 1/5 h to go in & it was a rainy day but it deserved Glory, beauty, artistic, but not enough time & we lost part of it

Go alone not with a tour and not hungry or in need of toilet. Stupendous collection. I got the 2 day internet voucher and spent first day of it at the Hermitage/winter palace. Next day was at the General Staff Building, which has all the Impressionists and almost all the toilets. I'd give the Hermitage 4 stars due to poor infrastructure for visitor comfort and the fact that it's packed with tour groups dully following their leaders and taking selfies. But since the art is over the top wonderful this brings it up to 5 stars. If you don't go with a tour and have the patience to wait while the hordes are blocking your view of the piece you want to see. While you're waiting go look at the other paintings the tour groups aren't looking at.

NOT TO BE MISSED. You need a full day to see this place. It is vast. Gold leaf by the ton. Get an early tour to avoid the worst of the crowds,with a good english speaking guide.The mind cannot take it all in.,but very much worth the effort .

Gold Room tour is a must!!. Gold room is a must visit, it is an extra cost but worth it. Do no bother on the diamond room tour as it is just a bigger room. If you like choose between the GOLD or DIAMOND room tour

Amazing. This museum is fantastic. If you took one minute to look at each display it would take eight years to see it all. Very clean and well maintained. This is a must see.. Maybe plan two days if you are a museum lover.

Not surprised there was a revolution!. Beautiful building and I've never seen so much gold. Huge museum and our 3 hour tour didn't do it justice. You could easily spend days if you were so inclined. I'd recommend taking a guide as they can take you to the really important pieces and explain the history etc.

Winter Palace Staterooms a 'must' visit. We didn't have an appetite for the spending hours touring the artworks but wanted to see the Palace staterooms - truly amazing and beautifully renovated. The private apartment of the Romanov's was a real insight.

The Most Amazing of Palaces!. The Hermitage is simply breathtaking and is a must see for anyone visiting St Petersburg. It is huge and requires a full day (at least) and the ticket can also include Peter's Winter Palace and the General Staff Buildings (both well worth visiting too). The decorations are fantastic and so is the artwork. If you visit in winter time then it will be much quieter and you may even get a private English tour by virtue of nobody else being there! In summer it is busier but still definitely worth visiting. Don't miss it!

Just wow. Impressive, magnificent... There's no words for the architecture and luxury. You need to visit this place at least one in your life. If you are a fan of art and history, you got good shoes this place is incredible.

Overrated - huge collection, but no must see WOW pieces! Overcrowded even early on pre-booked tour. . The place is loaded with art - great, but nothing that says..." You must see this" - like the Mona Lisa or Last Supper - skip the craziness.

Stunning, but busy.. Amazing collection of cultural icons and historic artifacts inside a spectacular setting. Well worth reading up on some Russian history before visiting to help get a sense of context and chronology. Good value and a great few hours soaking up the information. The only thing preventing a full rating is it is a victim of its own success in terms of the crowds. There are literally hordes of organized tour groups (a lot from cruise ships) that can detract from the overall ambience of the Palace, but go anyway, you'll be glad you did.
Hermitage Museum. This is a not to miss Museum.We had only half a day. You need at least a day or more to really appreciate it.

Gold and Diamond rooms. This is a trip well worth doing but arrange it with a tour guide mim 2 persons that way you are told more details than if you were in a bigger group. The time we went there were less people to see the gold room

You need a week. You really need at least a week to see the main highlights in all the different sections of this museum. We only had one day so we will have to go back. The highlights for us were the Treasure collection, the rooms of the Winter Palace and the post-impressionist collection. The problem is that there is so much that we did not see because we didn't have time! Next time....

6 stars - book online and consider late night Wednesday. Book online to save queuing and consider visiting late Wednesday afternoon (open till 2100) to avoid the tour crowds. The grandeur and sheer beauty of the state rooms are simply jaw dropping. The Egyptian room was also incredibly interesting. Plenty of art and other exhibits dating back centuries. Purely magical!Thanks for the vote if you found this helpful.

Start at the top and work down. That is our tip for not missing out too much. We head for the French impressionist galleries and its superb array of pictures and descend through other displays, selecting the exhibits we have highlighted before. You will never see it all, just cherry pick. Our favourite item is the wonderful peacock clock.

Pretty but nothing much compared to Versailles. Go for the paintings! And art overall; interior room deco was a disappointment, mostly very plain and white (alltho the library...).They have these ridiculous rules : you can't take water / liquids / food inside the museum (medium sized backbags are fine) ; i saw many poor elderly gentlemen literally dragging their feet and many were actually napping on the benches in the cafe.... so , I'd recommend you buy a ticket online which grants you a whole day access (or even two days) so you can actually remember what you saw, if you want to see 'everything' worth seeing.Regular tickets are sold in the ticket machines which have instructions in english, so you don't have to wait for hour(s) for your one-time-entry ticket.

Can't be missed. Extraordinary insight into the lifestyle of the Russian royals. Huge museum that needs a minimum of 2 hours to merely walk through. Best to be the first group of the day as crowds just build from then.

Hermitage Museum with great Buildings. I did not think the art collection lived up to my expectations, but the buildings which house the collection and the history behind the collection are worth the visit. The buildings are spectacular and it is amazing to think of the collection by the royals while the average Russian was starving. It was enlightening and I found the similarity between other European royals interesting.
Beautiful site . Incredible place! Worth to spend a full day. I would recommend to take a guide as the place is huge and you may get overloaded with the information and miss really important sites.
Tourist. One of the most amazing places we have ever visited. We want to bring our whole family back in the future. The architect is extremely impressive.
Essential to your time in St Petersburg. By far the most breathtaking and extensive collection of Art work, and artifacts dating from the stone age through to modern times.

I don't get what's the excitment is about. It's just a big museum combined with even bigger art gallery. Too big to see in one time. Why put it all in one place? You buy a ticket and can't see half of the place. Not only because you get tired of walking and MASSIVE crowdness, but also because they take away your water and you get THIRSTY after an hour. No place to drink in there. And you can't go out and return using the same ticket. That's simply ridiculous.

Impressive but also a bit too much and you need a long time. If you are not a museum indoor person, you will have tough time as this is huge and you need 4 to 5 hours at least to just see bits of it. You need 2 to 3 hours only for a glimpse. It covers everything art, history, Europe, Asia, ME, Japan and what not. It is huge but worth an experience. You do not need to see al if you are not a museum person nut just some parts to get an idea. No doubt that the building from outside itself is great.

More than a museum and art gallery!. On everyone's must see list the Hermitage does not disappoint. Of course it is impossible to see it all on one visit but a good guide is a must as they will take you through all the main state rooms and you will see the highlights of the collections. Their training is extensive and their knowledge is really essential to appreciate the building and the art.Must go back!

The Most Beautiful Museum . We went to the Hermitage Museum as a part of our Tour of St Petersburg. What a wonderful Museum, wonderful Art and even the floors were Gorgeous. I could have stayed all day, incredible. The Paintings, Furniture, Tapestries, the Cool Clock, and Gold Accents all over. OMG GORGEOUS. A wonderful Museum highly recommend it. Also the room with all the small paintings done by one Artist.

Breathtaking palace, one of the best art collections in the world. Do not miss this, just don't. Incredible art, spectacularly beautiful palace! I've been looking forward to the Hermitage for years and it did not disappoint. It is one of the best museums in the world---the collection really is that good. Amazing and beautiful things from all time periods and places. Stunning. We went twice for many hours each day and I think we still missed stuff. And the rooms of the palace...left me speechless.Some info/suggestions that I hope will help:1. The Hermitage is CLOSED ON MONDAY.2. Info I saw online said you have to bring your passport. Nope. We were there on two different days and no one ever asked for a passport.3. You can buy your tickets online. The up side of that is that you are spared a long and very slow line. Down side is that that charge significantly more money online. But you have another option! There are ticket kiosks in the inner courtyard of the Palace by where you enter from Palace Square. These kiosks don't let you buy the multi-day passes--only one day passes--but these are MUCH faster than the main line. If we had stayed in the main line we'd probably still be there waiting to get in.4. If you like art or beautiful architecture even a little plan on more than one day. This place is not to be believed.

Awsome. The Hermitage is huge, the biggest collection of art in the world probably. One a one day visit there is only time to see highlights. The building is lovely the floors ceilings lights everything. To do it justice one would need a month. When looking at this stunning collection one can understand why the peasants had a revelution.The nobility had all this richness and they lived on potatoes . The upside is that the modern generation are reaping the results by tourism bringing so many people to see the wonderfull palaces ect it provides much needed jobs.

Confusing layout. Wonderful exhibits. Full of tour group and confusing layout.. do remember that you can store your bags at the coat room. Please set aside more than half a day to have a brisk walk-through.. if you wanna have a detail exploration.. please plan 2 days..

Unbelievable!. This museum is never going to be visited in a day or even a year. We got an overview of the old/old, the old, the new, and didn't make a dent in the hugest museum ever. They have some of the most fantastic European art in the world. A definite five star event.

One in a Million. The Hermitage is a beautiful museum and a must for anyone who is visiting St. Petersburg. I was concerned about the amount of walking and stairs that are a part of this trip. As long as you have the ability to walk a half a block and do a flight of stairs at a time, you will be fine. There are so many people who go to the Hermitage in a day there is no moving fast through the museum. Which brings me to the point that you don't have time to look at the paintings for a length of time. You will have time to look at paintings, but not sit and ponder. The museum is a treasure. It is overwhelming with the amount of art, but not to be missed.

Unbeleivable wealth. A must for anyone visiting Saint Petersburg. Extremely busy and very few places to sit. You must have a guide to even begin to understand and appreciate the collection. Only a very small selection, about 3%, of the collection is on view. You must see the carriages, they are unbelievable.
Treasures. It is amuse see our good guide Elia took us in a 2 hour tour in heavenly art I was very much impressed by Medieval collection and the portraits but it needs more time

This is the crown of a unique and beautiful city.. There is little that can be said about this beautiful museum other than it is absolutely beautiful. I would strongly advise that you should take a guide when visiting and let the guide know in advance what type of art or artefacts appeal to you to let your visit can be as focused as possible.Realistically if you want to get a flavour of the Museum and have limited time with the guide is the only way to do so if not strolling around the museum itself will just give you an idea of the splendour of the place that is just beautiful.

A Must see. A Huge place to visit along with the Winter Palace there are so many rooms and displays to see it is a new experience around every corner. Allow plenty of time as it is a busy venue and so much to see. A full day at least.

An amazing experience.. We visited with a private guide on a very busy day. I would have hated to stand in the queues which were extensive. We were whisked past all of that in minutes and began our tour of this amazing art museum. We were ther three hours and only saw the highlights. For me it's much the best art museum visited. Amazing!

Stunning palace. One for your bucket list!. Firstly a word of advice, buy your entry tickets from the automatic ticket booths just inside the courtyard of the Winter Palace directly to your left. Don't join the long queue for tickets or buy them online! It only costs 600 rubles to visit each.So after bypassing the huge queues for tickets by using these automatic ticket machines we strolled into the palace. Don't take water or liquids. You will be asked to leave it at security. The palace is huge and stunningly beautiful. Every room is different, every ceiling is incredible, every floor a triumph. I'm not kidding either. I've travelled the world and I'm not easily impressed but this is a place you should put on your bucket list.The only problem is the large tour groups of people, they are mainly Chinese, who are rude and seem to spend their time blocking the doorways and elbowing everyone out of the way. The Palace opens until 9pm on Wednesdays. Try and visit later in the day when the tour groups have gone home. There is an incredible amount of art and artifacts on show but the star is the palace itself.

Museum & Palace All in One Place. We were lucky to be able to get in the Hermitage in the morning and therefore there was not too much waiting to get in. You need time to be able to absorb everything because the collection is vast. This time you do not need to put on the over shoes before you get in. The art collection by great artists such as Picasso, Van Gogh, Matisse, Monet.....etc. is overwhelming. All in all, this is a place not to be missed in St. Petersburg!
Lives up to its reputation!. An exquisite collection of masterpieces. You need at least 3 hours or so to see the highlights at a relatively fast pace.

Fantastic museum in an opulent palace. This is one of the great museums in the world. It is not to be missed. The art collection is huge and its setting in a beautiful palace makes it even more impressive. It was very crowded and hot when we visited, but those were minor inconveniences. A must see.

Stunning. This is the second time I visited the Hermitage. It is quite an incredible place. Leaving aside the collections on display for a moment, just look at the floors and ceilings. The craftsmanship is unbelievable, amazing to think this was once the actual home of the Tzar and his family. The displays are probably the greatest in the world, even though they can only show a small percentage at any one time. Apparently, it would take nine years to view the entire collection even if one were to only have a quick glance at each item. Not to mention the fifteen hundred rooms in the palace,A must see.

an amazing collection of treasures. I visited long ago but dream of returning. The treasures of centuries of Russian and European cultures are here. Oh wait..it was July of 1968...in high school studying Russian language!

The whole history of Art in one museum. Advise for all summer visitors: Yes it is growded full of guided tours but there is a small sneak: on Tuesday and Friday is the Emiritage open until 21:00 and after 18:00 it is less growded and enjoyable also in Summer when the tours have dinner ;-). What should I say - it is superb. The old palace building is one of the most beautiful ones I have seen yet. Every room has its one style and decoration with so many beautiful details. The pictures and paintings are like an who is who of Art from the 10th century until today. Don't miss the more modern part in the staff building across the palace place

do we really need another review of the Hermitage. it goes without saying that this is one of the best Museums in the world. Several rooms will take your breathe away as you enter. Try to go very early before the Tour buses arrive....well worth the effort. Sit when you can and soak in the Royal Life. It is wonderful

II wounder. why the present regime is so proud about presenting the Czar regime richness.. Very large and rich display the wealth of the Czar "family". You can grasp the limitless potential and wealth of the few. I think, that their biggest problem was to find a subject to allocate for the abundant rooms. The careless and the selfish ruler, made It obvious, that soon or later the Bolshevik revolution will appear. I wounder why the present regime is so proud about it.

A visit to remember for ever. We were on a cruise trip and the only way we could get to go to the Hermitage was on an evening excursion as it was closed otherwise on the Monday. It was an expensive trip but we will remember it for the rest of our lives. The gallery was closed other than to the tour party so we got to see all the works of art close up and personal. There are thousands of people there during the day and you just would not get close enough to do justice to the art. This way we did. My wife was in a wheelchair so she had a virtually unobstructed view, which would not have been the case during the day. At the end of the visit we went to the large Italian Skylight Hall and there was a concert by the State Symphony Orchestra of St Petersburg. The music was so good and the setting just stunning. It was a privilege to listen to such talented musicians in these surroundings. We followed this with a champagne reception. OK it was expensive but it was a magical night and we all agreed it was an experience of a lifetime.

Why the day is too short?. What a place, a 2000 room museum that needs many hours to just blink atWhat a wonderful history and great organization.Love it.Museum close at 6pm. Make sure you go early to see as much as u canMust do in St. Peter's

Amazing palace!. Any sightseeing should at least include: The Hermitage Museum with the Winter Palace, Peter and Paul Fortress, Tsarkoye Selo with Catherine Palace, Saint Isaak Cathedral, and Peterhof the “Russian Versailles”.

Hermitage Museum. This museum has thousands of exhibits best visited with a guide to explain the treasures and the history.
Very busy locations but we enjoyed it immensely and would love to return some day.
.

One of the best museums. The Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia has one of the largest collections of Western European Art in the world.
Wonderful!

You need to like art. A great museum with lots of artifacts and rooms to look in. The exhibits are great but you will queue to get in and have to leave bags coats while youlook around. You can take non flash photos but many rooms are dark. There are a lot of stairs and they will say it's a very confusing layout. I disagree it's just far to full and you get dragged along with the masses. It's difficult to get close to exhibits and when you do someone will push in front. If it was half as busy it would be amazing

One of the best and biggest collections of art you will ever see. I have seen the Vatican Museum, and I can vouch for the fact that the State Hermitage Museum can stand tall, for the incredible collection of art it has to offer. Its a must see for every tourist visiting Russia.

Immense art collection. A very impressive and versatile collection. Take some time to plan your trip in advace. Artworks are displayed in different buildings. If you are interested in the impressionist and post impressionist paintings, they are located in the General Staff building, on the opposite side of the square from the Winter Palace.
Must see. We were fortunate enough to have a personal (and knowledgeable) guide who very much added to our pleasure. What a fantastic palace. Such opulence!

Tourism. The museum is a must for anyone interested in history and fine art. Be patient, you may have to queue. Pick a good well reviewed your company. If on s cruise. You do not have to rely on the ship's own excursions.

Brilliant. Brilliant place but don't loose your group... it's massive... one of the world's best museums and a must to see when in St Petersburg... allow 4 hours.. The crowds are large but well worth it

I could have stayed here for days!. Nothing can adequately describe the Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace. You will not want to come to St. Petersburg and miss the Hermitage! Amazing architecture, beautiful gold, marble, artwork, and on and on and on...... If you have a guide it is better. We used TJ Travel and were connected with earpieces. It gave meaning to everything we saw.

A must-see. Incredible. My best tip: the museum is open 2 days/week until 9pm (M & F, I believe) -- you'll have the place to yourselves. Otherwise, it's quite crowded (we went in June). I particularly enjoyed Tsar Nicholas' library.

A Highlight of St Petersburg. This museum would quite possibly take years to see its nearly 3 MILLION pieces they have on display!! Only the Louvre in Paris rivals it's size and the quality of works in its collection. We unfortunately were on a tour that wizzed us though the highlights of the museum, but the day we were there, they were closed to the public and our tour group was the first through the door. We had the whole place to ourselves, no lines, no groups of people blocking the artwork. The only other people in there were artists painting copies of the masterpieces and a few employees. What a great way to experience this spectacular museum! Definitely a don't miss on a trip to St Petersburg!

Sublime. We paid extra to tour the museum early before the crowds and to get a behind the scenes tour at the storage building. This was well worth the money. The day included the most important works, the impressionist collection and fabulous tents and carriages not on display.

Pictures Won't Do It Justice. This place will blow your mind. The scale and opulence of every room is hard to wrap your head around. The museum exhibits alone are amazing, but to have it set in such an incredible place... You have to experience this in real life, the pictures can't capture the scale. Definitely worth the lines and crowding. The back story behind the existence, repurposing, neglect, and restoration is very interesting, too. If you can figure out the automated ticket machine in Russian you can avoid the line for tickets. Be aware that not all exhibits allow photos.
A must visit in St Pete. The tsars really know how to collect artworks and build a palace. Both are beautiful and seeing the original Rembrandt works was a treat.
Beautiful!. The Hermitage is an art museum, but as we visit it, we can also see the palace itself. It is astonishingly beautiful and rich (too much, considering its time, but evenso awesome).

Inaccessible entrance. Absolutely stunning rooms. Our own Royal Palaces pale into insignificance in comparison. But I use a wheelchair and had to rely on fellow tourists to carry me and my chair up a number of steps to the entrance. There is a level exit at the back of the Museum (and a well-designed disabled toilet) but no notices or members of staff directing those in wheelchairs to an accessible entrance. Considering the world importance of this Museum, it is time the staff got their act together.

MESMERISING AND SPECTACULAR. Visit to the winter palace in the Hermitage leaves the visitor spell-bound with its magnificent architecture and opulence. It not only gives us a peep into the luxurious lifestyle of the rich and the mighty but also speaks volumes about their love for art and beauty. The Golden Ballroom and the rich collection of artifacts is beyond compare. It is one of the largest and oldest museums in the world and displays paintings by great masters like Michelangelo, Raphael, Leonardo da Vinci, Rembrandt, Ruben and some of the French Impressionists. It is not just a museum but also a treasure house of Russian history. We were lucky enough to have a very knowledgeable guide who was also good at explaining the intricacies of royal whims and fancies. Three hours were just not enough for such a vast area and collection of artifacts.I wish we had enough time to enjoy the rich spread.
Dont miss it. Don't go on a hot day cause theres no air conditioning. Absolutely amazing. Not to be missed!! One room more magnificent than the next!!

OUTSTANDING. Visited the Hermitage Museum as part of a tour group .. totally blown away by the magnificence of the complex and the wonderful works of art After the tour I stayed on in St Petersburg by myself and revisited especially to see the magnificent Peacock Clock in action. Spectacular A must see

Too much awe!. We visited in May 2016. Ostentatiously lavish interior rooms and an impressive art gallery. We toured the Hermitage twice in one day - first with a guide and jostling with the crowds, and then on our own once the crowds had largely disappeared. My abiding memories are the small dining room where Tsar Nicholas II and his family were arrested, the Malachite Room, Hall of Heroes and the Rembrandt portraits. But at times, there were far too many people milling around for my liking!

Don't miss it. This is where I learned most about Russian history and culture during my 2 day stay. You need a guide to get the most out of it. We used Best Guides who we found on the internet. Very knowledgeable and also reasonably priced.During the peak tourist season there are huge queues so book ahead for a time slot or be prepared for a long wait. Whichever way, it is worth it. There is so much to see so it is advisable to read up on it before you go. The art alone would take a day to do it justice but most tours last 2 to 3 hours. Nowhere near enough. Just relax and enjoy the opulent surroundings. It's impossible to see it all in one visit.

A must seeing in St Petersburg . One visit not enough to see the treasure of the museum. It is the high light of the city and there hundreds of visits daily. I have not met anyone, who was not impressed.I visit St Petersburg for 4 years during summer season and although I went in the museum 6 times, still there many things that have escaped from my attention.
Wish I could've stayed for more than a day. This museum has everything you can imagine be sure to visit it + the general staff building infront of it.

Breathtaking. I was with a tour, which was a great way to go because we were able to go early. The crowds are almost unimaginable, especially by noon when we tried to get back down to retrieve our belongings in the coat room- and this was off season! The rooms with famous masterpieces are especially crowded, most notably directly in front of the works. But I wouldn't have missed this opportunity for the world. It would have been worth seeing even if there weren't any things displayed inside, the rooms themselves are so incredible. You don't have to wonder long however why the peasants revolted!

Blows your minds. I wish I could have spent more time in the museum. It should be a definite stop for everyone visiting the city. You will find delights around every corner. It is interesting to see how Russians view museum displays.

Wonderfull. I definitly advise a hire your guide othervise not possible to understand all photos meanings it can took your all day if you are intrested in art must see and i think you couldnt finish all
Must See. Can't even begin to relate the majesty of this palace and museum. Rooms and rooms of beautiful treasures.

Overcrowded and below average. I understand everyone "must" go to the Hermitage, but if you've done the Louvre or British Museums, this is a bit tired and uninteresting. The incredible Peacock Clock was unique and made the rest of the time bearable.

Keep calm and explore the Hermitage. It is impossible to see everything in one day. We visited the museum several times and never repeated the route. If you come in summer, be prepared for long lines and hoards of tourists wandering around. We bought tickets online, which saved us plenty of time and nerves. The beauty of the museum is that it has exhibitions of art (nationalized after the Revolution) in the original interiors of the Royal palace.The most striking were the decorations of the Winter palace. Take time to look at the ceilings and floors as they are original and were not damaged during the WWII. Be patient and be ready to have breaks for a snack/drink as no liquids are allowed at the exhibition.

Guided visit to one of the nicest museums in the world. The State Hermitage Museum is one of the nicest museums in the world, and the vastest. Therefor, I would recommend anyone who would like to visit to hire a guide. When I asked him what would be THE masterpiece, the equivalent of a Joconde, he smiled and answered they didn't have one, they had many. True that.

Number one museum. You could spend days here! Stunning rooms and stunning content. Renowned as world's best museum. Bit corwded but fine once you leave the first few main rooms. V well kept and general staffing well worth a visit, pther side of the square

So much to see, so little time.... There is so much to see, it takes an educated tour guide to make sure you see the significant areas of the museum. Getting the tour with advance ticket admission saves considerable time.

Unbelievable Museum . Fortunately we had tickets to enter before the general public. This the most comprehensive museum we have ever visited and the quality pieces make it very special. Please allow a number of hours to visit. Still you will only witness a tiny percentage of what they display.
A truly special and Unique experience. Once in a lifetime for us.
Very crowded. Extremly crowded but extremely interesting. We spent there 5 hours with our guide art historian and i feel that was not enough. Next time will spend all day.

Words fail me!!. I bought a 2-day ticket online before leaving home and it turned out to be a good idea....no ticket lines to wait in and I was inside nice and early. After 2 full days I was foot-sore and bleary-eyed but would not have missed a minute of it. All I need now is another year or two to see the rest. Best recommendation is to allow yourself ample time here - this is not a 'rush' destination.

Must visit.. There are so many things to see there - history, art.... It is certainly worth a visit. Unfortunatelly it is not so well organised, there was a huge cue arround the building to buy the ticket, than another one to enter, to pass control...... It is also hard to find the exit. Anyway you should be patient and prepared for waiting and very slow walking arround due to the crowd.

Bring your walking shoes. I went to this fabulous museum as part of a school tour. You will be walking a lot, there is soooooo much to see. Like others have said patience is good to have while visiting. There are so many groups, some are respectful of line & queues for major works of art, while others will pay no attention and push their ways up to the front bypassing the obvious line. Not many people speak English and I guess that's the excuse. Just be prepared for some physical contact if it's a busy time. I went on a major holiday weekend so that could be part of the issue. So much to see and so little time. One of my fellow classmates stayed until closing, giving the museum 9 hours of her day. I spent only about 5 1/2 hours and still didn't see everything. Took so many pictures because it was just so amazing. If you love art and/or history this is a must see!
Stunning Architecture. Beautiful building, with lots of baroque, rococo, and classic features. Gold gilt everywhere! Go early and avoid the tour groups!
wonderfull. its a very big museum we have been inside each of two parts about 6 hourson defferent daysbothof them are recomanded

Must see for your visit to St.Petersburg!. The best way to see the Hermitage is to hire your own private tour guide who has a thorough knowledge of Russian and western art history. We had a wonderful tour guide who got tickets for us and lead us through the museum before it is opened to the general public so there is no waiting in line. We had to fight for space periodically with other tour group but in general we have pretty good access.. Don't get to close to the artwork or the alarm will sound! We found out that most of the treasures are in storage however, but still a wonderful experience!

Has old Russian stuff.. Has old stuff, a lot of old stuff. You don't need to see quite so much old stuff as they think you do. There are lots of pots. Some pots are blue. Some pots are not blue. A guide told me why blue pots were interesting. I asked him to define "interesting". I didn't know we needed to have so many old pots. There are a lot of old pictures. It takes a surprisingly short time to get fed up looking at old pictures. I could continue; they had a lot of old statues. Some had their willies out. If you like museums they have a lot of stuff that museums have. Oh, did I mention that to have so much old stuff all together means that the place is very big; that makes it very difficult to know how long it will be before you have to stop looking at old stuff. Go alone - you can stop looking at old stuff quicker than if you're with someone who likes looking at old stuff.

Bring your Patience to the Hermitage. A truly amazing art museum. You could literally spend days wondering this magical place and always see something new. Our one day visit was just not enough...I can't wait to go back someday. One word of advice: go as early in the day as possible. Get your tickets/tours in advance...and get there when it opens. There were some extremely long lines to see some of the most popular works.

Top place to visit. Get there early as it gets really busy. The locals have long queues but you can pay for your tickets in the outside machine and go past these queues. You could easily spend a week in this place so a good one to visit if the weather is wet. Entrance is very reasonable. Get a map of the building and plan what you really want to see as there are 14 miles of corridors!

If you are not impressed with this museum, you have experienced premature brain death.. The historical/archeological collections are as impressive as the artistic collections. The early Siberian and Black Sea art objects are utterly stunning. Want a ogle an entire room of precious Rembrandt paintings? This is your opportunity.
Awesome gems of art. Brilliant masterpieces and unknown(mostly) gems of classic art. Different epochs and masters from all over the world

Experience of a lifetime...... I had the opportunity to go to the Hermitage 36 years ago when at 16 I didn't fully appreciate it....(at all really) This is truly an amazing museum. We were very fortunate to get an early opening....and were into the museum by 9:10. We were able to tour several of the halls before our entrance to the Gold Room which was set for 10:30. The Gold Room is magnificent and shouldn't be missed. When we had finished this tour there was a huge difference in how many people were there and we were happy to end our tour by 11:45 as trying to see anything was becoming more and more difficult. All in all an amazing experience.

Beautiful but poorly organized. We spent about an hour in the line, but when the dates were opened, it became a total mess. It's so unorganized, we were lucky the weather was not very hot. The place itself is beautiful, but it's better to take an audio guide if you don't have a regular one.

Riviera Travel Tour. So much to see it can become overwhelming but a good guide can pick out the highlights. Well worth a visit when in St. Petersberg but wear comfortable shoes as a lot of walking and only limited seating during the tour.

Must see - of course that is why it's so crowded.. This is our second trip to St. Petersburg and we spent four hours with a guide inside the Hermitage - we loved that the impressionists and post-impressionist work was moved from the Winter Palace and into another building on the property. It requires a separate ticket, but at least it gives you space and quiet.The Winter Palace, full of Raphael and Rembrandt and other amazing treasures - not to mention being inside the Winter Palace (and its history) is amazing. It's also packed with people who are fine with pushing and other non-civilized behavior. Even with a pass and guide that got our family in 30 minutes before normal open, the Hermitage immediately becomes packed during prime visitor season.That said - it's an absolute must visit.
Extraordinary!. This is the most amazing palace I have ever seen. The wealth and opulence is beyond comprehension. The museum collection is good...I loved seeing the Kandinskys.

WOW. A must see in St Petersburg. Hard to believe but there's a "WOW" in every room.
Its BIG and I highly recommend if you don't have a lot of time in St Petersburg, get a guide to take you through the Winter Palace and Hermitage. A fine example of Baroque style architecture like I had never seen.

Maybe the finest museum collection in the world. We had a rainy day and ended up at the Hermitage and were bowled over by its beauty and the amaziong colelction. Several days a month the admission is free and there isn't a better way to spend the day. Nice snack bars and coffee houses. And the gift shops were amazing.

Unbelievable and a must see. This museum is a must see. Plan on spending many hours to be able to see the most incredible displays. Recommend you set up a private tour with St. Petersburg Tour Company and ask for Nadya as your guide
Best in the world-Must see. If you go to the St. Petersburg this is first place you should look for. Amazing collection beyond any words to explain about this place.

One of the greatest museums on Earth!. I was utterly astronished by the great amount of collections in the Museum. Every collection has its own history to share. MUST VISIT! Spent about 5 hours there.

So crowded I gave up. I'm familiar with crowded museums and tourist sites but this was ridiculously crowded. My wife described it as fish swimming upstream. And that was with a private guide. What a waste of time and money. A traveling companion and bailed and when exploring the neighborhood which was much more fun. Beware!
Highlight of the tour. This Museum is stunning, beyond description, It can get very crowded so try and arrive early in the day,

Just wow!. Spent a whole day visiting the Hermitage yet couldn't see half if it. For buying tickets don't stand in the line; there are machines located in left and right. Some of them don't work properly so try another one to get the ticket. It's much more faster and the machince accept cache too. You don't have to wait in the line outside when you get your ticket this way.There are guides in every room and most can speak simple English so you can't get lost if you ask for directions every 5 min. Use the Hermitag application; it can help clearing your mind of what you want to see and how.

Early entrance a must. There are quite steep steps to get in to the museum so it you can't walk a few you will struggle. On the tour I was on my Mum did the steps slowly but the lady we were with had to be physically lifted in a wheelchair by our driver and a young wheelchair pusher provided by TJ Travel the tour operator.Once in there is a small lift to the 2nd floor but it's not signposted. Its worth the effort as is an amazing museum. But it gets so crowded you need to find a tour offering early entry to get the best from the visit. The exit had a wheelchair lift but ironically they won't let you use it to get in

Overwhelming in every sense. The State Hermitage Museum is overwhelming in every sense of the word. Plan to spend at least two half days, and research what you'd like to see online. For example, if you've seen plenty of ancient Egyptian sarcophagi in London or New York, you may want to save your energy for the Italian Renaissance paintings.First off, the complex is so vast that, although we had tickets we’d purchased online, to use them we had to trudge a kilometer, after walking a couple of kilometers from the Admiralty metro station, to an entrance in the New Hermitage, separate from the main entrance in the Winter Palace. A couple of kind staff members helped us get my husband a wheelchair and take it, via key-operated lift, to a bridge connection the second floors of the two buildings. He disavowed any interest in the ancient Siberian, Caucasian and Central Asian art, which I had read about online and was keen to see. He encouraged me to leave him sitting in a wheelchair tucked next to a crescent of a floor mosaic while I sought out the galleries. I expected to return in 15 or 20 minutes but ended up being gone an hour, partly because I got lost twice, despite having the museum diagram with me. (The floor plan was available in both Russian and English, but not in any other language, although the audioguides came in greater variety.)I finally found the section I was looking for. It was worth the effort. The display cases of artifacts were accompanied by texts in Russian, with briefer versions in English, explaining the excavations of the ancient sites by careful Russian archaeologists. Of special interest were the Sogdians, whose territory now lies in Tajikistan and Uzbekistan. In the Fourth Century BCE they were conquered by Alexander the Great, and some small stone carvings in his image were on display; but they were independent throughout most of history. Until their conversion to Islam, they were Zoroastrians. The Sogdians dominated trade along the Silk Road from the Second Century BCE through the Tenth Century CE. Thanks to the dry climate, many ceremonial and everyday items, murals and even Chinese silks survived to be uncovered in the 20th Century. Images of Sogdian merchants appear in ancient Chinese art; in fact, one word for “merchant” in Chinese is a variant off “Sogdian.” Among the things I appreciated about the ancient Asian galleries was that there were almost devoid of visitors. Only 12 other people were peering at the cases, several of the taking notes. There wasn’t a tour group in sight.One reason why the layout of the Hermitage is confusing is that it was designed as a set of palaces, not as a museum. In fact, the Russians deserve a hand for having accomplished the presentation of both aspects more or less successfully. Imagine merging the Louvre with Versailles!In fact, the painted, carved and gilded décor seemed to be getting short shrift from the crowds of tour groups, about half of them Japanese, intent on seeing the world-famous masterpieces hung on the walls. I somehow managed to pass twice through the Gold Room, Catherine the Great’s elaborate, glittering, imposing main ballroom. Huge urns, some lapis, others malachite, adorned the galleries devoted to Spanish art, including some fine Goyas and Murillos.Pushing a wheelchair through room after room of Italian Renaissance, Dutch and Flemish paintings was like parting a Red Sea of tour groups, all intent on the paintings by Rubens, da Vinci, Rembrandt and the like. The Hermitage paintings are dramatically unequal, probably because Catherine the Great tended to purchase entire collections when they came on the market. To the museum’s credit, the paintings of uncertain authorship are labeled “After Rembrandt,” “Workshop of Rubens” and so on. After three and a half hours, we had seen or at least whipped through everything except the Russian Culture and Decorative Arts portions of the Winter Palace and the Hermitage. Both of us were reeling, from the effort of taking everything in as well as the effort of walking kilometers amid jostling, distracted crowds. My husband, whose sore knee was feeling better, gave me a break by switching places and pushing me in the wheelchair, but we got to the point where we couldn’t even consider tromping over the General Staff Building to see the collection of 19th and 20th Century French art. So many Impressionists, so little energy!

Amazing!. One simply cannot go to St. Petersburg without going to Hermitage. Go with a guide. There is simply way too much to see and they will take you to the highlights. The palace in and of itself is spectacular. Add the art.... You can be there for years enjoying it!

Fantastic. This is a must see for every one. Please take head phones and lots of time. I have no words to describe my admiration of this place. It is vey close to the cruise ship terminal- just 5 minutes by walk.

Holiday. A great experience .go with a guide who can guide you through the place.Very busy. Too many tourists. That says something about the place.Grand n every way .By ones self , one would be confused and lost.

Beautiful architecture, wonderful art collection, but be ready to be patient. The Hermitage is understandably one of the most popular sites in St. Petersburg. It houses an exceptional art collection, but the building itself warrants a visit. The popularity of the site, however, requires patience for a visit can easily result in an over-crowded shufflng through the building.

Go at night and miss the crowds. We visited the Hermitage on a Wednesday night at around 5.30pm - 8.00pm. It was relatively clear of tour groups which was a relief and meant we could really experience the artwork, plus there was zero queuing. I'd also recommend downloading the Hermitage audio tour from itunes - really worthwhile.

too much. Large building, in one room (too) many paintings, what makes you wish to run to next room and hard to go into one work. In many cases paintings exhibited opposite the window, so light reflection makes hard to see the whole painting. Much better was in opposite building, where was impressionists.
Hermitage - great museum but crowded !. You must go - but be prepared for far too many people. A guided tour is a must to help point out key pieces. Use WC before you go in !

Big and very interesting. Really nicely thought museum, probably the best of Russia. If you like the content, it might be the reason for a stay in SPB. You can guess it's one of the most crowded places in SPB. Buy your tickets in advance.
Beautiful and elegant place. Place is luxurious and beautiful. Prepare yourself for a great tour and sightseeing that will take your breath away.

Huge selection of art. To enjoy all of the museum would take days. It's usually crowded, particularly with tour groups, because of its popularity. The art work is arranged in different sections for each style so you can concentrate on the type you wish to see.

Eleven years to see everything...... We were told by our guide that if someone spent one minute looking at every exhibit in The Hermitage, it would take eleven years to see every exhibit. An exaggeration perhaps, but an illustration of the size of this place.Tour groups are taken through a series of the most splendid rooms containing art, sculptures and other exhibits. Some amazing, rare and hugely valuable objects.The problem with all the main sights in St Petersburg is the volume of tourists trying to get access to view the beautifully restored buildings. Queues are long and many rooms in the various palaces cannot be seen to full effect because they are so full of people. The Hermitage is no exception and in the limited time we spent there – an hour and a half out of a two day tour – we had a tiny taste of what was on offer. Our guide was exceptionally knowledgeable about each of the rooms we visited and the items they contained. But with so much here, and so many other places to see in a short visit to this city one cannot do justice to this world-class museum and art gallery.For a decent chance to properly appreciate everything here, it would be necessary to make an independent visit to St Petersburg outside the cruise ship period and allocate much more time to enjoy the amazing exhibits. A guide is needed – if travelling independently and an audio guide is available, it would be a huge advantage to visit at a slower pace. The souvenir shops looked good, with an interesting selection of appropriately local souvenirs – similar shops were at most attractions and also at the cruise ship terminal and prices appeared to be much the same everywhere.

A trip to the history. It's not a museum, it's a place you can spent your time without be tired or boring. I've been there 5-6 times and always I found something new to see.If you been in St.Petersburg of course you'll visit it but try to find alone what you need and stay as long as you want there even if you see less.Even if you get lost it'll be a magnificient experient.

Wow!. Words just cannot accurately describe the magnificence of the Hermitage Museum. Expect long lines and being on your feet for a few hours but any inconvenience quickly fades away once inside. The opulence and the art work are simply stunning. Of all the places we visited in St. Petersburg during our two day stay this was our highlight. Don't miss an opportunity to see this. I'm certain you won't be disappointed.

Overwhelming Gold and Gem Galleries!. This place is unbelievable in it's size and scope of collections. It is simply spectacular. We concentrated on the Gold and Gem Galleries. You must have planned ahead for these visits and an extra fee and entry time are required. BUT, it is worth it. We had our tour company arrange everything and it went perfectly. The use of gems in ceremonial gifts to the Romanovs was extraordinary. You have your own guide who is an expert on the collection. We also had our private guide so translation was not a problem.Definitely a must see.
Great but be fit.. Fabulous place , be prepared to walk walk walk. Steer away from the paintings there is loads more to see and it is less busy.

Over the top!. This was the main reason to visit St Petersburg.... The buildings are as much of the reason to come as the art! The excess of the czarist eras is fully on display in the Hermitage! There is no photograph that impresses these opulent and excessive times that this museum shows..... The art collection is difficult to see when you are on a tour as they choose what rooms are visited...but the art that is included is awesome ....the crowds were large, so it was hard to spend a lot of time at a specific image...but the rooms, structure and architecture of the Hermitage made up for all of that!Not to be missed!

very long waits/queues. Visited on a Saturday which is a very busy day but had a very long wait to get in. Very rushed as they kept moving you on but have to say that you get so close to all the paintings etc. Spoilt by the way you are herded around, not enjoyable.
The Modern Art Collection is arguably the best in the World.. I have never seen so many Picasso, Matisse, Gauguin, Kandisky paintings in one place in my life! Each room is worth billions of dollars!

State Hermitage Museum. This is a large museum typically highly crowded. Recommended to get a guide that will take you through the main shows and provide explanations in your own language.2-3 hours may be enough if you would like to get a general impression,

Winter Palace of Red & Gold. Beautiful palace with amazing Golden Red & White walls and fantastic flooring of the 16th century. It gets too crowded on weekends and there is hardly any space to move, but not to miss. Hire a guide to better understand unless u know Russian.

Rich history. A museum and palace to big to do in a day! But the way the place has been preserved is great. Unbelievable works of art and artefacts!
Closed on Mondays!
oplulence. very, very crowded, but an absolute must-see. the glory of the czars. gold, gold, and more gold everywhere.

As Everyone Says - A Must See - With Guide is Essential. The State Hermitage is a must see museum, however, first timers should go for a guided tour. The gold and glitter is overwhelming with a clear overview of the lifestyle and historic background of the Tsars, etc. Great touristry photo opts and a fascinating indoctrination to the opulence of the elite Russia.

Don't miss huge inpressionist collection. Phenomenal museum overall. Don't miss the extensive impressionist collection of (liberated?) art now in a separate building across the plaza. We were blown away by how large the collection is. The only down side is that they had no English language guide for the impressionist collection when we were there (May 2016).
Wow. Amazing visit absolutely loved spending time here, so much to see. Well worth the trip, lovely area too.

Cruise trip. We recently visited St Petersburg on our cruise. It has got to be one of the most amazing cities I have ever visited. It is absolutely stunning. We did an organised trip through the ship which was amazing. Our tour guide was fantastic and she spoke very good English and she was very knowledgable. We was lucky as we were allowed to go in before the public could so we had a head start on everyone else, by the time the tour had finished it was heaving so go early if you can well worth it.

Beautiful and amazing!. please plan in advance! You need to dedicate a lot of time to visit and cover everything. You can buy the ticket at the Vending machines right at the entrance and save a lot of time (at least I did when we were there in June 2016)

Must See Museum while in St. Petersburg. It is not easy to get there, but it is always full of visitors. We went in as a tour group and wow, it is like the Lourve in Paris, and the paintings at the Vatican. As you go , we followed the commentary of our guide, thru a wireless headset system. The museum was made during the time of Peter the great and his wife Catherine for their daughter. There pictures are very well placed in the museum. The museum has man collections, paintings from the renaissance which are priceless, lots of them religious,sculpture, and artifacts. They have so many sections, from Italy, Greece , Orients, Europe and of course Russia. You should not miss this place.
Mesmerising museum . One of the best museums of the world. Unique master pieces and very well maintained. The best attraction and must visit places in st petersburg

Wonderful Architecture . The first thing that strikes you is the overall scale of the place and the total opulence of the state rooms .Add to that Michael Angelo , Da Vinci , gold here silver there and you have one of the most memorable museums in the world .One bit of advice would be to tour there early . We started at about 10am which was fine to start but by 11.30 the crowds were really building up and it was difficult to spend any time at exhibits .Most memorable place I saw in St Petersburg .

Art Collection. This is the biggest art collection museum that ı have ever seen.If you come to St petersburg ,you should see this museum but not a one day .. Think twice ıf you interest in history and art , you have to spend all day to complete this art museum!

BIG !!. You need to plan your time as to what you think you want to see in the museum BEFORE you go. The wife and I were on a three day visit to St. Petersburg on board the Silver Seas ship . Thought the ship we employed a private guide and driver, the BEST thing we did to see the museum and other sites in St. Petersburg. One of things to see I would suggest is the " Gold Room " ( additional charge ) . Plan to go first thing in the AM , Lots of people ,long lines , and gets Very hot inside no A/C .

Wonderful restoration. The restoration of the building is awe inspiring, but, dare I say, many of the paintings are less that note worthy. We were told that they were virtually bought in bulk to decorate the vast surfaces, and this was a bit obvious. We visited before general opening but could still hardly move for the crowds. Not to be missed though.

Amazing. A must see. Breathtakingly impressive and interesting. Cannot reccomend enough, you need the better part of a day to see everything and experience as much as you can. If you do one thing let it be this.

Highlight of our trip. I have been looking forward to visiting the Hermitage for a long time, it exceeded my expectations! it is worth getting a book about the Hermitage before you go so you can home in on areas that are of the most interest. We travelled with SPB and they managed to get us in earlier and when we left realised what a great bonus it was!

Buy e-tickets in advance. Hermitage is huge, so buying e-tickets in advance is definitely worthwhile, so one can spend more time in the museum. Plus the tickets allow entry on any one of the dates in the coming 30 days, giving visitors the flexibility. There is a special entrance for e-ticket holders, avoiding the queue. Remember to pring the e-tickets out which can be immediately used at the turnstile.For less arty first-timer, suggest to check out the highlights as stated in the Hermitage pamphlet first, as one day is definitely not enough for drilling into each piece of art work.

Awesome. Amazing and spectacular how many works of art are displayed here that are worth taking the time to experience. The impressionist collection is particularly impressive. Definitely not to be missed
So much to see. Wow. What a museum - quite overwhelming in its breadth and quantity. Amazing. Quite a good idea to hire a guide beforehand to get the most out of this world class museum

Chaotic place. Wow man! This one is insanely busy. Groups of Chinese and other tourists roaming the rooms and halls. Both the group and the regular visitors line stretches long around the corner. We bought tickets online (official website) and could skip the whole thing.Inside is art of all sorts. Paintings, statues, weaponry and handycrafts. But the most impressive in my opinion is the interior itself. Huge halls, ballrooms and stairs. All covered in gold, marble and paintings. Yes, this is absolutely a one of a kind palace

Hermitage St Petersbourg russia. Breathtaking,must have a guide to manage this massive place yes its huge but has so much that can not be seen unless you are organized outstanding collection of pieces,paintings and the amazing cokoo clock mast see

ONE OF THE TOP MUSEUMS IN THE WORLD. If you combine the Louvre and the Met in New York you have the Hermitage.
The Winter Palace and the Museum itself is a must if you visit this Russian version
of Paris.
In other words you must go not only to visit the Museum but the city itself.

Undeniable Grandeur. I had no expectations of this museum but very quickly found myself blown away by the grandeur of it.We were there for hours and easily could have spent the same amount of time the same day and still had plenty to see on a return visit. Like the Lourve, this is one you'll want to leave a lot of time for.Make sure you wear comfortable shoes and are good with stairs. We visited in July and it was warm inside, likely due to the amount of people. If you're with a tour group or just your family, it's easy to get separated because you're all picking your jaws up off the ground at different things at different times. I recommend finding the small cafe near the exit. It works well as a designated meeting spot and is before the actual exit so you are free to resume gawking until your feet give out.

Amongst the best museum in the world.. One of the most visited buildings of interest. One of the best place ever visied. The museum could be very busy when cruise ships are in town.We enjoyed the best collection of world renowned artist and paintings and their contribution to arts.
WALL TO WALL HISTORY. The Hermitage was quite amazingGreat architecture and some stunning paintings and statuesOne of the highlights of our Baltic CruiseWell worth the queuing
Busy busy busy . Elected to view only winter palace and state rooms which was a well judged 3 hours. Long enough! Essential to have a guide to get to the front of very long queues.

Give yourself a lot of time. Must see attraction. We took 2 1/2 hrs to see the main building and another hr for the Impressionists. The collections aren't as impressive as some other museums but its the number of them that overwhelms-master after master in just about every major art period. And some unique exhibits that will blow you away

Rooms are Unbelievably Huge. The depth of wealth is shown with the massive spending that occurred with the building and furnishing of the Hermitage. Most rooms are excessively ordained with gold and wood inlay floors and the furniture is amazing. The only real negative is the massive number of visitors take away from the beauty. Get a time certain ticket in advance to avoid the lines.

Not to be missed. A museum of art. You could spend days in this venue. A short tour only skims the surface but allows the visitor to admire the building and be guided to some of the more important paintings. Should be included in your itinerary for SPB.
Grandness like you've never seen before. So you've seen Versailles? Ha, this place makes it look like a dump... What a palace, this was some more place. Take pictures, folks won't believe you.

Unbelievably opulent. The richness and ornamental beauty of this building exceeds all expectations. tje gold and diamond collections are certainly worth paying to see especially if you have a curator talking about the collections.

Only With A Private Tour. Beautiful and worth many pictures. But the lines are VERY long to get in during spring/summer and the crowds are huge. Forget the guidebook for hints. Forget e-tickets with a LONG line to exchange for real tickets. Forget maybe-working ticket machines. Splurge on a private tour. It will save you many long lines and even help find a WC. If a private tour is not in your budget, then save for another year. It will make a huge difference in your sightseeing experience.We used Kremlin Tour. Bad name. They do much more than the Kremlin. Excellent experience. They somehow got us in quickly and moved us through a very crowded place. Excellent English-speaking guide with a good knowledge of the place. (We are experienced travellers and do our homework. This is simply not a place to tackle on your own unless you really like long lines.)

Marvellous architecture . This is the finest architecture I have ever seen in my life the work done by the additions is marvellous the colours the beauty everything is admirableMust watch for everyoneI could not understand the long queues outside to to buy the entry tickets while there was already ATMs installed to buy To take your camera charger as you're going to take a lot many images

Vast Museum. The museum is contained in 5 buildings of which the most famous is the Winter Palace that was the imperial residence. Also in the complex is the Hermitage Theater, the Small Hermitage, Large Hermitage and New Hermitage. The Hermitage contains 15,000 paintings, 12,000 sculptures and 600,000 works of graphic art. Be sure and visit the top floor which houses pictures by Renoir, Monet, Cezanne, Van Gogh, Gauguin, Matisse and Picasso as well as a sculpture by Rodin. If you do not have weeks to explore this vast museum it is a good idea to hire a guide who can navigate and get you to the most important pieces of art.

Hermitage Museum. The State Hermitage Museum is a museum of art and culture in Saint Petersburg, Russia. One of the largest and oldest museums in the world, it was founded in 1764 by Catherine the Great and has been open to the public since 1852

Essential. A visit here is essential, cruise passengers however don't have a chance to more than scrape the surface. It is sad to see tour parties being herded through the most awe inspiring rooms, past Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo etc. However if you can't spend longer it is worth visiting even for an hour.

One of the main museums in the world. Stunning collection of world art, one of the largest museums on the planet. The Hermitage has everything from Egyptian mummies to Russian Avant-garde paintings. The best way to explore it for the first time is to get a guide so that you don't miss the main masterpieces and don't get overwhelmed with the sheer scale of the place. Do pay attention to the interiors of the museum - it's a beatific palace, even doors are stunning. I'd suggest to go there at the beginning of your trip so that you are over and done with it

Amazing Museum, and Exhibit 1 for why the czars were overthrown. A full day, and barely scratched the surface. The palace is the most ornate, over the top collection of romp"stuff" ever. The Romanov's would have needed a GPS to navigate their quarters.

This is what you came to see !. The Hermitage links to The Winter Palace and New Winter Palace. Be prepared for queues as most tourists only arrive May to October courtesy of the cruise ships. Do not take large coats or bags with you as you can not take them in and they have to be left at a cloakroom. This cuts down on your time if you're on a 2 day tour.

Spectacular!. What an amazing museum (actually museums!). Incredible collections. It could take months to do the Hermitage justice, but don't miss it! But go with a group otherwise it is just impossible to get in....unless you go in winter (so they say!).

Private early tour is SO worth it.. We visited with an SPB tour guide during our cruise port stop and they arranged an early entry time for us. So, we got to see this amazing place without fighting for room to breath and having to elbow our way through. SO WORTH IT. They also just showed us the best things worth seeing in 2 hours, as my kids (and husband) were just done by then anyway. Don't miss the PEACOCK CLOCK. It is breathtaking.
Another Must see. Another must see attraction in St Petersburg with its intricate designs from floor to ceiling. Every room has been tastefully decorated in its era and is certainly one of its kind.

Don't miss. During our visit we took in the Hermitage museum and in the main complex the Winter Palace and West European Fine Arts collections – Old Masters. We had a private guide so no waiting in line. Stunning display of art and sculpture.

Large and extensive museum.. It is very big, and sometimes a bit confusing, but the interior of the palace is just amazing, and there are many interesting things to see. Allow a few hours, sit down a lot, and enjoy. It is best to buy your ticket at the automated machine as the queues to get in can be very long.
Beautiful but busy. A must see place whilst visiting St Petersburg. Many tour groups, so extremely busy, but full of incredible treasures,especially the gold room.

One of the World's Greatest Museums. Like other world class museums, there is more here to see than can be consumed in one day. Plan your time carefully - under commit and over enjoy rather than the reverse.It seemed to me that every school of painting is well represented, but they do not have many really important or landmark pieces. However, there is a whole room dedicated to Rembrandt.

Classical Art Overload . Incredible collection of classic works of art. After a couple hours you will never want to see a painting again, however it's well worth the visit. Beautiful building, with quite a history. Get your tickets in advance, otherwise you will want to get there very early (about an hour before they open) or you will be standing around for quite some time.

Must See!!!. This is definitely the #1 place to see in St. Petersburg. The history and artifacts preserved in the palace are truly spectacular! There are many options to see the museum/palace with a tour guide but my fiance & I prefer to go at our own pace. We usually breeze through at a decent rate, stopping for pictures and reading descriptions of certain items, and we spent roughly 3 hours here. So be sure to allow yourself plenty of time because you could easily spend the whole day here!
Amazing place. Spent all day in various parts of this amazing palace. Took the Russian language tour of the main areas, and also the gold and diamond collections. The Amber room is not to be missed.

Opulence of a bygone era. A must visit when in St Petersburg. We were taken to various exhibits with interesting narratives.The crowds are quite overwhelming.You really cannot linger too long at each site.At the end of the tour you are exhausted.Cafes are no help as queues are long.you are not allowed to take large backpack, small bag is ok.Otherwise cloakroom is available to store your belongings. Comfort stop is stairs down to basement. No lifts so be aware! Comfy shoes are necessary.

Amazing place . Wow. It is really amazing place to visit but you need more than one day to cover everything and get to understand history.
