It was very tiring to try and cover the Hermitage in less that half a day. But I would diffinately recommend travellers to visit the place. It is really worth it

Impressive. Visited the Hermitage as part of an SPB tour so we got in before opening time. Early on we moved with ease, but after opening time, it got much more crowded. The buildings themselves are awesome without even looking at the art, but the art was impressive too. This is not to be missed.

Evening tour. We were able to attend an evening guided tour through the palace and it was amazing! Highly recommend it. At the end, we were given glasses of champagne as we watched a symphony play. It was beyond spectacular and something I will never forget. We went back the next day with the rest of the family. Loved seeing so many pieces of art in one area.
Treasures to be seen in detail. Take the time to see this treasure trove on your own time - and not just whiz through a tiny selection of holdings as part of a guided tour.

To avoid the crowds. We went the to the museum late Friday around 4:00PM. It was open until 9:00PM. There was no line up for tickets at the machines in the court yard and we found many of the tour groups were leaving around 5:00PM. The atmosphere was much better after the groups left and your are left to enjoy both the palace and the works of art.We went to the administration offices when they first opened in the morning and the line up was quite small. The number of people was quite manageable. Most people went straight for the impressionists.

Very nice and big museum, real value for money. We didn't take a guided tour of the hermitage, but decided to visit it on our own. It is a real must see in St Petersburg and you can walk in there for a couple of hours or a whole day.

Amazingly beautiful. It is impossibly th put into words the beauty of this palace. The entrance stairway, the assembly rooms, ballrooms, the malachite room, there is so much, it is breathtakingly beautiful and exquisite. I thought the prince bishop's palace in Wurzburg and the Lichtenstein palace in Vienna were the best but they have slipped down the ladder now. Shame about the thousands of others that wanted to see it at the same time as I did and it would have been nice if many of them had had better manners.
Fantastic. Make sure u go across the street to see the impressionist section. Tickets may be hard to find on weekends. If u have trouble hire a guided tour they will get u in

Amazing collection with some surprises. This has been rated as one of the must see places in St Petersburg and it definitely lives up to expectations - as well as the exhibitions of paintings, and furnishings, the artifacts from 3000 years ago were really quite mind blowing - to see perfectly maintained exhibits was an unexpected bonus.

Winter Palace extended. The entry to the Hermitage says it all. The massive structure with the detailing that is exquisite matches any palace I have seen including the palace of Versailles. even though somewhat understated in appearance compared to Versailles, it was impressive in character and the contents. I had no idea that many Rembrandts could be in one place. It would take weeks to really take in all it had to offer. Unfortunately, I did not have that but had a guided tour that showed us the high lights. I imagine the reason to go to St. Petersburg would be to see this.

Amazing museum, but so crowded. Go directly to the Diamond Room.. This is a place to see in winter, not summer. The crowds were overwhelming, and there were busloads of people streaming in and through the building.

Something you have to see at least once in your life!. Wonderful collection of masterpieces, amazing exhibition of different times and different artists. Very huge collection, be ready to spend at least couple of days in order to see just the most famous staff.

Amazing art and treasures!. Amazing collection of art. Half a day may be not enough to explore it. Nice shops inside. Dont miss the golden peacock clock. Get the internet tickets from the official site of Hermitage and pass the line!!!

Be prepared to be amazed and overwhelmed . My friends and I spent about 3 hours wandering around the palace. It was so incredible.. And just when you think there cant be any more impressive rooms left in the palace to see.. You find another. They have many displays to see. It's a good idea to figure out what interests you and start your tour at that end of the palace. My friends and I were quite tired after the tour. Costs 600 rubles to get in. They do have audio tours.

Enough for Days. Like every major attraction in St Petersburg, the crowds are horrendous, maybe because good touring weather is in such short supply. But is it worth it? My God YES! You could spend days in here and still notvseevitball properly. Indescribable treasures.

At least three days to appreciate it's grandure. the hermitage is one the world's greatest museums. From the start you get impressed by the grand staircase that leads you to the first galleries. The building it's an attraction in it self, let alone the millions of art pieces that surround you. If you can try to give it a two day visit to appreciate its grandure

Main reason to visit St. Petersburg. The museum itself is a wonderfull palace, prepare yourself before going there and think of the pieces you don't want to miss, as the place is really big and you might wander around without seeing what you wanted, you'll be surounded with treasures and the best art the world has to offer.

Top top attraction, world class. Having lived in Chicago and recently seeing the Art Institute and Hermitage duke it out for top honors we were intrigued to visit. Breathtaking. That's all I can say. Amazing, wonderful, interesting, beautiful. Rare. MUST SEE.
Hermitage . A beautiful collection of art, particularly of the masters. Make sure you see the beautiful golden peacock clock!

The Hermitage - Icon and Jewel of Saint Petersburg. I have waited a long time to visit this famous palatial museum. The collections are vast and varied, ranging from Scythian Gold to Renaissance masters. I was worried at first that the Hermitage would not live up to all of my expectations, but in fact, it delivered even more than I thought possible. I recommend purchasing internet tickets, in order to beat the crowds and make sure you set aside at least a full day, or two half days. I think that the Hermitage alone would be reason enough for me to come back to this amazing city.
Nice Museum . You will need a few days to cover all the exhibits. There is lots to see and many stairs to climb. Would recommend hiring a local guide to the explain the exhibits.

Truly amongst the top 10. This probably vies with the Louvre as the most impressive museum/gallery in the world and probably beats it with the interior decoration, if not the actual exhibits. Best not stray from the centre of St Petersburg as the outskirts are full of dreadful communist built buildings, but the centre of town is truly magical with many sights worth seeing.

St.petersburg. Hey all . Must visit the place it's worth seeing this place . Nothing can beat this . The heritage . It takes almost 2 hr to see the whole palace . Tickets 600 rubal for express or 400 rubal if u can wait in line for 1 hr minimum . U can buy express tickets with your credit card at kiosk machines . Do visit this place with your children and experience the old culture , their clothes furniture , jewellery etc . Plz download the app for this place and wifi is freeThanks

A MUST See. This is a magical wonder. I highly recommend purchasing tickets ahead of time (300 rubles per person) to avoid long queues. The entire area is beautiful and the museum itself is full of treasures. There were many people there, but once you are inside, the crowds dispersed quickly. It's a big place!

Beautiful rooms, beautiful art but too crowded. It is a must-see of course, but realize that there may be as many as 60.000 visitors per day! It also a very long walk if you want to visit all four buildings of the complex. It would be helpful if not so many visitors would be allawed to get in at the same time.

Full of history... The hermitage or Winter palace is one of the crowded lace in St Petersburg. this site is filled with history, painting... you got dizzy from watching the ceilings in every room and hall... they have a place similar to chapel sisteen entrance... lots of portraits for virgin Mary...a hall for the genrals and militaries who participated in the napoleonic era... i couldn't stay more than 2 hours... but for those who like the Russian -catherine era it's the right place for them :)
Hermitage. It's a beautiful building our Gide told us eternal is 1500 Rubal Actually it's only 600 Rubels and it's easily available the kids go free below 12 years.

A Must See in St Petersburg. Plan ahead. Don't miss the Hermitage. Get tickets online in advance for this amazing museum. Tip! Use the official Hermitage website in Russian to get the best price. The English version charges twice as much!

A Top Highlight. The Hermitage was once a palace, but is now a massive art museum. They have two Leonardo da Vinci's, and tons of Great Masters on their collections. The place is mobbed in the summer, but sill worth the visit, provided you can even get in.

The building itself is one of the best works of art. The Hermitage deserves its place as one of the top museums in the world. But while the art is fantastic, the building itself - known as the winter palace - is a work of art itself.We only had one day in St. Petersburg so we were on a fast pace to see everything we could see. But clearly the Hermitage is one of the things you need to see when you are in St. Petersburg. Similar to the Smithsonian or Louvre, you could spend weeks here, but even if you only have a few hours it is worth the price of admission.

best paintings. paintings by Matisse, Chagall, Da Vinchi, Rubens Picasso, Van Gogh, not anywhere else seen, And so many others in a beautifull setting with special floors and ceilings, with a private guide.

Bigger and Better than I thought.. Every thing you could have imagined and more! Just a wonderful visit experience - You must go!
It was so very busy, but we stuck at it, we were on a guided tour, worth every penny! Give yourself a full day you would miss so much if your tried to do it in a couple of hours

The Hermitage in the Evening. On a Baltic Cruise my husband and I took a shore excursion to the Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace. It was just amazing! The art was incredible but so was the building itself. It is a work of art, too. Since we went on a Monday night the museum was closed to the public. Only a few people were there and we were taken by a guide to see several rooms. From what I saw the following day with lines stretching out the door and down the block, apparently going in the evening is the best way to do this museum.

one of the best art collections in the world. we booked a 2 day ticket and still didn't see everything! the paintings in the Hermitage collection are extraordinary. Hard to choose favourites, but include excellent works by Rembrandt Raphael, Da Vinci, Picasso, Matisse, Cezanne, Gaugin, Renoir and many others. The museum is very crowded and full of large tours with guides. We were on our own, and used an audio guide which was helpful as well as floor plan. It can be confusing to find what you are looking for, but not impossible. Getting lunch in the cafe was a challenge and not very good. Perhaps it is possible to go out and come back in again, but you may need to queue again! Well worth buying tickets online in advance.

Must see but in off season . Plan your visit. Try and get tickets with designated time in advance. Else the queues to get in during the summer tourist season are awful, specially if cruise ship groups are present. Even then, the crowds inside can get intense and excessive, impacting the ability to enjoy the sumptuous interiors and art work. Sunday and Tuesday are particularly bad since Mondays are closed. A good reason to visit in the off season.

Vast and Elaborate Museum. It will take several days to see all there is to see. Research what interests you and start with that. Also the museum can be difficult to navigate in particular getting across the ground floor which requires going upstairs to come back down. Wear comfy shoes. No back packs or coats allowed and the cloakrooms are free-for all Russian chaos. Most important-Book on line before you go. The difference between a 1 day and 2 day ticket is only $5, get the 2 day.

Great But Crowded. Unrivaled collection, but hoards of aggressive groups smothering the main attractions. Go to their new branch across Palace Sq. in the General Staff building for their amazing collection of impressionists and post-impressionists, and almost no crowds at all. The furnished rooms on the lower floors, and the French academic paintings of the 19th century, are also worth visiting in this beautifully adapted building.
Impressive!. The place, the oeuvres, the atmosphere. Amazing place not only for art lover. We spent there 4 hours and it was not enough ;)

Private tour worth every penny. Group of four, Elena the guide was excellent, with out her knowledge and interpseronal skills the museum would had been an exhausting trudge round. Once we had out private tours, with very few others around we were able to revisit the collections until closing time.

Beautiful interiors and art treasures. Of course we had to visit the Hermitage. Our tour guide Margarita (Ulko Tours) was able to guide us thru the lines and crowds and share with us the highlights -- there's enough here to see that one could spend weeks, but we had just one day .

Prepare before going to the Hermitage..... The Hermitage and Winter Place are an eye full. I will focus on the Hermitage.The collection of art is so vast I recommend you google the Hermitage, reviewthe collections, see what is showing and then find the rooms/collections youmost want to see within the Hermitage...... else you will be wandering. Wandering is still great but why go so far and miss what you most want to see? We bought tickets to see the gold room collection....small treasures and jewels. SKIP this. Waste of time and money. You cannot go through this fast they take forever and it is expensive.Stick with the main art collections.

If you like ornate gaudy!. I fund this museum severely over-hyped. Though there are a great many exhibits they were largely not to my tastes. I am unexcited about an entire hall devoted to portraits of Napoleonic era generals. There were several rooms devoted to the classical masters but that was but a small part of the collection. The real negative was the crowd. Many rooms were packed making movement difficult. We waited 20 min in line to enter and often had to wait in a line to view a popular exhibit.
Interesting.. Visited hermitage very nice place but as with most russian places nothing is written in english...you need to rent then it is difficult to navigate...

Very busy. Get internet tickets or special tickets as the line up is ridiculous.Have a plan and don't try to see every room, we saw atleast 30 rooms in 2 hours.It just amazing.Views are lovely too.The second floor is probably more Russian.

So Much to See - but so crowded!. This was a wonderful museum. Unfortunately we experienced it at a very crowded time which made it seem a bit stressful. Some areas were not exceptionally crowded, but the art work had just too many people in the space.

So much and more...... This is an immense museum/palace filled with unbelievable treasures and masterpieces. Tons of tourists, many of whom are quite pushy, come through this place daily. We were very glad to be with a tour as we were lead to the most important treasures. We were convinced that had we gone on our own we would have missed opportunities to see and understand much about the masterpieces housed here.

A few hours is never enough. We visited the Hermitage as part of a 2 day guided tour with TJ Tours. It was a packed itinerary so we only had a few hours but our guide showed as many highlights as possible in the time. If you're planning a visit then do a little research into the things you like and make a plan. We were ahead of the queues as we'd booked a private tour. If this is an option for you it is highly recommended.

One Of The Best Museums In The World.. The Ancient Greek,Siberian and Greek Antiquities are the best I have seen so far in my life.The Art Of Arms And Armours of the 15th to 19th Centuries are the best collection in the world.

No Piter-visit without Hermitage. This museum is a definite must-see in life. Take your time and comfortable shoes. You will find exhibitions and artefacts of antique, the renessaince, medieval age, the great masters of europe's 16-18th century. Seeing all is enough for a whole week. To make it in one day, you should think about the right strategy. If you are generally interested, you should pick your highlights (recommended in travel guides or even the maps on the info desk), spend some time with them and hop to the next. Don't forget to plan some time for the modern exhibition in the separate staff building complex opposite of the palais. It's definitely worth it. If you are especially interested in some era or old masters of a country / region you can spend hours in this resepective section. we enjoyed the building, the rich collections, the highlights and masterpieces but also very much the modern and impressionistic art in the separate building. Please don't leave the city without paying a visit to Hermitage.

Not to be missed top attraction in St Petersburg . Wife & I went on this fantastic group tour from our cruise ship. We were lucky to be first group allowed in at 10.10am with long queues building up behind. From the first wide staircase everything was intensely grand with elements of Renaissance, classical & moorish styles. Over 3 hrs we moved from room to room in the five buildings in awe of the decor & majesty. Also top paintings by de Vinci & Rembrandt. Highly recommended...not to be missed experience.

Great place of you like museums . I'm not an at lover, but I've been places. Hermitage is huge and quite interesting whether you're into paintings, interiors, sculpture or a little bit of everything as it has a lot of everything. It spans several buildings and takes a better part of a day to enjoy. Mind that if you buy tickets online you'll skip the line but pay double price. All in all a worthy experience even if I think I enjoyed Louvre a little more.
Overwhelming!. Holy cow - this place is huge!So much to see - but very crowded and hard to navigate.Nonetheless you cannot miss this one.

The most amazing museum in the world . It is impossible to describe the Hermitage! My advise is to go and visit it. I suggest to buy the ticket in advance and to rent an audio guide. It is also important to prioritize what you want to see, otherwise be prepare to spend there one week or more!

Book online to avoid ticket queue.. After booking online we still had to wait 30 minutes to process through the ticket scanner. The ground floor was absolutely packed. The highlight of the visit was the Imperial State Rooms.
Overwhelming. This place could take a whole day to go through. But the history and decadence is amazing. The artwork alone is extensive.

More and more gold!!. I must say that I couldn't finish the State Hermitage within 1 day, so I keep the rest for my next visit. The museum is huge and gorgeous. Lots of things to see with over 1,000+ rooms to explore. I love every minutes there! A must!!!

Make sure you go to the diamond section as well. You need to give yourself the entire day and be prepared for crowds. The amount of art work is huge and it just goes on and on and on. Pre plan what section you want to see as it is spread across a number of buildings

Spectacular!. What can be said about an amazing place such as this? It is quite unforgettable! We prebooked a tour through Trip Advisor for which we were very grateful as we skipped the extremely long queue and gained early entry before the huge crowds. We were a group of only four and we had an extremely knowledgeable guide, Olga. I strongly recommend a visit this way.

A lifetime's expectation fulfilled. Just incomparable. We had the benefit of a very knowledgeable private guide - I don't know how we would have managed with just two days visit otherwise. Gold and Diamond rooms well worth seeing - separate tickets as well as General Staff exhibits across the square. Latter much less crowded. Fabulous collection of impressionist and post-impressionists paintings.

Wow wow wow. I want at least 3 days to explore here. So many rooms full of arts and artifacts. We skipped almost half of the museum as we have only few hours there. To check all the art works, of course, I need 3-5 days!

The hugest and most splendid museum I have seen. If you are an art connaisseur, this would be one of the hugest challenges for you - there are defintely not enough hours in a day to see properly even the most important part of the musem's second floor where are all the paintings, sculptures and furniture of the Russian tsars' legacy are shown. They are also surrounded by a gilded, carved, painted, sculptured interior which is a piece of art in itself.Apart from that there are the first floor where Ancient Rome, Greece and even Egypt await you and the third floor where you can see remnants of long forgotten Middle Eastern and Central Asian civilizations.

Ranks at the top of world-class museums. Magnificent palace ... Extraordinary collection of works of art in an opulent setting. Everything I want to say about the Hermitage has been said by many others. I highly recommend a visit with a tour guide to get the most of your visit.

Impressive but very crowded. Great place to view western art and rebuilt Russian architecture. Amazing how they restored the Hermitage and the Palaces in the last 30 years. Crowds of tour groups can be overwhelming - lots of pushy people!

Stunning.. We did a 2 day tour of St Petersberg with TJ Travel. The best 2 days of our Baltic cruise. We had early entry with this travel group and well worth it. Very busy place but we were in and out before the crowds. Well worth the visit to see how life was in days gone by. We were blessed with an incredible tour guide whose knowledge of Russian history was very impressive.
AWSOME BEYOND BELIEVE!!!!!. If you want to know why the royals were obliterated, go and see the luxury they lived with. It is a must as it is breathtaking.

Stunning amazing place. Went on a tour with our cruise ship. The hermitage is huge and very beautiful and spectacular. Our guide was excellent and we saw the most famous pieces however if I was on my own I would not know where to start as there is so much to see. Even if you are not very into art or don't know very much you can't help but marvel at the decor and stunning chandeliers.
Amazing. Stunning array. A must see. A good first stop in St Petersburg to get the feel of the history of the city and the life of the Tsars. An amazing building which gives an idea of the grandeur.

Immense building, and a wonderful experience.. We had an evening tour with a musical section. We had heard the tour numbers n the day were very large and rushed and we hoped that by paying extra to visit 'after hours' would be beneficial. We were still We through the rooms fairly quickly but we could at least enjoy the paintings and the grandeur of the palace without the space being completely full of people. We had a guide who spoke very clear English. We obviously only saw a very small section of the Hermitage and had no control over which rooms we were directed through, (Its very possible that other evening groups were being shown around another part of the museum as it is sooo vast). Towards the end of our tour we were shown into a beautiful salon and we had a private concert by the St Petersburg state Orchestra. So much more than anything I had anticipated. I thoroughly enjoyed this part of the program. After being shown through the Egyptian artefacts towards the exit we were offered a glass of champagne or orange juice..

Amaazing. To visit the Hermitage was amazing. I recommend to take a 4 hours tour of the museum and after to stay and walk around at your own pace. It is so big that one day is not enough to cover the museum. For art lovers definitely visit for at least 2 days.

Visit the hermitage-practical info. A lot was already said, so just few practical info:1-Reserve tickets on Internet - there is a separate entrance and NO QUEUE at all!The other side was packed .2-take a guide-the museum is huge and if you want yo enjoy and understand take Shunde that will guide you through the maze3-go early - it's getting packed fast!4- there is an incredible collection at Thebes Hermitage.people tend to ignore. Go there to floor 4 straight and see the collection of Sergei Shchukin & Ivan Morozov who fled Russia after the revolution and left this collection behind!When you buy tickets online make sure they include the new Hermitage
Talkin Bout Big!. Went with private guide. Art and objects are great; but, finish of rooms /interior is spectacular! Three hours is more than enough time for most people.

Get there early. The opulence & luxury of the Romanovs are embodied in the Hermitage , the grand staircases , chandeliers , gilded furniture & an incredible collection of art , you could spend a couple of days here. The impressionists & modern works have been transferred to the General Staff Building . There are crowds of people , lots of pushing & shoving but its worthwhile to visit.

Spectacular . We loved this museum. It is very grand and many historic and priceless pictures and artifacts. What more can be said that has not already been told. The Winter Palace is spectacular. The crowds were difficult at times to negotiate. My wife and I self toured The Hermitage and the crowds made it difficult & confusing at times. Cafe was very average on both food & service with one person serving at lunch time. Took over an 30 mins to get our food.Despite some shortcomings very worthwhile visiting

Too impressive. One of the biggest challenges with a museum on such a grand scale is that it is literally impossible to actually see all of it. The number of pieces on display would take far too long for any visitor, but there are sufficient gems to keep any interest occupied. We found this the perfect rainy day spot in the city and easily enjoyed the entire day inside. That is coming from someone that is not even a major art buff.

Impressive building filled with worldwide treasures. I was here as part of a Baltic cruise. If you go to St. petersburg then you need to visit the Hermitage. I went to the Roman and Egyptian department and to see the paintings by the old Dutch masters. The hermitage has more Rembrandt paintings than the Rijksmuseum in Amstrdam! I did not give 5 stars because some paintings are very difficult to see due to the bad light. The Hermitage was not designed to be a museum but as a palace. The light can be extremely bad!

Magnificent!. This is a must if you are in St. Petersburg. It's good to arrive early. This is a lovely museum where Russian history and world art are equally on display. Like other large museums, you can't expect to see it all in a few hours or days, but even a shorter visit will give you a little taste. Not to be missed is the Peacock Clock!

Wow . We have been to the winter palace for the first time and could only spent two hours. I can describe it with only one word: wow. Amazing interior design, each room being a masterpiece by its own. An abundant number of paintings, drawings, statues, artifacts. I mean most museums an survive with 5% of the collection. We have been to only the winter palace, one floor, and possibly go through some part of it in a quite speedy mode and took two hours. I think one can really spend days here.

Reserve an entire day. A magnificent collection of art in the most splendid surroundings.Take your time and enjoy the atmosphere of history in the Winter Palace and modern architecture in the new Hermitage.

Beautiful Palace. This beautiful palace doesn't disappoint. The amazing peacock clock is not to be missed, and the works of art are stunning. Even the floors are amazing. Security is tight, and bags are scanned, and any bottles of water being carried will be confiscated, as they have had acid attacks on paintings and don't take any risks with bottles of liquid.

Glorious. As we were leaving someone in the long queue for entry asked my friend whether it was worth waiting. That's a pretty funny question really because the Hermitage is one of the world's great museums. A combination of palace, museum and art gallery, its collection is unsurpassed. There are so many extraordinary exhibits in this complex that you should allow at least 2 days to take it all in. And keep in mind as you are walking around taking in the sheer beauty of the place that Hitler wished to raze St Petersburg to the ground.

Don't miss the impressioists. The collection of Catherine the Great is extensive and although predictable is accentuated by the beauty of the palace. Don't neglect the separate collection of impressionist paintings largely neglected in the West. Dozens of beautiful paintings by the impressionist masters that I have never even heard of before.

Amazing place, an assault on the eyes!. Went to the Hermitage on a rainy Sunday in June and was very glad to have booked internet tickets (the queue for the ticket office was at opening already very very long.. The entrance for internet booked tickets is on the side of the museum and entry was relatively easy. You enter the museum through the amazing staircase and then there is just endless, truly endless, amounts of (old world) art of the very highest quality. If you are ever in St Petersburg, this place is a must-visit.
Marvelous place!. The place is stunning inside. You must visit there. Plan before visit because there is so much to see inside.Use guide for detailed explanation.

One of the top buildings and art collections in the world, all rolled into one!. The Winter Palace and connected buildings are absolutely spectacular -- what an impression this must have created for first-time and regular visitors alike! The scale, the gilding and decoration, the furnishings, and all aspects combine to create the feeling. Certainly make sure to see the grand entrance hall, the small and large throne rooms, and the ballroom, but there are also many other places to enjoy. I particularly recommend the gaudy great church of the Winter Palace and the dark, carving-decorated, almost brooding study of the last Czar, Nikolas II.The art collections are phenomenal, with something for so many different interests. In the Western European painting, I found the Rembrandts and the two da Vincis to be terrific, even if they were justifiably mobbed. We took a private tour of the Treasury Room, which I highly recommend, and marveled at many things, particularly the Scythian metalwork from more than 2,500 years ago. Also, Oriental carpets are a particular interest of mine, and the Pazyryk carpet is the oldest surviving pile carpet -- a stunning work -- with the felts from the Pazyryk tomb being amazing as well. And you'll have much less of a crowd in this area of the museum.I have to also put in compliments for the Hermitage food service. The items we had were very good, and not terribly overpriced as sometimes happens with a captive audience. The food lines moved along reasonably, and we didn't have too much trouble getting a seat, either.
Expected more. There was so much tourists that it was quite an adventure to see anything. It was very hot and muggy. Expected to see also Russian art but everything was at Russian museum.

Free on Thursday. Its free on Thursday! If you can't visit on a Thursday, buy ticket online from their Russian website(not the English version), its almost double of the price on the Russian page.I m glad to see Da Vinci and Raphael 's paintings. The audio guide is informative, almost too lengthy to listen to.

An Emperor's Palace!. Beautiful museum that is one of the oldest in the world. It was founded by Catherine the Great, open in 1850, There are 6 buildings making it the largest museum in the world. It has the largest collection of paintings in the world and contains over 3 million items, We did the Gold Room tour too, which was beautiful, but after a bit, it was too much. We thought we would get an English tour since we booked our tickets well in advance, but no... We had a Russian lady explain each piece, then the translator,,, and secretly I think the First Lady knew what the translator was saying, because she waited till she said every word, even if she tried to shorten it. Many in our group grew impatient. The rest of the museum was awesome, you could do it at your own speed. You could spend weeks here but we only had 1 day.

Poor climate and crowd controls. The collections are overwhelming. The structures historically significant and beautiful. However, while we were here in late May, it was horribly hot, stuffy and very sweat inducing. The crowds were very large and our guide had a difficult challenge getting us through. I felt that the irreplaceable contents were at hazard due to the exhibits' exposure to the hordes of people using flash for photos (not allowed per signage, but not well enforced by anyone) and the poor climate controls.

Breathtaking . There were so many beautiful collections,from ancient Siberian artifacts to early central Russian pottery and jewelry toancient Egyptian and Roman statuary.And the paintings were beautiful and extensive. There wasn't enough time to see it all.
Gild overload. A must-see. Each room is more ornate than the last. While this is an amazing museum, it was extraordinarily crowded.

Always go here!. This is a glorious place, comparable to the Louvre in Paris. I don't believe you can see the whole museum in one day. I just walk around gasping at all the beautiful creations of man. We took our Italian sister in law and she kept saying, "Yes, this man was an Italian." There is so much art here to enjoy. I go everytime I am in St. Pete's.

One of the best museum I visited so far. We did not have enough time to visit every rooms but we had an amazing time. Full of history, the building itself is impressive.A must go when you are in St Petersburg.

Great historical treasure!. We had read about this museum before visiting Russia, and were keen to visit the same, however when we actually visited this world Famous collection, we were really astonished to see the magnificence of this treasure and great Russian historical context behind this collection.

Really nice. Amazing architecture and interiors! The entrance is free the first Thursday of every month - however you need to queue up and get your free ticket at the ticket booth - I suggest you to get an audio guide for 500 rubles the languages option it's quite limited though this happen in most of the attractions in Russia - something that they really have to develope.
Beautiful Place. A must see for all people. The sheer size of the palace is breathtaking and the contents even more so

Favourite museum. I think this must be the one museum that I love the most. It habours an enourmous collection of art and history and has a rich history of its own. Even without the artwork you would spend a lot of time here gazing at the intricate detailing of the interiors. When you buy a full ticket (500 roebel) you also get acces to the central building with its collection of impressionists. I would advise to come here as early as possible as you tend to get big groups of excursions in the afternoon and it gets very crowded.
impressive. impressive so different fro anything I have ever seen in my life. an absolute must see. would go back again when i have the chance.

Amazing collection in one place. We saw the Hermitage and were blown away by the sheer size of the collection of art, paintings and the rich history it holds. 4000 rooms are open for public viewing and I later learnt that they hold only 10% of the stuff that is in their possession. A fascinating experience.

Vast And Overwhelming. In five buildings, joined together, this is a vast treasure trove. In summer, it is very, very crowded indeed and trying to see the artworks is not a pleasure. Go early or late to avoid the massive crowds of Oriental visitors' tour groups.We were lucky in having a guide who concentrated on showing is around the less-crowded outer rooms, which are very elaborate and a must-see. That alone - without looking at the art - took 3 hours.The gift shops are excellent and there are snacks available on the ground floor. Unfortunately, if you leave the building to go into the courtyard (it was a beautiful day when we were there) your ticket is cancelled. It's strictly single-entry.
Huge and unbelievable museum!. Amazing collection of art! Wear your walking shoes because this is one of the largest museums in the world.

Beautiful from all angles out and treasures within.. We visited over 3 days as wanted to see as much as possible = first Thursday of the month was free so that really helped. Even on the free day the Impressionist area was reasonably quiet.

Very impressive!. Small hint in the beginning; buy yor ticket at automatic cashier and you save long cure to the normal cashier!!! Huge museum with a lot of very rare exponats. It belongs to “must see“ if you are in St.Petersburg.
Calculate at least 4 hours or longer!

Very crowded place - beautiful but a tight squeeze. We had a group of about 30 for a couple hours of touring this magnificent museum. So much artwork. So many rooms. So many people. This was summer, so the huge number of tourists was not surprising. We did manage to lose one person, but he was smart and found our bus so all was good in the end.There is so much artwork here it is hard to know where to begin. I guess if I had to plan this all over again, I might have spent more time doing a little research on the place. We were on a cruise and this was a day trip. I found out later that there was another tour that was a special tour for cruise guests only that took place later in the evening with no tourists as it was closed to the general public. But that tour did not have the Golden Room included, so even though we fought for space with everyone else, we did get to see all the magnificent things in that room.Worth the visit, as are all major art museums around the world.

Wonderfull. This museum is spectacular. You need to be prepared to walk for hours.Its is enormous, you cross bloks and blocks, escalators, so choose before what you really want to see and focus it. In my opinion the most interesting place in STB.Super recomend it.

Lots to see - more time necessary. We spent time here as part of a two day cruise stay in St. Petersburg. There is so much to see but it is all worthwhile. As our guide said. If you spent one minute at each exhibit you would be here for 8 years. Worth it for even four hours.

Amazing. We bought the tickets online, so although more expensive, we were able to jump the queu. And it was a long one in February, all snowy. So recommend to do that. Also recommend to plan a whole day inside it as I have never seen such a big museum

Must see. You need to go here when you visit, huge museum you could and can spend days here, my advise is to select what you want to see before you go in or on entrance. For those on a short trip in winter, the Hermitage stays open late on a Wednesday, it's quiet and no queues. Great time to go, I have been about 5/6 times always find something new to see. I really appreciate the Russian rooms, so interesting.

AMAZING, pack your walking shoes and a small umbrella. This place is amazing and huge, the collection is staggering. I asked our guide how long it will take to go thru each room, She said, about 2 days and change. What is wonderful is that you can actually come close to the artwork and really take a look at them, Yes the art are not there for you to abuse, there are Ex KGB people patrol all over the place but if you respect the art, and NOT touch it they will not bother you. They are there for you to behold, study, reflect and see unlike (the LOUVRE).Anyway, we were part of a group so we have to use the group entrance and even that has tons of people wanting to get in. We came in there in the morning so the line was not bad, but still you have to queue. Unfortunately, it rained while we were in queue and of course I am not wearing a jacket, luckily there is a guy that is selling umbrellas, I believe it was 350.00 Russian ruble, so not bad and I get another souvenir. So if you go, the weather there is unpredictable, I suggest you bring a waterproof jacket with a hoodie or a small umbrella. The place is amazing and you will not regret going in.
Amazing. It is a wonderful place to visit if you are really into art you should hire one of the many guides in every language. Well worth the cost. Purchase in advance is highly recommended.

Delights Everywhere You Look. First of all, you can't see everything in one visit. I read that if you spent one minute on each item in the Hermitage, and did it for 24 hrs. a day, it would take eight years to see it all. Having said that, if you love art at all, this is a "must see." The collection is enormous, diverse and breathtaking in scope. An important note is that everything here was purchased by the Romanov family, unlike some museums which contain works that were "liberated" from other countries. We paid extra to see the "Diamond Room" and while the jewels and other jewel encrusted items were spectacular, the tour felt rushed (in fairness, the Diamond Room has it's own guides). We were visiting in May and even then, the crowds were huge. Be sure to go as early as you can, and even then, be patient. Once in, the wait will have been so worth it, but wear comfy shoes and be prepared for lots of steps. On our tour, according to my fitbit, we walked 3.11 miles during the tour; in just over 3 hours. Except in the Amber Room, you can take pictures, but no flash. Be sure to look up (ceilings are fantastic) and down (parquet wood floors, stunning) in addition to the objects in each room. From my point of view, just seeing the Rembrandts made the whole visit worthwhile; "Prodigal Son", "The Man in Red" "The Crucifixion"....just astounding. Oh, and the Malachite Room, the Lapis Room, the Egyptian Gallery, the Impressionist Room....you get the idea. Don't miss this.

Beautiful World Class Museum rivaling any western European Museum. Beautiful World Class Museum rivaling any western European Museum; way too much too see. Took a private tour with the Cruise Line Excursion. No crowds since it is normally closed on Mondays.

A beautiful Russian Palace. We had to wait in line to get the entrance tickets, but it was not too long (30 min or so). Inside we joined the guided tour, which lasted nearly 2 hours (for only 200 rubles). The palace is massive, so you cant see everything in one visit. You can easily spend the whole day inside Winter Palace if you are an art lover.

Hermitage. Excellent, mind blowing and breathtaking opulence!A must do once in a lifetime!My only regret is that we didn't have enough time to do justice to the Hermitage.But at least we got in early enough before the crowds came in so we could admire the breathtaking decor.

City's emblem. Hermitage museum is without a doubt the main attraction of St. Petersburg. One of the world's biggest museum, from what I've read, it is indeed huge and it would probably take a lot of time (and cost you a lot of money for the tickets) to visit it all. So, obviously we chose to see one thing of many, the painting galleries. We visited on a Saturday morning, hence the place was quite packed with tourists. Beautiful paintings from several Painting Schools (Dutch, Flemish, Italian, Spanish, French). The museum's rooms are also exquisitely decorated, very oppulent.The museum also hosts collections of Egyptian art, antiques, jewellery, etc.If I were to make a comment, though, the ventilation is nonexistent (compared to other big museums in the world-British Museum comes first in mind), and due to the crowds the air inside the rooms is hot and stuffy. This is not only annoying for the tourists, but also the lack of airflow could harm the painintgs in the long run. (Although there's obviously a few for this attraction, the conditions leave much to be desired. )The exterior of the museum's buildings, although gorgeous, is also in desperate need of a fresh coat of paint. (Is the Russian administration not interested in preserving its cultural heritage?)

Deserving multiple visits. You cannot State Heritage Museum in 2 days. Yes, we spent 2 days here, 4 hours each day and still didn't get to see all. You really have to plan your visit by studying the museum map so that you don't waste your time. Rembrandt's Return of the Prodigal Son painting was unbelievable. You are allowed to take pictures but no flash. I highly recommend that you buy tickets online (it is more expensive than buying at the museum) but you will get to skip the long lines at the museum entrance. With internet ticket, you can enter the museum through Millonnaya Street (at the end of museum building). There is an alley between 2 buildings. Look for the entrance sign (should be the 2nd door on the left). Go inside and show your tickets. It's a brand new entrance (yes, bathrooms are brand new too) with a big lobby. It seems like they designed this entrance for the foreigners. We were the only ones using this entrance while at the main entrance, there were literally lines of people (at least 300 to 400 people) waiting to get int. It's well worth paying for the internet ticket.

Catherine the Great's Great Gift. Your only regret will be the lack of time and maybe the massive crowds you have to navigate - second only to the Vatican and St. Peter's Cathedral. This is the worlds greatest collection of Rembrandt paintings - so if nothing else you will be in awe and amazement at his paintings. This place is nearly ineffable. Note that there is a KGB looking individual stationed in each and every room scanning every person to make sure they don't even think about taking a picture! They are very serious about this - FYI.

Everything has already been said. Be prepared for the walking. It is enormous. Be also prepared to wait a long time in the ticket line. Better to buy on line. It is magnificent not only the art exhibits but also the structure and decorations. Better to take a couple of days and see parts at a time. Bring an umbrella. You will be waiting outside

Could have spent days here!. We visited the museum and palace as part of a two day tour of St. Petersburg during our Baltic cruise. As such, the time we got to spend there was limited by the tour schedule but having a guide to take you directly to some of the key sights and give you background on what you were seeing was critical for a short 2 hour visit! You can only scratch the surface - but, oh, what a surface. This museum and palace were stunningly beautiful with so much to take in - it was my #2 favorite of all of the sights, even though the place was mobbed. You just have to block out the hordes as much as possible and focus on the incredible sights. Highly recommend-no visit to St. Petersburg is complete without it!

Must Visit if in Saint P. My wife and I took a private tour if this place. It is huge so we only saw the highlights which was perfect with a early enter ace thanks to the tour. I had heard that if you took 1 minute to look at every picture for 8 hours a day for 5 days, it would take 11 years to complete. Van Go, Rembrandt, and more. Do not miss this place - you might regret it.

Make time to go back. This is one of the great museums. It can be overwhelming. Go on a tour to get your bearings, the go back another day and look more closely at the things you like. My husband spent three happy hours in the Impressionist building.
Winter Palace. This is a must see on a visit to St. Petersburg. Every corner you turn has another treasure or treasures. Absolutely breathtaking.

3 Million artifacts on exhibit! It is the must-see museum in the world!. You can practically see everything you want to see from different centuries and styles."The collections occupy a large complex of six historic buildings along Palace Embankment, including the Winter Palace, a former residence of Russian emperors. Apart from them, the Menshikov Palace, Museum of Porcelain, Storage Facility at Staraya Derevnya and the eastern wing of the General Staff Building are also part of the museum. " ~ WikipediaThe best part is that you can buy replicas of the masterpieces at the museum shop because they're the only museum in the world who have license to re-produce them!

Artwork and architecture are spectacular so much to see. This is the second largest museum in the world and has a spectacular range of art from many famous artists. The building is also amazing. You will definitely need a full day and try to time your visit on the evening that the famous peacock clock is operated. Quite an amazing piece. The crowds were no so big the day I visited. The number one place to visit in St Petersburg.

Beautiful... !. Stunningly great work of architecture and lavish display of gold and precious stones, they said it's better than any European counterparts and claimed that they made this place best to every I to experience and see.

Incredible and a must see.. This was another highlight when touring this incredible city it is a stunning palace with such incredible history. Get a guide if possible then you are not missing important information.
Awe inspiring. The buildings are as impressive as the collections. The floors and ceilings are beyond beautiful. Definitely worth a visit.
Exceeded expectations. Going to this museum was the reason I wanted to visit this city.It was beyond beyond. A fantastic experience.

Wear comfortable shoes. The Hermitage is absolutely enormous and it's easy to spend an entire day here. Make sure you pick up a map with room numbers on when you enter as is isn't the most logical place and it's easy to get trapped on one area. Focus on the things you want to see as you are unlikely to be able to cover the whole place in one trip. I would recommend seeing the golden peacock as I've seen nothing like it anywhere else in the world. It's difficult to emphasise how large The Hermitage is enough. All of the cafe facilities and bathrooms seem to be on the ground floor so plan appropriately. This is a must see place if you go to St Petersburg. I bought my tickets online before I went as I had read that there can be long queues, but despite going in June, the busiest month of the year, and on a Saturday, it seemed fine to purchase them on the day.

Have to go, but be prepared for big crowds. You can't come to St Petersburg and not visit the Hermitage. With that said, you and every other tourist will be there, so if you have issues with your personal space being invaded you better check them at the door. We came as part of a Viking tour so we were there early and came in through the group entrance. Even coming early, there were still be plenty of other early bird tour groups. The groups from ocean cruises are on a tight schedule so step aside and let them pass or prepare to be trampled. As others mentioned there is a ton to see and the rooms in the Winter Palace are magnificent. Don't miss the peacock clock and watch the short film that shows how it operates. Once you are through the highlights tour the crowds will thin substantially and you can view at a more leisurely pace. There is a very interesting exhibit of arms and armor on the first floor that was practically deserted. Hang on to your map because they aren't available in the museum and you don't get one at all if you come with a group. There is an app you can download and the museum has free wifi. Be aware that much like the Louvre you can't always get from point A to Point B without a detour to C. Example, you can only get to part of the first floor from the second floor. Highlights for us were the decorative arts and the Russian rooms. All the Impressionist paintings have been moved to another museum. Not sure if that's permanent or not so if that's very important to you check before you come.

Simply unmissable. It's impossible to write any really worthwhile review about the Hermitage here. The place is enormous and would take weeks to see every exhibit. We had a fairly whirlwind tour of the most important exhibits with a guide which was very useful. For fine art lovers, you could easily take a whole day of a holiday here. The building itself is very impressive too.

Lives up to its reputation . A beautiful building made up of 5 palaces, full of magnificent collections from all over the world. You must linger at the Peacock Clock, all the old masters, jasper vase and of course the main staircase. Stick to the windows and you won't miss any of the main rooms.

Lives up to its reputation. Beautifully combined 5 palaces, full of wonderful collections. You must linger at the Peacock Clock, the old master painters, jasper vase and the main staircase, to name just a few. Stick to the windows and you won't miss any of the important rooms.

Absolutely stunning. First visit the rest of Europe,then come here because if the other way round-the rest might look a bit dull.The place is so grand and rich,it just shakes you.And never go withouth experienced guide

Need to stay more than one day. A trip to the Hermitage is an overwhelming experience. There is so much to see and do. The ticket is actually for several different museums at different locations. We got our tickets on line which made things easier. We got the two day tickets and it was definitely worth it. Even with the two days, we did not see everything we wanted. One thing to keep in mind (and probably the only negative thing about the museum) is that once you enter one of the locations you can't leave and then return on the same day. Also, it gets really busy with tour groups coming in waves, especially in late mornings and early afternoon, so it is best to visit the major works either first thing in morning or end of the day. The museum was almost empty the last hour of the day.

How to avoid long lines. The best way to purchase tickets is to buy them on line before going to the Hermitage, otherwise be prepared to wait two hours in line. This on line purchase will give you a voucher which has to be redeemed at the "internet ticket" booth to get actual admission tickets. Normally you have to print the voucher to get tickets there, but if you do not have access to a printer while traveling, make sure to click on the link in the email to open each PDF file and then using your Explorer cached pages on your smartphone, you can simply browse the pages for showing the person at the ticket booth. Note that the Internet ticket booth is behind the building not out front where massive lines of people are waiting to purchase them on site!
Fantastic Museum. Amazing collection of art and history in the beautiful Winter Palace. Need a few days to actually appreciate the many collections.
A museum not to miss in St. Petersburg.. The Hermitage Museum was absolutely beautiful and had some of the most unique and beautiful rooms and objects.

Beauty is all over the palace. My mum and I visited this huge museum and almost got lost in it's breath taking statues and unique paintings .If we hadn't had the tour leader we would be lost in it's huge history. But the bad point is that everywhere is written in Russian and no one understands English.
The reason you go there. The language expertise and knowledge of the place of your guide is critical to your enjoyment and understanding of this outstanding museum. Once visited never forgotten.

Rival to the Louvre. Stunning collection of antiquities art and treasures initially begun under the Romanovs but since looked after by the Soviets and the current Russian Government A room full of Rembrandts,two sublime Leonardo's, beautiful Roman statues and Greek amphora,dazzling golden artifacts from antiquity, and heaps more besidesRivals the Louvre bring comfortable shoes!The modern part to the collection including the French Impressionists has been moved across the square into the General Staff Building There is a room of Monets one of Van Gogh, two of Gaugain heaps of Cezannes two rooms of Picassos a room of frankly stunning erotic Rodin statuary The upgrade has been done superbly and this part of the Hermitage is not to be missed.

Huge and exhausting and easy to get lost in.. This museum is akin to the Louvre and the Metropolitan in NY. It is huge. The collection is amazing, the palace apartments are especially worth seeing. All the 20th century onwards art is across the road in the General Staff building. My favorite parts were the red and gold rooms of the winter Palace, St Georges Hall,the Great Church and the Pavilion Hall. The Da Vinci and Rembrant Galleries are a little misleading as they only have 2 paintings by each of these artists, and they tend to be mobbed by tourists taking photos! Wear comfortable shoes...you will be waking miles and miles!

Be selective and wear comfy shoes!. The opulence, scale, exhibitions and history of the magnificent Winter Palace and Hermitage should be visited by all visitors to St Petersburg. It's an integral feature of the city's history and evolution. However it's impossible to see everything so plan ahead using guide books and choose what you want to see.

The most beautiful of many museums we have visited. Our visit was a long-time dream come true, and exceeded by far our expectations. The Hermitage is incredibly beautiful, and the staff is very helpful. We bought a 2-day ticket on-line and avoided a long queue. We recommend a 2-day ticket, as it is impossible to visit all in one day.
Incredible!. The Hermitage was the most incredible museum I have ever visited! Our guide highlighted many interesting exhibits. The Hermitage is a MUST!

Incredible visit - the best collection of art in the world. We spent the most wonderful afternoon/evening in the Hermitage. The comprehensive collections of art from every era is staggering. We loved the Dutch Genre paintings, the Rembrandts and the General Staff Building which was filled with treasures from the Impressionists and Post-Impressionists. Unforgettable!
Maginficent but ro many people. Very nice but totally over crowded with thousands of visitors which is understandable as it is one of the most popular sites in St Petersburg

Absolutely incredible!. A wonderful place to visit and a must see if you are in St Petersburg. If you have the remotest interest in history, then you will love it, if you don't you will probably still love it. One of the most interesting places I have visited and would definitely go back to spend more time there.

Best of the best!! . The decoration, the exhibition, the art pieces are magificent! In my opinion, this is the best museum palace I've ever visited in Europe! Some sections might be a little bit crowded but you can always manage to get through. You can take photos inside but with no flash. Not quite nice use the Selfie stick inside the building, anyway. I adore the collections they have especilally the peacock clock on the second floor. It is just flawlessly beautiful! Our visit was a bit later of the day. We took a trolleybus from the bus stop near the hotel around 10 am (30 RUB per jump) It took us around 15 minutes to reach the palace square and 5 minutes walk to the main gate (the archway main entrance). Many people were queing outside to buy the tickets. To avoid the queue, go through the main gate on your right (in the garden area) there are many of automatic ticket selling machine (with the word KACCA) using either cash or card to purchase. English instruction is available. The local staff at the information office (near the palace itself) told us to do so. She even mentioned not to pre-book on the website because it will be more expensive. Buying tickets with the machine is easy, short queue, no fuss-no rush! Dining inside the palace is quite convenient. They have a cafe downstairs with English speaking staff. Be prepared for security checking prior to the entrance, you are not allowed to bring drinking water inside.

Huge and interesting . The museum is huge. Be warned!!We spent hours there and only saw a fraction. Negative - The crowds are terrible with little control. The worse factor is the large tour groups blocking the corridors and generally pushing and being rude. The tour guides seem to stand in door ways and block the way so their group control the flow. That gripe over the museum is stunning. Positive- tonnes to see, stunning architecture, art, history it's endless. The setting is stunning. WellWorth a visit. Oh and don't queue in the court yard, buy a ticket at the machine on the way in and walk straight in! They tried to deter us doing this, God alone knows why. They announce on the tannoy 'buy tickets and don't queue' and yet at the machine is a member of staff trying to advise us to queue! Bizarre.

Hermitage. We had an excellent English speaking young lady as our tour guide to our selves. She knew her history and she was a delight. She showed us the highlights in a little under 3 hours, which was about all we could absorb with all the crowds. She made our visit very worth while.

Beautiful but NO crowd control. This is a spectacular place to visit but it is chaos inside the Hermitage with groups going in all directions. A guided tour is great because there is too much to see and the guide selects a good range for your limited time. It would take days to see it all. It was weird the way that sometimes a magnificent room would be full of people and then there'd be a lull just long enough to grab a photo. Remember to have your elbows ready for some defensive action so you don't get swept away with the crowd.
it is a great museum in st petersburg. great place to visit in st petersburg , the museum has a lot of Henri Matisse , some Picasso and others french artists .

Amazing. This place is like a mix of Versailles and Louvre, but even more grand. There are so many grand and gorgeous rooms that you run out of superlatives to describe them. Come early to avoid the crush of tourists. You can download an app that gives you information and map. It's easy to get lost here, and hard to see everything. The prettiest rooms are probably on the second floor.

Hermitage. A must in St. Petersburg. Make sure you allow enough time and if you can get in early with a tour it is better. When we started it was early and not busy. By the time we left it was hard to move. Having a private guide was also very helpful we were able to see the highlights with a lot of history.

You'll need lots of time - But it's worth it. We were here on an excursion so we had our own guide; this meant we got in early but it also meant we were guided to where they wanted us to go. I would love to have several days to go through here, it is incredible ! The building itself is worth walking through and seeing, but the displays are ... wow ... ! If you are in St. Petersburg you have to make this a stop !! Our guide told us she is often asked how long it takes to see everything, she said if you stood at each display for 30 seconds it would take 3 years to see everything !! Luckily, the organization of things makes it easy to see what you would be most interested in seeing. Highly recommend !!

Ambience beyond belief. After queuing in rain for over an hour (due to cruise ships pushing in to head of queue.) very efficiently run inside cloakrooms plentiful. Lived up to its reputation. Magnificent n very interesting. Need a minimum of 4 hours to even scratch the surface.

A beautiful museum. I won't talk about all the collections as they are well described in the museum website, but will focus on the visit /tips. To skip the lines, book online! Easy and you get a separate entrance. If in need of a wheelchair, you can get one at every entrance. There is no charge, but they'll keep your ID/passport as a guarantee and return it to you when you leave. We toured the whole 2nd floor of the winter palace and little hermitage. Very helpful employees despite my limited russian knowledge and their limited foreign languages knowledge.

Splendor and Glory. This is probably one of the most attractive museums in the world. The glorious and exquisite art displays will leave you awestruck. The place is so huge that it easily tires out an average tourist. For some reason people don't seem to buy tickets from automatic machines which are very easy to handle. While there was a fair amount of queue at ticket office we got our tickets in seconds on the machine.

A Great Collection of Art. This massive museum of multiple building house a great collection of art. You can view Catherine the Great's fine collection of art. The building is old and the maintenance of the facilities is rather basic. There is no environmental control in the museum. Many of the items are poorly lite and hard to see. The Gold Room provided an opportunity to view the oldest collection of gold pieces from the 7th to 4th centuries BC. The displays were hard to view and enjoy. The crowds are large and at times very pushy to get the best views. While we enjoyed the art we did not enjoy the experience. Plan your visit before you go...it takes years to see all the museum has to offer.

Impressive!. Nothing quite prepares you for the splendour of the palace and state rooms. Then the arts and artefacts are astonishing. I can't give it 5 stars though because the crowd control was non existent. It doesn't help that people are allowed to take photos, which leads to extra bottlenecks. Worth researching when would be quieter times to go (we only had one window 10.30-1.00 on a Tuesday in late May so it was bound to be busy).

One of the finest art galleries in the world. Contains works by the masters such as Leonardo da Vinci, Rubens and Rembrandt, as well as contemporary artists such as Picasso and Matisse. Collections are split between buildings, with a lot being on display at the Winter Palace. An awesome display of art which you will need a good few hours to browse through.

An extremely famous museum, very well known world wide. You find old paintings from all over yhe world, take at lest 2 to 3 hours for your visit. The place could be very crowded and you have to be patient getting cose to each subject you're interested in.

BEAUTIFUL MUSEUM!!!!. This is a stunningly beautiful museum that contains precious works of art. We visited with a guide and were given a lot of historical information about the museum and the art. We had early entry and it was fortunate that we did. The later crowds would have prevented us from seeing all that we saw. Go as early as possible to beat the worst crowds. They warn you to watch out for pick pockets in the areas where crowds gather. We didn't have near the time that we wish we had and we hope to be able to return some time in the near future.
Amazing . You can even ignore the paintings just admire the decor of the rooms. But you can't, the paintings are amazing as well

Not to be missed. The most awe inspiring place I have ever been in, art and fabulous interior. Don't miss the throne rooms and main rooms used by the Romanovs . Get the online internet tickets , either one day or two, and there is now a special entrance and hardly anyone there! Brilliant, remember to ask for a floor plan.
Amazing collection.. Suggest you read about the history in advance, so much more interesting when you view the most amazing collection of memorabilia.

Amazing place, enormous collection. This is now my fave museum of all time (the old one was Field Museum in Chicago) for its awesome building, priceless collection of art and sculptures and overall pleasure derived from having rare historical artefacts. I especially love the giant malachite vase at the Jasper Reception Room of the museum, which used to be the residence of the Tsars of Russia in the older days.

One of the nest in the world. A must see but a cruise does not afford you enough time....go see it anyway. The exhibits are spectacular, varied and well spaced. We went two days and felt cheated with not enough time.

Sensory Overload. Try to avoid visiting when cruise ships are docked as they block book morning visiting times. Our group was forced to queue, unusually, in the rain for around an hour because of this. However on entering, in typical well organised Russian form, were freed of wet coats, hats and brollies and fed a never ending feast of cultural & historical delights. Too much to describe in this space - just visit - and if you remain untouched by the oppulance of the Romanovs or the impression they made on every European royal household after visiting this stunning Winter Palace, then there's really no hope for you!

Simply the best grand museum in the world. Whether you like 20th century art or immortal European classics or archeological collections or imperial diamond - or simply like to see where the tsars lived, come to the Hermitage.

Breathtaking!. We didn't know where to look first. EVERYTHING is exquisite. An absolute must.
We bought tickets online ahead of time and that way saved us waiting in endless lines. If you get them online there is a seperate entrance around the corner and you go straight in.
Enjoy!!!

Wednesdays are the day to go!. We went at 4pm on a Wednesday and had no line! We pretty much had the museum to ourselves with the late closing. We were able to see so much with ease. We did not take a tour, but spent about 4.5 hours there. We easily could have spent more time. We did not make it across the street to the General Staff building. (I didn't realize we could go there) The cafe was a good start to get some food and drink and be able to spend time in the museum without having to stop!

So much to see. 3 hours was not enough time, but we are thankful for what we were able to see! DiVinci's, Rembrandt's-- so many beautiful paintings, historical objects, mummys... you need several days to see everything in this amazing museum

I would travel to Russia just to come here again. I have seen many museums throughout the world and I can say without a shadow of a doubt that this is the BEST museum I have ever had the privilege of attending. It was amazing, every corner, ever inch of the ceiling. The building is just gorgeous and the collection is out of this world. My whole hearted advise is to do the museum in 2 days. You need two days its too large. I spent 8 hours there and only saw the 2nd floor. It truly was the highlight of my entire trip and I would love to go back one day.

An absolute must. If there is one thing you should do in St Petersburg is to go and visit this really incredible museum. If you can afford it book a private guide who will highlight all the wonderfull things as there is so so much to see
Day at the Hermitage. Beautiful if crowded. Try to find a day when the cruise ships not in town. Not to be missed and would take weeks to see everything.

INCREDIBLE. Only a taste of this amazing collection of works from all over the world. That any Russian should be hungry in the face of this wealth is inconceivable. Use TJ Travel tour guides for the inside views.

Not just Art. A visit to "The Hermitage" is a double-header. You get to see one of Russia's premium palaces, and also see the Art. It is an excellent experience on both counts. However, like other such places (The Louvre, Palace of Versailles), the biggest drawback is too many of us tourists. Try to be there off the main season; try to do it in a small group. We went as part of a two-day tour with T J Tours, and seemed to get spirited around some of the larger tour groups, and we also were usually not overcrowded. Highly recommended if you can cut the crowds.

Incredible - wear comfortable shoes. The Hermitage is one of those museums that you would need a week to see. It is inspiring and breath taking. There are incredible works of art and opulent architecture. It truly is a feast for the senses. As for visiting - you walk - a lot. If you have older guests, you may want to strategize the specific areas you want to see. There are stairs. Some rooms have air and others do not so at times it gets very stuffy. You are allowed to take pictures inside except for rooms with temporary exhibits and the Amber Room. If you're coming on a cruise ship - try to book a private tour - many are able to get you in prior to it opening. Though the cruise ships say they do too, it is VERY hard to be a large group in the Hermitage. You won't see nearly as much as you can with a private guide. (I used Guide Guru.) Remember...wear comfortable shoes. :)
Out of interest . A most valuable collection of art. Presented very aesthetically. A must see. It requires at least a full day.

Of course. you must visit the Hermitage. I saved it for the last day of a week-long trip to SPB. Small tour with private guide saved lots of time with early entry. Went directly to areas of interest and didn't wander. Spent 4 hours in main Hermitage and then another 2 hours across the square in the General Staff Building looking at impressionists. Great desert in General Staff Building after a long day of slow museum walking.

Peter & Catherine's great Palace. We spent an afternoon in the Hermitage museum and could have spent days. We took the English language live, personal tour and I have to say how impressed I was with the calibre of our guide - she was incredible! She REALLY knew her stuff and there is SO MUCH to see.

A modern, world-class museum - highly recommended. I last visited the Hermitage about 20 years ago - it had an extensive but tired collection in a tired, poorly lit building.It is now totally transformed. The collection remains world-class, but the building is now an equal star. Almost all the rooms have been extensively renovated - new parquet floors, beautiful building, excellent lighting. This truly does feel like a palace of the Tsars.Signage remains limited - consider another source if you want more than title, artist and date. But there is wifi throughout the building (ostensibly so you can download the Hermitage apps and buy content through in-app purchase, but I was able to use for browsing as well).Crowds can be crushing, but get away from the main routes and they thin out tremendously. And if you buy your tickets online in advance through the Hermitage website you can use the secret entrance off Millionarskaya ulitsa which was completely empty when we entered.As others have noted, the cafe is serviceable. We found it surprisingly uncrowded despite the hordes in the museum - presumably all on tours with lunch booked elsewhere. It gave us the energy to continue our exploration after lunch.A word about the new (2014) General Staff building which holds impressionists and modern art. This is included in admission and is a world-class museum in its own right - definitely make time for it. The building is a fantastic renovation of an older building, with glassed over courtyards and elevated walkways. Currently still 'filling out', only about 1/3 the rooms are full (May 2016) which meant we could tack on in 2 hours after the Hermitage (seeing about 1/3-1/2 the collection). When it is full it will require more time.All in all, wonderful to see how improved the Hermitage is in the 20 years since I last visited.

what more can be said. As everyone else has said, it's enormous, it's got amazing stuff, and it's hard to do it justice in words.A few ideas:Having a guide helped a lot because otherwise I'd have been lost in a momentCheck the Hermitage website for temporary exhibits. I found an exhibit my guide didn't know about that was fascinating (to me)The impressionists (Monet etc) are in the old General Staff building and most of the tours don't seem to go there. Much less crowded.Otherwise, go, enjoy.

You can only be floored by so much beauty. This is not for the faint-hearted because the place is H U G E and you just cannot believe how much there is to see. You need a week just to see the surface of it. Two Leonardos, a major Titian, several della Robbia panels, acres of Rembrandts & Rubens, all the major Claude Lorraines, a roomful of statues by Houdon, major Byzantine icons and ivory sculptures of which there are so very few--name a famous work of art it's there. The only drawback is that it is so very crowded. Avoid the cafeterias go to the General Staff building where you can eat and drink in peace. I nearly forgot: do not on any account miss the recently restored Van der Weyden!

Must visit. Museum is great, i loved it. You must reserve all day for this attraction, othervise, you even won't be able to walk around museum. If you are not russian, you must purchase tickets online or in termilal in Museum's garden, because almost all long line consists of native inhabitants of Russia, who purchases tickets with discount. I had Student discount and I had to wait in line for about 2,5 h! Inspites of my trip was in July, but in rainy day and I was very cold. So bring your umbrella and warm clothes with you even in July :D
Wonderful. Stunning place one OF the best museum in the world. Remember to visit also the Grand Building museum where are the impressionists painters.

You can never take in everything. The museum is too huge to be described in a review. If you are a museum lover especially one with an inclination for arts and paintings, you are likely to camp there for weeks on end. In fact, the guide who accompanied us stated that it will take more than 6 years to view every exhibit in the museum.

For lovers of art, history & architecture . Of course we had decided to see The Hermitage while in St Petersburg so we decided the day (not a Monday as it is closed) and got up earlyish as I had read that we would have to stand in line but instead when we got there we walked straight up and bought tickets. There was no one on the grand staircase with us and we got to explore rooms by ourselves which makes for good photos. But no matter the season you visit (meaning you might have to line up) it is worth visiting. The state rooms of the Romanov family were beautiful as was the furniture & the art work of course. It is definitely worth a visit for the history & because it is so beautiful & grand. We didn't get an audio guide but perhaps in hind sight it would have been beneficial. We also got really lost even though we had a map.....it's quite large. The cafe was packed on the way out (we had already decided a big breakfast was in order to avoid having to eat there as I heard the food was ordinary). Souvenir shops on the way out had some nice things & I think you can also shop online from their souvenir shop now as well. You check your coat after you have bought tickets and there are toilets in the coat room as well, make sure you go before you go through the ticket inspectors as I didn't see any toilets whilst wandering around.

Versailles a poor Cousin. Do not miss. More rembrandt here than in all other museums worldwide---or seems to be. The architecture is very unique & visually impressive. Been to all the major royal palaces etc & this one stands way above all others
