An art lovers dream.. Massive building with countless works of art, long queues can form, best to go early or use the services of a tour company

A great visit. A wonderful place to see various furniture, painting, sculptures, clothing and much more. A day is not enough to visit all the exhibits and a guide or virtual audio guide can be purchased at a reasonable price.
Not a big fan of arts.... It has a large volume of collection of arts from different countries/ periods/ styles. If you love museums you should definitely pay a visit.
Hermitage. Brilliant, but you need to see the impressionist paintings and the faberge collection in other museums as they have been moved.

The Winter Palace is just as fantastic as billed. All 27 of us were glad of our guide to take us through this amazing space as effectively as possible. The art works are astonishing. The Jordan staircase is wonderful. The original Da Vincis are lovely to look at when you can get near them.

Long queue was worthed. You need to go here very early in the morning as the queue to enter this museum is verrrryyyy long...this is the most popular museum in Russia so you need to be there early to beat others.

# 1 Palace in the world not to be Missed. The pieces on the exhibition are always top class but one should just visit Hermitage for the interior decorations and rooms of the palace itself.
Very crowded all times and long queues. 1 hour minumum waiting time.
But that s the place you visit before you die.

Incredible!!!!. If the Hermitage was a restaurant it would have three Michelin Restaurant Guide Stars. The Hermitage is worth a special journey!!!We visited the Hermitage at the end of October, and during our visit there were not very many people visiting. This makes viewing all the different rooms and exhibits very easy and pleasant. We spent five hours at the Hermitage, and then two more hours at the Staff Building where the Impressionist paintings are located. I can now understand why some people voice frustration when there are lots of crowds visiting the Hermitage. If you can visit during off-peak season, then you can appreciate the Hermitage even more.

Grandness personified. We made a mistake by not using a guide when we visited this wonderful place.You can get lost and we understood that we should have planned it better and focused on what we really wanted to see.You could spend months in there and not fully appreciate the beauty and history of this place.The room's themselves are incredible and grand not to mention the million's of pieces that would take you an age to digest.The room's seem to go on for ever and we just did not have time to check out the General staff building.Tip for buying a ticket....Buy it in the General staff building and you have access to most area's.It cost's 600 roubles per person.The qeue was massive for the ticket's you buy from the entrance to the hermitage and they are limited on what you can see.You could write a book on this place to advise people to visit.You really must go and see for yourself.When we return in the summer it will be with a guide for sure.

The most luxurious palace I've ever been to. I thought that I knew luxury after visiting France or Italy: this is so much more! Every single room has thousands of beautiful details, golden ornaments, exotic marbles and semiprecious stones... even the floor is gorgeous, with all kinds of woods forming beautiful designs. It is a MUST GO, definetly.

Beautiful museum. It's a beautiful building with gorgeous architecture and a huge collection of exhibits. However a lot of the exhibits are not encased or put within barriers. So if you're travelling with children, (even with silly adults) most likely you'd get yelled at by the Russian old ladies sitting in the corner watching if you touch any of the exhibits.

Worth queueing for? Absolutely!!. What else to say? It is a must visit purely for the interior. Without a doubt is what you would call a Palace, so rich, well crafted and opulent. Some of the rooms have the biggest chandeliers I have ever seen, the staircases are magnificent...just what you would imagine for Russia´s Royal Family.On top of this, there is also the fact that it is a museum and holds one of the world´s biggest art collections. Don´t think it´s possible to visit everything on the same day. The Palace is like a maze and every wall or room has a paintings or sculpture to be admired. On one of the rooms there was a group of men singing Opera. Magical!Nice museum shop and café as well!

The Highlights were INCREDIBLE.. We saw only a small portion of the art housed in the Hermitage Museum during our trip to St. Petersburg, but the palace itself is a work of art...only to be even more beautifully adorned by spectacular pieces from around the globe. Personal favorites were the throne room (don't forget to look up and down...the ceiling and floor are incredible) and the mosaic room. Was sad to find out the impressionist art had been relocated from the main museum. I guess I will have to see that another time!

Half day tour from cruise ship.. Had to queue outside winter palace for half an hour, not too long, but would not be pleasant in rain. Too many ill mannered tour groups vying for best views. Wish we had splashed out on the private evening tour. Having said that I wouldn't have missed it, absolutely fabulous place. Need much longer there though.

So much history!. This enormous building is attempting to encapsulate hundreds of years of Russian history and art. It is an incredible achievement. I only spent a few hours in the museum and knew I had only scratched the surface. I enjoyed the combination of art museum with preserved palace ballrooms, throne rooms and personal rooms. My favorite part was probably the English library, but I may be biased.

A wonder.. One day wasn't nearly enough to spend in this stunning museum. The sheer volume of exquisite art and objects in incredible condition is unimaginable. I plan to return to Russia and spend several days here. If you have the opportunity to go to the Hermitage, go.

Wow!. What can one say? I could have spent a week here and not taken everything in. This museum and residence is a true treasure. The opulence and artistic value is out of this world. If the Tsars and Nobility(the 1%) lived like this and the other 99% were starving, then no wonder there was a revolution!The Winter Palace and Hermitage are a must see in St. Petersburg!

New favourite. Thius is one of the worlds´s wonders. If you bare in St Pete, you just have to visit. This is our European culture. Stunning artifacts and artworks. Practical with a guide, a private guide was perfect.
must see. this is worth travelling to Russia on its own.it is unbelievable what is on display here must be one of the best museums in the world.

You just have to there. Every time I visit Hermitage I find something else. If I just want to relax I go there and visit couple of my favorite rooms. If go there there with friends I show them my favorite rooms.

the Hermitage. Ijust looove art. I can have it for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Or instead of dinner. Anyway, this is the place for such people like me. From the very beginning to the very end. Just 2 things disapointed me - NO IMPRESSIONIST and too hot. There were 5000 visitors that day and i hink 2/3 were CHINEESE. You can guess what i mean.

This one of the most beautiful buildings that I have ever seen.. The Hermitage boasts over 2.7 million exhibits and displays a diverse range of art and artifacts from all over the world and from throughout history, such as, works by Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael and Titian, a unique collection of Rembrandts and Rubens and many others.

Must do!. You definitely have to visit the place! The commection is outstanding and a piece of history itself. Best thing proöly to get a private tour or have a friend who knows his/her way around. The place is huge!

Beautiful. This magnificent collection of buildings is huge, and cannot possibly be seen in just a few hours. The staircases and ceilings are works of art in themselves. We visited just a few of the many rooms, each full of wonderful paintings and sculptures. Quite crowded, so keep close to your guide especially if wearing the earphones.

In city tour with DenRus through St.Patersburg. In the tour we booked we saw ,I think, all the things to visit in the city.Hermitage was only one of them.No que to get in , all the time to walk around with our guide Nadya.do not miss the DenRus company.I will not write more reviews over this city, just visit them by using DenRus.All the visiting were 100% prepared and lots of time to enjoy.

Very Beautiful Place. Huge place to visit, Leave plenty of time, we spent 5 hours and only saw part of it. You need a guide so you don't get lost, also to learn things about the history.Guide keeps you moving along and also beats the queues

Not enough days in a week. We enjoy visiting museums in every city that we visit and we could not wait to visit the Hermitage on our tour. We were shocked to learn that we were only going to see just a small portion of it! We knew it was large, but we never fully appreciated the huge scale of the museum until we were inside and experiencing it. Along with the shear size and endless exhibit halls are the other countless tours that are trying to cram themselves into these tight areas. If possible, allow two days to see the Hermitage. If more time cannot be given, then pre-plan. Also note that the Hermitage does not have air conditioning, so if planning a visiting during the summer, make it an early summer visit. The weather was pleasantly cool for an early July day, but it was incredibly hot and stuffy inside. We could not imagine what a hot August day must be like with all the tours!

Incredible Art Museum and PICKPOCKET ALERT!!!!. The Hermitage is unquestionably one of the world's finest art museums, not just for its collection (largest collection of paintings in the world) but also for its palatial setting. Comprised of several buildings, the core is Catherine the Great's Winter Palace, built in the mid-late 1700's. If you're on a tour, this is where you will go.As a museum, the Hermitage has been open since the mid-1850's. It would take you days to see all there is to see here, though most likely you'll be going through in a tour group that will limit your time to a little under three hours. That was the case with our "Highlights of the Hermitage" tour. Leaves a lot unseen, but a good experience.While this review could go on and on about the art, you'll see plenty on your own. The only disappointment was not seeing some of the Impressionist works, as that area or building was closed the day we were there. It may be that there's a renovation going on that will keep that area closed for a while. Check with your tour guide.Now -- PICKPOCKET ALERT!!!! Seriously, I saw this in action. Entering the Winter Palace, we were directed up a flight of stairs, at the top of which are a few ATM's. This pickpocket alert is specific to that area. As we were later leaving the museum, several of our group withdrew cash from these ATM's in order to pay for the tour we were on. As I stood there, I noticed a blind man, alone, complete with sunglasses and white cane, standing nearby, facing in the direction of the ATM's. What's wrong with this picture? A blind person in an art museum? Sorry -- no Braille pictures here..... As I continued to observe, a small group of folks, not in our group, who had just withdrawn cash started down the stairs to exit the museum. The "blind" man turned and followed them, closely, down the stairs. However, they proceeded rapidly and he stopped after only a few steps down the stairs. In retrospect, I think this was because he didn't want to be seen going down stairs at a rapid rate, unlike what a real blind person would do. He came back up to the top of the stairs, turned again in the direction of the ATM's and stood there as members of our group withdrew cash. Finished, it was now time for our group to leave. When we were about 1/2 way down the stairs, I turned and looked back. The "blind" guy was at the top of the stairs, facing our direction, but not proceeding down the stairs. At the bottom of the stairs, a man was sitting on a bench, phone to his ear. That may have been an innocent conversation, but it struck me that his gaze was locked on the purses of the women in our group as we passed by. I sensed that the "blind" guy at the top was communicating with the man at the bottom, telling him which purses had just had cash put into them at the ATM's, OR, having already been alerted by the "blind" guy, the man at the bottom was in touch with others waiting in the crowd outside the nearby exit, identifying persons and purses to target where the opportunity to pickpocket a purse would have been best. I alerted the members of our group, and, thankfully, nothing more came of this. I'll never know if all this was just coincidence or not, but something just didn't seem right here. Blind guy? I don't think so..... I'm not a paranoid individual; I'd bet money I'm right on this. Bottom line, enjoy the Hermitage -- it truly is fabulous. Just be alrert in the area of the ATM's if you use one.

A masterpiece - allow yourself plenty of time. There is nothing that I can say that others haven't said, but I will repeat some of them. I spent a lot of time mentally comparing this astonishing building and its contents to Versailles and The Metropolitan Museum of Art combined but it stands squarely in a space of its own. Prepare to be impressed and silenced by the grandeur. If you want to avoid getting lost keep reminding yourself to follow the map!It is worth pre-bookng a ticket voucher online - although I arrived at 10:15 I still had to queue for half an hour or so to pick up my tickets. But, walking past a huge line and then straight in made it worthwhile.Given the size of the place I can't neglect to mention the cafe. You will be in there all day and will need a stop. You are not permitted to take water into the museum with you - some people were having theirs taken off them, some were not (in the usual Russian way). I had seen the cafe described as 'dire' but was not prepared for what I found. Truly awful. Not only was the extremely limited food bad there was almost nowhere to sit. Hopefully they will see that needs some attention. Whatever you do, however you do it, make sure that you take this into account.You have to enter the Winter Palace by leaving the Hermitage and walking around the front on the embankment. Whilst the palace is amazing it is much smaller than I had anticipated (size isn't everything) and the few tours that were going around absolutely filled the small spaces making it impossible to see anything and read the information until they had moved on.
Fabulous museum and fountains-Summer Palace of Catherine the Great. It's one of the most beautiful spots in St. PetersburgGold all over - fountains which don't use pumps - just gravity -

An almost daunting selection of exhibits meets the eye!. An almost daunting selection of exhibits meets the eye from the first moment you step inside the building. The building itself is a landmark and inside the rooms were built to impress. A marvellous marble staircase take you to the 2nd floor. I would recommend a guide which in Sept 2015 cost around €60 for a two trip. She/He will take you to the main highlights of the exhibits. I'd strongly recommend considering a two day ticket which is excellent value and will be needed if you want to see more.

Russian Bling could again beat the French. If you have not been pre warned you will be shocked in the best way possible. It just can not be described without going over the top with personal praise but everybody has different tastes so visit and see if you join the That's Awesome

How the other 0.1% live. People actually used to live in this amazingly opulent building, just as they did in Versailles. The collections are also amazing, ranging from ones on early Siberian culture to portraits of Russia's Czars to ancient Buddhist images. Wonderful.
Leisure. Love it. Really nice place where you could touch the history. You could work your illision, creativity while watching all recvizits
breathtaking. I've traveled quite a bit, this place is one of the most beautiful places I have seen. Everything covered in gold, very extravagant. Russian royalty had great taste.

Want to come back. My family and I had an amazing experience with Guide for You in and around St Petersburg. The company made every step from booking and arranging the trip onward remarkably easy.We spent two days with our guide, Olga, and our driver, Sergey, and saw all the sights of St Petersburg! On the first day we were picked up on time and Olga guided us round the Hermitage, the Church of Spilled Blood, St Isaac's Cathedral, St Nicholas' Church and the Russian Art Museum. On the second day we went to Peterhof and Catherine's Palace by hydrofoil. Olga really impressed us with her knowledge and love of St Petersburg.We wanted an intensive 2-day program with a guide and driver, and Guide for You's planning and coordination meant we didn't waste a single minute. We stopped for coffee breaks en route in uncrowded places, and despite our busy program we never felt rushed. Guide for You booked all of the entrance and boat tickets, as well lunch reservations, and made an itinerary according to our precise wishes. We certainly could not have done it without them and their local knowledge!We would definitely recommend guide for you as we had a truly amazing time with them!Visited June 2015.

Amazing. The building itself if not the pieces inside is worth a visit. It is vast and the quality of the collections and exhibits are second to none. I would recommend this for all visitors to St Petersburg.

Hermitage-Must See. If you are going to be in St Petersburg, Russia on a cruise or for other travel, you Must visit the Hermitage. It is jaw dropping in its size and scope of art and architecture. The building its self is an art piece. Then take in the art within it. You could spend days here. Most of us don't have that time. So be sure to take a guided tour to see the highlights at least. Do opt for the early entrance, saves such time and less crowds when you visit. Be sure you do this, you'll never regret it.

Huge an impressive. Visited here during a recent business trip. Firstly - it's huge! I was there 2.5 hours and only scratched the surface. I got lost a few times and visited the same rooms more than once - therefore make sure you get a map! The exhibits are amazing and there is something for everyone. The palace rooms are really impressive. Leave your coat at the cloakrooms as it gets really warm here. Well worth a visit.

Beautiful !. Its worth going there to check a bit how used to be the place of the family Romanov. Im not a big fan of museums, took me around 7 hours to go around the museum and I still couldnt see everything and ended up a bit bored. You can find all sorts of 'arts' there, greek, chinese, etc.

An amazing place. What an amazing building! We went in with a guide we had organised through Troika Tours, and Olga was excellent. She showed us the popular items (da Vinci paintings, the Peacock Clock, the grand staircase etc), as well as showing us a few of her favourite things. I would recommend reading reviews and doing a bit of homework first to work out what you would really like to see, even if you are going with a guide. Be prepared to spend many hours here! It is visually amazing and stunning, so come with plenty of memory/battery life in the camera and marvel at the riches of the Russian monarchy.

World's Most Splendid Museum!. Catherine the Great's passion for art and beauty transformed the Winter Palace, one of the best examples of Russian baroque architecture, into Hermitage. More than 1,000 rooms house nearly 3,000,000 exhibits and displays, featuring some of the world's greatest art. Don't miss the highlights of this staggering collection on a guided tour.
We toured on a day there were few people. Our Alla Tour guide got us in on a day the Museum was closed to the public. It was like the movie night at the Museum. No pushy crowds. Fantastic.
Amazing!!!. One of the richest museums. I do not mean on gold but on art peaces and the meaning that the place has. Everything that you have seen on TV, you can see in this place. TRULY ROYAL

Best museum ever; get a private guide. The Hermitage is huge (one of the biggest in the world), and beside its amazing collection the palace staged very important parts of Russian history. That’s why I booked a private guide to help me through the museum, and it was the best choice I’ve made in the city (and the best money spent there). If you have only one day in the city, go to the Hermitage. It impressed me more than the Louvre, the British Museum, and others in Europe and USA.

WOW!!. This is a HUGE place and best seen by doing your homework ahead of time. We wanted to be sure to see the Picasso's and made a note of what rooms they were in so we didn't miss anything. Be sure to have your camera set so the flash does not go off!! While there were a lot of people and tours there, we were able to take our time and move freely about the exhibits. A must see!
Great!. You will see the magnificent of the Russian empire of the last 2 centuries.Huge Museum and it is a must.

Exquisite. This place is so incredible! Some of the rooms are so beautiful that they bring tears to my eyes. Bring your camera, plenty of memory on the camera and be prepared for stunning decor and design. It's hard to imagine that all of this was built so long ago.

wow after wow. Right from the start this amazing museum is room after room of the greatest artists the world has ever seen. Make sure you have a really good guide so you can truly appreciate this wonderful experience

Great and gigantic museum/gallery. Incredible, extremely large museum/gallery. we spent about 9 hours there! Don't forget to go to the General staff museum across the square if you want to see Impressionists and post-Impressionists!

Fabulous but overwhelming. Be warned of the entire interior courtyard being shrouded in scaffolding, and an overwhelming tide of visitors trying to go in different directions in the cloakrooms! Once you have negotiated the security gates you can begin to enjoy, but be warned that this entry takes a fair while. The Hermitage was much busier than anywhere else we visited here and we conclude that this is because of cruise visitors bussed in.Once inside, the state rooms are quite astonishing.Be warned too that if you are looking for something particular you need to find room numbers (over each doorway) and relate these to your floor plan. We didn't find the direction signs all that helpful. Also we had hoped to track down the Gaugin but were a bit bewildered by the floor plan's descriptions of areas. Souvenir Shops seem to be dotted about all over and there doesn't seem to be any one bigger selling everything. They tend to sell different items so buy when you see it or you may miss the opportunity.Altogether an overwhelming visit. Doubtless this is probably the finest art collection in the world in the most fabulous 'art gallery' but we felt dizzy at the scale of it all!!

Amazing. The size of the Hermitage is overwhelming and unless you have lots of time I would recommend you choose the areas that interest you and just see those or you will get museum fatigue. We visited the state rooms and then used the free guide that you pick up on the way in to see the highlights which are marked in the guide. I would highly recommend seeing the recently reopened chapel which displays the uniform of Alexander 2nd when he was assassinated. There are large queues to buy tickets but you can also buy them at the general staff building opposite. Don't be put off by the lack of signs for tickets on the outside of this building. Go through the glass doors and the security desk and then you will see a sign for the ticket desk which is a short walk. There was no one here. There are no longer separate tickets for using cameras they have just increased the overall price so you can take photos inside without flash. The price for all day entry to the various museums is 600 rubles and free for under 18. The price to see one museum only is 300 rubles

Excellent private tour!. A must see when visiting St. Petersburg is what everyone says, but this so true! The sun was shining all day and this gave an extra dimension to most of the rooms. Such an impressive museum, which we booked via the hotel were we stayed and the tour guide explained us a lot.

Awesome museum. The Hermitage is one of the best museums you can go to in the world. A truly phenomenal place to visit if you enjoy art and history. The Asian exhibit was good, as was the Egyptian one. The sculpture section was interesting, and the artwork of the rooms themselves (walls, ceilings, chandeliers) is beautiful. I found the Iranian exhibit to be very interesting. As soon as I walked in the room, and was like, "Wow. This is a totally different style of art." From a historical and current events perspective, what a shame that religion continues to ruin incredible cultures all around the world. The art of Iran was very interesting. I am not really into paintings of the despicable people known as Kings and Queens, but there are a ton of pictures of them if seeing human beings that had many other human beings tortured and killed in the name of power is your thing. I spent the better part of 5 hours at the museum, but you could spend a few days if you wanted to. The exhibits are wonderful. I saw three different actual mummies, which I had not seen at any previous museums. It would be nice if they had better quality food/cafes inside. It is pretty subpar for refreshments... Also, the view outside the windows is beautiful, but they have these extra panes of glass which make it very difficult to see or get good pictures of the view outside. Anyways, if you are in St Petersburg, this is a must visit on the list of sites.

WOWOWOW wow, oh my wow!. There is sooooo much to see here. We had a local guide and got the 'highlights' but even that took the better part of the day. Have a water bottle handy and take your time to enjoy all this beautiful palace has to offer. It can get insanely crowded with school and tour groups so be prepared for that.

Great museum pretty complete..... Excellent, so big that you can easily spend half a day here. I only wish there were more signs, guidance, if you don't go with a guide you can easily ms important rooms and important art work.

Art art art. This is a must see and the RUB 600 ticket incl the winter palace and the general staff building which houses works of Henri Matisse, Picasso, Monet.. Sad I missed this opportunity because we didn't research what would be in the building :( Peter's winter palace can be ignored as it was underwhelming, took about 10 mins to skim the rooms :/The Hermitage museum is grand and beautiful all round and you can easily spend 5+hrs there so I advise to eat before you go or after to find a place outside because our experience with the cafes in the museum is quite bad; orange cheesecake tasted like plastic and the sandwiches were hard.

Plan your visit as there are multiple exhibits across multiple buildings. People say you should spend days at the Hermitage and you probably could easily spend a few days seeing all the main things in the main complex alone. But there are also other collections spread across other buildings so plan in advance and make sure you know where to see the things you want to see. Download and app for explanations as there are limited details when inside. Even the free map is sparing with detail and each exhibit has only a name and artist (at least in English). The palace itself is amazing so some of the rooms are simply just to see the palace. The Caravaggio was missing when I was there which was disappointing as this was a highlight for me. It was apparently gone for restoration. 600RUB The line to get in to buy tickets vs those who have pre-purchased can be as long as each other so don't stress if you do not buy in advance. The line to buy tickets moved quickly. There is a restaurant/cafe inside if you are there all day and need food. If you are going there to see Faberge eggs then don't - they are now in the Faberge Museum at the other end of Nevskiy Ave. There is a Da Vinci, a Michelangelo sculpture and heaps of Rembradts & Rubens. A fabulous Canaletto. This is in the main complex. I did not get a chance to go to the other buildings.

The only issue are the crowds. You could spend days here but we only got a 3 hour tour. The museum has art from all over Europe and other parts of the world. The only issue is that it is so popular that it is quite crowded. We were in a 24 person guided group tour with radio headsets. So much to see, so little time.

L'or!!!!. Amazingly beautiful recent renovations and no one there at this time of year - even better! Free movement around the museum enables one to linger and savour the State Rooms and treasures of the former Imperial Russia.
Fabulous museum - you need 2 days minimum. This is an incredible museum but the amount of time given in guided tours is never enough - 2 days needed minimum

Fantastic, unbelieve. Please take a long time for visit this fantastic museum
Choose an special area, forget see all the museum in a unique day
You need a long time, and walking a lot for visit this museum

TOO MUCH FOR A DAY, BUT INCREDIBLY BEAUTIFUL. AND GO TO THE GENERAL STAFF BUILDING!. Don' think you can handle The Hermitage in one day. Try to make a choice with help of the website and pick out some sections. The Rembrandts, The Rubens... you must see them. Realize that the Friday evening the museum opens untill 9 o'clock; we were nearly alone! The General Staff building is completely new and so modern. The paintings have such a good expostion against colored walls. We did this on Sunday morning and belonged to the very few visitors. You have to find your way yourself, not many indications, but on the 3rd floor you will admire the most beautiful Van Goghs, Matisses, Renoirs, Cezannes, Bonnards..... you name it and you will find it! own

You can easily spend a day wandering around this museum.. Buy the tickets on line before you go, it saves time queuing and make sure you pick up a map as it is huge. We spent the whole day here, which was a rainy Autumn day so it was ideal. There is enough history and art for anyone. The impressionist are across the square in the General State Building which is also covered by the ticket price. A great day out.
A must for the first visit. One of the greatest collections in the world it is well functioned, but overcrouded as a Louvre and in a worse condition thana Louvre
The very best gallery+museum in the world.. Beatifully displayedIn astonishing awe inspireing pallace that in itself if empty would be five starAnd full full full of breathtaking pieces.

A must visit Museum in St Pete. I really enjoy visiting the Hermitage. I usually don't like museums but this one is a must see. We had a great guide who show us all the most important paintings and help us understand the art works. It is really crowded in the afternoon so if you can, make this your first stop in the morning.

the most impressive museum of my all life. I booked tickets on internet. You have to redeem the vouchers on the day you want to visit. Just after the big porch, right in front of you, before going into the courtyard of the palace, you will see a small wooden "cabane" hut. There is a sign on it saying internet tickets. It's open at 10.30 sharp. You don't have to wait.The lady will give you your ticket and then you will enter in an other world!!!.... My husband and I looked at photos before going but it's really grandiose!If you want to see the collection of french impressionists ( btw really impressive) it's on the big yellow building opposite side of the palace square. You are using the same ticket if you are going there the same day.so 17 eur for such a treasure it's really nothing.We started to visit the palace apartments, you can follow a very good free map given near the cloackrooms. Check out the wooden floors!! and the ceilings!! and the doors and the door handles.... then we went to see the leonardo da vinci paintings and then the impressionists: total: 5 hours and we just saw a tiny fraction of the Hermitage collectionWow!!ps: we checked the little cafe to find something to eat, forget it it's look horrible and expensive

Love It, Hate It Museum. Let me start by saying that this was the last major European art museum remaining on my bucket list. So I have a lot with which to make comparisons. Over a 3.5 day period I saw every room in this huge museum that was open to the public without a required tour (so I did not see the state treasures). On the Love It side the state rooms of the Hermitage are simply incredible and arguably the most beautiful rooms to hold art that I have seen. The European painting collection is superb. Other highlights for me were the Raphael Loggia, the Canova statues, and the French Impressionist/Post Impressionist art, the Peacock clock, and the Siberian art/art of ancient cultures of the steppe. The latter is amazing and something you will not see in other major European museums. Now for the Hate It part. The museum was very overcrowded with huge numbers of tour groups- much worse than any other European museum we have been to. The day before we went we found ourselves standing outside the Neva river facade waiting for a hydrofoil ride. Looking down the street there were tour buses in a long line as far as the eye could see (ala the warehouse scene at the end of Raiders of the Lost Ark). My husband and I looked at each other with wide eyes realizing that all those people must be in the museum and they were! This was to the point where it interferes with individual museum goers viewing the art as these groups stand in mass in front of the best works of art and pose with the art for photos. My best tip to avoid the mob is to be sure to go on one of the days the museum stays open until 9pm. I did this and the tour groups disappear by 5/5:30 and then it is a normal museum experience. I retook all my photos at this time so there wouldn't be 100s of people in them and was able to stand in front of the Leonardo's and the Peacock clock by myself. Also, to avoid the crowds you should see the Siberian/steppe art and the Impressionist/Post-Impressionist art during the day as these areas are off the beaten track with no tour groups. Another issue for me is that although the exhibit rooms were gorgeous the lighting was often poor. The chandeliers and many windows reflected on the paintings obstructing the view and ruining one's photos. And, the state of some of the paintings was poor- obviously not cleaned in a long time- making them dark with muted colors. This I found quite surprising. The ticket system although new and computerized is a pain. You are allowed only one entry per day so you cannot go out for lunch and the dining options are very,very limited with few tables. Completely inadequate for such crowds!! Also, if you do go to the Siberian wing you cannot then get into the main part of the museum without a very long and convoluted walk upstairs and over the ticketing area. I recommend buying tickets in advance so you can walk in-- the lines are huge from the minute it opens in the morning. Be sure to download the Hermitage apps and maps in advance. There is a self guided tour of the state rooms and major works of art which is very helpful. And unless you have multiple days as I did you will carefully have to decide what to see as it cannot be done in one day.

Impressive. I visited the Hermitage museum after I had visited Catherine's Palace, so I thought that nothing could impress me after that; I was wrong. The winter palace is just as beautiful. The museum collection is quite interesting- from ancient greek and egyptian collection to Leonardo da Vinci's and Rembrant's paintings, but also the building itself is fantastic; there are some private rooms that you can visit and they will totally impress you.
wow!. check out the impressionists, I am sure there are more Picasso, Monet, Renoir and Van Gogh here than other much more famous galleries. Simply wonderful.

Grandiose. Taking into account the fact that students have free entry and the adult ticket is 10 euros this is a must see for all the people that visit Sankt because the Hermitage Museum is unique in the world and has a rich history.
No meseum like it in the world. Stunning collection for the rarest arts. No amount is spared in the collection of the arts. A must see if you are in Saint Petersberg.

Mesmerizing. When I first stepped in, I felt like I was watching a movie! I cant believe how much effort and money was spent to make this place majestic as it is! And what makes it more amazing is that every room has its own spirit! I was blown away

Artists Paradise. There are several million paintings and sculptures on view. You could spend days viewing them and also the magnificent Hermitage itself. Get right up close to these famous exhibits. We were fortunate to be with Alla Tours, arriving earlier than the public viewing time and receiving a guided tour selecting the most famous masterpieces. Unmissable.

As spectacular as you would expect. Remarkable in every way, it is well worth paying the extra 300 roubles to see the Diamond Room. In the same way as the Vatican Museum, it does get a bit much after a few hours and one becomes somewhat blaze. Bear in mind that there are very few loos in this enormous palace and (although it didn't apply to anyone in our party) access doesn't look great for the disabled.
Must see while in St. Petersburg. If you are visiting Hermitage for the first time, you definitely need a guide or at least audio guide, otherwise you will get lost there.
Must visit. Great museum with lot to see. If you have time, it is worth to spend at least one day to see the collections.

Enjoy as much time as you can here!. What an experience! This is truly a museum and a palace in one. You will never have enough time to visit here unless you decide to live here for years. Our guide showed us the highlights and we were thrilled that on the day we were there it was not crowded! Don't stand in line even if you arrive and do not have a ticket. Go around the building to the internet ticket booth, buy your ticket there and just walk in.

Best time to visit Hermitage. Visited the Hermitage over two days starting about 4 pm when the crowds were gone. This was recommended by our tour guide and worked wonderfully. Hard to absorb everything in one visit by anyone's account!
Very beautiful. Very cool museum and the best thing is that there is always something new to see. Every room makes you travel back in time.
Amazing Palace.. A must see for history and art lover. The peacock clock is simply amazing and the various galleries is well worth the admission fees.

Not to be missed. St. P has several not to be missed places -- and this one is on the top. The sheer number of internationally recognized artworks is just amazing and must be experienced. We wait a little on line to get in but it was not too bad.

Family trip. An amazing place to visit, especially if you are into stunning works of are which to be fair isn't really my thing but I was more interested in the build its self. It's a must if ever you go to saint Petersburg but do wear a comfortable pair of walking shoes as the museum is massive and over 3 floors.

One of the greatest museums in the world. I have been to the Hermitage and the Winter Palace many times spending there hours and will go there again and again every time I am in St.Petersburg. If you an arts lover this is the place to go.

Impressionist Galleries WOW. THe Hermitages Impressionist and post Impressionist painting have been moved to new spaces in the eastern wing of the General Staff Building. The space is gorgeous and when I was there EMPTY ... seriously empty. We went there at 10:30 and bought the 600 Ruble combined ticket. There was NO LINE, while the line at the Winter Palace was huge. Then after an exhaustingly fabulous visit in the Impressionist galleries, we walked over the the Winter Palace and were able to skip the lines.Go, and go there first!
Interesting but crowded. Lots of interesting things to see if you are a fan of museums. Unfortunately, very crowded. Bring your student ID if you have one, usually you can get discounts.

Mind Blowing. I would advise you to book a guide, the place is so huge you could easily get lost or miss out on all there is to see.I went with an Alla tour, we had priority early entry and had the place to ourselves - excellent as we had a group of 14, moved around at a leisurely pace and could take everything in. Once the general admission time arrived it quickly filled up, we were glad of an early start to beat the rush. In the summer months it is evidently jam packed and uncomfortable, tours can be rushed as the stewards move people along.The first WOW was the winter palace, such opulence and so much gold - how the rich lived !!! We had time to absorb each room, words cannot adequately describe - YOU NEED TO SEE IT FOR YOURSELF !!! Next came the art collection - once again mind blowing that they have so many paintings by famous artists on open display. Anya our guisde took us from room to room and picked out so many important peieces of art and sculptures it was almost too much to absorb.A fantastic start to our tour of St. Petersburg.

Spectacular. The Hermitage Museum is more than deserving of its legendary status. The fine arts collection is formidable and the building itself, rich in history, has much to offer. Crowds permitting, step back and focus on the floors, the ornate ceilings, the chandeliers, balconies and colonnades. Truly spectacular.
Must go. Russia is very impressive! I didn't entered is the museum because the queue was really long. You better plan before going. :)

Stunning. Went here for the morning with my girlfriend. It was like stepping into Louvre-meets-Versailles and I couldn't believe it. I may have liked the architecture even more than the exhibits, but it was a close call.

A must. if there is a sight not to be missed in St Petersberg , this is it .
Magnificent room after magnificent halls. Gold everywhere, treasures, paintings, sculptures all in fantastic condition . I takes hours but the sore feet are worth it

Amazing. It is hard to believe that someone actually lived in this place at one time. It is so huge and amazing. Right from the front of the building, to inside to the back. The colour of the buildings are just so right for the time period and size of the Palace. You just walk from room to room and can't believe what you are seeing. The best way to do this museum is with a guide or you could get lost or not really know what you are looking at. The tour guides are like little encyclopedia's they are so knowledgeable. When you get to the sculptures and painting they can tell you such detail about each one. You could spend days here depending on your interest in the arts. Ours was more about the architecture, the craftsmenship is so beautiful that it is sad that this art has been lost. You just can't believe from the floors, to the walls to the ceilings the time that has gone into building each room so beautifully. When you see anything gold it really was or is gold. I have dreamed of coming to St Petersburg and seeing this great Palace for years and it did not disappoint in any way.

Not on a tour!. I like to take my own time as a tourist, looking at what I am interested in and therefore don't generally join the big tours. In Russia this can make for some interesting situations. I did some research before going to the Hermitage and knew if I wanted to see the Diamonds and Gold I would have to sign up for specific times and pay extra. At the kiosk on the way in I did that, although it seemed to cause some irritation from the lady doing the tickets. I was assigned some times to go, something like 1:00pm for the Gold Room and 2:45pm for the Diamonds. Since it was only about 11:00 am I went up to the main floor and got an audio guide - it cost about 400 rubles and you put a deposit of 2000 down (or some kind of ID card) that you get back on the way out. The audio guide does not cover everything but works quite well. You need to make sure you do not get in synch with the big tour groups who are going through with a guide talking to them on earpieces. When the guide is talking about the Leonardo de Vinci you have 26 people moving as a swarm to envelop the topic of discussion. The items on display are quite impressive but not quite as much perhaps as the Armoury in Moscow. I ran out of time so I went down to catch my tour at 1:00pm. There was a sign that said wait here for tours of Treasure and something else. I showed the lady there my ticket for the English tour and she said wait here. At around 1:00pm someone arrived and said something in Russian and some people left. I figured for the English tour they would announce in English so I waited a bit longer. after 5 mins or somI asked the lady again. This time she told me for the Gold Room I needed to go out of the secure area and go in another entrance, and she pointed in the general direction. I went out but could only see the entrance back to where I had been. I waited a few minutes and got to a lady at the Information desk. she pointed me through the cloakroom. There was no sign anywhere that would indicate this was the way. At the security check at the back of the cloakroom they had been alerted I was coming because they pointed me down the hall and said go right. I went right and passed a lady at a desk but did not see any signs to Gold room or equivalent. As it turns out this lady at the desk was in front of the Gold Room but perhaps you don't advertise this. When I figured this out it was perhaps 20 min late for the tour. The security person said can you come back at 3:00pm for the next one. I said no I was booked on the Diamond tour then. He then let me in the door to the Gold Room and pointed out the group I should be with half way through. I was able to browse at my own speed and catch up with the group , so all was well.After this I headed back to the original entry for the next tour. Since I had gone out my ticket would no longer scan, so they had to open a special gate to let me back in. I guess this is the way it is supposed to work. I was a little early so I went looking for a cup of tea. I found the cafe. It had perhaps seating for about 15, but was not crowded. The Hermitage has a cloakroom signposted for 3700 people, but a cafe for 15,. If Disney were running the place it would be the other way round. However it worked I got a drink, and headed back for the English tour of the Diamond Room. At the appointed time a lady appeared and announced in English for the tour. We went on a long walk to the entrance of the diamond room. The lady said she had been at the museum for more than 50 years, so she definitely knew her stuff but speed was not one of her main attributes. The Diamond room starts with more Gold trinkets that have been excavated from ancient digs. Since I had just been to the Gold Room I was ready to move on. So I wandered ahead a little to look. The person minding the room was most upset at this and told me I should stay with my tour. Two other folk who had also done the Gold Room were also getting anxious. Eventually I decided to make an escape and left with only a quick look.I suppose the best strategy would be to a) Speak Russian, b) Get a private tour guide so you can go at your own pace but navigate the intricacies or c) Not worry about it. I am a c) person. It was a little frustrating but I saw a lot, probably missed a lot, had a good time so not to worry.

Awesome- Hint to find impressionist paintings. The place is awesome in the true sense of the word - enough said on that in other posts. IMPRESSIONIST PAINTINGSThe guide books don't tell you - the fabulous impressionist paintings are in a new modem exhibition hall in the General Staff building the other side of the plaza.FOURTH floor - took me ages to find them. Well worth the effort.LADIES LOOS. big queues at main places, as usual.Use the ones at bottom of grand staircase in New Hermitage. No queue!

HERMITAGE MUSEUM IN WINTER PALACE (ZIMNIY DVORETS) - A PLACE WORTH VISITING MULTIPLE TIMES.. I visited Hermitage exposition in Winter Palace of Saint Petersburg in the beginning of May 2015 along with touristic group of “Ekletika” agency. It was the final part of an excursion, so our tour guide left us on our own. It’s up to you how long you want to stay in Hermitage. You can be there for hours and still not to see everything, thus it’s better to go back to the hotel by metro or taxi, there is no touristic bus provided. The Winter Palace is absolutely magnificent! It had been re-built and altered almost continuously between late 1730s and 1837, when it was severely damaged by fire and immediately reconstructed. Winter Palace was an official residency of Russian emperors up to 1917. Currently, the restored palace is an architectural complex comprising several buildings and housing Hermitage Museum.My advice would be to come early and choose working days. There are literally crowds of people on Saturday and Sunday. We had to wait outside for almost 40 minutes in queue, and then we had been standing in queue again, but this time in the wardrobe. Visitors are not allowed to enter the museum in jackets or coats, bring food and big bags. You can make photos, but don’t use the flash.If you are a big fan of Arts, this place is definitely a must visit! You'll have a great chance to see the biggest collections of Dutch, Flemish, Italian, French, German, British and Russian artists, enjoy the paintings of Paul Rubens, Diego Velasquez and Thomas Gainsborough, have a glance at vintage interiors and dinnerware of 17th and 18th century as well as appreciate the sarcophagus and hieroglyphs of ancient Egypt.Little tips:The museum is unbelievably big, so get a map; it’s free of charge. Focus on several halls and artists you really want to see. If you don't speak Russian, choose special excursion for foreigners with a tour guide, who will be able to explain you interesting details about the works of arts and the museum itself.Plan to spend the whole day in the museum not to be in a hurry and wear comfortable shoes. You have an option of purchasing a two-day ticket to visit two days in a row.Once you are done with the museum, find a pier across the road, where you can buy a sea excursion to Peterhof Palace or a sightseeing tour across Saint Petersburg Channels and Fontanka River.

Amazing art and Stunning structure!!. We booked into a night tour of this fabulous gallery/museum and we were not disappointed! Agreed, you have less time there doing it this way but the trade-off is you don't have the crowds and with only 30 or so people touring through the many rooms you visit, you are able to get really close to study the artists' skills or stand back and view and photograph the works without anyone getting in your field of view - brilliant!! The security guards accompanying the group were excellent - no rush, no push - in fact, they moved signs and barriers for us to get a better or uncluttered viewpoint! Can't argue with that! And as for our guide, Olga, a Masters Art degree graduate from St Petersburg University - she was outstanding! She told us so many stories about the collection and the artists, she made the evening truly informative, rewarding and memorable.We visited, we saw and it was well worth the journey from Australia.
How many rooms did we see?. The museum is well worth the time, though i have to admit that i found the palace a bit ornate. If you're going during a hot season, go early in the day.

Awesome and un real how big. This place was amazing would take you weeks to see everything. Was blown away with how many painting from all the big name artist they have. The building is self is art. A absolute must see

Stunning palace containing an extraordinary fine art collection.. This stunning palace contains an extraordinary fine art collection numbering in the thousands of objects. Plan to spend 3 to 5 hours touring the Hermitage.

Better than Louvre Museum!. It is beautiful, it seems like you walk through history!
If you can watch the movie Russian Ark before you go here, then you'll appreciate this palace more as you walk through it....

Must see. THE thing to see in S. Ptrsbrg. Allocate at least 4 hours and buy tickets online in advance. It is worth investing in a tour guide or, even cheaper, rent an audioguide for the whole group. Commentaries are short and loud enough for a group to listen to them. You don't need to rent one for every person. Do not go there at the weekend! You will jostle to see anything. But go!

A "must see" in st Petersburg. It's fascinating ,glorious n breathtaking.i couldn't believe this quantity n quality of masterpieces in one place. You are interested in art or not ,should see it.By d way i couldn't finish it in 6 hours.

The perfect place for art and history lovers. The State Hermitage Museum located in the Winter Palace square.It very easy to get there using the public transportation.They offer a private and guided tour in different languages and the prices for the regular entrance is different for tourists and Russian citizens.The museum is really big and have a lot to offer so I suggest you will go there very early in the morning as you can easily spend there a full day, not to mention another tip I have to give is wear comfortable shoes as you have a lot to walk.They have an inside cafe to rest and drink some good tea and grab some cake to eat.There are many groups of tourists visiting this museum during the whole day so I might be crowded during the hot season.The collection of art they have inside is amazing and the place is very clean and organized so this attraction is a must see when you visit Saint Petersburg.

Great value for money. A great museum (in the level of the metropolitan in NYC). We spent there 3 hours easly.We took the "dimond room" tour and we enjoyed that a lot (you can skip the "golden room tour" in our opinion.

Whirwind. Spent our day here, basically just like any other art museum, but a little disorganized with it's layout, which I expect when they turn a building into an art gallery.The reason I'm giving it 3 stars is while it's not my favorite collection worldwide, bu the windows and the glare on the paintings beside them. I couldn't get over there amount of direct sunlight some beautiful paintings are receiving. 3-4 feef from the window, with next to no blocking???C'mon. Epecialy the Spanist artsits, my favorites.
Amazing!!. It is HUGE so impossible to see everything so would suggest to do this with a guide. We saw loads of painting (French, Italian and Dutch) a MUST see in St Petersburg

So much history here. Out of all the places I have visited in Russia, this was by far my favourite place. All of the history in this building was amazing. I spent about 2.5 hours here and it wasn't nearly long enough to see everything. Visiting around this time of year is great because there is less tourists (it was still quite busy though). There is also two original Di Vinci paintings which I managed to see up close which was well worth the visit. Highly recommended
Lots to see needs full day. Lots to see there,definitely would like to spend full day there next time. Also best getting internet ticket as the queues are very long otherwise.

Outstanding. One of the prettiest palaces I have seen by far. Maintained very well and the best part is if you are staying in the central Saint Petersberg, you don't need a car to be there. Best time to visit is June, carry your winter clothes and an umbrella for drizzle.
Imagine the Life of a Czarina. Each room can fit a small 2 story house. Corinthian columns are gold leafed. The stairways are wide enough to fit an entourage. The opulance is beyond any expectation.
Hermitage Museum. You cannot miss this museum. It is full of opulence. There are amazing rooms filled with gold, silver, columns, priceless paintings and gems.

Georgeous. It was the best museum that i have ever seen. Such glorious katherina and petro. Wish you have seen these crowd in the museum from different nationalities, taking photios and admiring at all. Love art, paintings and the watch that katherina was gifted by her boyfriend :) definitely visit!

Watch out for the Golden Bird Clock!. The Hermitage is simply stunning, there's no two ways about it. The building itself, the pieces inside - simply all of it.My family and I visited in July '15 and booked our tickets online; I can't stress how important this is, unless you fancy standing in a queue for two hours (always surprises me how many people do).Once in the museum it is wonder after wonder, the sheer size of the collection is mind blowing and each piece is beautiful in its own right. If fair to say, it's however almost too big. To really give justice to it, a serious amount of time should be dedicated to visiting the Hermitage - or it is likely to go over one's head.For me my personal favourite was the Golden Bird Clock - an incredible piece of craftsmanship and absolutely beautiful. Go look for yourself!

A versailles of Russia!!. It a classic green building with ton of artists painting/ sculptor and country treasure showing inside. Rafael / Leonardo drawing etc. so on. Many room connect one by one to show all arts are. Cannot complete in 1 day tour!! Cloakroom deposit and souvenir shop with museum cd information VTR are for sell.

The best parts of European history. You need to spend some significant time here to do it justice. Also crowds are a definite factor and can slow you down especially in some of the more popular exhibits. There are art works and displays that you won't see anywhere else in the world so make the most of it. There are staff in most of the rooms and although they don't speak a lot of English they will let you know soon enough if you go somewhere you shouldn't or accidentally touch something.
Stunning. A mind blowing experience in a magnificent building full of art treasures and artifices . An essential visit.

Worlds second best art collection. When visiting the Hermitage you are not sure if you should be admiring the ornate and beautiful interior of the palace or the magnificent artwork hanging from the walls - its not named the worlds second best art collection for nothing. Make sure you book a guide to take you around - well worth the expense to make the most of the experience. Set the whole day aside and even plan before what you would like to see, because there isnt time for it all. And get there early - the queues are long, but well worth the wait.

Stunning, Magnificent!. L'Hermitage Winter Palace is a marvellous experience and not to be missed whilst in St Petersburg. Try to get there early since it is always very busy. Wonderful opulent rooms and staircases. Look out for the unique Peacock Clock: incredible!

You will need 5 hours minimum to absorb the Hermitage. I am not an art expert but I spent 5 hours wandering through the Hermitage and left very impressed. It is a must on your St. Petersburg itinerary.

The main Russian museum. The main attraction in St-Petersburg. Visiting this museum you will discover Russian Barokko and collection of masterpieces of worldwide heritage - Da Vinci, Raffael, Rembrandt and etc. If you want to avoid enormous queues arrange a guide visit - it also will be more interesting and really worth it. Unbelievable collection of impressionist is placed in separate building.You can enjoy it without big queues because it was replaced there from the main building not along time ago and not so many people know it.

Great place, but be prepared. Great place as per other posts. I suggest buying a 2 day pass in advance - available online and applies to 2 consecutive days. The place is huge, do your feet a favour and spread out the visit over 2 days. The newer artwork is in the "staff building" ie impressionists, modern stuff ... When we visited there were few signs how to get there. Cross the square to the staff building .... That is the one that is slightly curved with the arch and the horses on top.... Ok .... If you have your back to the hermitage walk across the square and go to the entrance to the left of the arch ... Not in the arch, off the square directly. Ok, now you're in the new building .... Cloak room is on the very bottom floor. Suggest you take lift to the top floor and work your wAy down each floor. No info desk or maps or much in the way of signage when we were there but really worth the effort. Lighting is much better than hermitage.

Don't miss the General Staff building, a must to see the modern collection.. Hermitage is a vast museum, it poses huge challenges, both mental and physical endurance on any visitors.From my personal experiences (visited three times) once followed a cruise tour, and twice on my own, I found it is impossible to see its entirety at one go. Hermitage has a general staff building, across the plaza, as far as I know, new ticket has to be used. one can't use the same ticket after visited the main part. So it is important to do home work about its collections, obtain a museum map in advance and make a plan of visiting route to cover the art works one would like to see in advance. if one arrives during the warm months, expecting to see lots of tour groups and vast amount of visitors. The queue in front of ticket office will be long and a bit of crammed when approaching to the ticket office window. Online ticket bookings rend little advantages, one still need that confirmation to exchange to actual tickets to pass through the automatic ticket gates, there seemed no designated ticket windows for such exchange process, so with the online booking, one will still need to join the normal queue.so if one only has one day for the Hermitage, I will suggest visit the general staff building first, it has impressionism collection, and Picasso and Matisse. if you still have the energy left, and time permits, buy the ticket there for the older part of the museum.

Great Museum, not to be missed. The museum is gigantic. The Guide shows the highlights in three hours which are truly excellent if you do not have any further time and you can barely see clearly with the huge crowds. If you like Museums and I think you can buy a two day ticket, you should go the next day by yourself as you have the orientation day before. My guide avoided the Impressionists which are housed separately but was kind enough to show me the place and I covered them one afternoon. Not many tourists know of them and the Groups definitely do not come. Thank God!

A breathtaking experience. I visited the Hermitage as part of a group in September 2015. Time was limited, but our excellent guide helped us enjoy every minute. The building with its extravagant interior and the artwork of old masters just amazed me. For me the absolute highlight was to see the painting of "the return of the prodigal son" by Rembrandt, after reading a book by Henri Nouwen that was inspired by this painting.

Royal and Great. It's unbelievable place, it was a palace and you will feel the royalty and the greatness inside, this place must be visited. You can't imagine the quantity of the gold stuff inside.it shows the the great history of Petersburg city .

Is Paris really the City of Lights?. First, see the palace at night from the opposite shore of the Neva River. Then ask yourself is Paris really the City of Lights?Second, hire a top rate guide. We used Michael and got him through Elena at Soko Hotel. Third, after you see the Winter Palace go through it again. Fourth, don't miss the da Vinci, Michaelangelo and Rembrandt.Fifth, notice how the art works are displayed.

One of the top 4 Museum in the world. A MUST see!. One could come to St Petersburg only for the Ermitage. The building is amazing, the collection is stunning. You need more than one day and be ready to pick and choose the pieces you want to see. You can see the impressionists' collection in the "staff building" which is a totally must see as well.Order you tickets via internet as the line can be very long and go straight to art pieces you want to see or else you run the risk to be swallowed by the flow of tourists.A dream visit that needs planning. DO NOT MISS IT!

Fantastic Amazing Gorgeous Palace A Wonder. Take 2 days to see this incredible "Winter Palace" of the Czars- Located right on the Neva River, easy walking distance to everything, especialy to Nevsky Prospect Street, which is another review! Russia is amazing, I am absolutely impressed with the people, the place..the history! Read the book about Catherine the Great before you go! Much better to understand some Russian history before the trip, as I did. So Inside this amazing Palace, thanks to Catherine the Great, you will find a treasure trove of paintings, sculptures, wonders of the World..the rooms / staircases alone are spectacular in their opulence and glory that was the typical of the Russian Czars- I don't even know how to put all this into words, but we, both my husband and I were completely blown away by the gorgeousness of this place..take your time, do not rush; it is yours to enjoy! Paintings by Rembrandt, many Italian, German, French, Dutch artists line the gorgeous walls of this palace..one room that is utterly fascinating to me is the chandelier room with the gold Peacock that moves! Fantastic wonderful gorgeous..outstanding- and well worth the effort to go; Bit of Advise, book tickets online! Just google The Hermitage, Before you go which I did; saves those line ups and time! Enjoy! Life is Short!

first thing to do. it is a huge museum with lots of artefacts, hard to see all collections better to start with your priorities, and necessary to have a local guide, you will get lost otherwise many times, some english information provided but not enough
YOU NEED A FULL DAY FOR THIS. Schedule at least a day, superb diamond and gold rooms. well worth a visit and a guide. incredible collection.

Meets very high expectations. Everything you have ever read about the Hermitage Museum is true. It's magnificent , It's spectacular. There is just so much to take in and so much to see. You could spend all day there and not see everything, but in reality your body and brain can only take about three hours, so you need to see the important things in that time. We went on a guided tour and were first group in the door when it opened, ( we got to see the grand staircase before it disappeared under people ) it quickly becomes very crowded, and hard to move around, the floors and ceilings are all very special and need to be looked at, which can be difficult. You can buy a recorded guide but really the only way to make sure you don't miss the most important items in the Hermitage it to go on a guided tour. As with most museums in Russia there is so much to see it can be a very trying experience. But certainly a "not to be missed" experience.

Very Packed Museum, Beautiful Palace!. Huge museum, our tour guide walked us through every room and identified pieces of history, I loved every second of it, however it was packed. The museum as well was very crowded so you don't get to enjoy the paintings as much as you would love to.

Exceptional -- likely the most beautiful fine arts museum in the world. Not only for the collection, which covers almost all countries and periods (with the exception of Russian and contemporary art) but also for the magnificence of the buildings, some of which are reported to have been recently renovated. Moreover the tickets are very affordable (even free on the first Thursday of each month, but beware of long waiting lines!) If you want to see the French impressionists and post-impressionists, you will actually have to cross the Palace Square (and eventually have to wait in yet another line) -- the collection is so comprehensive that it can no longer be fully contained within the Winter Palace complex.

Fantastic, of course!. What more can be said about the Hermitage! Go often, but late in the day to avoid the crush of opening. Be aware your ticket does not allow re- entry. Buy online in advance, don't stand in the massive line!

A surreal Experience.. The Hermitage beyond being an absolutely stunning piece of architecture houses innumerable collections from all over the world. It is impossible to see everything in a single day. There is a collection for every taste from Russian monarchy to Egyptian and everything in between. With so many other landmarks in close proximity there is no reason to miss it.

Atractive building, a bit boring collection.. I prefer smaller collections, like the Chagall museum and Matisse museum in Nice, the Picasso museum in Antibes, the van Gogh in Amsterdam, and I find the Musee d'Orsay, Prado, Louvre, Uffizi, Tate and Museum of Modern Art much more interesting. The collection was a bit boring to me.....The problem with overcrowding wasn't that bad in october, and we bought the tickets at the State Hermitage Hotel, so entering was easy.Inside the building was tired. Blingy, dark and overloaded. Very beautiful from the outside.I wouldn't visit again. Too many oldfashioned portraits of ugly, aristocratic numbsculls....

So Many Art Masters' Works in One Place!. What a thrill to set foot in the Hermitage! We had a guided tour for a couple of hours, and were lucky to have had an early entrance. Our group was the first enter, and we were able to see many works up close and unencumbered. The Ambassador's Staircase was grand, and the palace itself just spectacular. And then to see two works by Leonardo da Vinci right in front of us, well, it was quite memorable. We saw an amazing number of paintings by European masters in our all too brief visit, and sculptures, great-rooms and ornate hallways; even the restroom doors are fancy in here! The golden Peacock Clock was also something to see- extravagant, but lovely.I know we barely scratched the surface (not literally!) of the Hermitage collections, but what we did see is etched in my memory. If you go, have an idea of which section you want to see, and get a guide. There is a maze of buildings and hallways. You could easily waste precious time going the wrong way and exhaust yourself too- there are miles of exhibits here. Sample a bit of the Hermitage and don't rush- there is simply no way to see everything. Just enjoy whatever time you do have; every room we saw had something beautiful or interesting in it!

So disappointed at what we (slightly) could see, after years of anticipating this Museum. Hermitage is HUGE, and when on a tour you can't choose the section you get to visit - so it's "potluck" on what items from their incredible collection you might be lucky to see. IF you can see anything over the thousands of people also touring. We were pushed through rooms in such big groups there was no room to lift your arms to take a photo -- & if you were near the (unnamed foreign country) tourists who never let anyone else close to a painting or an exhibit case, there was no polite way to maneuver. It was a nightmare. The traffic was supposed to flow in 1 direction, but that didn't stop some from reversing course & going back through doors which were jammed with others going the opposite way. We never saw a Faberge egg, never saw a Russian royal jewel, & only heard our guide say there was a Rembrandt somewhere in 1 of the rooms. If you have only one day in St Petersburg, I suggest you go to the separate building where they've moved all the Impressionist paintings --- unless you are guaranteed seeing a better portion of the Museum than we saw. The selection of which area of the Hermitage is open on a particular day can't be controlled by any tour company, & so the 1000's visiting on any day are at the whim of some Russian roulette player. Good luck - & be prepared to forcefully elbow your way to what you want to see.

Incrdeible!. This is an incredible experience. We really did not plan to visit this museum, frankly, because spending hours looking at paintings was not high on our list. BUT......we were convinced to go and are so glad we did. To see original Rembrandt paintings is incredible! You cannot do this museum quickly so pick the few things you really want to see and visit those areas. The building itself is worth the trip. Remember, this was "just the winter palace" for Catherine the Great. If you have the time and are in the area for a while, take the time to go back and see it all. I wish I could.
This is a must. Completely over the top, gold leaf , ornate and the size is unimaginable. You could spend days here to properly see everything

You can't see it all in one day but you can try. One of the highlights of our trip. There was so much to see and if you have time, you will want to go back and see more. The Hermitage Museum is so full of history and the Winter Palace is beautiful.

Simply amazing! Add this to your bucket list!. We were blown away at wonderful art work on display. This is huge and would take a couple weeks to see everything - suggest you plan and research what is of interest to you before arrival. Can be very crowded at time (like the louvre or Versailles) check hours and schedules. They also have a website to purchase items or books. Audio tours or personal guides - helpful to offer history. A real 'jaw dropping ' experience!I highly recommend this.
exceptional construction and art collection. This place is a great building, exceptional restauration work, and an absolutelly amazing collection of paintings.

Worth the trip to St. Petersburg just for this museum!. The Hermitage is one of the top three museums in the world and earns the title and more. We had a private guide which was very worthwhile as many item descriptions are only in Russian. You also have the option of renting an audio tour which I would highly recommend if you visit here on your own. The museum is beyond expectation. The winter palace itself was worth the visit. The opulence of tzarist Russia was surpassed my imagination. The art collection has a huge number of Rembrandts, some Rubens and a separate wing of impressionist artists. You could easily spend the entire day here and be amazed at each room you enter. It is rumored that Catherine the Great once said of the Hermitage that only she and the mice enjoyed the museum, now thousands more can enjoy the vast collection that has become 100 times larger than she created. St. Petersburg is beautiful, but the Hermitage was worth the trip alone. An added bonus is that photos are allowed.
Get there early , avoid the line .. It's a museum on a grandiose scale , picture taking permitted , rest up , you need time to wander and see ...

If you love art, but don't care about coffee. The art collection is extensive, but not overwhelming as in some Museums. Good to visit out of season in order to soak it all in and go twice. Art like this should be taken at a slow pace. Loved the location and space of the café: but they do not know how to capitalize on their uniqueness. Run like a hospital cafeteria (sloppy, mediocre food and beverages, bland décor) . What an entrepreneur could do!

Nice afternoon. The Hermitage is a beautiful museum, very easy to spend an afternoon or a full day here, however if you do not speak Russian and/or aren't an expert in antiquities then a tour/audio guide or very good guidebook is a necessity to full appreciate this museum. We are neither and did not have a good guide to the Hermitage, so whilst we could appreciate a lot, there were some things which we felt we had missed out on and would have understood a lot more with adequate guidance. Come for around lunchtime from 12-1400 for the quitest periods as the tour groups gently trample over you at other times and block out any good views of the artwork or rooms.

Think amazing and prepare to be staggered. The Hermitage is the most incredible institution. It has something and more for everyone's interests. The place is well signed in English. Excellent beverages and snacks. Good value shopping. Very pleasant and helpful people. Efficient and customer friendly organisation. Outstanding heritage brilliantly presented.

Get the two day ticket. This is amazing - and overpowering - so huge - we had to go back a second day - you can get a two day ticket so this must happen a lot. Don't miss the internal church and the Raphael gallery. So many Rembrandts...

Loved Hermitage Museum!. I truly was impressed with the Museum. We were there in September where there were not too many tourists. Discovered my love for fine art and Russian history and architecture.

Impressive. It is definitely one of the greatest attraction in the world. I visited this museum in during Russian new year, it was very cold and snowy and it was of course a marvellous postcard that will always be impressed in my mind.

Worth a visit.. my only recommendation is to either organise a tour guide or get a hand held audio guide. Very difficult walking through the museum without knowledge. Though it is said that it takes about 4 hours. We were able to do this in 2 as we were particular in what we wanted to see.
Hermitage meusam is the best place. It was incredible place recommend this place who like art and historical thing actually l and my family enjoy ed visiting this meusam

Wow factor. A day is not enough... Is all o e can say!!Get in early as you will discover there is art of every discipline, from almost every art period to be viewed in a breath taking setting.I was excited to see ceramics by Picasso after a reading a book a few months prior to our visit, on Picasso.One of the best collections of art I think in the entire world... A top spot to visit on any respectable art lovers bucket list... You will leave exhausted but inspired.I will go back one day to see parts of the museum that we ran out of time to see.Should be top of Trip Advisor's list... But needs more visitors I guess to get there! Been to MOMA twice and stll think Hermitage tops!My visit was in 2008, cost was high then, but I am glad to have dished out the cash and will do so happily again.

Hernitage Museum. So overwhelming and soo gorgeous!! We were there "off season" and the Asian tour groups are OBNOXIOUS!! They will roll over you to get wherever!! And, I am married to an IMMIGRATION ATTORNEY!! I cannot imagine how crowded and pushy it would be IN SEASON!!!!
Stupendous!. History at its finest. All of the art you need, plus the charm of the surroundings. Be careful about tours that surround, they can spoil the experience.
Art Travel Trip. This is a place you have to see once in your lifetime. Incredible all this art and wonderful furniture and decoration. It is a very important place in Russian history.

Overwhelming. I was on a guided tour and really over-loaded with information. I visited in June 2015 and the Winter Palace was busting at the seams with tourists. I was told there is no off season. Beautiful rooms, gilt, paintings, furniture, ornate ceilings, all fantastic and well maintained. A half day did not do it justice.
