Very Wealthy. Well it is very hard to describe this beautiful palace which has been reconstructed after the war with all its splendour. They are very strict about no flash cameras and where you can go! But very worth a visit.

Russia's Hermitage Museum. I visited this incredible museum in the early fall of 2014. The palace itself is a masterpiece and almost takes away the beauty of the artwork. Your are completely overwhelmed by the ornateness of the building, halls, rooms, and art. Do not miss the golden peacock. I would suggest a private guide to help you navigate the museum. It is very crowded and they can help you get the most of your time there.

A Must See. Fabulous collection of art with something for everyone. From Michaelangelo to Rembrandt and everything in between. Need a full day just to see the highlights. Go early as tour groups are given priority access. Stunning architecture as you stroll from building to building.
Exceptional place to visit. A beautiful set of buildings. Inside there is so much to see. This does not disappoint and is a must see when you visit St Petersburg.

A world heritage site that is a destination attraction. One of the worlds greatest heritage sites, beautifully preserved and maintained. You should consult a guide book as this space in not adequate for a review. Truly remarkable

Totally, overwhelmingly stunning. The opulence of the rooms defies description. We also had a knowledgeable guide who gave a brilliant commentary, putting it all into its social and historical context. In the space of a few hours, we were able to see priceless artefacts and artworks, including Rembrandts, da Vincis, etc etc. The entry cost was amazingly reasonable, and the souvenir kiosks sold art books and memorabilia also at very reasonable prices. We were glad that we went quite early in the morning, as by lunchtime, the crowds of tourists from all over the world had built up so it was getting difficult to move around. You really need many visits to see the various collections, or target very carefully what you really want to see.
hermitge. You cant do this justice in a day. Its vast and the Faberge collection is very interesting as is the history behind them
Link to history. Maybe the most interesting and fascinating museum I've ever been to. Size of the palace amazed me and all the exhibitions left positive impressions

In top 10 of museums in the world. We arrived in St Petersburg on a cruise boat. We took a panoramic tour of the city in the morning then went back to the Hermitage in the evening. P and O had arranged for an evening visit to the museum when it was closed to the public. it was just brilliant. 80 of us had the museum to ourselves and had a one hour guided tour of the top exhibits. The paintings and rooms are just splendid (luxurious to the extreme, one might say obscene if you think of the poor masses?). The tour was followed by a wonderful classical concert (40 piece), just an hour and well known stirring music), just loved it. Finally, we had a glass of Russian champagne. What an evening; couldn't be bettered.

Great, large, special: The Hermitage. Open door: this is an extremely nice museum! One should see this of course. The art, but don’t forget to have a look at the building itself. The collection is extraordinary; many, many famous paintings, i.e. Rembrandt, ….., Picasso, ……. Further all kind of subjects, ceramics, furniture, Greek, Roman, ……. Too much to see.

The Hermitage Russia - Home of the Golden Peacock Clock and So Much More. The Hermitage is one of the oldest and largest museums in the world. In addition to including the former residence of the Tsars (the Winter Palace), it has four buildings to explore. While it isn't visually stunning architecturally, it contains works of various masters (Rembrandt, Titian, Renoir, Monet, Michelangelo) as well as sculptures by Rodin. The Jordan staircase is everything people say it is. Very impressive. And make sure you check out the Golden Peacock clock. Definitely one of a kind and amazing in both it's simplicity and complexity.To really get the most out of a visit here I recommend taking a tour or getting a guide that is knowledgeable. The books are nice, but to hear the stories behind the paintings really increases one's appreciation. We were fortunate enough to take a tour with only 300 other people. It sounds like a lot - but nowhere near the crowds they get daily. Plan to arrive early and leave late. And then want to go back again as soon as possible.

Most beautiful palace in Europe. By far the nicest palace I have visited across Europe. The quality of the furnishings (every room is furnished) is exceptional and surpasses Versailles by a mile. Unfortunately when we went it was crowded with inconsiderate visitors

WHAT'S BETTER THAN "EXCELLENT"?. I have seen many impressive collections and palaces, such as Versailles. However, none can compare to this opulence and grandeur--I am speaking of the Winter Palace. Everything is over the top without coming off as "Las Vegas" excess. Elizabeth I was responsible for most of the gold--her decor style? "Always add more gold." The craftsmanship of the wood parquet, inlay, & marquetry, not to mention the lapidary skills used in the configuring of massive decorative objet d'art, columns& furnishings. So much malachite was used in this palace and other places in Saint Petersburg that there is no more in the country. And OMG the ART! Just incredible. Huge massive canvases commissioned for the place. Entire collections purchased from lifelong collectors. After spending days looking at tons of icons in many beautiful churches and cathedrals, the private cathedral at the winter palace held (in my opinion) the two most gorgeous and extravagant ones. There is much too much to see! If you have been to Egypt, skip that section. If you have viewed the Greek & Roman collections at The Met, you can skip that. I did not get to see, but think it would be worthwhile to see the lapidary collection--separate price/entrance. This deserves a rating over five stars!

Stupendous!. It's everything they say it is. Arrange a guide in advance so you can beat the crowds and have the space to enjoy the magnificent artwork. You could spent a week and still not see everything. Don't try to see everything. Take occasional breaks. Go to the café and sit and have a snack.

again and again. YES.. you never got enough of hermitage. seeing it as a building of stunning interior and exterior decorations that the tsars lived and ruled in is one side. the other side of it is the vast collection of art filling those halls. your eyes will shine seeing such splendor in completion. they offer fantastic temporary exhibitions as well. I'd like to note that hermitage is not only 'ancient' art, but contemporary as well. a very fine mix.

Very impressive. Not to be missed!. We signed up for a private tour of the Hermitage with a concert performed by a local orchestra through our cruise ship. It was an amazing way to experience the Hermitage. During normal business hours, this museum is extremely crowded and it's hard to really enjoy the visit. At night, with approximately 100 people, it was ideal.
The Art & Architecture are Fantasic. What a joy to see so many treasures in one place. You just can't go to St. Petersburg & not spend time here!

Grandure, beautful. Be prepared for a crowd if it is tourist season. My first trip here was in 1982 and there were few crowds. That Leningrad but today it is one of the number attractions in the Baltic. Learn history and royal indulgences of the 17th century. Should be on top of your list if for no other reason to see how excessive the gap was between royalty and real life.

Thanks Seattle for the tip!. On the day of our visit, it was raining and we expected the Hermitage to be mobbed. We met a family from Seattle and they told us to go across the Palace Square to another entrance for the Hermitage and buy tickets for both sides of the Hermitage. Great advice! We had no line and were able to see the Hermitage's Impressionist collection as though we were at a private art show. It was amazing. Once we were done, we went across Palace Square to the Winter Palace entrance, avoided the long lines for ticket purchase and enjoyed the exhibits there, albeit it was much more crowded. Still seeing these treasures was a highlight of our trip.

Cultural landmark. This museum is so overwhelming, it's worthwhile to see it with a guide. We were able to see it as part of our tour with Alla Tours and our guide Olga was instrumental in our enjoyment of this cultural landmark; she knew a lot about art in general and greatly enhanced our experience. Also, you can get in early with a tour, and knowing where all the significant pieces were located meant we didn't waste any of our precious time backtracking to find something we may have missed. We found three hours here to be sufficient. Although you could spend more time, you'll be on overload if you try to do too much here.
Up there with Louvre, National Gallery and Metropolitan Museum. . If you spent only 3 minutes in each exhibit, you could be there 40 years. Just enjoy what you can and don't obsess over the rest.
all that glitters,here it is,plus some fine paintings.. More gold gilded stuff than las vegas. Too much to really see in one day...but another don't miss stop.

A must-visit in Petersburg. This is one of the largest museums in the world. It is a palace converted into a museum. This has a vast and diverse collection of arts and artifacts from across the ages. For museum buffs, this place requires atleast a full day to explore. At the least you require 3-4 hrs to even run through the museum.
Unbelievable Displays. It would take you weeks to see all the exhibits but it's a must see if you visit St. Petersburg. The grandeur of the inside is awesome.

Breathtaking rooms in which to view outstanding paintings. Whereas many art galleries are functional and one goes to them to see the paintings, the thing that makes the Hermitage to be absolutely unique is the rooms themselves. My breath was taken away as we moved from one amazing room to the next taking in the walls, floors and ceilings in each. And on top of that were some truly priceless paintings. There was also the Winter Palace to see, where the Provisional Government of 1917 was overthrown by the Bolsheviks.

Stunning and Spectacular. This is one of the most amazing museums in the world. It is enlightening walking in this museum. It houses some of the greatest artistic masterpieces in the world. The biggest surprise for me was that the artwork is not the only highlight. The architecture and design of the museum is also a work of art unto themselves. There are not enough words to describe what a joy this visit was for me.

State Hermitage Museum & Winter Palace. 6 of our group visited the Museum. We had a guided tour but we were told it would take 7 years to go and see all the exhibits. This is the main place to go in St Petersburg. Stunning - and there are SO MANY exhibits from paintings, statues, porcelain, and general opulence. You can understand how much money they spent and why there was a revolution !!!

Gold leaf interior and marvelous paintings, plus an architectural treasure. Lines were too long - 30 minutes wait .. One must visit the Hermitage Museum, it is one of the most beautiful buildings in the World. Needed more time inside, and would like to see the Impressionist paintings, which were in another building. Saw them in the 1980's though. Hope to return.

It's really impressive. It is too much to see on one visit; at the very least take a long day to walk around and just take it slowly, trying to escape the insane crowds that are pushing to see the "famous" paintings

Stunning and NOT to be missed.. Although the ticketing system is confusing and poorly organized, the Museum is worth any hassle and any wait. This would have to be the most stunning, beautiful and sumptuous building I have ever seen. Its extensive rooms and world class exhibits are numerous and would require a week to do it justice. Dont miss it, no matter what.

Spectacular and truly awesome. Pictures do not do justice to the exhibits or the absolute magnificence of the museum and buildings. It is at times overwhelming when you consider the history attached to the site.
I strongly recommend to everyone that this is a must see, if you have been debating you must go!
Amazing!!!

Fabulous, one of the best museums on the world. So much to see, it has been said that it would take 10 years to see everything.
Huge museum, so much history, so much to take in.
Lines are long, have to put booties on, the floors wooden.
Amazing museum. A mixture of architecture, culture,art and colors. This should be planned as a half day visit otherwise you won't enjoy it.

Great place but see Impressionists in General Staff Building. Everything was great except: Information about new Impressionist museum across the street is not updated in brochures and apps. Ventilation in Hermitage is terrible.
Hermitage Museum St.Petersburg. Beautiful palace to visit and so much was spent on these buildings and contents when others were barely able to be fed and clothed.

Beautiful . Beautiful palace and huge collection! It cam be quite busy though and not make your visit too pleasant.To give you an idea of how many people visit yhe Hermitage, the cloak tooms can accomodate almost 5000 coats!
So best time to visit would be off season.

Why queue?. Ostentatious and beautiful: full of wondrous rooms and objects but so sad when set aside the suffering of the masses.Everyone appears to join an enormous queue (it was at least 100 yards long and it did not move in the 10 mins that we waited in it). On-line tickets require that you swop your voucher for a ticket (approx.100 in that queue) and then another long queue to enter the Hermitage).TIP: Just through the arch, on the right as you enter the courtyard, there is a ticket machine. The instructions are in English and it costs 600 rubbles to buy a ticket. We bought tickets (NO queue) and walked to the front of the hot, exhausted seething mass of tourists: to our surprise and relief we were just waved in! So I would suggest you just turn up and use the machine: less than 5 mins to purchase a ticket and be inside the Hermitage! We found this to be the case at most tourist sights: long queues at the ticket office but no one using the machines! So always look for the machine and avoid the queues.

Art haven. Wonderful museum with masters. One full day is enough to appreciate it for most people.
FYI: there is not a good gift shop other than the one upstairs inside the museum, so if you want more than simple things do your shopping there before you exit.
Words cannot describe how beautiful!. Must see attraction. Definitely top 5 within the city. Can spend many hours lost within the buildings. Worth the purchase price.

The Hermitage... something for EVERYONE!. Stunning place! You could spend days here and not see everything! This museum is literal gold mine. If you love wonderfully decorated rooms filled with historic significance and antiques, its perfect for you!If you love museums stocked with priceless art, it's perfect for you!If you love looking out of the window onto famous landmarks that feature throughout the grim fascinating history of the soviet empire, it's perfect for you!This had a story for every room, not to mention Michaelangelos, Da Vincis, Rembrandts and even ancient Egyptian mummies! The building itself is a historical piece of art! The Hermitage is only 15 minutes from the cruise port in the centre of St Petersburg. I must say, this place is full of steps and endless rooms, so you really should wear comfortable shoes and bring a bottle of water. The place is always busy so be prepared for crowds by leaving heavy bags and personal items in the coach or in your hotel. TOP TIP: Visit in the morning when it is slightly quieter.
Great but very European. Breathtaking and awe-inspiring building and collections - but my feeling was that I'd rather see more pure Russian works while in Russia.

It's why you came to St. Petersburg!. Hire a guide, and let them help you plot out a visit. You want to see the state rooms and some art on your first visit. We were there for over 4 hours and only saw a tenth of the entire museum. Be prepared for endless crowds and bus loads of tour groups.

The jewel of the Baltic. I have wanted to visit St Petersburg for many years, last year I tried and didn't get a visa, I'm ex military, and the Russians aren't that keen on ex military having a visa..!!!?So this time went with P&O aboard the Adonia, it was a Baltic cruise with two full days in the city, so anyone who has trouble obtaining a visa, go with P&O and you get into the country with the ships block visa system.We had an evening tour of the Hermitage, only P&O passengers with a guide, what a fantastic way to see the inside of this magical building, plus no queuing, you stand up to two hours to get into here during the day.. Beware !!!I've been into many many palaces in my travels, but the Hermitage is one of the top five in the world, it's breathtaking to see the decor and fittings, plus it holds millions of artefacts.I don't think any words can describe just how beautiful the hermitage is, you just have to see it to believe the colours and grandeur of it.We ended the tour with an hour long concert, given by the St Petersburg state orchestra, in one of the grandest rooms I've ever been into, a memory I'll always cherish as one of the best trips in my life.I would recommend a trip here to anyone, its a bucket list place to visit.
Spectacular. Much like Louvre in Paris this place is way too big to take in at once. After 2 hours you have barely scratched the surface and you are exhausted. Every room is small museum in itself.
Master piece of art and history . Probably the best museum in the world. Three million art pieces mostly by Russian artist and few by non-Russian including Michael Angelo.

A must see for St.Petersburg . To buy tickets from inside is a mess. The queue splits to 2 in the garden but the signs are not clear to reach ticket booths from right queue. High heeled shoes are forbidden as all floor is wood. Got in at 11:00 and all tour completed by 15:00 without any special attention. If you plan to visit additional palace, second day is required. Also 600 rubles price for standard museum tour includes photo shooting permit.
Quite a Palace!!!. This is a must see in St. Petersburg. We had a grand visit there while on tour with SPB tours. The detail is unbelievable!!

A huge collection of art. This museum is huge, comparable to the Louvre and the British Museum, so it is extremely difficult to cover everything. I chose to focus on Russian and European art and that took at least an hour an a half. So, if you like classic art go for it, if not, move on!

Historical and comprehensive. The Hermitage is the centre of cultural and historical St Petersburg. The collections are extensive and international in flavour. It has art, sculptures, artefacts and oodles of history throughout its extensive and rambling rooms.
The are two areas that could be improved - the café (which was too small providing poor quality food) and the museum map which was unclear.

The Reason we Came to St petersburg. Room after Room of wonderful works, and the beauty is that even if there are lots of people around you do not feel crowded in, or part of a conveyor belt, in other words you have room to get up close and read the details
Hermitage!. Fascinating. Could spend days there. By going with a guide you get in earlier so can see exhibits clearly.
Worth the Price of the Tour. You could never cover it all in a day, take a tour and allow them to show you the highlights. Amazing!
order.. fabulous place and incredible sense of artistry. i was mesmerized in how effective this place is run -- irrespective of its size.

A Survival Guide for touring the Hermitage.. Let me start off by saying that this review is not for those traveling on some formal tour of Russia or tourist from cruise ships who have only a day or two in port. Rather this Survuval Guide is for those independent travelers who want to set their own pace and agenda.As so many have already commented and I will verify...the Hermitage is overwhelming.... Not only the artwork but equally important the architecture and furnishings. During my visit to St. Petersburg I spent approximately 8 hours touring both the Hermitage and the General Staff Building. I spent 5 hours during the first day just touring the top floor of the Hermitage and the 2nd day I spent 3 hours visiting the Diamond Room and the Impressionist Collection within the General Staff Building....a MUST see !!!Tour OrganizationYou have three options...you can hire a personal guide ( I'll explain about personal guides in my review...A Survival Guide of the Russian Palaces ) , you can rent an audio guide...or you can do what I did....research on line which pieces of art work you really want to see , print out the description and tour in your own. This may sound like a lot of work....but their are websites that list key pieces of art, a nice description of each and where in the Hermitage they are located. The advantage of creating your own tour is that you can pace yourself and only focus on what interests you.Being a photographer I also wanted to linger in a room and take it all in ......and I do mean taking in all the grandeur. The photo ops were great. When you thought one room was over the top , the next room just seemed to be even more spectacular. All too often people are rushed from one room to another to see pieces of art without looking closely at the room itself...be it the floors .... each room seemed to have a different inlet, the ceilings , the columns, the chandeliers or the walls....The Hermitage really consists of multiple attached palaces.....most of the rooms are numbered right above the doorway so it is relatively easy to find your way around. In addition the museum has an excellent map of the museum in English and a variety of other languages. And have no fear.....if you do lose your way as I did a few times....each room has a guard and in all cases they were very helpful pointing me in the right direction despite my speaking a word of Russian.You can also go the route of getting an audio guide....I was told that to take the entire tour would be about 3-4 hrs....of course you can skip art pieces along the way....again, I felt I had enough information about the 50 or so pieces of art I wanted to see not to have to buy an audio guide.Lastly ...given that you will be on your feet for hours...note that throughout the Hermitage there are plenty of places to sit and recharge ones batteries.Getting TicketsI would strongly suggest you getting the discounted two day tickets that allows you entry to the entire museum excluding the Gold and Diamond rooms.The museum is closed on Monday so you will need to check if the ticket is valid for a Sunday and Tuesday given that you must visit the museum on consecutive days.It is hard for me to fathom anyone trying to tour the entire museum...or at least the rooms and specific pieces of artwork without being totally exhausted.... There is just sooo much to take in. Again, I suggest you pace yourself and cover the museum over two days.Note...if you get your ticket on line you only need to show it at one of the ticket booths....there are internet ticket booths that are staffed just inside the front entrance...These may offer shorter lines then waiting to buy a ticket...make sure to bring some form of ID ...your passport or a copy of your passport pic...you will need to show that to have your online ticket verified.For the Gold and Diamond rooms you need to get your tickets the day of your visit and I am pretty sure you must buy it in person. There are only 3 tours a day of each room . I was unable to your both and when I asked at information which was better..I was advised to tour the Diamond Room which I did. Now....the museum opens it's doors at 10:30..... I arrived at the Museum at 9:30 and found only 5 people in line. At 10 AM the front gate is open ...at that time there were about 50 people waiting in line.....clearly not all were waiting to buy tickets for the Gold or Diamond Rooms.... You enter the museum courtyard...it doesn't matter if you go to the right or left you will have to stop and wait in line again for the museum itself to open at 10:30 ....then you proceed inside and there are 3-4 booths selling tickets for both the Hermitage and Gold and Diamond rooms.TimingOn my first day I arrived at the museum around noon and found it relatively empty...absolutely no lines at all. This could have something to do with the chill in relations between Russia and the West. In fact I saw very few westerners during my stay in St. Petersburg. The vast majority of organized tours consisted of Chinese and Japanese tourists.Note that I said I arrived around noon....this could also be a reason why the museum was relatively empty.... I say relatively in that the second day I went, at 10:30 AM ..it was considerably busier.My thinking is that tour companies want to get their touists into the museum early and then have them get out by lunch time...or they arrive in the museum after their lunch around 2 PM ...not sure how true this is but for myself arriving around noon I found the fewest number of tourists. On the following day when I took the Diamond Room tour at 2 PM I found it considerably more crowded.Now, this may be going to an extreme..... but I also checked on line for the number of cruise ships in port ..... I figured that the more cruise ships in port, the more crowded would be the top two attractions.... Peterhof and the Hermitage. I selected those days that had the fewest cruise ships for visits to these two sites....again all this information is easy enough to find on line.The General Staff BuildingHere is one of the most pleasant surprises of all.... For anyone interested in the Impressionist and post Impressionst art periods.... And who doesn't .....then DONT leave out a tour of the General Staff Building. This is the semi-circular , yellow building, broken down the middle with an archway that faces the Hermitage.When facing the staff building with the Hermitage at your back...the wing to the left is the one that houses the impressionist collection. The entrance is easy to find once you walk over.How many times can you say that you entered a museum and found yourself in a room filled with Monets or Van Goghs or Kandinskys and you had the room entirely to yourself !!!Yup..... This museum is a ghost house...during the 2 hrs I spent only one tour group went through. Again I can only guess why this is..... My guess is that the museum rooms are bland...just plain rooms..in contrast to the ornate rooms of the Hermitage. Tour companies probably prefer to hit their customers with the WOW factor of the ornate ness of the rooms of the Hermitage as well as through in some choice pieces of art. In contrast...a tour of the General Staff building can only focus on the WOW factor of an unbelievable collection of impressionist arts but that's all....no spectacular rooms at all.The Diamond RoomThe Diamond Room tour I would rate as a 3 star .... I much preferred viewing the collection at the Faberge Museum. The difference being you could not linger and look at the pieces in detail....the guide had to complete the tour within an hour so you always had to keep moving.The one advantage of this tour is that you first enter the Diamond Room via the Gold Room....and the guide does spend time hoping over a few of the beautiful ancient pieces before proceeding into the Diamond Room.Gift ShopI spent a good week walking the streets of St Petersburg....and other then seeing the poor quality if tourist gift shops selling the all so common nesting dolls, average quality miniature painted boxes and the enamel replicas of the Faberge eggs .... There wasn't a single shop I wanted to buy anything at...... Accept the Hermitage Museum store.I found a variety of gifts for both children and adults at the museum store .... good quality and well priced.

Must see, must go. Hermitage & Winter Palace are incredible. No words to describe the beauty. Definitely one of must-sees. Since the art collection of Hermitage is huge, I would recommend visiting it several times if you can. The only thing which imho felt a bit wrong was placing modern art compositions / installations in one of restored tzar halls. For me it created dissonance. I would rather enjoy beautiful architecture and interiors of the palace.. Again just imho

tiring but rewarding. The Hermitage, we all know what to expect but in reality it is awesome, thank goodness our guide, who was very informed on all the sites we visited, supplied us with headsets from SPb tours otherwise our visit could have been ordinary. just another plus from SPb tours.

Crowded, but deserves a visit or two or three.. A museum in a museum. The collections are incredible (the impressionists are no longer in the main building) but what is worth is also the architecture and all the furniture that is still visible. Minimum 5 hours just to get a taste.

Breathtaking beauty. Try to get there before it opens to the public to see when it is quiet. A private tour with Insider Tours allowed us to do this and the feel of having the place to ourselves left us without words.

Don't miss it even if you go for 1-2 hours. Since there are 500 rooms in this Museum in different buildings, and if you are there for a short visit, please go to the Rembrandt's collection, the Pavillion Hall, the Italian Room, the Raphael Logias, Mallachite Hall, Peter the Great's memorial throne, and try to go by the Jordan staircase which leads to the east wing palace. Don't miss the Golden Peacock clock

Too little time to see it all. Enormous building with so many different exhibitions. Don't expect to see it all in 1 day. There is something interesting for everyone. Even if you don't like paintings. The building itself is impressive.

Hermitage at night. Wow, what an experience. Visited at night which was good as it was cooler and only about 500 people in total where there. Our guide was excellent. The magnificent collection of artwork and the opulence of the rooms will never be forgotten

Hermitage - tickets. Forget hype about tickets - just go in through front gate and on the left of the entrance are several ticket machines in English where you purchase the tickets, which accepts 50, 100 and 1000 rouble notes. Tickets are 600 roubles each. Then you will see three railed rows, the left for tour groups, the middle for individuals i.e. non tour, and on the right those with tickets - take the right side row and just present your ticket at the entrance through the revolving door. Don't miss the Jordan stairs, peacock clock room (chimes at 7 pm on Wednesday only - which is late closing day at 9 pm) and take the diamond/gold room tours(extra cost)
Unbelieavable. Wonderful! in one of the world's largest and oldest museums in the world. There are innumerable masterpieces by greatest artists of the history.
hemitage. a definitely must see. be prepared to spend at least half a day. it is a beautiful palace worth seeing. no need to buy tickets on line. show around 10:30am and get you tickets.

Outstanding!. I spent just over 4 hours in the museum with an excellent guide and still barely scratched the surface. It is important to get there early as many people visit this attraction. If you are traveling by land perhaps the afternoon would be better after the cruise ship tours leave. Definitely take a guide with you, they are invaluable. Do some research before you go to prioritize your visit.

So much more than a great museum.. You need at least a half day here. Masterpieces by Picasso, Raphael ,Rembrandt, Van Dyke,Leonardo plus classical and oriental art are stunning. Even more impressive are the wonderful rooms in the Winter Palace, the Old and New Hermitage. The rooms are vast,beautifully decorated and the granite Atlantes columns 16ft tall form a wonderful huge corridor. We were fortunate to have an excellent English-speaking guide who was able to show us most of the important items in the half day. It was crowded but not unreasonably so, since the area is so vast. Bear in mind that legend has it that t would take a visitor 11 years to see all the exhibits. It is amazing that this wonderful grand assembly of buildings survived the ravages of WW2.
Art from all Europe are here. I spent 7-8 hours in this museum, but still not in details of each room.Should queue early morning because you have to take times in queuing.

Don't forget Impressionists across the street. Must see while in St. Petersburgh. Incredible architecture and exhibits. One dissapointing thing is that many titles are not transalted in English and many exhibits do not have description other then title. Also official pamphlets have not been updated to reflect that 19 and 20 cetury exhibits (Impressionists) are across the street in the General Staff building. That collection is as impressive.
sight seeing. a must to see in St petersburg. huge collection of paintings. good walking shoes because you'll be spending hours there.
Fabulous . Great one !!! It needs at least one full day and there are extraordinary arts !!!! You can go by yourself or by group , you can provide audio guid .
fantastic. I liked it all an experience I will never forget it was no adisappointment hard on the feet but you expect that

One day is not enough. We visited this as part of a tour. One could spend years in the Hermitage and not see all of the masterpieces. Best way to visit is with an organized tour where the guide can take you to the most noteworthy pieces of art. Stunning museum!

Unbelievable . Everyone knows that this is one of the great museums of the world.........but it still was such an awe inspiring visit! It makes Versailles and the Vatican pale in comparison...Try to book a private tour guide, as it makes the visit faster ( less waiting in queues and getting lost ) and much more enjoyable. Wear very comfortable shoes!

One of the Greatest Museums of the World!. The Hermitage is so large and has such an extensive collection that one needs to prioritize well as one could spends days and weeks and still not see everything. We hired an English speaking local guide who takes groups through the Hermitage almost daily. He was able to tell what was available and worth seeing and then navigate us efficiently. He took us around and showed us all the highlights in about 3 hours. One needs to make reservations ahead of time to avoid lines - your guide or tour company can do that.

Too many people. Yes this is one of the most impressive museums with an mind blowing amount of art work and historical artifact which you just cant see even a tiny proportion of during one visit. However my trip was ruined by the huge queues and the miles of tourist groups plugged into their translator leading with an stick in the air to follow barely looking at the art around. Very sad sight.

Impossible to take in. The view of the Winter Palace outside from Palace Square is stunning, but it doesn't begin to prepare you for the inside.If you put aside all your prejudices and just enjoy the palace for what it is, you will be astounded at the grandeur and opulence, the detail and craftsmanship.This is worth a day of anyones life. I am rarely impressed by anything manmade these days, but this is an exception.

A lot of walking but worth it!. The most important thing is to buy your ticket online in advance. The queue/lines are unbelievably long and when you have a ticket you simply walk to the entrance. Buy an audio guide it's worth it. Wear comfortable shoes and cool clothing, it's very hot inside. Plan what you'd like to see as you could just have an overload of pairings. The view over the Neva is sublime, what luxury they must've had! You're allowed to take photos. The golden pheasant clock is the most stunning piece! Take a break midway and have a coffee and cake. State rooms and offices not as good but still worth a look. Plan your days there and if the weathers inclement do this trip first off.

Breathtaking. A dream come true. I have wanted to visit St.Petersburg and especially the Hermitage for many years. It was worth the wait...The sheer beauty of this extraordinary palace is breathtaking. The collection of Russian, Italian, French and Spansh art is awesome and very well displayed. Although crowded, you can visit the palace in an orderly and organized fashion, especially if you have hired a guide, as we did.

So Much to See it will take your Breath Away. Had the opportunity to tour the highlights of the Hermitage as part of a tour. While I'm sure we only touched the surface, what we saw was awe inspiring and a bit overwhelming. What a stunning collection of art, furniture, sculpture....well, you name it and the glitz is there. It was awesome that our tour was able to beat many of the incredibly large crowds. This made the visit more enjoyable as we weren't fighting our way to see the exhibits. Definitely should not be missed if you go to St. Petersburg.

MUST SEE - One of the greatest museums and palaces worldwide. The Hermitage is part of the Winter Palace and houses an exhibition that is so huge that you can impossibly see all within one day. Tickets are expensive and cost around 40 Dollars. In case you are an art lover it would take you around three days to enjoy most that the Palace has to offer. Such tickets are even availabe and -revisited- I would seriously consider that. It took me hours just to finish the extensive Rembrandt collection on one floor, let alone there are other apartments and 2-3 more floors with the greatest paintings imaginable up to Pablo Picasso. The Palace residence tour itself includes so many rooms with the richest furnishing, decoration and most precious items you could think of. The internal splendour of the winter palace tops any display of aristocratic decadence by far and outshines all other palace residences I have ever seen. Revolution-provoking splendour it is in fact and stunning. The Winter Palace and its Hermitage alone are worth all the journey to Russia. A must-see worldwide.

mindblowing. incredible magnificence what a tresure.you seriously should save an entire day to even begin to savour this collection.not only suoerstars such as monet picasso da vinci;almost every culture has galleries

Spend a day in the Hermitage. When we were planning our 40-day backpacking trip around Russia and Europe, we really allotted one full day to explore The Hermitage. The collection was amazing! 9 hours was not enough. Just a tip: Come early, and don't queue. Go straight to the machines that sell tickets. :-)

The best thing to see in St Petersburg. WOW. The sheer scale of this building is the first thing that you notice, then after buying a very reasonably priced ticket you can spend days perusing the vast collection of art, antiques and sculptures, not to mention the stunning interior of the building itself. I would get here early to take in your favourite counties (collections are categorised by country/continent) before the tour buses arrive. One word of warning, any water bottle will be confiscated on entry.

Don't miss it. Almost unbelievable, so much to see and amazing that the treasures were saved from WW2 destruction saved. 3 hours is only enough to walk quickly round. It would need days to view in any sort of detail.

A must see place. Absolutely awesome place to visit. Crowded but so much to see that you can gawk for hours. Get ticket beforehand unless you want to queue or go to the ticket machines inside the entrance.

The Louvre of St Petersburg. The Hermitage is a magnificent building and quite breath-taking when you first encounter it. We did a guided tour which was excellent and showed the highlights as we walked through all the sections. It is an enormous and exhausting place so a plan of attack is definitely needed. Completely recommend.

Amazing !. The sheer size and opulence leaves one gasping !Just wandering around and seeing such magnificence in the building and the Paintings the statues the lot ! Gold in evidence everywhere.A time in History so well shared and restored. An absolute must for visitors to this city and the country as a whole !
Beautiful!. Excellent museum! Of course, it is huge. It will take you a week to go through it all. Wonderful architecture.
Hermitage. Two hours is only enough time to see what you are missing. Could spend several days to take in the extent of the treasures here.

Definitely worth a day!. All of the rave reviews of the Hermitage are true. So many art treasures, however, be prepared early and, if possible get your ticket the day before, as the ticket line is long.

Unmissable. Fabulous building without the wonderful paintings and statues. For people who are more interested in the historical significance of the building than art then don't miss the throne room, the Tsars throne standing on the Dias is a poignant reminder that this was the Royal Palace and home to the reigning Romanov family. The beautiful gold chapel room is breathtakingly and you can see several rooms that were used by the family. Also don't miss the intricate peacock clock that is now encased a a glass show case.For art lovers you could spend a year here and not see every piece. There is an interesting exhibition on Egyptian artefacts complete with genuine mummy.The Hermitage has a couple of cafes so it is possible to get refreshments, if you wish to visit the diamond exhibition buy the tickets and book your tour time when paying for admission as the set times very quickly sell out. The first Thursday of the month admission to the Hermitage is free but there are very long queues to get it. If there is a line in Palace Square the entrance from the embankment side can be shorter. However there is still a line at the ticket booths.

Wow!. The opulence of The Hermitage is mind-blowing. The enormity of the place, and the ornate decorations of the huge rooms is jaw-dropping. I would have liked to have seen the Impressionist paintings, but they are now in a different museum.

The Louvre on steroids . GO GO GO this was this is the most amazing place. No damage from The Revolution or the damn Nazis. Just pure over the top EVERYTHING. even the lobby art is what you dream to see. The floors are even art

Absolutely Amazing. The 200 meter (656 feet) long Baroque Winter Palace is the city’s largest and most opulent Palace. It was the official residence of the Czars, their Court and 1500 servants until the Revolution of 1917. Today, it houses one of the world’s greatest Museums. The Complex consists of 5 Buildings –Winter Palace, Small Hermitage, Old Hermitage, New Hermitage, and Hermitage Theater.Inside this amazing Museum is a fantastic collection of every type of antique and art you can imagine. Every room will leave you breathless with amazement. The ceilings, the walls and the floors are exhibits in themselves.There are statues, holy relics, jewelry, ceramics, porcelain, furniture, clocks, tapestries, weapons, clothes, precious stones, furniture made out of precious stones – you name it, they have it. There is a lot of stuff from the Greek, Mogul, Chinese, Japanese, European and Russian Empires. Plus there are more “modern” paintings by Renoir, Monet, Van Gogh, Matisse, Picasso, Rodin, Gaugin, etc., that are all awesome. It also has over 3 million works of art ranging from the ancient Scythian gold art to the modern Cubist art. The giant malachite and amethyst urns were stunning. The entrance and the staircases immediately take your breath away. You will sense the power of Imperial Russia as you walk around. By the time you exit, your mind is numb with all that sensory overload.We reveled in every minute of our time here, and left extremely inspired. Simply Wow!

Interesting and beautiful . Luckily we were one of the first ones in, so we missed the crowds. It's a well organised place with cloak rooms, shops, cafes . Like all big places , it's easy to get lost but we just wandered for hours, stumbling over amazing rooms and interesting artifacts and historical items. Well worth a visit.

So big, not enough time to see everything, but still..... So big, so many things, so little time. First thing first, remember to get the tickets from the ticket machines. You dont have to stand in the incredible long que. Get the tickets from he machines, and remember to choose the correct line after that. You don't have a chance to see everything, but if you spend three hours walking around in the buildings, you will see amazing art, furnitures, decorations and of course lamps. Remember to pay a visit to the appartement with furnitures, and the church. The visit is a MUST DO, even though the place is crowded with tourists.

Fantastic. One of the most beautiful museums and former Winter Palace in the world - must see if you are in St. Petersburg. Outside and inside gorgeous architecture. Wonderful decoration, paintings and furniture. Afternoon visit is a good timing.

Unbelieveable! Huge beautiful buildings with outstanding Art collection.. The Hermitage is one of the TOP Art collections in the World. Do not miss this! Some of the Worlds Best art is here. Second only to the Louvre in Paris. Don't miss the Impressionist Paintings in a separate building. Incredible collection! We were literally blown away by the collection!
Need plenty of time. Must see and one should have plenty of time to see it properly, especially the paintings by Leonardo

Oh My!!!!!!. A must see. Treasures that rival the Vatican Museum. Fortunately our tour had an hour head start on the general public. You really need a whole day here. We had 3 hours. A former palace...now holds national treasures. Amazing that so much rare...priceless treasures have been preserved. See the clock. I want to go back!!!!!
Allow enough time. If you are to fully explore the museum you may need a lot of time - however, if like me you are satisfied with a general walk around, then a few hours should suffice.

Best bet - pick your battles. We're not big art or museum lovers - but how could we not visit the Hermitage, aka, the Winter Palace? We kept it to the palace rooms and decor bcz thats what we liked. See whar YOU like but do some research. Or you could spend a week in there.

Crowded...get your timing right!. We got the timing wrong on this visit. The building is magnificent from the outside, gorgeous inside, and no doubt houses some exquisite treasures of art, but we entered at about 2pm and it felt like we were joined by every Asian tour group in St Petersburg. All of our small group of 6 was jostled by Asian tourists simply pushing to the front to get photos of every painting, even sticking their cameras, Ipads, selfie sticks in front of our face as we looked at the paintings or sculptures. Our guide tried valiantly to take us to less busy areas to talk about the items but it was packed in some parts and very hot inside as a result. My experience was certainly tainted by the pushy tourists here. Get your timing right to enjoy this place. I'd go early when it opens if I went again.

WOW!. Fantastic architecture inside and outside. This is a must-see if you are in St. Petersburg. Unbelievable decoration in the Winter Palace. We went with a tour guide and thanks to the headsets we were able to get info on what we were seeing. Downside was that it was terribly busy and crowded.

A National treasure...don't miss it. There are no words to describe our visit to the Hermitage. It is full of national treasures and I could have spent hours there. If you can, plan to spend a day here because there is so much to see

Very interesting place!. State Hermitage Museum and a magnificent ... imposing General Staff Building and the historical home of the Russian Navy ..Buildings Strong and Beautiful forms, ones are the most regular forms.

All the paintings are simple breath taking!. A must see of course! Take your time to see this incredible collection, will be very helpful if you have a guide who can take you to all important areas. Suggested time for comfortably seeing, at least 3 to 4 hrs.

A must visit, it isn't world famous for nothing!. This complex is HUGE!! The staircase when walking up and in will let you know what you are i for. Red velvety carpet runs up the marble staircase that is probably 10-15 fee wide! It's crazy how some people used to live, and the fact that it has been preserved is great for us! You could spend a whole day here...we went through in probably 2-2.5 hours. A must visit!!

it is a long walk. Heaving with people,lots of them unable to read the no photograph signs.the Next problem is trying to read the map it's like doing the Krypton Factor,once you managed this it is a superb museum,good value for money but need about 4 hours to do it justice.

Amazing Spb. Saint Petersburg, a city that surprised me - by its beauty,its architecture, people, attitude, order and Pride. Like its people, it is a young city has a certain sense of confidence and ambition. Young women smartly clocking their heels is a distinct, recognisable sound. Compared to other great European cities, it is only 300 years old, founded by its namesake Peter I - the Great, it has been the seat of the Monarchy for 200 years until the Soviet revolution in 1918 practically violated and raped its glory and riches. It has a bloody and well documented history and in a way the restoration of the city began only after the Perestroika ( which literally means restructuring) movement in the late 80s - and what a job they have done ! It has jumped up my list of favourite cities to break into the top 5. Listing out the great monuments and landmarks would be easy but my vocabulary would prove limited to describe the beauty and the grandeur of it all. It is not about a single landmark or Palace or a museum or cathedral or a fountain or square or canal or bridge - it's how it all comes comes together to give the old city its unique character. I think an impromptu reaction in marathi by Rahul Rahul Chandak when walking the halls of the Hermitage Palace best describes it...'Shrimanta cha tandav' he says - loosely translated to 'the dance of Opulence' The Russian pride in its past and the effort to painstakingly restore its glory is heartening and in sharp contrast back home. As the say : St Petersburg sparkles in the night. I offer a few photographs as additional evidence and rest my case.Another thing that was strikingly different was the sense of order. Four full days and we did not see a single policeman, no one broke traffic laws, people crossed at Zebra line, cars waited for pedestrians , Bikers zipped at over 100 kmph on the Main Avenue of the city - Nevesky Prospekt with confidence that one will step on the road, clean and dust free, thrash cans every 100 meters - it was almost military discipline.

Beautiful Museum and Palace. The Hermitage Museum and (Winter) Palace is beautiful and huge. It is a "must see" but you will need at least one day (and probably more than that) to see the most important exhibits. There are exhibits of most European artists and they allow photos (without flash) in most places.

A Great Collection. Seeing all of the Hermitage takes a long time and depending on your pace will take multiple days. Rooms are varying sizes and all are not directly accessible, but taking your time is worth while. If you are there for a cruise, stick to the main corridors and you see the main exhibits.

An incredible city. If you are going to Russia and only have time for one city, this is the one. You wuld never guess that it was totally destroyed in WW2. The siege of Leningrad (as it was then) lasted 900 days and 5 million shells and bombs were used on the city. You would never guess. The reconstruction is incredible. The St Petersburg people are different to Moscovites. They are more friendly and relaxed and make visitors feel welcome, a new feeling for me in Russia. We were offered a handful of strawberries by an old gentleman on the Metro just because we were visitors. The Metro now has all stations in English script which makes transport so much easier. Having said that learning the phonetics of the cyrillic alphabet will enhance your holiday as would reading a book on the city and the life of its founder, Peter the Great, before you go. So much to see. I only had 5 days and must go back. Missed the Museun of Vodka just for starters lol As for the Hermitage....BOOK ON THE INTERNET...it could save you a 4 hour queue. Enjoy

Magnificent Hermitage. We arrived at 10.30 and exchanged our internet vouchers at a booth located just under the arch. We then entered the museum through a a side door on the left rather than the main entrance without queuing. All very painless but we were early. Note there are no cloakroom facilities at the side entrance here to leave bags/coats - they were happy for us to carry reasonable sized bags and small back packs. We could pick up an audio guide at the side entrance although it is a somewhat tortuous process and you need to leave one ID for the group or 2000 roubles per handset. Personally we found the audio set useful for much of the art - but of little value for the rooms in the winter palace - so it depends what you want as to whether to get a guide. We did have a hilarious moment when one of the audio guides needed replacing - we did this at another desk in the museum but returned the replaced one to the first desk. The woman here ranted continuously in Russian as the handset number did not match what she had on her sheet and she did not want to return our ID to us. The museum is tricky to navigate. Their map is somewhat helpful. Anyone under the age of 35 speaks English but otherwise the guards in each room were largely unhelpful - even if you showed on the map the toilet sign they spoke to you in Russian and did not even try to point in the right direction.Vegetarians - take your own food as the cafe has little to offer. The service is generally poor. But the Hermitage itself - many adjectives are needed to describe it to do it justice. The rooms in the Winter Palace are just magnificent and are worth half a day alone. Do not miss the Hermitage as it is definitely worth it.

A must see, even if you see a little of it. The Hermitage is huge, but that shouldn't scare you off. We went there for a couple of hours and chose to focus on the Winter Palace interiors (2nd floor). It was absolutely magnificent. We were stunned by the grandeur and elaborate decoration. On our way out we found some gems of art and that combination made it one of our highlights.

Go with a tour or guide if you can. But do go!. Seeing everything on offer individually would likely take at least a day if not a repeat visit. We had a guide and she showed us her idea of 'the best' pieces on show in about 3 hours without a break. If you can, I'd recommend joining a guided tour or arranging a guide. That way, you won't just see 'pretty pictures' but hear the stories behind the art and the buildings it's housed in. Definitely book tickets in advance. Apparently the best time to go is from the second week of January till late March. Mind you, we were there in mid-June at the height of the White Nights and while it was indeed busy, it wasn't unbearable.

It makes Versailles look insignificant. An amazing place . I certainly can understand the Russian revolution the opulence of this place was amazing. . The reason for only 4 stars was that the impressionist art was no longer present here and was in a different building . That is the art I came to see plus the art that the Nazis stole and the Russia refused to return to the proper owners

STUNNING HERMITAGE. Obviously this is the most stunning museum in the World. But organised chaos and there should be a better method of timing entrance. Nearly knocked over by too many rude tourists from CERTAIN countries pushing and taking selfies on this awful sticks. They should be banned from doing this near works of art of this calibre.

Great place. Hermitage museum is a must see place in St. Petersburg. It is huge, but if you plan a whole day stay, it will be both pleasure and enjoyment. My advice is to visit Generalska building just across beautiful main Hermitage. You will be able to buy ticket for both collections, great masters and modern art, without a minute vasted in the line. As this year is 100th birthday of Black squear, a painting of Kazimir Malievich presented on December 19 1915, than it would be a pity to miss it. Besides, modern art collection is amazing. Almost all great painters of the first half of XX century are there. Don't miss it.Main building is dedicated to old masters and because of that is crowded, lots of turists wondering around not knowing what to see. I recommend Rembrandt with some of his masterpieces of early as well as his last period, Rubens, Dutch masters of landscapes, Van Dyck etc. If you have enough time, go through the grandious halls where Aleksander Sokurov made his film Russian Arc. Feel the time passing or stand still in these unforgettable rooms.If you are art lover, it will be the day for remembrance.After you leave this Museum, it will be enough time to wonder around parks and take a boat on Neva. In June you will fall in love with this city, cause White nights keep you awake and do not allow you to go to sleep. Enjoy by the river, enjoy on the canals, be part of this amazing city.

A must visit place. If you are in St Petersburg, this is the first place to visit. It is one of the largest museums in the world and has a breathtaking collection of antiques, paintings, war remains etc. from almost every country in the world. If you love visiting museums, plan for a 3 day trip to this place. I was fortunate to travel in an international group along with a guide who is working with the museum for the past 15 years. Having a guide is a big plus considering the enormity and range of the collection.

Must Visit. Do not leave St Petersburg without visiting this palace, lines are very very long and the place very crowded, I think they do a great job managing the numbers that visit the palace every day. Pre book your tickets and get there early.

Outstanding. Early Entrance a must. Plan half a day to stroll through all the rooms. Every room is as much a piece of art as the contents. Just when you think you have sen the most incredible you turn a corner and reset the bar.

Everything is fantastic, absolutely!. But if you visit there without a prepaid ticket, then do it round 10:30 am. After opening there is huge and long line of visitors in queue, of course you can have new friends there :) Seriously better be early, in Finland we say "aikainen lintu madon löytää" ;)

Hermitage. Fantastic, vasts amounts to see, lots of art, huge number of rooms, so much to see, you could spend ages there, but you hit sensory overload, before you see a fraction of it. The down side it the huge numbers visitors , be prepared to wait to get round, but worth it

Absolutely magical :). It's amazing what imagination, ambition and money will do. The hermitage is a diamond circle of great artists' imagination come to life. So many things to see. I especially liked the gold adorned walls by the red carpeted stairs. Absolutely wonderful architecture. The only reason that I do not give 5 stars is for the museum being so overly crowded in every room. I know that the hermitage is a very famous attraction and many people visit it every day but the crowds do make the experience just a bit less pleasant.

So magnificent...few can compare. From exterior to interior, this museum is rich with extraordinary design and an incomparable collection of artwork. We had a private guide for the visit which made this huge museum digestible in one day. Of course, it is impossible to see and appreciate the collections on display in one day or even one month, but we did our best. I visited the Louvre in Paris several days later and took a picture of the Mona Lisa over a sea of heads gathered around the legendary painting. But at the Hermitage you can view two DiVinci's from inches away to really grasp the structure and mechanics of his style. A truly unforgettable experience. Don't miss it.

Hermatge Treasures. Just returned from Russia & toured a half day at Hermatage museum. The artifacts of carriages, crowns, jewels, czar treasures, China, Fabrague eggs was breathtaking. One could spend a year visiting just this museum.

A must see. But pay for a guided tour. www.visitpetersburgrussia.com Our guide was Svetlana Ulyanov. It includes a guide, a driver and private guide. No lines, no waiting and you get the best points of interest.

Excellent, but frustrating at times. This place is a must. Plain and simple. It is the greatest museum I have ever been to. It has such a large collection and such a diverse range of exhibits. The one frustrating thing is that a lot of the exhibits have a large description in Russian and basically nothing in English (see photos). I'm not sure if they're trying to make some sort political point, or it's laziness, or even if it's because they want you to buy an audio guide in English but either way it's a pain. Such a Shame as you miss out on so much history. Really wish this would be fixed. Still must see.

One of the best museums in the world. One of the most extensive art museums of the world. One could spend weeks or months to see it all. Worth a visit and visit the diamond and or gold rooms if possible.

There's n other word for it...it's HUGE!. Vast and impressive state museum; there is a lot to see. Be prepared to queue to get on, but it's worth it. Beware - because of the fluctuating ruble, the online ticket price is about 3 times the amount you pay at the ticket office!

Fantastic, Enormous , You will run out of time !!!!. A must see in St Petersburg !!!! Fantastic collection of art with a sense of the grandeur and cultural wealth of St Petersburg. Was part of our two day w TJ Travel. We spent approx. 3-4hours but you could spend a year.

Buy the tickets online before going. The tickets are not expensive, and therefore buy the tickets online before you go to Russia. You have to exchange the print out to real tickets, but then you can jump the line and get fat to the security control. The lines are long in the mornings, but the place is so big that this gets less after just a few steps into the palace. Tip: start from the top - you avoid too many people at one place.

Wonderful. One of the world's great museums in an historic space essentially started by Empress Eluzabeth then much altered by Catherine who created the Hermitage to house her personal collection of great masters. Two Da Vinci, 2 Rapahel, a room of Rembrandt, great Dutch masters, Renaissance painting, a room of Canova marbles so much one could spend days here all in a palatial setting. The great impressionist collection has been reset in the guards building across the square-a room of Matisse, of Picasso, of Gaugain and Van Gogh including his last painting. A wonderful visit worth the trip to a Saint Petersburg.

Massive museum filled with treasures. The Hermitage is massive, our guide said that if you spent 1 minute looking at each item you'd be there for eleven years straight! lots of different exhibits for all art tastes. Can get a little boring if you're not into portrait art but lots of decor to admire

A Secret Gem . I stayed at The Official Hermitage State Hotel and was assisted by the excellent staff at the front desk. I told them I had been to the Hermitage before and was interested in impressionist and post impressionist art, what could they recommend? They said thought there are many fine galleries in Saint Petersburg I might be interested in a little yet known feature of the Hermitage. The General Staff build, found in the Hermitage courtyard. has been renovated and is to house the impressive collection of those periods I was seeking. I could purchase a ticket at the hotel or at the museum ( good for entrance to both). It was a rainy day and the hotel provided free transportation. The lines at the main museum were as to be expected easily 1,000. Well with ticket in hand, purchased at the hotel, I decided to explore the General Staff collection. I was overwhelmed. The exhibit had been opened in June 2015 and the floor plan and audio guides had not been made available as of yet, but what a gem I had been led to. The interior of the building was spectacular, and the collection was remarkable. Here is the amazing part. I was nearly alone for 4 hours with Renoir, Degas, Van Gogh, Cezanne, Pissarro, Picasso, Matisse and many more. I am sure when they have fill all the rooms still closed off this little secret will be a secret no longer.

Beware, Impressionist Collection in Different Building from Old Masters. I realized this at the last minute, and because we were on a private tour arrangements were made so we could visit both. The Old Master include DaVinci, El Greco, and many of the most incredible things you will see. The Impressionist Gallery was not crowded, and I thought it was world-class; Picasso, Monet, Manet, Degas, Renoir, Cezanne...it was fantastic and well worth it.

Architecture and beauty abounding!. Just amazing. This is, of course, a must-see if you visit St. Petersburg. We had an excellent tour guide who moved us through, assuring we saw and understood everything of importance in yet another display of the beautiful architecture in this gorgeous city.

Overwhelming!!!!. I agree with the greatest sensory overload review. You could spend a year here and still go back for more. This museum is one of the most impressive in the world. I think it's best to have a guide as we did so the highlights can be handpick end otherwise it's just too overwhelming. Of course the highlights are those chosen by the guide and I'm sure it's different for everyone. I appreciated it though. If given a choice I would go off season since it's incredibly crowded.

One for the bucket list. Of things to see in the world, the Hermitage has to be on the bucket list. If you do a private tour in St Petersburg extend for at least another couple of hours. This place is seriously big, it has over 3 million pieces. You will never see everything, so pick what you are most interested in and also just soak up the ambience. as a tip go before or after the major tour groups during he day, i.e. an evening.
don't miss it. so much to take in, so much to see. all treasures. best to go with a guide to help navigate and make the most of the time.

One of the world's great museums. This is truly one of the world's great collections of art. It reminds me of the Louvre in that you have to be selective on what you want to see, because even a full day here will allow you to only see about 2% of the works on display. The museum is absolutely enormous and comprised of multiple buildings, but most of the art you'll see is in the winter palace, so named for being the winter residence of the czars. This building has three main floors of art arranged in wings by the nationality and period of the art. Main sections include Ancient Egypt, Art of Antiquity, and art of the Orient, as well as the art of various nations (Britain, Italy, the Netherlands, France, etc.). There is obviously a huge Russian collection, and the palace itself is a work of art, with opulent decorations and historically significant rooms and furnishings.My favorite sections were the Italian Renaissance area (with paintings from Leonardo, Raphael, Titian, and Lippi and a Michelangelo sculpture) and the Dutch and Flemish paintings wings (Hals, Rembrandt, Steen, van Dyke, and Rubens). The rooms are relatively easy to navigate, but be prepared to stand in a line to see the big stuff like the Leonardos (while people take pictures with their phones).Taking a guided tour is helpful, as the guides know where to go to see the popular items. You'd spend a lot of time wandering around if you did it on your own. That may be exactly what you want, though, as every part of this museum is incredible. If you're there to see the most popular pieces, however, it may be too difficult to navigate the place on your own. Regardless, be prepared for a busy, long, crowded day.If you're trying to get to the world's greatest museums before you die, you need to hit the Hermitage. It's definitely on the list.

Amazing place, a Must See!. You could spend days here and not see it all. First, the museum itself is a series of palaces and is amazing to see even if it had nothing in it. But room after room and hallway after hallway is filled with beautiful art, sculptures, furniture and more. Its so much to take in and you will want to see all of it. We didn't see the Jewels section but those who did on our cruise said it was incredible. Don't miss the Museum Shop on the way out. High quality items at reasonable prices.

Hermitage is Overwhelming!. Opulence, beauty, awesome art and architecture! Don't miss any part of this. Take your time as much as you can to savor the experience. Even with a great tour guide, we still had to buy a book to read more about what we saw. A once in a lifetime experience for us!

So much to see, so little time. We went yesterday . The queues for tickets were long. We chose to use the credit card machines and there were little or no queues there. Students get in free otherwise tickets are 600 R. You could spend an entire week in this place and still not see everything . It is magnificent there are cloakrooms where you can leave in backpacks. Advisable to use those but you can take them in if toy really want. They pass everything through a security machine. There are lots of picture signs up about no flash photography no food no drink no stillettos at this security station but it's still quite confusing as they try to move people through ASAP and the numbers are large. Better to take as little as possible with you e,g a wallet a camera or a small handbag. There are lots of toilets and cafés on the ground floor and prices are reasonable compared to other museums we've been to. A chicken salad sandwich was 170R 220R for baked cheesecake , and the food is good. This is rated 15 in the top most visited museums in the world and it is easy to see why. There are artifacts dating back from prehistoric right through to modern day architectural exhibitions. My only regret is that we did not have enough time. The students among us are going back before we go home . Thoroughly recommend a visit here. You would be silly not to go.

the Greatest Sensory Overload. The best art in the world set in exquisite historic rooms. One needs a minimum of three days. Buy your tickets on line. When you arrive go through the Palace Square in front of the Hermitage and you will see the entrance. There are three arches. Do not make the mistake of going through the arch on the right and on through to the courtyard where people are waiting in a long line to buy tickets. Instead go through the middle arch and you will see a glass box office off on the right hand side with a sign for electronic tickets. You will exchange your paper tickets here for real ones. Best to buy two or three days in a row then collect all tickets at the same time. After you have collected your ticket you will not have to wait in any line the next day. At the end of the day do not take the white taxis parked in the Palace Square if you are facing the Hermitage to the right. They are scammers. They claim to be Hermitage taxis and when you ask how much they tell you not to worry that they have a meter. When you arrive at your destination you find out the meters are set to their own high prices. It cost us $30 to ride from the Hermitage to the Belmond Europa Hotel when it should have been 500 rubles. The Hermitage needs to go kick those guys out of there! There were three white taxis to choose from when we were there. Beware of all of them.

Good tips to avoid the lines. This place is a must see place, there’s no questions about it.Here’s the good tip to avoid the huge waiting line in front of it. Purchase the tickets online, and get the voucher number, then go straight to the gates, bypassing this crowd, right behind the main gate You’ll see the booth that says for online purchases/vouchers, present the number and You’ll get the tickets.I know it’s not fair, but for the retired people from outside former USSR the ticket costs the same as for adults without a discount, but if You’re and have a pensioner ID, You’ll be able to get in Hermitage for free, or other museums with discounts.But be prepared that You’ll not enjoy the museum 100%, cause now it looks like Turkish bazaar, with gazzilion people snooping around, I was trying to find out what is the lightest days, apparently Thursdays, that what locals told me, but not sure, cause I’ve seen the same line for the tickets on this day as well.So If You’ll pick the right time, You’ll see a richness of the Russian culture of Peter’s time and not only that, at some point You’ll understand how Emperors were living back at those time and feel the same for a moment.

Matchless. We love to travel (even our nine-month-old has been to ten countries, a few of them multiple times) and have been fortunate to see many wonderful places, but this was extraordinary. My husband is rarely impressed but even he said that he has never seen anything so amazing.I only wish we had more time to explore. You could literally spend days here. Make sure you take the time to look down -- the most beautiful inlaid wood floors in existence!Our six-year-old had a great time, too. Only wish we had enough time at the end of the day for a horse-drawn carriage ride out front. He was disappointed to have missed it.The location is convenient, too, and every room is more opulent than the next.You can't take bags inside, so make sure everyone is well-fed and hydrated.Also, the lines for the bathrooms were atrocious, so come prepared!

The highlight of a visit to St Petersburg. Simply stated, this is one of the worlds finest art museums, famously sited on the Neva river, in a indescribably grand palace. Get there early, its really crowded, and I'd recommend going with a tour that handles your tickets and entry. The option is long walks and long lines. If you're really into art here's what I recommend: take a behind the scenes tour that gets you in before the museum is opened to the public and includes at least an introduction to the major areas, and a chance to visit the off site restoration and storage facilities. Then plan a day or two to go visit areas of special interest to you on your own.My behind the scenes tour was 8 hours, mostly walking but it was worth it. I'm 75 and the tour was easy enough. Here's the only problem: on a tour you go at the speed of the group and this leaves you with only a minute or so with some of the world's most famous works. ( Like other huge museums you could not see it all in a few days or a week). Be prepared for big crowds, a lot of walking, and a lot of very long staircases. Disabled access in any of the grand Tsarist palaces does not meet the standards we expect in the USA but they are getting better. I suppose there are elevators, but you have to work to find them.
The best. It's the most amazing museum I've ever been to. Stendhal syndrome is guaranteed. I was dizzy when I left. It's truly second to none. It's open until 9pm on Wednesday and there's no crowd.

Do Not Miss It. This one of the few places in the world that can compete with the Louvre. If you only have a day in St. Petersburg you most at least drop bye. If you go with a tour you will have the advantage of getting in more quickly and touching many of the highlights (If you spend 1 minute looking at each exhibit it will take over 10 years to see it all). If you have limited interest and only want to see a very few things, (the impressionists have been moved to another museum)you can get a diagram and proceed directly but I bet you'll get waylaid by the magnificent structure or other exhibits along the way.

Great but crowded. The Hermitage is one of the great museums of the world. We spent an afternoon there with a guide and were only able to scratch the surface. The museum is five connected buildings of the former Winter Palace. The interiors of each building are beautiful and deserve a look of their own. Everyone wants to see the Rembrandt and Leonardo paintings so those rooms are crowded and you should wait for a lull to see them. Be prepared to walk for 2-3 hours

Great place but plan it in advance!. I went there with a group and got a guided tour, which I highly recommend. I would also recommend that you plan a whole day around the visit. When I was there there weren't a lot of people there since it was Easter and that was nice. Overall this is a beautiful place and worth a visit.

Great place to visit, lovely amber room. Went here as part of SPB tours - which I highly recommend! The palace was beautiful and the amber room was just lovely. It was crowded though, but definitely worth it to see this palace. I highly recommend going here with a guide - as there are a lot of things to see that unless you know your Russian history, you may miss a lot without a guide pointing out interesting historical facts.

Incredible Treasurers that you should not miss. A must see when in St Petersburg but it is overwhelming if not with a guide. In fact they say that to see all of the Hermitage spending only a few minutes at each item will take you over 11 years! We visited the Hermitage Museum with a fantastic tour person, Irina Mitireva of All Russia Tours, and she brought us to hundreds of the incredible treasures that one should see. We would highly recommend one consider having a guide. Fantastic treasurers, many one of a kind items, hidden throughout. What an incredible education and experience.

Excellent . An excellent museum that have 3 million pieces but exhibits only 20% of them. It's the biggest collection on the world after the louvre. Big collection of different countries and different ages, plus temporary exhibits every now and then. The Rembrandt exhibit is a must, plus 2 Leonardo da vinci originals. It consists of 5 palaces which are really wonderful and are inter connected together. The main square which is the Palaces square is a very beautiful area to spend some time and take photos. The hermitage is a must.

Amazing museum ... Comparable to Louvre in Paris.. Great collection of art and historical artifacts about Russia. It is big with lot to see. so need few hours just to get a glimpse. Very busy so plan to be patient.

Amazing!. If you are only in St. Petersburg for one day, see the Hermitage. If you are here for two days, you may want to go back again the second day! It's a fabulous museum, a bit reminiscent of the Vatican Museum in Rome, although probably even larger. There is art from nearly every historical period and culture here, though of course Europe is most represented. You could spend a week here and not see it all. Not only is there top-shelf art of every description, including all the masters, the building itself is worth the price of admission, each hall more beautiful and ornate than the next. A good way to get oriented is to take a tour. These often start before the museum opens, so you can see some of the exhibit halls free of crowds.
