Not huge collection but some quality pieces. Afterwards you can wander back downstairs to look at not only the wonderful art collection but also the settings, this was after all a palace. Particularly enjoyed the library.
Dazzling imperial splendor. The treasures here have been cataloged, arranged, maintained, and secured by dedicated curators to make the Tsarist past a tangible present reality for the visitor.
July trip to Saint Petersburg. An outstanding example of Imperialist architecture that blew us away. Every room was a work of art and we could not quite believe the scale of the opulence. Incredible
Endless pleasure of beauty and art. A taste of several hours from the best of art, beauty and a lot of gold. Must come back for longer time and enjoy the rest of this great museum.
One of the biggest. Amazing view from outside and fabulous inside. One of the biggest museum in the world going early help because its always crowded

A must see. Have seen this building in so many pictures and films etc. It is far grander in the flesh.There are a lot of people wanting to see it so queuing is ineviatble, but it is worth the wait. The building is incredible, and the paintings Awsome although sometimes with all the crowds they can be difficult to see. Also sometimes it does appear to be a bit of a route arch through the building. Would still not have missed it and there is plenty of time for photos.

General Staff Building; Far from the Maddening Crowd.. An extraordinary art and historical experience made even better by these 3 tips:1) Go on a Wednesday evening, after the crowds have subside and the cruise boat people are gone.2) Hire a good guide to maximize your time.3) Don't miss the general Staff building with the very best collection of Impressionist paintings in the word.Go early and you may be the only person in a room of Picassos or Renoirs or Matisse or Degas.

Huge Hermitage. We came here as part of a day trip from a cruise ship, the museum is huge! Unfortunately we did not have a huge amount of time here but from what we did see this museum is impressive. We were part of a guided tour, and I would recommend using a guide as otherwise you might miss the most famous art works or walk past interesting pieces as you might not know what they are. I did notice there was a café and toilets here. I am sure that with enough time here you would have a great experience.

Zaha Hadid Exhibition . Hermitage currently hosts exhibition dedicated to Zaha Hadid. Lots of works and photos available. Pretty saturated. Entrance ticket to Hermitage is valid. Venue will be quite interesting for those familiar with Z.H.

Hermitage is a must. The Hermitage is a must see on your trip to St Petersburg. There is a line to buy tickets and another line to get inside. It is worth looking for a way to buy tickets in advance so you have more time inside. The building itself is stunning. Check out the peacock clock. There can be big crowds and large tour groups so it is a bit hard to see some of the paintings.

Outstanding. The Hermitage cannot be missed on any visit to St Petersburg. We were lucky that our tour group got in a full hour before the general public, so we were able to see the Gold Room before the crowd swelled in. The place is immense and there is to much to take in in half a day. You are constantly refocussing from the ceilings, the walls, the floors and the art pieces hanging on the walls or placed around the museum. It does get a bit hot inside with so many people so be prepared to pace yourself.

out of this world. no matter how early you go, you will still need to queue for around 2 hours, so it's better to buy your tickets from tour organizers.no matter what, don't leave St petersburg without visiting

Palatial. Visiting St Petersburg, I think it is essential to visit The Hermitage. The building is magnificent with so many opulent rooms virtually all with gold decorations. There are a lot of staircases to negotiate but they are all beautifuly designed with huge amounts of marble and gilding. When we come to the artefacts, words fail me. It is said that if a person spent 10 seconds looking at each one, 24/7 for 24 hours each day it would take 10 years to see them all.So a 3 hour visit allows you to get an overall impression of the total beauty of the place and even that will involve walking for about 3.5 miles.When in St Petersburg, do not miss it!!!

Fantastic visit. We went here in June and we were amazed at the magnificent rooms throughout. They just went on and on. Although very busy our Russian guide was really good at allowing us to take in as much as possible. Her explanations were very informative. We only saw a fraction of the rooms in about 3 hours however is was very good indeed. Guide book only £5!

The must see place in St. Petersburg. The one must see place in St. Petersburg if you have only a short time. It will be crowded. Go early. Much work has been done in recent years so exhibits are somewhat different from in the past. Much has been done to restore Tsarist history. The giant Soviet map constructed of precious and semiprecious stones has been moved to another museum, and the large hall where it resided has been restored to the throne room. Very good gift shop.

Wonderful place but not set up well for the crowds. Went here while on a cruse ship top with Insider Tours. Our guide seemed to know where and when to go here avoid most of the crowds, but immediately determined that some of the key parts that tourists want to see were set up so it would be difficult to see them (why would you have a DaVinci in a front corner of a room with difficulty to see it instead of the middle of a room to accommodate a large audience is baffling). However it is wonderful to see, with many things that can interest different tastes. Was surprised to see many statues and carvings, as well as mummies for the kids. Next time that we come here would plan to spend more time here.

A must see place in St. Petersburg. This is a must see place in St. Petersburg. This museum housed a lot of precious arts and sculptures as well as the history of Russia. Irina, our tour guide is very knowledgeable and she captivated my attention throughout the tour.

Magnificent! . The Winter Palace is simply beautiful. As you enter the palace, you inevitably feel like you have been transported to the past and you cannot but wonder about who actually lived there and spent time there. The palace has so many different rooms decorated with the best china, silver, paintings, chandeliers, furniture that you feel very, very lucky to see all of its collections. WARNING: the queue to enter is extremely long so I would recommend being there at least one to two hours before it opens its doors - entry price for non Russians is about 600RUB. Enjoy.
Winter Palace. Great place to visit and the inside is almost unbelievable in its architecture, room embellishments and size of the entire complex. A must see.
Golden Russia. The Hermitage and Winter Palace in St Petersburg is Russian Opulence at it's finest. Endless art, gold guilt, Tsar abundance and an insite into Russia's past

A MUST- BEFORE THE IRON WALL COMES CRASHING DOWN AGAIN ?. We went in may- so the que was not too bad.Its an amazing museum,well worth seeing and every bit as impressive as The Met,MoMa ,Louvre,Brittish museum etc.Not the most central pieces of the greatest european artists,but so many fantasic others and The Catarina Hall and The Rafael Hallway are outstanding.DONT MISS IT - AND GO BEFORE ITS TOO LATE ??

Huge museum with an impressive collection.. This museum has a lot of interesting pieces and our guide took us to the areas that we were more interested. We spent one half day there and we didn't scratch the surface of the museum, probably you need weeks to see all what they have in there. This is a mandatory visit if you visit St.Petesburg.

Hermitage Visit. We've been here before and it was arranged better this time. We were disappointed to learn that the French Impressionist art had been moved to a different location. Sad to learn the Hermitage still does not have air conditioning to preserve the paintings.

An Outstanding museum.. visiting st. petersburg without being here is like nothing. this is the most impressive museum around here. it has collections of art work from Europe. the place is huge. it is also full of crowds. it is hot in the summer and the crowds make it even worse. i haven't seen any humidity control system in action to protect the valuable works. you need a full day to go over all the details.

Great art, terrible organisation. We knew there will be queues, so we got there super early before the opening and were in the first 10 people in the queue. Everyone is pushing hard out, so much for trying to get closer to beauty of art...One guy on crunches got run over by crowd, so very sad. We had a guide book and a map so knew exactly where we were going as wanted to see particular exhibitions. And we can speak Russian, still we got lost a few times. Can't imagine non speakers trying to navigate it without a guide. Groups do get in earlier at a different entrance. Buying tickets online is more expensive than at the gate. Also must agree with an earlier reviewer that French Impressionists cannot be missed -it's in the general staff building, not crowded and you can spend some quality time there.So: fantastic exhibits, very poor organisation of crowds and signage

Helps you understand why the Tsars were deposed. Absolutely amazing displays of art in many forms, paintings, sculpture, inlaid columns, gilded woodwork and more. . Unless you go in the winter, be prepared for massive crowds.
Hermatage Museum.. This museum is truly spectacular. So much to see ,we walked around for two hours covered about three kilometres and only saw a small part of what was on offer.

Completely paralysed by the beauty of art. To take the most out of this fabulous collection I strongly recommend that you have a good plan or itinerary for visit. Without doubt you can't visit the whole collection in one day (actually they say that if you spend one minute for each work in Hermitage, you need about 120 years to finish your visit). So with a little search you can find good plans and suggestions for the museum highlights. I personally suggest a deep visit to "Loggia of Raphael", a copy of Raphael's famous gallery in Vatican. Da Vinci and Rembrandt are " don't misses" of this museum. Don't bother yourself for a visit to Ancient Egypt, because it's simply descent and you can spend more time on more valuable parts.

Be sure not to miss the French Impressionists.. One of the great museums of the world. Up there with the Louvre and Vatican. The French Impressionists are across the square in a new gallery. Almost empty when we were there. Amazing collection from Monet to Picasso.

It must be seen. Get a ticket from the machine in the courtyard behind the main entrance. This costs 600 roubles and will let you into everything. It is 200 more than at the ticket office but saves hours of queuing. Then enter by any of the entrances behind the museum. It all leads to the same place. You may have to join a security queue. Maps are on the stands inside but they are hard to follow, better to ask. Be warned, the impressionist paintings have been moved to the building opposite the museum, all on the top floor. Also there is a great 'gifts from East to West' exhibition with stunning jewelled objects. Afternoon is the best time to visit to avoid long queues, but it has to be seen. Amazing.

Mass tourism and poor service, horrible experience overall. Our trip to the Hermitage was a terribly disappointing one. We pre-booked tickets online thinking we wouldn't have to spend at least 4 hours queuing on a Wednesday morning/afternoon. Got there and there were lines that were snaking from the inside of the museum and pouring out until the end of the Square bridges (at least 500m). What shocked us and everyone in line was that there were only a handful of ticket booths dealing with pre-booked and on-the-spot ticketing purchases. The staff working in the booths also had total disregard of dealing with the issue promptly and basically took their their with the tickets (imagine ~5-10mins per person). We were in line for almost an hour before the lady in our booth decided to shut the line without any reason. Everyone was just furious and despite looking for other staff for help. there were none on the square and the ones inside just shook their head saying "NYET- I DONT KNOW". This is the Hermitage you're talking about but the standards of service was just disgusting and 3rd world. Having travelling the world to various huge museum, we've never experienced such bad service and lines. It wa slike queuing for food stamps in the USSR days so it was an absolute joke. Inside it was a maze with hords of tour groups everywhere (expected in a big museum). Interiors were well-kept and delightful to observe, but nothing amazing compared to other big museums such as the Lourve or Sistine. Masterpieces were also mediocre and you had about 10 seconds in line to view masterpieces with a hundred people around you snapping photos. Maps were also lacking as there were only a few measly pieces in French lying around. Again, staff was no help (get used to the word 'NYET', and 'I dont know"). Some volunteer staff working inside the museum guarding the art pieces were nice however, helping anyone who was lost inside. (Be prepared to get lost). Unless you are a SERIOUS art buff or have a PHD in art history or some sort, I'd say skip this as it is better off spending at least 8hrs of your time in St.Petersburg exploring elsewhere.

Dumbstuck!. This is probably the richest museum in the world. 3mn art works in 100s of rooms would probably require days. Nevertheless our guide naina did a great job of showing highlights. She had so much energy. History of czars, catherine the great and what not. History of russia , splendour and naivety all in canvas and walls.
CLASS IN ITSELF. Must visit once in lifetime. Great collection of art and décor. Clearly shows the class and taste of queens of that era.

Queueing is a nightmare;inside is a dream. My big,big mistake was not to pre-book tickets online. This was because the online price is considerably higher than the ticket desk price- it would have been something like $66 (£42) dollars compared to R600 (£6.50) for myself and two teenagers- and reviews on here suggested that the queues are not that bad. They are horrific. We waited over two hours in a line that barely moved to get to a slow ticket desk queue followed by a quicker entry to museum queue. A girl standing near us fainted. The queues for terminals were as bad and there was absolutely no signage- even in in Russian- to show which queue is for which. (Previous experience had shown that terminals often didn't work, weren't in English and didn't produce free tickets so we didn't bother with that massive queue). Major renovation and building work is going on so perhaps that contributed to the chaos.  To get free entry for children and students produce their passport opened to information page - not a copy (keep a copy of passport and visa at your hotel). There was a map available in different languages but we failed to figure out how to obtain one (and were past caring after two hours) and used the very good information in our Lonely Plant St Petersburg guide instead. But I don't think they were difficult to acquire as most people had them. Either way you need a map. This place is VAST and the room numbers don't always appear to follow a sequence that I could discern.Once inside you need to leave your main bags in the cloakroom. You can take a small bag and handbag with you. We took a bottle of water and food for which we were very grateful after a few footsore hours. You can't eat in the rooms but downstairs by the entrance is a corridor with seats and no one seems to mind as long as you don't make a mess. I sent my son to attend to the bags while we waited in the short but slow moving inside queue for the ticket desk. There is a toilet near here but queues for the ladies can be very long and there are other toilets inside although all seemed to be on the ground floor (called the first floor in Russia). The imperial state rooms and private rooms of the tsars are on the first floor (second floor in Russia) and you go up via the spectacular Jordan staircase. At the foot to the right are toilets and a lift. There were a lot of people in the museum and the Chinese tour groups in particular are large and over-excited but the rooms are so vast that it is not a big problem. We calculated that our four bedroom house would fit about five times over in one room alone. I have visited a lot of stately homes and palaces over the years and nothing has ever compared to the sumptuousness and extravagance of the Romanovs. I wondered what the impoverished, hungry people of the revolution thought when they first entered the glittering, golden rooms to seize power from the provisional government.As this was the last day of our holiday and we were tired and had already seen a lot of paintings, we pretty much ignored the art, other than a quick look at the most eye-catching pieces, and just focused on the rooms on the first floor of the Winter Palace and a little bit of the adjoining Hermitage. Inside you don't really notice when you move from one building to the other and it is really easy to get disorientated. We spent the final hour on the ground floor. Coming back down from the first floor we accidentally exited the museum and had to be re-admitted on the other side of the inside corridor. This was not a problem once we found someone who could understand us. Make sure you hang onto your tickets. A more careful reading of the map would have shown the internal staircases and lifts the ground floor. This floor was practically deserted and had very interesting and exquisitely curated collection of early Siberian and Scythian artefacts including several naturally mummified bodies, including a horse. There was limited information in English, especially about the bodies.As ever in Russia, there was very little information in the museum in English- usually just a few short lines under a longer piece in Russia. There are audio guides available (in most places they request R1000 deposit but will also take a passport. You only need one deposit no matter how many guides you borrow). I did pick up a newsletter by the museum director talking about the museum during the siege of Leningrad. Despite starvation rations and terrible cold, the staff continued to work quietly on their research whilst facilitating the evacuation of a million artefacts to safer territory in the Urals and Siberia. This heroic devotion to duty and preserving Russia's heritage is a huge source of pride to Russians, echoed across the city. It doesn’t mention the many staff who were purged under Stalin such as the armour expect suspected of harbouring weapons. I felt that this was somewhere I would like to return to one day in slower time, in a quieter season with a tour or an audio guide to take in more. Older visitors or those with limited mobility might prefer their first visit to be done in this way. One visit is nowhere near enough and, despite the irritation of queuing and so many people, it was breath-taking and easily takes the title of the world's best museum.

The World's Largest Museum. The Hermitage is the world's largest museum by area. It possesses over 3,000,000 items. The building itself was once a palace for the Czars. It can be extremely crowded in the summer. If at all possible, take a private, small group tour after normal hours. That will certainly enhance the experience.

Hermitage, St Petersburg. This was an afternoon visit, therefore the place was very crowded. (If possible, try to visit early in the day.) The summer season is quite short in Russia, so crowds are inevitable. Museum worth seeing, apart from the queues to view the Da Vinci portraits. It's the building itself which is the real work of art.

A masterpiece. Perhaps the largest museum in the world. But one most important advice - buy tickets online else you might still be in a queue after a couple of hours. There is hardly any information in english other than wayout, enter and tickets written in the english language. Surprised as more than 95% of the guests were non Russians. Suggest you have take the app for the audio guide to the hermitage which turned out to be useful to understand the entire history better as we moved from one hall to another. But all in all a great place and experience.

buy tickets from machine, not by queuing!. huge and difficult to navigate. ran out of english maps/brochures. no staff to tell you that you can buy tickets from the machine and save yourself 30 min from queueing. The machines take cash and cards and operate in English too.also, don't buy tickets online in advance. they cost USD 18 online but only 500/600 RUB at the door.
The Hermitage. simply beyond.. need a guide to help you find your way. A total must!!! the building!! the art!!! the furniture!!! it is totally fabulous!!!

Hermitage in Saint Petersburg. Visited with a private tour guide during a three day cruise stop. This place is breathtaking. If you visit without going to the Hermitage you haven't visited Saint Petersburg. Larry & Suzy

Do it leasurely. Most tours spend half a day in the Hermitage. That is not enough. We took tickets for 2 days, including the Gold and Diamond exhibitions. The museum is enormous and has in the building opposite also the paintings of the impressionists. Order tickets online not to wait with the other hundreds of visitors to get in. Or get a ticket from one of the electronic ticket dispensors.

EXCELLENT, STUNNING, MAGNIFICENT, FANTASTIC !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!. To see all exhibitions in Hermitage you need 6 years every minute nonstop without sleep, without eating.We get in as a group with a guide-tour so it was very easy for us.Most of the rooms are very beautifull as this building was the winter Palace.Wonderfull decoration, ceilings, floors, curtains, paintings of famous painters everything is fantastic. Is a must !! don't miss it !!!
Very beautiful museum. Excelent place, it is with the Prado Museum in Madrid, one of the best museums of paintings.Very nice classical masterpieces and very nice impresionist colecction

Amazing. A must see for any traveller to St Petersburg. A never ending array of masterpieces displayed in a myriad of spectacular rooms. We were on a guided tour with SPB Tours which allowed us an early entrance, one hour before normal entrance, thus allowing us to see many of the exhibitions before the crowds rolled in.

So many thing to see!. I hardly suggest to visit this museum! I've been here three times to see every room and every time there was something new to see better :) If you have the opportunity try to go in a not-so-touristic period...I've been like just once to find it almost empty and it was amazing.
Rich in Culture, Beauty & State of the Art in Architecture.. Again ! A Master piece wrt Architecture + Cultural richness + sense of history all around you..Would like to visit again for sure.

Winter Palace and Hermitage - well worth the effort. If you are fortunate enough to visit St Petersburg (don't forget your umbrella, regardless of what the skies look like) you must see the Winter Palace and State Hermitage Museum. Amazing architecture, wonderful exhibits and some incredible paintings by world reknowned artists will provide you with an unforgettable experience. Avoid the afternoons and visit early if you can, especially in summer as the museum will be crowded and can become quite hot and stuffy. Also, be prepared to do a lot of walking and climbing of stairs. The walk up the main staircase in the Winter Palace is something for your memory banks for the rest of your life.

3 Million Art Pieces Mostly Not Available for Viewing. What does one say about an art museum that has three million pieces in its collection and which is housed in one of the world's most famous, most opulent palaces? Simply beautiful but beware: the palace overfloweth with customers and they only open certain sections each day. We were there a day when only the Old Masters were on display. I wanted to see the impressionists, but - sorry - not that day or the next.

A must see while you are in St Petersburg. Such an amazing museum, with every room full of beautiful art, sculptures, floors, and ceilings. The building itself is a wonderful piece of architecture. My daughter and I couldn't get enough pictures of everything.

A lot to see but after a while I was bored.. We were on a cruise and had a two day tour of St.Petersburg and the Hermitage Museum was our last visit on the second day. So maybe we were tired and it influence my review, but we spent about two hours there and I was ready to leave after one.The place is indeed incredibly big and there are very beautiful rooms, but there are uninteresting rooms too. There are so many different things that it is hard to find everything interesting. Some will prefer the historical rooms, other will prefer the art, but if you are not familiar with the place, you can get lost easily.In a lot of way it is similar to the Louvre in Paris.It is a must-see in St.Petersburg, but allow time according to your interest. A quick one-hour tour would have been enough for me.

A Must-See. Take a tour or buy online.. It is simply ENORMOUS. There are stats about how long it would take you to look at every exhibition, I don't know them but it is absurd. The exhibits are remarkable and the palace itself is stunning, and I'm not even a museum person. My recommendations are this:1) Take a tour. The place is just too big to do in an day/afternoon by yourself. Having a tour guide enhances the experience by streamlining you to the most important things, or to the things you would most like to see. If nothing else, at least do a little research beforehand so you're not just wandering around aimlessly, only to find out later you missed something important or that you would have liked to see.2) Buy your ticket online. If you go with a guide, you will likely be able to use the group entrance and save time. If not with a guide, BUY ONLINE in advance and you can go up to the left side entrance and trade your voucher for tickets. We found this out last minute while waiting in a 1000+ person line in the rain and it saved us at least 2 hours. Thank god for international data plans. If nothing else, get there early, there WILL be a line. And they are closed on Mondays, so look at the schedules in advance.
The Magnificent Hermitage. The Hermitage is a must see when visiting St. Petersburg. The art collection and the beauty of the rooms are one of a kind

Huge Collection and space. A huge museum spanning 5 buildings and endless rooms and hallways. Some great pieces and given the size it is relatively well organized. Fairly crowded and any of the highlight pieces were literally swarmed by people pushing (this was around 11 am). We left after seeing what we wanted as it was overwhelming and too crowded. Don't wait in the line and go to the ticket kiosks instead just inside the gate to the left. Just be prepared to wait for people who can't figure out kiosk screens to take excessive time (although they are literally as easy as an ATM).

Simply magnificent. We had pre-booked our tickets on line, and this enabled us to avoid the queue warning for entry. One painting was the catalyst for our visit. The excellent printed guide enabled us to go straight there, passing the works of many masters en route. We were ten able to target other galleries of particular interest, with short coffe breaks at the ground floor cafe. We were almost blown away by the beauty of the rooms we visited, and no less impressed by the collections we saw. However, a full day was not enough to do justice to L'Hermitage. I need to go back for at least another two to three days to see more of the collections.

Shame not to go. The winter palace is a museum, which is full of the most famous art pieces.Even though you can't really compare it to Le Louvre, in Paris, but the scale is not that smaller from it, and it's probably the proud of whole Russia.Whether you are an art lover or not, you will be astonished with how beautiful the inside is and amount of art pieces you will see. Be aware of time because you will easily be killing hours by just walking inside..

Disappointing. I have to admit knowing very little about art but I like my occasional visit to galleries and museums. And places in Paris, London and NY seem to cater for the novice and philistine like me so everyone can get the most out of what they see. Unfortunately, the SHM was a little dull, uninspiring and, let's be honest, poorly set out. Some of the rooms were spectacular but after the 56th, I 'lost focus', and started looking for the quickest way out!

A grand feast for one's eyes and soul!. Buy tickets at the kiosks in the court yard after entering the entrance gate - short or no lines. The English version of the museum website has a markup, but if you read Russian, buying tickets online is another option to avoid long lines. Research and do homework before the visit as the place is huge and the collection is enormous. Fortunately, there are staff throughout the museum to offer direction and help, although not all of them speak English.My favorites are the Jordan Stairs, the Pavilion Hall with the fabled Peacock Clock, the stunning loggia of Raphael, the room with Canova's neo-classical sculptures, and of course, Da Vinci, Michaelangelo, Caravaggio, Rembrant, and any celebrated master you can think of. If you are a fan of impressionists and post-impressionists, do visit the General Staff Building which is included in the ticket. Absolutely amazing palace and art collection! And a grand feast for one's eyes and soul!

2-day tickets are available on line.. The lines to buy tickets vary from very short to very very long. If one plans to spend two days in the museum, it is possible to buy 2-day tickets on line, but not at the ticket offices in the building.

A gem. Impossible to visit the city without including the Hermitage.
I could recommend to use a guide service, as the museum makes it difficult to choose what to see. They will help you prepare an itinerary based upon your preferences.

Excellent. The museum is as interesting as Louvre. I strongly recommend to buy tickets by internet to avoid long long queues. Some rooms are difficult to visit due to the number of tourists. Better not to go on Tuesday (more visitors), The cafeteria is so so small...
The shops sell very interesting material.
One of the Best Art Museums in the World!. It has been estimated, that if a visitor viewed each display item for one minute, it would take 11 years to walk through the entire museum!

Only a snapshot. We visited from a cruise ship. We had a limited amount of time and were given a guided tour. We had tickets for an early entry. It was extremely crowded when we left so glad we did.The rooms we visited were very interesting but I would have liked to see more and take my time. I didn't feel as though I had really done the Hermitage.
Prebooking via internet is a must. It combines one of the best art collections in the world with a beautiful restored palace. SuperbDreadful tour parties the price you pay

Words cannot say how amazing this place is. You simply must just go and see for your selves. Buy a ticket onlline to avoid queueing, take water with you as expensive to buy and be prepared for lots of tourist pushing and shoving. Take a different route, go against the crowd, keep your cool and off you go. It is a lot to take in so go with water and snakcks, comfy shoes etc.
What a stunning place. The Palace is a must see destination in St Petersburg. I was overwhelmed by what i say. Even if it is crowded it is still very enjoyable. Allow many hours for your visit

Fine Art, Painfully Crowded. Obviously, this is one of the world's great museums in a beautiful group of buildings of historical import. Unfortunately, the crowds, dominated by large tour groups from cruise ships, are so large in the summer that the visit is physically unpleasant, inspiring the desire to get out, rather than to spend the many hours the museum requires. Other major sites in St. Petersburg have managed to find ways to control the flow of visitors so that, while crowded, they are not oppressive. The Hermitage needs to do the same.
So Much to See. It is hard to know how to describe a place that is filled with so much beauty. Very, very impressive

GO. st petersbrg = hermitageyes thats sounds rightbe prepare for massive tourist streams, book your tickets in advance or you might end up in a queue which is endlessand furthermore, the hermitage consist by today of 5 different buildings with 5 different themes.the main building, the original one, the green one is the one which everybody wants to visit, it is here that you see the old masters in exquisitely restored rooms (the floors, another fabulous aspect)free wifi insidequite ok cafes inside

Overwhelming at best and a must see stop in SPB.. Our visit was too short due to lines, the number of visits, heat in the building and the pouring rain outside. I guess as a Tuesday visitor, an overload of people due to museums closure on Mondays. Consider this when visiting. As a cruise traveler, this was out only day to visit. Grand, gilded, gigantic. so enormous and too much to take in. That which we did take it was perfect. WE did visit the impressionists in another building, wonderful collection and very manageable and not crowded but not in space like the gilded glory of other buildings. We were lucky that we booked with KJOY Tours and so our tickets were waiting and we went in bypassing tens of thousands also waiting to be in awe.

Highly recommend a guided tour for non art buffs. We booked a tour through the Peters Free Walking Tours company for 1900 roubles each. The tour starts at 1pm each day and gets you past all of the queues. Our group was only 3 people which was amazing as it was like a private tour. It also meant we could dodge around the large tour groups and see more of the very extensive collection. Our guide, Tania, was absolutely amazing. She was extremely knowledgeable and full of interesting stories and anecdotes about the paintings and artists. She was also very frustrated on our behalf that some of the more interesting pieces were missing, most likely on a visiting exhibition elsewhere, but if she hadn't mentioned it, we would never have known. Nice that she was honest. The hermitage is enormous and would be extremely hard to navigate without a guide. We're travelling on a tight budget but I think paying an extra 1100 roubles to have a guide is well worth it. Similarly if you don't know much about the artists or stories behind the pictures it's a fascinating way to learn more. The tour didn't include the 20th century collection across the road in the General Staff bulding but we still had an hour and a half after the tour to explore the must see collection of Renoirs, Picasso's, Van Gogh's etc.I really enjoyed this tour, it was the highlight of our week in Russia.

You need all day. A must to all travellers. This amazing place is just stunning. If you can book ahead as the queues are not great. So much to see here, you will certainly need sensible shoes. Beautiful art, furniture and history just amazing - very high recommended

One of the World top Musea. Go early and pick up your ticket at the automtic machines for cc, otherwise you risk a long waiting time for buying your ticket. Make a choice what to visit beforehand as the museum is huge.

If you love artwork and don't mind battling large crowds of people. This museum is wonderful and filled with fantastic art work. The negative side to this is that is seems to always be packed it and it is very difficult to actually enjoy viewing the paintings as people push and show their way through the 5 buildings. We had a personal guide which did her best to make sure we saw the very top of the line art work and carefully weave us through the crowds of tours that were following their guides with their sticks up in the air with s stuffed animal or flag of some sort.

Well worth a go.. We were lucky enough to have the BEST EVER TOUR GUIDE. Victoria walked and talked us through everything. We went in August, would advise to go earlier in the year. Sitting on Deck in the evening was a bit chilly. They do however provide blankets so snuggle up and enjoy. LOADS to see, way too much to describe here. An amazing trip. The boat was full of elderly Americans, but hey ho!.. One thing that did surprise me was the lack of interest in the optional trip to the Space Museum, considering the history of the "Space Race" back in the 60s.

One of the best Museum in the world. One full day is not enough to see this museum. I wish I had more time to go there two days. Try to buy the tickets online in advance so you don't waste too much time in line. Because they have two lines now to buy the ticket and the second line to get in. If you have your ticket in your hand you avoid the first long line.

Essential visiting but share it with a cast of thousands!. Get there early with your online ticket (essential!), and at least experience the grandeur of the sumptuous rooms before you get swamped! The Hermitage has everything for anyone interested in art. The section of Rembrandts alone is fantastic, but every era and nationality of the best artists that ever lived can be found here. Be careful not to miss the Impressionists, displayed in a separate building on the opposite side of Palace Square.
Must see Palace. Very beautiful Palace and Museum. You can see every kind of items in the Museum and along with enjoy the beauty of Palace.

overwhelming, but a must-see. Crowded and worth the hassle, of course. Possibly the most extensive collection of art treasures in the world. One day is not enough, but if you're selective, very satisfying. It would take 7 1/2 years to see everything at 1 minute per item, so do a little research and focus on your priorities, or just enjoy the buildings themselves.

Cok etkileyici. We spent 3 days in Hermitage, but it definitely deserves 2 full days. See the palace rooms first (to the right). Since the tours start with the exhibition rooms, it is very crowded when the museum opens at 10:30. When you are done with the palace rooms, many of the tours have moved on and you can enjoy the museum rooms with less crowds. Don`t skip the exhibitions on the first floor since they are quite amazing, too. Make sure you buy your ticket online, since the lines for the ticket booth are very long. As soon as you are inside the building with your internet ticket, buy your tours for the Golden and Diamond rooms since the tours fill up quite fast and you might have to go back to Hermitage an extra day just to see those like we had to. If you have to choose one of the two, I would go with the Diamond Room. It is very impressive and not to be missed.

Tips for independent visitors. I visited on Friday morning of 24/Jul and the queues for the ticket machines were in the hundreds. Queues for the manned booths were even longer!If you have a credit card I’d highly recommend buying from hermitageshop.org under ‘tickets’. You don’t need to print out the emailed voucher. At the Internet Purchased ticket collection booth you can just show a mobile phone with the voucher loaded on screen. For purchase confirmation ID they were quite happy to accept my foreign driver's licence. With a ticket in hand you can walk pass all the other queues, straight into the building proper and head to the security screening. I’m sure it saved me at least an hour of queuing!I’d also recommend buying the 2 day pass. It’s only 25% more expensive than the single day pass but allows you to browse the museum without rushing. Or the worry that you’ll miss some highlights because you spent too long elsewhere.It’s probably best to eat a large breakfast before hand. I passed the ground floor cafes during lunch and they were packed. Some with people standing in the hallways while eating a purchased takeout lunch. I am quite sure outside food/drinks are not allowed in the gallery.The descriptions of the art and room curation was a mixed bag. In rare cases such as the Egyptian Eastern Collection everything was only in Russian. Others had extensive curation both in Russian and English using touch screen computers. While most rooms had English and Russian item descriptions. Some rooms also offered RU, EN,French and German curation that were printed on boards. Annoyingly not every room in the Hermitage was clearly numbered so it made navigation more complicated than it needed to me.Inside I didn’t find the crowds too bad. There were always plenty of empty rooms next to the crowded ones. The large tour groups usually collected together, so skip those rooms and come back later when they are gone. Unlike other famous museums such as the ones in Florence or Paris, the tour groups are not infinite. If you’re patient enough, the groups will dissipate and you’ll often have a famous masterpiece all to yourself.I also bought The Hermitage Guidebook for 700₽. It is probably not worth buying unless you want a keepsake. There is no numbered contents which made it extremely annoying to use. It’s only usefulness while in the museum was for finding the location of highlighted artworks and the maps at the back of the book.

Gorgeous building, splendid museum, but ridiculously crowded.. The must see in St Petersburg. The amazing interior, the outstanding collection of painting and sculpture from various countries and ages make Hermitage one of the greatest museum in the world. You will find here genius masterpieces. The Winter palace is so big; a day will never be enough to see it. The lines to the ticket office are terrible. The queue is much smaller though if you go to the electronic ones, I would recommend to book your tickets on the Hermitage website, where tickets are a bit more expensive.The place sure is worth a visit. You will need a full day if you're into museums, a few hours or half a day if just interested in the architecture or would like to get just an impression.

Exhausting. There is so much to see in this museum, it can be quite daunting, we had a guide who was very inflexible; she appeared to have a script and was very grumpy if we asked questions or wanted to go a different route, which I found quite frustrating. We visited the "diamond room" which seems a misnomer, probably to get more visitors, it's lovely and there are a lot of great things to see but not many diamonds!Although secondary to the exhibits the coffee shop and gift shop were very disappointing. Focus on the Russian rooms where the chandeliers are stunning. The mechanical peacock is a must see.

Lavish and Opulent. It's hard to determine which is more extraordinary: the building or the art. Personally, I feel that there are better art collections, but the building itself is the real attraction. The lavishness of the decoration is breathtaking. Do a little research about the development of The Hermitage before you go so that you have a context for what you are seeing. Like all world-class museums, The Hermitage is incredibly crowded so be prepared to be jostled by tour groups. Be there when it opens. Buy your tickets online and then go directly to the Internet window where you exchange your voucher for a ticket and then go directly into the museum; otherwise plan on standing in line for a few hours. You can not see everything in one day, don't even try. Pre-plan your visit so that you stay focused on seeing those exhibits that interest you, but make sure that you pay attention to the building...it's the real treasure.

Wonderful, gorgeous, marvelous central palace. Must be seen place! Located at the very center of the city it impresses you from the first sight. And inside is the major museum Hermitage, shall be visited as well!

Magnificent.. One cannot miss this , but be prepared for long periods of waiting, many tourists and even sometimes rude tourists!The art is astonishing, the opulence of old Russia makes one realize why the 1917 revolution took place.

Amazing!. Our guide told us that there are over 3 million items in the museum, so if you take just 1 minute to appreciate each item, and you do that non-stop, you'll need more than 5 years to see everything. If you walk all the walkways, you will cover 23 km.so rich, so interesting, awesome!Take a guide or rent an audio explanation system
Amazing place. As the guide explained, you'd need a few years to properly see everything, however what was shown to us was explained in depth and was very interesting and inspiring.
Language guide. Try to get on a tour of your language. Russian language tours are the most frequent. Or you can just go by yourself without the benefit of a guide and hire the electronic translator

Schedule a full day - excellent and impressive. Absolutely a must see in St. Petersburg. This was a huge museum, inclusive of the art museum and the "Palace interiors", you have a choice of what to visit, take both and enjoy the day.
One big museum. Very much worth a visit, however big queues for tickets. We got ours from the machines but were unable to purchase tickets for the gold or diamond rooms.

Great but Don't Try on Your Own First Time. A must-see in St Petersburg but you are smart if you visit with a tour group the first time. First, the admission lines are terrible. And second, there is so much to see that it is a good to have an experience guide give you an overview for your first visit.

Impressive Impressive Impressive. What an amazing place!!! Be prepared to spend your day there and even if you do all you get to see is a portion of this great museum and Palace. The evening before I was in Palace Square, a beautiful sight, wide open spaces. I just stood there mesmerised by all that vastness. The next day it was chaos, buses, tour guides, masses of people lining up at 9.30 a.m. (all ticket offices open at 10.30 even the electronic ones), the queue is much smaller though if you go to the electronic ones, but I would recommend to book your tickets on the Hermitage website. It is a little bit more expensive but certainly worth it as you don't have to line up. Once through the doors there is the cloakroom on your left side, you have to leave your backpack there, so make sure you have a small handbag to take with you while you are visiting the museum. Cloakroom is free of charge. After security check you're in, you can then opt to buy a booklet or an audio guide, take your id with you so don't have to leave a deposit . You are now ready to start visiting these immense halls and galleries, starting of course from the Jordan Staircase made first by Rastrelli's and then Stasov. A tiring but wonderful day!!!!!!
Ridiculously Crowded. I thought this place could be, would be, AMAZING. It was so crowded that I was shocked. Why not limit the people? Anyway I was disappointed since the crowds were overwhelming!!!

Vast museum in gorgeous building!. This place is huge, impressive, and seem so familiar if you've travelled around europe already.The building itself, the winter palace, is a joy to look at. Beautiful colours and architecture!The museum housed therein is monumental. it's so big, a day will never be enough to see it.. So pick what you wanna see!Also, I found it hard to navigate in there, but then again, I always do in large museums.However, if you've travelled europe a bit and visited your share of museums, this all seems extremely familiar. Interior architecture reminds a lot of the vatican museums, and the exhibits are basically interchangeable, except the paintings of russian tsars and emperors, etc.The grand staircase and ballroom, however, are just jawdropping. The place sure is worth a visit! A full day if you're into museums, a few hours or half a day if just interested in the architecture.

Great Museum. Due to the fact that the most visitors are coming from Russia the place is great for people who are interested on this matter.It gives you a feeling about the former times and the interference between Russian soul and Russian church.

Mostly possitive. Definately a must see in ST Petersburg. A lot to see inside. The building itself is very grand. Such a beautiful. Be warned of long queues. There is an automatic ticket machine just inside the palace gardens which is not sign posted and may save you some time. Can be tough to get photos as well due to the volume of people inside, but Russia does a great job of maintaining its museums. Definately recommended!!

Beautiful- too much to see!. Very beautiful and with so much to see you could get lost for days! Hire a good guide- I recommend dancing bears tour company as they were able to get us in with no waiting in line and expertly take us to some key highlights. My favorite part was the dining room where the last tzar and his family were captured. They left it intact and the broken clock where it fell when they were taken us still there! You could feel the history it was eerie as you imagined what that night was like.

A humbling experience even for avid museum goers - Absolutely stunning.... I totally underestimated the grandeur of the Hermitage and its value as a piece of architecture and history beyond the amazing art pieces it may hold. In peak July on a rainy day...definitely get online tickets ahead of time. I spent one hour in line starting at 3 PM, when I expected the lines would go down. It was a Wednesday when the museum is open until 9 PM, so many others had the same idea I did. In 3 hours in the museum, I barely had enough time to walk to the highlights noted in the museum map and the Lonely Planet, much less pay attention to the details of individual pieces of art!

Try and buy tickets ahead.. As far as museums and buildings go you can't miss the Hermitage if your visiting St Petersburg. We brought tickets from the machine in our hotel lobby, and was able to jump the long line. You could spend days here to take everything in. We not museum lovers so we narrowed down what we really wanted to see and with the help of the very good maps was able to see everything we wanted in a couple of hours, it really is breath- taking in parts.
Must see!. If you're in St. Pete, this place is a must see, plan to spend 90 to 120 minutes at least in this place!

Palatial. The Hermitage is a must see, but for me its more the buildings rather than the art. You can see much better art in better laid out museums, but few can compare with the building, the rooms, floors, ceilings etc. The only annoying factor is the many zombie like tour groups led through the same halls, when the adjoining room is empty and just as interesting.

hermitage museum. amazing...excellent...wow...what can I say about this place other than wwooooowwww....when you see a masterpiece and 3th. grand museum in the world...building in no.1...you will be really affected and appreciate russian architectures...it's a must....you shohld visit russia specially st.peters burgh ad hermitage

"Not To Be Missed". A one-of-a-kind, sumptuous building that houses the finest collection of art in the world after the Louvre in Paris. Plan to spend at least one full day there, especially if you treasure art as well as architecture.

Must See. We only spent two hours here, but that was truely amazing. The Hermitage is currently has 7 building diplaying the art, with plans to add another building. There is so many works of art it would take days to see it all. The collective has been gathered from far and wide. They even have some Rembrandt paintings. If you are in St Petersburg make time to visit here, you will be happy you did.

HERMITAGE IS OF COURSE A MUST SEE. This is one of the main attractions in St. Petersburg and definitely worth the visit. We toured in only a couple of hours as we had so many other places to see, but next visit we'll spend more time at the Hermitage.

The absolute highlight of my trip to Saint Pete. I had doubted whether to go into the Winter Palace or not, but finally I decided to do it and THANK GOD I made that decision! it is definitely the best museum - gallery - palace I have visited in my whole life. But it does consume a lot of time, so I would suggest to go early knowing that you will probably spend the bulk of your daily time in there. It is worth it.

Makes the Lourve look TINY!. Our group went in before it opened to the Public! This place is a MUST see! You cannot see the whole thing, so do sign up for a tour to get in early! They have pieces of art that you may have never thought you would ever see for yourself! Amazing Place to see!

Go in early with an organised tour. We only had 2 days in St. Petersburg, so we decided to join the excursion to the Hermitage that our cruise liner was organising. This was the easiest, due to visa restrictions. In retrospect, this was the right decision. Being on a tour meant that we could get into the Hermitage at least an hour before the doors opened to the general public. After it opens, it becomes almost impossible to see anything due to the sheer amount of people. However, the place is so amazing that it is really a must-see. If you want to do it properly, you need at least a full day, but I am glad we could go, even if it was just for 3 hours. Being with a guide also meant she could point out the most important pieces, explain the history behind them and take us quickly from room to room without having to constantly look at the map to find our way. You are not allowed to take bulky jackets or rucksacks, but there's a safe place to leave them if you need to.

Great museum but has its issues. The exhibits in the museum were amazing. Problems with this museum is there is no crowd control or flow. It is one giant free for all. Groups of 30 take up a whole hallway and will just stand there so you can't get by.

Excellent. St Petersburg iconic museum and one of the most known museums in the world. The museum closes on Monday. it's on the palace square unmissable. Be prepared for long lines, we stayed 2 hours waiting. Once we got inside we were already tired so didn't see it all. Go early and relaxed to enjoy it.

spectacular. The detail and impressive size of the Hermitage was incredible, with so much history, a visual feast to the eyes and the grand scale is impressive with a huge coverage of art work and history of the palace in one

Best in the world. We've been to museums on almost every continent known to man.But you ain't seen nuthin til you've seen this one.Worth it for the opulent architecture alone, but the artwork is magnificent. And if you are still standing at the end of a long day, use your ticket to get into see the French impressionists on the other side of Palace Square.
Mind Blowing. Buckingham Palace would fit in a wing over here! Absolutely amazing but haphazard queing system....NOT!

Absolutely Stunning. No pictures or words can define this architectural master piece. From the entrance staircase, through every room, it is just amazing. The fantastic peacock clock, ornate ceilings, priceless paintings. Depending on the time of year, art students replicate some of the old masters, great talent.Tip, get there early, from mid morning it is worse than the London underground!

"A way to see the world...". These words I have once heard to have remembered in an interview of the current director of the State Hermitage Museum - Piotrovsky Mikhail - who took over this responsibility after his father. The key message is that those who have seen the Hermitage, see this world differently than those who did not. The more you visit, the more refined becomes your own :) It resonates the truth!

Spend the day! Don't miss fourth floor staff building!. We thoroughly enjoyed our day here. On Wednesday in the summer, it is open until eight pm. We took two private tours. You can't buy these tickets in advance. As you enter the museum, you will see a separate booth for the Gold Room Tour and the Diamond Room Tour. Each tour costs three hundred rubles and lasts about an hour. There were two English tours for each room a day and they only let about fifteen people on each tour. The Gold Room tour is really informative and outstanding. Pick that if you can do only one. The Diamond Treasure has lots of snuff boxes, the horse decorations and blankets are memorable thoughWe had a private guide for the rest of the museum and state roomsSave time for the Staff Apartment fourth floor! It is a separate building and costs three hundred rubles. It is an impressive collection of impressionist paintings, lots of Matisse. It is not crowded and as far as paintings go by far my favorite part of the museum!

A must "go" for all. The Hermitage Museum is without a doubt one of the must see museums of the world. From Da Vinci to Michelangelo, from Ancient Egypt to Imperial Russia, there is something for everybody and this doesn't even take into account the Palace itself which is an architectural masterpiece. ! suggestion, take the time to visit palace square at night when the Winter Palace is shown in all its glory by a fantastic light display.
Wow!. Yes, this was such a wonderful place to visit. I have dreamed of coming to Russia and this did not disappoint. Could spent way more than the 4 hours we were in here.

Amazing collection of art, Rembrandts, but crowded. Have a private guide to take you through the Hermitage early in the morning when the crowds have not arrived- there is no way you would be able to navigate the highlights by yourself and you will get lost in a large tour group. The place is huge, crowded, and all of the signage for directions are in Russian. Also, you need to know a lot of history to appreciate some of the collections. The collection of art is absolutely amazing, so many Rembrandts from your art history classes are there. The mechanical clock is also astounding.Book as separate group tour of the Treasures of the Hermitage- the highlight of St. Petersburg. You get to see so many amazing jewel encrusted pieces from Russian history and Catherine the Great's possessions, as well as a Faberge egg donated to the Hermitage by Putin. Those group tours are limited to fifteen people, but be prepared to be astounded by the grandeur and scope of the treasures.There is a crummy cafe in the Hermitage by the gift shops that takes dollars and euros as well, but the lousy sandwiches will keep you from starving, given that you will likely spend the whole day at the Hermitage.

Never enough time. You're so wowed by everything that you'll never have enough time. Everywhere you look there's something spectacular. Yiu could spend an entire day looking at moldings, floors, doors, ceilings, fireplaces and never even look at the art! I enjoyed this more than the Louvre.

One of the best. Having been to many of the world's best museums I rank this with the Vatican and the Louve. We toured in a group of 8 and were directed to many of the great paintings that reside on the Hermitage. The only disappointment was that the impressionist paintings were moved to a separate building that we did not have time to see.

Jaw dropping. We booked a guide to take us round which was a good idea as the place is so vast you would just wander round & probably miss some of the good things to see. We had 2 & 1/2 hours in here & that was enough. There is so much to see in here but your brain can only take in so much!
Great place. Really interesting history about its original build then restoration. Gardens were also really impressive

Amazing . It's a historical canvas in its own right the works of art are almost incidental. Ignore the statistics of it taking years to see everything just give yourself plenty of time to spend lots of time there. Preferably go in the winter when you will not be swept along by the crowds. Get a good guide and plan what you want to see and then enjoy.

Love this museum!!　. Wonderful collection and lovely staff are at this museum. I fell in love with Russian artworks and staffs here. It's a top-tier and must-visit place in the world!素晴らしい内装及びコレクションはベルサイユ宮殿にも劣らぬ素晴らしさ。ここに来て、一気にロシア好きになりました。入り方が今一わからなくて、２０分くらい中庭とチケット窓口を行ったり来たりしたけど、スタッフも英語がわからないながらも指であっちあっちと頑張って教えてくれたり頑張ってくれたので、仕方ないです。正しい入り方は、私は前売り券をオンラインで買って印刷した紙を持っていたので、列の先頭に割り込んで窓口の方に提示するとすぐに発券手続きしてくれました！なんと割り込みオッケーなのです。ちょっとドキドキしました。美術館の中にあるミュージアムショップの女性も大変フレンドリーに接してくださり、大変満足いく時間を過ごせました。サンクトに来たら、絶対にまた前売り券を買って行きます！！

Stunning. The place is totally worth seeing! We had only 3 hours, which is not enought. The winter palace is so beautiful! There is also other building included to the Hermitage, but almost all our time was in the Winter palace. Even my boyfriend said this was his favorite place in Saint Petersbourg, and he doesen't normally even like museums. We'll come back next year. Little tip:You can byu tickets in the automat inside, so you don't have to stay in the line - the line takes really long. The automat works with cash and credit card.
An amazing collection!. We visited the Hermitage with a private guide early in the day. The crowds had not yet arrived and we had a wonderful visit.

Plan before you go.. The museum cannot be explored in one day, so its better to get a multi-day pass to appreciate everything. We also had a guide so if you have the chance to get one, better do so since it helps to have someone explain the history behind the works as compared to just looking around. Be there as early as you can so you can get space in the cloakrooms which get full quite fast, especially if there are multiple tour groups from cruises visiting at the same day. We only saw toilets in the ground floor so better use them beforehand.

Far and away the best Museum ever AN ABSOLUTE MUST SEE in St Pete. I am not a museum kind of guy but wife wanted to go. We went at 10 am and left at closing. Would take 2-3 days to see all there is to see.More Greek/Roman statures than in Greece / Italy. You can literally touch the displays. This museum has everything from the Czars to Egyptian mummies, Totally an amazing place. Never made it to the Winter Gardens (Next time).***Buy your tickets from your hotel and you won't have to wait in line. Go to the right of the long line and straight into the museum,** Good bookstore with lots of gifts for kids and adults.**There is an APP from the Hermitage which is quite useful* Pictures are allowed but no flash - Please adhere to this relic saving

"The Louvre of Russia". Similarly to the Louvre, the saying goes... if you were to spend a minute looking at each exhibit on display in the Hermitage, you would need 11 years before you’d see everything. Just know that only a very tiny percentage of art and paintings is on display, the rest in storage and of the items on display, you will only get to see a fraction. What you do come away with is the overwhelming beauty and scale of the Hermitage. Buy the books after the tour for future reference and information on what you saw!! The paintings I saw... wow! The furniture, chandeliers, ceramics, tile work... wow! The Diamond Room... double wow!! In this museum, it is allowed to take photos unlike many of the other Cathedrals and Catherine's Palace and Peterhof so click away... except in the Diamond Room where it is not allowed. Be patient as the crowds in the summer are huge and try and go early if you can. I was with my small Travel All Russia group so it was easy to manoeuvre around. Wear comfortable shoes and hydrate as you need at least 4 hours minimum!!!!

A lot to see, and then some. The Hermitage Museum probably isn't the best art gallery in the world. A handful of others might have better works, depending on how you judge these things.But the Hermitage probably is in the top 10, and it probably has more quality items than any other art museum. That means that it's an amazing experience to walk through, and you'll never see more than a tiny fraction of it all unless you move to St. Petersburg.I can't say I ever saw a Rembrandt before, and the place had a room full of his works. I've heard that many of the works here were more or less stolen, or at least purchased under shady circumstances.Our visit was on a Sunday, and no matter how big the place was, it was definitely oversold. It felt like a football game, particularly when I was caught in something of a mob of Chinese tourists who surged forward as a group and surrounded me. (Rules on personal space must be different there.) Their attention was focused on the picture shown, a work by da Vinci - I think. At least, I remember it this way when dodging the crowd.One interesting point about the place is that photography is allowed. Most galleries tell you to at least keep the flash off, but they don't seem to care here. Therefore, I've got several photos of some great areas in my album; I just felt like snapping away when I saw something interesting, and it was almost all interesting.

World class - a must see. This place gets really busy. We booked ahead for an early morning tour with a private guide. We didn't see it all, just highlights, and the guide got us through ahead of the crowds. Amazing art, and I could easily see some people spending many days there if cost was not a concern. .

Not To Be Missed. This is one of the world's most fabulous museums. You need a minimum of 3 hours and that would only be enough time for the ultra highlights! There are sculptures, paintings and multiple other artifacts and works of art to view! The museum encompasses 5 buildings which were former palaces.

Top site in all of St. Petersburg. Cannot do this in one day. There are two different experiences, the winter palace with all of its grandeur and beauty and then the art. For me the winter palace was the more important of the two. You can see great art in one of many museums around the world, the palace is very special. Was disappointed with the impressionist art which moved to new building, collection was quite thin. Also did this with a personal guide. Not sure how good the audio guides are. I used in one museum in Istanbul and was very disappointed. Other choices are group tour wherre where you wear earphones and the guide talks to the group via her mouthpiece. Seems very effective. Of course, private tour is best but more expensive. If we spend the time alone, it would have been difficult. Just navigating through the crowds to check your coat and bags could be an ordeal. The guide made this more easier for us. Can get through the Hermitage and see a great deal if spend 5-6 hours with guide. More time if you are really into the art and want to spend lots of time looking at each picture. Other advantage of a guide is that you get into the museum quickly. We observed the queue which could require 1-2 hours in line before getting into museum.

What Can I say Amazing Amazing Amazing. Well what can one say it is the best museum in the world! Top Tip make sure you buy your ticket on line and exchange your voucher at the internet kiosk at the entrance to the museum. No queues at all. Buy your ticket there and be prepared for a 2 hour queue. It felt great to walk straight in!! Of course it's amazing and busy. We bought a two day pass to use on consecutive days. I think on your first visit it's worth doing it as a private or small group tour just to familiarize yourself and get background information and a bit of an idea about whats what. The State apartments are awe inspiring. Then you have time to go back or see more at your leisure.
Hey mirage not to be missed. Another amazing building with treasures galore inside. From furniture to armour, and everything In between. So much history. Only drawback, crowds. Get there early.

Holy Hermitage. If you are going to St Petersburg in Summer you really are going to have to just suck it up and deal with the crowds because they are everywhere and 99% of them will be at the Hermitage.This said it is amazing and Russians are fond of reminding you that is the second greatest collection of art after the Louvre.The Tsars certainly splurged on everything but their people but thankfully this amazing collection is now for the people. This will take a number of hours to do if you want to remotely do it justice. We found a guide who took us around to the highlights and was worth every cent. A must see.

State Hermitage Museum. The State Hermitage Museum and winter palace is very large museum and it has 1500 to 1800 century scaplture as well as antic piece. the gigantic collection of nearly three millions objects and ranked as one of the world's major museums.
Breathtaking. Amazing museum, gorgeous paintings. It's a massive museum everyone should visit at least once in their lifetime and I feel very lucky I could get to see everything in there...

Great museum, lots to see. This museum has probably the most diverse & impressive collections of the museums I've visited during my travels. From da Vinci paintings to the worlds oldest surviving carpet, there is something for everyone. With my 1.5 year old in tow, I could only manage 2 floors & left my husband to do 3 by himself. Don't bother paying for a guide - download their app instead! (There's even wifi at the entrance to allow you to do so) We used it to navigate our entire way around. The line to buy tickets was around 30 mins, so buy online if you wish to save time.

Extraordinary !. The number one tourism highlight for good reason. It absolutely defies description -- awesome seems so understated. Even our group visit of 2.5 hours (and we were exhausted by the end) seemed so limited. Try as best you can to avoid huge crowds lingering around the most popular pieces of art -- let them pass if you can, and then jump in. It's challenging. We were fortunate to mostly see the most important artistis, but really the place overall is so over-powering that such crowding shouldn't let you down.A fantastic tour guide can make all the difference in your experience here. The audio guide, I am sure, is very good but an articulate licensed guide will make your Hermitage visit efficient and interesting (and of course, you can ask questions!).

What can I say - Absolutely Breathtaking. You have to go through the Hermitage complex - It is stunning - I did find the wealth rather obscene though and have much pity for the starving and freezing peasants of the time.

Absolutely Breathtaking . No words can describe this experience. This is hands down one of the most beautiful places I have ever been. From the amazing gold decorated ceilings to the huge amount of classic art, the Hermitage Museum is a must do for anyone traveling into St Petersburg, Russia.

Speechless!. For myself this is the best museum I have ever visited and the best attraction in this beautiful city. Da Vinci, Rembrandt, Michelangelo. All original pieces. What can I say. You have to see for yourselves. You won't regret it. This gorgeous palace is simply stunning. Try to go with an organized tour because they are allowed an earlier start when it's much less crowded. I am totally speechless!
Russian Glamour at its best!. Be prepared to spend many hours visiting this astonishing Palace. There is a lot to see. Art from many countries and regions, as well as sculptures and furniture.

Plan to stay as long as you have time for... so much to see... so little time. Unfortunately, we only had two hours to basically rush through the Hermitage on our booked tour and see the highlights. Our tour guide Anna from TJ Travels was full of insightful & intriguing information about the buildings, the art and artifacts and the history of the Hermitage. I wish we had a lot more time there but there's just never enough time on a vacation like this. If you must only see one place in St. Petersburg, let it be the Hermitage Museum.

Amazing. We went on an organised tour from the cruise ship and were the first tour party to enter the museum when it opened. As a result, there were no crowds and we were able to see everything we wished to see from close up. This is an incredible museum and it is impossible to see everything in a few hours. It pays to go really early, as it becomes very crowded by mid-morning.

Stunning. Hermitage museum is enormous and breathtaking with over 3 million exhibits. Attached to the beautiful winter palace. Recently the palace church for the tsars has been opened to the public. Stay in Hermitage as long as your trip will allow as so much to see and so much to photograph. Beautiful. We booked the St Petersburg 2 day tour with Denrus online at $189 per person whereas our cruise ship tour wanted $459 per person. Our tour was first class. All visa and entrance tickets included. Highly recommended!!!!!!

Rich and inspiring. No matter if this is your first, second or tenth visit to Saint Petersburg, you must spend few hours in the Hermitage. The richness of this place can't be seen in one visit and I don't recommend even to try to see it all. It's impossible! Take your time, dedicate it to part of the place. Enjoy your visit and come again.

Must do tour - take at the least a general guided tour. There is nothing to dislike about the Hermitage. The queue on the otherhand is rather annoying. If you can prebook your entrance and a tour - do it. There are limited English speaking tours, so check and work your day around it.
Great. One of the largest and oldest museums in the world, it was founded in 1764 by Catherine the Great. It has the largest collection of paintings in the world.

OMG!!!. I loved everything about the Hermitage.I'd waited 40 years to see it, & I wasn't disappointed. So opulent, extravagant, so excessive, and so beautiful. Both the palace and the museum (s) are worth a couple of days. Not for everyone, but it was a highlight for me.
Ermitage. L'ermitage the place to go in Saint Petersburg. Huge Museum you have to go for all pictures and scuptures etc... but also the museum itself

Simply amazing. Spend at least 2 days here. But a ticket on line. Try to accept the huge amount of tourgroups. It can be a Challenge, as they start before the individual visitors. See the palace before the Hermitage from the early morning, we enjoyed it nearly alone.

Don't bother unless it,s winter. Unless your going in the winter realy don,t bother. They jostle you in and pull you around by the nose. Too many people. You barely get to see anything barring the back of the person in front, so many beautiful beautiful treasures, and I came out feeling flat and disappointed with a sore foot from being stood on. My friend who uses a stick had to abandon the tour part way through because she was being so jostled she was struggling to keep up and frightened she would loose her footing because of the incessant jostling
the russian louvre. it's a sort of the russian louvre.Very nice museum with interesting pictures and sculptures to see.Too much waist of time to wait in line for everithing (like any place in Russia)

A "Must Do" When You Are in St. Petersburg!. The Hermitage is magnificent, is verrrry big, and a bit overwhelming. I recommend that you employ a private guide to see it all (we used Alla Tours) and plan for spending several hours in the museum (and still not see it all). The private guide, however, enables you to avoid standing in long lines, see the most outstanding sections, and provides fascinating commentary as you stroll through the museum. The Hermitage is featured in our video of St. Petersburg at https://vimeo.com/album/3471788/video/132972070).
Anazing experience of a historical moment!. One of the best art collection and the magnificient royal buildings! Must see attraction in St Petersburg...

Breathtaking & huge. A place to wondering!!
Too big that needs lots of time,
Group tour recommended, if go individually plan what you want to see first.

You could spend a month here.... This place is MASSIVE....and you see only a glimpse of it. Treasures beyond belief.  I would recommend visiting this attraction by booking it through a tour company. Number one reason is that you have a tour guide who will show you the highlights and explain what everything is (unless you are well versed in art). Secondly, and maybe most importantly, they take you in early - a little before it is open to the public. You can still encounter crowds but nothing like in the afternoons. The line-ups we saw when we were finished were crazy long. I bet people spent hours queuing for a ticket. If you wear a big jacket or take a knapsack, they insist that you check it in. An absolute must for tourists.
Very impressive. But!!Lines for tickets horroble....To main building.I sugest to start with new art in the Glavniy shtab building.Same tickets.No lanes.

Too many crowds . It is an amazing collection of history. Much of it was lost on me due to the enormity of exhibits and a billion people. It was just way too crowded. I'm very happy that such a massive display is now enjoyed by masses of numbers. Keeping this area for just a small group (royalty) is disturbingly ridiculous.Go early in the morning.

Must see, Tips on how to beat the lines!. this is a venue you must visit while in Russia. It will be more than you can do in a day. Russian grandeur on display like no other. Much more than a museum. The planning part is using a tour guide to navigate the lines that are hours long. We used St Petes Private Tours and Natalia was our guide. She got us to the front of the line and straight to an entry inside that had no wait (different floor, took a little negotiation on her part). She knew the museum very well and was able to take us to the parts we wanted to see and the highlight. Without her, it would have been a nightmare. Even the group tours move very slowly.

Be prepared to be blown away. This is a very big museum housed in the most beautiful of buildings.It has a wide range of exhibits and you must decide what you want to see specifically or you will be offered the taster version giving you the highlights of the best exhibit they have.The visits are fast paced and you cover a lot of ground.

every person should , must visit Hermitage once in lifetime. enormous , breath taking, unbelievable ,unimaginable beauty, don,t spend your money on the tour , get your tickets in courtyard where all Russians are buying tickets , they will help you anyway they can with broken English, go to the line of ticket holders and walk in, matter of a few minutes you are in Hermitage. buy a book at gift shop and explore and loose yourself in beauty of it.

Incredible. It's amazing enough to see this as a palace and royal apartments. Add to it the amazing art collection and it's just overwhelming. Do not miss this museum. If you can get a local guide that can get you in early, spend the money. It's the most amazing way to see the museum as you have it virtually to yourself.

The ONE thing that you can't miss in St. Pete!. Amazing museum! The huge collection would take days, maybe months, to be seen, so plan ahead in order not to miss the things you'd like to see. The Winter Palace building is not to be missed, beautiful architecture and majestic settings. Photos and videos are only allowed if you buy an extra authorization at a decent fee.

Awesome. The grandeur of the building, parquet floors, ballrooms, ornate ceilings, is worth the ticket price in itself.
