A must. Absolutly a must. This is the best collection of art treasures i have ever seen. Even though i am not an art buff it was well worth the visit. An absolute must when in St Petersburg. All the old masters are on display not all locked up a tiumph to the Russian people.

Hermitage is worth seeing. Not to be missed. Amazing collection of art pieces and works. Many rooms and it is pretty large museum. Our guide explained and showed us all the not to be missed art pieces. It was very crowded when we were there, as there were 3 cruise ships docked that day in St Petersburg. So imagine the number of tourists visiting the museum at the same time. We nearly lost our tour guide in the Hermitage museum.

Hermitage. This was the most crowded building I've ever been in, but even so, it was breathtaking. It was worth being bumped into right and left! I understand if I go back, it should be in Feb, when less crowded. Even if you can barely see the art on the walls, just the environment is worthwhile!

Overwhelming amount of fine art. This is an overwhelming group of palaces that are also a museum. It is very popular so you need to wait in a long queue just to buy a ticket. My wife and I had a personal guide so we did not wait at all since there were only 2 of us, the other guided groups had to wait their turn since there were so many of them, still they got in faster than those queuing for tickets. The Automatic ticket machines also had a large queue, at least in the morning. I thoroughly recommend purchasing tickets on-line and if for some reason you can't here's a tip: the tickets include the "General Staff" Building across the square there is a ticket office there too check if that has a queue at all, if you arrive from the Nievsky Propect Street, you pass under that building first anyway. Unless you are an art academic with previous knowledge about this complex, I suggest you get yourself a good guide, you need one to appreciate all the architecture, the interior architecture, the interior decoration and just to know where you are.Do not miss the display at the "General Staff" building - basically a chronological history of Russian art.To appreciate all the art there you will need a week! We spent 3 hours with our guide at the Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace, then went over to the "General Staff" building (keep your ticket, this is a separate entrance), after a short coffee break at Shokoladenitza on the corner of Nievsky prospect, for another 90 minutes. We still felt we haven't seen it all. We chose a Wednesday visit, entered at 15:00, left the Hermitage at 18:00, entered the "General Staff" building around 18:45 and left at 20:15, possible only on Wednesdays when the complex stays open till 21:00

If you visit St Petersburg you must visit here. the sheer size of the complex is daunting and like the Louvres in Paris you are not going to see everything. I strongly advise getting a guided tour because of the complexity of the layout and the fact that you will miss things of importance if you just wander. Secondly the line for the entrance for individual visitors is horrendous. It really is magnificent and even without its treasures the buildings alone would be worth seeing.

Book to see with a guide!. Due to the size of the palace and the number of exhibits the best way to see it is to have a guide with you and a list of things you want to see. We went expecting to get through our list in about 2-3 hours but it took us over 4 hours with the guide taking us here and there and getting in front of the queues. We didn't have the time to get to see the impressionists as well but I am very happy with what we saw!!

Amazing museum and palace. This is an amazing palace and an amazing museum. There are so many wonderful art work and decorative items in it. Rooms of the palace are amazing. Large windows allow so much light in. We loved it. It is hard to visit a museum this size in one day, we did as much as possible within reason. Still couldn't see a lot. But the point is to enjoy life not to push to the limit. We would like to return again one day. Not to wait in the queues, buy your ticket online in advance. If that's not possible, use the ticket machines outside of Hermitage. Once left the museum it is not possible to get back in so plan accordingly. It is very crowded. Store whatever in your hand in the locker room area. Wear comfortable shoes.

(Lost for words). If you're in St. Petersburg, you HAVE to visit the Hermitage. There is so much to see, and so little time. I was there for an hour or so, but really, you'd need a week to see everything. Is there an adjective that describe beautiful more beautifully? That is what I would use. I was lost for words when I was in there. There are room after rooms of beautiful intricate walls and ceilings, fine sculptors, delicate pottery, any and everything in between. I walked from room to room, in silence, struggling to process the amount of beauty that was before me. I was just imagining the skills required to create, paint, make, build anything in the hermitage. Just wow.Lost for words.I bought home with me, a copy of a painting. There is a lot of choice to choose from, from the shops before the exit. I'll have to come back again. One day.

Hermitage is worth two hours, two days or more of your time in St.Petersburg. The Winter Palace of the Czars which is also the home of the Hermitage Museum is a very impressive building and worth a visit on its' own. The interior is elaborately and ornately decorated and the staircases, floors, ceilings and open areas are quite impressive.The Hermitage,though, is the star attraction. Housing one of the largest and most impressive art collections in the world, it showcases major works by major artists such as Michelangelo, Da Vinci, Raphael, Rembrandt and more. One of the guides said the collection is so large that only 20% can be displayed. Another said if you spent only ten seconds looking at each painting or sculpture, it would take years to see it all.As overwhelming (and crowded) as this sensory overload can be, it is well worthwhile visiting even if you only have a few hours to spend there.

Stunning!. I've been to many of the most important musea in different countries and continents but this one is very special. Not only the extremely rich collection, but also the palace and its rooms are breathtaking. I went in at the left side while most of the people go up the Jordan staircase which allowed me to see a big part of the museum without crowds. Don't buy an online ticket when you cannot print it out. There's NI wifi and the staffmember at the digital ticket redeem boot speaks only Russian which is a pity for this lever of museum

Worth a visit despite Russian bureaucracy. The place and the collections are legendary. The gilding alone is worth the visit, and it is a pure demonstration of why the starving populace of Russia rose up in revolt. It is hard to contemplate the splendor, the riches, the elaborate workmanship without actually seeing it. And there is no possibility of seeing it all. In one guide book I read that it would take 11 years to actually look at everything that there is on display. So go! That said, at the peak of tourist season it is a huge crush. Go early, book online. But.... Coming armed with a print out of your purchase does not get you in. You still have to stand in line. A shorter line, but a line nevertheless. There was only one woman working this booth! It took us 45 minutes to exchange our online purchase into an official ticket. There are no signs to tell you which line is the right one only a few women asking to see the printed proof of pre purchase. Without that, there was a line that looked be a two hour wait. And once we had a ticket we still had to stand in a security line, and then getting in we were ushered into a back entrance and so the sequence of our visit was incomprehensible. And if you want to see the jewels - that is a whole different ticket, new lines and one has to do a guided tour. If you go with a group, you still won't be able to avoid the crush, but you can skip the lines. Really my best recommendation is go early and be the first in line.

Maybe get a two day ticket. The Hermitage is a must see, but because of the size of the place I think the two day ticket option is a good idea. We only took a day ticket and ran out of energy. However, we saw heaps and you cannot expect to really see it all properly - it would take a week or so. We bought our tickets from a machine just inside the gate and did not have to wait in any queues which was a pleasant surprise

The French Impressionists have moved. Latest news from St Petersburg - Attention all lovers of French Impressionists. We visited this wonderful museum today but before we entered, our guide (Anna) from Russian Express, let us know that ALL the French Impressionists and Modernists ( from Degas through to Picasso) are on display in the General Staff Building across the road. NONE are in the Hermitage itself.So as you stand in the centre of the Palace Square and face the Winter Palace (at 12 o'clock), the General Staff Building sweeps behind you in a semi circle and the entrance to the greatest exhibition of French 19th Century genius is at 4 o'clock behind you.Please visit the main museum BUT remember to also visit the building opposite particularly if the real purpose of your visit is to see the French Impressionists. There is a separate charge of 300 roubles per person but it's worth it !

So much to see. We had to queue a long time to go in even though we had advance tickets ,this museum also closes on a Monday . It is the most amazing place with so much to see ,Rembrandt and Canaletto etc all in this place which its self is a work of art .we only had two hours you could not do it justice if you had two days.

The green building . I have become one of many now that I have walked the halls of the Hermitage! Amazing building that you can't miss as it lines the banks of the River Neva. We actually saw 2 Leonardo da Vinci paintings as well as over 25 Rembrandts! Bold statues are everywhere but the ceilings are sure to draw your eye up. Grand stairways capture your imagination as to how it must have been. Greek and Roman antiquities, Siberian and Asian art and the building itself are just some of the remarkable art that you will see. Crowded, crowded, crowded though so don't be in a rush!
Art Overload. Magnificent works of art by masters such as Di Vinci, Rembrandt, Goya and more. Need to allow hours, and you still won't see it all.

Excellent. A fantastic place we went with Princess Cruises the tour of the museum was wonderful lots of interesting things to see. A very popular place with tourists very busy, really needed more time to see everything

Wonderful. Immense museum and when I visited (June) was packed with tourists. The wing of the museum where artifacts are from Ukraine, Asia, etc was absolutely empty, fortunately. The museum building is wonderful. If possible reserves a few days to visit the museum. Recently the exhibition of the Impressionists was taken to another building, a beautiful modern building. I think that it also worths a visit, buy the admission tickets for both museums.

Contents Amazing! Tour Groups - Not So Amazing. I had always dreamed of going to the Hermitage and it did not disappoint. The collection (of which only 10% is on display) is stunning. Room after room after room filled with treasures. My favorite was the golden peacock clock, we weren't there to see it in action but there is a video that shows you what it looks like. We loved the rooms that weren't as popular with the groups like the Roman statues and coins from the 1st century BC. It was very overwhelming because there were hundreds of tour groups (we were with one too) all of them vying for space in each room. It was hot and some people were smelly. We loved our tour guide but she was having to race us through each room just to complete the visit. Once we split from the group we were able to go "backwards" through the exhibits and go at our own pace. This was much better than competing with the hoards.

Hermitage St Petersburg. an absolutely amazing experience not to be missed in St Petersburg however best done on an organized tour as waiting time as independent sightseeing is long. I am not usually into this type of thing but have to say really enjoyed it. Also with a guide it adds a lot ore meaning to what your are actually looking at.

European feel. St. Petersburg was, as I read, built to compete with prominent European cities such as Amsterdam, Venice, etc., and I say it has lived up to its motive - the open space square opposite the palace and the museum, along with other attractions do exude a feel of being not in Russia but in Europe

Why are you wasting time on this site when you could be in the Hermitage?. Seriously, it is awesome, and massive. It took me 3, 4-5 hour trips to see it all, but worth it. that place is like a maze, it has leonardo da vincis, stone age art, mummies, gold on almost every wall. Seriously this place is great. Even with the time i spent it know i didn't get enough time to actually enjoy every piece there. the best part, most museums like the lav and the Smithsonian put up copies of the originals to prevent losing them, the Hermitage doesn't they put up the real deal, that you could if you wanted to risk being kicked out touch as there is no glass in front of them
Inside or outside?. The exterior of this building is beautiful - certainly worth walking by. The Museum itself is nice but there's not that much interesting inside.

One of the best. Definetly one of the top museums, right along le Louvre and the MET. Countless masterpieces in a historic and welll preserved location. Booking online is a must as the queues are massive. Dont be discouraged by the armies of group visits, good things come to those who wait.

most visited place. there are few words to describe this place. while the paintings are wonderful to see, the hermitage museum itself is the real stunner. the rooms and walls and floors are magnificent, and one cannot really ever spend too much time here.

Amazing!. My husband and I visited The Hermitage on our second day tour of St. Petersburg. When visiting, one must remember that there are many stairs to climb with no elevators or air conditioning. But, the visit is well worth it. There is so much history here -- so much you can't comprehend it all. But the art and architecture is amazing! Well worth your time and money to visit The Hermitage when in St. Petersburg.

Fantastic collection. Do not miss the Hermitage Museum visit. Purchase the tickets on line, otherwise the lines can be long, and they are not open on Mondays. The collection displayed in Diamond Room is fantastic, and plan to spend a whole day there.

A grand museum. A huge collection of art pieces, one cannot possibly see all in a day or two. A guide would be helpful for a visit to this museum. Long ques and crowds inside are usual. Recommended to take a early morning entry.
Amazing!. Gold gold gold and so much history! It was spectacular! We were there for almost 6hours... we needed more time!

Worth visiting the 20thC collection. There's so much to see here in the main building - many hours' worth! - best spreading over a few visits if you possibly can.But despite what the room plan might tell you, the modern collection has been moved to the other side of the square. We had to buy separate tickets, but well worth it! A roomful of Van Goghs - some of which I'd never seen illustrated before; another of Monet, two rooms of Renoir - a great collection.

White nights in St Petersburg. It's the largest museum I've ever seen. You have to separate one day but it will not be enough. At the weekends it is very crowded you have to wait may be one hour at entrence.

So big, history of the whole world. From history of russia to history of britain, french, middle east, japan and other countries. A lot of history to brain in one day. If you are thinking about visiting hermitage museum then make sure to come early and had a good breakfast. The queue would be long by 12 pm especially in summer and it will take you one day to finish the whole museum, so make sure you have energy for it. I dont encourage buying souvenir from the museum as it cost more but theres no harm to do so. A great place for artists - theres a lot of amazing architecture and paintings.

A museum not to be missed.. This opulent palace is quite outstanding and with so much to see cannot be a rushed visit. Staying at the State Heritage Museum Hotel we were able to buy tickets in advance at a discount and did not need to join the lengthy queues at the museum.

By the tickets online:). Must have!!! The biggest museum of the world!!! Just buy your tickets online and come in the first part of the day!!! The most interesting hall with kids is with knights! Food inside is not very good but expensive... So, that would be wise to take smth with you or eat out later!Enjoy in any case!!!

WoW! The Granduer is Spectacular. A must see when travelling to Saint Petersburg. We went with an organized tour so only had a few hours, but you could literally spend a few days. The Winter Palace and it's grandeur is amazing. The palace rooms are simply spectacular. It is overwhelming to think of the grandeur of life at that time. The art at the Hermitage Museum is spectacular. There is so much to see that you literally could spend days seeing it. There are world class pieces of art. It's pretty crowded in the museum, especially around the world class pieces, but it wasn't too crowded in the palace itself. Our tour operator knew so much of the history and it was a fantastic way to navigate through the museum. Overall...SPECTACULAR.

A Must See. Every tourist goes to the State Hermitage Museum and for good reason. There is just so much to see of Saint Petersburg history here that it could take days to absorb it all. You will not be disappointed. If you have never been here, put it high on your "bucket list".

So Go - Just dodge the crowds!. Follow the advice of the seasoned travelers - get tickets on the internet (note - the 2 day tickets are for 2 consecutive days - if possible - go for Tuesday and Wednesday - the Museum stays open late on Wednesday - and the crowds go home.)Tour groups flood - FLOOD - the museum in the morning - it's horrid. So plan to do the less visited first floor in the AM - maybe a Gold or Diamond room tour - then head up for the headliners after the tour groups have gone home for lunch! You really don't want to try to see the Peacock Clock, say, over the heads of 300 people do you?Also - your ticket from the internet will include the Impressionist and 'Under the Eagle' collection at the brand newly renovated Staff building - and the renovation is an absolute must see. Glass walkways 2 floors above the heads of other tourists. Seriously.Cafeteria in the Staff building was inexpensive, and relatively good food. Avoid the food in the Hermitage proper at all costs. It's positively the worst ever. Pack in - which is fine - but be aware they won't let in back-packs. Plastic bags are fine however.You must see this museum - just plan your visit in reverse - important stuff last - after 2:00 PM - and you'll have time to stare and contemplate and enjoy.

Hermitage..a world class museum.. What a joy to visit this place. Superb art & artifacts displayed in an absolutely beautifulbuilding. Crowded ? Well ,yes, but don't let that deter you going. Get a private guide,such as Alisa at stpetetrip.com. & you will be well rewarded. This is one of the finestworld collections..don't miss it.

Exceptional. You will need more than one day to see this museum / castle. If you only have one day - go directly to the 2nd floor - the Russian part - it is outstanding - furniture, wooden floors, paintings, porcellan, ceilings, etc. If you have time look at the diamond room - needs special ticket - the most beautiful blingbling I have seen up to now....
A wow experience. A must see for everyone visiting St. Petersburg. And do allocate enough time - it is amazing! Suitable for young and old.

One of the very best in the World. We had over 2 hours but really you need several weeks to do it justice. There is so much to see and not enough time so you have to be selective...Make sure you have a guide otherwise you will just be lost. We went on an SPB tour with Maria and we got in early and avoided the crowds and also she was very knowledgeable about some key pieces which were must sees!Try to include the Peacock Clock...a masterpiece automaton clock .

Intriguing history of one great empire.. Hermitage is the great arts Museum in the heart of the Saint-Petersburg. The building itself was a residence of Romanov royal family for several centuries. The exhibition is divided into several time periods - and you can see a lot of portraits of Russian famous people, and historical paintings, and the evolution of Russian arts in the period of Romanov dynasty. All the building is the masterpiece of luxury and arts. if you are really interested in painting technique you will be without any option excited by the exhibition. But it is not only art itself but a part of a great period of history of growing empire. Good guide can really make some sort of time travelling adventure for you, as you will see the living palace and a people, most of them are on the paintings in exhibition crowded the halls, waiting for emperor and his family, talking e.t.c.This part of history was tragically ended, but it shadow cover some people in Russia nowadays as they wish Empire to be reborn. Though there are two groups wishing Royal Empire and Soviet Empire. This museum will give a foreigner more understanding of light and dark in Russian history and maybe more about the country and people types. Anyway it is a great experience. And it must not be missed. Have a good time1

Breathtaking building and art collection out of this world. If you are art lover, don't try to "do" all of the collections in 1 day. There are so many beautiful pieces, try to take time and enjoy them. Please note the entire impressionist collection was moved to the new premises across the square. You can buy tickets for both buildings at either location. I recommend the English guided tour for the impressionist wing as place is vast and collections are moved all the time at the moment. As this is very new arrangement, apparently they are still trying to find best way to make space work. Everybody very helpful, but their English is often very basic so do your research in advance and know what/ who you want to see. With name and a map they can direct you through the maze of this amazing building.
The Hermitage. I loved seeing the Hermitage. It is absolutely beautiful inside! It was very interesting to see how the czars lived and to see the large collection of artwork displayed there.

THe Winter Palace State Rooms are really stunnung and impressive. Due to limited time in St.petersburg and other things to see, we only visited the amazing Winter Palace and its State Rooms. I am far more interested in architecture and how people lived than art, The Winter Palace from its frontage on the Neva river makes a statement in its gren colour to impress. The opulence and extravagence of it all, certainly must have stunned visitors; either court or ambassadorial. From the vast winding staircase things just get more impressive - gilt and marble and massive chandeliers. The sizes and dimensions of the rooms are awe inspiring. Two thrones; a superb 1812 Gallery with portaits of Russian military heroes, Malachite room and the magnificent Alexander Hall to name a few.. The private church is stunning. I have never seen a palace to match this one in pomp;but like the vast majority of St. Peterburg looking to the west of europe and forgetting real Russian style and tradition. Before or afterwards try to see the slightly strange but absorbing Russian film on DVd " Russian Ark" and you can put togehter inyou mind how stunning the place was when it was used; for instance as the first ball of the Season in the Nicholos Hall.Take your time and stroll taking it all in.

Stunning Treasures and Artworks. Founded by Catherine the Great in the 18th century has more than 3 million exhibits occupying 1000 plus rooms. Rare and stunning artwork includeDa Vinci, Raphael and Rembrandt. It also has stunning parquet floors, ornate staircases, gilded furniture and lots of Malachite items. There are ornately decorated domed ceilings, mosaic floors and enormous chandeliers. Good selection of gift shops with a wide range of prices. Be prepared to see only a small part of The Hermitage due to the size of the buildings. Again very busy.

Beautiful...must see!. Lovely museum. The building alone is worth the visit. We visited (four of us) with a private tour guide. We had prepaid tickets and were able to enter without much wait at all. Although it was busy, we felt that we were able to cover all the rooms in a couple of hours.
hermitage. beautiful palace worth seeing,in st.petersburg.go inside and you will be surprized.it was destroyed by fire now renewated and open for public

Well, not bad!. If we could put together the Louvre and the Hermitage (which I was lucky enough to see within a month), there would be a perfect museum.Hermitage is more personal, with its ups and downs, but they cannot handle the crowd, the entry process is a disaster, they cannot speak ANY English (WHY?!), and I had problems with the lighning as well, could not see the pictures from the front, because of the light played on the surface. Only from the side were they visible enough.I had problem the information system (if any) as well, since they do not tell (or show) they have a large collection of Manet, Monet, Kandinsky, Sisley, etc., but in another building! You won't see it unless you ask - and show something to them, because unless you speak Russian, they won't know. The girl gave us museum map in French (we are Hungarians), she did not bother to ask!The good: they put English description beside the items (which Louvre does not).All in all, I give 4 stars, but only because of the name.

Amazing and huge collection. 1First of all - you will find the English name of the paintings, sculptures etc. It's a good point. But the map what you can get is outdated. You can find most things easily, good and informative. But what could help you the Hermitage app, on your phone, we don't get lost, not like in the Louvre. There is some collection that has been moved to other building (General Stuff Building). The staff - except in the information desk - doesn't speak English, so they just show you it's closed. It's a good strategy, if you show them what you looking for. That's how we could look ie. French impressionists and other exhibition. To get in the museum is quite and unecessary difficult (for exemple they close one entrance, but they don't close it and after you walk there they just say and show it's closed so you can walk back and find the other entrance). The museum shop - like many in St Petersburg and Moscow) in the museum, you have to have ticket to go there. In the General Stuff Building there's no museum shop, so if you have one day ticket, you use the museum shop in the Hermitage. The enter into the museum is quiet chaotic, they could learn a lot from the Louvre.The collection is amazing, the State Rooms are wonderful, and after 1-2 pm there is no huge crowd (except the main highlights ie. peacock clock) If you want to see the peacock clock while it moves, you have to be at least 5 minutes early and wait 5 minutes after hour. It is not automatic, so it's depend when the staff starts it. We missed it, first it was 5 minutes after hour, and second time it was over few minutes before the next hour.

what to say..... The Hermitage is well known and the initial view is just Wow... inside there is so much to see. you can easily stay all day here and still not feel that you have done justice to the collection.The cafes on the ground floor are good value, and the shops have excellent selections of books and artefacts.It does feel rather busy if you get caught up with one of the group tours, but everything passes eventually and you can still be solitary

Great. Even 2 days are less.. Huge collection. A lot to see. They have shifted a lot of paintings specially the Renaissance in separate museum in front of the main building. Not much on the 3 rd floor. Plan accordingly.More English signage would help.Overall a must see.
You must see this!,. A very, very special place!Great for solo, couples, families with young children and teens!You have to see this when you are in Russia!
culture. If you like art, than this is the perfect place...You need a looot of time to try and see most of it. The souvenir shop has loads of good stuff to offer :)

A palace full of art.. Large attractive building, on a par with the Louvre. I went through this museum in a group with a tour guide and saw only highlights. I found this museum had more tour groups than I had ever encountered in a museum. This occasionally caused serious congestion, so patience is required to see the exhibits properly.

Great Museum. Beware of Guide overcharging. We purchased tickets only to save on the queuing time but it is not a good idea as you can buy tickets half of that price at the vending machines in the entrance. Once inside we were approached by a guide ( See picture of him) who offered us a tour for 8,000 Rub and reduced it to 5,000. Afrer 20mn he left us and we had to go back to reception to ask for our money back. The audio guides are useless as only 10% of the art is described. I strongly recommend you arrange the visit with a guide that you book before you enter. It should cost you around 1,000 Rub / hour .

Gold star magical palace and museum. It would take months to see every item in the collection and a brief visit does not do justice to everything there is to see. It is just like being in a sweet shop with every item as tempting as the one before. A goods tour guide is essential to navigate the queues and crowds and to point out the "must see" items. Photography is sometimes difficult at busy times and it is a good idea to film short videos to give an overview of a wonderful experience.

Spectacular. You just need to see that! No words can describes. The fact - if you stand in front every piece of art that it's inside only for 10seconds, you will need more than 10years to see everything.

Awesome. Rated as the Best Museum in the World. Must be seen to be believed. Could spend weeks inside. This is my third and not the last, visit. Rafael's Madonna with Child alone makes it worth it. Death of Adonis is a bonus.

Tour groups are an insane crush. Great museum but so totally over run with people you can barely think...I can also say if you can go in winter time do it but otherwise be prepared for in sane crowds and security for some reason really gave me a going over...
theres,never enough time. We have been to the Hermitage twice for many hours,each time. Go with a private guide. There is a mind boggling amount of incredible art.

Art and opulence. A must see.. This building is so immense and the exhibits so vast that it would take several hours/day over several days to really take in all the sights. If you don't have that kind of time then a good tour guide can help point out the most historically significant items and events.
A wonderful palace and museum. Bursting with Russian Tsarist culture, epotomising the wealth created by the Tsars; beautifully exhibited priceless artefacts and works of art from around the world

Fabulous collection in an incredible facility. A visit to the Hermitage was a key component i my desire to visit St Petersburg - and it did not disappoint. The facility is a work of art and the collection is extensive. Although there were crushing crowds in the entrance room, the crowds quickly thinned out and we were able to visit the rest of the museum without feeling crowded.

Busy. The Hermitage is an amazing place with lots of Priceless works of Art.As expected it is busy very busy, we both found it very stressful getting into the build as on a tour and several tours turned up at once, causing a crush at the entrance and nobody from the staff able to sort the crush
hermitage museum. One of the best museums of the world!The museum is located in a beautiful riverside location,and it has a very fine collection from all periods of history!!
A must see for art lovers!. Home to three million works of art and one of the largest and oldest museums in the world. Founded in 1764 by Catherine the great.

Gold, gold, gold. The Hermitage is just amazing. Opulence on a level that is hard to imagine in this comparatively more egalitarian time. Combine this with a world class art museum and you have fodder for several visits. Everyone gets an entry time and of course most people are part of a tour. This means you whizz past Goya, Velasquez and other masters that would be the stars in a lesser museum. If I go back I will get a private guide. Be aware that 19 and 20 century masterpieces are now in the annex across palace square. It isn't yet on the tour itinerary, so you have rooms of Monet, Pissarro, Seurat, Sisley, Renoir, Van Gogh that you have never seen before to feast your eyes on. Go now although Matisse and Picasso are not yet on display. This extension will become a major draw once finished!
Hermitage museum. our tour guide Michael works there and knew all his way around the crowds and disregarded the boring stuff

Perhaps unparalleled. Awesome.! Staggering art collectionMake sure you have enough time to take in most, if not all, that is on offer. May need more than one visit. Take the time to stroll outside as well as inside.

Wow!. We wandered through here with a guide for four hours and didn't come close to seeing everything. It has an amazing collection of art from the masters and other priceless collections. Just amazing!

Breathtaking. From the second you enter the Winter Palace prepare to be blown away by the incredible, extravagance of your surroundings. There can be no doubt that the Tsars of all the Russias were masters of a huge empire and all its wealth seems to have flowed into places such as the Hermitage.With more than three million works of art in its collection only a tiny proportion are on view at any given time (it would take you about eighty years to view the lot!) but what there is is utterly amazing.To be honest I was just as blown away by the jaw-dropping architecture and design of each new room we entered but the artworks cover the whole gamut of human civilisation. Egypt, China, renaissance paintings, Dutch and Flemish masters, porcelains, Greek and Roman statuary - everything is here under one roof. Seriously, the Louvre struggles to compete. Truly one of those places you must see before you die. Utterly incredible.

REQUIRED VISIT. The Hermitage is in Palace Square and was actually the Tsars' Summer Palace. It is one of the greatest museums in the world, started up by Catherine the Great but greatly contributed to by her courtiers.  They have several daVincis among many, many European masters. The building itself is a masterpiece. I suggest choosing your highlights and zoning in if you have limited time. This is like the Louvre. It needs 3 days (the galleries are over 20km I'm told). This place is very very crowded so I went with a prepaid prebooked tour group, having only one afternoon for it. I maintain this was a smart idea. Beware pickpockets. Some are so sophisticated they wear the tourist earpieces to blend in more. And of course the museum shop is not the cheapest in the city, but the quality and selection are great.

The Hermitage. Cannot express ever the Hermitage and it's wonders. We were very fortunate to be on a Viking Tour that allowed us 8 days in St. Petersburg with an emphasis on the Hermitage. We spent many hours there; on Monday we were there when it was closed to the public. We also had a visit to the storage area where thousands more treasures are housed. Art came alive, the gold room, the jewels, the beautiful halls, the Peacock Clock, the massive urns. This is a place where several months of study would be such a gift. Our guide was fun, knowledgeable and she was very professional and answered all our questions.
Excellent. Wonderful museum; As good as any other museum i've been to in the world. Amazing collection of paintings. Beautiful palace. Would have been impossible without a guide.
Awonderful gallery of paintings.. This museum could take all day to see properly. The crowds when we went were a bit bothersome but it was still worth seeing.

A definitely must. I suppose the place is on the "must -see" list of every visitor to St Petersburg. It is big and contains so many treasures - paintings, sculptures, jewelry, tapestries and so on. Yet, its enormity and popularity also make the place forbidding. Expect massive overcrowdedness, and imagine admiring the Old Masters behind five rolls of tourists. I made such a visit years ago and came away quite disappointed. I visited the museum again this June and came away with a very different experience. I was on an excursion organized by Princess Cruise. We were allowed into the museum one and half hour before the usual opening hours, ie, well before the other visitors. We formed into small groups of about 25 and led through the rooms by the local guide. During most of the time, the small group of 25 was the only people in each room, allowing much space and time to appreciate the decor, and the artwork, and to take photos. Jewelry lovers would certainly love the exhibits in the Gold Room. I am sure we had not visited all the rooms and the entrance fees must be higher. Yet, the extra costs are certainly worth it. It was a most enjoyable two and half hours. It should also be mentioned that free wifi is available in the coffee shop and book store and it is very efficient too.

W O W, One Of The Most Fabulous Art Museums In The World. If you love art, you will live the Hermitage in St Petersburg, Russia. The main museum consists of 5 buildings filled with the finest collections of all main European art schools. The collections had originally been started by Catherine the Great. There are other buildings scattered throughout St Petersburg. A must see if you are in St Petersburg.
Magnificent. One of the most beautiful palace I ve ever seen !If you staying for a long time check the date when the museum is free or if you re a student make a isic card for free entrances ;)

It is a must. It is a must to see winter palace!So much history and culture under one roof! However if you plan to make it in one day, just skip it! You need at least one and a half to briefly check all wings.Have been here three times and still I miss some points on checklist!

Amazing building and art collection. This is I believe the most popular building in St Petersburg and keeps a very important art collection. From Impressionism to Art related to Peter the Great the Museum has a huge amount of pieces. Only thing I didnt like was the setup. A good painting needs to have proper place and light and i missed that. Otherwise the Museum is amazing.

Unbelievable Artwork. Everything in the Hermitage is priceless, beautiful artwork. There are so many floors and rooms filled with amazing treasures. No way can you take the time to truly look at and appreciate the beauty in just a few hours. This is a place that you need to visit several times for at least 3 hours per visit in order to really look at and savor all the beauty offered to you. The artwork includes paintings, sculptures, tapestries, glass, jewelry and many other items. It is very crowded so it makes it difficult to get close viewing at times. Also, pickpockets love the crowds so beware. It is not air conditioned and with so many people, it gets extremely warm so dress comfortably.

Hermitage. It would be impossible to see everything in the Hermitage in a month much less 2 days. The tours here are really just an overview of all the great works of art that exist in the world. If you want to say you have been to the Hermitage go on a tour. But if you really want to see the Hermitage you need to go to Russia and spend at least a week going through it to appreciate all it has to offer.

Fantastic Palace and Museum. The museum is one of the best Art museums in the world but even if you ignored the Art work inside it would be well worth the visit to view the interiors of the Winter palace and its annexes.

A must see, but not the experience we hoped for.. This is arguably the best art museum in the world. Our tour arranged for early admission along with the rest of the free world. When we arrived we were herded like cattle through the only small door to the museum (the front door to my home is wider. One door for thousands of people going in and going out. Once inside, you just went with the flow just to catch a glimpse of the art. Our TJ tour guide was great in keeping our group of 12 together throughout the entire visit as she was able to navigate through the throng to the more significant works . By the way, don't expect a smile from any of the employees at the Hermitage Museum or anyplace else in St Petersburg for that matter.Despite the experience, the works were phenomenal and we were glad we went.

Hermitage Museum. Wow wow wow.
Up close to amazing works of art. Heavenly experience.
Catherine the Great's legacy lives on.
The majority of exhibits were "acquired or donated".... Freely? I wondered.

Hermitage. At the Hermitage we walked through the Winter Palace with its numerous reception halls and to its Throne rooms and halls. It hS the most exquisite crystal chandeliers, the amazing Peacock clock and a beautiful collection of Iralian Renaissance art including masterpieces by Leonardo da Vinci & Rafael and Rembrant's artistic career.

Must visit. The largest museum, should spend a couple of days here, like the Louvre. 4 hrs tour is a fast walk thru of the highlights but must visit if in St Petersburg. The collection is wonderful. Hermitage has a 'branch' in Amsterdam also.

Nice museum , but crowded with tourist. Of course the museum is fantastic, but because it is so crowded
you can not enjoy it as you would like and that spoiled for me
the visit a little!!

Overwhelming!. Another must-see in Saint Petersburg. Visited here as part of a tour group and were absolutely overwhelmed with the quality and quantity of art that we saw. As we only had a couple of hours at the museum, we did not see all the displays but were certainly given a good overview. There was so much to look at that we ended up taking a huge amount of pictures so we could enjoy them in comfort once home. Huge crowds - don't lose sight of your companions as you'll have difficulty finding them again.

This the Secund Time i try to see. The big Problem to get Ticket to see Hermitage, or you by in advanced on line or you can stay 4 hours on Line to take a Ticket and more 1 hour to go in side.I think they need to arrange same good solution to help the people to by a tickets to go to see hermitage Museum.

For those who love art and have artistic mind and heart. I guess that one day is not enough to see all those masterpieces! We spent there 5 hours and still we did not see even the half of everything. For sure will go there again. Too many tourists, if you want to make a nice photo you really need to catch the moment when noone will be around... this is hard task :)

The Hermitage. Funny name for such an enormous museum. The most beautiful museum I have ever visited. They say that if we stop for just 5 seconds in front of every piece of art we would spend years without even taking a break. I believe it! It's wonderful to see so many originals from the masters.

A grand palace chock full of treasures.. Visited the Hermitage for a few hours as part of SPB Tour shore excursion in May. What a remarkable palace with a wealth of art treasures. Barely scratched the surface during our short visit. A must see.
wonder and awe. So much to enjoy at this museum. You could spend months and months here and not see everything. My favorite was the Michelangelo pieces.

All about the Winter Palace!. I'm not much of a museum person but booked a tour here because of the Winter Palace. Talk about grand! I was in awe room after room. Absolutely the most beautiful interior of any palace I have ever been to or will ever go to. I can't imagine anything topping this one!It is very crowded getting in. Be patient. The crowd will dissipate and when you leave you can take even better pictures of the grandiose foyer. We also got to see the chapel which they just opened. DO NOT MISS that! You will be floored and really taken by it's beauty.

Such a gorgeous place!. This was a great place to visit. Loved going here & parts of it is amazing to see. It's very interesting. But, it was crowded so be prepared for that! Also, buy your tickets ahead of it. Will save time waiting in the long lines.

Lives up to the hype. One of the great museums of the world. Fabulous building from the outside and dazzling with deoration and gold inside. And that's just the palace rooms. The items on display are priceless royal treasures from Tsarist times and confiscations following 1917 revolution. Far too ambitious to think you can see the total collection even in a full day. Half a day allows for visiting rooms with the best known exhibits though you will have to be patient. Exhibits such as the Golden Peacock Clock are continually surrounded by tour groups all babbling but it is possible to get good views if patient. Take time to admire the ceilings, chandelliers and marquetry floors. If you are lucky, you may even spot some of the 50 cats that reside at the Hermitage. Catherine introduced cats to keep the rodent population under control so that rodents did not destroy her treasured collections. There have been cats there ever since. Number 1 St Petersburg tourist attraction. A must see.
Amazing. This museum has the best art work by the most famous artists that I have ever seen, the collection is huge and displayed beautifully. the building is beautiful inside and out a must see

A fantastic building with an incredible range of beautiful rooms and artworks.. We spent 10 hours there over 2 days and were bowled over by the beauty of the rooms and the breadth of the available artworks. Our only problem was caused by the fact that we had planned our trip based on their website information which was out-of-date. We found that the modern art which was supposed to be on the 3rd floor had been moved to another building or was not on view due to renovations. This meant re-planning our trip where we were inevitably tight for time and also purchasing additional tickets to enter the venues where the art was now on view. The newly accessible General staff building has been imaginatively modernised but its modern art collections, which have been extracted partly from the Hermitage, are poorly distributed and badly signposted entailing lots of walking along endless corridors. More of the Hermitage's modern art now appears to have been moved to the Russian museum which is a distance away from the Hermitage. This is not obvious from the Hermitage website.

This defines St. Petersburg. Awesome!! A must see. I read the Madonna's of Lenningrad before arriving. It provided a greater appreciation for what the museum keepers did to preserve their heritage. Can't wait to show our slide show of photos to friends.

The Hermitage St Petersburg. I would start by saying that, for me, it would hVe been preferable to have a couple of days to spend in this Palace/ Museum. We spent 3 hours here and felt, to really get the most from the rooms, artworks, sculpture, etc. it would have been nice to have a break from all the visual splendours. Felt like we just could not take in any more and did not have enough time to just sit and enjoy - not that there was anywhere to sit. I believe, to walk the whole Museum, we would have covered 22 kilometres. It is a must for Visitors to this part of the world and the mind 'boggles' at the sight of so many treasures on display. We started our visit early, thank goodness, and by the time we had spent 3 hours here were well in need of a coffee and somewhere to sit.
Amazing but crowded!. Amazing place but wow was it crowded! Be prepared to share this place with thousands. It was so busy when we were there that we could hardly move. It is a must see.
Lovely Musuem. Brilliant and very interesting. Very educational trip especially for my son. Love russian architecture. Our guide is brilliant and plenty of knowledge in every aspect. Worth a visit.

Highlight of our tour. The works of art and preservation of the building is wonderful and awesome to behold. It is a privilege to experience this and that the Russian people share this with the rest of the world

Awesome but busy. Of course, this is one of the premier sights of St Petersburg - but be prepared for crowds as you arrive. I wouldn't let it distract you, but it's a busy attraction. Also, you won't see everything in a short visit - but what you will be exposed to is nothing short of breathtaking.

A must in your lifetime. With millions of exhibits you probably need a few days to enjoy this great collection of arts. The palace itself is the main attraction with wide staircase having side rails decorated with marble statues. We would have got lost in the vast area and crowd pressure. But our guide was really helpful in getting us entry minutes before the crowd starts and she guided us through the main halls where priceless artifacts collected and stored by czars and czarinas.
A must. This is one of the most beautiful museums in the world.Its not only the astonishing collection but also the building it self.

Amazing attraction. A must see when in St. Petersburg. Amazing attraction. A must see when in St. Petersburg. This winter palace of Peter the Great is the far one of the most opulent places I have ever been. Soaring 50' ceilings covered in art. Massively large rooms and not to mention all of the original famous art work. A must see.

Everything you would expect it to be. We had a private tour guide to visit this enormous Museum & we were so thankful we did. We spent 4 hours there & Elena was able to take us to all of the main attractions without really having to fight through the crowds. With over 20,000 people a day visiting this place you could spend a lot of time being overwhelmed by the people & not seeing as much as we did. The Palace itself is simply stunning, let alone the works of art that are available to see. Not being real art buffs we absolutely loved seeing the works of the likes of Rembrandt, Rubens, DaVinci & so on.....would recommend a guided tour if you can arrange it.

One of the World's Greatest Displays of Art and Culture. So , so sorry we had only three hours to just sample a few of the great collections of art. As this is an authentic palace of the czars with a magnificent impact just as a building, we had to realize that being built over two centuries ago, it has endless steps, crowded faclities and the tourist crowd pressure is such that it's hard to really see and ponder the great art collections. The standard ships' tours are far too restricted in time and access to fully enjoy extensive collections of art that could take weeks to fully view and appreciate.

Awesome but Crowded. The Winter Palace is filled with history and is a must see event of any trip to St Petersburg. Wear good walking shoes! This place just goes on forever! I only wish we had more time to spend looking at everything and less of a crowd to deal with. This place is like the Prado in Madrid and needs a couple of days to really see it all. By the end of three hours, your feet begin to ache and everything starts to look the same. Make sure you get into a small tour group with an excellent guide. This will make all the difference! We spent as much time trying to keep up with our group as looking at everything. Other tour groups just intermingle with yours and it becomes a real mess trying to get back together. Review your Russian history prior to coming here and you will get so much more out of your visit!!

Don't look at the Walls. We went in the evening. On a special tour. That is, 40 or so people, non-Russian speakers.The French Impressionists were not on the tour. In a different building, we were told. Okay, next time I am in Saint Petersburg, I will add them. Ha. I will never be back. Who makes two trips to St. P? Not many people.Da Vinci (2), lots of Rembrandt, Murillo, Goya, Ribera, the Spanish collection is wonderful. Had a number of, "so THIS is where that is" moments.The gift shops were closed. And you had to not get too far from the tour, a scary guy in a leather Eisenhower jacket kept trying to push the tour guide along. And the guide seemed to take a perverse pleasure in adding details of one more painting in the room.The walls, the decorations, are garish. Ugly in combination. But the art is fantastic. This is how to see it. A private tour, one where you do not have to keep one hand on your wallet.
another must see. world renowned and deservedly. I could have spent several days wandering around here. Take a camera and gets lots of memories. Photography is allowed. wonderful place!

a must see. probably the best museum i have ever seen.around 350 different rooms with top art from top artists from all over the world. i guess the value of the items shown is enough to cover the whole state debt of Belgium.
TJ Travel gets you in before opening hours. We were able to explore the Hermitage and some of its many treasures in the comfort of pre-opening hours. An amazing place that one could spend days in -

Awesome. This is a place that every traveler should visit if possible. The history, the art, the artifacts on display, the décor will impress anyone. To see the lifestyle that the Czars had is something that will impress anyone. Expect very large crowds because this is a very popular place with tourists from everywhere but it is worth the effort. If possible also try to get into the gold room, very, very impressive.

Got to be seen to be believed!! Opulent, over the top but so amazing! Must book special tour of the gold treasure rooms. Could spend days going all through this collection. We had an excellent guide who took us on an afternoon tour that showed us the highlights of the rooms of the winter palace , the amazing gold peacock clock ( a huge lifesize automaton clock where the peacock sets it's tail on the hour) they are saving the mechanism and it only runs on special occasions but they have a good video clip showing it running and some of the work involved in keeping it running. Everywhere you look there is gold leaf and amazing furniture.The guide then took us to highlights of 3 of the major art collections and rooms of the small Hermitage to show the difference between the generations. Excellent commentary.The next day we returned to do the Golden rooms - this has to be specially booked and has timed entry. This is a must see. Ancient gold jewellery finds, collection of incredible Chinese gold hair combs presented to royalty, diplomatic gifts of amazing wealth and craftsmanship. Bejewelled swords , crowns, jewellery, horse rugs embroidered with 115000 diamonds !Even my husband was amazed at what was in these 2 small rooms. Same guide took us to the mummy rooms and a couple of other interesting exhibits while waiting for entry which were different from the previous tour.These 2 tours barely scratched the surface but if you have limited time take a tour that shows a range of collections otherwise it would be easy to be bogged into a limited collection due to the crowds.Suggest use a guide familiar with the museum so that you do get variety and if you have a personal guide research what you want to see before you go and they will be able to move you more quickly around the museum - this was obvious with both our guides that they knew shortcuts and ways around the traffic jams

Iconic. Best to prebook online, the queues are long and the process slow.... they like queues but admission costs are reasonable. There is of course far too much to see in one visit. We concentrated on paintings. Some rooms were closed for reorganisation and the modern French paintings and impressionists were therefore located in another building which we visited later. The rooms themselves are fabulous as are the parquet floors - so many designs.

Breathtaking!. We took a tour with SPB from the cruise ship. They took us straight to the Hermitage and we had an opportunity to enter before it actually opened. There were no crowds and our tour guide Elena was fabulous. She gave us an amazing overview of the museum and the Winter Palace. The furnishings, the grandeur is just breathtaking. So historic. I couldn't believe I was standing in front of some of the masters of the art world without having to push to see it like I have had to do in places like the Louvre. It was magical and really not to be missed!!

Second Visit. Last review five years ago I said it was a wonderful place. Still is, but the only downside is the abysmal website for booking extra tours to Gold, Faberge rooms etc. Despite having an English version of the website they do NOT respond to e-mail queries regarding bookings.

A must see museum in St Petersburg, Russia. A phenomenal museum and a must see for anyone that visits St Pete Russia in modern times. The architectural will mesmerize you when strolling though the winter palace of Peter the Great. The high ceilings and attention to detail make this a must see. Take an entire day because there is so much to see.

Normal. It has very important works but this museum doesn't well organized for me. I didn't want to stay there more than 2 hours however hostel administrator told me that I need to spent there two days. I can spent two o more days in galleries in Moscow, don't wanna promote them but that how I feel.

Stunning Museum. The Hermitage is a stunning museum, as grand as the Louvre. The setting on the river is beautiful and impressive. The buildings themselves are every bit as impressive as the art they contain. You will find yourself noticing the ceiling, the molding, the floor, and the walls as much as any painting or statue. The amount of gold is staggering! Don't miss this gem.

Must see. This is a very busy museum so be prepared , once inside it is worth any wait ( from 0-45 minutes max) we had a guide which I suppose was the right thing for us because you need good steady pace if you want to see all this building , our son is 9 and was in a wheelchair chair and we had no problems that I can remember. This building is magnificent and every room is amazing in decor. We settled in quickly despite how busy it was and just took it all in . Make sure your SD card for your camera has enough memory because you just want to take photo after photo, like I said every room is different and has its own marvels. The Russians are very proud of there museum treasures and you will see why when you visit . We are looking to go again .
THE must visit!. Although busy at times, you just cannot miss what has to be one of the greatest museums on earth. A wide array of masterpieces rival even Le Louvre.

Russian Ark. Second visit following reading "Russian Ark"-one of my favourite films.
Magnificent opulence and it requires many visits to get a full picture.On both occasions I had excellent guides explaining in English the historical events.

Hermitage & Winter Palace. Stunning! Amazing! and Beautiful! Words cannot describe how beautiful! Spent several hours here seeing some of the most popular items. Could take years to truly see everything. Cannot believe all the "gold" found in Russian Palaces!

Too much to take in during one visit.. Several reviewers have expressed good descriptions of this attraction so I just would like to recommend the value of hiring a guide. My wife and I knew we would probably not be returning to St. Petersburg so we spent "a significant fee" to have our own guide and we enjoyed 5 full hours of interesting history and art. When we arrived in one section that was a little busy our guide whisked us out a door and around to a different and less crowded room, returning to the previous room later when it was less crowded. This was the best investment we have made in relation to a tour, anywhere. And worth every dollar.

My Dream!. To be in the Wintet Palace and the Hermitage is the ultimate. We were able to be two hours earlier than the regular time, what a chance to walk among the finest Art/fabric and the feeling of greatness. We had a private performance in the Catherine theatre, obviously I love Russia for lots of reasons. Toured Peterhof later, finest workmanship In the world!

Unimaginable wealth at the expense of the poor. This is a magnificent venue for displaying a massive accumulation of art, sculpture, possessions, power and greed. Although beautiful one has to ask oneself where did all the funding come from the support acquiring over 3 million pieces?Clearly the aristocracy or state government pillaged countries and taxed its people to fund their unlimited desire for wealth.It is crowded so go early. Watch out for pickpockets.

Unbelievable opulence. Incredible collection of art. Difficult to comprehend such an abuse of funds when the mass population had NOTHING. Interesting to see so much of the worlds most fantastic art objects in one place.
One of the most beautiful museums in the world.. This is a must if you travel to Russia. Plan a day, and take an accredited guide for the tour, especially if you don't speak Russian.

Wow. This was a most impressive place to visit. We were lucky to arrive early and dodged the crowds and it was worth it. Would have loved more time here as there is so much to see. Absolutely fantastic and a must do when visiting Saint Petersburg !
Wonderful. This was wonderful loved the Peacock clock all the art . Tour guide knew everything about every piece was so informative

A must see, but.... Likes: the sheer magnitude and volume of exhibits and state rooms provides something for everyone. Dislikes: you only have to walk past the cafe to see that it's as dire as everyone says (what a waste!). Also missing are a really good guidebook and map, and the two apps you can download failed to do so, both whilst in the building and on trying several times that evening in the hotel. Signage is poor, in both Russian and English, with exhibit description more interested in whose collection the price was acquired from than its actual provenance. Disappointing. Advice: Make sure you book tickets online before you go - queues are hundreds deep, but with my internet-bought ticket and a copy of my passport, I walked straight in. Also, ignore the main cloakroom downstairs which is hard to access due to the sheer numbers of visitors. Use the 'small' cloakroom up the stairs just before this, signposted for school groups: completely empty (and free)!

The Sculptures & Paintings are stunning. Despite of the huge crowd, it's still worth to visit the Hermitage & the Winter Palace. The highlight of the magnificent piece of treasure was the Phoenix Clock! Unfortunately, we did not have the time to spend the whole day but we were glad that we visited.

Wow loads to look at.. If you have a Russian with you get them to buy the tickets as its cheaper for Russians than foreigners, secondly take food and a tent this place is massive and busy. I was there all day didn't see everything got lost twice and told off for taking pictures of things I shouldn't lots. Enjoyed it.

One of the most famous art museum. This is one of the most famous art museum of the world. It is located in beautiful Winter Palace and there are lots of works of world best artists. Name one and you can see it here. You can stay here hours and hours and it is still not enough to see all the main works. Fantastic !!

Very nice. Well Well the Russian emperors knew how to enjoy their life and they knew to build a great palaces. This Winter Palace is simply amazing and one of the must sees when you are in St.Petersburg. Don't miss to get there and have first a walk from outside and take some time to get the full impresion of this palace. If you have enough time during your stay in St.Petersburg don't miss to visit the Hermitage museum. Depends how big lover of arts your are, you have to choose how many days will you take to discover the whole Hermitage museum. But the basic tour through the museum is also great and it will take your breath away. Its simply amazing.

Breathtaking!. The Winter Palace... what a place! Each room is a gem. Make sure you dont miss the Peacock Clock It was manufactured by James Cox in the 2nd half of the 18th century and through the influence of Grigory Potemkin it was acquired by Catherine the Great in 1781.

Despite the crowds it is magnificent. Like: Cannot believe that the building and its contents have risen phoenix like from the ashes of the Battle of Leningrad.Dislike: The tour companies have shot themselves in the foot by offering "private early entry before it is open to the public" This means that there are more people trying to get in in the first half hour. The timed tickets do not work, the times are ignored.

Stunning. Not only is the artwork at the Hermitage fantastic but the galleries are incredible. Can it get better than that? I didn't get to see the Impressionist or Expressionist work because they moved those bodies of work to another building and it was closed for three days. Be sure to call ahead if you want to see those collections. However I did get to see a great collection of impressionist work at The St Petersburg Artist's museum. This is a very small museum that almost no one goes to and was great for contemporary impressionism.

You can't miss this! . Like most places in Russia the history speaks for itself but seeing it first hand and soaking in the grandeur is unrivaled. This is one of the many museums I went to that I would also say is in my top 5 ever.

The best bit is not even in the main building!. The Winter Palace was spectacular. An unbelievable opulence (built on the misery of millions of serfs). But -- and I'm not sure I want to share this -- the collection of Impressionist paintings across the square in the General Staff Building will live longest in the memory. The Winter Palace as you'd expect was mobbed by tour parties, not least around the Da Vincis. So it's a fantastic but wearing experience. But our decision to persevere by checking out the more modern collections away from the building proved inspired. It may be because we went at lunchtime but it was virtually like a private viewing. Using the very same tickets we were able to view Monet after Monet, Degas after Degas Cezanne after Cezanne, Van Gogh after Van Gogh... You get the picture. Unbelievable. And not something I will ever forget.
Speachless. We enjoyed visiting it tremendously-what an art collection! Not to mention the State rooms! One and only-a must see! Had a lovely meal in a Georgian restaurant off the Nevsky prospect.
Spectacular palace and art museum. Don't miss the Russian state rooms. Eat someplace else as the cafe is small, and has terrible food. An art lover;s dream

Wondrous!. It is hard to believe that Petersburg would house such a wondrous collection of art.And the museum also houses the living quarters of the King and Queen with all their finery,furniture,royal crockery,and even their beautifully stacked wooden library! This place has to be seen-- to get the feel of how the royalty lived-- and to see the very place where the Russian Revolution began.
a must. one of the biggest museums in the word full of masterpieces... what else to say? a must for anyone interested in art!

Fantastic building. The building itself is amazing and incredibly huge. I believe you should choose which areas you would like to see and then just go there first. We arrived in the evening and spent only 1.5 hours there. Not enough to see it all of course but at least to go directly to our rooms of interest. Wed evening it is open late which is good when you have limited time during a business trip!

A Must See. The winter Palace is beautiful and should be number one on everyone's tour list for St. .Petersburg. We were a private tour group and walked through the gardens as well as tour of the Palace. We loved St. Petersburg and the Winter Palace and Catherine's Palace were our favorite historical sites.
Nice, lots to see and get know. I like the tour of the Diamond Hall and over the all museum. Huge interesting info can be found. First Thusday on the month - is free of charge for visitors.

Great national museum, so much to see, but horrible crowds. We had the privilege of being able to go to the Hermitage while on a 2 day tour of St. Petersburg. Our local guide took us on a fairly fast tour of the museum since we had other things to see in the city as well. Unfortunately this museum is so vast you would really need a week to see everything. First the positives. The museum itself is gorgeous. You used to be a palace so the rooms are beautiful and well laid out. The artwork presented is an unbelievable collection. 2 of Leonardo de Vinci's 7 existing paintings are housed here. Rafael, Rembrandt, you name it, it's there! The museum is laid out pretty well as far as finding your way around and there is a safe coat and bag check area, restrooms, and a very nice souvenir shop.Now the negatives and why I rate this 4 stars instead of 5. The crowds are utterly horrible. I realize it's summer and prime tourist season but the museum needs to control it alittle better. The lines to get tickets and to get into the main entrance are awful. And once in, there are several small doorways that are used for entrance and exit and pushing and throwing of elbows was common to see. Unfortunately this made the experience very exhausting. It makes me want to go back in the winter time when there are no crowds (or so our guide told us) and see the museum again.

A world best!. This is one of the worlds best museums - and its story is also amazing. - the staff are very helpful under trying conditions as many Chinese tour groups disregard instructions and insist on taking pictures in rooms where it is not allowed - but this is a problem everywhere so I won't dwell on Chiniese Tour groups except to say that they are a handful and the staff of the Hermitage did their best under very trying circumstances to control them - it makes it unenjoyable when there is one rule for all but one group constantly disobeys, are so loud and make it uncomfortable for everyone else in the room, place or Restruant - the staff do their best to make everyone comfortable - I hope they can stay that way :). They must all be saints!The Hermitage is a must and you need to see it and hear it's story of survivalOn a 1 to 10 scale of world museums - this is a 9

Would that we had all the time in the world... Unfortunately I went on an organised tour..so time was limited..but despite having to miss out on the impressionist paintings which I really wanted to see..there is no doubt about the beauty, opulence and magnificence of this museum...it's almost cultural overload, especially if you are with a good guide, so much to see..you could spend days, weeks ...if only it were possible. We went on a Thursday..and although there was a queue it didn't take that long to get in..beware the street hawkers..although I was tempted by the dolls ..and I don't mean the matrioska's.

You need lots of time!. It is one of the biggest museums in the world! If you are an art lover - this is place to visit. My favorite piece was Michaelangelo's "Crouching Boy" statue - I am just in awe of his work. The Jordan Staircase with it's opulent gold features everywhere to the Malachite Room which was stunning to the Large Italian Skylight Room, oh my everything just takes one's breath away. Make sure you have plenty of time alloted to see this national treasure.

A must see. Huge and impressive. We wanted to visit on a Thursday but as it was the first in the month, entrance was free and half of Russia must have been queuing to visit by 10.00h - so we gave up and came back the next day - admission £12 for the two of us but queues had gone and you could walk round freely and leisurely. Exhibits and rooms were breath-taking but navigation was challenging. Allow at least half a day.

Things you should know that I didn't. The Winter Palace has a far more spectacular interior wise than the Hermitage which is part of it. Try and see the palace time permitting. The impressionist paintings are not there, but have been moved to another venue. It's Old Masters for the most part. Go with a private guide who gets you in first thing in the morning. I was there end of May and it was crowded. Our guide said that come June-August, there is a long waiting line to get in and 1 1/2 hours wait to see the Da Vinic paintings. There is a flight of steps to get in - 8 or so. No handrails. I had a travel scooter and several people helped carry it up and down. Wheel chairs are available, but I saw only a dozen or so.

Memorable buildng with a vast collection of paintings.. The down side is that most tours pass through the rooms too fast to see anything but a few paintings chosen by your guide. Even so the buildings are well worth visiting even if there were no pictures and one only saw the architecture and decorations. If you have time visit again on your own and study the paintings at leisure. As with all world famous attractions the crowds are large. I am told that visiting in winter, except Christmas/ New Year period, the buildings are less crowded.

Highlight of my cruise. Absolutely Fantastic! Part of 2 day St. Petersburg private tour with TJ Travel - Anna was my guide. The crowds were almost overwhelming and even when you have pre-booked tickets, you have to wait to enter - but definitely worth the wait. The art on the walls, the exquisite floors which we were walking on, the chandeliers - were outstanding. Thanks to Anna we did not lose any of our group - the crowds are so huge - you really have to be careful to stay together. Anna, our guide, was truly wonderful at keeping us on schedule and shepherding us around - her knowledge of the art and buildings which we viewed made our visit truly memorable. This is my no. 1 must see place in St. Petersburg
amazing experience. this vast place needs at least 2-3 days to do it justice, it was an amazing place to visit nontheless and would highly recommend!!
A MUST see stop if in Russia. If you are lucky enough to visit Russia, this is a MUST!!! The history alone is fascinating but the beauty of the Hermitage is breath taking.

Out of this world. Arguably the best museum in the world in terms of the collections and the location. Book tickets on line to avoid queues, but be prepared for lots - and lots - of people. No trip to St Petersburg would be complete without spending at least a day in the Winter Palace.

Hire a guide!!. First of all, if you're planning a day trip - bring a yummy packed lunch. There's a small cafe, with not a lot of options. After walking around for hours on end, you might build up a bit of an appetite. :) There was a food truck outside when I was there, we bought some of what we thought were fresh baked goods - and they weren't so fresh. hard as a rock. Be prepared! ;)The palace was beautiful, and really amazing. We did not have a guide, and did not know much about the history of this country. It would have probably made a HUGE difference. We were really amazed for the first couple of hours, then after a while it got really tiring trying to figure things out... so we walked quickly through and admired everything, and left. We probably only spent half the time normal groups do inside. We decided to go on a whim from a friend's suggestion, and a little research before would have helped us- now we know if we go back. All in all, it was a good trip. Pricing was reasonable, and we had a really great experience.
Amazing Place. It is somewhere I had always wanted to go and I was not disappointed.The palace itself is great to see and the art in it was overwhelming.

Hire a guide to get the most out of this extensive collection. We only had a half-day to visit this large museum, so we hired a local guide via our hotel. This is highly recommended as she got us access via the "short line," then took us to the most important and interesting parts of the massive collection.
Anna Getmanskaya, St. Petersburg Guided Tours
email: get_ann@mail.ru

So Much to See. If you have done any traveling throughout Europe you know that there are palaces and museums everywhere. Opulence and splendor are a part of the history, for better or worse, that led to wars and expansions all around the world including the United States.Many travelers will skip St. Petersburg because of the political tensions between the US and Russia and the necessity and hassles of additional paperwork/visas. Don't miss one of the best of the best.You must visit the Hermitage as part of a tour (large or small, land or cruise) and let the tour company handle the paper work. It just makes it easier and there is a part The Gold Room, that you can't do on your own. To really take it all in you must allow at least a whole day. Versailles, Palacio Real have nothing on this edifice to the excesses of the Csars and Russian history.It is impossible to write a short review because it is truly overwhelming. There is so much to see in St. Petersburg that even a week might not allow you to cover everything.If you have the opportunity, DON'T miss the chance.

A must place to visit. If you are interested or not in art and history - you have to visit the winter palace. You will be overwhelmed by all gorgeous art you will have to see. You need a lot of time there, because it´s so much to see!

WONDERFUL. If you only have time to visit one place in St. Petersburg, this is the one but leave yourself plenty of time, you could and should spend a whole day. Try to arrive early as the place gets very busy and stays busy all day. You will pass from one fantastic room to another, each more beautiful than the next. Visit with a guide, if possible to get the full history of the place. We were lucky to manage to get tickets for a performance of Swan Lake in the Tsars theatre in the evening

AN EXTRAORDINARY EXPERIENCE. There's no comparison. This is the most extraordinary collection of great art from the earliest ages to the contemporary.It requires at least a half day, and more like a day and a half to see the collection. A strong suggestion, get a local expert guide to steer you through as it's a bit of a spicer web of a journey; a guide knows where the stairways are......where to bypass the crowded rooms and when to come back....and the art and artists. well worth it.prepare in advance. establish areas that are priorities. and be prepared to be overwhelmed. it's great
Excellent art - very crowded. The artwork is amazing but we were there when 4 cruise ships were in port and the museum was packed with visitors.

One day is simply not enough!. We were fortunate to come very early in the day with a group and avoid any kind of lines. Our guide was exceptionally well informed to point out some of the highlights and give us time to explore on our own.
