The Impressionist and post-Impressionist collection was in a different building, and we were surprised that it was free of charge, and no waiting.
Amazing. We used a private touring company and had a great time in this museum on our Baltic Cruise! SPB tours was awesome.

Unbelieveble . You have to visit the hermitage if you are in St Petersburg buy you ticket outside in the ticketautomat you can pay cash and save you a lot of time To see everything, I think it is impassible. But I wanderd around in Millionnayastreet it is wonderful.
Feel like Royalty !. Must see of our city ! The combination of decoration , interiors , paintings , sculptures and stories of the good guide will make your visit unforgettable :)

Mind blowing. The palace of the Czar peter the great....The rooms are a combination of the finest artifacts from the parquet to the exquisite chandeliers to the rarest collection of paintings. Do give this place atleast three hours to do justice to it. A guide is definitely a must here

The Ulimate Russian Experience. An absolute must-do before you die! In fact, it takes multiple visits to appreciate this extraordinary place. The building itself sells the experience - the art collection is a bonus. Just standing in the square outside is overwhelming...

Crowded. The place is crowded. Pickpockets are all over. The museum is extremely large and will take several days to get to the impressionists. Meanwhile, do not place your hands on the glass box like I did or you will get a shove and a hand slap! Our SPB tour got us in and you are able to take countless, no flash photos. Be sure to wear comfortable shoes because you will be standing for more than three hours for this event.

beyond expectations. The amassed art and historical pieces are beyond belief. You can only scratch the surface in half a day. We were lucky enough to have a great guide, Irena from Best Guides, that knew the museum and was able to move us (group of 10) into prime areas for viewing ahead of and avoiding increasingly large crowds.

Unnecessary complexity to gain access . Tips for avoiding the queues and getting into the museum.1: go on a week day, aim to get there for 10am to purchase ticket not from the ticket office but from the self service machines that take cash or card. There were no queues at this time of the day then you can go into the shorter queue for paid for tickets on right hand side and wait till 10:30 when the doors open. Note if you have kids then the machines don't have the ability to give you a "free" ticket, once in we beat the people needing to buy tickets and asked nicely for a child's free ticket.2: you could buy them online but they are more expensive and there were no queues at the self service machines.3: no rucksacks, plastic bags, coats (although some people did have coats on) or bottles of water are allowed in the museum either take a small bag or buggy (if have kids as we had) and load with snacks, get lunch outside once finished. 3: buy bottle of water in cafe before going around.4: we followed lonely planet guided walk which took us 3.5hrs. Took us to the best rooms. Just have to elbow your way past the tour groups and keep track by looking at the room numbers above the doorways.5: there are plenty of WCs lonely planet and map next to the ticket office show them throughout and further around the museum there are no queues.

Breathtaking!. One can only speak of The Hermitage in superlatives. It's an amazing place, where one could spend half a lifetime admiring the collection. The only drawback is the crowds of visitors. It seems everyone wants to see the two Leonardo Madonnas. So, skip them and move on elsewhere! And if you like The Impressionists a visit to The Hermitage's collection in the General Staff Building across the square is guaranteed to please

Magnificent but too crowded. This is indeed an incredible museum but I had to rate it less than excellent because every room is so crowded that it is impossible to really enjoy it. We had a guide for the morning who managed to take us to many of the highlights. We thought we would tour on our own in the afternoon but it is very difficult to mange that way. After about an hour we decided to leave the main Hermitage museum and cross the square to the separateHermitage building housing the French impressionists (separate admission fee). That was truly excellent with the largest collection of impressionist we have ever seen with a separate room for each of the main French impressionists. It was not crowded and I would highly recommend it even if you don't want to face the mobs at the main Hermitage. That evening we also saw a beautiful ballet at the Hermitage Theater. It is a small intimate theater so you are very close to the dancers. There are no reserved seats so I recommend getting there about 45 minutes early to get a good seat, first come first served.

What opulance. Fascinating to think that the artifacts (only 3% on show to the public) have withstood the ravages of recent times and that buildings such as these were designed & built by master craftsmen over many years centuries ago. What price did the lower class pay for such opu;ance?

so much to see so little time. Most amazing museum I have ever visited. The hardwood floors tapestries, paintings, sculptures, furniture, light fixtures, mosaics, window treatments are incredible. One would need to spend years here to see everything. Rubens, Goya, Rembrandt, Da Vinci, and Michaelangelo just a few of the fabulous artists whose works are here.
Crowded but worth it. You may need to spend a month in SPB to cover this place. So huge, on rival with the Lourve that's for sure.

World class art collection. Opulent state rooms. You'll never see everything in one day. Decide what you would like to see, plan your route and get an audio guide. At the weekend you will need sharp elbows to get in front of the da vimvi and rembrandt....

Wow!. We are not really into art but this art museum is worth seeing if only for the building itself. The architecture and finishes are spectacular. You could spend weeks in here if you're into art. We did a 90ish minute tour focused on some of the more notable parts of the building and the Da Vinci and Rembrandt works. Well worth the visit.

Art Heaven: A Euphoric, Elegant and Historical Experience. Seeing the Hermitage was a dream for me. Russians take art seriously and I was grateful. Not only did they protect their art collection from the Nazi siege, they were able to make the Hermitage a place where art lovers can get in close and see many great works of art in a way that doesn't exhaust. I greatly appreciated seeing the Rembrandt rooms, as well as the Cubist and Expressionist Rooms. I would recommend covering those pieces that are most renowned, like Michaelangelo's crouching boy, Da Vinci's paintings, the Grand Stair Case, the peacock clock!!!! Rembrandt Room and then go from there. We were allowed to take pictures without flash and the staff were not all uptight. In summary, visiting the Hermitage is a must see for any art lover, and I would rate it as a top destination.

Breathtaking but very crowded. The hermitage of course has an amazing collection of art. The building itself inside is worth seeking. However it was crowed with buses of Asian tourist that can bypass the line up. And walk around with guided tours ( very noisy). I was not impressed at all and almost had an argument with one of the guides that pushed me away from a Canaletto because he wanted to show it to his group. I suggest you try to see it outside the season, the shop has beautiful replicas on canvas at very attractive prices. It is a must when in st Petersburg, but you will need to be very patient during the summer months. ( midnight sun) as it is overcrowded

One of the world's greatest galleries. It is hard to know whether to look at the art or the rooms in the Hermitage Museum. The art collection is huge, but the interiors are mind boggling. This truly is a must see destination.

Wow!. This place is insane! The art is beyond belief! You can easily spend an entire day here. It is one masterpiece after another, everywhere you turn. We were on a cruise/tour so we were jamming, moving quickly from one piece to another. It was nice getting a brief explanation of each piece but of course it was rushed. Crowded, yeah! If I were to go back to st Petersburg Russia this would definitely be #1 on my list of places to visit.

Don't go on a Sunday........... I planned not to visit the Hermitage on my 4 day trip to the city but then started feeling guilty about it so decided to go. The museum was overcrowded, mostly with cruise ship tours which made it not such a pleasant experience. People were almost fighting to get a glimpse of a 2 Da Vinci paintings. Well, they were actually not interested in seeing the painting, they just wanted to take a picture....... dreadful.I will return here during a weekday in winter when there are less people.I did get to see some very nice and famous paintings, so don't get me wrong, this musueum is certainly worth visiting.

The World's Most Spectacular Museum. Housed in the Winter Palace of Catherine the Great, the Hermitage is a vast collection of some of the world's most celebrated art. Make sure you catch the two Da Vinci's and the Rembrandts. The rooms are works of art in and of themselves.

A must see destination. We have been to many of the worlds art museums and we think one is the best so far. The collections are outstanding. The rooms are over the top decorated. The ceiling details will blow your mind. To see the collection plan a 2 day ticket. The French paintings have been moved to a new exhibit in a different building across the square. Well worth seeing. Buy ticket online and exchange voucher to get your ticket. This will save you time to. Vouchers can be exchanged at 10am. Museum opens at 1030. Closed at 6pm but 9pm on Thursday. Bags need to be left in locker but it seems no in and out privileges but we did not test that. Photography is allowed with no flash. Be warned gets very crowded with the cruise boat tours by noon. Crazy crowded.Worth it anyway. The art is outstanding. Recommended. A must do.

Superb as expected but buy your tickets beforehand and get an audioguide. The Hermitage has a world class reputation and of course it did not disappoint. Tips for future travellers are firstly to buy your tickets in advance if possible. The day that I visited with friends in May there was a huge line outside: there must have been hundreds of people waiting and I have no idea how long people stood in the queue. Secondly if you are an English speaker I would advise that you get an audio guide - these are not expensive and really give you a lot more information about the museum. The alternative (if you don't have a detailed guide book) is to rely on the few English language signs which you find inside. Please note that you need to leave some kind of ID with the vendor of the audio guides, to then be picked up when you return the audio guides. Alternatively you can leave a cash deposit in place of ID. Lastly, you have to put any coats and bags (even handbags) into lockers before entering the museum's galleries. Make sure you have cash for this.

A Must See!. Absolutely stunning and breathtaking. There is so much to see that you need a full day (maybe two) to take it all in.With great disappointment, we were on a 3 hour tour and missed about 80% of the grounds. The only redeeming factor was the rarely seen Romanov exhibit happened to be running at the time. If you go, do take the whole day. You won't regret it.

Fantastic place to visit. We toured St. Peterburg's world famous Hermitage, built by Peter the Great's daughter Elizabeth in the 18th century which successor Tsars (especially Catherine the Great) filled with thousands of paintings, art work, vases, jewelry, and statues until it became the finest art collection in the world. There are so many paintings, if you stopped to look at each one for 1 minute it would take you nine years to see every one. When Hitler approached the city which he later sieged for 900 days, half the paintings were crated and shipped to Siberia, the other half hidden in the cellars. Round the clock guards swept incendiary devices dropped by the Nazi's off the Hermitage roof. This is a must see for anyone!

One of the greatest museum experiences in the World. Utterly compelling and exhausting, probably always overrun with groups, but worth every last effort. Allow at least two days to enjoy your favourite sample of exhibits. There are items on display that will surprise the best educated lover of history and civilisations, an unbelievable collection of arts and historical artefacts, many not really known in the West. You will do your own research before visiting of course, suffice to say this museum is on a par with the very best and alone merits a visit to this charming friendly town where history comes alive and people approach you to help the welcomed tourist. The metro and buses operate on a flat fare and are easy to use. The Cyrillic alphabet is not so hard to master and the Russians are charmed by your 'spasseeba' for thank you and any other simple words of Russian you can master before going. There is a nice cafe in the museum where you can take the weight off those tired feet and take in the extra calories you will need for a museum with two Da Vincis, rooms full of Rembrandts and Rubens, just to mention a few stars. This is really not to miss, art lovers! Over the square in the other large building, the 'General Staff', there are the impressionists and other miderns, and many other fascinating exhibits, though, sadly, this month, the extensive collections of picassos and Mattisses were not open to view.

World class museum. Although we were there for two days, what we saw required several more days so that we could feast our eyes and souls to satisfaction. Here is a pro tip: when you visit the Hermitage, be sure to visit the 20th Century collection that is located in the General Staff building. You get to see an intricate collection of beautiful Kandinsky's and impressionists.
The best. Better than the louvre in Paris sorry to say but it is so impressive collection can't compair buts it's close

be sure what you know what you want to see. Love it! but it's huge so do your research and go straight to what you want to see or are interested in. Best if you go there everyday for a few hours to truly appreciate the exhibits.

Absolutely Unreal!!!. We have been to the Louvre and this was as impressive. Spent about 3 hours here on a guided tour. If a tour will get you in before the general admission it is worth every penny. The crowds were Unreal when we got there but completely out of control by the time we had to make our way to the mandatory coat check. It was a gong show. People would have waited 2 or 3 hours just to get in I am sure. We were fast laned and it was half an hour in the rain. The collection is jaw dropping. Worth the crowds and I don't say that lightly.

A museum and a palace!. No museum I have been to compares to the all inclusive experience of the Hermitage! Imagine walking around a palace which preserves the glory of the Tsars while looking at Rubens, Rembrandts, and Da Vinci's! It just doesn't get much better than that. There is more than enough to do here for several days. Make sure not to miss the 20th century collection in the General Staff building. With an impressive collection of Impressionists and some beautiful Kandinskys. We were somewhat frustrated with the entrance procedures because there was no line for those who had reserved tickets online. The booth the online instructions had told us to find was closed. We finally had to just elbow our way into the museum and then trade the online vouchers for tickets at an information desk. It did still save us a TON of time from waiting in line, but it was annoying. Another disappointment to me was the relative lack of accompanying information in any of the galleries in Russian or English. The paintings are accompanied purely by tombstone artist date information. So I would suggest getting a guide or going on a tour if you are not super familiar with art history.

Up with the best world class museums!. I was going to buy the tickets online, as I had read many reviews about long queues. I'm glad I didn't as the queue for internet pick up was huge. We walked through the entrance into the square and there was several ticket machine booths, with no lines. The whole process probably took 10mins and we got there right on opening at 10.30. The museum is massive, so its best to get an information leaflet map and head to the exhibits you really want to see, as you could easily spend a day here. Also there is no café or refreshments for sale and large bags have to be put in storage. There is also a lack of toilets and these are all on the ground floor.

Hermitage. What a beautiful place! We had been told that the crowds were bad but we did not experience any crowds. The palace is beautiful and well worth the time spent! We wish we could have spent a longer time at this beautiful museum.

Wonderful Place. You will have difficulty finding words if you love architecture and the arts. The state rooms are magnificent architecture, the details. Look at the stone work and the finishes, look at the great urns. The artwork collection is 15-18 th centuries European art. It has a great Greek collection of antiquity. If you have time, go across the plaza to the General Staff building and see the impressionists collection, it is a little lost with the loose ends of the Hermitage. It feels disorganized, it is a separate ticket, but a good collection.

Treasure House. Stunning collection of artworks- in fact it is too large a collection. A good idea is to go with a tour group - in that way you get to see the most famous and important artworks within a shorter period of time instead of spending hours and hours viewing artworks and not getting to see the famous ones. Be prepared to stand in ques to enter no matter what time of the day.

Not enough time. There was not really enough time to soak in the magic of this place. Photos do not do it justice. We used "Best Guides" tour company in St. Petersburg. They took care of our travel visa!

Should be a Wonder of the World. You must visit Hermitage when you visit Russia. This museum is enormous with over 5 million artifacts inside,. You will see all original art including some paintings by Rembrandt, Picasso, and other famous artists. It will take you approx. 3 days to observe this great museum.

Too much, too many.... The Hermitage must be seen but you should do it according to some kind of plan: you have to choose what do you intend to see because the museum is really huge. Try to buy tickets not in the Winter Palace but in the General Staff building - there is no queue there!

A house full of art. First thing to know about Hermitage, it is huge.To avoid the overwhelming art blast, make a plan before you go and decide what you want to see. You can find floor plan for example from Hermitage homepage.Take your time to look around also the building itself. It is astonishing.

Highlight of our trip. The most impressive gallery and museum I have ever seen. The building itself is amazing but the artwork is incredible. The sheer quantity is mind boggling! We went in May so not over-crowded but even so, we were glad to have a guide and pre-booked tickets. Queues were very long.

A great site that meets every expectation we had for it!. We have heard nothing but good about the museum for years. It was a thrill on every level--art, architecture, design, history and sheer size. The place is huge! There is no way to do justice to this museum on a cruise ship visit! We had a "special pass" on Holland America to let us visit the key galleries prior to the huge crowds (which are there EVERY day); therefore, we were able to see far more than most people will see in a day, but we still just scratched the surface! The ancient Greek, Roman and Egyptian collections are nice, but there are better ones in other parts of the world--use the time for the more significant collections.The building is beautiful--inside and outside. The rooms are jaw dropping! Spoiler alert! We were not aware that the Impression art collection has been moved to a different building in the Hermitage collection of buildings--with it's own entry fee and line at the ticket booth. It was a shame (it had been high on our list) that we did not get to see it, but we can wait for a future trip. That may be far easier said than done! The visa situation and the logistics of getting around can be very challenging. The visa is very expensive, but you do not need one if you are on officially sanctioned tours and are staying on the cruise ship. Not everyone will feel comfortable trying to navigate the city on your own. Do your research on this issue and what you want to see--there is so much to see that you need days/weeks! There are some areas of the city that are best described as "rough."

Amazing palace with beautiful paintings. I wish I would have had more to spend in the Hermitage as there would be so much to see. Anyway, the parts I saw were very beautiful and I was impressed as with the paintings as the palace itself. I can recommend it outside holiday season as otherwise the queues can be quite long.
wonder how they maintain it. what collection of old time artefacts and the maintenance of the place is awesome. every piece speaks for the era it represents. if you like history, this is the place.

See the Hermitage now and read why!. Regal Princess, 8,9 May 2015, two-day excursion with Alla Tours and I can recommend them. May 9 celebrated 70 years since the downfall of the Nazis, so three cruise ships (Celebrity Solstice and Aida) all had to go to the hermitage on the 8th. At 9:30, the early entry time for tour groups, the independent queue was already a mile long and we had to push past them. Large bags and wet anoraks are verboten, so roll up the wet stuff as the two cloak rooms for 5,000 people have another long queue. Hesitating at the cloak room meant we lost our tour group but caught up with them later by joining and contacting another Alla rep. with mobile phone. If you spend only one minute per painting you need ten years to see it all, so the pace is brisk; the toilets are down a long stairway, so if you are mobility-challenged you have a problem. Why see it ASAP? Sometimes six cruisers are in town and if you wait until the Indian, Chinese and Brazilian middle classes have exploded, you will find the queues impossible to beat as it is a mad push already. 50 Rubels/US$ and the toilets cost 30 Rubels, have them on you for the two-day excursion as your guide may not have any. The attendant may take your Dollar? There is no ticketing system like at Sans Souci (Potsdam), where a quota is enforced inside by giving you a ticket, which also has the entry time printed to stop flooding. Booking with Alla meant not having to pay AUS$120 each for the Russian visum, being picked up at the pier after immigration, seeing all the worthwhile sites in and around St Petersburg for two days in a small bus and getting a guide with excellent English, ear phones and two meals, one in a stolle pie shop and one in a restaurant. And there is a choice of a Comfort Tour, which we wrinklies took, there is also a more demanding Grand Tour.

Totally worth the visit. Stunning in all facets, amazing building to view and inside with the museum is fabulous.Spent many hours at the museum and was amazed at its beauty it truly a historic place to visit.Make sure you visit this place when in St. Petersburg.

spectacular palace museum. Stopped in St Petersburg on a cruise. Had to use a tour group to visit Russia in order to get Visa, part of the tour was the Hermitage. Since we had a guide the ticket was included in the tour, so we did not have to stand in line to buy it. What a mad house, the crowds were smothering. You have to check your bags and coat, which is free , but another line. The palace itself is gorgeous on top of all the antiques and priceless art. You could spend years here and not see everything. Well worth the visit!!

don't go in the summer. do buy your tickets online and do go on wednesday night when it is open till 21.00 and the place is empty. otherwise very crowded.too bad some paintings do need restauration and could do withe better lighting. very friendly staff everywhere

Fantastic, cannot be described, must be seen!. Beautiful! Prebook tickets at your hotel and avoid the lines. May is a great time to visit, before the real tourist season starts. My only wish is more information in English, everything is written in Russian :-(

trip to Hermitage May 2015. Totally amazing many many rooms with world famous artists, statues, pictures. We had planned 1/2 day but spent the entire day. Tickets were easy from machine 600r near entrance (like those at movies at home) no line-ups. locals get discounts and therefore need to buy where line is. Impressionist paintings now across at General Staff Building (same ticket) Great DayLouise from Canada

Infinite museum!. For sure, the Hermitage museum is one of the biggest in the world and you can spend forever in it. You can discover so any things there and not only about Russia but it covers history of culture of different countries as well!
Wow!!. An absolutely amazing place to visitfull of culture, exhibits and paintings from all the great masters. This really is a must if you are visiting St Petersburg.

It's recommended to take a guide. If it's your first visit to this museum, it's advisable to take a guide or a guided tour to have some idea of what is there to see. I was there on a Sunday, it was quiet crowded and I was told to be aware of pickpockets.
World-class. One of the top collections in the world. Everything is here. Compares to the Louvre, and I'm not sure what else.I only wish I had more time, but I will be back...

Another excellent attraction. Who can miss this fantastic museum ?
Go with a guide as it offers to much to see and you will need help to pick the best.

Still as beautiful as ever. This is my second trip to the Hermitage, with the first one being about two years ago. We only had a limited amount of time, and unfortunately, I didn't think to ask for a map before we ventured inside. The exhibits are gorgeous, and there is a reason it has been nicknamed "Russia's Versaille", but keep in mind these few factoids: Very few of the docents speak any English. You will need to be dependent on your map reading skills. It is a winding, huge place, with many loop backs and dead ends. You will be dependent on your map reading skills. Little kids will likely tire out, and teens may get bored. Be prepared. It is something that should not be missed, but do be aware of those limitations. Definitely get web tickets and skip the lines in the summer.
Excelent!. One of the greatest museums in the world.I enjoyed my tour here though I haven't seen everything but its inposible to do even in 10 hours)

Hemitage is Russia : Hermitage is History. The Hermitage is unlike The Louvre. It does not have imposing lawns or fountains instead it has, in my opinion, the grandest collection of art in the World.I'll not cheapen the museum by listing the fabulous artwork but it includes pieces from nomadic Asian tribes to the finest Europe has to offer.Time is the enemy as this collection is so large you should study on what interests you rather then to try to follow the massive rooms until you find what you like.

Not to be missed. Really a must see on any trip to St. Petersburg. The building itself is part of the museum, not simply the collections. It gives you a glimpse into the decadence of the Romanoff's and makes you understand why the people revolted.  Be prepared to walk over 2 kilometers just to see the basics, so wear comfortable shoes. It can get very crowded, as well.The reason for only 4 stars instead of 5 is that there is no accommodation for anyone with mobility issues. Walkers and wheelchairs are not possible here.

A Wondrous Place but you need more than three hours to visit -- try two days. Overwhelming doesn't even half state what the effect of experiencing this museum is about. Unfortunately, they don't pace the groups that visit and the result is pretty much chaos. The guides (at least ours did) felt that they had to rush us through all of the rooms, thereby you did not really have a chance to take a lot of what you were seeing in. Think that they should set aside special days for schoolchildren also so that they have a better educational experience. But, they really need to pace the groups going in (like some other museums) so that there is not so much madness and perhaps people will act a little less rude to one another trying to push through everything and get closer views.

Museum Without Comparison, 5 Stars Plus. Hermitage and Winter Palace represent Russian nobility and wealth so immense and magnificent that mere words are inadequate -- you must experience this at least once in your life. The art museum is completely endowed with renaissance, pre- and post-renaissance works from every significant master. Rembrandt, Van Gogh, Vermeer, Raphael, Giotto, della Francesca, Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Titian, Monet, Matisse, Manet -- you must allow minimum two full days, but three - four days is better.The Winter Palace displays silver and gold finery, armor, and culinary. You will not believe your eyes because this is fantastic. Sparse but helpful stewards and attendants. You must search, some of the best rooms are barely listed in the guides.

Fabulous bling-fest. This is a wonderful museum set in a glorious series of historic buildings. The interiors are splendid - a visual feast of gold and elaborate mirrors, mouldings, carvings. The art is almost secondary to the setting, but it makes an unsurpassable combination. World class. Allow lots of time, or book a guided tour - ours was excellent and I really feel helped us get the most from the place.

More Than an Art Museum. The major display occupies five buildings forming the Hermitage museum complex. All of them were designed by celebrated architects of the 18th and 19th centuries. The Winter Palace was a residence of the Russian emperors until 1917 and houses exhibitions of European and ancient art. The Treasure Gallery may be seen only on guided tour - tickets purchased at the museum ticket office - and has a fascinating display of golden artifacts found in the Caucus dating back to the 6th Century BC. There is also a dazzling array of jeweled artifacts belonging to Russian royalty. The French Impressionists have been moved into the newly renovated General Staff Building on the opposite side of the square from the Winter Palace. If you arrive early, you may enjoy a military band playing in the courtyard.You can easily spend two days exploring the above mentioned exhibitions. If you are short on time, I'd recommend skipping the Winter Palace of Peter I.

Enormous - and rambling. you really need a guide to se the hermitage - there is just so much to see, and unless you have 2-3 days, you need someone to show you round the highlights if you are to manage it in only 1 day. Very impressive.

Magnificent Even For Non-Art Lovers. Even if you don't like art, you can't help but being overwhelmed by the magnificent architecture and grand staterooms, reception halls, throne rooms, etc. Inside you're surrounded by marble columns, huge chandeliers and art masterpieces from throughout the ages. If you are part of a tour, be sure to get there early as we were told that only tours can get in prior to 1000. After that time crowds bulge and can result in several hours of waiting in line to get in and an impossible task to maneuver around the exhibits.

Hermitage. Massive place, definitely need a knowledgable guide to maximize your visit. Group tours have priority and early entry which enables you to see the rooms before they become too packed. Will need another visit to see different sections of the museum.
Army of cats. An incredible and unique collection from across the globe. Under the museum is an army of cats protecting the art from rats.

The halycon Hermitage. The Hermitage has to be one of the best museums in the world - from the amazing architecture on the outside to the phenomenal rooms and works of art in the inside - it is truly a must visit when in St. Petersburg - you need a week to fully appreciate this magnificent attraction.

One of the wonders of the world. This is for art lovers a place for pilgrimige. The only problem is that it is too large to cover in hours, but actually requires days, just like Louvre or British museum. Leonardo da Vinci department can get very crowded. Go there in the morning, before the groups.

Fantastic. First of all, come early! Second of all, wear comfortable shoes. Thirdly, plan two visits - one to admire the architecture and interior and another to look at the exhibits. It is a MASSIVE building - something quite unbelievable and overwhelming. You really have to see it to believe it. Plan ahead - get a map of the museum and plan what you want to see because it's absolutely impossible to see everything.
Amazing. Must see, lots of art, lots of history and lots of info. Install the application and study it before you go. The portraits are amazing.

Art and Architecture to overwhelm the senses. 300+ rooms of art, rooms that dazzle with their architectural uniqueness. Order your tickets online to avoid the long line and buy a two-day ticket so as not to become overwhelmed. The cafe is dismal so bring a snack with you if you want to take a break during your visit.The peacock
Museum is Stunning but don't bother with the Winter Palace. Loved it all - from the band playing in the biggest square we have ever seen to the grandeur of the museum itself.

Absolute must do - take a whole day . I don't consider myself an arty person but this really took me back. Not only does the Hermitage house some incredible works of art but the building itself is unlike anything I've ever seen. You could spend the day just looking at each of the halls/rooms. Highly recommend this for a day in St Petersburg.

Excellent museum and glorious interiors. You'd need a lifetime to do justice to all the objects and artworks in here.It's an incredible place for a wander - intricate ceilings and gold leaf everywhere and each room is just more ornate than the previous one.The info sheet with colour coded zones is helpful, and the glum security guards brightened a little when asked for help in finding things. I spent ages in the more obscure bits - Central Asian art etc - and had the place to myself. But the main areas are crowded, as you'd expect,
Magnificent place!. Amazing museum, very well preserved. Rooms full of art.We don't know where to fix our eyes: the painted ceilings, the wooden floors, the furniture... Everything is wonderful!

avoid queue with Internet Tickets. Unless you want to spend a couple hours queueing for this magnificent museum you better buy your tickets in advance online. You will have to print the receipt and show it in the special internet ticket booth (no queue! If closed go directly to the information booth inside the museum) Credit card machines to buy the tickets are also a good option but they do not work always

Hermitage and St Petersburg. We added a visit to St Petersburg to a trip to the Baltic States. It was very easy to do and well worth the relatively modest cost. If you go in by ferry from Helsinki and stay less than 72 hours (and buy a $25 per person transfer package from the ferry line) you don't need a $250 per person visa. To put this in perspective, our ferry transportation, stateroom, meals and drinks for the round trip cost only $440 for both of us (i.e. less than the cost of two visas). The toughest part was figuring out how to use the Russian St Petersline ferry website but it was well worth the learning curve. I had previously tried to book the ferry tickets through two different U.S. agents for the ferry company but they were heavily marking up the trip. Also, we stayed at the upscale Kempinksi Moika 22 hotel on the two days between ferry rides and, due to a pre-paying discount and a favorable exchange rate at the time of booking, it was less than $200 per night. Since the hotel is less than 1,000 feet from the Hermitage it is a great location!Prior to getting to SP I arranged for a private tour guide and driver through Stan Jacox (an American ex-pat) http://www.tickets-and-tours.com/. The total cost for two days, with admission tickets was 440 Euros (also substantially less than quoted by the US travel agents). Also, by using a guide we avoided lines at several locations. I highly recommned Stan's service. He met us upon arrival and again at the end of our tour and was very helpful.

even 15 visits is not enough. Over the period of three years, I have visited hermitage over 15 times and have still to come to grips with the beauty and enormity of the treasures held. Comparable to the Louvre in every way and much more, a must for any tourist to st Petersburg.
Superb museum. One of the biggest and perfect museums in the world. I know only one-two comparable - e.g. Vatican museums.

Wonderful museum. First tip, buy the tickets from ATM's in the courtyard. Then you will not wait for the ticket line.Second tip, go early. Then it is too crowded.Third tip, get a museum map, it is very easy to follow.Fourt tip, there is not many place to sit down so be ready.Fifth tip, museum shops are very nice.

better late than never. Visited many years ago now and it was a fabulous Museum. Many beautiful paintings and furniture and works of art on display which shows how cultured Russian history is and in some cases how closely linked to France it is.

The best museum in the world. The Hermitage lives up to its reputation. It is impeccably ordered and maintained and has the broadest and deepest scope of art you will ever see. Unlike the Louvre, you can get up close to the artwork.
Great. Great museum! Many great pieces. Would take forever to try to see it all. But is Must stop if you have any time on your hands.

Up there with the best. Ok, first up, how to beat the queues. Buy your tickets from the ATM like machines just inside the main arch and to your left. There are 4 of them, in Russian and English, and no queue. If booking via internet you have to go to a booth to get tickets and there is a waiting line, similarly if you buy from ticket booth in the museum you could loose at least 30 minutes if not more. The ticket machine takes card or cash. Once you have the ticket, there is an express entry line so minimal waiting to get in. Make sure you pick up a museum map, in several languages, near information counter before you pass ticketed entry point - without one you will not have a clue where you are at. Room numbers are clearly numbered and staff will help you if lost. Another thing, there is no longer a charge to take photos or video. Cannot use flash and only several rooms do not allow photography. We arrived at opening time 10.30am on a Friday in May, entry was a breeze. Remember you must check in coats and backpacks at before entering ticketed area and no drinks are allowed to be carried in. Toilets are only on the ground floor (4 locations) so keep that in your planning. Do you need an audio guide, personal choice. We didn't and found enough English explanations to improve our knowledge. I overheard some of the tour guides who would have bored me to tears. There is a lot to see and everywhere the building interiors are stunning but don't miss the Palace Interiors section. Cafes (2) on ground floor meet basic needs but service may be slow at busy times. We needed 5 hours to cover 60-70% of the building, think 3 hours is the minimum time for 'highlights'. Everything here is grand, loved it and has my highest recommendation.

Spectacular!!. Don't miss the Hermitage!!Like all the architecture of government buildings and palaces, it is splendid from facade to interior. Views of this building's exterior are more complete from canal boats. Recommend.
Wow!. Abundance of art and gold. I hate that reviews have to be 100 characters because I am a person of few words!

SPECTACULAR. This is an absolutely spectacular place, one must visit the Hermitage Museum even if they stay one day at St Petersburg. It is a grand and for someone who loves art - this is the place to be, one could see paintings of Leonardo Da Vinci too.

Fabulous!. The museum is huuuuuuge!!! It has too many interesting things to see which I didn't have enough time with my family to see it all! There are many sections of different civilizations, arts and historic events inside this enormous museum.The museum is very spacious and is very organized in a way that makes you interested to visit every tiny piece and area of the museum. The decorations inside the palace are just simply majestic to say the least ... we had a very nice time inside there ... you can't visit St. Petersburg without visiting this place.
Voucher. Get yourself a guide, so much to see you'll miss the best bits. Get your vouchers from the Hotel, it's much quicker and, you go straight to the front of the Que

Magnificent. Make no mistake this is a location everyone wants to see on a visit to St Petersburg. It is difficult to find words that adequately describe this palace as it is so beautiful. The outside is an imposing sight but once inside no-one could fail to be impressed. Marble everywhere as you would expect, artwork to suit every taste. It is hard on the first visit to just take everything in. Due to it's popularity, organized tours get entry ahead of those waiting in the entrance queue, so suggest that this is the way to go initially.

Absolutely fabulous .....with so much to see an entirety isn't enough!. A must see in St. Petersburg. It is well worth the time to check out the official website and trip advisor posts BEFORE visiting to plan and make the most of your visit. The immensity of size and volume of works is daunting. If possible don't bring a back pack or coat/ jacket, this helps to avoid the cloakrooms which are very busy. A pre paid ticket from an official source is a big advantage as otherwise there is a big queue. Tickets are great value for money but single entry only.There are some rooms much more crowded than others due to the popularity of the works present - the second floor rooms 254 and 227 in particular as tour groups zoom around and can be pushy. A visit to those between 1 and 2pm is less crowded. Other areas are much less crowded and more enjoyable as a result. Staff told me winter time is very quiet and a good time to truly appreciate the exhibits. The impressionists are now located across the square in the General staff building. The layout is a bit confusing but was very uncrowded the morning we went increasing the enjoyment! Picasso and Matisse works were not on display at the time we were there which was a shame but c'est la vie! This is a visit even for those who do not particularly like art, the rooms are amazing, the selection of exhibits from ancient civilisation and there ate appartments are equally captivating.... Just go!The restaurant was busy, we didn't use this. There a 2 or 3 WC areas not just at the main door. Make use of the really good museum plan!

Breath taking. This has to be your number one stop in st.petersburg. It is beautiful. each room has something new to offer and you could spend hours looking around and not being to be bored. I highly recommend this.

Amazing museum. Go on a weekday when there are less crowds. We just finished our tour of the State Hermitage Museum. Like many of the other reviews, we also found the museum to be a bit overwhelming but mainly because of the huge number of people that were there on a Friday. In every single room, we'd bump shoulders with many people so going from one room to another took forever. Once we got out of the winter palace, it became a lot less crowded so we were able to go thru the museum portion quite easily. We didn't spent too much time looking at each painting, more focusing on the architecture of each of the rooms which are all quite grand. Its tough to pick which hallway was my favorite since each hallway has so much detail, especially the columns in the various museum rooms or in the grand staircases of the winter palace. We also arrived late to the museum (2:30) so that may have contributed to the crowd and was also a reason for why we didn't spend too much time looking at the art. We did save some time by buying our ticket from the hotel (Hermitage Hotel) which was very helpful. We also didn't get an audio guide due to the time but we did notice that the first desks in the winter palace were out usually but if you went into the museum and up the staircase, there's another desk where you can more easily get one.

How the other half live!. Incredible buildings - inside and out, but I found the museum hard to navigate. The sign posting and information was poor and we found it hard to find the things we wanted to see. Some of the art - in particular the Picasso collection - was fantastic, but the arrangements/displays all seemed a bit amateurish. Well worth a visit but be prepared to queue to get in, although once inside there were no queues, and allow lots of time.

Like Versailles and the Louvre in One. We spent the entire day here and it was one unbelievable room after another. You need to look everywhere in every room as the floors and ceilings are as masterfully decorated as the walls, furnishings and art. We purchased tickets on line ahead of time, which even on a chilly April day saved us a long wait. Do not miss a visit here!

Astounding - do not miss this. Before going to St Petersburg we had been advised it would be best to book tickets in advance and that one day is not enough. Well, both pieces of advice turned out to be very helpful indeed. I booked via the Hermitage website and booked a two-day ticket (these will be for two consecutive days, you won't be able to go one day and then again three days later). The other pieces of advice were: The cafe is terrible and expensive and also you won't be able to self-tour. The former was totally wrong, the cafe is brilliant and serves MANY different, delicious items of food at reasonable prices, the second was half right. We decided to buy a Lonely Planet guide to St Petersburg and their suggested half day tour was very easy to follow. And mostly, we just used the museum map and had no problem finding what we wanted. The buildings themselves are stunning and do take the time to walk around outside to admire them. On the first day we spent 4 hours on the 2nd floor (that's Russian and US 2nd floor, in the UK we'd call that the 1st floor), where all the beautiful Winter Palace state rooms are. In 4 hours we did NOT see the whole floor but we guided ourselves and we were very happy to do so with the Lonely Planet guide. On the second day we explored the first floor (UK ground floor) and again, we guided ourselves with a map without difficulty. We again spent 4 hours walking through just that one floor. In summation, you need TIME - if you had locked us in there for a week we would still have not managed to see everything. As to the exhibits, I don't really know whether I can describe adequately my feelings as we walked around. "oooh" and "aaaaah" upon entering almost every room, as not only the exhibits in the rooms, but the rooms themselves are art. Those ceilings, walls and floors could be in an exhibition all by themselves, never mind the near fantastical collection of every type of antique you can imagine in multitudes of versions: Greek, Mongol, Chinese, Japanese, European of all kinds, Russian Empire….jewellery, paintings, statues, holy relics, porcelain, furniture, clocks, tapestries, weapons, clothes, every precious metal and stone and whatever else comes to your mind. They have it there. And then some. Also a separate mention should be made about the prehistoric exhibition showing VERY ancient Siberian finds. Trust me, you will struggle to find a collection of such ancient yet stunningly preserved artefacts almost anywhere in the world. Practical information: If you have a pre booked ticket, you'll get in FAR QUICKER than queueing - the sheer volume of people will make you doubt your sanity. If possible, travel a little out of season and avoid weekend visits to the museum. The less people in the museum, the more you will enjoy it. In the summer months you will feel like a sardine, no kidding. There is a cloakroom for coats and large bags, which they will insist you use (as in most Russian attractions) and it is free and very convenient. Upon entry, buy a bottle of water in the cafe (they won't let you take any in and there is a security scanner for bags and people, no point trying to conceal any), it is well worth it as wandering the halls for hours is thirsty work. There are many toilets inside, you won't need to worry. And, if I did not already say it, you will need TIME. :) We loved every minute in there and could not recommend it more highly.

Too much!. Absolutely loved our chance to participate in a 1 1/2 hour tour of this amazing place. We saw so much during that time but look forward to spending a leisurely full day in the museum some time in the future.

another fantastic experience. This is a great place although we had a young art student as a guide and she told us a lot about the paintings before we got there and then as we were walking through she would question us and of course we had forgotten all she had told us . She then got very annoyed with us and rushed on without explaining any more . One elderly man fell on the stairs while trying to keep up. He broke his arm and had to be taken back to our cruise ship . So it is such a shame that we weren't able to enjoy this gallery to the fullest . I hope we do get back there some time to visit again

Incredible museum. The state rooms of the Hermitage will take your breath away. While there are thousands of tourists there, the museum is so larg that, as long as you are visiting independently, you can often be in rooms with only a few other people. The Matisse and Picasso are not on display as the more modern art (third floor) is in the process of being moved across the square to the General Staff Building. On exhibit in this new space is a large collection of Impressionist and post Impressionist art. It was not crowded and is included in the general entry ticket.

Must see the impressionists' collection. As a gallery-goer I only visited the marvellous Winter palace to see the interior - to realise the power of Imperal Russia. The rooms's decor and the ceilings are beautiful - much interesting to visit with the excursion. I enjoyed visiting the wing of Staff building. No crowds and people around and you can see the national treasures collected by famous art patronages and masterpieceses's by Renoir, Buden, Monet, Van Gog, Kandinsky, Malevich all by yourself! I liked the greeting words by one of the custodian lady: "Here we set your good mood. You'll leave us inspired. You can't go to the Hermitage in a bad mood." Thank you!
Dazzling!!!. A great place with architectural beauty and dazzling paintings!!Includes treasures....Never miss visiting this place!No more words....just dazzling!!!

One of the best museums . Never expected to see so much art and artefacts at this museum. It's very big and would match the best in the world like Louvre in Paris. The restoration has been down excellently and painting from the best artists in the world can be seen here. Other than that the winter palace's grandness is visible Add to that the Palace square's beauty, and you have a very compelling reason to visit this place.

Must see. Hermitage is one of the biggest Art galleries in the world. Smth. what each person must see. If you want to visit all exhibitions of Museum - 1 day is not enough- too big. Recommend to get there in the morning to have some time to visit smth else.

Great place. I was surprised to read that some visitors think that it is expensive. I think that if you buy a ticket in the official museum the price is not that high. Pay attention- the impressionist collection is not in the main building anymore but in the buliding opposite Winter palace. It's a good idea to read about this place in advance to make sure that you know what to see as the place is huge.

Stunning. I deducted a star as despite asking for the 300 ruble ticket for admission only to the winter palace, the very stern woman gave me a 600 ruble ticket and wasn't in the mood to take no for an answer. Aswell as all the impressive gold twirly bits there is a great museum here too.
Wonderful time. It is so big and rich museum. Get ready and discover all the tresures from the history. You have wonderful time but it is quite big place and so many things to see.

A must see. This is one of the worlds great museums but it is not just the exhibits that are awesome. The building itself and the rooms are amazing and would be worth the admission price alone. Add to it some of the greatest artworks in the world and it is an experience you will not forget. You stand inches away from Da Vinci paintings or Rembrandts and because it is so large you have plenty of time to enjoy them. An experience not to miss

The best and richest museum of the world!!. so big and so rich that you cannot get bored. Luxury itself in every part, the floors, the walls, the doors and the ceilings are all state of the art, which is changing colors in every room. Considering the fact that everywhere you can find unique pieces of art, I don't thing that hermitage is a place that you can forget during your lifetime!!!!

Way too expensive to visit, but definitely the Best in the world.. The Hermitage combines the best aspects of world heritage. The entrance admission is way too high just for foreigners while residents pay a bit less.The first Thursday of every month visitors can walk without paying. Be sure to arrive early to skip the long queue. Students with ISIC cards can enter free.

Best museum I have seen. They have more incredible sights than the next 3 museums combined. It is a vast collection of stuff confiscated, donated or bought my Catherine the great and successors czars. The breadth and depth is astonishing. Must be seen to appreciate it.
Main monument. This hermitage museum is so enormous that one wonders how long it must have taken for its construction.Also it acts as winter palace which is amazing.Must see

Two Day Highlights of St. Petersburg. I was lucky enough to visit the Hermitage prior to opening hours on my visit with TJ Travel, arriving at around 8.30am. This surely has to be the most magnificent museum with the largest art collection in the world. The building is enormous and I'm sure you could visit every day for a month and only see a small part of it. We visited some of the more famous works of art including the famous peacock clock purchased by Catherine the Great in the late 1700's. It's an automaton featuring 3 beautiful birds - an owl a peacock and a rooster, all of which are guilded and enclosed in a huge glass case. Works from all the great artists through time are represented here both in artwork and sculptures. Some of the most incredible marble sculptures are here and also the worlds most famous paintings. The rooms themselves are truly magnificent. For most visitors to St. Petersburg only a short visit is possible - but make the effort and go as you will not regret it! Spend as much time as you can but a minimum of 2 hours so as you can see a small section.For those interested in seeing more of this building there is a movie called "The Russian Ark" - the only movie ever filmed in one take, which all takes place in the Hermitage with the actors all in 19th century costume. Filmed in 2002 it portrays historical figures from 200 years of Russian history.

Wow. This museum is filled with treasures. There are mosaics, paintings, sculptures, tea sets, vases and so much more. They cover Roman, Italian, Egyptian, and of course Russian works of art. It is very extensive. The day we went the peacock clock wasn't demonstrated, our guide says they only do it once a week however there is a video you can watch. This is a favorite attraction so expect crowds and lots of walking. There is a place to eat and several areas to purchase souvenirs.

Excellent. The best selection in my trip. Seven Stars for State Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace.
Perfect for children and adults.
Beautiful place, history.
Was a reality dream.

one of the best in the world. This museum is two museums in one. Both the buildings as the arts it has are worth the trip. We took a personal guide and we got a great flight by the highlights in two hours. We did need some time by ourselves, though, as there is so much to see.Most beautiful, I found, is the Winterpalace with all its gold and the beautifully decorated rooms.Seemingly unendless number of artpieces. Will definitely go back, if I have the chance.

Astonished by the architecture and art. As someone who has traveled to over 100 cities, I was astonished by the Hermitage. My jaw was sore from dropping at the various rooms we entered - the building itself was so beautiful. I would highly recommend the Hermitage, St. Isaac's (don't be discouraged by the outside - the interior is stunning), and Church of the Savior on Blood - in descending order but all highly recommended!

You should see. I appreciated new areas for expositions in General Staff building. There are big atriums, new nice halls for temporary exhibitions and renovated interiors of Tzar military minister's residence. I enjoyed seeing the famous Hermitage collection of impressionists in new halls.

WoW, that was worth of every RUB. First a hint, take a map, otherwise you will get lostA huge building, a lot to see, paintings, arcitecture, history etcYou need time.Don't be afraid, the que moves fast at the ticket box, and you can pay with credit card.Enjoy your day..

Not too crowded off season. You do get an overload of great art at this place so there is a need to plan your trip. Most guide books have details of the rooms. the Rembrandts are great as are the van Dykes and there are modern works too although Russiam Suprematists may be out on loan
Needed more time here!. This was an amazing museum. You will see one of the world's largest and most valuable art collections. My favorite was the Amber Room.

You could spend your entire life inside the Hermitage and not see everything!. I almost cried tears of joy... this museum is the real deal! Never have I seen such opulence and beauty. The exhibits are incredible. Make sure you have a big chunk of time to explore and are well-rested, as there is so much to see. It's free for students, so be sure to bring your ID if you have one. And hurry fast, because I'll be moving in next month. ;)

The best reason to visit St. Petersburg. We all know that the Hermitage is one of the best museums in the world as far as their art-collection is concerned, In my opinion they do not make the best use of the exhibition space and their lighting system leaves much to be desired. In good Russian fashion there maps are poor, but typically there OH so beaurocratic rules and regulations makes life for the unaware visitor very frustrating. Even though you have a full day pass, if you use an exit by mistake you can't get back in to collect your ccoat and bag. But to visit St. Petersburg without visiting the Hermitage and seeing this magnificent collection of art would be unthinkable for me. Their large outstanding exhibition of Impressionists can only be described in superlatives. I was aware of their ideosyncratic passion for beaucracy and their passion for bossing people around, but if you love magnificent art and the immense pleasure it gives, allow at least 2 days in the Hermitage, it is simply a fantastic place. A word to the wise, buy your tickets on line in advance, it saves you long lines and that part is pretty well organized.

Get ready to be amazed.. Outside it is a butterfle building. But inside you will get blown away with treasures. Amazing grand steps lead you to the farry tails of kings and queens. Rooms and rooms deals with amazing pictures, statues take your breath away. Your head spin and you forget about time. You get lost in knight room. Go thru the secret pass to the garden. Listen to the chambers music at teater. Painting from all over the world from 2000 BC up to now working as a time machine. No way you could see it all in one day. Just go and get lost in the rooms.
Amazing . It's amazing in every way. Be prepared for walking though. Don't understand why ppl take their small children there though, they get bored way too soon, so think twice if this is your plan.

Overwhelming. I visited the Winter Palace Museum back in November with a class trip to St. Petersburg. Like the Louvre or the Met, it was a huge museum - almost overwhelming. While November is not a high point in tourism in St. Petersburg, it was still very busy. We went in an hour before it closed - putting us on a tight time crunch for seeing this massive museum. It was nonetheless an experience that I was not to pass up, and a great way to defrost form the cold Russian air. However we had gone to the Dutch and German exhibit to see the massive paintings and portraits, which of course were very impressive. What impressed me the most about the Hermitage was the breathtaking architecture of the place, especially the ceilings. Worth a visit if you are in St. Petersburg - but I advise to take more time than just an hour!

The collection of Old and New Masters is now split. The collection of Old Masters is now housed in the main complex of the Hermitage (it comprises 5 buildings: Winter Palace, Small Hermitage, Big Hermitage and Hermitage Theatre). The collection of New Masters is kept in the former building of the Head Quarters of the General Staff of Russian army - it's the building in front of the Winter Palace, across the square. One needs two separate tickets to see both collections.

A place with numerous and immense rooms. Like the Louvre in Paris, it takes a lot of time to explore all the exhibits of this palace. Only opens at 10.30 am. Very interesting and has to be absolutely visited.
Cultural!. We loved the State Hermitage Museum. Be sure tl have about 4 hours to see it in its entirety. It's really amusing ad interesting.
Amazingly Huge.... It's a beautiful museum with millions of pieces.. You might need the whole day to explore it properly. Bring your GPS and don't get lost . Absolutely worthy.

Winter Palace. Hello everyone! I would like to recommend that all the tourists coming to our North Venice (St. Petersburg) would visit all the places of interest. But you need to decide which architectural style you like most. All the places belong to diffedent times. Each place is original. If you would like to get to know how have lived russian tsars visit the State Hermitage. There you can find old furniture, many paintings and so on. Its an excursion for one day :-)

Unlike any other art museum. Housed in Catherine the Great's winter palace the collection and the building are unlike any other. I recommend you watch the film made a few years ago called "Russian Ark" before your visit. It will give you a sense of the place and its history. Its a good idea to know what you came to see and go there first. We especially wanted to see the French Impressionist collection and it is spectacular. More than we have seen in any half dozen other museums.

Wear comfortable shoes!. This museum is vast and I would have easily got lost had we not booked a guided tour. Personally, if you're not local, I think this is the only way to make the most of what the Hermitage has to offer and to fully appreciate the artwork on display. If you are able, book through an 'official' vendor as tourists are able to enter the museum earlier on certain mornings than 'regular' visitors. This is a bonus as the museum does get very busy and can be quite crowded in some areas despite its huge size.The paintings and sculptures are wonderful but so are the ceilings and the flooring! The level of detail on the ceilings left me gawping at regular intervals! The guided tour around the Gold Room is strictly in group order and, whilst fascinating, I'm not sure that I would spend the time I did in this one area with so much else to explore. Well worth a visit but do wear comfy shoes as there's a lot of walking involved.

Great Museum - but not amazed, due to museum organisation. Absolutely great Museum and Palace with rich history, BUT museum organization and procedures made me mad. First a fall, even you buying online ticket which is more expensive you have still queue outside for long, same as others. Secondly, in case you coming to Saint Peteresburg in the winter like I did, it was disaster. I was waiting for 2.5 hours outside with minus 3 outside and ice cold wind, no much fun. Please try to come before it opens so it will guarantee you that you can take all tours you might be interested in. But overall museum was very interesting, Egypt room is not that awesome as British Museum. But the rest of Palace is a masterpiece.

Do not miss this incredible place...... What amazing treasures ! So many Rembrandts !
Allow yourself plenty of time , and most importantly, wear comfy shoes!

One week is NOT enough in this museum. This is a phenomenal museum! We only had one day reserved for this museum - our huge mistake! We barely got a chance to see anything as we ran past so many rooms -- we need to go back and spend a week there (which is not enough). This museum has multiple buildings (some located far away) and we only got a chance to visit the main building -- absolutely breathtaking! If you only have one day, visit it! If you only have 3 days, visit it! If you only have one week, visit it!
Amazing Museum. This museum was extensive and beautiful. So many things to see! It is a must-do in St. Petersburg, but budget lots of time to see it.

Be prepared. If you are not an expert then take a guided tour and save a lot of time. The layout is confusing and the choice is bewildering.My personal view is to do the Diamond collection and skip the Gold collection as there is overlap. The guide hinted that they would amalgamate both soon. Allow two days to enjoy at your leisure as we ended up 'running' through dutch art to glimpse the prodigal son and running back to catch the Gold tour.So much to see needs planning and hard choices.

The best museum we've ever visited!. Absolutely stunning! You could spend a whole day here. Room upon room of beautiful exhibits. Worth getting a guided tour. We used a guy outside who offered to show us the best bits in an hour as we were pushed for time. He only charged us 400 roubles! Well worth it and he was so knowledgeable. We will definitely return.

Probably one of the best museums in the world. The Hermitage as a building is worth seeing, but it is so full of art, you would need days (they say years) to do i justice. We spent one day in the main Palace, and another at the General Staff Building. This is a must, not only for the art but also for the beauty of the restoration of this building. The Foreign Affairs wing is beautiful.
Great place!. Realy a truly beautiful place. Those big great halls, corridors, paintings and everything else, is just breathtaking! Visit it, but come early!

Just spectacular . It is just spectacular. 5 grand palaces that hold one of the most extensive art collections in the world.Just walking in the palaces takes 3-4 hours, if you are an art lover then put aside some days just for this place.

Unbelievable experience. Visiting the Hermitage Palace is a must for everyone visiting St. Petersburg. It is highly recommended to buy entrance tickets in advance in internet to avoid hours-long queus, especially during weekend. Luckily you can buy ticket with a credit card from a vending machine - only 10 people before you. Do not forget to bring a tourist guide book with decent museum layout map (especially if you only want to see most famous attractions and skip all the art) as museum's free brochure has extremely miserable layout map! Guiding inside the museum is almost nonexistent completed with only Russian-speaking grannies. There is a small cafe inside.

Fantastic. No words can describe the opulence of this historic building.Be prepared to get lost and make sure you wear comfy footwear.Its the rooms that outshine the works of art here, you won't go home disappointed......my advice don't miss it.

Overwhelming. Spent two days in the museums just managing to see the highlights.Essential to take a map and mark out your area of interest. The museum staff in the room were very helpful in pointing out directions when you get lost.The sheer number of of masterpieces leaves you feeling dazed..

Wonderful! Go in April to avoid crowds!. It really is amazing and everything we had heard. Although April was cold (snow on the ground) it was worth it as the cruise ships cannot get to St P's until May so the crowds were not there in the museum and we could see everything at leisure. There is so much to see tho' you will be disappointed not to cover more. Get a guide to show you around for one day or half day and then return on your own for another day. We wanted to see the Van Gogh's which are in a separate wing with so many impressionist paintings. This area was newly opened and across the square from the main museum entrance. There were barely 10 people looking at these paintings with us! The art there is amazing.

You need more than a day!. This place is beyond belief, it matters little what type of art you are interested in, or for that matter what you are interested in, the quality, size, splendour and majesty will sweep you away.We arrived early on Sunday morning (it closes on Mondays) and had to wait about 1/2 an hour to enter - be prepared, you'll need a full day - at least - to even take a glance at what's there.Don't leave Russia without visiting The Hermitage!
Interesting and imresive. We took the short tour becuose we didn't had time,but it was perfect and we'll come back again for sure

Visit to St. petersburg in begining of april 2015. The hotel i stayed was only 50 steps away from hermitage and hermitage is museum that you can spend days and days . we were there in font of museum at 9 in morning but it was closed. Not with suprise , the guard didnt know english and at the end of body language he showed us a sign with opening hours. at 9:45 we awere back in front of museum and there is queue of 30 person around, allready . after the doors opened and we are invited inside the garden . then we again started waiitng till doors opened. The queue was very very long in short time and russian people are not polite in waitin queue and we find ourselves in back of queue and strugle to come in fort again :)the museum is very big and you need days to see each room . there is no one entrance and directions to move , one room opens to other rooms and therefor i dont think we could see each point . i recommend you to go and see every day 2 hours -3 hours if you will stay long .

Overwhelming!. We had a private art historian take us through this museum and I have no idea how we would have managed without her expert guidance. She arranged a special tour with one of the museum curators who took us through the diamond rooms. Amazing. It would take days to see everything in depth in this museum. And new wings with more of the later collections are still opening. I thought The Louvre was overwhelming but nothing can compare to the collections and history of The Hermitage. We were so grateful for our guide being able to bring this museum to life for us. It was a wonderful day.
Amazing. Home to a great number of pieces of master artists. Halls and halls of Rembrandt's works, mind-boggling!

Amazing. I' m italian, I lived in Paris and I was many times in Spain and London, so I know very well the best museums in the world but, this one I think is one of the best... perhaps the best...We were 6 hours inside and we didn't see all because it's impossible.Masterpieces from everywhere inside a masterpiece building... and in february... NO PEOPLE... NO BUSY
Worth it. Every room you enter makes you gasp. Rich reds beautiful goldenseal. Artists from da Vinci to picasso

Breathtaking. The State Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace contains an amazingly massive collection of art pieces from all over the world. It is quite a unique experience to view these art pieces in the Winter Palace, which in itself can be considered an art and architectural wonder. You ascend a marble staircase lined adorned with golden decor and then immerse yourself in the many art pieces. The magnificent rooms of the Winter Palace compete with the collection displayed within it. Staying for a few hours is simply not enough. Taking pictures without flash is allowed but pictures alone will not be able to convey the magnificence of the place.

The most impressive museum of the world. I'm very travelled and visited many museums around the world, but the Hermitage is awesome for anyone. You can't really visit it in a single day and probably the only one where the beauty of the building is comparable to the masterpieces in its rooms.

Hermitage Stunning. Quite simply breathtaking. Has to be seen to be believed and allow a lot of time to see the treasures within. They say you could visit every day for a month, all day, and still not see all and I quite believe it!
Not to be missed at any cost.

Great experience. Amazing museums containing a wealth of exhibits from all over the world. The architecture is breathtaking and the sense of grandeur seeps out of every corner. Organize a professional guide and allow plenty of time for a wonderful experience.

You could spend days here. This is an outstanding museum and you will experience masterpiece overload. I was expecting say one or two Picasso or Rembrandt's not whole rooms full of them. The Canova sculptures were particularly fine. We used the machines by the queue to getour tickets which was much faster. 600 roubles each. This was a special day for us.

Simply unique and amazing.. It was such an unbelievable experience to visit this museum! So much to see and sadly only so little time. Breathtaking rooms one after another and all that art made feel so small. We didn't need to stand in the queue since we bought our tickets from ticket machines located in courtyard, saved so much time doing that! Buying tickets from the machines was quick and simple, no need to worry about that!

Save a whole day for this beauty!. An incredible collection of art and also very interestingly decorated, so if the art is not your thing, interior design/architecture might just do it for you.It's a whole day kind of affair, and just a privilege to be there. I hope you enjoy it as much as i did.

Russian treasure island. Amazing palace, especially 2nd floor. So many pieces of art and decorative details that sooner or later you'll get blinded by the shine! Absolutely worth visiting, minimum stay at least 4-5 hours... Buy tickets on the courtyard ticket machine and you can bypass the outside queue (can be 50-100m)

Stunningly huge and beautiful museum..... Fantastic museum, but boy does it take a while to walk round. A must is to book a ticket in advance, to avoid the queues (even in Winter, we went April). All coats etc., have to be put into cloak room, so if its cold outside - it is very warm inside.... Best to plan what you want to see in advance, it is so vast and so amazing that you can easily get lost, we did although we did not have a guide. I don't think very young children would like this place, they would be bored. But we saw amazing pieces of history, beautifully restored, set in an amazing palace. A must cultural visit for history lovers.

So much to see. The Hermitage museum has an outstanding collection of art, that is set in the Winter Palace, which has to be one of the most beautiful "homes" ever built.If you only have time to visit one place go here.

One of the greatest museums, 'nuff said. I grew up in St Petersburg, and then moved out , Ermitage was part of my childhood and recently I took my 8 year old son there. He loved it. Museum contains vast amount of exhibits in absolutelly magnificent surroundings.Even if you are not into classical art - you will find plenty of exciting stuff - from Egyptian mummie to Knights armory.Buy tickets online or at the automatic machines in the courtyard near entrance to avoid queue.

a must see. Choose a section of interest before you go, cause there´s too much to see it all in one day. Or you have to go more than once.
Very good jewellery in the Museum Shop on the 3 floor and very friendly stuff.

Families plan before you go. Fantastic sight not to be missed but some tips: children under 18 are free but you still have to get a ticket for each at a ticket ofiice. Buy the adult tickets at the machines on the left of the courtyard (you need cash with notes no larger than 1000 roubles) then by pass the queue as ticket holders to enter the museum and get the free kids tickets at the ticket offices. If you want to join a tour or arrange a private tour you go first to the Excursion Office under the arch as you enter the courtyard and on the right hand side. You can only buy tickets at the machines or the ticket office for the same day. If you want to buy tickets ahead of today you have to buy them online (very annoyingly!). We decided to arrange our visit by one adult who wanted more time to see the museum going a day ahead alone. This meant that the second visit with the kids could be more efficient and speedy to accommodate their more limited interests and one person in the group could take everyone else around the main sights without getting lost! Well worth doing. It is also worth looking at the website online and seeing what is there and making note of the location of the main things you want to see and planning a route accordingly if time will be tight or interest of younger members of your group are limited. The Impressionists are now housed in the Geneal Staff building across the square and it might be best to go there first as we found no queue for tickets which included all the Hermitage for adults although we had to get the free kids ones again in the main building after we had finished in the General Staff Building. You can take small backpacks into the museum and thereby bring water and other items children may need. The cloakrooms work excellently for leaving things for free. Toilets Marem rather far and wide so best to make ur everyone goes before you leave the cloakrooms! Cafe services are adequate but not great.
Breathtaking. Fantastic. So much to feast on make sure you have comfortable shoes.Pre-buy your ticket to avoid the queue and make sure you have a bottle of water with you.

Amazing heritage Building!!!. Hermitage its definitely a must do in St. Petersburg!!! We got lucky and got the Thursday free ticket tour, but its also synonymous of confusion and too much people!!!The collections are great but in some points of the halls are light challenges to watch some of the Icons!!! Even you cannot miss it!!!
