Our tour included all the galleries and the quite intimate Hermitage Theatre. Albina is very knowledgeable about her city and it's attractions, her english is PERFECT and she is a wonderful and personable tour guide. Thank you Albina, you made my time in St. Petersburg unforgettable!

It's not enough to visit the Hermitage once.. It is true that you need come many times to see all the collection. I especially like a greece collection, Roden's sulptures, modern arts including impreccionists, modernists. Big collection of 1812 heroes protraits. Russians tsars collection. Also recommend to visit Gold and Jewelry collection. YOu can be lost among of huge number of tsar's dimonds, golden crowns etc.

Overwhelming!. This museum really was mind blowing! Huge doesn't even begin to describe it - so vast. If you are there for a short time, i'd suggest just concentrating on a few things that interest you.

Impressive for art lovers. I hate to say this but if you're not an art fan, you will quickly get bored. This is worth a trip simply for its history, but if you're looking to learn about that, you will be disappointed. It's all art based - interesting in itself, but for those of us not into art and want to know about the history of the Winter Palace during the 1917 revolution and before, you will be disappointed.
Marvelous but with too many portraits. Huge but fabulous collection. Rembrandt's "Progidal Son" was stunning. Restaurant could be nicer. They only offered simple salads and sandwiches.

Return and Return and Return [LOTS to experience]. If you are interested in this magnificent collection, plan on several visits. We spent 3 hours on a "tour" on our first day in the city, and hired a private guide [and expedited entry] on two other days.I wouldn't know where to begin in describing it. Expect: At the risk of hyperbole, this is the finest [and most exhausting] museum I have been in - and I've been visiting museums everywhere for at least 65 of my 74 years. I cannot believe I waited to long to go to this one; I shall return. Soon!

Astonishing. When you are in St. Petersburg you don't want to miss The Hermitage, one of the largest and oldest art museums in the world! It is known that if you take only 1 minute to see one display, you will need 11 years to see everything. The building itself is beautiful and unbelievable and exhibitions are amazing. I have spent a whole day in Hermitage until physically I couldn't walk anymore. One of the greatest experience in my life!
The best museum. If there is cold and grey outside you should visit this museum! Is the best. But be carefull u can spend whole day there without recognizing u did)))
Beautiful. Take advantage of the no visa and arrive via the ferry from Helsinki. Spend the day at the Hermitage museum, summer palace, and the church on the blood. Amazing, beautiful city.

Unbelievable art in a beautiful palace. The art here is out of this world. So much choice and variety, However the building is just as fascinating and we spent about equal time admiring the palace interior as we did the art.

Amazing. Imposingly attractive building in a huge square with vatican like arches on one side.I go in late winter or fall as the queues are less.It is for me a three day visit to see it all and enjoy.The Winter Palace is imposing and spectacular from the throne room to the ball room and the wall of family portraits.The Museum is so extensive with corridors of etchings and frescoes, each slightly different. I am struck that all military personal are free of charge but more thoughtful is that 'Heroes of the Siege of Leningrad are free of entry fees. I go back again and again
Hermitage mueseum. Our visit was a wonderful experience and one of the highlights of our visit to StPetersburg. We also enjoyed the ballet performance at the Hermitage theatre in the evening.

amazing collection of art. The Hermotage is a must do for all lovers of Art. It is impossible to see everything in a day so choose wisely. The Palace itself is so opulent and breathstaking.Go early to avoid the queues and the crowds

Stunning space. I was in St. Petersburg in January. I hired a private guide to take me around as I had very limited time. It was well worth it because the museum's size can be overwhelming. We just bought the tickets at the entrance, no lines because it's low season. We were able to enjoy the collection without the usual crowds. The museum is spectacular even without the art.

Hermitage - not for Hermits!. Crowds and Crowds, Queues and Queues - but still worth seeing. If you are disabled, ask for the lift to take you up. We just missed Vladimir Putin's visit with his entourage - here in St. Petersburg for a finance conference - thank goodness our driver knew how to get round the blocked streets.
Everyone loves this one--and so did we. Long lines, but worth it, on both days. Everything is here--whole rooms of Rembrandt, etc. I wish this museum were closer to more of the world's population!

Amazing!. The staircases lined in red carpets are truly royal!!! I'm not a big museum fan but this was much more than just a museum. It is large and BRIGHT! More than just paintings on a wall. Do not miss this must see!!!

Stunned. Everything about the hermitage is spectacular. Honestly, all the art could be removed and the winter palace itself would remain a spectacle worth a couple of days exploring.... And the valuable objects will truly take your breathe away....

Well Worth a Visit .. But. Do visit this place is really worth a visit beautiful inside and outside - We made the mistake of doing the Diamond room and gold room tours which we're to similar - If going back again just do the Gold Room tour - The diamond room tour really should be called the 'snuff' box tour - There wasn't many diamonds at all and alot of similar pieces to the gold room tour

One of my favorite places in the world. Words can't describe the experience of visiting the Hermitage. First, you are in the most beautiful palace (better than Versailles in my opinion). The art collections are amazing- they are edited and you don't see 50 million pieces of art/sculpture- you only see the best, maybe 40 pieces or so per collection (French Impressionist, Rodin etc). For me, the Louvre had too much- I just want to see the best. You can walk right up to anything- the paintings aren't roped off. The Peacock clock (animatron) was a favorite of Catherine the Great and is one of a kind. The octoganal exhibition glass displays of artifacts is very beautiful. The portraits (which in most museums are boring to me) were so beautiful- Christina Robertson was an amazing artist and the portraits are true works of art- I have never seen portraits like these. On my second trip, I booked a tour of the gold treasure room- it was beyond expectations. There are gold earings, jewelry, crowns etc from B.C. that look brand new and are so intricate there is a magnifying glass to see the detail. For me, I have never been very interested in objects that old but these artifacts are so amazing- in present day, I can't imagine how they would be created much less a couple of thousand years ago. I have traveled the world and the Hermitage is in my top 3 to see- I could go here every day and it overwhelms you with all the beauty and art. Same goes for the city of St.Petersburg- so beautiful. Buy your tickets online - it is closed one day a week and the lines can be long. Enjoy!

Even if You're into Art you have to go here. No queues to talk of. We used a ticket machine to print out 2 adult tickets and 2 English Tours. We also paid for a ticket to take photos but everyone seemed to be doing it with no obvious pass or sticker so perhaps that was some money we could have saved. Guided tour was a good 2 hours and moved us through the enormous museum at a good pace. We like art but aren't art buffs but it's a big part of your day. Cloakrooms for coats, cafe and places to sit but if you're an art lover, get a 2 day pass. There is so much to see
Good. I liked the museum, but didn't like the fact that we had to wait in the queue for such a long time during winter as we were freezing!

Prehistoric section is finally open again. Amazing collection of ancient archeological objects; go early in the morning to avoid crowds; my husband spent ten minutes alone in a room with a Picasso - no crowds on autumn mornings. Buy tickets at kiosk as soon as you enter the first interior courtyard, and walk right around any additional line - a great benefit on a cold day!

Must see!!! On Wednesdays they open late.. This place is amazing, so sumptuous and the details will certainly catch your attention. There is a lot to see, however, a 2 to 3 hours tours may be enough to see the main pieces and rooms. The audio guide is not really good, but helps in case you do not speak Russian and do not have a private guide.

Great. Both the building and the internals are quite great things to explore. The only downside is that in some places the paintings are covered by glass which reflects the light coming from the windows opposite. But all the rest is no doubt wonderful.
Breath taking, and a must visit place.. Just fantastic. There were nearly just to walk in, since we were visiting at winter. There are thousands of things to see, so you need the day.

One of the Top 10 Museums in the World. Breathtaking in scope and inventory.
Always crowded. If yo are serious, go in the middle of winter: stay at a nearby hotel for three days.
What a place. We went round with a tour guide (recommended). Spent 3 hours and still didn't see everything. Would definitely go back to see the bits we didn't have time to see

A must see the next time you are in St. P. As palaces go this one is a fine example that should be a must see on any trip to St. Petersburg. Try to prearrange a guided tour to avoid the masses. The building itself is hugh so get there early. Too big to see all in one day. It's all about The art work and antiques the guides will show you the best pieces to see and awe at. ... From there the square in front leads to more hugh buildings, incredible statues and friendly people everywhere. This place is why people call St. Petersburg, the Venice of Russia. You won't be disappointed.
Wow!. You could spend a full week in there since you would have to walk 23 miles inside in order to see all millions peaces of work.

Very impressive. Visited the museum in July as part of the Cruise ship two day tour of St Petersburg. We didn't need to obtain the expensive visa which was included in the tour price. The museum building itself is incredible. There are so many works of art and to spend just one minute viewing each piece would take around 14 years. The main advise is to arrive early as the queue is very long. We had an excellent guide very knowledgeable about all the places we visited. Be a bit careful as we lost my wife twice as she got so carried away taking so many photographs and she wasn't alone I saw a few people rushing around looking a bit lost. St Petersburg was fantastic but recommend getting a good guide. I heard that other groups on the tour didn't have such a good guide i.e. could understand their English.
Winter Palace warm inside. Amazing Palace and Museum. Best to book a couple of the guided tours. Get there early and yes, there will be thousands of people there, but, enough room for everyone.
World class Museum. Incredible collection of art. The building itself is worth a visit. Each room is more impressive than the other. Impossible to miss.

Amazing, a must see. They say it would take 11 years to see everything in this museum, I think we did it in 6 hours. Make sure to eat a good meal before you go, the lines to get even a snack are very long.
astounding. breathtaking place. this is a must see. one needs at least 7 days to start to grasp and take it all in. its just amazing.

A Disappointing Visit. We were guided through the museum on a set path. We didn't have time to stop and admire any of the paintings. It's the second largest art museum in the world. The collection is evidently bursting at the seams and some parts of the collections are being stored across the square in a building not open to the pubic.The gold leaf as you walk up the staircase is a marvel. This was the Winter Palace built by Peter the Great's daughter Elizabeth. The art collector was Catherine the Great but the collection could only be seen by royals and invited guests. The Winter Palace is only one of the four buildings that make up the Hermitage. The collections are hung in chronological order which makes it easy to see favorites. Our tour was fast and only started touching the major portion of the total collection.
Would not miss this while in St Petes. Why would you come to St Petes and not come here. A great collection well preserved almost overwhelming. Provably needs a few visits.
Great museum. The quantity and quality of the architecture and artwork is incredible here. The best place to see in St. Petersburg if you could only see one. Very impressive place.

Spellbound by Magnificence of Art. The Hermitage Museum has so many wonderful works of art, that it would take you a month to go through it, and you would enjoy each day! They have numerous works by Picasso, Gauguin, Van Gogh, Da Vinci, Rembrandt, Velasquez and many, many more. The interior of the museum is a work of art by itself. The grand staircases, high ceilings, design work on the walls and ceilings and floors make you realize this is a 'special place'. The museum has over 1,000 rooms. I visited the museum in October, and had a hard time leaving, I will definitely go back for a longer visit. Probably the nicest museum in the world.Jon LeFeber
Perfect!. Possibly the best museum in the world! You could spend an all month there and you wouldn't see half of it. Can't get much better than this.

Going going gone. My husband & I visited this facility twice, both days for 8 hours. We both enjoy fine art and have visited many of the fine art museums of the world, starting with The National Gallery in London, The Tate, The British Museum, The Prado, The Louvre, The Metropolitan, Boston Museum of Fine Art, The Van Gogh Museum, The Rijks, The D'Orsay, The Vatican and many, many others. We have great appreciation for art and art conservation. We enjoy historic architecture. We travel nationally and internationally primarily to view great art and history.This trip to The Hermitage should have been the apex of a year of planning. However, it is sadly rundown. You can tell that the monies that might have been available went for the Olympics, the Mariinsky Theatre II, and the war. Perhaps more money might be directed to the upkeep of this beautiful building and its amazing collection if more people wrote less fawning reviews and demanded the upkeep that this place deserves. It probably should be designated a UNESCO site in trouble. The Russian politicians will not direct any monies to this museum until they are shamed into it.As several people have noted, the blazing sun (especially on the Rembrandts) through ancient glass has oxidized most of these paintings. You can practically watch the colors changing into muddy brown before your eyes. I am sure that The Hermitage has qualified conservationists who love their collections, but I am also sure that none of the admittance money is going into conservation or improvement. The galleries are either very cold or very hot, not the best conditions for preservation. There are many panes of broken glass, and loose floor tiles. The frames for the windows are flaking and rotting. These are just the things the casual visitor can see, what you can't see must be horrific. We visited in early October, so the hoards of people were not a problem for us, although it was still crowded.The third floor (which is difficult to find, probably deliberately so) does have a nice selection of Impressionists and modern art, and it is very well conserved under moderate lighting and temperature. I wonder if this part of the collection is the "stolen" art and may have to be returned in some time. Perhaps the Russian politicians are worried about the condition of this art and so devote better care to this collection. The collection of dancing Matisses has been moved into another, separate building which we never saw. Perhaps they have oxidized completely. In any case, the practical necessities of this site are pretty demanding too. The booth in the garden square where you collect your e-tickets was completely obscured by stacked building supplies, with the small informational sign tipped over. We spent a fair amount of time looking for it, once the rude informational clerk at the receptionist's desk directed us outside, where an half hour search started. The cloakroom (where you must leave your coat) is across from the toilet rooms, of which I availed myself. Even though the museum had just opened that morning, the wastepaper baskets (full of VERY USED toilet paper) were toppling over and falling on to the floor. My husband, who was waiting for me in the hall, was gagging from the smell. These were the only toilets we ever saw in the building, other than a few next to the cafeteria. If I ever return to this museum, the wearing of Depends underwear might be advisable.The cafeteria was terrible, with some bolted down seats that reminded me of prison seating. The food offered was terrible too, and we were glad to leave the place.There was a wonderful collection of the last tsar and tsarina's clothing, along with some poignant remnants of the children's things. It is ironic that these items were kept in glass and in very low light, so that this collection of clothing will probably outlast all the paintings. The part of the museum that is dedicated to some of the tsars' living areas is quite nice, and so is the throne room. I would like to have seen the area that The People's Will bombed, but couldn't figure it out. It was good that we'd seen The Russian Ark several times, so that some of these rooms very familiar.I wish there had been some explanation of The Hermitage's staff's roles in World War II, but sadly there is none here, although you can read about it in some books. The little gift shop areas were one bright spot, where most of the clerks have been allowed to smile and to chat with shoppers. Their collections of "Faberge" egg pendants and cloth Christmas tree ornaments were quite nice and we bought a large variety of things as gifts for the people back home. I highly recommend the gift shops, as their selections were very good and the prices reasonable. Too bad the entire facility isn't run by the people in charge of the gift shops. I can tick the box that I've seen The Hermitage. If you have grandchildren who want to see the Rembrandts some day, tell them to look in a book.

OMG. We had two trips to the museum, one independently and then when we joined our cruise we returned. Luckily it was in a different section to our first visit. It was truly amazing, the marble, the gold, the art work. The first section we visited we were told that you couldn't take photos unless you bought a "pass" The second was visit to a different area and there was no mention of a camera pass so we snapped away. So glad we have these photos to relive this amazing place

A must see. This is probably the most impressive museum I have ever seen. The Vatican Museum which is great is overshadowed by this. The building is superb, the interior fantastic. It was everything , and more than I expected.

Exquisite. One of my favorite places in Saint Petersburg. Elegant both inside and outside. I love the architecture and all the exhibitions; no neat and absolutely gorgeous. It is so huge and they even expanded more museum spaces when I was there in July. You could spend a whole day or for me even a couples in this place, but unfortunately I had limited time. I'll go back there for sure. Totally well worth the visit. Exquisite landmark. Don't miss!

A MUST IN ST PETERSBURG. The long ticket lines are terrible.It is better to go as part of a day long sight seeing trip with a good operator/ guide. The tickets (and entrance) are quickly obtained. The museum has soooo many halls...it is unbelievable. Each section has excellent exhibits ,most of them historical and priceless. Spend atleast three hours in this museum.

One Of The Greats. I can't really add much to the reviews, but it is certainly worth going in mid-Winter as that is the time when you can appreciate everything without being crowded out.It may be bitterly cold outside but this will be the only opportunity many people will get to relax in such grandeur. Obviously, the residents of St. Petes are used to freezing temperatures and everything still functions, even when it is -30. The more adventurous might also consider staying with a family, rather than a hotel. Many people have several careers of which Hermitage expert/guest house (or flat) owner/translator are quite popular choices. If someone can plan what you might want to see beforehand at least you have a chance of seeing most of the "treasures" without being conned by some of the guides.

Must-See in Petersburg. The most valuable aspect of this museum isn't even its vast collection of art, but the building itself. I highly recommend taking the time to walk through the rooms that this palace is comprised of to really gain appreciation for its significance (the two throne rooms, Peter's library, the gold room, the white room, the long halls, etc.) Don't forget to look up (at the ceilings) and down (at the ground). It's quite a walk through history.

An Absolute Must See. This is a massive museum (3 million artifacts) with original art by several famous masters (and they let you photograph them without flash). The size and scope of this place is overwhelming. We were thankful that we had a tour guide with us to let us know where to go and what to see. Each and every room is a sensory experience, not only for the art, but also the decor.My only disappointment was in a very nice gift shop within the museum. I picked up an item of interest to me to see the price, only to find the "made in China" label inside the article. That item was not purchased, since I had hoped to buy something made in Russia. We did not convert any cash in Russia, so were unable to purchase items in the cafe. There is a restaurant where we could have eaten with credit card, but did not want to take the time.We were cautioned more than once that pick pockets frequent the museum, so you need to ensure your valuables are in a safe place on your person. We did have to turn our coats into a cloak room.The museum is celebrating the 250th anniversary.

A superb experience….but try to visit at night. This visit to St Petersburg we bought tickets for a private visit and tour at night….no crowds……you can get up close to everything. I highly recommend scorching an out of hours visit. There must only have been about 100 of us in the entire place and we were all taken around together.Then, we were treated to a marvellous one hour performance the St Petersburg's top symphony orchestra and in the setting of the Hermitage state room, this was something to savour. They also served sparkling wine included with the tickets.To be able to enjoy a relaxed visit to the Winter Palace and during the same visit tour the summer palace brings the world of the Tsar and his family to life.

Quite simply, one of the most impressive collections of classic art worldwide. While the impressive and beautiful building is itself worth visit, it is of course the collection of early modern European art that is the core of the experience. This must be one of the best and most comprehensive collections of Italian Renaissance art outside Italy. The Rembrandt room is also overwhelming. And the list goes on and on. A must.
Amazing. There is just no other museum like it, time is the key, it is not possible to see even a portion of it in one visit.

Perhaps the best museum in the world. It is huge. Cannot be absorbed fully by anyone. It is an amazing experience. Limited english explanations but often it is fairly obvious what you are looking at. We just soaked up the experience. Wonderful building inside and out as well.

Silly to rate an unquestionably superlative place. Dear Reader, we are both very silly. You for reading a tripadvisor report on one of the world's unique experiences, and me for wanting to receive my Top Contributor badge. But there you have it - unintended consequences of globalism. If you are in St. Pete, and you don't go to the Hermitage, I believe you may regret it.

Pace yourself. The problem with the Hermitage is that it is absolutely massive with so very many works of art, its hard to know where to start. Our guide was the best and took us to some of the highlights of the museum over the course of half a day. We had also booked a tour of the Diamond Room which has to be done in advance - well worth it.

AWESOME experience. fantastic museum with very beautiful building and huge number of artworks. i can not visit it in just 3 hours and i will visit it in future if i have the chance to come there again. need to spend a week to visit it and enjoy it. if you want to see each painting and think about it and enjoy it , it needs to visit there every week. Absolutely recommended in St. Petersburg.

is one of the best museums I've visited in my life. The building of the Hermitage Museum is very luxurious and impressive at the entrance. The collection is huge and very rich, it would take months to see everything. You need to take a guided tour or you do not get to see even half of the highlights of the museum. Must see, great, unforgettable experience!

EXCEPTIONAL. Unmissable! One of the most beautiful museums in the world, both by collection and by architecture. Book at least 3 or 4 hours for visitation. Do not miss the medieval collection and the hall of crystals. Free entry for students.
Must do visit. A really memorable tour of a beautiful palace. Opulent, classic, inspiring this will sit in the memory for years. It is a bit painful with the entry process but so well worth it.
Very interesting place.. It is just to big, but there is so much to be seen specially on a rainy/snowy november day. You could prepare youself and focus on one subject. Then it would be OK i guess.

Over whelming. What can I say about arguably the best museum on the planet? Okay, lets start. the Winter Palace is not the same as the Winter Palace of Peter 1. The Hermitage has so many articles: however unless you can read Russian the descriptions in English (where they exist) are very short. It can be difficult to navigate- the floor plan we were given was in Korean, which was as much help as if it was in Russian- and the downloaded app was close to useless.Despite this, I would never miss this experience. The opulence that the ruling class enjoyed is staggering. And the amount of art in the form of paintings- it is such a wow factor.Tip: buy an Internet ticket and avoid the queues. We found one day to be sufficient, but this would depend on your dept of interest in the culture.2nd tip You can't get a pass out for lunch and the cafe is abysmal so have a big breakfast. Plenty of toilets.

Достопримечательность N 1. If there is a need to assign numbers to attractions in St. Petersburg, the Hermitage, of course, in the first row. Visit the Peter and not visit the famous Winter Palace just can't. This is how to visit Paris and see the Eiffel tower. Yes, Yes I'm not mistaken - not the Louvre - and it is - famous Parisian tower, because the Hermitage, in a sense, is a symbol! Too much history associated with this place, not to mention those countless treasures in the literal and figurative sense that there literally at every step. The Story itself though lives in the building, striking in its grandeur, luxury and beauty. For those born and raised in St. Petersburg, it is not difficult to navigate in huge abundance of facilities and collections, because none of us probably will not say how many times he had been there, if we have in mind that it is almost a tradition to spend the weekend at the Hermitage with family, friends, strangers, or just walking. But those who came into town not too long - you should rent an audio guide and not to seek for one day or for a couple of hours - get around it. In Peter's still a lot of other interesting places and spend all their time at the Hermitage would be wrong. I think, just to plunge into the atmosphere of history, luxury Golden time to dream, just to wander through a few rooms. This can also be quite enough. And if you gear - then you need to come specially to dedicate a few dais.
100 visits would be enough. Or may be not. Do not try to see everything, choose a topic and watch it close. Then just stroll thru the halls and feel the place.

Be Prepared for Crowds. Catherine the Great's Winter Palace is exquisite. However, be ready for large crowds and prepare yourself for endless rooms of gold and beautiful oil paintings that seem to never stop. Don't pass up visiting the Hermitage but do prepare yourself.

So much to see. The Hermitage and Winter Palace need separate days.Only minimum queuing for tickets and admission at the Winter Palace was experienced, but the Hermitage is a different matter. It is also important to buy a camera ticket if one wishes to take photos. Without a ticket one is not allowed in with a camera and it will be detected by the x-ray machine and failure to purchase the ticket means returning it to the cloke room, and this puts you again right at the back of the crowd of people waiting to get in. The splendour and array of various types of architecture in the Winter Palace is astounding. One needs at least 3 hours to explore the rooms leisurely to take everything in - but it is worth it. It is said that it would take 15 years to see every exhibit in the Hermitage. so you have been warned!
A must see!. Nice museum with easy access all around! Big square in front and a very well maintained place. some maintenance was going on when i went there but didnt really crate any hassles for us.

Breathtaking. If you could only visit one thing in St Petersburg it would be the Hermitage. From the moment you walk in the grand doors you step back in time to an opulent existence of the the Tsars. So much history, so much stunning beauty, from the parquetry floor to the gilded ceilings and hundreds upon hundreds of priceless artworks and statues. One day isn't enough - one week wouldn't be enough.

Amazing collection of 3000 objects d' art. We visited this museum from our ship the Marco Polo on an overnight stop from Tilbury, England.We chose to do a full day tour with St Cathetine's Palace in the morning and a quick 4 hour visit to the museum in the afternoon.We were led by a guide with headphones connecting to our headphones with instructions to keep together or we would get lost and when out of range not be able to pick up the information.We were given her personal selection of various pictures and rooms.It was good to see so many people visiting of all ages and nationalities.You would need months / years to get to see the entire collection.I recommend you do some careful research and plan out your visit begorehand.

What should you see in Hermitage in just 3 hours (my opinion).. In case that you have just 3 hours, you would definitely would need to be very selective. My first suggestion is to focus on 2nd floor (per Russian way of marking, in Europe it would be 1st ). When you come up from main stairs and you choose to go to the left side of that floor where you can find numerous paintings and exhibited items, related mostly to the Tsarist Russia in 18th and 19th century. In this group I am including “Portrait Gallery of the Representatives of the Romanov Dynasty”, “Suite of State Rooms in the Winter Palace” etc.Practically do not miss those rooms - 193-197, 270, 271, 282 289, 304, 305, 307, 308, 151, 153, 187 – 176, 157-167.This is by my opinion “must see” in order to better understand Russian history&life of this period, which should be maybe first goal of foreign visitor . Ofcourse note that even for above listed you would need to be quite fast to visit it in 3 hours.Finally, if you just wander around this 2nd floor, you would be fascinated with any other part of permanent exibitions on this floor, such as Dutch or Italian arts.

World third best museum.. One of the place that everyone must see in russia.There is a collection of world wide art.Some of them belong to other nations.And without guide you where loose in this place.

My favourite museum in St. Petersburg. Professionals say it would take one over 2 years of visiting Hermitage everyy day from 9 to 5 - no lunch breaks, no vacations - to see all what it has!I love it for its diversity and classic Petersburg atmosphere: paintings, interior, rich decorations of barocco mixed with plain ones of classicism.There's huge collection of foreign (Dutch, Italian, Spanish, French ..etc) art on the 2 nd floor, ancient sculpture (Egyptian, Greek and Roman) downstairs and most of modern art (20th century) on the 3rd floor.See the small halls with impressionists a bit aside from main halls as well as royal everyday parlours in the further part of 2nd floor from the main entrance.When I was a kid of 5-6, and in the beginning of 90s there were not so many tourists there, some museum clerks saw my interest in one of the wooden bureaus. He took out the kes and showed me all the secret drawers and safe places of that masterpiece. I was excited!Today after 20 years I still discover something new everytime I come there. And it's a true pleasure for those who love art and history

Old Boys trip to St. Petersburg. The best museum i have ever visited !! It has everything, masterpiece after masterpiece,in every room, the place is like the tardis, it goes on forever!! The queue was massive, and as it was raining, made life a bit grim, but once inside, and after you hand your coats to the attendant, it is soon forgotten. You will never see so many pieces of history in one place. Your life will be enriched with the experience !!
Not to be missed. Two very interesting and very different Mary and Jesus executions by Leonardo da Vinci that stand out. Rembrandt and the old masters aplenty.

Amazing. It is almost unbelievable that this was once a private collection. The exhibits match those in the Louvre, Florence or London. You need plenty of time to explore it. For a brief visit to see the highlights you need a guide.

One of the best Museums in the world. This museum has every conceivable artist and sculptor on display. You could spend 3 days there and not see everything. it is a bit crowded, but if you get there early you will be able to get through most of the first couple floors before everyone else arrives. Well worth the visit and make sure you have a full day to spend there.
A must visit!!. Is it just one of the most important museums in the world. Worth the visit. Entrance not so cheap though. But worht it.
Amazing!. Fantastic museum with an amazing art collection! Had an advanced ticket with a guide, the best way to see this collection if your time is limited, as mine was.
State Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace. we bought tickets and the door on a weekday and the process was a jumbled mess. it was fine once we got in though
Not to miss. One of the best museum, i really enjoyed visiting there, really it have huge collection of masterpiece. one should not miss visiting to hermitage museum

Amazing. Something for everyone. We spent one day here. You could easily spend a week and not run out of different things to see. Amazingly it didn't seem crowded when you are in the actual rooms. The corridors and lobbies were busy. No problem taking photographs without a flash. Loved the portrait paintings and the glass. And the ceilings, well everything really. But wear comfortable shoes. There is little opportunity to sit.

Gorgeous Museum that's a must see in St. Petersburg. We went as an excursion during our Russian River Cruise from Moscow to St. Petersburg. We had advance tickets, so we did not have to wait in the long line to purchase tickets. It was packed with people of all ages when we visited on a weekday afternoon. But the galleries that we visited were all enormous in size, so we weren't viewing the paintings and sculptures standing three deep to see them thankfully. The interior of the museum and Winter Palace are exquisitely beautiful with the beautiful carved moldings and marble and dark wood. The art ranges from Russian icons to Russian decorative arts to European masters, including Claude Monet. You could spend a whole week here and only scratch the surface. So figure out what you really must see and plan your visit accordingly. And enjoy the view of the Neva River.

This is worth 6 stars!. I have been fortunate enough to have been here 3 times now, and I still do not think I have done it justice. This is simply the best collection of art/history/artefacts I have ever seen in the one place. Take your time to go round all that is on offer. Go early in the morning or later on in the afternoon to avoid the guided tours. Make sure to buy a guide to ensure that you miss nothing. There is artwork on display from just about any famous artist you can name and you get to view it close up, unlike many other galleries. It is well laid out, easy to follow. In a word...breathtaking. You cannot come to St Petersburg without spending at least half a day here. Word of warning..it's closed on Mondays.

The oracle of the arts. True sanctuary of the pictorial arts, exemplary baroque and classical interiors. I really got impressed by the incredible splendor of the buildings, inside and out and enormously huge collection, that absolutely harmonizes with the surrounding richness and uniqueness. For sure one day is not enough to fully absorb all the exhibits and the beauty of the palace itself. When being inside you just want to get lost among the tremendously gobsmacked decorated halls, staterooms and picture galleries.  The arrangements of all the collections perfectly correspond to the on its own gorgeous room. You are guided by the signs above the doorways and information signs in the departments.  Definitely worth seeing and coming back. Pure cultural heritage!
Amazing. I've been around the world. This is a must. Just incredible. Be patient because not everyone speak English. Russia is a hidden gem.

Must See - and need more than one day to see it all.. This is a fantastic museum and palace that you get to tour. No trip to St. Petersburg is complete without spending some time here.To big to get it all in one day, but worth the trip and you can always come back. Believe it was 500 rubles for entry and another 200 to be able to photograph. Opens at 10:30 and stays open to 6:00 PM, later a couple days during the week. I enjoyed the Medieval Collection of arms and armor - four full knights in on horseback in full armorBest tip - when you are looking all the exhibits do not forget to look at the building and room you are in. The entry stairway is an amazing construction. Walking around, look out the window as you will get a nice view of the river and surrounding area.

Fantastic place to visit. We were told about having to queue for hours to get in here and so were pleasantly surprised by the fact we walked straight up to the ticket desk and were the only people in the ticket hall at 11am! No charge for children under 18 which was another surprise.Brilliantly laid out and organised - an amazing spectacle.

WOW!. Having travelled the world I thought I'd see it all ... until The Hermitage. Just stepping inside was awesome and the Russian displays were wonderful. The queues to get in and around were another thing ... get there early and be prepared to push a little - especially when the tour groups descend and seem to get priority access.

Worth Visiting. World class art housed in an incredible setting. Try to go sometime other than summer. If you go on your own, GET A MAP. Even the museum staff have a little trouble telling you how to get from here to there. If you can get a tour to show you the highlights, that is good because this museum is enormous - 11 million holdings. Then, get a map and take time to look for collections you'd like to see - Siberian artifacts, Egyptian relics, Russian modern art, sculpture, Fabrege eggs. Lots of nice gift shops with something for everyone and every pocketbook. Nice cafes.

Too big to it all. make sure to plan your visit as there is so much to see and you need to make priorities or you will overwhelmed. We liked the mineral rooms where tables and vases were made from a particular mineral (lapiz, jade ....). The wealth that was accumulated is flabbergasting. The lines to get in are long and so be ready to wait.
Trip of a life time. Went on a cruise from Harwich to St Petersburg visited the museum .so much to see it was fantastic . Well worth going

Great Museum. Really take in the vastness of the Palace itself, it's easy to get caught up in all of the art. The true gem is the actual palace! Don't miss the golden peacock clock - that was best room to see.

Huge. Spent two days in this amazing museum and would need many more to see what deserves to be seen! Terribly difficult to find certain areas, China seems to be split into two, with a wonderful display of Chinese Buddhist art but never did see Chinese decorative arts. The staff English language is uneven to say the least! Hard to navigate because of closed sections requiring going up and down again to get from one section to the next on the same floor.

Stunning - and tiring!. It had been a lifelong ambition to visit the Hermitage and I achieved it on a Baltic cruise! We were part of an organised tour and spent an afternoon here. If I had been visiting on my own I would have picked the pieces I wanted to see - there is absolutely no way you can see everything in such a short time - but at least we got an idea of the vastness and opulence of the building. The whole place was absolutely stunning.If you are mobility-limited, do be aware that you have to walk long distances, that there are very few lifts(not usually handy, either!) and not too many places to sit down. However, don't let that put you off, it was well worth all the effort and the resulting sore feet. Would go back tomorrow!

World class museum ... !!!. After years of wanting to visit, it was a joy to roam the vast expanses and see the endless treasures here. This city is beautiful and the Hermitage is the gem of it all. Plan to spend many hours ... or days ... because there is much to see. Tickets were not difficult to get after a very short wait, and many guided tours of different durations and in different languages are available; both in person and via audio. We were pleased to find such a casual inexpensive cafe where we could SIT and enjoy good food. The cafe is near a couple of museum shops that have a wide assortment of books and other items. There are small souvenir kiosks throughout the hallways, but the actual shops have much better selection and English speaking staff. This is a huge place, so mentally prepare. The rooms are incredibly ornate, the artwork encompasses sculpture, paintings, furniture, and every other imaginable form. If you care about museums, you MUST visit St Petersburg even if it is only to see this magnificent museum!

Diamond and Gold. I'm going to keep this nice and simple. If you're going and don't book into the Diamond and Gold treasury tours then do not bother going. The entire place is stunning however the 2 most important rooms with some of the rarest items in the world is a must. We did both and are still left speechless with the collects. Both tours around the private vaults took about an hour and were stunningly beautiful. Some of the best pieces I've ever seen. You can't take photos which was a shame however the rest of the building is hit and miss depending on the guard who's around. Expect to spend hours in this place we arrived just before 12 and didn't leave till it closed at 6 and when they say it closes at 6 they push you through the doors out no later than 6. You have to leave all your stuff in the cloak room however there are several cafe areas so make sure to take your money. Once you have left the cloakroom and gone through the turnstiles you cannot come back. There is 0 chance of getting back in. The rooms are beautiful and the collections are impressive but expect to get lost as there is no set route however take note all the rooms were numbered and they can be found above each door of the room you are in. Would say everyone needs to go look at this. It costs around 1000 rubles for the entrance ticket and the private extra rooms but totally money well spent for a whole days worth of entertainment

An absolute must one of the best museums I've visited. Allow a day for this or at least a good half day. Book tickets online to avoid the queues. The plan supplied is good but it takes a few minutes to understand the layout so study the plan so that you can ensure that you see what you are really interested in as there is so much. We hired an audio guide which is excellent and if you listened to every description of all the pieces / rooms it features I'm sure you'd be there for a week! If you have a good guide book that devotes a few pages to the Hermitage that would probably be good enough.We focused on the palace rooms eg Romanov living areas, throne rooms, they were spectacular! We also made sure we saw the Renaissance and Impressionist art. It was vast to have so many awesome artists under one roof was breathtaking. Very good value for money, don't get hung up on paying more than the locals it happens everywhere in Russia.

Huge Palce. Clearly a MUST do attraction. However, it is HUGE. You can't really do it justice in just one day. Better to either decide what you want to see before you go and just do those things, as we did and do, or take several half day trips to cover all the ground.

Allow plenty of time here. Beautiful building with a most extensive collection of art and culture on display. Don't let your tour guide rush you through as this is a place that deserves some time spent drinking in the superb art on display. It was rather noisy on the day we went as there seemed to be endless groups of children doing school projects, but this attraction is a "must see" in St Petersburg.

It was as expected.. I am a museum junkie and hit all the museums I can fine. This is an excellent Museum of international value. It was everything I expected. It is massively big and you can have no opportunity to see the entire collection. It's best to get a guide and go to targeted key spots

amazed!. over 3 million artifacts, if you had to see every exhibit for 30 seconds, it would take you 9 years!everything from Van goghs, to da vincis, to beautiful ceilings and chandeliers, highly recommend!!

Excellent art collection worth a visit. It is said one needs a whole year to see all the exhibits in the Hermitage, but our local guide showed us the most outstanding exhibits. There are paintings, graphic works, sculptures. The collections include works by Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael and Titian. A unique collection of Rembrandts and Rubens. An essential stop for those interested in art & history.

Beautiful St. Petersburg. We visited St. Petersburg in mid-August and found it to be a perfect time to be there. The weather was pleasant and the days were long so that we had a full day of sunshine for our visit. We used a Russian travel group, ALLA, for our tour and had only 13 people in our group. The guide spoke perfect English and was very informative and helpful. St.Petersburg is a beautiful city with a lot of history and many outstanding places to visit. The hightlghts of our two day tour were: The Hermitage Museum, Peterhof castle and gardens and Catherine's Palace. We also enjoyed a ride on the spotless subway and took a canal tour, which was a great way to see the City. All in all, it was a once in a lifetime experience and we highly recommend a visit.

Simply beyond imagination. It is overwhelming. If you combine the Palace with the Art Collection I do not know how you cannot agree it is the top museum in the world. The palace is pristine and the artwork is amazing. Because the Palace is so huge you must just go for the highlights--As with everything Russian it is very confusing just to get and definitely bring some food with you!

Impressive inside and out. This museum should be on every visitors tick list who visit St Petersbugh this is an impressive building from outside and more so inside especially the main staircase.The number of paintings on show including English,German,French,Italian and others are just so many to see in one visit and i suggest doing a little home work on the paintings on show before a visit,the paintings cover all periods.If there is one item in the museum not to be missed is the English clock situated in the pavilion.

Need a Guide. Amazing place and so much to see. Must have a guide to explain the exhibits and history, as well to move you through the crowds to the more important sights. We were lucky enough to have Ana from Academservice looking after us for 3 days and we got the highlights tour.

Breathtaking palace, Hermitage. You can feel the hitory and the glory that has surrounded the palace and people living in it.You can imagine Rasputin walkin the rooms in rooms out. The spirit of the Russian tsaars on the hallways. Like outside world would not exist. Looking through the Windows you can imagine the poor people outside suffering of hunger and so on. The rest is history.The square in front of Hermitage have been many times an outdoor concert place for artists like Paul McCartney, The Rolling Stones etc... That's what we were told.So this is a must place to visit.

Beautiful building and contents. I think I would need days to see it all, but for me it was so worth it to just walk around the hermitage and see the architecture of the palace. I had 3 hours and was only able to see a bit of one floor. But well worth it even for that brief amount of time!
World Class. The best museum I have ever been in! Wonderful artworks and paintings. Also the maintainance is excellent

NO VISIT TO ST PETERSBURG IS COMPLETE WITHOUT VISITING. This was my third visit to the city, but fifth visit to what is arguably the best museum in the world. If your first visit to the city, go on a guided tour, but try and return later (in the afternoon when it is not so busy) just to soak up the atmosphere. Don't just look at the exhibits, but at the architecture as well. A complex of four buildings, including the Winter Palace, it is a gem in its own right, regardless of its treasures. There is too much to take in with just one visit. Note that re-admissions are not allowed, so you will need a new ticket if you cannot stay on solo after a tour - but it is worth the extra expense. The main staircase is a dream and my other favourite room is the Pavilion (with a really super English clock that makes me proud to be British whenever I see it!). On this visit I paid extra to visit the 'new' Treasures Gallery but quite honestly it was not worth it. Apart from the miniature replica of the Crown Jewels by Fabergé, there is not much in the display case devoted to his work. Additionally, while some Scythian treasure is on display, the best pieces are in the Gold Vault (for which an additional fee is payable). Unless you are in St Petersburg for an extended visit, the is enough in the main museum to see. During the main tourist season, it is very busy.

One Day Is Not Enough!!!. This is artwork paradise!!! To do justice, one actually needs two days to see everything!!! This is a "must" attraction in St. Petersburg!!!! Review their website before you go so you can plan your visit. Also, this is not a place to take children. They would be too tempted to touch things and that is a big No No. Security is everywhere and rightfully so. There are so many art treasures to protect!!!

Too much to see and too little time. If you have any interest in Russian and European art and history this is the place for you. We only had a couple of hours so made a whistle stop tour of a small part of this vast museum but still managed to see some fantastic pieces of history. Grab the app for your phone before you go and take advantage of the free wifi to make the best of your visit.

Marvellous.. One of the better museums in the world we have vissited. The wealth of the collection must be immense and it is displayed so well. You need hours to fully appreciate it. The palace is as beautiful as is the collections.

Hermitage Museum. Wonderful, beautiful, magical. Or inspiring. Couldn't believe the art work and that we were standing by original pieces. Could easily get 'lost' looking at everything it had to offer. Both the building and the art work were incredible.

Outstanding. There are so many works of art on display that one visit is hardly enough, especially for art lovers. From Leonardo da Vinci, Titian, Rembrandt, the Impressionists - there's something for everyone, not to mention just the experience of wandering through the palace.
Unique.. Absolutely amazing collection of art, in a stunning venue- we even managed to miss big crowds and had a relatively uncrowded afternoon. Unmissable.

Better than the Louvre. The inside and the outside are magnificent. You can feel Czarina Katherine's presence. If you can, buy your tickets ahead of time to avoid standing in line so you have more time to enjoy the art furniture and the magnificent rooms. Unlike the Louvre, all of the items that belonged to the royalty are on display and you get an idea of the luxury that they were surrounded in as they lived in these large palaces. You also get an understanding of why the peasants and lower class disliked the royalty since there was such a large disparity in life styles. Most every room has many unique pieces of art, crystal, etc. Also don't forget to appreciate the structure itself with the beautiful floors and ceilings. It is helpful to take a guided tour so that you see all of the important pieces than you can go back and see what you may have missed or want to spend more time viewing.

Excellent place for historical and art lovers. This great palace is amazing and have one of the greatest collection of art, sculptors and more. It's better to take a tour, so you will be able to get as much as possible information about the place history and the collections of art that you will see there, also you may visit specific type of collections that are separate by the halls.

Very Interesting. In June my partner and I visited Russia to be specific St Petersburg and it was a very interesting City to explore. We went to the Hermitage Museum, there were endless exhibits to see which we were informed would take 7 years to view thoroughly. It was a beautiful building as it used to be a palace of the late tzars. There was one exhibit that I particularly enjoyed which was a mechanical clock designed like a tree with a peacock and owl. It was a gift to the late Catherine the Great from an admirer and it had been manufactured in England. On the hour it starts chiming, play music and all the mechanical birds would start moving their wings, absolutely delightful. If you go to Russia and St Petersburg do visit the Hermitage Museum it is definitely worth a visit.
Amazing. Amazing, you will need more then a day to see the museum. Take the time to see all that is available.
Hermitage St.Petersburg. Toured with a guide.Excellent walkabout,took about two hours,very informative.Superb collection,so much to see.Highly recommended.

Get your tickets ahead of time. Nothing more needs to be said about the place but be sure to get your tickets ahead of time or you will stand in line forever. I strongly suggest planning the visit to see the things that interest you.

Put it on your bucket list. If you have any doubts about visiting St. Petersburg and the Hermitage then dismiss them immediately and put this place right at the top of your list of to do's. It is right up there with The Louvre in Paris. Given it's popularity it helps by having a guide as they have special entrance admissions, otherwise you may spend a couple of hours in the queue waiting to get in. There is so much to see that unless you have a couple of days you'll not touch the surface. However a visit of 2 to 3 hours will certainly give you an overview.
Need a day at least. It is full of beautiful statuary and paintings but it is so large that it is hard to see more than the highlights on a cruise ship excursion

Amazing Palace. The Tsars really knew how to build a palace. Lots of gold, beautiful woodwork, etc. Gorgeous buildings to house a very interesting musuem. Kids loved the costume displays & walking through a normal Russian apartment after seeing all that opulence in the palace.

Outstanding. A simply incredible collection of art.
No matter how much time you set aside you will only skim the surface, but it's all worth it.
Quite honestly the best single thing to do in St Petersburg.

Must see! (preferably in 2 days or more). I only had the opportunity to go here for a day. I so wish it had been more!! Art art everywhere! Part of the building itself is the famous Winter Palace and let me tell you..if you have never been inside a Russian palace..you are in for a treat! The European palaces you always hear about cannot compare to what you see in Russia (sorry Versailles).There are some exhibitions you can only enter with a tour (and of course paying an extra fee). This was kind of a bummer for me because I couldn´t enter the diamond exhibition due to time constraints. Nevertheless everything in this museum is worth seeing but I strongly recommend you to have a look at the Peacock Clock...by far my favourite piece from the Hermitage!PS. If you are a wifi-maniac I am afraid there is only one little cafe in which you can get wifi (if you buy something of course)...so it is better to forget about your phone for a while and enjoy the art
Unbelievable!. They say you if you spent 1minute on each exhibit in this museum it would take you 11 years to see everything. Fantastic
One of the world's finest. Prepared to be amazed by the beauty of the Hermitage and Winter Palace. The building and its art treasures are breathtaking in equal measure. Do not miss it.

Too Much to See in One Day!. If you have a free day in St. Petersburg, this is the place to send that free day. Just to much to see in a week for me, but I would go back any time and send the freedom there and explore more. Between here and the Storage Facility you could spend your entire Russian Vacation and never look back, but if course there is so much more to see. Crowds are normal and you will be moved along if in a tour group. Audio tours are available in many languages. Food and restrooms are available as well as souvenirs and tourist stuff.As with many facilities in Russia there is NO wheelchair access and many, many stairs so if you have limited mobility be aware of this restriction! Free coat rooms are available and you may NOT bring large bags or backpacks into the museum.

The main attraction of St. Petersburg. Undoubtedly, the Louvre of the East, this museum holds a vast collection. What is really striking is the incredible wealth that must have been held by the Emperors and Empresses that collected this treasure over the 150 year period of their reigns. Beginning with the Empress Elizabeth, and greatly expanded under Catherine the Great, the collection spans antiquities to turn of the century Impressionist paintings. All of this collecting ended in 1917 when the Bolshevik revolution happened and the Tsar Nichaolas and his heirs were all executed .When you realize the backdrop that most of the works collected were already recognized masterpieces and that they were collected methodically, you being to realize how widespread was the reach of Russian power at the time of these Tsarist regimes.Having only a half day to devote, we narrowed down our tour to the Western Art collections. There were 25 Rembrandts, including, We saw two DaVincis, and a Michaelangod sculpture. Catherine the Great had a great interest in the classical renaissance paintings, and even recreated Raffaeollos Loggia. It seemed as if we had entered the Vatican Museum, with such a collection.After moving through rooms of Titian and the Dutch and Flemish masters, we came to the rooms were the impressionists had been collected. There were several Monets, a room of Gauguin from his days in Tahiti, several Renoirs. The only disappointment was the collection of Matisse is being moved, and was not available for viewing. Oh well, now another reason to return.

So Much to See. expect crowds anytime one visits here. So much to see and just not enough time to really appreciate the contents of the museums. The splendor of the building itself is worth the visit. Art viewing to no end, pictures after awhile tend to run into each other and you forget what you have seen. Good café s in the museum offering fair prices. Worth more than one visit.

Better than the Louvre. What a magnificent place. Not only are the artworks and exhibits amazing but the building itself is a wonder to behold. I have been through the Louvre in Paris but I enjoyed this so much more as there was more variety. Worth every minute , we spent quite a few hours there and it is definitely not an expensive place to explore. We would recommend this as a must to do in St Petersburg

The most amazing art gallery & museum. The most amazing art gallery & museum I have ever visited (including the famous Louvre in Paris). The sheer size of the Hermitage is mind boggling. You will need days to see everything. It s an extraordinary place in its own right, even without what it is home to. Some of the most famous works of art in history are housed here - many instantly recogniseable works from many of the great masters. My favourite - the Remrandts. A must see, even if just for an afternoon.

The Louvre of St. Petersburg. Just like the Louvre, you can't see everything in one visit. But everything that you do see is glorious. These buildings were the royal palace of the Tsars,so the rooms themselves are a riot of gold leaf, high ceilings and much decoration. Prepare to do a lot of walking and working yourself around the many other visitors. We were only there about two hours, but we got to see the highlights, including the Rembrandts. We were able to take photos, no flash, please. If you love art, you must make a visit here.

9 hours non stop walking. This is amazing museum.. A lot of word already written about the Hermitage Museum, BUT nothing is like be there.
Huge. fascinate.
I spend a lot of time, and it was worth any minute.
Something that no one in St Petersburg can allow himself to miss.

Huge thing!. You could pretty well spend a week inside there every day and it would still be not enough to fully admire this place and the art collection. I spent there 2 afternoons - 8 hours in total and i still feel like not knowing the place. Must see - but only if you can take your time and amire, not only art but also the palace itself. No use to run through it. Free of charge for students, also international ones!

Was there many times and will go again. For me, this is the place that never exhausts itself. Each of the halls is an adventure and the variety is just amazing. Most of all, I love the third "impressionist" floor with amazing paintings by Monet and Van Gogh.

Czar opulence. This is a fantastic art treasure loaded with art of invaluable worth. I am not a art expert and most reviews dwell on the art, thus I will skip that aspect of this museum. What impressed me was the sheer size of a summer place for the King/Queen of a poor country. The size and cost of this summer residence is mind boggling. Another fact that is so strange to me is that the Communists did not destroy this treasure. The murdered tens of millions of people eradicating the royalty and anyone resisting communism and yet preserved this incredible symbol of royalty. And, of course, are still spending a lot of money preserving the place.The preservation of the art is rather primitive and thus the results of temperature changes, light and etc. are damaging the paintings and artifacts.
A Superb Art Collection. There are several top old masters, superb Rembrandt collection & great impressionist collection. One of the worlds great art galleries

My favorite attraction at St. Petersburg. I went on a cruise trip among the Scandinavian countries and our last stop was St. Petersburg. I must say this is my favorite place. I spent three day at the Hermitage Museum and I barely covered the major exhibits. There are so much to see and you will not regret it.

Hermitage. This is my personal favorite. We were only there once an only for a day. We elected to not take a guide and that worked out fine. We found miles of corridors filled with art and artifacts from every era. I would need at least two days to tour and a day off between to see what I wanted. English guidebooks were available.We were there in 2000 and I always wanted to go back.

must see it!. You can spend the whole day there and it will be not enough to see awesome art!There are no words to describe this museum, you have to see it! free entrance for students! definitely I will come back.
So many riches to admire is hard to take in all in one day. There is a lot of art that I have never seen anywhere else of very famous artists. That was very enriching.
Must see. like the louvre,there are many precious tableaux in the museum,including two of Da Vinci.There are also many beautiful furnitures wothy seeing,
So many paintings, so little time!. We enjoyed the paintings that were displayed. We did not enjoy the modern art as well as the earlier paintings! What detail!
excellent. After Hermitage visit, you can start thinking - what is better, Louvre or Hermitage? :) No words, must visit place.

Swan lake at the Hermitage theatre. we booked in to go to the Hermitage theatre 8pm show as the seats are not allocated we arrived at about 715 , got to the door and was abruptly told to check in my suede jacket I protested that all I had was my shirt sleeves and that I would be cold the answer was "it is not cold" so I checked my jacket and entered the theatre after 20 mins I was cold as I was sitting in a draft, I went back to the door and said please may I get my jacket as I am cold the answer was " it is not cold regulations ". The alternative was to not see the ballet and lose my money. Fortunately a kind lady lent me her scarf which helped to stop me shivering! Russians are quite something else the never smile and the lovely young girls become Rosa Klebb at 40! Russia is surely a destination of curiosity not choice I was very glad to leave!

Truly amazing, with some room for improvements. It is definitely one of the world "must see". Full of treasures, well cared, not awfully expensive. So everything good but one not minor detail. Some, or even many, of the paintings are not properly lit and are, depending on the time, not easy too enjoy.
Good museum. The worlds one of the largest museum. The shop inside is a little bit expensive, if you are in St. peterburg you must see this museum.

Stunning, Overwhelming and a Must See. The collection is truly amazing. The palace is beautiful and really BIG. I think preparation and the right mind set are key to enjoying a tour here. Be prepared for a lot of walking. It's also crowded (it's a popular choice for visitors unsurprisingly) even before it opens to the public. You will almost certainly encounter other visitors that will violate your personal space, bump into you repeatedly, step on the back of your shoe, ignore queues, talk while you're trying to listen to your tour guide and find other ways to be irritating. Bring just a little patience and don't let these annoyances ruin your stay especially if you don't have the luxury of visiting again any time soon. Unless they are picking your pocket or committing some other crime, ignore them. You are going to see some of the finest works of art in the world. You will be rewarded for your virtue. My family was in St Pete's for 2 days on a 9 day Baltic cruise in early September so we knew there wouldn't be a lot of time here. The tour company, SPB did a great job of managing our expectations and focused on the most popular exhibits except the Impressionists. We had a little free time at the end of our 2.5 hours to either shop, take pictures outside or head to an exhibit that was not included on the tour, like the Impressionists. By the end of the tour I was feeling a little overwhelmed. I don't think I would have enjoyed it as much if it were a lot longer.There is a cloak room to leave large bags and coats. We were fortunate the weather was fabulous so no overcoats were worn by our group of 16 but nice to know it's there. There are signs instructing visitors to turn off the flash on your camera or prohibiting pictures all together but they aren't always visible when the rooms are filled with people. Take a second and look around or ask your guide if you aren't sure. I thought it was helpful to check out the website and do a little research on the exhibits but more important to know what would be included on our tour because you can't just wander around this place and hope to run into what you're looking for. However, our tour guide anticipated some of us might want to see the Impressionists and provided a little time and directions. Signage is not great so I was happy to have her directions.

Amazing palace, too many people. Going with a group saved us the hour long wait at 10am. The palace itself is impressive and the many objects that still remain from the actual life of the tsars are amazing. There is for example the peacock alarmclock which is an absolute masterpiece.The exhibition covers all the great European masters. In it's totality it doesn't reach the spheres of the Louvre in Paris or the Uffizi in Florence. Also some of the displays are not well placed for the amount of people and block some rooms.People management overall is mediocre, too many people are being allowed in at a given time which spoils the experience slightly.An absolute must visit.
Too much to take in. Great museum, huge place. Has cloakrooms for bags and coats. There are guided tours available and loads of souvenir stalls around it. You just can't take it all in on one day.

Massive collection, beautiful Palace. I am not a museum kind of a person and usually avoid museums, but this was something else! The palace is huge (over 1000 rooms) and beautiful, every room is different, in terms of decor and every room has beautiful artwork on its ceilings. There is an enormous amount of art, furniture, jewelry, clothes, carriages etc - over 3 million collectibles! You would need a week or more to see everything. The palace in itself is beautiful and very grand. So even if you are not a museum enthusiast, this is definitely worth doing. An important tip - as soon as you enter there are kiosks from where you can buy entry tickets. Just go there and buy and you dont have to stand in a queue. We saw a lot of people waiting in a queue, God knows why! We just strolled, without any issues. They also ask you to buy a ticket if you have a camera - not required. Everyone has cameras and no one asks for a ticket for that.

Stunning palace even on its own. Absolutely must not be missed, but far too big to take it all in; you'd need to stay there for many years to do that, so just get from it what you can. Our visit was a 3 hour guided tour around the Western Art collection. It was great, but after a while the shear volume of grand art started to become overwhelming and I found myself barely glancing at some of the 'Grand Masters'. Next time I'll definitely arrange a private tour guide rather than joining one from the ship so that I can see what I want to... would have loved to have a sampling from all the eras rather than just one collection. But even without the objects, the palace in which they are kept is absolutely stunning, The highlight was the "Amber room". On entry to the museum our guide told us that low cut coats could be worn, but on our visit that day even thin bomber jackets had to be deposited in the cloakroom (unless they were rolled up very small and tucked under the arm, as did any bags much bigger than a normal SLR camera bag. It's big, it's grand, it's stunning, and must not be missed if you get the chance.

Loved It!. The State Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace is a MUST-SEE! A visit to St. Petersburg would almost be a void if you miss this amazing showcase. Words will not be able to describe the collection so I am going to bore you with it. You will not be able to see all of it but just walking through the exhibition halls is a thrill in itself! Spend at least half a day here if not a full day. Highly Recommended!!

Such richness, such grandeur!. The guide book said a minimum of 3 hours and that is really the bare minimum. You can visit this place for three days. Room after room of fantastic art, the architecture more magnificent as you go one. Just absolutely fascinating!

Punchy. Great it might be but after a while you get punchy from all the art. You are never going to see all the treasures it contains but what you can see on your tour is impressive.It could be easy to get lost, and I did. I got separated from my group when leaving my jacket in the cloakroom and the guide didn't wait. They were almost away in the museum itself before I spotted them.Lots of sullen old women left over from the Soviet Union guard the rooms to make sure you don't lean against a rope, dawdle about in a room or some other heinous crime. They scowl as if their life depends on it, and the word 'Nyet' is never far from their lips.The shop is quite good with lots of overpriced things such as little Faberge type eggs for the unwary tourist to buy. I know, because I was that soldier!The place is quite magnificent.
Top Notch Art Galore. The museum's a people packed must see. Wear comfortable walking shoes. Expect stairs. Backpacks and jackets must be checked. Beware of pick pockets.

Best place to visit en St. Petersburgh. The best place to visit in St. Petersburgh. Of all the places we visited this one was the best. The Winter palace is beautiful and the paintings they have at L´Hermitage are breathtaking. With a 2 hour 1/2 guided tour you will get to see the more important things.
Wear good shoes and remember the patience pill!. Don't forget your soft healed sneakers for this day in St. Petersburg. There are many, many, many rooms with lots of gilding and all maner of art.
Overwhelming but inspiring. The special exhibition of dresses was superb. The library was the most beautiful library I have ever seen. There was much more to see than the paintings.

Glittering Images. The Hermitage is the crown jewel of St Petersburg, precious enough in itself. We have a focus on renaissance art which made it easier to bear down and see our highlights-but the lucky traveller with more than a few hours to spend will be rewarded. Comfortable shoes and clothing will help, and don't forget security will not admit large backpacks or bags.The art itself is amazing, but the preservation of it through wars and revolutions is also exciting.Then tour around and savor the awesomeness of the experience. Finish up with a canal boat tour to cleanse the palate.

Opulence, glory and Russian history. I was so lucky to have a full day tour of The Hermitage with the tour out of Viking River Cruises. If you want to know some of its past, read the book "The Madonna's of Leningrad" which talks about St. Petersburg/Leningrad during the hard times of WWII when the Nazis surrounded the city and people starved. Much of the precious artwork had been moved out of the Hermitage prior to the occupation. This is an amazing art museum as well as including attached the Winter Palace of Catherine the Great. Lots of stairs so be prepared.

No wonder the peasants revolted!. To really savor the museums exhibits you need to spend 3 days at least. The gold room was not what I was expecting but is well worth the time to go through it. There was a fantastic exhibit of clothes worn by the nobility in the time of the Tzars. It is well worth the time.

My favourite Place. Visiting the Hermitage and the Winter Palace and looking out onto the Palace Square gives one an awesome feeling of "greatness". St Petersburg is just that - an all round feeling of Russian greatness. So much history and culture, art and music....

Best approach to visit. There are so many collections. Their english web site are full of informations. It is better read it before going. Off peak season particularly after September (Cruise season) may even be better. However, it can be cold and wet and be prepared to line up at the cloak room. It will be more enjoyable if you have a art expert accompany you.
beautiful. Beautiful palace, beautiful colors of building and wonderful museum with large collection of painting and jewelry,

A must-see in Moscow, but boy is it crowded. Thankfully we had an expert guide from St. Petersburg to shepherd us through the vast offerings of the Hermitage: The largest Rembrandt collection in the world, an impressive array of impressionists tucked as they were in a badly-lit upstairs gallery, period clothing, special entrance to the "Gold Room", huge halls, a view of lovely gardens through the windows, tapestries, dishes, the Peacock clock, and much more. Our professional guide remarked over and over again how unruly certain groups of tourists were--who pushed and shoved their way in front of paintings--hundreds of flashes going off, some even touching the priceless paintings, and no one stopping them. She said, "These paintings won't last if this is allowed to continue." I agree. The Heritage houses one of the world's greatest collections. I hope it survives.

One of the most important museums. Hermitage is one of the most important museums in the world. There you can see from Ancient Egypt art to modern France paintings. I spent almost 8 hours inside Hermitage and could visit around 60% of it! Fantastic museum!

Great museum but need time to appreciate it. The State Hermitage Museum is considered one of the world's largest and most prestigious museums. It is largely housed in the Winter Palace which was formerly the residence of the Komanov Tsars. Since we went in a group, there was no way one can enjoy art pieces based on one's preference. The fact that most displays were beseiged with tour groups forced our guide to herd us through their pre-arranged route. We went through quite a few statesrooms which showcased the extravagrance of the former Emperors and Empresses. Then we were ushered to see the 18th century still functioning automated Peacock Clock (a video of the movements was recorded and showed on a flat screen TV next to the display), Leonardo Da Vinci's famous painting The Madonna and the Child, and Rembrandt's The Return of the Prodigal Son. We pass through a lot of canvas paintings, sculptures and artwork but missed out on the Picasso collection and works of Matisse, Monet, Cezanne, Van Gogh and Renoir probably because they are the most patronized. Will definitely have to return and spend sometime in the future.
