Best in Europe. When you go there , visit Places shown in the Map of the MuseumAsk help from room-controllers if you needThey good to help you

Combination of the Louvre and Versailles. The State Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace contains some of the world's greatest works of art. It is really huge and would be hard to navigate without a tour guide. We spent about 2 and 1/2 hours here. We were on an escorted tour so we had a wonderful English speaking Russian guide who showed us the highlights. I was overwhelmed by all that I saw. Besides the art pieces, sculptures, mosaics, and tapestries, the architecture alone is extremely impressive. And the golden walls! Oh my! A must see in St. Petersburg.

One of the great collections. I had visited the Hermitage back in 1978 when Russia was under the old regeme and I didn't appreciate what was under my nose. I expected one or two Picasso's, not over 30 paintings and 10 sculptures, then there are scores of works by, Matisse, Van Gogh, Rembrant, Giogione, Degas, Rousseau, Poussin, Titian, Rapheal, Goya, Veronese, Vad Dyke, Ruben, Grainsborough, Chezanne, Sisley, Renoir, Monet and Kandinsky to name a few. If art isn't your thing human history is also on display with items dating back 100's of thousands of years. Then of course the museum is the old Tsar's home so you can see how they lived.It's like the Louvre, Varsaille, Schronbornn, Chatsworth and the British Museum all rolled into one.

Take the tour!. Probably, one of the best museums in the world. It is, however, quite big. I took the official tour with English speaking guide (Olga) and it was great. In two hours we had a good understanding of the museum and received some great info on the most important art pieces and the building itself (which is a masterpiece itself). After this great introduction, spent one more hour and felt complete satisfied with my visit.

Gate 1 Travel: Russian River cruise. We recently (Sept, 2014) took Russia River Cruise trip by Gate 1 Travel. We had a wonderful travel experience, the service of the ship (from St. Petersburg to Moscow) was excellent, foods and drink were good, all activities were just right for different level of travel people. The tour guide did very good job to help find hotel, taxi and metro/subway for our extended stay.
Hermitage Museum. HUGE MUSEUM. Some nice features, suppose one would have to be an avid art fan to really appreciate it.

Amazing. Beautiful architecture, and the biggest collection of art that I have seen in one place. Also, there was a display of Emperial Royal Dress and it was wonderful to see what the Tsars and Princesses wore in the day. Very emotive and I felt very priviledge to have had the opportunity to see it.

Magnificent But Overated. For years I have heard that ''The Hermitage'' in St Petersburg is the be all and end all of such attractions. Having been to the ''Louvre'', ''Buckingham Palace'' and even the ''Peterhof'' in St Petersburg which in my opinion are much better attractions. I went through with a group and we were let in 1 hour before opening time and even then it was shoulder to shoulder with all the other tours that had been also let in early!!!!! There is no doubt that this is a magnificent attraction and no trip to St Petersburg would be complete without a visit. But it definitely isn't up there with similar attractions in other cities around Europe. (Versailles, Schoebrun et al.) The gloomy look on the female guards (affectionately referred to as the '' Dragons'') do nothing to add joy to the occasion. The winter palace and the wonderful collection of art and artifacts is impressive. But the underlying story of Catherine and her conquests and young lovers adds a lot to the intrigue of the whole attraction. Don't be put off by my review as no-one can possibly go to St Petersburg without going through the ''Hermitage'' but don't go along thinking it is the greatest attraction in the world. It's not!
Busy. Glad I visited this world class site but nearly got knocked off my feet by other tourists jostling to photograph the Leonardo

a must...even if you are not that into art...a must.. one of the most impressive collections of masterpieces in an almost even as impressive museum. It is one of the world leading museums, so don't miss it when in St. Petersburg, even if you have only a few hours to spare ( as I did on a business trip) it will be rewarding.
Fantastic museum. You need at least 2 days ticket to do this justice.Make sure you get a plan. There are rooms full of Picassos , etc not just one. The rooms in the winter palace are stunning.

Highly overated. The building is magnificent, it is huge with poor signs on how to findexhibits and even WCs. The place is very crowed. Many of the exhibits are repetitive i.e. furniture, floors, interiors in general. It was even hard to find the entrance to the museum

Not for me. We spent a few hours here and decided to call it quits. I feel it is just to big. You could spend all day here and it is just not my idea of a day well spent. Yes there are some great paintings and wonderful statues etc. Was I tired? Not sure. I enjoy going through these wonderful museums but not today. I know I never got tired in the Louvre or any of the other of the ones I have visited so I cannot say for sure why I did not enjoy this one. I still think it is worth having a look at but either be prepared for a long long haul or limit the time and pick an area of it. Not sure sorry.

A wonder. After visiting the V&A, the Louvre, and others famous museum, I was still surprised by the beauty of this one. its location, entrance and hall make you feel like back in the time where the tsars were still completing the collection. You will need more than one day to enjoy its full potential but one day is enough to get a good feeling.

Most Impressive ever. The biggest and the most impressive museum ever.
a must see in saint petersburg. Highly recommended to go with a guide to reduce ticket lines and not to get lost in the museum because it is huge.

Best Museum. This museum allows you close up access to an amazing number of paintings. The building it self and the views from the windows are beautiful.
If you get the chance this should not be missed

Get early for Gold chamber´s tickets. My favorite Museum worldwide, I was even more impressed than by the Louvre and although it is busy you can not visit St Petersburg without having been here. If you arrive around 9:15 am (it does not open until 10 am), take an umbrella with you even if Sun shines and get a ticket for the Gold chamber.
One of the greatest museums.. One can spend a week in the Hermitage and still haven't seem most of it so a visit has to be preplanned. See the Italian and Flamish paintings and the Golden Room.

Hermitage Museum. We joined a local tour company and visit this museum. This is definitely one of the biggest museum in the world with thousands of collections. Unfortunately we only had two hours in this tour to see a few collections by Da Vinci, Michelangelo, Rembrandt and more. Both of us agreed that we need to come back to this museum down the road with at least a few days to explore. This is a must see attraction.

A must see in SPB. An Amazing place, think would need a couple of days or perhaps four days for a comprehensive visit, the museum is so big, that you might get lost inside, and get ready for a minimum wait of 10 minutes in line, when off season.
Amazing site - a showplace!. A must see! The grandeur and abundance of this place is second to none - a reflection of the prosperity of the Czars and the royal family.

This place is just so amazing - a must do!!!. Make sure you go mornings before 10 and get your ticket at the machine just inside the main courtyard gate and then join the middle lane for entrance, not the right one that is for non tourists.I cannot begin to describe its beauty. Make sure when you give your Bag in at the cloakroom that you have something to drink on your way around as cafeteria is on ground floor and not particularly good or cheap.You need a minimum half a day for a real impression

Overwhelming attraction. We spent several hours visiting this amazing collection of art, architecture, and other displays....could have spent many days as there is so much to see. This is a "must visit" tour for any visitor to St. Petersburg, Russia.

Massive & beautiful - the top attraction in the city. If you only see 1 thing in St.P it should be the Hermitage. It's really 2 attractions in 1 - the Winter Palace could hold it's own as a tourist attraction but stuffed full of art, jewels and all manner of fascinating artefacts it's a real head-turner!You need a day in there, or better still 2 half days as it's hard work being on your feet and dodging crowds.Unless you know a lot about art, do get a guide. Also a great way to jump the long queues!

Dont expect to see another Louvre. If you like big religeous paintings by the big name masters, you are in the right place. Rooms are beautiful. But to call it one of the best museums in the world would be overstatement.

Hermitage Museum.. This place was incredible, the only problem we found was the length of time it took to go through, but it was interesting, when Julia, the Guide, told us about the Museum just prior to the Germans invading, that all the art works were removed for safe keeping, and also the story about the Museum Cats in the basement, they keep the rat numbers down, in so protecting the art work stored in there.

Busy but worthwhile. We (my friend Jill &i) visited as part of a two day tour with Alla Tours. We were on a cruise and had been led to believe we had to book any tour with the ship, not so and having found this company we can highly recommend it.We were in a small group of 16 and had an early timed entrance, slightly beating the crowds. The Hermitage is huge and you are only able to sample a small part of it. It is very busy, but our guide was excellent at finding interesting but quieter things to see. I would imagine your experience would vary according to how busy it was, how much time you spent there and how good your guide was. But if you go to St Petersburg don't miss it.

Could spend a lot of time here. Didn't manage to make it until our last day in St. Petersburg. Have to come back to go again! Quite impressive collections, really overwhelming and amazing. Made it across the square to see Manifesto 10 to see the Matisse, Kandinsky. Closes most days at 6 pm (one night it closes at 9pm) so recommend starting earlier than we did and picking the exhibits that are most attractive to you! Saw lovely clothing temporary exhibition of the royal court.

"Do not miss mind blowing!". From the moment you enter the museum your senses are heightened as you realizes a experience awaits you that can only be comprehended by being in this great palace - museum.You could spend days here in the incredible surroundings of art and architecture,but whatever time you can spend in this museum will stay with you forever.

Self guided is best if you know a little about art. Warning: The Hermitage may leave you emotionally exhausted. I was chatting last night at the Opera (Tosca) to a Dutch tourist, and he had had the same experience as I had. If you love art, you cannot imagine the impact. A Picasso room, a Van Gogh room, etc. Get the map once you are inside - free and very helpful. One idea is to start at the top floor - it is a bit easier to grasp the layout. I had made the mistake of booking on both Treasury tours: the Diamond Room and The Gold Room. The first one was 1.5 hours and very good but I cancelled and got a refund on my ticket for the second Treasury tour as I was too tired to immediately follow with the second tour. These Treasury tours show you the real wealth in the Museum; and are worth the extra 300 Roubles. There were only three in our group (English speaking) and the guide Anastasia was excellent. For the entrance: I queued up for a ticket but maybe next time I would buy one on line. If you have an internet-booked ticket the place to get your ticket is just inside the first large set of gates. There is a lot of queue jumping to buy on the day so do not expect any order at that point. You do not need a guided tour or audio-guide for the main part if you know anything about art. It is less tiring to go at your own pace. Enjoy. Plenty of cafes to have a break inside. All large bags,liquids, and all jackets/coats have to be left at the cloakroom. Buy your water inside at a cafe.
Another SPB highlight. This is a must for all visitors to SPB, the gardens and exhibits are unlike anywhere in the world, exceptional.An organised tour will help avoid long entry lineups.
Liked this Famous Museum. I loved seeing all the famous paintings housed inside. The walls need a bit of updating. This amazing paintings could have been displayed better

Jaw Dropping Experience. We have just returned from a Baltic Cruise the Jewel of this amazing Holiday was our visit to The Hermitage Museum which is in part is housed in the Winter Palace. Words will not do justice to the splendour that will greet your eyes as you wander from room to room stuff full of wonder-us works of Art, Paintings, Statutes and jewels, The sheer size of some of the Exhibits are stunning The Decor of each room is a wonderfully opulent to say the least, But be Warned you are squeezed thru the main entrance with what seems like dozens of tours all heading haphazardly up the main stair case, but stick with it as the crowd soon thins out and it is well worth the jostling at the start.

Awsome!. This vast beautiful building houses an enormous amount af art which is spread out. You need to grasp the size of the museum before you start a visit as you could spend days in here and have blisters on your feet! The highlight of St. Petersburg.

a must see. Collection is outstanding. One of the largest art museums world wide so plan to spend a lot of time here. 4 hours for a quick look. They have moved the Matisse collection and plan to move the impressionists to a separate museum across the plaza. (thus more admissions collected). Both collections very worthwhile, even if you must pay additional. Having a guide is helpful to know where to find what.
heaven and hell. your senses are enanced and you are in heaven beacause of the incredible art works you are in hell beacause you can easily get lost and spend the rest of your life in the museum.

Fabulous art. This museum is vast. We were in St Petersburg on a cruise & the Hermitage was part of our tour with Alla Tours. We spent 2 hours walking around just looking in a few of the hundreds of rooms. The quality & selection of art, sculptures etc is wonderful. I think 2 hours is about right as after that you become 'pictured out'! It's very crowded as you first enter & go up the staircase, but after that the crowds disperse.

WOOOW!. Wooow! That's what thought each time I was entering a new room in this stunning museum. I used to think that the Louvre was my favourite museum in the world, after visiting the Metropolitan, the Prado as well as the ones in London and Rome but, hey, there's no competition. The Hermitage would be just amazing even without the icredible amout of Tintoretto's, Tiziano's, Rembradt's and impressionits' works it contains. The decorations in each room are breathtaking and glorify the paitings that are exposed in. The audioguide has not to be missed. The explainations are exhaustive but without being too long or boring and really allow to fully enjoy what you are looking at. At the time of my visit, the works by Matisse and Kandisky were being exhibited in the General Staff Building and the latter also deserves a visit! Overall, I spent one day and a half in this outstanding musem, rushing in some sections of its and without being able to see everything. The Hermitage is ART and people loving art should really think of going there!
Amazing. Beautiful & amazing. Well worth the trip. Lots of rooms, all differently decorated. Very beautiful and amazing.

Outstanding. It was our first visit to Russia and we were in Saint Petersburg as part of our cruise. We were there for two days and Hermitage museum was part of the guided tour. The museum is massive, outstanding and is of great architecture. It has almost 3 million items on display. We spent around 3 hours there which wasn't enough but could pass through about 50 rooms. The collections are amazing and rooms are very bright with excellent golden decoration. The museum is spread into 6 separate buildings inter connected. We were informed that there are about 1000 rooms in all but only 350 rooms are open for public. Truly amazing and must see in Saint Petersburg.

Amazing.. You could spend all day here and not see much at all. There is so much to see there. Get a tour guide and get them to take you to the highlights otherwise you will get lost in the crowds and walk around aimlessly.

Two words: Fantastic and Massive. We spent several hours at the Hermitage Museum this afternoon and only scratched the surface. If you spent just 1 minute at each of the 2.7 million items in the museum it would take over 5 years to see them all. So, since we didn't have 5 years to wonder around the halls, we could only see a few things and will have to leave the rest for one of our next visits. Without a doubt, the Hermitage is really one of the worlds greatest museums. The size and opulence of many of the rooms is simply amazing. Even the hardwood floors throughout the museum with all the inlays and designs almost want to make you step carefully. The paintings, sculptures, furniture, vases and everything else contained in the museum makes you want to stay much longer that most people can. Certainly another "must do" while in St. Petersburg and if we make it back a second time it will be on the list again.

First stay in Russia. My wife and I stayed in Russia the 1st time. And the 1st city we chose was St.Petersburg. It was terrific. The whole city looked like a palace. And the Hermitage also. There we saw lots of paintings that we desired to see. Our guide told a lot about the development of Russian paintings. Worth visiting

Louvre in Versailles. Amazing, Stunning, Fabulous. One runs out of adjectives to describe this place.All the great masters, exquisite works of art , gold and diamond treasures from ancient times all that and more.One has to look at the paintings, the walls, the ceiling, the doors. A virtual feast for the eyes every where, It. is Louvre and Versailles put together.We spent two days and managed to see a fair bit. If you love museums this is spectacular . Definitely a must see.., and carry a plan. The museum ladies are very helpful in giving you directions if you want to go to a particular room.

Fantastic. Can't wait to return!. I visited the Hermitage as part of an organised tour. This allowed us access to the museum before it opened to the public. Although there were plenty of other tour groups in the museum at the same time, I didn't feel that the space was overcrowded or that we had to queue to look at paintings etc. I frequently visit the museums in London, and have had to deal with worse crowds there.I was very lucky with my guide who was incredibly knowledgeable and passionate about the buildings and exhibits. Our tour took a canal boat ride afterwards and it was lovely to see the palace from the water, particularly the parts of the building we were walking through just minutes previously. I really can't wait to return someday!Toilets by the entrance were clean and free of charge.
Fabulous. This is a fabulous place to see. There is over three thousand pieces of artwork. The decorations are also unbelievable.

An unusual place !. This was our first visit to Russia so didn't know what to expect to see ! We were not disappointed in what we did see !The complex covers 5 buildings and houses over 3 million exhibits ,and what exhibits they are .The Gold room is the most interesting ,at least we thought so ! There is an absolute fortune in there , they are so precious you are not allowed to even take any photographs of the exhibits many of which came from England .The art gallery is beyond belief. There are priceless paintings from all around the World ,Dutch masters and Flemish French Masters in abundance ! Seeing is believing !It took us nearly 5 hours to go around the different rooms ,including the Gold room ,the art gallery ,the throne room and the treasury as well as the old Hermitage.A must to visit !
Gorgeous. Impressive. If you are a museum fan, you certainly buy a 4 days ticket. 1 day is not enough to see it all. there are 3 million pieces!

Enjoyment depends on your Guide. This vast treasure trove can only be glimpsed in the time most of us have. On our first visit a few years ago the Guide asked whether anyone in the group ( about 20 of us ) had particular interests. Some of us did and she made sure these were included which was great. On this occasion we were given a " standard" tour. ie shown the various State Rooms , toured the four buildings which make up the Hermitage complex and shown the paintings/sculptures deemed their " greats" ie Michelangelo, Leonardo, Raphael, Rembrandt etc- plus Military paintings of Russia's "great and good ". Our guide was passionate about her subject with an excellent command of English but after two hours we began to ache. Fortunately there are a few chairs and benches when energy wanes and enjoyment transmutes to education.

A Must See In St. Petersburg!. It is a gorgeous museum with endless rooms filled with amazing artwork. As stated in other reviews, the rooms themselves are pieces of art to enjoy! I recommend finding a guide or purchasing the audio guide which can be rented inside the museum. Each time we have been here, we were only able to spend a few hours since we were traveling with our child. This time our daughter was 11, and she enjoyed it with the audio guide. I would love to be able to go back and spend much, more time in the Hermitage! Oh, I do recommend eating before you go, the cafe food was not that good and as museums go; overpriced.

Humongous museum with so much art and history. The amount of exhibits and items is ridiculous! You could easily spend weeks wandering the halls. From Western art to an armoury!Be careful not to get lost though as the museum stretches on and on and on! And look up every now and then, the art on the walls and ceilings are amazing!

Hermitage - 5 buildings. We toured all five of the buildings but there was only enough time to get a quick overview of all the treasures gathered in this one location. You would need a week to admire the many works of art.
Breathtaking. Due to our restricted time, we could only visit one floor, and we opted for Russian culture. Clearly, we missed many other worthwhile works of art. Helpful staff.

Do it alone. I loved this museum but I recommend doing it in your own time. Our agent recommended a tour to see the main sights but I'm glad I ignored this. We did scan the main attractions first as a group (of five friends) but we split up along the way to focus on what was of most interest to each of us. My husband spent a lot of time in the Greek/roman type sections (I know, weird ha?). Our friends really just wanted to see the main sights but I wanted to linger. I feel like I saw everything I wanted to with no sense of rushing at all. I spent ages in some galleries and palace state rooms, dawdled over a special exhibition of clothing (including clothes of the family of the last Tsar- slightly unnerving...) and bumped into my husband for a brisk walk through the basements in the way out. I loved it- make sure you read something about it before and get an audio guide. It's nice to know about tables of food coming through the floor so as to avoid nosey servants, beautiful clocks (check out the video - the peacock clock really is exquisite), small creatures amongst the vines on a beautiful silver wine server, and where all those priceless treasures come from. Take time to enjoy it if that's what your into or just do the highlights with the map and an audio guide. Ps take a snack in your pocket. I was told food was really expensive and you might be there all day.

Wear comfortable shoes. This is up there with the Vatican, I know that sounds weird but honestly the number and quality of items in here is breathtaking, someone compared it to The Louvre but I think this eclipsed it. Take a guide to avoid the queues and to help you pick out items to see, otherwise take good walking shoes and be prepared for a long day!

A must while in St. Petersburg. We visited the Hermitage Museum whilst in St. Petersburg on a cruise ship and visited with a Russian guide. The museum is vast but although we only had a limited amount of time we were expertly guided through the most interesting rooms with amazing art work. Every room offered something different with all the famous masters shown and the decorated ceilings are absolutely fabulous. It does get crowded in there but you have to accept this at one of the best museums in the world.

Over the Top. This was the highlight of our trip! Such an amazing palace. The architecture, the paintings, the gold and diamonds,and the clothing of the queen blew us away. I could have spent another day going though this beautiful palace. The queen never wore the same dress twice, so you can imagine the collection, plus the matching shoes, gloves, and jewels that went with each outfit. Oh, this was the visit of all visits!

the Hermitage!!. We heard so much about this place before the trip and it did not disappoint. The museum collections are unique and there are so much to see. We got to stay only 2 hours, just enough for a glimpse.

Great museum. My wife and I just did three hours this morning on a self guided tour. I believe we are in an off season or at least fewer tourists. Nevertheless we had to wait 40 minutes in line to purchase tickets. I tried the electronic machines to the right as you enter the courtyard but they wouldn't take my credit card or cash. I would advise you to purchase a voucher or tickets advance to avoid this wait, but the weather was nice so it was no big deal. There were numerous tour groups and drain at the same time we were. So we decided to go to the top floor and work our way down to avoid these groups which turned out to be a good decision. We feel we saw a lot in three hours with a break downstairs in the cafeteria to sit down and have something to drink. The self-guided tour worked for us following the map that the museum gives you at the entrance along with the help of the various women sitting in the rooms as guards. In many instances tours are good but in an art museum we like to go in her own pace and perhaps inspect different works more closely then a tour would allow. We also saw various impressionist paintings which we had never seen or read about so it was interesting to see them.
a must to do. Was really beautiful to visit and should definitely be on your to do list. As it is very big, take your time for it.

A must for anybody. This is a experience in its self it hold so much of the arts of the world you will only able to see a small section of the works of arts unless you are prepare to spend years of studying all the art works

A must see for everyone. This museum by far exceeded all expectation I had and then some. The first Thursday of every month is free and doesn't include the diamond room and gold room. Get there early because you can spend several days there and not see everything. We took a tour of the diamond room and was very impressed with many of the royal gifts encrusted in diamonds and even the faberge pieces as well. So many fascinating pieces of art it truly is phenomenal to be surrounded by such inspirational artists.

A journey through the history of European art. There is a room devoted entirely to Rembrandts. The 19th century French paintings are incredible. Plus Goya, Velasquez , Caravaggio , the list is endless and that is just the paintings. Wonderful sculptures and a copy of Raphael's Loggia. The list is endless.

Gold Room was AMAZING!. The sheer number of paintings housed in this museum is unbelievable. It boasts room after roomed filled with works by the great masters. A highlight for me was the Gold Room. I have never seen a collection of diamonds, gold, and other precious stones to come even close to this. Timed entrances with guides kept the crowds well managed. I was not sure if the extra fee charged to view the Gold Room would be worth it, but it turned out to be a real highlight of our vacation!
look at hermitage. You need plenty of time. You will walk a lot and see many, many paintings. I love the sculptures the best. Easy to see all three - Old, new and winter palace.

great. be aware the palace is very busy with loads of people having said that it was amazing the works of art amazing, if you aren't in to art then look at the building, the doors the ceilings they are works of art in themselves

Just confirming every "wow" review. Yes, it's everything great stated by other reviewers. You can spend days in the Hermitage. Unfortunately, we visited in August when it was crowded...we'll try to visit again off-season.
a tourist place. It will be a great place for art lovers. I don't know if it's always crowded all year round. There is no air condition inside.

Doing the Hermitage solo. Though I have been all over Europe to visit art museums and palaces, I had neglected St. Petersburg until after my 60th birthday. So I made it a special destination. Suspecting that a group tour from a cruise ship would not be to my liking, I went through the expensive visa process and flew to St. Petersburg, budgeting four full days for the Hermitage, one day for Peterhof and the Russian Museum, and one day for other city sights. That turned out to be just about right.Though the museum is large, certain parts downstairs are probably not of interest to many visitors, and so the main parts are manageable in a few days. They put out a very impressive app with maps and 360-degree panorama views of many of the rooms. Though I studied ahead of time and had a plan for each day, I ended up just wandering all over the first day and then deepening my exploration the remaining three days.The museum impresses most as architecture. Many rooms have spectacular walls and ceilings. Also, the relationship between the museum and the city and water around it is interesting to observe. (There are many, many windows.) The spaces decked out as period rooms were a bit tawdry (seeming so especially since I had just visited the Louvre's renovated period rooms a week earlier). The painting collection has its strong and its weak points, though certainly it is one of the top ten in Europe. Alas, it is a very difficult collection to enjoy, for two reasons. First, because of all the windows, there are substantial glare issues in most rooms. For some major paintings, there is not a spot in the room where one may have a view without this issue emerging. And second, more than any other museum I have visited this one is frequented by tour groups. Thus while searching for that perfect spot to see a painting you may very well be run over by a group of tourists. Some areas, like the Rembrandt rooms, are wall to wall tourists from opening time to closing time.It was interesting to read the cards. Some objects were listed as in Berlin until 1945. Others were transferred from other Russian museums, so that this one could be an especially impressive showplace.All in all, I was delighted to have my four days at the Hermitage. (If you go, buy two-day passes on the Internet ahead of time, and if you intend to visit for four days make two separate two-day pass transactions.) I think I was in every room that was open. And I probably will come back some day. But I would advise this as being a venture to undertake only after gaining a strong foothold in other European museums. Get to know the Louvre and the National Gallery and the Prado and the Gemäldegalerie and the Uffizi well first. Then think about spending some time in St. Petersburg.

Beautiful - a few tips for a smoother visit. The building itself is a piece of art not to mention the thousands of priceless pieces it contains. We had a wonderful visit and wanted to share a few tips 1. If you have specific pieces you want to see get a guide. You can find a reasonably priced private guide by doing some research on TA. We hired a young woman with fluent English for $35 USD/hr. She had a degree in art history and was extremely knowledgeable. This allowed us to go directly to the pieces we wanted to see and not follow the normal route. For example, we saw the peacock clock with maybe only 5-10 other people in the whole room. By the afternoon when we walked back through the room was packed.2. Buy you ticket from the electronic machines to bypass the large line. It seems like not many people realized you could do this. They are located to the right as you walk into the courtyard where the main entrance is. Anyone can use the machines. One is cash only and the others take credit or cash.3. Don't bring a bottle of water. You will have to surrender liquids at the security because of an incident where a radical threw liquid acid on one of the Rembrandts.4. There is no climate control and very packed during the summer months. There are no 'good times' to go although like most tourist attractions first thing in the morning or closer to the closing time is somewhat less crowded.
WOW!. most people ,I guess, come to St. Petersburg for a visit to the Hermitage....its amazing. We had 2hours with a guide and then a further 4 hours on our own.So glad we have seen it
a world class site. You can't go to St. Petersburg and not go to the Hermitage. Wello you can but why would you? This is one of the great museums of the world.
Beautiful...until the end!. Very crowded once general admission occurred. Very dangerous trying to get downstairs to retrieve coats...no organization
a good place to visit. Give yourself plenty of time to see everything and wear good walking shoes as you walk a long way. and again use a good tour guide company. I recommend Alla tours

Greatest Museum in the World!. I have visited most of the top museums of the world and you think to yourself - Hey I've seen almost everything - then you come to the Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg and you realize there's no competition. This is without a doubt the best museum in the world. Visit the room of Gold and the Gogan rooms - you could come here for days and will definitely return.
Magnificent. The Hermitage is unique and the collections are absolutely out of this world. We can easily get lost there and enjoy it.

The museum all others compare to.. Beautiful, immense, gigantic, well organised, numerous exhibitions, themed exhibitions. If you have not been to the Hermitage, you don't know what you are missing... Reason enough to visit Saint Petersburg!

Spectacular Treasures. The Hermitage is one of the largest museums in the world, with three million works of art (not all on display at once), and one of the oldest art galleries in the world. Like so many historic sites in Russia, this place has been through the mill. Over many war-torn years, large portions of the collection have been stolen or sold. Portions of the collection have been added by donations and various other (sometimes not so admirable) means. During Russian Revolution, the looting of the massive wine cellars by Bolsheviks fueled weeks of riots and continued unrest that was later termed "The greatest hangover in history." Later, hard-liners in the Soviet government did not pay much attention to maintenance of art, which was officially labeled as "bourgeois" and "decadent". During the 1920s and 1930s, under the rule of Stalin the Soviet government ordered the sale of over two thousand works of art, including some of the most precious works from the Hermitage collection. After WW II the war the government attempted to compensate for its recent losses by transferring to the museum some of the art captured by the Red Army in Germany. The most highly-priced part of the booty were originally taken by the Nazis from private collections of German (Jewish) business elite. These paintings were considered lost until 1995 when the museum unveiled them to the public as "Hidden Treasures." The Russian government maintains that these works provide just a small compensation for irreparable losses inflicted on Russian cultural heritage by the German invasion in WWII. The State Duma (legislature) actually passed a law forbidding the return of disputed works to their owners on the grounds they were guilty of financing the Nazi regime.We saw many iconic works of art that, before today, I had only seen in books. Hours later, we went to the Hermitage Treasure Collection. Our Hermitage Treasure guide was an immaculately dressed woman of about 60. The woman spoke only Russian, but through eye-contact and her enthusiastic delivery, she helped make our tour exciting. Our guide translated as we viewed an incredibly rich collection of the applied arts, including works by Faberge and Imperial jewelry.

must see. If you want to see art history at its best you have to visit The Hermitage. One advice: take at least two mornings (or afternoons) because this place is huge and there is a lot to see. The only thing that was not so good was the routing and if you ask one of the staff they do not always speak English well.

One of the best museums in the world. This museum is located in the Winter Palace. Consequently, the rooms that house the works of art are works of architectural works of art themselves. There are 17 kilometers of halls in the museum. It is large. We spent two days there. The first day helped us get the lay of the land. We noted places we wanted to revisit for our second experience there. Get there early and bring comfortable walking shoes.

Beautiful but almost too much.. Yes what shall I say. Of course when in St.Petersbourg you have to see this to believe it. But on the same time I thought; all this opulence, splendor and brilliance for a few fortunate, whilst the ordinary people had absolutely nothing. Yes, sorry, but too much is too much but still, that is my humble opinion. Go see it.
A must have... So much to see, so much gilding! If you want to see the Faberge and Jewellery make sure you pre- book the 'Vaults' tour also as its an extra.

Incredible!. The only drawback to seeing such a magnificent museum is the huge crowds that also want to see it! But the line does move along through the splendid rooms and you have the opportunity to enjoy some of the worlds masterpieces.

Art History at the extreme.. We didn't have enough time to visit. We did get to see quite a bit of it but our time was short. We could have paid for an extended early tour but opted not to. A must see when in St. Petersburg, Russia.

Fantastic. What we liked? Everything. And you can read it most of the previous comments The only thing we didn't like? We haven't had enough time to see all rooms and exibitions. So we have to come back.
Luxury. Beatifull, fantastic.. Nice collection, but the arquitecure of the palace is the best!! You have to go

Overwhelming. Absolutely stunning, and we only saw the Winter Palace (or rather some of it) Eighteen miles of exhibitions, apparently. To be perfectly honest, the Palace itself is totally spectacular. Room after room after room of sheer opulence, magnificent doors, walls, floors, ceilings. I was totally enthralled with the building itself and have to admit I paid little attention to paintings and sculptures! I would highly recommend a visit, you would need to spend days, rather than hours, in order to take in the stunning displays/exhibitions! Breath-taking.

Best Art Museum In The World. If you can afford it, hire a private guide. WE lucked out and had a guide who was an art major. You don 't wait in line with a guide and they show you the important pieces of work. Otherwise you can spend days in this magnificent museum.

Must Visit. It will take almost 10 years for somebody to enjoy all the pieces of art in the museum. Well maintained and excellent collection. But heavily crowded. Photography is prohibited in some places within the building and no Flash Photography.

A trove of art treasures meriting repeat visits!. Did the highlights tour with a group tour -- 2 1/2 hours long. Thought I might want to stay late with my wife after the group tour, but was exhausted, as it is simply overwhelming. Room after room, and this was only in the Winter Palace! If you are fortunate to visit St Petersburg again, this definitely merits a repeat visit!

great. one of the largest museums in the world full of incredible items. they say that if you spent just one minute viewing every item in the museum or in storage it would take you 80 years.I can assure you that you can see a lot in 5 hours
Hermitage Museum. Unbelievable! This is a must see in St. Petersburg. Best to go with a tour, otherwise the lines are too long.

Outshines Versailles and rivals the Louvre. It's actually hard to give your full attention to the art treasures here because of the opulence of the palace setting with one jaw-dropping room leading to another even more elaborate one. Definitely the highlight of our Baltic cruise. The only downside was the massive line waiting to get in and the overwhelming crowds inside, probably because we went at the height of the tourist season in July.
Give yourself plenty of time. This museum is huge and crowded. If you can get in with a group, you will save yourself very long lines outside and a tour guide can take you to see the highlights.
Beautiful buildings and stunning collection. Beautiful buildings and stunning collection. The second largest museum in the world. The winterpalace is beautiful in itself.

Almost Overwhelming in Size and Scope. You simply must go if you are in St Petersburg. A tour of two hours does not even begin to give one an appreciation of what is here. From great masters of art to exquisite furniture, every turn you make has amazing things to see.My cruise ship arranged an after-hours "private tour" that reduced the crowds to manageable levels. I highly recommend this if available to you.

Outshines everything!. It is difficult to find the words to even describe The Hermitage. It is simply the best Museum and Palace that you will ever see. We have been to Museums and Palaces all over the world, but nothing prepared me for what we saw when we walked through the doors. It is very crowded and at times you wish the sea of people would part so that you could have a better look at certain things. It was hard to know whether to look first at the art or focus on the building itself! We visited Buckingham Palace a week later and it paled in comparison.

Impressive Palace with Incredible Art Collection. This museum rivals all other museums including the Louvre. The collection of art is not just impressive - it is amazing. I stood in a room by myself with five Renoirs, five Monets and five Cezannes all in the same room with no one else around. It was so incredible to enjoy the art without bumping into one hundred other people. The museum itself is a work of art as well. This needs to be your number one priority in St. Pete!

INCREDIBLE. The biggest and most complete museum in all Europe!It's a Palace, a history museum and an art museum, all together and with and incredible variety and quality.You will find one of the best collection, if not the best, of post-impresionist pictures (Matisse 's La Dance, for example).It's very cheap (and free if you are student), with free wifi and app, and it's allow to take pictures.You will need at leat one complete day there.

Must See. There is so much to see in the Heritage Museum. You can onlysee a part. Each guide has a route to take and you have to keepup with your group. Everything is very rich. It's hard to absorbeverything as your mind can get a bit overloaded. The good thingabout going on a tour is that everything is attended to. time of entry , prices etc. Definitely a must see if you go to St Petersburgh.
Going Back inTime. The beauty and history is beyond what I expected. Our tour guide was wonderful and gave us a great education. There really was anything we disliked except lines.

A magnificent palace complex that would take days toexplre. Even if you might only have a couple of hours to explore the complex of palaces, don't dispare. You will see beauty and grandeur, the likes that the world has not produced since, and rest assure, you will want to come back to explore and learn more about the Czars and their palaces.

A must see in St. Petersburg. Magnificent art collections, stunning classical antiquities, and jewelries. It's a must see in St. Petersburg. You will need lots of time to see everything, one full day at least. It's very crowded, so it's hard to take your time and admire all the details. A special tour is recommended if it's possible; you will get see the palace before its opening time accompanied by a knowledgeable guide. It's well worth the cost.

Amazing Venue and Collection. It is the must see site of the city but the crowds a huge. The entry is timed for groups. You will need to allow a lot of time to see everything.The Palace is worth a visit even without the extensive art collection.
have to go. You cant imagine the beauty and extravagance inside these buildings. its something you will never see again in such abundance

Amazing collection, terrible presentation. This is one of the largest collection in the world of art in all its physical forms: paintings, sculptures, porcelains, etc. Everything. Amazing. However, its not well presented. Lighting is very bad and there is so much of it, its difficult to focus on what you is most important. Modern museum in the rest of the word, have changed difficult to make then more user friendly. Not here. For example, the Rembrandt collection -- the best in the world -- is amazing, but the lighting is terrible and difficult to see.
The Hermitage. I had no idea this museum would be as fantastic as it is. Such an amazing place. We loved our tour. A trip to St. Petersburg must include a visit to The Hermitage.

Another must see. It is hard to believe the opulence of the Winter Palace and Hermitage until you see it. Despite crowds, the connected buildings of the Winter Palace and Hermitage were so large in scale and beauty, it didn't detract from the experience. You can't see it all in one day, our tour guide led us on a "good taste of the Hermitage" and added in some things we wanted to see.

A story of art, greed and richness. TripAdvisor The HermitageHow can I say this? Simply a site not to miss, art lover, enthusiast or being draged by the wife. This is a course in history, art is the frontal subject while greed, prepotence, abuse of power, class supremacy are the underlying subject . It is also about beauty, opulence and wealth, the nobles and the proletariat. About classes.Get ready to walk but while you do that, imagine yourself living there with your three children while people outside lacked the basics.Yes, there are very special works of art but I could not get over the buildings and the luxury attached to them.If you have made it to St. Petersburg, then this is the site to visit, there is nothing to compare anywhere in the world. You will like it, for whatever reason.Those who rank this site avg or below need to check their cultural level. You do not have to be an art enthusiast to be impressed or shaken by all that happen here.Wear gooood walking shoes

the most beautiful museum I have ever visited.. I could ve spent two days wandering the rooms. The Hermitage is colossal, pristine and the art work is jaw dropping. No museum can compare. The beauty of the Winter Palace as a setting for all of the art work was brilliant.

Simply impressive !. Alongside the Louvre and British Museum, the Hermitage boasts one of the biggest collections in the world with more than 3 million objects ! Here's something to see for whatever your preferences are. Mine are with paintings - especially the impressionists - and what a reward to come here !! Seldom you find so many great names in the same place - it was an adventure walking around in these magnificent palace gallery rooms to enjoy all this wonderful works of art !Make sure to take your time with the exhibitions you prioritize, with no need to rush from room to room, you will never be able to see it all anyway.A piece of advice : Buy your entrance tickets upfront on the internet and collect them at the main entrance to pass the ticket waiting line - which can be very long....

You must go to the Hermitage. Spent the afternoon at the Hermitage, there's so much art and history, you can't miss going here. The presentation and commentary are excellent, and you get a real feel for the history of St Petersburg

Well worth the trip!. Our first big highlight of the trip. This place is as fascinating as the louvre which I love dearly. Could have spent entire days wandering the corridors exploring all the artwork and relics. It's great to get to see such masterpieces in an atmosphere that still feels a lot more comfortable and less structured than most western art museums. A refreshing change! Also there is a temporary exhibit on with some of the last royal family's clothes and they are all perfect examples of great craftsmanship and good preservation. Some of the ball gowns are very modern and stunning in shades of black and red whilst there were some cute additions like the little leather boots some of the boys in the family wore and their tiny replica rifles. Also the Picasso gallery was quieter than any other gallery of it's type I've ever seen and it's lovely to be able to take photos of such classic masterpieces for memories (as I've been to quite a few places where it's no photos allowed whatsoever). Beautiful palace - wear comfy shoes though as you will want to be on your feet all day checking out all the things on display!!!
Treasures of the Tsars. We enjoyed the paintings of the masters...and all in one fabulous museum. The silver service exposition was unbelievable; Today you would pay millions for such luxury!

Rich heritage, too much of an art show. As you get pushed by bus load and bus load of tourists clicking photos behind you, you shuffle slowly thru this elegant piece of Russian history. Watch the pick pockets! Read about this place before coming, The artwork is something to see. But after room after room, it gets a bit much. The rooms are beautiful, the chandeliers, paintings on the ceilings superb. Look at the special pieces and ornaments. The architecture and furniture neat. Make sure you get upstairs to see the Van Gogh and other masters work. Get your souvenirs here as they are better priced then the tour operator locations you will be taken to, with much made in Taiwan. Also PAY by credit card, which will be in roubles, as the pan handlers want US dollars and euros to over pay.
A must. The Hermitage is a combination of Versailles and Le louvre. A must when in St Petersburg. A tip; book in advance to avoid possible long queues
Simply the best museum in the world. That's it!. the title says everything.....don't miss the visithave plenty of timethousands of pictures from all of the renowned artists!!!

Huge . Apart from the huge collections of European art, two points really struck me:1. As a Russian, it was the first time I've ever been so close to the imperial part of my history, and I must say it struck a chord :) Several rooms have been restored to the way they were in the 18-19th centuries, and you can imagine how magnificent the palace of an emperor looks like. 2. There's a very very interesting collection of Central Asian and Siberian art mainly covering two periods: the first states (very broadly around 500BC) and the Mongolian empire (13-15 centuries). If you in any bit take interest in those regions, I suggest you have a look. It's on the ground floor.

Another must- see place. My husband and I visited with a private tour guide. The private guide is essential to navigate the lines, crowds and to see what you need to see. Everyone knows you can spend years seeing everything in this magnificent place, but you can hit some important must-sees with a guide. The art collection parallels any other major world museum with works by the Old Masters, Impressionists, etc. the State Rooms are also amazing. We saw a temporary exhibit of clothing worn by tsars and tsarinas and other nobility. Quite interesting. This is my second visit and I would go here every chance I get to go to St. Petersburg.

This palace/museum is huge - great visit but time was to short to see everything.. This was part of our SPB Tours in St. Petersburg, Russia. You see these places in pictures but nothing can compare to see these places in real time. Unbeliveable...This palace/museum is huge - great visit but time was to short to see everything. Thanks to our SPB tours, we got an early entrance and our tour guide directed us around and explained what we were seeing. it is difficult to retain all these facts for a first time visitor, This museum is huge and you could spend days exploring the rooms that are open to the public.
Breath-taking. We were lucky enough to go when it was not too crowded. The collections and building were simply awe-inspiring. Be wary of pickpockets, including vendors outside who may work as teams

It's THE Hermitage. Some of the most spectacular art on the planet, to rival the Louvre, the Met, the Vatican etc. it is a must see while in St. Petersburg. Most people probably would not want to spend all day there, but it definitely warrants a guide and the fee for early admission to beat some of the crowds.Russia surprises me, none of their sites are climate controlled, and I wonder how long the art will survive with the extreme heat, cold and humidity.

Saw much but not enough. My cousins and I had a very good tour guide ( just the six of us) we spent a day in St. Petersburg enough to see the city but not enough to emerge from the Hermitage content. We saw all the important pieces of art, thanks to our wonderful informative guide!

Marvellous museum of world class standard. Such a wealth of paintings from well known artists and from those known to the Russian hierarchy. Well worth a visit. I will return at sometime in the future.

Visitors need more information. In my opinion visitors in Hermitage Museum need more information about different rooms, different itineraries and buildings.Before my visit to Hermitage I explored the website and the virtual tour they recommended. I selected about 25 different rooms, from different periods and styles, and I writed them down in order not to get lost.But at the entrance, the staff to whom I showed the museum map even did'nt know where were we situaded when they looked at the map. The same with several people from the staff we asked during our tour.I missed Kandinsky and the russian avantgardes. And I was obliged to go through the romans and egiptians.I tried to do at my own, following my interest, and I found myself following the crouds.Dear managers of Hermitage Museum, you wont loose visitors, I know, you have one of the best museums in the world, but if you want to offer a good experience, lets each visitor decide their tour according their criteria and interests. They will be happier and no so tired at the end of the visit.Please, provide good maps with updated info and tell your staff to learn a little more about your museum. And more information about how to get in other buildings and what to find there.You have a piece of gold, let us enjoy it.Thank you!

A day isn't enough time to get round all of the artwork.. This is about 4 galleries/museums under one roof, so there is a lot to see! Stopped here on a guided tour for ONLY 90 minutes. Not enough time. Plan a whole day here if you have time, and like art. There is so much to see that you won't get a good look around otherwise. I'd advise you to go at a time when the coach tours from the cruise ships are not there, as they are brought round by a guide who takes them to individual pieces which they all crowd round, climbing over each other to catch a glimpse of a masterpiece, such as Da Vinci, Michelangelo, and Rembrandt (to name a few). Check out the golden mechanical clock!

All the art in one place. Even if you are not a big fan of art you MUST go and visit this place. With more than 3 million art pieces, Hermitage stands as the most prestigious and rich art museum in our times. In terms of paintings you can find a rich collection of paintings from Rembrandt, Renoir, Gaugim , Matisse, Da vinci... The place and the rooms on their own are a piece of art besides the paintings they contain. Other rooms contains art from around the world (china, middle east ...) In the lower part there is a hall that displays the costumes from the tsar era. Note that you are not allowed to carry on water bottles, and if you have a jacket try to wear it (but not hold it) , since it makes entrance procedures harder.

Excellent. This is one of the highlights of visiting St Petersburg and it is everything and more than you could ask for in museum. As well as the museum it has one of the largest Art collection in the world

Unbelievable. From its setting on the Neva River to the great plaza at the side it was amazing. The magnificent interior, the art work, the displays were beyond belief. Our guide made sure we saw everything.

Simply must. If you come to this city and don't visit this Museum, you are a disgrace to humanity. Its a stunning mixture of state rooms of the Romanovs in all their splendour juxtaposed with art galleries dotted with Dutch masters, Renaissance masterpieces, vast swathes of impressionist art amongst everything else. For anyone who wants to really take it in I would recommend taking your time and doing it over two days as their is so much to see. I have never seen so many people casually walk by works by Bernini, Canova, Rodin or even Michelangelo as I did when I visited simply because they were rushing to see the 'big' attractions. It is a wonderful place to get lost in (there are hundreds of rooms, its easy to lose your way), its simply enchanting.

Russian but not rushing crowds.. This is an enormous, crowded, world class museum with far more than you could comfortably see in one day. BUT it is, and should be, on most people's bucket list. For me, the more interesting part of The Hermitage was the separate storage facility in a separate 'behind the scenes' Viking tour.

One of the best museums in the world. Make sure to make a list of what you want to see, as it it so large, you would need at least a week to see everything. The staff in the museum are unhelpful and do not speak any other language than Russian, so don't expect anyone to help you. Entrance is free for students. If you have children, you can rent a costume from one of the stalls located in front of museum and take pictures/have them taken.

Amazing!. This is a must see in St Petersburg -- there would never be enough time to spend in this amazing place. Pick and choose the specific areas to visit and not rush through -- read in advance all there is to see here.

Amazing. When you hear it rivals the Louvre they are not mistaken. I have now been to both and recommend both. They each have such unique pieces of art and history that they must both be on your bucket list. My family and I cannot spend hours starting at one painting or sculpture and are in no means experts but the shear mass of the collections ensures there’s something for everyone. Highly recommend.
Beautiful Museum. The peacock clock is quite unique. The architecture of each room is really beautiful. My favorite was the Flemish Paintings of the market 'departments'.

Well worth the visit. Don't skip this. The richly decorated palace rooms, as well as the antiques collection and the impressionists paintings all speak for themselves. Even with multiple days of visiting, you can still find new things in here.

best of all, better than the louvre and the prado. Not only is is a world class art museum, but the art is better displayed than the great ones in Paris and Madrid. The rooms themselves are works of art, and then the collection is amazing. The Tsars left a great legacy

One of the best museums in the world.. Plan to spend extra time, mid day has a bit less crowds because morning tour groups hve left and afternoon haven't arrived. Guide is a must, lots of subtlety will be lost without guide. And check your coat, the palace is warm to hot (check is free). See the web for a list of what is there.

Get there early!. The Hermitage opens at 10am so make sure you are there and in line by then as the queues (even in August) move slowly. Quick tip - you can queue both on the left and the right of the central garden area once you pass through the gates from the main square. Recommend buying the extra ticket to the gold rooms (from the ticket office inside when you get your entrance ticket) and also suggest you buy the 'Hermitage in an hour' book. It will keep you focused on the key things to see (still took me 4 hours!) and give you the route around the rooms. Don't take in a backpack (even small), they will make you put it in cloakroom. Over one shoulder bags (regardless of size) were fine.

The Big Art Gallery. The Hermitage may be over-rated and crowded but go. Choose what you wish to see beforehand, certain galleries will be of interest to you, not all. You can go without a guide, or pay for one from a tour agency. p.s. they will not let you out of gate back to restrooms or snacks so plan for it.
Beautiful even in the rain. It was not a nice day to stand in VERY long lines, but it was worth the wait. A must see while in St. Petersburg. The crowds were absolutely horrible inside.
Hermitage. Its a wonderful experience. You can spend there the whole week. Do not forget to inspect also the ground floor, a lot of interesting there.
One of the best museums. Like: excellent collection. Dislike: a little bit crowded; could be hard to find your route (but not impossible).

Go to see the Winter Palace. Beware if you're in a wheelchair.. A must see, of course, but I advise focusing your time in the Winter Palace building. The architecture, the sheer grandeur, is breathtaking. The awe factor of the other buildings, architecturally speaking, goes down, way down, from jawdroppingly fabulous in the Winter Palace to buildings that have no decoration, that are humdrum, walls that are as plain as your bedroom at home. If you have only a few hours to spend, there is no question, stay in the Winter Palace - see what is Russian. The art that is housed throughout The Hermitage is obviously world class, but there is no doubt in my mind that if you are an international traveler visiting The Hermitage, you already know art - you've been to The Met, to the Louvre, to the British Museum - you know Monet from Manet, Rembrandt from Renoir. The great art museum near your home has pieces from the masters, but it does not have the Winter Palace. Focus all of your attention there, unless there is a particular masterpiece that you must see - Rembrandt's 'Return of the Prodigal Son' comes to mind, pretty fabulous to see that in the flesh, most definitely. So, do your research online, decide what pieces you must see first hand, and after that, focus on the Winter Palace building itself. You will save yourself loads of grief. This place is MOBBED, the most crazed sea of humanity I have ever experienced, as horrific as the Vatican Museum, the Sistine Chapel - we are talking insane numbers of people. You will have palpitations, you will feel faint, you will break out in a cold sweat - mobs of tourists! So go, but plan your visit wisely. Research the heck out of The Hermitage before you go. Have a game plan. Do not wander aimlessly, it is just too big, and you will waste your time. A final note, if you are wheelchair bound, you won't see a thing (I know). Your view is blocked by all of the people since your vantage point is low and no one cares about you - no one steps aside to give you a view of the paintings. They want to see for themselves and the crowd mentality prevails, survival of the fittest, which isn't you. Not to mention the oddly placed elevators. Go with someone who can aggressively make way for you or grow a thick skin with a loud voice. It's a beautiful place, but the crowds are suffocating and seriously detract from the overall experience.

Excellent - get a guide though !. Classic museum - where you can get overwhelmed very easily. Avoid the queue to get an entry ticket by purchasing one from the automatic machines on your left as you enter the courtyard. Have a guide who will make sure you don't miss the art classics by da Vinci, Picasso etc (some if which is never loaned out as the Russians sort of acquired them during the fall of Germany after WW2 - says the guide!)

If you are a museum hound, you're going to love this!. Today, I toured the Hermitage in St. Petersburg and I am still reeling in the vast abundance of history! It is not impossible to see it all..you just need a whole bunch of inner energy, good walking shoes, a full understanding you will go up and down stairs, and expect crowds. We went on a Tuesday, the kids were back in school and the place was packed. Don't bring knapsacks, and keep yourself safe from pick pockets! That said, you will find this place totally awesome! We had a Russian historical guide...I was a River cruise...who trail blazed us through rooms so grand, so opulent, so customized with specific exhibits. First, were Royal Russian czar and wealthy families dresses and men's clothes full of customized brocades, beadings, feathers..women with 17 inch waists and tiny, brilliant shoes. We moved to brilliant columns and ceilings you can only look up with dropped jaws! Gold leaf as far as your eyes can see, marble and malachite, ebony furniture a from the late 1800s thru early 20th century. Amazing if you are decorator or just appreciate the finest in decor! Keep going to the European Impressionists..Cezanne, Renoir, Van Gough, Gaugain...visit walls of Rubins, Picassos..hosts of cubinsists amongst the old masters. Be prepared for an amazing Egyptian and Greece exhibits. There is a limited place to eat. Once in, you can not reenter with purchasing a new entrance pass.Give yourself the time and if you have few days to visit, go back. Google the site. I plan on buying some fabulous books on this place when I get home. Too much great information and the pictures tell the story!

You just can't see them all :(. l have seen Louvre Museum before but never ever in my life l felt that tired because l didn't wanna miss a single item in there. But I've been told it was IMPOSSIBLE unless l stay in St. Petersburg for at least a year:) Huge museum, more than 1000 rooms filled with work of art, such as paintings by most famous painters, statues, interesting items etc...You should give a full day to this visit - considering you'll be very tired - but if you ask me start with the 3rd floor where most of the famous paintings are displayed but if you are a Leonardo Da Vinci's fan stick to the 2nd floor. Every single section is being monitored by old Russian ladies, so be careful, do not cross the red line or touch the works of art. I have seen a very young boy being scolded :)

An afternoon visit. We were so put off by the TA reviews of huge long queues and queue-jumping that we didn't schedule a long visit here during our time in StP. However we thought we'd take a chance and visit later in the day, thinking that perhaps the crowds would have cleared out. We were right. By 3:30pm the queues were gone, the cruise passengers away, and we went directly to the cash desk to buy tickets. There were still a lot of people mulling around, but it never felt claustrophobic. The downside, of course, is that there is so much to see here that a 2.5 hour visit is just not sufficient to do it justice. We didn't even visit the top floor, for instance. Note that when going in you have to go through a metal detector. They won't let you bring in liquids and I had to leave my pocket knife too. That caused a slight delay as I had to rush to the cloak room.We focused on the 1st floor state rooms, which was a good choice. The first floor is a good choice if limited on time.

Boring!!. I do know a bit amount art but this was just too much.Picture after picture after picture after picture - you get the................picture!We visited as part of a cruise in July. The rooms were very busy and very warm and the unfortunate thing.... You are not allowed to take bottles of water in with you so be prepared to dehydrate!
Awe inspiring. The wealth and beauty are unbelievable. Lots of walking. No air conditioning. Ambassador's staircase exquisite. Plan to spend some time.

Amazing !!!. Hermitage is truely a unique experience to all travelers.The museum opens at 10 oclock. There was a long queue but Luckily We bought our tickets online. So we did not wait and got wet in the rain. We had only one day in the museum which was not inevitable enough. Especially I am quite impressed with Winter Palace. Amazing.....I will be back and spend more time in this gorgeous place. Highly recommended.

Stunning Collections and Palace Buildings. The Hermitage is truly a world-class collection, or more accurately, series of collections.Even a person not particularly motivated to visit museums and galleries etc cannot fail to be impressed by the stunning, almost endless collections of priceless items.One could easily spend several days, focussing on specific collections. There are rooms dedicated to specific artists (one room contains 27 Rembrandt works!) and at every step of every room or gallery there is another super item.I would highly recommend The Hermitage. If you have a particular interest in fine arts and antiquities, you should plan to spend a full day here. If your interest is a bit more casual, a couple of hours will give you a whistle-stop visit that no-one should miss.

Our second favourite sight in St Petersburg.. The sheer volume of artistic artefacts is just stunning! Room after room of pictures, sculpture and of course architecture to appreciate. My only concern was the sheer volume of visitors which limited one's ability to contemplate and appreciate the art on display.

Visit. This was the most unspoilt , wonderful place packed with so much something that sticks in my mind is the beautiful tiras and precious stones and. An amazing long boat made from ancient tree . The treasures in this palace are outstanding. You need few days at least as your want go,back for more .
The Hermitage. a very beautiful and vast museum. it takes 12 years to see everything in it but we only spent 3 hours!!!louvre is more beautiful by the way

Celebrity Constellation Baltic Cruise. We had an excellent time visiting the Hermitage Museum in St Petersburg Russia in August. Our Celebrity excursion visit took place in the morning and even then it was very crowded but well worth it. We spent two day in St Petersburg and as a whole it is an amazing city to visit.

So much to see,so little time. Catherine the Great's Winter Palace combined with other buildings make up this beautiful museum on the Neva River. It is best to go with a tour, as the individual wait can be hours. you must come with a plan, else the museum becomes overwhelming. We chose the rooms of the Winter Palace and the excellent paintings from the Italian greats to the Dutch masters.After spending about 2 1/2 hours it became a little tedious. You can't see everything in a day. As other reviewers have written, you must see the peacock clock. Truly amazing.

Speechless. The Hermitage is mind numbingly beautiful but the crowds make it a little difficult to appreciate.an experienced guide is a must as there is no hope of finding your way around otherwise. This is the show piece of a truly beautiful city .

Absolutely Amazing. Everything you've heard is true. The Hermitage is a must see and well worth the time. Truly amazing.It is always busy so be prepared for crowds. It is usually quieter if you get there as early as possible in the morning.

Must see - preferably when the place is not too crowded. Visiting a museum in St-Petersburg is an event. If only to get in. Even though we had bought are tickets before leaving for the city of Peter the Great. Going back and forth to get tickets inspected, exchanged for entrance tickets, cloakroom, etc ... Don't expect to enter the museum in just a few minutes! And in front of nearly each masterpiece: hundreds of people, listening to a guide, trying to take a photograph, pushing people away ... But both the collection and the architecture certainly do make it worth a while visiting!

One of the top museums in the world. Catherine the Great was an avid art collector, the collection in the Hermitage is just amazing. Probably a visit of around 3 hours is enough, any longer and you feel phased out. It's a beautiful building, you need to plan your visit carefully to focus on specific areas.

The Louvre- Russian style!. Brilliant collection in a 4 building museum that was purpose built - palace meets museum. Massive so bring good shoes! D'avinci, the impressionists, Rembrandt, all the greats in one place. I would go back as it happened all too quick! Most phenomenal piece was a gift to Elizabeth 1 (I think). It's a Peacock clock that is life sized that is activated by all the little pieces attached ie. dragon flies and other pieces and each works separately and animates the bird....gold leafed, in a cage...phenomenal.

great museum. The sheer size of this museum is astonishing and the amount of art present impressive. Especially the no. of Rembrants and the imprssionists were a great surprise. The interior were opulent and great to see as well

15 out of 10!. We thought we'd have a late afternoon look as we weren't too keen on all the art stuff. But wow! We did the second floor which is the state apartments with a couple of stunning staircases plus the rembrandts and the Leondardo Da Vincis thrown in. Fantastic. Spent a couple of hours there and came aware satisfied and not bored by it all.
gorgeous art. A guided tour was most helpful to showcase the best art and the history of it all. The building is beautiful and it helps to get in early when you go a a tour group.

Museum Visit in a wheelchair. This was definitely on my bucket list. This visit was part of a tour for wheelchair users offered by Liberty Travel. We entered with no wait with our guide. There is a wheelchair accessible toilet on the first floor. We made it to the second floor via elevator with no problem, but the elevator to the third floor was out of commission with no promise of when it would be working again. (Museum Staff didn't seem to want to follow up). The visit was still incredible. I highly recommend a guide just to deal with the logistics and the crowds. We were fortunate that it wasn't as busy when we were there. I'm told by many people who went via a cruise you only get a glimpse of the major paintings. The Hermitage always has special exhibits-it was costumes when we were there. I think my favorite was the peacock clock.

Art&sandwiches. Spent two days here seeing as much as possible- weeks would be needed to see all. The sandwich grap spots are very small ( while the empty staff room is large) so it was a blessing that all taking a break helped with sharing tables and chairs. Contemporary art presentation of Matisse/Kandinsky was great, one must remember to take first and second day tickets as the scanner in the contemporary doesn't recognize tickets. Very helpful and polite personnel at all locations.

Incredible Art Collection!. OK! The title states the obvious, but it is beyond imagining. The wealth and range of the artefacts is beyond belief. The fact that you can get your nose right up to a Titian/Gogh or whatever and pore over the strokes is wonderful. The lighting isn't great and we were there over two bright days (wear trainers it is a serious expedition!) consequently there was a lot of sun coming through windows and little air-conditioning (rather surprisingly). One had to move around a fair bit to get an ideal view (cancelling reflections) of some/most paintings. The palace that houses all this is well, exquisite, and on a larger scale than I could have possibly expected. We walked miles both days, enjoying every incredibly ornate ceiling, painting, sculpture, at every turn more beauty tempted and met the eye. Absolutely wonderful. One word of advice: "Don't go outside for a moment, let alone lunch - they won't let you back in! Single entry tickets. Go and be amazed!

The must see attraction in St Petersburg. The Hermitage is one of the largest museums in the world.With that in mind, a guided tour should be seriously considered to get the most out of it. Apparently it would take eight to eleven years to see everything so you'll want to see the highlights. As it gets very busy some rooms can get very warm, and you are not allowed to take water in to drink. The paintings on display cover a wide range of periods with many by the masters such as Michael Angelo and Rembrand.No trip to St Petersburg is complete without a visit.

Magnificent Museum. A very brief visit of only two hours was to short to explore all art. There was a large staircase with gold trimmings everywhere. Magnificent rooms and the art gallery with paintings from the whole world. Interesting to see the Rembrandt paintings and of course it was a great experience to see DaVinci and Michelangelo in real life. I would like to go back and stay longer next time. I think it is better in the winter because now it was to many people and you had to queue in front of every famous painting.

So much to see like the Louve. We spend 1/2 day here and bairly scratched the surface. So much art to see. We will definitely come back and see much more next time. We just hit the highlights this time and focused on the rooms with the masters. The museum is in the Romanov's Winter Palace. Photos outside are a must.

Go for the tsar treasures, not the art. Yes, this has the largest museum collection in the world with much-trumpeted works of Matisse and other masters which you can only see here but that's not really what stands out about the Hermitage or why people come here. It's not the art, it's the preserved memory of the tsarist era with all its glamour and pathos - so it's the entrance staircase and the Throne rooms that are probably of most note + the diamond treasuries (separate tickets, make sure you get those from your concierge). An obvious must-see for a first-time visitor.

One of the most inspiring museum I've ever been. The Hermitage is definitely a must to see if you get the chance to visit the beautiful and cultural city of St Petersburg. You need a lots of time because i couldn't even myself visit all the place in one day so i will back there sometimes. The city is one of my favorite as well. Nothing to compare with Moscow or any other cities in Russia, the St Petersbourgeois are different, educated and helpful.

Where do you start?. Unusual method of entry - you can buy tickets at automatic booths and then walk past the queues and enter - the queues appear to be for those wanting to pay cash (I think).
