Once inside take a floor plan guide and decide want you want to see and go for it - the floors are fantastic and the art on show stunning, the gold room was special. Very busy.

Full of Tourists and Crowds. At the outset let me just say that I consider these kinds of museums as dead places that have nothing to do with the present moment which is where I live. They are suffocating with trapped energy made worse by the teeming crowds and hordes of people (increasingly the Chinese) who have no interest or appreciation in the art or the treasure, but merely to click away pictures. They also serve to provide livelihood to the hundreds of guides that accompany these tourists. It is on the must see list, and unfortunately I fell for it too!The place is huge like the Met in NYC and the British Museum in London and the Louvre in Paris. Avoid the New Hermitage at all cost, and save your time and energy. It is depressing with poor lighting, and even though it is much less crowded than the main complex, it is quite boring.

Fantastic! But dispersive.... The Hermitage is fantastic, but it would help to have more indications for the visitors who do not have a guide... It's very dispersive, with a massive series of rooms running in parallel. I realized ex post that I missed several of the best pieces of the museum. Also, in some rooms or on some items, there are no English language descriptions, which is very bad for such a famous museum

You need plenty of time. The Hermitage is an amazing museum of art from around the world. The museum is in the Romanov's Winter Palace and it is absolutely lovely. In order to fully enjoy this museum, plan on spending a few hours. And maybe a 2nd visit. There is a great gift shop and a cafe also in case you get hungry.
Hermitage Museum. Every room was filled with countless wonders. Beautiful architecture and history combined to enhance your new knowledge of Russia.

Busy but awe inspiring. A very brief visit of only two hours did not do justice to this magnificent museum and art gallery of originals.The first experience of going up the large staircase with gold trimmings everywhere just gets better and better as you move through the different rooms. Eventually, sad to say, it becomes "culture overload" on one visit and when you realise that several more visits are required. On our afternoon visit, it was quite crowded - think that's the same no matter when - and there can be a bit of jostling and sometimes rude shoving past (by a certain part of the human race that will remain nameless but you will know them when you see them). Also can get quite warm but few places to sit down. The museum staff are everywhere - no leaning on walls or taking sips of bottled water close to the works of art. One piece was severely damaged awhile ago by some lunatic who threw acid at the painting so one can understand the staffs' anxieties.No photographs or videos allowed unless you have a "camera licence" which is around 5 Euros apiece. With that, you can snap away happily.Magnificent place but plan ahead if you can and choose what you want to see.

Loved the art work. Not a great fan of big art museums but this is an impressive place with virtually all the great artists represented. Crowds huge and if you pay for it best to go with a private guide and get in early. Can see most things without being pushed out of the way!

Not to be missed if in St Petersburg. We were on a cruise and this was part of a tour. Luckily we were first through the doors as soon as the museum opened so this was a big bonus.Even if you are not into art this museum is not to be missed. Our guide told us if you stopped at every painting for 1 minute it would take you 11 years to see everyone. The main hall is fantastic with a great staircase leading up to the first floor. Not many museums allow you to get up close to the paintings from artists such as Rembrandt and Van Gogh. We did not see every room but what we saw was fantastic.Be mindful of pick pockets wherever you are in St Petersburg and we were told that a gentleman had his wallet stolen while in the Hermitage.

Outstanding Museum.. A dream come true! If you go in summer time, get prepared to HUGE línes, even if you buy your ticket by internet ( 19€ for one day or 29€ for two days; closed on mondays , they OPEn at 10:30 and close at 18:00). If you go by yourself, try to find someone of the staff members: they will HELP you skip the second long línes of guided tours to get to the main entrance. Get your audio guide on second floor ( shorter line than on first floor, costs aprox. 10€ and they ask your passport) I loved Rembrandt's colection: " The lParabole of the Lost Son " is as visited as is Mona Lisa at The Louvre. So many other beautiful colections : Murillo, Raphael,etc. ...only a few Gaingsbourough or Fragonard's.... The halls and corridors with exquisite and opulent decoration. Don' t miss th e zar, zarinas and princess costume's room: is gorgeous! Food store small and far from the halls.

History within history. This is a fantastic museum. Unfortunately we only had a few hours to spend inside. The collection is extensive and it is of the great museums in the world. Whether you appreciate art or history this is a must see. Even if you don't I recommend going. The crowds were a bit much. I would recommend a self guided tour. It is impossible to see everything they have in less than a week, let alone a few hours. Check it out online and choose the exhibits you want.
Baltic cruise stop. Excellent place to visit but is very hot and busy. Take time to see the art masters if you can squash through the crowds.

trip back in time.... take good running shoes, start on the 2 level, work your way down and pick sections of interest before you go everywhere, but the Matisse is not there anymore and no one tells you before, you just find a little sign in the room it was suppose to be, that it has been moved to another building opposite the Eremitage. The girls in the shopping corner on the 2 level are fun talking too and they have tasty jewelry and art items, worth to take a look at, but after 4 hours i couldn't take in any more information and needed fresh air and some water…great place…worth coming back to see more.Security does not smile...

Very nice collection. Not the Louvre, but definitely worth a look. Raphaels especially great. Post impressionist and pre-Renaisssance a little weak. But whatever you do, try to go in the afternoon in the summertime. The morning is an insane "mosh pit" with all of the tour boats and groups trying to get in. It's a pick pocket's paradise in the mornings. Hard to appreciate the art w pushy people trying to get photos of the art.

Too much to view too little time. You need a week to explore this place it is so huge, the paintings are amazing, great costume display, gold everywhere, decoration beautiful, corridors based on the Uffizzi in Florence. It is just an amazing place.Disliked too many people, air temperature in the museum is not good, many of these artefacts will be destroyed unless they are looked after more rigorously.

Hermitage. The number of priceless paintings and collections in this museum are unbelievable. the winter palace has been restored to reflect the opulence of it's time. Should not miss seeing the Hermitage when in St Petersburg.

Breathtaking. Visited the Hermitage and Winter Palace as part of an excursion from our cruise in August. Words cannot start to describe this wonderful piece of architecture with its vast and wonderful collection of arts. Quite breathtaking indeed. It's a must see!! Don't know how busy it is all year round but certainly very busy when we visited in August. We had an excellent guide who seemed to know everything about everything!! You certainly need more than a few visit to see it all. Excellent!

Amazing and a "must do". First of all, buy tickets on internet to avoid staying in the queue to tickets office for hours. You are buying a voucher which you can instantly (without waiting) exchange to a ticket in d special office at the entrance to the Hermitages. Pay additional 200 Rub for camera permit, it`s worth it. Then enter the museum and No Panic (it will be stuffed with people in the lobby area and groups with guides), take the map and make a plan for what you want to see before you try just wandering through. The art collect is amazing. But it`s not just art to see, the building itself is incredible. Take a small bottle of water with you as you will thirsty very quick and too long to go back to the lobby area to buy some water.

Hermitage. wonderful place, fantastic collection, incredible architecture. . Unfortunately overcrowded with tour groups who only stop to take a selfie in front of something. If you're not taking a picture, but trying to enjoy the work, expect a tap on the shoulder and a request to step aside.

FABULOUS ART. This was a wonderful experience. Wish we had more time to see more. The "GOLD ROOM" was extremely interesting ... artifacts from nomad era and Attila the Hun. It was extremely crowded and we had trouble seeing a few of the paintings but it was still worth the visit. The surroundings are also amazing as it was once the Winter Palace in St. Petersburg

Unbelievable. The sheer amount of famous works held within its walls is truly amazing. You really could never see it all in one day and appreciate everything. As crowded as Russia can be its still spacious inside. (Go early,) My advice, make a plan for what you want to see before you try just wandering through. Otherwise by the time you reach the third floor it gets too crowded and you've already been there for 3 hours. It's huge. Makes the Louvre look like a preschool art class.

Fantastic!!. An absolutely amazing building with an equally incredible interior that is filled with art treasures of all kinds. You will need more than one visit to see it all - and be early to miss the queues.

The place is excellent - but do not go there in August. It was, fortunately, not the first time I visited the Hermitage Museum… because I would not know how fantastic it actually is. I had never seen so many people jammed in to a museum (and I have seen a few around the world) - it was a thoroughly unenjoyable experience! In addition, there is no air-conditioning there, so the thousands of visitors must survive without air in the August heat… Terrible.

Excellent. Spent around 3 hours here today, what a wonderful experience, have never visited anything as good as this, you could spend two days here and not see everything. Wonderful rooms, furniture, pictures, and artefacts every time you move from one room to another you are amazed. It cost us 800 rubbles for 4 of us via a card from our hotel, 200 rubbles to get a camera permit (not sure this was needed) but you can't enter with jackets/coats on.I would aim to spend a day here with a pit stop at the ground floor cafe for lunch.Will post some of the amazing pictures when I get home.
Best Museum. The building itself is a master piece! If you love art, just reserve a two or three days for your visit.

phenomenal breadth and quality but very crowded. We were impressed with the breadth and quality of the collection but also a bit let down. For a given type of art, like the impressionists, it is far behind a Musee d'Orsay. For renaissance art, there are many spots in Italy, Amsterdam and Vienna that have better collections. But no other museum has so many varied collections of this quality. We went with a private guide from Marina Wilson tours and would recommend doing this for the best experience. Normally we don't hire a guide but with over 300 rooms you need help

Overwhelming. It is huge, and somewhat intimidating, but full of beautiful paintings, sculptures, and memorabilia of all kinds. If I had not been on a tour, I would not have known where to start, or what to see. Solo travelers need to research before visiting, and focus the visit on areas most personally meaningful.

Too busy. This is an incredible museum filled with amazing art and historical pieces. Unfortunately the fact that it is just too crowded to see and appreciate what is there is disappointing. You could spend many hours and even days but the throngs just make you want to get out.

Quite a grand museum. This place is so huge that our 2 hour tour only touched on the most visited areas including Winter Palace. The work of art and tapestry were priceless. Go in the morning if possible, no a/c and not as crowded.
Fantastic visit. Wonderful musem and we had a great guide that really helped us through the whole palace in a good way.

Badly managed museum, though great art!. Be aware that this museum is totally overcrowded, to the extent of being claustrophibic, due to the huge crowds and large tour groups which dominate everything but the ground floor. I was frequently prodded and elbowed by overeager tourists needing to photograph everything they saw. The Hermitage really needs to regulate the number of people coming in, particularly tour groups. Unlike museums which have been built to be museums, there is no natural flow to the Hermitage - it is a total maze and I was lost several times. Do your research beforehand to establish what you want to see and be sure to bring your own lunch and water with you. And buy tickets online in advance.

museum. like it so much history there remember pay extra for photo pass there are little old lady's station inside parts of museum watching you for wrongful photos, if there in winter were a t shirt because is so hot in there leave coats jackets at cloak room now is a room got to see

Overwhelming. Hermitage is a huge museum - with many rooms restored to Tsarist levels of "well over the top" opulence. Recommend a guided tour of the gold or diamond treasure collections. The exterior of the buildings have been restored to near-new condition, and are as impressive as any we have seen in London or Paris.

Enormous and amazing collection. This is my second visit here. The collection is vast and very rich. Try to divide your visit to several (2-3) days, and see a different part each day. Use the audio guide! Very informative most of the times. Also, use the help of the staff. They are quite friendly and helpful. I loved the 19th-20th French century collection, the palace exhibits, Rembrandt and the Ancient Egypt section. But, as I said, I wasn't able to visit all the collections and I am sure there are many great ones besides those I have mentioned.

Massive and impressive...but not for a short visit. To be fair, this is a phenomenal museum. Unfortunately, I went there on a shore excursion, actually several, and it is too massive to appreciate in the short time shore excursions spend in the museum. Unfortunately, every shore excursion in St. Petersburg made at least one stop at the Hermitage. Even with the extra stops, I saw only 1% of what the museum has to offer. Like the Louvre in Paris, this is an all day or several days type of place to visit. I do not recommend it as a shore excursion, though I saw no other choices. It is a wonderful museum and one the Russians are rightfully proud of.

One of the best museums in the world. In the Winter Palace, the Stairway and the Palace rooms facing the Neva river on the first floor are not to miss. It is a huge museum with collections of art from several different countries and historical periods. Remarkable paintings from 15-16th century Italian and Dutch artists, and many Impressionists on the second floor: Renoir, Monet, Gauguin, Van Gogh, Matisse...

Wonderful artwork. We should have gone earlier in the day. Lines were long and the museum was too crowded to really enjoy ourselves. The Winter Palace is beautiful and the artwork is amazing. Wish we could have spent more time here.

Do Not Miss. Do not miss the Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace. It is jaw droppingly beautiful. We were on one of those tours and had to rush through it which was really a shame and a regret I have to this day. I visited only once before and really wish to return. The Malachite Room, and all the other rooms (too many to even mention), paintings and masterpieces are a sight to behold.

The Hermitage - Some of the best art in the West. I love art museums. And I've seen some wonderful collections. But I was surprised by how extensive the Hermitage collection is, especially of some of the great French Impressionist works. Notable artists included Picasso, Monet, Cezanne, Titian, Goya, Rembrandt, Rubens, Gainsborough, Gaugin, Van Gogh and many others. The Hermitage is worth a trip to Russia alone.
A must see. It compares to the Louvre as a museum that has to be seen to be believed. This August exhibition of the Romanov's family clothes is in itself worth the visit.

Improvements to make. Of course it is a must-see, it is wonderful and it worths its reputation. But the museum rests on its laurels and doesn't make any effort to improve the tourists' visits :- First of all, it is very hot in the rooms (whereas it was cold outside) and since they forbid bottles of water they could at least sell some, otherwise people may faint or feel dizzy... - Then the museum is a real labyrinth, it is not well explained on the map- The audioguide is useless if you want to discover the Russian collections : nothing is explained about them - The young paymistresses inside the museum are really haughty and contemptuous towards the tourists, a little respect would be significant.If you want to discover Russian paintings, don't miss the Russian Museum, it is beautiful and very interesting.

fast way to enter Hermitage museum. The long raws to get tickets to enter the museum was solved by a ticketing machines but few know about it , internet tickets must also replaced by normal tickets with longest rows . leave the rows enter the outer gates look left get your tickets with multi languages 400 ruble , photo ticket 200 ruble ( but no body ask about it ) pay by your card , move left the long rows inside museum garden , put your ticket on gate reader and go inside
Huge. İt is really huge museum. İt takes you to the old russia and history of the closest countries you sholud spend half of a day

As advertised, one of the best art museums in the world. You should go to St. Petersburg just to see this museum. The huge collection has some of the finest art anywhere, of all kinds. I was especially taken by the Renoirs and Rembrandts (including Rembrandt's "Prodigal Son"). The buildings themselves, from tsarist times, are pieces of art themselves. Be prepared for large crowds and lots of stairs.

The Hermitage in St Petersburg is an awesome museum!. This is something you must see during your lifetime! If you ever go to Northern Europe, you must include this museum. We had a guide so it was easy to see and learn about this museum. I would not suggest going without a guide as it is so big and so much to see. The guide shows you the highlights. It is so much to see however, you cannot see it all. Magnificent!!! So much history!

Just amazing. It is just plain beautiful. The fountains in the lower garden are a must see. We got there with hydrofoils which takes about 40 min. They are pretty easy to find, just behind the Hermitage and cost 450 rubles for students. Could not go in the palace because the queue was just tremendous and you need to get another ticket for 300 rubles (for students). Walked around in the lower garden, it is a beautiful place though could not find the labyrinth that was shown on the signs and noone seemed to know where it was. Left with the marshrutka busses, they cost 60 rubles and take 20 min to get to Avtova station.

Gold and Glitz. A shock and awe fest, so many stunning objects in a unique setting amazingly restored to it's original glory. This was a complete surprise for me, and one can only admire the resources and committment which have been put into the 1st class restoration. The four buildings of the museum contain a vast treasure trove of truly uniique and beatiful objects to rival any public exhibiton in the world.

On of the most impressive museums!. We were lucky to come with a guide and didn't have to wait in lines. All arrangements were made in advance and this is a way to go. Also it's very difficult to arrange a visit to a Golden room, and if you don't book in advance - might be a problem. We got to see this beautiful room along with the rest of this amazing museum. If you want to see everything - you'd need several days. So you have to plan your visit according to the time you have. We were lucky to have the guide who showed us the best highlights taking into consideration our wishes. This is definitely a must visit in St. Petersburg, but I am sure you already know that.

Must see. This is simply a Must see. The museum is huge, so if you do not have endless time it is good to plan in advance what you want to see. If you want to take some pictures for your personal memories you have to purchase a "photo ticket" but it is worth to do so. You can not visit St. Peterburg without visiting this great palace.

Fast track into the Hermitage..... Do not buy your tickets online!! We were in the long line to buy tickets when a person who was onto her way to work in the museum suggested we buy our tickets from the automatic ticket machines. They are on either side as you enter the inner courtyard. This was brilliant because the machines took cash or credit card. This allowed us to skip all queues and go straight into the museum.We put aside a whole day to do what we could. A couple of breaks were require!! Even though we got there early, you can only do so much before the throngs catch up. This museum does not match some of the other wonderful museums, art galleries of the world eg Louvre, Vatican or Uffizi. With one and a half hours to go to closing time, my husband wanted to view the antiquities display, I decided to spend time viewing the marvelous costume display (special exhibition). Many of the amazingly intricate garments were those of Empress Maria Feodorovna.We visited 22/8/14 and I saw a notice mentioning there were 107 days to the 250 year celebration of this museum - just in case you plan to visit about then!!Oh, and enjoy the beautiful rooms too.

Think about the ticket queues. Not to be missed - but can be stiflingly hot in summer and packed with tour groups. If you're not in a group, think about internet ticket booking in advance...you still have to queue up to collect them, but the queues for on-the-day individual tickets can be very long and in the sun.

Amazing and Impressive. Do visit the Winter Palace/Hermitage Museum, you will not regret it. In summers the place can be very crowded with long lines. Taking a private tour with a guide is well worth it as you will bypass the lines and have a knowledgeable running commentary. The collections of the Hermitage are among the finest in the world. This was the former Winter Palace of the Romanovs and as such a historic building in and of itself.
Fascinating. Pure opulence extravagance and beautiful. A must see. The Hermitage museum is incredible I loved every room and there were a lot of rooms to see.

Huge, beautiful, amazing, very crowded. Buy tickets online.. A must-see for every visitor to St. Petersburg - and that makes it very crowded. I'd recommend joining a guided tour, otherwise you'd be lost after 10 minutes. But, if you have plenty of time, getting lost in such a wonderful palace is not a bad thing, isn't it? Do yourself a favor and buy the tickets online in advance (their official website http://www.hermitageshop.org/tickets/) - that will save you a lot of time! The ticket lines could be pretty long during the tourist season (and I'm not even sure if there is such a thing as a "low season" in St. Petersburg).

Beautiful art!. This place is gorgeous, and if you've been to the Louvre in Paris, you will definitely notice the similarity between the two museums - both huge, both located within beautiful palaces, both potentially somewhat confusing to first-time visitors without a tour guide. (To be honest, though, the Hermitage feels a little less organized. The map is slightly harder to decipher than that of the Louvre. In fact, I would say that if you've been to the Louvre, you might be a tiny bit disappointed with the Hermitage. That was how I felt, but I'm not crazy about art, so...) I won't even go on to describe the works of art that are contained within this museum, because there is a such a vast range of them. You'll also definitely want to pay attention to the interior design of the rooms themselves, since they are absolutely magnificent and each has a lot of history to it.As for the technicalities:If you find a good timing for your visit to the Hermitage Museum (i.e. weekdays, early on in the day), you won't have to deal with too much of a crowd. When I went in July 2014, the fees were as follows:Normal entrance: 8-ish euro (400 rubles)If you can provide proof of being a Russian/Belarusian citizen, you pay 1 euro less.Children under 18 and students (must provide student card) go in for free.You are supposed to pay extra to take photographs (4 euro), but honestly, the place is always fairly crowded and nobody bothers to check whether you have the ticket that allows you to photograph. Personally, I didn't pay extra and would just take my phone out occasionally to take a picture or two, and nobody said a thing to me.You'll want to put most of your stuff away into storage, since they don't let you in with large or even medium-sized rucksacks and bags (handbags are an exception, I think).

Hugely impressive!. It is massive and would take forever to see everything so just do what you can!! The rooms are ornate and beautiful. We just visited by ourselves and whilst museums aren't my number one thing to do, I found time running away with itself in here. Before we knew it, we had spent a day there and it was time to leave! Go, you'll enjoy it even if you aren't entirely taken with museums it's interesting to see.

wonderfull for art lovers. Well if you dont see hermitage in russia then you have missed it all ..Grand palce with over 1000 rooms and 7 million artifacts and objects to see .. great for art lovers and people who love history and ancient objects .. need 3 hours minimum if u visit like a tourist only..

Spend a day!. It doesn't take much reading about the State Hermitage to realize you will probably need an entire day to see it. Reviewers are not joking about how much there is to see, but it is totally worth it. Part art museum part palace exhibition you will constantly be jumping back and forth between tour modes. Entry is free on the first Thursday of every month and while the line to get in was long I wouldn't say it was any longer than any other day of the week. Definitely worth waiting to save the cash as tickets can be expensive. If you do plan on going another day of the week I'd recommend buying your tickets online to help skip the long lines. My only other recommendation is to get your fill of water and food before, as they make you throw your water out upon entrance and the prices inside are absurd. Other than that it is an amazing experience and a must do in St. Petersburg!

Exceptional Art and Sticky fingers. Returned recently from a Baltic Cruise. Main reason for going was to see the Hermitage. It didn't disappoint. I was hard pressed to see a famous painter not represented, maybe Signac. Amazing architecture. Amazing wealth. Understandable why the Russian Revolution happened. Same can be said for Catherine's Summer palace. We were fortunate to have a guide who was truly well informed. Others on the same cruise didn't. She informed us not only about the history, starting with Peter The Great down to living behind the "iron curtain" and working for the KGB. The food both days was to say the least very disappointing, and I am not a picky eater, discerning though, but you won't starve. A word of caution, believe everything you hear about pickpockets. They abound. Our guide cautioned us that that they are the best in Europe. On our cruise, one Aussie had her card stolen from the inside pocket of her purse. Within an hour, there was 8K wracked up on their card. This happened on the 2nd floor of the Hermitage, not anywhere near the stores All my pictures of St.Petersburg were taken with one hand. The other was holding on to my wallet inside my pocket. Avoid any kind of crowd, watch for swarming. Don't be tempted by vendors selling books while you are waiting in line. Enjoy yourself, it truly is a feast for the eyes.

DO NOT MISS THIS! Go early!!!. My husband and I hired a private guide through our cruise ship and were the first ones into the Hermitage . We had an unbelievable tour and literally had every astounding room full of objet d'art to ourselves. We'd read that it would be crowded and hot and the wait to get in quite lengthy so finding ourselves in this vast palace turned museum with nary another soul in site was worth the extra money. What an amazing place. We are in awe. Don't miss it and go early!

Spend at least a day here.... And get a tour guide! The history and the breadth of art will astound anyone! 2.4 million pieces of art is quite hard to imagine and obviously not all is on display. Catherine the great really went to town accumulating this collection.

Greatest in the World?. This such a massive museum spread over several buildings, that it would take an age to see everything. The Winter Palace building is awesome, with fantastically ornate ceilings (some ceilings have a 'mirror image' on the floor), much gilding, and wonderful furniture. As for the exhibits - well, take your pick. If you have a particular interest, try to get information beforehand. as it is easy to get sidetracked with so much fine art, paintings, sculptures, porcelain, etc. A truly wonderful, impressive experience. Do not miss the Peacock Clock - a ridiculously impressive piece of British craftsmanship!

Rude staff at the cash desk and not well organised entrance.... You enter the palace court yard and you feel that Russian Empire times...And you imagine how it was here back to 1917, when reds stormed these gates and the building...You go through the doors and realize there is actually several queues there and the chaos, as nobody gets where to go. No signs, nothing to direct you in the right direction. Some russians try to pass without queuing up.The best advise is to book your tickets online and use the cash desk just behind the main gates in the court yard.The museum itself is a palace, so its very rich and nice with lots to see and discover.

Fabulous!. Where to begin? It is overwhelming, on a class with the Louvre in Paris. Just the art itself would be enough reason to visit, but add to it the vast palace itself with its gilded rooms, the alabaster items, the jewelry, etc, etc. An entire day inside is barely enough. If you only have time for one attraction in St. Petersburg, this would be it.

One day is not enough. The Hermitage looks marvellous from the outside and even better inside. Filled with wonderful objets d'art, paintings, exquisite rooms filled so ornate from the painted ceilings all the way down to the splendid floors.A lot of visitors - advise to get there early and go with a good guide to lead you to the important exhibits.

Impressive collection of art. On par with the Louvre and the Vatican. You could spend days in there. It is Western European art though. For Russian art, go to the Russian museum.Recommendation: there are automatic tellers to buy the tickets that allows you to cut queues.
amazing. The museum is absolutely stunning. So many magnificent works. We could spend there several days. You can feel the power of the tsar's time.

You will leave wanting more (time there). There are 3 MILLION exhibits here and there will not be enough time for you to see even a fraction of what this place has to offer. It is only second in size to the Louvre, but highly impressive. You can take your camera in and take photos, but most will come out poor since you cannot use flash and since the lighting on the artwork will cast shadows on your shots. HINT: Use private tours or at a minimum, get the audio guided tour.

Great Museum. Very great and beautiful museum. Don't miss this attraction. its very crowded and little hot inside.the paintings and arts were brilliant. it takes more than one day to visit all parts. full of everything about Russian history and culture. Recommended.

Very good but it needs too much time to see everything. What an amazing place, but to be honest, there is far too much, so you end up having to be selective about what to see. This was one of several stops on our TJ Tours itinerary, but should this be the sort of place your love of art requires you to visit, you would needs days to see enough of it. There is a statistic about requiring several years to see everything even if you spent only a few seconds looking at each item. Some of the rooms are a bit samey, but they have segregated each style, artist etc so with the right guide or map, it is quite easy to target special interests.

Must see, but have a guide. The Hermitage is a wonderful world-class art museum. Anyone visiting St. Petersburg should see it.However it is ENORMOUS. Millions of pieces in hundreds of rooms spread out over seven interconnected buildings each with multiple floors. One could spend months, even years, trying to take it all in. On top of that, the lines for individual tickets can be well over an hour long. This is why I highly recommend taking a group tour with a company that has access to the group entrance. It will save hours of time.The other issue is that the museum does not have climate control. Expect that if there is any sort of crowd it will be hot and stuffy. The museum doesn't allow outside water bottles in either so be hydrated before entering.
Amazing museum. this is the largest museum in the World. Here you can find lots of arts, building is amazing. When you come to Saint-Petersburg you are to visit this place for sure

Want to see great masters under the heavy rays of sun? Go to Hermitage. Totally shocked and overwhelmed! In the summer heat most windows are open and you "enjoy" the great works of legendary artists under the rays of sun, which to my non-professional knowledge is the quickest method of spoiling artwork! Well thank you for a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, because nowhere else in this world one can enjoy Rembrandt and Rubens under the direct sunshine, but, really, this arises a couple of questions - either the museum management is crazy and totally incompetent, or what we saw were not the originals (I personally would prefer the second, otherwise this is a genocide of artwork). No conditioning whatsoever, the smell of sweat is killing, the women sitting in the rooms are looking at their watches every now and then and their gloomy faces are expressing "when is the lunchtime, sick and tired" (though the latter can be true for the whole country - every russian seems to be aggressive and mad at life). The collection was amazing really (but again, were we seeing the originals?). The palace is breathtaking. But... we left angry at the open windows, the hit, the stinking, the angry and aggressive museum staff. At the closing hour we took a sit on the benches in the front yard and heard the loudspeakers announce closing of the museum. Under the impression of the museum staff behaviors and the russian behavioral style in general, we started joking that perhaps now there will come an army of militiamen with dogs to drive the public out. And guess what... several militiamen came out (where were the dogs?) and got the people out of the museum territory. :))) ... Who said soviet union is no more?

Some tips. You should spend here at least 2 days! One is not enough! There are two additional options - gold and brilliant rooms. Choose one you like - they are nearly simillar, excurtion tooks 1,5 hour. Make a note - that if you are Russian then children go free, and the ticket costs 350 roubles instead of 400 roubles,

HUGE place!. We are not fans of art, museums or whatsoever, but ofcourse you need to visit this place. There is a lot of everything. Just few tips I wanted to mention. On every first thursdays of the month its free entrance, but there will be a lot of people then so be ready to spend 1-2 hours queing.And if you want to visit the "gold or diamonds" room, make sure you are there early - be cause after 12PM those are sold out. You will visit those chambers with 10-20 people groups and all the time heavily guarded by security. But its interseting. Enjoy!
Hot Hot Hot.. Try and visit in the cooler parts of the year. The crowds were huge and with very little air-conditioning it was very uncomfortable.
Hard on the feet. The art work and the decor blow your mind, do wear comfortable shoes as you walk miles (5KM) apparently but well worth the effort
wow. It is just like Louvre but better.There are very unique pieces there and the palace itself is just great.you must spends hours or days to see the whole place!

Book on line, and don't miss it!. Go early! If you book on line, and line up at 10am, you will be in soon often opening (10:30am). We felt that the audio guide at 300R was most worthwhile; it fills the gaps in English, and would be essential if you do not speak Russian or English. A tip, to get your ID back, come out the same exit you went in!There are multiple entries, exits, cafés and souvenir shops, so follow your map, or you will soon be disoriented.

Gargantuoulsy beautiful. From the moment that you enter and walk up the opulent stairway, you know this place is something special. Not only is it architecturally beautiful, it is enhanced by the amazing art collection. It is said that if you were to spend a minute admiring each of the approximately 1 MILLION! pieces of art, it would take 8 years to see them all. All of the Masters are represented there and it is delightful to visit. Enjoy!

One of the World's greatest art collections. An amazing collection of art from prehistoric times and through the great masters to the modern. Other museums pride themselves on one or two paintings of great masters whereas you can see whole room-fulls of such paintings. Having watched "The Monument Men" on the flight, it was clear how some of this art was obtained, although apparently the czars and emperors had their buyers throughout Europe. No wonder the peasants lived in poverty. Nonetheless, not to be missed. Special mention needs to be made of the Gold and especially the Diamond Rooms which one can only visit on a tour and photos are not allowed there. Most spectacular snuff boxes one can imagine, as well as the jewel encrusted swords etc. It is amazing that one could go right up to the priceless treasures on the walls. There are too many of them to protect adequately, I suppose. Other museums in Europe also don't allow photography so this is a rare opportunity to just imbibe the art. We spent two full days (we'd bought the two-day ticket) and could have spent more. The Peacock Clock was also a highlight - it is only operated at 7pm on Wednesdays and you need to get there early as it gets crowded.

Heritage of the world in Hermitage. You can not believe that all the things one day have dreamed to see it has gathered here and you have a variety of choices, from paintings to handicrafts.try to completely visit it and it would be better to have in mind that you should spend at least one day for a museum that if you spend 1 minute for each part shown there, it takes you about 11 years!don't miss sections devoted to Egypt and Iran( Although Iran part was closed)if you have elders in your group, its better to bring them a wheelchair to have no trouble.

Highly educational. Having visited the beautiful palace if we were to have the opportunity to go again, I would get there early, book tickets on the internet in advance, choose to have a tour guide, the English one was surprisingly small - 8 people? compared to others of 20/30! We did The Diamond Room, exceptionally beautiful & our tour guide was fabulous! Highly knowledgeable & entertaining.

How can it not be Number 1 must see.... Well worth the time to see the greatest collection of art you can imagine. The whole experience os the buildings and the art is once in a lifetime. What is unbelievable is that the building is not more climate controlled than it is. Priceless art and furniture is almost exposed to all the elements. Windows open and close depending on the guards moods. Humid day when we were there and windows were open although some were shut when it started raining. Dust blowing in at other times. Crazy.

Amazing collection of art. Amazing that photography is allowed in this gorgeous place and to be able to snap a photograph of a Da Vinci is quite rare anywhere else in the world. Although the Chinese don't make it easy with all their pushing and queue jumping. Such a large collection of art it's spell bounding and unique although the number of visitors can spoil the experience. A must see and difficult to avoid.
not to be missed of course. Again, it pays to go with a small private group because the hoards of tourists can be overwhelming. The art work and the rooms are simply breathtaking.

Allow at least 6 hours!. Just go to the kiosks near the entrance and buy the tickets here instead of queuing up. However, you won't get tickets to all the rooms this way, nor will you get free entrance tickets. There are a lot of people entitled to free tickets, which is great if you are one of them. Artists are allowed in for free. Wonderful room full of Roman statues, as well as many Rodin statues interspersed with the French impressionists. There were plenty of seats to sit down on and rest when we went, which was at 10.30 in the morning, when it opened.

Outstanding. We booked a tour with SPB Tours. We had a group of 10 people. Our guide was able to avoid the lines throughout our visit. He was a young, knowledgeable St. Petersburg native. He made the tour an outstanding experience.

Amazing. This museum was the reason we came to St. Petersburg and it did not disappoint. We are on an organized group tour and would highly recommend that you book with a local operator where the groups are much smaller and you have the option of lingering in areas that interest you.The day we were there it was over 40 C and the rooms were stiflingly hot--you had to wonder about the safety of the masterpieces on display.Not to be missed!

Absolutely Stunning!. Honestly, enough can't be said about this place. The art, the displays of carriages, Faberge' Collection, .....if you get a chance to go to St. Petersburg, this is a must see! Get plenty of sleep before you go so you don't miss a thing. When we went through, we had been awake (flying) for over 30 hours so we were all a bit groggy. The things you get to see here are so unique and such an integral part of Russian history you'll be spellbound at every turn.

Must see. I spent almost 2 days in this great museum/palace. impressive. even non-art fans can spend half a day just by walking. I strongly recommend to visit Central Asian Artifacts part (which is mostly skipped by tourists), where artifacts from BC 2000 maybe more, found in Siberia can be seen.
much higher than expected. This place can not be decribed in words by a human been. Wonderfull architecture, huge galerias, unexpected valuable list of pictures and sculptures.
I wanna be the king who lived in Hermitage. There is perfect museum. Russian people are so lucky because of having this kind of museum. I just can say one thing about museum. Perfect!!!

beautiful. Amazing palace and art gallery. Personally, I loved the building and every room had a real wow factor (not so keen on the art) This place is a must see. We were taken there quite early by SPB and saw it before the crowds got there.

Just incredible.. This was part of our tour on Gate 1. It was wonderful. but it is very busy during the summer. With 5 cruise ships in port and many river cruise ships as well in port, the place is packed. Our Gate 1 tour guide did a great job keeping our group together and explaining the many artifacts, paintings and rooms to us. Some many artifacts that if you saw each one for a few minutes, it would take you nine years to see them all. Also when we left, Gate 1 had the bus there, which is so easy. The driver handles the traffic and you sit back and enjoy the sights.

What can I say? A must see in St Petersburg.. Of course this is a must see. Just google it because there are too many exhibits in this massive complex to describe. History, art, etc. Trying to remember if it was Wednesday when fees are waived? Get there very, very early if you want a free entrance. Even if paying I recommend an early arrival.

Peacock Clock a highlight. Ensure that you get a good guide, otherwise you will get lost and waste time. Amazing collections. Wide display of Rembrandt, Picasso, Matisse. Go early and wear comfortable shoes.

Great!!!!!. We come to this amazing museum every time we happen to be in Petersburg. This time we went to see the impressionists and Geinsborough. Fantastic as usual and very special.A tip-there're terminals in the museum yard, to the right from the entrance-don't waste your time in the queues, they're very looooong, buy your tickets in the terminal and be happy. There were very few people at those and veeery many people in the queues. One more thing:the collections are numerius and the museum is huge, so plan beforehand what you want to see to make your visit unforgettable. Otherwise, you risk to turn it into an endless and senseless wandering along the corridors and rooms of the Hermitage. Please don't let anything spoil the impression from this amazing temple of art!

Crowded in July. The Hermitage is located inside the Winter Palace. It houses so many beautiful Russian treasures. Everything is worth seeing but crowds made it very difficult to get around when we were there. Have talked to friends who visited in winter when it isn't as busy and they were able to take their time and explore

So much to see. Amazing amount in the Hermitage and it would take days to see all that there is. If you don't have a guide the queues are horrendous and it is extremely busy. There are lifts if you need them but the stairs are not deep so it is not too difficult to walk up.

#1 in St Petersburg. Everyone knows of it, and all of us aspire to see it in our lifetimes. It does not disappoint! I recommend getting a private guide for a few hours (from your hotel, cruise ship, etc) as it is well worth knowing where to go and see what you are interested most in seeing. A guide will also allow you to enter without queuing in what can be monstrous lines. The most fantastic special clothing exhibition was on when we visited....saw items worn by the Tsars and Tsarinas, the princes and princesses, especially loved that we were able to see those of the last Tsar's and his family. RIP

Utterly Breathtaking - Especially 'The Gold Room'. If possible/practical, seek the support of a knowledgeable and experienced local guide to ensure your visit to this magnificent museum is 'time well spent'. Simply 'wandering' through the museum might result in you 'missing' the best of what The Hermitage has to offer (the museum is huge and suffers the effects of being a tourist 'hot spot' - extremely busy!).We arrived early with our tour guide and were taken to those areas of the museum which were of greatest interest to us - seeing (close-up) the Leonardo's, the unfinished Michelangelo sculpture and works by Canaletto and Caravaggio - stunning. Of course we also saw many other works of art - too numerous to specifically mention.Whilst the spectacular of the Museum's rooms were in themselves, unforgettable, the 'highlight' of our visit was our private party tour of 'The Gold Room' (which required visit pre-booking - made by our local guide) as this area of the museum is jaw-droppingly special and should be planned into your schedule (wherever possible).I can only 'highly recommend' a visit to The Hermitage (even if you are 'not' really into art) as the impression this visit (minimum 3 hours) will imprint in your memory, will undoubtedly be one to treasure!! Enjoy.

there's everything in there!. It offers a rich collection of just about everything, from classic to modern stuff. Definitely a must-see for art buffs. I would recommend at least half a day in there to get a good overview. A full day if you're looking in details.

Must see museum. The Hermitage is definitely the signature mark of St.Petersburg and Russia. I have been more than 10 times, and every visit was something special. The most productive and impressive way to explore the museum is to find a good guide and discuss with her/him in advance what are the most impressive collections in the Hermitage, then overlap with your own wishes and concentrate on one or two collections per visit, otherwise it's too much and too tiring to grasp a bit of everything.My favorites are Dutch and Russian art, and for those who aware of ancient Greek mythology, Greek collection will be extremely interesting.

Beautiful Hermitage with History. Be sure to allow a lot of time to wander through the four buildings that make up the Hermitage. It reminds me of the Smithsonians in DC. Lots of beautiful artwork, statuary, historical items. Worth a visit!

Impressive. We were on a tour, coming from Scandinavian countries, with 6 other friends.I am NOT into art, being called Hagar or Attila at times, but there is a bit here for everybody, even me.First, the area/buildings - and around it is impressive. Lots of buildings, spread over quite a lot of city blocks. It was crowded, and as usual, people that MUST preen in front of everything and get their pictures taken to prove that they were there. Conceit or Ego?Lots of art treasures, Russian culture and costumes, tons of paintings by renowned artists, plus some modern ones - you know, the paintings that if you hung it upside down, nobody would know the difference. To me, it was a bit of overkill, place was crowded and just too much bumping and jostling. Also, this is not really to my liking, too fast-paced, and the fact that you only get the description at the END of the room doesn't help me to understand it. We enjoyed the mosaic Malachites the most - as it is unusual and we had not seen anything similar to this. We also saw some more green amber, which is very interesting in how they 'create it'.If anybody is interested in seeing EVERYTHING in the Hermitage museum - warning! If you came here 6 days a week for 8 hours, you can probably see ALL the pieces in about 28 years or so, assuming one piece a minute.Interesting that one display of a chess set with the board - pieces are set up incorrectly! With all the Russian chess grandmasters, you'd think that someone could set a board and pieces up correctly!

One of the best museums in the world. We were on a guided tour, since we were in the area as part of an Oceania cruise. To say this is magnificent is an understatement. The museum is huge and really an all-day affair if you are an art lover. There was a special exhibit of Impressionist art, with pieces that had just been in storage at the museum. Can you imagine, having a Renoir just in storage? I still pinch myself since it was a lifelong dream to visit this museum. My only regret is that we did not see the Gold Room, and you will need an advance reservation for this special room.

Very poor management. A huge exhibition and the management are obviously only interested in making as much money as possible. Thousands of tourists are crammed into the buildings, with no control on numbers in each room or route they should take. It was impossible to view any exhibits as everyone was too close and too busy trying to take photographs. Highly claustrophobic and we couldn't wait to find our way out. A huge disappointment.
Hermitage Museum. The shear size of this museum is overwhelming. The amount of artifacts one can see is breathtaking. Every period of history is represented.
Hermitage. This is a must see if going to St Petersburg.So many different paintings from different eras.you will never see it all but what you can see is awesome.

Wow!!!. We were just sorry that we didn't have enough time to fully appreciate this amazing collection of art, history and architecture and much more! At least one full day must be reserved for the Hermitage!

Something for Everyone. I am not massively into art and so I did wonder whether a trip to the Hermitage is worthwhile. It certainly was though as the building alone is impressive enough to merit a trip.We went early in the morning to try and avoid the crowds but I suspect the only way to truely do so would be to visit in the winter when the cruise ships are not there.There is a lot to take in but I think half a day is sufficient unless you are a real art afficionado. I'm not sure my legs would have lasted the afternoon as well.

Top of the bucket list - tick. This is an absolute must do for visitors to St Petersberg. Recommend go early in the morning. There are ticket machines which assist you in skipping the massive cue, however you can't get your discount (ie student) tickets there. It also pays to identify your must sees and cover them off first. There is simply too much to see in a day, I was certainly overwhelmed by the end.

Exquisite pieces. We enjoyed our tour of the Hermitage and were impressed with much of the art and artifacts gathered here. To our amazement, the facility did not maintain temperature and/or humidity for the preservation of these items. It was one of many instances where we observed corners being cut to save government funds.

Massive. We visited as part of a cruise tour with P & O so the museum opened early for us. Our guide, Elena, was knowledgeable a took us to an eclectic mix of highlights with something for everyone.Worth a visit.Plan ahead.Arrive early.A definite must see. 3hours at least.

Clearly one if the best museums in the world. One 'problem' - a special room within the Hermitage is the 'Gold Room' but, it is so special, you have to book a separate tour (which we did not). In any case, just be aware, if you are going to the Hermitage to see the Gold Room, plan accordingly. Even if you do not see the Gold Room, there are thousands of spectacular art objects - paintings, sculptures, clocks, on and on. One special metric - 1 minute per item, 8 hours per day, 15+ years to see it all. Enjoy - clearly the #1 attraction in St. Petersburg.
An Absolute Must See. This shows you how over the top the Czars were. Gold everywhere. Ornate to a fault. But absolutely gorgeous.
Must see Hermitage. Wonderful site to explore. Need at least 2 hours to see. Some people spend 8 hours to see every detail. We did ours in 3 hours. Excellent!

How Big?. In order to see all of this museum you would need a week. We spent 3 hours or so and were excellently guided through and saw most of the highlights. Some day we will return and try and see more. Worth the visit. Early arrival may help to avoid long waiting lines.
Plan your visit!. It is huge! No chance to visit during one day. So plan what you want to see and stick to you plan. Buy the tickets via internet as this will allow you to avoid very long lines.

They need some air con!. Obviously a must see when visiting St Petersburg, buy tickets online (you will still queue but slightly shorter). This place is vast and very, very busy - beware the tour groups who decend on anything well known and barge you out of the way to take photos. Good selection of 20th C art. They need to sort out some air con though for sake of visitors and the exhibits!

Hermitage antiques and rooms. An experience for historians and art lovers. A must see place for those who are in St. Petersburg. See paintings by Rembrandt..such beautiful paintings. History unto itself!

Is there any comment needed. Is there any comment needed for this wonderful museum.
As week the building as well as its collection is very very impressive and you will need many hours to see it all.
Make a good plan and enjoy

Great Art, confusing place. This place is so big, it's very confusing, even whilst following the map.
If you book on line, you need to print your tickets (my hotel did this for me).
I found the place extremely confusing to walk around. Tickets are for 2 days (which is great) but they close on Mondays, so plan your trip well.

Fabulous museum, with one nitpick. We spent four hours here trying to take in what we could of all the different collections. From the glory period of St. Petersburg, there are lots (and lots) of fancy clothes, furniture, and personal effects on display. It’s almost as if some curator was rummaging through the remains of the Hermitage storage bunkers and started putting everything on display. There were some interesting paintings, such as the ball commemorating the 300th anniversary of tsarist Russia in 1914. Little did they know.There are nice collections of 700- to 2000-year-old Eastern European and Central Asian artifacts—things not likely to be seen in other museums outside of Russia. However, it is not very easy to get to these collections. The Hermitage is so large that it’s really easy to get turned around despite the free museum maps that are available at the ticket counter. Visit tips: buy tickets online if you can. The special exhibits (such as the gold room) are times and sell out early in the day. Arrive early to be near the front of the queue for picking up/buying tickets. We luc out by going the day before when the museum entrance was free (first Thursday of the month, usually) as the lines to get in were super long. Non-flash pictures are allowed in much of the museum. Expect to walk a lot; the museum is vast and you will want to check out everything. Like much of the country, the museum is not really wheelchair friendly.And the nitpick? There is a definite lack of air conditioning in this museum. I know that it's not uncommon for there to be no air conditioning. However, in this European city with one of the top collections in the world, it seems that the comfort of the visitors (not to mention maintaining the collections) would be up to world class standards.
Tours of St. Petersburg. We get the first VIP guest visit and wonderful place and a lot precious paintings and collections of Russia. It is a most glory museum to visit.
suerb. you should take a tour with th guides from the museum, it will make your experience beetter,, prfect

Hermitage-Louvre-Prado museums. No doubt about being one of the greatest museums.Do not compare it with other museums, just buy the ticket and enjoy.But before you buy the ticket: at the hotel we stayed, they offered tickets without staying in line but for double the price.It is up to you to consider this option.We did not buy from the hotel and stayed in line maybe 15 minutes.Groups have anyway a different entrance and they already have the tickets.Most of the visitors are Russians,except the groups.There are a few options to buy different tickets so be ready when you reach the counter.They do not understand English too well so the decision what kind of ticket to buy is yours.Check even before you get there which day of the month the entrance is free.This time it was the first Thu. of August.It was closed on Mondays.Students entrance is free.Locals pay much less than tourists but this should not bother us.The other issue to take into account: you are not allowed with food or water under no circumstances.Do not try to fool them.There are coffee shops inside the museum that serve lunch menu so it's OK.You are not allowed to carry bags and you have to leave them at the storage room(no fee) but another place you have to wait in line !Come without bags !More: for how long do you think you can walk and wonder around the museum? It is not easy and you will need at least three hours.There are few chairs along the museum halls for a rest so you might consider going down to the c/shop each time you are tired.I saw toilets only on the ground floor.For the regular visitor I suggest to take the free museum plan.In this plan they pointed out already for you the most well known works of art.So now you have a start point which will take you to all the important works you knew about or did not.The plan is very helpful and clear and besides, the staff watching the visitors can be helpful too.At some points you will have a view to the Neva river.In case you know what you want to see than the same plan can be helpful because it explains where are concentrated the works per period or by culture. You can take pictures but not with a tripod.You can buy a combined ticket for two days(two entrances)And before you leave: don't forget the souvenir shop.I am sure you will find something there.Enjoy it !

Overwhelmingly beautiful. It would take days to see it all. In the heat is can be a sit 'close' but still incredible. An English speaking guide is a lovely treat but they do have maps in English and one can make their way around quite successfully without a guide. In addition, the website doesn't mention it but there is a café in the basement as well as two cafes in the entrance courtyard, so don't worry about having to spend the whole day there.
A visual feast!. The two day pass was good value and meant we didn't feel we needed to cram everything into one day. There is just so much to see!

Magnificent. The Winter Palace/Hermitage is stunning. It rivaled all of the museums I've ever been to, including the Louvre. The best part was that the building itself was part of the museum. as well as the artwork. It is very confusing, though, and at times hard to find your way around, but it's worth it. You could spend three days there and not see everything. We were only there for one day, and I enjoyed it thoroughly.

Fabulous!. It is so huge it is overwhelming. We spent 4 hours and saw only a small number of exhibits in that time. I was more interested in the grandeur of the palace itself. One negative is the crowds. I have been in museums in many countries and have never been in one this crowded. Definitely go with a guide. We had a wonderful one who was a wealth of information about the exhibits as well as the history of the buildings. Also, spend the extra money and visit the Gold Rooms. I have never seen so may jewels, etc. in one place including the Crown Jewels held in the Tower of London. If you are in St. Petersburg don't miss the Hermitage. It was the highlight of our trip.
Now a Museum. Wa the Winter Palace not a fantastic art museum. One of the largest collection of art in the world. Beautiflly decorated.

So much to see!. There is so much to see at The Hermitage - I got told that if you looked at every item for one minute, it would take 9/10 years to look around the entire museum! There was a really cool gift shop, and the sales assistant that served me was really nice and chatty. It was incredible to see works by the likes of Monet etc in real life. The only improvement would be a wider range of foods and drinks in the cafe (e.g. more vegetarian/vegan options, more coffee choices etc). I would recommend this museum to anyone, and I hope to return someday.
The Hermitage. A must see place. amazing architecture and beauty. Paintings and sculptures as well as overall layout undescibebable

Amazing, so much to see. Ensure you book your tickets in advance on the website. US$17.50. Then exchange your e-voucher at the kiosk under the main archway. We arrived just after 10am, got in the queue and were amongst the first to enter. Back packs etc go in lockers but if you have a large handbag there is no problem. We took the audio tour R300 (take a photo driving licence to leave as a deposit), however not all rooms or all items are on this tour. Look at the map you are given to see which rooms are included. In addition, you will then find certain other items which have and audio number. As we were there in July, the main attractions were busy (mainly cruise groups) but some rooms are quieter.

Days are not enough to view it all. There is so very much to see here it can tend to be a bit overwhelming. Our guide told us if a person spend only a few seconds per exhibit it would take them 15 years to see it all. The grandeur of the exhibits is definitely something not to miss!
Breathtaking. An art collection beyond belief. From floors, to ceilings, even to the doors, there is so much beauty to see here.

Fabulous collection. Amazing collection that you need time to explore. I did a first visit with a group and guide - it was all a bit crowded and rushed. Then I went back. I bought tickets online for 2 day visits. You print off the voucher and go to the little booth just inside the entry to the Winter Palace from Palace Square and the voucher is exchanged for tickets. You do need ID such as a driver's licence. Then go past the long line (30 min wait) and into the line for groups and people with tickets and you go straight in - wonderful!The museum is vast so you need to work out what you want to see. There are two areas with French impressionists one on the second and the other on the third floor so do not miss the third floor which has a more extensive collection including two rooms of Picasso. I found the Russian culture area interesting . Needless to say the other collections are great as are the interiors.
Russian Jewel. Go with a Guide. It might cost more but you get straight in. Well worth a visit. Great collection of Monet and Picasso.

Heritage museum st petersbugh. This first thing that strikes you is the opulence of the decorations. I have not seen such a beautiful place before. It is an enormous in size and as we were only there for two and a half hours we only saw a small area. I cannot begin to describe the decor, colour and furniture. It also has some beautiful art. The building is well looked after and well worth the effort to see how these people lived.It was a warm day and very busy which was uncomfortable at times, also it was hard to take photographs. Unfortunately a member of our tour had their wallet stolen, it is a pick pockets paradise!The guide said it was much quieter to see this building in the winter as there is hardly anyone there. I was memorised, a must see for st Petersburg.

So much to see, too little time. If you're into art and/or history, it's worth it to take the time to explore everything at a leisurely pace. If not, check out the highlights. Don't forget to look at the architecture of the building itself, stunning.

Need lots of time. The display and exhibition is great. You do not know if you should see outside the Windows, the paintings of the palace... there is so much to see. I enjoyed and wish I had more time to see everything.

2 day de luxe tour of St Petersburg. So magnificent!So much to see and absorb!SPB tours are really great - their knowledge and attention to every detail -AMAZING!The only drawback is the time, there are tons of groups all merging together and one has to keep on moving when inside the Winter Palace - SPB - Dasha handed each person on the tour an ear phone - SUPERB IDEA! - so one is able to keep up with the interesting facts as one is led in this special Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace. If I had to do it again, I would go with SPB Tours and our tour guide DASHA - Congratulations you are OUSTANDING!

Tour group hoards. I went independently end of July and spent 2 whole days there - so I saw most rooms. Obviously the art itself and the rooms are beautiful. But hands down this was the most challenging art appreciation experience I've ever had, due firstly to the hundreds of tour large groups, many of them completely without manners. Every time a tour group swarmed my way (about every 5 minutes) I felt like a sandcastle in a tsunami. I was bulldozed this and and that by the groupies in their endless quest for photos of absolutely everything the leader showed them - family photos, selfies, videos, and who knows what click click clicking away like a cloud of locusts. I found myself escaping to obscure rooms such as the Byzantine on the third floor just for some peace. Beyond the crowds, which were exhausting, the paintings were hung in rooms with absolutely no lighting consideration. Many many works were difficult to see due to the glare of sunlight from the windows(!). In the busy rooms (like the Rembrandt rooms - resembling the floor of the NY Stock exchange more than a gallery), it was steamy like a sauna - another thing I felt a bit queasy about in terms of art preservation.Hoping for a break - it was too crowded to sit down in the cafe and the loos were inadequate, with long lines at the ladies.My colleague visited in March and she said it was nothing like this - with only the odd tour group - so that would be my recommendation. Avoid cruise season at all costs.
So much to see. We had a private guided tour which made it very special. The clock was a highlight! A must see while in Saint Petersburg.

If you can bear the crowds and the chaos, do it and don't forget the new contemporary wing across the square!. The Pros: To me, better than Peterhof for exploring architecture and grandeur, the rooms are incredible and I was more impressed with the ceilings and detail than a lot of the art! That being said, there are whole wings of secret impressionists that no one even bothers to look at because they are all lining up in some ridiculous queue to take flash photography (!?) of the Da Vincis. The Cons:THE TOUR GROUPS!!!! I was wandering on my own and felt like I was consistently being pushed against the grain and bashed up against the wall to avoid throngs of people coming at me from all directions. If you can figure out when the busiest times are, AVOID THEM AT ALL COSTS!!! Tips:1. For really good contemporary art - walk across the square and you'll find their other wing, which holds awesome exhibitions (manifesta was on when I was there) as well as Kadinskys and Matisses. Bonus: it is literally empty, no tourists at all. Also, just because it is not on the audio guide or a highlight on the tour map, doesn't mean it's not there. If you're going for the art - spend 2 minutes googling their collection and you'll be amazed at what is there but most don't know about.2. Order your tickets online or at the kiosks out front. I have no idea what people were standing in line for an hour. I literally walked up to the machine, got my tickets and walked straight in.

Emerald of ST. Petersburg. Emerald of ST. Petersburg or may be Emerald of Russia . in spite of greatness ,....it is too crowded and too noisy , numerous people come and go and there is no time and no space for looking at art masterpieces .

A few tips for visiting the Hermitage Museum. The Hermitage of S. Petersburg is one of the best museums in the whole world and a "must-see" place in S. Petersburg. Because of this, long QUEUEs are formed at the opening hours, i.e., currently, at 10.30 am. If you arrive there even 30 minutes earlier, you may still expect a long queue, unless ... ... unless you are part of an organized group, as groups have some priority and a reserved preferential queue. BUT if you are alone or just a few individuals, the "trick" is getting the ticketsfrom the Automatic Ticket Machines, on the left side while entering the garden gate. But be careful: the machines do NOT accept credit cards, but only NOTES. Thus, bring with you enough cash in notes to pay: 400 rubles per person, PLUS - (strong suggestion!) - just 200 rubles in addition to buy the permit to make photos (without flash) in most parts of the museum. It is definitely worth of it!

One of the World's Great Museums. To think that this was a private residence boggles the imagination. The museum is well organized with an amazing collection of art. Unless you have a few years,you will only skirt their collection but whatever you are interested in, you are guaranteed a treat.

Worth visiting...tips for kids.... We visited the winter palace and hermitage with 2 kids and 2 grand parents. We stayed at the local Renaissance/Marriott which allowed us to bypass the lines and buy our tickets quickly. Saved us 40 minutes! You can spend the whole Day here, but given the moderate interest of our group we spent about 3 hours. Everybody loved the Winter Palace. We down loaded the iphone audio App which provided adequate information. We followed the recommended path and took lots of pictures. We then found ourselves in the Hermitage which is stocked with all sorts of artwork. Most interesting for the kids was the Da Vinci art, the hall of sculptures from early in the century and the Egyptian mummies. As non art connoisseurs we agreed to walk thru the halls quickly and stop when we saw anything interesting. I recommend bringing along water and sandwiches or snacks.

A 5-star must!. We visited in very hot weather and could not spend more than a few hours in the museum. Even so, it was a true delight to walk the corridors of this magnificent building and appreciate works of art in surroundings with such history. I could spend a week or more just learning my way around this museum!

Too much to see. There was just so much to see at the Hermitage that it became overwhelming. I did not like the fact that you were not allowed to take water in. It was very crowded and hot (St Petersburg was 35 degrees that day). There did not seem to be any places to get a drink, either, so I was very dehydrated by the time we were there for 3 hours.
Awesome. If you love the art, you'll found everything for art. There's huge and awesome.I think it's one of the best museums in Europe.

Wow!. Visited the Hermitage as part of an all day trip off a cruise liner. All I can say is, it's fantastic, beautiful, enormous and very hard on the legs! Our group must have walked miles around the museum and I'm sure we never saw everything. It was well worth it, though, but there's not really anywhere to sit down if you feel tired.

WOW! Dazzling and beautiful museum.. Let me share an insight our guide told us. This museum has about 3,5 million works of art in it's collections. If you would spend 30 seconds looking at each one of them on an uninterrupted 24/7 base, you'd nee about 8 years to see it all. Don't blame me if the math is not accurate, I haven't bothered recalculating it myself. We only had the opportunity to spend 2 hours in this museum. Beautiful rooms and great works of art. Probably the most impressive art display I've ever seen. If you want to attempt a serious visit, my tip would be to plan 3 guided visits of about 3 hours each. Event then you still will only see a very limited portion of the exhibited work. Impressive!

Impressive in content but really could be curated better. Lots of tourists, lots of paintings and sculptures; but overall it was OK as museums go. I gave it an average score. I would not put this at the top of my places to visit for St. Pete, if you have already been to the British Museum, National Portrait Gallery (London) or the Louvre etc. This is unless you specifically want to see a particular painting or set of paintings or an exhibit. The best thing for me were the ancient and near-east antiquities -- but thats just my preference; this collection is highly limited; but still ok. The paintings especially were not displayed properly -- slightly better than an adhoc arrangement in my books; the curator needs to be sacked an replaced. Many of the paintings had far too much light reflection from lighting indoors or from a poor positioning with regards to windows. You would never find this in the Louvre for example. We bought our tickets online as we were advised that the queue becomes very long. However, as we came on a weekday, the queue was small.

Amazing place. This place is absolutely amazing! We were only able to spend a short time...we saw about 10 rooms, and what we saw was amazing! It was very crowded...and you do need to be conscious of potential pick pockets,,,,but it is worth a visit.

A must see. What a wonderful palace, the amount of wealth inside of this building just amazing, be prepared for a lot of walking and a mass of tourists, some long queues but the wait is well worth it. Beware of pickpockets they are pretty much into the tourists so take care.

A must. Decide what you want to see and aim for those. the place is overwhelming. go to the Amber room, to the 200 year old clock (peacock), and decide which works you must see. after four or five hours the museum lies on your shoulders.

art crowds make viewing difficult. What a change in the ten years from my last visit. Crowds of people all jockeying for places to take pictures of the artwork on display while the tour guides almost march you through the galleries. Beautiful architecture to see as well as the various floors. So crowded the day I was there I was convinced no-one would escape the museum should a fire or other emergency happen.

Our second visit. First visited with cruise tour 2012. Paid a lot to visit in the evening for guided tour when museum empty. Ended with concert by symphony orchestra and champagne. Our second visit a bit of a nightmare. The queues are terrible. We got tickets at credit card machines and walked straight in from Palace Square. But wanted to see Faberge and Gold rooms. Our daughter was allowed to go back out to queue in heat for tickets. But Faberge sold out. Book at your hotel or book in the UK online if possible. We took English tour of Gold Rooms but guide's English wasn't good. People got very bored and wandered. The rest of the Hermitage was packed and we found the map hopeless. We were up and downstairs all the time looking for exhibits we wanted to see. Toilet queues phenomenal for ladies. Check day of closing before you set off with all Russian tourist sites.
great place to visit. Absolutely wonderful but too many tourists once again.Every where you look the articles and paintings were very excellent however some displays were not translated in English.

Better than the Louve?. The Hermitage rivals the Louve in terms of paintings, and may actually be better. The Louve has some components that the Hermitage does not have, but for painting purists around the world, the Hermitage is a must see.

St Petersberg on a Reagent Cruise. We have just returned from a Reagent Cruise Line Baltic Cruise and I have to say that it is something that is worth the effort and expense. Visiting all the sights of St Ptersburg was absolutely awesome as my grandchildren would say. The Hermatage was spectacular and only complaint I have is that we were rushed through it. To walk into a room of Rembrants and have 10 minutes to enjoy them was upsetting. The original city and what was built between 1703 and 1850 it truly beatiful.The wealth that was required to build the palaces,residences and collect the great artwork must have been huge. The more recent additions to the city between 1930 and 1990 I am guessing, reflect a much different image. Grey concrete 10 to 15 storey apartment buildings,poorly maintained, reflect a very depressed time in the history of St. Petersburg. The 900 days of seige during the second world war and the Stalin era I feel truly sent the city into a downward spiral. But putting all that aside it is truly worth a visit. We arrived at the winter palace,and walked into the Amber room just as the sun came out from behind a cloud. The light,reflection of light from the amber and the music being played took your breath away.Truly something that you have to see.
