I could go on and on but I repeat if it is your dream,it is worth doing and possily before 2018 World Cup which may change a lot of the city.

Great museum but a challenge to visit. I've wanted to visit the Hermitage for over 20 years after realising in art history class that most of the artwork that I admired was on display in either the Hermitage, Prado or Louvre. The other two crossed off my list, the time had come for the Hermitage. It seems that most foreign visitors to the Hermitage are a part of an organised tour, but the museum offers english speaking tours for those who aren't a part of a group. So far, so good. However buying the ticked for the english speaking tour is then quite a challenge as it's nowhere to be found on the price list at the ticket office. And the nice old ladies manning the ticket booths don't speak english. We ended up finding an information stand behind the ticket booths and asking them to write in russian what ticket we wanted to buy (english speaking tour).The tour with the museum guide was very informative. The museum itself was packed with organised tours, so at times it was challenging to see the actual artwork. Most of the galleries don't have any place to sit down and admire the art, they probably want to keep the large groups moving through the museum. Finally, one of the key artworks of the museum, which I wanted to see, had been moved to another building because of a temporary exhibition. By then we were too tired to go buy another ticket for that building. Despite these challenges, the museum is well worth the visit.

Probably the Best Museum in the World. This place is amazing, better than the Louvre, Prado and London's National. The first major sight is the Jordan staircase which is mind blowing, but only a taster for the treasures inside. Classic paintings include Rembrandt, Raphael, van Dyck, Rubens and Da Vinci. Impressionist works of art feature my personal favourite, Monet, plus Matisse, Picasso, Gaugin and van Gogh. But it is not just paintings, sculptures by Canova and Rodin are highlights, jewellery, furniture and silver cannot fail to impress.Unfortunately the place is too big to cover on one 3 hour tour. I missed English treasures like Reynolds, Turner and Constable. The Hermitage is also very busy, and tiring. I am not an art fanatic but this is a must see for any traveller.One tip, stalls and guides sell a top quality book for 5 Euros. Buy one, it is not only a good guide book, but it is brilliantly illustrated.Unusually, photography is easy and the only prohibition is flash. The lighting is excellent so no flash is not a problem.

Beware of the crowds - love the arts!. A great MUST DO in St Petersburg - the crowds can be crazy over the summer, but make sure that you visit no matter what. Take your time and breathe in the beauties.

Get a guide. So much to see you don't know where to begin, make sure you see the golden peacock clock as that is amazing and a good guide who can take you to the most interesting artifacts is very helpful
Mindblowing interiors!. for special interested buy a two day ticket - you won't have time to see it al in one go ;-) it is huge!
A must see. This palace is beautiful and maintained to a high standard, the exhibits are amazing it is worth the visit also the history that goes with the palace adds to the day.

Good place but you get rushed through. An important place in modern history, so worth a visit if you are in town. Beware pick pockets and don't be distracted by criminal gangs of 'street actors' who are there to control and facilitate the crimainal elements..Far too many items to look at whilst you are whisked through the tour route. 3 million items apparantly.

Immense collection of every artist you can think of!. The Hermitage encompasses 2,000 rooms in 5 buildings and is simply the most amazing collection of art in the entire world. Room after room of incredibly famous work that Catherine the Great amassed in her lifetime. The ceilings are unbelievably gorgeous and seemingly go on for miles. Stunning!!!

good but very crowded. i had heard lots about Hermitage. the display area is huge and the museum is easily accessible. however, when we went inside, it was so crowded that we couldnt spend more than 3 hours....there are no explanations about the things on display like in most other galleries... that makes it boring after a point. since it is an important attraction in St.peters, one must visit. some pieces are spectacular... i loved the Tretyakov State Gallery in Moscow... it has far more character and is tourist-friendly than this one.

You'll need a lifetime for this place.. Go with a guide the first time then on your own thereafter. The trips organised by the cruise lines are rushed and their huge groups are a pain for other visotors.A bit like the Louvre, get a plan in advance and decide what you want to see.

Beautiful; Crowded. Granted, I was here in July, height of tourist season, so the museum was full of pushy, uncooperative "guests". But the inside will absolutely take your breath away -- the stairs, the gold gilt on everything, and be sure to look at the ceilings and floors in all rooms with ornate plaster on the ceilings and inlaid wood on the floors. You (or I) can't help gasping at the over abundance of decor in every room. Even with a tour guide hustling you along, this is a long trip; so wear very comfortable shoes. And, they don't allow big bags inside; so don't take your back pack.

A class by itself. It may not be in a class by itself but it doesn't take long to call the roll. I haven't been to all the great ones but it compares favorably with those I have seen. Although I would say I favor the Louvre, this one is close. Like the Louvre, it is huge and a true fan could spend days here. For those of us on a (ship) schedule without the luxury of extra time, you have to hope that your tour hits the high spots. Ours hit the works of many of the great masters. It has plenty of those. Not being a student of art history, so consider the source, I think its only shortcoming is the lack of a signature work or two. You won't find a Mona Lisa or David and the handful of others of that acclaim but you won't find that level of classic work many other places. Be aware that if you are there mid-summer, the crowds are horrendous and if you have a schedule to keep, a good guide is essential . Our young master from Alla Tours got us to the old masters in a most efficient manner. If you like to leisurely peruse the great works of this great museum, come off season.

A mindblowing museum. Like MMM1968 below, I'm not a big museum person but the collection of this place is staggering - they really do have everything that anyone could want to see. The setting is also beautiful - the rooms are really ornate. Chances are, whenever you go, it'll be busy - take a guide if you can (you get to go in via the tour guide entrance which is quicker) as they'll be able to give you the run-down on the best pieces and can guide you to see other parts of the collection at the end.

This is a Once-in-a- Lifetime Experience. I was lucky enough to be able to visit this museum twice. Once ten years ago and again, last month. You must go on a tour as entry is very difficult on your own. The palace rooms where the artworks are located are so vast that one only catches a glimpse of many as you walk through several main hallways. One must be capable of scaling many stairwells and walking very long passageways otherwise it could be a difficult experience. It reminded me of the Vatican Museum in terms of the both the grandeur and the distances one must walk. The building interiors so opulent (including a room made of gold), that you begin to understand a bit more about how the Russian Revolution came about. The art works are priceless and include works you have only dreamed about ever seeing in person. You are allowed to get dangerously close to the art and sometimes you wonder how its survived all the years. The collection astounds and the architecture amazed and the furnishings are something you never forget. Your mind races as you reflect both on the works of art, the palaces where they are housed and the huge plazas outside where you can almost imagine the history of the starving and poor trying to imagine what might be inside these buildings. Its something everyone should be lucky enough to be able to see.. it really should help us understand both the beauty of art and the reckless and greedy excesses of the rich in all periods of history, including the present.

Forgiveness. "The Return of the Prodigal Son" by Rembrandt literally took my breath away when I entered the room of Dutch Masters at the Hermitage. Painted a year or so before the artist's death in 1669, you can't miss this giant work when entering the massive room. Rembrandt captures perfectly all the emotion of a moment when you don't deserve forgiveness yet someone important to you forgives you anyway. So stunned by this work, I forgot the crowds.So it is with the Hermitage. Gorgeous surroundings full of truly stunning works. Highly recommended.

Floors filled with a good mixture of historical artefacts. Get up early and buy your ticket at the self service machine to avoid queues. Floors filled with historical art, clothing, artillery and much more. We managed to spend 3 hours in there but you could spend much longer browsing. Has English labels as well as Russian.

Beware the toilets!. Amazing collections of pictures and artefacts to be viewed here. Remember to look up and down as the ceilings and floors are often as incredible as what is being displayed. Visited the ladies toilet when our tour group arrived and they were not nice, three hours later they were bad. The smell was nauseating, open bins of toilet paper adding to the bad experience.

Archaeological treasure. Everyone raves about the paintings and the state rooms, but the most amazing things in the Hermitage are on the ground floor, among the archaelogical finds: in particular the treasures from the burial mounds in the Altai (2nd century BC) and those that accompanied the princess in her tomb in the North Caucasus (9th century). In both cases, with clothes, carpets and even a wooden horse-carriage, perfectly preserved. Completely mind-blowing!

A must see. This is without doubt one of the must see attractions. Biggest advice is to buy the tickets online before you get there to avoid incredibly long queues. If you dont manage to do this, there are ticketmachines in the inner courtyard (CASH ONLY) where you can buy your tickets.

not into museums but.....!. We didn't get a chance to go into Peterhof so I missed all the "foo-foo". I did get a chance, however, to view some of the "foo-foo" of the Hermitage since it was the winter home of Peter the Great. The entrance was gorgeous so I can just imagine what the summer palace was like! The collection of art was amazing too--not that I'm a big fanatic of museums. It was a little crowded but again, it gave me a taste of the opulence without spending the additional money to go inside Peterhof--we just explored the grounds/fountains. I just really enjoyed the architecture both inside and out. If you're a museum fan--it will be just icing on the "foo-foo" cake!

Plan to spend a week!. Our guides gave the highlights, but a week is needed to really just brush the surface of the amazing contents of the museum. Do take a tour as there is so much to see that there needs to be a shortened agenda. Would like to visit again.

Massive!. This is the place you see most on TV. The square is very popular with all the tourists. The museum won't disappoint you with all the art, statues, and artifacts. Second only to the Louvre in France. This is a must see while visiting SP.

Overwhelminly Great!. There's more to see in this museum then I could wrap my head around. I lived in St. Petersburg for a month and visited the Hermitage twice and didn't get a dent put into it. You can visit the art exhibits if that's your pleasure or visit the living quarters of previous rulers for history lessons. I chose to do both!

Goin through Russia. This is an absolute must on your travel to St. Petersburg. You could 5-7 days in this place. Being on a tour makes it hard to see everything. You will just have to pick and choose what you want to see.

Terrible management. The museum and buildings are impressive. However, the management is terrible. Do not buy tickets on the internet as you will still have to queue as they check your passport and change your voucher for the entrance ticket (the queues are long). If you can, buy them in the automatic ticket machines. The day we went the museum was stifling and there is no airconditioning. You will be amazed but many of the priceless paintings are incredibly badly cared for, being situated in direct sunlight. Beautiful place but room for a lot of improvement to make the experience more pleasant.

Wall to wall people. The building and the art are wonderful but the crowds are very off putting. The museum is wall to wall tourists all who seem to be taking pictures rather than looking at the art.We made a second visit to the Hermitage a day later an hour before it closed and the crowds were more manageable. The magnificent art is somewhat overwhelming but the French impressionist and post impressionist section on the third floor is very worthwhile as well.

Didn't meet my expectations!. Surely it's one of the biggest, most important museums in the world! It contains amazing international art throughout the centuries and you need days to see all of it! Planning what to see before you go is a great tip BUT unfortunately, that's not always an option!We visited as a tour group, during a cruise excursion. First AND LAST time we do it this way, but we didn't have an option because without a visa, you are not allowed to step out of the ship! It was a sunday, and the museum opened especially for cruise takers that day! It was hell on earth! Six ships docked that day in St. Petersburg and it seems to me that all passengers entered the museum! It was so packed you couldn't see or hear anything or even walk from one corridor to the next! It was hot, frustrating to get close to a painting you wanted see and take photos, everything was a struggle! After the first hour I felt faint and went out to get some oxygen! It was so hot and crowded, no air con, windows shut, I thought I would die! I'm sure this experience would have been different if they didn't allow huge crowds to enter at the same time!

A truly massive collection, the sights are overwhelming!. If you have a favourite artist or sculptor then chances are they will have something here for you!My favourites were the two paintings by De Vinci and the huge collection of Picasso's, but the list is endless, so many pieces by so many masters! I loved the hanging gardens. some of the massive mosaics, I could go on and on! I only had about two and a half hours here as part of a larger tour, I could have easily spent a couple of days here. If you're lucky enough to be going, enjoy!
Just Wonderful. Three hours and it felt like fifteen minutes. So beautiful and so much to enjoy. I only wish I had several days rather than a few hours. A must see museum and grounds.

Amazing Museum, But So Crowded. We visited The Hermitage as part of a tour of St Petersburg. There is no doubt that the museum and Winter palace buildings are grand and ornate both inside and out. There are rooms and corridors full of beautiful and priceless works of art from masters through history. It would have been nice to sit and study many of these, but we had to move on quickly just to fit in the highlights of the highlights! The only downside was the crowds. Our early entrance got us past the queue, but it did not take long for the place to fill up. With many cruise ships in, the main rooms became crowded and hot, with long queues to get to see the key exhibits. Not an ideal way to appreciate art.This is a must do when in St Petersburg, but if you want to avoid the cruise ship crowds avoid May to September.

Packed with people. This place was what we went to see but next time it will be out of the main season as we where so disappointed in not being able to stop and see some of the worlds greatest pictures rush rush rush.

The most exuberant museum wordwide. Maybe the Metropolitan Museum, British Museum or the Louvre have equivalent or even mor spectacular collections, but none of them is located in a location of similar beauty, with stunning views over the river and extraordinary interiors, reminding of a gigantic Fabergé egg. Hermitage alone justifies the trip to St. Petersburg.

Free entrance to the museum and the amazing clocks "Peacock". I live in St. Petersburg and I love the Hermitage as it combines the best aspects of world heritage. My favorite masterpieces are the sculptures, the beautiful decoration of the halls and the Italian drawings, i also love the amazing clocks "golden peacock".  Unfortunately, the price for the entrance is high not only for the foreigners but also for the residents, so I prefer to go on the first Thursday of every month when entrance is free for everyone. Do not miss this chance if you are going to be in this wonderful city, as the 7th of August is very soon. Be sure to come early (to the opening) to avoid the line. Also keep in mind that any student who has a student card (ISIC) has a free entrance at any day of the work.  By the way, the amazing clocks "Peacock" are working for the visitors each Wednesday at 7 pm . You can see the schedule of the Hermitage below

Hermitage Museum. If you love world-class museums and art, this is the place to be. it was impossible to see all of it, however. A map helped some, but I'd recommend just going and seeing what you can. Trying to find specific artwork in specific rooms was difficult, as the room numbering system was beyond my comprehension as well as my travel companion's. A definite must-see experience.

Plan what to see before you go.. Have concierge etc. buy your tickets online 1st to avoid hours of waiting in line to purchase tickets. There is only a very small café inside so be sure to eat and drink first. There is a Subway sandwich shop on Nevsky prospect near the Hermitage. Plan your visit and decide what you want to see, it is impossible to see all in one day.

Majestic Monuments. Hermitage museum is part of a world class museum. It contains one of the most important international art collection. It takes time to see everything. A large number of people are admitted at the same time and you don't have time to stop and admire. However you get a pretty good idea of all the treasures collected by Catherine and Peter the Great. No crowds during winter time.

Surpassed even my high expectations. As unique as the collection is, it is the complex itself that captivated me. Its history, architecture, decoration and contents make it one of the top "must sees" on any traveller's list
Just incredible. No words to discribe this beautiful buildin and the different types of art. You can spend a week inside

Magical and glamorous. You will most likely get very tired of the art very quickly. Don't worry, it is overwhelming and takes several lifetimes to admire for anyone from the bored student to the art connoisseur. Just take a look around, the Winterpalais is incredible just by itself. Relax your eyes on the view over the Neva river and try to imagine the pompous balls echoing through the walls.

Stunning. We were part of a tour group so could really only do a whistle stop tour. Our guide led us to some key pieces and gave us some real insights in to the artists and the history of the paintings. We would love to go back and spend more time there one day. The restoration of the palace is incredible and was clearly a labour of love. Room after room of paintings by the Masters, set in a beautiful environment. We also saw an exhibition of 18th century clothing that was fascinating.Well worth being part of a guided tour to make the most of the visit.

Must see. Nothing can be written in a thousand characters to give the traveler a hint on this tour. You cannot visit St. Petersburg without seeing the Hermitage. Maybe one suggestion to avoid long lines is to purchase your tickets on line or at an electronic kiosk just inside the arch. Plan to spend more than four hours per visit.
Amazing place. If you have a month to stay you still wouldn't have enough time to see everything in details.Lucky We don't have to queue to get in, got free a VIP ticket from Hermitage hotel.

A tip if you don't like crowded places. I went to the Hermitage Museum in March 2013.Which means a very cold weather (everyday under -15 degrees celsius), which means no queue to enter the museum.Thanks to that and my personal guide, I spent 4-5 hours in the museum, only focused on what interested me, mostly Spanish paintings.If you're OK with cold temperature, I recommend visiting St Petersbourg in winter, the clean and cold air makes the city look astonishing!

History itself…. It would take you no more than 2 days just browsing less than a minute for each artwork showcased. The vast collection is a privilege to see and the rooms are very elaborate, reflecting the culture and history. Highly recommended!

More art than you can imagine!. Thanks to our tour guide Konstantin, with Travel All Russia, we were able to go through the high points of the entire museum in about four hours. He knew how to get around the crowds and seemed to be able to describe everything.
A must see!. The rooms are breathtaking and the vastness of the art collection surprised me. We saw Manet, Monet, Van Gogh, Renoir, Cerat, Da Vinci, Gaugin, the list goes on!

Saint Petersburg Hermitage ticket information. If you are buying an internet ticket at 17.95 USD bear in mind the following. You will have to pick it up from a kiosk where only 1 cashier is serving all the people who have also booked online. She goes on lunch break between 1200 and 1300 when nobody else will take over. Other people will push to the front of the queue because it says in Lonely Planet that your voucher "allows you to jump the queue..." (if you try to put them straight they will not understand Russian. Or English. Or French...) Tickets bought on the day cost 400 RUB (11.25 USD approx). The queues for the cashiers were long (students go free with ID) but there are several ticket machines with instructions in Russian and English that take cash and credit cards and had no queue at all. It's also worth noting that all food and drink is banned inside the museum (as are umbrellas). We saw a couple of people in organised tour groups with bottles of water but most had to surrender at the airport-style scanners as you enter the museum.You'll forget all the hassle once you're inside though as you get swept away by the art and interiors. If you need your own space try the Siberian or Caucasus collection. The church is currently closed for restoration. Bonus: contemporary European biennial Manifesta 10 is taking place in St. Petersburg this summer with exhibits sprinkled about the Hermitage.

Breadth of top notch displays is unbelievable. There are many pieces from so many renowned artists all in one place. The building couldn't be bigger and art completely fills every room. This museum is not sparse on exhibits. The impressionist section is quite noteworthy. A/C is not very present in Russia and it would have added to the experience in the museum. It was very crowded and quite hot during our summer visit, enough to detract some from the experience. Popular pieces we're surrounded by large crowds. This is great for people watching and the cultural immersion, but a bit distracting at times to experiencing the art.

Magnificent. Unbelievable collection of art and sculpture - try and spend at least the whole day there - there is so much to see - well worthwhile buying a photography license as you can film almost everything

So much to see here. If the outside isn't impressive enough the layout, decor and artefacts will consume a best part of a day or longer if you are an enthusiast. The audio guide is limited, if you want to make the most of it utilise one of the many guides on offer.

Very nice. We had a two hour tour with our tour guide. The museum was very crowded and busy. The articles on display were excellent. We saw real Rembrandt's up close and personal. There are 5 million things in the museum. Don't even try to see them all. After two hours we were ready to flee and museumed out.

Magnificent. I thought they were separate buildings but they are co-joined. You could spend days wandering around looking at the exhibits, particularly the painting by various schools. Lots of old Dutch Masters and the like. Well worth extra time. Our SPB tour guide had early access passes and was able to conduct us around the highlights in the 2 or so hours we had available.

Humongous!. Visited the museum mid 2013, and it is by far the largest establishment of the sort i've ever set foot in. Egyptology, Renaissance art, take your pick. Beautiful, affordable, but just one tip: do take a day-long visit, because of its size.

A definite highlight of my visit.. Its no easy task seeing the whole Hermitage. It took me four trips to fully explore. Luckily as a student entry is free except for the two special rooms. If you are in a rush i would still recommend visiting at least one. Each takes an hour. There is a wide range of things to see from neolithic to modern art. It gets very busy. Luckily I was more interested by exhibits less frequented by large tourist groups. To see the tourist highlights I would recommend Wednesday evenings when it is open untill 9pm. It is considerably less busy around then and I found gave a better experience. Overall a must see attraction.

Awe-inspiring. Wow, wow, wow! I couldn't stop saying 'wow' when we went round the Hermitage on the 22nd July. The treasures are absolutely amazing. Three of us had stopped off at St Petersburg on a Royal Caribbean Baltic cruise, and booked to have a driver (with a super Mercedes) and English speaking guide. Liliya, our guide, was excellent and pointed out treasures of special interest (to name one a Michael Angelo statue). We went quite early in the morning, so avoided the many tourists visiting later in the day, as when we left at about 12/12.30 there were long queues. The Hermitage is an absolute must for anyone visiting St Petersburg - it's awesome!

The Jewel in the Crown. Think of any of the famous artists through the ages and there are examples of their works in the Hermitage. To stand in front of any of their works is something even someone who hasn't a leaning for art must appreciate. There building also has other interesting features for example the Throne Room where the Tzars made proclamations and the theatre where private performances were given. The place is full of things to see and it would take several visits to get through them all so perhaps it is better to take a guided tour and be shown the highlights.

hermitage museum. what a museum.wow!if you looked at all its exhibits spending about a minute on every one it will take around 11 years to see all the exhibits.Pablo Picaso,rembrats,da vinci and othere original works,rare scuptures and furniture.unmatched,definitely worth a visitone maniac patient destroyed a painting by throwing acid on it and slashing it.It took 11 yaesr for the painting to be restored.It still has marks of acid dribbling down.He was jailed for 15 years.That shows the importance of the art

Great museum, but plan visit to avoid crowds!. We really enjoyed our visit to the Hermitage, but we were part of a cruise tour, and really felt rushed to get through the place in the allocated time. The palace is awesome and this history fascinating. I would strongly recommend getting in a tour group or getting the audio tour, which is available in multiple languages. You really need the history to get the full appreciation for the place. It was awesome to see the Rembrandt works, the prodigal son in particular. The impressionists are here too but I don't think the devote as much space as I would have liked. You cannot see everything in this place so set realistic expectations before you go. Do the research and go see what is of the greatest interest.But this place is a must on any trip to St. Petersburg.

Mind boggling Museum. It is the Hermitage. It could take years to see everything. The architecture is worth the admission. The winter palace has a tremendous history dealing with the revolution. Long lines to get in

A must see. Its a museum, a palace and exhibition hall. It is huge and loaded with must see paintings. We spend half a day here with a great guide and only scratched the surface. Unless you have day(s) to wonder around strongly recommend going in small guided group with clear understanding of what you will see and not see.

Get the most out of your Hermitage visit. The Hermitage is a stunning place and it should be on everybody's bucket list. Here are some tips on how to make your visit here the most pleasant.WHY WORTH SEEING: it was the winter residence of the Russian royal family and one of the best art museums in the world.BEST TIME TO SEE: FOR EVERYBODY - in summer the best time to see the Hermitage is on Wednesday after 5PM. Not very many people know that every Wednesday the museum is open till 9PM, as a result - even in summer you can see the place without huge crowds of people. 2 or 3 hours is more than enough to see all the highlights of the museum (which I marked on the Hermitage map attached). DO NOT STAND IN LINE FOR THE TICKETS. Once you enter the courtyard of the palace, in the corners you'll see ticket machines with almost no line. Buy your tickets there! Those machines even accept bank cards. Another option - buy your tickes online: http://www.hermitageshop.org/page.php?pagename=ticketsFOR ART CONNOISSEURS - plan on coming twice. First time, come on Wednesday night, as recommended above. Second time, come in the morning and visit the Gold and Diamond rooms plus the new building of the Hermitage, where Matisse, Kandinsky and Malevich are on display. Unfortunately, it's impossible to buy tickets to the Gold and Diamond rooms in the machines, so you actually have to stand in line for them. That's why I recommend seeing them on a separate visit. For that, come to the Hermitage quite early in the morning, about 9:30, before it opens, and get in line. At 10:30 the museum will open and you can buy tours of the Gold and Diamond rooms in English. Those have set timing, and you will be told when they start (it's different every day). It's likely that you'll have some free time before those tours start, and it's the perfect time to check out "The Staff Building" or "General Hearquaters" (a yellow building with an arch), where Matisse and others are displayed. Then come back to the museum for your Gold tour, the groups gather after the entrance turnstiles. THINGS YOU MUST SEE. I have attached the map of the Museum to this review. Below I will list the things that are worth seeing in the Hermitage. Just print out the list and the maps, and you will find those things easily.1ST FLOORTo start with, the whole first floor is meant to exhibit ancient art. So skip it, if you're not interested in Greece, Rome or ancient Asia. Egypt - the egyptian collection consists of sculptures, bas-reliefs, sarcofagi and a mummy.7 - the part I would recommend the most. Here you can see stuff found in a burial in Siberian excavations. It includes a mummy and THE OLDEST CARPET IN THE WORLD.8 - hall of Greek vases. Don't miss "Regina Vasorum" - the Queen of Vases - under the glass case. The room itself is beautiful, too, designed specially for the collection of vases.9 - the hall of Roman sculpture with a gigantic statue of Zeus.10 - the statue of the Venus of Milos, purchased by Peter the Great.2ND FLOOR All the main highlights are located here. Go up the main staircase and turn left to see GALA ROOMS, including the Ball room and the Throne hall. Then move on to see the room with the PEACOCK CLOCK (the most beautiful room, in my opinion).Then move on to the part with art and see Italian (Da Vinci, Titian, Michailangelo, Raphael, Carravagio, etc.), Dutch (Rembrandt, Hals, etc.) and Flemish (Rubens, Van Dyck) art.There are some private rooms here, such as the Malakhite hall and others, all marked on the map. Among them you can see some sitting rooms, the library, and the dining room.1 - if you like the impressionists, these rooms will be interesting for you. Here you can find some pieces by Degas, Renoir, Monet, Van Gogh and others, all broght here from Germany after WWII. 2 - not a highlight, but interesing for those who like history. In this room you can see a good collection of knights' armour.3 - known as Raphael's loggias, but basically is the exact copy of famous Raphael's loggias in the Vatican.4 and 5 - French art of 15th, 6th, 17th and 18th centuries. The interesting thing about those rooms is not the art, but the fact that those were private rooms of Catherine the Great (see how modest she was!).6 - staircase leading to the main collection of the impressionists.3RD FLOOR:All rooms marked in pink house the collection of French art of 19th and 20th centuries: the Salon art, the impressionists, post-impressionists, fauvists, Pablo Picasso and others. Please note that Matisse got transefed to the "Staff building".PLEASE NOTE:- You are not allowed to bring in big bags, backpacks, rain coats and drinks. You will be asked to check them in the cloakroom.- Photo taking is allowed, but without flash. There is no need to buy a photo permit, because nobody ever checks if you have one. It's not allowed to take photos in the rooms with temporary exhibitions.- The Hermitage is probably the most handicapt accessible museum in St. Petersburg. There are elevators which are marked on the map. If you can't find one, you can always ask somebody.- There are a lot of WC's as well, all marked on the map.- Once you checked in or threw away your water bottle, you can buy some in the cafe on the 1st floor. - To visit the Gold or Diamond rooms, you have to buy a separate ticket. Even though they are called "room", each of them consists of 4 or 5 rooms, which is lots of gold and diamonds. So unless you are obsessed with jewellery, I would recommend to see only the Diamond room, because it has gold, diamonds and other precious metals and stones, religious items, diplomatical gifts, things found during excavations in Greece and the shore of the Black sea. - The cafe in the museum leaves much to be desired, so those those who want to spend the whole day there - take some food with you and just buy drinks in the museum cafe. However, there is a decent Movenpick ice cream stand next to the cafe.- Right now (Summer 2014) in rooms 155, 156, 190-192 and 195 there is a very impressive temporary exhibition or royal gowns and the uniforms of people employed by the royal family. Totally worth seeing.

spectacular. the Hermitage was fantastic.the marble and gold entrance hall was wonderful.we hired a private car and guide,it was worth it as she showed the brillant collections and was very knowledgeable.room after room of treasures Rembrants and Di Vincis you were so close to not like other musemes.there is so much to see it would take you days that is why the private guide is a good idea.I would highly recommend the Hermitage a must see in St Petersburg.

Surpassed My Expectations. The Hermitage has been on my bucket list for years and I was not disappointed. The beauty of the palace and the amazing collection of art (pre-historic to impressionistim) surpassed my expectations. A guide brought us to the highlights. Without her, we could have easily been "misplaced" and would have missed seeing important works in the time alloted.

a million artifacts and a million tourists. Stunning collection of art and artifacts. The Hermitage is a must see for Petersburg; the palace itself (even without the art) would be a day tour. They say that if you spent 2 seconds with each piece on display it would take a week to see it all. I don't doubt it, so plan your visit! I did a quick walk through of the european art section and spent most of my time in the downstairs display, which includes archeology and finds from Siberia, as well as the very popular exhibit of clothes from imperial russia.Be forewarned- this place is always very crowded in Summer and is also very hot inside. (Air conditioning is not common in Petersburg.) Buy tickets at a kiosk in the courtyard rather than at the ticket counter- save 1/2 hour! Musueum store is lovely but overpriced. Knowing this I still bought souvenirs there.Definitely worth the visit!

Outstanding!. We were on a tour so only had a couple of hours here. The building alone is amazing!! Every room we entered had the Wow factor! I would go back to St Petersburg just to spend more time here.

Wow ... Wonderful outstanding what a place. Seeing the outside walls and windows already gives the eremitage a mighty look ... seeing the inside, the halls, the paintings, the small and big surprises lets one feel the dignity and passion of human being ... The eremitage ist a man made Palace ... full of wonder
You could spend days here. It is a little overwhelming, but shouldn't be missed. If you have a guide like we did (KJoy Travel), then she can bring you to the highlights and you can maximize your time
Wow! Wow! Wow!. You could visit here every day for a month and not be able to see all the wonderful works of art and items on display. This museum and so much more than a museum...

Horrible, but amazing art works!. This is a must see museum while you are in Saint Petersburg, but I was not impressed at all. Unfortunately we were on a guided tour and only saw a fraction of what the museum has to offer. There are some amazing pieces in the hermitage especially from Rembrandt and di Vinci that I have been waiting to see. I have been to dozens of museums in Europe and this completed my top ten in the world. That being said I was not impressed at all!First off the appearance of the building is in bad shape. The workers of the mesuem are in street clothes and can barely be identified. Not to mention they happen to be extremely rude and verbally abusive to visitors. I witnessed one screaming in Russian to a child, the mother was horrified. Granted the child was petting a marble Lion but still uncalled for. Back to the condition of museum inside. It was dirty, dusty, and obviously unkept. On the chandeliers in one of the main rooms, the candles are missing, falling over or leaning. It was a beautiful chandelier that weighed two tons but it looked awful, dirty, and unkept. I felt a lack of pride in the way the museum was kept. I debated giving this review two or three stars. Here is how I came to my decision. There are maybe five museums in the world that are 5 stars. Another 35-45 that are 4 stars. Rounding out the top 100 would be 3 stars. The reason I gave it 2 stars is because of the condition it was kept and overall sense I received from the workers and their lack of pride in the place.

Magnificent. We said "Oh my god" too many times to count while we walked through this palace. It is unbelievably splendid. (Twice, though, they had some random modern art displays that didn't fit AT ALL, but it was easy to ignore them. The rest is simply amazing.)

Crowded! Go early!. Dislikes: Extremely crowded. No a/c in most of the museum. otherwise, it was an amazing experience to be able to see the things that the Russian nobility owned. The golden peacock clock was really interesting to see, my guess is it is a one-of-a-kind creation. As it is a former palace, and the Nazis were stopped outside the city, it is well-preserved and a beautiful place to stroll through. Like I said, the crowds were terrible, but in the middle of summer in St. Petersburg, what would I expect? They didn't diminish my experience, I truly enjoyed my visit. :)

Early bird.. Taking tour gets you into almost everything early. Also, we choseto take the extra tour of the warehouse. I don't think that this wasworth the extra cost. After you see what is in the Kremlin Armory.the Hermitage warehouse was a waste of time and money.
Superlative building and contents!. No visit to St P. Would be complete without the Hermitage. Get a guided tour if you can. Cultural overload is a real risk!
Hermitage museum. spectacular...only wish we had more time to see more of it...2 days is not enough. great tour guide who provided a very good sense of the history of the area and Russia in general.

The Hermitage. We visited the museum as part of a guided tour booked in the UK through cruisingexcursions.com. Once you enter this great palace you can only look in awe at the sheer splendour of the many rooms as you walk through. The collection is so great it would take over 4 years to see everything. It was very busy but our guide arranged for headphones to be provided so we could hear her talking as we walked through. This is a must see sight if you are in St Petersburg. Even if art is not your thing - go and see.

Torn Between Art or The City. Incredible art and culture---3 million works of world art/ artifacts in 365 rooms in 6 buildings. Can stay here for days---the architecture alone is worth exploring. But with limited time in St. Petersburg, one is torn between the museum or the city itself (like Art Buchwald's comedy sketch, "The 2-Minute Louvre"). So, the advice is to prepare in advance---know what art you want to see, e.g. the Amber Room (destroyed in WWII and recreated in 2003). Then, you'll have more time to walk St. Petersburg---to feel the city's soul. Later, a canal boat ride, at sunset with wine and cheese, gives a nice overview.

shocking beautiful hermitage!. I went to visit this shocking beautiful hermitage in the exclusive evening for holland america cruise line last month - June 2014. Since the museum was closed to public so it was empty. I was so happy I went without the normal crowded surounding. Very huge, very gold, very grand---- shocking once you step in! A must see once in your lifetime. Wish we could be there longer. two and half hour is not nearly enough! Photo is allowed with no flash light - too many treasures and paintings and sculptures to take photo for!

What else can be said...?. This is the reason people to go St. Petersburg. The collection (Rembrandts, da Vincis, Renoirs, Michelangelo, Picasso, Rodin and more) is superior. Add to that the rooms in which they are housed and you're mouthing "wow" every time you cross a doorway. We spent 5 hours there and could have spent more. Exhausted and satiated when we left.
One of the best museums in the world.. This is easily one of the best museums in the world. The museum covers every area of the world. Plan on spending a whole day here.
Great artworks. Absolutely worth a vIsit even if only to see Rembrandt's Return of the prodigal son. Many many rooms to see and too much to take in on one visit.

Beautiful but bad luck with a guide. We bought general tour in the booth on the right after you enter the territory, so that we didn't have to stand in the queue. But the guide that we had was dreadful. Not client oriented, very self-centered and haughty. But it was still very beautiful and worth it.

Beautiful art, and beautiful building. The Winter Palace that houses the museum is as beautiful as the art. Do not miss the Canova sculptures, French and Dutch paintings, and the Egyptian and Greek Antiquities (not usually and antiquities fan....but I was at the Hermitage). If you come in July, the interior of the museum gets pretty warm.

this is the Hermitage museum that all talk about. an exceptional attraction, with palace rooms and facilities, amazing art, and typical Russian overwhelming size. It's very popular and very crowded. Plan accordingly.

Rooms almost outshine the displayed artworks. We visited the Winter Palace with SPB Tours who had arranged an early entrance (9:30am) for our small group before the palace opened for regular visitors. This palace is so huge with many rooms that the guide gave us a fast paced commentated tour to enable us to see a good portion of the buildings. The artwork is organised by region, time period, and country with rooms being devoted to each. The collection is unbelievably large with important/famous artists' works. One can only marvel at the budget at the disposal to Catherine II, the collector of these pieces. Being an art history major, our guide focused on certain rooms (we missed the Egypt rooms), certain artists, and certain artworks in a room. There was no lingering at any one spot. With this fast pace, we saw paintings, marble sculpture, tapestries, ornate staircases, rooms with gilt wall trim, and even a hall done up as a copy of a space in the Vatican. While the paintings are labelled in English with the artist's name and name of the painting, and are hung like those in an ordinary art gallery, we relied on the guide's commentary to tell us what we were looking at and its importance to the art movement. Even though we walked miles in that building, I am sure we didn't see all of the rooms during our 2 hour visit, but we did see the "must see" paintings usually listed in tourist guides for this attraction. Going on a guided tour with early entrance was great because we weren't pushing crowds, the paintings were not obscured with people's heads, there were no delays in going from room to room, and it was relatively quiet in them.
Very much like the Palace of Versailles.. Huge place and Museum. We had half a day and I would take days to take it all in. Reminds me of the Palace of Versailles without the gardens.

Never ceases to amaze. Have been three times and the place is still incredible. Wanted to get an English-speaking guide but they didn't seem to offer it. Took a Russian-speaking guide was really quite unfriendly and a bit boring. Otherwise, great place!

Impressive. I don't know if I enjoyed the architecture or the artwork it houses more! You could easily spend an entire day here! To beat the crowds/lines, enter through the courtyard; there is a ticket kiosk just to the left (and I believe there may be one on the right, but I am not 100% certain). During my stay, it only accepted cash (rubles) and did not give change. By using this machine, I was able to bypass the ridiculously long entrance line. I would caution that if you want to tour any special exhibits/rooms, wait until you get inside and ask the woman at the ticket desk there. The signs posted outside said one time while the staff had completely different times/information.

More than expected. This is an incredible history landmark. I was stunned (still am) that there are so many great pieces of art in that place and I don't know if it was me, but I didn't see that many security measures. There are works from da vinci, and other great painters. It does need a little bit funding to restore the place to its original magnificence. I would come back to finish the tour because it is so big, you will need a looooot of time to see all the museum attractions.

AMAZING experience LONG LONG lines. One of the wonders of the art, historical and architectural world. Do not miss this attraction. Way too much to describe - but this will be one of the highlights of your trip. Lived in St. Pete for 7 years so take it from a local resident!

Huge museum with worldwide art!. I got the ticket (ticket price was 400 rubles for foreigners) at the ticketing machine which was located near the museum garden easily. After entering the main building, saw lot of peoples standing in a queue to get the tickets.If you are solo visitor and don't want to take the help of Tour Guide, you can get Audio Guide after paying 350 rubles plus your identity card as deposit (if you opt not to deposit ID card, you need to deposit 2000 rubles). You can connect your headphones to audio guide so you don't have to hold it like a mobile phone all the time (don't forget to take your headphones :P)Loved it :)

We paid for early access. The Viking tour company arranged for early access, and it was totally worth it. We got in early and had far fewer crowds than we saw later in the day. Actually could look at the contents. Do it if available.

One of the worlds great museums. The Hermitage in St. Petersburg is made up of four interconnecting palaces including the winter palace of the tsars and the old and new Hermitage. To fully explore this magnificent museum would take a considerable amount of time as it consists of 365 rooms of displays. I would suggest reading about or visiting the museum online to plot out a course of action to maximize your time. Museums can be exhausting and this is no exception. Do not miss the wondrous Peacock clock! Even if the actual clock is not operating a continual video is displayed nearby. The Renaissance Italian room features works by DaVinci, Caravaggio, Rembrandt, Monet, Van Gogh, and Picasso which can be viewed in a fairly short amount of time. A recent worthwhile exhibit is the clothing display. I highly recommend a viewing of the movie "The Russian Ark" in which a ghost resides in the Winter Palace and visits many of it's treasures, including the gorgeous Jordan Staircase. Speaking of stairs there are many between floors. If you are able take a lift to the top and make your way downstairs. I did not see many wheelchairs or ramps and the museum gets quite crowded which makes it a challenge to navigate. Buy a skip the queue ticket available online. Note that large bags must be left at coat check and bottles of water are not allowed in any museum in Russia. Non professional photography allowed but no flash.

One of the best museums in the world. We enjoyed this tour and Alla tour got us in before normal hours so we felt like we had the museum for ourselves without the huge crowds. One can easily see why this rivals the Louve in Paris and is one of the finest museums on the planet
Amazing Museum. We loved this museum , it tis huge , never expected to be so big and precious with a lot of culture and marvelous things as well as history behind everything
More Than Expected. We were told that it would take 12 years to spend one minute looking at every item in the Hermitage, I'm willing to try...

Amazing, but too much and too crowded. The Hermitage and Winter Palace are one huge building, housing much of the art Russia has collected from abroad over the centuries. If you are an art lover it will require days to absorb. Fortunately our guide Olga's training and foresight allowed us to escape all the lines and most of the crowds, and her knowledge of what art was where allowed us to pick and choose, so that we emerged exhausted but fulfilled. The Russian art mostly has moved across the plaza and to the Russian Art Museum, as has much of the collection of French Impressionists. The place was vast and ornate, with loud reverberations and beautiful, intricately decorated inlaid floors, walls and ceilings.

Absolutely speechless. Every exhibit is amazing and not to mention the building itself! The museum is definitely the best I have ever been to, better than the Louvre and anything else! They have a great collection of art and is, in my opinion the number 1 MUST SEE when you go to St Petersburg.

A must see. Would have liked a bit more time here but as we were part of a 2 day tour we only managed a few hours. VERY busy.... too many people but try to see as much as you can. Book a tour with a small group and it is possible you bypass the huge lines of people...we did but not sure it would always work.
Never seen opulence like it. We spent around four hours marvelling at the opulence of this place,and still could not understand the dedication of all the works of art.

What is there to say? It's the largest, greatest museum on earth. The Hermitage Museum must be the Number One sight to see in St. Petersburg, Russia, for any person who takes the time and makes the considerable effort to visit this amazing city. I know it was number one on my list, for many reasons. Yes, there are other attractions greatly worth seeing -- Trip Advisor says the Church of Our Savior on the Spilled Blood is number one. With all due respect, Trip Advisor is wrong. The latter is a spectacular work of art in the form of a Russian Orthodox Church. There are many such churches in Russia, and quite a few of them are as beautiful, or more so, than the Church on Spilled Blood in St. Petersburg. But there is only one Hermitage Museum on the face of this Earth. At last reckoning, this is the largest museum on the planet. That of course doesn't mean much, if the things housed in it aren't worth seeing. But this Museum contains enough priceless and unique masterpieces of the very highest, the most supreme quality and importance, that it must outrank almost all other museums. The collection of Rembrandt paintings alone is staggering. Not just the number, but the amazing value and significance of ALL the paintings by Rembrandt on display. One painting –– The Return of the Prodigal Son –– is thought by many, myself included, to be Rembrandt's greatest work. It was certainly one of his last, and was the fruit of all his years of effort, experimentation, growth, and spiritual development. I could sit in front of it for hours. But this is only a tiny drop in the ocean of this museum's wealth. And beyond that, the collections themselves are housed in the Winter Palace of the Czars in St. Petersburg –– itself an amazing work of art, filled to the brim with history and historical art and artifacts beyond description. Without question, the Hermitage Museum is the one thing no one should miss seeing in St. Petersburg.

One of My ATF. It is hard to imagine a better museum and content combination that this. Yes, the British Museum has more stuff. Yes, the Louvre is more famous. Yes, the Pergamon may have the most authentic collection. But, the Hermitage has both a great collection and a building that, itself, is one of the greatest works of art, known to mankind. The Hermitage combines everything. I could have spent all day in this place. I recommend budgeting half to a full day.

Overwhelming!. We're glad we had a guide to take us around because the place is huge and overwhelming. The array of riches within is simply astounding and reminded me of the Vatican. The few short hours we spent here barely scratched the surface. It was a nice bonus to find out we could take photos - the various rooms were as stunning as their contents.

So disappointing. This is the worst kept museum I've ever been to. It is a virtual how to of what not to do. Huge window without curtains letting in so much light that you can barely see some of the paintings. Don't even bother with the 200 ruble expense for your camera, you won't be able to take any pictures. You're better off to look at pictures in a book.

The Hermitage. As you enter The Hermitage there are huge queues. Before you enter on the streets there are people selling copies of the Farerge Eggs. The guide gives a hear piece to all so that we can follow the explanations. In fact I got lost in the Hermitage. The grand staircase is a sight to behold. Loved the Eyptian room with the mummies. There are so many great artifacts that you cannot pin point anyone. its a visual delite.

What a Museum!. This was my second trip to St Petersburg and the Hermitage and it still was amazing and surprising. We had a tour guide supplied by the museum this time who sort of spoke English. Even with only understanding about 25% of what he said it still enhanced our experience.

Worth dealing with the crowds. It is said that it would take up to 11 years to see everything in this amazing museum. It might be best viewed with a guide to see the highlights and understand the significance of some of the collections.

A Definite to see!. The Hermitage Museum was absolutely huge. We had a tour guide take us through to point out those special areas as the museum is huge. The artwork is beautiful and the rooms so impressive. A must visit.

The Temple of Art. As an art buff, who has visited most of the major art museums in Europe multiple times, I was dazzled by the Hermitage! It's not just the collection but the splendid, opulent setting. It is a feast for the senses.I bought the 2-day ticket online for $25 and spent most of Tuesday inside. I then returned on Wednesday and stayed from 1:00 until 9:00 PM. Please keep in mind that during the day hordes of obnoxious people disembark from cruise ships and stuff themeslves into tour buses. They stream through the Hermitage, group after group, making it impossible for the genuine art lover to have any sort of experience. Their sheer crassness and frenetic picture-taking (why don't they just buy a book on the Hermitage?) will drive you crazy. If you really care for art, you MUST be there on a Wed. evening wnen the museum stays open late. The barbarians all depart by 5:30 PM, and you'll virtually have the place to yourself. However, given the sheer size of the collection, you must give yourself another day and then visit the highlights on Wed. evening.

Unbelievable. You could spend a year here and still not have time to see all the exhibits. I am not a fan of museums but this one is spectacular. The building itself is amazing could spend time just sitting outside admiring the architecture. We were on a guided tour with SPB tours (excellent company) - you really do need a guide to get the best from your visit. It is so vast and so easy to get yourself lost and you would miss the signifigance of some of the exhibits and rooms.When visiting St Petersburg this is a must see.

Go to the far end when it first opens to avoid the crowds. Cruise ships drop all their passengers here and move them around in little mobs. Go to the far end quickly right when it first opens and then slowly come back--you will miss most of the crowds. The collection is simply stunning--second only to the Louvre and yet it has recent stuff like the Impressionists that are not in the Louvre.

HISTORY. This place is full of history. Make sure you have plenty of time to see at least 1 day but we were there a few hours with our tour from the cruise ship. the art work is beautiful and sad too. the bad part was the rude tourist bumping and cutting you off to see exhibits, unbelievable, take plenty of patients, you ll need it. The secureity ladies are very rude!!! But all put aside its very worth it!ps. restroom lines out the door, unbelievable and take wipees

Impressive museum. I visited this nice impressive museum on Saturday afternoon and It was a big mistake coz, overcrowded. Apart from this disagreement, I was impressed by the beauty and the collections exposed. A very big museum containing a huge number of collections (Egyptian, classical antiquities, prehistoric jewelry, decorative arts, renaissance ...). I spent 4 hours and was able to visit only some parts of the museum. Believe me it's quite exhausting to stay there 4 hours especially when it's full of people. My advice is to select the parts you're interested in; otherwise you will need 1 day even more! Another advice is to purchase your ticket online to avoid the long queue at the entranceAudio guide with recorded spoken commentary is not so useful!

just wonderful.... I enjoyed my trip to such an extent that even though it was for business I plan on going back for vacation, it was that wonderful and since I love history and Russian is a particular favorite of mine going to the Winter Palace was a must. I plan on returning and am sure I will have much more time to spend at the sites then I did this time. But you do have to visit the palace its a must.

Catherine the Great... This is a history lesson you must attend. See how they lived and walk through the halls of were they partied and slept…the rooms and finishings will just blow your mind..A must do..
Par excellence. Russia is full of history and significant events. The museum will astound you with its fine paintings and collections of Russian art. A must see place

Has to be seen to be believed, do not expect to see or take in everything on one visit. Hard to believe the sheer size of this palace, especially given the size of the square in which it is located. An absolute must-see on any visit to this city. With the crowds of tourists visiting each day and the enormity of the interior, one can only hope to see as much as possible within any one visit. Each room is absolutely magnificent and having a good tour good is very helpful for this visit.

Almost unbelievable. This really is one of the world's great museums/art galleries. Sumptuous rooms, beautifully maintained and restored, wonderful works of art and paintings (the Impressionist collection alone is world-class), glorious views out over the River Neva from the front of the building, good information in Russian and English. There are lots of groups visiting, of course, and looking at the same major attractions - but the collection is so vast that you have to be really selective. We were certainly really grateful to go round with our own guide who selected a manageable number of paintings and sculptures to look at in a very full half-day visit.Just wonderful - and we'd love to go back.

Must do in St.Petersburg.. The state hermitage museum is a brilliant place with a large collection of historical artefacts. A minimum of a day is required to do justice to this place. The collection is organised in terms of various civilisations and time periods. The entry is crowded and even inside the museum the major attractions are all humming with people. There are artefacts from wide variety of pieces from paintings to marbles to mummies to picassos. Some rooms just blow your mind away as you enter them, the decorations of various rooms is an art in itself.It is a lot better to explore the place with tour/audio guide as it will guide you to the main attractions through this maze of wonder. TOTALLY WORTH IT..!!!

Exceeded all expectations. Spent four hours visiting the exhibits in the Hermitage, and enjoyed every second. Purchased our tickets online from home, and were very glad because the lines at the ticket booths were extremely long. We saved a lot of time, and were able to get into the facility in minutes. You could spend days in the museum, so we used Rick Steves' book on St. Petersburg to guide us around to the most important sites. During our visit they had a temporary exhibition that showed clothes worn by people in Russia from 1700 up to the present day. This was one of my favorite,however I never could understand why taking pictures was prohibited in the temp exhibit only. Enjoyed visiting the room in which Bolshevik revolution started. Loved all the paintings by the masters. I would strongly recommend that all visitors be required to visit the museum because they teach history from a completely different perspective from that we've been told in the West. .
Amazing place. full of culture and beatiful place to visit full of history, but make sure to go early to see all the hermitage.

Excellent Museum. Brilliant examples of 18th and 19th century decadence. Rooms and displays were stunning but there is so much to see you really need top go at your own pace rather than a guided tour. Not sure what the modern paintings or various ethnic displays had to do the history of the Palace.

Truly amazing!. The Hermitage Museum would be well worth a visit if the place was empty and void of artefacts,the architecture is so awesome. For me the magical ingredients are the crystal chandeliers. The art work and furniture leaves you wanting to stay longer because it is impossible to see everything you want to so it is better to prioritise before the visit and to remember that even then progress is so slow, due to vast numbers, that you will not see everything on your wish list. It can be very hot in the rooms and you are not allowed to take in bottled water. There is a ramp into the building (and six shallow steps at the entrance by the river) and hidden lifts solely for wheelchair users which the guides can access. An outstanding attraction and a must visit despite the discomforts.

Impossibly beautiful collection. The buildings themselves are art. Then, of course, there is the art....all the old and new masters. A wonderful collection too overwhelming to really take in. We especially enjoyed the Pissaros, Picassos and Monets. The only sad part is that nearly all the art is unprotected from the heat, humidity, cold, etc. a shame they do not take better care of their immense collection.
The museum of all museums. What can I say? Nothing beats Hermitage. Nothing is remotely similar to this formed residence of Royal family filled with European and world art masterpieces.

The world famous Hermitage Museum is superb. One of the major museums of the world is not to be missed. Jewels, artwork, sculpture, clothing of the Tsars’ families, are displayed as well as almost any type of luxury items that you can imagine. The rooms are immense and decorated in gold. Take your time; it is worth your while. The Hermitage is composed of multiple buildings and every nook and cranny is beautifully decorated.Fortunately and unfortunately, we were on a tour. That got us in without waiting two hours in line, but then we were pressed to keep up with our guide. We prefer to amble through a rich museum and look at what we find interesting, but on a tour, you only see the highlights. And, in the morning the place was packed. We stayed after our tour left for other venues and found the galleries more leisurely.One of the major museums of the world is not to be missed. Jewels, artwork, sculpture, clothing of the Tsars’ families, are displayed as well as almost any type of luxury items that you can imagine. The rooms are immense and decorated in gold. Take your time; it is worth your while. The Hermitage is composed of multiple buildings and every nook and cranny is beautifully decorated.Fortunately and unfortunately, we were on a tour. That got us in without waiting two hours in line, but then we were pressed to keep up with our guide. We prefer to amble through a rich museum and look at what we find interesting, but on a tour, you only see the highlights. And, in the morning the place was packed. We stayed after our tour left for other venues and found the galleries more leisurely.

WONDERFUL. If you are in St Petersburg and appreciate a bit of culture, this is the place to go. Everything is outstanding and you will spend hours here.The peacock clock is worth seeing (so is everything else).

Incredible, but watch out for pickpockets.. Fulfilled a dream of mine to visit the Hermitage Museum. We were part of a tour group with a very tight schedule and, even on a timed ticket we had to wait outside for about 15 mins, during which time various people 'accidentally' brushed past us touching our back pockets to see if we were carrying anything of value in them. Once past the chaos around the cloakrooms, toilets & ticket barriers the museum was amazing and it is so vast you can't take in everything on a 2-3 hour taster tour. From ancient to modern art and antiquities there are exhibits from throughout history but mainly focusing on the amazing works of art. Audio guides in different languages are available as well as guide books but as we were on a guided tour we had a constant commentary as well as being reminded to move swiftly along due to other groups being in the area..I loved the temporary exhibition of court dresses and uniforms from the monarchy era but were not allowed any time to look at them as we had to keep moving.Go to admire the priceless collection of art but, if your tour allows you to wander freely with an audio giude i would suggest that this would be a more enjoyable experience as it will give you the freedom to view what you want to see rather than their personal choices.It is a very hot, crowded and tiring on the feet attraction with a number of stairs to climb so i would not recommend it for people with mobility issues or children as there are not a lot of seats to sit on. Again there is the issue of thieves patrolling round and our fantastic tour guide was happy to point them out to us & to remind us to be vigilant at all times.

Must see. The Hermitage is a huge palace/museum and you should arrive early to avoid the crowds. The place is really beautiful and worth visiting. Great Rembrant's, Rafael's and other masters paintings.
one needs three weeks to see this truly amazing place. history, art,decoration. we only touched the surface in a half day tour. It is very crowded though so you need stamina!

Many treasures.. Too many things to see in a few hours. Millions of arts and collectibles tucked away in here. You can op to visit here on a Wednesdays as it closed at 9 pm instead of 6. Be sure to catch the peacock clock.

Dodging the Crowds. I went to the Hermitage twice during my visit to St. Petersburg, and I still haven't even come close to seeing even a small portion of their amazing art collection. First, a word about the long waits to get in: If you are not planning to do any of their special room tours (Gold Room etc), it is very easy to avoid the long wait in line: As you walk into the palace garden square, on either side, there are ticket machines. These machines charge slightly more (400RUB) for a ticket, but it was completely worth paying slightly more to avoid the very long line. Once I had my ticket, I was able to simply walk past the long ticket lines (using the group/ticket-holder line), drop my backpack at left luggage, and head inside.While the museum was packed during my visit, since there are so many rooms and exhibits, it was actually very possible to escape the crowds and still see some incredible art.The Winter Palace rooms and Italian art collections are great, but they are (of course) always packed. I found most of the first floor was infested with giant Chinese tour-groups and hordes of cruise tour groups, and sure, they have some great exhibits on the first floor, but I tend to prefer pre-Renaissance art and artifacts, so I gravitated toward the second floor's Byzantine and Oriental rooms (all fantastic, and the artifacts from the silk road are very cool -- The Hermitage branch in Amsterdam currently holds a lot of their best silk road artifacts though, and that is well worth a visit if you're there too). The other area I particularly enjoyed was the ground floor exhibits on ancient cultures (including a room with some amazing 2000+ year old Siberian finds).Many of the collections on the second floor had very few people in them, and even the babushkas were more friendly. A few of them even smiled at me. On the ground floor in the ancient exhibits, again, I was almost alone for most of the time. The museum's collection of Greek and Roman and Egyptian artifacts was great, but it was worth escaping the crowds for some of their lesser-known and more unique rooms.

An absolute must see. An incredible art museum. Had art from all the most famous and lots of it. Best to do with a guide as there are so many tourists that you can get lost and not see half of what you want to see. With a guide you can get to the art you want in double fast time. You also beat the queues to get in as you can get in through a separate entrance. Would totally recommend the hermitage to all. We took 3 teenagers and they all loved it.

Truly Overwhelming. Admission is slow and chaotic even if you have bought a ticket online. The signage is non-existent, the cafes are awful, and the toilet facilities are totally inadequate. Good luck with finding the cloakroom where you left your coats. But if you can endure the discomforts, this is a truly outstanding experience. I suspect that about 3-4 hours in one day is enough for most people--the brain can't take in much more. Plan in advance which paintings you want to see, and leave the rest for next time. This is a set of palaces as well as the world's largest collection of paintings. Be sure to take in all the state rooms, and marvel at both their beauty and the shameless display of wealth and power they represented.

Too Big to Appreciate.. Many times when a site is too big, a visitor simply can not have the time or the energy to appreciate the place. The State Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace is one of those place. Even before we enter the museum, we had made up our mind that we needed to limit ourselves to certain regions of the museum and we did. However the valuable collections within the museum overwhelmed all of us. We all agreed that to do justice to the site we must spend at least 2-3 days to stroll through the place. I believe that the museum can be better appreciated if the collections can be arranged into small sections with different interest in mind. The visitor can have their choice of only the section they are deeply interested in.
just like a dream. one of the greatest museums on earth with 3 million pieces of art and collectible. reflects the power and wealth of great russia and the Romanoff dynasty. visiting is a must!

Wow !! What a visit.. What can you say about such an amazing palace. Went on private tour with our guide Irina for the morning. When she left us after lunch, we stayed on for another 3 hours. Such opulence !! Amazing art collection.

Just didn't have enough time. We bought a 2 day ticket but couldn't use day 2 as there was just so much still to see in St P itself. I had bought tickets online and that did speed up the process however it is a bit confusing where you get the vouchers to get in. If you see small white huts painted red and black stripes, jus as you go through the gates, this is here you hand over your passport and other ID then are given a voucher. Take the voucher and go straight to the front of the queue waiting to get in at the front entrance. The steward will then let you pass. Once inside ignore all other ticket offices and once you've put in jackets and bags go the the entrance archway where there is a turnstile and you show your ticket at this point to gain entry.

Incredible Place, Extremely Big!. My friends and I went to the Hermitage on a Sunday morning. Buying the tickets is incredibly easy from the machines in the first courtyard and we could not understand why people were queuing. We first visited the main halls of the winter palace. It is incredible to see the lavishness of the tsarist palace. It was so interesting and very beautiful. There is currently an exhibition of clothing from Russian history which we enjoyed.We are a group of language students and art is not exactly our thing, we found it very interesting but difficult to find our way to the pieces which we knew due to the scale of the palace and lack of signage, therefore we did not manage to see many famous works. Additionally there is a very small amount of English information about the pieces, we have all studied Russian but the vocab is very specific and therefore we could not read or understand much of it.I would definitely recommend a visit but suggest getting a tour would be the best way to see the aspects that you want to see. Or alternatively be prepared to walk a lot and spend hours there. Also there seemed to be an extra charge for photography but everyone was taking photos regardless.

Seriously speechless........ This was by far the most amazing thing of our 12day Baltic cruise. I have been to many famous museums, however this one is easily at the top of the list. Someone wrote "Everything is big, with a capitol B", this is SO true. I cannot believe I was up close and so personal with several Rembrandts. I've never seen (not one, but two) HUGE Van Gogh's, again, so close. The Picasso's...omg..The Monet's!!! all the others..The staircase...the peacock clock...WOW! The history is immense and will amaze you. I am still over whelmed with all that I have seen. We went at night when the crowds were gone...I loved this place. This is truly a must see, I am so thankful I was talked into going, I simply cannot imagine having missed The Hermitage.'

need a month to see everything absolutely brilliant experience.. spent a day trying to see the highlights, mind blowing to see so many works of art in the one place. Would needmuch longer to get round all of it. Can't find enough words to describe it. Unmissable!
WOW -Amazing!. it was so intrseting with so many things to see we so little time. spent there 4 hours and yet didn't see even third of it.... go there !!!

Genuinely a Work of "ARTS".. If you are an art lover this will be a must on your places to visit, there are so many works to see that cover all the famous artists that you will be enveloped in the culture, history and complete atmosphere of not only the art but the building it is housed in.

Great museum - a bit crowded. This is a must see in St. Petersburg. It seems that this is the number one tourist attraction as this was the only place we visited that had a line and felt sometimes very crowded inside. In spite of this I highly recommend a visit. Beware of how huge it is, you must choose which parts you are going to see or otherwise you will be there for weeks.

Absolutely fantastic museum. The Hermitage combines all the grandeur of the Winter Palace architecture with art from all over the world and through the centuries. They recommend at least 4 hours to do it justice but if you wanted to see it all, I would probably say 6! We focused on the more recent art and managed it in 4 hours. Definitely worth buying a ticket in advance which gets you in directly. We went on a day when access was free for some reason and the queue snaked round the courtyard and halfway across the square. Feels great to walk to the front of that!

Everything I hoped for!. Great museum, fantastic exhibits and well laid out. It is a constant battle against the crowds and if you are on a cruise and have the opportunity to visit exclusively in the evening, grab it. We did both a scheduled group tour in the day and cruise special at night, and the second was so much better with time to stop and look.

Best sight in St. Petersburg. Set aside the day to explore this massive building and huge collection of art. If you (like me) don't care much for art, go anyway, as the architecture of the Winter Palace and Palace square right outside will blow you away. During my visit, July 2014, they had a wonderful temporary exhibit on the third floor about the art of the early Islamic caliphate. Entrance is only a few hundred rubles, but queues are long (expect about an hour).
Wow. Art museums are not my thing but anyone visiting the Heritage has to be impressed. Just the buildings alone are worth going to see!

Like the Louvre-overwhelming at first. The way to see this massive collection is to pick up the floor plan and then make a scavenger hunt of the top items in the collection. Otherwise you will exhaust yourself wandering the rooms! The Peacock Clock is a must, as are the Grand Staircase, the Malachite Room, impressionists, and the various ornate halls. Plan an entire day. Buy your ticket online to bypass the lines - you just go to the Internet Ticket booth (inside left of the main arch - hard to find) and exchange for tickets.
Garden. The gardens were beyond words, the place was so huge and beautiful I would go back and spend more time there just to take more in. Certainly a must see
Wonderful. From the grand entrance hall to the varying rooms and collections - it continues to amaze and delight.
