Fabulous!. This museum impresses at every turn - the architecture, history and art. We were fortunate to get a personal tour of the gold rooms, too, with many ancient artifacts from the area.

Top museum ever. Having been to thousand, this was my best. Before you die you have to go to. Go on a longer day when quieter and roam around and just take it all in. From the ancient artefacts to the best well know artist collection in the world. Magnificent. The building is amazing. I will definitely go back and hang out for a week!!!! If rejuvenated me!!!

Mind blowing. All the superlatives about the Hermitage are deserved--the amount of priceless art on display is difficult to comprehend. You don't get one Van Gogh, you get a roomful. Two rooms of Picasso, a number of rooms ( I lost count) of impressionists and so and so on. You can get up close and personal-- very few protected by glass screens or any other protection, so you can get as close as you want to see the detail. Not all the display conditions are ideal-- the light coming in the big windows on a sunny day causes glare here and there, but that doesn't detract from that fact that literally billions of dollars of art are on display. We tried to book online, but had no joy, but in hindsight probably didn't matter much-- you still need to convert your voucher to a ticket when you arrive. I think best bet is to use the ticket machines inside the courtyard-- simple to use, and you then get in an express queue. We arrived at 10.20am, and were in the museum a few minutes after opening at 10.30. Probably also worth going to the displays you want straight away( there are hundreds of rooms) to beat the tour groups, which tend to move like locusts through the place. Overall, unbelievable art, must see.

Too crowded. Famous and too crowded. Yes, it is filled with masterpieces and would take about 7 years to see everything in this massive museum. The one thing that ruins it is the vast number of tourists (especially summer months) going through their doors. It does not house any Russian Art so if you are looking for that, there are probably smaller, less crowded museums for that, I suppose. The building is magnificent. Perhaps the best time to see this museum is in the dead of winter when most tourists prefer to stay away from arctic cold...

Museum grand style. Fascinating to compare the Hermitage with the Louvre and a host of western art galleries, museums and palaces. Everything is Big (with a capital B) . It is easy to get lost. The saying that 20 seconds spent viewing each exhibit would require an 8-year visit can easily be believed.

Do not be temptated for free Thursday enerance.... Very reach and colorful museum . Let your self a few hours to visit and still you had only 10 percent of it. If you are a real masochist try the free Thursday ( the first in every month) entrance... ( you will wait for 3 hours Que ...)

Astonishing!. Totally unbelievably massive absolute must see!!!There are more priceless works of art in this place than you can shake a stick at, and it is beautiful inside. Be careful you don't "out museum" yourself. Pick a plan of what you want to see and stick to it. It would take you years to see all of it!

Needs at least a month to see it properly. The Hermitage building is hugely impressive in itself. The contents are simply amazing. To try and see it in one day is really an insult to the curators. But millions of visitors, like us, try to do it!

Incredible amount of art!. Visited the Hermitage as part of a tour with Insider Tour St. Petersburg. I'm not a great fan of art but knew I had to see this Russian icon and I was not disappointed.It may have helped having such a knowledgeable guide. Marina visits the museum 3 or 4 times a week with guests! She took us to all her favourite sections and showed us the cream of the multitude of work on offer. It's said that if you spend just one minute in from of each piece it would take you 8 years straight to see everything!! So with only two hours you really need someone that knows what they're doing!I loved seeing the originals from famous artists like Renoir and Leonardo Di Vinci but the best part for me was the awesome architecture. The buildings inside and out were just stunning!It was very warm inside and is apparently like that most if the time, so dress accordingly :)I highly recommend giving it a visit!

Historic but frustrating. We pre-booked our tickets but still had to queue for nearly an hour to collect them only to find that the clerk couldn't read the bar code and were redirected to the reception. Once we had our tickets we had to fight our way through the crowd and decided to visit the upper rooms to return back for the Dimond room. This was a bad mistake as in the afternoon it is only possible to visit in groups or to be Russian. In saying all this we loved all the exhibitions and we were mind blown.

Not just for the art enthusiast. This palace houses 3 million artefacts. I thought it was heaps better than the Louvre in Paris and the Prada in Madrid, mainly because the palace itself is simply stunning. The gold gilding mixed with the beautiful architecture is a sight to behold. I didn't appreciate art until I took an after hours guided tour of this place. The Rembrandt room is special.

Huge, crowded and amazing- definitely use a guide. This is a museum like nothing I've ever seen- the collection is vast and it would take weeks to see it all. We spent about three hours here, and it was like eating every chocolate in the box- by the end of it it was difficult to absorb and appreciate what I was seeing. It was strange to see works of art out in the open, exposed to sunlight and whatever else might come in through the wide-opened windows, but that seemed to be the norm. The lines for admission are very long, so it is worth it to go with a guide, as you will be able to skip the line and get to what you'd like to see without wandering around confused while trying to decipher the map. Its best to arrive as early as possible if you're on your own, before crowds from the cruise ships descend. Still, even with the crowds and challenges of navigating the vast collection, it would be a shame to visit St. Petersburg and skip this museum.

Worth the wait. You could be left waiting for hours but the artworks and the structures themselves are a wonder to behold. You could spend weeks and not see everything so study up before visiting and decide what you want to see. An experienced private guide is a good investment.

Best with a guide. The Hermitage is the largest art museum in the world, with 3 million artifacts. You cannot see it all in a single trip, even if you spend all day every day of you vacation here. To see the best, get in early before the big crowds, and get the history, book a guide in advance. Our guide, Elena, was terrific at asking what we wanted to see, explaining the history of the art, and even what the artist intended. $58 per person which included the entrance fee for 3 hours through Best Guides. The Hermitage packs up with visitors in the morning but is less crowded in the mid afternoon.
OMG!!. Iloved this museum, It is sooo nice! I have been to Paris and London and etc...but the Hermitage is one of a kind. Very worth visiting if you go to Russia and St. Peteresburg

Try to get there when it opens. We were with a tour group that had gotten tickets to view the Hermitage and the off site storage facility of all the overload of items. We started at the museum when it opened and our guide took us backwards at points to avoid crowds to give us closer look. Not a bad strategy. By the time we left the place was packed and viewing would have been more difficult. The storage facility is not generally open for the public so we were lucky. It was filled with paintings, furniture, and other objects either being preserved or deemed not worthy of general viewing. It was a treat.

Excellent, fantastic & everything else:. One of the reasons we took a cruise on the Baltic, to some six ports of call, was to see St Petersburg. We felt it was easier to enter Russia via a 2-day shore excursion from the cruise line than to travel there independently. After docking, the State Hermitage was our first stop and we spent virtually most of the first day there. Our guide, Alexi, was fantastic; his command of the English language & his knowledge of the arts was extremely helpful. We were thankful he was our guide for both days.As you climb the staircases to enter the museum let your mind wander and you will be momentarily transported back in time to opulent Tsarist Russia. The Hermitage has an immense collection of art and ornately decorated period rooms where you could spend hours at each location. It is a fantastic must-see museum on a par with major museums in other countries; perhaps even better. We were there on an overcast & rainy Tuesday morning at the end of May and it was crowded. Those of us who had raincoats and/or umbrellas had to check them downstairs before we were allowed to enter the museum. Later in the day, at the end of the tour, when we went back downstairs to retrieve our personal belongings, it was chaotic. There were literally hundreds of people moving in every direction trying to retrieve personal items, checking personal items or looking for rest rooms. (This could happen if the museum is crowded & you visit on a day when there is inclement weather.)Bottom line: This is one of the museums you must visit. Bring a good digital camera with a large memory card and be aware that flash photography is not allowed.

If you have 7 years, and can walk 20 miles, you can see the whole thing! (spending a minute at each work of art!). The main staircase is breathtaking all by itself, but the priceless art collection contained within these walls is staggeringly beautiful and worth lingering and marveling over. Masterpieces by Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci, Rembrandt, Reubens, Van Gogh, Caravaggio, Raphael, Titian, Tintoretto, Cezanne, Renoir, Degas, Gauguin, Matisse, Monet, Picasso, and I could go on and on.....incredible to see the actual works of art that most people only see in pictures. (and yes, you MAY take pictures of them!) Sculptures as well--Canova, Michelangelo...ancient Greek and Roman art, Oriental art...5 buildings full of 3 million exhibits! Spend as much time here as you can! You'll be awed by everything contained within the Hermitage!

Not to be missed - but try to get there early. We visited the Winter Palace and Hermitage with a tour group and had so-called "privileged access." This meant we started our tour 90 minutes before the normal opening time and I strongly recommend you do this if possible. We had a fairly civilized visit, but later on it was extremely busy and I would not have liked to visit it under those conditions. This is really a double tour, because there are the opulent rooms of the Palace and then the priceless collection of art works in the museum. A bonus is that (unusually) photography is allowed, and is free! Not many museums allow you to photograph grand masters without at least paying a fee. Our arrangement also allowed us to see the storage facility of the Hermitage, which is in a different location. Photography is not allowed here. It was interesting to see the state-of-the-art custom-built building and to marvel at all the "extra" works of art they have, but I don't think it added very much to the tour as a whole.

Wow!!!. So much to see and so little time! It is worth doing in a couple days if you have the time. One thing that really stands out for me is the mosaic pictures and tables..... they look like they are painted. And the beautiful clock!!!!

A quick visit. We went on the train all the way to the Peterhoff (the hydrofoil wasn't running) and got off at the station in a massive thunderstorm, got soaked through, and then came all the way home again (after a minor argument with a grumpy wife!). In the end we went to the Hermitage but didn't have much time. We concentrated on the state rooms of the winter palace itself. Lots of the rooms have lost their original decor and are quite plain, but the rooms that remain intact/renovated are breathtaking! Worth the visit for those rooms alone. Thumbs up!

Art. Some truly amazing paintings in here - despite the crowds there is so much to see here that you can still get close up - much more so than in a western Europe gallery! The perspective paintings by Canaletto have to be the most amazing ones.

Amazing building and art collection. The Winter Palace and Hermitage collection is everything that it is described as! Just amazing. The Palace building itself is impressive, the architecture and the rooms are incredibly opulent - always look up and check out the ceilings! When I was there, there was a temporary exhibit of clothing from the Tsarist era. For me this was the most interesting bit - it made the people come alive. You cannot see everything so get a map beforehand and work out what you want to see. I recommend buying a guide book. There are plenty on sale at the various shops and kiosks both within the museum and around the city. The pictures in the book are far better than you will ever get on your camera, and if you have the book then you don't need to worry about taking photos and can actually look at the art! As with everything in St. P, go early to avoid the tours from the cruise ships. Booking your ticket online beforehand (you will need to print it) does help beat the queues.

Early Entry was Key to a Great Visit. You can literally spend years in this place if you wanted to see it all. We visited with a knowledgeable tour guide in association with Alla tours. Being with the tour allowed us early entry before the place was overrun, and being with a guide allowed us him to make good choices for as to what to see in a short amount of time.

Can be overwhelming. One has to give the Hermitage an excellent rating just for what it is, a massive collection of fine art objects as well as opulent interiors. It can get very crowded, and one can only see a limited number of the many exhibits in any given block of time. Unfortunately, the lighting is often poor, sometimes inadequate for appreciation of the paintings, while in many rooms light streaming through regular plate glass windows reflects off the works. (How long can they go without fading?) Despite the negatives, however, the museums are a must see in St. Petersburg.

Beautifully utilized Palace to share History & Art. This is an amazing landmark off the shores of the Neva River. Gorgeous building that is being taken care of very well, and inside it's equally as gorgeous, if not more. There is just so much to see and soak in that you can very easily spend a day or more there. Not only is the artwork collection magnificent, but the building itself and the grounds are meticulous in details and history. One tip to visitors, do not wear big coats, or you will have to check them in the coat room. Plus it's quite toasty in the building. We found a couple open windows and rushed to stand by and get some cooler air. Between the hundreds of people in the building and lack of air circulation, the heat was a bit distracting from all of the treasures surrounding us, but you will find pieces that will amaze you and check off those bucket list items, of things to see with your own eyes.

A Top Art Museum. This has to be one of the world's top half dozen art museums. The collection includes an interesting sculpture by Michelangelo and numerous excellent paintings by the masters from Raphael to Da Vinci. We particularly enjoyed a couple of rooms devoted to impressionists, including Degas, Pissarro, Monet, Cezanne, and Renoir. As many have observed, it is impossible to visit the entire collection in a day or two, so having a guide is valuable. We visited selected parts of the second floor for roughly 2-3 hours. At least on the day of our visit, early admission was invaluable since we saw crushes of people trailing our path. Photos without flash are permitted, but paintings are typically covered with glass panels, producing some reflections. We visited the Gold Room, which often involves an extra fee. The collection in the Gold Room is mostly devoted to ancient gold ornaments, dating back before the earliest Greek craftsmen. As one of the Peter the Great's Winter Palace, the Hermitage is also an impressive architectural visit in its own right. In this regard it cannot compare to St. Catherine's Palace for opulent decor. Free bathrooms are best accessed at the beginning of the visit.

Just go here!. This is an amazing museum full of the most wonderful treasures and apparently if you looked at every exhibit it would take you eleven years!From the moment you enter the Winter Palace you have a sense of what life was like for the Tsar and his family. Ascend the Grand Staircase and you are transported back into the last century. All the rooms take your breath away.While we were visiting there was a special exhibition on - costumes - you could spent hours in this one exhibition alone marvelling at the work that went into each gown.qThe Art is fantastic - best exhibition of Impressionist painters outside Paris.Spent a day here and then go back for more!

A must whilst in St Petersburg.. We did a tour of this museum as we only had limited time here. What a treasure trove of exhibitions! Be prepared for the crowds and a few queues, but it's well worth the effort. It's vast amount of exhibits really is mind blowing and simply amazing.
The Hermitage. What an incredible collection of art and historical pieces. Besides that, the 5 buildings are also sumptuous. One needs and entire day for each of the buildings to do it justice!

Too little time to see too much. We loved this very historic museum and loved looking at the clothes of the monarchs. We also enjoyed Russian and European art. However, we only had two hours, so we couldn't see too much.

Spectacular. There is so much history and so many incredible works of art all in one place! More paintings in a Hermitage than any other place in the world. Having a local guide is a must. Minimum time is at least 1/2 a day, which barely scratches the surface! Amazing

Okay museum but needs better oversight. Having been to the British Museum in London, another gigantic museum, I assumed the Hermitage would be equally as good. Yes the Hermitage had fabulous paintings etc but the pushing and shoving crowds to see the paintings of the masters was out of control. This combined with the idiots taking FLASH photography when signs clearly said no flash photography--and the docents/museum staff sat idly by without saying anything--it was ludicrous. I'd rather look at the Hermitage collection in a book.

Mind blowing. If you visit St. Pet. You have to visit the Hermitage(winter palace). It is such a sensory explosion, you can't miss it.Inside the palace there are private tour guides, which seem to hover around and you can approach them. They will then allocate a guide to you for an hour. You can negotiate a price, but it is well worth it.There you will see some of the greatest works of art you will maybe every see in your life time,certainly in mine.The Hermitage which consists of i think 3 adjoining palaces is on the Banks of the river Neva , which when we went last December, was frozen over in wave like shapes. It was stunning.Saint petersburg is a place I will never forget. I went with my daughter aged 26, and we had the best time, there is so much to see.If you are a culture vulture like me, you will be amazed.

A must see!. The palace is beautiful, and the art was amazing (even for this non-art-museum-loving family!) We visited with Tailored Tours (see my full review there) and received so much interesting information along with our tour!

Can be enjoyed on wheels.. Just returned from Baltic cruise and this was a real highlight. Yes it was crowded but tour groups get in early, so we were an hour ahead of independent travelers which made it posslble for me to see the exhibits even in my wheelchair.There are about six steps to encounter at the main entrance for which I needed help but after that there are two lifts meaning the main 4 buildings are accessible, this tour is not recommended for wheelchair users but if you can get up a few steps with help ignore the advice and go for it - it 's worth it!!Obviously on a half day tour you can only get a taste of the place, but the opulence of the rooms,particularly those the Winter Palace is breath taking, and you see a countless number of master pieces. If you have enough time I think you would need to spend two days in the Hermitage to do it justice, but there is so much to see in St Petersburg this may not be possible, so just do your best.

Not an Artie fartie and still enjoyed it.. Not being an Artie fanatic, but having taken a much deeper interest in art after visiting here! Lovely artwork on show here in a show itself the museum being made with gold and lovely rooms and decor. The bit that was fascinating was when I came across paintings I knew or artists I knew, the naughty room was fun with its exotic artwork. Sme hidden naughtiness in there if you look carefully. Definitely recommend a guide! Massive place and so much to see and know about. Worth a visit, lived up to its famous name, but I would say it's once in a lifetime for me. I enjoyed it even without having a huge art interest.

World Class Museum. Right up there near the Metropolitan and the Louvre albeit not quite as extensive.
Museum has been curated well and the layout of the various buildings is quite logical and flowing.

A must see... No1 in St Petersburg. Do NOT go to St Petersburg without visiting the Winter Palace now known as The Hermitage, it is a state Museum with possibly the biggest collection of Art & Valuables from all over the World..... this place is simply the number one place in St Petersburg to visit, as beautiful as the outside is this is nothing compared to the breath taking interior...... luckily for me my wife is a former Russian Tour Guide so I got the full treatment on our first visit to the Palace, I would recommend a guided tour with an official guide to get the best from this attraction.... unless of course you speak Russian.Also forget the Old image of Communist Russia..... things have changed a lot since 1991 and Russia and the Russian People are fantastic

What a Disappointment!. Hundreds and hundreds of people, only saw the art work that the guide knew...walked through very fast and had to vie for a space to take a photo...Schönbrunn and Versailles are far superior!!! Actually, St Pete was a disappointment!!!
Absolute MUST. Went recently and two days is not enough even with a fabulous guide. the range of exhibits rooms etc take your breath away. By far the best museum I have visited.
Much more than a museum!. So much to see it can keep you occupied for hours .. or days if you wanted! Went in February so no queues and clear views of exhibits .. brilliant place to explore!

Amazing. So much to see here. Make sure you have a minimum of 4 hours. Wednesdays the museum is open late (until 9?) and is when I went to avoid the crowds I observed on other days during regular hours.

One of the best museums in the world. The building itself is an incredible work of art and of course the amazing collection that covers the many centuries of art "at it's best". Look for a new wing opening (I think) later this year!

A day is not enough. Have been here twice and wish we had more time to explore.Words can not describe this place.There is so much to see. Great place to spend rainy days.Look for the peacock clock! Love it.

Amazing. The place is just amazing,so rich and so perfectly keeped, I'm just amazed of size and of perfection with the smallest detail. Pictures can't show all the beauty of the place.u must just see it.

Famously Beautiful. The Hermitage is famous for being a beautiful building - and it totally is. The collection of art is amazing, but it's the decorations of the rooms that I went for. Pay attention to the floors - the inlay is spectacular. Make sure to buy your tickets from the machine outside so you won't get frustrated by waiting in the line with the locals - this can be a very frustrating experience.

magnificent. The palace is huge.
Unfortunately during the white nights period is also very crowded.
It takes at least one full day visit.
It is better to buy the ticket online and plan in advance what to see.

A fantastic collection of art. Be prepared to spend an entire day here. It took us an hour to figure out where we were and how to read the map to follow audio guide. There are more than 320 rooms here spread across three floors and you can't get to the 3rd floor without a lift. The lift is well hidden. However, every room has an employee and they are very helpful. You can point out where you want to go on the map and they will guide you. If you don't have an entire day, make sure you know exactly what you want to see and their room numbers. The audio guide gives you a brief history of the important paintings and rooms. While most people moved across rooms quickly, if you are an art lover one can easily spend an entire day here.

Wonderful. We were part of the dreaded cruise group but luckily were able to enter the Hermitage before the crowds, spent two hours viewing the wonderful pieces of art, very tiring but wouldn't have missed it. I believe there is one day a month when entry is free and have been told it is impossible to move inside, so avoid these days.

OMG. go there it's so fab - but get there very early to avoid queues - we were lucky enough to be the first group in but by the time we got out you couldn't move for bodiescheck out the peacock clock - amazing!

Top site to see. We were there in April so no crowds. We used the self serve kiosks at the entrance so could by pass the line of people waiting to buy tickets from the office. The entrance hall is breath taking - use the map to find your way around and don't be afraid to ask the volunteers where you are. It is a massive site and easy to walk down the wrong corridor.
Don't get lost. So much to see - amazing exhibits - but this is a maze. If you have to separate, make sure you know where you left your companion.

A must!. The architecture of this building is just beautiful. The art is breath taking and you can spend hours enjoying pieces from Rembrant, Monet, Picasso etc. Even with the crowds you can see the pieces.
Great history and art.. Overwhelming. Personally would recommend a tour guide unless you intend to spend a week. Brush up on your Russian history first.

Avoid the crowds - have lunch elsewhere!. Nearly 100% of visitors to St. Petersburg go to the Hermitage. Additionally, it rains a lot (yes... a lot) in St. Petersburg, so museums (and churches) are busy. Try to avoid the crowds by checking if any cruise lines have docked on the day you plan to visit the Hermitage - reschedule, or be prepared to manage elbow-to-elbow crowds. While we were at the Hermitage 4 cruise ships brought busloads of visitors, who like us, wanted to see it. That meant we were herded through the Amber room (2 minutes). There was a 45- minute wait to get a small lunch, and it was very difficult to reach the WCs and coat rooms. Of course, it was worth it, but it can be better with good planning!

Works of art are amazing!. THis was my 2nd and last trip to St. Petersburg, and 1st time to the Hermitage.What an amazing place! Myself not a big museum fan, this place on the other hand was amazing!The works of art are jawdropping to DaVinci, Rembrandt, Monet, Picasso, a must see place to go and visit while in this beautiful city.Go early enough to try to avoid the long long lines, better to go in as a planned group if you can.

A must see Palace. Of course this is one of the places that you must see if you go to St.Petersburg. I am not a huge fan of art, but more of architecture. I reserved 4 hours for my round in there, but found that I spent there 5 hours until I checked what the time was.Some tips: I booked my ticket online and had to queue to change the voucher to actual ticket. I went there 5 minutes before the museum opened and there was a huge queue for the kiosk, where you get your ticket. Although I didn't need to queue more than 15 minutes, I found out that if I just had bought the tickets from the vending machines, I would have just walked to the machine, bought the ticket and walked in. So no need to buy the ticket beforehand.Plan before you go! I knew what I wanted to see, but I didn't plan the route to go. So I ended up bouncing back and forth the Palace. So think beforehand what you want to see and plan the route you will walk beforehand. There are maps available in the net where you can see what is and where. Also you can download such apps for you tablet or mobile. And take into account that the place will be crowded, even from the opening time of the museum.Go beyond, after I had seen what I wanted, I found a very interesting gallery of Siberian history, where there was almost no one else.

Winter Palace St Petersburg. The Winter Palace in St Petersburg has to be seen to be believed. It is absolutely enormous and the sheer scale of the place is striking. It houses over 3 million art works. There are a lot of visitors but you are still able to appreciate the contents of the place. If you pre-book your tickets online or buy them from the ticket machines you can jump the queue, but the queue only takes about 10 minutes. Wear good walking shoes because we covered approximately 7 kms on our visit.A must.

Treasure trove. An amazing museum containing some of the finest arts in the World. Picasso,Rembrant,Leonardo, Monet, and many more - too many to mention.Its impossible to estimate the art value and how the Romanov dynasty acquired them.You will see a bigger selection of World renown artists than anywhere else.Sadly the Russian assistants who sit in their chairs with expressionless faces look very unwelcoming.

Overwhelming Amount of Art. The Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg is huge and the rooms inside are beautiful and filled with an enormous amount of amazing art! The entrance to the building was filled with tourists, but it is so large that it was easy to get away from the crowds and walk through galleries with very few people in them.As you walk from room to room you become overwhelmed by the amount and quality of art on the walls.There are 27 Rembrandts, countless Picassos and one room contained 33 Cezannes!There was a huge temporary exhibition of clothing worn by the Tsars and Tsarinas going back as far as Catherine the Great. The condition and quality was amazing and I could have spent all day looking at the intricate details on the gowns and military uniforms.A few hours at the Hermitage was definitely not enough time. It would take multiple visits to see and absorb even a small part of what was on display.

Masterpieces by the metre. What can you say about this wonderful museum. We went up the impressive marble staircase to start our tour. We saw a lot but still only saw a fraction of what is there. I bought a DVD which I have found useful to remind of what I did see

My main reason for going to St. Petersburg. I wasn't disappointed, despite the crowds. I chose to visit only Renaissance Italian and Spanish, 14-16th Century Dutch and Flemish, and Impressionist art, and the Fabrege eggs,but it was still time consuming, as the Museum and Palace are huge. Fortunately I had a guide and advance tickets so I did not need to wait in line to get in though it still took time to enter and get to the exhibits. IF you have difficulty walking this is not the place for you as it involves a lot of walking and elevators are very few and far between.
Stunning. It is amazing inside and you can't take it all in at one visit.Disadvantage was the long queue to get in and as my son lived there we got there early but still a long wait.

Oozes history. Nerve-tingling for anyone with an interest in history. Eisenstein's epic (albeit fictional) storming of the Winter Palace comes to mind. The interior is just as breath-taking. The ceilings are magnificent. Wonderful, wonderful, wonderful.

Long queues and even longer walking!. To me, the Winter Palace is a must see when in St Petersburg, but that's all it remains to be as once you've queued to get in, then queued to the ticket office, then the cloakroom, you're already tired out, let alone knowing you have to walk around with very little seating once you're in there. I'm glad I can say I've been in it, but once is enough!

Wonderful art but the facilities...!. We bought online tickets for 2 visits; my main objective was to see the Matisses on the top floor. This we did on our first visit, but the second time, a few days later, we found only two completely empty rooms!! No information as to why, or where the paintings had gone (is this the biggest art theft of the century?!), I have tried visiting the Hermitage website and emailing visitor services but the email is bounced back (asking the website manager if the address is incorrect produced no response). This seems a very cavalier attitude for a top-class public attraction.Secondly, our Lonely Planet guidebook assured us that there were plenty of toilet facilities aside from the obvious ones by the entrance. However, according to the Hermitage's own map, there are 2 further loos on the ground floor, *none* on the first floor and *none* on the second floor. The problem is heightened by the fact that there are only two lifts for the main building, only one of which goes to the second floor. Signposting for these facilities is sporadic and unclear. I suffer from bursitis which makes walking difficult, and trailing along the long long corridors searching vainly for a lift (or even a staircase!) was very unpleasant and spoiled the whole experience for me. I hate to think how a seriously disabled person would manage. The cafes are laughably inadequate for the number of visitors; don't bother with them. A world-class institution should do better in the 21st century. And WHERE ARE THE MATISSES?

Get there early. One of the 4 most important art museums in the world - a must see! But if you want to see all exhibitions - arrive early to get the tickets - by 12 noon tickets to Gold And Gems exhibitions are gone!

Crowded, but spectacular. Spectacular collection of art and magnificent rooms. For some weird reason there is only a very minimal cafeteria so plan to eat at one of the excellent restaurants on the canal behind the museum.

Wow!!!!. So beautiful and comprehensive!
Great museum, but can get very busy and hot in the summer!
Make sure to go with a tour group to avoid the lines!

Hermitage Museum a must see in St Petersburg. Hermitage - must be the one of the major highlights of any visit to St Petersburg. Centrally located, it was once a home of the Romanov dynasty and now houses 3 million items, which it has been estimated to take 12 years to see every single object. One of very few palaces or museums where photos, without flash, is allowed - hooray. The Hermitage contains some truly magnificent artworks and sculptures, Rembrandt, Davinci, Michelangelo, Rafael, Monet to name a few. There are also numerous other items to see not forgetting the wonderful internal structure, decorations, tapestries, parquetry floors and so forth. We went one evening when the museum was especially opened for us and so no queues, but I understand during the day it can be wall to wall people inside the Hermitage and therefore long periods of delays getting into the Museum. Whatever it takes, a visit to St Petersburg must include the Hermitage Museum.

Tips for your visit to the Hermitage. Buy the two day combined entrance ticket on-line which allows you entry to the Hermitage and also to five other museums within the next five days - not two! At the Hermitage join the queue for visitors with tickets and proceed to the Information Desk where your voucher will be checked against ID and you will be directed to a special kiosk to collect your tickets. This process took just a few minutes. Once you have passed through security and the turnstiles hire the audio guided tour which comes with a map and suggested route and enjoy! Don't worry about getting lost, there is ample signage and even if you do get a little lost it is a wonderful place to be lost in and you will eventually find your way again!! Allow at least a day and take time out for a snack/meal at one of the cafes on the ground floor. Also don't worry about the crowds. It does get crowded at times but the tour groups move quite fast and it goes from being crowded to just about empty very quickly. We also went on a guided tour but that was not particularly good. The guide appeared to be knowledgeable but spoke very indistinctly. The audio guide is better. Your combined ticket also allows entry to the Winter Palace of Peter the Great and the Menshikov Palace, both well worth visiting and the latter has some stunning interiors, and there was hardly anyone else there when we visited!

Getting into the Hermitage: Helpful Hint. The Hermitage has the reputation for being one of the best museums in the world and it is a reputation it deserves. Instead of adding my praise to the millons of others who have been awed by this museum I will give you a helpful hint on how to make sure you are able to get in. We decided to go on the most crowed day, Sunday and during the White Nights. The museum opens at 10:30 am. We got on line at 9:00 am and were among the first on line. By 10 am the line stretched across the plaza to the Peter monument. At about 10:00 am the outer doors were opened and the line moved forward to the inner courtyard. At that point, groups and those with internet tickets were let in first. Finally, those without tickets. We finally purchased our tickets at around 11:15 am. So, unless you are going in the middle of the week in the middle of the Russian winter, get on line early or buy internet tickets or join a group.Inside the museum, expect crowds especially in the Rembrandt rooms. The rooms are very warm so dress appropriately. You an take pictures of the paintings (without flash) but quite honestly given the glare that comes in from the windows, you are better off buying a book of prints. Given all that, the Rembrandt rooms alone make this museum special. We found the ancient art rooms (Roman and Greek) to be less crowed and quite stunning and the original Winter Palace rooms on display are by themselves worth a visit.The cafeteria was crowded but quite efficient and served sandwiches and beer and pastry. The sandwiches were pre-made but quite good and the pastries were excellent. Finally, do not expect to be able to exit the Hermitage and re-enter. The ticket is only good for one entry per day. This means you cannot enter in the morning, exit to have lunch and then get back in. To do that, you will need to purchase another ticket.

State Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace Excellent. This was an amazing site to visit. We should have allotted three days to visit this beautiful site, due to all of the treasures exhibited. Our three hour visit was not long enough to see all that we would have liked to see. The national treasures contained in this massive museum are beyond description.

Great museum but no Louvre. The Hermitage is often referred to "The Russian Louvre" however it does fall short of the French counterpart.The bathroom facilities are really poor and there aren't any places and they don't even let you take a bottle of water with you in the museum. They don't even have a place where you can buy a bottle of water and the vendors outside don't take credit cards or non Russian money.

Hermitage Museum. Even if you are not that into art, this is an amazing place to visit. The building itself and the gardens are truly beautiful. We were treated to a song from four tenors in one of the rooms, goosebump moment! we were on a SPB Tour and so we were escorted in before the opening time, and went through with very little people so it was ideal.

Best part. of Saint Petersburg. Both gallery and historical rooms are very interesting and 'must to see' in Pit'er. Only problem is undersized background - especially enter and bufet. Also there should be more benches.

Too big and not clear directory. The museum was very big and the directory and signage were not clear. Worst was that many exhibits did not have English explanation so we didn't know what we were appreciating. The temporary exhibition was very good though.

Overwhelming. The Hermitage is one of the greatest museums/art galleries in the world. It would take days to see everything. It is also very busy in the tourist season and we were lucky enough to be on a private tour with a guide who really knew what to look at and to make sure we saw the highlights. It would have been very difficult to browse on our own in the time we had. The collection is pretty eclectic, purchased as it became available. The Winter Palace is spectacular and in many ways is the main exhibit. It would now be good to go back and view at leisure but this would have to be off season when the cruise ships and tour busses are long gone.

Beautiful rooms and way too crowded!. We took an excursion during our stop in St. Petersburg while on a Baltic cruise. There were at least five other ships that we were aware of that docked that same day, so that probably had something to do with the fact that it was soooooo crowded and chaotic at the Hermitage. This made it difficult to enjoy the amazing art in the museum and decor of the rooms in the palace. Plus, our time was limited so we were streaming in and out and often going against the flow of foot traffic. I was particularly taken by the beautiful parquet floors with their intricate designs. I would suggest visiting in the early a.m. when visitor traffic might be lighter. Either way- it is well worth the time to go there.

Visit 2x: once via tour group, and then again on your own. We've visited The Louvre 2x on the same trip to Paris, and I did so at The Guggenheim Bilbao, and The Prado, and The Tate Modern, and what art lover has ever walked through MOMA just once? Endure the crowds, and then return again with just a friend or two. You'll nimbly move among the galleries to your favorite painters and periods. And either before or after your visit, can I recommend Alexander Sokurov's 96 minute film "Russian Ark", shot completely inside The Hermitage. It contains the longest unbroken shot in the history of film (96 minutes), moving solely through the galleries and halls of the museum. Besides your own photos, you'll be able to return to The Hermitage whenever you wish. And for me the experience was as much about the palace as it was the art it housed.

Incredible Museum. Fabulous art in a magnificent palace. The palace itself is art with amazing ceiling and floors, in which the art is displayed. I can see why there was a revolution in 1917. Buy tickets in advance to avoid a huge line. if you love art one needs more than one day to see it. More than 7 miles of hallways so wear good shoes

So much art, so many chandeliers!. The Hermitage is overwhelming, but so worth it! We spent a total of 13 hours there over two days. You simply must purchase tickets online, to bypass the lines. Print your voucher, and stop at the internet ticket kiosk just inside the main gate. They'll give you your official tickets, and photo-permission stickers. Then walk on up to the left of the long line of cruise ship tour groups and head straight to the coatrooms. We did the two-day tickets and still felt like we were just hitting the highlights. My husband and I are both art historians and museum professionals, so were just fine without a guided tour. We could have benefited from some cartography training to follow the maps though. We spent a lot of time lost, and I spent quite some time in lines for the restrooms, of which there aren't many. And good luck finding them when you need one- I'd recommend using the ones down by the coatrooms before you start into the main galleries! We went on a Thursday and Friday in early June, and found the Thursday crowds to be quite reasonable. There was barely a line to get in, and I was thrilled to be able to spend one-on-one time with many of the masterpieces. Friday was a different story! Just stay out of the path of the tours (they won't stick around in one place too long, so just let them march through and go back to whatever you were looking at).The only true negative for me was the condition of many of the paintings. You can definitely tell which ones had received conservation treatment and which ones hadn't. Thick layers of darkened varnish obscured many of the subtleties of color, but with a collection in the millions what can you really expect? I'm jaded by my profession though- a casual viewer is unlikely to notice or be bothered by it! Whether you're visiting for the art, architecture, or interior design, you won't be disappointed!
Wow... Wow... Wow.... Don't miss this one Hermitage and winter palace are truly Breathtaking the Amber room and the Gold room are unimaginable you have to see it to believe it... Enjoy!!!
Extremely interesting. Loved the museum, showed off a lot of Russia's heritage. Was a great day out and you can use your camera in the museum although all the signs say you can't

Must see.... I gave State Hermitage 4 stars as I ranked it right below Peterhof but both sites are can't miss destinations in St. Petersburg.The museum is vast and as you venture from one room to another, it keeps impressing.One thing that is great is that photos are allowed on most items thus you will come away with an impressive photo album of the wonderful displays, both rich in color and history.

Want to see more. We were fortunate to be allowed access earlier than the public so we had time to enjoy some of the more well know artists. The Hermitage is so huge you cannot see much in 1.5 hours. You do have to appreciate the magnitude of this museum as well the spectacular art works

One of the most impressive museums!. This is not just a museum, it is a complex of palaces and museums......overwhelming but fantastic!I chose not to take a tour since my husband and I were "toured out", although we did learn that in Russia, it is important to spend the money and take a tour. I purchased tickets through the Hermitage website and selected only the main museum option> there is an option to include all of the corresponding palaces if one chooses. The coupons were printed out immediately along with a diagram of which entrance to use.There is always some confusion in Russian monuments regarding entrance locations (reason to have a pre-arranged tour). Finally we were able to locate the correct window to submit our vouchers for entry tickets. We did not have to wait in line nor was there a line on a Sat. around 10 A.M.We did not wait for the 2 hour tour in English (additional charge), but decided to wander with our floor map. The Winter Palace is HUGE!!! even though the rooms are labeled, we constantly felt like we were in a labyrinth (not like in the Louvre). The sheer size of the buildings are overwhelming and after 2 1/2 hours, we called it quits. There is a fabulous "period" costume exhibition of actual clothing of the Tsar's royal family members and children. This is definitely worth the visit if it is still current.In the end, I probably should have booked a 3 hour tour so that we would have had someone to guide us through all of the collection highlights.

not just an art museum. Even if you could not imagine going to an art museum on vacation, put this on the do not miss list. The buildings that house the art are amazing themselves. You only know Picasso - they have a wing! Get tix in advance to bypass the lines.

rating would have been higher if crowds smaller. also the people, mostly women, watching the crowds could learn to smile a bit (I am sure they have hard lives, so I should give them a pass). THEY NEED TO HAVE LONGER HOURS AND BE OPEN 7 DAYS A WEEK, WAY TOO MANY PEOPLE. On days before and after they are closed, crowds are almost doubled since most tourists are from 2 day cruises and are forced to come on the day before or after closing. The architecture is just as amazing as the art, in fact I actually liked that better
Great!!!. This place is huge. If you are in to museums you need to see this one. After awhile it all looks the same to me. I can appreciate the art work though.

Rooms are more impressive then the art collection. Lots and lots and lots of rooms with art.. but I found the decorations of the palace itself to be much more noteworthy.. such opulance... such showmanship.

Not to be missed. Even if you are not really in to museums, this is one in the world which should not be missed. The range of artworks and beauty of the building itself is incomparable. Do the two hour tour at least to get an overview. Just loved it.

Oh, my both the building and the art are impressive!. Chance of a lifetime to take a tour while on our Baltic cruise! The building is magnificent with its rooms and rooms. The art is amazing and there are such wonderful masterpieces everywhere. It would take years to see all the artwork inside. The giant staircase with all the gold trim sets the stage for what lies within. We went with a guide, so were limited in what we saw, but even that was overwhelming. Try not to go when it's hot, because there is no air-conditioning. Can you believe that this world famous collection is not in a temperature controlled environment? No money to install it we were told. When we saw people opening a window, we were shocked, but I guess the artwork has lasted all these years...but it does get hot and stifling on the upper floors. A must-see! Try to go early before all the crowds, but you will just not believe your eyes. It's almost sensory overload!

Trick tickets. So, just visited the Hermitage, 2 days, full on fantastic. The latest low down for ticket buying to avoid the queue problem. Buy them on line and you may find yourself in a very slow moving queue to turn your internet generated voucher into tickets. But, at least you are under shelter while you stand patiently waiting. There are 8 electronic ticket machines just inside the first gated arch, fast, but the tickets from these machines do not include the right to photograph stuff, not that I saw any one else with the little sticker on, and certainly no one was checking to make sure... Everyone was using cameras, not sure if I would take the risk though. Ticket at the point of entry, least most favourable option, long line in the open, and once your inside, another long line - bedlam. No perfect way, perhaps Internet still a good option though we were frustrated at the time. ABSOLUTELY WORTH EVERY MOMENT OF DISCOMFORT ONCE YOUR INSIDE. AMAZEMENT!!!

Fabulous. Well worth the visit although of course 3 hours didn't even scratch the surface! Our tour company SPB arranged early entry tickets and this was well worth it as we got to see the exhibits we had targetted without too many people queuing or being in the way. The peacock clock is just amazing and must be seen!

Wonderful Museum. This is a huge building which had been added to over the years and houses a magnificent collection of mainly Russian paintings from the 1600's to the 1900's. It is laid out so that one can walk through rooms in date sequential order so that you can experience the change in style taking place over the centuries. Again here you need quality time.

Bucket list minus another one. The Hermitage was high on my bucket list but never dreamed of ever being there. Our guide said that if you were to spend one minute in front of each piece of work in the museum it would take eight years to see them all. I could have spent a whole week just in the Impressionist rooms alone.Our visit was restricted to only a small amount because of our tour schedule. There is so much to see and so little time to see it. Put this on your bucket list without doubt.

The BEST. If you enjoy ART or have an appreciation for it....this place will bring back memories. I don't have space in my brain for this now...but I do remember when studied. Good to see again at this point in life. Young people in College would appreciate this art!!!
push through the crowds - it is worth it. Well the massive art collection which would take months to see. I didn't like the crowds but this is the most famous collection in the world.

Something special. A bit of an artmuseum. Very big, but you don´t get tired of walking around in here. An interesting show of clothes that belonged to the tzarfamliy in the 18th Century an of interior design of earlier periods. You can of course get lost in there. I did not like them to tell me to put my bag and kamera in the wordrobe, as a lot of people took Photos. 4 hours in here is not too much.

Spend a day here - great art. This is a must see in St Petersburg. The exterior of the building and the statues atop are impressive, but there is so much to see inside. We went straight to the Rembrandt room and lucked out, having The Return of the Prodigal to ourselves for some time. Quite an impressive painting. We moved on to see paintings by Van Gogh, Cezanne, Monet, Picasso, and other great artists. It was a highlight of our trip. I'd go again, as there is way too much to enjoy in one go. I did not take photos inside, figuring it would be difficult to really enjoy the art while taking photos of it.

Stupendous. This is worth visiting just for the splendour of the buildings, regardless of all the treasures contained in it. When we went it was very full and we only had two hours so we barely glimpsed some of the wonders. Spend a day at least here, if you can. I particularly loved the peacock clock.

You cannot miss this. If you have only one venue to visit in St P, make it this one. The problem is, you really need time to appreciate it, because it's so big. And energy, as you push past thousands upon thousands of other visitors. I found myself running to keep up with the group, which was marched from room to room effieciently and fast in order to cram in as much viewing and info as possible. But what a treasure trove. The art works are legend - though many of the originals are locked up and good copies are actually displayed, understandably. Although I'm not a big museum person, I was stunned by what I saw. Three hours was not nearly enough to do it justice.
Wonderful - but need more time. What an amazing place, filled with the most amazing works of art. Really enjoyed the experience but was a little confusing when buying a ticket for me and my camera!

Early Entry is a MUST. This museum is amazing for both the quantity and quality of its works, and also for the amazing beauty of the rooms themselves. The building is its own work of art. We got early entry tickets through the tour that we booked with Alla Tours. I'm not one to pay extra for that type of thing (or to get up early unnecessarily), so I probably would not have gotten early entry if it hadn't just been included with the tour. But I must advise that it is almost a requirement for this museum. It was incredible when we were virtually alone in the early open hours, but it soon became very crowded, and we were amazed at the huge lines that had formed outside by the time we left a few hours later. I don't know how to get early entry on your own, but definitely spring for it if you can.

Yep its world class. I had always heard the State Hermitage was one of the top 5 museums in the world. Having visited, I thoroughly agree. First of all it is huge. The winter palace, the building in which it is housed, was a former residence of the czars. Its stunning beautiful, but more impressively, it is MASSIVE. The current configuration has 2 MILLION square feet of floor space. Never have I been lost that much. So of course the collection is huge. Some really interesting and diverse historical artifacts. The Vatican Museums and the British Museum will always my favorites. But then for me it is the Louvre and this place. And then everything else is a weak imitation. FYI. The Russian transportation system is pretty good. Took the 4 fast train between Moscow and St Petes. Didn't have to fly Aeroflot and got to see some cool Russian country side. And the metros in the city are easy and cheap once you have a metro map in both english and russian.

Everything I expected and more. We were on an NCL Baltic Cruise with a one night stopover in St. Petersburg. We chose to go on the Hermitage and Gold Rooms ships excursion..This place is huge and beautifully situated on the banks of the River Neva. Of six buildings of the main museum complex, five, named the Winter Palace, Small Hermitage, Old Hermitage, New Hermitage and Hermitage Theatre, are open to the public. Our guide advised us that there was a charge for taking photographs and quoted us in US Dollars and Euros. I had changed money into Roubles so asked to pay in Roubles (Roubles 175 and this covered it). If you have roubles and don't ask they will take dollars or euros off you. We were also advised that no large bags were allowed inside, nor bottled drinks – story behind that being in 1985 Rembrandt's painting Danae was damaged by a man who threw sulfuric acid on it and cut the canvas.Our guide, who spoke very good English, gave us headsets and actually did a very good job of keeping us all together. As we went through the various Halls eg Hall of Peter the Great with its beautiful decorations, the Gallery, St George's Hall to name just a few - we were told about the history/stories behind it. We visited the room with the famous Peacock Clock and there is a video showing how it works. Our guide was very amusing and kept us all interested. Next we were taken to the Gold Rooms and surprisingly it was not crowded, so again we could appreciate the wonderful pieces of jewelery and artifacts in gold covered with priceless gems. We spent about 40 minutes here. We then continued on to the Art - Dutch, French, Italian, Impressionist etc and saw paintings by Picasso, Van Gogh, Matisse, Leonardo da Vinci - his famous Madonna Litta and Benois Madonna, Gaugin, Titian, Raphael, Rembrandt. Our guide was very good because he spoke about various paintings and as we had headsets we were able to wander around the room and take photos (without flash). I was particularly interested in the Art so the time spent was too short for me, but to be fair, I did see what I wanted and obviously with a group of about 25 our guide needed to move on. For me this was a wonderful experience, however, we were not allowed time in the Museum shop.A word of warning - on the ship's organised tour (and probably private tours) the guides are obliged to stop off at a Tourist Shop. This lasts about 20-30 mins. We were not allowed time in the actual Museum Shop. I wanted specific postcards of various paintings, however, in spite of being told that the Tourist Shop will have these, they did NOT. I told our guide this and he apologized (as he had told me I could get them there) and suggested I look in the shop at the port. Fortunately I was able to get some but not all of the ones I wanted there.If and when we come again, I would opt for one of the private tours by SPB Tours as these have small groups of about 8-10 people and they also arrange visas etc. However, I was very pleased with the one we did. Such a beautiful place.Definitely not to be missed. Absolutely fantastic.

Pre-book, get there early and pay for a guide - it's worth every penny. I'm not a history geek but the hermitage may have just persuaded me to become one. The magnificent paintings, sculptures, rooms and artefacts are outstanding. We paid for tickets for early opening at 9.15 and it was still packed. However our wonderful guide was able to navigate us quickly through key rooms of interest taking sufficient time to explain the history and origins of the paintings etc we were looking at. Works by Rembrandt , Michelangelo, Monet, to name but a few all came alive under the expert explanation which we would not have understood or fully appreciated without the guide. The place is huge you can easily get lost. The 3 hours we spent was no where near enough but long enough for us on one visit. You will need to check in large bags and long coats so be prepared for queues at the cloakrooms.

Wonderful collection of art and historical items. The Museum is a bit of a misnomer - I think it is about 2/3 museum and 1/3 art gallery. The museum building is wonderful, the contents are spectacular and the only reason to not be a 5* review is that it is tricky to navigate yourself around and the crowds are just ridiculous! We had prebooked on the internet and followed the instructions to go to an area under the arches to collect our tickets - unfortunately this is closed, so looking around we saw a sign to go into the main building to collect our tickets - however that is where the signage finished... We had to walk around and have a look to finally come to the information desk which is where you actually get the coupon to then go to a desk to get your tickets. Even with this messing about, it is a _LOT_ better to prebook rather than stand in the very long line to buy tickets.The food inside is not good... I suggest eating a very big breakfast, skipping lunch and when you leave, have an early dinner as the "cafe" is minuscule and does not really have much available.

Best museum I have ever seen.. Not only is the art inside this building some of the most amazing pieces in existence, but the building itself is a piece of art. If your not wowed by some of the most famous artist in history, this probably isn't the place for you. Spend a long time here. You can devote an entire day to seeing this place from top to bottom, maybe more. The building itself is huge, be prepared to walk... a lot.

Massive museum in beautiful palace. a huge, internationally renowned museum located inside the palace of one of Russia's tsarsThe setting is stunning - alongside the Neva river, inside the Winter Palace of Russia tasar's, the Hermitage deserves a full day of your trip. We spent a whole day inside, we got lost, we learnt a lot, we took loads of photos and it was brilliant. No food or drink allowed inside, it does have its own little cafes - they get very busy around lunch time.

Nice palace . I knew about it from a friend but didn't have a chance to enter becaue was not working at a Monday never try at Monday ? It is a very huge palace and very nice and in front of it is a very nice statue

Beautiful Museum with largest collection. Like the building and the location,as it is in the heart of the city.actually this museum has got more collections apart from display.the are stored secret in the underground.only 10 - 20 % of collections are displayed here.Rest is secret in vaults.

Probably, the best museum of the world. This is the only museum I visited which the museum itself competes in beauty with the masterpieces which are inside. Even if the museum was empty, it would be wonderful. To give an ideia, Hermitage seems to be like Versailles having inside the masterpieces of Louvre. One day is absolutely not enough, even if you skip some sections that you have seen similar elsewhere (like mummies). Try to visit on Wednesday because it's open until 9 pm and avoid the first Thursday of the month (because entrance is free and the lines are enormous).

Hermitage museum Russia. This museum is one of the oldest and largest in the world. Full of paintings, sculptures. So much history. Very strict in there, you can not walk around with "big" bags or where big coats, security will make you check large bags/coats as they wont let you in. It gets very crowded in there so lots of patience required. It is well worth seeing though. You can take pictures, no flash......they watch you very closely.

Amazing museum.. One of the better museums we have visited in the world. Gives the Louvre a run for its money. Main tip is to buy a ticket from the touch screens on the entrance. Could not understand a 200 metre line of people lining up to buy tickets. We got ours from the touch screen and walked straight in. Be careful that you dont just take the receipt. You need to wait for tickets to drop in a holder below the screen along with your change. We had a woman come up to us when we buying our tickets wh thought that the receipt from the screen was her ticket. She did not wait for her tickets to drop.

The State Hermitage Museum. This museum is spectacular and majestic. And we are really impressed with its vast collection and the enormity of it. Our experience is great because of a wonderful guide who kept us in awe the entire duration. The only downside is its too crowded. Because of us heeding the valuable advice of passed visitors, we visited it without carrying too much that a visit to the cloak room became unnecessary!

When visiting St. Petersburg the Hermitage is a must.. It's the Hermitage, what more needs be said. Go early (or late) as the crowds can be suffocating. Make use of the "back" stairways to get around and investigate the areas of the museum that are less crowded but don't have the most notable art.

Incredible but busy. I did a solo visit to the Hermitage and I think it may be the way to go. There is so much to see and so many people to navigate around, that if you're by yourself, you get to see exactly what you want and don't leave disappointed. I also downloaded the Hermitage app and had a map of the museum that I made notes on and used to plot a route that incorporated everything on my must-see list. I think this is one museum where it's best to be organized and not wander around in the hopes of spotting what you want to see (unless you have unlimited time or are prepared to come back). I paid to see go on the Gold exhibit tour (the Diamond one was already sold out by the time I made it to the front of the queue) and that also broke up the day nicely. It was incredibly interesting, the tour leader was infinitely knowledgable on the exhibit and was definitely one of the highlights of my day.

So much to see.... The rooms in the palace are gorgeous--with the Amber room being one of the most remarkable. The dancing hall is one of the few large rooms we saw devoid of art so you were able to appreciate the room itself. The large peacock clock was also neat, though we were not lucky enough to see it "go off". Our guide mentioned that it is set at a secret time for fear that the Hermitage would be inundated with visitors otherwise.We visited the Hermitage as part of a 2 day tour so I had not bothered to read up on it beforehand. I was, therefore, quite surprised at how much western european art were there (some notables being the Rembrandt room, Madonna and Child, and Cupid and Psyche sculpture). It would be wonderful to spend more time in the museum since there is just so much to see but the crowd will probably wear you out first.If you are doing a tour, I would recommend one with headsets. There are so many people there that it would be very hard to to hear your guide even if you are in a really small private group. We had early entrance but it seemed like everybody and their brother was there so I'd hate to see what it's like when it's "really" busy though perhaps it was unusually so because the museum is closed on Mondays and we went on a Tuesday.

More than what I had imagined. There are many things on display here. I originally planned for a half day visit (as I am not an art addict, I thought it would be more than enough), but at the end I stay much longer. Audio guide cost 350 rub while a general museum guided tour cost 200 rub (English one seems to only run once a day at 13:45). If you only plan on visiting the museum for a single day, and are more interested in the building, the general information of the colection and the highlight of the museum cilection, then I highly recommend you to go for the guided tour. Only get the audio guide if you are interested in the individual art pieces and extra info for the rooms. By the way, the audio guide required either an ID or 2000rub for deposit.

Incredible museum. Not only is this a palace but it also house some of the rarest art collection in the world. Similar to the Louvre in Paris that it has lots of different artists, but the building use to be the winter palace of the royals. You will never be able to see the whole museum in a whole day but will be able to see the main highlights.

Make time for this.. The palace is extravagant, you will continue to be amazed after every hall. The art is extensive, well rounded and unmatched by most collections. Purchase the tickets before hand on the internet you pay about twice the price($18) but you may save up to 2 hours waiting in line. The audio guide is money well spent (~$10). If you take a purse or hand bag you won't have to check it in which case you might be able to smuggle some water or a few snacks. Checking backpacks is pretty seamless and beats the alternative of walking the city all day without anything i.e. umbrella, guide books, or food. The cafe was average and overpriced, but considering the monopoly they have on food it could be much worse. If your are going to visit the hermitage, dedicate 4 hours so you can truly see some things.

Too crowded to see anything. I fled the place after one hour, there were so many people - it was like Venice in July, but it was a rainy day in May in St. Petersburg!The management should make better orhanisation, like the castle in Dresden, where you have to choose the date and hour in Internet, and you have to come within a wondow of 10 minutes, otherwise you loose your ticket. So they garantee that not too many people are in at the same time.

Great museum. We were with a small tour group and enjoyed the many exhibits, paintings, porcelain etc. that we were able to see in a four hour visit. We barely touched the surface! A very special museum and well worth the visit.
Amazing. You would need a lifetime to do the Hermitage justice. I only had one day and absolutely adored the Winter Palace, plus all the different portraits/architecture etc.
A Must See. The Hermitage is a must see if in St. Petersburg and the palace is out of this world in its own right. So much history and beauty.

Opulent and Awe-inspiring Hermitage. A jaw-dropping experience to see so much opulence, so much gold and such wonderful ancient architecture in one place. Original paintings by masters were seen everywhere, it seems to be a dreamland of treasures and one has to pinch oneself to realise how real everything is! More than one visit would be required to absorb much of the treats in store. If only to confirm that everything around you is in fact real.

Unbelievably Huge. This place is amazing and the artifacts are incredibly impressive both in number and type. We walked around for hours and everything we saw was great, including the architecture of the museum itself. If you are interested in seeing something specific, you may want to create a plan as it's very easy to get sidetracked by another interesting subject.

Comrade, you must see this if you love art or history.. It's like all the Smithsonian's rolled into one, except no aerospace. With millions of things, arranged like the best of the museums, it is spectacular. For a half-day guided tour, it so whetted our appetite, it was almost unfair. You need days going through it.The collections of paintings you'll recognize is amazing. Didn't know who owned some.From ancient civilizations to modern exhibits, they have it all. We must go back. Unbelievable.Tips.....pictures are forbidden, unless you have a silent shutter and a movable viewing screen. They DO stop you from taking ANY pictures. Alarms are everywhere.If you want a good book on The Hermitage, but it here since there are no good ones I've found here.Outside in the square, the prices for lacquered boxes, Nesting Dolls and other items are pennies compared to elsewhere. Buy the here. I have 4 sets of dolls for under $50 total which cost $100+ each other places. Even US presidents, hockey players and others.It's a museum not to be missed. A tour is good, but to wander for days is even better.

Massive museum. Started our 2 days in St. Petersburg at the Hermitage. This massive museum consisting of five different buildings and the winter palace is impressive. We also were able to walk through the Gold Room and heard interesting stories of selected pieces. There are exhibits from around the world, although a few (like the Egyptian) are a bit smaller compared to the Louvre or the British Museum. You could spend hours exploring all the various rooms but a few hours is fine for the highlights.

Wow, wow, wow! Amazing place.. This is one of the highlights of my life. I was enthral led to see the palace from outside but inside was spectacular. The Rembrandt collection was the highlight and to see The Prodigal Son in person was great.Sadly my wife was pickpocketed and three credit cards were used within an hour amassing $12000 so it appears well organised gangs operate so watch your valuables. We thought we did.

It's massive.... You could easily spend a week here and still not see everything. There are the permanent exhibitions and when we went there was also a special exhibition of gowns and uniforms from the 17-19th C. They were exquisite. One tip - unless you have a compact camera you can fit into your bag, you'll need to check in your camera in the cloak room or pay 200 RUB when you buy your ticket to allow you to take photos. You'll be given a special sticker for your camera. You'll then be frustrated that everyone is taking pictures anyway and it isn't policed.

The Hermitage. This huge palace was almost eradicated by the Nazis. It was looted, bombed and burned. The reconstruction and restorations done by the Russian government are amazing. The fact that thesome things have been left unadorned because there are no photographs documenting the original decoration, (as in the ceilings and floors of some rooms) is impressive in their desirefor authenticity of what they have replicated. The famousart collection is beautiful and well worth the time to appreciate it.
Super mooie..... Awesome museum, prachtig, very unique and historical of Russiam inside. Very long line visitors who excited to come into.

Hermitage Museum, St Petersburg, Russia. We visited the Hermitage as part of an independent 2 day tour with Alla Tours, from our cruise ship. My review of this 'attraction' has absolutely no reflection on Alla Tours (please see my 5* rating for them) but on the Hermitage itself.Prior to our HAL 2 week Baltic cruise, everyone spoke about the Hermitage in glowing terms. Architecturally, the five building are impressive, but you do not need to go inside to appreciate this. If you enjoy paintings by some of the worlds most renowned artists then maybe this is for you.For me, the 2 hours and 5km walked was alas not top of my priorities, with so much more to see in and around the city. If you are blessed with a National Gallery at home, I would suggest you maybe look to book an alternative tour (I would recommend Alla!!!) which maybe bypasses 'old paintings' and spends more time at St Catherine's Palace, Peterhof Palace etc etc.
Wow!. So much to see and absorb but again our Guide made sure we were fully informed and answered all our questions.

Awe Inspiring!. An awe inspiring vast collection of art, sculpture and magnificent palace quarters - we spent 5 hours in there - not intending to spend that long! It's excellent value compared to all the other palaces etc which we thought were overpriced.
Top!! 5 stars. The Hermitage collection is a must see! The rooms are magnificent and there are lots of famous paintings. You must see The Return of the Prodigal Son by Rembrandt.
Unique.... A unique museum full of treasures!!! A lot of art , a lot of luxury and elegance. Typical barok building. Paintings from El Greko to Kandinsky. A unique experience and must see museum.

Two Great Places To Spend A Day Or A Week. We visited both at the same time which is quite easy as they are joined. We could easily have spent a week. The Hermitage is in a class of it's own. What ever you do, don't miss the archeological exhibits in the lowest level of the museum as well where you will find amazing artifacts from the 5th Century BC to 1,000 years ago. Including the oldest woven rug of incredible quality, fabrics that you would wear today and many other interesting items. Of course the art of all ages in this magnificent place alone makes your entire journey worthwhile.

MARVELOUS COLLECTION. The joy of the visit starts as you enter the huge palace square and see the wonderful facade of the winter palace,the Alexander Column and the great sweep of the General Staff Building -magnificent. A visit to the Hermitage requires " military " planning and we made three visits this year & two in 2011 -starting with obtaining the tickets online. This saves you time on your first visit and as you need more than one visit - the second or third are a breeze as you are in the fast lane. An early start is best -opens at 10.00hrs but there is an entrance at 8.00hrs. if you pay extra. Once in you have to decide what you want to see-this is a huge collection & the following may be of assistance for your first taste :* Jordan Staircase* State rooms including the two throne rooms, gold drawing room, boudoir, malachite drawing room and a selection of different rooms from various czars including the library.* Impressionists - fantastic collection on the third floor* Peacock clock* Rembrants -magnificent* Two beautiful paintings by Leonardo da VinciIf your interest is the collections of the Ancient World,Far East & Russian icons then you will not be beaten by the guided tours that are whisked around at speed .Our strategy was let them in & out - then have a quiet look before the next horde descended - and this May ! You need a map to get around & you will still find it difficult to get to the rooms you want - but this is an opportunity to see other things. A Marvelous collection and one of the best museums in the world.

You'll never have enough time!. Well, it's actually 4 large impressive buildings all linked internally. Massive place and great collection. It gets REALLY busy though. If you go on an organised tour, it seems that you can get in an hour before the general public, which gets you ahead of the crowds, a bit. However, lots of organised tours start together, so swings and roundabouts! Enjoy.

Spectacular . On par with the best museums in the world. Unbelievable collection of impressionists and post modernists. Very interesting second floor of Russian clothes, furniture and rooms. Opulent is a word that comes to mind. Must buy ticket online ahead of time and save yourself horrific lines. Start on the third floor and work your way down. Wear comfortable shoes. Expect many large tour groups. Audio guides are 250 rubles each but were worth it.

Hermitage. There are no words to describe this wonderful museum, we spent the whole day there and saw only a minimum. We were told that one would have to spend 11 years going each day to the museum in order to have seen it all. It is unforgettable, mind boggling, one gets lost looking around.

Go In With A PLAN. This museum really is so big, you HAVE to go in with a plan, or plan to spend 5 days in there to comb through everything.
