Just when you think you've finished one section, there's another and another and another......it's surreal. There were long lines, and we did use the kiosks, but word of caution, make sure the one you jump on takes credit cards (some do not). Also, they do not work well if it is raining (for real). The currency readers have a hard time with humidity and keep returning your ruble notes (as we found out, when we mistakenly hopped onto a kiosk that did not take credit cards...and yes, it was raining).We also found that the lighting in some of the rooms was quite bad. I'm not quite sure why that was. I work in a historic home where I am from with original paintings from the 1800's and we keep the lights off for tours, using only the window daylight for lighting to preserve things, so maybe that is why they keep certain rooms darker.Our tour books complained about the 2 cafes in the Hermitage as far as pricing and food quality was concerned. I think that given the size of this museum there would be more than 2 cafes (which were quite small), but, knowing there were only two and that the offerings might be questionable, we had a big breakfast before going in. When we decided to see what the cafes were like we went off of the main lunch hour (after 2pm) and had no problem with lines or seating at the internet cafe.Actually, we had a small pizza, sandwich and an awesome piece of cake (which they were bringing in from a local bake shop) with our coffees for about 25$, which was about right for museum prices, so I don't know what the tour books were so down about.Bring comfortable shoes, have a plan, eat well beforehand, and enjoy yourself. You'll not see a more impressive collection of artwork under one roof anywhere else. And, we made this mistake: Even though the Faberge Eggs were manufactured in St. Petersburg, they are not in this museum collection. You have to go to the Kremlin Armory Museum in Moscow to see these little beauties!If you are in St. Petersburg for a week, you can hop the Sapsan (high speed train at 6:45am or 7am or so) and be in Moscow in 4 hours---it'd be a quick day trip, or if you are planning from home, like we did, we tacked it on as a final 2 nights out from St Petersburg) to go see them.

JAW DROPPER. Be smart and choose wisely what you want to see. We were told if we stand in front of every exhibit three minutes we would have needed 8 (eight) years to finish. Allow at least half a day and to beat the very long lines hire a guide. Otherwise you will not hear the small stories behind the works.
marvellous. Wow, so many things to see. So many gold is impressive. The rooms, the intelligence, the architecture and the museum with his gallerys are impressive.

To See To Believe. We’re told by our tour guide that if you only spend 3 seconds in front of each art work, you need 3 years to view all the collections! Fortunately (or unfortunately) only certain portions of the museum’s collections are for public display, and we’re totally in awe of the enormous and magnificent treasures the Russian Tsars had accumulated over the centuries. One couldn’t help but to appreciate the tastes, foresight and deep pockets those acquired them, especially Catherine the Great.It’s better to book with a local tour company to get an early entry privilege ahead of the big crowd. We pre-booked with Alla tour after extensive research on line before the trip, and paid only half of the price others paid to the cruise line, and traveled in a very comfortable van rather than a big tour bus.

Must see - The Hermitage Museum. Viewing the unbelievable wealth of the Hermitage art collections is a must see! The museum had 460 rooms and over three million exhibits. It's impossible to see the entire museum in one visit.

Overwhelming in the extreme. Ideally, the time required to see the millions (no exaggeration there) of items, art, wonders, the buildings themselves, would be about 4 days (just to ensure your head doesn't explode). Just brilliant.

Typically Russian. For a supposedly world class gallery, the Hermitage proved somewhat of a disappointment. We were travelling on our own - not part of a group tour and had booked tickets online, in order to avoid queues. The booking process was simple, but collecting the tickets was not. We were first sent off to entirely the wrong place but after a bit of perseverance we were issued our tickets from booth 5 (KACCA 5 for anyone planning an imminent visit).Inside the museum, the various gallery attendants were mostly the grumpy, unhelpful, over-50's type that we have come to know rather well on our short tour of this unmemorable country. We were looking for one particular painting, but none of the attendants seemed to know where it was and we were sent off on various wild goose chases before finally giving up. We also wanted to visit the Islamic gallery, but it was closed for renovation although some items were apparently displayed downstairs in a temporary display. Except they weren't. On the plus side, there were some lovely paintings displayed, however the lighting was poor and a number of artworks were very hard to see due to either too much lighting or not enough.In general, we felt the place exuded that good old Russian 'couldn't care less' attitude that has characterised our visit to this country. What a shame. It should and could be one of the great galleries of the world.

Fantastic Museum. Definitely worth the visit. The queue seems long, but the trick is: You do not have to queue! There are vending machines where you can buy tickets and just bypass the queues. This will not allow you to get student or resident discounts, but the fee is not that high (400 Rubles). There is also a permit for private photography, but nobody really cared, so you can pretty safely ignore this regulation. There are plenty of cloakrooms - don't rush to the first you see, as this will naturally be the most crowded one. There could be more toilets in the museum. Now for the collections: Splendid. Probably the best and vastest collection I have seen. The only one that it compares to is probably the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The comparison with the Louvre or the Prado is a joke really: Both are much smaller in what they display - let alone their archives being much smaller as well. The collection is impressive: Excellent Antiques, 2 da Vincis, 25 Rembrandts, numerous Rubens, Goya, Picassos, Manets, van Goghs, Monets, Manets ........ very easy to spend several days in the museum if you want to see it all - including interesting collections on russian pre-historic development. There are audio guides in various languages. Also the presentation seems to be quite stable: I used a guidebook from 1972(!) which was still a great tool for some background information and for finding various pieces of art.

So much to see!. the hermitage Museum holds an incredible variable collection of paintings and artefacts from the world over too many to begin to list in this review. The Winter Palace contains memorabilia from the tsarist era. A footnote every 1st Thursday of the month the admission is completely free!

Not the Louvre but a great museum. First of all this is a crazy busy place. The lines are long and the crowds in the museum make it difficult to appreciate many of its masterworks. However, that being said it is a must see in St. Petersburg. In a full day you will only be able to see a small sampling of its treasures so pick and chose wisely. Any large coats, backpacks and camera bags need to be checked which is a real hassle. So leave any unnecessary stuff either in your room or on the tour bus. Pictures are allowed so be sure to bring a camera. Most tours take you through the 4 of the 5 buildings which make up the museum and the winter palace. The original building has some fascinating architecture so keep your eyes open.

Long queues but worth the visit. We visited The Hermitage on the first Thursday of the month, and entrance was free. This could have explained the queues, but it seems from other reviews that this is usually the case. That said, it only took us about 40 minutes of queuing. If you prebook, you get to jump the queue. We paid an extra 200 rubles to be able to take photographs though. This is quite common in Russian attractions, we noticed. The museum was quite crowded, but we managed to dodge the tour groups and found quiet spots. The Hermitage offers a very nifty iPhone app that operates off the museum wifi network. Look for it at the entrance and download it there, where signal is strong. It tells you where you are, and labels each hall. It helped us find the bathrooms, as well as the exit. Avoid the bathroom in the main lobby near the cloakroom as it's crowded and not very clean. We found quieter bathrooms on the upper levels that were better. You are required to check back packs etc into the cloakroom. You are also not allowed to take drinks into the museum. All handbags and purses go through a scanner. Carry your valuables on your person as the storage cloakroom doesn't look very secure. We spent about three hours there, and that was enough, as it was very crowded. We found the artworks very interesting, especially those by the masters like Picasso, Matisse and Gaugin. We also enjoyed the Egyptian civilization hall.

Watch the cloak rooms. The museum itself is amazing although I would suggest some prior research to avoid getting overloaded, there is just so much to see. We booked 2 day tickets online which made it so much easer to avoid the lines. One word of warning, leave everything, bag, jackets etc at your hotel and just stuff some cash in your pocket.Anyone off the street regardless of whether they have a ticket or not can access the cloakroom. The Hermitage forces almost everyone (depending on who you get at the ticket gate) to place bags and coats in the cloakroom. In the press of bodies while trying to retrieve my bag and coat someone managed to steal the lens right off my camera which was on a strap around my neck and only out of my hand for a minute while reaching to grab my bag. The Hermitage maintains very little control over the cloakroom.

Poorly organized. Went on an organized group tour along with way too may other organized group tours that were there at the same time. The place was so packed that it was almost like being in a riot- like situation with people pushing and shoving, trying to move either in or out of the building. Left our entire group happy just to get out of there in one piece. The museum itself was a very nice, but the architecture of the building was personally of more interest. Unless management does better for crowd control I would recommend passing on this one.

Amazing sight!. We toured the Hermitage with a small tour group (16) with our guide, Maria, from TJ Travel. It was difficult to really appreciate the beauty of the building & exhibits due to the extremely large crowds. This said, is certainly one of the major attractions in St. Petersburg, not to be missed!
Unending artwork. The museum is huge! Extremely crowded when we were there. Amazing to see original works from such famous artists. Many forms of artwork on display. The building itself is beautiful,
stunning.. This is breath taking it is hard to understang how anyone can live and suvive is such a palace!! I would to like to have experienced living in such a setting. It is so well preserved.

Overwhelmingly good!. Take my advice and pre purchase a two day pass on line. You will save yourself the queues from hell. You will have five days to use your pass. You could spend many more days in the Hermitage. Problem is there is so much to see outside as well. Go lose yourself and enjoy

Fantastically curated. This was not only a great collection of art but it is fascinating just to be able to see the inside of the palace. I was not able to get out of st Petersburg to see one of the palaces (e.g peterhof or Catherine's) but felt this was a good consolation. The opulence is amazing. Even if you walk through quickly and skip exhibitions you're not interested in, it will probably still take about 3 hours. We went at 12.30pm and bought our tickets from the ticket machine just to the left of the gateway as you walk in and so missed the huge queue- make sure you look out for it!

a very beautiful palace. This is a very beautiful palace, one of the most beautiful in the world. It will be twice interesting for you if you like paintings. I do not recommend you to take an excursion if you do not like paintings. It will last very long, you will be bored, the children will play hide-and-seek and you will stop understanding what the guide says.
Huge. We only spent a few hours in the museum on a guided tour but we still saw plenty of art and history. The rooms are incredible as well as the art from all the great European masters.

By far the most amazing museum EVER.... One thing about the Russians, is they KNOW how to put together a huge collection of absolutely fantastic artwork and priceless treasures, and make an absolutely stunning museum.We was fortunate enough to have booked a private, English-speaking tour guide for this part of our trip, and it was well worth it! She knew everything there was to know about everything in the museum. Room by room, she told us the story behind the most beautiful works of art I have ever seen. I will not forget the amazing giant cuckoo clock; never seen anything like it before!Some things that people who are considering a trip to this attraction may wish to consider:In Russia (or at least the attractions we went to) you check in your coats and baggage so you do not trapse around the museum with it. This service is free.I do not recommend this for people who have small children. My observation when I was at the museum observed a peaceful serenity... in all honesty I do not recall seeing any children at all! The museum itself is very large and you could easily spend most of your day here. However its proximity to the Nevsky Prospect means that you can pop out for lunch quite easily!All in all, an amazing time at the museum. I will try and upload some of my photos when I have access to them.

The Museum of All Museums.. No trip to St. Petersburg should be without making time to at the very least walk through the museum. This was the museum of all museum meaning that of all the large museums this was easy to navigate and one of the largest collections of beautiful pieces of art.

Hermitage is a must see . The state hermitage which also includes the Winter Palace and is in Palace square . The paintings includes the Italian collections including Raphael's Madonna Conestabile and Tintoretto's Birth of St. John the Baptist as just two of many examples . The collection of Dutch and Flemish art has to be one of the best in the world in my opinion . Do not miss the golden Peacock Clock . There is a lot of renovation ongoing and there are many parts not air conditioned so dress accordingly in the summer . The crowds are enormous so be prepared . You could not see everything if you had weeks so you must plan very well to maximize your trip . I would highly recommend a guided tour that will focus on your interest . It is truly amazing and a must see in St Petersburg .

2 hour guided tours move really fast!. Many ships' tours offer early entry and some have an evening visit so the hoards of summer tourists are less, but you are not left on your own to visit the areas of choice, but taken through rapidly with occasional stops for an in depth mini-lecture on this or that painting or sculpture. It's a broad overview and given the choice of that style of touring or NOT seeing it....well that's an easy choice. The Hermitage is one of the "Big 5". Know the other?

Elbow room only.. Even though we had a prearranged tour it was very crowded. People were pushing and it was difficult to stay with the group. Coats have to be checked and are very hard to retrieve when the tour is over. Grim looking museum attendants carefully watch over the tour guide and tours. All in all an awesome collection of masters.

The Creme de la Creme of Art Museums. Imagine an entire room of Rubens paintings, an huge room of Rembrandt's work and the same for van Dyke. On the third floor you'll gape at the rooms full of works by Picasso and Matisse. They show porcelains and other specialty works that you won't see anywhere else. And you'll gape at the famous peacock clock and the Amber Room. Catherine the Great had so much money she'd purchase 200 works just to have the particular one she wanted. You could spend days browsing the halls of this marvelous place.
Art, Art, and more Art. If you like art, then this is the place for you. One one is entirely dedicated to French impressionists. The opulent designs in the palace are unbelieveable.

Wonderful museum. We liked seeing the museum on our own, renting the audio tapes in English. The tour books scare people off from doing this on your own but we found the whole process easy. We booked the tickets on line the day before and lines went fast. Walk the opposite direction from the tours and you'll find you have some rooms to yourself. We particularly loved the room with all the general's portraits from the wars. Very imposing.

Do not miss it.. This is a museum on par with the Louvre. Take your time here to see the incredible works "acquired" from all over Europe. It does not overwhelm like the Louvre but still gives an incredible visual, cultural and historical experience.
The best attraction. This attraction is a must if you are in St Petersburg. It takes a long time to visit ,but our guide made it possible to see the most.

Need more time. What a great placeSadly we had a limited time here but used the time wellBeing on the Den Rus tour we were taken to the front of the queue so saved time there so much to look at some wonderful art to enjoy

Mind blowing!. To see the living quarters of the Russian royalty was like being part of history!And oh so opulent!The gold room left us quite speechless and really opened our eyes to this part of the world.The art collection was staggering to say the least.Spend a minimum of two days at least.

An Extraordinary Collection. Buy your admission, Gold Room and Diamond Room tickets in advance! Fabulous art. Pitiful presentations - have they not heard of museum quality glass. I understand that they need to protect the pieces but the glass is the worst. You see yourself reflected in each. We went in early April - weather was miserable but it was great to see the treasures of St Petersburg without huge crowds.
A museum to Remember. As impressive as the Louvre. Make arrangements to see the Gold Room, only 15 let in at a time. Collections are incredible.

Wonderful if a bit too popular. It is undoubtedly fabulous and probably the main reason 90% of tourists come to St.P's. However, that is exactly the main problem - the hoards. Those on tours are in a mindless haze and seem to trample, push or shove anyone in their way. The whole Da Vinci thing is just nuts - selfies in front of the two Leonardos!! Anyway, it is fab, and a must do, but just try and be clever with your timings to avoid the horde.

One of the best museums!. We bought a two day ticket on line, but there were very short queues at the end of May, so no need to buy in advance! You must leave coats in the cloakroom, which takes time, so go without if you can. We went on the Gold Room tour as well, which is very interesting. The museum is open until 9 pm on Wednesdays which gives you more time, although it was busier that day. We visited every room over the 2 days and saw so many beautiful and interesting things away from the crowds. The audio guide gave useful facts and information about the paintings. Don't forget to look down,as the intricate designs in the parquet flooring are amazing. This museum was the highlight of our trip!
Fabulous. Please go to the hermitage.The interior is spectacular.Lots and lots of bling.If you love art there are some wonderful paintings.You could spend all day in the Hermitage.

Truly brilliant. This amazing museum is huge please note that you need to be very fit & mobile to view this museum it is very big and you may need 2 days to view , many steps to climb the lifts were not well located for people with disabilities but the art work and history is truly brilliant very well taken care by the curators
Incomparable museum.. This incomparable museum is unbelievable. Its collection is amazing both in size and in quality and a visit provides a once-in-a-lifetime experience.

worth to see. more than 3 million works of art. just go with the tour company and they'll tell you what's worth to see unless, you prefer to see it all which you need a lot of days (or a week) to browse. don't wear jackets or overcoats otherwise, you have to check it in (no fee but lines to give and to take it back)

Amazing. This place has it all. Brave the crowds and go. If you stay at the Marriott Courtyard Vasilievski Island you can use your room key to buy tickets in a special line that has no one in it. You enter through an entrance that no one uses. You can go back to get your backpack without exiting. There are toilets at this entrance that have no lines. There's an unused elevator. Map out your visit carefully - the Lonely Planet guide is very useful. Stay out of the way of the numerous tour groups - just wait a minute and the herd will leave.

amazing place but cloakroom hell. did a brief tour of the place ..which was too short to do it justice really. i think we had a busy day with 5 cruise ships simultaneously hitting the city...you have to get rid of your coats in the cloak room.. it was manned by one person. A heaving mass of people on a stairwell...some trying to get up. others trying to get down.. pondlife scum pushing in with complete disregard for the safety if others. Accident waiting to happen. if you can avoid the cloakroom...do it!

Great Collection and interior But…... I have never ever been to such a badly organized museum, the crowds in the entrance are horrendous but what makes matters worse is that the entrance is also one of the main exits! Everybody coming and going through the same door!!! If you had to make a fast exit due to illness you would be out of luck.The collections are magnificent as is the interior of the building but was ruined by the number of people that are allowed in at once, you just cannot appreciate the art around you because you are swept along in a tidal wave of people. Officials of the museum really need to step back and see what can be done to improve this situation.

ONE OF THE FINEST MUSEUMS IN THE WORLD. This is one of the largest museums in the World with 100's of rooms of art and culture displays.They don't show you all of the rooms.There are so many special artworks to see but the best part is the palace in which they are displayed.This is a very opulent display of art and architecture not to be missed.One important art work you will see is the "Madonna and Child with Flowers by Leonardo Davinci."

Wished I Had a Week to Properly Explore. The museum is extremely large and had a lot to look at. One could easily spend a week exploring and fully appreciating the art. On should also spend the time marveling at the architecture as well as the art as one walks through. In particular the inlaid floors and extravagant ceilings were amazing. Truely one of the great museums of the word that one should explore at least once in their lifetime.
Russia trip.. What can you say about near perfection. The whole building is superb ,gardens magnificent and the rooms inside are just fantastic.This is a must if visiting Russia.

Similar to Louvre. Spent 2 hours visiting the winter palace. Walls and ceilings are covered with gilded décorations. There is so much to see that 2 hours is definitively not enough. You see the most interesting parts of the building with a rapid look at the paintings and sculptures. You cannot stop at each and read the inscriptions. It would take you too long. So the best way to visit is with a guide. Every room has its own decor and story. Words do not render the beauty of the Hermitage.
Amazing Collection. An excellent collection of impressionists. Although the museum was busy on the day we visited the crowds seemed limited to a few rooms that we skipped.

Go early in the day. We arranged a tour with SPB which allowed us access prior to when it opens to the public. This is well work the money and the only way you can really enjoy the museum. We spent about 3 hours and truly could have spent the rest of the day.

Not visitor friendly. The collection might be world class but it fights to be seen in this grotesque and maze like gilded palace. My tour group all came out clearly on the side of the revolution. Compared to most great art galleries this one does not have customer comfort as one of its key performance indicators. You are not allowed to take in any liquids, which is fair enough. But it is almost impossible to get a drink of any kind in the museum. We found one coffee kiosk with 2 people serving and a huge line of customers most of whom -like me- gave up because my time ran out. The only seats I could see we're for the security guards. I left the museum tired, very thirsty and without the time or stamina to continue to explore the collection.

Disordered Museum / Very bad old Winter Palace. Much worse compared to Louvre, British Museum and Metropolitan in terms of both experience and collection.The whole experience, from start to end, is like caos, starting from buying your tickets (even if you buy online), when trying to find a specific room/collection in the museum and if you need to visit the one and only cafe and W/C for both of which there is a very looonnngg que. Almost no English speaking staff. Extremely crowded which cannot be controlled unlike the afore-mentioned museums.In terms of collection I would say the other museums mentioned above are much better and comprehensive except the peacock clock which is the most beatiful and intricate clock I've ever seen in my life and perhaps the royal attire collection.I'd say if you have been to the British Museum, etc., but you would like to see Russian art, then visit the State Russian Museum instead, even if you would like to enjoy the interior of Hermitage due to the fact that it used to be a palace-- because you may visit the Catherine Palace in Peterhof instead.In any case don't pay extra for the Old Winter Palace beside Hermitage which is totally a crap.

Two amazing days in St Petersburg. We have just returned from a Baltic cruise with Cruise and Maritime in the MV Discovery, which was excellent in its own right. However, the highlight was two nights in St Petersburg. The city is stunning in itself, but three specific experiences were quite unique. In the St Peter and Paul church, with its extraordinary profusion of gold leaf, we were unexpectedly given a short a capella concert of Russian church music by five black-cassocked Orthodox monks which was superb and deeply moving. Then, in the exquisite palace theatre in the Hermitage we attended a magnificent performance of Swan Lake by the St Petersburg ballet company which was magical. Next morning, room after masterpiece-laden room in the Hermitage Museum itself. Absolutely unforgettable.

Wonderful but very busy. Amazing collections but problems with the lighting. At certain times of the day, with the sun streaming in, it is very difficult to see many of the paintings. All you tend to get is a shiny reflection. Worth the effort though.

Diamond of museums!. The top of the best europien museums.The best Peter's the Great art collection .Beautiful place of location in the heart of old center.Gorgeous Neva riva view and Palace's Bridge.Lots of history.

A day is never enough to visit this awesome museum. Great historical collections most especially the art pieces.As a souvenir, was able to buy 2 medium size paintings titled "The Prodigal Son and Calleto"

A Wonderful Blend. A world class institution that blends the Louvre, Versailles and the V&A. Of course if your time is short a guided tours will have its benefits, but we saw dozens of groups seemly fly by, it was hard to understand how their appreciation could be anything other than cursory. From the art of the 13th cent. European "dark ages," to prehistoric Siberia, we were there when it opened (1030) and left when it closed(1800) and felt we missed a lot. And the Greater Throne was ethereal.
Unbelievable collection. Arrive early to beat the queues! The mix of stunning palace stuffed with every imaginable type of Art and collection demands a long visit.

WOW !. Each room was more spectacular that the previous one, exhibit could have been observed for hours at a time instead of minutes allotted; the Hermitage is is like getting 50 pieces of your favorite desserts and then trying to decide which to eat.Underneath however begs the question "How may riches is enough?"- what about some thought for the common man?

my visit ti Hermitage. OMG There is an amazing place which is I ever saw. You can spend there one week and could't see everything. It's a very big space. I was so exited to be there and see arts which are come from the whole world. God bless Saint-Petersburg.

WOW. The wealth and breadth of the exhibits are impressive to say the least. We particularly liked the impressionists section but the classical arts was also great. In essence it is similar to the Louvre but the building is also very nice from the outside.

The mind boggles!. If you have time, I would suggest making two trips to the Hermitage. One to view the architecture of the building itself and another to view the artifacts and paintings. It is a massive building. When viewing the artwork, I suggest planning what you want to see before you go and stick to your plan. There are literally thousands and thousands of pieces and you will be exhausted and frustrated if you try to see them all. Hiring a private guide is a great idea as you can discuss what you would like to see before you go and he or she will know the layout of the building very well so no time will be lost by being lost!!!
All the art of books in the original. There is so much to see here: Impressionists, Italian school, Rembrandt etc, plus the actual buildings, Tsars chambers, etc etc it is breathtaking

Second only to the Louvre. Most mention of the State Hermitage Museum compare it to the Louvre and I can see why. In terms of size and collection, it really is very comparable and worth a visit. Vast collection of art from all over the world, with particular focus on Europe, Russia, and "Asia", of course. Could take a couple of days to really see everything, or a day for a quick walkthrough.

Not enough time.. Loved every minute of our visit. We bought tickets on internet ahead of time to avoid the queues but on arrival found very little by way of long queues. Staff were friendly and assisted us when required. So much to see, we spent the better part of two days taking it all in. Cafeteria downstairs was more than adequate for short breaks. Loved the Rembrandt room and also the Rubens room. Entrance is always impressive across the square.

Worth the extra to take photos. 200 roubles to take photos is a bargain! But be aware if u buy a 1 day ticket it is for single entry only so if u go out u won't get back in, although the people at the front were really nice and let us back in, as we went for a drink outside at lunch, even though they didn't have to :)

Get the two day ticket. Thanks to the TA forum, we purchased the two day ticket online which saved time in the end. Unfortunately, the student ticket we also needed had to be purchased on site but that did not take long at all given the short line off season. Just make sure your student has their ISIC card which is indispensable for any student visiting Russia.The two day ticket allowed us to thoroughly enjoy this wonderful museum without feeling rushed. Mind you, two days is not enough but it does give you a good starting point. We felt privileged especially when we saw the tour groups who were rushing through the museum.Hint: Download the Hermitage app for your smart phones. This helped guide us to the areas we wanted to concentrate on.

One of the best Museum. This place is huge! It is better to visit it without guided tour so that you can spend time as much as you want. You should buy the e-ticket from their website, it will cut a lot of time as you dont need to queu with other visitors. The queuing line can be very long especially during peak season.

Big collections, especially of french/Spanish art. A very interesting section on early civilisation including Sumerian etc, and then vast rooms of art. The real jewels were the whole room of Picasso, whole room of Monet, Gauguin, Van Gogh etc that allowed you to see a significant body of work from each. Really the must see of st petersburg.
State Hermitage Museum. Perfect Stay, we were there only for two hours and it´s very short time for savouring this museum. Personal is very helpful. Students have free admission.
Hermitage Museum. One of the most beautiful and recognizible places in Saint-Petersburg, full of art and cultural masterpieces. Every last Thursday of each month is free entrance.

Fabulous. This is a "must-see" experience in St. Petersburg. The castle and grounds are absolutely beautiful ... trimmed in gold and filled with artwork. Even if you are not a big fan of museums, you will come away with a sense of the Russian soul.

look up and down. As well as so'm e magnificent exhibits, the real star for me was the actual building. The ceilings match some of the floors. Intricate and ornate designs. Wonderful doors. You need to spend time here or be prepared to go back.

UNFORGETTABLE!. This is absolutely one of the best museum I ever seen…impossible to describe it …too much…of everything: paintings, marbles, gold, gemstones and furniture….and the most amazing things is to have the chance of discover the capability of the humans to produce such kind of treasures….Be careful: English tour for the gold and treasure chambers are not clearly indicated and two dedicated tickets are requested. For those two rooms only guided tour are allowed and only one English tour a day is foreseen in English (14.15 and 16.30 pm)….better to ask at the information desk!The museum observe a closured day and once a week is opened till 9.00 pm. On internet is possible to buy a 2 days ticket. The second one can be used within 5 days form the first one (on the web site is declared two consecutive days). The 2 days ticket is recommended: 2 days are extremely tight for a complete tour of the museum…Enjoy!

The Hermitage, at St Petersburg-- An Art Lover's Paradise.. For an Art Lover, This place is Paradise Lost. It is so well grouped in sections. Like the Egyptian Section, Indian Section, Photography, Paintings (Impressionist/ Renaissance/ Modern Etc) Obtain a book which shows you the various Sections, & then Proceed to the section you like, with the help of the Floor Map Enclosed. To see the whole Museum, would take you at least a week. The best thing would be to Buy A Comprehensive, Book on the Artifacts in the Hermitage, from the Bookstore. It costs around approx $100/-. It is very well designed & looked after, & their are Lifts to take you up. Go Early, as their is always a queue to buy Entrance tickets. The Renaissance Paintings, Of Monet, Picassa (not Picasso) & others, are a real treat.

Heritage an art lovers heaven!. The Hermitage is indescribable in words until you see it - it is literally 5 connected buildings of art work and Russian furniture and culture - an art lover would need at least a week to truly enjoy the beauty of this place - do not miss this if you are here - and go with a private guide or time will be spent lining up for tickets and harder to maneuver inside to see the rooms.
Hermitage Museum. The artworks are fabulous and the palace is grand. Such a masterpiece art collection to rival other museums.

Just brilliant; not to be missed.. We were so lucky, we visited at the end of April. I can only imagine the crowds come Spring and Summer.I am amazed at what little security appears to be in place for the millions of dollars of art work on display.Do your research and don't go the day it is closed.
Another must do with a guide. Again we took a private guide and car for efficiency and were not disappointed.it was a bit more expensive but the AUD was high at the time so worthwhile.

amazing art. The reason I dont give the museum an excellent rating is because I felt that if you are going to have those amazing make you want to cry pieces of art the museum should be at least clean right? But I didn't minded at the end because you get to see some pretty amazing art!

Awesome. This was our second visit, and we still have only seen a fraction of the most amazing collections of art work in the world - which is simply staggering. For anyone with the slightest interest in art this is a lifetime must do. In addition to the art, the building is also awesome, and greatly improved.A big tip - book to get in early to avoid the crowds....which can feel like being trapped in the exodus of a major sporting event. We booked admission for 08.30, which gave at least two hours of relaxed viewing. My sister and family arrived at 11.00 and they felt as if they were being processed rather than having the opportunity to appreciate the exhibits, which detracted from their enjoyment.Second tip - be aware of pickpockets.

One of the Best Museums in the World. Visited the museum in late May 2014 and it was crowded beyond belief. If you go, find out the days the cruise ships are in and go another day. Outside of being packed like e sardines, the Museum is Awesome! I visited the Hermitage in 1990 and it is amazing how much work they have done to make it a world class museum. A can't miss if you are in St. Petersburg!

Unreal not to be missed. Get there early if you can.or go on a group trip where you can get in early some times and miss the crowds.it gets very hot inside with no air con.and the amber room wow what a room if you like gold you will love this one.the only problem I found was getting out of the the building. They only had a small door open and hundreds trying to get out

Speechless. This is the only museum that can stand a comparison with Louvres or Vatican Museum. It's simply humongous and full of every masterpiece in painting, crafting, sculpting, carving, building.It's impossible to describe it's beauty. Just visit it. And buy the 2 days ticket online! Better to visit it during weekdays. Close on Monday.
Beautiful building and great collection. The collection is similar to other great museums thoroughout the world, however the building is magnificent and worthwhile spending ana entire day if you can.

Superb......of course!. This is everything you imagine it might be. Crowds make it fairly impossible to fully appreciate the glories, but try not to mind, know you will only see a small part, and Drink in just a few of the masterpieces. Any one of many thousands will be enough to justify going. In this spirit, my not to be missed would be the roman mosaic floor in the room that contains the peacock clock. Awesome!

Unbelievable collection of art. You would need many visits to see this amazing collection of art. Incredible and so huge. The building is so big and each room is full of beautiful art. Don't forget to visit the gift shop. It is very good value. We bought a Faberge egg pendant.

One of the greats. We were discussing the Hermitage afterwards and were a little off-hand about the collection (not the buildings). It's very good, but doesn't really rival the Louvre, Quai D'Orsay, Prada or Metropolitan. Then we realised maybe we were holding it to an impossible standard. It is a very good collection beautifully housed.
Crowds. If you go, try to choose a time when the crowds will be smaller. Despite the size, the place is packed with folks, which make viewing the art a challenge.

Not to be missed. Most of all because of the Palace itself. Browse through the vast buildings of international art. Very impressive. Avoid arriving in the morning with all others. Buy tickets in advance (you still have to stand in line but it's not so bad as the other) and use your guidebook

One of the World's Greatest Treasures!. We just loved this place. Oh to live near for at least a year and to visit many, many times! The art is second to none and it is easy to spend many happy hours browsing it all. Words just do not express the beauty of both the rooms and the art. Absoultely wonderful - visit if you possibly can.

Words are Feeble to Describe . It is hard to describe the beauty of the 400 plus rooms (no, did not see all of them!) much less the artwork, statues, clothing, objects of this museum. THE HERMITAGE MUST BE EXPERIENCED; SO HARD TO DESCRIBE ITS IMMENSENESS AND BEAUTY OF ITS COLLECTIONS.

Architectural masterpiece. The building is stunning. The art is varied and appealing.
Strongly recommend going with a tour guide and a small tour group (not more than 8) to ensure that you see the highlights and learn the history and the legends. The museum is too big to navigate efficiently on your own.

Simple beautiful..!. This is MUST SEE in Skt Petersborg..! Can't be described.. - you must expierence this. This is so overwelming and impressing and the same time crazy as so much value in one place and you expierence pure ness in other places!!

Superbe! . This is an absolute must experience in St Petersburg, whatever interest you are in Hermitage has something for you.A few tips to best enjoy the whole experience. 1/ go "early" meaning opening time 10.30 am; I did and there was absolutely NO queue ! 2/ pre purchase your ticket online, ideally take the 2 days one (it includes the picture taking and 4 other sites). Print the voucher and bring your ID.3/ check before hand which expo is on and the different areas. Hermitage is huge so you might as well start with what interest you the most.4/ personally big fan of paintings (European) so went straight to 1st floor (which has THE most sumptuous palace rooms) then 2nd floor. If I was to redo it I will start with 2nd floor and chances are that I would be alone with the Matisse, Renoir, Monet, Picasso and the list goes on! To do so, take the corridor on the right after ticket check/ before staircase, keep going straight and at the end take a right. Further there is an elevator that will take you straight there. You can then enjoy the 1st floor and if you still have energy the ground floor (Egypt / antiquity). Enjoy!

Unique building. The building itself magnificent, in my humble opinion surpassed the Louvre, each room a monument. I focalized in paintings, my main interest, and sculptures, quite a unique collection.The pictures collection is quite small by international standards, but it figures.You need, by all means, a private guide, is worth every dollar.

One of a Kind. You really should get a guide. Here's a great one tanya.sv@me.com (Tell her the Frosts sent you.)The Hermitage is daunting in scale and it really pays to have someone show you the important works. It is also helpful to have someone help you negotiate the entrance, if you son't speak Russian.Nowhere will you see such impressive and significant works of art in a setting so impressive.

Deep Breaths. This place is magnificent. One of the best galleries in the world. You do need to maintain a steady rate of breathing, otherwise you could easily pass out from the sheer size of the place and intensity of the art that it houses. If you like art, go to Russia just to go here. Incredible. And take pictures.
Great art but building needs updating!. Great art but it's sad to see it so poorly cared for. Poor climate control and improper lighting. Impressionist and post impressionist rooms are a must!

You should stay a week, but you must stay a day. This is an overwhelmingly rich experience, both for the lavish architecture and decor of the Hermitage itself, but also the knockout collections housed within it. You do need a whole day (and preferably more), and don't be fooled by the understatement of some of the basic guide materials. Rooms which aren't deemed important enough to have a highlight on them in the main plan can still turn out to be stuffed with some of the best paintings produced in Western Europe in the last 500 years. Do get an audio guide. Some of the observations are relatively banal but as a whole, the coverage is admirable and you really won't know what you are looking at without somebody, real or artificial, whispering in your ear. If you can, buy your tickets in advance on the internet - this comes with the camera permission you should technically have to take pictures (always without flash) with a little blue sticker to show you've paid the fee. And take the odd break in the cafe just to get your breath. It's a huge visit.

Unbelievable. to do justice to this complex, one would have to spend at least 2 weeks looking at the huge no of artifacts and paintings. Every iconic artist is in the museum.. very impressed with the collection and the preservation of the heritage.

Wonderful Palace. Really big palace..If you don't want stay queue, you should book online. You need more than 3 hours for average visit..You can get chance to see Descent from the Cross;Abraham and Isaac from Rembrandt and two Da Vinci...I strongly recommend to find guide, because not a lot of signs inside for the guiding.

Amazing. Amazing museum, it could take days/weeks to take it all in fully. Some practical info though: Definately try and book online, you can stroll straight past the never-ending queue. You have to go through the first door to reception who will endorse your email confirmation, then towards the cloakroom to booth 4 if i recall, who will give you the actual ticket! Very long-winded, but this is Russia! Also beware: If you don't get there early, you will queue once to get in to buy a ticket - as you do, no real issue with that, BUT then you will queue for what could be hours to deposit bags and coats if you need to - the problem here is they don't have anywhere near enough pegs for the shear volume of people coming in - so you may be waiting for someone who has finished their visit of the Hermitage to leave! When we left at about 2pm, there was a long queue of about 40 people just stood waiting in front of a bored-looking cloakroom attendant sat at the desk who jumped up when we presented our coat token, and a very relieved and thankful American couple at the front of the line said we had made their day! (No idea how long they had been waiting but I wish I'd asked them now!) My advice - either get there at opening time at 10am or try and not wear a coat, or bring loads of bags/umbrellas etc with you, then you can walk straight into the museum (Difficult, I know especially in the rain and in winter).

Art? What art?. I'll explain. The moment you enter the Hermitage, you'll have real trouble enjoying all of the beautiful art it has on its display, because the building is an art in itself. So, some useful advice for first-time goers:It's essential you get your online tickets beforehand if possible to guarantee your immediate entrance. Even though it's possible to buy the tickets on the spot, the queues might be long, depending on the time of the day. Then comes the queuing for the cloakroom and so on.You also need to determine the length of your visit. You can basically run through all of the rooms and make it in half a day, or really dedicate your time. Lonely Planet has a very useful route suggested which maps all of the highlights of the museum. You can find it in the St. Petersburg chapter of their Russia guide. Anyway if you're really short for time, or just are aware that it's simply too much for your attention for one day, have a look at the map museum provides and check out the rooms with the highlights. If you've been maybe to the Moscow museums, or the gallery in Mikhailovsky palace, then go and see mainly the ornate state rooms and large galleries with tapestries. And the golden peacock, of course. I would try and see the main sights on your first visit and dedicate yourself to the art on display after the bling loses its initial shocking effect. I found it much more overwhelming on the first impression, than, let's say, Louvre or British Museum. Anyway a gorgeous museum, and a must-see in St. Petersburg. And their giftshops have an amazing collections of really pretty souvenirs. I recommend malachite jewellery or crystal-ware.

Eat and drink before you start the visit of Hermitage. The museum exposition is great but the facilities for visitors need improvements. There were enormly time consuming queues in front of the cloakrooms and when it was our turn the cloakroom attendant refused to accept our coats due to no capacity. So we had to wait in another queue and the same happened again. We should better have left our coats in the car.No food and drinks can be brought in. And there is only one bufet on the ground floor that was full. Also toilets are located in the basement only.
Hermitage. We rented the audio guide which helped make this massive museum much more approachable. 2-3 hours was a good amount of time.
Must for every European. Wow, must must for every one!!!! This is exactly the place I have visited Russia for. Probably the only such a place in this country.

Impressive collection. This museum houses numerous paintings from different countries and periods of history. The collections are situated in various rooms over three floors. All areas are clearly signed and a full audio guide is available for use in various languages. This is a great place to visit not only for art lovers but for those interested in the architecture of the building and the interior designs of each of the rooms.

Can't spend long enough here!. I went back a number of times, and always found something new - this is literally one of the biggest museum I've ever been into. Free for students I would recommend going again and again, and for others head down in the morning when it's quieter, make use of the free cloakroom in Winter and get a little lunch at one of their cafes - it's worth spending a whole day in. There's such a range of things to see, there literally MUST be something for everyones taste here!

Worth the trip. We had a private tour guide for our family for this museum. We paid extra to get in 30 min earlier than the rest of the public. Worth every penny. To be able to walk around with no big crowds was amazing. So quiet. My daughter and husband were able to pretend to dance in the large ball rooms.

Beautiful but cloakroom disorganisation. The museum is fascinating and some of the exhibits are beautiful. There is a lot to see so you can easily spend 3 or more hours here. You can buy tickets from the self service machines outside as the queues are less than the long ones where you but them inside the entrance.Was told you cannot wear your jacket inside which seems strange and you must hang it up in the cloakroom. Massive queues and lots of pushing and shoving at the cloakroom and when you finally get to the front of the queue you are told there is no more room left and then everyone runs to another queue. If you are made to hang your coats up then there should be better organisation and better equipped facilities to do this.

Not just about the paintings..... I have a passing interest in Art and have been to some of the big european galleries already. The Hermitage has an amazing collection. But to be honest that was secondary to the building itself and the other treasures held there. I loved the antiquities section (alot less people too) seeing the finds from the ancient peoples of the eurasian plain I found fascinating.I spent a surprising 4 and a half hours here (surprised as I thought my limit was about 3... but the time just flew by, even if my feet are feeling it now!) it is a little tricky to navigate, especially when the floor plan guide looks like you can wander from room to room, to discover that those particular 2 rooms are not connected (or the door is just locked, or room is closed or whatever) There are a distinct lack of toilets (only on the ground floor) But like all great museums of this size, if you like art then you won't be disappointed. I used the ticket kiosk to buy my ticket when I got there, and didn't queue at all. I was told to check my jacket in (but stuffed it in my bag) I was able to take my bag in no problem. The crowds were pretty big in some parts, but I managed to find lots of rooms that weren't overrun with large tour groups. All in all an enjoyable experience.
Amazing!. Fabulous museum from start to finish. Incredible building, great collections and well displayed. The only snag was the long queue for the cloakroom as coats are not permitted in the museum.

Fantastic Place must see. The Hermitage museum is fantastic on at least two levels(a) it was a Palace and quite a few room have been left in the style of a Palace(b) its a great art gallery with a very broad collection of art. In Planning your visit I would suggest the following(1) go on a week day and buy your tickets from the ticket machine in the inner courtyard. You can then enter almost immediately. In any event the fastest way in is to buy your ticket from a ticket machine dont get in the queue to buy tickets.. Remember you need to pay a separate fee if you want to photograph of 200 roubles...The Museum is open longer on a Wednesday.(2) They have a rule ..No Pass outs..Pretty well adhered to. The Cloak room is before you enter the museum so if you are going to need to get anything from the cloak room whilst doing your tour, such as medicine or spare camera battery take it with you dont leave it in your bag in the cloak room(3) Focus on the layout when you enter. As others have said it can be a frustrating building to get around..particularly if you want the toilet or a coffee. You can get free a basic museum guide and you will see the museum is 3 buildings...the quite large building you enter... a skinny building it adjoins and a third building..Focus on how these connect because to get to toilet or coffee you really have to get back to the main building you enter(4) Focus on what you want to do. We focused on the official Palace Rooms and some areas of art in visit 1 and other areas of art in day 2(5) we found a book with a Rembrandt Painting of a red man on the cover very helpful as it had a separate section showing the official Palace rooms and gave major details of the paintings(6)dont think you can do this place justice in a few hours... you simply cant so dont be overambitious in your plans.. I would estimate 3 days minimum to do this and then there are another Museum across the square in the former military quarters,(7) we found the staff friendly and helpful but they dont speak English ( except for a few) and we didnt speak Russian so communication at times was difficult, for toilets, food and how to get to other rooms, but they tried to help and often showed us where to stand to photograph, pointed out other rooms where an artist was if they saw us interested in a particular artist...
A mass of pictures. Too much to take in in one visit, its massive with thousands of pictures many of immense value. As too the general decor.

Don't be talked out of visiting.. Everyone says that the Hermitage is too crowded and too big to see. It is crowded and it is big but it is worth the effort. The guide books say it would take 15 years to see everything. We visited with an English speaking guide who through a carefully orchestrated forced march was able to show us the highlights in about two hours. If you don't go with a guide read up on it first so you know what to look for. The period rooms showing how the royal family and commoners lived are particularly interesting. If you relax and don't worry about seeing everything it will be a great experience.

Definitely Allow Time!. This was just as spectacular as everyone says it is! We bought our tickets in advance, online. This is a definite MUST. Otherwise you'll be waiting in line for hours!! Just go to the Hermitage website and you'll be able to buy them there. We did the two-day tour as it allotted us more time. It was the best feeling to bypass the huge lines of people and go right in to collect our tickets and go into the Hermitage. It's massive though so plan which areas you want to see, go there first, then if you have time left go see the other areas. That is what we did and even though we could have spent days there we still left feeling satisfied that we got to see the things that interested us the most. Definitely check the opening times too, often it closes at 6pm but I think one day is open later. Info on their website. Have fun!

A Gem. The reputation of the Hermitage is very well known and it is a must whilst in the City.. The entrance process was very chaotic at one point the cloakroom was full, so no one else could enter. The free cloakroom facilities were much appreciated. Be sure to go in flat shoes otherwise you will have sore feet, it's worth doing some research beforehand to ensure that you focus on the parts that are of interest to you - there's too much to see and take in, after 3 hours you will have walked enough, also there are many groups who push in and make close viewing sometimes difficult. It is a tourist site which will have to be revisited on many occasions.

Do not miss and be prepared. Great collection of various arts, including paintings, sculptures, applied arts, palace interiors. One day is not enough to see everything.Tickets could be bought in ticketing machines - the queue is much shorter as compared to the queue to the cashier. Waiting time could be substantive, so my advice is the earlier you arrive the better.

Astonishing, and seemingly endless. Not entirely sure how any review can do justice to what is surely the most spectacular museum in the world.Where to start? the collection of artwork, from Picassos to Monets to Van Goghs to surely everything else in between is phenomenal. Egyptian antiquaries, Greek/Roman pottery, the collection of statues from all ages, tapestries the size of houses, Far Eastern relics... Suits of armour, paintings, honestly, a list of endless things to see.We went for two days (admittedly, not full days for a couple of reasons), and we still didn't see everything.And yet, even to discuss such artwork is to almost miss the point. I never imagined going to a museum with that line-up of artists, and find them coming second to the venue itself. The most incredible building I've ever seen, and the most beautiful building we saw in St Petersburg (which is saying something, given the preponderance of palaces). Every time you walk into a new room, there is something new and beautiful and amazing just in the ceiling-work, or the walls, or even the floors, or all three. Amazing architecture, varied, intricate, beautiful, breathtaking. Honestly, removing every single piece of art wouldn't diminish the place, such is the grandeur and beauty within. To add in world-famous art is simply the icing on top of the cake.There are a couple of things worth noting, though, if you are a first-time visitor -1. Russian bureaucracy is epic, and is perfectly demonstrated here. Be ready to queue, and plan everything in advance. Firstly, get your tickets online and skip the massive queues just to get to the ticket office (and when you do, make sure you go to the information desk to get your pass signed to go to the ticket office, where there will be a queue with people randomly pushing in.2. You can't take your coats inside - if you are going in a group, split up, and dump off your coats in the vast cloakroom to save time.(we ended up queuing in the ticket line before being sent away, and then the entry line before being sent away, which might only have cost us 15 minutes, but was enough to frustrate).GO early, spend lots of time there. It will be busy, people will push past and around you, and groups will randomly materialise from nowhere to stand in front of you because they can. Rooms will randomly go from full to empty and back again in the space of 3 minutes. It is crazy and beautiful and an absolute must-see.

A wonderful private viewing. Had an amazing experience with Private viewing and then a Classical Concert in the evening. One would need to spend a whole year to be able to appreciate all the wonderful art decorative pieces. So glad I had this opportunity

one of the must in Russia. Ermitage museum is so big that you better begin by what you prefer. For us, this was on 2nd floor with Picasso, Van Gogh, Monet, Renoir... but we found that this is an old fashion museum with rooms not highlighting works !

Everybody will tell you : "this is a must - see ...". and will be right. Hermitage is simply a "juwel". You can spend there days and still having a feeling that it was not sufficient. Or you can look at the guide and just pick up few things which attract you the most. And then just sit and watch the atmosphere and sprit of the building and "the old times"....And at the end of your visit you will say for sure again : ..."yes, they were definitely right ! "
An abundance of stunning buildings and outstanding art. You have seen the pictures, but reality is something else. The scale of this museum is enormous, and you can easily spend 5 hours here.

As stunning as expected. The reputation of the Hermitage is well known, and the visit proved the excellent reputation to be well deserved. The free cloakroom facilities were much appreciated and the architecture and exhibits were fantastic. You need stamina and plenty of time to make the most of the visit and it's worth doing some research beforehand to ensure that you focus on the parts that are of interest to you - there's too much to see and take in in one day, so you need to accept leaving some sections out or returning for multiple visits.

Overcrowded museum with a team of grumpy rude staff. The Hermitage in itself is a great museum, beautiful architecture building with extensive collection. But because of mismanagement, it has lost all its museum power to provide a good experience for visitors. Personally, it leaves a bad impression and bad memory to me. This is easily the most chaotic museum I have visited. There is no control of visitor flow or order for queue. It is like a flea market with people frantically pushing and jumping the queue. There is not enough info or signage inside the museum and when there is one, it leads you to someplace closed!! No AC, no ventilation, the place is hot and stuffy and crowded.Finally, the staff here is the most grumpy and unwilling staff that I have encountered in my years of travelling. Every member of the staff was rude, unhelpful and openly displaying their dislike for foreign visitors. When ask about a direction, they will simply point to the signage without utter a word or even look at you. But the signage is not relevant to the one I am asking about, Such arrogance!! Probably should just shut down this place if they are so unwilling to accommodate visitors, they act as though they were doing us a huge favour by letting us see the collection we'd paid handsomely. The cloakroom area is crowded with people waiting at the booth nearest to the entrance because the next booth or the booth next down the hall wouldn’t take any coat. Note these booth staff are either chatting or simply just sitting idly. The staff manning the functioning cloakroom keep shaking her head and huffing and sighing as if taking and hanging the coat is the hardest work on the planet.I decided to join the expensive guided tour which gave me a bit of general information about the collection and winter palace. Finally the guide is the only person that I have met in Hermitage that still has a bit of sense of humour in her. After the tour, I rewalk the guided tour route and appreciate the collection in more details at my own pace as one simply has to make the best of a bad situation.

breathtaking environment, above-average collection. I have just visited the Hermitage Museum, St Petersburg. It is true that the full collection would take many days to view each item - but that is not how the average person enjoys a museum. I picked the 'stars' in the collection and had a very satisfying afternoon. The musuem has a very fine collection of grecian vases, classical and post-renaissance sculpture, with one or two outstanding items such as Canova's Three Graces. It also has an excellent collection of Italian, Dutch and Flemish old masters, with Rembrandt and Reubens very well represented, again with a few thrilling highlights like The Return of the Prodigal Son and two exquisite small paintings by Leonardo. They also have a minor but still-pulsating statue of a crouching boy by Michelangelo. There are some lovely French impressionist and post-impressionist works, as well as a good selection of Picasso's works. But most of the sprawling collection is overwhelmed by the sheer, almost orgiastric opulence of the succession of exhibition rooms. Marble, precious stone and metals of every hue and in gob-smacking quantity, in doors, furniture, walls, window frames, columns, ceilings.You can really imagine the Winter Palace, that was the main residence of the reigning Romanov dynasty for 200 years, at the centre of a vortex that sucked the riches of the Russian empire and transformed them into marvels. It even puts the Versailles palace in the shade. So it is well worth visiting the Hermitage to see the setting itself, what used to be the Winter Palace and the Old and New Hermitage that now make up the museum. As for the collection itself, it has some fine highlights, but I have seen better at the Louvres, the British Museum and the Vatican Museums.

Excellence in a grand venue!. A must see... Many many many wonderful pieces of art of many different types. The palace itself is a grand piece. Many artists from around the globe... With many styles and really to much to see in a day.. Maybe to much to see in 2 days!!!

Wow !. Only spent 3 hours here and hardly scratched the surface ! If you like your History then this is not to be missed. Remember though if you wish to pay the entrance fee by credit card take your passport for ID purposes ... Or they simply throw your card back at you ! True !

Amazing!. Amazing building, worth visiting for sure, especially if you have limited time and you don't know which museum to choose. On Wednesdays it stays open till 21:00 so very convenient to finish your day with. When we were there, there was a concert taking place in one of the rooms that anybody could attend, such a pleasant surprise for us!

OMG... just phenomenal. This is without a doubt my most favourite place in the world... the architecture is to die for and the restoration is fascinating... also it's a lovely (albeit very cold in January) walk from Pushkin town up to the Palace! We really enjoyed our time here, and even got ourselves here quite easily using the metro and taking the bus (just keep saying Tsarkoe Selo until someone points you in the right direction, they will eventually!)

Stunning Art Collection and Opulence. Give yourself a whole day, or a second if you have it, to take in the feast of artwork on display by both the masters (Rembrandt, Tizian, El Greco, Goya, Rubens, Van Dyck, Poussin etc) as well as many, many others.One of the finest art collections in the world with displays of most of the European classics but also includes displays from Asia and other parts of the world.

Beautiful art, gorgeous furniture, large crowds.. We’ve been here twice now, both times on a cruise shore excursion short time frame. It’s not enough time, because there are so many treasures to see. They confiscate drinks at the security check, but if you’ve got deep pockets and a small water bottle, you can get it in. You’ll need a drink, because it gets warm in there.The art is stunning, but the rooms and furnishings are equally gorgeous. As part of the cruise package, we got to go down to the Treasure Gallery. It’s a lot of ancient items made with precious metals. No photos are allowed in there. The Hermitage docent is required to speak in Russian, and then our guide would translate into English. Humorously, the docent corrected the English translation several times (speaking to our guide in Russian, of course). It was really warm and stuffy in the Treasure Gallery. Having to say the spiel twice takes a long time, so we finally tuned them out and wandered around on our own. You can’t leave until the group does, so that contraband water bottle came in handy (out of sight of the security cameras, naturally).The Hermitage is wonderful and if we get back to St. P, we’ll try to spend a lot more time there.

Wow!. Massive collection, beautiful rooms! Get there early to avoid the lines and crowds if going on a weekend. Could easily spend days here but if all you have is a couple hours its still worth it to come and see what you can.
Amazement through every doorway. This place has to be seen to be believed. The opulence and grandeur is something to beholdEvery time you think you have seen it all. Another amazing room opens up.
Wonderful visit. A place not to be missed but leave lots of time as it's huge. You will probably not see it all in a day so plan ahead. Get a knowledgable guide too if you can.
Best art gallery on earth!. With something close to 500 rooms to visit and all the best art in the world - this place is an absolute must see!!

plan, plan, plan and be amazed. only gorgeous and amazing. I so loved the Hermitage because of its history, content, curators and cats. The da Vincis are dull, the Caravaggios wicked, the Breguels in a corridor, almost abandoned are superb, the 20 c collection breathtaking. But these did not make the collection so special, it was the ambience, the history of how Catherine amassed such works, the dedication of the Babushkas, the history during the siege of the city in WW2, the cats,What did I take away from my visit. I think that a bit more explicit respect of Russia articulated clearly to the Russian people would go a long way to recalibrate relations between Europe and Russia. Quite clearly, they are equals with a magnificent cultural, artistic and intellectual hinterland. We need to engage as partners and move on, together. Get your act together Europe.

Not for young children. Beautiful museum with fantastic art & history. They are very strict regarding young children watching us to the point of being uncomfortable so would recommend leaving this attraction if you have toddlers who like to explore! Also won't allow drinks to be taken in due to past vandalism. Enjoyed the visit but could have been a little more relaxed! Couldn't take my eyes off the floor, ridiculous but beautiful!

Wow. Wow I believe it is under the 3 Top museums in Europe (Hermitage, Louvre and Prado). The collections are really great and the building is awesome. I've been there 4 times (whenever I'm in Petersburg) and even though I spent more than 10 hours in the museum I always discover something new.

Amazing !!. A must visit place if you ever find yourself in St. Petersburg even if you are not a big art fan. There is more to this place than just paintings and sculptors, the building and rooms are just as stunning has the things that are being housed in them. Would advise if you can to do a guided tour as english is not hugely spoken.

Fabulous. Is one of the most fantastic things you would see in your life. You should go at least twice. I enjoy the visit very much as I like russian furniture. Don't miss the modern paintings from early 20th century and English painters.

Walking on the tsars footprints. The Palace is stunning. We decided to book a guide to visit hohe museum. Her explanation were great and we Follikel her for more than 2 hours. We have three children and they loved the museum (mainly the Leonardo da Vinci paintings, the egyptian area and the knights armors. We will go back because we haven't Seen all hohe paintings we wanted to see.
not to be missed. Great moment, fantastic pieces of art; with post soviet service ... not always there, and could be uneasy if you do not speak Russian.

Absolutely beautiful. We travelled to st petersburg as part of a tour and visited the hermitage and winter palace...and we were not disappointed. It was beautiful and everything has been so well maintained and looked after. Anything that needed to be refurbished or redecorated has been totally in-keeping with the building that you wouldnt know the difference. The rooms have been lvovingly restored and various bits of furniture which are more than likely originals or very good and expensice representations have been cordened off to protect them. Staff are very friendly and know a lot about each room to give visitors extra info if requested. The gift shops and cafe are all excellent and very clean and also very well priced for a building with such quality and historic significance,.

Great place, hard on the feet.. Wonderful collection of French art in the 19th and 20th centuries. Dutiful building and could imagine the Romanovs sweeping down the main staircase. However I found it badly organised and difficult to get around even with a map. Thanksfully some of the attendants spoke enough English to point to stairs. Oh and the cafe is really basic. In fact, give it a miss and go tot he internet cafe instead. You need a day to visit this palace/museum. Just standing outside and looking to the building is wonderful.

It's everything it's cracked up to be. You cannot spend enough time here. One room goes into the next goes into the next ... with more fascinating and wonderful treats for the eye than you know what to do. Enjoy it while you're there, bec you may not be able to find it again (I couldn't.) You'll be able to indulge the most arcane interests, and you'll find yourself fascinated with things you'd never have imagined yourself stopping for. Shops on the entrance/exit level are also wonderful, so leave yourself time to indulge!
Amazing. Free for students, beautiful building and interior and some incredible art pieces!This place is incredibly beautiful and wort seeing!

Amazing exterior and picture collection. The exterior takes your breath away. It is big and beautifully decorated. The interior is worth it for the rooms alone....don't forget to look at the rooms and ceilings when you look at the pictures. As for the pictures, well that's some collection! All your favourite painters and many you will not have seen before. I read it's 13 miles if you walk all 400 rooms. You could spend days here and still not see it all. Decide what you want to see in the time you have as its massive.

A full day's visit. This is a huge palace. If you want to take ohotos remember to buy a photo permit - then you allowed to take pictures of their permanent exhibits and artworks. The rooms are beautiful and the variety of art is excellent. They have a cloakroom which is compulsory to use (but free) - this is worth it as the museum is kept quite warm in the cold weather. It will take almost a day to see all around this location - no water is allowed in the museum (leave it in the cloakroom) but there is a cafe. Well worth a visit
A must see to have lived....., and again and again...!. One of the most interesting and comprehensive Museums anywhere....., every time i get back it is like a new overhelming experience....Enjoy!
A visit to the State Hermitage. It is one of the richest museums in Russia.. If You want to see all the exhibitions situated there It will take You a very long time. But it is worth seeing.

Two days is really not enough. We paid for an expensive guide. That actually saved our queuing for much too long - and we went in February - out of season and well before the cruise liners disgorge their thousands.. There were 16,000 pictures. She knew them all. She was fantastic. Vista after vista, fabulous luxury and world heritage masters. Just unforgettable. Walked us off our feet before she left. A day's visit is too tiring. Take two half days or three punctuated by a break at the barely adequate cafe on the ground floor. We went one day for the experience and the second visit to find our favourite pictures and sculptures.
Fine museum even thou you don't like museums at all. History of russian royal family 17-19th sentury, and a lot of other exhibitions ih whole palace inside

Incredible. This museum is amazing. We spent 6 hours there and didn't see everything. Highlights included the state throne room and the room with gold walls. The artwork is from all over the world, from all periods. It's a fantastic collection.

one of the greatest museums in the world. The museum features some three MILLION items. Technically if you want to see them all, it will take about nine years in a row. The absolute must see highlight of St. Petersburg.

The Greatest Art Museum in the World. It is difficult to describe all treasures - pictures from Leonardo to Picasso, jewellry and gold from aincient times, sculptures, etc, Buildings themselves belong to the best examples of baroque and classic architecture. At least half a day - for quick visit.
A must!. The 3rd largest museum after The British museum and the Louvre. Good collection of french impressionists, authentic interiors of the Russian zars in the Winter palace
The main place to visit. Unforgettable place! Everybody who os visiting Saint- Petersburg has to see that Palace and Hermitage.

Great museum. Really enjoyed our visit. Has a huge number of things to see. It would take a few hours (or days) to see everything, we just went to the highlights. It was our favorite thing to do in St. Petersburg.

WowWowWow!!!. It has a been a life time's ambition to visit here & it sure doesn't disappoint. Paid extra to have a tour of diamonds/jewellery, well worth it although got off with a disorganised start. The collections here are incredible and bling does not even do it justice. This place is a jaw dropper. Well worth a visit & can't wait to go back to see more

Set a day aside.. Set a day aside for this huge buildings. Yes buildings.... Because when you go to purchase your ticket, half of it is outside around the corner. Restoration work is underway at present but you can still see lots of art. It's a gallery. Once you find your way around, which is not easy as it's so big and confusing, make sure you get to the 3rd floor for the major artists. Also get over to the 1st floor, if you can. Not many people here as you can't find it. Seriously confusing and still 90% a gallery.

The Greatest Art Gallery in the World. The Hermitage is a stunning Gallery which competes with the works of Art for attention...it is difficult to remember it was once home to the Tsar one filled with crowds...an early visit is recommended. I bought an internet ticket for 2 days which was reasonable and meant we could avoid queues. Please note that on the first friday of each month the Gallery is free to visit.

Hermitage is a must see. The Hermitage is immense and filled with incredible objects and paintings. There is so much to see that you have to plan out where you want to go. Even the museum itself is a historical relic. Wear comfortable shoes. I spent 3 hours strolling the halls with a guide (I highly recommend a guided tour).
