A must see... One of the top museums in the world, do not leave St Petersburg without visiting. Don't expect to see the entire museum in one day, it would be overwhelming, but choose a few galleries beforehand. The staterooms are opulent, enjoy the beauty and history of this truly amazing museum.

Amazing. It is an amazing museum! Antiquities, paintings, state rooms, all contribute to a great experience. One should choose in advance the collections in which he/ she is interested and get familiarised with their location in the museum (the Hermitage's site is very helpful). I visited the museum early in April and there were no queues or large crowds. The musuem cafe is decent, although it should be larger.

Wow!. Amazing museum. There are tours at the museum and you should buy it with the cashier. Otherwise skip the line and buy at the machines outside the museum. Also, make sure you have an idea what you want to do their... there is a book of hermitage in an hour that you can by at the book store.

Must Visit. It is very big to get around and in busy season I would pre-book tickets- the majority of the masterpieces are on the second floor but they do provide a very good guide map. beware the guided tours inside they try to get you to join are expensive and most of the main pieces are in english
Must see. A perfect place to visit, even a MUST SEE, if you have a longer WE in that former Russian capital. Plan minimum half a day.
I simply loved it. I liked almost everything also its free for students so worth watching..& it has real good setup things to watch

Gigantic place. Of course it is a must visit place in Russia!Tips: buy ticket online before the trip to avoid long Q. Even during winter time.bring your own food if possible, the choice are limited inside.If you have limited time, dun stay in one room for too long, you either can follow the given boucher/ lonely planet to see just the important rooms, unless you are ready to stay for days.The golden mechanical peacock is awesome, dun miss it.
Better than the Louve. Very ornate, with a lot of different art. Lots of Picasso/Monet/Renoir etc. The jewelry and gold are worth seeing as well.

Mind blowing. The sheer scale of the museum is overpowering. The beauty and magnificence of the rooms and exhibits can not be taken in, in what was a first, short visit. I can understand why it is said it would take 11 years to see it all! Definitely take the audio aid.

Art-A-Plenty. The Hermitage and Winter Palace are extraordinary places to visit. The rooms, staircases, and architecture are a feast for the eyes and worth the visit even if the rooms weren't filled with art. Speaking of the collection - amazing! That said, we found the docents difficult to communicate with. We had purchased our tickets online and downloaded the map app for our phone. Still, we couldn't find what we were looking for in many cases. For example - there was a Kandinsky room on the map and app, and yet, it wasn't there. We went to the appropriate numbered room and there was not a single Kandinsky piece in it. We asked numerous docents, each of whom sent us somewhere else. We never found them. Perhaps they were on loan or in storage, but we were not able to have that communicated to us. Like many non-US museums, the art could be better conserved. Still, it is an amazing place to visit. The collection is superb. We spent two days visiting and it still wasn't enough to see everything. My favorite was the spectacular golden bird automaton!

Immense - limitless art to explore. I lived in St Petersburg for a year and I still don't think I saw all of the Hermitage. I would definitely recommend a local guide to show you the best parts. I'm not really a big art lover but there really is something to enjoy for everybody.

Definitely not to miss. This is a treasure for art and history lovers. It is a grand palace and museum. Plan to spend a full day (at least) and arrange for a local guide if possible. If you want to avoid the crowd, plan your trip for late autumn (during summer months expect long queues).

All smoke, no fire.... It is rather expensive to enter but after the first hall itself it becomes boring. One can expect to see the lifestyle and the household set-up of that era but there are only household articles and paintings displayed randomly. Not worth going inside. Waste of time.
just what you have always expected. A beautiful palace - and all the treasures you have read about. fantastic to see the Old Masters paintings and sculptures in the flesh

Amazing Hermitage. A number of beautiful buildings containing some of the great works of art. To see it all would take a few days but if you are on a short break I recommend you book a guide to show you the highlights.

a rennaisance. This is one of the most captivating building of st petersburg, the style and unique features is a must see and the beautiful decoration with an environment green is a feast for the eyes.

STUNNING ON THE OUTSIDE AND EVEN BETTER INSIDE. Just visit the place, you will regret it if you don't.Stunning architecture, stunning history, and restored toan incredibly high standard.Value for money.

Spectacular, Stimulating, Superb .. This is one of the largest museums in the world, with over 3 million items it is second only to the British Museum (9 million) in terms of exhibits. Clearly not all are on show, but there are still so many wonderful things to see several days would be needed to really appreciate the Hermitage fully.Guided tours are generally for half a day and although this isn’t really long enough, the guides are excellent and the pre arranged route takes in most of the prestigious rooms and exhibits. The Main Staircase, The Peter Room, The 1812 War Gallery and The Large Throne Room were our favourites. When it comes to art, we all have our own favourites, but whatever your taste it will be well catered for, the world’s greatest artists are all represented many times over and this may be your only chance to view these particular pieces. Photography is allowed but we recommend you buy a book e.g “THE HERMITAGE” by Alfa Art Publishers, which contains the history and a description of the Winter Palace and its contents. It also contains hundreds of photographs that you would love to have taken, if only you had the time and opportunity. We cannot imagine coming to St Petersburg and not visiting this spectacular museum.

The Everest of Museums. Go here when you are ready not to go to any more museums for a few months. It is huge in size and scope and diversity of collection. The quality and completeness of collections is overwhelming. We did the audio tour but had trouble finding our way around. Down load the app it will help. Be discerning, you can't look at everything unless you are prepared to stay for a few years. Do yourself a huge favour, it costs extra, and see the Diamond and Gold rooms, making sure you work out where you go to join the tours - it isn't straight forward. Tours are small groups and the guides are decorative art experts - such a treat. Don't miss the Siberian exhibition. Look out for The Hermitage Choir in the Russian section. We stayed two days, one would have been heartbreaking. Good luck, try to relax and enjoy whatever you see.

A dream come true to visit this museum. I have wanted to see the Hermitage for many years. I will need another trip to see more of it! It is huge. But I managed to see some great masterpieces before I tired out. The building itself is a magnificent work of art.
in one word: amazing!. We had little time (4 hours...) and selected the parts we wanted to see: 3rd floor and the boudoir and golden room on 1st floor a must see!

A Pleasure for your Senses. A walking tour that will stimulate your senses. World renowned artist that you will enjoy all under the same roof. Great museum gift shop with many prints of the famous artwork that you get to see up close, and you can take home with you. Very reasonable prices, a must see on your trip.

Could spend weeks in here!. What an amazing collection of art and sculpture, housed in a beautiful, vibrant and (fortunately) warm building, set back on an incredible square. There was too much to see in our full day visit and we yearn to go back to enjoy the more modern art rooms which we breezed through. Don't forget to look outside at the Atlas like men who hold part of the (enormous) building up. Best seen with a guide if you can manage it, helps you get the best out of the history of the building. Toursbylocals provided a fabulous and knowledgeable guide for us. Kate - we had such a great time in ST P thanks to you!

Lives up to Expectations. Because it was the middle of Winter we were able to walk straight into the museum, without having to stand for hours in a queue (our tour guide had never seen so few people there). In the two hours we had available we only managed to see a fraction of the Hermitage collection, the highlight being a Picasso work, "Les Trois Femmes", which my daughter had admired since she studied it in high school. Not only did she finally see the original painting, but she was able to buy a reproduction on canvas.
beautiful. very beautiful. if you love art this place is a museum of art. and should have time 1 day for this place.

One day is not enough!. Make sure to plan your visit in advance and decide what you want to go to see, because one day is not enough for this awesome and very large museum! It houses an important collection of art and historical treasures. I especially enjoyed the Ancient Russian exhibition, with exceptionally well preserved over 2000-year old Scythian artefacts made of fabrics and wood. Remember that there's free entrance to the museum on the first Thursday of each month!
Fabulous. Wonderful exhibitions. So much to see that it is worth taking two days but go with a guide to get the most out of the experience and avoid queues for tickets which can be hours in summer.

More artwork then anywhere in the world.. We visited in June with my family of 6. We had a great guide, which really helped keep our teenagers attention. I could have stayed all day, but they were done in a couple of hours.Would go back again.

Such a wonder. Went and visited one weekend while living in St Pete, definitely need to go again. One Time is not enough because it's so huge! I loved all the amazing art pieces by Da Vinci and Michelangelo and other artists like Rembrandt.

Beautiful. This is one of the most beautiful places i have ever visited. The traditional Russian rooms left me opened mouthed, they are magnificent and completely grand! We bought a 2 day ticket and i'm glad we did! So much to see, in the last hour we were rushing round the last bits we hadn't seen!So highly recommended! A must see if you are in St. Petersburg!

One of world's great museums. One fabulous large hall of treasure after another.Too much for one day really. Paintings, sculpture, furnishings, jewels, armor, clothing, tapestries. Adequate restrooms and nice but crowded gift shops round out the experience.

Amazing....but don't do the Diamonds Room tour. Like other reviewers we were blown away by the Palace, the art, the remarkable and quirky organisation, and the wonderfully expressionless ladies who sat in every room!However, we paid for the English tour of the Diamonds/Gems room.....not the Gold rooms. We got a softly spoken, abrupt and frankly boring lady of advanced years as our guide. The tour is scheduled for 1.25 hours. After 35 minutes of looking at the gold up to the first century AD, which was admittedly, amazing, we went, with several other tour members, to look around a bit in the next room. Oh no we won't. A very large, aggressive and threatening gentleman bellowed that we must "go to group, stay in group" and marched us back. Well, not all of us; 3 of the group walked out. The rest of the trip we were closely monitored by this gentleman.However, this would have been fine if the Gems room had not been such a huge disappointment. We weren't expecting the Crown Jewels, but this was basically, personal dress jewellery from a variety of people with a few other pieces, displayed in basic cases.Hermitage is a must...but invest your time in the place .....not the tour.

Disappointment Russian Style. Yes, the collection is one of the best in the world! However, the way the Hermitage takes care of its art work is a travesty. There is no air conditioning and windows are left open. Masterpieces sit in direct sunlight. The Impressionists are kept in on the top floor, under fluorescent lights on white particle board. The curators should be sent back to school. Your enjoyment of any museum is dictated by the way you see the art. The Hermitage leaves much to be desired.There is no restaurant, wine bar or amenities of any kind. There's one place you can buy awful, stale, overpriced sandwiches and sit in a hallway to eat. If you are familiar with the Louve and think you are going to find the same level of food, wine, coatrooms, restrooms and museum store, think again. The Met, the Louve, the Prado, The National Gallery of Art, the British Museum and the Philly Museum of Art are all much better in every way. The Hermitage doesn't even have a Vermeer. There is impressive art, but the overall experience I had at the museum completely distracted me from the collections.One of the biggest disappointments was The Treasure Rooms. I thought that would be the highlight of the tour. However, once we arrived at the museum, we were told it was an additional $278 USD per person to visit the special gold and diamond Treasure Rooms. Since there were 3 of us, we passed on yet another version of the "Russian shakedown of American tourists." What I would recommend is that you pay the extra money to get early entry. We arrived at 8 am and had the museum pretty much to ourselves for about 2 1/2 hours. Once the cruise ship people start to roll in, the galleries were so crowded you couldn't see a thing. We left about 3 pm and there were approximately 1,000 people in line. What these poor folks thought they were going to do in 2 hours in one of the largest museums in the world is beyond me.Should you go? Well, if you are in St Petersburg, then yes. It's why you go to St Petersburg. The other attractions are very interesting and all, but the Hermitage is the highlight. Just be prepared. Go early and don't get your hopes up too high. Remember, it's Russia.

Great exhibits. an amazing museum - so large it would take days or months to look at every exhibit carefully. The range of paintings, sculptures is huge. We spent a whole day there and it was a day well spent.

I had great expectations... and they were met. Unfortunately We only had a half day to see this, and you could easily spend a whole day if not more. Having said that, it is quite amazing, beautiful pieces and a true sense of history. Some beforehand planning is advisable!
Awesome place. One of the best museums out there! Every room holds a surprise that will make your trip worth while. Make sure to visit the Palace interiors and the Egyptian section.

Must See. Excellent collection, excellent restoration after war damage. It appears that original materials may not have been used in restoration, but very well done. We had a guide and got rushed through the Impressionists - the guide almost passed them by entirely but there was nearly another October Revolution when she suggested it. If you like are museums, allow an entire day, perhaps two.

The Hermitage: What they don't tell you!. First, The Hermitage is wonderful. You can spend days in the place because there is so much to see and to see it well. It is not only an art museum, but a palace as well. Because it is so massive and usually you are with a tour, you are pushed through the place rather quickly. We would have loved to have spent more times in certain rooms. (We would enjoyed more time with the impressionists and post impressionists for example.) Second: We saw several people having difficulty with all the walking and the lack of places to sit. Each room has a Russian lady who seems to be the guard. They get tired of sitting so they go off to visit with friends. Then, you can sneak over and sit for a moment. I did that a few times. I did see people who left their tours so they could find a place to rest. There is special help for people in wheelchairs, but you have to contact the museum. There is more than one floor to the museum.Third: Besides having the most paintings on display in the world, there were other outstanding pieces of artwork that I saw people just walking by without really looking. There was some blown glass pieces that were just beautiful. There were huge Empire-style vases made of semi-precious stones that took years to produce. The wood patterned parquet floors flooring and the mosaic flooring were beautiful as well. The ceilings were amazing too. It is just a remarkable place! After talking to others in different tours, the guides can make a difference on what is emphasized. Some are more knowledgeable than others. Our guide knew little about the vases and yet our friend's guide new about the vases in detail.

Beautiful Palace.. Even when you don't like museums and aren't interested in art all too much, this museum is a wonderfull place to visit by just strolling through and admiring the beautiful rooms and their decorations.

The best museum. The best museum I`ve been to and that includes W.D.C., N.Y., Paris, Rome, Berlin...Go there in Winter time and you have space and time. Take a guide!!! We loved the impressionists but were shocked about the mouldy ceilings in this area. The ground floor is in a fantastic condition.

Completely Amazing!. WOW! What a collection of artefacts and artworks! This place is apparently the 2nd biggest collection in the world behind the Louvre in Paris... it's not hard to see why either!We spent a couple of hours on our last day just wandering around and managed to get lost numerous times, fortunately there are heaps of staff around to assist you should you need it.Don't go on a Wednesday though as it's closed!

Beautiful, but difficult. The Winter Palace is absolutely beautiful, and it is definitely worth the wait, but that's the issue. The lines are extremely long and the staff does not do the best job of funneling people through. It is not to be missed, but allot yourself enough time so that you do not feel rushed and can really enjoy the beauty.

obviously the best art collection in the world. it will take you two days for french impressionists alone. if you want to liven up one of the (mainly) female security guards falling asleep take a flash photo of a van gogh

wow!. Stunning place....not expensive to visit especially if you buy an all inclusive ticket. Make sure to include a photo permit, you will definitely want pictures! The art work is awe inspiring as is the decoration of the building. The cafe is good too but not cheap.

Once is not enough..... The Hermitage is a must if you visit St Petersburg. Getting a ticket is not easy if you only speak English but you get there eventually. Don't forget a photography pass if you want to take picture. Tours allow you to see exhibitions such as the Gold Collection. The building and exhibits are vast in scale and navigating the museum is not easy - it's very easy to get lost. You simply cannot see it all in one visit. So plan before you go what you really want to see. For such a great gallery the lighting in some areas is a real disappointment - but the art shines through.

St. Petersburg = State Hermitage Museum. If you visit St. Petersburg please do not forget the visit Hermitage Museum. We were there with our friend group. They spent about 2 hours inside but we spent about 4-5 hours because even one day is not enough to see all ! So bring a high quality camera with you and do not use flash light inside !

What a pity. Although the structure is beautiful, the amount of people that are there every minute of the day is beyond belief. Since the tourist season is short, the local tour operators get every human they can through the door all day, everyday. The structure is beautiful but the crowds make it difficult to enjoy.

Hermitage Visit. Obviously one of the must see museums. A former palace of Russin tsars, it is located along the Neva River. The interior is grand, and as with other palaces in Russia, rivals Versailles and Schoenbrunn Palace in grandeur. The floors are amazing in their patterns, wood inlay and the artwork on display is fabulous. Nice gift shop for souvenirs.....although can be pricey for some items..

Stunning Art. The Hermitage is an absolute must in St Petersburg. I personally am not a fan of art however in the hermitage I was truly fascinated by it! The pieces of art come from artists like Da Vinci, Van Gogh, Monet and Piccaso are stunning. I recommend getting a guide book as we had a top 10 list of the art works to see which showed us the best art in the museum and gave us information on them!
amazing place. what to say more ....it needs more than one day , after a full day of visiting you get tired ....so many things to see .....incredible ....will go back again Patrick

great visit. This is a world class place. It a shame the government does not take better care of what they have. No AC & paintings facing bright sunshine from the windows. How long will these treasures last?

Do not even attempt to cover it in a single visit. Hundreds of extravagantly designed/decorated rooms filled with thousands and thousands of paintings, sculptures, ornaments etc. from all over the world covering almost the entire classical and modern art history! So please-oh-please do not try digesting it all in a single visit... Plan your trip well-ahead (preferably doing some research) and try covering a specific section each day of your visit. For instance rooms of Rembrant, Matisse or Picasso each would require at least a few hours for at least getting the gist of what is on display in this magnificent palace. Alternatively, of course, you could skip the whole content and simply be amazed by the architecture and decoration of the palace with its golden pillars, furniture made of marbles of all colors etc.

Amazing. Sadly we only had 3-4 hours here. We could have spent far more because this place is huge and is filled with amazing features. The grand stair case is a gem, but I don't even know where to go from there. There are so many things to see that the only thing I would recommend is to stay as long as you can.

One of the World's Great Museums. Truly breathtaking - there can be no museum like it anywhere in the world. I spent three days there and could have spent another three without real effort. One of the great destinations on the planet

Book tickets in advance to skip the line. We made reservations in advance, this allowed us to skip a queue of hundreds of people. I hope you to do the same!Once you're inside the Hermitage the tour starts, and you understand the power and wealth onces held by the former heads of state. Every room you enter is more breathtaking than the previous ones. We spent a few hours without a guide but still felt like we got the most important facts and information. There are a lot of tourists here so be aware!

Hermitage and Winterpalace. You can use days. Study it before you enter, it is culture and art in one. Buy a book in the bookstands inside. Bought a good book for 300 RBL, beautiful pictures and good written

Fabulous!. The museum is fabulous! What I did't undestand was that the staff were not concern that the big temperature diference can damage the paintings. There were rooms where they were keeping the windows open and you could feel a bit cold (it was February!!!) and ringt next to that one a room with high temperatures. I've seen paintings curved. it's a pitty! but over all, the building, the collection.it was incredible beautifully!

Awesome location, incredible contents. The Hermitage is an amazing building with mind blowing displays. I have never known a museum / gallery where you can get so close to the exhibits. The Gold Rooms in particular were stunning. Unless you have a lot of time I would recommend a guided tour as these normally get into the museum before it opens to the public.

Early Entry - A Real Bonus !. We were provided with early entry with our SPB Ships tour and arrived at 09:30 and accessed right away one hour ahead of general admission. Our guide Katerina was wonderful in providing a very informative and knowledgeable tour throughout the many treasures of the Hermitage. The museum is huge with something over 3 million pieces which was started with the collection by Katherine the Great. We covered so much ground in the tour which was truly spectacular. Just a pity we could not spend longer as it would take two days at least to cover the Hermitage properly.A memorable highlight of St Petersburg.
A must see!. We visited in the afternoon as our guide knew that morning visits are extremely crowded. An amazing place!
Great museum. Huge museum with plenty to see, you could spend an entire day here. Great value to enter attraction.

Beyond Description. The building itself is awe-inspiring. It is painted a lovely lime green which reminds me of the Caribbean, but somehow the building screams Russian! The palace sits upon one the largest squares I've ever seen. Interestingly, there weren't any food or souvenir vendors on the square the day we were there. That certainly added to the regal atmosphere. We had purchased tickets online as was recommended. For these tickets you must turn in the voucher at a kiosk located outside the palace. It is right inside the middle archway. We did not enter this way and had some trouble claiming our tickets, but the staff worked it out. Once inside there are several tours to choose from. We did the tour of the palace rooms as we could not resist the splendor as we caught views of the main staircase. We were not disappointed! We were there for the peacock clock demonstration which was wonderful and I highly recommend. Each room in the palace was more beautiful than the last. Most impressive were the floors. Each room had its own design and the floors were made from the most beautiful woods. We also took the time to view the Dutch painters as this is a part of the world we aren't very familiar with. The Rembrandts were amazing and we carved out time to visit one of the many gift shops to purchase a copy of one of his paintings. We elected to do the museum with the audio guide and were quite pleased. We prefer the freedom of moving at our own pace and the audio guide had more than enough information. The employee at the audio center spoke excellent English and was a tremendous help getting us set up. Because of the size of the building, it can feel overwhelming, but truly worth the time.
Excellent - must see. Excelelnt place. You should come out of the season to fully enjoy otherwise very crowded. Guide recomended.

Possible the best Art museum in the world. No trip to St Petersburg is complete without a day spent in the Hermitage, quite simply this is one of the finest museums of art I have seen and I'm comparing it with the Louvre! Room after room of breath taking masterpieces and for me it really paid off to have a guide so we went straight to the highlights then wandered the rest of the building at our leisure afterwards. Difficult to pick out individual favourites but at a push I'd go for the collection of stunning Rembrandts...

One of Worlds Major Museums. Ranks up there with the Louvre (Paris), Prado (Madrid), Metropolitan (New York). Equally large, so a guide or group tour is recommended on the first visit, or you will get lost and run out of time to see anything. Collection covers all major art and classical periods. However, although the French Impressionist wing has a significant and well done collection, the guides treat it as an option in favor of the more traditional, and Russian artifacts. I suppose this is to be expected.The highlight for me was seeing the extremely large Badakhshan Vase, which towers 6 feet above visitors heads, made from the brilliant blue stone lapis lazuli from Afganistan.
About the best day ever!. What to review? The palace? The art? It's so overwhelmingly wonderful. Wishing only for a hired art tour guide.

Art was Good, Crowd Control Not. After seeing most of the other major art museums in Europe, the Rijks, the Louvre, Vatican Museum, Uffizi and Prado, this museum was on our hit list. The art itself is very beautiful and interesting. There are lots of pieces to see. Unfortunately, compared to other museums, they are a little lacking in some areas. The crowds were enormous and it was difficult to move around the building. There were way to many people in the rooms and since you generally have to follow the same walking pattern around the building for the first bit, it was very frustrating. There is no AC in the building so that with all of these people, you better check your coat and have lighter clothing on because it rapidly becomes a sauna. I don't believe that this is good for the preservation of the art. Lastly, people get much closer to the art here than a other museums which I don't believe is good as well.Overall we were disappointed with the museum, its collection is vast and can certainly require a 2 day visit, but I don't think we could handle the environment. Definitely not the best museum in Europe for us.

you get little if you have not a guide. There is a big difference between walking in a museum and watching it. Unfortunately I went to this great,really among the top 3 worlds museums,by myself and I see little.Guide books and signs are not enough ,and I think having a human guide is essential.Collection and the building itself are magnificent,and big,need more than a full day to visit important parts.

The historic buildings of Russian Tsars. It's large spread out building with lots of rooms, windows and separate areas with various functions and purpose. I wonder how it was being managed and cleaned with such lots of rooms and areas..?!

Can't get enough. It's one of the most beautiful museum in the world for sure. It's impossible to see everything. You have to focus on what you really want to see. It's worth to be there early as it gets very crowded. It's easy to get lost. Truly a very nice and memorable experience.
One of the world heritage. One of the world heritage. It's impossible to describe all treasures. You must see this majestic, beautiful museum.

Lesson in History. It is a walk in History. You cant but be awed by all the historical memorabilia in one place.It transforms you to another era..Involves a lot of walking so best planned in advance. its impossible to view everything that's on offer so for serious history lovers, plan plan plan in advance.Casual tourists.. just walk through and soak in the atmosphere.. either way you will come away impressed.Long queues exist and the internet booking is a great way to save time and enter quickly.

Incredible. More to see than any of us could ever manage. Catherine the Great acquired on average 300 pieces of art every day throughout her 30 year reign! Some exceptional pieces in a very unique building. Having a guide helped us to focus on specific pieces rather than try to see it all.

An Embarassment of Riches. St.Petersburg is one of my favorite cities and the Hermitage collection in the Winter Palace has my vote for the #1 attraction in the city. This museum alone would make the trip worthwhile if you have an even passing interest in art. This is far and away the greast art collection in eastern Europe and can legitimately be mentioned in the same sentence as the Louvre and Prado. The setting itself in the Winter Palace is simply overwhelming; despite the dozens of magnificent canvases in many galleries I find myself lost in the archtecture of the building itself. The collection of western art is encyclopedic from Greek statuary to the early 20th century masters, plus there are nooks and crannies on the upper floor where you can find unique things such as thousand year old Armenian illuminated manuscripts. I have heard horror stories about immense lines amd crowds during the summer, but going in the off season (I was most recently there in mid November) is a different story. I got to the entrance at 1020h. (opening is 1030h) and there were exactly 6 people ahead of me and for much of the morning there were rarely more than a few people with me in a particualr gallery. A few minor points; there are only a few places to go between floors, this can lead to much time spent backtracking. Bathroom facilities are also rather sparse apart from those near the entrance and cloakroom. Eating options are also quite limited and a bit pricey. These should discourage no one; just be prepared.

Simply Spectacular! . What can one say about something so grand....AND with arguably the best Art Collection in the World. You just CANNOT miss this from any itinerary. .....and then go back and vist again next time around. If you're not into art....it doesn't matter here....you'll still be captivated. ...romanced... enthralled here!

A must!. Winter Palace/ Hermitage Museum is a must if you like art. One of the best museums/collections I have ever seen. State rooms are fantastic as well. I visited the museum in January and it was half empty which is a big plus, in Summer Hermitage is extremely crowded and you can not stop even for a moment to admire objects you like.

Get there early. I am not a big fan of art. But this place is so beautiful. The only thing i do suggest is get there before the gates are open, because the line is so long....and if you remember buy your tickets at the terminal located out side near the entrance or even better get them online.Don't try to see everything in one day....It is TOOOOOO much...if you wish to see all the exhibitions prepare your self for 3-4 days in that great palace.
Overwhelming. A vast museum that would take weeks to fully explore. It's worth buying your ticket online in advance - that way you by-pass any queues.

A dream come true. If you like art you will leave the Hermitage loving art
So much to see and so much to absorb. What a problem to have, too much to see and not enough time
No matter your preference: Italian, Flemish, German, Russian, impressionist you will find it at the Hermitage

The most marvelous collection of art in the world. The Hermitage is considered one of the premier art collections, if not the largest, in the world. And this marvelous collection is housed in a sumptuous example of architecture, bringing together diverse styles reminiscent of the era.

Wow - what a building. We unwittingly chose a 'free tickets' day to visit so had to queue in the cold for 2 hours which was most uncomfortable, but wow. Surely one of the most comprehensive art collections in the world in a stunning palace setting. While you could spend days there, if you're not a massive art enthusiast half a day is probably plenty. My advice: check that it's not a free entry day - it's worth the ticket price just to avoid the wait!

Great!!!. I have no words for Ermitaz!It is a very nice museum.Visit it!!The ticket has a good price and you can choose to have a guide.Our guide was smiley and very helpful,for 2 hours she explained everythink to us!!TIP!!At the entrance there are machines where you can buy tickets with a credit card,without waiting.We didn't know that,so we had to wait for 1 hour.

Absolutely overwhelming. Just like in the other palaces around town, the gold decor on the walls and the restoration work is superb. The museum is so enormously big, that you'll have to either come back every day for a week or settle for a tiny overview - tough choice. We did the overview basic tour in English and our guide did a fabulous job. I would recommend paying for a tour as everything is written in Russian and alone we would have gone lost in the palace. Entrance is free for children, which is a nice break from all the fees you keep paying around town.

For art and history Lovers. The hermitage is on the same page as the Louvre in Paris or the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam. It has the originals of some of the msot famous paintings in the world. It is a large museum and definately deserves time to go through everything. However, if you are not an art/history lover, then you would probably be bored at the Hermitage. Whats great is the free entry for students from any country if you show them your student ID. Definitely a must visit.

Overwhelmingly huge. To be clear: This is an excellent museum. Go there. The building itself is worth a visit and, bonus, it's filled with amazing art. The downside is that if you visit during the summer, the crowds are quite overwhelming. I found myself glancing at Rembrandt's work and retreating to the neglected Asian wing just to get away from the crowds! Give yourself a day to see this place.

One of the best museums in the world. This museum I think is the most fascinating of all the ones I've ever been too...and I know quite a few.Peter (the tzar) was an avid collector and building Saint Petersburg really to "market" his own country better. The visit to his museum (formerly his winter palace) is fascinating...not only for the pieces of art but for the quality and history of the buidlings. Museum staff are not that friendly; I went there with an amazing friend of mine who contributes to it so we enjoyed a great visit to the best areas within it (otherwise you'll get lost, Im sure). I had pre-booked my entrance but my friend invited me there (as he is a member contributor or sth) and the staff (although very hard to talk to) actually returned the money I had payed in advance which is sth that i realized some days after leaving Russia. Also, the looks from the windows...just amazing.

unbelievable. Really, un-be-lievable, the amount of treasures these czars have amassed. We were here for one morning and I think another month at least would do some justice to the place. Need to go back!
Too much to see!. Took 3 hours just to do one floor! Their collection of Dutch art - mostly paintings is phenomenal! Beautiful palace!

AMAZING museum!. It's very recommended! My boyfriend wasn't really into museums but even he enjoyed it so much! There's plenty of everything - art and sculptures (Da Vinci, Michelangelo and such!) ,antique furniture, armory room and a lot of other cool stuff. It took around 3 hours of wandering :) You should probably try to get in there as early as you can, the lines to the tickets can be insanely long.

St. Petersbugh : Architecteral gem. Hermitage is one of the largest museum in the world. It contains over a million painting by every European artist you can name. They are not all on display. Although I spent six hours, it needs 2-3 days to see and admire all the paintings. The building itself is an architecteral gem, as are all buildings in this most European of city.I got free entrance, courtesy a Russian paramilitary man. Near the ticket office, as I approached to buy the ticket, I saw six of them coming out. One approached me, handed his ticket and said " Go" pointing the entrance ! This is called Russian hospitality.St. Petersburgh is a city one must visit for arleast five days before one dies.

Just Amazing. In my opinion this may be one of the largest museums in the world and the most impressive. It is simply huge. If I go back I will certainly select where I want to go and what I want to see first. Otherwise you can be overwhelmed by the displays of art, etc. i loved it!

Huge varied museum with great historical value. . You really need to visit this museum for parts of several days to see it all. If you are like us, we can only endure 2 - 3 hours at a time, so plan accordingly to make sure you see what you really want to.

A must-see on your bucket list.. I would recommend going early as there are usually line ups.My preference was the second floor, however, the museum is so large that you need to leave yourself lots of time to see it. Allow at least several hoursIf you are real art lover, also organize a private tour of the storage facility, which was amazing. You will begin to understand how large a collection of art there actually is. The collection horse carriages of Catherine the Great is mind-blowing.
Amazing!. This is one of the most incredible museums in the world and a must see! There is something for everyone.

HERMITAGE. Top priority - GO EARLY in the morning! Allow at least 3 hours for your visit. Second floor is the best. But if you like antiquities give at least half an hour for the 1st floor of the palace.

Just one massive treasure trove. We spent two half days here and barely scratched the surface. Our guide had an idea of what we wanted to see so was able to maximise our time there. The place is huge and you really need to know your way around if you don't want to waste time. Some of the treasures are so breathtaking it's easy to lose sight of the stunning architecture which houses them. We visited the gold room and the diamond room which were separate additional tours but well worth the extra cost and time. The art exhibitions rival any in other major cities with many very important pieces. We could have spent a jaw dropping week here and still gone back for more!
Better than I expected. The collection was better than I expected!Take the time to see the whole collection.

Need Lots of Time. You could spend days here. There is just so much to see. Our trip was early Sept and it was HOT which is unusual. It's not air-conditioned and it pains me to see some of the paintings getting dark from humid conditions. A 15 ft Rembrandt was practically brown. I wonder if a few treasures could or should be sold to climate control the place and save the rest.Oh those EGGS! Fabulous Faberge. Wonderful gems.

The Best Museum. I think the Hermitage has to be one of or even the biggest Museum other than the Louve in Paris, with 5 building connecting full of all kinds of treasures. An amazing museum, in the Egyptian Exhibit a mumified body lies in perfect condition, You heard of the Bird in a Guilded Cage, well it's actually at the Hermitage, perfectly polished beaming brightly. Every Artist is represented. Ancient antiquities, gods, statues, from achelogical sites. Be prepared to walk, you can't see it all in one day. Wonderful, went in November 2012.

The huge musesum better be explored with a private tour guide. When you have a group of 5 people and rather limited time it makes a perfect sense to hire a private tour guide to get the most of this beautiful museum and its collection.Our Russian friends recommended Irina Seits as one of the best in the business. She exceeded all our expectations. Irina expertly guided us through the most interesting exhibits (given our time constraints) and was able to answer all questions related or unrelated to Hermitage in surprising depth.What stands Irina apart from other tour guides we've hired before is her passion and enthusiasm about the history and excellent American English -- she spent a year in Utah as an exchange student.In short, Irina was able to enhance our experience of Hermitage so much that it became a highlight of our trip to St. Petersburg.The fee was much less than what you would pay for private guide in Vienna or Jerusalem.We can highly recommend Irina Seits to anyone who wants to makes the most from a visit to Hermitage or other museums in St. Petersburg.Irina can be reached at irina.seits@sh.se or at +7 921 754 1646
Wonderfull. Fantastic, such treasures and opulence, frequently had a sharp intake of breath so much bygone Russian culture.Lost of art, sculpture, an absolute must.

What can I add...?. The main purpose of my visit to St P.Amazing,overwhelming, awesome ... all that and more...If pushed for criticism: the ticketing facilities and other logistic details can do with some modernisation.

Wonderful Museum and thats a real compliment coming from me... Museums generally bore me but this is without doubt the best I have ever been to. The Louvre pales in Comparison to this- The setting is just stunning and more importantly the art inside!! As I walked around I nearly soiled myself at every turn seeing paintings by such famous artists I had no idea were in this Museum.To top it off I visited on the first Thursday of the months and it was FREE :-)Wonderful!

worth the wait to see it. As with all other tip places to see in St. Petersburg it is crowded with people but worth the visit. Don't skip the third floor full of art. The impressionist work is beautiful. The palace is beautifully done with gold gilding work throughout the second floor. Allow enough time to take your time and take it all in.

Jaw dropping amazing. Somehow this is even more incredible than Peterhof, though Peterhof's gardens set it apart & makes it pretty unique. The grandeur is really over the top & can even be a little overwhelming at times. You are left not knowing where to focus your eyes! There isn't an inch of this place that has been left without perfect attention to oppulent detail. To me the actual building & furnishings were more incredible than the art. I am not discrediting the art, but I feel that you often see similar work from the same masters in other museums (I live in NYC) where as there is no way to curate a show of buildings such as the Hermitage.

The Hermitage. There are no words. Really, is anything as wonnnnderful as this? I don't think so. In the city of Palaces, this Palace of the Czar is a total jaw dropper. From the moment you walk in and feel like you just landed on top of a gigantic wedding cake... to the hall after gorgeous HALL of incredible artifacts, paintings, oh... really.. THERE ARE no words. It's out of this world. If you go, be sure to sign up with SPB Tours and they will get you in without all the crowds. It's a bargain for what you get. I could move there just to go here once a year!

An Amazing Art Collection. The museum is huge, largest in Russia with something over 3 million pieces, and started with the collection of Catherine the Great. It actually consists of five buildings including a theater, so depending on your art interests, you need plenty of time to see it all. We booked the tour as part of a cruise shore excursion, and it was well done with a good guide. My only disappointment was that I was under the impression that we would see the Faberge Egg collection as part of our tour. Unfortunately that was a separate tour, and we did not see them.
beautiful. easy to get around, well worth the money, tons of walking, we were here for 3 hours and should have planned for longer something for everyone

You can't go all that way and not visit the Hermitage. ummmm, WOW!!! This place is totally amazing. The Russian floor is a few hours to see properly, especially considering the photos you'll take (where they allow it). And then you'll have to hit the higher floors. Do yourself a favour, block an afternoon and immerse yourself.
Fantastic. Doesn't everyone want to visit this amazing place. On a tour no waiting in line. Great place to see with a guide. Wear flat shoes and make sure you take in the surroundings.

The best museum in the World. Thousands of rooms in some 10 buildings await. The problem is you need at least 3 days to visit. Buy your ticket on the internet to save an hour getting in. In the summer go early to avoid the rush of busloads of tourists. Most come to see the paintings so go there first. The Gold Room is the most amazing place I have ever been with 1000 year old gold objects beyond belief. You need to arrange for this one early.Later you can head downstairs for the exhibits from southern Russia and the "stahns" where artifacts unlike those seen elsewhere await.

St. Petersburg to Moscow on MS Zosima Shashkov with Gate 1 Travel. My friends andI traveled to Russia on the Gate 1 Russian River Cruise in September/October 2013, and I would highly recommend this tour. It is a good value for a complete experience. Before I left, I had many questions, so I wrote this review to help others who will be taking this cruise.Ship: Our ship was the MS Zosima Shashkov. The ship was built in 1986, has been refurbished, and is in very good condition. Clean, comfortable common areas, lounges, and bars on 4 floors. There are 2 large dining rooms. Our room was small—just big enough for 2 single beds with a table between them and a window above. There were shelves and a closet to store our clothes and other items. Space under the bed to store a small suitcase. The bathroom had a toilet and a sink, and a shower curtain that wrapped around when you used the shower. Sure, the entire sink area got wet when you showered, but there was a high shelf over the toilet that could hold things that you didn’t want to get wet. It was a way of saving space and it worked well. Each bed had a built-in light in the wall. There was one 220-V outlet with 2 places to plug in items. The small refrigerator was plugged into one of the sockets. Be sure to bring a 220-V adapter for charging electronics that are 220-V compatible, and a converter if your item is not 220-V compatible. If you have many things to plug in, bring a multiple tap to provide extra plug-in space. At the reception desk, they lent out 220-V hair dryers, but wanted them back after each use, so if you can bring your own 220-V hair dryer, you will save a lot of time. The ship offered wi-fi internet in the Small Bar at the front of the ship. Connections were spotty and depended on the ship’s location. Sometimes we had good connections and speed. We soon realized that we could almost always get connected when we were going through the locks.Food: The food was excellent! They offered many authentic Russian and local dishes on the menu. Meals were attractively displayed, tasty, and varied. There was more than I could eat! Breakfast was buffet style, with a variety of omelets and sausages, sweet rolls, fruit, juice, and yogurt. Coffee and tea was available throughout the day. For lunch and dinner, we selected our choice of soups, entrees, and desserts from a menu for the next day. There was usually a salad or appetizer. There was enough variety to please everyone at our table. We received a bottle of water at the lunch and dinner meals. Wine, beer, and sodas were complimentary at the dinner meal. For ease with the menu orders, we were required to sit at the same table for all the lunch and dinner meals. This was a nice way to get to know some new people.Tours: Many shore excursions were included in the cruise package. Each one included a local guide who spoke English and provided abundant information. Headsets were provided to listen to the guides with ease while we walked in various areas. We had a great guided tour through the Hermitage in St. Petersburg. The museum is so large that the guide was very helpful to get us to see the best artwork. Additionally, each group had our own guide from the ship who constantly watched out for us on the various tours. Katya, our group guide, was always at the end of the group, smiling, and making sure that we kept up. She was willing to take our picture for us at various sites—and she is a good photographer! Tour busses were comfortable. Some extra tours were available for an extra cost. There was something for everyone. I highly recommend the Catherine’s Palace and Peterhof Park tour, Rivers and Canals of St. Petersburg after dark, Moscow at night and Metro Tour, and the Armoury Museum of the Kremlin if these are available. We were not able to book these tours before the cruise. We signed up for these optional tours during the cruise. My only complaint about the tours was that I would have liked to spend more time at some of the sites.Tips: Bring some one dollar US bills to give tips of $2 to $4 to the local guides and bus drivers. You can tip them with Rubles that you get at an ATM machine, but these ATMs usually dispense large bills and sometimes it is hard to get small bills in change. There are many local tours along the way. For the cruise staff and tour director, either bring US dollars or get Rubles from an ATM machine to pay these larger amounts at the end of the tour. Many street vendors take US Dollars or Euros as well.Entertainment: The staff provided enjoyable shows with talented singers, dancers, and musicians, all in native costumes.Activities: A variety of activities were offered during the cruise. One could participate in Russian language class, learn local dances, music, and culture, watch history movies, attend a tea ceremony, meet the Captain on the bridge, or be in a talent show. Throughout the cruise, there were times to attend very informative talks about the ports which we would be visiting. Some fun events included a pirate scavenger hunt and a dance contest. The optional Vodka Tasting was well worth the extra cost as there were delicious appetizers to go along with the vodka and special entertainment. Dress was casual on the ship. Some people dressed up a bit for the Captain’s Dinner, but it was not required.Staff: All of the staff members were professional, friendly, and helpful. Tour Manager, Tanya, was friendly and answered any questions we had along the way. She seemed to be involved in everything!Visa: We used the tour’s agency to arrange for our visas. It worked out well.Flight: We flew to Moscow from JFK Airport on Aeroflot Russian Airlines. Our flight left JFK 2 hours late and we were concerned about our connecting flight to St. Petersburg since that flight was due to take off before we landed in Moscow. To our amazement, when our group of about 30 deplaned, we were greeted by a Gate 1 representative who quickly guided us through immigration and customs and got us to our connecting flight in record time. We were surprised that they held the plane for our group, even though we were very late arriving. From then on, we were very well taken care of, and felt much more at ease. Tanya was waiting at the gate in St. Petersburg (and it had been a long wait).I highly recommend the Gate 1 Tour. It was an enjoyable way to visit St. Petersburg and Moscow and sites in between.

The Hermitage will leave you in Awe!. We were so excited that we were going to be visiting the Hermitage, but never in ourwildest dreams could we have imagined the sights that we visited that day! Opulenceof gilded rooms, paintings by the masters, ceilings painted magnificently, a room done allin amber that was simply amazing! It was one room after another of amazing treasures.The largest museum in the world would take an unbelievable amount of time to see it all,we were only able to visit a small portion of it, but the grandness of it all was over the top!
Stunning. So much to see one day was not enough time and quite overwhelming. We have never encountered so much artwork in one location.
a must see. its one of the major attractions of st pertersburgh and righty so. it leaves you spell bounded and in awe.. a must visit for tourist and it is seen to be believed..
Hermitage Museum. Too many treasure to see, it was truly amazing, the Peacock clock, and the many paintings by the masters including Da Vinci

It would take you a month to see everything properly!. Just stunning, inside and out - the sheer amount of historical artworks and artefacts is mind-blowing. We only had about two hours and we barely just scratched the surface in terms of taking what we saw - sully in. The Rubens display was particularly fantastic as were the Italian marble sculptures and decor. One of the wonders of the world.

Fantastic. It lived to all my expectations, the building is really amazing and the collection impressive. Unless you plan multiple visits during your trip, you will have to make choices on what you really want to see as it is gigantic. I would definitely go again if I return to St Petersburg.

Amazing. Do not miss the Hermitage if visiting St Petersburg. The building itself is well worth the visit. The collection is huge, and it would take days to see everything, so take a look at the maps and select what you want to see. There was a big queue to buy tickets when we arrived, but there is also a ticketing machine which no one seemed to use for some reason. It is not well signposted, it is just on the right when you cross the gates. It was in perfect working order and it saved us from queuing for ages !

Outstanding and shocking. I liked everything but it is very very expensive so take enough founds if you want ti see all. I was so tired after 3 hours in the Hermitage. Wear comfy shoes and take water to drink.
art. The new space of The Hermitage is for contemporary art exhibition. Thiere are a great space and good exhibitions. You are welcome!
Our Hermitage visit. This museum has to be visited. The French, Dutch painting collections has to be recommended for all visitors.

Beautiful rooms - average museum. The Winter Palace as a building is well worth visiting, even if the long lines look a little ominous. The restored rooms are stunning. Having visited a number of other galleries in Europe, I found the Hermitage difficult to navigate. The various collections aren't easy to move between unless you want to walk through every room and the information map/pamphlet provided by the staff doesn't make the task of finding what you want to see any easier. Still, if you're in St Petersburg with a spare day, it is still worth the visit - just go early!!

Great time to visit!. We were visiting iin November and we couldn't have picked a better time. There were school children doing tours but for most of our time we had many rooms to ourselves. We took two days to visit and had tour guides for each day. There was some duplications but it was good to hear the information again. Everything was spectacular!

Best museum in the world. This is the museum which you must to see. This is real encyclopaedia of classic art from Europa to Asia. And don't forget too see main halls of Russian Emperors. There are fantastic view

The great museum of Russia. Hermitage is the most known and most big in size great in exibits museum of Russsa. Actually you can visit this only museum and have a complete image of Russia. Of cource it is impossible to visit all Hermitage in once - it will take from 3 to 10 visits to see all it has. As opposite to Cairo museim that is extrembly boring with dry mummies and stones, it is very intereting and exciting. Absolutelly different arts and styles, from stoneage exibits to modern art, from over the world, not only from Russia. It is amazing an there is no words can discrybe it you MUST SEE IT!!

I wish you to say at the end:"I've seen Madonna!!!!!". Take into account, you can't make it just in 2 hours, schedule at least the whole day if you wish to see 1/20 of the collection. The museum is not just "an Art gallery", a visitor can see one of the best world collections of Fine and Applied arts belonged to the Russian royal family located in the real Tsar's interiors, gala and private rooms. That's why NO BIG BAGS OR BACKPACKS in the museum in purpose to prevent possiblity to damage precious decor of the rooms. After a act of vandalism happened in 1987 wnen Rembrandt painting was damaged by the acid brought in the water bottles - bottles of water are not allowed, too. But in the lobby there are 2 cafeterias and 1 internet-cafe, so if you get tired and thirsty you can come down and have some coffee breake. Then continue your discovery of Leonardo and Rafael, Caravaggio and Tician as well as French Impresionists, Egiptian mummies, Greek sculptures or just find a window where Nicolas II crabbed on the window glass his nickname.Make sure this museum is good for well fit visitors: 5 adjucent bldgs, 2 stories and almost no banches for rest except of lobby.
Hermitage. The Hermitage is one of the best museums in the world ! You need to visit it at least two times to view all the artefacts there.

Must must see. This museum is the museum of museums. I can't imagine a tip tot the city not including a stop at the Hermitage. It's HUGE and there is no way to see everything in one visit. We utilized a private guide service during our stay and it was invaluable. Our guide quickly and efficiently maneuvered around large crowds and we were able to see much more than we would have on a standard tour or by ourselves.

Fun for everyone. I went to the hermitage as part of a guided tour and it was wonderful! There was so many exhibits and the Winter Palace was also lovely. There was a VERY long queue which could of been a problem, however, as we were on a tour we went straight in. Only downside was it was quite noisy and busy but it wasn't as bad as places like Disney Land! Overall great trip, recommended! :)

It is worth it!. The facade alone will get you on your knees. Yes it is a Museum but even the outside is like a work of art.Yes the lines are long, but you need to be patient as it is one of those Museums where the Art inside is not only one of a kind but very uniquely Russian.So if you plan to visit just ONE museum in Russia, I suggest you make a trip to St. Petersburg and immerse yourself in the grandeur only found in Russian Art.Decide on what you want to see, as you cannot and I repeat, you cannot, see everything in the Museum even if you spent 3 hours in there. It is so big and just imagine hundreds of people with you just to go around the place.Do not fret, it is truly worth it!

Private guide worth the price!. The Hermitage is huge, and I found it hard to find my way around in it. We had two tours, one with our cruise and a private one. The private one was hugely more enjoyable, we were able to skip crowded places and come back to them as we felt like. Even after those two tours, I would go back tomorrow, since there is so much to see. Overwhelming! But, well organized.

Wonderful Russian History. This was a highlight of our river cruise holiday through Russia. St Petersburg is a wonderful city and the Hermitage is a jewel in the crown. Who would have thought this city was part of communist Russia once upon a time. The home of the Tzars. A must see city and location. You will be surprised and delighted.
Get there early. Suggest you get there early on a Sunday for in the last few hours the lines can be very long and the tour crowds can be numerous.

A must see but very overwhelming. The Hermitage is so large that you should definitely choose the items you want to see prior to leaving for Russia. You can’t see everything and after spending a few hours there you feel overwhelmed by the size of the complex and the many rooms of beautiful art work, sculptures and furnishings. We visited with our tour group and were taken to all the main attractions in the Hermitage complex. We spent the majority of time in the Winter Palace. The Jordan Staircase, Throne Room and The Raphael Loggias and The Malachite Room were my favorites. The green stone in The Malachite Room was mined in the Ural Mountains and the color is so rich and brilliant especially when the sun was shining in. If you have an opportunity, make sure you view the Hermitage at night. It is truly magnificent. I would also suggest that you eat prior to arriving, the food choices are limited and it is very difficult to find seating especially when the tour groups arrive.

An incredible place. The Hermitage is not just a Museum. It´s set IN the Palace and therefore you don´t just find magnificent pieces of art, but you also get to walk around this UNBELIEVABLE palace!! One of the most wonderful things to do in St Petersburg.

wow. 30 min ticket queue in winter main downside.Bought entry, English museum tour and English Gold room tour. Only one of each per day. The only way to see the gold or diamond rooms is to book on to a tour. Also need a photo ticket.Both tours had 5 people. Guides English good. Gold lasted 1½ hrs and okay....very detailed in one area. Overall tour lasted 2¾ hours. Amazing. True value for money. Knowledge first rate. Amazed at the scale of the collections.You could scratch the surface in a couple of hours or spend 2 days, depending on your appetite for art. We were there 6 hours.

Carry a map, you'll get lost in here. I think this is supposed to be one of the largest collections of artwork in the world. The cost is reasonable, but it really is so large that like The Lourve, you can't do it all in one day. You need to pick what you want to see and then decide if you can do more.The exterior looks a bit tacky - bad paint jobs. The interior however is everything you expect - gold, gold, gold everywhere.You can easily just stay in one area and forget to see what else is in the museum.The modern pieces are so diverse. I didn't realize they owned some of those pieces. You literally can touch the art - don't - but unlike other places it's so accessible and not behind layers of glass and rope.Totally worth it if you like art. I'd skip the tour guide as you may want to spend more time in areas than others. The map is really helpful... and do not hestitate to ask security (well, the stern old women standing to make sure you don't touch the art) for directions.

A fine museum. This museum lives up to its reputation by having the paintings and other exhibits that are expected. Fine French furniture, a room full of Rubens, another of van Dyke, a fine Gainsborough, Van Gogh, Monet, aplenty. A really fantastic collection covering a huge number of periods and subjects. Absolutely wonderful from this perspective.However as usual in Russia the labeling of exhibits is poor and you need to take your own book (which doesn't cover everything, so good labeling is still essential). Signage around the museum is also poor. I also felt that some of the paintings desperately needed cleaning.Being November there were few visitors, which was good.There were two special exhibitions which required extra payment to get in an we could not get into either because the tours are fixed and the only English language tour that day had finished and we were not told about when we specifically inquired at the kiosk on arrival; which rather annoyed us.I also felt that the museum is trying to do too much in one place. Why not have the types of exhibits in different places. Paintings in one museum, furniture and porcelain in another, armour and medieval weaponry in another, etc etc. There is lots of room in other palaces etc.

Best of the best art in the world. We took 2 tours and both times wished for more time in the impressionist rooms. The guides want you to see a sample of everything, but there must be some way to get permission to spend more with the French impressionists.

Not normally an art lover but..... The building is magnificent. Never been much of an art lover but our guide kindled a fair bit of interest with her short but informative talks. Loved some of the other items as well - especially the peacock clock.

Hermitage museum. Fantastic Place. They got everything in old and modern paintings.But avoid tourist season. Go off season so you can enjoy everything. Nice coffeshops so you can have a break before you go back and enjoy more

Hermitage - a winter palace and art feast. Whatever you do in St Petersberg don't miss this sight. Simply awesome art from da Vinci's Madonna to Renior and Russian master pieces every painting would be worth the visit, but add the amazing surroundings of the Winter palace and it's gold leaf having survived years of mistreatment by Germans, fires and now been restored beautifully to its former glory.Advice on skipping the queue - for tickets - you can only by for the day if you go to the ticket office. Alternatively buy online in advance a voucher which needs then to be presented inside to the administration desk - allowing you to queue jump and then join the front of the ticket queue! All a bit beauracratic, and if you have a camera be sure to buy a further ticket for 200rubels. And do take the opportunity to take pictures as the summer palace at Peterhof doesn't allow it.

Hermitage museum. Am az ing. Well woth the visit but pace yourself as its very tiring but beautiful works of art and opulent rooms chandeliers in abundance. Yousopov palace with the Opera another must on a visit to St petersberg. Peterhof fab but fountains closed during winter months.

Exhilarating but challenging. Rather like a long walk through beautiful mountain scenery, the experience of visiting the Hermitage is exhilarating but challenging. Some tips from recent experience:1. Work out in advance what you most want to see, and where it is in the museum. Plan accordingly.2. Buy tickets on line to jump the queues. Consider the two day ticket (valid the first day you visit and the day after that).3. Be aware that once you are through the turnstiles you can't re-enter that same day. 4. Consider going through the left hand turnstile to get to the absolutely incredible displays of Russian and Central Asian archaeology. Probably like nothing you have ever seen before, and you will have the rooms almost to yourself. 5. However, if you follow step 4, be prepared for a long, circuitous walk to the better known art exhibits.6. Be prepared for lots of long, circuitous walks in any case.7. Do not miss the Gold Room - an extra ticket you buy on the day. Accompanied tour only. Fantastic.8. Be aware that there is only one cafe and a small, hopelessly overloaded coffee bar for the whole gigantic museum.9. The Hermitage opens into the evening on Wednesdays, and is less crowded later on.10. Be patient, pace yourself!11. Do not miss visiting the Hermitage, in spite of its challenges!12. Take time to check out the museum shops.

Ran out of superlatives. Spent 2 hours in here but could have gone back many times if we were able. An absolute treasure house of everything you can imagine and we were lucky enough to be in the music room when a quartet of men started singing - a fantastic experience!

It's a must!. This place is huge! You need the whole day to tour this place. They have amazing arts, tapestry, history and interiors. What i didnt like about this place is the coat check. They have only a few places to accomodate and yet they allow hundreds of people to come in, wheras you can't enter the museum with coats, so you dont have a choice but to wait for someone to leave so you can get space for your coat. It's crazy!

Huge range of exhibitions, tonnes to see!. The Hermitage's collection is obviously vast beyond comparison and only a small fraction is on display. This said there is still a very wide range in exhibits but some did leave me a little underwhelmed, once you have seen one portrait of Russian Imperial nobility you really have seen them all! The hermitage itself, as a building, is worth the visit alone! Free entry for students of any age so I'm not complaining!!

Don't miss the Peacock Clock. The hermitage is a bit overwhelming, suggest that you plan your visit to make the most of your time. The intereriors are just as impressive. Don't miss the gold peacock clock. To avoid the queues, purchase your ticket on line. To redeem your ticket, head for the main ticket area and show staff at the queing area, they will point you in the direction of the cash office where you swap for a real ticket.

Lives up to its reputation. It's certainly a museum that you can spend the day in. There's art that covers the entire range of art history, including Egyptian and Greek, and it's all presented well. I would say the outstanding thing about it is that it attempts to cover everything and it succeeds. As such, you won't find comprehensive sections on any particular area of art history, but you'll find a representative sampling of every area.

No words to describe it !. First of all: loooooong queues to come in ! Waited in line for 1 hour 15 minutes, and for many times line stopped by, museum was full ! So, book your tickets in advance, but you will need a printer for tickets. The museum is very, very big - 5 buildings !and you'll need at least 2 days to visit it all. I had a few hours, so visited the house collection. The woodfloor is cifferent in each room and is magnificent ! Worth a visit !

More masterpieces than you could properly view in one lifetime. If you had asked me where I would expect to fine the greatest and widest collections of fine arts in the world, I would have exhausted many guesses before getting to the State Hermitage Museum.There are so many works on display from grand masters that you dismissively walk past some of the finest masterpieces, and although the displays are very extensive the vast majority are locked away in store rooms and vaults.Even the building is lovingly restored and maintained.A true art lover or art historian could be happy here for many lifetimes. If you have ever enjoyed visiting an art gallery put this one on your "bucket list" it is truly beyond compare. We were unable to name a single master from any discipline who was not represented.

Awesome as expected. There's so much here you don't know where to start. Everyone reading this this will alread know it's the biggest collection that money can buy. So here's some practical advice. Get there before opening time and get in the queue. You can't take food or drink in, you must check your coat and backpack into their cloakroom. You have to buy the right to use a camera for 200 Rubles. Once you're in you can't go out and get back in on the same ticket. They have a cafe that sells water and basic refreshments. You can buy access to the diamond room or the gold room, we went for the gold room and got met by a guide at a designated time and place. There was only two of us on the tour of the gold room so we could ask anything and our guide was extremely knowledgeable and we had the place to ourselves, it was an awesome and impressive collection.

Tour the World - within the Hermitage Museum. First off, dont think that its compulsory to dash around hanging on a tour guides coat. This collection of world famous art and decor is like a good wine - slow and enjoy. I bought my 2 daypass via the internet for $25. Best move throughout my 7 day stay in st Petersburg. Major benefit is that you fast track hundreds of visitors waiting in long queues, security is paramount so dont ignore warnings. Great time is after 11am, and continue over lunch break which appears to be taken by all organised tour parties. DONT miss the Greek, Roman and ASIA displays on the lower floors. This is really a 2 day job, if you end up being caught up in a flow, you miss the chance to stand back and absorb what in mind humble opinion, is the world's best collection of art, furniture, jewellery is state hands.This is number one on the TO SEE list. Something for everyone, every young children

If you are interesting in Art and History highly advice you to visit Saint-Petersburg Main Museum!. One of the greatest and biggest collections of paintings, sculptures, engravings, applied-art items and other. First visit the Ambassador Staircase, The Field-marshal's Hall, the Armorial Hall, St.George's Hall to look interior decoration of tzar's times. St.Peter's memorial throne room is closed unfortunately because of restoration. Continue a walk visiting the New Hermitage and The Pavilion Hall with the Peacock Clock, mosaics and fountains. Then enjoy paintings and sculptors of great Italian, Spanish, Dutch masters. Also must visit the 2nd floor (impressionists).

Me and da Vinci!!. Too many superlatives for this huge, unbelievable place containing unbelievable art. Try to find a day when it's not packed, if possible. I really lucked out on a Wednesday morning and had many rooms all to myself--really! I was the only person, other than the docent, in the huge room containing the 2 da Vinci madonnas. I was able to consider both of them for a long time, and appreciate this total master even more than I did before.

a 2 day pass isn't enough!. Just to be in a room with not 1 but 2 of Leonardo da Vinci;s paintings was incredible. It really is like one magnificent sweety shop for art lovers. Rubens, Gainsborough, Titans, Raphael the whole place took my breadth away. The decorative arts amazing. You must take the Diamond and Gold room tour at an additional 300 Roubles to your entry ticket. Priceless gold and diamond objects some dating back to 4BC in perfect condition. You could spend 3 years inside the building and still only glaze over it. Plan your visit and its worth getting the App for your iphone on the Hermitage. Plan which collections you want to see, because no matter how wonderful everything is, you will eventually get museumed out!
Surprisingly really.... I wasn't expecting my six year old to be at all interested in the Hermitage but he really enjoyed the knights hall and Ancient Egypt.

Wonderful art gallery and pallace. The art gallery is huge and contains many wonderful paintings of the grand masters including da Vinci's Madonna and Child. Rooms in the Palace have been decorated as they would have been in the Tsar's time but didn't quite match our National Trust Properties. Lovely views of the estuary from the windows.

Catherine the great's treasures. One of St. Petersburg's main attraction.Gorgeous building,lots of great paintings.
Two works by Da Vinci and many other masters,like Rapahel,Rembrandt,etc But they allow too many people in and all the rooms and halls are crowded.The Hermitage is now fully restored.
But only a portion of all the paintings are displayed.They may have to construct another building to display more paintings.

Worth your Time. This museum is huge. HUGE. I think anyone who is thinking of visiting the Hermitage Museum should know that prior to visiting. Come prepared - rested, fed, etc. You'll easily spend several hours here both enjoying the incredible collection of art, artifacts, and the beauty of the building itself. Make sure you have your map handy at all times, the layout can get a bit confusing. This truly is a must see if you are in St. Petersburg.

Disappointing. I found The Hermitage quite disappointing. The building from the outside looks fantastic and very grand. Inside was quite different though. Yes there are lots of items to see and lots of important pieces, but they are just hung on the walls of dark and gloomy rooms and corridors without a whole lot of thought or effort.They isn't a lot of information in languages other than Russian so you don't always know what you're looking at. We didn't get the audio tour, which I was suggest that you do so you can get more information.

Hard to navigate around . I will say I'm not the biggest art fan in the world but when visiting at petersburg I knew I had to come here. I'd booked tickets online in advance to "save time" it did not. You have to check your bags when you get there so I did that keeping my eticket out. I was then told I needed to exchange my eticket for actual tickets. I went to a booth to do this and she asked for if which was in my checked bag... Eventually she agreed to the exchange but she couldn't give me the tickets I then had to go to another area to change my tickets! Total waste of time and effort.The museum itself... The building is absolutely incredible inside and out. There is do much to see in the building. There are maps in several languages which helps. But I recommend checking what you want to see before you get there so you don't miss anything and you can plan your route around the museum too... They have an app who chef helped me do this. It was really difficult to navigate your way round and we couldn't find stairs after about 20 mins of walking so had to ask people for directions.
