They were helpful but it is difficult to navigate around.It's something everyone recommends in st petersburg and it was a good rainy afternoon activity.

October visit. We had read all sorts of horror stories about complexities about accessing and getting tickets.We found it straightforward and as long as we picked up a free floor pland relatively easy to navigate!
Treatment for soul! . A dreamlike place, if old style is what you like, liked a lot! That place is so big and just a nice travel through the past, that what I felt!

World's Top Art Museum but no "in/out" privileges. I first visited the Hermitage 10 years ago on a whirlwind trip to St Petersburg, and had only 3 hours to dash through this magnificent collection. In October I spend 8 days in the city and devoted two full days to the Hermitage. The collection is sufficiently varied (from Greco-Roman sculpture to 16th through 19th century paintings) and the building itself so incredibly beautiful, that one doesn't tire through sheer determination to see as much as possible. Imagine an entire room filled with Rembrandts, two breathtaking da Vincis, marble staircases, two-story high halls with granite columns, restored palace rooms equaling those at Versailles, and a room generously trimmed with malachite. This is the Hermitage and more. My sole criticism is that those who purchase a one- or two-day pass should be allowed in and out privileges to distribute their viewing time as they wish. Buy your tickets online before leaving home to bypass the lineups!

Almost indescribable. Superlatives just kep flowing after visiting The Hermitage and the Winter Palace. My mouth was agape for most of the visit. The vast wealth and collections within these buildings are almost too much to try and take in in one visit. Great place, be aware many parts close as winter comes....for maintenance and restoration. You have to go there.

Wouldn't Have Missed It!. When we arrived at the Hermitage we were confronted by a queue that stretched round the block....and it's a very big block! Fortunately we were with a tour (AllaTours, excellent) so we jumped most of queue and were inside within 10-15 minutes. Apparently it's like this most days.Inside is breathtakingly beautiful and it's immediately evident why it's one of the world's top museums. There is much - too much - to see: the ceilings, the windows, the chandeliers, the archways etc.And that's only the building itself. Then you've got the exhibits themselves. Another long list! For me, the paintings were stunning and worth the visit alone. Two paintings by Leonardo da Vinci, Madonna and Child and Madonna with a Flower seemed to garner most attention and consequently the biggest crowds and the slowest queues. To view these paintings required you to shuffle past them which seemed to take forever. That was my only gripe. If I was to revisit, I'd bi-pass them.You can't do the Hermitage justice with a 3 hour visit: it's just a taster, but I wouldn't have missed it for anything.
Needed more time. Use a private guide if your time is limited. There is so much to see here, you need all day, plus. With a private guide you can see the highlights and get a great history lesson.
Must see. This is simply one of the most stunning buildings in the world with the most lavish interiors and best art collections in the world, it really is a must.

Amazing and beautiful. The Winter Palace was absolutely stunning. It was incredibly ornate, and our guided tour was very interesting and helpful. You simply cannot visit St. Petersburg without a visit to the Winter Palace. The history and the artifacts (art pieces, silverware, thrones, etc..) were both interesting and beautiful. You can certainly stay for a long time and visit the entire museum, but on a time crunch I would stick to the winter palace and spend some time at other amazing attractions in the city as well.

abandoned in museum. We went on a P AND O TOUR of the fantastic HERMITAGE .All went well until we were told by our so-called guide to proceed up in alift and she would meet us on the 3rd floor.When we got there she had forgotten us and gone on!you can imagine how we felt at 65 being left with no map,no visa,no Russian and no guides speaking English!Eventually more by luck than judgement we managed to find our way to the meeting point.To be fair to P AND O they did eventually sack the guide and give us minimal compensation for aruined trip.

Great paintings in a run down building. Brilliant collection of paintings, the main rooms look great but the majority looks a bit run down, people take flash photography of some amazing paintings and nobody seems bothered with that. At that rate the paintings wont last long. The facilities are shockingly poor. The whole place leaves you with the feeling that there is little respect for the works of arts hanging on the walls which is a shame and a concern.
Overwhelming but amazing museun. I had the chance to visit 3 times and it still wasn't enough. A truly magnificent museum and the building itself is a work of art.

Allow Plenty of Time, the number of exhibits are vast. The external facade of the building is amazing and the inside is vast. You could visit this museum for 2 hours or 2 weeks! We found the particular items of interest to us and worked our way around those exhibits. We spent about 3 hours there and only saw a fraction of the contents. The only negative is that for a building of this size the cafe facilities are very poor. Remember to check in your coat and bag as you cannot take them into the museum. The signs indicate that you cannot take cameras in but nearly everyone was taking pictures. A must do whilst in St Petersburg.

One of many places to see in St. Petersburg. There is so much history in the city and so many beautiful buildings. This is a typical example of them, having art, furnishings, and items from life in another era.

Too Amazing for Words. You can wonder through this Museum for days and not get tired of viewing the art. The variety and amount of art work is unfathomable. The crowds were dense, from tourist like us to locals, students, military and fellow Russians. Mind boggling the amount of art in one sprawling building. A must see - you will not be prepared for the works you will see!

Wonderful. What a huge place - we had a guided tour which was really worthwhile - we saw so much in half a day and had some great explanations and critiques of the art we were viewing - loved the top floor in particular. Busy place with tour groups and school groups but we stayed on and found that around 12-1pm it was really quiet when everyone else was having lunch and we were able to wander around more freely then

Great Museum - Reserve More Time to Enjoy It. It is a must see if you visit St. Petersburg for the first time. State Hermitage (Russian: Госуда́рственный Эрмита́ж) is located in the city center and one of the largest and oldest museum in the world. This prominent museum was founded in 1764 by Catherine II, also known as Catherine the Great. The museum has six buildings: the Winter Palace, Small Hermitage, Old Hermitage, New Hermitage, Hermitage Theatre and Reserve House. The first four buildings are partially open to the public as museums. Before we came to the Hermitage Museum, we only knew the Winter Palace was the official residence of the Romanov Tsars, but we did not know it is part of the museum. The museum has more than 3 millions of collections.We entered the museum from Winter Palace, and there was a long queue. All hand carried items must be checked with metal detector. No liquid is allowed inside the museum. They have a cloakroom to store what is not permitted. It is wise to bring as little as possible when visiting the museum. A special ticket entitles you to take photographs or videos for personal use. There are a total of three floors of rooms for exhibits. Due to the limited time, our guide skipped the ground floor exhibitions. Once we entered the ground floor we saw the beautiful Jordan Staircase that brought us to the first floor. We saw numerous collections, including ones on Western European Art (13th to 19th Centuries), Modern European Art and Oriental Art. We were surprised to see huge collections of Picasso, Matisse, Monet, Van Gogh, DaVinci, Rafael, Renoir – to name a few. I don’t understand why most of the attractions we visited in St. Petersburg did not have any information in other languages except Russian. There must be millions of tourist yearly visiting St. Petersburg. Luckily, we found English descriptions of the displays in State Hermitage Museum. The museum closed on Monday. If you have limited time in St. Petersburg, remember not to include Monday in your stay.

A lot to see but worth every minute. Once inside I changed camera discs and realized that the one I brought was a full one and not an empty one so I started deleting pictures off of the full one to be able to take pictures, it is not a place you want to be without a camera and it is good that they let you take pictures inside. My father went 30 years ago and ran out of film; he scheduled a trip the following year so he could film the rest of the Museum and Palace. It is that good. The paintings are worth the effort alone without all of the other things to see. Catherine was very astute when it came to acquiring paintings and she ended up with a great collection of Leonardo Di Vinci, Michelangelo, Van Gogh etc. I loved the 2 Madonna with child but my favorite was the Prodigal Son. The sculptures, the Egyptian artifacts, and the Palace itself is fabulous but the best of all was the “Gold Room” I thought it was going to be all gold leaf but it is the Russian Treasury. Some of the items are absolutely gorgeous and priceless, rings, broaches, artifacts of gold and diamonds and precious jewelry, it is something that not everyone gets to see who goes inside the museum, it is limited to only a few so be sure that your tour includes it because next to the paintings it is the highlight of the visit to the Hermitage. Again it is something you cannot miss if you are visiting St Petersburg.

Has to be seen to be believed. Possibly the best museum I have ever visited. Has to be taken in small doses because it is so immense. Incredible works of art and furniture, and the ceilings are a work of art in themselves.

A must see in St. Petersburg. It is very good and very big, therefore make sure you allocate sufficient time for the museum! I was surprised to see how crowded it was although it was a week day in October!

Simply superb. We first went to the museum on monday but learnt that it is closed on mondays.We were disappointed but came back the next day.I had bought the entry tickets online but the place is very crowded with no proper signs in English.We had to go from counter to counter to get a proper entry ticket in exchange for online ticket.Once inside the place is simply out of this world.The collection is enourmous from paintings to furniture apparel.Dont miss the peocock clock.The place is very big so it might be better to take a guide.It is the main attraction in St Petersberg.

Impressive. Remember to make a choice - either to spend the day or to select certain parts of the complex. Huge and overwhelming, and a seemingly endless series of architectural and craftmanship show-off manifestations. But definitely a must-see - almost a reason in itself to see St.Petersburg.

Should be visited in off-peak period. We had a conducted tour through the Hermitage museum in an afternoon. It is vast. Spread over five palaces.Our entrance opened to a grand magnificent staircase. Red carpeted. The steps had a very low rise about 3 inches . So a very low slope. It increased the grandeur of the staircase. So low steps that I stumbled as I was not habituated to such small rise steps. Our guide spoke though microphone and we used earpieces. Only thing I remember that I just ran after our guide though this humongous installation. It was crowded. All guided tours following the same set rooms to traverse. I do not think I could hear our guide clearly through our ear pieces. it was so noisy. I do not remember a single painting now. It is a vague memory. After our guided tour, my wife left with the group to go for the cruise boat. I stayed over an extra hour. I stayed on the main floor. In the Antiquities room. It was far from the madding crowds' ignoble strife. Could see the sculptures, jewelry in a leisurely way.I went to St. Petersburg mainly for the Hermitage. But I was left unsatisfied after the trip. I have to go back someday. Would take print-out of the lay outs of the rooms from the internet [they did not have printed maps on our day of visit]. Would go in fall ,or late fall . [Not in murderous winter]. Stay a few days just for the museum. Start from the opposite direction of the guided tours to avoid mayhem. If I take another cruise , I will take after-cruise stay over for a few days. Well, let me dream.

A must see but plan wisely.... Hermitage is the place to see first in St Petersburg. Even it you're not that into arts and stuff, the building and its rooms are enough to pull you in. Meanwhile, it is HUGE, and I mean it, so if you're by yourself, plan wisely and define your priorities. Hire a guide if you're wealthy, if not, at least an audio-guide will do; but once again, have a decent planning of your visit, or you'll just waste time and energy.

History and art-my dream come true. I have been interested and a pupil of Russian history since I was a child, so to finally experience this amazing museum after all my reads of reading about it was just wonderful. If only I hate a year to spend being able to see everything there is to see. Just not enough time during a three day visit. My only complaint was the same I have about every public building that I entered during this visit.. Turn down the heat!!!

Huge, great paintings. Huge collection of arts, some great painings, the buildings need some serious renovations.No chance to see it all in one day. But an average tourist will have enough after 2.5 hours anyway.Long queue to buy tickets can be easily avoided if you buy them in the machine (rather than in the ticket office). Nobody will tell you even if the queue is long ...

Stunning Collection. The Hermitage, like most of the 19th century attractions in St. Petersburg, was destroyed during WWII, and the Soviets rebuilt it and the others (obviously, at great expense) to replicate exactly their previous appearances, gold leaf, amber and all. The art collection is absolutely superb. We toured with a guide, so we had to follow her and be content with what she pointed out to us. But she made a point of directing our attention to the most significant items in the museum. So we feel that we saw enough to understand the scope of the collection, without leaving the museum completely brain-dead. Perhaps if we have occasion to visit St. P again, we will do the Hermitage on our own and really take our time. But we were amazed and impressed by what we did see. This is indeed a "don't miss".

Superbly presented. This museum / gallery has a fantastic range of exhibits - all beautifully presented. We were fortunate to go on a guided English tour (we were the inly English on this) it lasted 2 hours and was very cheap - it was an excellent way of seeing the best of a vast collection

Great Museum. Very highly recommended. This museum is one of the best art and culture museum i have ever seen. The collection is huge and absolutely breathtaking. It is one of the finest art collections in the world. You must visit this when you are in St Petersburg. Only downside is that the entry fee is higher for a foreign visitor than a Russian citizen. Have walk around the beautiful river Neva and get into explore this wonderful museum. Don't forget your camera as you will have a lot of photos to take for sure)

Allow 4 or 5 hours. First buy your ticket voucher in advance on line which we did from this side of the Atlantic. On arrival at the museum you go to the front of the ticket line and exchange your voucher for the entrance ticket. We were selective in wanting to see the Egyptian exhibit, the impressionist paintings particularily Monet, and the various ball rooms and private quarters last inhabited by Nicholas II and Alexandra. Don't miss the peacock clock.In no way did we see everything but we covered the basics and our specific interests in 5 hours.

not enough time and way too crowded. large tour groups made enjoying the Hermitage difficult. It would have been much better if they controlled how many people entered.There is so much to see and we just didn't have enough time to devote to the museum. You really need a full month! Know what you want to see prior to going so that you can head there directly.
outstanding museum. It has a fantastic collection of art, furniture, sculpture. I spend there 3 full days and am ready for more if I return to St. Petersburg

I will recommend it to everyone. We bought the ticket on-line (a few dollars more) in order to skip the long line-up.It is a must see in St Petersburg. Not just the exhibit items are excellent, the celling and floor of the palace are wonderful too.

A Glittering Treasure Box on the Neva. An almost rival to the Louvre (on the Seine), and its trove of Modern French Impressionist and Post-Impressionist Art (Matisse, Van Gogh...) that should not be missed!Also take time to see Rembrandt's wonderful portraits and paintings of myths and lore. Go early to try to avoid the madding crowds.

Awesome Museum cum Palace. This is Louvre of the East. We spent a whole day admiring the lovely sculptures, paintings, ceilings, furniture, and other art objects. Photography inside is permissible if you buy tickets accordingly. The building itself is very impressive and takes your breath away as soon as you reach the place. The square is large and one can spend some time outside as well and take some memorable snaps. Suggest buy your tickets online to avoid long ques and waste of time. Free storage is available if you are carrying big bags.

So Much Beauty, So Little Time. The Hermitage Museum is worth a day to go through, but it's easy to suffer sensory overload. I agree that it takes planning to make best use of your time. A guide is a must and you should make a list of the artists work that you most want to see first, so you don't waste time wondering around only to find you are too tired to get to the highlights.
Excellent. If you visit St Petersberg, this is a must. Although you MUST get a guided tour as it is massive. We spent about 2 hours and saw some amazing stuff.

Just Incredible!. This museum is just overwhelming, you could spend days, weeks, months there and never see it all. The buildings themselves are works of art , every detail extraordinary. We had a guide, who showed us some of the highlights. I personally would not have known where to begin, or have wanted to be on my own as it became very crowded as the day wore on. The guide brought us quickly to some of the most important pieces. Do have a plan if you go! But do go! The art, the architecture incredible!

Wonderful. The paintings are great with a room for armour and lovely tables and chairs a good display of precious stone and wonderfully kept. The tour started before the hermitage was opened to the general public

You'll need a full day!. A breathtaking museum set in the centre of St Petersburg. The architecture is superb and the rooms ornate with stunning ceilings and wall coverings. The art work is very impressive - Picasso, Degas, Monet etc etc It is worth buying your tickets on line in advance as the queues are massive and you could spend well over an hour waiting to get in.For a very small fee you are allowed to take photos - which is unusual in art galleries.

Must see if you are in St. Petersburg. A beautiful palace with beautiful contents. It shows you a lot about arts of Russia and other countries. However, it does not equal other palaces that I have visited in Europe like Louver or Buckingham.

As good as the Louvre!. Wow! Katherine's collection was unbelievable. We were fortunate to get in 2 hours before the museum opened with our ship's guided tour. Our young tour guide had been an art major in college, and was guided us through the Hermitage with great skill. The architecture, lighting and museum pieces were amazing. If you can spend 2 days here, I recommend it.

A must to visit. Hermitage is one of the places you have to put in your "to visit list" in St Petersburg. We could only save half a day for this museum so we've made a list which we wanted to see - like , paints Stolen Kiss, Lady in Blue, Madonna and Child of Leonardo da Vinci, sculptures The Three Graces, Jupiteri, etc.)- We have visited the museum for 5 hours and saw more than we've listed. Entrence is 400 ruples for adults and you can have an audio guide for 200 ruples. You have to leave your coats in the checkroom. you will have a plan of the palace coloured in different colours showing the palace interiors , exhibitions of different civilazitions - central ASia, ancient greek, French, Italy, German, etc. - The building is a palace , it has not been built as a museum. So it is not like other museums where you can enter in one end, follow a line and exit from the other end. In Hermitage follow the plan you've provided where you can see the coloured parts and number of the chambers. If you are tired take a boat trip just in front of Hermitage.

Wonderful building but unpleasant experience. The Hermitage had been on my bucket list for sometime before I got the opportunity to go. The building is extraordinary and the collection is huge. However, if I am honest, the experience was unpleasant. There were just so many people, it was difficult to see some exhibits or enjoy the splendour of the architecture and decor. The day we were there (with a guide), it was hot, stuffy and frankly stressful. Not sure how one can avoid this if you find yourself in Russia in the high season but I am sure the officials could brainstorm some solution because I don't think I was alone in finding the experience unpleasant. Oh well, I shall just have to return in the winter off season!

Totally awe Inspiring. This must rank as one of the greatest museums in the world. We only spent one day there, and it was clear that we had not scraped the surface. This vast treasury of art and artifacts would take far more than just a fleeting visit to appreciate, in fact our guide assured us that if we went every day for seven years, we would not see all of it. As it was, the collection that we did see was a veritable statement of the colossal wealth accumulated by the Russian aristocracy, not just the exhibits,but the incredibly ornate rooms and corridors, which seem to go on forever. What was particularly astonishing was that everything had survived wars and many other traumas, but still appeared to be in pristine condition. I was most impressed with the knowledge and friendliness of the staff, who invariably were keen to explain any queries that I had,Our tour guide could not have been more helpful, as we had no difficulty in entering the Hermitage, possibly as it had just opened. I would guess that if you did not have a guide, book beforehand and go early. All in all, a wonderful experience which hopefully I will repeat.

St Petersburg and Moscow Sights from Gate 1 Tours. Just returned from our second Gate 1 Tour this year. We traveled from St Petersburg to Moscow aboard a comfy river cruise ship. Visited the Hermitage, Catherine's Palace, Church of the Spilled Blood, St Isaac's Cathedral, and took advantage of all the excursions offered. Stops along the way were interesting and beautiful. Moscow was great - the Kremlin, Cathedrals, Gum, St Basil's Cathedral.....and much much more. This is a perfect time of year to travel with the beautiful fall colors. As a bonus, the winter Olympics will be held in Russia so there is a presence there already. Great tour at a reasonable price. We docked beside Viking cruise ships and we followed the same route. We've signed up for our next tour leaving the end of this month. Gate 1 offers some great tours. Recommend you consider them.
A must !!. Everything about the Hermitage was superb. A place everyone should visit in this life. Highly recommended.
Must see. Don't bother with the two day pass. Buy online before and skip the lines. Allow enough time for one day. Awesome exhibits. Bring lunch.

Overwhelming. An amazing gallery and despite the crowds queuing to enter once inside it is so vast that it never feels crowded. There is too much to see in one or two visits. Take your lunch as there is only one very small coffee shop which gets very busy at lunch time

Hermitage. I especially liked the rooms with the period furniture. Very ornate; beautiful floors, ceilings, and furnishings. Audioguide available in English, but I thought it was limited in what it covered (mostly paintings). Best to go in the morning, before it gets crowded. Also best to purchase tickets on-line so you don't have to wait in line.

From Russia with love. The Hermitage was central and easy to walk to from the Ambassador Hotel. It's a huge expanse, covering a number of buildings, with views of the square and the Neva river. We had pre-booked our tickets online, so avoided the queues. Despite visiting on Saturday/Sunday, we felt we had the place almost to ourselves. Tour groups went through very quickly, so we were pleased to do it ourselves. Guides who could speak a little English, were very knowledgeable and helpful. We had a 2 day ticket, which was needed, despite us only being there 4 days!The art and other artifacts were amazing, breath taking and quite spectacular. We took both pictures and brought cards, from the areas which prohibited taking pictures. Lovely café, clean loos, expensive gift shops!

Unmissable collection , incredible building. Firstly pre- book your ticket online - we did not and had a wait of around an hour although we arrived early. Definitely consider the extra options of the Gold or Amber Rooms. We saw the Gold which was an excellent collection of gold jewellery through the ages.The museum is immense and the building alone worth the visit- especially the mirrored hall and the staircase. If you have limited time, a guide would be helpful. However if you have tackled major museums before and chose your exhibits, the Hermitage is easily manageable on your own. Just don't think you can see it all! There is an excellent app you can download which provides live information about most of the exhibits - we did this onsite at the cafe with wifi.

Too much to see in one visit, go prepared and buy tickets online to save time.. We knew our river cruise was providing a tour of the Hermitage and found that almost all tour groups follow a set itinerary that covers the old masters, the throne room and the Palace rooms. We particularly wanted to see the French Impressionist collection which is huge, so we went a day early, purchased our tickets online (to save a lot of time at the ticket window) and were able to spend as much time as we liked enjoying the paintings we most wanted to see. If you are going with a group you will pack a whole lot into about 3 hours. Be prepared to walk up many flights of steps and use the restroom before the tour starts because the restrooms are on the lower lobby level. No matter what you see you will be amazed at the size of the collections and the casualness with which they are displayed. Windows were open to the outside air (thank goodness) when we were there or it would have been very stuffy inside. If you are a museum gift shop aficionado be aware that there are many spread throughout the museum and the ones by the lobby area may not have just the thing you saw upstairs. If you have the flexibility to buy when you see it, do so or you may have to find your way back. There are good maps that are available when you first come in, we were able to use the map to find what we most wanted to see. I noticed though that the next day when we were with a guide we bypassed those maps - if you want to explore after your tour you will need one!Enjoy this amazing museum.

Spectacular experience. We toured this museum with a local guide and were stunned by the beautiful architecture and the magnificent collection of art. Make sure you're rested and have good walking shoes, this is a commitment and a test of stamina. It really gives you a sense of the opulence of the era. The magnificent staircase is an entry point to room after room of masterpieces including the works of the great artists, gorgeous parquet floors and striking columns, urns and tables in malachite and lapis. It is well worth the time to visit.

Beautiful building but very crowded. I had wanted to visit the Hermitage for many many years and was a little disappointed when I actually got there. I much preferred the Lourve. Some parts of the building internally were beautiful but those areas were not as extensive as I imagined. I guess I have seen a lot of artwork so am hard to impress but the crowds here made it virtually impossible to see things up close. Perhaps there just wasn't a lot of my favouite art on display at the time of my visit. I would encourage people to go to the Hermitage and form their own opinion.

Impressive. We only stayed there for a couple of hours. The Hermitage is sooo big, sooo impressive, with so many important and valued things to be seen...I would recommend to do the homework before, I mean to see what interest you the most. Our guide (this is a really good idea! she knew how to work the crowds !) took us where we wanted : first, the impressionists! Excellent collection! Then she knew what it Is really important and unique and she took us there in a short time. Anyway, you need to go there many times, better in winter! when there are not so many people. It is amazing!

Awesome Art and Architecture. The Hermitage is clearly one of the world's great museums. Room after room of masters and lesser know artists almost overwhelm the visitor. Even if the walls were empty, the builiding is worth the visit. Walking up the entry stairway helps you understand what it was like to visit Catherine the Great. I strongly recommend either significant pre-planning or a professional guide to make the visit as efficient as possible.

Even better than I expected. There is not much about the Hermitage which hasn't already been said. So all I will say is don't just go to see the artworks, stunning though they are. Make sure you remember to look up..at the amazing ceilings, and down...at the gorgeous parquetry floors. The whole complex is one of the world's great cultural institutions and should be on the must see list of all art lovers

Amazing art, stunning museum. The Hermitage was one of the highlights of my trip to St. Petersburg. Not only was its art collection amazing-- I have never seen so many of the great masters all in one place-- the building itself is magnificent.

Amazing Palace. Visited the Hermitage Museum a few weeks ago with 72 in my group. We were all blown away by the sheer majesty and opulence of the place. The beauty and artwork is exquisite and is just about everywhere from the floors to the ceilings. There is so much to see in every room. We used the TJ Travel Tour company and their guides were extremely knowledgeable. This made the visit so much more meaningful and memorable to us. We also went to the ballet at the Hermitage Theatre and just the opportunity to enter that historical theatre was a treat, then add the splendid performance to that, made for a perfect end to a perfect day in St. Petersburg.

Not to be missed. Our time in The Hermitage was everything I had dreamed it would be. We were there during the G20 meeting and SPB Tours had adjusted the entire two day schedule to be sure we would see everything. They rearranged the order and in some cases the day. Our time in the Hermitage was a bit over two hours. Granted, you could be there for weeks, but we saw so many things and Maria S, our guide was amazing and informative.
Russian Hermitage. An overwhelming collection of treasures. Beautiful pieces displayed well. A must see in St. Petersburg. One could easily spend at least a day enjoying the many, many items on view.

Not to be missed!. The Hermitage is one of those sites that you just can't miss if you are in St. Petersburg. It is so enormous, and the art collection so extensive that it would take years just to take a quick look at everything. We were happy we had a tour guide (small group of seven of us) who used the audio receivers to give us the commentary (it is mandatory for all guided groups of six or more.) We just spent the better part of an afternoon there, and were happy to have the guide take us through, and point out the highlights. Remember, it is mainly an art gallery, albeit one in a very opulent setting.

Hermitage. Beautiful rooms, paintings, everything. Our tour group (AHI) was led by a guide very knowledgeable. We were there about a half a day and some people chose to stay on their own for the rest of the day. It's good to go with a guide then have free time to return to places. Amazing history and collection.
Too wonderful!. Almost too much to take in at one visit. Visiting was enhanced by Guide-Guru. By pass lines with no waiting.

What can I say that hasn't already been said?. The Hermitage is a reason, by itself, to go to St. Petersburg. If you are going to St. Petersburg for any other reason make time for the Heritage if you have any interest at all in art. The extent and scope of the collection is staggering. Buy your ticket ahead of time to shorten your time in line. Beware of pickpockets in the coat check area (one of our party lost his wallet there). Consider engaging a guide unless you have allocated vast amounts of time to your visit and are willing to just wander around to see what comes into your vision. A knowledgable guide can maximize your return on time. We spend a day and half there and only scratched the surface. Don't forget the third floor. While not collected by the Czars these early 20th century pieces are a delight to the eye and heart. Think about how you will deal with food. The cafeteria is only fair and the lines long. Try to avoid the galleries packed with tour groups.

Hermitage is not to be missed. As part of an Alla Tour we visited the Hermitage Museum. It was stunning and breath taking. The amount of art, tapestry, furniture was breathtaking. The amount of artwork contained in the Hermitage far exceeds that located in Rome, Paris and London. On top of which it is all accessible to be viewed. Our Alla tour guide was top rate and her navigation of the museum made it a lot easier to see and enjoy without being bumped into by other tour groups. The Hermitage has to be high on your must see places in St Petersburg.

Outstanding. If you see nothing else in Russia, you must go to the Hermitage. A guide will help you navigate the largest art collection in the world, or you can wonder around on your own. There are a dizzying number of rooms, and the queues are formidable. Any inconvenience is worth a look at the buildings and collections; truly an international treasure!

Mobbed and exhausting. I visited the Hermitage twice during my six day stay in Petersburg. I had a guide the first time who knew little about art and sped me through the museum. The second time I had a very knowledgeable guide who made sense of so much. This museum is redolent with the history of the czars and Petersburg. Allow plenty of time and do you homework. The food is sparse so bring snacks with you. The gift shops are disappointing but it is THE museum so you must visit.

Great museum. The hermitage is an wonderful art museum. We went with a tour guide which was helpful in making a quick run through and catching the highlights. We would have loved to have had the entire day to go through at our leisure. This is a must see in St. Petersburg if you love art.
Russia's Versailles. We were fortunate to have a private tour after hours. Nevertheless, the Hermitage is a mini Versailles. There is fantastic art, and the Peacock Clock is a must.
Must see. So many great collections etc the highlights are already great. The structure itself is beautiful as well.

Stunning. It is not just the building that is incredible, the square in front, the golden archway opposite, the river the other side, how many more delights can there be, well go inside!! The art available to see is breathtaking. I have never seen such a collection of Picasso, Manet, Monet, Da Vinci etc. It is just inspiring.
Excellent exhibition. Extremely happy with our visit. We had an excellent guide who was able to choose a good number of the exhibits with excellent explanations.

Super. The Hermitage is a must see if in St. Petersburg. It is hard to imagine that this was once a residence. The art is amazing and the collections are fantastic. I would recommend hiring a guide to help you make your way through such an awesome collection of art. The Peacock Clock is gorgeous and I'd recommend going on the day and time when it is in operation. If you're pressed for time, you should identify several of the areas you want to see and make a beeline for them. Rembrandt's, Monet's, Renoir's, you name it, they're all here. Well worth the visit. And when you're done, take the boat ride up the river to Peterhof. It's another place well worth seeing.

Beautiful palace and great museum collection. A massive collection of art which can take you the entire day if you go through piece by piece. Plan your visit ahead in terms of what you want to see or get a guide who can show you the best items in the collection.

The Hermitage is a museum like no other. The hermitage is packed with the world's finest art and archaeological items under one roof. You will be gob-smack with the displays. I would like to go back again, again and again.
A must visit.. Simply amazing. Great works of art and stunning decor. Good opportunity to see art and obtain information

A museum so fantastic like the Louvre. I visited Hermitage Museu, in St. Petersburg, Russia in 2012. It is a visit for one day, because the collection of art and historical objects is immense. I can compare this museum with Louvre, in Paris, but it shows local historic and art objects, besides the European art. But, In Hermitage, there are French artworks that I could not see in anyoneEuropean or American museum, like some Matisse's. The building is marvellous too, situated in a big plaza connected with the Winter Palace. The ceilings of the saloons of exhibition are decorated with beautiful and delicate motifs. You can buy the tickets by Internet so easily.

Thank you Peter The Great. The Winter Palace is a beautiful home for the wonderful treasures within. As a visitor I was unable to truly experience the wonders, you need a life time to see and appreciate it all. In the 2 hours I spent there I was truly blown away.

Alla Tours. Booked with Alla tours following a recommendation from an acquaintance and so glad we did! Booking with Alla tours allowed us to enter the museum without unnecessary queueing as well as providing excellent and relevant background information.My only caveat, and one that cannot be reconciled, is the sheer size of the museum. It is simply not possible to look at the myriad of exhibitions in a few hours and my advice would be to thoroughly research what you want to see before booking with a tour company. Basically it's a catch 22 situation booking in advance avoids queueing and gives you access to expert knowledge however you will be restricted to the time available.

Best Museum in the World!. This collection of buildings would be fantastic if there were no art at all in them - the art collection in my opinion exceeds the Louve and Orsay combined. By coming in early Oct. we missed the crowds which made it even nicer - needed at least ten hours over 2 days and still did not see it all. iPad app made it easier but prepare before you go to make most use of the time. Dont miss the "trophy art" which adds to the already impressive collection of Impressionists..compare Pissaro's "Still Life with coffee pot" which was owned by Matisse with latters' painting of a coffee pot in the upstairs Hermitage collection. The Matisses' and early Picassos' are stunning. Non flash photos allowed.

Magnificant!. The hermitage is magnificant and breathes power, wealth and even If there is a lot of people visiting the museum at the same time you wont get the crowded feeling since its so big there. When you walk around in some of the rooms its easy to get lost in fantasy imagine what it must have felt like living there during the Tsar dynasty. Anna Pavlovas beautiful dress on display and you could almost see her dancing through the big ballrooms.The entrance fee system does dull the experience a little since you have to pay for the main exhibition 400 RUB and then another 200RUB if you wanna take pics. then there is extra fees for treasury and other special rooms so a family can end up with a pricey day at the museum..although going to St. Petes without visting this place would be as eating fries without ketchup! It´s simply a MUST DO!Enjoy!

Loved the experience!. How lucky we were to roam the halls of such a beautiful museum. We purchased tickets online.I expected very high priced tickets, they are not. If confused where to go read signage. The map led us on our way. There was much to see to keep both my husband's interests peaked.I recommend, take your time, we stayed close to closing as the crowds dwindled.
A must see in St. Petersburg!. This is one of the great art museums of the world. Couple that with a spectacular palace and what's not to love? Plan to spend at least half a day there,

One of the Best. I have been travelling a while but this is one of the best things I have seen. If you are an art lover, this is worth seeing. I went with guide who took me to the best works but if I had my time again I would book twice - once with a guide and then on line a second time and go all day and look myself. The art is incredible.

It's the Hermitage.. Check it out at their website, or Wikipedia, or the books written about the building and its collections. Or see Alexander Sokurov's movie "Russian Ark." My opinions would be superfluous, like saying "The Louvre was a really terrific experience," or "The Met was awesome."

Not What It's Cracked Up to Be. This is a fantastic facility with beautiful rooms, floors, hallways and grounds. But the art inside, with a handful of notable exceptions, is really second rate, compared to the Louvre or the Uffizi or the Met. During peak hours of the peak season, when we were there, it was also tremendously crowded, making it hard to get good views easily. On the other hand, the volume of material the museum displays is impressive and you get a good sense of how lavish life was for the ruling class of Russia. So it's worth the visit, but with reasonable expectations.

Early Access to Hermitage worth the price. Went with Viking River Tour to Hermitage and got early entrance to museum and special tour of the museum's separate storage facility. Early entrance really worth it as it was uncrowded and quiet. Even in late Sept. the crowds, once it opened to the public were dense and loud. Museum is vast and to see it all would take weeks, but targeted visit is worth it!

Beautiful building. Spent six hours here and still didn't see everything. I don't think it's possible to take it all in in one visit but that's all we had time for, so much else to see. Paid for tour of Gold Room which was interesting but guide spoke very quickly, and rushed us through even faster. I would have liked to see more of the building as it was as the Winter Palace, but it's a museum now though still very much worth a visit. Would recommend to anyone visiting St Petersberg.
awe inspiring. You could have spent a whole week in the Hermitage the palace itself is amazing and then add in the works of art and the artefacts and it made a truly memorable visit

The Hermitage. You’ll need a considerable time to see around The Hermitage… and even then, there’s no way you’ll see it all. Someone once calculated that, if you spent a minute inspecting each and every artefact … to see everything would take eleven years.The whole collection is housed in a complex of ornate palaces, joined by a complex of raised corridors, so there’s no need to go outside to pass between the buildings … and, that, considering the coldness of the weather, seemed an excellent idea! If you want to take pictures, you mustn’t use flash, but that’s no imposition. All the rooms are airy and well lit. You will have to buy a photographic permit, though.There’s much to see here; our guide seemed to concentrate mainly on paintings. We would like to have seen more; but I don’t think we were allowed to wander round on our own … since we were part of an organised tour group, the visa requirement had been waived, so I think ‘free time’ is forbidden.
Absolutely Spectacular. The Hermitage is over the top in terms of the number of excellent items of artwork and the opulence of the setting.

Art is Amazing. The art in the Hermitage Museum is probably next to none. One could spend days in the Museum .... however, for me it tends to run together after a few hours. In late September the crowds were tolerable.... I have heard that in the summer months with the ships coming into port that the crowds are impossible. So, enjoy and don't get to frustrated with the crowds. Very worthwhile spending 2-3 hours even if you are not an art major!

wonderful. this place is so big they are right when they say it takes 3 years to go around it . best advice is to have a guide to help you find your way around or you could get lost and to show you the best of the best

if you miss this. you deserve to be flogged, teared and feathered. Got it? :-) One of the BIG museums in the world alongside the Prado, Louvre, Pinakothek, the Met, and British Museum. A must see for both the collection and the building itself.

one of the best. HermitageMuseum is amazing as a building and as a museum by itself. full of woeks of great artists all over the world. it is impossible to see even third of it during my shot visit to St Ptersburg. one needs to order the tickets in advance also to the gold work exhibition in order to have the best in the shortest of times.

Must see. If you visit St Petersburg, you have to visit the Hermitage and you will be amazed!!! P.S. don't miss the painting (Love Scene by Julio Romano). You will need to spend at least 3 hours for a very brief review. additionally, you can buy some souvenirs outside the hermitage at a good price.

Highly popular museum for good reason. Despite the long queues and having to dodge to tourist parties in the museum, this is a museum of so much history and grandeur. A lavish golden entrance and amazing paintings can keep you walking around for hours. The shop is just as expensive as the interior, but it comes as no surprise. It's popularity is for a sound reason.

Better than Louvre. I have been to many museums in Europe and I very much enjoyed the Hermitage. The outside of the palace itself is absolutely gorgeous painted in the green of Catherine's eyes. Overall a great experience. Would highly recommend getting a guide for a private tour of the museum. It is too big to go through the entire museum, but a guide can make sure you visit all the "must see" parts.

Excellent - world museum. The building it self are Worth the visit. When you get the art items and other interesting items - it is just overwhelming. Words can not describe this Jewel of a museum - you just have to go there. People who think this is terrible, poor or average - has not been at the State Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace - simple as that.If you have a chance to buy Your tickets online (hermitage shop) before going, you save a lot of time in lines (hours).Make a plan of what you want to see - You will not Reach all - and you can easily get lost.

Belle Hermitage. This museum has rare artistic paintings and esculptures very beautiful. The gift shop has canvas ofsome famous tableaus, in addition to other items at accessible prices. Two days are not enough to visit all of this museum..

An art lovers paradise. This outstanding museum is situated on the River Neva and was the former palace of Catherine the Great. There are millions of exhibits to be viewed and in the few hours we toured this museum we managed to see quite a few, however it is impossible to do it justice in a few hours. Never mind it certainly will not be a hardship to return again and again. Every famous artist is exhibited, such as Degas, Van Gogh, Matisse, Monet etc etc, the list goes on and on. There are rooms full of antiquities and beautiful furnishings. A visit is a must.

Quick visit but one can only absorb so much. Our visit was a guided tour that lasted a couple of hours. Saw and appreciated a lot, I am not a museum enthusiast and as our visit to St Petersburg was a 2 day cruise ship stop. This was one of the many sights our tour package included and I am glad it did.

Dont know what is best: the state rooms or the art inside !!!. Amaizing amount of art not only in the state rooms but also the art collection inside !! As per any museum you have to dedicate hours and perhaps days to enjoy in detail all of the Hermitage... In your next visit allow good time, include in your budget some food in the cafeteria and then go back to the rooms... Marvelous...

So crowded, hard to enjoy. I visited on a Monday when it is normally closed. It was open only for tour groups from the cruise ships in port. Yet it was still so crowded that I could not see many of the paintings or enjoy the visit. The museum guards kept hurrying our tour guide along. Perhaps a system to limit the number of visitors at one time is required. Very strict rules about no coats or backpacks or large purses. Overall the objets d'arte, statues, etc seemed more interesting the painting collections.

Part of 2 day organised tour of St.P. We were allowed in before the main crowd due to the agency we booked with (Alla). This was fine until the main public caught up. It is very busy. If you are an art/museum person then you should arrange your own and give as much time as you need. We had just short of 3 hours and even that meant being on the move all the time. Still: it's an amazing experience.

So much wonderful art. The Hermitage Museum in St Petersburg is a simply fantastic place to see *so much* art. The collection is huge, and I believe that the displayed items form only a fraction of the total collection. You could spend days in the complex. Apart from the multitude of famous paintings etc. the actual rooms within the Hermitage and Palace themselves are also quite stunning. I really enjoyed the visit, and would suggest that due to the size you might wish to make a couple of trips. I think you can get free entry on the first Thursday of every month but of course those days will be busier.

Home of the Romanovs. In terms of area, the Hermitage is the biggest in the world. But in terms of collection, I do not think it's the largest.  However, what made it different was that it was also the Winter Palace of the Romanovs so here, our guide highlighted the portraits of the Romanovs, notably Peter the Great, his wife, the Cinderella, Catherine I who was of peasant stock, their  beautiful daughter Elizabeth who loved the rococo style, plenty of mirrors and gold gildings by Rastrelli, apparently to emphasize her beauty, her sister Anna, the Beast, being big and ugly, of course Catherine the Great, who married and then strangled her husband, Peter III, grandson of Peter I.  There was Maria, wife of Paul, the sad one who suffered from tuberculosis and the knowledge that her husband had a second family.  The staircase of the Winter Palace which was built by Elizabeth, the Beauty, was truly magnificent. Elizabeth, according to our guide, was blonde and blue-eyed, slim and tall with long limbs, who loved masquerades where she dressed in men's clothing to show off her long legs, and balls where she never used the same dress twice and nor did her guests as she forbade them.  Her balls and dinners lasted 4-6 hours so that at the end of her days  she became fat and clumsy.The Winter Palace and Hermitage was located along the river Neva and it did have a great view of the river.On the way down, Natalia showed  us one of the famous cats of the Hermitage.

A step back in time. For a taste of opulence and extravagance in previous times, head down to the Hermitage. An exquisite building and exhibition space. Look for the golden peacock and get lost in the maze of corridors that draw you back in time.

The Palace Itself is the Real Star. Be sure to allow plenty of time for the Hermitage, as most guides will try to rush you through seeing highlights of western European art. Best time to go is mid-afternoon, when the mad rush of large groups is winding down. After 3 you will have the place to yourself for another 3 hrs. I would go first to the Winter Palace rooms, then the Siberian Artifacts and the Russian Culture sections, as these cannot be seen in any western European Museum. After that, if you still have the energy, you can roam the Dutch, English, and French galleries, but you will find things similar to what you would see in those countries.

Tourist friendly. The Hermitage was excellent except when we came down to the ancient egypt place but there were no signs in english, only Cyrillic fonts which for us was no way of understanding what was written there. Other from that fantastic place to see.

Outstanding and a bit overwhelming museum. The Hermitage deserves all of the superlatives which have been written about it, but its sheer size and the massive number of objects in the collections can be a bit overwhelming. You could spend the rest of your days in there. Also they seem to have frequent closures of collections for maintenance, so check in advance if you have something particular you want to see. To avoid the long day ticket queues, buy a voucher on-line beforehand, print it and take it along with your passport.

Hermitage. The museum/palace was an awesome experience.I hadn't really planned on seeing the Hermitage; but since I was visiting St. Petersburg, I thought I had better see it in case people back home asked me if I had. I had a map and a guidebook with me, and it took me a half hour to figure out the layout. I went through the palace part of the museum as that is what I really wanted to see. The rooms were numbered according to the book, so I was able to get around fairly easily. It was an interesting and awesome experience. The Malichite Room was especially impressive as well as Czar Nicholas' study.

Must Experience. As with other places we visited in St. Petersburg, it is hard to imagine the level of opulence and grandeur in this palatial museum. For me, there were no negatives. I would definitely go again.

It's the building. It has terrific art, but it's the building itself that I'll remember. OK, I was in the city on a cruise, and we only had a couple of hours or so to spend at the Hermitage. The place was absolutely jammed with visitors, and we were lead from this masterpiece to that one. I love art, but I have been to most of the world's great art musems so it's not like I have to come here to see great art, but the building itself, both inside and out, is what I left impressed with. If I had had much more time for a leisurely visit, without some of the crowds (presumably after cruise season), perhaps the art would also have made a lasting impression.
The Best!. Magnificent collections, well presented - what more can we say. The only limitation of the Hermitage is how much time you are willing to spend there.

probably one of the worlds best museums. I bought tickets through the St Petersburg booking site, the two days is well worth the cost. It was fortunate that I went in early October and arrived early and got straight in they took the printed booking receipt and gave me two day tickets, the second day must be taken within 5 days of the first.Ask for a guide map or pick one up before entering, believe me it is vast. You have to leave your coats in the cloakroom, they are safe there. I tried to plan my days but still left out some of the rooms, To get an idea of how cheap the two day ticket was I paid more for two Movenpick ice creams near the cafe than the entrance fee.

Fascinating!. Many interesting things to see! Our tour guide was terrific with many detailed explanations of the exhibits. This site was particularly one that would be extremely enjoyable for those visitors interested in history and art. It was explained to us that it would take many years to visit every exhibit in the museum
Wow. Truly one of the top art museums in the world. No exaggeration. As good as the louvre except that the palace itself is as breathtaking as the art.

Simply the Best. A magnificent building, so much to see and admire. A highlight was the ballet in the Hermitage Theatre. Tickets were organised by Tickitnow (over the internet) and they were delivered to our hotel the day before the ballet. Excellent service!

Get a visa, book online and go against the flow. We were on a cruise so could have visited with cruise party but fortunately had got visas in advance so could tour St Petersburg independently (not totally for the faint hearted). Also bought Hermitage entrance tickets online in UK which meant a giant queue-avoiding leap on arrival. But NO SIGNS saying you can go to the front if you already have tickets (picked up at special desk with just 5 people waiting), so I just asked. Inside, because we weren't in a group and had a guidebook, we just went where we wanted and if we saw 100 people following a numbered lollipop we just went the opposite way. Bliss. Not bad cafe on ground floor (queue!). Few loos (big queue), and you have to leave bags at cloakroom: not bad queue to drop off but allow 20 minutes to collect (missed our taxi). And Wish we'd bought a two entry ticket.

Be sure to get a guide!. It is well worth the time and energy to see as much or more of this fantastic place...but have a guide in place prior to your arrival!We saw so much, heard more history and had time to just soak in the art. So glad we put this on our bucketlist!

One of the world's great museums, a must see. We went to St. Petersburg primarily to see this great museum. Like the Louvre, this museum is vast and packed with wonderful artwork. The museum gets a rating of four for a couple of reasons, one being that the museum has a confusing layout and is difficult to self-tour, which I like to do so I can spend as much time as I like looking at my favorite pieces. Second, even though we went at the very end of September, the museum was still packed with huge tours, which made going around the museum difficult and tiring. However, still a must see museum, one of the greats!Please also note that this museum, like most of the places in Russia, is not wheelchair or disabled friendly and that there is a great deal of stairs and walking.
A must visit. So much to see ! Lots of interesting items & loads of paintings by well known artists. An Art lovers dream!

A must see -- for the bucket list. We went at the beginning of December, and there were no queues, which is far better than summer when the queues (we are told) can be very long. This must be one the great galleries of the world with some much fine art ( which even then is only a small percentage of what they have stored). Not just one or two pieces by Picasso, Dutch masters, Gaugin and similar caliber, but entire rooms full of their works. There is also a fine collection of ancient artefacts. We spent an entire day here and still did not see it all! (Sadly, the food is not up to much!)

Pomp and Splendour. The outside facade is impressive enough wih its beautiful green and cream combination but when you step inside you are taken into a dream world. Entrance steps are awsome and as one climbs the stairs every corner is steeped with history, beaytu and magnificant structures. Murials and paintiang all across the wall, ceiling and pillers are one of the most beautiful items one is ever likely to see. The collection of the State Hermitage includes more than three million works of art and artefacts of the world culture' It occupies 120 rooms in the four museum buildings, and reflects all the stages in the development of art from the Middle Ages to the present day. The collection includes numerous works by outstanding masters from Italy, Spain, Holland, Flanders, France, England, Germany, and other Western European countries.We were definitely overwhelmed with the building and its contents in most magnificent surroundings. One of the best preserved building and the treaures.

Tour given by Alla tours. We were as amazed by the Hermitage building itself as we were by the art collection. It was wonderful to see the works of the masters in such a beautiful building. Definitely worth the stop, even if you aren't into art works.

Catherine the Great's Gift to the World. Amazing, overwhelming collection of over 3 million items. A museum-goers' fantasy. My friend and I went twice and stayed until closing the second day, and still didn't get to see everything we'd intended. Tip: go with an experienced guide or do your homework. (There is a smart phone app that we found helpful.) Determine what you mustn't miss and keep an eye on the time.

September the time to go. September is a great month to go and see the Hermitage, not crowded as was out last visit.....Better with a good guide, definitely need head phones with a large group and guide.
Must see. The museum not only showcases a marvelous art collection, which includes european classic, Russian art, Egyptian antiques, but the Palace it self is a wonder.
Marvellous Collection. We had a guided tour which took in the most famous paintings.You would need days to see everything. The Hermitage café was very crowded with a shortage of seating.

So much to see. Only managed a few hours at the museum but wow, what a pace.So much to see but we concentrated on the classical art.Surprisingly this was the first time I have seen priceless masters so poorly hung. Not straight an swamped by light! But still very much worth a visit.

Hermitage. We are not inclined to linger over art galleries so a full day was sufficient - we confined our art viewing to 19th and 20th century European rooms, that is the Impressionists. We are more interested in the buildings, the artefacts and the quite magnificent interiors - the wooden floors are stunning and we were surprised that visitors are allowed to walk on their unprotected surfaces. The peacock room is a must and please note that the builder of the incredible clock was British! A good point is that the guides accompanying tours use throat microphones and their tourists have earphones so their commentary is discreet and unobtrusive to other visitors.
Impressive. Very big and spaciously set up. Sign-posting not great, but not a real problem, it's fun to get a bit lost between all this art and beauty
Go by yourself & see what you want. Most tourists get a standard 2 hour shuffle through the huge place. Go by yourself if you can, esp. on Wed. when it is open until 9 PM, or go when it opens.

A fantastic collection of art. You could spend a month here and still not see everything. It would be easy to become overwhelmed by the extent and wonderful quality of the collections, so don't linger too long over any particular gallery. Take your pick from antiquities to Impressionists. It's all there, including some fabulous pictures that never leave Russia. The general impression is good enough. The rooms are palatial too, and the views over the river are fine. But if you want something to eat, be prepared for disappointment. The cafe is far too small for the crowds of visitors, and although the staff do their best, queues are inveitable. The quality of sandwiches and snacks is poor, but the coffee is OK.

Hermitage Museum. There is so much to see here. They have different sections dedicated to different forms of art. Need at least 3 hours to see anything and a full day is better. If you are an art lover you won't be disappointed.

Hire a guide or you may miss some of the most interesting stuff.. The Hermitage has such an enormous collection that the tour guides will tell you it would take two years to see everything. Others say you would need to walk 24 miles to visit every room and if you spend a minute or so to view each item that would take you three years. Ok, I think I made my point..... It is big.We went with a tour from our cruise ship and only spent a couple hours looking around. Our guide knew exactly were she was going and explained that she was only showing us a selection of some of the most important items. My advice is not to go it alone unless you have done your research in advance on what you want to see. If you hire a guide or tour company make sure you ask what exactly you will see on your visit. I did notice some people had one on one private tours so if you are really interested in only certain items you may want to go that route and customize your visit. Remember this is also a former palace turned into a museum. It's beauty alone will keep your interest. It reminds me of the palace at Versailles without the expansive gardens.

a must to visit. Great place but is overwhelming. We were exhausted at the end of a few hours. We went in late September and the place was packed. I'm told it's much worst in the summer. Saying all that I wouldn't have missed it.

A minimum two day event!. You need at least two days to get through this amazing museum. Make sure to buy your tickets on line before you go and you will be able to avoid the long lines of people who did not plan accordingly. The vouchers do not commit you to any days so you can go when you feel like it. The two days must be consecutive. If you want to split it up go on Sunday, the museum is closed on Monday so your next day is Tuesday!

a GREAT museum. After hearing a lot of marvellous stories about this Hermitage Museum, during my trip plan with tour, it was a 'must see' place. Unfortunately the schedule fell on Monday, where the museum does not open on that day. So i worked hard to deal with the tour to change it to Sunday. I made it and thanked God I have insisted that way. The museum was really great. And you can also take picture inside the museum. It was a grand place where you could see a lot of things with their own histories and unique stories. The walls, ceilings, doors, everything were decorated very beautifully. You would see a lot of state of the art works. All were done in details. You wouldn't be able to stop taking pictures unless you run out of battery or memory. Don't forget to watch the golden peacock.. If you are lucky enough you would see something different there. Press your luck! Spend your time leasurely.. Don't forget to look up to the ceiling and pillars.. You'll be amazed how at the old days the tzar was very rich!

Beautiful!. So much to see. We took at tour that only showed us the artwork. While seeing Da Vinci and Raphael was amazing, we would have liked to seen some Russian artwork and other artifacts that related to Russian history. We are aware that they exist within the museum and are disappointed that we were not able to see them.

STUNNING. The buildings that house the museum are visually stunning, in an OTT gold everywhere sort of way, and it was amazing how close you are allowed to get to world famous works of art. It is well worth a visit and was the highlight of my holiday. However be warned that the museum is vast, with lots of walking, plenty of stairs, very few seat and no air-con.We went on an organised tour, but you can do it yourself,. I would recommend an organised tour as we didn't have to queue for tickets and it seems that the tour guides organise their groups so that everyone gets a fair bite of the cherry in busy areas.

comfort tour st petersburg. first impression was wow the size of the building and inside the decore was elegant the wonderful paintings sectioned off, I felt there were too many people all trying to view at once so missed quite a lot.
Must watch. A must watch in SPB and should visit on the first day with lots of time.at least spent 1day in hermitage if not more
Fantastic collection of art & artefacts. You could spend weeks looking at the marvellous collection of exhibits on show, a very worthwhile experience

Amazing Collection. Hermitage has an amazing collection which worth to see and pass 6-7h. inside it.
I'd recomend you to made an online reservation not to wait on entrence for hours.

For free for students. Normally Hermitage costs 400RIb (10?) for entrance. If you are student, doesnt matter which country, its gonna be slways for free. Museum requires 2 days to see all the collection
Amazing. We were truely amazed at the historic significance of the Heritage. The paintings were all originals and the interiors of the rooms, especially the amber room, we will never forget.

More is more. Five main buildings, 3 million items, they say it would take 15 years to see them all if you just spent 60 seconds in front of each. Either plan your visit with military precision, or take a guided tour to take in the main highlights (the general English-language tour lasts about 2.5 hours). It is well worth the money.

Stunning. We were very lucky to be able to incorporate an afternoon tour of the Hermitage Museum and the Winter Palace into our trip to St. Petersburg. What a stunning Palace and we enjoyed the experience very much.

Incredible site with marvelous art works. This Museum is much more than a home for fantastics works of art. The building itself is an amazing palace with room after room of sculpture, paintings and other forms of art. The audio tour was excellent. The only negative was the fact that we were there on a 100-degree F day and there was no A/C or circulation.

You can spend a month there........ It goes on and on and every step is breathtaking. If you are in St.Petersburg you have to see this museum. Words really can't describe it.....have to see it to really appreciate the time and effort which has gone it to this to make it one of the top places I have even been in. Not many of the Russian personnel that actually works there will help you but you can navigate around this museum for days.....it's that big and vast!

Amazing!. I've been to plenty of museums in different parts of the world, including the Louvre Museum in Paris, but I can say that I enjoyed this best. We were ushered right in as part of a tour group so we didn't have to queue for a long time. The amount of artwork is in the superlatives. I was so surprised how close you can actually see (& almost touch!) Leonardo da Vinci's, Goya, and Rafael's artwork (to name a few). I mean its right there in front of your face and not cordoned off meters away like the Mona Lisa at the Louvre. It really is one of Russia's gem.

Museum like no other. Ermitage museum is second only to Louvre in Paris. If you appreciate classical art and interesting exhibitions, you need to visit St.Petersburg, if for no other reason, to see the Ermitage!

Left speechless. This is an amazing place. The weaith and power of the Russian Tsar is on show at the Hermitage. Be prepared though for big crowds.
Weekdays if possible as the crowds are slightly reduced.
Tour groups do have priority and the professional guides give insights and inform that could easily be missed.

Spectacular--could spend days there!. We were part of a guided 'overview' tour to give us an overall perspective. The artwork of the masters is well-laid out. The decor is beyond words...
It would take some planning if touring on your own to determine what areas to focus on. Lots of steps and walking--it's huge!
Art, Art, Art. A beautiful palace filled with wonderful pieces of art. Amazing exhibitions and culture to fill a day in St Petersburgh

The Highlight in St. Perersburg for art lovers. Our visit was on a weekend and the crowds were very large. We had a booked tour through TJ Travel and they got us right in ahead of the long lines. You need to do some homework before your visit so you can see what is of most interest to you. It is impossible to see everything. This not only is a great place for art but important in the history of Russia.

Don't miss the 2nd floor. This was our 2nd visit to the Hermitage, where you can buy tickets online. For an additional $5.00 you can get entry for 2 consecutive days, which you really need if you've never been there before. The Hermitage is closed on Mondays, but you can go on Sunday and Tuesday with this ticket. It really saves time because the lines are quite long to buy tickets onsite.The 2nd floor is mostly the residence area, with beautiful living rooms, studies, bedchambers, etc. It's much less crowded than the exhibits on the 1st floor and it's nice just taking your time and walking through without getting pushed and bumped by other tourists. There's an audio guide you can rent which is very informative since there are not a lot of display signs. I think you should see 1 floor per day, because it is a massive palace that takes a long time to get through. There is a wifi zone in the basement near the cafe that's always jammed pack. Don't count on eating there unless you don't mind spending 30 minutes in line for a cheese sandwich then have nowhere to sit because of the crowds. It's a small complaint that can easily be avoided. Make sure you have this high on your list when you to to St. Petersburg.

A Feast of Beauty. The outside view was imposing - long, low and situated along the water. Our tour had been arranged for a time before the official opening time so we were ushered straight in. Everything was so beautiful. The art collection was amazing, the jewellery spectacular, the peacock clock a masterpiece - just so much to see and really not enough time to just stand and gaze. It would take many visits to do justice to the amazing things on display but even a short visit will stay with you forever.

Definitely a must and will take many hours. I walked 6 hours in the Museum and could only see a little bit of what Lonely Planet suggested. Unlike other reviews I've read, I found the museum in general very organized, not unbearably crowded and in good shape as far as the conservation is concerned. No doubt it is the no. 1 attraction of St. Petersburg, should not be missed and if possible account for a whole day or two visits.

Beautiful! But get there early!. I was part of a travel group, so I was given early admission at 8. If you can possibly see the museum with a tour group, I would recommend it. I know, it's nice to do things solo, but this place has millions of people swarming to get in as soon as it opens. Getting in early enabled me to experience the art and beauty without being crushed by the sheer amount of people. It's a must-see when in Russia. You won't see all of it, because it is enormous, but you will see enough!
Day 1 of St Petersburg. Travellers..... do NOT miss this magnificent building, and the Gold Room. Totally unbelievable wealth accumulated by the Russian hierarchy!

What a Magnificent Museum. This is one of the most extensive art collections you can find with Rembrandt, Cezanne, Monet, and Renoir to name a few. There is also ancient Roman, Egyptian, Russian and German artifacts. The Peacock Clock and Catherine the Great Palace are spectacular. Allow several days for this museum. You can prebook tickets online and save time and money with a 2 day pass

Overwhelming. We recently visited the Hermitage, accompanied by a guide. We seemed to have an allotted time, 1:30 in the afternoon, and walked right in. While there were some tour groups, it was not that difficult to work our way around them and I was not that bothered by crowds. Our guide took us to specific paintings etc, making sure we saw the highlights. Left on our own I think we would have just wound up wandering around. What impressed us was the architecture, more than the artwork. The buildings themselves are amazing. I used my camera without a problem (had no permit). If flash wasn't allowed, then I didn't take any pics, since my flash sometimes goes off on its own. If you're in St. Petersburg, this is pretty much a must-see, to whatever degree meets your interests. I probably wouldn't be able to stay for hours on hours, it would exhaust me since the place is overwhelming in scope, so I was happy with our abbreviated visit.

Excellant. It was great to see treasure from another time, except it was the end of the g20 meeting, there were dignitararys visiting which made it very difficult for the tour groups to move around at leisure.

Take your time and wander. A massive complex of art and architectural variety and splendour. It's a labyrinth so take your time to visit this museum. The ground floor (archaeological collections) is not as busy as the others but the collections I saw were well worth the visit. There are a number of important artists represented here. The rooms (and floors) alone are worthy of your attention. Don't miss it.

Fascinating Museum. If you are visiting St. Petersburg, you cannot forget to visit this. Those places are all full of deep spirit, magical pictures and atmosphere that´s going to take you really into depth.
Unbelievable. Simply did not have enough time or energy to do it justice. Better than any other gallery I have visited
A must if you are in st Petersburg. Fantastic visit, although very hot and tiring, felt a bit rushed, but we certainly packed in a lot in 2 hours. The grandeur of the rooms and the art was amazing

Great palace and art gallery. Lots of european paintings in a palace setting. Excellent artwork to see. Apparently you can also see the royal jewellery but this is by separate tickets and needs to be booked in advance. We didn't know about this option until it was too late.

Gorgeous. It is worth a visit. You need at least a day to get through the various impresive museums.There is so much to see, besides the arts and ornaments the interior decor is stunning. Each museum is different. So make sure you crane your neck and look up at the ceiling then down at the ground and then the wall. Stay away from the cafe and bring your own snacks. the sandwiches we had were stale and inedible.

So much to see, so little time. It depends on what you want..a tourist hit-the-highlights tour which lasts 3 hours, or an art lover, which will require 3 or more days. It is highly recommended to use a local tour guide for St Petersburg, which will handle the language barrier, etc etc. The guide I used was well versed in the hit and run tour, and we felt coming away satisfied, if a bit rush and crowded. After the 100th painting they all start to look similar to me...HAHA. Anyway its a must see, and the highlights are the mechanical bird clock, Leonardo da Vinci's paintings as well as Monet's. the guides will also provide audio headsets for translations and guiding (no more yelling or waving pennant flag). I would want to spend a day there if i get the chance to visit again. For those who are more art loving than me, negotiate for a specific tour route to hit your highlights.
