Note: although the Gold room is in the same building, its a separate tour with diff charges and requires booking. I didn't manage to get in

The #1 attraction. This is one massive museum with lots of collections including Egyptian/ classic antiquities, Italian renaissance etc and has works like Leonardo da Vinci and Titian to give a sample. The building is very impressive too and is a great setting for museum of this magnitude. One thing to note, this place requires time to see and digest the exhibits and would require in excess of three hours to scratch the surface. The queues to buy a ticket were what seamed like kilometers but there are ticket machines next to the entrance so its not necessary to wait in this queue. The place was rammed with tourists and i believe the were cruise line passengers on day trips. I'm told its constantly packed at any time of year. Well worth a visit.

Allow lots of time. The place is enormous, so allow plenty of time to see all you want to see. The cloakroom system is efficient and quick and it's worth leaving behind all unnecessary baggage to be able to wander freely.

You need a day. As other reviewers noted this place is just one beautiful photo after another. No flash allowed though. I suggest you go with a group tour because they get specific entry times and there is no waiting. Another nice feature is that they require the use of headsets so guides do not have to shout over each other. We went on a Sunday and the place was packed. The building interior itself is ornate beyond belief and a massive structure you can easily get lost in so all the more reason for going on a guided tour. The art decorating the walls of the place is staggering both in quantity and beauty. The collection is impressive with at least one work from all the greats. If you visit St. Pete, the Hermitage is a must see. Just be prepared for huge crowds and a long day if you want to make a dent in seeing the major highlights. If you found this review helpful, please click below.

So huge. This has to be seen to be believed. Make sure you have plenty of time as you could spend the day looking around the Hermitage. The art alone will take a full morning to appreciate. Im only sorry we didn't get to see all the beauty on offer as it was so busy. We did have to queue for a while to go in and there is now where to buy refreshments so we left due to hunger. If you go to St Petersburg you have to visit the Hermitage.

Stunning! One of the world's greatest buildings!. Being in a tour group we got in early. Every room is jaw dropping! Look up at the ceilings, look down at the floors, the walls, the gorgeous doors and chandeliers and malachite and lapis columns... Oh yes!! And the art on the walls, too! Rembrandt, Monet, Matisse, daVinci, Michelangelo, Gaugin, van Dyck... It never ends! And the gold peacock clock just knocked me out! This was a dazzling over the top building and art collection. Sensory overload at its best.

Add this to your bucket list!. Of course, a world class art museum. But perhaps the best aspect is the Winter Palace itself - just fantastic. You have to pay a little to bring in your camera (no flash allowed). Tight security as it should be. Skip the one indoor cafe and try the two in the courtyard inside the main Hermitage entrance but before you enter the museum building. Yes, there is a Caravaggio! (we won't mention the travelling Caravaggio exhibit I missed by a few days!)
Give the Hermitage an entire day at least. The depth of the collection is unbelievable. This is a "bucket list" visit for any art lover, or art academics.

Lack of organization. We booked online the tickets because we read that this way it was possible to avoid the queue. When we arrived there the internet ticket desk was closed and at the administration desk they told us that the service was off, but she said we were lucky because that day there was not so much people. The personnel at the ticket desk then was rude, so we spent something like half an hour to get in. The exhibition is very rich and well maintained but it lacks of a clear path to follow, that would be preferable

Definitely one of the best museums in the world!. The State Hermitage is composed of several buildings, one of which was the Winter Palace for the Tsars of old Russia. The buildings are all joined together, and one just continually go up and down staircases and long hallways to reach different rooms. We were told that if you were to spend one minute gazing at every item on display at the Hermitage, it would take you eleven years to see everything!They have the a lot of paintings by the old masters: Rafael, Rembrandt, Da Vinci etc. Their collection is amazing! They have paintings, pottery, jewelry, furniture, toys etc..One of my favorites is the 18th century mechanical Peacock Clock. The figures of a peacock, cockerel and owl form an elaborate mechanism that has all three figures moving when it is wound up. It is apparently the only mechanism in the world that is still in its original working condition. Unfortunately, it was not wound on the day we visited. Kudos to the Russians for doing such a good job of keeping this wonderful museum in such pristine condition. You would never believe by the condition of the carpets on the floor that thousands of feet trample by on them daily!

Stunning. We had pre booked tickets to avoid the queues and had mapped out a route to take us round the key things we wished to see, otherwise i think it could all be a bit overwhelming. Highlights were the Jordan Staircase, State Rooms of the Winter Palace, the Impressionists Paintings, Raphael Loggia and Pavilion Hall. Although the artwork is priceless it was the building itself that was stunning to see, especially if you have read up a little on the Romanov family.
A must see.. Amazing amount of original paintings of great artists. The building itself is a museum.Worth a visit.

WOW!!!!!. This place is absolutely amazing. It is impossible to see it all in one day and you do have to heed the warnings and plan your visit and pace yourself. Absolutely worth the trip to Russia on its own

Quite simply stunning.. This is one of the best museums in the world. It has so many wonderful artists that after about half an hour in your jaw starts to drop and then drops further and further the more you see. An amazing place. I was not particularly desperate to go but once inside I could have spent all day. Amazing. If you learn a little bit of Russian you may even get in a the local's price !

Amazing!. I had 3 hours with a guide and only saw a fraction. It is closed on Mondays, so it is pretty busy on a Tuesday (several people on the cruise commented about the crowds). I was there on a Wednesday - still a lot of people, but not overcrowded. The art is beautiful and so are the surroundings. Had a snack at the cafe, a piece of pie which was very tasty. You are allowed to take pictures. Wear comfortable shoes and enjoy.

Holiday guide tour. We had a brief visit as one of our excursions booked by the tour company. The guide gave us a whistle stop tour of just a small part of the art gallery side, whilst this was ok, it would be much better to do a trip on your own, and don't forget to take a lok at the grand entrance and not just to side door that we were taken through

This is a must see while in St Peterburg.. Long lines and at times hard to see some of the displays. With that said it is a must see. Beautiful, interesting and stunning works of art depicting Russia History. Must see.

Give this place plenty of time. Do a little reading up on the various exhibits so that you can make sure you see the exhibits that you most desire. After that spend the rest of the day wandering from hall to hall. Some really nice exhibit are hard to find and all are worth a look. Highly recommend an audio guide. Don't forget to take a break and enjoy a snack in the cafe. Be prepared to be dazzled.

Hermitage: Not to be missed. The Museum (closed on Mondays) sells itself as a rival to the Louvre in Paris. While both places are outstanding, the Hermitage in our opinion is not as superb as the Louvre, simply because of the number and nature of artifacts and paintings on display in each. Having said the the Museum is beautiful, well maintained and offers a great variety of art, most of which cannot possibly be seen even in a few days. So, in fact, a half day or, better a full day, visit is needed and then one need to limit one's viewing to specific sections of the Museum. Retaining a guide is really strongly advisable. The Museum tends to be crowded at all times but one gets used to all the shuffling feet.We were advised to watch out for pickpockets both inside and especially outside the magnificent baroque buildings. A "must" visit when in St Petersburg.

Wow - Fantastic Visit to Hermitage and Winter Palace. We had a guided tour of the highlights of the Hermitage organised by SPB Tours of St Petersburg. The priority entry (an hour before the general opening time) let us have gallery after gallery to ourselves before the hordes of other tourists arrived. Our Guide Katerina had already taken us on a Niva River Cruise and shown us the Underground Station at Admiralty some 600 ft underground before we arrived at the Hermitage at 9:30 am. Our tour allocated 4 hours for this visit and we covered 4 of 11 different buildings. The Hermitage was everything and more than we could have hoped for. Gallery after Gallery of priceless treasures and paintings. My favourite was the Peacock Clock. A must see highlight on your visit to St Petersburg

Fabulous. The Hermitage and Winter Palace is certainly everything I had anticipated and more. It is one of the most famous and, therefore, one of the most visited sites in St Petersburg. Very crowded during height of tourist season. If is your main reason for visiting St Petersburg, I would suggest going in the winter so you can really enjoy your visit without fighting the crowds. However, it is well worth the visit anytime.

Very crowded - disappointing. The Hermitage and Winter Palace are visually stunning. Unfortunately, I thought there would be more Russian artefacts and culture on display. The collections are mainly by European artists, which I can see nearer to home! The Museum is obviously one of the main attractions, so is very crowded and you are 'herded' around. Preferred to view it from a boat on the river!

huge, beautiful. beatiful, huge, various arts in this museum
you need to visit this museum many times

Even Better Than The Hype. We had a guided tour of the highlights of the Hermitage organised by Alla Tours of St Petersburg. The priority entry (an hour before the general opening time) let us have gallery after gallery to ourselves before the hordes of other tourists arrived. And the terrifically knowledgeable Katrin, our tour guide, made sure that we saw the most treasured works of art whilst giving us the freedom to explore our own interests. TIP: Don't lose sight of your guide: this place is so big and houses so many fabulous treasures you may never find the exit without help. And DO use a eputable local service like Alla - we learned, later from fellow cruise passengers who had been on the ship's organised excursion, that it had taken almost an hour to gain entry and that, once in, they had been herded around with the hundreds of other people all trying to see the highlights.

Astonishing place!. As soon you are in front of the Hermitage building you need to take a breath for few seconds... and the first word that comes to your mind is...impressive!The story of the building starts with Empress Elizabeth Petrovna and her 5000 shoes and 15000 dresses... that she wanted to show! That's why Hermitage was built!The collection of the Hermitage has more than 3000 works of art of the world! A two-hours visit is not enough even if you do not understand so much about art!The real top painting is "The Return of the Prodigal Son", Rembrandt - boundless love and regret at the belated spiritual awakening.My suggestion: It is good to vist it in an organised tour, otherwise ...

One day is not nearly enough.. It is not possible to see much of the Hermitage in a few hours. It is in several buildings and if you are a true art lover, I do not know if even a few days would be enough.

Beautiful setting, impressive collections. I have visited Russia and been to the Hermitage - so this was not a first trip. When walking up to the museum and first seeing the familiar building, on the river, with it's green and white façade, it's absolutely awe-inspiring. The exterior architecture is iconic - and the interior provides a beautiful space to display art, sculpture, furniture and other exhibits. My only disappointment was that some of the exhibits that I have seen and loved in the past - the Faberge eggs and the carriages - are no longer exhibited. The Faberge eggs are owned by various collectors and the carriages are in the Hermitage Storage facility. I love Russian history and missed these exhibits....... though we certainly still enjoyed the Russian culture and the Treasure Galleries.Be aware that The Hermitage is open until 9:00 pm on Wednesday nights - so a lovely way to spend an evening! It's also interesting to read about the history of the museum before you go - to provide some context about how the art was collected, the various exhibitions, the Hermitage during the WWII. The Hermitage website provides excellent information.
amazing. amazing amazing amazing. Like Buck Palace, the National Gallery and the British Museum rolled into 1

This is a great stop...must do!. One of the great museums in the world. Filled with art "treasures" so plan a good part of the day for a nice visit. Very crowded in the morning but the mid-day to afternoon was much more leisurely...and enjoyable. I am not much of a Museum visitor but this one was pretty cool!!!

Absolutely amazing. Actually visited in May 2012 when on a Baltic cruise. The crowds tended to bottleneck in some places due to the volume of people. That being said, everything else about the visit was amazing! Picasso, Monet, Van Gogh, Da Vinci, Rembrandt, and much much more. The works of art were awe inspiring. Could have spent days there. The structure itself is beautiful with such impressive architectural details. Lots of walking, as the place is huge, could be a challenge for anyone with decreased ability to walk distances or climb stairs. Go and plan on plenty of time to see everything

So much to see!. We walked 6 hours just to see all the rooms, we could have went easily 2 days. There is just so much to see! And it's not very expensive for the cleanliness of the place and the beautiful rooms (18$, we bought the tickets online - pre-booking to avoid the line). I also saw some of the cats (outside) which stay in the basement of the museum.

Excellent but watch out for pickpockets. The building and contents is amazing but watch out for pickpockets. A guy in our group had his wallet stolen from thigh pocket, and before he had finished the tour and reported it to police, they had already taken several hundred pounds from accounts and also phoned UK trying to get more money sent to them.

Worth the visit. There is just so much art here, you could spend days. Our tour guide from spb did a great job of showing us the highlights. You will not find tons of Russian works showcased here however.

Half a day is not enought. We booked our tour with DenRus and it included a half day visit to Hermitage you could spend a month and not get bored, Ive never seen such an extensive opulant museme anywhere in the world the place was very crouded but their was only 5 in our group and our guide Lisa was very informative i dont know how you would manage to see much if you were in a large group.

Breathtaking. I have been to the Hermitage twice, spending many hours there each time. It is as breathtaking each time as you would expect it to be. The Louvre, the Metropolitan, the British Museum and the Hermitage - they are each unique and equals.

Impressive but too crowded. If you are visiting at the height of tourist season, this may not be the best use of your time as it was so crowded as to be almost impossible to move through. However, it was very impressive and seemed to be endless in size. If you are an art lover, then it is probably a must see. If you are not and have been to the Louvre to Paris, then you might want to spend your time elsewhere. But it was very impressive, crowds and all.

not to be missed. no way you can cover this in one visit but well worth seeing and its ivery accessable although you will be faced with queues. the exhibits are of many different aspects of life in Russia in 17th and 18th century along with stunning art
The Museum. Unbelievabl e! A must! The best art collectionI have seen and I include theLouvre and El Prado. A walk through The artístico marvels of not only Europe but The Orient.

Amazing. This is amazing. The works of art are fascinating as is the history; to stand in the throne room next to where the last Czar would have sat is awe inspiring especially when you can see a photo from around that time taken with the Czar on his throne. It is lovel just to wander the halls dipping in and out of the magnificant works of art. Well worth the visit be you an art lover or not.

World Treasures. The Hermitage is one of the biggest and most impressive museums in the world, there's so many art treasures to see. I intended to try to see as much as possible - but, of course, you can't in such a short time. So, on my first visit, I concentrated on my favourites - the Impressionist paintings - absolutely breathtaking! - then, over the next two days, I absorbed as much as I could of everything else - before my legs gave out. It gets very crowded, as you'd expect, so try to get there earlier in the day, before the coach tours arrive. It is a place definitely not to be missed, even if it's just one opportunity to visit in your lifetime - I bet you'll come back again.
Fab!. Awesome!So much to see.The Amber room is amazing , as are practically every other room for different reasons.Visually amazing

Waste of time ! Do not do a tour !!. Do not do this beautiful place as part of a day tour !! Horrendous ! Thousands and thousands of people all herded in and out of a few rooms , we were down to a shuffle shoulder to shoulder along the corridors and when we got to the few rooms we were seeing , it was a quick march !!! Crazy, crazy !! It was the worst experience I have ever had . In fact I was getting so cross , we told our guide that I couldn't walk any more and tell us where to meet up in an hour. We were not tired !! We just looked around properly a couple of rooms that were off the tour track !! Much better

Not a fan. I'm not a fan of such things so I found it rather boring (as usual).
But scale of it is impressive, looks like you can easily spend several days there if you are interested in arts.

State Hermitage Museum is unforgettable. I visited Hermitage and the Winter Palace with my husband when we went to Russia last year. I have heard nice comments about the museum, but even going with high expectations, still it surpassed them. We had the luxury at this time to spend 2 whole days in the museum.But since it is one of the biggest and best museums in the world, still we didn't see everything. Especially if you don't have much time, is key to select your main interests and then most probably a guide could really be helpful.You have to make choices. I was happy on visiting many rooms on Russian history and the huge collection on impressionists. I was amazed for example by the number of Picassos they have and the 2 huge Matisse they had, almost ceiling to floor.The building itself is an attraction in itself. The Palace is located in the margin of the Neva River in Saint Petersburg, giving a wonderful view from many rooms. The collection was started by Catherine the Great in the XVIII century. I love photography. So for me, an additional attraction was the security staff which is composed of senior ladies with no uniform, carrying their own bags with them and sometimes quite bored of being there. Often they mingled with visitors and you couldn't say who is visiting and who is protecting the Museum property unless you see their badges. So many interesting expressions!...It is advisable to go early and to by tickets in advance. My husband bought them via internet and save us from being in a long line.Museum shops are great. Irresistible are the many different eggs on Faberge style.

Visit of a lifetime. We spent an evening enjoying paintings and sculptures we had only read about before. We had a Russian guide who was quite informative, and the architecture is fascinating. Sometimes we needed to pinch ourselves to believe we were really there. We are not usually art museum people, but the opportunity to see one of the world's greatest was irresistible. Don't miss it.

Perhaps don't use a tour guide?. We visited this excellent museum twice during our visit to St Petersburg. We were on a Holland America cruise ship and booked through them to go in the evening when the museum is closed to the general public. The advantage of this was that it was no-where as busy as during the day. It was still crowded as we were only able to go in specified rooms but we were able to view the artworks more easily.During our 2 days in the city we did an excellent tour with SPB tours which included a visit to the museum. I had read one review that said that she saw exactly the same rooms during her evening tour as in the day tour, and I was hoping that it would not be the case with us but it was. We were taken on the stock standard tour, and saw exactly the same rooms. The advantage of going in the evening was that we had the place to ourselves. Still crowded, but no-where near as much as in the day time. If I had to do it again, and had the time, I would visit on my own with a good map, so you can see the other rooms that are not on the standard tour.A word of advise, we visited in July and it was hot and stuffy inside, so no need for a jacket. This was surprising as so many art galleries have air conditioning to preserve the paintings, but the hermitage?? The place is so cavernous it would cost a fortune to air condition it. No idea what the inside temperature would be in winter though, so probably only need it in summer.Enjoy the museum and palace, but I must say I enjoyed the Louvre in Paris much more.
Don't miss it!. Beautiful museum. The buildings are breathtaking. Even got to see some Monets. The Peacock Clock was gorgeous! A Must See museum!

One of the most beautiful museums I ever visited.... ...and I visited quite many. A couple of advices for visitors: 1) book your ticket upfront via internet: you will receive a voucher that you can convert into a 2-days ticket, website: http://www.hermitageshop.org/page.php?pagename=tickets 2) plan your visit: there is so much to see, you need to make a choice; 3) evaluate whether you want to buy the extend ticket, that allows you to visit the other bulidings connected to the museum.

Nearly as rich in treasure as the british Museum. We went on a free day (first Thursday of each month) so it was a bargain. We spent nearly all day there. I felt sorry for the group tours being whisked around in an hour or so as there is so much to see. I particularly liked the ancient Mongolian section where the clothes and furniture is the original from two to three thousand years old, having been preserved in the frozen tundra. Very fascinating museum but very chaotic too. And as usual in Russia all the attendant have their coats on half an hour before closing time, staring at lingerers in a hostile manner.
Amazing selection of art. This place is incredible with huge selection of art pieces. The interior of the palace was stunning. Allow plenty of time!
Wow. Dont miss the Hermitage, so much to see and the beauty of it all is hard to take in, I felt rushed through though as there were lots of groups visiting.

Fabulous. One of the best museums in the world, inside and out. Lots of masterpieces from all over the world. Paintings, sculptures, traditional examples of day to day life from all over the world. Absolutelly amazing...

The most outstanding palace we saw. Well this palace is as grand as they come! No wonder the was a revolution. Well worth a walk through the state rooms and personal areas. It is also a great art museum, second only o the louvre. If you can organise a guide, do so, as our tour group had one and she was an arts graduate. We were educated about art as she showed us the main highlights. Then we had free time to wander. The third floor is full of the French impressionists, Picasso and many other masters. Allow time to go through. As you do, also look out the windows where you can. Great views of the massive square outside and the column in the centre.

Beautiful museum. Aside from the exhibitions, the museum itself is set in an old palace, so the setting is very beautiful. One of the highlights of the visit is a golden clock in the shape of a peacock. The collections are comparable to those at the Louvre and the Metropolitan, and has few local art, since, as explained by our guide, there is a separate museum of Russian art, which hosts those pieces.

A museum and art gallery in one building. We bought our tickets online which avoided the queue as we could go to the eticket box under the archway entrance off the Palace Square. The two children (under 12) were free.It is no wonder this building is so famous as the architecture and history are stunning and on top of that it is full of amazing art work and Egyptian antiquities. We spent hours there and only touched the surface.We paid for the audio tour rather than have a guided tour which allowed us to listen at our own pace (which was good with children) and also listen in detail about artworks which particularly interested us. I would recommend it.Although there were a lot of people there it did not seem crowded. We were able to move around easily. Our ticket included a permit to take photos.There are some food options but you cannot take food or drink into the building but you can into the grounds.

ONE OF THE WORLD'S GREAT ART MUSEUMS! SPECTACULAR COLLECTION. The Hermitage is one of the world's greatest art museums. From personal experience, we would rate it even with The MET, Moma (both in NYC), Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam, The Van Gogh in Amsterdam, The Philadelphia Art Museum, The Uffizi in Florence, The Walters Art Museum (Baltimore) and the Getty Art Museum (LA). The scope of the collection is mind boggling and palace location accentuates the experience tremendously. The saying is a picture is worth a thousand words. So I will be quick about this and get to adding photos. If you come to St. Petersburg, you must see this museum! TIPs: bring your camera and extra chips (you will need them) and try to go with an organized tour. Added Note: There are many other artists featured beyond what I have photos attached. Chagall, Rembrandt, Leonardo da vinci, Titian, Rafael, and many others.
Amazing Museum. Inside and Out this place is beautiful. A must see for anyone traveling to St Petersburg, Russia. I could have spent days at this spot with so much to see.

Amazing museum. Even if there were no Picasso, Matisse,Rembreandt etc in this museum, the Palace itself is truly amazing. But beware of the crowds! It can be just a little too much, to really enjoy the vsit
Good collections for European arts. It is one of the nice museums with quite a few great collections, Personally I still like Louvre and London National gallery better

Well worth the visit. We went on an organised tour from our crusie ship. As such we were there at 9am and went straight in , no lines no crowds. As other say it would take you days to see all of the art work. the peacock clock is something really amazing. Also included was a tour to the restoration centre which is in a different part of St Petersburg and well worth the visit if you can do a tour there as well .We definitely want to come back to St Ptersburg again and the hermitage would be worth another visit .

hermitage. truly a world class museum . the art work was spectacular. the opulence of the different venues was over the top grand. our guide enabled our group to enter the site hours before public opening which allowed us to see and enjoy the museum at our own pace.

Excellent for Art Lovers. The buildings are lovely, and the paintings are even better. There is so much to see, it maight take you 2 days to see it all. Beware, there is no air conditioning. On a hot day during the peak season (June), it gets uncomfortable. The guided tour we took was excellent. I enjoyed it more that way then I would have on my own. Highly recommended!!!!!!

WELL WORTH A VISIT. We are not 'arty' types, though having visited the Hermitage Museum, you appreciate the beautiful authentic Rembrandt, Monet, Picasso, Van Gogh paintings - you can't help but be impressed. The Winter Palace is so opulent - just go, admire and enjoy!

Never enough time. You could come here for days (and with students getting in for free, you actually could!) and not see everything. It is impossible. We would walk for hours, and then turn a corner into a wing we hadn't seen yet, or a never ending hallway full of beautiful paintings that you didn't realize was there.Luckily the rooms had numbers that made finding them on the map a bit easier. I can't believe people used to live here.Standing on the famous staircase where Lenin rushed into the palace was also amazing. It's one thing to read about something, and another thing to stand where it took place.Unforgettable. I was sad we only spent 5 hours in one day there!
Awesome. You would need forever to see everything but however long you have, its worthwhileThe opulance is staggering, the treasures fabulous and the overall visit is awesome

Wow what a place. Omg so overwhelming, we were on a tour so our itinerary was sort of fixed. What we saw was amazing and at the end we hit the floors with the impressionist, my favorite. I was floored y the size of the collection and was wowed by it. It was an exhausting day so you must pace yourself and wear comfy shoes. Bathrooms are a bit scary and the gift shops are awesome but expensive. Glad we went. Very impressive. Then I read the book the ordeal of the hermitage about how they had to empty the entire museum when the nazis were approaching. That is a feat of amazing magnitude.

Awe Inspiring. Every room in this amazing Palace is perfect. Decorative and ornate, with such beautiful attention to detail. Allow yourself at least 3 hours. Even if you aren't interested in the art as much, the place is so bit you need that time to do it justice!The only slight disappointment was that some of the less "classical" art, but also some of the most famous, was stuck up in the florescent tube light lit 3rd floor rooms, where they were not done justice to. Rooms of Picasso, Matisse, Monet etc were slightly ruined by having to find the right angle at which to look at them without catching the glare of lights. Definitely worth a visit though.

Amazing Experience. We need to appreciate Russia's zeal to protect & project its history. Hermitage is a standing example. Gallery has excellent exhibits. Please have ample time in hand to go through the exhibits. Rushing through not recommended as it will not allow you to enjoy the grandeur & allow your eyes a great experience. Do engage a guide ( English speaking guides are available). Best luck & enjoy an unforgettable experience.

Hermitage Museum St. Petersburg. If you get to St. Petersburg then the State Hermitage Museum is a must visit. Even if you do not like are museums as a rule, you cannot help but be impressed here. They say that if you stopped at each exhibition for 2 minutes it would take 7 years to get through it all. I had a day, which is nowhere near enough.There are paintings there by Van Gogh, Gaugin, Picasso and Da Vinci as well as many others.So if you are in St. Petersburg, then visit the Hermitage Museum. You will be glad you did.

Chaotic. It seems almost like heresy to say but this museum was only mildly worth visiting. The problem isn't with the collections but the non-existent crowd control & traffic management. Huge crushes of people were everywhere with no apparent attempt at controlling the volume or direction of flow. It was almost impossible to appreciate any of the individual works because of the jostling & oxygen deprivation. It may be that July is just generally over-crowded in St Petersburg so perhaps going in Fall or Winter will allow appreciation of the art.

Over the top. The Hermitage has topped my bucket list for 50 years, and it did not disappoint. However, the next list topper had better be a bit smaller and closer to home. After traveling 30 hours, lost luggage, and the other stresses of getting from the Caribbean to Russia, even jet lag did not diminish the experience of seeing the French 19th/20th century works I had heard about. On the way to the 3rd floor, one sees the opulence of the Imperial era in the collections and the decor of the halls and other rooms. The royal palaces of Spain and France cannot compete. A study of the flooring alone is overwhelming. I maxed out at 4 hours and barely scratched the surface of this extensive collection. My research proved accurate: plan on at least 2 mornings for this place. Get there at the museum opening time to avoid the hoards of bus tours and lines at the ticket office. I did not get the audio tour for my first visit, as I wanted to take my time with the Picasso's, Monet's, Matisse's and Gauguin's. My second visit will be with a tour, just to see some of the rest.

Fantastic place - you must go here. What a fantastic place! Even for someone like me who really isn't into art, you cannot fail to be impressed and amazed by both the building and its contents. A must-see attraction in St Petersburg.

Jaw dropping!. Expected our tour of The Hermitage to drag a bit & bore the children (11 & 17 years). Not a bit of it. We all came away completely amazed. We were touching distance to works by Degas, Pissarro, Cezanne, Van Gogh, Gaugin, Picasso, Monet, Renoir etc etc - walls & walls & rooms & rooms of them! It was a real OMG experience. As it was August it was very busy but our guide was brilliant at navigating the hoards & masses so we could get up close to some fantastic pieces. Only complaint was we did not have long enough to more than glance at the various pieces - it was whistlestop but fabulous. Saw the Amber Room as part of the tour but for us seeing so many paintings & statues we had read about, all in one place, with what appeared to be minimal security (I'm sure this wasn't actually the case & certainly no-one tried anything!) was just fabulous. Best time to go would probably be from end of September until late spring when the cruise ship season is over. It was raining the day we went but v warm inside & I bet it would be uncomfortably hot if the sun was shining so think carefully about what you wear. Raincoats / jackets are supposed to be checked in on arrival (big queues) so take yours off as you go in & roll it & carry under your arm. Also long queues for the facilities afterwards (for men as well as women) so bear this in mind when drinking anything!

Not to be missed. Wonderful exhibits here, but it is a big place and you really need to choose what you see carefully as it is hard on the feet and there is so much to see. On their 3rd floor there are some wonderful impressionist paintings, so do not miss these. On the first Thursday of the month entrance is free here.
overload on the wow factor. You simply have to buy a 2 day ticket, and event then it wont be enough to see it all. wow, wow, wow....

Too many delights!. I only saw a teeny, tiny part of the Hermitage but it's very impressive. Exhausting certainly - but wonderful.It's not only a fantastic collecton of art but I can testify to some extraordinarily beautiful floors and beautiful ceilings, too!

One of the world's great museums. The Hermitage collection is clearly one of the best anywhere but the museum is itself is large and confusing, spread over three separate buildings, only one of which was designed as a museum. Some works are hung and lightly poorly by standards of best western museums but an absolute must see if in St. Petersburg and it alone is worth the trip. Museum can be crowded and working with a tour group that can get you early access is a real advantage.
A must see!. Very impressing, large palace! Comparable to the Louvre in Paris in size and grandeur! You will need more than one day if you want to see everything it has to offer!

Wonderful. Enormous museum. The best were the original palace rooms, they are all grandiose and extravagant. Do go see the Western lower floor which is less visited, but shows items from regions not usually covered in other museums (Siberia snd Central Asian). The Diamond Room tour was nice. We were there early on September's free day (first Thursday of esch month) and the line was not too long.

fantastic museum. The jewelry and other artwork are fabulous. There are so many beautifully crafted pieces. There is gold everywhere. The building is also beautiful. It's easily one of the best museums in the world.

Most beautiful place in the world. You can miss this! If you are in moscow take a train to peter! This place is breathtaking, you probably will run into at least a few brides taking wedding photos here

A must. Try to go with a tour group that will allow early entrance o beat the crowds. You can also try to get away from the masters - rembrants etc and the crowds thin. The building and its history are just as impressive as the art within it

World class art collection. We purchased advance tickets, on the Hermitage web site. This enables you to skip the often long lines at the ticket booth. We spent 2 days at the museum, and only scratched the surface.
The collection of Impressionist art is the largest that I have ever seen,outside of the Jeu de Paume Museum in Paris.

Not enough time to explore the museum. This museum is comparable with Luv in Paris where you can easily spend days to enjoy all the precious art items it has. The collections are excellent and unique. The Russian Zars really collected valuable stuff over the years. It is impressive to see how much effort the Russian goverment has made to restore the site after so much been damaged by WWII and by communist rule.

Probably the best museum in the world. Well, maybe the title is overdoing it a little but it's certainly among the best and the setting would be very hard to beat in such a fabulous palace (or series of palaces). We were told that there are 3 million exhibits in the whole place, so you might take a while to get round it all! Even a good look would take days, though I imagine museum fatigue would set in after 2 or 3 hours. It would be great to have the option to go in for a couple of hours over several days and pick different parts each time. If you're doing it on your own it would be well worth planning what you really want to see and heading to the main things quickly. Go as early as you can as the crowds can be terrible, especially around the really famous stuff. Alternatively, go with a small organised tour that gets you in before the main opening as we did (see SPB Tours) and accept their choice of route and highlights to keep you ahead of the crowds... you might miss a few things you'd prefer to have seen, but just getting to see the palaces when it's quiet is a real bonus and any good guide should pick lots of interesting things.

Unbelievable museum. You will love the peacock clock and the Rembrandt paintings. The massive place cannot be all seen in a week, so just hit the highlights. AllaTours in St. Petersburg is the tour group to hire to take you around the cityand see the sights. Their guides are outstanding!
FANTASTIC. Just fantastic but watch out for the pickpockets, particularly if you are on an organised tour and trying to keep up with the guide and buy something in the shop....be warned
Amazing. One of the best collections of art I have ever seen. Wheelchair travelers should take advantage of the accessible bathroom(basement, locked bathroom) because there are so few in Russia.

Went to see art, was wowwed by building. We went to see some of the millions of pieces of art housed in the Hermitage/Winter Palace. While we enjoyed that, we were surprised at how beautiful the ceilings, walls and inlaid wood floors are! My eyes had a hard time knowing where to look!! AMAZING WORLD TREASURE.
A sight to behold. Voted no.1 in The Times - I agree. It can actually take 8 years to see it all, so in 3 hours we only had a taster, but worth every bit.

A must in St. Petersburg. The museum has an exceptionnaly rich collection of art and one needs many hours (and stamina) to see it all. It is advisable to plan at least two visits. And you definitely need to use the plan of the rooms which you get with the entrance tickets.

Way too crowded. Visiting the Hermitage was a highlight of our journey in Russia. But, it was also very disappointing. It was way too crowded...seven cruise ships were in town that day and one could not move easily through the rooms.Because of the crowds it was often hard to hear our guide as other guides were talking to their groups at the same time. We were limited in how long we could stay in an area and somewhat overwhelmed by the opulence. It's an interesting site to visit and which I'm sure would have been more enjoyable if it had been less jam packed with tourists such as us.
Must see. This is definitely one of those places you must see in your lifetime. Go early and beat the crowd. Also, go when it is cooler out.

State Hermitage museum and Winter Palace. This was really a wonderful experience. All the decorations -such richness - gold, marble and the ceiling paintings! Wow! Wish we had more time, especially viewing the paintings of well-known artists. The Peacock clock was really beautiful and not forgetting those chandeliers!!
Impressive. Impressive. But recommend visitors to allocate at least two days to be able to see everything. The place is huge.

One one of 200 palaces in St Petersburg!. The Winter Palace was exceptional. I didnt know what to expect but was stunned by the pure opulance of it. We didnt spend too much time in the rest of the Hermitage but saw all the "must sees". Our guide for excellent.

Art Exhibition. Very impressive art gallery! The rooms are stunning - beautiful ceilings - gorgeous candelabra - opulant rooms. Many famous artist's paintings adorn the galleries including Renoir, Monet, Michel Angelo, Rembrandt. It was very crowded when we went as there were 6 large cruise ships in port. It was still worth the visit.
Must see if you're in St. Petersburg. Our guide was excellent in that she covered all the highlights of the various artists and proceeded through the museum at a very comfortable pace.

Very crowded. Magnificent building and decorations and I loved the peacock clock. But the cruise groups were a complete pain, far too large, too many and noisy. I would rather pay a bigger entrance fee and allow the museum to limit the number of groups allowed per day. Also PLEASE PLEASE ban cameras in museum. Everyone is so busy taking pictures and getting in everyone else's way that they do not have time to appreciate the painting itself at all.

Paying for a good guide can get you in ahead of the crowd! So worth it!!!. The history is overwhelming! We enjoyed our first day in St. Petersburg at the Hermitage. I recommend doing this first since we were fresh and full of energy and our minds alert. There is so much to see and learn at the Hermitage and Winter Palace. A little work and reading ahead of time is well worth the effort. Understanding a bit of the royal history can be valuable in putting events in order and understanding how people and things link together.We hired a private tour guide for our group of 4 and I would highly recommend this. We were admitted early before the crowds and we could see the long queue outside and were very grateful for the little bit of extra time inside when it was quiet and we could see some things without lots of people around.I relish the history and thinking of what life would have been like in those times. What was it like for the royalty? And what was it like for the common man? A person can not visit Russia and feel the trip is complete without visiting the Hermitage. So many treasures. The Gold room is fascinating and worth the time and money in our opinion.

Overwhelming!! Free every first Thursday of the month!. This place is really incredible, indeed exceeded my expectations. Reserve about 3 hours to explore it, there are three floors full of amazing things and rooms. However, almost no information in English, rent an audio guide and try to not be stuck with huge groups. Every first Thursday of the month - entrance to the museum is free to all! But If you go on free day and high season expect huge huge lines, arrive earlier..

State Hermitage Museum. A little disappointed as we visited on a hot, crowded evening. Our guide was a local and she was hard to understand and a bit rude. Overall I enjoyed seeing the priceless artwork.
impressive. not only the collection but also the Winter Palace is impressive. Although there were a lot of visitors, it didn't feel as too crowded. A must see.

Only if you are interested in this!!. It was way too much artsy stuff for us. We are not into all this and found the tour too long.If you went on your own and could skip out some parts and hit the high lites that would be ok.And yes it is crowded and vry hot! It just wasnt for us, it was too much of the same.

A World-Class Museum. We visited the State Hermitage as part of a SPB guided tour. The morning we visited it was raining so being inside was good. First of all the Hermitage is on a grand scale. With 3,000,000 objects in their collection don't expect to do anything but scratch the surface, even if you spend a dedicated day or two. Our tour lasted 3 hours so all we saw were the highlights. Our tour started before the general public was allowed entry. By the time we were half way thru our tour the crowds were everywhere. Our guide navigated her way from room to room pointing out highlights along the way. We were not disappointed. The museum gift shop is very good - we bought a canvas reproduction of Rembrandt's Return of the Prodigal Son that we had seen earlier. One of our friends back home had asked us to take a photo of the actual painting which we did (no flash permitted in the museum) but we also bought the reproduction that they just loved! When we left the Hermitage it was still raining and the lines to get in we're very long! Glad we didn't have to wait to get in earlier. Bottom line- the State Hermitage is a "Don't Miss" if you are going to be in St Petersburg. Plan before you go so that you use your time wisely but expect lots of people trying to move about and appreciate the great works of art.

Not to be missed. Just returned from 14 days in Russia. One of the highlights was trip was the Gold Room at the Hermitage and the Hermitage storerooms in St. Petersburg. We were very fortunate to have a wonderful English speaking museum guide for the Gold Room tour, usually your tour guide interprets for the museum guide. The gold items and the workmanship of items that date from 4BC was remarkable. No photos in the Gold Room, However most everything else you could photograph without flash. No backpacks allowed and the coat room will not check them.  The visit to the storerooms was remarkable. I behind the scenes tour of hoe thing are stored, cataloged and rotated into what is on display in the museum. If you are planning to visit the Hermitage allow plenty of time and if your guide can get you in early all the better.
Great. So sad because not enough time for me. Really great place, do not missed...

It's a must.... ...and it's a wow! I'm not even a museum person..and it exceeded all expectations. A few tips....no sense getting tickets on-line as you still need to wait on line. Just go buy tickets in the museum at an "off time"...and come back. Having a personal english speaking tour guide...was also terrific...It was SO crowded, however, due to the cruise ships arriving that day...but nothing you can do really. St. Petersburg is one of the most beautiful cities I have traveled to...and the Hermitage is no dissapointment.

A MUST in St. Petersburg. It is needless to say that it is a must when visiting St. Petersburg. It's like going to Paris and not visiting Louvre. It definitely can be pretty overwhelming, so it was helpful for us to decide in advance what we wanted to see. The glamour of the Interior rooms is really breath-taking, Italian masterpieces are to die for, and modern art collection on the 3rd floor is great.

Hermitage museum. If you have been to the Louvre Museum, this is a museum that have to be seen. The galleries full of paintings that are not in any of the other museums, makes it a first if you are in St. Petersburg. Also I would recommend Peterholf castle and gardens. Beautiful. If you have been to Versailles, this is fantastic place to go.

Very crowded but amazing. With our SPB tour we had early entry to this Museum (it opened at 10.00am) and we were able to miss the queues. There is so much so see that you can only gain an overall impression of the exhibits. It was very crowded, but definitely not to be missed.

Hermitage Museum. Wonderful collection of art.well worth a visit if in St Petersberg We spent 3 hours on a guided tour with a very knowledgeable guide.He gave us background information/ history of all the artists,pointed out all interesting aspects and highlights of all the artists/ art.All the relevant History of Russia was a bonus.All the history of Catherine the Great including jewels and gowns were on display .Involves a lot of walking in a very popular tourist attraction in Russia

Hermitage Museum. Absolutely outstanding, from the moment of entering there was so much to see, we were told by spending one minute looking at each item it would take eleven years to see everything.
We were on an official tour so went straight inside
, the oppulence was out of this world.From the marble staircase to all the displays of art.

Great Experience ...... 1 day is not enough !. Visited this amazing museum recently ..... its not possible to visit the entire museum in a single day so try to go as early as possible and be prepared to spend some time in the queue as well. The main museum is closed on Monday and opened from 10.30 AM to 6.00 PM on Tuesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday. On Wednesdays, the museum is open till 9.00 PM. Apart from the main museum there are also 2 special rooms i.e. Diamond and Gold and a separate entry ticket for each of these rooms is required.

Wonderful Modern Collection. If you are a fan of the Impressionists and Expressionist schools of art, this is the place for you. Matisse is well represented along with Gauguin and many others. Having a guide is very helpful since there will be a lot of tourists (ocean liners dock near there) and this will help you navigate the crowds.

Opulent. The huge malachite vases, the gold rooms, the magnificent furniture, this former palace of tzars still makes you feel as though you are visiting royalty. There are more interesting exhibits at the British Museum, there are more famous exhibits at the Louvre, but nowhere are any exhibits contained or presented more magnificently . It is well worth the price of a private guide to avoid the long lines and to have a knowledgeable expert at your side .

Fantastic Museum. As other have said, you could spend a week at this wonderful museum and not see everything. Between the paintings, statues, busts, artifacts, books, and the history of the building itself, it is a must see for anyone visiting St. P.

Magnificent. This is the most impressive architectural structure I have ever seen to house such an eclectic art collection. Some advice: Do the online tour before you go to save time acclimating to your surroundings. And purchase your tickets in advance online. It will save you at least 45 minutes waiting on entry lines. The museum is extremely crowded from the time it opens until at least 1pm. It may be worth waiting until the afternoon until all of the tour mobs have already left. Enjoy!

Great collection. This museum is very expansive. It contains artworks for the rennaissance all they way to Impressionism. They have 2 Da Vinci, 2 Rafael's, a Velazquez, Goya, El Greco and lots of Rembrandts. Then collection of impressionist paintings...wish I could have stayed longer. Not too impressive with the sculpture. Would love to go back and have more time to ponder and lose myself in these paintings...thanks Catherine, the great for giving us the Hermitage....

Fantastic. A must see is the Winter Palace - breathtaking, all blues, whites and gold, there is no way to describe the majesty and splendor and this is also where the Hermitage Museum is located. Plan for several hours and a lot of walking, there is much to see. The home of the Russian Ballet is also located in the Palace, tickets were fairly reasonable at about $100.00. Outside you will see the canals. It seems that Peter 1 had visited Venice and loved the canals so much, he had then built them all through St. Petersburg. I also like to visit local "grocery" stores when we travel - this one had the most splendid wall coloured glass wall sconces I had to take pictures.
Hermitage. Wonderful art. Lots to see. Would lke to spend more time there. Good lighting and room to walk around.

This place is a feast for the eyes. The art collection is vast, and the Palace that houses it gorgeous and opulent. We bought 2 day tickets online and were able to skip long line to get in. The Hermitage is huge and full of tour groups. Some rooms can be very crowded, but the tour groups move on quickly. So if you have the time you can comfortably view what you want. The 2 day ticket also includes the Wooden House of Peter I, which we enjoyed with only a couple other tourists. And the Staff Building across the square which houses modern art and special exhibits. The 2 day ticket was a very good value.

Expecting Hermits, saw art. The Hermitage was grand and stately and I was glad that the wife made me go. Seriously, the guides narration was educational and entertaining. The "Amber Room" was beyond comprehension. Whatever you do when visiting St. Petersburg, Russia this is a must see to have on your itenary. I tried to take photos of the museum's matriarchial sentries located in every corridor for a photo documentary. Will post a few later. They were stern and unyielding in their stares reminding everyone not to venture. I think a few were KGB retirees.
Incredible Museum. You could easily spend a week at the Hermitage and not see it all. Pay extra for a private guide to navigate the throngs of tourists and bypass standing in lines.

The Hermitage is overwhelming, but doable. We knew that the size of the Hermitage is overwhelming with huge amounts of art and sculpture (although the great majority of what it owns isn't even on display). As a result, we signed up for a special tour titled "The Gold room and the Hermitage"; it was not cheap but it allowed us to get into this justifiably famour museum at 9 am, rather than the 10 am opening time for the public. The wide hallways were fairly empty and the four gold rooms - full of extraordinary items of jewelry, gifts to the Czar and archeological finds - were completely empty when we arrived. This made viewing the exhibits, with the assistance of our guide, a real pleasure. Our guide happened to be a fan of the Dutch paintings so we went there next and experienced the large crowds for which the Hermitage is known. Then, we went to see a DaVinci and other iconic paintings; the rule of thumb is that the more well-known the item, the larger the lines and the less time to actually see it - in fact, the harder it is to see. By the way, for those who are unused to crowds and the pushing, shoving and pulling that often results from being in the middle of them, be warned. These diverse crowds are pretty pushy. They are not a reason to miss the Hermitage but if you have any way to minimize exposure to them, take it.Recommendation: wear very comfortable shoes. There is alot of walking down long corridors and after a visit of several hours, you'll be exhausted. Even more so if your shoes don't provide support.

Elegant, Interesting, busy as all get out in July!. This is a must see if you are visiting St. Petersburg, Russia. July has to be one of the busiest months. So if you are not with a group, you will wait for a very long time to get it.
One of the world's greatest museum's. The artwork was displayed in a piece of artwork, the Hermitage, where the architecture was phenomenal..

Incredible art collection.. This collection is so vast that if one is an art lover one needs to allow more time than most tours would allow. The impressionist collection is not as extensive as one would find in Paris but there are unique pieces that are worth the time. Arrange for tickets ahead of time t o avoid waiting in line, and to make best use of your time there a guide with good knowledge of the collection is worth the money

The building is as incredible as the art!. The Hermitage has a world-famous art collection that would take days to see in its entirety. We were equally as impressed by the ornate ceilings and intricately inlaid wooden floors. The crowds were quite large and the entry process a bit chaotic, but it was all well worth the trouble. Be sure to reserve tickets ahead of time online and bring the print out with you to escape the long entrance lines. Very little at the museum is in English so patience and perseverance are important!

Hermitage Museum and winter palace. Is it worth the long line? Is it better than the Lourve or the Prodo? I have to beg you the difference from most of Trip Advisors. It is grand but not better the Lourve or other well known museums in Europe. I found that Hermitage Museum is too much hy but not better than other great museum and I definitely would not wait and repeat the visit.

A visit of a lifetime. .. My lifetime dream came true with this visit. Not only were the artwork and artifacts mind boggling, but the setting for the art was a dreamers paradise. History came alive. Not to be missed.

The Hermitage. Whether you are an art lover on not a visit to the Hermitage is an exprience you will remember for the rest of your life. You need at least three hours to gain an appreciation of the place and at least 8 hours to see some of the exhibits. Of course a knowledgeable guide is necessary.
Must See. What is there to say except that this incredible building and its priceless collections should not be missed. There will likely be huge crowds, but a visit here is priceless.

huge, but intimate. Don't even try to see most of the 3 million works of art - but any time you do spend will be richly rewarded. We were there during a special exhibit of impressionist paintings, many of which were stolen by the Russians from the Germans who stole them from the Jews.
Awe Inspiring. Incredible collection of art in a remarkable setting. The grandeur of this complex is beyond description. It would take a lifetime to see it all.

Astounding and stunning - a must see!. This museum is astounding and its collection of art and artefacts is staggering. We were able to avoid the usual long lines to get in since our hotel has a special deal with the museum. Check with your hotel to see if they can help you with this. Even if you do need to wait, though, it's worth it! Over 3 million pieces of art! We tried to see them all in one day. Wear comfortable shoes. We spent over 5 hours there and it really flew. Our favorites were all the Impressionists. Never saw so many in one place at one time. Stunning. You must go if you're in St. Petersburg.

He Sure knew what opulence meant. We were lucky enough to be on an official tour so missed the obligatory lining up to get into this place. It is said Peter the great knew he had the wealth of this great nation at his beck and call and this museum certainly supports that premise. The piece de resistance was the solid gold dinner setting for over 100 and decadence is everywhere in this salute to the memory of a time long gone in Russia.
Truly amazing. Perhaps the finest array of paintings ever assembled, in a truly awesome building. best visited with a tour guide. I recommend Alla Tours.

So packed.. Moved around the museum pretty good only because of our guide. But it was so packed. I would never go back in August again. Only reason we were there this time of year was of the cruise we were on. One of the rooms I was starting to feel physical sick because of so many people.Always wanted to visit and great we got the chance. But would go back to the Museums in London and Paris first.

Lots to see if you can... Horrible crowd control... super hot and sweaty..(August) Thousands and thousands of rude pushy people.. no set traffic order.. NO CHANCE to see much since you are fighting crowds all the time! Beautiful stuff if you were lucky enough to see above through and around .. LOTS and Lots of art.. 20 years to see it all..but 15 of those years would be waiting in line..Could have been a highlight.. instead.. no desire to go back.. Get the DVD or see it online.. No benefit to seeing in person in August.

museum visit. what an amazing place you have to visit it to really appreciate it . Full of wonderful works of arts ,antiques ,rooms with the most amazing decorations ,curtains wallpaper art work and furniture .You need lots of time to really appreciate it and lots of patience as it is very busy but well organised.Bit of a queue for the toilets though !!
Visiting St. Petersburg. St. Petersburg, visiting the Hermitage on a weekend , I can recommend a visit to the Hermitage, and St. Petersburg to anyone, St. Petersburg is worth every penny!

The Hermitage in St. Petersburg, Russia. After touring The Hermitage for 2 hours, 30 minutes, and viewing ONLY originals, no copies, of the worlds finest painters, sculptures, weavers, one understand whey the Hermitage has the 50,000 visitors per day. We were on a tour, and the tour leader directed us to the well known artists through out the Hermitage. Because we had "whispers", an audio system that the guide uses to speak into and your reception is through an earpiece, you did not need to be near the the tour guide to get the full description of what you were viewing. Would only do the tour with a guide.After 2.5 hours on your feet with NO water or food, climbing stairs, the tour could be a challenge to some with physical disabilities.

A great tour guide can even enhance the Hermitage. A two-day cruise stop in St. Petersburg was a highlight of our vacation. We scored big with our Alla Tour and our guide, Angie. She walked us in past the huge line waiting to get in and then proceeded to lead us to the highlights of the Hermitage walking 3 miles inside the 5 buildings for 3 hours. We felt that we had really seen as much as we could possibly internalize in one visit, and we never felt rushed. The Hermitage is a can't miss attraction--fabulous palace and incredible art gallery all rolled into one.

Wonderful collection but too many people. Wonderful building and collection. Too many people and priceless paintings poorly cared for. People were photographing paintings with flash and several wonderful paintings had the sun on them!!

The Most Impressive Museum I've Ever Seen. We went in August, it was crowded, but our tour guide helped us focus on the more important highlights and avoid the crowda as much as possible. Only had three hours. We could have stayed days. The paintings alone were the most impressive collection I have ever seen. Picassos, Rembrabdts, Van Goghs, Da Vincis, Monets, Matisses, and much more. And the opulence expains why there was a revolution.

Don't try to "do" the museum. Just pick out an area of interest (mine was Italian Renaissance) and limit your visit to that - the museum's collection is too big to try to "do" it all. Save leftover time to just tour the Winter Palace, where part of the collection is housed.

must visit!. I would recommend this museum to the ones that are interested in paintings and interior designs :)I was just enjoying the decorations and interior design. It has too many painting which take a lot of time to see all.

Busy but beautiful. Visited as part of a cruise party, so it was heaving with people - the beauty of the place though made it all worth while - so much to see and we only had a glimpse on what was on offer - a once in a lifetime experience

Palace of the palaces. My no. 1 on the list in Sct. Petersburg was the Winter Palace. And I was amazed. Even after seeing so many pictures - it was overwhelming in a good way.I know all the art paintings there is priceless, but to me the buildings were the most special. Of course there were crowds of tourist everywhere, but I guess it goes for any big / the biggest attraction of a city. You have to walk a lot so please consider that, and not many chairs to rest on. It is worth all the commotion and I would gladly go again, just to see all the decorations, chandalieres, vases and tables of lapis lazuli and malakite.

Beautiful place to visit but too full of group tours!. This Museum was just incredible. The interior of the building itself is worth spending hours there not to mention the endless artworks. We went in the middle of summer however so it was absolutely packed with tourists (like ourselves!). We had bought our tickets online so we did get to go to the front of the line but once inside we had to line up to covert the print out tickets into proper tickets and this took us about 45 minutes as there was no order to the queuing system and many people pushing in. It was great to walk around however we often found ourselves squeezed between group tours. If possible try and avoid a time that they go as they take up the whole room and there is no way to get around them as they walk slowly through everything.
largest museum.. must see for all, largest museum in the world. cant explain in words. should visit and needs half a day to tour complete palace.

One of the world's greatest museums. The Hermitage Museum, or actually, Museums, would have to be one of the very best in the world. In many ways, it's even better than the Louvre or the Prado Museum, if only because there are fewer tourists and pieces of art that are world class but a little less well known than those in the Louvre or the Prado.
Grand glory. Wonderful to see the grandeur of a past life. It is mind boggling to view the wealth of art and opulence at the Hermitage and in St Petersburg.
You cannot be in St.Petersburg and avoid visiting the Hermitage. Simply Amazing. Hire a guide and ask her to guide you through simply what you cannot miss. Approx 180 minutes needed.

as good or better that paris. So close you can touch the art and did but you should not they get a little upset - lol - unbelievable big and the collection is amazing I think it is the largest in the world. This is a must for anyone to see in there life time

The Most Exisite Site In St. Petersburg. While in may take more than a year to cover every room in the Hermitage, spending three hours there will be a remarkable experience. The art is unrivaled anywhere in the world. The breadth of art is remarkable. Make sure you have a good guide.

Hermitage Winter Palace. Total chaos. In disrepair, no humidity control, wood windows rotting, no organization to seeing everything, easy to get lost, ticket buying online was no advantage, as the gal was not there and the others disliked you going ahead of them when they had waited for a long time. Much of the art was gone - I hope to other controlled museums.

Don't go in August....its Hell. Too many huge tour parties. We will go again but another time of year. It was hard to see some of the famous art works as people were so crowded in taking photos. The museum was far too crowded and hot.

So much to see. Had heard about this museum but was not prepared for the beauty and the amount of arts. We liked all the arts but disliked the waiting time. Too many people at once. Thank God our guide knew of another place to let us in.

Very good but get a map. It really shows a lot of good pieces and of course the large Matisse collection that my wife loves. Bought some nice gifts at shop they have some good pieces. More information in English would be nice. Get your tickets via the museum web site to avoid the large lines at the museum

Endless Artwoks in Historic Setting. Of course if you are visiting St Petersburg for the first time the Hermitage is likely to be on your 'to do' list indeed it should be. A huge art gallery housed in a magnificent building steeped in history really should not be missed. Just blindly pitching up at the door and going with the flow does not mean it is impossible to appreciate (it's what we did) but a few tips will help you make the most of it. Firstly, don't expect to see everything. The collection is enormous with, for example, two or three galleries devoted exclusively to Madonna and Child paintings. Do a bit of research and target what you want to see or pick a few galleries at random rather than plan to do the lot. As for tickets, if you haven't got them online beforehand, and it is probably a good idea if you do, use the automatic machines to skip the line for the ticket office. We waited twenty minutes in a reasonably short queue to get served in an attempt to take advantage of a student discount, unsuccessfully as it turned out due to lack of documentation. If you want to take photos you should pay 200 roubles (GBP4) for a permit. They give you a sticker to wear but everyone seemed to be snapping away, sticker or not. As you leave there is a little post office which is a great place to pick up stamps at face value. A 25 rouble stamp is required for international postcards. For us, the best artwork there was the building itself and it is a bit of a shame that more isn't made of its history of the building and the events witnessed within its walls. There are a few rooms in the western wing that make reference to the Romanovs and the library appears to be authentic but the majority of the building is purely there to display artworks. There are beautifully painted ceilings, marbled staircases, some impressive chandeliers and suchlike but it would have been nice had more rooms been fully restored to their imperial splendour. That being said you will still be able to say you have followed in the Tsar's footsteps and at 400 roubles (GBP 8) a ticket you can't really complain about that.

Magnificent art collection in a beautiful building. The Hermitage museum is a magnificent collection of art housed in a breathtakingly beautiful building. You are allowed to take photos, and the building has sufficient natural light to make this worthwhile, but the guards will shout at you if your flash goes off accidentally (yes, personal experience...).Every visitor will have their favourite room or period. There is a lot of Christian iconographic art, and a fantastic selection from the Renaissance masters (Leonardo da Vinci, Raphael, Titian) as might be expected, but some unexpected treasures too: intricate glass vases from Venice, delicate ivory figurines from 14th century France, beautifully enamelled dishes from 16th century France and Italy. My favourite paintings were a conventional but sombre and imposing ‘Crucifixion’ by Alonso Cano, and the spooky 'Die Insel der Toten' by Arnold Böcklin.You can rush through the Hermitage in a half-day at a push, but it really needs a full day to absorb the sheer volume, range and quality of this collection. If you have enough time and can stand the queues outside and the crowds inside, I would advise breaking up your visit into two half-days. Either way, the experience is overwhelming.Hint: I happened to have my sight-seeing day in St Petersburg on the first Thursday of a month, not knowing that entrance to the Hermitage is free on that day. This is not a bonus. I had to queue outside for over two hours. Russians love their art, and they love it even more when it’s free. Go any other day of the month, and pay!

Ok if you like art. We went as part of a tour group, and they mainly focussed on the artwork, something that bores me, so I didn't like it, however if art is your thing I image you would be in heaven. The building itself is magnificent, the worst thing were the crowds, you had to fight your way through a few rooms and that is never pleasant.
Very crowded. This is a review of my trip - we were rushed round by our guide, there were so many groups it was difficult to follow her. I would recommend doing your own tour with your own headset.

Almost too Incredible to describe. You really don't know where to look as you walk through this museum, with its ornate ceilings and magnificent works of art. We could have spent days here and still not see a fraction of its treasures.
Do not miss this!. Wow, so much history in one place? The things inside are priceless, and so beautiful. Plan to spend all day.

World Class--how to Get In Quickjly. Imagine if the collection from the Louvre was presented inside Windsor Castle. That is the Hermitage, both world class art museum, and tsar residence. Incredible! Getting In: If you have an online ticket, about 20 feet inside the gate will be a kiosk with a small line to exchange your voucher for a ticket, that includes photography. However, if you don't have a ticket, DO NOT WAIT IN THE LONG LINE. instead, go about halfway past the gate to the building, where it opens up to the sky, and far to your right and also far to your left, are credit card (or cash!) self service ticket machines. I went on a Saturday morning in August, and I had overslept, and between the 2 credit card/cash self service machines to buy tickets or the kiosk for online purchasers, the lines were 1 person, 1 person and zero people. Meanwhile, loads of people were in these huge lines that extended forever it seemed. The only disadvantage of these approaches is that the only way to buy tickets for the Gold Room is in the long lines, even if you bought what you could online.

Packed but worth it.. There were 6 large cruise ships at the Morskoy Vokzal so the museum was packed with tour groups being led by their guides. I have only been there once so I do not know if this is the norm. It was not very busy at 11 but by 2 it was so crowded that we had to wait our turn to see some of the most popular exhibits. The museum has an exceptional and varied collection. We rented audio devices that were comprehensive and gave good explanations of both the rooms and their history and the collections that are now displayed within them. We were happy to not have been in a group and could go and see those things that we had researched beforehand. Even if we had been alone in the museum, we could not have seen every piece in the collection in one day. I recommend getting there as early as possible and seeing what is important to you early and then spending the rest of your time wandering around. The audio guide does not enforce any particular sequence. You press in the number of the room or the piece of art and you get a comprehensive explanation. You are free to wander around at will for as long as you like. Non-flash photographs are allowed. There are nice views from the windows but the lighting is not great for photography. There are plenty of restrooms and the restaurant is in a location where you can visit it and then go back to the exhibits. The museum diagram is free and you will be lost without it.

A treasuretrove. The Hermitage was spectacular. We arrived a day early just to spend a full day there before our tour began. The art collection is outstanding and the history of the Hermitage sight is remarkable.We had another l/2 day tour with our tour company but it focused on the Great Masters and we were pleased that we had seen the Monets, Van Goghs, Degas, DiVinci's, etc. on our own. Catherine The Great had quite the collection!

stunning. it's bigger than Louvre and full of masterpieces! It's impossible to visit in just one day. Too much crowd to visit the Leonardo and Raffaello's masterpieces. The groups should enter at definite time, not with single visitors.

Come Prepared. I did enjoy the hermitage, and i guess it is just one of those places you have to see once, but there are a few 'buts'. We bought our tickets online which means that photography is free and you don't need to line up for tickets. We also arrived at 10am (10.30 is opening time) which basically put us at the front of the queue for entry. Be sure to exchange your computer printout for your proper ticket in the little office under the entry arches before you cross the courtyard to the main doors- you will need your passport as ID. Arrive rested, hydrated and wear hiking boots (hey, kilometres of marble floors are tough on the feet!). You cannot bring drinks into the museum, and larger bags, jackets etc. have to be checked into the cloak room. I took a handbag instead of a backpack to save the bother. Wear light clothing and a cardigan to layer in summer as some rooms are cold and others quite hot. There is a cafe in the museum and whilst the food is good it is wildly expensive and the service was terrible for russian PR or an insight into soviet history - depends on your mind-set! If i went again i would smuggle in a packet of biscuits to eat in the eating hall. I definately recommend doing your research before you get there and printing out a list of things you would like to see ESPECIALLY which room number they are in. We could only find a map in french, but i doubt an english map would have been any more use as it only lists which regions are covered in which rooms (eg. Rooms 207-238 Italian). This is probably fine if you are an art officianado, but not much help to the rest of us! You definately need to grab the museum map as you will get lost without it. The first floor (ie. the one that you enter the building on) has all of the services, cafe, and some nice souvenir shops. It houses historical artefacts from ancient egypt, asia and other places- similar in content but not as big as the british museum collection. Having been to the british museum i wouldn't have bothered with this floor at all if i had have known. Also, mummified remains creep me out - and there are several. The second floor (up the grand staircase) is STUNNING but be warned that the map and info booth have almost ZERO information about the rooms and architecture, so if this is what interests you, come prepared with the room numbers of what you want to see before you arrive. Do not try and see everything - the number of tired and grumpy couples I saw on the verge of divorce was a bit funny! I do wonder if the 2 day ticket for slightly more money is a better choice to break it down into maneagable amounts. I don't have children, but i can imagine that it could be tricky to keep them amused for long enough to get around in one visit. We lasted 4 hours.
