Early admission a great help. We were pleased to see this attraction with a group of 16 enjoying early admission with SPB tours. Our guide Lubba was excellent and leading through the museum

So good , we went again. Excellent museum, shame about the 'police' in every room, such a contrast to UK museum or National Trust staff where they take an active role in helping people enjoy the visit.

A great way to spend a Day!. This museum is on e of the best in the world! A wonderful way to see fantastic art plus experience the opulence of Catherine's Winter Palace. A trip to St. Petersburg would not be complete without a stop here.

Incredible!!!!. We visited the Hermitage as part of a day tour of St. Petersburg. This museum/palace is huge and extremely crowded with tourists. You could easily spend days exploring all the rooms/exhibits. The museum oozes opulence and atmosphere of a different time in history. The art work is on the walls and ceilings are incredible. The masterpieces on display included Renoir, Rembrandt, Matisse and so many I couldn't name them all. This museum is a must for anyone who visits St. Petersburg.

fantastic experienc. We spent a full day and a half and still didn't scratch the surface. A fantastic museum. We also toured the gold room. It was definitely worth the added fee. The lines are long to get in unless you are with a tour group or book a privated guide.

Insanely big!. Impressive - there are many exhibits to explore, but the most impressive are the rooms they're housed in. We fly through most museums, but this one took us over 3hrs and we had quite a bit we didn't see. However, you'll have sensory overload if you spend a whole day there.Tip: Buy your ticket at the kiosks on the left just after you enter the courtyard and you can go right in and not stand in line.

Brilliant, except for the enormous queues.. The museum houses one of the most precious art collections in the world. Everyone who visites the city of St. Petersburg should definitely go there (at least 2 times!). Everything about this museum is fantastic, except for the enormous queues in front of it. Especially in the tourist season one should expect waiting times ranging from one- till two hours. Shockingly, this is mainly due to the fact that even with such enormous queues, only a small percentage of the cash desks is open. This spoils a lot of the impression.

Disappointing - not visitor-friendly and rude staff. These world class museums and galleries are probably more exciting if you don't come from a city that has one. I've been to a few, so I had high expectations.Like other top galleries, the collections hold more than can be seen properly - even with our two day ticket. So we tried to select particular sections to visit - especially the Siberian antiquities, artefacts from 'the near east', and Russian art - all of which we probably wouldn't be able to see elsewhere.However navigation around this place is a total nightmare. We tried to get to certain sections, but there are no maps on display, some rooms aren't numbered, signage is confusing, and some staircases on the paper plans were closed. When we politely asked for directions, staff wouldn't give any. We paid for the audioguide, but that was a waste of money as there was little or no information about most of the collection - at least not in English.Finally, every single member of staff we encountered was rude and unhelpful. Few were willing to speak to us in English, and the people in the rooms were jobsworths, behaving as though they were doing us a favour by letting us see the things we'd paid handsomely to see. One kept chasing me down to tell me not to use flash when I hadn't been. And the cloakroom staff we just as bad - huffing and sighing as if taking bags wasn't part of their job description. And the staff were getting their own coats on half an hour before it even closed!It's a lovely building, but the information about the collection is poor and the customer service non-existent.

Wow!. From the moment you walk into the square in front of the palace the hairs on the back of your neck prickle. The place simply oozes atmosphere and the sense that major events in history took place here.Once inside, the building itself and the art collection are incredible. I could get lost for days inside this place wandering around with my mouth open at the astonishing range and beauty on show.I love the Louvre in Paris but would choose the Hermitage if offered a free trip to one of them, no more needs to be said. It can get very crowded but I was lost in my own little world and did not notice. I highly recommend you visit this place if you get the chance.
Good but.... ...it was crowded with cruise liner groups and the lighting was not terribly good. Otherwise a really impressive collection.

Wow doesn't begin to cover it!. There is no way you can see the entire palace in a few house. Our guide commented that after 2 hours of looking at art, there can become an overload. She showed us about 20 exquisite pieces that I will remember...

Do not miss this. The outside looked amazing & the inside was magical, every room was beautiful, and then the paintings, Leonardo davinci, Rembrandt , Monet , van gough, to name a few. Very large place lots of exploring the different rooms & the staircase was amazing. I'm so glad I went here.

Amazing museum. Recently visited St. Petersburg for two days. The Hermitage is a sight to behold and beautiful art and architecture all around you. It was incredibly crowded but I did go in August at the height of tourist season but it was worth it.

Art Lovers Haven. The depth and breath of the collections of art, furniture and artifacts are astounding. Displays and museum spaces are extremely well done. If possible allow 3 days to explore this incredible museum.
Too crowded. Impressive building and art collection. But plenty of loudy groups and with a staff not interested in helping visitors. (I must confess I dislike crowded museum).

It's all about the time and the timing. Recently visited the glorious Hermitage when in St Petersburg as part of a Holland America cruise. Apparently most cruise ships' passengers visiting St P are allowed special viewing times. This means that you won't see everything - because your time is limited by the Museum Authorities (and remember, this is Russia - not known for flexibility!). But you'll see SO much that you will love it and will probably feel that you could not fully appreciate more. Also, there are so many fewer people allowed in at these sessions, you really can get close to the art you've dreamed of seeing and spend all the time you want enjoying particular pieces. The city itself is beautiful - go there for the Hermitage, the rivers, the palaces, the cathedrals. Don't go for the weather!

Just buy the main ticket --- IN ADVANCE. Def buy the ticket in advance instead of getting it on the spot at the museum (totally bypasses the extremely long line). Also no need to splurge for the two-day pass. You'll see enough just on the basic ticket.

Mind Blowing. Prepare to be amazed when you visit the Hermitage Museum. The buildings are ideal settings for the museum having been the Winter Palace for the Czars. The magnificence and splendour of these are almost beyond words. The ingenuity of man to create beautiful and opulent buildings is amply demonstrated here. Even though the museum is extensive in area it only can display some15% of the artefacts which it has in its possession. The story which you will be told is that if you spend one minute in front of each item it will take you 4 years to see everything.When you go you will be shown around at a furious pace and you will be astounded at what you see from contemporary paintings to masterpieces by Rembrandt and Leonardo. Artefacts from all over the world and items by Faberge and other masters. Do not miss the Gold Room which has some of the most beautiful items you will ever see including a horse blanket made from spun gold and silver thread and decorated by 150,000 yes 150,000 diamonds. Seeing all this wealth and riches goes some way of beginning to understand the foundations of the revolution...with so many people literally starving outside these walls whilst the ruling class dined of gold plates! again though this is another must visit place but allow a lot of time for the trip.

Must Visit. Recently visited The Hermitage whilst at St Petersburg for 2 days on a cruise. Certainly well worth the visit, in spite of the queues. Our guided tour was in the evening after the museum had closed to the public. After the tour we were all entertained by the St Petrsburg Philarmonic Orchestra, this was an experience in itself.The Hermitage is a place that must be visited, photographs and written articles do not do it justice. It is correct when they say it is impossible to see it all in one visit.

Massive museum!. Definitely one of the biggest attractions in St Petersburg. The museum/Palace is very grand with lots of exquisite art work. The museum is crowded with lots of tour groups and it is advisable to visit with a guided tour. If you are a student you get a discount which is quite significant. Well worth the visit!

Our crown jewel. As one of previous reviewers said, the Hermitage is the crown jewel of St Petersburg, and I couldn't agree more! This splendid palace hosts a marvellous collection of art, and one visit is hardly enough. I've been to the Hermitage countless times, and there are still halls and collections I haven't seen... yet :)

Good as Expected. Over the top elegance and great works of art. The highlight of St. Petersburg, Russia. Seeing it with a tour guide was efficient, not only due to skipping long lines, but focus was on the major features of the palace and the art works.
Avoid queues. You can avoid endless queues buying tickets on machines in courtyard. Staff in museum are kind and helpful.

Tips to take into account. Remember to buy the tickets online since the queues are usually too long, we are talking about 1 hour if you are lucky. If you already have your ticket, you will be able to omit the queue. Also, if you visit Hermitage during summer, try to use light clothes because there's absolutely no ventilation inside and you can feel a bit uncomfotable. It's a great museum and you should go there with enough time (that depends on your personal taste).

Great art, serious problems. The art is great, the management has a long way to go. One problem is that photos are permitted. This not only means that flashbulbs are going off everywhere (although flash is forbidden) It means that tourists line up 30 deep in front of the more famous paintings to take photos. You might want to loot at a Divinci, but you can't because a tourist is blocking it with her tablet. and the tourist beside her is holding his tablet at the ready. This museum desperately needs a no-photos rule.Longer hours would help spread the massive crowds.1. You can buy tickets online, in advance, but make sure to do it at least two days ahead, because that is how long your confirmation email will take to arrive.2. You can buy tickets at kiosks in the entrance courtyard, although the lines may be long3. You can buy them at the ticket booth, but the lines will be very long.Ticket does not allow you to go out for lunch,and return the same day.The cafe in the museum is woefully overcrowded, totally inadequate to the crowd.The restrooms are terribly inadequate, and not kept in repair.The app you can download is merely a map with room numbers and less info than the fold-out map they offer. The art is magnificent. But you knew that.
Soo much...Soo Rich...Soo Beautiful. So much to do and see and never enough time. This can be a little overwhelming, but worth the visit.

Excellent but crowded. There's no way to avoid the crowds at the Hermitage, so just go with it. Honestly, I found the collection not really equal to world's best but the setting more than makes up for that. That said, yes, they have a Leonardo and at least one of just about anybody else you can name, so the collection is certainly not shabby. But the Winter Palace is just incredible. You really don't know where to look. A must-see in St. Petersburg. And I'll say this for the Russians, particularly Catherine the Great, they paid for each work of art - they didn't steal any of it.

This is a must see. St. Petersburg has an embarrassment of monumental riches. The hermitage is the crown jewel. Arguably, the best museum in the world. Unless you are among. The rich and famous the best way to visit is with a guided tour. The tours usually last a little over two hours. To carefully review everything would take a visit lasting years. The highlights making he visit a must do...the golden peacock clock, the reconstructed amber room and Rembrandt's the return of the prodigal. To see that masterpiece is worth the time, the crowds and all the bother. Beware of pickpockets at all times....even in the museum.

State Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace. This is one of the most beautiful building in Europe walk around the main square and you could even have you picture taken with people dressed up in the 17th century clothing but is is a very nice peaceful spot in St Petersburg.

We needed much longer. We visited the Hermitage as part of an organised tour which meant we had limited time there. The artefacts are wonderful,but we were pleased to have a guide to clarify the many questions we had. The ceilings alone needed time in which to gaze at them because they are so ornate. This is definitely a must if you are in ST Petersburg
A huge museum. It is a very extensive museum, would take several days to thoroughly explore. Had a quide that gave us the best of.

Wow, impressive building and art for everyone.... I was looking forward to this trip, which I recently did whilst cruising and so the place was opened up to us on a Monday (usually its shut), despite this it was really crowded, so I cannot imagine what it would be like in peak season...........I think that there is something for everyone here though, and the rooms themselves in the old part with the great chandeliers are amazing to look at, no wonder the royals lived here along time ago!There's a little bit of everything for everyone and we started with the Italian artworks, including Da Vinci, the Michelangelo was not open on the day itself. Then we toured the Dutch rooms, Rembrant, French rooms and Impressionist rooms including Monet, Pissaro, Van Gogh, Gaughin, Picasso etc......would recommend reading about it before going though as due to the large crowds you really need to keep your eyes open for all the famous paintings otherwise you could easily miss them. The hanging gardens on top of the palace roof are lovely as well so keep your eyes peeled for great views of these and of the River Neva as you wander between the entire buildings of the Hermitage!Apparently you need to be careful of pickpockets who operate inside the place, but we were fortunate as the place was closed to the general public. There are only toilets on the ground floor when you enter the building.
CHECK OPENING DAYS. brilliant - but take care to check opening days and times before planning your time in this incredibly beautiful city!
Wonderful Museum. At least a day must be spend in here! It is hot and the cafe isn't worth the queuing But the rooms and the pictures are worth seeing

Fabulous. This was the main reason we came to St Petersburg and we were not let down. Some tips: 1. Buy your tickets online first, print out the receipt and get in the short queue between the arches to collect your ticket. This then allows you to go to the front of the big entrance queue. This will save you time and patience. 2. Make sure your ticket includes use of your camera if you want to take photos as otherwise you need to check it in the cloakroom. 3. Ensure you are fully hydrated because you cannot take in water and after a number of hours you will need it. We were told there was a cafe inside yet, due to lack of observation skills or art overload we could not find it. 4. It is closed on Mondays. 5. If you are not going on a tour get a map from the audio desk just up the main flight of stairs when you enter. The map is great and really helped us - obviously didn't help us find the cafe though. The rooms, art, sculpture, building and even the gift shop were all fantastic. If you are a photographic fanatic leave your tripod at home your 1000 lenses in their bags at the hotel bring a camera with a telescopic lens that takes good photos without a flash and enjoy the moment and commit it to memory as your photos will do less justice than your memory.

One of the world's great museums. An outstanding collection of art from all over the world, filling many rooms of Peter the Great's massive Winter Palace. Make sure to pay attention to the details of the palace as well as the art. Make sure to save time and buy your ticket online in advance if you are not part of a group. Tour group crowds in the summer make it a challenge to see some of the art. My strategy was to start on the top floor with the French impressionists, since not all of the tour groups make it up there. When I was here 30 years ago, it was the dead of winter in the Soviet Union, and I had this world-class museum almost entirely to myself, so the difference was very significant. Don't miss the Rembrandts in Room 254.

wonderful!. The palace where is the museum is wonderful - cristal at the windows, baeutifiul worked parquet floors, mirrors, chandeliers.... and their collection is huge...painting, sculptures, photos.... you can stay for a week and you can't see everithing!

Art for every taste. The#1 attraction for a reason! Buy your ticket in advance online, print the email, bring to the little ticket booth near the entrance gate, and skip the long lines. Get a map and plan what you want to see. You can visit for a few hours or all day depending on stamina and interest. There's a little bit of everything from Impressionists to armor, to mummies, to Da Vinci, to jewelry - and on and on.If possible, do research before you arrive to determine your "must see" list. The museum is huge and covers multiple buildings, so best to do a wing or floor at a time.

Must see. The primary reason to visit St Pete. Otherwise, pretty drab buildings and miserable people. But this museum is something special. Just dont piss off the KGB refugees sitting in each room with their signature frowns. You woukd swear they were sent from Hollywood's Central Casting.

Great works badly cared for . While the art is impressive how the Heritage takes care of them is appalling. Windows that are open letting in outside air, smog and dampness is a travesty. These works of art deserve better.The employees could care less if people used flash photoraphy on all the great works of Rembrant, Da Vinci, Monet, Picasso and others. Try that in the Louvre.

Awesome Details. A must see after dying. Never seen something similar, you will see a lot of superfluous excess in the building itself, the decoration and the displayed pieces of course. Since is a top attraction there a lot of tourists and all of the rooms and entrance is very crowded, so be patient.
very unique rooms, crazy amount of people. I've been here twice, both times impressed, but both times crazy with tourists (wkd worst, try to avoid)

What a building(s)!. Pay attention to the remarkable architecture, mouldings, gilt, windows.....as you walk through the 5 buildings. Take note of the collections of Impressionist paintings, etc but spend most of your time on the building.

The Hermitage is the Pearl of St Petersburg. This stunning building of 1100 rooms astonished us even though only 5% of the enormous collection is on view at any one time. To see such glorious art in such a beautiful palace was the highlight of our trip to St Petersburg. Go as early as possible with a pre-booked ticket or with a group.

Very impressive - must see.. I didn't know much about the Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace before I got to St. Petersburg, but wow was I amazed. This is the second largest museum in the world (the Louvre is the first) and it is spectacular. The opulence of palace and art collection is incredible. There are millions of items, so you really could spend at least a full day here. The palace itself is beautiful from both the outside and inside. From the outside the beauty and size is jaw-dropping. Once you get inside and walk up the main staircase you can really feel the essence of the time period and history in which this palace was built. Every room is perfectly detailed with gold and the works of art from the greats (Monet, Rembrandt, Van Gogh, Renoir, Degas, etc.) is incredible.This is a must see in St. Petersburg. Talk the time, get a guided tour so you know what you are looking at and enjoy this masterpiece. If you love art, history or architecture you will love this museum and palace.

Interesting but.... This is a palace turned museum and while it is very beautiful and has a vast collection of art, sculpture etc. it is very similar to many other history museums and really just made me think about how wonderful the Louve is. There are a couple of impressive items in the palace to include a giant mechanized clock with moving birds including a peacock that moves around. I would say that was easily the highlight of the collection.
Amazing Busy. Go later queues forever it closes at six in the evening. The art is out of this world you need to spend a few hours here to really appreciate it.

What can be said that hasn't already been said?. Unbelievable. Overwhelming. Unfortunately when we were there it was high summer and there were thousands of people visiting. There were also a number of cruise ships in the Harbour so incredibly crowded. Do an organized tour. Remarkable.
Overwhelming. Read a bit before you go. It may help to have some history knowledge but you can certainly learn as you go.

Stupendous!!. Wow! I have never struggled so hard to concentrate on stunning art when assailed by stunning architecture, nor struggled so hard to concentrate on stunning architecture when assailed by stunning art. The Hermitage is mind blowing. You could spend days there...BUT...you can't, because you cannot take food or water in (that's right, no bottled water or drinks of any kind) AND there is no food or drink available inside AND its really hot and incredibly crowded in parts, so about the most you can seriously manage if you are fit, well-fed and well hydrated when you start is about 4 hours, before you have to leave for refreshments AND there are no pass-outs, so once you leave you will need to buy another ticket if you want to go back in. I think this must be some form of Russian moderation mechanism, so you don't get too overwhelmed with culture and/or don't enjoy yourself too much. It compares terribly with the Lourve, where you can break at lunchtime for a great restaurant meal in the museum and then continue in the afternoon on the same ticket. But then you can probably summarise the Russian versus the French character right there.Perhaps another example of it is the curation, which is puzzling sometimes. In some of the huge ballrooms which can easily accommodate thousands of people they have some relatively obscure works, while all of the amazing collection of French artists - Monet, Renoir, Gaugin, Pisarro, Rodin etc etc - which are extremely popular, are squeezed into a suite of relatively small rooms on the third floor, which become crowded like the toilets at a football game when the tour groups get there. Again, it's probably just the Russian way and not surprising they relegate the French artists to such conditions!Don't let the imposed hardships put you off, in a way it adds to the intensity of the experience. The Hermitage is simply one of the top collections in the world and must be seen to be believed. The Winter Palace which houses it is also quite stunning. Make sure you pre-order your tickets on-line, as this allows you to walk past the unbelievably long queues and straight in. I simply can't understand why everyone doesn't do this. there is a short queue at the little kiosk after the entrance gate, clearly marked "Internet Ticket Pick-up" (or similar) in English, where you collect your ticket. This queue moves fast because half the people in in think it is the queue to buy a ticket and when they find it isn't they go away. pre-booking the ticket also allows you to take photos without extra charge, but not in the temporary exhibits. You need to put large bags (backpacks) in one of the free cloakrooms before going through security (where they take your water away!).So, a unique experience and a uniquely Russian experience. The Hermitage is one of the best cultural experiences of my life; totally worthwhile and completely mind blowing. More than 4 hours might just be too much anyway.
If you like art.... This huge art museum has some amazing art work by all artists. I rate it one of the best outside of Paris.

Evening of Classical Music At The Hermitage. If one is in St. Petersburg, Russia, there is no question that one must visit The Hermitage. What people might not know is that there is a private tour in the evening of small rooms in the museum, and then a concert in one of the smaller rooms filled with paintings and sculptures. The orchestra is wonderful. The choice of music was perfect. What a treat!

A MUST VISIT. one of the best places to visit in St Petersburg. to avoid the long ques book your admission ticket online so you can exchange it at the entry with the entry ticket. it is very important that you take a site map so you can know which sector are you in and which next sector you would prefer to visit

Stunning...amazing and incredible!!!. This is the most incredible museum/art gallery we have ever visited. It is simply stunning!!! After 3 hours we had only seen a mere snippet of what this incredible museum has to offer. If you go to nothing else in St.Petersburg, visit this stunning collection of art. We would come back to this amazing city just to revisit the Hermitage. However, if you look at each exhibit for just 1 minute it would take you 8 years to see them all. In the meantime, find a good guide and see as much as you can. Fabulous!!!

A must see. This is a must see if you go to st petersburg. You really need to go with a guide and see if you can get in early before the crowds. If you enjoy beauty and history then this museum is a must see. You could spend a week here.
Breathtaking!. The beauty and splendour. Wish I could have lived there. Our guide Olga has an incredible knowledge and made our visit very special.

Huge collection. Located in the banks of the Neva River, in a beautiful palace. We bought tickets in the same day without trouble. as you enter the gate, there´re a few tkt machines on your left, very easy to work. Unfortunately, like all places in Russia, there´s no sign whatsoever in english. Save a few hours to explore the State Hermitage Museum, you won´t regret. There´s no air condition inside, the cafeteria is in first floor, and the masterpieces , like Van Gogh, Monet, Matisse , are in the third floor. Don´t forget to get a map at the entrance. The rooms numbers are at the top of the doors. If you like museums , don´t miss it.

Go early & in off season to avoid crowds. The Hermitage is not only a treasure of Russia but also the world. Since it is so famous, the crowds and collection can be overwhelming. Try to get to the museums either right when they open or late in the afternoon. A private tour is nice but expensive. I've gone to Saint Petersburg in August, March, and the winter months. One of the best times for me has been going in March. The Hermitage and other museums aren't as crowded and since it is off season, prices are lower.

A cache of art treasures.. I must say that even I was impressed by all the treasures held within the Hermitage although the ladies who guard each room were downright forbidding. Smiles are free, ladies!

Can't miss this. This is a must when visiting St. Petersburg, even if you are not a big art buff. The building itself was a palace and is beautiful inside. If possible, try to avoid July and August as it is very crowded.

Very crowded but some interesting sights. Lots of people pushing & shoving. Tour group guides keep their groups moving often at the expense of other visitors. English audio didn't work for the rooms - staff on the desk didn't seem to care. Still, some greast sights to see. Allow at least 4 hours (if you can move quickly)

Crowded, no AC, no decent infos. I was desappointed with this attraction not because of the museum itself, which is wonderful with lots of art displays, but with their set up. What was supposed to be an enjoyable day in St Petersburg turned out to be a very tiring and annoying day. Museum was packed with people, it was hot inside, no ventilation, no good info on how to move around, grumpy old ladies working in the museum making it even harder for us to try to enjoy the visit. At the end we just wanted to leave and did not get to see what we planned. Best would be to avoid going there during the summer.

Lots to see. Allow yourself a lot of time to see everything thats inside. Exhibitions are devided by themes, they spread across 5 buildings, and are well worth seeing. Make sure ask for a map when entering.
Louvre is better. Yes, it's big, but we feel that the Louvre is bigger in all definitions of that word (surface, km, number of pieces on view,...) and - much more important: better!

A Highlight. An after hours tour when closed to the public was absolutely marvelous. To explore the largest art collection in the world without any crowds, roaming the galleries, halls, exhibits, it was incredible. The art from prehistoric to contemporary, from Russia to the Far East, in such an amazing historical structure, including the Winter Palace was ever so grand. We enjoyed the assembled art collection, the paintings, jewerly, the neoclassical marble sculptures, the halls and decorative art plus the Peacock Clock, all in one of the oldest and largest musuems in the world, it was definitely a highlight of our trip.

Beautiful palace, great art. This is a grand old palace with beautiful stately rooms and filled with history. The works of art displayed in the museum are treasures and very impressive. Beware the museum is huge and after three hours we were winded and left so be sure to select the hilights that you are interested in and focus on them. Museum was very crowded so I suggest you buy tickets in advance. We went with a tour guide who got us tickets so we avoid the lines.

Mind blowing. As anyone reading this probably knows, The Hermitage is one of the great museums of the world. Millions of curated pieces, including priceless masterworks, pack a complex comprised of multiple conjoined buildings. I am not an art expert (but I have stayed at a Holiday Inn Express) and had trouble keeping everything straight. Still, our guide helped immensely as she described and explained what we were seeing. For visitors with mere hours to spend, a guide is an absolute necessity. Much of the museum complex is grand, but parts are pretty bland and borderline shabby. This really doesn't detract much from the overall impact of this fantastic collection. If at all possible, make sure your tour provides entry before standard public hours. Viewing hundreds (thousands?) of painting was much easier and more pleasurable before the crowds built later in the day.On balance, this is a "must see" attraction for just about any visitor to SPB

Amazing Collections. You can spend days in this museum, but I suggest you check out their virtual online tour to see what inerests you beforehand, so you dont get overwhelmed! The peacock clock for me was the top contender and it is stunning to see what technology they had a couple of centuries ago to move all these animals in their natural form! Its an out of this world experience! You have to see it to believe it!

Excellent museum. The State Hermitage is an excellent museum, the best way to see it all is to rent an electronic guide. The museum includes paintings of the greatest painters and other special items, no doubt Hermitage is one of the world's great museums.

Amazing. A visit to the Hermitage on a short stay is only a taster for longer visits in the future, the size of the place is enormous and it is filled with so many exhibits of all kinds to keep any visitor busy for months on end. Don't be put off though even a short visit will take your breath away. The building it's self is magnificent and the contents of the many rooms are joy to behold. Try to do a little research before you go to help guide you to your own particular interests and get there early in the morning when for an hour or so the place is reasonably quiet before the crowds arrive. If it is possible for you go in the winter when there are far less visitors, but be prepared for sub zero temperatures. It is impossible to single out any particular room to visit as they all have their own unique character but a visit here will leave you wanting to return for more.

Overwhelming Art & Architecture but Crowded. The Hermitage and Winter Palace are--justifiably--highlights of a St. Petersburg visit. The Palace is huge and each room is chock full of items to see (e,g., the Peacock clock) as well as a variety of world-famous art. The Tsar didn't buy a painting a time; he bought entire collections so there's too much to absorb. Do your homework with a good guidebook or a guide (preferably both) because the crowds make if difficult to tour.

Paintings Galore and other. Anyone wishing to visit will need at least two days to see it all but not spend time at each exhibit, from the furniture to the statues to the paintings, to the Antiques. to the decor of the building itself especially lit up in the night time . Expect to see crowds and lot of them at any given time but early afternoons is better than mornings. If you visit St. Petersburg the winter palace/Hermitage museum is a must see and it is in the center of the city on the square.

As beautiful as promised. Even if you don't like art, it is worth visiting just to see the interior of the building. The greatest draw back is it is so big. You have to decide you can only see so much.

I feel like a heathan but wouldn't go again. It did not really appeal to my wife and I's personal taste but admission was included as part of our guided tour. Yes it is massive and yes it has some famous paintings and yes we both like art galleries but neither of us are keen on the older darker paintings. The rooms we went in to seemed to have all these, as well as many, many other visitors. The rooms were stylish but nothing special to us. We wouldn't have gone in if we were on our own and I wouldn't go in again just not my cup of tea!

The best way to see St.Petersburg. Just returned from a Baltic Cruise which stopped for three days in St. Petersburg. We booked a three-day tour with Red October (in New York). Everything was seamless - picking us up at the ship and returning, preparing the documents for us, etc. The BEST part was that we had a marvelous guide named Dmitry. His English was perfect and he was so knowledgeable, articulate, and had a great sense of humor. We would highly recomment Red October as a tour company and if you can get Dmitry you will be getting an excellent tour.

A Decade Won't be Enough. With 3 million artifacts our guide said that spending only 1 minute per would mean 11 years at the museum. While that maybe a bit long the ½ day we spend here was not nearly enough. If you love history the museum is a former palace and if you love art then prepared to be amazed. Even with our limited time we benefited from taking a guided tour. Friend who had been to the Hermitage, but wandered themselves, did not gleam nearly as much as we did with a guide. Enjoy however much time you have here.
Jaw dropping. Amazing building , amazing art!!!Hoards of people though, not sure if there would ever be a quiet time though

What a treasure trove!. Loved the Hermitage! I was afraid that we wouldn't see everything which we wanted to, since we were traveling with two teens, but we were there practically the whole day, and they were just as fascinated as we were! An absolute treasure trove and a must on your trip to St. Pete's...
Amazing. Definitely recommend a visit here for at least a day. Wish we had more time. The upper floors are less crowded and house most of the European artists. A must see!

Be sure to pre-book the 2 day ticket.. We booked the two day ticket thinking we would spend a couple of hours there on two separate days. As it turned out we were happy to spend far longer there each day. The museum is fascinating. The amount of works by extremely famous artists is mind-boggling. And the building itself is exquisite. The museum is huge so make sure you take a free map. And only bring a small bag or you will be forced to use the cloakroom. The shops are lovely and good value. However there was only one small cafe with premade sandwiches and chocolate bars. The museum is missing a trick by not providing better restaurant facilities. A wider postcard selection would be good too. I would also have welcomed more information on the history of the building and some basic history of art information beside painting...perhaps in a similar manner to the Rijks museum in Amsterdam.

Would be fantastic without so many people. Arrived at 10.30am (opening time on a Sunday) to crowds of people, most on tours. There were long queues at ticket offices but tickets are easy enough and quick to get via self service machine. R400 each plus R200 for use of cameras (although this was never checked). These are to the right as you walk in through the courtyard. Once in the building, there are again, long queues waiting to get into specific parts of the palace. Advise heading left to a less congested entrance. Backpacks have to be handed over. There were only a few people going in this way and we were soon able to get upstairs and more or less straight into the malachite room (AMAZING) and other state rooms. You have to do a bit of creative thinking to avoid the swathes of tours that can take over! Be aware that without a map, it is hard to find your way back to the entrance! 2 hours was plenty for us but we did none of the art, just furniture and various rooms. The Jordan staircase is impressive, but again, heaving with people!

Who's into art?. Our group had just 2 hrs at this venue.......it should have been 10 at least......and we are not really into art, Before I could check out the art pieces on display, the building is quite exquisite in itself. Then of course there are quite unique art pices on display. We were very fortunate to have an art lover as our local guide Igor. We were part of a Cosmos tour group - and he was able to take us to specific rooms to view the original art works of Da Vinci, Rembrandt, Picasso , the exquisite and rare peacock clock, and of course the many many original canvanses of Russias leaders and families over centuries. But then there was much more....with sculptures, costumes, jewelkery , ceremics......we just didn't have time to explore! I would definately recommend to pre- book and with a guide and allow as much time as is available.

As good as its reputation. spent a couple hours with tour guide Nadya from TJ travel.made the trip very informative and enjoyable ,one could spend hours in there but with well informed guide that can direct you through the highlights, paintings ,some displays did not seem well displayed and the Russians seem to have redone the interiors very gaudily takes away the focus from the art itself.It is probably the first thing you want to see if you have only few hours in town.Go with a pain guide to avoid long wait lines.

#1 St. Petersburg Museum. So much to see, so little time. If you can name a master artist, their work ill be here. We had 3-hours here but you just scratch the surface and to think, just like the Smithsonian Museum in DC only a small % of the collection is on display.

Excellent. Unbelievable building full of equally unbelievable artefacts. Can't believe you could ever see all of them. Difficult to find your way around without a guide. It is a good idea to book your tickets on the Internet and collect them at the hermitage rather than queue on the day. Suggest you buy a two day pass and try to plan your route beforehand.

So much to see! You will certainly need more than one day to fully appreciate.. I am so glad that we had the opportunity to visit the Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace whilst in St Petersburg! My only regret is that we didn't have more time as there are still areas we did not see!From paintings, sculptures, mosaics and prints to ceramics, costumes and jewellery, there is sure to be something that sparks an interest with most people!We were lucky enough to admire beautiful works by Vincent Van Gogh, Leonardo da Vinci, Henri Matisse and Claude Monet to name but a few!If you decide to go, I would recommend buying the early entry tickets as once the museum is fully open, it can become very crowded. We were lucky that we had early entry tickets so we were able to browse before many other people came in.All in all, a fantastic day with lots of great photographic opportunities.

Outstanding. We were fortunate to visit early in the day and found that for the first two hours that the Hermitage was not too crowded. Made more enjoyable by having a guide who ensured that we saw all the paintings and sculptures that we wanted and provided information about the rooms and art works.
Must see the Hermitage. A must in San Petesburg is to visit the collections of the Impressionist at the Hermitage for more than 1 hour. usually the tous go fast and dont allow you plenty of time.

Deserves five stars, no matter what. Hermitage and Winter Palace are 'hors categorie'. Even if you don't have a full day to visit, even though the palace could use quite a bit of renovation, even though some of the interiors are hugely overdone, even though not all art collections are that great, even though some of the finest art is horribly exhibited (like Rembrandt's Prodigal Son, which is on display next to an open window), even when the lines are long and the crowds are pushing: don't hesitate, buy a ticket and go!

Unforgetable. A must see. One day is not enough because of the richness of the museum. there is no enough words to describe the beauty of the exterior and interior.If you pass by St-Petersburg for a short visit, program at least a day to visit the Hermitage.I can provide a helpful hint to visitors. The line is very long to get to the cashier. To cut the wait, there is an automatic ticket machine at the very entrance under the arch. Buy your tickets there so you do not have to wait for an hour to get to the cashier.
Awesome. An absolute must see. The Hermitage is packed full of art and treasures. Really can't do it justice in 2 hours but you need a lot of energy if you want to see more.

Wow. The setting of this museum is spectacular; on the river with marble, crystal and gilding galore. The paintings, sculptures and other precious pieces of art compete with the palace for the wow factor.

True artistic treasure. One advice that I can give is that to go on Wednesdays as the museum closes at 9pm instead of 6pm and it is better to go in the afternoon when there is less people as the big tour groups usually goes there before lunch as their first stop of the day

Amazing Place. This is full of so many beautiful art woks and furniture. The library is especially amazing. It is a beautiful building as well. Make sure you leave an entire day to see it however and if you go in summer like we did drinks lots of water before you go in because there is no air con and no water allowed inside. Its very hot.

More about the hype. To say I've been is great.I loved the temporary Lissitzky exhibition, Rembrandt's Prodigal son and others such as Monet, Rubens, etc. Pleased to see some Russian rooms, Greek artefacts and so on too.We'd pre-bought tickets on line (a reasonable choice to buy 2 days for not a lot more- good to have the choice) so we could by pass several hundreds of people.Over crowded throughout- unlike any British museum I've experienced.Tours take up so much space that you could be waiting a while to get through a smaller door.Not very helpful or polite attendants.Audio guides unavailable - told AFTER queuing due to low batteries so had to go elsewhere. Poor signage.Difficult to know where to move floors.Cafe not great but at least the cashiers were happy and efficient:)Free wifi available- dont pay- that's just for computers. A day enough for me (6h) although could've done it in less time without the ridiculous numbers of people.

Truly awesome. Obviously one of the best museums in the world. Try to avoid the crowds if possible. It can become very hot. Don't miss the Impressionists on the third floor and if you're into jewellery, book a tour of the Treasure Gallery before you leave home. It's worth every penny.
Beautiful. This museum was amazing. It is worth seeing while visiting St. Petersburg. The winter palace is beautiful.

Czars palaces. After seeing them, no wonder they had a revolution. Opulence is a gross understatement. Was told if I spent just 1 minute looking at each painting in Hermitage, would take me 3 years to complete.

Prepare to be overhwelmed!. You could spend weeks going through the rooms of the Hermitage. WE only had 2 hours and saw as much as we could with a fairly steady pace of walking. Beware of pickpockets!

World-class Gallery and Palace. We only had 2 hours to visit as part of a St. Petersburg Grand Tour. In truth, only 2 full days might have done the Hermitage exhibits justice. We will go back for more.

definitely try to include a guided tour. An incredible facility as well as the artwork it houses. Would definitely recommend having a guided tour to not miss some of the special elements in the building itself and the masterpieces.

Has become more of an arts exhibit than that of the palace itself. As with many other similar museums and palaces in Russia you have to pay extra for the right to take photos inside. You cannot bring in large bags, backpacks food or water into the museum, but free attended locker-rooms are provided for this.Make sure you visit as soon as it opens as the queue can be over an hour long even half an hour after opening. You'll need a whole day to see even just a part of the museum. We split up our time there between the rooms we actually wanted to see and simply walked through the rest. Several days if not weeks would be needed to see it all, especially in more detail.There was very little signage around the museum outside of a few signs in Russian and the odd brief paragraph in English. I'd recommend paying for an audio-guide if you're interested in more detailed information about the different rooms of the palace.I have visited it several times and on the most recent visit found the museum becoming more of a host to art exhibits (which cannot be photographed even with the purchased permit) than a display of the luxury of Imperial Russia. I was more interested in the history of Russia/St. Petersburg and beauty and opulence of the palace and its room than imported paintings, so I was quite disappointed in this respect.

breathtaking collection.. Amazing collection. I spent 2 days slowly going through the museum and still probably only saw about a half of the magnificent collection.Impressive impressionist and french modern collection if not housed in a rather less impressive floor of the building. Couldn't believe that they open the windows to air the rooms with -20 degrees snow outside...The cafe and internet areas need considerable customer service lessons and the booking for the gold and diamond room should be clearer, but otherwise without doubt the best art museum in the world.
Wonderful Palace. A remarkable place to visit. It is very large and there is so much to see.It is amazing. One draw back is there is one cafe inside which gets very crowded and the service is slow.

Magnificent!. What can I say? The ticket worth its money! I discovered the beauty and nobility of old Russian palace. One pleasant detail: you should not wear that ugly museum shoes, just do not wear highheels. For visiting some of the halls and filming you will have to pay app.15 $ The souvenirs are very expencive.The place is a masterpiece. You definitely should visit it.
It's everything you've ever heard about. The Hermitage is a must see if you like art, history, and architecture. It's impossible to separate the three in this facility. You could spend days here.
Beautiful. Just a wonderful example of beautiful architecture. Beautifully furnished with period antiques. Splendid service from the docents and willingness to answer any questions.
Amazing!. Get your entry tickets from ticket machine right at the left as soon as you enter through the gate, otherwise you wait for an 45 min to get tickets

Overwhelming amount to see & enjoy.. We had heard how extensive and important the art collection here is, but hadn't understood, before visiting, that the "museum" is also a gorgeous palace. We spent 6 hours here with our marvelous private guide, and enjoyed every moment!
Crowded but worth it. AMAKatrina ship delivered us by hydrofoil to the dock across the street so access was easy. Lots of climbing and walking but very interesting.

Unbelievable!. We fortunatly were with Mikhale with the DenRus tours. He took us to the front of the line and then to a number of rooms that he felt we would find interesting. Amazing art and decor. Really need more time though than we had available.
2 Day Deluxe Tour. An excellent memorable experience. Do not miss any of the attractions in St. Petersburg. Experience a performance if you have an overnight stay.

a must for all visitors. If you are in Petersburg, visit this place full of historic paintings, objects and sculptures. a great attraction and worth to spend at least 3 - 4 hours. The best is to do it with a private guide, so you have immediatly access, no waiting.
The Hermitage. Allow a few hours, get there EARLY (preferable on a private tour) and understand some of the history in order to appreciate this unique jewel.

Beautiful buildings and gardens. We enjoyed the space to see the exhibits. A most enchanting place to spend a half day. There was only one room my husband could not visit on his scooter because of the lovely, but very old, wooden floor.

Magnificent works of art in an outrageously beautiful building!. Ooooh - the interiors of the rooms and the chandeliers and ceilings were as breathtaking as the art treasures! Even non-art lovers must visit - just for the impact of the architecture! Like The Louvre or the Uffizi, you could easily spend a full week in this museum and still find things to wonder at!Top tip for wheelchair users:Just about every palace and museum in St Petersburg has the most beautifully restored parquet/inlaid floors and paper slippers/shoe covers are required to be worn by all visitors. Having hired a brand new wheelchair on board The Arcadia, we were (very fortunately) allowed to go around The Hermitage because it had new, clean, light coloured wheels. People who had older, black rubber wheels on their chairs were being refused entry. You do not argue with Russian matriarchs working in Museums and Palaces!!! If you plan to visit with a wheelchair, I would highly recommend making some white towelling or cotton wheel covers that can be slipped on to protect the floor from being marked by your wheels.Unless you are semi-ambulant, you will need some help to get the wheelchair up about half a dozen steps but once you have accessed the museum you will be able to use lifts. There may be an alternative side entrance that would not involve steps but please check before your visit.The male staff were very helpful and allowed us to use the goods lift between floors but there appears to be little awareness/consideration for the needs of wheelchair users in St Petersburg. Hope this helps!

Inaccurate pin point position. This pin point is not accurate to where the hermitage and winter palace actually is. It is near the water kind of at the end of the main street nevsky prospect. However once you fet there it is amazing.
Plan. If you want to see the gold and diamond rooms you must make reservations in advance. Cruise ship excursions get most of the early morning slots to plan on the afternoon.
Do you have a few weeks to spare?. Because you'll need it in order to see everything! Don't get lost and find the peacock clock!Amazing, amazing, amazing!
Wonderful museum. This is such a huge museum with many wonderful exhibits. By having a guided tour with T J Travel, you are able to go straight to the important sections without getting lost.
Not to be missed. This vast collection of art is best seen with an experienced guide. It would be impossible to find all of the highlights without a skilled navigator at your side.

A must to visit. There are so many works of art to see here that you can spend days if you look at everything. Hint - go with a tour. They can get you into the museum earlier than the general public and also guide you to the must see pieces.

A must see in Peterburg!. Magical place, but very hot inside, a tip - you can buy tickets from the machines outside and miss the huge queues, really it was very strange - hundreds of people waiting to buy tickets from the cashier desks...

A wonder in St-Petersburg. This is a must-see in St-Petersburg. The place where everything happened from Peter the Great to the last Tsar. You will see incredible rooms, and pieces of art. Don't miss Rembranlt

no conditioning. wonderful museum, but it was really HOT inside. They have no air conditioning and thousands of tourists inside. Be prepared and wear a t shirt. Also good idea to smuggle a bottle of water.

Awesome. The Hermitage is SO vast you almost don't know where to begin. I recommend that you take one of the guided tours. Unless you are an expert in art, they will astonish you with the depth of their knowledge
nice and wonderful. a very nice place and especially the diamond room with all treasures, very easy to visit with the help of people of the msem

Stunning!. Home to one of the world's greatest art collections, you can't help but be impressed with the Hermitage with rooms full of Monets, Gauguins, Rembrandts, Picassos and the occasional Da Vinci and Michelangelo to top it off.In many cases, the rooms themselves were more impressive than the featured artworks, with some of the ceilings particularly awe inspiring.Unless you're a student (free entry regardless of nationality) or Russian (discounted entry), buy your tickets online and save the extraordinarily long queue.You can also buy 2 day passes, but after one full day of masterpiece after masterpiece, I was on sensory overload and ready to leave satisfied!

Overwhelming, crowded but a must see. Large and crowded. If you're there first thing in the morning go right to the third floor and then work your way down. The impressionists won't be as crowded and the second floor will be just as crowded later as it was in the morning. There are multiple entrance points so do just jump in the first big line you see. Also, you're supposedly not allowed to bring in water and food, but we had ours in our bags and even though they went through the scanners, nothing was confiscated so you can save some money by bringing in your own stuff.
So much to see in so little time.. The Hermitage was amazing -- the artwork was incredible. Our guide said if one spent 30 seconds on each item, it would take nine years to see everything!

Awesome, breath-taking..... So much to see, so little time. I would go back again! It would take weeks to see every single item in The Hermitage. The Winter Palace is amazing.
The number of tourists are crazy, but all quite well managed.

Very Interesting But Exhausting!. When visiting St Petersburg this is an absolute must to see but there is far to much to see in one visit. It is also very hot because there is no air conditioning so wear cool clothes in summer.There is an amazing collection of paintings and the building itself is beautiful.
Very Good. I'm not that interested in art but they had collections of a wide range of different paintings and styles from the worlds most famous artists.
Do not miss this. If you do not spend the extra money to get a guide you will miss out on a great experience. Do not get a recorded tour. Get a live guide who will take you through. 2-3 hours

Too much, too jumbled, too Soviet. One of the difficulties with the Hermitage is that it is so jampacked with paintings and works of art that are, quite simply and even to the untrained eye, not of museum quality. The lighting is disastrous, explanations pathetic and the place is stuck in the dark ages. It requires a go-ahead Director with modern ideas to bring it forward. Close it for 10 years, send the many masterpieces elsewhere and bring the place up to scratch.
we will definitely return. The Hermitage is now my favourite museum, beating Vatican Museum and Louvre. We have agreed that we would return in a few years time. Magnificent place!

The Hermitage & Gold Room. Not to be missed, this is an amazing building housing some of the best art in the world. The architecture is amazing and the Gold Room well worth the visit. Suggest though taking water with you as it is very hot during July and August and there is no airconditioning the it takes quite a while and walk to see it all. Lots of crowds but still absolutely worth the effort.

Be selective. Everybody talks about the size and magnitude of the Hermitage. Believe them, its true. If you do not want to walk yourself into a standstill, make sure you know beforehand what your preferences are. You just cannot see nearly everything.We had a guide but did not explain our preferred artists and art movements beforehand. Eventually he focused on the wrong works and the most important works like Impressionists, van Gogh, Picasso etc was greatly neglected and we were rushed through those rooms. A great experience but a bit daunting.

Fabulous experience. We were lucky enough to be with a group that was allowed in the museum on a Monday when it is usually closed. We were able to spend hours there with a very knowledgeable guide. A bonus was that art students are allowed in to copy some of the art and we got to see them doing their work, all through the museum. Don't miss this place!
Superb.. It took two visits to view - in order to appreciate the contents we consider that having a guide on the first visit is essential.

Arrive early. This is a massive place and the crowds can become uncomfortable, so arrive early. The place is heavily heated, so it does become really hot!! Check you bags in at the cloak room on arrival.

The art is wonderful: don't forget to look at the rooms !. The depth and breadth of art is unequalled anywhere in the world and so is the setting. It is crowded but there is so much to see that you can find yourself in a room alone - especially if you are not on a tour.We prebought 2 day tickets off the hermitage website US$25 each. No queueing to get in and no stress to see it all in one hit.The building has no aircon so it can get warm.If you have the luxury of time wander at ypur leisure. For most its a once in lifetime experienxe and no other art gallery in the world is even close to this. You can take photos but no backpacks allowed.

Magnificent but too large to see in a day. This museum-palace is world renown for the fecundity of its collection of art, furniture, and luxury. My only complaint is that the collection is far too extensive to be seen in even an entire day.
HERMITAGE MUSEUM. We prepared to do a lot of walking on this tour - 5kms in fact but very informative and overwhelming

Worth it!. Amazing to see so many works of art in one place! they have an extensive Impressionism collection that you must see! if on a tour be sure to tell your guide so they will give you more time in those galleries!
fabulous collection. I liked the fact that the collection is actually in a Palace and when we were there, there was a special exhibit of Caravaggio's
best in the world. This is the greatest museum in the world, considering the setting and the art combined. And I am a museum curator.

Hermitage. Very crowded. But happy I saw it. Our guide supplied us with audio tours and she was very organized getting us around to the highlights in the museum and her account of each piece was excellent.

Can't be missed. The Hermitage is amazing. It would take days to see the entire museum. Do not miss this. It is one of the most wonderful museums in the world. The art is beautiful, and the history is fascinating.

Not much to add. That this is one of the most impressive museums in the world is not a secret. You need considerable stamina to explore it, one day will not suffice, but you can take your pick from what are your favorites.Only drawback: hordes of cruise tourists that tend to clog in front of some masterpieces everybody is obliged to see (and make a photograph).If you are not part of a group, order tickets by Internet, otherwise you will end up in a long line.
4 Aussies in St Petersbugh. Quality and extent of priceless treasures. Works by Leonardo Da Vinci, Rubens, Rembrandt, Monet, Picasso, Matisse and Van Gogh to name a few.
Amazing treasures. Loved the impressionist paintings, royal carriages, jewels etc. lots of walking and steps but well worth it.

Hermitage a Must. It was a simply amazing museum. The bulding itself is incredible and there was an amazing amount of artwork to rival any museum in the world. We did not spend long enough. I would visit over 2 days and spend 3-4 hours each day.

Hermitage Museum Art. The Hermitage Museum is a walking intensive venue. It would take weeks to tour the entire museum. We were on a 2.5 hour tour and saw a lot of the most popular paintings and sculptures. We really enjoyed the baroque/ gilded staircase and the history of the Romanoff's that was captured in paintings and sculpture. We went with SPB Tours and were pleased with the tour.

stunning. Loved it, too much to see and an artists delight..We need 80 years to see and appreciate this exquisite collection of art in a proper way.. But we got an idea.. We RAN through it in a morning... I mainly looked a little bit more in depth at all the Dutch art masters..I had to pinch myself... YES indeed ..its all real and original...
Hermitage. Be prepared to stand in wonder at the size and grandiosity. Remember , this was a Palace built for one family.

Beautiful but not enough time. Because we were on a two day tour, our time was limited to 1.5 hours for this magnificent museum. It is a must see on any visit to St. Petersburg. The opulence and wealth was extreme and it is clear why the peasants started the revolution. The gold, the crystal chandeliers, the art, the fountains, the courtyards, AMAZING.

A must for lovers of Russian history and art. A magnificent palace where no expense was spared by the Tsars. Now an excellent art gallery with many paintings to suit all taste. We were told it would take several years if someone stood for a minute in front of each painting.

The beauty is overwhelming. The Hermitage is easily one of the most impressive museums I've ever seen. The artwork and treasures are incredible, but truly, the building itself is the highlight. I could have spent hours just exploring the architecture. No visit to St Petersburg is complete without a pilgrimage to the Hermitage.

Hidden Treasures. The audio tour is very good and the color coded map is very good. If there is something specific you want to see, check on where it is located in the museum before you go. I wanted to see paintings from the Hidden Treasure Exhibit and got to see them! It was a dream fulfilled.The museum shop has reasonable prices and nice items.

Must See Romanoff Hangout. You step back in time and embrace the opulence and tragedy of the Romanoff dynasty. The tragic period of 1917 and the slide into communism is brought into focus by visiting this "winter palace" and the focu of Lenins wrath.

Amazing. There are no word to explain the hermitage museum...It's absolutely great and a must when comming to St Petersburg. I just took the audio-guide and it was fine for me, this way you can visit all the rooms you feel like and stay watching the paintings as long as you wish. I would recommend the online tickets for two days ( it's so huge I don't think it's a good idea to try and see all in one day). If you have a small budget, you can visit it for free the first thursday of the month, but you should be prepared since there are very long lines to get in , and because of this, the attention and the information is not the best.
Amazing Museum!. Great Museum - one of the greatest in the world! You can spend days in there. A quick advice: get your ticket online in order to avoid the potential long line-up.

Fantastic. When you enter the Hermitage you do not know whether to look at the artefacts, the floors, the ceilings or the walls. There is just so much to see. The siver galleries are superb with lots of English Silver! The peacock clock is out of this world. The paintings are the best collection probably in the world and the Russians keep buying as much as they want. We went to see the gold galleries in the vault- it is rather alarming to be locked in by one of those doors you see in films about bank robberies where it is a round circular door with a bar which they twist round and round- actually too warm in there but the objects are unbelievable.We have spent 2 whole days there and only saw a tiny amount. Cafe gets full and only takes payment in Roubles. As I walked down the Jordan Staircase I could not help thi nking about the Tsar and Tsarina walking down the stairs in full evening dress. Would love to spend a month there.
A first class museum. Too crowded- but the treasures of art are wonderfulThere is a great variety of periods and styles so everyone can find something to enjoy

My favorite is the third floor. The museum's collection is huge, but recommend keeping forces to the third floor, which contains the famous paintings by French Impressionists. Now, when I go to the Hermitage, is immediately sent to the third floor.
Wonderful, even if you don't have extensive art knowledge. The Hermitage is amazing. It is so huge and so much to take in. The art work starts to grow on you and you become more of a fan than ever.

An impressive museum. You have to marvel at the art works of "the great masters" and there are plenty of them represented here. There is so much to see that it is a bit overwhelming. We found it better to go for a few hours over a couple of days than to try to see it all in be day.

Fabulous!. Get an interpretor asap! then spend two days here! i love it,, do not miss the winter palace, where the Russian revolution started with a shot from the battle ship on the fontanka river just in front.

Not enough time. Thanks to SBP Tours our group was admitted before the general public had access, so we could look at some of the wonderful art collections. When we left after about two hours we saw the long lines waiting to be admitted.
Incredible treasures!. Beautiful museum, rivaling the best in the world. Incredible history. Well laid out. Work from Degas to Renoir, Van Gogh and many others.
Huge museum. Greatest collection of treasures! Lots of people because it's the one of the biggest Russian museums. Take several hours to spend there

Crowds and bureaucracy overwhelm art. Visited Hermitage Museum twice recently, as part of a cruise visit to St Petersburg. I had been before on two occasions 3 years ago and I could vaguely remember the place. Unfortunately the overwhelming numbers of visitors and the administration somewhat dampen the pleasure of seeing some of the world's greatest art. Visiting is strictly controlled but the sheer numbers of foreign and Russion visitors made the experience uncomfortable. July weather was hot and sultry and there appeared to be no proper air conditioning in the vast complex of the Winter Palace that holds the Hermitage museum. I question whether this is ideal for the works of art on display, and particularly, the priceless paintings.One is not allowed to photograph inside without a permit, which costs 4 euros /5 US dollars. But it is better to buy the illustrated guide books than to try to photograph works on display above the heads of visitors!On the two tours I took with a guide, the same route and 'highlights' were included. This is good if one is not familiar with the works of art or wants a 'quick' run-through of what is important, but for me, knowledgeable on paintings etc, I found it frustrating. Better to wander yourself perhaps and focus on what one likes best.Understandably the show works are the Italian 15th/16 century (Leonardo, Raphael, Titian), the Dutch 17th century (Rembrandt), Flemish (Rubens and Van Dyck) and the Impressionists/post-impressionists and later (Monet, Cezanne, Gauguin, Picasso and Matisse). These last are displayed in hot, crowded rooms on the third floor. There appeared to be no air control and I found the experience distressing - mainly for the paintings!But, having said this, the Hermitage is a must if visiting St Petersburg and it does contain some superb masterpieces.

Take a tour with early admission!. Our tour started before the museum opened in the morning, so we avoided many of the crowds. We also had admission to the Gold Room (Diamond Room?) at the museum, which was amazing!
Hermitage. Fantastic - regardless of how much time you have spent there it wasn't enough. Crowded, especially around the Da Vinci's and Raphael
Stunning experience. Wednesday evenings the hermitage is open til late take this opportunity. Buy a two day ticket on line before going in case you get galleried out

Amazing modern art collection; head straight to the 3rd floor. The Hermitage is something you can't miss in St. Petersburg, so obviously there WILL be crowds of people. If you want a break from all of them, you can head downstairs to the Ancient Egyptian and Greek/Roman sections as well as the 'golden horde' section where we found very few to no people as well as interesting exhibits. The 3rd floor was also a pleasant surprise as the crowds were thinner than the 1st and 2nd floor. They also had an amazing collection of several famous artists. If you like Picasso, Gaugin, Matisee, Renoir, Monet or any other contemporary artists, you will definitely love this floor! Not to be missed!PS: buy your tickets on-line to skip a VERY long line! Also, on-line tickets can be used any day, and anytime, so you can still be flexible with your plans.

Hermitage Museum-Too litttle time. We visited the Museum for two solid days and still it was not enough. Very crowded as the collection itself, we spent two solid days and still it was not enough. The cleanliness and the sumptuous museum are beyond any description. It is a Palace going from one block to the other.We had purrchased the tickets beforehand and the guide was awaiting us on time.Most of the rooms are Golden and overwhelming. You must have enough perseverance in order to enter the gold room because there aqre always queus. Thw chandeliers are great and so are the marble stairs.This is a must museum built on a former pqlace. Walking shoes are inevitable and July is their summer time, so casul dressing is a must.

Too much to take in. Be careful of pickpockets.. The Hermitage museum is a complex of multiple buildings and has three million pieces of art, only a small percentage of which are on display. The crowds are large, the distances between different exhibits chosen by our guide were large. We spent a couple of hours running after our guide, trying to keep the group together, and fighting the crowds. It is a beautiful museum, and well worth a visit. But a lot is lost in the perfunctoriness of the visit. It is a staple of St-Petersburg. It has nothing to envy of the British museum, the Louvre, or the Metropolitan museum of Art.Be very wary of vendors outside the museum. A tourist on our bus had a lens stolen right off his DSLR!

Extraordinary place. We spent two days in the Hermitage, enjoying the building itself, as much as the collections. We avoided the long queue by booking online beforehand, which was a definite plus. Inevitably, the crowds in some sections were dreadful, but the rooms housing such things as the ancient Greek and Roman finds were relatively peaceful.My only negative comment about the museum itself is that some of the information is in Russian only. As a museum of international renown this seems a shame. Where a translation was available, the provenance of the artefacts was sometimes imprecise. The staff in the shops, cafes and galleries were very pleasant and helpful, but the cafe did not really live up to the overall feel of this fantastic museum.

Take a full day. This is one of the greatest museum worldwide. For impressionist lover like me its paradise but i discovered much more. Make sure you visit the Gold Room. Allow you at least 5 hours for this beauty

Beautiful---you can't begin to see it all in a day/. Beauty & art beyond belief. It gives you an understanding of why the revolution took place. The people were starving and the royalty living in opulence.

Lives up to the hype!. Simply a must-see.Some tips:Buy your tickets on line in advanceArrive earlyPick up a paper guide from near the information deskIt is worth paying for the photo permitWe started in the roman section, the rooms are beautiful, and no one else was there, so we were able to enjoy wandering in solitude, a rare experience in this museumThe cafe is tiny and food awful, but there doesn't seem to be any alternative as you can't go out and back in againFirst Thursday of the month is free. We didn't know this but are still glad we had paid in advance as the queues were horrendous.We spent an entire day here. We didn't see everything but felt we saw enough.Focus on the state rooms, coloured in green on the map, and the New Hermitage rooms which are worth visiting for the rooms alone.Be prepared for specific rooms to be closed or works out on loan.Wear comfortable shoes!
Must see museum!!. We only visited for 3 hours - and wish we had more time. The palace as well as the art collection is overwhelming!!

Never Enough Time. The sheer size of the collection is overwhelming. Preview the collections online and then hire a guide to walk you through. The crowds are almost as overwhelming as the collection but persevere, especially through the Gold Room which is only available by timed entry.

Must see. It is a great museum. The general line for the tickets is very long. If you stay at Renaissance or another participating hotel, you could get in by going to ticket booth #6. That's what we did. Otherwise, buy the tickets online to avoid the lines.Also, be prepared for long lines for the toilet and food.
Hermitage. It's Grand. You could spend days in the museum. Classics. Go early or we've heard you can be stuck in mass lines.
The Industrial Revolution its not explained anywhere. We were expecting a nice explanation but didn't find it. An advice, buy your tickets online. Its the same price and you don't have to queue.
A must see. You could spend a week there and still not have seen everything. A knowledgeable guide is essential for maximum enjoyment.

HermitageMuseum and Winter Palace. Both amazing places. The only catch in each case was the long long line to get in. We went with a tour and this shortened the wait but it was still long. I went back to have another look but the lines were too long to make that possible so my advice would be to set aside a full day if you can and see all you want to then..

St Petersburg highlights. We loved the history of the city and the pride the people have for Peter the Great with the building of the city. The Russian Orqthodox churches at times left me speechless, as did the St Peter and Paul fortress. My favourite was Peterhof, with the grandeur of the building and art work, the fountains and gardens.

Not a Hermit in Sight!. The Hermitage is a stunning example of architecture and art. I would recommend that if you love art, you would want to buy a 48 hour pass for this attraction, because it is massive: it is bigger than the British Museum. There is a vast variety of content, from interiors of various ages, through to impressionist and Renaissance art and spectacular Assyrian, Roman, Egyptian and Greek artefacts. There are many stairs and you will want to wear comfortable clothing and shoes! The gift shops have products such as enamelled gilt jewellery and good-quality reproduction paintings: lovely mementos of a trip to St Petersburg!

Very interesting but pretty crowded in June.. We were there in June, there is no airconditing so bring lots of water and dress for summer. June is also a very busy time since everyone seems to be on vacation.
A guide is a must. A guide enhances your time here, expertly moving you through the crowds. We also were able to visit the Diamond room, which was an worthwhile edition.

Awesome tour!!! Lots to see!!. Went to the hermitage as part of our cruise St Petersburg excursion tour so the trip was pretty short. However we were totally blown away by the exhibits and the decor in the museum! It is just amazing to see how the Tzars spend their money! In terms of the exhibits, paintings from Leonardo and Rembrant and the scuptures of Michaelangelo are a must see. Wish we had more time there but absolutely great place to visit!
Must, must see. It's one of the greatest museums of the world and I don't have anything else to say than "If you are in St Petersburg it's a must see"

An Art Lover's Paradise. I entered the Hermitage and literally spent hours walking around, looking at artwork from across the world and different time eras. So areas were, of course, rather crowded, but it was never unbearable. The Winter Palace itself was a work of art, and the overall experience was flat out incredible.

Long, long lines and masses of humanity. If you want to see something of the Hermitage besides the ceilings and exterior, skip this attraction and buy a book or a video. In fact, skip all the great sites of St. Petersburg in the summer. Maybe the only time to see this city is in the dead of winter. The lines are hours long, and ours were outside in the pouring rain. I've never experienced the huge throngs of people that I experienced in these palaces, and I'm a 65 and a New Yorker and have experienced Holland on Easter weekend and the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. The unairconditioned Hermitage in July is exactly like Times Square on New Year's Eve, no exaggeration!

so much to see - so little time. Our guide took an approach of highlighting pieces of art that marked the transition from one form of art/painting to another. Doing so allowed a structure that took in most areas being exhibited without looking at all of the pieces on display (which would take weeks rather than hours).At the same time, the buildings and rooms are equally astounding. Some of the most memorable locations had the least on display, just allowing the room to speak for itself.
