a must while in Saint Petersburg!. If you are fond of arts and culture the HERMITAGE is really the place for you. Notice that you need more than one visit to see some of the collections exposed but still even one time is worth every second spent there.

One of the most interesting museums in the world. The Hermitage is a unique place with amazing collections. One can spans days walking around the spectacular rooms and reviewing the paintings, sculptures and great history. Prepare yourselves for at least 3-4 hours, preferably with a guide to take you around.

Beware of the Lines. Spectacular museum. Our guide said that someone had calculated that if someone took 30 seconds to view each of the 3,000,000 pieces of art and artifacts, it would take 2 1/2 years. I believe it. Way more than can be absorbed in a couple of hours. We used SpB tours and somehow had an easy entrance timed just right. If you go on your own, be prepared for long lines at the entry. A good guide will get you right in, and know how to get you through the crowds in optimal time. Regardless, this museum is a true "must see".

A must-see, but very crowded, very large, and perhaps over-rated.. Many of the great art treasures of the world are here, of course, and its worldwide reputation goes before it. BUT: it is HUGE! It would take years to get around the place if you looked even for just a few seconds at every object. So plan in advance what you want to see and stroll past everything else, glancing as you pass.Be prepared for huge crowds, queues, and slo-o-ow moving coach parties with their own pushy guides. Don't be intimidated by these guides, who will try to move you aside to let their group see whatever you may be looking at - they have no more right to be there than you do!
Amazing Museum. Amazing collection, not to be missed.I have never seen anything like it except maybe for the Lourve in Paris.

Incredible paintings by the masters. The Hermitage has paintings by the masters, and in itself has history, as it was the Czar's Winter Palace. The masters include painters such as Rembrandt, and his famous "Saskia as Flora." There are other treasures there as well.
There were many different paintings from famous artists.. We liked the culture, but there was alot of walking. You better be in decent shaped to walk the Hermitage.

11years non stop viewing !. WOW!!! I was on an organised whistle stop tour of St. Petersburg so no way did I give this amazing museum anywhere near its just desserts. It is fantastic and I feel privileged just to have seen some of its masterpieces . It's very crowded and can get very hot , but, you are encouraged to move on at a reasonable pace so you can enjoy some of the world's greatest artists- how did Canaletto produce that perspective. ??? Walk back and forth a few times-absolutely amazing. Catherine the Great was most certainly a woman of great vision. Thank you for a wonderful experience !
Amazing Hermitage. Awesome! jaw dropping place, don't miss it. Be warned it gets busy! You really need 2 or 3 days to give it justice!
Beautiful. Very large, need some days to really see it but worth a stop. Our tour just hit the highlights but I'm glad it did. The architecture and paintings are amazing.

So crowded, but so worth it!. Visiting this legendary museum became a "bucket list" item for me when the wall came down. Now that I've had the privilege of seeing a fraction of it, I am convinced we'll be back some day soon during the off season....

Wonderful!. Officially it's he most big museum of the world! The main part of it's collection is still not exposed. Well, ot's just necessary to see, the words are useless to explian how magnificient this museum is.

Great Place for an Art Lover. old unique amazing gigantic art works and sculptures that are top of the world..... world's second largest museum ... need atleast 2 to 3 days to cover the entire museum ....

Wonderful Place. great place with rich heritage and marvelous piece of architect i have ever seen. The boat ride and yummmy lunch at Lucky Shot restaurant made my day. Do not miss Hermitage museum as well ...

really one of the best. I am a bit of musuem hound. been to many famous large and small one. this one is special. great collection but also being housed in an imperial palace setting enhances the experience. must go once in life and 7-8 days may not be enough.

Awesome, Didn't have enough time to see everything.... The Nermitage Museum indeed has an enormous collection of art perhaps not as big as the Louvre, however, the building itself is a work of art being the winter palace of the royal family. It is a bit crowded during the summer time with all the tourists so you can't really take a good look at all the art being displayed. I would love to return when it is less crowded and have a chance to go through the museum at a more relaxed pace.

No one should miss this wonderful place!. One of the greatest museums in the world. Rich collection of paintings, sculptures and other artistic items. You can see the collection of dresses worn by Russian tsarinas. Luxurious interior and famous staircase. After visiting don't forget to hang about the Palace square and walk along the magnificent embankment of the Neva.

a huge collection of works of art. I think one day too little to explore the magnificent collection of the museum. Each person must choose their priorities for inspection. Or visit the museum several times. I really like the Flemings. I do whenever I'm in the Hermitage, be sure to admire them.
Amazing place. U cant see all beauty of the ermitage in one day. U can take aj electronic guide which is very helpful.

You were not in Hermitage - you were not in Saint Petersburg. Hermitage is the first place you should visit in Saint Petersburg. You spend there more than two hours because there are a lot of exibitions and all of them are very interesting.

Too immense for me.. There were simply too many exhibits to see. I like a museum but you could spend way too much time indoors looking at all the artwork here. An interesting sidenote- at the end of WWII the Russians looted many museums in Berlin. They signed, in 1993, a pact to return these goods. They actually have no intentions of returning any of these items. They look upon this artwork as "war reparations". They will be in Mother Russia for a long time to come.

Big and beautiful art and interior. We liked everything about it, and especially the treat one gets when being a "Friend of the Hermitage": free entrance without waiting, not only in the Hermitage itself but also in its annexes, like the awesome Menshikov Palace. And also in the annexes outside Russia, e.g. in the Netherlands. Annual cost of being a Friend is € 60 for two people (in NL).

So big, better get a guide. The place is beautiful, we recommend to get local guide so your trip is able to be shortened in just 2hrs if you are time limited. Behind the place was a great square where you can rest and relax. A must visit place when you are in St P

The first place to be visited in Saint Petersburg. The Hermitage (Winter Palace) is the first place to be visited in St Petersburg. The place itself where this masterpiece is situated is wonderful:granite embankments,the Neva, Palace square, marvelous sight on Petropavlovskaya Fortress - everything is around you. The collection of the museum is unique and grand.Highly recommend to visit.

Soo much to experience. Definitely use the museum's website to buy the voucher for swift, easy entry -literally by-pass the long line of people waiting to enter the Hermitage. The ground floor has very interesting ancient artifacts and is uncrowded. Besides all the amazing paintings the "apartment rooms" of the Tzars should be experienced!

Too beautiful. I had visited twelve years earlier and loved it. This time it was still mind blowing. There is just too many beautiful and interesting things to see on a city tour. You have to go, but it would be so much nicer to be able to just visit SPB for a few days and really check out the Hermitage, one of the great museums in the world.

Stunning Museum. The Hermitage is a world famous museum, and rightfully so. The overall beauty is just incredible not to mention all the amazing works of art. It's tough to truly enjoy then entire museum if you are visiting via tour group from a cruise ship. Nonetheless, still a must see.

It's number ONE!. Take the British Museum, the Louvre, the Vatican, and the Met, join Versalles Palace. The Hermitage beats them all. I have been to these and many other museums around the world, but I wasn't prepared for the Hermitage. For the first time, I simply couldn't stop exploring. I didn't want to leave that atmosphere. The Vatican was my favorite before yesterday. Because of the Sistine Chapel and the decorations of the every room and hallway. The Hermitage surprised me incessantly. Each room was a reward that kept my tired legs going on and on.

It is just the best museum !. No matter what you like, art there is just amazing, present and every where ! Impressionists, sculptures, antiquities or old guns just go our city museum... 3 floors of pleasure ! and the tips -> if you can do not miss the treasure room and the gold room, you will never forget what beauty, arts, gold or jeweleries mean!! JUST AMAZING... and for the profane -> the Armoury
Super!. Beautiful place for all visitors in Russia.I recomended Hermitage museum for inspection.This is beauty that Louvre in Paris in my mind.

Hermitage is a huge museum. Hermitage museum occupies the Winter Palace ( ex Russian Tzars residence) and some more buildings. It has excellent collection of Italian art and of Impressionists. I love its collection of Cameos as well. The visit to Hermitage museum lasts generally 3 hours.
Visit Hermitage Museum. Please note that during tourist season (May-September) there are alsways quees to get into the museum, so the earlier you come the quicker you will get in.

Excellent. You could spend a day in here. It reminded me of Versailles with all the many rooms and the incredible designs and decor.It is apparently the 3rd largest museum in the world along with the Louvre and the British Museum in London.If you wish to buy a ticket on the day, don't queue up in the ticket queue but try the little green ticket vending machines. Much quicker and then you go round to the proper entrance at the side of the River Neva and go in there. The machines do not take credit card, so have roubles ready. It is 400 roubles per ticket and you may need a permission ticket for photos for another 200 roubles.The first Thursday in every month has free entry!When I went there were no English guide maps left which was annoying so I had to make do with a French one as I can read a tiny bit of French.Many of the info signs for the exhibits are in Russian only, which again is a pain.I loved the corridor with the portraits of the Tsars and the Tsarinas. Very interesting.You probably should invest in the audio guide, I didn't and I regret it.But if you come to St Petersburg then this is obviously the Number One attraction.
brilliant. Awesome experience inside and out in the gardens. Tour guide (paulina Alla tours) ensured that our tastes in art was catered for.

Too much for one afternoon. Everything about the Hermitage is larger than life, and that obviously include its buildings and collection. Don't make the mistake of trying to cover everything - both your legs and your eyes will not bear it. Our guide wisely asked us to prioritise on the architecture/rooms or the art work. Even narrowing the choice, combined with the huge crowd, still made the afternoon like a watching a movie in fast forward.For art lovers, plan separate visits, each with a theme/personal favourites. Else it is impossible to do it justice.

Great Museum - a must to visit. The Hermitage Museum is gorgeous in its architecture and it held great collections of art. I agreed with Alex, our guide from TJ Travel, that it will take us 3 years to fully enjoy this museum. I am grateful that we have a guide, Alex, to take us around this museum, because he zigzaged through the museum making sure we go to areas that have less crowds (there are tons of tourists at the museum).We were also at the Hermitage Theatre to watch our ballet "Swan Lake". It was a very small but cosy theatre, but the sound system are good. The only complaint was : it was quite hot inside the theatre.

One of the finest Art Museums in the World. This museum is housed in the winter palace of the Czars. It is one of the few museums in the world where the venue rivals the art within. The museum has an outstanding collection including 2 Da Vincis, a sculpture of Michaelangelo and many other famous artists. Admisson cost 400 rubles or $12.26 US. The cost is usually rolled into the price of St. Petersburg tour. You can easily spend a full afternoon there and still only see a fraction of the art. The excellent gift shop takes credit cards and rubles.

Worth another visit. Thanks to SPb tours' early entry we avoided the lines. The guides followed a routine that allowed us time in each area, rather than being crowded with another group. Like the Vatican, and the Louvre, more to see than you possibly can, but even the taste was amazing.

Unbelievably impressive!. I was blown away by the Hermitage. The building is absolutely beautiful, and it is full of beautiful things. We were guided by Alla Tours, and I highly recommend them and I recommend on going on a guided tour since you get to enter the building one hour before the general public. There are so many things to see, as in the Louvre, that you have to be strategic in how you approach it.Tthat's where a guide is invaluable.

superb. Absolutely superb and beyond expectation.you must see it yourself.The items in the museum are unique.The masters from Italy,France,England,Holland & England have their best works displayed here

What Can You Say. Certainly one of the great collections of art that exist. In the short two hours we spent in the Hermitage we saw masterpieces by Michelangelo, Matisse, Rembrandt, Piccasso and too many others to list here. It was too much to appreciate in the short time we were there. You literally need days if not weeks to put quality time in this museum.

Amazing!. We went as part of an excursion with a cruise line which seriously diminished the amount of time we had to wait in line to enter. The collection is unbelievable and well worth the visit...it is INCREDIBLY crowded, so you are advised to keep all your money and personal belongings close to you--this is a pickpocket's nirvana... If you can be patient, you will be treated to a veritable smorgasborg of some of the most famous works of art...ever. While you're waiting to see some of the paintings, take a moment to enjoy the building--it is beautiful. Imperial Russia was a time of luxe and this is clearly evidenced in the Hermitage. I feel honoured to have gone there and wouldn't have missed it for the world.

Amazing Museum. The Hermitage is amazing and enormous. If you want to visit it, I recommend at least two days, otherwise you will only see a very small part. If is possible, buy the tickets by the internet. Doing this you can avoid long lines. I loved the paintings from Van Gogh and the statue of Zeus.

Magnificent museum!. How in one place they have some many pieces of art.. fanstantic place, superb place.. we enjoyed walking trough and admiring such great paintings... The crowds can be a bit of a pain as they can be inconsiderate of others in front of you.

The Louvre meets Versaille. Be sure to book your tickets online! The line ups were huge. Be prepared to spend all day there, since there is so much to see. The exhibits and artwork are amazing but the palace itself will take your breath away. Be sure to see the Peacock Clock. Hint: you are not able to leave the museum once you are in so try to sneak in a snack in your purse (they do not allow backpacks). No liquids allowed either.

A Must Visit When in St Petersburg. Anyone who visits the Hermitage gives it 5 stars and for good reason. First of all, the museum and palace is opulent and beautiful since it was the home of the czars and czarinas. Secondly, the art collection is outstanding. I love impressionist paintings so the collection was definitely "impressive." Lucky for our tour, I traveled with Holland America on a Baltic Sea cruise with 2 days in St Petersburg. Special to our cruise group was an evening excursion tour of the Hermitage--after hours so the halls and galleries were open only to us and no crowds. Taking pictures inside the palace cost $5 per person but so worth it. I couldn't snap fast enough to capture every beautiful moment.
excellent tour with Alla Tours. nothing. it was great!very well organized, excellent guides, very professional. would recommend it to others.

Mayhem but magnificant. A collection of buildings housing what is, deservedly, one of the most famous museums in the world and a ‘must see’ but the sheer number of visitors and seeming lack of control does detract. Particularly problematic when the cruise ships dock! There are separate entrances for tours (groups and private) and for individuals. You will face long queues either way. There are pre-timed entrance tickets for the tours but there is little control over the flow of people once they are in. On the plus side photography is allowed but this does slow down progress even more. Reasonable restroom facilities. No bottles of water allowed and the café inside is very small. Bags greater than 20 x 30 inches, umbrellas and raincoats must be checked in. The Staterooms are the main attraction and are simply sumptuous - they take around 45 to 60 minutes to see. Most space is dedicated to the various art collections. If you are really keen on art get a two day ticket and buy a hard copy guide or use the audio tour. If you have limited time, it would be better to visit the Hermitage as part of a group or private tour or buy a museum book.
Fantastic. The crowds are extreme like the at Louvre in Paris, get there early or late to lessen your problem with crowds.

Too much at the Hermitage.. You will never have enough time to see everything that you want to see so you must make a list of the things that are at the top of the list and arrange for a guide to take you directly to them. Make sure that you tell the guide to not allow you to become distracted or you may never get to see the things on your list! It is mindblowing to see all of these treasures. The halls are PACKED with tourists, so be prepared for crowds. Do your homework, read about what you want to see beforehand - you won't be disappointed.

One of the World's greatest museum. I would say that this is the greatest museum, but I haven't been to all of them. I have been to the British Museum, The Louvre and the Metropolitan in New York and the Hermitage is the equal at least of those. Get the two day pass, you'll need it. The one way in which it falls down is the cafe - expensive, crowded and not very good.

Essential viewing.. A unique collection. Mind blowing opulence. Just don't think too hard about how some of the collection was acquired shortly after 1918. Buy a two day ticket for a few dollars extra - you'll need it.
hermitage. Amazing. Every room was filled with the fines of everything. Gold leaf everywhere. So hard to describe, it was overwhelming

Exceeded my expectations. I was very impressed with the art, and the building. And as large as it is, it does get very crowded in certain areas. I came via cruise ship, and we were able to enter before the general public, which helped at the beginning of the day. My favorite art is Impressionist. There are many rooms of beautiful paintings by Monet, Renoir etc and that part of the museum was not crowded. It was very crowded near the two da Vinci's (much like it is in front of the Mona Lisa at the Louvre).This is my first art museum visit with a tour guide. I don't think I will ever visit a large museum again without one! She was amazing. She gave details about the building and the art that I wouldn't have been able to get so quickly on my own. Plus, as much as possible, she tried to work around the crowds so we could maximize our time.I think it is a must see! But the crowds do detract from the experience. Perhaps they would consider a system like the Borghese in Rome where everyone has a ticket for entrance at a specific time. I loved that experience!

Gorgeous buildings with enormous collection. best to buy a two day museum pass online that allows you to skip the line and offer better value than 1 day pass. You need to plan your visit on which area to cover as there are really many rooms and collections to spend few hours on.

Too many people; no crowd control. We had visited the Hermitage some years ago, but I don't remember such crowds as we experienced in July of this year. Our guide warned us at the beginning that it was easy to get lost and gave us a meeting place in case that happened. Fortunately I managed to shepherd my two grandsons through, but I saw virtually nothing. Every painting of note had so many people in front of it that seeing it was impossible. It was so hot that I was afraid of passing out. Also, photography is permitted, so everyone was lining up to take photos, even setting up easels in the traffic paths. This is, of course, a fabulous museum, but joining the crowds in July was not the thing to do. Go only off season when, I assume, you may actually be able to see something. Maybe the authorities should consider controlling visitor traffic as they do in Peterhof.

Busy, busy, busy !!. Obviously, well worth seeing. BUT - choose your time carefully. If you get there at the same time a cruise ship disgorges it's contents, expect long waits and difficulty in getting close to the exhibits. I suspect they get there first thing at 10ish, so bear that in mind.

Internet tickets under the arch.. Get in quick. Order online before you go. Go to the booth just under the arch to redeem your voucher. If you get to the main yard you have gone too far. With ticket in hand go to the right of the main queue and walk straight in. This must be the best museum on the World. It is fabulous. We got a two day ticket which means you have to go on two consecutive days. We spent a good 5 hours and have only covered half of the exhibits. We will return tomorrow to finish the job. As well as the main exhibits there are some brilliant temporary ones such as the one on Freemasonry in its early stages in Russia. Take a bottle of water and a snack with you. It's thirsty work and although there is a small cafe area there the food will not tantalise your taste buds. This is the highlight of the city and ranks alongside the likes of the Alhambra in Granada.

Hot and stuffy: Russia needs to upgrade. We loved the architectural beauty of the Hermitage, and the collections were impressive, but the viewer/user experience left MUCH to be desired. We were herded/hurried by our Russian "english speaking" guide Elena, through the rooms so hot and stuffy, all five of us agreed it would be a long time before we returned. I have travelled to many different countries, and always go to see many museums, so I have a lot of great national museums to compare this to; and this was so far below our experience we have had for example at the Louvre (I have returned 8 times there), the Vatican, or at the British Museum (4 times) that we would not go back until Russia and St. Pete's spend some time and money addressing the problems such as no air conditioning , no apparent place to stop and get coffee/ food, information kiosks poor, excessively long lines, lack of restrooms, and stuffiness, no fresh air flow. Even though large and small windows were there, they were not opened to the beautiful cool summer weather outside as Versailles does. Our Emglish speaking guide sanctioned by the hermitage "elena" didn't truly have command of English, so I whispered to my daughter more detail about certain paintings as we were viewing. I was glad to leave Hermitage and sadly that shouldn't be a viewers experience after spending as much money as we did.
You could spend days here.. Make sure you have a good guide and be prepared for huge crowds of people.I would recomend using Alla tours if you are doing the rounds in the city.

A Delightful place. The wonderful array of artworks of modern and masters was a delight to behold. Be prepared though to have to cope with huge crowds and no air-conditioning. Photographs can be taken but there is a charge to do so of 3 euros for cameras and 9 euros for videos. There are also a lot of stairs and a lift that one must make arrangements to use. The Winter Palace was also a wonderful experience.
Beautiful Museum. Liked the building and exhibits. Lots of tourists and tour groups so there was a lot of jostling to see things.

Truly impressive but way overcrowded. The collection is superb. Everything you have heard about this museum is true. It rivals The Louvre. But, unless you go at low season, you will not be able to enjoy this place due to unbelievable massive crowds. Ideally, you should budget an entire day.

a must. an absolute must. we spent all day there and only touched on the treasures within, food and drink only available on the ground floor and toilets as every ware in russia a problem to find also the crowds and tour groups from the ships are a problem. get away from the crowds that go to the tourist trail through the museums and find your own treasures

One of the most spectacular museums I have seen. This museum is so impressive you will not believe what you are seeing. There is so much to see here. They said that if you spent only 8 seconds at each piece it would take 9 years to see everything in the museum.I was only there for 4 hours and can tell you about the little I saw. It was unbelievable!! I wish I had much more time to explore. We saw pieces from Da Vinci, Romono, Canova, van Gogh and many more unique pieces. One of the most unique pieces is The Peacock Clock. I believe it only chimes on Wednesday nights so if you can arrange to be there it is a treat.

Impressive... a must see. The Hermitage is one of the largest museums in the world. It consists of 4 buildings: the Winter Palace (the "New Hermitage" and former residence of Russian emperors), the Small Hermitage, the Old Hermitage, and the Hermitage Theatre.Buildings themselves are a work of art, however the number of paintings and sculptures on display are the perfect complement.The number of paintings that you can see is impressive, I think that the Hermitage is the museum with the largest collection of paintings in the world, including masterpieces by da Vinci, Raphael, Veronese, Tintoretto, Velázquez, Murillo, El Greco, Zurbarán, and many many more.During the cruise season (June-July) it is extremely crowded and you can't enjoy the museum as you should. I suggest a visit in late August or September (also to avoid the cold weather)

Why did they massacre the musee. Here is one of the most beautiful palace in the world and with one of the most re-known art collection, that has been left to be organized by I do not know whom? Beautiful rooms, beautiful parquets, non protected, overcrowd of paintings and pieces of art. You want to enjoy the Ermitage, just choose a few rooms per day to enjoy, do not go like the other tourist that just pass by like suitecases ( not to say cows) that are more into tuning their cameras for which they forgot to turn off the flashes than to appreciate the art richness of the place. If it is only to say you were there just buy the entrance ticket as a souvenir. If you really want to enjoy choose your visit pace and thema yourself and you will have a great experience even though you will be surrounded by hordes of suitecases visitors. I wish for the Russian that the future conservator of this musee will be more attentive of putting less art pieces inside for the people to enjoy them more than to go there as a must stop to be able to say I was there. for the people who enjoyed piece of art parquets go fast there because I do not believe they will resist the tourists since nothing is apparently done to protect them. A beautiful place treated as a money maker instead of as a musee.
Can't miss. This can't be missed in St. Petersburg. If you wander a bit you can avoid the cruise ship crowds, so don't give up when you arrive and find yourself surrounded.

One of the Great Museums. The Hermitage is an amazing structure. Beautiful architecture restored after Soviet neglect housing a fantastic collection of the worlds exhibits. Only a fraction of the Hermitage holdings are on display. They do add new exhibits regularly. Like the British Museum, the Louvre and the Smithsonian complex you can easily spend a lifetime exploring all there is to see and process.

Yon cant miss it!!. it is a good solution to buy in advance by web the tickets; You will save two hours visit at least for by passing a long queques. Very interesting too is to rent for 250 the audioguides so you can visit your own and you will be free from the guides and the crowds of cruiser people following them. The location is very important and exciting full of most important arts masterpieces The Winter Building is a picture gallery too, so you have all in one. It takes 6 hour to visit at least (pictures). The audioguide explaines abot picture and building history too

Excellent. A must see when in St Petersburg! The artifacts and history was amazing! We had a tour guide which I highly recommend. There is so much to see and to avoid the crowds, I would go the first thing in the morning!

Baroque Opulence and a wonderful Art collection. You have to ignore the crowds but it is one of the best buildings and content I have visited. The sheer magnificence of the decor is phenomenal but the Hermitage Art Collection is one of the best in the world too.

Outstanding. If this is the only place you visit in St. Petersburg it is worth the trip. There are two parts to the Hermitage. First are the rooms for the Tsar and family along with public rooms and there are the display rooms for the art. The Tsar's rooms are spectacular and the art collection amazing and vast. To properly appreciate and savor all plan to take 2 days to tour the Hermitage. It is worth doing so.

Amazing. We enjoyed our vist to the WInter Palace and Hermitage. Make sure you buy your tickets online before you go. Kids are free with adult so read all the fine print before you buy. You must stand in line to redeem your online tickets to get the same day tickets (welcome to Russia) but it is still much faster than the normal line.
Masterful. Seeing the masterpieces of my favorite artists was wonderful. Allowing me to get up close and view the details of each artwork was an unexpected treat.

Too big!. Beware of the tour guides which fill this place up, get a map or else you'll get lost, find the audio guides its a must! and if you can get tickets online if you don't want to be in line for 40 mins. This is a MUST SEE museum that demands planning and a couple of days to visit, yes it is that big!

Outstanding!!! Definitely the No.1 place to see in St.Petersburg. We had an organised tour to the Hermitage and Winter Palace, avoiding queues that formed from 11am. Try to get there early if you are not on an organised trip. The crowds were at least 300+ at 11.30am. Ensure you use the washroom on the right on entry as it takes a couple of hours on the tour. This building houses the most amazing artefacts in the world, from Monet, Van Gough, Rembrandt, Picasso, etc. You can take photographs throughout, except in the personal art collection. You can't see it all in 2 hours, but from what we did see, this is a enjoyable tour and you won't be disappointed. They don't like people bringing in water, so make sure you are hydrated before entry.

If it's on your list of "places to see before you die," then see it. I've visited every top museum in the world. The Hermitage was a disappointment. The lines are extremely long to get in. To avoid this, you need to get your ticket on-line and bring your passport for security purposes (I presume). You will be paying more than a Russian citizen, so you might as well get in first. I felt sorry for those who were standing outside in all kinds of weather, however. I did not go on a tour, so it was nice to move about at my own pace.Second, it was difficult to know how to get to the 3rd floor. When I tried the elevator, a museum worker told me the elevator didn't go to the 3rd floor, although another worker had told me it did. The woman denying me elevator access didn't speak English, but her rudeness and the abrupt "dosvydanya" was clear. I finally found a stairwell amidst the construction leading to the 3rd floor, after a lot or walking.Third, the Rastrelli gift shop closes before the museum on a Wed., when the museum stays open until 9:00 p.m., so if you want to buy anything, do it before it closes. I had wanted to buy an item for about $300 and was disappointed to see the doors locked, probably by 5:00. I returned the next day with my old ticket to see if I could simply be allowed into the gift shop, located beyond the turnstiles (strangely enough). No chance. No one at this museum, including administration, had the wherewithal or imagination to figure out how I could buy this item without standing in line and paying for another ticket. If you want to experience a "cold war" atmosphere in Russia's supposed age of "freedom and democracy," try bending one of its rules. When you get to the point when you're wondering, "Who do I have to bribe to get them to take my money?" you're having a "cold war" experience.Fourth, the Hermitage is extremely huge. Therefore, it's necessary to have a map with you because a staff member in each room will be, by and large, cold, rude, arrogant and unhelpful. No one appears to speak another language other than Russian. This museum knows it has a captive audience, so why be user friendly? I should add that the National Heritage docents in the UK do their jobs FOR FREE, and couldn't be more obliging, whether speaking another language or not. The UKs' standard of living is higher than Russia's, so that could explain the attitude differences. Still.Fifth, the Winter Palace was not lived in by the Tsars after the assassination of Alexander II, taking place where Church of the Spilled Blood now stands. Also, it was shelled during WWII, so massive restoration had to occur. The library of Nicolas II interested me as it most closely represented his actual library according to 1900's photo in the room. However, other rooms looked completely different, with few original furniture items/pictures surviving revolution and war. Better to use your time trying to locate the stairwell (NOT THE ELEVATOR-- unless you want a Russian reprimand) to the 3rd floor to see the ca. 19th C. works there.Sixth and last, the beautiful peacock clock is supposedly set to go off at 7:00 p.m. ONLY on a Wed., or so we had thought. However, the staff in the room could not communicate this to us. We inferred it when a large group of tour groups stood around the exhibit at 7:00 pm, waiting, waiting, to no avail. I guess somebody forgot to wind the clock. The video nearby was helpful to get an idea of what a piece of art this is.

Must see. The museum is very nice and has a lot to offer. Just that you can't pay by credit card at every office. And a tip: enter through the back doors from the river side and avoid all the waiting lines in the front.

So crowded may as well not have bothered. The Hermitage was meant to be the highlight of my trip to St Petersburg but unfortunately it seemed that every other tour group in the city (including huge numbers from a cruise ship) chose the same afternoon to attend as our group. The groups follow the same route and, as a result, the visit was three hours of being pushed and shoved by other tourists, no time to look at any works properly and feeling faint in hot, overcrowded rooms. It is important to mention that the Hermitage is huge and there are many hundreds of other rooms which were empty but if you only go to see the most famous stuff be prepared for a crush. In the Impressionists gallery, the crowd was so bad that I could not even enter the room and gave up. The Rembrandt room was so overcrowded that I had to leave because I felt faint. I do not think this situation is really anyone's fault as everyone comes with the same good intentions but I suggest that you visit early in the day before the tour groups get there in such big numbers and try and focus on less prominent works to get the most out of your visit.

Awesome!. This museum features art and other exhibits originating outside Russia. (There is a separate Russian Museum). I was particularly impressed with the extensive art collection including lots of impressionists with extensive hangings of Gauguin and Picasso. Sadly, I went as part of a limited tour so we were rushed past lots of interesting exhibits and missed lots of sections. At a guess, I would suggest a minimum of two days for this attraction and, if you are really serious perhaps leave free a day or two more. Definitely go as an individual and hire an audio system. You'll save a lot and you'll be far far happier.

More like 3.5/5. The Hermitage Museum has some beautiful artwork, but I felt that it was just another art gallery. If you have been to the Louvre, then you will not be amazed. The front entrance was a little disorganized and the many tour groups did not make for a pleasant museum experience for independent tourists. The cafe was closed and the exterior of the museum was undergoing renovations so the scaffolding was a damper for pictures.Nevertheless, it is a "must-see" in St. Petersburg due to the history.
Not to be missed. A must see in St. Pb.. Awed by all.Numerous inspiring paintings from numerous different artists and countless countries. Nothing like it outside the Louvre.
Amazing, more impressive than the Louvre. The Louvre might have the more famous pieces, but the Hermitage had more works by the individual artists, and the structure itself was amazing as well.
Must See. Museum was amazing! A lot to see. Our guide was so excited in showing it to us. It was a very hot day, no air conditioning and very crowded. But worth it!
wow, incredible collection. one of the best museum for me and my family, if you go there you cant miss it, you need time, at least 2 days to see everything, not expensive
Marvelous Hermitage. I went there for two days, and stayed 9 hours the firt day and 6 the second. It was really worth it!!! For me, it can be the most impressive museum in the world!
wonderful site. The only down side of this wonderful place is that there is not enough time to see it all. A must see.

As good as the louvre, 3rd most important museum. The masterpieces include the return of the prodical son by rembrandt, a couple da vinci and raffaello paintings as well as a beautiful sculpture by michaelangelo. This museum has an extensive picasso, monet, matisse, van gogh and renoir collection if you are into impressionism

overwhelming if you don't have a guide. Big, busy, and not air conditioned- at least not well. Huge range of art, including a nice selection of impressionist. it is 4 buildings connected together, so can be confusing. Luckily we were with a skilled guide from SPB tours who lead us through, and with her we line jumped right in to the tour line, so no waiting. We were there for about 2 hours, you could easily be longer, but it does get overwhelming.
Surely one of the best in the world. If I had just come to St. Petersburg to see the Hermitage, it would have been worth it. The sheer volume of top notch exhibits is overwhelming.
Amazing. Buy tickets on line in advance to avoid the massive queue. Then go on Weds after 4 its open until 9pm. There's nobody there!

Over Crowded. Beautiful buiding which I believe contains over 1,000 rooms. I couldn't wait to see the former home of Czar Nicholas and his family. I believe this was called their "Winter Palace". I am not rating this as a 5 star because the crowds were unbelieveable. We just shuffled from room to room and it was very, very hot. All I could think of was if there should ever be a fire, we would all perish. There is no crowd control like in North American. They just keep letting people in and it doesn't matter how many. Surprising, people were taking photos of the paintings with their cameras which can cause deterioration to the paintings.

Worth it for the architecture and decoration!. As with many of the palaces and buildings in St Petersburg, the Hermitage is full of gold and riches reflecting times gone by. Almost every room I walked into was awe-inspiring as I tried to imagine what it was like when people were living and partying there. Certainly breath-taking. In terms of the artwork, it's hard not to compare it to the Louvre in Paris and I'm sorry to say that I would put the Hermitage in second place.Hint: make sure you're there early in the morning as the crowds build up very quickly - by the time we left there around 11am, the crowds waiting to get in were huge!

Fantastic. This is a must see in St. Petersburg. Unless you have a deep understanding of Art history I highly recommend a guide who will explain the art in chronological order. Russian history is very interesting but can be tricky due to similar names.
Beautiful. What an honor to see this fabulous museum - it would take weeks to see it all. We didn't get to see all the art rooms, but the state rooms are so impressive. Especially the amber room.

It's really hard to imagine. Need to see it yourself.. We went on an organized tour of the Hermitage. Our tour guide was an art major in college, so you can imagine his passion for the works of art. We toured for over three hours and saw a small percentage of the paintings. It really is hard to describe. You really need to experience it yourself. It is just a ginormous museum with thousands and thousands of paintings. What a collection. It gets very crowded due to all of the tours, so if you can go on Wednesdays late in the afternoon, it will be a more enjoyable experience.Catherine's Winter Palace is also a must see. Catherine enjoyed gold. You will get a sense of it during the tour. Definitely worth the time to tour.

Stunning. This museum is such a treasure; we toured this site with a tour guide (Alla tours). It would be a waste of money to go through the museum without a guide. The ceilings, the floors, the walls and stairways are a majestic sight to behold; not to mention the art and artifacts on display. Don't miss the DaVinci Room, the peacock clock, the Picasso room, the Renoir room and the Michelangelo statue. A couple words of warning: Do not disobey the "Do not photograph" signs and don't touch anything. There are women that watch every move you make and are not friendly when they approach you for violating a rule. Also get there as early as possible; another good reason to go with a guide because the museum gets very crowded and it is hot inside. The museum bathrooms are free and they are also clean.

A great attraction. Although very crowded, our guide took the time to keep us together and point out all the masterpieces while giving us enough free time to enjoy the pieces we like the most. So much to see and the size of the building is truly impressive. I just wish we had had a whole day (or 2 !) to see everything on display.
Beauty. Its full of History and culture. It also has Egyptian, Italian and other history from various countries. Great painting . Leonardo da Vinci painting was amazing.

Must be number 1 attraction in St.Petersburg. Too much to explain, so just look at the pictures and be amazed. Absolutely gorgeous place, where you can easily spend whole day. Few tips: Line on the Neva River side is for groups only, so if you are alone/with spouse etc. go in from the square side. Once you get in, buy your tickets(and photo license) from the machine, because inside there usually is long line. Best time to get there is in the morning when they open, because daytime place is really crowded!

State Hermitage Museum. The Museum is open on Wednesdays till 9pm, so the best time to visit is on Wed evening. We went around 6pm and there was no line for tickets, no tour groups and no crowds. The Peacock Clock is wound only once a week on Wed at 7pm, so that was the only crowded part of the visit. The Museum is huge, so make a plan and decide ahead of time what you must see. Be selective, the distances between rooms are vast, some rooms are so crowded with paintings that your head will spin as you try to take in each piece of art.

Huge. We spent four hours here and we covered only a small area. We were told that if you spend 1 minute at each painting it would take you 10 years to see this place. Awesum. See the masters-Van Gogh, Renoir, Monet and Picasso. Must see in St Petersburg

Buy your ticket online to avoid the long line. Very beautiful palace rooms!. Go to the website of the State Hermitage to buy your tickets before leaving home. Print your voucher and bring it with you to Sct Petersburg. On the day of your visit, you go to the museum to exchange your voucher to real tickets, and then you can enter. We experienced NO queues because we had done this. Otherwise queues were long. Use 4 hours if medium interested in art and very beautiful palace rooms. I really loved the Jordan stairs. My father loved the very old Pazyryk carpet which was also beautifully displayed in a rather dark room. Unfortunately information only in Russian. Use more hours in the museum, or even two days, if you are very interested in art. Mainly European art. If you are not interested in art, or if your are a 7-year-old child, then just use around two and a half hours to see the overwhelmingly pretty Jordan stairs in room 192 and the other extremely beautiful palace rooms such as rooms 204 and 197 which really rival the art exhibition. If still up for more, go see the interesting portrays of women in the French sections, in rooms 322 or so. If many in your group, try to split up and walk no more than in threes. Bring or buy your guide book. It didn't seem desirable to follow a guide for hours with a big group in this huge museum. There is plenty to see in your own pace. Cafe not recommendable because of boring and dry sandwiches and the very noisy location. Ok for a quick cup of coffee. Not expensive, though. Eat before and after visit. Buy ice cream just outside the museum. A lot of people but possible to see and navigate. We were not pushed around. Free wardrobe where you have to leave bug bags. Photos ok in most rooms, but never with flash. Benches in every third room or so. Elevators, so available for wheelchair users.

Unusual mix of palace rooms and artwork; buy tickets online!!. We tried to visit the Hermitage on a rainy day, and waited in line for more than an hour to buy tickets, and had at least another hour to go when we decided to abort our plans and try another day. The ticket line is very slow to move, and people are only allowed inside in small batches to be able to queue again at indoor ticket windows. Later that night, we then bought tickets online, and asked our hotel concierge to print the voucher. There is a desk under the entrance archway where the voucher can be swapped for the tickets. A passport or identity card is needed to verify the identify of the person who purchased the tickets. Our child (age 5) was also given a free ticket when we exchanged the voucher. n.b. online tickets are more expensive, but it was well worth the speed of entrance, compared with that loooooong line.if you buy online, use the fast track line and directly enter the building. Inside are several free cloak rooms where you can leave coats, large bags, etc. There are also toilets, although the ladies side had very long lines, so be prepared to wait. The museum does restrict what you can carry inside, and you have to pass through security like an airport (baggage screening and security screening to get inside). Interestingly, the sign said no high heeled shoes (stiletto heels). Presumably this is because of the many hard wood inland floors.We found that the most interesting aspect of the Hermitage is the fact that it mixes both historic rooms of the palace, some of which are furnished with period pieces, with other rooms where artwork and sculptures are displayed. The mix is fascinating, as this is both an art museum and a palace. Some of the rooms had amazing gilded ceilings, chandeliers, and intricate inlaid floors. Cameras were allowed. Some people had stickers showing a camera (for a fee?) and many others didn't. We asked, and were told that cameras for private use were OK to use, with no flash. If we were a professional or had significant equipment, then we would need to purchase a permit. Despite many signs showing no flash allowed, many visitors shamelessly used flashes throughout the museum. Given the priceless works of art, this was very selfish behavior.The interior of the museum is very warm in the summer, with only a few windows open throughout the enormous property. We easily could have worn shorts and t-shirts, despite being chilly outside. Dress accordingly.We did see a cafe outside in the courtyard, but didn't see any refreshments inside.The enormity of this property cannot be over-emphasized. Each floor had hundreds of rooms. Our 5-year old child barely made it around one of the floors, and the started to melt down, so we had to leave. There are relatively few places to sit (some benches in rooms from time to time), and the site is very crowded with tour groups constantly passing through. Some of the museum staff were very strict, asking us to keep moving along, not to take up too much of the bench seating (when our child reclined), and not to get too close to the windows (when we were quite warm).Regarding other reviews mentioning pickpocketing, we did find that the rooms with famous art were exceedingly crowded, and at one point, we saw two teenage boys who were loitering in a room and checking out the visitors as they passed through, literally eyeballing bags. Nothing happened to us, but we could see how the environment could be prone to issues. It seems prudent to leave anything important back in your hotel safe.We did find this a fascinating site, but it takes a careful planning and stamina. Plan accordingly!
History at its best. A private tour and a speedy entrance. We had visited before so did not go again to the Gold Room. Very busy but spent a couple of hours visiting various parts of the Palace.

tikets info. buy tikets on line before getting there! it will save you A LOT of time and long lines. Consider also the two-days tiket option so you can split the vist in a more spine-legs-feet friendly experience. Remeber there is also the winter palace and not only the art collection to visit.

Fascinating place - can spend days here. So much to see and do - two days here at least to see everything.Some amazing pieces of art and the collections of art / sculpture / plundered artifacts dating back thousands of year is stunning. It can be a bit too much at times though.The only downsides are the queues and tourist groups - ironically. There are thousands of tour groups just wandering around without aim or direction. If you have no patience or are intolerant of other tourists, go early morning when it opens at 10am.

Very crowdy - but a most see!. First of all: Be prepared for many tour groups. Plan your visit if there is something in particular you are interested in viewing. With millions of art items from all the streams the 'hermitage" one can never be able to see it all therefor plan your visit by checking the website.

Get your ticket on-line to avoid waiting in line. We saw two long lines of people waiting to buy a ticket. We had bought our ticket on-line at our hotel just minutes before walking to the Heritage, and we got right in, even without a guide. DO get your ticket order printed at your hotel and head over to the Hermitage with your passport (for the person whose name is on the ticket). Pass the long line to the right and walk to the entrance with your ticket request. You will be allowed in to arrange for the actual ticket. It saved us about an hour. Beyond that, jaw-dropping rooms with terrific art. On Wed. the museum is open until 9:00 p.m. Many of the beautiful chandelier lights are on at that time as well. You will need at least 4 hours to see the key rooms and top art exhibits. We stayed for 8 hours.
Hermitage Highlights. Saw the highlights in a day. Doable because more may be information overload. Although that happens to me in most museums.

Must see but try to avoid peak season, if possible. Breathtaking collections.
The venue is faboulous, walk around and dont forget to look at walls and ceilings, verbally.
But it was overwhelming number of groups and crowds sometimes too difficult to pass through.
Spectacular!. Too much to see in a short few hours. A stunning range of art from all over the world in impressive surroundings!

A Must See. We did a private guided tour of the Hermitage. We had booked 2 day tour of St. Petersburg with Red October. The Hermitage is really large, but we got through without any problems. We did our tour early morning, but as the time went on it did get crowded. I'm not a huge art buff but I really was glad I did this tour. As time was limited I think we stayed just under 3 hours but of course its a personal thing how long you wish to take. It was a warm day and as the Hermitage is an old building it gets a bit stuffy with crowds. You have toilets at the start and again I saw some near the end of the tour also. Did not see many during the tour of the Hermitage. Lifts were available also. They don't allow flash photography where there are oil paintings. A tip for shoppers. I purchased a lovely print on canvas which looks really well, Vincent Van Gogh - Landscape with Horse and Ploughman year 1889. This worked out at $30 and was packaged for me also to carry. I got it home in the package rolled up and it did not get damaged. I would however have preferred a circular carrier. They have cardboard ones with handles. But it did the job. They had a huge selection of prints really wonderful, so well priced.I found the Hermitage shop to be good value. It had all the usual stuff, fridge magnets etc and good value also. I used U S Dollars to pay with.

Nothing special to me. I am not really an art expert, so I have only limited knowledge mainly for popular art such as Monalisa, Venus de Millo etc. I dont find anything here which is interesting for me. Offcourse the place is huge with so many collections but if I knew not about any stuff, I can not really say then that I like it

amazing. Go there and try to do it in a private tour, not like cattle if you can! The line outside the Hermitage became amazingly long the morning we went but with a prearranged tour you just walked in- brilliant!The treasures there are only rivaled by the Louvre.

Unique nothing comes close. We spent 3 out of 7 day stay in at Petersburg in the hermitage and we neededMore te I have visited many usuems around the world but nothing has so much in quality and quantity

Old Trafford with art treasures!!!. Yes it is packed with wonderful art treasures but either because the Russians are so greedy or too relaxed to say no to the tour operators you would be lucky to see any artwork in the way that it should be seen.Great paintings should be seen without interruptions and should be seen quietly on a one to one basis with the viewer able to contemplate and enjoy what is before him.For myself I would not want to see all the artwork on offer but would rather see those periods of painting that really excite me in the manner I have just described.To see them in the way that I exit Old Trafford after a United game being jostled and bumped for hours on end with a glimpse of a Rembrandt,a snatch of a Matisse and so on is almost a pointless exercise.Nothing sums up the cruise ship mentality of "I've done this or I've done that" as a visit to the Hermitage.Very poor!

Wonderful. We spent half a day in the Hermitage, I'd recommend at least a day. The exhibits are stunning, everything from paintings by the old masters to mummified remains. I didn't have much contact with staff, but those I did speak to we're friendly and helpful.The hermitage is actually four museums joined by corridors, one of the museums being the Winter Palace. It is centrally located, with easy access to the river for boat trips.

Crowded, but still a must see !. I'm not quite sure how such a ginormous building can still manage to be so crowded in every nook and cranny.... but nonetheless, its simple.... book your ticket in advance, turn up early (before the majority of the crowds) and plan to spend the whole day there (wear comfortable shoes !!).Enjoy !

Simply amazing! Unbelievable.. I am no art expert but this place simply blew my mind! To see such riches in one place and the ornateness of the building. You just have to see it to believe it! Thank goodness for restorations!

One of the best in the World, but so disappointing!. We paid for a private tour with early admittance to the Heritage with SPB. However, until that morning you do not know the exact time that you will gain admittance. For us, we got a ticket allowing us in 15 minutes before the regular crowd! We were not impressed! We stood in line and did not get in until after opening time. It was extremely hot, 30 Degrees C outside, and the Hermitage has no air conditioning. It was absolutely packed with swarms of aggressive people jockeying for pictures of their favorite Raphael or Michelangelo. We asked our guide to cut it short many times as my daughter and elderly mother could not handle the heat, and frankly we had had enough! So disappointed to go to a world famous museum with amazing collections, only to leave early! Our guide tried to protect us from the pick pockets, but it really did take the shine off for us! There was no place for water or food, and few places to sit down.
Huge Museum. Stunning building and great art. As with any large museum, you can only see a bit at a time. It was VERY crowded.
must see in St. Petersburg. Everyone will tell you this, of course, but it is true. Tons of art of every kind in palatial surroundings.

Hermitage Visit. One of the top museums in all the world. Along with Vatican and Lourve top art museums of Europe. Strongly recommend going with private guide to get early entrance and see highlights before being overwhelmed by crowds. Impossibly big with strong collections in all major European categories.

Go late afternoon!. We bought our tickets to the Hermitage ahead of time and were happy we did. We purchased the two-day pass online. The kiosk for the voucher is under the arch immediately as you enter the palace. (we passed it when we first went in.) Once you trade your voucher for tickets, go in and to the left of the long lines. (There are two different lines--the long line for those who are buying and, when we went, the no-line route for those with tickets.) You end up by the information/entry/coatroom. Head in, toward the grand staircase, through the metal detectors and you'll see the studio guides directly ahead. The English audio guide (350) is absolutely worth it for the upper floors as there's limited English-language signage throughout the museum.--(well, really, throughout Russia--lol) We went at 2:00 and crowds were beginning to thin. Once in, we simply made sure to go in the opposite direction of tour groups and did fairly well at having breathing room. Day two we did the bottom floor--the audio guide doesn't cover this floor. Be sure to visit that floor as many folks do not and, while it was a zoo upstairs on a Sunday afternoon in July, we had the ground floor (where the Egyptian and Roman items are) to ourself. Stunning museum, great experience.

More of the same. The Hermitage is a well known museum in Saint Petersburg. It contains collections of paintings, sculptures and everything else you expect to find in a museum. It is well situated with the Neva river on one side and a large Piazza the other side. But it is not different than, for instance, the Louvre in Paris. The worst thing is the amount of visitors. You cannot watch quietly a picture without dozens of spectators between you and the painting. No air-condition and terribly hot. A difficult experience!

A most amazing museum. You need a few days to see all. Better than the Louvre. We only spent about three hours because we were on tour. We rushed through the impressionists and could have spent several hours just wandering in this one section. We definitely have to return one day to expore this in depth.

Crowded with more than Memories. A short visit cannot really do justice to this magnificent museum. We visited with a tour group who shepherded us to many of the museum's most famous paintings and sculptures, but I left wanting to go back and see much more. I, however, am an art enthusiast, so not everyone will feel the same. I must warn you that in mid-June the museum is EXTREMELY crowded in many spots with tourists elbowing and jockeying to photograph their favorite pieces (and often not very courteous about allowing others the opportunity to enjoy the same). Based on our experience, be prepared to experience very crowded conditions in the galleries displaying the daVincis and the Rembrandts expecially. Unfortunately, pickpockets are known to love the Hermitage as well, so be aware of your belongings at all times. We did not have any trouble, but a friend of ours had his trousers expertly slit with a razor in an attempt to access his wallet (unsuccessful but embarrassing). Our guide made traversing the galleries easy, but the lack of English direction markings and no comprehensive maps would make a trip alone a bit daunting. I am particularly sad to have missed the Treasure Room.

the best. This is a magnificent palace with extraordinary art. It is difficult to describe the opulence and beauty of the the Hermitage. Even if you have a small bucket list for your life, this should be on it

Beathtaking National Treasures but beware. So many breathtaking rooms full of marvellous paintings by so many famous artists, sculpture and objet d'art. The history really enthralling. But beware of professional pickpockets inside The Hermitage itself, we were robbed, as were others on our cruise.

Beautiful!. The Hermitage is amazing! You are not sure what to look at the amazing art exhibits or the building itself. We did a 3 hour private early entry tour which was a great introduction to seeing the highlights. There is no way to see everything so I suggest checking out the website and having your guide hit the things you are most interested in. It is best to go early because it is quite warm in the building and if it is a warm summer day it would be very uncomfortable inside the museum and the lines are incredibly long after regular opening time.

Go for the building alone. This building is phenomenal, if you don't like art, it's worth visiting just to see the palace and its incredible furnishings. The art collections are pretty cool as well. The maps aren't terrific, plan for at least 1/2 a day. Smuggle in some food and water because options inside are very limited.
Hermitage. It was all good. Big - lots to see. Hot in the summer. Wear comfy shoes, not many places to sit. Art exquisite and architecture in rooms, furniture, wonderful.
Very nice and very very crowdy!. With millions of art items from all the streams the 'hermitage" is a must!! Just be ready to be among a lot of other visitors!
a must see. we loved everything about this place - the history - the interior - and the architecture. One of the main attractions in St Petersburg so make sure to visit.
just beautiful. amazing art,amazing architecture,furniture,decorations.overwhelming.we had a guide which was great.there is so much to see that a guide is really a must

Absolutely awesome...even with the crowds. The Hermitage is everything you think it is going to be...and then some. We were on a private tour through Ulko and since it was just the two of us and our guide, we were able to spend as much time as we wanted to, and still get in all of our tour. We spent three hours in the Hermitage and it was wonderful. We saw all of the highpoints and other works that most tourists do no see when they are part of an organized tour.

You could spend a lifetime.... This is an absolutely "not to be missed" attraction with an amazing amount of Master artworks. You'll never be able to see it all, so plan your visit first by checking our The Hermitage website.

Great Museum. Although quite busy, we managed to see the highlights by going on a private tour that entered early. Unique place that you have to see while you are St. Petersburg. However, best seen with a guide who knows the ropes and can avoid the huge crowds.
Awesome!. To be in the presence of such incredible art in an incredible place is beyond description. Book with a tour group, such as SPB to gain entry before the public hours.

Amazing Collection. Its Huge. Like the guy in the funspot ads. There is so much to see. We had a guide who knew how to get around, so I told her what we liked. We got in early to see the most popular items (Michelangelo's unfinished crouching boy is sculptilicous) They had a great collection of Monet and Renoir. Plus a clock I could have stared at for 2 hours. WOW

TRULY AMAZING!. We had a fabulous guide (Anna) who really knew her stuff about the museum, and I think we were able to see more than the average tour group because she was soooo smart and knew how to manipulate around and through the crowds. Of course one can spend years there and not see everything, but just to see the highlights is a truly amazing experience. Interesting that the Russians seem to put the former rulers on a pedestal, then one realizes the people revolted and overthrew them, but thanks to all the palaces that they built, tourism thrives! Obviously, a visit to The Hermitage is a must!!

comparable to louvre. we had very expert leader there and he make everything more beautiful : thanks Babak for everythingI wish be there again and have minimally 2 days time for see more itemsbeautiful painting , amazing sculpture , ... inside a very fantastic palacewhat I can write only recomend that spend 2 days there .
Our visit to the Hermitage. The tour was exciting and wondefrful. The guide knew he subject and had in depth knowlege of the artists

Overwhelming. The Hermitage is housed in 5 interconnected buildings. The collection is huge, and if you plan to see more than just a few selected treasures you must spend a few days here. If, like me, you're just there for a day, then you must pick and choose, so an experienced guide is needed. I saw the Leonardo's, the Rembrandts, Picasso's and so many others that it is almost a blur. Luckily you are allowed to photograph and videotape freely.

Wow a museum in a palace. Get tickets ahead of time or join a tour as can be very crowded, Has something for everyone and you cannot see it all in one visit so try and determine what century of art would you would like to see.

Second time around felt as good as the first.. We had visited the Hermitage 6 years ago and again last week while on a cruise where we had three days in St. Petersburg. We selected to half day tours in the Hermitage. I recommend getting there early in the morning before the crowds arrive. We did the introductory tour that walked us through the important works and rooms then on Day 2 we toured the treasures which were amazing. The jewels and gifts that were on display were unbelievable. The opulence was and delicacy of some of the pieces were impressive. Gold, diamonds, watches snuff boxes were something I will remember forever. The jewels that even the horses of yester year wore were over the top. My friend who toured with us who spoke little English said "I want to be a horse!"
Impressive Museum. One of the world's first class collections of art housed in a sumptuous piece of architecture with tons of malachite for columns topped by life size angles in marble and gold.

Awe inspiring.. The interior decoration of the Winter Palace is absolutely stunning, as are the many treasures on display. However it's always very, very crowded with tour groups. One has to be constantly on guard against pickpockets. Tiring work just to skim the surface of what's on view. One estimate suggests that if you spent just 2 minutes looking at each exhibit you would need 17 years to see everything.

crowded but must see. Even if you do not like art museums, the palace rooms and corridors are incredible. Be prepared for huge masses of people. There is so much history and art to see, so either get an audio guide if you prefer exploring by yourself or join a tour group (which is more informative but only covers the highlights). definitely go to the second floor and see the 20th century art.We went on the morning of the first Thursday of the month, when the museum is free to the public, so there were hordes of people. We stayed there for over 3 hoursthe Frugal Traveler sums it up well: "Imagine what would happen if you took the works from the Louvre and displayed them in Versailles"
Mindboggling!. This museum is enormous! If you are with a guide, make sure they take you to the impressionist wing. There are plenty of Matisse's, Picasso's, Monet's, Van Gogh's, etc. up there.

Grand. The building itself is a museum, a piece of art; so if you only have a half of day concentrate on visiting the building rather than the collections. Buy tickets online, in order to avoid queueing; but do not get a two-day ticket, not worth it, one of the other museums is actually closed for restoration, others are further away!

Easy to buy tickets for 400 rubles at the electronic booths now, and then walk straight in.... No queues unless you like them. There were no mention of the ticket dispensers on website (which charge US$18 (£12)) and when we arrived there were long queues for tickets, but if you walk past the Internet ticket counter you can then just buy entrance tickets! We bought the photo ticket for 200 rubles but were never asked to show it anytime also wink wink

Maxibalt Tours St. Petersburg. The museum and the winterpalace are beautiful , it was a pity that it was very crowdy. It was not a problem to take photos on both locations and you could take your time to look quietly around.

Oh my goodness!. This building has the world's history in hundreds of rooms. Every era is represented and every conceivable artist style is on display. We flew through the rooms as we were limited for time but in 4 hours we managed to see everything although not in any depth. Wear flat shoes and cool clothing as it gets hot with so many under one roof. You can't carry a bag in so leave your valuables in a hotel safe and travel light. There is something here for everyone.

A Must See Place while at St Petersburg. Built over 8 years by Catherine III in 1764 and spread over 353 rooms, there are 3 millions items to see which if you spend one minute each would take about 11 years without sleep or eating to see, is a must see place to visit while at St Petersburg. You see originals of great masters like Rembrandt, Picasso, Michaelengelo,, Da Vinci, Rubens, Van Gogh and Rafael and many others which is a fascinating and a life time experience. You really marvel how the old time kings and emperors spent wealth on building such huge buildings and collecting rare items of arts.
remarkable. It is better to go early in the morning or afternoon, it is extremely crowded. Must see thing what ever the difficulty.

Overcrowded Babel of arts. From the organization point of view I can´t rate more than the average. After 2 hours of queuing up and still not ready to enter that temple of art and masterpieces from the past, you no one could rate better…Museum exhibit is perfect.

Interesting Russian heritage. This museum was part of a tour and we don't normally do museums, but this was a very good look into Russian heritage and culture Lots of famous artists are featured here and the winter palace is pretty amazing.

It is big, but not special. The different sections were of different quality. Many of the areas were indeed spectacular but the presentation of artifacts in some areas was uninspiring and quite old fashioned. The one thing I wanted to see when there was in a section close for refurbishment.

You must visit here, world famous... but..... But all in all it is just like any other museum in Europe. Paintings, statues, artifacts, etc... We wend in June and this place was packed. If you are not with a tour you will wait in line for over an hour. you could easily spend all day here. My kids (6 & 3) got bored about 30 mins in.

The Hermitage. Not only a world class collection of art, but the environment in which the art is housed is magnificent! From the parquet floors, magnicifent chandeliers, sculptures at every turn to the greatest works of art by the most renowned artists from every century- this museum is the best I have seen.

you have to go even if after you wished you hadn't, but you will tell every one you have. Undoubtedly this is one of the most amazing museums in the world. The word excess doesn't even begin to describe what you will see. The guide said that if you could stand in front of every picture or artifact they have for just one minute it will take 16 years to see everything!!! There are paintings here by every one of the worlds greatest artists but getting to appreciate them is a different matter. The reason being that this museum is visited everyday by literally thousands of tourists.Rules to know, this is ideal ground for thieves and pickpockets, make sure you hang on to all your valuables. If you have bladder problems, the wait for the ladies could easily be half an hour. If you have problems with other peoples BO put a peg on your nose. Inside it can get hot, there is no air conditioning. Can you appreciate the paintings, YES of course but I sufferred serious painting OD after 2 hours and by then I hadn't even scratched the surface. Glad I went, you betcha, would I go again, No i'd buy the guide book

Hermitage Museum. An awesome Museum. The building itself is breathtaking with its marvellously decorated ceilings and floors. We were lucky as we took a trip with a cruise company which was on a Monday and the Museum opened especially for the cruise line, hence it wasn't very crowded and no queues!There are a lot of stairs although if you ask there are lifts which is great for anyone who needs them. To my mind a "Must See". Such Talent!
Breathtaking and Overwhelming. Be prepared for many tour groups. Following the map is not an easy task, so research before you go if there is something in particular you are interested in viewing.
Excellent. A must. Buy your tickets online. You will save time. The forts Thursday of each month is free. That is good but is crowded.
Amazing!. Loved everything about it. Our guide said if you spent two minutes on each item, it would take over ten years to see everything! Filled with history, art, etc. Beautiful and a must see!!

Wonderful Experience. So much to take in and so little time! Our guide,Inna, did an excellent job of giving us an overveiw of many the to see. Everything was absolutely beautiful! It's hard to imagine so much wealth. My wifes' favorite thing was to enter the first room AFTER all the gold rooms. Inna had us turn around and look backwards down the golden corriador. The look on my wifes' face will forever be embedded in my brain. I'm sure glad we had a good guide. She maneuvered us around like a beautiful waltz! Gift shops had beautiful books at reasonable prices. We'll enjoy them forever.

Excellent. There was so much to see from paintings to peacock clock to ornate rooms. Beautiful. Have a guide. It was v busy so give yourself time and choose what you want to see as you won't be able to see everything.

One of the World's Truly Great Art Treasures. Unlike most art museums (other than the Met in NY, the Prado in Madrid, and the Louvre), the Hermitage is almost overwhelming in presenting major pieces of art by major artists of almost all epochs. Among the collection are 2 Davinci's, an incompete Michelangelo, Rembrandts, Rubens, Goya's and a very impressive collection of Impressionistic and post Impressionistic art. You can do the highlisgts in about 5 hours. A full tour of all 4 builcings would take weeks. If you enjoy art, this is a total must!

Wonderful museum. The art pieces on show were not as famous as thse in other top museums, but however were still very incredible. The museum is in the Winter Palace so you get to see the incredible opulence of the royalty. Every ceiling, staircase and pillar is so carefully and artistically designed and sculpted - imagine the expense required by the royal family in a city of poverty. No wonder it finally culmulated in revolution.I'm more of a history person than an art person, so what interested me were rooms 188-198 on the second floor, where the attraction is history, not art.Russian royalty once partied and feasted in these begilded, bedraped, and bejewelled chambers. In 1917 February Revolution, the Provisional Government met for the very last time in the green-pillared Malachite Hall (room 198), before being arrested in the adjacent dining room. The building faces Palace Square, where Lenin’s Bolshevik forces assembled before storming in the Winter Palace and deposing the government. The museum is in the czars' old Winter Palace, the green-and-white building between Palace Square and the river.Tips:- Make sure you take a compound map of the Hermitage before passing the ticket barriers, as there are none to be had after them - and you'll be hopelessly lost without one.- Adult tickets purchased at the normal ticket counter would cost 400 roubles (approx. USD12). Students have free entry (show your ISIC!) but still have to line up at the normal ticket counter to claim the free ticket before entering.- Online purchase of admission ticket is available for adults and cost USD17.95 instead, and you get a voucher printout that can be exchanged for the ticket itself on the day of visit (you don't have to know your date of visit when you buy online, as the voucher is valid for 6 months). The exchange is done in a priority queue, separate from the normal counter. Tickets purchased online include a free photography permit (normally 200 roubles).- If you buy an adult ticket online but have students with you, these students together with you can join the priority queue with you despite them not having reserved any online. ISIC must be shown.- No one checks whether you bought a photography permit when you snap away- There is a Hermitage app on the Apple AppStore, although it's not very useful, it's free, you might want to check it out.
Alla Tours with Marina. Our tour guide did a great job of exposing us to the important highlights of the museum as we did not have 11 weeks and ony a couple of hours.

Overwhelming must see. No trip to St. Petersburg would be complete without a trip to the Hermitage. It is huge so you need to decide what you like to see and focus on that. We focused on interior and architecture and spend a very fast 2 hours which we thoroughly enjoyed.
