Remarkable Building and Exhibits. A marvel, both the palace itself and for what it contains. We visited as part of a tour with The Red October Tour Company, which was very important because we had limited time and needed a guide to show us through this massive facility. This is of course a must-do in St.Petersburg, as one of the largest and oldest museums in the world. Being able to see works of art by Michelangelo, da Vinci, Raphael, Degas, etc. is truly remarkable.

The Hermitage is Fabulous. No air-conditioning, so exhausting on a warm day. The buildings and the rooms are the must see. The art collection is among the world's best, AND the building may be the MOST beautiful in the World?Go.

Catherine the Great knew how to live. Recently spent a couple of days in St. Petersburg Russia.A must visit is the Hermitage museum and winter palace.Expect long lines and plan accordingly. One could literally spend days here. The ornate surroundings and works of art are amazing. However, leave it to the Russians to make a visit here somewhat difficult. If your flash goes off on your camera by accident, expect to be chastised and sent to the gulag.Plan the paintings you want to see in advance. It is easy to get lost and the palace is huge and imposing. Do not expect to see any signs in English so you may want to have a guide.We could not find the elevator to get to see the impressionists. However, even missing them, the other works of art more than compensated.If you love museums, and this one is one of the best in the world, give yoursellf as many hours as you can afford. Most tours will allocate a morning which is not enough time.The bathrooms are inadequate. Make sure you bring your own tissue paper with you to avoid unpleasant surprises.

Beautiful museum. This museum is massive and beautiful. You could spend a week just walking this museum and not do it justice. Beautiful artwork and sculptures not to mention the palace itself. I highly recommend buying your ticket online before going to the museum. If you just show up the lines are massive. It's not very well posted, but if you buy your ticket online you pass all the lines and just go to the service desk to get your entrance ticket.

Beautiful location, fabulous art collection, terrible crowds. We had a 2 hour guided tour so did not have to queue for tickets thankfully. The museum is vast and rammed with visitors so we just saw some of the highlights on our tour. The rooms are as spectacular as the artworks themselves. It was a hot humid day when we visited and with the crowds and the non-airconditioned rooms, we were sweltering. Beware you are not allowed to take drinks or any fluids in with you (they are confiscated if found as you enter) so hydrate well before you go in.

Needs more than one visit. Thankfully we had a guide! It has been said that if you take 1 minute to look at each item, it will take 9 years to visit! Had we been looking for items, or trying to follow a book, we would have needed a month. Each item more overwhelming than the next!

Ditch your guide, group. Get your map and go for it. THE Hermitage is pretty amazing , do,some research before hand to work out exactly what YOU want to see and go,for it, ditch your group, arrange a meeting  point  with your guide afterwards /grab a map and use the time wisely that way you won't be treated to,the Russian rooms and Russian paintings FROM YOUR russian guide but can actually appreciate the incredible selection that is there.  Take some extra time to,use their internet cafe ten cents for twenty minutes! And buy from their gift shops, truly a good selection. We had a ball in three hours , did loads at our own pace, ou can get English speaking headphones for hire
Hermitage. Building was fantastic! Art collection is much the same as other museums. It was crowded and very warm but I would not like to have missed it.

Man made wonder of the world. This place is so vast so big and so amazing that one wonders that centuries a go RussianTzars must be richest living kings on this earth. They have such a huge collection of rarePaintings and Statues made in various materials including solid gold and silver. A person canspend endless time watching these marvelous pieces of art.One must visit at least once in a life timeAnita Kshitish India

Oh, the crowds!. The big negative is the queue to get in and then all the pushing and shoving as you go around but the experience was worth it. By the time our guided tour had finished I had had enough and didn't stay to look around at other parts of this huge complex. You'd need a long, long time to see it all. However, the grandeur and the works of art are eye popping and mind blowing.
Beautiful!. Wish we had a week to explore this museum! I'd read about the winter palace and it was absolutely magnificent.
Another wonder of the world. A must see for everyone. Even if you are not into art or looking at artefacts the interiors of the rooms alone is worth the visit

One of the World's Greatest Art Museums in one of the world's great royal residences. The collection of Art within the Hermitage is second to none. There are over 10 Rembrandt's, several DaVinci's, Monet's, and Picasso's -- a veritable cornucopia of great paintings. In addition, the Hermitage now includes the Winter Palace, Peter the Great incredible mansion on Palace Square in St Petersburg.
Try to plan in advance what you want to see. The Hermitage is huge! Try to plan in advance what you want to see. Otherwise, you will be exhausted and could miss some artists that your wanted to see.
SPB tour. Big queues here but with SPB tours in immediately. Lovely sunny day and the hermitage was breathtaking
Hermitage. Too much to see but its worth a try on a short visit. Amazing art and decor, impossible to take it all in but worth the try.

Magnificient Art work. The Hermitage has many works of art that are worth the time to see. In addition the building itself has some spectacualer rooms that must be seen. It can be quite crowded as many tour groups visit this museum but we spent the money to hire a private tour guide who was able to provide us with many details about the Palace and the artwork.

Wow, wow, wow. So much quality and so much quantity. You need much more than 2 days to see it all. All impressionists were great, Gauguin, Cezanne, Matisse. Then you have huge rugs that I am stll wondering how they could be sewn. Furniture from old times. Just wanted to highlight for other TA travellers a tip I read in a previous review and that proofed to be really useful. Once you get in thru the main entrance, there are 2 automatick entrance tickets dispensers, both at left and at at right side. Avoid the queues and the crowd and get the tickets there. 400 Rubles in cash get you in and that is all. Change is provided by machines.

Hermitage. Everyone says it is a must do in St. Petersburg, but I am not so sure. For someone who visited most other great museums of the world, our visit to the Hermitage did not even come close to the Louver. Part of this is due to the fact that most people who arrive on cruise ships are allocated only 2-3 hours there, and they all arrive about the same time which make the visit extremely crowded (think of a visit to Versailles these days). In addition, the place is not air conditioned and can get very stuffy. But putting all this aside, I still found the Hermitage rather boring. There are very few important world famous pieces there and it's just not the high level as the Louver and d'Orsay. JMHO

The Hermitage..museum'd out. Huge. You need days to even see a small section of it. Dont like tge idea that you have to take a guide to get entry into the Diamond RoomDisliked - you pay a bomb for the Diamond Room and are zipped thru it in minutes. Frankly i couldnt understand the hoop la. Topkapi has a lot more
Hectic. Unfortunately during the short summer period the museum is overcrowded. Difficult to see anything. However, book the private viewing of the gold and diamond room which is spectacular

Unbelievable!. The Hermitage is much too big to be seen in the small amount of time we had, but our guide did her best to show us the highlights. It was simply amazing, all the gilt and carving, all the paintings from every genre from Old Masters to Modern Art. I heard that if you just spent a minute looking at each painting, viewing all the Hermitage would take seven years, so it was amazing that we saw so much in such a short time.

Beautiful. Everything was beautiful. I was a little bit frustrated becaused I ´ve purchased tickets for the Winter Palace and when I went for my visit, it was closed in the morning, and there was no signs informing it. As I had other activities to do in the afternoon, I couldn´t return to visit that part of the Hermitage.
Hermitage. Wonderful -- very clean and well maintained. The people were all very friendly and helpful. Paintings were magnificient. Tour guide was very professional and knowlegeable.

All is said already. Go there and enjoy. There will be a lot of people but it is a huge place. We booked a tour guide and that way avoided the queues. The tour was excellent and effective. Meaning that we could see the most important bits and listen to the very interesting information at the same time via headsets.

Comparable to the Louvre and just as exhausting--some tips. 1. Go on Thursday when it's free only if you are poor--extremely crowded in summer. 2. Get Tix online if you can so you go to head of the long line. 3. Go Wednesday, buy a ticket, and see the guidebook highlights, and then go back Thursday to see more obscure stuff tour groups skip. 4. Plan ahead what you want to see-- use a travel guide book like lonely planet. 5. Take little breaks to look out the window or sit on a bench and people watch or you'll just burn out. 6. Look up--the ceilings are amazing.

I could spend weeks here! History runs deep in Russia!. I spent 5 hours visiting the various parts of the Hermitage on my own, and 1.5 hours with a guide. This was some of the best spent time in Russia, and even in Europe. If I lived in St. Petersburg, I would bring all my visitors from around the world to see it - not just to share it and impress them, but for me to enjoy it again and again! Thank you Russian Federation for preserving this priceless home for your heritage.

4.5 Incredible- but crowded and frustrating.... Absolutely a must for everyone- a visit to the Hermitage. If you go during the summer months however, be prepared. No AC, crowds and lines that rival Rome, and the workers at the museum are, let's just say they aren't in a good mood, ever. They rush you through, you can't stroll and stop to take stuff in without being yelled at- but this was all expected. Despite all that, the building/palace and the art and exhibits are amazing and makes it all worthwhile. Something for absolutely EVERY taste and interest. I recommend taking part in a group tour, as they usually get to skip the long, hot lines.
tour part one. amazing art work, but very crowded, although we had early admission...the art was original, but much of the building had been restored to its former glory...amazing workmanship

Unbelievable Place. This museum is must on each itinerary during visit to this amazingly beautiful city. I just loved the city in my 2 visits with in 6 months. The museum is a combination of a palace, art gallery, jewelry collections and some of the rare paintings. One needs to avoid rush since it may get very crowded at times. This must be having one of the largest porcelain collections at par with Paris and Cairo, If I can recall my memory.
horrible guide. our guide was just awful(( no emotions, nothing interesting told, no useful facts, so we just left our excursion and enjoyed this place on our own!

A Must see. Housed in the winter palace, An amazing collection of Titian, and Da Vinci's Madona. the jewelry vault is a must see >book in advance as only a few visitors allowed everyday. Beautiful art pieces, sculptures , paintings,porcelain.
Amazing!. Unbelievable collections of Art dating from classical up to 20th century Picassos. Get there early if possible to avoid crowds.

Amazing. A must to visit. Beautiful museum. You cannot take it all in in one visit. Research what most interests you prior to visit and focus on that. Our guide said it would take 7 years in you spent just 1 minute looking at each piece in the museum!!! Dont miss the art gallery with the Monet, Picasso, Rembrandt etc. Also the Peacock clock is something to see. I there is any way to get the special viewing which is only about once a week go for it. The clock works perfectly still after 300 years. Look it up on you tube.

Superb. Too much to see in a day - all the other reviews already cover the art, artefacts and architecture any one of which on their own would justify the visit. My favourite place on St Petersburg. We visited as part of a trip with Guide-Guru, who got advanced tickets and also saved a place in the queue for us so we entered very quickly, with no waiting at all. It is just as easy to avoid the queue by getting advance tickets online. We didn't follow the guide - there were 6 of us, all with our own agendas for the visit so we just did our own thing. You will not see everything in one visit - I recommend you do a little on-line research before you go so you can focus on your own favourites to get the most out of your visit.

Gem of museum! MUST see. One of the greatest place "must see" in Russia. We would like to share some advice.1.There are many many visitors so be prepared. Buy ticket online is highly suggested.2.Waiting for lunch at cafeteria will consume your precious time (a long line) so bring along small pack of lunch is suggested, but don't bring bottle of drink since it's not allowed.3.Go early at 10 am and go to the highest floor first, then walk down, this will avoid congested rooms.4.Study before you go, have specific rooms in mind, you can not see all in 1 day.Enjoy!We took lots of photos, might give you the idea what are inside, take a look at https://picasaweb.google.com/100092841543065224921/StPetersburgRussia2013

Extraordinary. My third visit to this marvelous museum. Their "new" online purchasing of tickets and thus an "express" path to entry is a must as the morning entry lines have been ridiculously long and slow every time I've been there. And you must go in the morning because there is just barely enough time in a day to wrap your head around this place and limiting time to an afternoon is a travesty!

Great museum. Great museum/gallery. Ensure you allow yourself plenty of time to visit. We were there for 3 hours and didn't see all of one floor! There are 3. Tip - to save queuing, try automated ticket machines just in the left as you gi through the main entrance gate. They're not well signposted but you'll save loads of time and once you have your ticket you can go straight past the very long queue.
Good Gallery. Lots of old masters, new modern art, too much to see in a day, or even two. The crowds are the only thing that stops it getting 5 stars for me

Must See, Do Not Miss. This is a very impressive museum ranging from the architecture and finishes to artifacts, sculpture and art. There is much more to see than one would originally expect. Amazing original works of art. I would strongly recommend a guide to both help you navigate and gain some insight into the individual pieces as well as gain the advantage of early access such that you remain ahead of the large number of groups on bus tours or cruise ship shore excursions.Amazingly they allow photos of the original art masterpieces.
great visit. great visitguide was very knowledgeable and informedwe were there before but never saw as muchwe had a tour and also had time to ourselves to explore art we were interested in

Words fail me. Trying to see everything that the Hermitage has to offer in onw day is impossible. The sheer beauty if both the building and the art and artifacts it holds makes the task overwhelming. There is no surprise why it's the number one attraction of this great city.

Just answering other reviewer's comments. 1, Buy your ticket(s) in advance online. You can buy as many as you want and go as often as you want. You print your paid receipt, present it with your passport at a kiosk marked "Internet Tickets" and that's that. The lines to get in were huge. It took me less than five minutes to get in.2. You certainly do not need a group and since a typical group had about fifty travelers in it, they looked pretty miserable, being herded through the already crowded halls. 3. Use the museum website to plan ahead and just mark on a museum map what you want to see. If you don't want to be rushed, allow one day for the Old Masters, and the second day for the French Impressionists, ancient art, and anything you happen to really like4. Use the Audioguide. It's about $12 and is a really an art education (plus a tour of the winter palace)5. If you're going with another person or persons, agree to meet at the end of the day at a certain time and place. It is VERY easy to get separated (envision a Rolling Stones concert letting out). In order to avoid constantly keeping an eye out for traveling companions and not seeing any art, we all deliberately split up for the day and met a few hours later

Overwhelming experience - plan your visit carefully. Avoid the queues by booking a trip with a guide. Our guide smoothly whisked us past the quarter-mile line on a very hot day. Note that water is not allowed inside. I advise not to visit when temperatures are above 30 C (90 F) as the museum does not have climate control.The museum is much too large to see everything, try to find out beforehand what you would like to see, such as the collection of impressionist paintings, or the Gold room.The collections are most impressive, and we saw an overwhelming amount in 4 hours. Despite the crowds we were able to see all the important things clearly and up close, again our guide did a great job.

Magnificent palace. A palace-musium full of tresuries. You can enjoy the rich decoration of interiors and the masterpieces of the worlds heritage in peintings, sculptures...and the history of the russian royal family

A Must see, but leave time for the Russian Museum. We are huge art lovers, so spent 2 days at the Hermitage and used the Lonely Planet guide to guide us through. There is so much to see, so we felt an audio guide would be too much. Some of the guides seem to be going on forever, so we were glad we didn't have one of those either! We would also have to conclude that the best of many of the well know artists (Monet, Matisse, Degas for example) would be found elsewhere, and in better condition, however the collection is still worthwhile visiting.Do bring water and food with you, and a plastic bag to put it in that you can carry around with you, the one small counter serving refreshments is hopeless. Also, definitely book your tickets online before going, it means bypassing all the queues. Another think to take note, the 2 day ticket is only valid for 5 days.
Mindblowing. Hey - It's The Hermitage... What's not to like? Ranks right up there with The Louvre. The architecture, decorations, painting, sculptures. A "must see".

Fantastic do not miss. Well worth a visit when in St Petersburg. Fantastic paintings , and antiques. Make sure you book through a local tour company. We did a 2 day trip with SPB of saint petersburg. See our review which will be on this week.

Russian decadence at it's most splendid!. The Hermitage is a wonderful feast for the eyes,whether you are into art or not.The guided tours(collective visa) are fine for getting you in quickly and avoiding the crowds but they are rushed affairs.If we go again we will apply for our own visas and be able to visit at leisure.Priviet!

Absolutely Incredible - And Huge. First, the museum is never NOT crowded. My group was in the museum 1.5 hours prior to opening, and it was still wall to wall people. But it is so large that once you get up the main staircase, you can get to some areas that are manageable. The incredible amount of art spread through the museum and Winter Palace is almost unbelievable. BUT all tour groups will hustle you through all areas, so on your second trip, get an independent VISA and spend a day or two there.
once in a life time to see just see it. Its one of those places to see in your life time just go to see it and if you on a Thomson cruise all the better

Amazing collection, but terrible staff. The Hermitage is of course a must-see in St. Pete, both for art-lovers and for who has no idea of whats going on and is just following the tour guide. The collection was started by the art-lover empress Catherine the Great (who loved Da Vinci, so you'll see 2 of his 14 known canvases), and was extended over the years with donations including the fantastic Schukin collection, with a lot of Picassos. I also loved the hall with Canova's sculptures, Matisse's Dance and the fabulous Gainsborough Women in Blue. Having that said, the bad part of Hermitage is that it's located in Russia, which means TERRIBLE staff, almost nobody speaks english and the unfriendly russian ladies taking care of the rooms are never prone to help you. Seriously, these people seem to hate the foreign visitors. To get inside is a MESS, they don't have organized queues, people just gather in front of the gates and fight their way when they open. Therefore, my rating is ONLY for the collection and the building itself, staff and service are just TERRIBLE.

a must-see but overwhelming and practical aspects are missing. There has been so much said about the magnificent collections and incredible views of the museum that I do not have enough words to explain my emprissons by the art. You must go there! However, there are some aspects that do require improvement or you must be prepared to deal with. The first thing, which is more of a comment as there is not much to be done about it, I think that the tickets should be sold for 2-3 days entrance. The collections are so big that, despite their amazing content, my friend and I just passivley walked through half of them as the brain can't process this much art in one day. Now recommendations with comments. Make sure that you wear VERY comfortable shoes as there are many rooms and you "have to" see them in one day, but there are very rare benches standing in the corners of the corridors, so you always have to walk and cannot stop to contemplate looking at the picture (if you stop, you will be pushed by the crowd). The bathrooms are terrible and so few that there are always long lines, then it is not very clean (although alright)- this was already mentioned by other reviewers. The cafeteria, another complaint of the reviewers, is bad. Very few tables for such a huge museum, and a small variety of food. I won't complain about the prices though as everywhere in the world the prices in the museum cafes are higher. My friend and I paid 450 rubles for 2 sandwiches one green tea and one water. It is about 13USD- even cheap for some museum cafes. TO wrap up, I wrote all these to help you prepare for the difficult parts as they can really spoil the whole event, but you still must see the Hermitage as it is incredible!

Must visit here!!. Full of beautiful rooms, objects and art. I was part of a small tour group and our tour guide was able to take us through each room and she had extensive knowledge of everything which was fantastic. I would do this with a guide only who can talk you through each room and all the history.

Overwhelming Awesomeness. We were in St. Petersburg for three days and spent a half-day at the Hermitage. That does nothing more than whet your lips for a future visit. There are boundless treasures to be seen in this museum. Of course they won't tell you that after the 1917 revolution, much of the artwork and assets of anyone with means in the country was confiscated and nationalized - which serves as the foundation of all their modern artwork. In any event, the museum is phenomenal and should not be missed. Amazing history.

A place of Art missing enough toilets. Okay, the only thing is bad about Hermitage is that it has messy directions and it takes some walkaround to find a proper stairs or a toilet room if you are not using guide services. iPhone app helped a bit with Hermitage map, but still it was not that helpful as expected.
Hermitage Museum. Wish we had allowed more time to tour the state hermitage Museum and Winter Palace, so much to see. It is well worth allowing at least a full day to do a tour.

Must and maybe only museum to see in Russia. This has over 3m items and I think even better than louvre. Only thing ticket lines are long. If you want to avoid the hotel can book VIP ticket for 1500 rubles instead of normal ticket of 500 plus. You get the enter VIP way. Second for photography additional ticket is required 200 rubles please pay worth taking photographs. It is divided into three parts hermitage , winter palace and small hermitage. If you want to see all it can take more than one day. The most beautiful I liked was the peacock clock made of gold and silver. Also the ancient history has an excellent collection. Also the throne room worth taking pictures. The staircase is opulent. Also must see Russian room which is unique part. The cafe is really nice to take a break on ground level. I don't think you need a guide as it is very organized as books and audio guide is available. The cost of indivisible guide is around 1000 rubbles per hour and min 4 hrs. You can bargain if you can speak Russian. Tours in group much cheaper. Also the museum shops are good to shop. Please take camera coupon worth 200 rubbles. Our guide name was Janna aleksandrova , an English teacher around mid forties, number +7 981 799 79 29. Email is Alexa-zhanna@yandex.ru.

excellent. Too big to see in a day .its worth spending your time here.it is in city center and has a very pleasant surroundings,Many tourist sites are at vicinity and the museum display is splendor to watch

THEFT. Two days ago I was robbed of my wallet with credit cards and cash in the Leonardo da Vinci galleries. I did not feel my pocket picked. The distraction was by a Russian looking woman of 40-50 years old, round face with blond hair.Be extremely careful, these are professionals, within one hour they had taken a lot of money out of the account.

Great Museum. Excellent Museum.They run out of maps in English and couldn't care less to get more.Hardly anybody within the museum speaks english and they couldn't sometimes point us in the right direction.

Amazing art, but don't go hungry.... The only bad thing I have to say about this museum is the small, crowded cafeteria. It is such an amazing museum one would like to be able to sit and rest and eat something. it's terrible food but really terrible food so be sure to go eat somewhere else or bring your own. Only 3 choices of poor sandwiches and some crisps. Toilets crowded, not very clean. So the museum is amazing, the art and decoration do the 3 buildings are breath taking! We went on the white nights and although it is crowded it is not too much and one is capable of enjoying, sitting and admire the art peacefully.
blows your mind. If you look at each exhibit for 1 minute it would take 7 years. We didn't see every room but walked about 3 miles in the museum. definitely a must see in St Petes.

Amazing collection of Art. The Louvre pales in comparison to the Hermitage's collection of paintings. There are 26 Rembrandt's, two rooms full of Picasso and a large number of Van Gogh, Monet, Da Vinci, Caravaggio paintings amongst many others. You will struggle to take in all of it as there about 400 rooms in total. Wear comfortable shoes, take a bottle of water and some snacks with you ( the cafe inside is very pricey with limited choice) and don't miss the 'hidden treasures revealed' exhibition on the second floor which has some of the famous works by Monet.

A must visit. The art collection was amazing.I booked online and hence avoided the queues.This place is popular.The voucher must be redeemed at the entrance.A tour of the Diamond room was recommended but we did not get tickets for the English tour!Give yourself at least 3 hours or longer!
Overwhelming range of treasures. No wonder the people revolted! There was no limit to the amount the Tsars were spending on building up their collections.A must see!
Outstanding. Every room visually stunning, magnificent works of art. Once in a lifetime experience, fantastic place to visit,

Hermitage. Easy access for wheelchairs and mobility scooters. Fabulous Museum with works of art to suit every taste. 3 hours flew by. We were lucky enough to be able to visit earlier in the morning, Lifts available for disabled persons.

Magnificent. It is as impressive on the inside as it is on the outside. If you go to St Petersburg, you must not miss the Hermitage. If you can, set a whole day aside to see the Hermitage, because there is a lot to see: artworks and the beautiful palace. All is very well kept. The cafe is a bit crowded at lunch time and not as magnificent as the rest of the place, but passable and reasonable prices.

Hermitage and Winter Palace.. This is huge and one day is just insufficient. One should start early as the queues are long during peak season. All backpacks, umbrella, water bottles had to be deposited in the cloakroom, which also had a long queue.

My favourit culture. When I visited St Petersburg for the first time, I thought how much I would have liked to be a student here!But better Princess ... :)State Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace it is a must for art lovers. It's a great place. Not to be missed! One of my favorite place.

FABULOUS. The best site in St. Petersburg. The Hermitage is a must. Absolutely beautiful inside and so many rooms of art it is unbelievable. Try to get in as early as possible. We had a preopening visit at 9:30 and by 10:30 it was very crowded. There was a line outside by the time we were leaving at 11:30. One visit is not enough.

A. Maze. Ing!. Wow! Now THAT is an art museum! So many treasures to behold! Art is everywhere - from the hand cut wooden floors (a different design in every room), to the gorgeous architectural details on the walls and ceilings, fabulous chandeliers, and paintings and sculptures everywhere! My favorites were the Impressionists on the 2nd floor - Matisse, Monet, Renoir and friends, the throne room, and the gift shop (reproduction Faberge eggs are currently 20% off ;) Must Do (and with a private guide who can get you in front of the humongous line and direct you through this maze!)The Dismond room was amazing! Gorgeous diamond and gem encrusted snuff boxes, jewelry, Faberge miniatures of their Crown Jewels, religious bling, even bling for horses (along with bejeweled swords, daggers, and walking sticks)! The cafe has drinks, pastries, and pre-packaged sandwiches. Watch out for pushy, shovy tourists - some of them can be a bit obnoxious!

What a place. This museum has everything one could imagine. Someone said it would take 11 years to see everything there. I knocked it down a notch due to the chaotic scene there. They need to do a better job
An absolute MUST. We spent the whole day in the Museum and Palace and I could have spent more and more. It is absolutely fabulous - IMO better than Versailles

Wow - biggest and best art collection ever. We had reserved a 2 day pass to the Hermitage and made good use of the time. Nice to have an English guidebook to help lead the way. The building itself is an amazing place - but there is art here for everyone. Considering we came during White Nights, the crowds were manageable - should be on everyone's art bucket list.

Hermitage Museum. Set on a street opposite the river The Hermitage is an imposing building painted a soft green.In side this vast museum are some of the greatest Art work in the world ,in a word breathtaking.Give this amazing collection as much time as you can and it still will not be enough.The only drawbacks I found were it is very crowded and as there is no air conditioning very hot.
So much to see, not enough time. Allow lots of time to see this museum. There is so much to see. It is quite crowded and you need to keep up with your guide in order to hear.

Amazing, of course.... Great museum that is typical of its type. Not only do you see countless rare pieces of great art, but also you are touring a great piece of history. I wanted to compare it to the Louvre, but I can't, Russia is just too different. They are similar in some ways, but vastly different. The Hermitage was a full day of touring for me and I enjoyed every bit. It isn't as kept up as other museums of its caliber would be (but then it is Russia) and I liked that feel. This is of course a must stop, you cannot go to St. Petes and not see the Hermitage.

Fourth place on our cruise. Wow, I had always wanted to come here and it didn't disappoint. It was, however, very busy despite us being allowed in at 9.30 a.m. We took a tour organised by our cruise ship which was excellent, our young guide was very knowledgeable about the works of art and the building. It was, however, a bit rushed, we would have liked more time but as we were all worn out by the end maybe we just needed more days! Definitely a place to return to.
Hermitage. Great visit, very crowded. Our guide was excellent and very informative and knew how to try to avoid the masses of people

wonderful. the museum is very beautiful, plenty of important paintings and sculptures. The building is marvelous,but very big,so is important to make a plann of the visit.The informations are not very clear. I bought the tickets some days before my visit, in the site of the museum, but this is not necessary. The lines are inevitable.

Make sure you book a tour. OK, it is summer but there must have been 80,000 people visiting the day we went. Thankfully we went on a tour and skipped the 300m long queue. I strongly recommend booking a tour beforehand or at least getting your tickets online before you go and then hopping on one of the many tours inside the Hermitage. Having said that, it's a "must see" - its HUGE and you could easily get lost without a guide. The Winter Palace and Hermitage are amazing to see in themselves, plus all the art treasures own display, including Da Vinci's "other" Madonna which you can actually get up very close to as opposed to the Mona Lisa in the Louvre. Allow 2-3 hours to see the best of it. And be prepared for the huge crowds in every room and the sheer enormous scale of the place.

Fabulous Art. We were not disappointed in the fabulous art, but were disappointed in the time our tour allotted us to see it. Apparently the "Gold Room" is what they wanted us to see. So, we RACED past the fabulous paintings by Rembrandt, Titian, Caravaggio, Goya, Botticelli, etc. to get to the Gold room. there we spend an hour on a docent led tour which should have taken 15 minutes. I expected jewels and crowns, got snuff boxes and beads. If you have a choice, opt out of the Gold Room and go for more paintings.
exceptional. impressionist on the 2nd fllor is great. the luseumis very big. you better have to prepare your visit before

Beautiful, but crowded and hot inside- Diamund Fund tour disappointing. Unfortunately we went during 'White Nights' in June so the crowds were out which made it very warm inside the hermitage where a few open windows was the only source of air. We were blessed to have gone as part of a guided tour (Travel All Russia) which allowed us to cut some of the lines/crowd and gave a great commentary as we walked through all the rooms. I wish i would have had more free time to explore the galleries on our own but at least we hit all the highlights. We paid ~$75usd per person for the Diamond Fund Tour of the crown jewels etc and it was not worth the price, had we bought tickets through the hermitage it would have been only ~$10usd which would have been worth it for the price. My husband and I actually enjoyed the Armoury Tour at the Kremlin which was included in the Kremlin admission and was way more interesting to us due to the variety of items. The highlight of the Armoury Tour at Kremlin was the gowns and chariots on display, there was a room with ~20 chariots/stage coaches that were the most exquisite and ornate things- beyond your imagination!!
St Petersburg Cruise. Great tour, Very crowded, Loved getting in without waiting in line. Tour guide was great, spoke very good English and had alot of knowledge about the artwork.

A very special place at this time of year. If you intend to visit the Hermitage Museum, give yourself plenty of time. There are 3 lines: 1 for those getting free, on the day tickets, which is by far the longest, 1 for those buying specific tickets and 1 for those with pre booked online tickets. BUT, if you have an online voucher, you still have to line up to change the voucher into tickets. THEN, you line up inside the Winter Palace, which is the pastel green building, to scan your ticket before you can enter, but bear in mind at this point you meet up with hundreds of people in tour groups coming from the rear of the building, the side near the river. Soooo, in essence, give yourself plenty of time. They don't allow you to take liquid into the buildings and there is only one toilet area in the whole building. Which is at the front as you enter, so be warned. Once inside it is pretty well laid out, but so bloody big that you really must have set in mind what you want to see, because you will get lost. If you intend to see most or all of it, you wont do it in a day unless you zip through the rooms. I cannot impress on you the number of people at certain pinch points. Unbelievable, so many in fact that this in itself is a photo opportunity. Possibly due to the time of year. It has some absolutely stunning rooms and an obvious must. A little disappointed with the lack of info on most of the exhibits; where, why, how, who etc, but it didn't spoil it. I could go on and on. In a nut shell: do it. Don't go thirst or hungry or needing the toilet and take time to sit/stand and simply wonder. Have a great time.

Amazing!!!. I think the most precious and worthiest place in whole Russia is State Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace. I spend three days and each day 4 hours to see the most important objects. It's better to book a ticket in advance otherwise there is a limitation of visitors for each hour, and then you have to wait for long time in a long queue. Do not forget the Davinci Hall there you can two of its original works from 19 remained works of him.

Hermatige a beautiful gracious museum and palace. It is so huge. People treasured it even during the Soviet era, and died during the siege of Stalingrad ( as St. P was known in Soviet times) to protect its treasures from damage. The art is world class, and so are the furnishings, ceilings, floors and general decor. It would take you 6 years they told us without break to see everything in the palace. We were fortunate to see it at night when it was closed to the general public, and that made it so much more special as the crowds were just three or four groups from our two Holland America cruise liners, and there was no crowding so you could see everything without feeling squashed or fighting others to get a look at a painting or sculpture etc.

Go at 3AM.... ...And sit by yourself near that most incredible statue, right in-between these two awe inspiring structures. Listen to that guy playing jazz trumpet behind the paper mache moon by the Hermitage.Then take a nap, strap on some comfortable shoes, and get to the museum early to avoid lines that will make you remember what it is like to wait in Customs.

speechless wonder on earth. How can anyone describe the incredible beauty of this giant palace and museum . Take comfortable walking shoes a good guide and arrive early .. HOrdes of tourists from Asia had already flooded the place when we arrived.. the efficient ticket and entry gates made the visit truly memorable.. Hermitage is a true wonder of the world and the gardens of the winter palace are remarkable.. Both buildings are testimony to the great vision of the Russian rulers.. their opulence and vision and also reminds us all about the rise of the Bolsheviks and the Communist ideals against such contrasts.. GO GO GO and take lots of pictures.. Truly inspiring..

Building was interesting. The building was interesting, but thought the collection were not as much. Be prepared to leave much of your belonging in cloak room. Not worth paying the extra 200 rubles for the camera.. nobody has the sticker on them and are taking pictures. Management of the lines to access ticketing are not great.

Excellent Museum. The Hermitage is an excellent museum with many displays. One really needs to be able to spend days here to fully appreciate all the items that are on display. A visit of 3 or 4 hours is great for a quick overview but that amount of time does not really scratch the surface on what is here.

On par with the Louvre. Beautifully restored building and amazing artworks ,thought it on par with the Louvre and it takes just as long to see through it.Unfortunately did not have long enough there to really appreciate the architecture and the diversity of the artworks.It is possible to do a snapshot tour of the museum in about 2 hours but you are barely scratching the surface ! Was very crowded when we were there and because there is limited air conditioning it was not for the feint hearted,make sure you have some water with you if you plan to spend any length of time there.There is also limited wheelchair and disabled access and no lift access to some floors.Some elderly people we were with had difficulty with the stairs and the heat
Hot summer afternoon. Given the weather and the heat I was surprised to find that there was no temperature control and that visitors could take photos of most of the items on display

Amazing-Don't miss it!. Went with a group tour, and also with it seems thousands of other group tours - which goes to show how popular it is. The buildings itself of the Hermitage occupy 5 impressive buildings, which you walk through from 1 to the others.It is amazing both outside and in, and right on the banks of the River Neva. The artifacts and original paintings by painters such as Leonardo Da Vinci and others are a must see. It was one of the highlights of St Petersburg which in itself is an amazing city.You don't need to do a group tour , there are times when groups don't go in. The opulance in these buildings which date back hundreds of years, show how rich the rich were and in contrast how poor the poor were. The decor was incredible.
1st Trip to Russia. For a first visit I enjoyed everything. Just very expensive, so when you plan make sure you include any expensive meals and drinks into the budget.

Misnomer of a name. I fail to understand as to how this luxurious palace of Catherine the Great has come to be called Hermitage, normally an abode of hermits who live solitarily. Many visitors rush through this Art Museum in a jiffy but you need many hours and even days to see and appreciate the best collected Artifacts. It is also said that if a connoiseur spends one minute for one exhibit, he would need around six years to view the whole Museum. Such is the magnitude. The Palace itself is an architectural beauty and the pastel shades of white and green chosen for the exterior is eyecatching when viewed from the far off Fort. The Red granite Alexander Column in the courtyard is something unique in its class. It is also unfortunate that this Palace was the first target of Revolutionists in 1917. A World icon indeed.
Amazing Collection of Treasures. Works by many of the greatest craftsmen and artists can all be seen in one place, a truly fascinating collection.

A must see!. We traveled with SPB tours...they got us in early and through the main parts efficiently. Do not expect to see it all, there is simple too much to see. If the weather is warm be warned that there there is no air conditioning in the buildings.It gets very hot. As well, it will get very crowded so get there early. It is very sad to see some of the pieces as they are exposed to the heat and elements like light and humidity. A must to see!

A must. This museum is the 2. largest ( no. 1 is Louvre) in the world. But that is not the main reason to visit this museum. It is restored in a unique way with authentic materials collected from all over the world. So it is in the same condition as when it was built. And it is very special, as it was restored under communist regime. And many, many kilos of pure gold was also used. And as we all know, the rest of the buildings the communist made were just awfull.

one treasure after another. The art here is remarkable in its breadth and depth. One needs a good guide to savor the highlights and steer one through the crowds in four hours. If you have two or three days you can go by yourself to see this vast museum..

Arrive early and be prepared for crowds.. If you can stretch your budget, book a guide as there is very little non- Russian signage. We paid 300 rubles each for the audio headsets - was disappointed as many of the rooms and displays are not covered. We booked guides through Star Travel in St. P. and they were excellent.
everything we'd heard about and more. The entire experience was excellent, with convenient wheelchair access and friendly staff making our visit to this world-famous attraction a genuine pleasure.
very good. The tour was very good, excellente.This was my 2 time I went to Russia, St Peterburg is a beatiful city.

place to visit. If you visit Saint-Petersburg, it is a fact that you should visit its cultural stronghold-Hermitage, if you don't like ancient or classic art, visit the last floor to take a look at modern one or visit temporary exhibitions
Very nice Museum. Very nice museum! Stunning art! Including original piece from Leonardo Da Vinci, Rembrandt and more! Very big, but well worth the see!

The Best Museum in the world?. Hint: Avoid the one day of the year that has free entry at all costs!Hint: Try to find an English speaking guide who speaks good English!! Hint: It's a bit like Disneyland of museums and one day will not do it justice, especially when 25,000 other people are visiting because it's free. Eat in the cafe, take in the scenery from the amazing windows and just absorb the absolute ridiculous wealth that surrounds you. I actually found it more fascinating than The Louvre, with a totally opposite feel to The Guggenheim, truly one of the best Museum/ Art Galleries in the world!

Great experience. We enjoyed our trip to the Hermitage. Every room holds another wonder. The building itself is remarkable. Every time we'd enter another room first thing we'd do is 'look up'. Then, 'look down'. The floors and ceilings should not be ignored. The exhibits speak for themselves. The pity of it is that it is so very crowded but for the most part the crowds move steadily. We enjoyed a light lunch in the Hermitage Cafe which was quite reasonable. The books in the bookshop are very well priced if you're wanting to purchase books.

The beautyof the buildings the fabulous masterpiece collections. St Petersburg is an amazing city ,the history, impressive churches filled with historical background like the Church of Spilled Blood.St Peterhof Palace that is like the Palace of Versailles with even more to look at!The metro stations that have chandeliers & marble not to mention the glass figurines and the most spotless trains!Everywhere there is so much history and beautifully maintained buildings.

Huge museum, Fantastic inner palace rooms. Spent about 2 hours in the winter palace this afternoon. Its a great building with some incredible rooms and exhibits to look at. There is an extensive art collection which is very impressive. 2 hours was the minimum time in which we could have gone round it. There was a lack of English translations around the museum which was frustrating. We got an audioguide which gave us a lot more information at a cost of only 350 rubles which is a hell of a lot cheaper than hiring a guide. This was the main attraction we came to see and were not disappointed. However beware the location marked on the trip advisor map is incorrect. We didn't have any other maps and ended up walking out to a random part of town looking for it. In hindsight it was a schoolboy error, but I'm sure we are not the only people to ever do it!

Wow! No wonder there was a revolution!. Fantastic place. Went as a tour from a cruise ship so we were on a timeline. Paid extra to see the Gold Room - well worth it. Got very crowded as the morning went on but didn't spoil it besides having to wrestle the Japanese tourists away so that you could actually see some exhibits. Fantastic modern art section too - never realised that Picasso did ceramics. Just scratched the surface in our 3 hour tour - you could spend days here. No much accommodation for those with walking difficulties - there was a lift (allegedly!) We dint require it but felt sorry for those who struggled.

Whow!!!. A real treasure! Cruise ship groups are a pain, just try to avoid them. Dedicate a full day if possible, it is worth the effort! Very positive: liberal photography policy. Buy a ticket and shoot as much as your memory card takes up and the battery allows.
One of the worlds great art museums. Buy your ticket online before hand (even that morning) to avoid the big line.See your fill of Rembrants, Monets, etc etc. This is a big time museum for sure.
Not to be Missed. The collection is on a par with those of the best museums in the world. It is vast and having a guide is a huge advantage, starting with avoiding the long line at the entrance.
Splendid art works and opulent rooms filled with treasures. Our visit was in high tourist season,so the rooms are crowded and we were forced to move on quite quickly.
Absolutely beautiful. We had a very well-informed guide who gave us a great two-hour tour showing us the highlights, and I was very impressed with the museum and with the tour.

Overwhelming. Luckily we had a tour guide who picked up quickly on what we wanted to see because after 21/2 hours we just touched the surface. Supposedly what is in the museum at present is only a fraction of what is in storage. Even though a tour is almost mandatory for foreign visitors, some of our group wandered off by themselves to see particular exhibits. The winter palace has been totally refurbished and one gets a good incite into the life of the tsars. It is amazing that the government of Russia has put so much money into restoring an era they wouldn't recognize for years. There is so much to see but very little is translated into English and it is not easy to find out where many of these artifacts originated. Well worth many more visits.
Alla Tours at the Hermitage. Early entry allowed us to see so much with no crowds. Our Alla Tour guide knew so much and moved quickly and efficiently through.

Go early. We went by oursleves and not with a tour but had an incredible time, took about 4 hours and when we left the line was long. I wish we would have known we could have gotten tickets from the cruise ship.

Strong impressions.. It's very huge and beautiful museum. First thing you need to know about Ermitage - you never examine it for one visit. It has many halls, expositions, relics and pictures... When I was there for the first time - I got lost there, seriosly! You can see a dawn of the Russian culture, Egyptian and even the Greek exhibits. Excellent place for those who is interested in mythology.

Immense. Its amazing that despite the revolution and anti czar feelings, despite WWII, so much was preserved and not simply destroyed. Get on a small tour - DenRus does tours of St. Petersburg with 12 to 13 people. This place is worth the trip to St. Petersburg.
Hermitage Palace. Astounding and outstanding historical icon with so much artisticdisplays to see. Absolutely unique.

Hermitage/Winter Palace. Visited the Hermitage and Winter Palace on our tour with Alla-Tours. We got early entry and it is a fantastic site. Our guide was very knowledgable and gave us a great overview of everything we saw during our visit. A must see when visiting SPB

Take your time with your favorite painters. In addition to the imperial splendor of the buildings, this museum has among the most outstanding collections of Rembrandts and of early 20th Century painting (Cezanne, Matisse, Monet, Picasso) in the world. There are also Greek antiquities, etc. Take at least two days to break up your visit. Make sure to buy tickets online in advance; it will save you a TON of time waiting in line. The only negative is the ridiculous behavior of tour groups of all nationalities who literally dash through the museum, shoving you out of the way to take pictures of paintings they don't even bother to look at.
Worth a visit for sure. I liked it, but it's so big that when I finished I had no more energy for anything. It's is so pretty though it's a must go.
Stunning. The paintings by such masters as Van Gogh and Da Vinci are rightly displayed in this magnificent setting. The history contained within these gilt walls is fascinating.

As important as the Louvre. Having a private tour avoided some of the crowds. You need to decide before hand what you want to see since the Hermitage is vast. It takes hours to see some of it. Wear comfortable shoes.
good. Its a huge museum but worth seeing. It is very near to city center and easily accessible.The royal jewels display is very good and the palace is marvellous

Incredible..... Both the buildings and collection are of outstanding quality. You need at least a day (possibly 2) to do justice to the Hermitage. Also you need to be determined enough to get to the far reaches of the museum. For some of the best is hidden away, such as the red and gold small state rooms,

Amazing - Breathtaking - Crowded. Believe me this is very, very crowded. We were fortunate to arrive there just minutes after it opened - I think from memory 10.30 in the morning. Our guide was incredible - she was a history professor from the St Petersburg University and hefr knowledge of Russian history was mind blowing .. she told us on a number of occasions that 'this is my life'. So - put up with the crowds and take your time - it is truly spectacular and the art .. well - they have on display two works by Leonardo da Vinci of only seven left in the world. The Russians are spending mega dollars restoring these palaces but be assured that this is as good as Versailles in France ... By the way - be prepared to walk ... we walked over three miles.

One of the best museums in the world. They have so many collections of arts and treasures, not only Russian or Europe, but also Asian pieces. It was really mesmerizing walking to each room with different themes. However, the line to buy ticket was really long ,but I am a student which was free to get in, so I cannot complain about that.

Once inside, wonderful. We got our tickets ahead of time "to avoid waiting on line" No one seemed to know where you had to go with the online voucher to get the tickets and when we finally found the place, there was a huge line. We would have been better off going to the kiosk to buy our tickets (and would have saved the extra fee).Once inside and away from the initial crowds, it was magnificent

Beautiful Palace, Superb Collection. There is very little to add to the previous reviews, this is truly a treasure house in terms of the collections and the palace itself. A few tips - (1) We purchased a two day pass online. With your online pass, from the main plaza, proceed through the courtyard (past the lengthy lines) and enter the main entry hall. At the information/reception desk in the center, your online ticket's validity will be verified. At that point we directed to a less crowded ticket box (near the cloak rooms). the cashier generated tickets for our party (first day/second day tickets). One observation, line etiquette is not always observed, be patient and persistent. (2) Our college student was able to get a free entry at one of the regular ticket boxes next to the information/reception desk. She used her regular university ID card, from a well-known school, instead of one of the "international student ID cards" that most of the other venues expect. (3) The two day ticket is well worth the additional cost. It allows you to break up your visit and avoid "museum fatigue" - this is a huge site. (4) A beauty of independent travel is the ability to enjoy the palace and collections at your own pace. We repeatedly found ourselves leisurely marveling at the private and state rooms as tours raced by at a breakneck pace.

Not to be missed. It is fantastic, but besure to get early admission. Lots of walking! Our guide from SPB tours, Luba gave us great information in every room and guided us so that we did not have to stand in lines.

Must See. Purchased two-day pass online. Must print out invoice and go to a SEPARATE line to exchange for tickets. Took 30 mins at 10:30 am. Once you have your tickets, DO NOT wait in the next, long line. Go immediately inside. Will need to put large bags etc. in the cloak room. Take small only. Seemed EVERYONE was freely taking photos everywhere with cameras and phones without paying extra for the privilege. Only can't photograph what is marked no photo. No flash on paintings, only flash for statues. SUPER CROWDED. Turn immediately right upon entrance and use ticket to pass through turnstiles. Absolutely get a free map in your language which shows the three floors and color codes and numbers the rooms according to what era-nationality painters you wish to see. The room numbers are above almost every door and are for the room that you are presently INSIDE, NOT the one you are entering. Also, the Winter Palace is amazing architecture and history itself. The mechanical gold Peacock clock functions ONLY on Tuesday. Check for the time. Recommend starting on the third floor and working down to avoid the massive crowds and annoying tour groups who act like they own the place. Internet cafe good for lunch and a sit down. Allow for three hours daily. Excellent value for two days. Lovely location on Neva River in the Nevsky Prospect.

One of the most impressive attractions I have ever visited!. This is a must visit in St. Petersburg – it is just overwhelming! I recommend to buy a ticket in advance on the museums website and stay in line half an hour or more before it open to avoid the crowds. The Hermitage is huge with many buildings so you need at least 5 hours for your visit. If you would like to take some nice photos during your visit (see my attached photos) I recommend a wide angle lenses!RegardsSvein-Magne Tunli from Bergen, Norway.

For art lovers. Though the museum is huge and packed with impressive works of art (as well as an exploration of the lifestyle of the Tzars) it is not as well curated as the British Museum. I am not a huge lover of art galleries but I went to the Hermitage because it is one of those places that you are told you have to go and see when in St Petersburg. If I had the choice though, I wouldn't go here again. There were so many tour groups that it was often difficult to get close to any of the paintings or sculptures and the staff were characteristically unfriendly. Also, the café was absolutely dire so make sure you eat before you go. My advice would be to go to see the impressive building from the outside, and if you are going to Moscow as well as St Petersburg then the Tretyakov Gallery is far more impressive.

Stunning. Took a two day pass and spent a couple of hours both days. So much to see, you have to be selective. Rembrandt , Reuben , Van Gogh . Wow. And the palace, the opulence, the marble floors and staircase..... Incredible.

Impressive. Largest museum in the world full of pairings statues and many more things used by tsars and zarinas it is not possible to go through whole museum in one day you need to skip so many things to complete it is very interesting

St. Petersburg - The Hermitage. Today in St. Petersburg we had a half-day tour of the Hermitage, something of a continuation of the "gilt trip".from yesterday's tours of the Catherine Palace and Peterhof Palace. I think I’m going to have to paint all the ceilings when I get back home, plain old white ceilings will seem so vanilla, after all this. I guess I can do that after I install the new fountains I’ll have to order for the garden (s); once those are finished I can tackle the parquet for the floors. The Hermitage is one of the world’s great museums, the problem with the ship’s tours however, is that you get herded through the museum like cattle. It’s the only option unless you hold an individual visa - like most passengers we were under the ship’s visa which only allows you ashore as part of the ship sponsored tours. Since we didn’t have a tour this morning we had to stay on board, border control is very strict. Anyway, while you wouldn’t want to miss seeing it, the Hermitage in the summer is hot, crowded and rushed. You come away with a general impression of the wonder of it, but there’s not time to really learn about anything in depth. The commentary was along the lines of: “Important visitors came up this staircase, here’s the throne, here’s a picture of Alexander the Great (no it’s not Napolean), now we’re going to see Tintoretto – please move to the right, we have to squeeze in with this other group.” Like a high-speed car chase through Manhattan and then you can say "There! I've seen New York!"I’m kind of surprised at the museum; not having climate control, allowing works by famous painters like Raphael to hang in direct sunlight, the crowding in front of the most renowned works by painters like Tintoretto, Reuben and Davinci. They don’t make you wear shoe coverings, and the priceless parquet floors are getting worn and pitted. There were many people even taking flash photos, although the signs say not to … nobody stops them! I guess the government has more critical issues to address than art preservation, but it was surprising after being in museums like the Smithsonian or the British Museum in the past.Don’t get me wrong, the Hermitage is spectacular – I just hope they get a bit better at crowd control in the future. About 5 million people live in St. Petersburg (20% or so are illegal immigrants, which is hard to understand with the tight border controls), but about 10 million a year visit as tourists. Especially by cruise ship. Makes for some real chaos when there are six or seven ships in port at the same time.We also swung past the Sts. Peter and Paul Fortress, but there wasn’t time to go inside – at least I saw the exterior. There are so many great works of art & architecture in St. Petersburg that you just can’t see it all in a short trip, but you do get a sense of the importance of this city on the Neva and it’s place in Russian history. (Did you know that EVERY Tsar was assassinated? They lived well, but paid a high price for it in the end.)To see the rest of my blog about this trip please visit http://sailorscruisenews.blogspot.com.

Nice Museum. If you go to Saint Petersburg and plan on visiting a few museums, this one has definitely to be in your shortlist. Located at the center of the city at the very end of the Nevsky propect and right by the Neva, you can't miss this impressive white and green building. (the museum is housed in the winter palace)It's easy to wander for hours in the museum without still having seen the main attractions. I advise you to start with the second floor and get the chance to navigate directly among the royal apartments. Then depending on the time or on your tiredness, you'll either choose to climb the stairs to see the masterpieces of famous French painters (Picasso, Gauguin, Matisse) or to go downstairs and enjoy the Antiques.Plan on spending at least 3 hours in this museum, entrance fee : 400p
not to be missed. It is worth getting a personalized guided tour for 1 to 3 people, there is so much to see. One day is not enough.

We visited on a day when it was closed to the general public so it was not so busy. We were very lucky.. We had an excellent guide from Alla Tours who knew the place very well and managed to show us a good selection of paintings and sculpures from the collection in addition to the royal apartments.

Outstanding Art Works. They call it a Museum which in respect it is but the collection of Art works places it more on a par with the Louvre in Paris.It is a magnificent building and the paintings are well displayed. The two paintings by Leonardo da Vinci are small but outstanding.Great place to spend some time.

Amazing places. I love visiting the museum and palace. There are so much to see but not enough time. However, the tour guide was excellent in avoiding crowd. She knew exactly where to go to see all the most famous point of interests!!

Incredible. Anyone going to St. Petersburg is going to the Hermitage, it is a must...it is overwhelming..the art is outstanding and there is so very much of it, that it is hard to take it all in and appreciate it. You would need we were told if spending one minute in front of each exhibit, 13 years to see everything....
Hermigage Amazing. Very Interesting, went with tour guide Alla Tours. So many paintings amazing place and so much to see.

Excellent collection of art. Beautiful building with an excellent collection of art. Like the Louvre and the Vatican collections, this should not be missed. Highly recommend a tour so you get in before the crowds (one hour early entrance). Will make the Hermitage much more enjoyable when it is just you and your guide looking at a piece of art that you know in one hour will be mobbed!

Must see the gold room. Our tour of the museum was a little whistle stop as we were delayed by the St Petersburg rush hour which starts a t 9am and finishes at 6pm!!!! The Gold room was magnificent despite the fact that a boring Russian guide spoke her bit and our guide paraphrased and shortened it.It is not just gold but gems,ceramics and case after case of beautiful artifacts.Many pieces had been bought or gifted to the Czars and the wealth was amazing,no wonder they had a revolution!The museum is huge and resting is not encouraged and getting in through the turnstiles a bit of a bun fight as you can loose site of your guide,

Vast Museum. We recently toured a small part of the Hermitage while on an excursion with SPB Tours. We selected this tour company to do six days of tours while in St. Petersburg, Berlin, Aarhus Estonia, Helsinki and Stockholm while on a Princess cruise.Our guide was Eugene and he was excellent. He took us to the part of the museum that most people want to see and that was the Master's paintings, like Picasso, Monet etc. They were fantastic to see, but the rooms were very crowded. We were advised at all places with these conditions to protect our wallets.Anyway, the Hermitage is huge with many buildings and it contains some spectacular collections. When you only have an hour, it is tough to see much. But If you have more time, it is a must see and well worth the time.

Long lines. We visited toward the end of May, which we were told was off season.. Be prepared for extremely long lines due to cruise ship visitors. We were told that the summer season is even more crowded. An obviously great museum in the 'French style'. The museum contains a most basic cafeteria

Never enough Time for this Must See!. We spent 3 hours in one day and saw only the highlights of the highlights. IF you are a museum person, you could get lost in its 4 buildings. Just go early. The crowds are terrible. Wall to wall people which makes really seeing things a bit hard unless you go with an after hours program

The ultimate museum. This is the must see museum, thats coming from a person who doesn't usually go to museums. There is no way this place won't exceed your expectations. Do yourself a favor, buy tickets online, and go there on a full belly. Amazing place.

The Hermitage, St Petersburg. It can be very,very busy, so get there as early as you can and don't try to see it all - it is impossible. If you only stopped for 1 minute at each exhibit it would take you 12 years to get round! There are excellent guide books which recommend what to stop at.

Absolutely STUNNING collection. If you love art and are spending some time in St. Petersburg, DON'T miss the Hermitage. HOWEVER, I would recommend going on the day it is closed with a private guide. This way, you will avoid the stupid masses. The idiots who aren't there to see and appreciate art, but rather are there to simply check it off their list of places they've been and to take endless pictures of themselves and the art. I realize that this is the way things are now, but seriously? Sorry, I digress...The collection is absolutely amazing. The buying spree they went on before the Bolsheviks was one helluva spree! From Da Vinci to Matisse to Chagall to Picasso. ALL of the big names are here, but it's also the vast collection from lesser known artists that were the most stunning (Mikhail Vrubel!). This place is HUGE, so choose your collections carefully and don't forget to take in the grandeur of the Hermitage itself. If you don't have a guide, be sure to get an audioguide. Although they're a bit spotty in certain collections, overall, they're really good. They also have a lot of info about the building itself.
Hermitage. Purchase the services of a guide for three hours. They are very helpful and make the visit twice as valuable.
A must see. It's just amazing. The art work, the antiquities, the jewels, the crystal......OMG it was so totally awesome.

amazing. would say a highlight of our visit to st. petersburg.
beautiful edifice. such opulence. amazed at the paintings.

Unparalleled Opulence!. You may love Versailles, the Louvre or the MET; but until you have experienced the Hermitage and Winter Palace in St. Petersburg, you have not witnessed quite the same vast and wondrous collection of art, architecture and history housed in one site. Two days was not enough time to see it all; but certainly whet the appetite for a return visit. Simply marvelous.

Watch Out St. Peters, Louvre, etc.. Museum has a vast collection spread across many miles of rooms. Don't plan to see it all in a day. Most formal tours run about 2 hours. Thee are indeed amenities such as bathrooms and lockers. Don't miss the Renaissance and Impressionist rooms (a whole room of Rembrandt, for instance). Remember to look up, down, and around corners, The mix of art, craft of the highest caliber, cabinetry, etc. is spectacular. This is a MUST SEE.

A Breathtaking Experience!. The Hermitage….. one of the oldest and largest museums in the world is breathtaking! The palace is amazing with its intricate details, the decor and paintings on the walls and ceilings… all portraying overwhelming beauty. The artwork, namely, the room of Picasso's works, was worth the visit in itself. Our visit to the Hermitage, with early entrance, was part of our tour itinerary with SPB Tours. As soon as we entered the Palace, we were thankful that we had a tour guide to provide us with the history and facts surrounding the Palace and Museum as well as someone to guide us through the numerous rooms! It made our experience so much more memorable!

Hermitage Museum- Wow. What an experience visiting this wonderful, old, historical museum with all it's interesting items. I was here on a tour via the travel agency SPB Tours and the few hours we spent there just getting a little taste of the museum was to say the least, not hardly enough to appreciate all there is there. There is so much history to this museum that one should read up on it before coming here. I will only say that if you're in St Petersburg for any length on time, this museum is a MUST and if you're taking a tour, I highly recommend SPB Tours because they use 16 (max) passenger mini bus. Our guide was outstanding because she gave us so much information it was unbelievable not only while we where in the museum but through out the whole tour on places we visited. My tour lasted 2 days with them while my cruise ship was docked. They had their mini bus waiting for us each morning as we got off the ship. Bottle water was provided and also lunches was good and different.

Billions of dollars of paintings guard by Babuskas. The inside is a little worn...but definitely worth seeing. The artworks are amazing but some rooms are poorly lit with florescent tube lights which give glare. we went first time with a private guide...it is so immense I can't imagine going by ourselves the first time. This place has no decent cafe. The museum could make a fortune on the hungry tourists if it had one!

Fantastic Museum. This is a must see for travelers to St Petersburg, although good to keep in mind the sheer size of this place! I only had a few hours here which was not enough. A day would be good to take it in and I would get an audio guide next time as very little information is in English. Staff are helpful (even when not speaking English!) and exhibits are set out well.
Amazing but overwhelming. Catherine the Great did a fantastic job getting this place set up but it is a bit of a cultural/art overload. You need a few days to really appreciate it but worth seeing.

Amazing - so much better than was hoping for. Thsi place is amazing. Extremely interesting and laid out so much better than the Louvre. Dont waste your time with Paris, go to St Petes, purchase a ticket on line or at the machine to avoid queueing, avoid the cruise crowds by not following a route but by just wandering. Take water with you and be prepared to spend the day in amazement

Glorious past of the Tsars. Art work of Picasso,Rembrandt ,Goya and all the royal possession of the Tsars .The museum is located in the winter palace of theTsar, which must be kilometers long you need 3 to 4 days to see the museum . The collection of the artifacts is mind boggling. A must visit.
Beautiful but busy. Lots of art and artifacts. I liked the everyday items that were displayed from everyday life of the wealthy.

The Lourve of St Petersburg. The Hermitage is one of the largest and oldest museums in the world! I, generally speaking, prefer to saunter through museums without a guide, but in the case of the massive Hermitage having an expert to show us the highlights was helpful. We attended art classes onboard our cruise ship and this also enhanced the enjoyment of our tour. The crowds were the downside even though we went during the off season. I can't imagine what it would be like during the peak season.
Worth the 4,000 mile trip to see it!. World-class, fabulous, the equal of the Louvre or NYC or Cairo museums. I could have spent a month there.

Book in advance via INTERNET!. you will save much time in the queue. Hermitage worth also a 2-days visit so for fewmoney more you can buy a Internet access in advance and enjoy your visit to one on the most powerful collection in the world. Three millions of masterpieces worth some calm to be visited.Be happy!

Do not miss this museum. If you are a lover of European art and/or historical buildings, then this is a must-see. From Old Masters to the Cubists, they can all be found here. The architectural details from the wood inlay floors to the painted ceilings will leave you awestruck.

THE stand-out St Petersburg attraction!. I recently spent a morning at this museum, but would have loved to go back the next day. There is far too much to see in one visit, but three-four hours at a stretch is probably as much as the average person could manage. The building is magnificent in itself. I doubt that I have ever viewed so many masterpieces in any other gallery or museum. Our group also had a private tour of the collection of royal jewellery, china etc and the guide's explanations were extremely interesting and helpful. If you go to St Petersburg, you MUST go to The Hermitage.
Great Visit. Its worth going, must take umbrellas, as it can get hot and our guide kept seeking shade and avoided sunny areas.

A must see even with it's drawbacks.. The Hermitage Museum in St Petersburg, Russia houses some two million pieces of art. I have wanted to visit the Museum for many years and finally got the chance when we cruised the Baltic Sea. The collection is housed in the Winter Palace of Czar Peter the Great. Perhaps because my expectations were so high because of the reputation of the museum, and because I have had the opportunity to visit so many great art museums, I found myself greatly disappointed. Because it was a residence, albeit a grand one for a Czar, it is not well organized for viewing the collection. Added to that, I thought the collection was not well displayed to be able to enjoy the experience. In most of the museum the art is over shadowed by the beauty of the Palace itself, and it is without question a grand palace. We might have had a better experience if the number of people in the museum had been better regulated. Entrance to the museum is theoretically time controlled by a reservation at a set time. Apparently there capacity control is not well managed as it was very overcrowded making it difficult and in some cases impossible to see some of the more popular pieces. Shocking to me, considering the value both historical as well as intrinsic, was the lack of temperature and light control. Natural lighting from large and extensive windows have got to be taking their toll on the collection as well as making for poor lighting for viewing. The rooms were overly warm and they opened windows in the galleries to help cool the spaces. All that being said, the art is great and I would not have missed the experience. I would heartily recommend a visit to anyone who has a love for art. Just something you have to do.
Amazing. the small group tour allow us to see more than other tours, the art ant the palace itself are wonderful

Breathless!. We bought our tickets online prior to leaving the UK. We decided to buy 2 consecutive days access as there was too much to see on one day. This does avoid the queues which can be really long. A good tip is go and have a general look round on one morning and then visit again the next day if you have an interest in a certain aspect. Ticket prices are very reasonable and easy to buy online. A fabulous insight into the art world of not just Russia but many other parts of the world. The rooms are breathtaking and with the help of a simple plan that visitors are given it was easy to find our way round and see the highlights as well as certain things we wanted to see. It has to be one of the most fabulous collections of artwork anywhere in the world.

Wow. What a fantastic collection the only fault was that it would take a week to go around it all. We bought our tickets online from the Hermitage official site this saved us queueing up another tip is to make sure you have a drink before entering as you cannot take water in with you.

Amazing - even if you dont have clue about art!. So much to see, we enjoyed the impressionist paintings the most and we found this was the area of paintings that we recognised. We know nothing really about art but would recommend a visit here.

Disappointed. I was disappointed by the displays which were badly lit or under direct sunlight.
