Also disappointed to see no real logic in the display, it felt lie everything salvaged from the Soviet era had been thrown where ever it fitted. Some rooms were breathtaking such as the library or stair cases and the crystal chandelier room etc.

Unbelievable !!!. A visit to St Petersburg is not complete without a visit to the Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace. The art, sculptures and the rooms are breathtaking. You do not have to be an art lover to appreciate the beauty and history on display. As the number 1 attraction, it is very crowded but the crowds move through in an orderly fashion and there is always someone there to keep things moving. Our guide told us that is you were to stop and look at each piece for only 10 seconds, it would take 6 years to see everything. Amazing.
Breath-taking. If you see anything, you have to see the Hermitage. Amazing collection of works from every famous artist. The rooms alone are beautiful works of art.

We could've spent the whole day exploring the Hermitage Museum. The paintings , the sculptures , the palace itself is.. I liked everything about both the museum and the palace. Both have so much interesting history and beautiful setting.
Amazing. The palace is incredible, but I'm glad we had per-booked tickets through a tour group because the queue for general admission looked very very long.

Another Museum. Not quite,breathtaking.lots of gold,Amber,paintings.Crowded but not too bad,but do not lean on anything,a buzzer sounds and someone rushes up to get you off.Unfortunately not enough time to really take it all in,but a good taste.

The rooms are as interesting as the art. While it is a great collection of art, I found the rooms to be the best part of the museum. It is certainly a huge building. Even with a plan of what I wanted to visit we were there for the better part of the day and saw very little of the museum.

It doesn't get better than this!. Every step is breathtaking! Every detail of every inch of floor, walls, doors, ceiling, lights... everything! Before you even make it to a gallery you will be blown away by the intricate details of... everything!I have been to museums all over the world, and this stands at the top, along with D'Orsay.Allow more than one visit to even get close to seeing everything.Renaissance work is particularly fantastic.

Fantastic. Don't miss this venue if you are in St Petersburg. It does get crowded but there are so many rooms, you're not likely to miss out seeing the items you want to see. Our two hours here went by so quickly ! So stay as long as you can - the collection is amazing.
Impressive structure and. contents. The quantity of art tends to overwhelm the visitor but the quality is impressive. Saw Swan Lake in the palace theater, a real treat!
Better than the Louvre. You need a month to see it all. What we saw was magnificent. Our guide, Tatiana was excellent, keeping us informed and on schedule.
Breathtaking. So much to see. Fine art or priceless relics at every turn in an unbelievable setting. You cannot see everything in one day. Watch out for pickpockets

Interesting. What a visit, a lot of art on display. A lot of paintings by the Masters. The palace itself was amazing, the decoration and painting on the walls and ceilings was totally overwhelming. The room of picasso's was worth the visit in itself. It did help having a knowledgable guide who knew her way around. The museum was relatively quiet as we were allowed to enter before opening time.

This is a must see for St Petersburg. The outside of the palace is being restored at the moment so it isn't as grand outside as it might be but inside it is still amazing. Either one of the art or the building would be an attraction in its own right.

Not a museum goer!. I'm not a museum goer, especially art, but we did this tour with SPB Tours. They got us in early ahead of the crowd and I have to say I totally enjoyed it. The art work is beyond fabulous and the Hermitage itself is worth seeing. Enjoyed my visit.
Must see. Outstanding and so beautiful wear comfortable shoes. Is an experience. A good English speaking guide will help

The Grand Hermitage. We spent the afternoon on a tour of the Hermitage and famous Gold room. Its a huge museum and very, very crowded. I highly recommend that you were comfortable shoes and be prepared for non-Aircomditioned rooms. Its worth visiting even if youre not an art fan.

You can't miss it!. The hugest art collection that I have ever seen! Not only the collection is interesting, but the building itself with enormous rooms and beautiful decoration. Plan at least one hole day for it!
Exhausting but unmissable. Best to go with a guide. Ours was so knowledgable about the art works and we would never have picked up the details she had. We spent 4 hours: not enough, but exhausting.

A much neglected El Greco painting. The Hermitage holds a much neglected El Greco painting, A seated young woman with (IMO) the same haunting quality as the Mona Lisa. Seek it out in the El Greco Collection - you can't miss it (sorry, I couldn't find a link online)
SPB Tour. Loved it. Got in early as part of a small group so it was easy t move through the museum. Amazing things to see along with all the history involved. Must see.

Overwhelming!. This museum is very large and you should not expect to see it all in one day. We were with an english speaking tour guide and she was able to take us through the main areas and point out the most famous of all paintings is just one morning. (We were with a Tauck Tour) Even if art is not your thing, you should see this museum! Besides the art, which is some of the best in the world, the palace itself is stunning. Catherine the Great's lifestyle was unbelievable. (in stark contrast to the rest of the Russian lifestyle during that time and now) If you go, inquire about the Peacock Clock and when they will make it work - a must see. Guided tours are your best option.

Unbelievably magnificent. On the good side: The building itself is a wonderful exhibit. The decadence of Tsarist life leaves one in awe. The floors, the walls and he ceilings have the most amazing decorations/paintings etc. So much wealth. It took my wife and I two days to cover all the ground and we could not look at everything in the detail it required. We were able to get into one of the treasury rooms and the gold, silver, and gems on display was far richer than I have seen anywhere else (except the hope diamond). The Louvre fades when compared with the Hermitage. We also saw the Peacock clock work (Wed @ 19:00) and it was amazing - you can find videos on YouTube.On the bad side: very few tours in English, enterprising Russian offering tours in English for a lot of money ($100), rude Russians working in the Hermitage and rude Russians visiting it. Fortunately there were not too many of them (all seemed to be old, so a hangoer from Soviet days?). Once in, you cannot leave (so you have to eat within and its not good value or good food).

More than a full day. Like the "Smithsonian" in Washington DC, the Hermitage in St Petersburg, Russia, is so large that no one should expect to see it all, ever. If you're a museum "fan," allow at least one full day, or more if you can afford it. Best time of year would be outside the spring-summer period. Best time of day would be as early as you can possibly start. The masterpieces in the collection are absolutely stunning, too numerous to list here. Guided tours are your best bet, though that would limit your time available to wander through all the floors. Check the dozens of web sites and books that discuss the Hermitage collection, and prepare yourself before entering. This is not the kind of place that lends itself to zipping down the hallways. There's just too much to see. I would recommend this only for grownups. There's just far too much for kids to see without getting seriously bored and cranky. If there's one site in St Petersburg that you must visit, this is it. There is a special section called "The Gold Room," which is fantastic, and requires an additional admission fee. No photos in this section, and it's easy to understand why. Small groups only, and each group is escorted and guided by two associates. Then you leave. Very tightly controlled, but an absolutely amazing collection. Again, grownups only for this and the entire museum, unless you have a serious student in your household who's able to absorb the grandeur and history without getting bored.

History with a wow factor!. A stunning experience, not only are the contents of the museum fascinating, but the museum itself is stunningly beautiful.Would have been good to be able to take food or at least water into the museum, consumoption in designated areas would not be a problem as people would understand the need for this. Around the museum cafe it was absolute bedlam, and rather than fight our way through this we stocked up before and lasted through the visit without sustenance - but there is a lot to see and visits will be long!

Fantastic collection...if you have the time!. We heard a few different numbers on how long it would take to look at every piece in the Hermitage...3 years, 5years, 8 years...needless to say, it would take a frickin' long time! The museum has some beautiful works by many famous artists. The Peacock Clock was really neat, I had never seen anything like that in real life. Kinda reminded me of that movie "Hugo". Anyways, it think it is best to go on a tour with a guide for this. They will explain all, book ahead of time, and take you to all the important pieces. SPB has a lot to see, it is best to be as efficient as possible if you are on a timeline.

An incomparable rappresentation of the glories of the past. Great: find an impressive collection of masterpieces of the most famous artists in every field, species of the Italian Renaissance.
The indifference of the police for tourists attacked by thieves.

Fabulous Collection and Palace. There is something for every art aficionado at this museum. We tried to concentrate on collections not typically available us back home, e.g. portraits of Russian Tsars. Nice combination of history and art.Terrific time just wandering through the halls of what was once a formal palace. Be sure to have a map or use the IBM kiosks to map your route to favorite displays.WARNING: If there is a way to buy tickets ahead of time, do so. We waiting on line for 2 hours to get tickets.  We met some interesting people on line which made the wait seem much shorter!

Purchase your ticket in advance!!!. Please, for the love of everything that is holy, purchase your ticket online, on their website and have a print-out of the ticket with you in hand!!! I did just that, without expecting what I saw upon my arrival at the Museum. It was a cold rainy day, perfect to go to the Museum. I get in the front arch, leading to the entrance and there was probably more than a thousand people waiting in line. Yes, a thousand! I just could not believe it. I took a picture from a window inside and counted more than 600 people and it wasn't the full line. Being a witty traveler, I decided to go see what was going on at the front of the line. I saw two lines. One, over a mile long and the second line... Empty. Why? This line was for people with tickets. So I go in, and inside, the signage is not clear. There are many ticket offices, for different purposes. They do have employees that can guide you to the accurate line-up. So i just picked one line and this employee came to me, seeing me with my print-out ticket in hand. She told me to follow her. A few minutes later, I had my real ticket in hand and could start my visit. Litterally an 8-minute process, while people outside were waiting hours, in the cold rain to get in. The Museum itself is an absolute masterpiece. Every room is more overwhelming than the other, it's just spectacular. It's worth the wait, if you have to wait in line for your ticket. Even if you wait 2hours, it's worth it. I have read that this museum has so many artworks and masterpieces in it, that if you spent only a minute in front of each, you'd spend 11 years in the Museum. When they say it's one of the biggest museums in the world, they are not kidding! Plan at least two hours to do the quick room-to-room tour. If you enjoy art, then it can be longer than that! So remember: purchase your ticket online at http://www.hermitagemuseum.org/ and you'll thank me later!

A Must See. I hope no one goes to St. Petersburg without seeing the Hermitage. Magnificent rooms, fabulous art and jewels. You can't imagine the wealth posed by the Czars until you see the Hermitage; and that is just one of their many palaces. I read biographies by Peter the Great, Catherine the Great and Nicholas and Alexandra by Robert Massie and Russka by Rutherofrd to name a few, prior to the trip. It helps to have a background in their history as their is so much information to absorb.
A monument to excess. The museum is a must see, and you certainly need several hours to do it justice. A very large a varied array of art in a setting that is expansive and opulent.

Art museum with bling. We visited the museum in a small group with a guide. We viewed the stately rooms and many of the rooms of paintings. Seeing the chandeliers and the gold gilt as well as all the works of art was a total sensory experience... Add to that the fact that you are actually in the Winter Palace! Our guide provided all the necessary history and details. She also navigated the maze of rooms for us...saving us time and keeping us from getting lost. Our guide also arranged an early entry, so we were able to see much of the museum before the serious crowds entered.It is a DNM (Do Not Miss) sight in St. Petersburg. Visit with a guide and go early. It is warm in the museum, so leave your jacket on the bus. There are several nice gift shops, a coffee shop, and restrooms on the entry level. There are stairs in several places. It may not be handicapped accessible ...if that is an issue, it would be best to check with the museum before you go.Also, be careful of the souvenir hawkers across the street from the entrance. One in our group was pickpocketed there.

Very popular, we were told 50,000 visitors a day. Russia is not a pro at organization. Beware they do not have a separate line for groups, and independent visitors.For some reason when we visited people exited through the same door we were entering. The crush was amazing.Also an issue if you are traveling with a disabled person, people were having to push through these large crowds with a wheel chair, and had to carry the person up the stairs at the entrance.Cruse ships docked also had people who wanted to visit. There were crushing line ups at the entrance with tour groups such as Globus. So be ready.BUT.... Say this once you enter the exhibits are amazing. Very glad I was able to attend. If traveling as a group. Pick a meeting place at the entrance. Our Globus group members got separated twice from our group.There is a snack place at the end and gift shops.Enjoy

Unbelievable and awesome. The Hermitage is immense and impressive.Our tour was not long enough. This Museum and Palace are steeped in Russian history and I would love to return.The palace has over 1000 rooms and it would be impossibleto see it all, but I would love to see more.

Died and gone to heaven on the 3rd floor. Impressionists and post-impressionists on the 3rd floor: Countless Monet, Cezanne, Rodin sculptures, 4 Van Gogh, 26 wonderful Matisse, 4 Vlaminck, 8 Derain, 5 Van Dongen including "Woman in a Black Hat" and "Red Dancer", 7 fabulous Marquet, 2 Raoul Dufy, I missed the only Utrillo!, 28 Picasso including "The Absinthe Drinker" and some of his lovely pottery, Kandinsky, Leger. I took as many photos as I could (without flash, of course) but found a book in the shop called "The Hermitage - French Art from Monet to Picasso" for 500 roubles, postcards 10 roubles, and small reproductions on canvas of paintings at 600 roubles each.

Beautiful. The state rooms are the best part - absolutely beautiful. I also enjoyed the French art. I would recommend using the audio guide if you're not going on a tour. It was great being able to hear about the history of the building and of the importance of some of the artwork.

Awesome, Yes. But Needs Work.... One of the greatest museums in the world. Hard to add to what you already have heard, but perhaps the biggest surprise was that a fair amount of the art is second tier, not compellingly curated and poorly lit. Highlights were the astonishing, huge carved Jasper urn near one of the entrances, the Rembrandt room, The da Vinci paintings, two old men by Reni, a luminous portrait of a woman by Franceschini, the incredible chandelier room with the giant, motorized bird clock, the Monets, Renoirs and Van Goghs in the Impressionists galleries, the perfectly preserved mummy in the Egyptian gallery and the knights on horses. Also, in general, the architecture and decorations in most of the galleries are eye-popping. The surprises were that much (though certainly not all!) io the Impressionist and Dutch art was of lower quality than we expected--the Metropolitan Museum, Chicago Art Institute and Louver/Musee d"Orsay all tend to have better examples of a given artist's work. Also, the lighting on the paintings is almost uniformly poor, including the fact that many hang next to windows, fully exposed to sunlight. Another highlight is the main gift shop, which had better, superb quality amber jewelry, mother of pearl and filigree, lacquer boxes and other items than we found elsewhere int he city.

Simply great. Going to St. Petersburg without spending few hours at the Hermitage wouldn't make any sens. We would have needed more than a day to visit the whole museum. It's simply huge. The artwork is great and with a lot of varieties. Too bad that they do not control the flow of tourists. It's packed and not always easy to look at ease.

Made superb by guide. Like many of the worlds great-but-vast museums, you could spend all your time looking for specific items. If you have a particular interest or goal, pay the money and get a guide. They go all the time and know it like the back of their hand enabling you to make the most of your limited time.

Unbelievable. The amount of treasures on display is mind-blowing and it is a real mixture of paintings, sculptures, porcelein etc. You need to decide what you would like to see before you visit rather than wander round aimlessly as there is just too much to see in one visit.
Increadable. So much art to see. You really need to be an art person to fully appreciate it, but it is still great to see for the non artsy.

Be patient and wear your most comfortable shoes!. I felt like a kid in a candy shop....so much to taste and savour here. We did the 2 day pass and paced ourselves between paintings and the staterooms and the antiquity collection...What is so absolutely amazing is that the art is set in rooms designed to enhance what is being displayed. There is probably no other museum in the world like this!

Awesome. This place is so over the top and huge that it was too awesome to take it all in. I would love to return and stay an entire week devoted to the Hermitage. At one point I felt like cattle just moving from one room to the next (almost like the Vatican museum and Sistine Chapel). So many beautiful works of art and such an ornate palace. My favorite was the Prodigal. Sat for a while in that room admiring. Summer is beautiful time to visit and the staff was friendly. Definite must see when in St. P!

The Hermitage. Overwhelming so if possible buy a combined two day ticket online. There are battalions of tours but some rooms are deserted. Not much in English as they prefer visitors in groups or with an official guide.

Awesome!!. You could spend weeks in this place and not see everything. It is absolutely spectacular.If possible go with a guide because you surely could get lost here. We were lucky our guide took us in before the official opening. The lines were very long when we came back outside. It isabsolutely beautiful.

Lovely Museum and Palace. A definite stop when in St. Petersburg, the Winter Palace is outstanding and the museum pieces are beautiful. This museum does not have the same quality exhibits as the Louvre, Vatican or Met in NYC but it holds it's own. Looking beyond the artwork, the palace itself is lovely. A very good stop but if you only have a day in town, we would recommend Peterhof and Catherine's Palace to see first.
Great!. The museum where there are absolutely the most pieces of art in a couple of rooms I have ever seen! If you like museums.... Go here and you have a great story for the homefront as well.

A must do!. Magnificant decor, artifacts, paintings (including Rembrandt, Caravaggio) and gold everywhere. Everything is on a "grand" scale here. It is difficult to really do it justice but most folks on our tour thought it "jaw droppingly good". I particluarly liked the art exhibits on the top flloor - saw some great paintings by Picasso, Matisse, Monet, and Gauguin. Had 2 hours to do the whole thing - but I guess a whole day would really be needed to do it justice.

Loved it!. An amazing collection of art from early Byzantine/Russian straight through to the 20th century masters. The state rooms themselves are also spectacular and worth seeing. A couple of notes: The Amber Room is not at the Hermitage, it is at the Catherine/Summer Palace. Also, hordes of tourists make it advisable to get there early and try to allocate multiple days to exploring the collections. A guided tour might be a good idea your first time through, just to collect all the little tidbits, but then wandering through at your leisure (at least, as much as is possible with all the other tourists in the way) is the best way to soak it all in, I think. I believe special evening tours are available and that might be a good way to avoid the crowds, which are the main reason this did not get 5 stars from me. Photo permission is an extra fee.

Amazing. This place is huge and is easy to get lost! We saw most of the rooms when we were there. There is a fantastic amount of art on display by so many famous artists, we are not particularly art lovers but enjoyed the setting and appreciated the amount that was on display.

A must see in St Petersburg. The Hermitage is such a famous museum that you couldn't miss it if you visit St Petersburg. You could easily spend days visiting all the paintings and treasures, but half a day with a good guide will show you a good selection. There is an excellent museum shop, but after purchasing a small piece of jewelry I saw it for a quarter of the price in the nearby market. Be selective, go to the market first. It is outside the Church of our Saviour on Spilled Blood.

Picasso and Matisse this time. I have visited the wonderful Hermitage several times. You just have to, as there is so much to see. This time I just concentrated on the Picasso and Matisse collections. They are both staggering in their quantity and quality. Just walking to these collections takes you through magnificently decorated state rooms and past innumerable other works of art that it is hard to tear your eyes away from. My recommendation for someone visiting St. Petersburg for a few days? Don't even think of trying to 'do' the Hermitage in half a day or a day. Your brain will explode! Instead, decide what periods / collections you really want to see and set aside a couple of hours for each day of your trip. That will enable you to at least scratch the surface!
Wow. One of the best Museums in the world, a must see.Every room is different and special. You can spend hours there.

A Treasure Trove. The State Hermitage Museum & Winter Palace is a complete treasure trove. It is so beautiful, it's difficult to describe. You are completely overawed by the beauty in one room which leads on to another of equal, if not surpassing beauty. From the portraits of all the Ramonovs and learning their history to the priceless works of art by Da Vinci, Raphael, Van Gogh etc, no visit to St Petersburg would be complete without a visit here.

Is ther art after Hermitage?. Forget about the rooms of the palace, go straight away to the top floor and dive into the best painters of all times. From time to time go downstairs and have a cup of coffee and cake in the cafetería. Too much art must be delighted slowly.

Stunning. It's difficult to explain what an amazing building The Hermitage/Winter Palace is.It is unique.The art collection is wide ranging, and has top quality paintings by so many of historys greats. If you think that it's pretty good to see, for example, 4 or 5 Piccasso's in a major gallery, then be amazed to see here in one room no fewer than 28. Every room seems to be stunning. Everyone should go to The Hermitage once in their life.
Not to be missed.. This museum is worthed a visit not only for its huge and fantastic art collections, but also because of its architecture. Plan on spending several hours inside
Outstanding museum. We spent two days at the Hermitage, and could easily have spent more. I loved the Impressionist collections.

Made even better by SPB. I have wished to see this Museum for decades, at a time when traveling to the then USSR was not feasible (or desirable). I am happy I waited, because I saw a beautiful museum in the company of a small group (16 in total) with a knowledgeable guide and before the "rush hour". i visited St Petersburg while on a cruise, and the highlights of the cruise were the excursions. By the time I finally visited the Hermitage, maybe I was less in awe of the art pieces (my favorite is still the National Gallery in London) but this is a Palace out of a fairy tale and the guide made it all come alive.

Superb. Undeniably one of the greatest buildings in the world, both inside and out. We only spent half a day here, but would have loved to have spent longer. The extravagance of the place is stunning. It is hardly surprising that the common people revolted when they saw how much money the Tsars were spending on a roof over their head. Whatever the rights and wrongs of spending so much public money on a building, it should not be missed on any visit to St Ps. Every inch inside seems to be covered with some form of carving or gold leaf. Extravagance gone mad and I've not even mentioned the world class art or museum. Our visit was finished off by a coral recital in an adjacent building. We so wanted to spend longer here and we must return - I just wish the visas were easier to obtain!!

The Collection that belonged to the greatest Empire. You can find here ANYthing from ANY time of history from EVERYwhere. Statues from Ancient Greecу and Rome, a real mummy with lots of all kinds of stuff from Egypt, Babylon, Shumer, etc. All-armoured Medieval knights -- my daughter's favorite; paintings from all over the world. Well, it definately will take you years to view everything, but at least you have to see some of it.

Whow!. Amazing collection. Loved Rembrandt and all the other Dutch masters (de hele 'Pijp' hangt er). Van Gogh, Monet, Manet, Picasso... All to good to be true. 2.floor lots of paintings are not hanging strait. Also minus: bad lighting (on dirty) glass makes its hard to see the paintings well. My favorite: Rodins statue 'Romeo and Juliet'.
Great museum. Took 1400 English tour wih only 2 other guests our guide was excellent,passionate about what she was sharing with us,

Our biggest WOW in St Petersburg!. This was THE wow factor of St Petersburg for us! Not only is the exterior of the palace soooo photographed and world-famous, especially if you are lucky enough to be there on a sunny day and when there's no remodelling happening, but the inside has double the wow factor as a museum. What riches and treasures are contained within! So many periods of art and history with each artist almost in a room of the palace of their own. To be in the presence of such greatness was magical! We spent over 3 hours there but could go back several more times and still be wowed. Coats and bags are cloaked at Reception so expect this. Stairs are involved to get to all rooms but elevators exist if you have a Guide and can locate them, otherwise there are museum experts sitting in every room to assist. Car parking is across the other side of the very large square out the front, but disability access is available. There's a souvenir gift shop, of course, with books about everything you want to know re the Hermitage. Eat before going in as there's no food inside. It's located very close to the centre of the city and where most tourists would stay in hotels, so very easy walking distance. We cannot say enough about how impressed we were with this world-class museum with priceless works of art from the very best of artists around the world. Having an excellent Guide made the experience far more exciting than it would ever have been if we'd just been there on our own. Luckily we were also not in peak tourist season so not feeling overcrowded.

Save plenty of time to see it all. Our excellant guide, Olga with SPB, made our day even more exciting and worderful to see the Hermitage. Make sure to have a full day to see it all as it has many people there and can't always get as close as one would like to see. So much there and it is gorgerous.

Best advice....time your visit right!. Even though we are not museum lovers, you can't fail to be impressed by the Hermitage. The buildings, the scale and the collections are very impressive.I therefore thought I'd pass on my best tips to ensure you get the most out of your visit.- buy your ticket online before you go. Then exchange your voucher at the kiosk within the entrance square. This allows you to queue jump.- if you have the time buy a 2 day pass. It's only a little more money but allows you to split up your visit.- time your visit so that you do not coincide with the hundreds and hundreds of tour groups who are also visiting. If there aren't many coaches parked out the back and front, then go on that day! It makes a difference!- as the tour groups seem to go in the morning or the afternoon, go to the popular sections at lunchtime. We went into Italian artist section twice, the first time in the morning, where I almost wanted to scream with claustrophobia. The second time around lunch, we had whole rooms to ourselves. What a difference!- finally there seems to be a quieter entrance to the winter palace. Go in the main entrance after purchasing your ticket and instead of joining the queue of people to go the the barriers on the right. Go up the stairs to the left (also marked as entrance). Go past the indoor shop and post office and up the stairs and you are in the Winter Palace, long before any other group will have made it there.

World-class museum. There is quite a long queue to get in but it is worth the wait. The palace part is beautiful (in particular the Jourdain stairs) and shows how the tsars & courts lived in very nicely and richerly decorated rooms. Then the (huge) collections feature items from all times & civilization, with some very famous one. The bird-clock is a masterpiece. Note: it is not allowed to take water & food in, which is a shame because the visit takes at least half a day. You can buy some inside but it is expensive.
A day you will never forget. All of the world's beauty in one museum... It lets your mind travell to all the places and eras you always wanted to go

What an experience!. We were on a cruise and called in here, sadly only for a day and a night.I could spend a month in St Petersburg it is so interesting and there is so much to see.We were lucky enough to go to a private party viewing of the Hermitage in the evening, when it was closed to others. We also had a concert by they Conservatoire of St Petersburg play for us, with a glass of champagne. What a treat in those surroundings.So much wonderful art, far too little time. We must return.

WOW. This is my favorite museum as it contains quite a variety of stuff to see. It is rather crowded, so be patient as you walk around. Plan 2-3 hours minimal. You could spend days if you are a real museum fan.
Fantastic!!!. Save time to see it all. The French Impressionism collection is very good. This has to be the very first visit in S. Petersburg while you are still in a good shape.

Best museum ever. The hermitage is the best museum that I have ever seen... even if it is not so well organised : for example the map that they give it's not good...inspite of this the collection is amazing... Some advices:  1Before the visit organised your plan: choose what you interest most because it isn't possible see all the things. 2 if you are students show your student card the price will be less... And it is not true that the dépliant it is only in Russian there are in french Chinese, German Spanish and etc... Beautiful

Buy your tickets on-line. This is a don't miss if you have any interest at all in art. There are fabulous, extensive collections of the Masters (an entire hall of Rembrandts, for example, and three rooms of Picasso) and a wonderful complement of Impressionists. Like the Louvre, it can easily take more than a day just to walk through it.We bought a two-day ticket on-line, which was a very good thing, as it saved considerable waiting at the ticket booth. Also, go early in the day, as tour groups accumulate and it's more crowded from mid-afternoon on.

Hype?. Not sure what all the hype is about. Yes it has lots of paintings. Some interesting many very dark. Lots of queues and having to dodge people taking photos of pictures and the like Buy a guide book - they have much better pictures!
Impressive building. The building and decoration are wonderful, but sadly too much restored and missing artifacts due to WW2 and Revolution. Needs time to wander at your own pace.
very very large. 1 day is not going to do it, get a two day ticket on the net and avoid congestion for tickets. Packed full of the very best art. You'll want to take some time

A Must See. I really enjoyed Russian history at school and this was a real treat for me. I had a spare morning and was thrilled to see the Winter Palace. It won't be everybody's cup of tea but it was mine.

so much to see - so little time. The state rooms are fantastical - and the paintings brilliant. Beware the cafe - but you are rather stuck as if you leave the Hermitage for something to eat you are not allowed back in, so you have to put up with the gastly cafe.
Very Large Museum. Very large museum with lots to see. To see everything you need a full day at least. A couple of hours is needed for the highlights only.
Must do. Went there, so did 10 000 other tourists and locals alike. Prepare for long lines and lots of people. Wonderful room and decor and hundreds of paintings etc.
Do not miss this one. The sheer opulence of it ,just as I had imagined it would be , try to miss the crowds as they are enormous when it gets busy, and geta good guide

Don't usually enjoy art museums but......... This is the must visit in st Petersburg even if you're not an art lover.the rooms and settings themselves are breathtaking and if you visit with a tour guide they can show you the most important pieces.in a three hour tour we saw about 10percent.of the available items.you would need to be seriously into art to see it all!
Get a guide. Absolutely amazing as long as you like art! Either get a guide to give you the highlights (we did it in 4 hours) or be prepared to spend a week there.

Best Sight in St. Petersburg. This probably isn't a surprise, but I thought the Hermitage was the best sight in the city of St. Petersburg. It's the world's second largest art museum so it has plenty of masterpieces, but if you're not into art museum, don't worry. The palace it's inside of is even more impressive than the art it holds. It's very opulent, and a lot of work was put into restoring the rooms.A few tips before you visit:1. Buy your ticket online. I actually wrote a note to myself to do this in advance, but I forgot about it so I was stuck on a line for 1 hour, 45 minutes. People with printed internet tickets just breezed past me.2. Don't buy the photo permit. I think it's 200 rubles, but no one checks whether or not you have a permit and everyone is constantly taking pictures.
One of the largest collections in a beautiful palace. There's not much to dislike except there's not enough time to see everything and because there's so much, everything starts to look the same.
Reserve enough time for yourself!. You need to reserve enough time when you go here, it is interesting! Unfortunately we didn't have enough time to watch all the historical things in the museum.

Amazing - must visit. Even if you aren't into art or museums I would recommend a visit to the Hermitage. The rooms are amazing, simply beyond words to describe.I was in St Petersburg with friends, we went to the museum together but then split up as we wanted to see different things.I would absolutely recommend purchasing your ticket online before you go as you save ages waiting in line.Don't pay the 200 Rouble photography fee, no one checks.

A must for culture vultures. This is one of the "must do" visits in St P. Personally I am not into the sort of art on display, but with a really good Russian guide it was an interesting two or three hours. Real culture vultures would love it.
Truly the best Museum in the World!. It could do with more coffee spots and you need at leaast a full day's visit which is very hard on the feet and back!

Beautiful Museum. I visited the Hermitage Museum as part of a group tour therefore we had a guided tour around all the exhibits. The museum is beautiful and I especially loved the grand decoration of all the stately rooms. There is a lot of things to see in the museum and you could easily spend the whole day here. I did notice that the queue to get in when we left was very long therefore I would recommend visiting early in the morning.

amazing. If you do nothing else in St Petersburg, make the time to spend and least a couple hours here. It is impossible to see more than a fraction of what is on display, but don't miss looking around at the beautiful décor of the building itself. Some of the ceilings were works of art in themselves. We were on a guided tour so managed to see a lot in a short time. The Impressionist section was fantastic.

Very nice museum but requires lots of walking. Museum is beautiful. Great location. However it is huge and will require lots of walking. It can be tiring for senior citizens and children. Also it is important that you have qualified guide to explain you art effects

Beautiful museum and Palace. We only got to stay about 3 hrs in the museum so you know we were moving fast but better to see some than none at all the flooring paintings and ceilings and artwork was fabulous the hall full of pictures and the beautiful ballroom just wonderful l hope l get to go back and spend more time

no matter what you allow it will not be enough to see the Hermitage. The crowds trying to get in through the group tours entrance were way above expectations. However the scrum was worth the effort as the museum is awesome ....
Lives up to its reputation. Ge tickets on line, if not interested in the two hour standing in line experience. The items for sale in the museum shops are surprisingly a good bargain.

An obvious place to start. No trip to Saint Petersburg will be complete without seeing the Hermitage. Suck it up and brave the queues - there's no place quite like it. Don't plan on seeing anything even like 10% of what's around but definitely try to see the "gold treasuries" for a special tour - book in advance with your concierge

It's essential to understand cultural transitions between east & west. After tiresome entrance challenge, magnificent tour starts by staircase with the view of golden-like gilt ceiling. It's possible to see many arts like paintings, sculptures belongs to 17th to 19th century of Europe & Russia. But one day would be not enough because of swarming crowd. For the sake of the entrance fee is about 450 ruble ($15) including camera allowance, this extra visit is not burden to your budget.

Wonderful!. Hermitage is wonderful. You need days or even months to really explore it. The art collection is so diverse that there will be something interesting for everyone. Unfrotunately, I had only a few hours there so I would love to come back! What is a bit confusing is finding your way around - I didn't find the signs very helpful.

Lifetime goal achieved!. My husband and I have wanted to visit the Hermitage for many years, and it definitely lived up to the expectations!We bought tickets in advance on the Hermitage website which allowed us to skip the very long queue in the courtyard. (And queues in Russia are something to avoid if possible - they're unpredictable and frustrating!)The crowds were impressive even in May, so I cannot imagine how it would be in the peak of summer. I downloaded the Hermitage app onto my iPhone in advance which was nice in that it gave an overview of some of the top pieces you should not miss. (It would have been more helpful if included a GPS based map to guide you to the pieces.) We got the English language audio tour which was helpful. However, if I were going again I would either plan my visit in more detail using the virtual tour on the Hermitage site, or hire a private guide at the museum. The map that comes with the audio guide is awful (or at least we struggled with it, and my husband made easy work of mastering the Moscow Metro to give you an idea of what we're used to). We purchased a map at one of the book shops but still had quite a time finding our way to the Picasso room. Overall, it was an amazing visit to an amazing collection of art. Don't miss it!
very enjoyable. There is so much to see that you have make a plan and stick to it .My only complaint is that the only refreshments are on the ground floor.

Wonderful museum. So many beautiful things to see in this museum, some classic Impressionist works of art. Only negative was how warm it is inside, and there is nothing for vegetarians to eat, other than cabbage and boiled egg pasty (which was a lot nicer than you'd think!!).A must for people visiting St Petersburg

An absolute must. Great art collection, displayed in a magnificent scenario as the winter palace is.Make sure you buy the ticket via internet. It will spare you the huge cue and the "at-least-two-hour-waiting" to enter.

Be prepared to get lost. They reckon it would take someone about 11 years to see all the Hermitage has to offer and I think they are right! If you don't want to stand in a huge queue to get in then buy a voucher online before you travel.The Hermitage is extremely big, covers several linked buildings and the floor plan/map is not the easiest thing in the world to follow. It is a fascinating and fantastic museum with paintings by almost any of the famous artists you care to name and the state rooms are beautiful.You must leave your coat in the cloakroom but this is fine as there are lots of them so never usually big queues wither to hand in or collect coats/bags.
worth to be seen. It is too big to see everything in one day, but it wonderful. It is better to purchase tickets via internet, there are many people waiting for entrance.

unbelievable scale. the building is whats most interesting here. The collection is immense but if you've been to museums in Europe it not anymore electrifying. They do have two rare Leonardo Da Vincis and a small Raphael.

So Much to See - get a private tour. The line up to get into the Hermitage was very lengthy but as we had booked a private tour we were able to skip it and go in a separate entrance. Even with a guide though we did not have enough time to see all. Plan on spending a day if you can.

Worth seeing. We went with Insider tours and asked to see the best things and saw marvellous greek urn big as a room carved out of a piece of stone, wonderful egyptian artifacts, roman statues, a gorgeous gold room, a golden bird clock in a glass case plus much much more-so much to see

A must do whilst in St Peterburg!. Beautiful building, huge!!!!! Took ages to walk around, lots to see. We got in free as part of our competition win package but usually it can be pricey to go in! Still worthwhile and lots of shops and attractions nearby!

No words - see by yourself!. If you visit Saint-Petersburg, it is A MUST. Better to go with a guide as the museum is huge and the guide will show you the best of the best.By the way very often the guide can order the tickets in advance for you not to stand in a long queue! :)The ticket is valid just for one entrance, so it is better to take snacks inside the museum (to buy in the cafe) of to have something with you (but no water as the water is prohibited to be taken inside in security reasons) No backpacks, long coats or big bags are allowed inside!So take with you a small snack in a small bag and have a nice breakfast before you enter the museum to spend there at least 3 hours or even more!

A little overwhelming!!!. Be prepared for crowds of people. We got there early (bought tickets online so we didn't have to queue in the same huge queue as everyone else) and decided to work from the top down, it turned out to be a good move, we had some of the collections completely to ourselves (phew!).You are not allowed large bags/backpacks or water with you, and so it would be wise to have a small bag and a small bottle of water with you - as the rooms were hot and it's a long day. We were in there from 10am-6pm. Felt a bit overwhelmed afterwards, but it's so engaging you just don't want to leave.We had coffee and cake in the restaurant downstairs which was ok.The collections are incredible and so, so powerful. A really wonderful place and the architecture inside is stunning too. Plan a day outside before it - and after it - so you have a balance of being indoors for an entire day.
Pick a specialist area. We centered on the British collection and the Royal portraits. Get htere early in the morining and avoid holidays and weekends
Somptuous. A wonderful palace with an impressive collection of master pieces from European artists!A must do.Free the first Thursday of the month but come early to ensure you get in!
could spend hours here. The rooms, furnishings, paintings, history and the fact that it was open until 21:00 on Wednesday evenings.
Amazing!. It was my second visit and still, did not see much. This is a real Palace and this time we take time to see the decoration and the rooms more than the paintings.

' A thing of beauty is a joy forever'. The Hermitage, itself an imposing building is a treasure trove of ART by renowned masters. Its interiors are exquisite and one can spend days taking it all in. Sophia, our well informed guide from TJ Travels showed us the highlight of highlights which was awesome. As March is off season, the hermitage was not overcrowded and we could spend time admiring and photographing the paintings, sculptures and artefacts that we liked, unhindered and without having to move on.

Must not be missed in St. Petersburg. I first visited this incredible museum in summer 1994 with my son, shortly after the city was redesignated as St. Petersburg from Leningrad. On the first trip we wandered amidst a disorganized collection that has been immeasurably improved. The English speaking guide that we arranged through our hotel this time, an art student who had studied at the Hermitage since she was a child, enhanced the experience tremendously with her knowledge of every nook and cranny.

Wow Wow & Weary. What can be said about St Petersburg top attraction that hasn't already been said, from moment you hit the Jordon staircase you go WOW and that continues from one sumptious room to another. Top tip book on internet before hand as queues can be very lengthy and with a pre booked ticket you bypass the queues, and the two day ticket covers you for some other attractions. You have to remove your coats not sure why but the whole palace was lovely and warm even though it was cold outside. I took the optional tours to the gold room and the diamond room which cost 300 rubles per person, and for me the gold room was a bit of a disappointment especially as on the tour of the diamond room also showcases gold artifacts so if you have to choose it's diamond every time.I could have spent the day in the diamond room alone.

Everything you need to know about art. This is a really big museum with mostly just 'good stuff'. It's not like some places where 90% will not interest you and/or be forgotten soon, but instead it's packed with works by good/famous artists from different decades. Especially people that don't have that much interest in arts can fairly quickly get a feeling for different styles and artists by just visiting this one museum. You can do it in about an hour if you just skim through the most important stuff, or spend a whole day immersing yourself in everything.During summer season, the lines will be long. I went in April, and there weren't really any waiting at all. They have a 2-price system (charging about half for russian citizens), which is why so many stand in line with their passport ready.

The Hermitage. Just too much !!!!! Maybe our fault but you really have to research this one before you visit as the scale of the place is off the gauge compared with anything in the west. It is on one site the world's third best art gallery , museum , historical palace of great significance whereby any of these on a stand alone basis would be enough but all three done properly would take forever.
Loved it. You can't go to St. P and not go here. Buy your tix in advance to avoid the crowds. Pack a lunch so you don't starve but remember, only small bags or plastic bags allowed. No back packs

Waited all my life for this!. I have always wanted to go to St Petersburg and I finally made it. The Winter Palace is awesome. The buildings are fantastic, the state rooms beautiful and then there are the exhibits, everything from an Egyptian mummy , to Greek vases to da Vinci's Madonnas. Finding your way around isn't always easy and it is so huge it is exhausting. If there is something you particularly want to see you need to be organised, but for the most part I was just happy to discover some of its treasures and accept that I might have missed others.... Cafe was a bit uninspiring but that's the only negative part of the visit.
Must do. Astonishing but be prepared to queue to enter. The great state rooms are well worth a visit, even if you are only interested in the art, especially the Pavilion Hall, and room 197.
Loved the Egyptian exhibit and the palace. We aren't the biggest art lovers, but you can't help but be impressed with all that the Hermitage has to offer.
Incredible Museum. If you are in St Petersburg, you must visit the Hermitage. It's arguably the largest museum in the world. We loved it. Make sure you pay extra for the Gold Room tour.
Gorgeous. Museum is gorgeous, it was founded in 1764. Building and monuments are glorious. Everyone must go and see this building, especially Jordan stairs which are architecturel achievement.
Fantastic. Best to go on a guided tour as queues can be horrendous, but whatever you do you must go -fantastic experience.

Outstanding!. I purchased the two-day ticket online before arriving. I am an art lover. I also, with great pains using the Hermitage website, made a spreadsheet per room to identify where all the art pieces were that I wanted to see. (By using the virtual tour and comparing numbers to actually gallery numbers on museum map.) Keep in mind, some of the famous works will be out on loan. But masterpieces abound. What can you say? Plan on going with others with same level of art appreciation as you. Leave the non-art lovers at home. Some of the greatest pieces of art in the world. I spent a total of 8 hours and this was rushed. If you have a ticket, barge through the line and small front revolving doors and go to the information desk where you can exchange your voucher for a ticket. (no help directing you this way.) Check your coat and backpack and then (with pre-planning) know which way you'll go from there. Pre-planning with gallery numbers is a must but you will still lose your way. Make use of the guards in each gallery. Some don't know any english but many know some. I experienced a wonderful classical vocal group singing in the reliquary room. Off-season visit was still very crowded, especially at inadequate entrance and in popular galleries (where tour groups go.) Get there at opening. I went directly to Leonardo da Vinci paintings on day two and was the only person in the gallery. See my photos for more information. If you found my review helpful, please click on "yes." Thanks.

Awesome winter Palace. I was visited this Palace int he late winter of February 2013, its really awesome Palace that I ever seen, its huge and have complete collection. Fortunately we were there in the late winter, thepalace still have some snow in the Garden, it was wonderful moment when I was sitting in the small garden with the snow around overlooking the Palace. And when I was inside another atmosphere were shocked me. I didnt have enough time to go around and visit every room. But I have visit some beautiful rooms with beautiful decorative and painting.It was not too many people there, so I can stand for a bit long in every room.

In a League of its Own. If you took all the art off the walls , removed the statues , the objects , just left the palace empty , you would still be left with one if the most amazing places in the world.Every single room has an incredible ceiling , beautiful floors , intricate carvings and plaster work.The works of art...as others have said , there are no words. Be sure to take a look at the works of Matisse. The size and colors , the movement...wow.We had a private tour guide...hard to imagine touring without one unless you have many free days to tour on your own.
Crowds but amazing art. Amazing collections, too many people. Getting there early meant avoiding the queues. Needs a lifetime of visits. Ceremics, furniture, architecture, and then the paintings....
Museum and world heritage. Super collection of works of art and layout . Well maintained museum. But one needs atleast 4 to 6 hours to do justice to it

All You Have Heard is True...This Place is Amazing!. There truly is no museum quite like the Государственный Эрмитаж! There is so much to take in...the ambience, the history, the art...it is all extraordinary and impressive.

Beyond Mortal Review. There are certain sites and attractions that should not be up for 'review' or 'rating'. Instead they are the standard by which other attractions are judged. The Hermitage is such a site. This is the immutable standard against which all other museums (save perhaps the Met and the Louvre) are measured. You simply cannot say that the Hermitage is better than or worse than something else--it would be a failure of language. It would be like reviewing a "kilogram" and saying it is too heavy or too light. That said, there are some things that could affect a visitors experience. Lines could get long, feet could get tired, food and water are rare and expensive. Adjust for these by going early (or in the bitterly-cold off-season), resting periodically and planning for water appropriately. Do so and you will experience the Platonic Form of museums.

Almost impossible to find words to do justice!. Heeding the advice of others we ditched the kids and planned a reasonably short and contained visit. We absolutely loved it. Was ready for the magnificent art but not for the eye popping interiors and bits and pieces of history. Loved this place so much...glad we were there in off season as no crowds at all!

Beyond compare!. This is a must see if you are in Saint Petersburg. Book tickets online to avoid queues and on arrival ask the officials where you should go. Highly recommend to buy the tour or audio guide.The Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace are beyond description, both are simply GRAND!!! I have visited these several times. They still leave me speechless...

A must see but think about what you want to see. The Hermitage is vast. Everyone will tell you this. it is true. You will see lots of people wandering around completely dazed unable to take it all in. Don't try. There's too much, so be selective.The state rooms of the Winter Palace are an experience to be sure. It is a toss up whether there is more opulence here than there is in Schoenbrunn in Vienna or at the Dolmabahce in Istanbul, but if you like your wedding cake gilded, this is the place for you. It is a one-off, so it is worth doing.But after that, pick your art style, pick your country. There are some fantastic archaeological remains from the Steppe in a very out of the way part of the museum - on the first floor but you have to go up to the second floor and down again to get there and there is only one way in. These are from tombs in the permafrost, so lots of wonderful textiles, wood, even some tattooed skin. If you want more gold, get the additional ticket you need to see the Scythian gold.You need to pace yourself in the Hermitage and if you don't know what you want to see, you can just wander aimlessly. So really it is worth doing a bit of homework to make sure you do see the really special things.

The one place you must see - wear comfortable shoes. If you only see one place in St Petersburg it must be this. Possibly the biggest museum in the world - and no copies!!It is not just the biggest collection of art possible - the buildings are works of art with more gold, marble and every sort of decorative style imaginable. Make a point of seeing the large peacock clock - the person who presented that to Catherine was rewarded with a palace! We spent a whole day there - luckily lots of places to sit as it is hard on the feet - and only scratched the surface!You will probably need to visit the cafe - be aware coffee is 100 rubels a shot - if you have a large one it is 200 rubels and an extra 10 for the milk - so £10 for 2 coffees in cardboard cups !You can spend years there and not see everything so if possible go with a guide for the first hour or two - and enjoy'!!!

Be brave and jump the queue with pre-purchased tickets!. We arrived and joined the queue with our pre-purchased tickets. There were no signs to tell visitors with pre-purchased tickets to go to a different place and we were too British to queue jump straightaway. After 5 mins in a non-moving queue I saw an official peer round one of the front doors, so I left my husband in the queue, went to the front and waived my computer print out at him. He waved us in and were directed straight to an Information Desk where our passports were checked and print outs exchanged for real tickets. Then we walked straight through the turnstiles and were in! So so glad we plucked up courage to queue jump as there were a few disgruntled people in the queue who must have waited a very long time.

Usually don't care much for museums.... ...as i prefer the city vibe to them, but this was nothing short of spectacular. The winter palace is enormous, i've seen many great artists' work for the first time, and my very first mummy :) The staff on the other hand is very rude, especially the babushkas in charge of the cloakroom, but hey, it happens all the time in Russia. But anyways, you can see everything here, from Leonardo to Picasso. The downside is, to see as much of it as you can, you have to stay inside for a long time, and that, combined with lack of oxygen in the rooms equals great fatigue. Expect to be worn out after just two hours of walking around.

Majestic Palace Museum. This is the primary destination for foreign tourists to St petersburg and a MUST SEE for any artist, historian, designer and/or architect. Must spend at least all day and even several days if particular works require more reflection and travel time allows. The Gold and Diamond Rooms are separate entrance fee and might just as well get in to see their collections. To complement this visit, have to spend another day at the Russian State Museum too, where Russian Art is displayed. Hermitage displays Western European art, many commissioned by the Tsars. Just Marvelous, Majestic, Magnificent.

Pick the highlights and don't forget the floors. On April 2nd, there were not too many visitors and we were able to see most of the main section of the museum in a 3,5 hour visit. Don't forget to close your mouth when you keep looking at all the various ceilings, gold leaf walls and more than anything the inlaid wooden floors that stretch forever. For me the Da Vinci's were overrated (for very small), the museum itself is impressive. For 200 roebels you can buy a camera ticket and no one will stop you taking pictures, but without flash! Some of the special exhibits are clearly marked and cannot be photographed. Well worth a visit!!

No better way to start your visit of St Petersburg. Book tickets in advance to avoid queues or arrive at 10-30am when it opens, I can add nothing the previous reviews which caused us to visit it remains a must place to spend 3 / 4 hours of your time, top tip there are 3 floors and the third can easily be missed, you need to access it from room 280 on the second floor which is not clearly signed. Pay the extra 200 roubles for permission to photograph and remember to turn your flash off or face the wrath of the large Russian lady which I did.

Obviously a must - impressive!. They say that you need to spend two years in the museum if you look at every object for one minut. Probably true. The size of the building and the enormous amount of art is overwhelming. A bit sad that you after a while rush by 30 paintings by Matisse because you have seen another 30, but still it is an awesome experience. Highly recommend to buy/borrow the audio guide, without you are a bit lost. Perfect way to choose what you want to know more about (just punch in a number by each room/object and listen to all the interesting facts). The very Russian looking women sitting on a chair in every room is kind of an attraction as well.
It's not Versaille. The rooms showing the palace furniture could use a feather duster. At least they let you take pictures, but no flash.

Set aside one day just for this. If you're coming to St Petersburg, you need to visit the Hermitage. If you don't, you'll have that moment of shame for the rest of your life when people say, "Oh, you were in St Petersburg? Did you see the Hermitage? Wasn't it amazing?" You don't want to hang your head and admit you skipped it and see the look of incredulity on the other person's face do you? Of course you don't.Some specifics: -Wear comfortable shoes. The floors are works of art in themselves and are not built for comfort. There aren't many benches in the viewing halls either.-Buy tickets online. That lets you skip some of the crazy lines and includes photography in the price.-Use some sort of guide. The audio guide for rent at the Hermitage is fine but can be deadly dull. There are professional guides available who speak excellent English (some will self-refer themselves in the lobby or in the viewing halls) who know every nuance of the museum and the art within...but that can be overwhelming. Another option is to get a book in advance that contains the history of the various halls, art, etc. that will let you be as specific as you like. There are plaques in Russian and English for every room and every piece of art, but they are bare-bones info.-Make a plan. It's easy to get hung up in one section or another. By the time you get out of the 18th century Russian halls...you might be exhausted and amazed at how much time has flown by. So decide in advance what you have to see (da Vinci, Monet, Picasso, peacock clock) and see them while you still have the strength.-Take a break. The Hermitage has adequate cafes on the first floor. You'll feel better after a cup of your beverage of choice and an ice cream sandwich...we did.-Young kids? Bring your stroller - See my note above about lack of seating. You are allowed to bring a stroller in and you should if you don't want to be carrying your four-year-old through dozens of rooms.-Take a day. There's just so much to see...the palace itself would be worth it even if it weren't filled to the brim with priceless statues, furnishings, and paintings.

Most impressive museum. Undoubtedly the top sight at St Petersburg. Arguably, it has the biggest and best art collection in the world. I would personally say that I prefer it to the Lourve. The Hermitage was huge! We made it a point to arrive early at 9 plus am. Except the 30 mins when we took a break for lunch at the Hermitage Cafe, we stayed in the museum till it closed at 5pm and we couldn't finish all we wanted to see! There were simply much to take it. The palace itself, the grand Jordan staircase, all the artwork, the Gold room and its treasures, What a feast for the eyes!! Wish we had more time for it. There were many visitors at the Hermitage but due to the sheer size, we really didn't feel the crowd (except at the Jordan staircase). We took the English audio guide that gave very informative and interesting background to selected art works. we also took the tour to the Gold Room which took about 2 hours. The elderly lady guide gave really interesting commentary. Gave us very good background to the Faberge and lots of other intricate gem pieces in the collection. I highly recommend the Gold Room tour. Book it as soon as you enter the museum in the morning. Limited vacancies. If you are a lover of art and architecture, this is a must see for any visitors to St Petes.

Palace of miracles. We are not too much in for art, so I was a bit concerned about this tour. I was wrong! Hermitage is not only an art gallery. We saw marvelous rooms all decorated with gold and marble. Elaborate furniture and wonderful chandeliers of gilded bronze and crystal. The paintings so beautiful that even I was carried away. One can find anything there. What I would recommend – do go with a guide. We had our own private guide Olga from the Best Guides Company. First of all without her we would simply get lost in the Hermitage with its numerous rooms and chambers. Secondly we would never find certain things on our own. Like we wanted to see the private rooms of the Russian Tzars – Olga took us there. So we were able to see for instance the private library of Nicholas II, that as far as I understand is away from the main tour quarters. But the main thing is that Olga told us all those stories about each room, and we felt like we are witnessing the life of the Russian Court with all the balls, receptions and political cataclysms. That was fantastic!Another fantastic experience was visiting the Gold Room. What a temptation for a woman! All those glistening snuff-boxes covered with diamonds. Watches, rings and pendants covered with enamel, rubies and pearls… Can you imagine – they have a horse harness decorated with Colombian emeralds and two other decorated with thousands (I do not remember exactly how many thousands, but it was really thousands!!!!) of diamonds. Poor me – after that any jewelry store would be just a toy shop.

Louvre doesn't even come close. This is the most exceptional museum I have ever been to. Paintings, sculptures and the Palace are extraordinary. One room more beautiful than the next. Due the museum in two days, or be prepared to spend the whole day there. Book tickets online, otherwise you can spend long time waiting in cue for tickets....it is after all Russia.Enjoy.

Palace and Museum was Amazing!. After walking through this palace, I felt like I had never really seen a palace before seeing this. Wow! It was truly magnificent. The artwork, statues, paintings, relics, furniture, chandeliers, etc. were incredible to behold. I was blown away by it. This is a must see if you are in Saint Petersburg. The only problem is it would take a lot of time to see all of it. We spent only a few hours here, so we did not see everything, but the few hours were well worth it. I especially enjoyed the historical artifacts, gaining an understanding of the early culture in Russia as well as the culture that existed at the time of Peter the Great. God bless Catherine for her desire to collect art and artifacts of history. I read that out of 3 million total items in the collection, only 65,000 are on display. Truly amazing.
just a museum!!!!!. I was disappointed as I thought there would be more information about Russian culture rather than the rest of Europe

Biggest collection of art works. The collection is so extensive that even after a few hours, we merely saw a fraction of what is available. Legs got so tired from walking, even though we are reasonably fit. This place was one of the highlights of our visit to St Petersburg.
Probably the Most Incredible Museum in the World.. Unbelievable quality, volume, and variety of art and objects. You could probably spend a month here and not see everything.

Beautiful and must see!. I didn't have time to view all the beautiful paintings and instead I spent majority of time taking photos of all the historical architectural buildings, monument and square etc. On a beautiful sunny day, it was great for a long walk and photography too!

Overwhelming!. its 400 Roubles to get in and 200 Roubles for camera licence to take photographs - you get a little badge - our badge was the only one we saw despite everyone using a camera! Its the best 400 Roubles you are likely to spend!The place is absolutely beyond compare - look here half a dozen exquisite Rodins - glance there and a room full of impressionists - walk a few rooms and its Van Dyke et al! I'm not a fan of Picasso but if you are there are rooms fullStatues new, old and ancient - beautiful artifacts, jewelry and suits of armour - on and on....Its the fabric of the place as well as the contents - the place is over powering - 4 hours just went - when a sit down in the Internet cafe was required for black tea (or coffee if you like) and an ice cream to follow - I sent a number of emails with picture attachments to friends for a proxy visit for them!!Beyond brilliant - I hope the fire defence systems are perfect!

An amazing museum. The Hermitage is one of the most amazing Art museums I have ever visited. There are works by master's form so many different eras. What is even more amazing is the number of pieces that were part of the private collection of the Tsars. Give yourself at least a day to make a dent in the museum. The room dedicated to the Dutch masters could take an hour alone. Regardless of the time period of art you enjoy, you will find something here. This is a must see, one of the best art museums in the world.

Beautiful building and amazing art. Even if you are it an art fanatic you will be impressed by the sheer majesty of the interior of the building, it is amazing. Remember to buy a camera permit as they won't let you even take a camera in if you don't have the right ticket. You have to leave your coat in the cloakroom, as with a number of Russian museums, and you can't take drinks in. the cafe has delicious cakes and savoury food so you can stop for refreshments during your visit. There are too many opulent rooms to mention, so capture what you can to make your friends back home jealous.

Breathtaking, but hectic. A staggering collection of artefacts , and artistic treasures. We set aside a half day for this visit and probably managed to see 1% of what was to be seen. The first problem is to drag yourself inside away from the sights and sounds of this fascinating city. Then when you are inside the exhibits are so breathtaking you just have to linger. My favourite was a room containing nothing but"Matisse" paintings.A lot of walking is involved and on the day we visited it was very busy.Cannot recall seeing much in the way of disabled facilities so best to check in advance.You still require a visa for independent travel in Russia, but there are many indepentent tour guide agencies which negate the need for a visa. Guides we have used spoke excellent English. For tourist purchases everyone is happy to accept Sterling, Dollars and Euros as well as roubles.

Amazing!. Considered one of the must-see 5 museums in the world, the Hermitage doesn't disappoint. It is magnificent - from the beautiful palace that houses it, to the unworldly amounts of exhibits on display. They say that at any one time, only a third of the entire collection can be displayed and it would take days to fully take in the museum. The interior architecture is grand and then to have the amazing artwork to adorn it makes it that much more beautiful. There is art from literally all over the world and you feel like you've taken a stroll through history after walking through the museum. There are floors dedicated to the different regions and so it's easy to pick and choose what you want to see. The grounds of the museum are beautifully landscaped and it's a pleasant stop before you head onto the water ferries, etc. On the day we were there, there was a gentleman sitting with a small bear that you could get pictures taken with, and another with baby monkeys! A must see when in St. Petersburg!
Exceeded expectations. The architecture and decorations were so spectacular that the art almost became an afterthought. Getting tickets in advance meant that you could avoid lines.
Tremendous collection of art and furniture. Went with a guide which was very helpful. It is a an amazing place. Just walking through gives you a sense of the times.
One of the best 'museums' anywhere. Everything they tell you about the Hermitage is true. It is a joy to visit, particularly out of season avoiding the crowds.
Nothing like that in the world. I was born there in Saint Pete and travel around the world, live in US now. Nothing even close to Hermitage anywhere! Must do if you are in St. Pete.

Just being inside the Hermitage was a beautiful experience.. Just being inside the Hermitage was a beautiful experience. The rooms where the Tsars used to live are beautiful. One of the things that I enjoyed the most was the fact that we got to listen to some men singing as we were making our way through the museum. I’m a big fan of Picasso as well and there was a huge collection of him there. Being Colombian, I was so surprised to see a Fernando Botero Sculpture as well!
Hermitage. Absolutely the finest art display in the world. It is amazing that so much was saved during the 900 day siege and we are fortunate to be able to enjoy it.

Fab even if art isn't your thing.... The first time I went I was just walking around aimlessly, I thought the state rooms were beautiful and impressive but wasn't sure what I was looking at. I went again with a friend and we purchased the audio guides which I think were around 200 rubles. Students get in for free so this was just like paying the entry fee really. Now, art is sometimes a little lost on me but we spent about 4 hours wandering from room to room listening to the history behind various paintings and what each state room was used for etc. Because I had the audio guide to point it out to me, I saw things I never would have picked up on and I really found it interesting and could appreciate it much better.TIP- DON'T buy drinks from the cafes- it is such a rip off! Bring your own water and snacks as there are places to sit but there are plenty of places to grab lunch or recharge nearby.

A must see feast for the eyes. So much to see that you can easily spend the day here. We got an English speaking guide to point out the must sees. Such a massive collection of art all under one roof. The patterned flooring and chandeliers are as amazing to see as the fine art. There was a lot of crowd in the museum so be prepared with some comfortable shoes on and a good breakfast before you walk yourself to exhaustion seeing this must see sight.

Amazing!. This palace is of the Versailles equal.There are Michelangelo paintings, Rembrandt paintings, Leonardo divinci paintings. The have over 3 million pieces of art. You have to see the gold room that is gold leafed from floor to ceiling! Amazing!! There are paintings, sculptures, furniture, and gardens one more unbelievable than the next. You could spend weeks here and never see everything. There are one of a kind pieces unlike anything we have ever seen.

THE must-see in St Petersburg. They have not one, but two Da Vinci's! And then a whole host of other painters including Picasso, Manet, Monet, Van Gogh... And that doesn't even begin to touch the sides. The mummy in the ancient Egypt section was pretty amazing too. And the building itself is like walking around the palace of Versailles-opulent, beautiful, completely perfect in every way and gives an insight into how the Tsars lived. Truly amazing and if I ever go back to St Petersburg, I will go back here.

Simply incredible!. No description necessary to be fortunate enough to visit one of the finest museums in the world. Tips: choose your battles and decide where to go and what to see beforehand. Online ticketing is slow and confirmation email might go to spam. However, I received 3/4 credit when I finally did hear from them. Another tip: have 100 ruble notes and bypass the ever present cue and ask for kiosk machine in lobby opposite ticket windows. Quick and efficient and does not give change. Gift shops on bottom floor have great sale items which make the lovely gifts a buy. Coffee shop with nice salads and free wifi on this lower level. I went early April at opening time so it wasn't crowded. When I left the que was the length of the courtyard and then some. It was nice to be the only one in the smaller galleries.

Amazing, but know the room numbers of what you want to see. The rooms are beautiful and the opulence is indescribable. Tip: book online! We did and got to jump the queue. However, I found it was poorly organised. We were just given a map of room numbers but didn't really know what was in the rooms. If you find out what room numbers they are it stops you from wondering aimlessly for hours on end wondering if you're seeing the right things.I reccomend the Malachite Room, the French artists and the peacock clock. Knowing what we wanted to see, we were ready to leave after a couple of hours. Don't expect to get round all of it, it would literally take you a decade!
Amazing interiors. The Opulent rooms of the old palace are unbelievably opulent and heavily decorated. You will never see chandeliers like it!

Too little time to see so much greatness. You absolutely need to see the Hermitage once in your life if you. It was so massive that I'll definitely come back and try to take all in. You'll need at least a couple of days to see and comprehend the amount of beauty and greatness this museum has to offer
A day at The Hermitage. Be sure to check out the peacock clock on Wednesdays, it is the only time you can see it move. If you miss it there is a good video about it right side of the exhibit.

Amazing. The Hermitage is an amazing experience. Even if all of the artwork were removed, the building itself is extraordinary. I highly recommend buying the two day ticket in advance online.
