I was there in the off season and on Saturday there was a very long line outside of the building to purchase tickets.Typical of the whole experience, finding where to pick up internet tickets is not easy but assistance is readily available if you ask for it. Note that you cannot wear a coat or carry plastic shopping bags into the museum so be prepared to check anything you have with you.The free map provided by the museum is useless and I found the map in my St. Petersburg Lonely Planet guide much more helpful. On my second day, immediately after going through the ticket turnstile, I was approached and offered a guided tour for a fee. Having spent my first visit wandering without direction through the vast, somewhat disorganized collection, I knew I needed help and immediately accepted the offer. Since it was off season, I ended up alone with the guide and got a private 1.5 hour tour for $40. If I had the visit to do again, I would have sought out a guide for both days. There are gift shops throughout the museum and the best things they sell are handmade crafts so don't assume that if you see an item you like, it will be available at the main shop near the cafe. The shop near the Impressionist art on the third floor had two really unique lacquer boxes, the like of which I didn't see anywhere else in St. Petersburg. The sales person told me that they were made by one artisan exclusively for the museum shop and since it was the Winter the whole museum only had the two at that one shop.

Fantastic place and a must-do in St. Petersburg. There was a wealth of fabulous art in the Hermitage and when you go there, you should pick a few things you want to see and see those. Otherwise there is just so much to see that you will just end up wandering endlessly through the museum.

One of the best in the world. Regardless of whether you're art expert or just love art or just interested in history, Winter Palace (Hermitage museum) will reach your soul!I just visited it for the 4th or 5th time and can say that it is useless to write about this or other painter, this or other exhibition. What I can warmly recommend is that you dedicate to the visit there at least half a day with appropriate break for a tea in local cafe. Most importantly is that you read in advance about the museum and plan your visit there. Take a guide. It's well worth the money. And if possible, arrange a visit to the Diamond rooms. Those are more impressive than Gold rooms.

Vast information, but poor English language labelling. This museum is incredible and my girlfriend and I were able to spend hours walking around marvelling at the displays. My main complaint is a very selfish one and is that the descriptions of this incredible archive of objects were all, almost exclusively in Russian. The titles of each object are in both languages, but from my memory that is all. This is a shame, as there were many western tourists during our visit and this makes it a challenge to appreciate the objects. Admittedly, the museum is incredible value to enter (costing the equivalent of a few English pounds for a student), but it was a shame to not realise the story behind so many of these incredible items. A guide, speaking both Russian and English, could be hired, but this would substantially increase the cost. However, given the additional benefit and enjoyment this would provide, I would strongly advise doing so. Additionally, if we'd have done so, I think the rating would be 5/5!The museum itself is quite stunning, being housed in the former palace, which is extremely ornately decorated, with some rooms alone that are worth the price of admission! The displays are diverse, spanning many different civilisations.Overall, a fantastic museum that only has 4/5 because of my lack of ability to speak Russian and my inability to do the research to realise the added benefit a guide would have brought.
Obviously a must-do. Superb collection, very impressive grandeur that you can't find elsewhere and you can really feel the heritage of the Tsars. Must-do for any visitor to Russia
Wear comfortable shoes. Amazing and unique. Buy the books when you are there as they cost a fortune to buy online with P&P added!

Magic! Romantic! Lovely place!. The Hermitage museum is one of the best museums in the world to my mind. It's like the museum inside of the museum, 'cause not just the enormous and great collection is what really worth to see but also the rooms, halls, breathtaking ceilings and floors are interesting themselves.Every time I go there I find something new, moreover, there is some funny statistic of the hermitage which says they posses about 3 mln items there. So, if you want to see every item in the Hermitage and spend only one minute in front of it, you’d have to spend 8 years out there. Just observing the pieces of art!)))Oooopsy! Almost forgot to tell that there is a cafeteria on the first floor with really good hot chocolate! Hah! Someone drinks, someone smokes, I’m desperate chocoholic. The last but not least, is the line to the ticket office, sometimes you'd have to wait! Sometimes it takes really long time!

Almost Overwhelming. A spectacular sight in St. Petersburg. Be sure to allow a half-day at minimum for this sight. I was enthralled with the building itself. It is a fabulous palace with endless amounts of decor and gold decorations. Not to mention the thousands of pieces of artwork!

Great collection. Great collection. Not too crowded in this season. Personnel ok. Rather confusing exit signage:-) I recommend to pick up rooms or works of arts and not try to see everything. My personal discoveries: Giampetrino: Repentant Mary Magdalene. Francesco Melzi: Flora. Gerard van Honthorst: Childhood of Christ.

Galina the guide. We were approached by a man with a stand just inside the turnstiles who offered us an English-speaking guide. We were introduced to Galina who gave the four of us an amazing tour - probably around two hours though I never looked at my watch and can't be certain. She was brilliant. Cost us 500R each; probably the best money we spent in St P. Highly recommended.

one of the worlds wonders.. One of the joys of wandering around the Hermitage and Winter Museum is that around each corner in each room there is a wonder. there are the well known pieces such as the Da Vinci works but for me finding a room of impressionist paintings with no one in it bar us to literally worship at this art was a joy. Make sure to get in early the more time and space you have the better. No one should visit the city - even on a short business trip without making it to this museum. My advice - read up on the museum so you KNOW what you want to see - so anything after that is the icing on the cake. The qurikiness of the Russian museums - security is one little old lady sitting in the corner of every room with her handbag sitting on her lap and yet - you do get the feeling that if she had to tackle someone ....she could do it better than you!!!

Simply Amazing. My wife and I were on a Baltic cruise, and one of our stops was in St. Petersburg, Russia. One of the excursions offerred was the Hermitage. Although I would not describe myself or my wife as an art aficionado, this place is amazing. When the revolution started in the early 1900's the revolutionaries confiscated the paintings, etc. from the Romanov's and the royalty. They distributed the works to various museums. So, this place is filled with original art work from Rembrandt, Monet, Picasso, etc, etc. We had a fantastic Russian tour guide, who helped our experience so much. I strongly recommend a tour guide who is familiar with the works of art. Our tour guide told us there are 1000 rooms in all, with about 300 open to the public. We probably saw a little over half of the rooms, Most of these rooms are huge, and unbelieveably beautiful in themselves--beautiful marble columns, gold leaf, intricate mosaics, and hand-cut inlaid floors. You walk from one room that you think can't be topped to another one that is even more beautiful. One tip for wheelchair folks. The Hermitage will be described as non-accessible. However, my wife (who can climb stairs slowly) was able to fully enjoy this beautiful building. Once she climbed the main stair case, I was able to push her companion wheelchair throughout the building with no problems. There is at least one small elevator in the building. I don't think it reaches all the floors.Don't miss this.

Fantastic. This has got to be the best Art museum we have ever visited - it is huge - so plan very carefully what you want to do. Book ahead online and you will beat the queues - hint - there is no obvious way to do this but wave your voucher and one of the officials will tell you where to go. The best part for us was the 3rd floor, where some of the finest French Art of the 20th is to be found

St.Petersburg,Russsia. The city was so amazing-thinking of the preserved center. The GUM Dept. store is like an inside mall that looks like the 1940's.You pick out what you want from a variety of counters,they give you a paper,this goes to the cashier,and you finally take this reciept back to where you ordered.This is stilll done in some of the less progressive Eastern European countries.That aside To me the Hermitage was beyond description with beautiful exterior and literally hundreds of gorgeous rooms. The grandeur speaks of the former glory. You could literally spend a week in the Hermitage.The next thing my guide to me to see was "The Church of Spilled Blood." The multicolored onion-shaped domes are even more stunning that what you see in Moscow's Red Square.We traveled in the stunning subway system-yes it's true they use golden canndelers!The final stop was at the Winter Palace.Unfortunately the visa system is so complex that you must hire a knowledgable travel agent here to do the paper work.You could easily spend a week in St.P.You'll find the Russians very coordial.This was definitely not the case when I was there during "The Cold War."

One day is not enough. Every room is an eye-opener. The building in itself is worth the visit, let alone the marvellous art collection. My advice: get a 2-day ticket if you don't want to feel too exhausted after one visit. And buy your ticket online before your trip - it spares you the long queues.

A world must do before you die!. Simply incredible! Totally spellbinding. We toured the Hermitage & Winter Palace for two days but just scratched the surface. I could spend weeks or months looking at the millions of exhibits and breathing in the history & ambiance. Russia is a fascinating country and the Hermitage is a window into it's soul. However, don't miss out on The Russian Museum nearby adjacent to the Church of our Saviour on Spilled Blood.
Awesome Museum. This museum was fantastic!!! There are millions of works of art from renowned artists from all over the world.It was open late on Wednesday night and not busy at all.

Great day out. Best thing to do in winter.. Glad I double check the official website and found that they offer free ticket for any students (regardless of nationality). They even accept a photo on my iPhone of my student ID card.My favorite part of the museum was the third floor modern European painting, the others I kinda skip through it. Only spent around one and a half hour there and I think it's more than enough at least for me. After visiting the Vatican museum, the Louvre and the Hermitage, I like the Louvre in Paris much better.Visited in march and there's no queue at all at noon, a pretty low season to visit because of the cold. Best to avoid visiting during weekend as there will be a lot of school kids.
Best Museum. The rooms are as beautiful as the art! We spent nearly 8 hours in the museum and loved every minute!
One of the best places. If you manage to speak Russian and go for a local, you get a discount. Won't work if they get tempted to ask for your passport. ;-)

A veritable flood of major artists' works. The Hermitage boasts 3 million exhibits. What's amazing is that very little of it is filler. We're talking not 2 or 3, but literally dozens of works a piece from major names like Rembrandt, Reubens, Renoir, Picasso. It's almost like the Smithsonian but crammed into a single large building. I did manage to go through all the rooms in a single day, but I wish I would have had more time. Don't forget the bottom floor where they have a truly unique collection from ancient Central Asia, Siberia, and more. The only slight is that I didn't see a huge quantity of major works, but you'll be hard pressed to find a painting that you don't think belongs in a great museum.
A must!. So much history, you do need to go here and you do need to get a guide, it is well worh it! this country has a long and extremely exciting history

Top Class - allow two days. It IS most definitely one of the top 4 art galleries in the world in the most stunning building.You can buy your ticket online before you go - you get a voucher which is valid for any day (or better 2 consecutive days). Bypass the queue - take your passport for ID, get voucher verified and then convert it to a ticket(s).
Fantastic. This was one of the few attractions which had an elevator. That means a lot to "older" tourists. The palace is amazing and the art spectacular.

A good day out... :-). A good day out, great pieces of art and sculptures to see.. plus you are allowed to take photographs in most rooms. However, the only downside, there is staff in near enough every room, who appeared to watch us like hawks in each room whilst we were taking pictures, which definitely negatively impacted in on our experience in the Hermitage which is a shame!!Definitely worth a visit whilst in St Petersburg... buy tickets online to avoid queues.

This palace is huge. The winter palace is home of the hermitage museum ,the biggest museum in the world,they said if you look at a sculpture for few minute,it take a few years to finish the whole museum,It is that big.

Cultural overload. The State Hermitage Museum is amazing - but please allow yourselves at least a couple of days to try and see it all and appreciate it all. I didn't and I became quite immune to the wonders that it holds simply because my brain became quite overloaded.

Worth going in the winter?. March may not seem like winter in temperate climates but in Saint Petersburg it was bitter. But a big compensation comes with ease of access to the tourist attractions. There were a dozen people ahead of us in the queue to get in and once inside it was almost as if we had the place to ourselves. The ice-breakers may be the only boats on the river but having this treasure house to yourself makes it well worth going off-seasonI can't add anything to the millions of words in praise of the Hermitage and Winter Palace but hope this review might encourage anyone doubtful about going off-season.
"Ludmila Tours". The interiors of the Winter Palace are magnificent and the history of the museum collection is amazing!

A M A Z I N G!. We spent 5 hours at Hermitage (wish i could spend more time...) as we love everything there! the paintings,sculptures,antiquities! Buy your ticket online! It will save your time, and the ticket will allow you to take pictures and videos ;-)

Fantastic museum!. I went as part of a small private tour, we had a guide. (Anastasia tours) The Hermitage was excellent and vast! We were told if you looked at every item on display for one minute and had no breaks or sleep it would take you 12 years!The guide took us around the most important parts as we only had a few hours in our two day itinerary. I had hurt my ankle and the Hermitage kindly loaned me a wheelchair to make things easier.The ladies in twin set and pearls guarding every room were fierce! An absolute must if visiting SPB we would love to return

Amazing. It's the Hermitage, one of the greatest museums of art in the world! Not only is the buidling astonishing from the outside and the interiors awe-inspiring but the art on display is fantastic in its quantity and quality. Several days in this museum would just about do it justice.

Go early!!. Visited whilst on a cruise ship. They allowed cruise passengers in an hour earlier than the general public. It was quiet on arrival and we had plenty of space. Once everyone else arrived it was packed - virtually impossible to get into the Impressionist rooms.Had a wonderful art collection. Some brilliant paintings and sculptures. The museum is set in the Los Winter Palace and the decor was amazing. Never been in a museum like it! One bizarre thing was we paid in roubles in the gift shop and were given dollars back as the staff did not have enough small coins or notes!!Just wish we had the time to look round more! Could have spent a week in there easily!

Art as far as the eye can see!. The Hermitage is an amazing art gallery, full of famous works, and stunning as a building in it's own right. Be prepared to spend many hours here, it's huge, and there's just so much to see!

Pretty magnificent as a Museam. You could spend a day here. I'm not big on museums and gor bored after a couple of hours but enjoyed the painitngs although there seems hundreds to see. If you go opn the first Thursday in the month it is free. Go early to avoid the mass, although it was busy it didn't feel overcrowded.

Be ruthless or be overwhelmed .... The exterior, interior and collections dazzle and, according to one guidebook, if you glanced at each item it would take 9 years to tour the musuem. With that in mind, here are several approaches that prevent becoming totally overwhelmed: Just walk. Soak it in, admire the interior, the views of the river, the fortress. No pressure. Make sure to see the Peacock Clock. Leave when you are ready or have an espresso at the cafe to reenergize. And, you can bring your own food and have a picnic en situ. Choose. You receive a map with the ticker purchase or just after. Have a seat, take a took, select the items that pique your interest, plan a route. Whatever you select, it will take longer than you planned. If what you've selected is important to you -- ignore everything else. Don't stop to examine interesting items, don't allow detours, stick to your plan or accept the consequences. And, there's a cafe to revive you with espresso and food. By the way, the salmon sandwiches only have salmon on the edges. Deceiptful. Yes, you can bring food in with you. At least, we saw people with food they had brought. Plan. The night before (or something similar), research what you want to see. Find it on the map. Once you are their, work with the people at information to plan your route. I am not kidding. We wanted to see the Siberian Collection and an employee started to explain how to find it and said, "Nevermind, you'll never find it. Follow me.". He is right: We never would have found it. In fact, I'm not sure what we saw: an amazing collection of items with all explanations in Russian only.Favorites: Peacock clock, the random four-man choir, The Rafael Loggias arcade, the views, the staircase, the light throughout the building, getting lost, espresso to clear our heads and revive our spirits.Least favorite: the bathrooms by the cloakrooms. AVOID. There are better WCs wihtin the musuem. Enjoy. It's a great visit. We are considering returning. And, we visited in winter,. No idea what the crowds are like on summer.
must see. amazing museum..you cannot finish it in one day..try to get inside in the morning in holidays ..after 12, there is a lot of people waiting outside...

Truly exceptional museum. The size and grandeur of the place is amazing. Apart from the physical aspects of the palace The Hermitage also has one of the greatest collections of art in the world. We visited in February when the place is much less busy so you can really appreciate what is on offer. A truly exceptional museum.

Hermitage and Winter Palace. For those of us with only a glancing acquaintance with fine art, I recommend concentrating instead on the truly magnificent rooms of the Winter Palace itself, never mind what's hanging on the walls. Such opulence! No wonder there was a revolution. . . Plus, the Egyptian mummies in the basement are worth a look. And free admission for everyone on the 1st Thursday of the month!
Symbol of Russia. I think it is one of the favorite reasons to go to StPet. If you are in StPet you should visit it. No doubt. It is one of the biggest collections of fine art in the world. Mustsee.

Don't miss it!. We visited the Hermitage mainly for the architecture and to see first hand a palace of the Imperial era. It is breathtaking. The art collection is something else too - it must rival the L'Ouvre in Paris. Amazing, I had no idea.

A. The main staircase leading into the museum is worth the entrance price as it sweeps you up into the rooms.As you walk in you may be asked if you need a guide but these people seem to be working for themselves and not the Hermitage so we refused and followed our guide book and asked the staff who are in every room for directions

Must see. Lots to see from arts to history. I would really recommend to eat before going there and maybe do some research about what you want to see. The place is a little labyrinthine. Entrance fee was 400 rubles but if you are a student there is no entrance fee. I highly recommend everyone to go there.

Extraordinarily Beautiful. I visited the Hermitage in 2002, it may have changed since then but I sincerely hope not. The St Petersburg is a beautiful city (especially when compared with the more industrial Moscow - although that has its architectural marvels in the subway, yes subway!, and Red Square...). The Hermitage is a huge museum and easily takes a few hours to see everything - take your time, enjoy the glit decor and magnificent carriages and ornaments.

Absolute Must See. Should be at the top of your list of things to see in St. Petersburg. In one place you can combine art, architecture and history. You could easily spend a couple of days in the Hermitage but I would recommend doing some research ahead of time and picking a few things you really want to see (e.g. Matisse) and after that just wander for a couple of hours. After 2-3 hours you'll want to take a breather. Recommend getting a two-day pass so you can go back. Also highly recommend buying your tickets ahead of time and bringing the print out with you - you get to jump to the front of a very long and slow line.

Wow!!!!!. Just amazing! The rooms are very beautiful and the paintings are overwhelming. So many famous paintings in one place... The peacock clock is amazing. You need to pick what you want to see as there is enough for two weeks...

WOW. It's a MUST. Beeing in Sankt Petersburg and not seeing the Eremitage - it's jsut impossible. Never saw such an amount of fantastic and splendid rooms. Not to talk about the paintings and treasures...
Great to visit in Winter. Massive job to get through in a single visit, but Winter avoids the crowds, so much easier. The French Impressionists are great, as is most of the collection.
Amazing. No words could be said to describe this massif masterpiece. Be prepared to do at least 8 hours to breeze bye the whole thing. Remember there is a coat check downstairs which is mandatory.

Get tickets ahead!. Well worth the trip, but lines are hours long! Book at a hotel that can get you in with the group tour by pass lines. Standard Russian style museum, but best collection of art in the country!

AMAZING...need a week. Thee was nothing to dislike and to much to absorb. You will need a week to digest this museum. First Wed of every month is free. If you want to take pictures you need to pay an extra 200rbs. Entrance fee daily is 400rbs. Nice coat check facilities and plenty of them. Nicer staff than other museums.

You need plenty of time!. There is plenty to look at. Possibly not the most interactive museum for children, but they are certainly welcome. Something for everyone among these rooms and the rooms themselves are very beautiful.
Amazing artichtecture. Well worth the visit, though don't plan to spend the day there, you can wizz around in a couple of hours because most descriptions are in Russian only!

Endless Amazement. This was quite the experience. I am more into active things but there is no way I was leaving St. Petersburg without seeing the 2nd largest museum in the world. We only had two days in St. Petersburg because we were on a Baltic cruise. This was two days with every second packed with things to do, the largest amount of time being at the Hermitage. Not only are you looking at wall art and sculptures... every hardwood floor, ceiling, door, etc was amazing. The absolute best thing we did was splurge on a private tour. After seeing the crowds and chaos at some sites I can't even imagine how harder it would've been without a private tour. We were in and out and always on the move, not waiting for 20-50 other people.

The best museum in the world?. This is surely the best museum, art gallery, palace, call it what you will, in the world. If possible, get yourself your personal guide as the place is vast and very easy to get lost in. Smile at the custodians in each room - they appreciate it.
Fab. Took us all day to cover about 80% of the exhibits, but it is the most amazing experience. Not very busy, blissfully warm, and each room opened into another box of delights.
Impressed!. I was impressed by the huge & diverse collection in this beautiful museum, it was my first visit & for sure not the last... This was for me a "discovery" :-)

Absolute must in St. Petersburg. Hermitage is impressive, to say the least! I wish I had more than one day to spend there. The collections are amazing! The rooms that once served as home to Royal Family are mind-blowing. Tip #1: make sure to buy online tickets to avoid major lines to the entrance. Tip #2: If you have two tickets for 2 days, notice that they are actually marked Day 1 and Day 2, and use accordingly. Each ticket is valid for passing trough turnstiles only ONCE.

Fantastic. Not being much of an art lover, I must admit, I did enjoy the Hermitage but it did help that we had our own guide. My feelings about the Palace were not as good. Thinking that people were starving back then and then to walk into this huge ornate building was difficult but that is the way it was I guess

The most awesome ever of museums. This Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia was the most awesome museum I have ever visited. It had 3 stories and art work on every wall including the ceilings. The paintings were so beautiful, Sculptures were all fantastic and outstanding. You stand in awe just walking through all the rooms filled with art from all over the world.
Amazing. You definitely need a few days to marvel at this most beautiful place....just go you will not be disapointed (well maybe the toilets but it's a small price to pay!)

Fabulous. This is a wonderful place to visit and every trip to St Petersburg should include a visit to the Hermitage. If you can go as part of a tour group you can avoid queues (which can be extraordinarily long and eat into your time in this magnificent city. Lots to see, so be selective and read up before you enter. This was one of the highlights of our trip.

You could spend days, even weeks, here. There are so many pieces of art it is overwhelming. Luckily, we had a private tour guide and ventured off into some of the lesser viewed areas. I am fascinated by sculptures so we spent an hour or so looking through the sculpture rooms. You could literally spend weeks here and still miss some pieces as there is so much to take in. I am not a huge fan of museums in general, but I was impressed with this Palace turned Museum. I allocated a couple hours for this stop which was plenty of time for me but I can see why many tours spend an entire day here.
must see. wonderful!! really a great collection. very well kept. your trip is incomplete without this visit. But keep sufficient time as it takes quite long cant be rushed.

great history lesson. the guides are acceptable to bargain on tour guides.
we got it for 1000 rubles, wintertime. 1 hour
200 ekstra to take pictures

A true wonder. Certainly one of the best museum I ever visited. It can take a while to see everything so, please plan to spend at least 2 days if you really want to enjoy all the collections. Buying tikets in advance is advisable as queues at the entrance can be long.

You need days for this. I was with a tour party on a visit to the city, and the plan was to follow a tour guide lady for two hours around the Hermitage Museum. I knew immediately that it was a better plan to say "I'll see you all at the front doors afterwards," and charge in on my own. The Winter Palace is vast. Yes, it's the place the Bolsheviks stormed in 1917. Today it claims to be the world's biggest art museum. They seem to have a stern old lady sitting in every room, eyeing you suspiciously. I pretty much jogged around, map in hand, desperate to see a few items of great personal interest. I'm VERY glad I did. I found myslef in a room crammed with Picasso Cubist works. The contents of the walls were probably worth ten million quid. No thanks, keep moving. All of a sudden I found myself in heaven, in a room full of Gauguins. Extraordinary. I sat, inches from canvasses, seeing at last where strokes of paint were applied. No photos can substitute for really looking with your own eyes at the lumps and bumps and brush-strokes on the real thing. I felll crazily in love with Renoir's portrait of the actress Jean Samary. She's standing expectantly, as if asking "can I see it yet?" 120 years later her charm and character still shine. You'd need a week to see around this place any way properly. Otherwise I recommend taking a beeline for a few favourite items your heart longs to see.

Beautiful Winter Palace square. We did not have the opportunity to visit the museum because it is closed Mondays, but a visit to Winter Palace square for a memorable photo was awesome! I certainly hope to visit the Hermitage at some point in the future.

come here during the summer!. Came during the winter didn't get to see the garden with planted flowers, should be amazing....the Winter Palace tops the 'must visit' list in St. Petersburg simply because it has the most collection, most complete of historic pieces, more than the British museum I could say!

The World's largest and best collection of art. You will never have enough time to see everything so you need to plan your visit. For me the paintings collection was the attraction so many and such famous paintings carefully displayed but without obvious security screens. In half a day we perhaps saw half the collection. Aside the buildings themselves are splendid such opulence and splendour, money was both no object and had to be spent. A light bite in the cafe kept us going as you have to make the most of your visit. But I will have to go back.

Kind of sad when you think of it. Beautiful art of all traditional European genres, large oversized rooms and many of them. Thank God there is a Russian Museum for Catherine the Great was so busy trying to acquire the treasures of the world she seems to have slighted her own culture. Although larger, it reminds me of any of the great collections in London, Paris, Florence, NYC or the Vatican; for that matter . Never the less, its wonderful to enjoy Da Vinci etc. in that setting.Just a tip. Make sure you visit the restroom before exploring as they are far and in between.
It is a wonder!!!. I liked everything. I only hated to leave - my advice - go twice. I went with a guide first time and the second time - on my own. You just can not make it in one visit!!!

Should have allowed more time. We only allowed 2 1/2 hours as we wanted to see The Winter Palace rather than the paintings. However, when we got there we were absorbed by the beauty of the rooms and tried to see as many of the highlights we could. You can purchase tickets from a machine as long as you have the correct notes as it doesn't give change which apparently saves queing during busy periods.

Huge, crowded and not informative. We visited the Hermitage in October 2012 and the expectations were high. Mostly thay were met, because the art is very beautiful and versatile there.However, you should practically spend days to see all the items. Also, not surprisingly, there are a lot of other people too!What was most disappointing, the descriptions of the works were mainly in Russian, not in English.
Hermitage/Winter palace is a must. just fantastic imperial Russian experience, just the size of things there and the ornate beauty is breathtaking

Great. Get there early as even in winter there is a hugh queue, they take your jacket so don't be like us and leave your camera in it, we were allowed to take photo's a magnificent building and an truly amazing art collection

A stunning and moving tribute to Russian perseverance. Perhaps it was due to the skill and knowledge of our guide Maria (from Ulko Tours), but we learned so much of the Russian experience by our tour of the site. Through the lens of history, notably the difficult times during the siege of Leningrad and the sacking of the city's treasures during World War II, our guide helped us understand the heroic strength of the Russian people and the vision of their leaders.

Some practical tips for one of the best museums in the world. Won't go into the details of the artistic, historic etc value of this amazing place - think it's quite obvious. Some practical advise for those going there on their own: if you're going in the holidays season buy entrance tickets in internet - we spent 2 hours in the queue under the rain as we went there in the New Year's week (absolutely worth nevertheless). The museum is huge so try to spend there about 3-4 hours and prepare in advance thinking about which sections are you going to see - finding your way through is not very easy! The royal halls with restored interiors (situated after you enter through the main stair are a must in my view, then everything depends on what collections are you interested in. There's a cafeteria with wifi and OK food inside the museum.

fantastic day in the Hermitage. We enjoyed our time in the Hermitage: numerous paintings, beautiful rooms, and professional knowledgable guide Maria.magnificent Leonardos, Numerous Titians and Veroneze and an hour spent in front of every Rembrandt's work - he is my favorite one. I know that this is the place where i wish to be back one day and definitely with the guide we had. She knows so much that 5 hours we spend inside passed like a minute! She actually said that we were very lucky as it was winter time - there was almost nobody inside, while in summer i can imagine how different it is! Great job, Maria, and thank you TJ Travel for taking such a good care of us

Top Five Museum on Planet. Simply amazing. Overwhelming, and massive. No wonder it is #1 attraction in the city. Wing upon wing of paintings, drawings, amber, vases, and every other type of art imaginable. Go early!

Beauty of real arts!. Visiting Hermitage museum, you always start from the Palace square where Hermitage is located. All this square palaces decoration astonish you with their interior beauty and you are trying to imagine what is inside then. Hermitage itself is a great architecture masterpiece with all its rooms and halls. But the most valuable thing is its huge collection of paintings, sculptures, crafts, gathered all around the world. Trying to describe what is inside has no sense. It's impossible to describe, it's worth seeing. And if you plan to go there, remember 3 hours it's minimum, needed to glance at this palace's contents. I agree with those people who say that the best time to visit Hermitage, it's time when as less people as it's possible there. I visited St. Petersburg and Hermitage in September 2012, and I would say that it was enough comfortable to observe the museum without huge crowds.

Never enough time to see the beauty of this place. I loved everything, I could spend days in this place, loved everything about it !! I had a fantastic guide and went at a time when the queues were not long with groups of tourists, if you dont mind a bit of cold weather I would definately recommend November to beat the crowds !

So worth it!. Traveling to Russia is a hassle with the visa regulations, but it is so worth it to see the Hermitage Museum. We have a small version of Hermitage in Amsterdam, which I visit frequently, but the real thing in St. Petersburg was certainly above my expectations. Go there!

A monument of atr. I has been in St-Petersburg 3 times now.The first thing it was to visit this famous palace-museum.Of course there no need to hear from me about this amazing museum.But i have some tips for you:1}If you visit the museum late spring or in the summer,you have to book 2-3 months earlier.2]This museum is full of masterpieces so you need 2-3 days to see all of them.i suggest to get information ,just to be ready for the treasures you are interesting in.3}Got there early in the morning to have space and avoid the crounds.4}Leave everything heavy to the vestiare.It is not convenient to to visit this huge museum holding things. 5}Take with you only water,otherwise you have to drink either bear or vodka.They are less excpensive than water.6}take a break of, at least 30 min and then go on.7}In the front yard you can find a guide who will explain everything. He will make a proposition for his payment but you must propose the half of it.It is faire enough.I recommend this amazing museum with all my heart.

Amazing!must see. after seeing the hermitage none of the other palaces in europe quite measure up to this one. Its really huge and you need to dedicate a time to slowly look at the palace. I wished I was not in a rush...although I was there for few hours....

Fantastic !!. Allow at least half a day as a quick tour and a full day if you really want to see everything.The building itself is an exhibit. But the collection is wonderful. It enables you to understand the gap between the rich and poor which preceeded the revolution. Perhaps a major cause!!You cannot take photos (offcially) but a small pocket camera without flash worksin some locations.Really a must see

One of the best museums in the world!. Excellent collections, the palace is itself amazing. Take plenty of time to really savour it.Buy your tickets online, saves queues, but beware that foreigners get to pay a more expensive price compared to the locals.
Queues. We went on the 1st Thursday of the month (2nd Jan) when it's free (and a public holiday). It took 2.5 hours to get in.

Amazing. The Hermitage was amazing. It is hard to decide what is more impressive, the palace itself or the art collection inside. I would recommend doing some research before you go, I wished I had done so.
A day well spent. It is wonderfull to spent a day here, actually a day is too short. To much to take in in just a day.
Simply amazing!!!. This is one of the most complete and astonishing museums ever!!! You need to reserve a whole day if you want to really admire everuthing it has to offer. An absolute must see!

Not where it says it is on trip advisor. Still trying to get there to visit and just wanted to let other travellers know to google its correct location. Was long walk and in the opposite direction to its corrwct location.
Incredible collection.. Very difficult to navigate and crowded. The Matisse rooms are fabulous. Decent English audio guide. Could take two days if you really want to see everything.
Always worth the trip!. The building is magnificient ( winetrpalace the highlight), evry room is worth the detour. Take your ticket on the internet and you will skip the very long lanes...

Disappointing. The Hermitagae has an excellent, international reputation. We were therefore disappointed to discover that it is not particularly well curated for today's standards and in particular that many of the exhibits lack translations of the Russian explanatory text. Even the Russian text seemed short on detail. There also seems to be a fairly haphazard approach to providing the translations otherwise we would have clocked on to how bad it was earlier, returned to the start and paid the extra for the audio guide or a tour guide! Also, a few signposts wouldn't have gone astray.. We had a map (and are quite good with maps!) but had to rely on trial and error for locating much of what we wanted to see.

A huge amount of great art works. I like the palace and the museum shop where you get get some nice replicas of the paintings they have in the museum.It offers a huge amount of exhibited art works. Cannot cover them all in one day. I disliked the fact that a lot of the exhibits were stolen from the Berlin Museum at the end of WW2.It is worth a trip if you are there but if you intend to properly see it all it will take about 3 days.
Fantastic. Great collection and beautiful building. You can spend several days in it. It should be the top priority in visiting St. Petersburg.

highlight of St Petersburg. if you are in St Petersburg for pleasure, of course you are going to see the Hermitage! It is the #1 attraction, and it didn't dissapoint me. Definitely give yourself a full day, or even two. (And if you really love art, I recommend going to the Russian Museum as well - it has more art by Russian painters.) At the Hermitage, buy your tickets at a machine to avoind lining up. Beware of being scammed by the guy with the dressed-up monkeys beside the Hermitage - I really wanted to pose with the monkeys, but afer I was finished he put the monkeys on my brother's head (who was an unwilling and terrified participant), saying "two for the price of one" - and then after I took a picture of him with the monkeys on his head, the monkey owner made us pay twice! (because it was for 2 monkeys - not two people, apparently). Anyways....when you are dealing with monkey street performers, I suppose you should expect to get ripped off! if you can't resist holding adorable costumed monkeys, it is still worth it!

Great Rooms Art Average. Even with our vouchers took half an hour to get tickets on first day. From line to line. (Second day had ticket and walked in.) Beautiful marble staircase, marble on floors and walls beautiful, loved rooms with furniture showing how Czars lived. Actual art collection second-rate compared to New York Metropolitian Museum of Art, Prado in Madrid, Tate in London. Impressionist collection nothing compared to Impressionist collection in Paris, etc. But loved the Peacock clock.

Amazing museum and river view. Hermitage had a significant collection which, plus the architecture itself, was extraordinary. The museum even had a iPhone app for their exhibition, floor plan and necessary information. Entrance ticket covered the main exhibition area (three floors). There were other guided tours which required extra tickets (e.g.gold collection) but you would need to buy the tickets at the entrance and be at the assemble point at the right time. Outside Hermitage was the Neva which was blue and soothing.

Just Overwhelming. Like: Something for everyone. Bigger than I had ever dreamt. the ability to get close up to some works of art. The ability to take pictures Dislike: Crowds, it is so big one can get lost very easily.

Inefficient attendent and sad place. Kilometres of lines for buying the ticket for the entrance. At the cash machine I ve been stolen 600 rubles because the ticket machine doesn t give change back. I went to the managers, they made me wait 50 minutes and didn t give me money back. The museum is sad, not happy place. Visiting people are ugly, bad dressed, but most of all, bad smelling, because most of them don t wash themselves, especially when they sweat. You can imagine whe you are in line in front of a painting or at the wardrobe for waiting for coats. Attendand are slow and inefficient. Bad experience.

Viva the internet. When I arrived that morning, there was a queue of +/- 500 m: people that wanted to get in the Hermitage. Luckily, I ordered my ticket 2 days before via the official internet site. Only 2 people waiting before me...Anyway, it was worth to visit the museum and spend a complete day there. However to me the department with the work of the Impressionists was most "impressive".

The Best Museum / Gallery I Have Visited. Extraordinary beauty inside and out; more works of art than you can ever hope to look at, less crowded and overall more pleasant than any other gallery I've visited, which included the Louvre.

Not a big art fan, but one of the best collections I've seen!. Visited in December 2012, the collections are impressive - artists names just keep appearing and the number of paintings in each collection is amazing. This is the first place I have really experienced the chronology of art in a way which enabled an understanding of how different styles changed over time. Some very famous paintings to see as well. Worth the visit.
WOW. Must see - 2 days to see it all. Stunning architecture. Loved everything about it. Was truly magical in the snow. Everything I expected and more.

A few hours well spent. World class. Impossible cover all the highlights in a few hours so have to pick an interest area and even then you cannot see all that either. Not to miss though as one of St Petersburg's greatest treasures.

Absolutely beautiful. Arrived early, got in fast. Just an hour later I noticed there was an endless line waiting outside. But It would've been worth the wait. It's absolutely beautiful. The famous painting are but a bonus, the building itself and the work done on the walls and ceilings are just as fabulous.

Lovely and unique. There is one thing that seems to set this musem apart from others atound the world, and its the interiors. It is almost like steeping back into anither time period, as each room is ornately and individually designed and decorated. The only disappointment for me was that the Egyptian section only had information in Russian, so you had no idea what/who you were gazing at. All in all, even if the art isnt exactly what you are looking for, the architecture and ambiance alone is worth a visit. I am not too much of a museum buff, so this was my case, but I am very happy I went. One last tip: there is a glass encased, very large golden peacock about halfway through the museum in the most beautiful room of all -- one that sits on the corner of the museum and overlooks the river. It sings at 5pm everyday and I've been told this is something to see!

Beautiful Petersburg Tour with White Nights. Like: Culture and history stored in Hermitage Museum; Manificient Fountain Park in Peterhof; beautiful Neva River.Dislike: Language barrier, so could'nt move freely and easily to see more things and places by trams or subway.
Stunning. Wonderful place even without the fabulous exhibits ! Main thing to improve is to provide cafe facilities.

Amazing art gallery/museum. This place is larger than life. It's basically a massive art gallery, and we had fun wandering around for half a day. We never expected to see everything but were happy with what we saw. It was thankfully not particularly crowded because it was winter.
Amazing historic museum. This a terrific museum to really experience Russian history and art. It's probably a good idea to get a guide to give you the full experience.

Stunningly beautiful but average museum. The outside of the Hermitage Museum and Winter palace is extremely beautiful - it was a snowy day and the place was magnificent. However, the Museum itself was OK... some of the collection such as Adonis statue and Nature paintings were great, but overall, the collection was average.

Spectacular. Well, the words are inadequate to define how wonderful it is! I'm a museum-lover. And it's the best one I've ever visited in my life. It's quite big so visiting with a guide is a must. Because you can miss very important artworks. Try to visit it in other seasons than summer. Because I've been told that in summer it's too crowded.

Best with guided tour. We had a 2 hours guided tour in the Hermitage, I must say it is huge museum, one of the biggest in the world, and the best time to visit it is to avoid the holidays and summer time when it is crowded with tourists. A guided tour will give you much better information about the several different collection the Hermitage has. It is a must see when you are in St. Petersburg. especially if you are a western arts lover. the Russian collection is in the Russian State museum and not the Hermitage.

Very busy and crowded. We had really looked forward to visiting the Hermitage, but found it a little overwhelming due to the crowds. We weren't given any information which could have guided us to the more popular parts of the museum. We ended up wandering around a little blindly and probably not seeing as much as we could have if had had some sort of guide book.

Wow. Allow time here. Like Versailles or the Louvre, too much to see in one visit. Beautiful. You could easily spend two days here. Very crowded, many tourist groups. Gift shop was surprisingly mediocre.
Jaw dropping, as ever. Extraordinary. wonderful. brilliant. Tip: get a two day ticket online. you can then split up your visit. it helps take in the wonderful building and the collection.
Biggest Art Collection in the World. Overwhelming collection of the world best paintings. If you're an art lover than this should be number one on your bucketlist !

Simply a must in Saint-Petersburg. This is obviously a must for anyone - everything has already been said about it but until you've walked up that main stairs, you can't really say you've experienced it. I think it's better to start in the early morning when there are fewer people.
Breathtaking. An amazing place, from the massive and grandiose building to the fantastic art that is on show. They also have English notes for the exhibits.

Fabulous. You have to see this to believe it. Opulence is an understatement! Each room is beautifully decorated. The heating system in the rooms is a ceramic structure. I couldn't get over the fact that even such a mundane thing has such beauty. We had a very excellent guide who originally was from Kazakstan. Her English was excellent and she was very knowledgable. She solved more than one beaurocratic problem on our two day tour. You need your passport to get on and off the ship.

Plan carefully to experience the best!. Not being part of an organised tour you are treated as a second class citizen! There is so much to see that you will be disappointed if you have not planned your visit carefully in advance

Terrific - French Impressionist Paintings Amazing. The French Impressionist paintings are well worth the exhibit. Our guide was knowledgeable about all that we saw and allowed us to proceed at our own pace within the 3 hour tour. I highly recommend the use of a guide as you gain early entry before opening to the general public. It was very easy to arrange for a guide at the Marina S Wilson Tours web site and communicate directly with Maria via Skype to confirm details.We found 3 hours sufficient time to see the collection highlights and avoid museum fatigue. A must see attraction in St. Petersburg

It's amazing!!!!. It's a huge old antique style building plus a big, wide Winter Palace... Remember, can not bring any large items into the museum. Any Bags, briefcases, big coats, umbrellas... must be left in the cloarkrooms, free of charge but lot of hassle on crowd daỳs..... Photography and video recordings are permitted only on purchase of a special ticket...
Fantastic!. Never enough time to see it all, but happy to say I saw some. I unexpectedly, loved the priceless art by famous Masters. I am not 'into' art, but those that we saw were beautiful.

Amazing pavilion room. students get in free (regardless of nationality) so that was a huge bonus for our budget (otherwise its 400 rubles). I've read that you can't possibly see the entire museum but I feel that we saw it all without a problem but granted we didn't spent too much time at one particular art piece, we didn't have a guide and we got there early (we also only saw the main building due to the high cost of the extra rooms). I was disappointed that many of the palace rooms were closed. The pavilion (peacock) room was incredible and I really enjoyed that (though the clock no longer chims). We paid 200 rubles extra for a camera permit (sticker) to take photos inside but I noticed that there were many people who did not have the sticker but they were taking photos regardless, so I guess the photo stickers aren't enforced. We started on the second floor (had most of the things we wanted to see), then moved to the third and lastly did the first floor. The single digit rooms on the first (ground) floor didn't have much to see and the area seemed to be used more for storage than museum viewing, however the small section of Siberian art and culture was interesting. In the museum, most of the major items were marked in English, abet most of the time it was only the title and artist. They also ave an app but its pretty much worthless. It's only added value above the provided map is that it gives you the name of the room for the apartment section but since most of the apartment rooms were closed and others were labeled "Hall" it didn't help much. Also, at least for the winter, there was no ticket line so don't bother paying the fee for online tickets.
VERY NICE & HUGE!!!. Very nice, HUGE, took a long time to visit, don't spend the 350 rubles to get in as there is much to see without paying!

beatifull architecture, great ballet performance in Hermitage theater. I have been there at rainy night (what else in November 8o) - but even at that condition it has been very beatifull experience. It is a "must see" experience when U R in the citiy. I had no chance to visit the museum, but I experienced the ballet performance in Hermitage theater (Tchaikovsky's ,utcracker) and it has been stunning!! I have not visited ballet for more than 25 years - but this one was beatifull, amazing - just go! The theater is a great experience - relatively small, beatifully decorated, stylish, historical - just beatifull. There was Shagals painting exposition in fore room - extra artistic experience itself!

Take a breathe and see the history. If you visit St. Petersburg and don't see Hermitage then something is wrong with you...Well to much info about Hermitage already that nothing is left...Just note that few hours isn't enough, you may need up to 2 days to see everything in Hermitage. Then walk to city center (Gostynny Dvor) to shop in passage. Nice experience.
One of the best museums in the world!. There is so much to see that you could easily spend there 3-4 days. In Winter Palace you'll see ´housing of the czar family and the Hermitage is devoted to art.

Breathtaking place! Guided tour is a must.. I knew from reading and listening to others that it is incredible and not possible to see in one time, but no words can describe the feeling of magnitude and beauty and excitement I experienced on my first visit. I have been to Louvre and enjoyed it but the magnitude of Russian Zars is mindblowing. Knowing from reviews that it is not possible to comprehend and see it in one visit I planned to visit it for four days in a row to really see and explore it. On a first day I spent one hour exploring it on my own while awaiting the scheduled guided tour. Then I enjoyed two and a half hours guided tour which was called "Introduction and overview of Hermitage" and is the best choice I could have done to start my exploration of Hermitage. It was so rich in history, art, impressions that I had to take a break and change my plan and visit other places next three days. I returned for another visit on my last day and had time on my own. I regret that I discovered only upon leaving that there were few other guided tours available of permanent collection. I recommend to get acquainted with the choices of guided tours offered and displayed on the wall near cashier's booth and on the follow up visits to take advantage of them. I plan to do so on my next visit.

Something for Everyone. This museum really is spectacular, and after visiting my first time, I felt it was no surprise the Russians had a revolution. My most recent visit was on the occasion of my traveling companion's first time in Russia. As she had an interest in Russian history, it seemed essential to visit the Winter Palace. We didn't stay a very long time, as we knew there was too much for one visit. We focussed on collections that were of special interest to us, starting with the Egyptian rooms! I bought our tickets on the Internet, which was the smartest thing to do. We needed to print them, so it was fortunate we were staying somewhere with a printer. On arrival we walked past the very long line, showed our tickets to the folk at the door and made our way to an information desk. We were escorted to the entrance gate and thankfully didn't have to deal with long waits or huge crowds. I find the crowds around the entrance hall very difficult, so my advance purchase helped enormously. Once you are inside the museum, the crowds aren't a problem. One more helpful hint, which didn't apply on this visit. A number of years ago I was escorting a group of pensioners on a tour of Moscow and St Petersburg, some of whom had difficulty walking. In this museum we were able to get a wheelchair which made our visit manageable. I don't know if that is still possible, but if you can arrange it, and you need it, it is certainly worth it. We just asked on arrival. I am not sure I remember correctly, but I believe there was a fee.

Magnificent. A previous winter palace with four adjacent buildings housing amazing pieces of creativity...This is a treasure trove of artistic appreciation with beautifully presented artworks...Oh, what a marvelous day out and I will return to enjoy the experience in totality...Piece of advise, it can get terribly crowded. Do your research....

Very impressive museum. You can never say you saw or visited all of this wonderful grandiose Museum. You need weeks long to spend there but thanks to our wonderful guide whose name I cannot remember we believe we saw all important displays and know a bit of their history and background. A guide in this Museum is «must». I still don’t believe I was standing in front of all the shining gold and diamonds. I was deeply impressed.

Westernization. In the normal westerners mind Louvre and the Met is the 2 biggest art museums in the world. Well guess what Americans, the "communists" has something of equal magnitude. (Yes humor was involved in writing this review.)Students get's in for free.

A month of Sundays and you still couldn't see it all. A wonderful palace with an unbelievable collection of art and treasures.If you ever get to St Petersburg, then the palace is definitely a must see visit.

Vast collection brilliantly displayed. Refferred to as " The Hermitage" the scale of the displays is quite overwelming and you spend days which of course no one has when they are only in a place for a short time. The gold and diamond room is the jewell in the crown and you must have a guide I cannot emphasis this enough as they will detail the history behind these magnificant pieces and will give you a greater appreciation of there importance. We had a brilliant guide. This lady's knowledge was vast and her capacity to convey details in a simple manner made the tour very pleasurable.We only had a brief time to view the impressionist paintings which are vast in number and displayed expertly. The Hermitage is as important a museum sa any in the world and if you are a lover of fine art and jewellery you will be simply love this great experience.

Art, History and Architecture. Whether you are in to Art, History or Architecture - the Winter palace will definitively impress both You, Your spouse and any children you may take along. The exterior as well as the interior are so grandious, well maintained and full of details, colours and gold to impress all of you. Besides - we were suprised to see one of the most extensive art collections in the world: Van Gogh, Picasso's, Matisse, Renoir, Monet, Cezanne, Gauguin, Rodin etc.

A Must See. There is no doubt this is one of the "must see" in St Petersburg.It is quite simply magnificent. The scope of the collection has to be seen to be believed. The lay out can be a little confusing and requires some attention to ensure you don't miss something significant. I was there in late November so there were no queues but I can believe other users' reports of lengthy waiting times to get in as the system for payment seemed quite haphazard. The only other piece of advice I would offer is make sure you get the audio guide, it's worth the money.
Unmissable ,. The cloak room, nil by coats allowed , lighting is poor , but some great art , head straight to the 3 rd floor , and work down, for some crowd control

My favorite attraction in St.Petes. The Hermitage went under my radar as one of the best museums in the world. I have been to many in Europe and the states and this is in the top 3 for sure. I like seeing famous works of art and this was probably only surpassed by Louvre, but the architecture and furnishings at the Hermitage were more impressive to me. Also...just to clear up a point of confusion, there is another Winter Palace Tour, located along the river to the east/north, where you can tour Peter I actual winter palace. It is very cheap/short and less impressive but still worth the trip and very historically significant/cool, just don't expect the Hermitage part 2.

Excellence and wealth!. It is the biggest museum I have ever been and although we spend about 4 hours there I think we saw only a little part of it! It is a national treasure in there and is a must see for everyone who is visiting St.Petersburg. Just remember to wear cosy shoes!

Historic Visit. You need two days to fully apreciate this Musium.
Book tickets before hand , saves quing.
So much to see and aprecieate

One of the Best art museums in the world. We trully enjoyed our tour to the Hermitage museum. we had a general tour, which included the Gala rooms and the best paintings of the european art, that the museum posesses. Surely, it is not possible to see all of them during one visit, but are sure we saw the best ones. Of course, most of our great impression was to the fact, that we didn.have to stay in long lines to get to the museum, as we have a booked tour with a guide (TJ-Travel company). it was superb - we didn't wait for a second - our diver took us to the entrance, where a special representative of TJ-Travel was already waiting for us with our tickets (our guide phoned the lady, that we are approaching). So, not a seconf waitning, we went directly inside! and after the tour there our guide called the driver (it is not allowed for the cars and busses to park for a long time in the embankment there), he came in 2 minutes, and off we went.

Fabulous. Hermitage is top museum in St. Petersburg. Quite long queue when we visited there (about 45 minutes). There was a girl who sold tickets (about 10 euros) that you can bypass the queue but have to buy the ticket (other 10 euros). Double pricing, so you have Russian passport, it is much cheaper. The museum itself is fabulous and there is so much to see that one day is not enough. Decided to leave some parts of the museum to next visit. Nice cafe available

Much more than you can explore in a single day.. Be sure to give yourselves a couple of days to explore the Hermitage. Go early to avoid the crowds. Come back late in the evening to see the raising of the bridges.

Fantastic treasure trove of Russian history. Long Queues to access so book online or expect to wait up to several hours. One not to be missed. Possibly the best collection in world if possible visit more than once there is a huge amount to savor
Weekend trip St Petersburg. The long waiting was all worth it!!!The interior is so fantastic. Take your time though - at least half a day. The place us huge!!
Stunning. Difficult to work out if you are in one of the most impressive royal palaces in Europe or one of the finest art collections

Unbelievable in every respect. Ask to tour the jewel room! Catherine spent her unlimited wealth on the best and most exciting art and artifacts from Europe and the world. At least the better part of the day should be reserved abd the more time the better.

Facinating site - needs a few days to see propertly. The security staff are quite rude. They didnt allow me to wear my coat inside and barked at me to check it in. They couldn't explain this properly in English.

Overwhelming. It's amazing and impossible to cover in 1 day or in a short review. Huge collection in hundreds of rooms. Gives good impression of tzar's lifes in 18 & q19 centuries. Try to do some research & then go see what you want - but preferably go with a tour guide. Of course, it's a must if you ever go to Russia or at least St-Petersburg.

Not the most friendly. Exhaustingly large museum with hardly anywhee to sit and take the weight off. ignage can be misleading. I ollowed signs for French, German and Dutch art well but tryingto findBritish art, which there is a large collection, proved impossible. I three hours and went for a much needed beer. Internetcafe staff do not seem too bright. I asked girl where an |ATM was. eve after showing her a museum map she cold only say " I only work in the cafe". Seemed not to have the slightet idea she worked in one of the world most famous museums, or care either.

So large. The exhibts are so many and varied that as a whole they defy description. The dissapointment is not in the palace and its contents, but that on a shire excursion you do not have enough time, and the place is stuffed with shore excursions! We resolved that if we go back to St Petersburg (and we'd like to) we'd go out of the cruise ship season. This criticism applies to almost every sight in the city.

Just beautiful. The hermitage is one of the most beautiful museums i've ever been. It is gigantic, in three hours you haven't seen everything. booking in advance may be a good idea since there are always lines outside, but definetly worth waiting for. The museums is closed on mondays. We kept losing track of where we were, it would be a good idea to make some sort of route on which you can see the most beautiful things.

Beautiful museum, mess of a ticketing system. Nothing much to add on the quality of the collections, simply unbelievable for some of them, or the magnificent interiors of the Winter Palace. The price, roughly 10 Euros for foreigners (5 for Russians), is completely justified. The ticketing system, however, is a nightmare, while you will have a hard time finding the automatic ticket vending machines (cash only, of course). Overall a great experience rendered a tad chaotic by the obvious mismanagement of the ticketing system.

Jewel in the crown. The Hermitage really is the highlight of any trip to St Petersburg. It's a beautiful building with an amazing collection contained within. We had a guided tour and I'd recommend this as the building is huge and if time is short you'll want to see as much as possible. As an added bonus we enjoyed a fantastic orchestral concert in the evening as part of our visit.

Crowded, crowded. All visitors are accepted so make sure you visit early in the morning otherwise you will not be able to see the Museum properly. At a certain point I could not set my feet on the ground...........

Use a Guide!. Be sure to have a personal guide (The best is Timofey Kruglikev) as the lines are daunting! Timofey will keep you out of the lines. And only inside, he will direct you to the best of the best of this huge, amazing collection.
Wow. Amazing art collection,inside an overwhelmingly beautiful building.I am glad we visited at a quiet time of year, I imagine the volume of visitors would be unbearable at peak times.
Must see. This is an amazing museum. Great collections. You haven't been to St. Petersburg if you haven't visited the Hermitage.

Make plenty of time available to throughly enjoy. This is the premier of Russian Museums and brought the multi day ticket. Spent the first day at the Hermitage going to all the rooms and looking at the art and design. Skipped the ancient history stuff. On the second day hired the audio guide to look at the art in greater detail. Where can you stand 2 feet away from two Leonard Di Vinci paintings? There is a cafe at the lower level to recharge. The time we visited was excellent as there were few tourist and have been warned in the summer that the place is packed an not much fun.

Huge Museum on the canal. We visited this museum while on a tour with TJ Tours. Our guide was able to move our group through the museum seeing the major exhibits while avoiding most of the shoulder to shoulder packed rooms. The rooms showing the major paintings of the Maddona and Child were extremely crowded. Our guide gave us the tour in English and highlighted the important exhibits.
Fantastic. We loved the Hermitage. We went on a Sunday and had no lines. The art is amazing and the audio headset is worth the extra cost

Wow Stunning!. We ordered tickets online and printed a ticket off before we travelled. Following other reviews went early and avoided queing. Despite our lack off speaking Russian the staff were all friendly and very helpful. I can't write about the exhibits there are so many but a personnel favourite must be the royal portraits, Tzars sledge, the ornate corridors and THAT staircase ... so so beautiful and grand. There are other palaces you can visit with a two day ticket. Well worth the money.

We went back three times and were still wanting more. Give time to go to the vaults and see the gold collection.Top floor two rooms one with Picasso paintings and sculptures and the other with Claude Monet.But whole place is full of great works of art.

A gorgeous museum building and beautiful art too!. There is so much to see, and we were really grateful for the cafe and a chance to sit down. It is overwhelming, but we were able to see everything in one afternoon.

It's huge with lots of interesting things to look at. This really is an impressive building with a huge collection of art, you can very easily get lost for hours. You really have to go when you come to St PetersburgThe signs seem to suggest that you can't take you camera in but lots of people had them with a camera sticker so there must be something you need to ask for when buying your ticket.

Cool. The Hermitage is a huge museum, with Picasso, Matisse and you can actually photograph them, so that to me was quit strange but i took tons of photos of great painters. I actually got screamed at not for taking photos but for stretching my back. Go figure.The Museum cafe serves average coffee and food, nothing tasty really.

Quite overwhelming. A vast collection of art in a beautiful location. Some of the rooms are breathtaking. Allow plenty time as there is so much to see. We, quite by chance visited on the first Thursday of the month and it was free!

Breathtaking. The entry fee is approx 400RUB but if you are a student or ICOM member then remember to bring along your ID cards. These are normally only accepted at certain ticket desk, (when I visited both times it was 3 and 4) obviously there is normally a longer queue, and remember to purchase an amateur photography ticket even if you want to take a picture on your mobile/cell phone as they are very strict about this. When you pass through the ticket check point they will not admit you into the museum with a camera if you do not have an amateur photography ticket. It is free to store your coat and belongings in the cloakroom. The museum has 2 main cloakrooms; upstairs and downstairs, I would recommend the upstairs one which has only 4 desks but is normally much quieter as its mainly used for tour groups. The downstairs cloakroom is always extremely busy and very noisey. The cost for an audio guide is 350RUB for foreigners and 250RUB for Russian, CIS nationals. Sometimes if they server knows you’re a student they will allow you to pay the 250RUB. I would recommend it, as many of the objects and grand rooms of the palace do not have detailed interpretation/information displays, and if they do it may only be available in Russian. However there are some limited English signs. It is a handheld electronic device similar to an iPhone or PDA, extremely simple to use; all you do is enter the number of the room your in and you will hear an explanation or information by someone with a very British accent. The museum itself is simply spectacular, from a museum point of you this one of the worlds leading and largest art collections with apparently 3 million objects on display through out the hermitage and winter palace. Make sure to have your photograph taken on the famous stairway and look above to see the images and frescos of ancient Greek gods. Its very easy to be overwhelmed by the building and forgetting that each room is filled with priceless art and objects. They are currently renovating certain parts, hallways, stairs and lobby areas so at times don’t be surprised if certain galleries are closed. Services wise, in several parts of the museum there is private stalls selling books, souvenirs and various St Petersburg items, the real museum store is located next to the cafes. The museum store is actually normally priced and even has special offers. I was rather disappointed with the catering facilities available to visitors, just a simple coffee/tea bar and then another self service café. For a museum this prestigious they are losing out a key market being able to cater to good standards. One would expect the hermitage to have several high quality cafes and restaurants similar to that found in the British Museum, National Museum of Scotland and the Victoria & Albert Museum. Make sure you see all of the museum, if you’ve only spent 2 hours int here you haven’t seen it all, I would recommend an entire day! Enjoy it! The place is amazing!

National Treasures. The array of art pieces and the opulent interior of the palace make this a worthwhile visit.Be prepared to spend at the very least half a day here. I visited Hermitage at the end of October. It was not the peak period then. Got my ticket online (which was slightly more expensive) just in case there was a queue. It was totally unnecessary.The only complaint I have is with the lighting - the reflections made it hard to view the paintings.

Beyond my wildest expectations. I actually never had any burning desire to visit St. Petersburg but when friends asked us to join them on a Seabourn cruise of the Baltic Sea, with three days in St. Petersburg, my husband and I said, sure, why not?Definitely the way to see The Hermitage, as well as the palaces at Tsarskoye Selo and Peterhof, is through a cruise ship tour company. Because Seabourn is a small ship, we were docked at the English Embankment, which is a very short drive to The Hermitage. And cruise ships get preferential opening times so we were in before the crowds of visitors.If you love decorative arts, architecture, Western European art and antiquities, you must promise yourself to visit The Hermitage at some point in your lifetime. It houses the largest collection of Western European art in the world. Catherine the Great bought 13 Rembrandts, I believe, in her starter collection along with da Vincis, Van Dycks, Hans Holbeins. Subsequent rulers added to her collection, and even during the Communist regime, collections were added (Matisse's muse donated a large number of his works).But if you're a decorative arts junkie like me, you'll barely be able to see the paintings because you'll be so busy looking at the phenomenal parquet floors, exquisite plasterwork, the marquetry on the furniture, the architecture detail of the rooms.We had the most wonderful young woman as a guide. Her English was excellent, her knowledge of art history, Russian history and the details about The Hermitage and palace complex was entertaining and extremely informative. It's said that if you spent a minute in front of each object at the Hermitage, it would take you 15 years to see it all. It would be well worth the try.

Must see in St. Pete. Beautiful, HUGE, incredible experience. Loved the Rembrandts! This place will blow your mind...they even let me in for free. Must have known about the stellar review I was destined to write. :P
Brilliant. So much to see, such beautiful artifacts and paintings - could spend hours, busy in there ... The top place to see in St Pete - amazing, very busy but a mnust see

Three hours in the rain to get a ticket. The museum is wonderful.But be prepared for a long and unpleasant wait to get a ticket and when getting into the museum be prepared to be pushed by a crowd of tough people trying to let you back in the line.

One of the world's finest!. This is an amazing museum. You could literally spend days here and not see it all. Highly recommend using a guide. There is an additional cost for photography. The rooms of the winter palace are absolutely stunning too. A must see!
Amazing. You could never possibly see every exhibit or visit every room in just 1 visit. The place is vast. Tastefully restored and benefitting from some amazing art displays.

Have a day in St Petersburg?. One word. WOW! There is really no where like this building anywhere. We found, from talking with others, the best way to get around this museum is with a guide. There is so much to see, and so far to walk that we missed a lot of what the Hermitage has to offer. There is millions of displays to see, our guide told us if you spent 2 minutes in front of every single display you would spend 11 years in there. All up you walk over 25kms to see everything, we did the "short" tour of 4 hours and 5kms. As with every other museum we went to in Russia you must check your bag if it is too big and you have to pay extra to be able to take photographs. It was hard to retain all the information we were told, though, as everything has a different meaning and story. There is a wonderful Rembrandt selection which I could have spent hours at! Definitely worth the visit and i just wish we had taken the whole day to see more.

Of course a great art collection. Although started during Catherine's reign, the collection interestingly grew in the early 1920's, the mid-1930's and after the Great Patriotic War. The labels reveal the provenence once unexposed.

Not at al what I was suspecting. Rather disappoiunting but well worth the visit. You can bypass the queues by buying your ticket in the automat located in the corner of the courtyard - ignore the sign that says it closes at 1600 - it doesn't...!
Do not miss this amazing place.. As expected the art is stunning. If the opportunity arises take a tour of the vaults too, though it s expensive it is well worth it.

Lives up to all expectations. Both the building(s) and the collection(s) are superb. Our guided tour was included in our package so we had the same guide as for other trips. She was exceedingly well informed and obviously enthusiastic about the collection. Her English was excellent and the audio facility meant we could all hear above noise of other groups. Obviously in a few hours we could only see a fraction of what was on offer but a tour such as this did mean we saw the main highlights and we did not feel rushed.
