After the main tour we we offered the chance to stay on and explore other areas which we did. With limited time available this was a great introduction.

Place number one to see in Russia. This museum is one the most famous in the world and the first one by the number of its exhibits.You should see just the basic things during the first visit. It is no use to try to see all, smb had counted that if you want to spend at least a minute in front of each exhibit, you have to spend 7 years there without any sleep or food breaks. That is why the general tour around for onde or hours is quite enough for ordinary tourists. Mostly this is royal rooms and a lot of art, paintings. Italy; Spain, France, England. You can find smth interesting for everyone. They have a very good collection of impressioniosts, the most interesting part for the majority of tourists. A spesial tour is devoted to Royal treasury, there are two such rooms in different sides of the museum. One has a lot of treasures found during excavations, while the other one is more modern and spectaculous, shining diamonts and "royal toys". Interesting and unusual, for those who want to see smth different.
a must!. great collections, impressive buildigns, fastous environment, top place to visit. And very well organised

Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace. A world class museum, the Hermitage was the Winter Palace of Catherine the Great (1764) and became open to the public in 1852. Having over 3 million artifacts in it's collection and the world's largest painting collection, the Hermitage is massive. The Hermitage is actually comprised of several building, Pavilion Hall, Picture Gallery, Antiquities Hall, Museum of Porcelian, Menshikov Palace and Staterooms of the Winter Palace. It is a good idea to have some knowledge of what can be seen prior to your visit. Sokurov's 2002 film Russian Ark (96 min) is one way to become familar with the museum. There are virtual tours online, as well as, guide books at large book stores like Amazon or Barnes and Nobles. The Hermitage e-shop sells guidebooks. The museum has it's own website. There is a Hermitage Museum app for IPhones. Once in the museum there are audio tours and English speaking guides that hover around the entrance. Tickets run about $17.95 for an adult, It is $25.95 if you wish to see the Porcelian Museum and Menshikov Palace. The museum is always free for students and children. On the 1rst Thursday of every month it is free for everyone. It is closed on Mondays.

Winter Palace has something for everyone. We only visited the 'Palace Interior' section of the Hermitage/Winter Palace but if you are interested in art there is an endless display. We had no queues as visiting in a quiet time. It was possible to take our baby buggy around with us as there were lifts. The process buying tickets is a little confusing if you weren't prepared. Decide whether you want to pay the additional 200R for tour (at stated times), 300R Diamond Room, 300R Gold Room (which are both only accessible by guided tour), 350R audio guide (well worth it). There are other separate exhibitions which require separate tickets.

Jewel in the crown. THERE is simply no other place like it, the contents and interiors are stunning and unrivalled, We booked on line and printed out the two day voucher ( you can choose the day you want to visit and we avoided a day in the rain by attending days apart) following the printed directions . We called in a the info desk and were ushered to the front of kiosk 3 ahead of the queue and it was plain sailing from there.Judging that two days would be sufficient to do the place justice , however you cannot see everything even if you wanted to.Having read two travel books we noticed that the cafe was'nt great and a better option would be to take your own food, so we bought sandwiches at "Subway" on the Nevsky prospect close by and it worked for us.Too see the Gold collection and the Silver collection there is a 300 rouble fee for each along with an English speaking guide who was a nightmare talking so quickly to script and not answering questions that his input was pointless, however you have to pay for the service or you wont be allowed into the rooms. The cafe area is on the ground floor with a large seating area next to the internet service and has two shops for souvenirs.

Amazing collections. One of the world's great collections housed in a series of outstanding palaces - we had 2 days among the collections and were continually amazed - a must see but spend some quality time there

Best art gallery in the world. Simply the best! Booked online, a week before our holiday as I'd heard from friends how long the queues can be (cost approx $7 more for an online ticket). Slightly chaotic process when you arrive and present your voucher at the 'internet desk' and then have to move to another kiosk (no 3) for the tickets but once through security barrier, we had a super day. The map available from the 'info desk' was excellent and far better than the one in our guide book, it was worth the 10 mins it took to work out our 'route' round the Palace and gallery. There's no way we could see it all in a day, so one day we hope to come back! nb Coke and sandwich about £5.
Hermitage/Winter Palace. Beautiful building, definitely worth a visit but I've now spent 6 hours there and still haven't even seen half of everything. The place is huge
Very worthwhile. Amazing art collection and interesting historic palace. The only thing I disliked were the massive crowds of tourists, but I paid extra to bypass the very long lines.

WOW! 1st thursdays are free, use your student ID for discount on other days. we were in petersburg in the beginning of Aug, and reserved the thursday for our visit to this lovely palace... went to the entrance at 8.30 and were right in the beginning of the queue... crowds built up to the end of the square in a short time... as soon as the gates opened at 10, rushed to the counter to get the tickets for the gold room and the diamond room as these special exhibitions are not free ... our gold room tour was at 12 noon, till then we looked through the other rooms with the help of the map we had printed out from the official website...http://www.hermitagemuseum.org/html_En/02/hm2_14.html it was tough to orient ourselves to reach the gold room in this palace with 1057 rooms... we approached an official and he very courteously took us all the way as we could not understand the directions in russian... a guide took us through the exquisite gold stuff... then after a self guided tour of the gorgeous palace interiors, we went to the diamond room for our 3.30 tour... again had a terrible time trying to trace the room but some how managed... the old lady guide was exceptional in explaining all the exhibits.. had a grrat time... after the tour again tried to see rest of the palace and got out at 6 when the security started closing the palace... we did not cover all the rooms... it is impossible as there are so many
Stunning. There is so much to see and all is stunning. Very beautiful at every turn and then even more beauty at the next turn.
what a great museum. one the best painting collection ever seen, took the tour in english., plus audio guide well worth it, get voucher for ticket beforehand (internet) you can jump queque

Makes The Louvre Appear Like an Elementary School Art Exhibit. Wow! is all I can say. We saw so little of the Hermitage, yet spent almost four hours there, but was blown away. As they say in real estate, "location, location, location" and being on the Gulf of Finland, adjacent to Nevsky Prospekt, is major.We purchased tickets ahead of time at home. To be honest, I don't think that was all that necessary. We were in the Hermitage in mid-August and the lines were not that terrible. While we did not have a guided tour (highly recommended, though), we did purchase a book which provided a decent enough overview (it cost about $7 or so, and makes a very nice souvenir).Do not miss Catherine's Hanging Gardens, the peacock clock, the throne room, and take some time to visit the third floor, where the impressionist paintings reside. The floor itself needs some TLC, but the paintings are just spectacular.

Must-visit!. You haven't been to St. Petersburg if you haven't visited the Hermitage. The Hermitage/Winter Palace is truly magnificent and impressive. I love the huge collection of arts and intricate architectural details of the palace. Note that you should try to visit the Hermitage earlier (it opens at 1030am on weekends), cos lines start forming in the afternoon and after-lunch. And there are self-service ticket counters in the courtyard, so you don't have to join the line at the ticket sales counter.

Surpassed our Expectations. Located overlooking the Neva river located in the historic heart of St Petersburg.Firstly do book online, in advance and come when it opens before 10am. We read this on Tripadvisor and it proved to be a very valuable tip. We went in May and there were not to many tourists in the City, however at the Hermitage there were thousands !! However, at 10am there were two lines, one very long line where people were buying tickets on the day, the other (where we were) which had half a dozen people in it. At 10.01 the doors open, and the line we were in were allowed in and allowed to pick up our online tickets. The line with hundreds of people were let in at 10.05 and it was a mad rush, so be warned!!Once inside the Hermitage the first thing you see is the Jordan staircase which is magnificent and provides a great photo opportunity. We bought a two-day ticket and to be honest two days is really not long enough as the Hermitage is massive and there is so much to see, the collections are so diverse that you really need to priortise what you really want to see, if you try to see everything it is unlikely that you will absorb it all.Highlights for us was the art collection, furniture and gemstones.

Amazing!. Not only is the artwork contained in the Hermitage amazing but the building itself is stunning. The inlaid floors, painted ceilings and plasterwork and gilt walls attracted my attention even more than the collections. We were there with a tour group at the end of September which was a good time to go. The cruise ship season was over so the thousands of people they pour into the historical sites were not there. This is a must see and if you have the choice, go in the autumn.

Hermitage. Nothing to dislike. An amazing place that. My only regret is that I didn't have more time. Very well organized and easy to navigate. There was always someone readily available to provide directional assistance.

You need a week. You would need at least a week to do the Winter Palace and Hermitage justice!What a stunning collection of art, sculpture in a wonderful location on the River Neva.Don't miss the French Impressionis wing and the wonderful collection of Rembrandts

My favorite museum in the World!. I just can say that this place is amazing. Every time that you enter a room you are getting surprised over and over again. The floors, the ceilings, the lamps, the pieces of art are just beautiful. I read in previous reviews that you should buy your entrances in advance. I thought that it was because during the summer time it can be very busy. Nobody mentioned that for the collections of Diamond and Gold there are limited cards per day. So, we arrived to the museum, it wasn't busy at all, so we thought that we were lucky, but when we wanted to buy the cards for this collection, they were sold out! We missed our chance of seen this collection!!! So, now you know, buy your entrances for the museum and these collections in advance!!!I definitely will come back to this beautiful place. A must in your next visit to St. Petersburg.

Beautiful. This museum was very cool and worth the wait. We went with a tour group and got in early but about an hour later the lines were very long. So glad we were there at opening. Worth the wait and glad we went

Has to be seen to be believed.. All that can be said has already been written by others. Such oppulence has to be seen. Be mindful of the crowds, and the poor organisation. Despite booking on the internet, you still have to exchange your e-voucher for a ticket - when the doors opened nobody was in the kiosk to do that so we end up joining the scrum inside the main ticket hall and arguing aginst being sent out back to the unmanned kiosk!

It will knock you over!. I have been here three times and each time I see more and learn more. I do recommend a private tour and if you can, try to go later in the day when the hoards of visitors are gone and you can really get to see and experience this amazing museum.

Exceeds expectations. We arrived early and booked for the Diamond Room and the Gold Room tours. We would suggest just booking for the Diamond room as it also has an extensive collection of gold, the gold room had items very similar to those we had seen. You could easily spend an entire day there, it was amazing.

Beautiful - Some of the best exhibits anywhere. Sitting on the Neva river the Museum is the center piece of a huge square where is is common to have displays music and performers. You can not visit St. Pete without visiting the Hermitage. Expect HUGE lines in the spring and summer months. GO EARLY!!! or stand in line for at least an hour.

A must see before you die!. Hermitage is something so colossal that words just can't describe it. Only a moran passes this!When you search for luxury, when you're willing to see art from all the most famous artists room after room you must give a visit!The problem for this museum is it's size: after few hours you are totally exhausted, you understand you haven't seen anyhthin yet and you are ready to surrender. But visit it anyway and come back when ever it is possible!And sure, big house has big challenges: endles queue to get in, super rude employees, worst cafeteria ever, disgusting toilets...

a must see but take your time. huge museum and art gallerie, very impressive, book your ticket in advance online to skip the line and go for the 2 days pass (the camera fee is included). You have to leave your bags and jackets at the entrance but it is free.
Impressive collection. The Hermitage has a great many rooms, and there are lots of things to look at. Allow plenty of time as it is well worthwhile.

Bucket List for Art History Afficionados. If you go to St Petersburg as a tourist, you will undoubtedly be taken through the Hermitage. Going for only a few hours or a half day is painful if you are a true art history buff. Make sure you have a whole day to see as much as possible. The lavish interiors, intricate (amazing!) inlaid floors, and the vast collections of Russian paintings tell the history of the country, but the more contemporary and impressionist paintings are virtually unknown outside of Russia. (A whole ROOM of Picasso paintings!) Also, beware the taxi drivers outside! My worst experience of the whole trip was with a taxi driver outside who tried to take me for an expensive ride in the opposite direction from my destination. Having lived in NYC, I knew what to do, but the average tourist would feel kidnapped.

Amazing. I could not believe how amazing the collection was. I was not prepared for that. If you like art or museums I would block off a lot of time to see this. I was already museumed out having spent the better part of the previous day at another museum, but I could not tear myself away and spent much more time than I was expecting. Really a highlight of my trip.

One of the Great Museums of the World. Great museum housed in the opulent Winter Palace of the Tsars. Exhibit range from Leonardo da Vinci, Matisse and Picasso painting to an incredible array of everything Russian. The Peacock Clock is a major feature. You've not been to St Petersburg unless you've been to the Hermitage Museum.

Excellent collection of great art. If You like french art as I do, do not waste time in lower floors. Good tip is: they usually close at 6pm and last time to get ticket is 4pm. There are long lines waiting, but in the entrance gate You can get tickets from automatic machine, but You must pay exact value, so lot of people is trying to get change. For each person You need 400 rubles and 200 additional for photography. Tickets are sold separately, so make sure You have exact money for each ticket/permission. With the ticket from machine You do not wait but go straigth inside. Further You must place all Your clothing and bags in guarded storage and You will not be allowed to enter with camera without permission (kind of airport security check). You can go fast through in 2-3 hours, but even 5 hours wont make you bored! Especially at 3rd floor is a part of french art - there is a room with Picasso only (like 15pcs), Van Gogh (10?) and so. Enjoy!

A truly enriching experience. This museum is enormous. If you can, take two days to fully appreciate it. If you're a student, it's worth to take the (long) queue, as you're gonna save yourself 400 rubles (10e - come on, that's a meal!).Even though they have a vast amount of great art pieces and a lot of works from the world's most reputed artists, the rooms themselves were, in my opinion, what made the experience really worth it. However, I did miss some American art and history. Also, the fact that most signs are in Cyrillic make the experience a bit disappointing some times.This was my first "European" museum, and I'm afraid I'll have way too high standards from now on.

badtrip. I would advise anyone thinking of going on a Fred Olsen cruise to the Baltic and in particular to St Petersburg to think again! We had only one and a half hours in the State hermitage Museum - we were not allowed to leave the group while in the museum to be free to see what we wanted to see...there was a great deal of time wasting. Fred Olsen said "2days in St Petersburg" but we were only there for one and a half days.

simply amazing. Everybody knows that this is a wonderful museum. My tip is to get an audio guide as they are excellent and rather better than the people guides we overheard in the museum. And if you don't read Russian, you won't appreciate everything you are seeing.

Buy your admission online. We bought our admission tickets online and were glad we did. There are two lines for admittance, one for those with tickets already and one for those without. We got there before opening and were first in line, but the other line was perhaps100 yards long. After a while as the cloakroom fills up, somebody must leave for somebody to get in, so getting in early is your best strategy. We toured the Hermitage about 4 hours and there was just way too much to see. It was a shame to see such great works of art, and just rush through as we tried to see as much as we could. You pay a few dollars extra for the online ticket voucher ( you turn it in for tickets on the way towards the entrance) but it was worth it to us as we didnt want to waste valuable time standing in a very slow moving line.

More beautiful than Louvre. I know Louvre is the most famous, with some of the most important artworks in the world, but the Hermitage has one feature that beats Louvre: the decoration of the room. They are by themselves an artwork. Each room is perfectly decorated with marble and painted ceiling. Really nice!

Half Day Tour from Cruise Ship - Hermitage & Gold Room. We did a 1/2 day tour from a cruise ship, not the cheapest way to see the Hermitage but the most convenient especially as visas were needed to go ashore and these were included. It was a pleasant easy drive into St Petersburg. Our English speaking guide gave us all headsets so her commentary was quite clear. We did the tour in the afternoon and as it was early July is was quite crowded. The rooms were spectacular and the most incredible artworks occupied room after room. It was quite walking around as there is no air-conditioning. We paid extra for a tour of the Gold Room and for this we had to have a Russian Guide. It was just a few rooms with show cases full of gold artifacts, each one was explained to us by the Russian Guide and our Guide translated for us. This all become a bit tedious after a while. We toured 4 of the 6 Palaces and at the end we were given time in the Gift Shop. This shop sold a wide variety of cards, posters, books and good quality souvenirs. On the way outside to rejoin our bus we stopped at the Snack Bar and bought ice creams. A good tour but 1/2 day was enough time to spend there.

excellent. I am writing to give you an update on out trip. My wife and I enjoyed the trip to Europe and the cruise. The cruise was perfect. The off-shore trips in Tallinn, St. Petersburg, and Helsinki were all perfect, in terms of length and also for all the amenities and services. THe tour guides were very knowledgeable. The best was a young man in St. Petersburg, called Dimitri. This person is extremely well prepared and very good in meeting the needs of the clients. My wife and I, he two of us, had him with a minivan and driver for ourselves. The day was planned brilliantly. Others who took the ship's tours had to wait for as much as 45 minutes to get on the coach with 30 people. We took 5 minutes to clear the port and on our way. WE will recommend to anyone.So, thank you very much for everything. BEWARE OF PICK-POCKETING!

Wonderful .... but very tiring. We had a guided tour of the Hermitage museum while on or last cruise holiday. What can I say that hasn't already been said? And by much more eloquent correspondents than myself ?? This really is one of the "must sees" if you are in St Petersburg, despite the queues, the crowds and the heat (there is no air conditioning in the museum, although they do open a few windows in an effort to cool things down)For me, the buildings, the ornate ceilings, columns and mouldings are as large an attraction as the treasures the museum contains. Just for openers, the grand golden staircase which you use to ascend to the upper floors was used by royalty and the nobility .... and me !!! Amazing !!!It would be great to be able to visit in the quieter winter months, when the hoards of tourists are off searching for the sun - then you would really be able to appreciate the rooms, the works of art and all of the treasures. Just watch out for those little old Russian grannies who keep guard in all the rooms - they're not averse to hitting you with their walking sticks if you get too close to their precious possessions !
Wear Comfortable Shoes. Great exhibits and much to see. Many wonderful artworks. There are few places to stop and sit, so is sometimes difficult for older less mobile people. It is terrific

Do visit. A must for any visitor to St Petersburg. Amazing art and architecture. What spoilt it slightly was large tourist groups led by guides who were not using radio mikes/earpieces and instead choosing to speak loudly. Very irritating and needs to be policed more by museum staff.

Allow sufficient time for your visit. Two day combined online tickets to avoid the long waiting lines on Saturday and Sunday is highly recommended. We used a half day to visit the Palace and some of the collections and another 3 hours on the 2nd day for 19th and 20th century French painting and parts of other selected collections. Both the Palace and the collections are very impressive. After two days we agreed that there were a lot more to see.

Awesome. This is vast and requires either multiple visits or a good guide. Like in most Russian places of attraction you are not allowed access with rucksacks, large handbags and must obtain a permit for photography.

Wow. You need lot of time to look around. One full day is minimum. The ancient things from excavations from various parts of russia are amazing. Ofcourse all paintings and sculptuers from the famous artists are amazing.

Most astounding collections ever seen. The incredible reputation of the Hermitage is ever so true. Can recommend visiting in early October: the crowds are really manageable and famous paintings can be viewed at leisure. It pays to engage a guide, even if only for the minimum of 3 hours. You need at least 2 days to get an impression. Buy tickets via internet beforehand; arrange guide at same time.

Wonderful. An absolute must when visiting St Petersburg. So much to see that it is overwhelming. Beautiful buildings filled with treasures. Several hours is not enough time so make a list of waht you really want to see.

Overwhelming opulence!. For me, visiting the Hermitage and the Winter Palace was as much about seeing the interior architecture and decoration as seeing the art. It's a busy place on the busiest Sunday of the summer season when 13 cruise ships are in town. However, the crowds dispersed quite well once we were all marshalled past the main foyer. You may wish to take extra time to go around again on your own, to visit works of art in which you're particularly interested. The architecture, gold leaf and chandeliers were overwhelming. It was hard to take your eyes off the ceilings and the adjoining rooms to even concentrate on the art. We abandoned our tour group to take our time, had a picnic in the gardens to the side of the Winter Palace, grateful to have time to enjoy the space and symmetry of the Palace Square - away from the crowds!

As good as you can expect. Spectacular collection. You could get lost in the endless collection. The Royal apartments were my favorite. You could indulge into the luxurious extravagant Royal life back then and be amazed with the splendor of the prosperity at the time. If you like arts, this definitely won't fail you. It is a place that must go.

Don't miss. The art collection is amazing and the building itself is lovely.. Do not miss the rooms that were a part of the private suites for the royal family. There is so much to see that it's a good idea to read about the Hermitage to decide just what it is you want to see.

This is a truly huge art collection. They say that if you look at each exhibit for 20 seconds it will take you 20 years to see everything. The opulence of this palace has to seen to be believed. Allow a couple of days. The top floor contains an amazing fine art exhibition - walk into the first room and there are 20 Picasso's , the next room 20 Mattise's and so on. Book the entrance tickets online to avoid the very very long queues. email them to your Hotel reception so they can print them.Audio guide is v.good and you can get an App for your IPad.

Huge and Worth the Time. Not too busy when we visited the Hermitage museum which was good and the huge size of the place made it easy to feel like you were wandering round this stately palace just like the olden days. Hard to imagine anyone ever really living there and simply just not ending up lost! The exhibits are easy to find and easy to see, unlike some big named museums in other cities we have visited. Only minor negative was the queues for the restrooms and cloakrooms, otherwise a long, tiring worthwhile walk around historic European and Asian artworks.

stunning. nothing to dislike it was stunning everywhere was so clean it was so beautiful it was a bit crowded but very well run they kept people from lingering to long which was great as there was too much to see

Brilliant!!. An absolute must do! Depending on your tastes and time on hand it could take a full day to a week, possibly to completely cover it! You can however go online and choose which section you would like to see in detail and see parts off the rest.

An Amazing Museum. Had a private guide to show us around and was able to see the main highlights in this amazing and very large museum. One could spend days rooming through the beautiful rooms and looking at amazing pieces of art. Only had a few hours and I feel like I only scratched the surface. Would love to go back and spend more time! A must to see!

It's Overwhelming. It is magnificent. The rooms are astonishingly beautiful. It is huge, And it is just too much to see. We got in early because we were on a tour. We spent several hours there. We needed several days. One is overwhelmed by the beauty and opulence of what one sees. The art work is, for the most part, poorly displayed and difficult to enjoy - at least until one arrives at the more modern sections where it is much better. My own feeling is that it is worth seeing but that several days are needed to really appreciate everything that is there. One should initially take a tour and be led through the museum but then go back several times and concentrate on small areas so that you are not overwhelmed by the size and magnificence of the entire place. The biggest down side is that much of the older art is poorly displayed and difficult to see well compared with other museums such as the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York or the Philadelphia Art Museum. At the Hermitage, enjoy the building, the opulence, the extravagance. Enjoy the quantity of extraordinary art. Be prepared to want to go back again and again, even if you can't.

Jammed even in September. Imagine June. 2 English tours , 1030 and 2, but double check at your hotel. If you do not have tickets, you can stand in line for 2 hours as we did. Does have hand held tours in multiple languages incl English.

Brilliant Art and Artefacts. Very interesting, lots to see, be warned you have to leave your coat in the cloakroom, the queue we stood in was for organised tours and we could have stood for ages, and despite a lovely Russian lady trying to tell us in Russian we were in the wrong queue, as our Russian is non-existent we eventually worked it out for ourselves as signage was NIL!The Hermitage houses some amazing art, if that's what interests you, Cezanne, Picasso and the like and some of the furniture etc., is stunning. Worth a visit for sure
Wow. All those treasures and and art! Don't miss this when visiting. Long queues if you are not part of a tour.

You need days and days to see it all!. The Hermitage is legendary but we were still blown away by the quality and abundance of art from all periods. We did not buy our ticket ahead of time (as suggested) - but the kiosk just inside the courtyard was automated and very simple. Only 400 rubles ($12) per admission ticket. You MUST check your coat, but it's free to do so. Great gift shop and coffee/snack kiosks. Plenty of bathrooms. Beyond the painted art, look for the room interiors, icons and antiquities.

Czarist Grandeur on display. This is a must visit in Saint Petrsburg. Time frame 2 to 4 hours atleast. The entire palace and museum is a multi-stage structure and provides a good idea of the Czarist grandeur and opulence.

The Ermitage. Certainly the number one attraction in Saint Petersburg. It deserves all the accolades it receives. There's a beautiful palace to see and a museum with a huge and valuable art collection. It's located at one end of Nevsky Prospect, Saint Petersburg's main artery, and right by the Neva River. Don't think about missing it..
Most superb museum. Incredible collection, housed in an incredible building. Very easy to access. Need plently of time to stroll around.

You need a guide for optimal visiting time. There is so much to see in the hermitage, enough for day. We had a guide and she was great! She asked before what we want to see and in four hours we were completely satisfied. The rooms, the paintings, the gardens, lamps ect. it was briljant.

You need a year to see all there is. We spent a day at the Hermitage with a guide. We only really got to see a fraction of the treasures and art. This is because there are four buildings and four floors!! We found it a little crowded in some sections eg Van Dyke art but not everywhere. The Impressionist art section is incredible. Go!

Building tired - Contents Spectacular. W e spent the morning in Hermitage with our own personal guide. She was able to bypass queues and took us to main sights. So much to see......blown away with the masters section which had pictures by every master you could think of. A wall full of Picasso's !! Probably covered to quick, spend a day.

So much to see, maybe too much. This museum is huge. Room after room after room filled with art, historic items and statues, both Russian and from other countries. After walking around for 2 hours at a fairly brisk pace, I think we'd seen about half of it, at which point I got culture-overload and gave up.If you go, then pace yourself and expect to be there the whole day. It would have been nice if they'd kept part of it as authentic, with the rooms laid out as they would have been 300 years ago. Instead every room is just full of exhibits.

Highlight of visit to St Petersburg. Wonderful treasure of art set in beautiful settings. Opportunity to learn in depth about the artists with samples from different periods of their life. Worthwhile having a good guide

A must do. I loved the rooms, especially floors and the ceilings but there is SO much to see you need days just to skim the surface. Three hours was about as much as I could take in at one go but would loved to have gone back again the next day.
Best in the world. Amazing heritage, wonderful works of art, grand setting - truly captures the way kings used to live - if you don't see the Hermitage in Saint Petersburg, you haven't seen anything

Elegant palace. We visited outside the main tourist season - so there were few visitors, and therefore no queues. Easy to walk around the grounds, and down to the Gulf of Finland at the shore. Beautiful fountains - water supply operated by gravity. Suggest visitors avoid the palace during the winter, when the fountains are not operating.

It earned its title as one of the greatest museums.. This museum has so much to see. One full day is not enough. Don't miss the special Scythian gold guided tour (separate ticket). Prepare to walk and eat lunch there as half a day will only get you through the staterooms.
Moscow in St Petersburg. This is a beautiful church. It is much smaller than I expected but packed a punch with the amount of art and adornments.

Words cannot do this justice. It is just mind blowing,a tip-they do say if you had just a glimpse of everything on display here it would take you nine years to see it all,definately get at least a two day pass,can book on line and save queues,free for locals on a Thursday so a busy day with lots of school children.

Great Place worth to be seen when visiting St. Petersbourg. I liked everything, but be prepared for a long queue and a crowd.
If you visit the Hermitage on first Thursday it is free of charge!

Art overflow. Italy, France, Russia, paintings, sculptures, carpets, furniture, plates ... you name it! All here, be sure to take your time when going through this museum. The building itself and the art collection are astonish. It might take you a lot of time to see everything, so a good advise would be to prioritise what you really want to see.Tips:- get your ticket online, queue will be very large (or go early in the morning as we did)- get the online App of the museum for your smartphone, audio-guides are expensive- you can buy the rights to take pictures, but no one inside checks if you have bought that or not while taking pictures (you get a green sticker when you pay the rights for taking pictures). In our case, it was frustrating to see everyone taking pictures without the green sticker.

Excellent. ButWe read our guide books, telling us about the impossibly long queues and we deicded to prebook our tickets to the Hermitage online. This resulted in us paying a fee of $2.95 per person on top of the entrance fee of $16.95. When we got there on 20September, there was no queue at all, so probably not worth pre-booking off seaSON. The Museum is stunning, one room after another of astonishing works of art and ceramics. We stayed about 3hours and did't see half of it. We walked across the river to St Peter and Paul Palace, which is the burial place of the Tsars and recently the murdered Tsar Nicholas and his family, doctor and servants were reburied there in a simple chapl..very poignant. There was a Swiss sstyle restaurant nearby and we had a really nice Russian meal there, sistting in the late September sun.

Swim Upstream. This place is epic. The rooms are unbelievable and the collection of art is stunning. This is probably the best museum I have ever seen. We went 2 separate times. If you have a student ID, even an old one, use it as you can get in for free. My wife's ID was almost illegible and they let her use it. The one downside is the crowds. Prepare to fight your way upstream through periodic rivers of people when tour groups walk by. This would be the only downside but if you can dodge the big groups it will improve the experience.

Awesome, but you could spend weeks here.. There's nothing I didn't like, with the exception of the muesum's English speaking guide's inability to project his voice and deliver detailed information. I returned for a second visit and rented a pre-recorded audio guide that provided a nice historical overview of various artifacts, The Hermitage and Winter Palace.

Too much hype about this museum. Beautiful European paintings, but you see the same European artists in Europe and the USA. To me, the museum does not match European museums like the Louve, Prado, etc. Bizarre experience getting into the museum. Takes an hour in line and a lot of pushing and shoving. After 2nd time with this experience, I decided not worth visiting the Hermitage. If possible, book through a tour group and you walk right in without waiting. I am not a big fan of the Russian architecture and interior decoration seen all over St. P. and especially in the Hermitage. This Hermitage is main reason I went to St. P and was a big dissappointment.

Vast Collection. Almost impossible to navigate without a sat nav or guide especially if your in a hurry! But I guess you shouldnt be in a hurry if you want to marvel at the assembled collections on offer here. It is a confusing and ever changing layout in this place but worth planning in advance to get the most out of the areas you might be most interested in. There was an amazing modern collection of architecture and models featuring motion and design that was the highlight for me but there is something for everyone.

A revisit to the Hermatage. This was my 3rd vist to the Hermatage, and a week later I was in the Louvre. There is so much to see at this museum, I just wish the presentations were better. It does seem to have improved since the last time I was there, but it still has a long way to go for the presentration to match the outstanding quality of its art.

Hermitage Highlights. The Impressionists - Lost works of art from WW2 were a highlight as I have never seen before, however there are so many other world master pieces it is a 'must' visit if in St Petersburg.. The building itself is also incredible...

Incredibly crowded but great art. I am not sure whether one goes to the hermitage to see the building or the art. Both are spectacular. Most of the art came from private collections when Russia became Communist. More recent pieces came from Germany during WW 2. Read all you can about how to skip the lines. Our solution was a private guide.

A bit too much. It's a wonderful place - all the paintings and design and decorations of the rooms but you need to come there prepared and know exactly what you want to see -the place is tooooo big you can not see everything even if you start running around ))

Always a wonderful place. I've been 3 times now and there is still so much to see. unfortunately or fortunately, last time I was there was about 20 years ago so now it is like going for the first time. wonderful place. very crowded though. that's the only problem. People love it.

Outstamding in a class I it's own. On the day we went the ques were quite large and seemed unorganised to the foreigners eye. Masses of people trying to get through one gateway so be prepared for this.Once through the museum is outstanding we spent about 5 hours but didn't see half of it.The art section was fantastic as you could get really close and works were not behind glass or ropes.

Arrive early to avoid the crowds!. The Hermitage is certainly worth the effort and the State Rooms are not to be missed. It is a shame that the excellent Siberian and Russian areas are not made more of - as this is a rare thing to see outside Russia.Arrive early as the crowds after 11 are off putting and, in true Russian style, customer service and organisation are non-existent!Unfortunately, there is hardly any information in any other language apart from Russian. Also, the internal cafe is ridiculously expensive: £3.50 for a terrible black coffee!Still, this is the one thing not to miss out on in St Petersburg!
Incredible!. Vast, splendid, evoking the wealth of the tzars at the time when the serfs were starving! The scope boggles the imagination.

Hermitage Museum & Winter Palace. Hermitage is very grand and very beautiful. Incredible art collection. Winter Palace must have been stunning but unfortunately is not as well maintained as it should be. The gardens are also somewhat neglected. In spite of all of this the experience and knowing stories about the family, etc., were well worth the visit.

Do not miss it.. This building is why you go to St Petersburg. Nevermind the art, I couldn't keep my eyes off the floors, walls and ceilings. Every room is different, decorated, and beautiful. The very definition of Russian opulence, the Winter Palace is a must-see.Be sure to book your tickets online -- we did that, and made a bee-line for the internet ticket booth. Once we had our tickets, we just lined up until the museum opened, ran in, dumped our backpack in the cloaking room (first ones to do so -- we woke up the clerk!), and headed to the museum. Really stress-free way to get in. I pity the poor people who had to wait in line to pay for their tickets.We could only handle a few hours of the Hermitage. Definitely something to do over several days if you have time.
breathtaking. A Must see...allow plenty of time and take a camera.Have never been so close to such fabulous paintings,

Allow enough time. We spent 5 hours visiting the museum and could have been there longer but got tired. There is not much of a place to eat or drink so make sure you have eaten before you go. We went early so missed the crowds but later in the morning huge groups arrived and made it harder to move through the halls. Be sure to make time for the French painter on top floor, amazing collections. Something for everyone.
Disappointing. I was waiting a lot for this visit, but it appears that many paintings are not to be seen. I like the impressionist period and found much more paintings in the book of the museum.

Not to be missed. The building itself is a major attraction, beautifully designed and ornamented. The collection is so huge that my advice for those who want to restrict their visit to - lets say - 3 hours is to get a personal tour. The guides know the shortcuts there and will take you straight to the most interesting rooms of this gem. Don't miss Da Vinci and also the impressionist rooms in addition to the historic tsar rooms.

You simply must go here. If you travel with a group: make sure to remember the cloak room on the group entrance (do not follow the exit signs, you will leave via the main entrance and will be outside with no coat). Make your choice, the collection is overwhelming. It is allowed to take photos (no flash) in most rooms.
Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace. A must to see, unbelievable. The whole palace is magnificent with every room a real gem. Many photos will be taken here.
Hermitage. You just MUST go there and spend all day if you are in SBP. Every first thursday of each mounth is free of charche entrance day for everyone without exception.Audioguides available.

In Awe of the Age of the Tsars. From the outside the gray, white and gold walls beckon you to the treasures inside. Once inside you begin to see the glory of the pre World War I nobility from around Europe. However, it is the grand staircase that takes your breath away. There are more are objects than can be seen in a half day tour, a day or even a week - many theme rooms - Greek, Roman, Art of all schools and masters. But you have to see the Gold Room! This special room takes the use of gold from prehistoric jewelry through the historic empires to the empires of the 1800's. Many gold and silver implements, clothes and weapons are highly adorned with diamonds - perhaps too highly adorned. To live like this while your people starved was to in the end to invite revolution.

Beautiful but be aware of the pickpockets !!!. The Hermitage for me is one of the best museums in the World. St. Petersburg is beautiful and amazing but it is very sad to listen everywhere about the bad experiences that the tourists had during their stay with the pickpockets. I had the same problem too. We had the same problems 02 persons in this group. Anyway the city is amazing !!!

The Best of the Best. A day is not enough to tour this fantastic awe inspiring palace. If you visit nothing else, do not by pass this one. Expect crowds because this should be on everyones bucket list.

Magnificent outside and fantastic inside.. I spent 5 hours there - much more than I normally do in a museum ( 2 to 3 hours). With so much to see I was not tired. First I took a map in the entrance and just then decided what I want to see. Part of the Hermitage is housed in the former Winter Palace and has splendid rooms what already make it very special. Today fully restored and more magnificent than ever, it is definitely a must to visit even to people that is not into arts. A impressive and fabulous collection of paintings and other precious works of art, furniture and much more make this one of the best and largest museums of the world.

Great Explanation on Italian Renaissance Art and Impressionism. I've visited the Louvre four times and I still haven't finished seeing it all. But I always went on my own without a tour guide. There is something more to touring when a very educational tour guide is with you who majored in history and explains the detailness of the paintings you are viewing. The lighting and the shades and the colors whether it was vibrant or dull depending on the mood it wants to impart to you. I now get the better picture and I have appreciation for the painting. We opted to concentrate on the Italian Renaissance art and the painting of Renoir, Monet, Van Gogh and Gauguin. There were so many tours you had to be quick in explaining because another group had to move to where you are. You can't just take your time enjoying the paintings. But it was worth it! If you ever go to St. Petersburg, I strongly recommend the Hermitage Museum and Peterhof combination. It's a MUST to see. I also learned something new. The royalty's bed was a bit short for someone of their height and it was explained that they slept almost sitting up. This is how I sleep when I had "acid reflux" because of the regurgitation of the food to the throat. So this is just a guess. Maybe they ate so much and they had to sleep after that so it was recommended to them to sleep that way. That was my doctor's recommendation to me if I had to sleep and I ate late. That style of sleeping cured my acid reflux!

Worth the crowds. This is an incredibly unique place. It is a complex of five palaces which are interconnected and together form The Hermitage. Mostly the buildings hold the art collection (including sculptures, paintings, tapestries, and porcelain) of Catherine the Great. But also to be seen is the sheer opulence of the rooms, with their gilded doors, chandeliers, ceilings, and mirrors. Everywhere you turn are huge urns, vases, or candelabras of porcelain, silver, and crystal. There are wine fountains made of silver which are large enough to bathe in. There are galleries filled with works of all the master painters.A handful of rooms still contain some furniture which includes beautiful writing desks, console tables, clocks. Some have inlaid semi-precious stones. The Malachite Room is particularly impressive. I haven't been to a place this crowded since the Vatican, but it was worth it. You definitely need a day here. Ticket can be used only once (no coming and going). Take some sort of guided tour because the place is so huge, you will want someone to point out the highlights - BUT make sure your group is small, otherwise you will spend the entire time waiting, while 30 people file past a small work by Rafael. The audioguide may be your best bet. There are extra tickets for the Gold and Treasury Rooms which can only be bought the day of, and are extremely limited in number (about 50 per day, i think). So if you are interested in this, plan to go early and be flexible.

So much to see. We've had 2 tours here and still haven't seen it all. If you love art then this place is great and takes you through the history of western art. The majority of the masters can be seen. I love history and saw the Roman, Greek, Egyptian and gold rooms which were excellent. I enjoyed the Roman and Greek rooms as they were decorated with the style of the time which was very evocative. The best section was the Gold display, from prehistory up to the end of the Tzars. The detail of the pieces were exquisite. The opulence on display was breath taking and you could see why there was a revolution.

Number one target to see in St Petersburg. It is no surprise that is Number one! Prebook your tickets-separate ones for the jewels and the theatre. Possibly aim for two 1/2 days as less mind boggling and foot testing.Wear trainers for comfort --even the most superficial trip will require hours on foot as one gasps at the beautiful furniture in the rooms of the Winter Palace and then wonders just how many more rooms stuffed with the great Impressionist are to come!Bizarrely one is able to use a camera everywhere so make sure you take yours to get the screensavers of a lifetime!With our Internet booked tickets we had a little camera icon and this apparently said Ok to pics.Food is present but indifferent at the cafes and there are occasional loos.Don't miss the amazing gilt peacock clock Be there on the hour to watch it chime and raise its tail.

Very Beautiful!. Bring your walking shoes and camera! This was like a "mini-Versailles", which, of course, it was designed to imitate. Gorgeous room after gorgeous room, full of paintings, antiquities, sculptures, etc. While it doesn't have the expansive gardens of Versailles, there is a small roof-top garden on the second floor that is very nice. There is an internet cafe - 35 rubles for a half-hour, and some rather expensive food in the cafes. Ask about the cats, though! They sell buttons and bags and such to celebrate the cats.

Great collections and magnificent winter palace. Thanks to Uniworld River Cruises for a wonderful tour of the Hermitage WITHOUT the crowds! We were able to see the magnificent collections and the splendid architecture of the winter palace, in an unhurried, un-congested setting. Turns out that Catherine was the best of the "catalog" shoppers in her day and the collections show that. But the decor and architectural details were my favorite along with wonderful views of the city, the garden and the parade grounds surrounding this gem. You can't possibly see it all in one visit, but visiting without the crowds was priceless...but, of course a private tour with Mr Putin would be even more amazing! I'll have to save that for the next visit.

Its A must to see all the paintings.. Its very crowded at the Hermitage but you have to see the collection of arts. you have to get a guide so you will have a better explanation and the to be directed the most important part of the museum, specially if you have limited time.

A Must See in St. Petersburg!. Local regulations only allow guided tours a maximum of 2 hours in the State Hermitage Museum. Having our DenRus Guide ensured we maximized the use of our 2 hours. She pointed out the highlights and expertly maneuvered us to avoid the crowds as much as possible. Not only was the art wonderful; but the setting of the Museum and Winter Palace provides such a great setting for the art.
Hermitage. Such a world class museum. Just to know that it is in the former Winter Palace adds to its allure. One could spend much longer than a few hours viewing the wonderful art.

Must see if visiting St Petersburg. The Hermitage Museum on the outside is beautiful. In side there is so much to see, infact if you looked at each exihibit for 1 minute it would take you 3 years to look around it. The opulance is there to see, even a WC designed by Versace for 1 million dollars,(I think they just paid for the name).

sooooo big. the museum is gorgeous.. i mean.. just gorgeous and huge. Decide what you want to see and then make a beeline to those exhibits otherwise you are going to end up exhausting yourself and not seeing what you want to see at the museum. I like Impressionism art and they have some of the most popular paintings by Degas, Renoir etc in the world. Loved seeing them up close and personal. Also, didn't realize that they had "the dancers" by Matisse so that was a nice surprise.
Number One site!. Don't miss this palace-art museum combo. We had a private guide, and enjoyed all of the three hour tour!

Overwhelmingly big. We only had 3-4 hours for this museum, which is far from what you'd need to enjoy everything. We decided we'd just go from room to room, taking in the general feel of each. Simply the rooms themselves are each sites to behold.

So much to see so little time. This is perhaps one of the top three art museums in the world but the group tours do not allow enough time to properly view a tenth of it. What we did see represented some of the best of the best of renown artist of the world.
The wow factor. Amazing! The scale of the building and rooms is overwhelmingly impressive! Lovely to walk around and marvel.

Maybe it is not #1 in the world, but it surely is not #2. To avoid lines book your tickets online. During lunch time (noon - 3PM) when big tour groups leave to eat it is less crowded. IMHO while the two special collections (jewellery chambers) are interesting if you have just a day to see the museum focus on the paintings, sculptures and state reception rooms. Most impressive royal jewels are at the Kremlin in Moscow at the Diamond Fund. Impressionist department is very big and has outstanding paintings so if you like Impressionists leave at least an hour to see that part of the collection or better yet make it separate visit.

Superb. É ótimo ter um guia privado para com voces.O museu tem uma entrada magnífica e com um guia voce percorre as melhores atrações e conhece a história real deste belo lugarIt's great to have a private guide for you. The museum has a magnificent entrance and walks with a guide you may go in the best sights and knows about the real history of this beautiful place

Historic and Beautiful. The Winter Palace was on my bucket list and I was not disappointed. Accompanied by guide Tania from Red October Tours, the Palace is breathtakingly beautiful. The rooms display museum pieces, but it was nice to see a sitting area from Empress Marie. The Hermitages are incredible. To see works of the greats like Raphael, Da Vinci, Rembrandt and Michelangelo, just to name a few was unbelievable. The small Hermitage was my favorite, with the garden behind and a beautiful mosaic floor and the most amazing clock ever.

Wonderful experience in St. Petersburg. What a pleasure to finally see the Hermitage!! This is a must do in St. Petersburg. The museum is housed in several of the connected czars' palaces facing the Neva River right downtown.It holds a fantastic collection of art plus the buildings are a marvel too. The only problem was that it was a nice day and very hot and crowded, very. I hardly felt any AC ever. WE were with a small group so received a lot of information as well. I would definitely go back. One afternoon was not nearly enough.

overkill. I visited St.Petersburg during a Cruise in August..On the night we docked 4 other liners arrived each carrying 3 - 4000 passengers(not to mention 3 others carrying 1500(avg).Circa 20,000 people were trying to see the major palaces/museum over the next 2 days.Our guide to the Hermitage said 15000 to 18000 visited every day. Queues were massive:there was no chance to stop and admire/study anything.These massive ships are now ruining everywhere they visit causing overcrowding.My cruising days are over and I will avoid anywhere they call in.Beware. Oh! visit a loo before you go as there is little provision.
Alla tours. Our visit with Alla tours got us in before it was open to the public. Fantastic!Empty corridors. No crush!

Aim for Saturday nights. Absolutely breathtaking museum. More beautiful than the Louvre, in my opinion. The interior rooms were my favorite part. I would recommend going on a Saturday night as the museum is open until 9 pm and there were absolutely no crowds. We had whole rooms and halls to ourselves.

Queue starts to form @ 09:30 although ticket office opens @ 10:30. I'd recommend arriving @ main (black) gates @ 10:00 to join queue since this is when gates are opened to allow you to queue for ticket office in the courtyard which opens @ 10:30It's vast therefore decide what you want to see. I'd recomend the apartments on the first floor. Easy to spend all day inside.

The Hermitage and Winter Palace. This is arguably the largest and finest art gallery and museum in the world. We enjoyed having a private guide to help us absorb the setting and the contents of the palace. This a world class experience that is not to be missed or rushed.

Need lots of time to see this museum. The range of artwork and the state rooms are magnificent. Closure of most the 3rd floor for renovation was disappointing.Like all museums you need a lot of time to see everything - we spent 4.5 hours walking through the various displays and probably say less than 50% of the museum.
Great art. The great masterpieces, Rembrant, Picasso, Degas to name a few. Additionally, the rooms that house the art quite beautiful in their own right.
Well...it's a classic isn't it?. It was all I expected it to be ... the near-perfect museum experience. Just do it, go there and enjoy

Don't be overwhelmed: pick your specials!. We did a tour with a guide, which we've intsructed to do "our things". It worked extremely well. Repin, Rembrandt, the French impressionists, the beautiful and well restored halls. Enough for our brain, eyes and appreciation.

possibly the best in the world. a must see, artwork and pieces are outstanding. special exhibits are exceptional. try to at least walk the entire museum even if not enough time to stop a take all the details in. impossible!
A hidden jewel in Russia. Great art, overpriced cafes, cheap tickets. Enjoyed the art but I wish the people were a bit friendlier.

Worth to see - and plan ahead. Note if you have a student card your queue is shorter and you do not pay too much. There is plenty to see, and if you want to have a proper tour I recommend to hire a guide.

Treasury home. The most beautiful museum in Russia!!! It'll take you about 11 years to look all pieces of Hemitage during 1 minute/piece. BUT - it worth to see! A lot of beautiful things - monuments, pictures, architecture.. I love the Hermitage!!!Little notes to the visitors: Don't forget to take some sandwiches / chocolate or such snacks with you because a cafe inside is a little bit expencive. And high-heel shoes aren't recommended - you will be too tired.Enjoy!!!
A treasure trove. Lots and lots to see and experience, too much for one lifetime. Make enough time for this amazing museum.

Get tickets beforehand to avoid queues. Too much beauty to take in all at once at this fabulous repository of wealth and priviledge! It is worth getting your entry tickets online before leaving Australia so you can avoid the long queues to get in - head round to the kiosk on the right of the entrance to present your e-ticket. You can take photos inside if you buy a special permission (though I never saw anyone checking if you had it!)

Very well maintained. A definite visit, if you are in st.Petersburg. Located in the centre of the city, easily accessible by metro. The collection inside is worth a thousand words. I am not going to mention them, let it be a surprise that you will eagerly wait for.
Not another room full of Picassos. You really need a full day as there is so much here. Amazing art and exhibits. Truely world class.top tip: wear comfortable shoes
You could spend 15 years to see all the exhibits.. So much to see you can't possibly see it in a few hours follow the set route and you will see some of the more stunning exhibits.

One of the greatest places I ever visited. The State Hermitage Museum is one of the most amazing things I ever saw. I also recommend seeing the gold and diamond (brilliantov) rooms which are separate ticket you can purchase together with general admission. The visit to this museum is an excellent life experience, I would truly suggest everybody to see.

A treat - and wear your walking shoes. This is one of the great collections in the world. It is painful to have only a day in St Petersburg. We visited the Hermitage with a private guide and had a rich experience. There are different dimensions to a visit. The museum is architecturally rich in a Baroque style. There were a number of grand halls, each different, that would be a treat to all who are architecturally inclined. There is a wonder picture collection spanning several hundred years of European history. Our primary interest was the Impressionist and Post-Impressionist rooms. It tuned out the Post-Impressionists were stronger, since we understand some of the Impressionists were on tour. Even so, the experience did not disappoint. We never got to the antiquities and could see from the floor plan there appears to be a good collection here as well. There is lots of walking and plenty of stairs. Elevators seemed to be few and far between. There is a cafeteria and only one cashier accepted dollars. Since we were with a private tour, this meant we did not need to have rubles this day. Since this is the biggest attraction in St Petersburg, most visitors will seek it out. Definitely do so if you have an artistically appreciative bone in your body (or are trying to nurture one). We did this on a private tour so had more time on site than the typical cruise tour. I can recommend this approach. We used Red October.
Beyond expectations. A place where you would return and return and keep discovering new gems. Well worth all the time you can devote.

Wow.. this is one of my favorite museums. We were part of a 2 day tour with SPB Tours and our guide was excellant in explaining the inner working of the Winter castle and gave us lots of time on our own to explore. Because I am a huge Van Gogh fan I was not dissapointed at the collection they had. They also had a very fine Gaugin collection from the Tahiti years.
Beautiful Museum. Other than the crowds, this facility is one of the most exotic museums in the world. 2 hours is not enough for a cursory visit but that is what the tour groups get.

One of the premier museums in the world. This museum has to be seen to be believed. The world famous Winter Palace on the waters edge in St Petersburg has to be seen to be believed. Inside are one of the two most extensive and complete collections in the world, with the Paris Louve being the only true competitor. The collections of paintings, sculptors and more is unparalleled and a must see in St Petersburg. The only problem is to decide just what to see and if one day is enough.

Very nice museum!. Staff is professional and many speak opther languages. They will try to assist as much as they can. You have to visit the Winter palace, and in particular the collections of impressionism and postimpressionism as well as as the Flemish, the Italian, and the Spanish art collections. You will see wonderful works made by Picasso, Matisse, Rembrandt, el Greco, Caravaggio. Do it independently. The tours take you very fast and they fight amongst them to show tyhe paintings. The audioguides are very good. There is something very few people know. The museum opens until 900 pm on Saturdays! It is wonderful because after 600 pm there are not tours and there are very few people and you can enjoy everything! The museum is practically yours!The archeological part is not the best when compared with other museums. If you dont have time just visit the paintings.Better place for you to buy tickets is the ticket machines outside the museum. Then take the left door (It is faster). Do not pay to do photography (You will see why once your inside). However, bring your camera.

Fantastic museum. There is just so much to feast your eyes on in the Winter Palace! You need to allow plenty of time and expect to get a little lost at points. Highlights for me were all the state rooms. Fantastic.

great. If you like history and art - this is a MUST und just great ! There are so many famous artists, that it is incredible. Unfortunately there is just never enough time to really appreciate even the important things there.

A Must See. A breathtaking sight. Everything is so impressive. The art, the history and the collections are wonderful to see. If possible, take a private tour. Our private guide, Maria, got us into the Hermitage immediately, no lines. See took us to each area and explained the history and art is the most wonderful way. She was better than any college professor I ever had. Three and 1/2 hours and not enough time to fully enjoy. A trip of a lifetime and a wonderful morning at the Hermitage.

Extensive and impressive. The collection is stunning in its size and quality and certainly a must to see if you visit St Petersburg. We added on the tour of the diamond room with its extensive jewellery displays - this went for an hour and a half and was very informative.The audio guide provides excellent commentary for anyone doing it on their own - unfortunately there is little other information available in anything apart from Russian. Very easy to get lost as the display is spread over a number of interlinked buildings with no clear connection between them shown on the maps. The location to collect tickets organised over the internet was hard to find and the staff outside where useless in telling us where it was. This resulted in a lot of time being wasted.

Great collection of art. If you go to St Petersburg, this is a must see.While the building itself is magnificent, it is the art inside that is worth seeing. It includes works from masters that you will know. Went there on a cruise excursion. The tour takes about 1.5 hours and you only touch on a fraction of the collection. As many have said, it is very crowded and sometimes hard to keep up with your guide. They charge you $4 to take pictures but I saw everyone taking them and nobody questioned it. You give your money to your guide and they are supposed to monitor it but they don't seem to. So--it is basically a short tour of great art by masters and I would definitely recommend it. Take the tour, since most will never be back anyway. You could spend several days there.
Visited as part of a tour with Alla. Once again our guide got us straight in and guided us past the long queues. An amazing place you could spend days there and not see it all.

one of the best museums. Being an art lover, this museum is definitely my #1 in Petersburg. Located inside the former magnificent winter palace, Hermitage Museum houses one of the most valuable art collections and can be the sole reason for arranging a trip to St. Petersburg. With all its artwork, it is not possible to finish the museum in a couple hours or even a full day visit, so my advice is to study the major highlights and plan your visit before arriving, or visit Hermitage every time you are in Petersburg.

Absolutely massive. Lovely building on the outside. Eventually got to grips with the floor plan, so much to see and do. A fantastic time to be had here whether it's a quicker or longer look. Free entry on a Thursday.
Fabulous. An incredible museum inside a fairy tale palace... The palace itself is a great work of art, in the winter you can see the iced river out of the windows...

Top Museum. Top notch museum, hosting masterpieces from most well known artists (incl. Rembrandt and Da Vinci), many different collections - Roman, Greek, Egypt, etc. The museum is huge, and a knowledgable guide is a must. You can easily get lost in this museum, and I would suggest you dedicate a full day to explore the museum.Give the "Gold Room" a skip though, not worth the additional entry fee. The groups are too big, the guide is completely uninterested and just mumbled through a script, and you are not permitted to view any of the displays unaccompanied - which was really irritating given the size of the group and the small displays.

Simply stunning!!!. For history, architecture and art lovers alike this is a magnificent place to visit! We were limited on time (by that i mean we could only dedicate half a day to it) so didn't get to explore everything but it is awe-inspiring and truly worth a visit.

Fabulous!. This museum is really huge and you have to go early, really early, if you want to walk easily and see as much as you can without a background noise. The building itself is amazing. I spent only 4 hours in the museum which is not definitely enough, but you can make a quick tour and get an idea. If possible don't bring any big shoulder bags or backpack or coat, otherwise you have to wait extra to deposit those in the cloak room and get back. Since it is so huge and very little, almost no place to sit down, be ready for a huge tour and bring your own water. In every room, there are old ladies stationed at the corners, who keep an eye on you constently and warn you if you misbehave. And they are not tolerant at all. If you have days in St.Petersburg, then discover the whole museum and you will definitely enjoy it. But if you have limited time, definitely take a guided tour or go around with someone who really knows the place and can show you the best pieces. St.Petersburg as a city which is trying to catch up with European cities, although not succesful yet, but this place is the number one site you have to see in St.Petersburg.

The early bird. We visited with an organised tour and got there early (but not extremely early) but even so there were quite a few tour parties already waiting to enter.We got in without too much trouble and our experienced guide took us to the most relevant places including the Gold Room, where she had to defer to the State Guide.The treasures on display in this one room alone are mind boggling and they must be worth more than the GDP of many countries around the world.As we emerged from this room it started to become crowded and we were taken around to various works of art, which were all worth seeing, biut don't think you'll have time to stop and stare as the pressure of people increased to an uncomfortable level and even with radio headsets linked to our guide it became difficult to hear as the general background noise increased.We spent about 3 hours in the museum and given its vast size only really sampled what it has to offer.Although I thoroughly enjoyed what I saw and the knowledge the guide imparted, by the time we left about midday I was some what releaved to exit the building and the crowds although even as we exited the line of people waiting to enter was still long.So to sum up, defintely go, but join an organised tour (necessary to access the Gold Room) and make sure it has an early entry time..

Awesome. This place is huge. It took me an hour to get out of the place because I kept getting lost and finding myself in yet another room that I had missed previously.In addition to find art, the state rooms are a must to be seen. I bought the regular ticket, and paid for a sticker so that I could take photographs.I did not pay for the extra tours, and I'm glad that I did not because I never would have had the time to see them.There is a cafe on the grounds. Actually, there are two. One where you could actually sit down at a table, but I didn't see that until I was leaving.Be sure to pick up a free map in the language of choice. I had a tour book with me, but the map was much more helpful.Beware that the rooms do not always increase in number, making it a bit confusing at times.You must leave your coat in the cloak room, and large backpacks must be checked in as well.Bathrooms are hidden throughout, but marked on the map.Don't miss it. It is worth every penny spent.

Even better than I had hoped!. Visiting the hermitage has been on my wish list for decades and I was delightedto find it bigger, better and even more magnificent than I could have hoped for! And that's just the building - the museum is enormous! Over 2 days we only managed a fraction of what is on offer - French Impressionists for me, early Egyptian and Sumerian for my fellow traveller. You have to buy an extra ticket if you want to take photos - well worth it. Top tip - Thursdays are FREE entry so you only pay to take photos. Very tiring and few places to sit down and make sure you take your own water, snacks, cafe comparatively small and expensive. back packs are not allowed (you can see why when you see the fragile fingers and exquisite staues!) but I carried my (small) back pack like a shoulder bag and it was ok. Be prepared for lots of security checks and armies of babushkas (old ladies) stationed, one per room, to keep an eye on you!

Art overload. Fabulous art museum too much to take in incredible displays from all over the world our guide was tops in describing the artist and the portrayal of the orgins and details of the paintings

Hermitage-A Rousing Success. Our group were scheduled to enter this museum/palace at about 11:30 am. When we got there the lineup was long and as soon as we enter it became a madhouse as people were pushing one against another. We loved this museum more than Louvre; however, because many people are sent in at the same time, you cannot even sit down and enjoy the works of art. There are so many interesting pieces; the palace alone is a work of art by itself and leaves you breathless.

Imperial Russia's Gift. Visited St. Petersburg for two days; spent a few hours in the Hermitage and Winter Palace. While you could spend days here, it was worth the visit especially with a private guide. The range of artwork is overwhelming and architecture of the palaces simply awe-inspiring.A must see in St. Petersburg.

Mind Blowing!. The Hermitage offers a mind blowing experience and caters to all tastes from art work to porcelain. The place is huge so you need to decide what you really want to see as if you saw everything it would take 3 years! Only downside is it is so very very busy and chaos reins supreme. It was a relief to get out into the spacious square at the back.

The building itself is a work of art - never mind what's in it!. Miles upon miles of gold, more gemstones than you can count, diamonds upon diamonds, artwork, architecture..........................3 million separate items, EACH of which is worth an estimated average of $1.5 million. I doubt even the Vatican is sitting on this amount of treasure. We had a guided tour which included the Gold Room (worth it - has to be booked separately though, time-specific) and our guide (who, quite frankly, spoke better English than the English!) was fantastic. I would definitely recommend a guided tour - the Hermitage is a bit like the Louvre - you can't possibly see it all in one visit, you need someone who knows their stuff to show you the best bits. To be fair, the building would be worth seeing even if there was nothing in it! I've never been inside such an elaborate and extravagant building. You may need sunglasses to shield your eyes from all the gold and crystal!Lots of walking, lots and LOTS of people, very long loo-queues, and would be a very confusing if beautiful place to get lost in. So don't!! Also, make sure you behave yourself in terms of obeying the instructions as to which way to go, not to touch stuff etc etc. These guys are NOT tolerant of misdemeanors! Definitely a must-see in St. Petersburg.
Fabulous excess. How can you go wrong looking at the fabulous excesses of the very rich? Incredible sized rooms covered with gold leaf, beautiful floors and completely like a dream or movie set.
Great museum!. We visited as part of a tour and were rushed through in about two hours. We saw all of the highlights, but you could easily spend a day or two in this museum! I highly recommend!

St Petersburg with I Travel SPb. Not into Museums, neither were we until we visited this one, we only had about 2 hours to explore and our guide gave us a very good general look at the place. This is a museum that even those who dont like museums could easily spend a full day in. its simply mind blowing.

Most elaboborately beautiful art museum anywhere.. An absolute requirement for art, history, archetecture, design, and history mavens everywhere.Biggar than the Lourve, more diversely curated than The Vatican, brighter and more open than The Met....The Hermitage not only has the crazyest largest most mixed up and exciting art collection in the world...the building itself is a vision of rare inlaid mozaic wood floors, sculpted wedgewood and bejeweled ceilings, the most humongously ornate cristal chandeliers, literally-furnishings fit for a Czar, or two, or three, but it's floor to ceiling windows in most rooms and hallways make it the best naturally lit art museum in the world. Take at least 3 days to see as much as you can, and def hire one of the docents. Interesting, there are lots of well educated Russians just hanging around the steps who are actually qualified to guide you for 50 dollars, and it is certainly worth it. These folks know and love their art!

Once in a lifetime . . .. Everyone should have the opportunity to visit this museum! Not only does it include numerous works of art, it also portrays the lifestyle of the Russian royalty from a time long ago. It is pristine and highly organized, making it easy to tour for an hour or a day. Beautiful in every way!

A definite must to see!. We visited the Hermitage Museum and Gold Room on our cruise in July - we were thoroughly delighted and as it would take you 8 years to tour this museum in its entirely - we do intend visiting it again some time in the future.
Michelangelo Up Close. Got as close as you possibly can to being in the same room as Michelangelo. . . got within a breath of the stone he brought to life.

Encore! Encore!. Unfortunately, we had only about 4-5 hours allocated to this site on our private excursion, and felt that we had not even scratched the surface of what there was to see. The collection of art by masters from around the world is simply beyond belief. The rooms are decorated in a variety of styles, with gold coating many of the surfaces. China is exquisite, furniture is magnificent, portraits of Russian royalty is not only beautiful, but gives one a great perspective of the history of Russia. I could go on and on, but all I can say is that we want to go back again and spend at least a full day.
