I heartily recommend hiring an experienced guide, who not only will bypass the long lines for you, but give you tremendous insight into all the site has to offer.

Don't leave without seeing the treasuries. Make sure you arrange a tour of the Hermitage treasuries (this isn't included in standard admission) - some incredibly rare items from the csars are hidden here ... some defy belief in extravagance stakes!

Makes the louvre look small. Get your walking shoes ready. You must be in good physical shape to tour St. Petersburg. This city is not ADA friendly at all. Example the Hermitage only has two elevators in the entire museum…

wealth and opulence. A lovely palace with fascinating rooms full of objets d'art and gold leaf. We had an early morning tour but it was crowded even then, with queues snaking round the block for entrance, with our small SPB group we just walked in. It is tiring though so be prepared also watch your valuables as one very nice Russian lady reminded me. It is hot inside so take a bottle of water with you if possible. There are museum shops as you exit and a cafe.

Revolutionary art museum. Too few tourists realise that the Winter Palace, aka The Hermitage State Museum, is the place were the October 1917 Russian Revolution began. In one of the rooms, the Bolsheviki staged a coup against the government of Kerensky following a cannon signal from the cruiser Aurora. And it is a fabulous art museum and palace! Like the Louvre and the Metropolitan Museum, crowds are enormous and important artworks are surrounded by hordes of tourists and their guides. Would love to come in late Fall when he crowds are not so big.
Breathtaking. This is a must, you cant leave St Petersburg without visiting the old masters. It was easy to get tickets . there is just one word WOW!!

Not enough time. I have always thought the Louve was the premier museum on the continent and while I was aware of the Hermitage, I did not expect to be blown away. We had about 4 hours with a guide who was quite knowledgeable; we needed two days. There are rooms and rooms filled with great masters as well as jewels, armor and over 8 million objects. There is only room to display 350,000 or so at a time, according to our guide.If you can figure out a way to stay in St. Petersburg longer, you will not be disappointed. This doesn't even consider Catherines' Palace or the Peterhoff, both of which will "blow you away."

Highlight of my Russia Trip!. Brilliant! This is definitely the highlight of my Russia trip. It is huge, we took half a day to complete the must-see art pieces and paintings. 2 days would be great to take your time and enjoy most of the art (of course, to see all would take years), however since we did not have the privilege of time, half a day is fine ;)

The hermitage. Organisation is terrible....getting in is a nightmare and there were literally thousands of people milling around. Don't expect to find assistants that speak English. Maybe we should have taken a guide but we don't do things like that.

Incredible!!!!. We recently went to St Petersburg on a cruise vacation, and only had 2 hours to visit the Hermitage, but what a 2 hours!!!! I had done some reading prior to prepare myself, but cannot describe how wonderful and grand this museum is! Around every corner was something that blew me away, and only wish I had hours more to enjoy more of the museum! Whether you are a museum fan or not, please make sure you set aside time to visit the Hermitage, you will not be let done at all!

Beautiful.. The Hermitage was the most beautiful museum I've ever visited. Beautifully decorated before you even get to the paintings' area. Try to hook up with a tour that gets you in earlier than the crowds ... it definitely made a difference.

So much to see, so little time. Even though our guide was fantastic, we only barely touched the surface of this collection. It makes the Louvre look small in size. It is said that it would take two years just to spend ten seconds at each item.

Overwhelming. The Hermitage is an unreal experience. There are just so many amazing pieces and it's such an fabulous setting both from an architectural and historic point of view. We were there in July and it was very hot and packed, and we were rushed through the rooms but our guide brought us to the most impressive pieces and we got a brief overview of what is available. I don't know how we would have coped if we had gone on our own. There is just so much to see.

Too much to see in one day. This may be one of the largest museums I've been in. Tons of paintings and prehistoric items but no signature display. After a while all of the paintings looked the same. Many items did not have English descriptions. But a Must See if you visit st Petersburg

put on your track shoes. This was on our tour. We were fortunate to have early admission. The crowds are large after the regular opening. You have to check bags and large coats. The place is so vast you almost have to run from room to room. They have Leonardo da Vinci's The little Madaonna., many works by Rembrandt, Renoir, Degas, Monet and other great painters.

Absolute must to visit. This is an absolute must to visit, so very Grand and Huge. We were on a cruise so only had limited time to visit so will have to return one day and spend more time. There is so much bling it's ridiculous but Awesome to see. Make sure you allow a good few hours when visiting the Palace as even a few hours isn't enough.

Another Wonder of the World. There is so much to see in the Hermitage that you could stay for weeks and never even see it all. Unbelievable masterpieces from all over the world and all centuries. Totally enjoyable!

Bling!. As we were on an organised visit to the Gold Room the doors open earlier than normal. There were people in side but not to crowded. Bling was every where !.
This palace is so big,a year is not long enough to se all its treasures ten kilometres of corridors.
Must see. If your in St. Petersburg, how could you not go? Incredible beauty and excellent collection. Crowded. Alla Tours fast tracked our group.

Have A Plan Before You Go. The museum is massive. Once inside, you either need a plan or expect to spend the whole day. If you only have a few hours, you must plan the exhibits you want to see and have a good map. Make sure you have a map, before you get there. An incredible collection. Also, take a water bottle, it gets really hot in the museum.
Must see and ... come bacjk to see the rest. We were there for three hours and although with our guide we had a very intensive tour...she told us that the whole tour takes about 24 kms...

outstanding. Absolutely outstanding place and MUST SEE POINT in Peterburg. Sculptures, paintings, chambers everything is breathtaking:) I am not a big fan of museums but spent 4hours and been happy to be there, it is place worth to spent every rubbel(in opposition to Peterhof palace museum)
Must see once in a lifetime. I do not think this needs to be explained - grand museum, grand art, once in a lifetime experience for everyone

Huge, vast, mammoth art gallery!. Visited the Hermitage, with a Russian Guide, as part of our ship's stopover in St Petersburg. My review is possibly unfair to the extent that because of time constraints we only saw art & sculptures & none of the other exhibits in this museum. This palace is really huge & one would need perhaps a solid week to do it justice. However, the reputation of the Hermitage lists it as a must-see & maybe suggests it is like nowwhere else. Not true in my opinion. We have been to equally good art galleries but admittedly none so large. The fact is that during the normal time for a visit it is impossible to cover more than a fraction of the rooms or contents. It also becomes impossibly crowded at times. If you want to see a real attraction in St Petersburg try the Peterhof for something really different with its gardens & wonderful fountains. Frankly, I was disappointed with the Hermitage & think it is overhyped.

Great, spectacular, breathtaking.. The Hermitage Museum is a must see. Though be aware that there are many people in the summer season. To really enjoy the treasures located there, a visit in winter is advised. Approximately whole day is necessary to see most of it.

One of the best. We only had 2 hours on our tour in the Hermitage which is the norm. Very little time considering the size of the museum but I was excited to see whatever we were able to see in a very very short time.
Riches beyond belief. If this is the only thing you see in SPB, make sure you stay for a year! The treasures and paintings in this museum are mind blowing! Be ready for crowds.

Get a licensed tour guide and tickets in advance. 50,000 people tour this location daily. Order tickets and tour guide in advance or stand in line forever to buy timed-tickets. There is a lot to see and you want someone who knows the contents and layout as well as the history of the buildings to walk you through the vast and confusing structures. We paid a guide for 3 hours and toured 3 more hours by ourselves. Could have stayed for days.

Beautiful palace, but too much to see. This place is ginormous...it would literally take several years to see it all even if you only spent 5 seconds looking at each exhibit 24/7 non-stop. So...plan on a full day....but you still won't see it all.
Massive!. We arent art buffs... So halfday wasa enoughfor us. Take water and lunch if you are planning a full day. Get in early to avoid the crowds and definitely buy your tickets beforehand!
What can I say?. The best museum at both sides of the Chinese wall!!. I think you can spend here more then a month. Excellent exhibition. We were flabbercasted.

Most incredible art museum. We could not finish the endless rooms of works of art by masters of all countries. Plan for 1 or 2 days to experience all,the artworks and the history of how they came to be here.

An amazing display of opulance. We were with a group of fellow English Speakers. We had an English speaking guide who gave us a brief but all-in-all good orientation to an amazing palace/ museum. Even tho the guide claimed it to be not very crowded the day we were there...it seemed that way to us. We were greatful for being on a guided tour with a guide that spoke our langange. Many of the explanations of the sundry art masterpieces were only in Russian.

Don't miss this. The State Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace was the reason Imcame to Russia - it did not disappoint. The incredible volume of breathtaking artwork and priceless antiques here are impressive. Over 3 million items on display and these only represent 20% of what's stored away. Allow at least 4 hours to see the highlights.
A bit boring. Although the building was very impressive, the entrance stairs are amazing - every other room looked the same as each other, when you've seen one, you've seen the lot...
You need a week there. Recommend getting a ticket on-line beforehand. Saves huge queues, All sites are expensive - be prepared.
Gorgeous Museum. One of the biggest museums around the world. Try to visit early in the morning to spend most of the day. Incredible views and beautiful saloons & rooms.

A whole day affair, but worth a visit even for a few hours. We visited with a guide which I highly recommend. We had no idea where to go , and had no idea where to locate the important areas. The building is huge and has many facets. We had booked to go to the diamond room and gold room ( costs extra and must be booked ahead). Neither were worth it. Our guide could not take us through these rooms, and quite frankly the museum guides were boring and one in particular monosalabic. The diamond room has very few diamonds! The exhibits were mostly gold articafts and not particularly interesting jewelery. The diamonds were in crowns or some jewelery and nothing like the Crown Jewles of London. The gold room was more of the above....if you must go to one, do the diamond room.Of course you could stay the day, but half a day is enough as it becomes overload. We ate at one of the restaurants, not expensive but not much of a lunch.....our guide did not want to waste time at restaurants. The Amber room is stunning and free!
awesome. so much to see...had a guided tour of the main exhibits and then had free time to explore the top floor with more modern paintings.

Wow! Great collection and diversity!. This museum has an extensive and diverse collection of art. I highly recommend to spend a least two visits to this museum since there is much to see. The cover charge is about 8 euro. There are two paints from Leonardo di Vince, a nice coLlection of Vicent van Gogh, Cezanne, Monet, and Rembrants just to mention some! They have tours in English and they have audio tours. The gardens are a pleasure to walk and appreciate the art pieces strategic located. If you go on winter, then is a nice place to hide from the cold and enjoy a colorful world of art!

The State Hermitage. One of the greatest museums in the world! Plan at least a half of a day to visit Hermitage. Personally I recommend the impressionists exposition on the third floor of the Winter palace to be seen first of all.

Avoid Hermitage in summer. The Winter Palace has a beautiful interior, but during summer months it is impossible to enjoy it because of the crowds. The palace turned out to be like the Roman Coliseum. We arrived in the afternoon and you could see a huge line trying to get in. Our female guide bulled into the front of this mob and we lowered our shoulders and wedged our way in. Inside it was a zoo. There were mobs of people trying to get into different rooms at the same time. You could hardly concentrate on anything but survival. Not a wonderful way to view great art. It was like Giants stadium at halftime. Our guide said she had seen much larger crowds. I find that difficult to imagine.

Great visit. If you are short on time, just see the highlights in under 2 hours. Or you can spend a full day.. You can book your tickets on line and save about one hour in line. My favorite part of the tour was the palace areas.
ten out of ten. totally unbelievable experience. every room/hall is arrestingly beautiful and wondrous. wonderful historical material. superb.

It's a toss up.. The place is beautiful. It's also huge. Unfortunately, there is one bathroom..in the main building..all the way downstairs..the line of women comes out and around. So you can be on the 3rd floor of one of the other buildings and you will have to walk all th way back and down to use the facilities. The place is packed on a daily basis. I would suggest going on more than one ocassion. After several hours of walking around, I got tired of it and just wanted to leave. We went extra early. But once the crowds come in you can barely see the paintings. Everyone is standing all over the place, people are posing for pictures in front of the paintings. It becomes a mess of a museum.

Though it is a must to be seen attraction,I would grade it as a good collection thats it!. It has been over talked about,over written and over praised.It is a collection of various objects of art and thats about it.Louvre at Paris has far more paintings of imminent artists,and so do many other art galleries.It is advisable to have a guide to point the more important works and push through the relatively lessor important works.

Wow!. Fantastic range of art from many countries including ancient Egypt, Greek, French, and of course, Russian. Many portraits, sculptures, and architecture also to enjoy. Different exhibitions with different focuses means there is something for everybody to enjoy. The library is something i especially enjoyed with the stairs that ascend to almost a second floor the ceilings of the rooms are so tall. Also, the architecture room at the beginning filled with different models and the actual finished picture of the building.

Hermitage Highlights with TJ Tours. Our TJ Tours guide was able to get us into the Hermitage before it opened to the general public. Although there were other tours present, and the 2 1/2 hours seemed to go very quickly, we were introduced to the masters from classic, baroque, rennaisance, Spanish and Dutch masters, and impressionists. Our guide was very knowledgeable and efficient - making sure we did not miss any important exhibit. We thoroughly enjoyed our time walking through the opulent, baroque rooms, amazed at the skill of the artists, as well as the architects.
Just go. I can't imagine anyone goes to St. Petersburg on holiday and skips this so I don't really think there is much to add to that.
No words to describe it.. The most beautiful museum in the entire room. Words can not describe this experience. Pictures that were taken do not do it justice. A must to see!!!

most amazing place. it is all that it is reputed to be. incredible things to see. we had a private tour guide(ulko tours) who was amazing and made sure we saw everything important. we toured the diamond room which was very interesting.

Jaw dropping beauty. This was one of the highlights of my Baltic cruise trip. I've seen a lot of museums and art galleries and this is probably one of my favorites. The lost master craftsmanship that went into building the grandeur of this place is phenomenal. There is so much artwork, extravagance and gold everywhere that I can see why there was a revolution. The Peacock automaton clock was spectacular. Sadly, I didn't get to see it operate but they will operated it on certain occasions.
Huge!. My goodness. The place never ends. I know nothing about art but even I was impressed. Saw something from every artist I have ever heard of, sculptures are amazing. The place is huge!!!

Give Yourself Time, More Than 1 Day if Possible. First massive tip: If you're a student of any country, bring your student card! The museum is completely free with a valid Student I.D. from any country. For such an astounding museum, this deal is completely amazing!Other reviews go into more detail, so I'll just say that if you're in the city for a longer period of time, try not to take on the Hermitage all at once. It's extravagant, it's massive, and it can be overwhelming. Rather than trying to take everything in & not appreciating it, give this remarkable experience some time!Other than that, it's one of the most phenomenal collections I've ever seen. And if you're ever not interested in the art/sculptures/etc., all you have to do is look around at the building and its rooms to be amazed at its beauty.

most amazing!. i think the collection is better than metro in new york, better than the louvre, even the british. huge collection, took to days to "walk" through! from the ancients to Picasso. only problem is some of lighting is horrible and ac does not seem to work everywhere. and do buy the tickets online before u go!
The Hermitage. Room upon room of fantastic treasures (more than 1000 rooms) - famous painting, huge chandeliers, more gold leaf than you've ever seen. Fabulous.

Must be seen to be believed. This can be done in a day, but really requires two to be appreciated. Art lovers will want to go straight to The Italian Renaissance, the Impressionists and Modernists, and to see the Rembrants. But that is only the beginning.
I guess this is why one travels to St. Petersburg.

OK BUT. This has a lot of great art and a magnificent building . We spent 4 hours here on our last day in St Pete. Maybe it was because we were tired and with a guide that wanted to make sure we saw everything important but we were wasted before it was over. Again, the building is beautiful. the art is great and the sculptures outstanding. The only negative comment i had is that the guide made reference to the Nazis stealing art from Russia but didn't mention the Bolshevist's stealing art from Russians. I guess it all depends on your perspective.

Hermitage. Unreal. Puts the Metropolitan Musem of Art and the Louve to shame.The building, castles are a work of art in themselves. Not enough time--need a week to absorb the glory.Unlike museums for art and sculpture, the actual building with its moldings and floors and gilt and gold and chandeliers is awesome.It must be twice the size of the Met.

Great place. Too much to see though. History buff's delight. The audio guide is quite limited i should say. I think we covered about 70 % of the museum.It has more of paintings and historic stuff related to pre 1900 era. You dont find much of modern world history. Nevertheless, a great place

magnificent!. I liked it all, there is nothing wrong.A good advice to the foreigner students who are enrolled in language schools: ask to your school for the student card, even if you stay few weeks, because with it, you will have great discount prices on all the museums

Out of this world museum. Stuffed full of antiquities and hard to absorb on one visit with such a wealth of items but truly impressive. Arrive at least thirty minutes before opening to avoid the hoardes of tour groups. I would suggest a brisk initial visit and then a more leisurely return.

Nothing special... poorly mantained.. I was very disappointed when we visited this museum. I had references from a couple of people that told me it was a must see in St Petersburg. The building is poorly maintained and the art inside is good but not amazing. What really surprised me was the artists that are painting copies of some of the artwork, they are young and they do a really good Job.I've been to most of the best and largest museums in Europe, and definitely this is not on the top as many people believe. Louvre in Paris, and Del Prado in Madrid are much better than the Hermitage.The visit is still worth it.
must see at all cost.. more famous paintings that you can see in one day. Considering the distruction from ww2 It is amazing.

Imagine Versailles stuffed with everything from the Louvre. We spent a full day touring the Hermitage and enjoyed every minute. The State Rooms alone occupied two hours, and then the collections of art were extensive and fascinating. The old masters paintings were worth the trip to Russia alone, but don't miss the extensive collection of Impressionist paintings.
unbelievable.. It was fantastic. really a wow factor. The building was out of this world never mind all the artifacts inside.
beware. very frustrating experience! In august it was extremely crowded and very bad light. impossible to really see the paintings!

a must see!!1. very big museum with many interesting artcraft to see but the guidance is very good.
You lost bwn rooms.

One of Europe's Best!. Wow!!My husband and I have been to many of the best and largest museums in Europe, and we found the Hermitage to be right there at the top. With over three million pieces of artwork, it is difficult to decide what to see. They say if one spent just one minute at each piece of art at the State Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace, it would take somewhere between 11 and 16 years to see everything. This means you have to have a game plan and limit yourself to the amount of time to be spent at this incredible museum.In terms of museum size, the Hermitage is the largest with 24 km / 15 miles of galleries to walk through. In terms of paintings, prints and drawings, the Hermitage’s 12,000 is second only to Le Louvre’s 30,000. Madrid’s Prado has about 8,600 pieces.It is best to have a Russian tour guide to take you around the Hermitage. Two of the biggest reasons are the ticket prices and the queues. Tickets cost 400 Rubles for citizens of Russia and Belarus. It is our understanding that prices for everyone else are unfairly priced. Having a Russian tour guide also helps one to get to the front of the queue. One can spend hours waiting in line to gain entry if you do not have a Russian to assist. The other big reason for a Russian tour guide is that they can develop a “plan of attack”. My husband and I allotted two hours for our visit thus we wanted to maximize our time. Our guide asked us for our input, and she took us around, explaining what we were seeing. The Hermitage says that to take amateur videos and photographs, a special ticket must be bought from the museum ticket office. We do not think this is enforced as thousands of people were taking photographs. Besides, a major London newspaper recently stated the policy is not enforced. For your planning, the museum is closed on Mondays, 1 January and 9 May. Enjoy the very best place in all of Russia!

Huge collection of Art. A full day required. If you enjoy art, you will want to spend an entire day here. you might as well, given that your ticket lasts the entire day. If you rush through the exhibits to squeeze everything in, you're missing out.

Must see and spend enought time. Excellent places. You need a good tour guide to explain things. It will save time. Too many visitors. It is a problem. But it is worth the time. So spend enough time there each.

Don't miss a great experience. Just being able to see the beauty and craftsmanship throughout the palace and seeing the work of most of the top artists of their time up so close. many other treasures also display the creativity and beauty these early artisans could create
Queues!. The Hermitage is worth seeing. But before you need to stand in a very long queue! The prices in the inner cafe can be not so high. In general - very good.

Beautiful palace and museum. The Hermitage is definitely a beautiful palace. The sheer size of it is overwhelming. And I think on any visit to SPB it is a definite must. Every room is gilded and beautiful to see, but there is no furniture so you don't really have the sense that anyone lived there. The museum collection, while very large, was not as impressive as other large art collections in Europe. They have two small Da Vinci's, two small Rafael's, and several Rembrandt's. We didn't see the impressionist works, though those seem to be their claim to fame. I was expecting more from a place that has been compared to the Louvre. Overall, I highly recommend seeing it. We went with a tour guide and I think that really helped to narrow down what was worth seeing.

It's BIG. Choose what you want to do beforehand on the Hermitage web site so you don't have to wander around this huge place. We took a special tour, I think it was the "Gold" room or some such, and that wasn't really worth it. Be prepared to walk up and down stairs. The cafe was fine for a quick lunch. Be sure and look down at the inlaid floors as well as up at the incredible ceilings.

More than you can handle. Everything you have heard about the Hermitage is true.....and then some. There is so much to see, and it seems that everyone wants to see it at the same time. It gets quite crowded in most parts. The modern art exhibitions are a bit harder to find, but worth it, and are less crowded for some reason. Bathrooms are scarce and busy. If you do some homework before, and know what you want to see it will not be so overwhelming. Make sure you pick up a map at the entrance (in different languages). Enjoy!!!

The best there is. This is a beautiful museum, one of a kind. You'll find contemporary and historical exhibits. The entire building is a work of art, including the walls and the windows. Sure the personnel are not always helpful and it takes a while to get in but it is all worth it. If you have even just a few hours to visit the place, great. Ideally you'll have a few days as there are many, many exhibits. Learn about the hours in advance, the place is closed at unusual times.

Mild interest Western paintings. The Hermitage Museum is in the reality a huge gallery of western European painting. Very few people realize that even ...AFTER have visited the museum. I liked only two sections of the museum-(palace). The Golden Room with the outstanting collection of ancient Scythian Treasures and the rich collection of Impresionists. The rest of the paintings are of uknown or lesser known western painters , The left overs from the European art collectors , bought by the the Russian Tsarinas. None is well known outside the walls of the Hermitage. Ask a friend who has been there and you will be surprised to discover that he does not remember any particular painting after a while!!!

Unbelievable. Problably the best museum in the world. Impossible to see in just haf a day or even one day...Please , plan your visit carefully beforehand so you have an idea where you intend to go, before you start. There is jus so much to see and do that one can get easily lost in between the so many works of art.

Hermitage Museum. Try to get signed up with a tour company that can get you in early before the crowds! We were on a Viking River cruise which got us in earlier. We were also able to do the "Behind the Scenes" tour which included a nice lunch and then areas that are less crowded (due to the extra charge to have this tour I'm sure). The works of art in this museum are fabulous but the lighting of some of the paintings is poor. You are allowed to take photos which is a plus. They do rent audio headsets which helps you understand the art in front of you; well worth the money! If you are really into art then you could easily spend a whole day here! I thought it was funny that the "hanging gardens" of Catherine the Great are really gardens which are planted on the roof of what is considered the first floor; nothing is hanging! This attraction is a must see in St. Petersburg!

Hermitage Museum. You could spend years in this place! With that said, we were able to hit what we considered to be the highlights, in about 2 hours. With only 2 days in St. Petersburg we had to prioritize our time. We walked fast, took a few pictures, but didn't have time to read or really absorb the magnitude of the exhibits. The coat check was quick and efficient, however, the restroom facilities by the coat check were another story. Be prepared to wait in line for the restroom or ask your guide where another one is.

Fantastic World-Class Experience. Plan a half-day minimum, a whole day is still hardly adequate. Don't miss the Impressionalist collection. Fantastic glittery interior. One huge hall copied from the Vatican. Only downside is that million dollar paintings are poorly lighted, sometimes with a single strip of fourscent tubing hiding the colors of these classic paintings, and with opposing walls windows allowing bright sunlight streaming through creating blinding glare.

One could spend days in here. So so so crowded at certain sections of the museum such as the da Vinci paintings as there were a lot of tour groups. They don't seem to be particular interested in the paintings, they just all want a photo of it! This museum is huge, not to be missed.
Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace. The Hermitage is truly one of the finest art museums in the world with a collection that has few rivals. Some of the Palace rooms are beyond belief.

Not as crowded as I expected. I went on August 1 and Aug 2 is the free day at the museum, so maybe I got lucky and people waited to enter free on Aug 2. I was even able to get a photo of the grand entranceway without a single tourist. I purchased my ticket on-line and arrived 15 minutes before the doors opened. I was the third person in line. I chatted with a British couple that had been the day before and took the English speaking tour. They recommended the headphones as the tour moved too quickly. I rented headphones and had a lovely day visiting the museum.One small issue, I bought a tea at the cafe and the young man accused me of not paying him. He was very nasty about it. I am 100% sure I did as I was not familiar with the currency so I stood to the side and pulled out my money before I even got up to the counter. I refused to pay him a second time so I waited until a manger came over. In the end, they did not make me pay again. So just be careful when you hand over the money. I enjoyed the building and the room decorations as much as I enjoyed the art. The next day I took my husband back (who had to work the day before). We arrived around 4 and entered for free. It was crowded, but still nothing like people described. And it was free! A must see when in St Petersburg.tip: purchase your ticket on-line at home and print - hotels charge more than 2 times the entrance price to do it for you.

Magnificent - just amazing, breathtaking sights.. We just loved it all, we were totally enthralled listening to our guide the whole time. Magnificent buildings with breathtaking interiors and amazing art work. Parquet floor designs and chandeliers so lush throughout.

Interesting museum, but disfunctional organisation. The museum has great paintings and sculptures and the building itself is already worth a visit.But it is very crowded and the organisation is disfunctional: I tried to buy tickets online, but they were not sent to my email and customer service was unresponsive - of course I was still charged the booking fee ($4). So we had to queue outside (thankfully on that day only about 30min and no rain). Of course you get terribly lost - but staff does not speak English and they don't even have a map themselves. Though I quite liked the helpful iPhone app.

A Must do. The collection of the Hermitage is amazing. The art collection is huge! It is a place to visit even if your not an art person. If you can go to the Treasury, it is worth the visit. You must book in advance however. I recommend a reservation for the Hermitage as well, to avoid lines

Best museum ever seen.. Ticket I booked on internet and in 5 minutes we by passed teh queue. Never seen such much art and well presented. No guided tour is needed. Go on your own with audio guide. A must to see in SPB. Will come back!

Amazing. What can I say...the best museum in the world, by a long shot. Book your tickets online and early, otherwise be prepared for a massive wait! And take two days to see this- one day wasn't enough for me! Will have to go back again...

This is really an outstanding museum of art with an awesome collection of Monets, Picassos and Rembrandts.. The collection of art at the Hermitage rivals the Louvre. I saw originals I had only seen before in pictures from my favorite Impressionists. Their collection of Rembrandts rivals anything we can see in the United States. It helps to visit with a tour guide who can take you to see the great works of interest to you, because it is a huge, sometimes crowded place.

Too crowded. This is a must-see if you you travel to St. Petersburg, but be forewarned. It is jam-packed with tourists just like you who want to see everything. It's impossible. Try going in the early morning when the crowds are not so bad.

Biggest and top quality. The Hermitage is amazing, we were there for two consecutive whole days and could only see about 75% of what they have on exhibit.It's a bit of a labyrinth, so if you have less time available, get a map and go directly to the rooms you wish to see. It's difficult to choose, though: they have the second largest collection of Rembrandts in the world, plus many impressionist masters, two rooms with works by Picasso, a nice selection of Egyptian artefacts and the palace state rooms alone are worth the visit...Do yourself a big favour and buy your tickets on the internet: you will avoid standing in a queue for over an hour; ticket holders can go right in bypassing the long lines.
Don't miss it. A must see but overrun with tour groups? Make sure you go early. Opens at 10.30 but the queues start well before that,
Ice Palace. Beautiful architecture and quite inviting for tourists ..disliked locals trying to seel their warews in front of bldg . made me feel uncomfortable

Hermitage - must see. We loved our visit to the Hermitage with our private tour (3 of us) with TJ Travel. We were able to get into the museum through a different door than the general public who just come without a tour company. Anyway, the museum is very large and it was helpful that our tour guide was able to maneuver us to the highlights. Please note that the Hermitage is NOT air conditioned and though the windows were open...it was still very warm. So leave your jackets in your tour vehicle.

St. Petersburg's Must-See. The Hermitage is a truly amazing place to visit. It is a huge place -- in our two and a half hour visit, we saw only a tiny fraction of its offerings. The Hermitage itself and its furnishings is even more amazing than the paintings. We had a guide (from Den-Rus tours) who was very knowledgeable and helped guide us through so we could maximize our visit. If you are visiting on your own, check out the Hermitage's website first, and decide what you really want to see.

The Hermitage, Saint Petersburg, Russia--seven thousand miles for a two-hour visit.. I have a dream. It's not as noble as that of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and no more likely to be fulfilled in my lifetime than was his. I have a dream of visiting every major art museum in the world. In mid-May my wife and I returned from a transatlantic cruise, coupled with a nine-day cruise of the Baltic Sea and all the major capitals of Northern Europe. The highlight of that far off adventure was two days spent in St. Petersburg, Russia. The highlight, coupled with Catherine's Palace and the Peterhof Palace, was the Heritage Art Museum.I have a confession to make. We spent 21 days on the seas and a total of five weeks away from home to allow me a meager two hours to peruse the holdings of one of the largest art museums in the world. Worse, part of that time I was lost, searching for the main entrance so that I might rejoin our tour group and not spend the rest of my life in Russia. But that's par for the course. I seldom go to art museums and not get lost. It goes without saying that the Hermitage (pronounced er-mit-TAJ) is huge, on a par with the Louvre in Paris an the Met in New York. Moreover, it has not been "twenty-first-centuryized" as have the most other world-class museums. For instance, only one floor, the former servants quarters of the palace, containing the museum's modern art, has been air-conditioned (not that it mattered since we were there in May when the whole city of St. Petersburg is air conditioned). Here was to be found Matisse's famous Dance, as well as works by Picasso, Braque, Kandinsky, Vlaminck, Derain, Malevich, van Gogh, and just about every other name one might recognize from modern art (plus a few I didn't recognize).Like the Louvre, the Hermitage is a hand-me-down, a onetime palace dating from 1764 before the Tsars moved to the suburbs to spend most of the year away from the big city. Besides the Summer Palace there's also the "Small Heritage" (which isn't), the "Old Hermitage," and the "New Hermitage" stretching out in an extended linear progression to rival Versailles--which undoubtedly was the tsars' intentions. Like the Louvre, the Hermitage is not an ideal structure to house a billion-ruble (or billion-dollar) art collection. In 1989, the Chinese-American architect I.M. Pei tamed the Louvre. I wish he would do the same for the Hermitage. The main thing the Hermitage has going for it is sheer scale. And if crowds were evenly dispersed among its hundreds of rooms and galleries, this scale would somewhat mitigate its organization shortcomings. Unfortunately, that's not the case. The main galleries are often shoulder to shoulder while the remote venues seem downright lonely. Now, having complained about the museum's many faults, let me dwell on its strengths. If you like the Baroque, you'll love the Hermitage. Management sometimes refers to it a Russian Baroque, and indeed, there is a distinct difference. Russian Baroque is more baroque than its southern European kin. Though I'm a painter and I love looking at paintings in museums, in that regard, the Hermitage is simply too much of a good thing. Leonardo is represented by his Madonna Lita, Titian by his St. Sebastian, Raphael by a couple of his many Madonnas, Giorgione by his Judith. The Hermitage collection also includes works by Tiepolo, Carracci, Caravaggio, Velasquez, El Greco, Rubens, van Dyck, and over 20 works by Rembrandt.Sculpture, on the other hand, was, for me, the most memorable of all the museum's offerings. There was literally tons of it, the best of the best the Baroque world had to offer by virtually every sculptor working at the time. There's even a minor Renaissance piece by Michelangelo, Crouching Youth. Names such as Canova, Rossellino, Bernini, Giuseppe Mazzuoli, the Venetian Antonio Lombardo, Riemenschneider, Houdon, Eugene Falconet, Rodin, and Versailles own A.Coysevox dot the landscape. There was much more as well. The Hermitage, being an old Russian palace, has its share of ornate domestic furnishings from gold leaf thrones (the Russians love their gold leaf) to porcelain sculptural pieces that would look good on my coffee table. There were carriages (more gold leaf), clothes, china, crystal, silver, and tapestries representing two centuries of Russian tsarist extravagance and impoverished suffering by the peasant masses. If you've ever pondered the cause of the 1917 Russian Revolution, you need look no further than the Hermitage or any number of similarly ostentatious palaces decorating this former Russian capital.

Amazing collections!. Plan your day carefully and don't exit the museum until you are sure that you've finished - they will not allow you a second entry. If you go on the first Thursday of the month it is free entry, but there will be a big queue - so go early. Doors open at 10
Do not miss it. Give it a full day.. Loved the prehistoric Siberian wing. Mummified bodies, tattoos, horses heads, carpets and the cool artistic swans.
A must see. Just did not see everything but saw so much,you have to see to understand what is in the buildings.Our guide had so much knowledge and spoke very good english
A must see. You could spend days there...so much beauty and history in one location...make sure you allow enough time to absorb it all.

Monday is the best day to visit!. When booking a baltic cruise, we were initially disappointed to see that our only day in St Petersburg was a Monday, when the Hermitage is closed. If this happens to you, do not dispair! Tours booked through cruise lines are able to visit the Hermitage on Mondays.... I arranged a private guide for myself, my husband and daughter through the cruise line, and we spent two wonderful hours wandering around eerily empty rooms, gazing at priceless works of art against a backdrop of stunningly beautiful rooms. Even though the place was virtually empty (although we did occasionally come across large cruise tour groups) the guide seemed unable to slow down to a more leisurely pace, and and whizzed by amazing Dutch Masters and Impressionist masterpieces far more quickly that we would have liked. Unfortunately, there are no refreshment facilities and limited souvenir opportunities because the museum is officially closed, and no access to special exhibitions. Nevertheless, a throughly unforgettable experience.

The Hermitage in St. Petersburg - WOW!. It's unbelievable how huge the museum is, and how impressive, let alone the exhibits themselves. There is so much to see in here that it would probably take over a year to see everything. We chose not to use our cruise's tour, but instead used a Ruswsian tour company called Red October. That way, we had a private tour, didn't have to wait in long lines and although the Hermitage was crowded, our guide always seemed to know where there were less people. Every part of the museum is decorated, floors, walls and ceilings, and the artwork on display is priceless! If nothing else, when going to St. Petersburg, be sure to visit.
Simply great. I liked everything, it's just fantastic. You need at one entire day to see a fraction of the collection.

Spectacular, but go early. It feels a bit odd to write a review for such a legendary museum, but the 5 circle rating is certainly warranted. We were part of a tour, and we got there pretty much as the museum opened. Our guide hustled us through the grand entryway to the Impressionist gallery, as it evidently fills up quickly. The exhibitions are mind blowing, but honestly the interior trappings are more spectacular than the artwork. Gilded, ornate decoration is everywhere in vast rooms, with lapis and malachite urns and tables everywhere. The opulence has to be seen to be believed.Do yourself a favor and visit. Outside of summer would probably be better, but if you are in St. Petersburg this is a must see. Go early, as the lines can be very long by lunchtime and you'll wait at least an hour to get in.
Great but to crowded. Well worth a visit but beware the guided trips coming from the cruise liners who clog the place up! This museum has world class exhibits and has plenty to see.

Wonderful, a must for your visit to St. Petersburg.. The beauty is unbelievable, and the art work displayed is some of the best in the world. I wish we had had more time. Be sure to do early entrance or you will be in long lines.

A Highlight. We only spent about 3 hours here but wished we had allocated more time. There is so much to see and at least a half day is necessary. If going on a hot day, go lightly dressed as it gets very warm in there with no air con.
Hermitage. A fabulas museum. There is so many things to see I wish I had more time. The building itself is also candy for the eyes.

Huge collection, not to be missed!. I was planning to do this for a half day and I end up staying for the whole day.So much to do and get the audio tour as most description are in Russian. Great collection from a rich country with a colorful history.Arrive early to miss the crowds of tourist.For students don't forget your student cards to receive the student discounts.HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

Overwhelming, but probably a "must-see" in St. P.. Loved the vast collection of art and the beautiful buildings and gardens.Disliked the crowds. But sometimes, you get lucky - maybe after cruise ship season is over?
There is so much to see!. We had reserved a guided visit! What a good idea because it is the most crowded meseum we visited. Lots of pushing around in front of the main paintings.

It is a "must" in Pieter. We liked it all and did not have to wait to get inside. Buy tickets in the machine just inside the entrance gate, instead of lining up in front of the "kassa" - Tours use the entrance on the riverside.Can't say more than : http://www.saint-petersburg.com/virtual-tour/hermitage.asp

Went for the Palace, not the art.. We did see lots and lots of amazing art, but it is also worth the trip to learn about the palace itself and the Tsars. I loved seeing the art, but learning about the palace and its additions over the years, the final storming in 1917, etc was fantastic.
Fantastic collection, helpful staff. Amazing art collection - so big I would recommend you take 2 days to go around this place. A must go to in St Petersburg!

Not the Louvre, but close..... The Hermitage s wonderful. Daunting in its size, wonderful rooms, a fabulous collection of art and antifacts....not to be missed. We happened to be there during a heat wave, and without AC it was very hot and stuffy inside, and the crowds on a Sunday were terrible. Nether the less this was a highpoint of our trip. There is so much to see that the French impressionists were an afterthought....our guide sent us up there on our own during our last half hour.....that indicates how much great stuff there is to see.

Be ready for hoardes of fellow-art lovers.. GO EARLY! This anticipated HIGHLIGHT was actually a disappointment because everyone was there at the same time, or so it seemed. Like any large art museum you must plan your time and your route because there is so much to see.
Well worth a visit. Fabulous place to visit. With over 2.7 million exhibits do not think that you will see everything. There is no air conditioning so it can get very warm inside.

Hermitage in a Hurry. I would take years to see all of the Hermitage, and we had just under 3 hours. The palace was a wonder. We were constantly amazed at the splendor of each space we entered, with adornment from floor to ceiling, all thoughtfully planned. We had so little time to truly absorb every detail, and piece of art, but the time we had there sped by. Our tour guide, Tatianna of SPB shared great insights and her passion for the art.

Just wonderful!. We were there in March, so we were lucky enough to find the Hermitage devoid of long lines. The sheer amount of quality and fantastic art is astounding. The building itself is a piece of art - the intricate detail in the rooms of this old palace were beautiful. We actually went 3 times over our stay just to make sure we saw everything (I was there for six months, so it wasn't hard to fit the visits in).One of the highlights for me was Matisse's Dance. I was lucky enough to see Dance (I) later on in New Yorks' MoMA

amazing. We got to see so much. The rooms are amazing and the gold rooms were worth the extra cost. I wish we could have gone in the morning when there were fewer people, but our guide was very good about avoiding the bigger crowds.
Doesn't need a comment. If you haven't heard of it, you must be living on Mars. Best museum in the world, hands down. Plan on at least a full day there, anything else doesn't do it justice
Hermitage. Incredibly opulent and beautiful, with thousands of pieces of exquisite art, but crowded and hot inside.

Unbelievable Museum - Do Not Miss. Magnificent buildings housing an incredible collection of art and artifacts. We spent 2 days in the museum and didn't see nearly all of it, but what we saw was mind blowing. And the various rooms of the former winter palace? Unbelievable, just unbelievable.Spend as much time here as you can.

Breathtaking, but crowded. Must visit, both for the paintings and artwork inside, and also for the magnificent palace rooms themselves. Just extreamly crowded, and some very famous paintings put in small alcoves, that need to be moved to larger areas so more can enjoy them at once. Nice gifts shops, but many expensive items. Some times they offer an evening tour, from like 7 pm to 10 pm, and they say it's a lot less crowded, and that would make a lot of sense to that that tour, rather than one during the day.
not to be missed. I disliked queues, in September is better than in July, the summer high season is too busy. Very well organized the reception and assistance.

A wonderfull museum in a wonderfull palace. The Palace il super, the building is well maintained
Very interesting the section on russian culture, siberian history
I don't like tourst in big group.
Pure History. Of course the place you MUST visit when in SPB. Unfortunately as much tim you take it is not enough to see even the most important exhibits. So make your plan before entering museum.

Wonderful works of art!!!. This museum is the largest and oldest in the world. It was founded in 1764 by Catherine II, empress of Russia and opened to the public since 1852.At the start of the tour, we caught a glimpse of famous Dutch painter, Rembrandt's Prodigal Son in the inner room. We had our fill of this Rembrandt piece at the end of the tour and was definitely the highlight!Some of the beautiful works we saw are: Da Vinci's Madonna Litta and Madonna BenoisCollection of Flemish painter Peter Paul Rubens, Lady in Waiting.Malachite vases are prominently displayed in most rooms.the Russian emblem of two headed eagle are also visible in most areas. There is a large vase, 700 tons of jasper which was installed there before the walls were built.Tip: A guided tour is a must to not miss the beautiful collections in the museum.
Gayle D949. We had a small group of three and the most wonderful guide called Victoria. Shea made the tour come alive for us and we avoided the crowds

Even though you are not a museum lover, you will be entertained inside the Hermitage.. It's massive and has got sooo much to offer. You really have to spend the whole day inside, roaming from one side to the other. I had to wait for 40 mins in the line before entering the museum. It's best to book the ticket online. There are also the different in price when you would like to take some pictures inside the museum.

Great museum..pity the poor crowd control. This is a highlight of any visit to St. Petersburg. It was the winter palace of Peter the Great with additions as time passed.To avoid queues, organize your visit with a registered tour guide..preferably in a very small group.Go as early as you can can. No waiting. Straight in..plus the use of the guide.The museum is rich...a lot of gold adornments. The art collection is excellent..but it takes time if you want to study the works. Once the crowds come in..it is not a pleasant experience..so many people..too many for my liking to appreciate what the museum has to offer. We left early than we would have liked because of this.

Amaying collection-take your time!. most important advice: buy tickets online!! Waiting in lines is not anyone would like to see and you will see a very long line first to buy ticket then to get in. With printed voucher you get your ticket in a minute and go behid line in no time. Use the opportunity and save more time for enjoying the tour. Guides are available and recommended as collection is so various and the story of Peter and Catherine is very interesting and worth listening.If you don't have enough time to see the whole museum, I'd suggest to pick a period and see at least one floor, leaving the other parts for some other occasion.My personal reomendations goes to Impressionsits...absolutely breathtaking :)

Good range of things to see. It was hard to say whether the building itself or the art was the thing I preferred! At times I bypassed the art and spent more time looking at the fabric of the place. I have spent much time in galleries and museums and I think the benefit of the Hermitage is its variety. There is something for a broad range of tastes, be it geographic, based on period or style. The queues were not too bad even in summer and I am not sure I would pay the extra for the expedited entry, especially if you qualify for a reduced price ticket.

Impressive-Must visit!. Highly recommend hiring a guide for your visit to Hermitage, this place is huge, a guide will help you maximize your time and bring you to the most interesting halls and exhibitions according to your interest.
Absolutely Stunning. Has to be one of the top 5 museums of its kind in the world. Absolutely enormous; while I only had time to see a small fraction of it, I came away thoroughly impressed.

An art lovers dream. It had been a dream of mine to visit the Hermitage museum. Our visit was part of a two day tour of St. Petersburg. The museum facility as part of the Winter Palace gives you outstanding art along with a historic and beautiful facility to enjoy. It is crowded, but facinating and was the highlight of our trip to Russia. Make sure that you tour the museum with a guide as you can get overwhelmed with all the information available. Not to be missed.

lots to see, very impressive. loved seeing the palace rooms as well as all the other museum items. If you are going by yourself be sure to stand in the left line if you are using a cc, luck we had cash, we were in the right line. Lots to see, so pace yourself. We saw just a bit of the artworks, since I figured we could see that in other museums.

The hermitage is VERY crowded.. Consider that Russian museum as an alternative. My husband got claustrophobic. I loved the impressionists, but you will have to endure rooms of Christian martyrs first.

Managing the Hermitage. Be sure to buy your tickets on the internet before hand so that you avoid the long ticket lines, print out your voucher or get your hotel to print it out for you, and don't forget an ID of the purchaser. Get there before opening and race up to the third floor. We had the 19th and 20th Century rooms to ourselves for a good hour before the hoardes of tour buses arrived. Make your way down and be sure not to miss the Da Vinci and the Rembrandts. An absolute treat.

A MUST in your visit -one of the greatest Art Museums in the World. The Italian renaissance is represented by works of Raphael, Lippi, Botticelli and Leonardo Da Vinci.Rembrandt is well represented among the Dutch anf Flemish masters.The Palace can be very crowded and lunchtime is recommended for a more tranquil visit
must see. Even if you don't care about art you have to visit winter palace. So many rooms all decorated, amazing!!! watch out for pocket pickers.

State Hermitage Museum of St. Petersburg, Russia. The State Hermitage Museum is part of the Winter Palace. The artwork in this museum consists mainly of paintings of a fine quality. There was an abundance of work by Dutch masters, with a great variety of European artists represented, including Italian, French, British, and German. The majority of works were 17th to 20th century. I did not get to the Asian art work. The museum covers most if not all of the palace. Prepare for a lengthy visit. Not all of the paintings are spectacular, but you will be rewarded with an amazing collection, surely one of the best in the world.  The State Hermitage Museum should not be missed when visiting St. Petersburg.
Great. Great place- you need more than a day, however. There is simply too much to take in and the crowds are huge.
STUPENDOUS MUSEUM GALLERY. Unbelievable treasury of art and artefacts. One full day was exhausting but not enough to appreciate the wealth of this institution

good shows and prep for lots of walking. The Hermitage is an all day thing... or better get tickets for two days and break it up. Purchase beforehand! The summer lines are stupid long. And try to time it when there are not 1.3M people trying to see the same things at the same time... go when there is ice and snow outside... Summer is a disaster.

Elegant Italian architecture and top museum. The Hermitage is the immense palace of the czars, whose most beatiful part in rococo' style, the Winter Palace, is due to the Italian architect Rastrelli. Looking also from distance one is captured by the harmony of the Winter Palace with the white of the columns and the green of the rest of it. Inside the Hermitage hosts one of the greatest art museums of the world. In three hours we only had time to visit the Italian painting section. Among the world famed masterpieces do not miss 'Annunciation' by Simone Martini, ‘Madonna (Benois) with a Flower, 1478’ and ‘Madonna Litta, 1490-91’ by Leonardo da Vinci; ‘Madonna Conestabile, 1502-03’ and ‘The Holy Family, 1506’ by Raphael; as well as masterpieces by Giorgione and Tiziano Vecellio. What concerns to Italian sculpture of the 15th to 20th centuries, includes ‘Crouching Boy’ by Michelangelo and ‘Cupid and Psyche’ by Antonio Canova. We then moved to the French Impressionists and post-impressionists located in the simpler rooms of the third floor. Outstanding are the collections of Matisse, Gaugin and the first Picasso, while I would rather recommend 'Museum of Orsay' in Paris for the impressionists. The museum was very crowded, but the lack of legends in English is a more severe handicap, since we are only provided a map of the museum, the exhibited works are so many to get confused at times, and the attendants only understand Russian. Still a must for a tourist. But my feeling is that a few visits are needed to really appreciate the wealth of this museum

Absolutely Incredible!!!. The Hermitage is a cross between touring a palace and a museum. There were many beautifully appointed rooms to see as well as an incredible collection of art from around the world.

Spectacular. We visited with a cruise tour and therefore only spent 2 hours inside the museum/palace, yet were overwhelmed by the magnificence and volume of the collections. Fortunately, we had a guide explaining what we were looking at and that added a lot to the experience. Also, taking lots of photos helped us remember what we saw; many paintings can be identified on the internet. Countless artworks by masters are on display and I wish we had done more research before visiting to know what to look for. If possible, plan on spending many hours here.

Hermitage & Winter Palace. My life long dream was to see the Hermitage, and it did not diappoint. The most fabulous collection of art. You could spend years there, but if you only have a day, it's still very much worth it.
Fantastic. The whole place is just amazing from the outside and the square to the art work and the palace itself. Tip get a ticket in cash from the machine and avoid the ques.

Fabulous place but take it in small pieces. WOW! This place provides 3 different types of attractions:ART - world class collection;ARCHITECTURE AND INTERNAL DESIGN - beautifully executedHISTORY - dwelling of Tzars, place of revolutionary fightsI really love this place, this was my second visit and I come prepared - really.I have left very-very tired. It was very hot and uncomfortable to navigate in July when it was literally swamped by tourists. Therefor I would like to advise following:1. Get help - take guided tour or higher a guide;2. Don't take all of it in one visit - select a theme for your visit: see just 19th and 20th century art or just talian art or just Dutch art or come to visit only the staterooms and halls.3. Buy your tickets on the internet to not wait for hours in queues; Please remembers that anyone needs more than few visits to see everything.

Best museum in the world. This museum/palace/church is an absolute must see for any visitor to St Petersburg. Allocate at least half a day for the visit, make sure to grab a map and mark the rooms as you go, otherwise it is easy to get disorientated.
The best art collection yet. Fantastic place. The collection of art and antiques are the best I have seen yet as museums go. NBTake your student ID card for free access
fabulous. unbeatable sites, well organized, well told by guide, will remember it always and have great photos to shore with friends and family

Full of History. I have been to lots of museums around the world,but this one is different.History is alive here and it takes you back in time.We were lucky enough to have a wonderful experienced guide that made all the difference.We were amazed with the museum and you have to appreciate what it provides.Thoroughly enjoyed it.
Midlander. You could spend the two days in the Hermitage there is so much to see. The architecture and treasures that the Hermitage houses are incredible.

Overwhelmingly beautiful, incredible artwork. This really is a "Do Not Miss" attraction. While clearly speaking to the excesses of ruling families it is also an incredible collection of centuries old artwork, scultures, furntiure, etc.. We REALLY enjoyed to several hours we spent there. Tour group is probably the best way to go or you'd be wandering aimlessly through what seemed like miles of rooms and exhibits. If you visit nothing else in Russia......

Wrapping overshadows the gift. Anyone who remotely appreciates art needs to spend a day at the Hermitage. I'm at best an amateur art lover. I took a few art classes in college and appreciate good art, but I'm no great art student. I loved the Hermitage because not only is it filled with beautiful art, it is itself a piece of art. The building is the winter palace of Peter the Great, and it is so grand that I think it engulfs the amazing art inside. Again, I don't know that much about art, and an art scholar would probably cringe at my comments, but the marble halls and pillars and grand staircases and patterned floors were more magnificent than anything I saw in the city of St. Petersburg. Go to the Hermitage to see the art, but you'll be blown away by the building that houses it.
Hermitage. Like the Louvre, but more to see. Makie sure you allot over an hour time for the impressionists roooms

An amazing place. I had a wonderful visit to the Hermitage. It is an amazing building with some pretty spectacular sculptures, furnishings and exhibitions. The art gallery on the top floor has rooms full of paintings by da Vinci, Raphael, Picasso and many other great artists. You can get up really close to all the works of art and take as many pictures as you like. It was well worth the visit.

An experience of a lifetime!. The opulence of this museum makes you understand the revolution in russia! Each room seemed to bring more gold and beautiful pictures. One room is the actual place the last czar of russia resigned from his position. It is just breath taking!
Wow. They say this is the best museum in the world and rightly so. Went in the afternoon around 3pm so the queues weren't the longest.

The Russian version of the 'Louvre' and 'Vatican city' put together. The state rooms of the Winter Palace and the art-works from all over the world painstakingly collected over centuries with the intent of putting it on show and sharing with the world is amazing. Like the Louvre and the Vatican - it is just too big and the collection to vast to be covered in a day or even a few.The day-tripper would do well to go in armed with a short-list of 20 things to see and decide if he wanted to come back and spend more time at a later visit for himself.

Don't miss this museum. I am not a great lover of art museums but this is something else. The combination of the winter palace rooms and art gallaries mixes well. Make sure you have a knowledgeable guide who will ensure you see the key exhibits / rooms before setting out on your own. We were lucky, we arrived early and the building was close to empty - our guide advised that she had never seen it so empty which allowed us to see the rooms with few people around, take incredible pictures and view the main pictures before it got too busy. Our trip lasted just over 2 hours but you could easily spend the whole day and still have more to see.

buy online tickets. * the best way to not stop in the qeue is to buy the tickets online before you go there (because the qeue is very long).* if you and all the people in your group are adults and need adult tickets you can buy them when you arrive there throught the machine at your right hand after the main entrance as the qeue here is not very long (they dont sell children or student tickets at these machines).* you need to go there earlly so it will be less crouded and you will have time to see every thing.

Spectacular.. There is a reason millions of people visit The Hermitage every year (I think they were all there the same day I was). The collections of art, exhibitions, furnishings, sculptures need to be seen to be truly appreciated ... it is even more impressive than it appears in the spectacular pictures that are available. I was part of a cruise trip tour, so fortunately was able to skip the long line-ups. An afternoon tour does not begin to do the place justice (for that matter, neither would a week of afternoon tours) but provides a sampling of Russian history and life through the years. Absolutely not to be missed!

Uber Museum with exquisite treasures!. Winter Palace, the former state residence of the Russian emperors. At par with many European Museums. Great collection.Leonardo da Vinci, Titian, Raphael and many more.Great paintings, graphic works, sculptures and much more.

A Huge Museum!. This place is huge! usually there is a queue to get in (not very long when we visited). At the time we visited there was a music band that would play the national music of the tourists' groups' country in front of their group. Which felt quite good while waiting in the queue.What can I say about inside of it? It's a must see place in Russia. A lot of paintings from ancient time to the some present and modern ones. Also there halls specialized of different countries pieces.There are some cafes at ground floor too. so you can rest there after a long journey.

get tickets online- skip the line!. I got two-day tickets from the Hermitage website. I printed out my receipt (they will email it to you) and I got to skip the *massive* queue both days.Also in the SIberian section in the basement, check out the Altai mummy woman from 4th c bc- all of her clothes and jewelry is still perfectly preserved!

Beautiful, Need a lot of Time To See All.. This Palace is beautiful, with the art and colours of the inside and outside it is a photographers paradise. The rooms have been restored to the original opulence that they were. With our tour we were marched past the long crowds and were taken through seperate entry to the waiting public which was terrific as we were shown around at a quicker pace. Well worth a visit even a quick one, makes you want to come back again!

The most amazing museum that I have ever visited. The spectacular interior and the art collection, which boasted so many famous names ,and in each room only a certain number of paintings or sculptures so that it was not too overwhelming for the visitor.

Plan to Spend the Day. This museum is absolutely wonderful. There are literally thousands of paintings, sculptures and artifacts. The gold room, located in a very large walk in vault was outstanding.The rooms of the Winter Palace are restored to their original splendor and opulence. The palace reveals a world far removed from buildings of today.You should arrive early and plan to stay all day if you want to see most of it. There is no way to see the entire place in a day. We were told that if you spent just one minute looking at each exhibit/painting, etc. it would take several years to see everything.

Crowded but a must see. This is a must see in St Petersburg even for people who aren't massive art fans, as it is an amazing palace (former Winter Palace of the Tsar NIcholas II) and has a wide range of art, sculptures, and ancient Egyptian artifacts. I can't stress enough how important it is to book online first to avoid the long queues to get in. It gets extremely crowded inside with lots of tour groups, however these tend to move quickly so if you hang around they disappera. Also good to plan your visit as it's so massive it makes your head spin. As a note, Lonely Planet says the cafe is dire but we found it quite good.

Need several days to see!. What a magnificent and beautiful place! From the inlaid floorings to the amazing ceilings, the light fixtures, gold work, art of all different kinds to make everyone happy. The marble, lapis pillars, large tables and urns and other beautiful semi precious stone made into all sorts of things. The whole building is a jewel in itself and all that is in it makes it sparkle more. A must to see but allow time for crowds and long lines. Thank goodness we were with a tour and our guide took us to places that she thought were the best. She was an art major in university and well trained.

A must see, but needs time!. We visited the Hermitage as part of a cruise ship's shore excursion. The museum, not normally open on Mondays, was packed with tourists and too crowded. Because the Hermitage was not normally open, some exhibits remained closed. I am not an appreciator of art, but was blown away by the art displayed here. There are originals by masters such DeVinci and Rembrandt. There was a lot of what our guide called functional art (non-paintings) that was beautiful and interesting. We spent a couple of hours rushing through a museum that if someone spent ten seconds looking at each object of art, would be there for more than three years! If you really want to see the museum, allot the time. Another hard learned lesson. There was only one restroom located near the entrance (supposedly there is a second one somewhere that was closed because the museum is normally closed on Monday.) The point to be made is that if you have feel the slightest need to go, do it when you enter. It is very difficult to find your way back without going through all five of the palaces that make up this museum. The Hermitage also appeared not to be wheelchair friendly.

Beautiful but exhausting!. Loved seeing the architecture, decor and paintings. But felt like I had just brushed past everything and was mentally and physically exhausted after just a few hours. Would need to spend a week in St. Petersburg and visit it only a couple of hours per day to absorb it all.

Roller Skates Would Have Helped!. What an amazing place. There is so much art, so many rooms, so little time, really. 14 Rembrants! Our Den Rus guide kept us moving for two hours, and we barely scratched the surface. Didn't even have time to go to the main store, picked up a book in English at a corner shop so we could see what we saw!
Complete 2 day St Petersburg tour with Denrus. Magnificient, so much to see not enough time to even scratch the surface. Crowded and exhausting but well worth it

Museum at first class, endless wonders.. Very much impressive place, although it takes roughly 2-3 hrs, depends how much u want to seeof it, coz its a big place, just be aware of no big bags allowed, nor strollers for kids.carry light, we got to this place from the cruise ship located an hour away from the peterhof, just 30 mins from the harbour, so for us its just a perfect day to end a long excursion from the cruise ship started from 7.45 and back in the cruiseship at 6.30 pm, so very long day, my advice is dont bring to small kids to this excursion, its way to exhausted well at least for us.
Worth visiting. A great museum to match The Louve and The Prada.those speaking English are not well catered for or charged a large premium
wounderful collections. you need certainly a day to visit it's maybe long and ...think to the reservation by net. The collections are wounderfull but the interiors are a little bit disappointing

Museum of Grand Theft. The impressionist collection is splendid, but it wasn't so much collected as expropriated. So there's only one Utrillo and there isn't a single piece by Toulouse Lautrec. It's a huge museum and was a huge palace. Unless you're in a tour bus, the parking is half a mile away, even though there are vast empty spaces right near the building. The place is handicapped averse (one lift in a building almost the size of the Pentagon), and the stairs are formidable, but I had the sense that the Russkies rather enjoy that. Tsars, Stalinists, Putinists--they're all the same petty bureaucrats reveling in the exercise of power over the powerless. Airlines still use LED as the code for St. Petersburg,and they're' right, because Leningrad is as good a name as any.

Quite a collection and what a building!. The size of the museum is astonishing and you can spend 3 to 4 hours there and not get round it all. Personnaly I get pooped after that. In truth you may want to 'skip' some bits (like the Egyptian stuff) because there better places to see such stuff. The layout of the place is not well signposted so try to get a map when you buy your ticket. Go as early as possible to beat the rush.

Such Jaw-dropping Opulence !. This was an amazing experience and one that needs more than a few hours to appreciate - try a few years !! We wandered through great halls of gold and glitter to get to the Impressionists - my goal for this visit. I think there are about 22 rooms of Impressionists to take in. Luckily we were with a tour guide and bypassed the enormous queues and our tour guide was very knowledgeable as we wandered the vast halls. My advice is to not try to cram the whole Hermitage into one visit, isolate a few exhibitions and take a guide with you.

Possibly the best art museum in the world. Collection consistently excellent, unlike that of the Louvre, which has lots of mediocre stuff. All works are displayed at eye-level and given enough space, not stacked from floor to ceiling.
crowd heaven. go in fall as you can hardly see anything due to the massive crowds it was very dissappointing for not living up to the billing

An Art Museum in Your Home. Our visit was a part of an excursion tour. How great is it to have an art museum with a Rembrandt, a Renoir, a Rubens, and a few others in your home? Well, that's what you will see as your traverse through the palace area into the museum area and note just some of the over 1000 rooms and at least a few of the hundred or so staircases. Opulence, ornate interiors, ornate exteriors, are just a part of this a spectacular presentation of....... history.

Badly organized. The museum is -OF COURSE- beautiful, but getting in there, even with ticket bought ahead via internet, is one BIG MESS! They got to do something about this! Ridiculous to face the queues for bad information and unfriendly people, to then find out that all we had to do is pass in front of all the others, simply pushing our way through :(
A gem. An amazing place, rich in art and beauty. Arrange tickets in advance as the lines will be long with cruise and summer crowds.

Overwhelming. I loved my visit but would advise you to be focused. We followed the Lonely planet suggested route and if I could go again I would do it in reverse. By the time I got to the 3rd floor with all of its Picasso, van Gough, Cezanne etc I was exhausted and didn't enjoy it as much as I would have done if I had gone their first. The Romanov family rooms were worth the visit.

fantastic!.... We had wisited a whole day from opening to closing, need two days more. A palace with wonderfull furnitures, lambaders, rugs, and painting collection. You can see paints of L. da vinci, Rambrant, or Picasso. Russian ladies at each hole does not speak English, and not polite.

must see on anyone's life list. One of the best palaces in the world, with world-class art. To large to see in a day, but you can visit the areas that most interest you in one day.We stayed at the Rennaisance Hotel, and they have a special line so that you can skip the long line to enter the Hermitage.Food options are limited, our hotel prepared a free lunch for us to take with us....we checked it in at the cloakroom when we entered, had lunch at reasonable time, and then continued to see other parts of the museum.

Not to be missed!. Stunning collection of artwork that rivals the Louvre. The Hermitage is definitely a place to put on your must see list. Words cannot describe the variety, beauty and history of this place. Our Russian english and art major tour guide told us it would take 8 years, stopping at each piece only 8 seconds to see everything. So get a map inside and only go to the sections that you want. You can get an overview in 4 hours but all that does is whet your appetite for more.
Amazing. I loved the architecture as much as the art! There's something for everyone from portraits to paintings to sculptures to artifacts.

Stunning. Not enough time (4 hours) to do it justice? So much to see but make sure you take a small guided tour as the queues to enter were immense ( tour bypasses them). Star travel in st.petersburg are a good option.

Too much to see too little time. WE had a guided tour which lasted about 2 1/2 hours. We were taken on a specific route which was breathtaking. It would take 6 years to visit all the rooms in this museum so I suppose you are taken to what is considered to be the "tourist" rooms. I would have loved to stay longer but then would have missed the optional tour to Peterhoff. To return on another day meant queuing to get tickets-not available in advance.If you are in St Petersburg do not fail to visit The Hermitage but try and stay all day and "do your own thing" if possible then you will see the art that appeals to you rather than what the guides think you want to see.
