WOW!!!!. This museum is outstanding. There is so much to see between paintings, artifacts, sculptures, ceramics etc. One visit is not sufficent. We went twice for 4-5 hours each time and still did not see everything.
Absolutely fabulous art. The best collection of western art I have ever seen. A bit unfortunate that the lighting of the paintings is sometimes very poor.

Great museum, just avoid going there in summer. This museum has more exhibits than the world famous Louvre and it is a must-see while you are in St Petersburg. Here is a tip - avoid going there in summer because the museum HAS NO AIR CONDITIONING and can get very stuffy with thousands of tourists inside.

Truly amazing. This massive museum was the absolute highlight of my trip to SP and I would recommend the journey for the museum alone. Obviously with only 1/2 a day to spare, I could barely do it justice!
Top 5 in the world!. This is a GREAT museum that you need time, it is very big and impossible to see it all in one day, so make up your mind what you want to see
This place is huge. Come prepared. Thre are plenty of guidebooks around. MOst important: preorder entry tickets on the Web, you pay little more but skip the huge queue!!
GREAT!. Loved the variety but it was a bit overwhelming. So much good art in one place.
massive!. so much to see here, you could easily spend a day if it's your kind of thing
Wow. Any visitor to st Petersburg don't miss this museum.will need a good day or two.a must

Beautiful place to visit. Absolutely a must to be seen place in St Petersburg. All those interiors an stunning peaces of art would stay in your heart forever. There is a very long line to get in so come really early in a morning or better get online tickets.

Not enough time!. An incredible amount of wonderful art, loved the Impressionists and the pottery we saw, there really was not enough time to even make a dent in the collection. It certainly shows the opulence of the time period. I was dismayed that proper museum equipment to make sure the temperature and humidity conditions, necessary to preserve such an irreplaceable collection, was not in evidence. Both buildings and contents are international treasures.

Huge and dramatic. The setting of the collections in these wonderful buildings was as impressive as their huge scale. Does not lend itself to relaxed viewing: miles to walk, very limited English explanation, no seats other than those occupied by rather grim old ladies watching for misdemeanours. Irritating to hear our guide explain that, unlike Western museums, the collections were not created by imperialist lootings - apparently the euphemistically termed "nationalisations" by the communists is still seen as acceptable.For the informed art lover, a treasure trove indeed. For the less-skilled, a must-see tour de force but oddly disappointing as an elevating experience.

Excellent. Visiting Hermitage was my dream since my childhood. I enjoyed it during my 2-days shore excursion and I wish I could be there for the whole day, not for couple of hours.Inpressionists on the 2nd floor are really worth visiting: you can find Matisse, Picasso there
Superb exhibits, good organization!!. Like: Superb exhibits, good organization!!Dislike: nothing :8
hermitage: a must see museum. love the expositons. Deliked the poor information in english
Large. The collection is vast. Give yourself plenty of time, and unless you speak English, hire a guide. The Gold Room (Russian jewels) is a separate ticket, but worth it
Great experience wonderful art. We spent nearly the entire day in Hermitage, and still could only enjoy a fraction of the collection, but worth while to reserve time
Catherine the greats palace. Loved all the history surrounding the building, but too huge to cover in a short trip.

“The Majestic Hermitage”. “The Majestic Hermitage” review excursion around the main museum of the country for free with the Guest Card. You have a chance to visit one of the best museums of the world – the State Hermitage.The excursion introduces the history of the museum and its buildings to You, and lets You see the staterooms of the Winter Palace, Pavilion hall of the Small Hermitage and the famous Peacock Clock. Outstanding works of the greatest masters of different art schools of Western Europe are presented in the picture gallery. Collections of the monuments of Ancient Greece and Rome familiarize You with art of the Ancient World. Masterpieces of painting and sculpture are supplemented with the brilliant collection of applied art – carpets, furniture, silver, glassware, porcelain, arms, and armour.Visit Saint-Petersburg Guest card at http://www.spbguest.ru/ or our fb page: http://www.facebook.com/spbguest.ru

Interesting History- Lot too See in Little Time. This is a fantastic place....It felt more like visiting the palace of Versille in France rather than an actual museum though, because it consists of actual residences but is now housing lots of art. It is full of culture and a must see if visiting St. Petersburg.If you don't speak Russian, don't get lost!! Two Americans had their passports stolen the day before we visited.

TOO BIG. So much to see but so little time :( I guess the best thing to do is to look at the important works of art instead of spending your time reading all the descriptions because you won't have enough time!

Beautiful Building. The architecture of the winter palace and hermitage was breath taking, nice colour and the paintings in the museum was awesome especially the picture of "The Prodigal Son" The bible comes alive !

Awesome. Take at least 4 hours to tour and as large a memory card as you can. Pictures are alowed and make sure and look at the floors and ceiling they are incredible. If you like art you will love it.

How Sweet It Is!. This art museum is the most encyclopedic art museum that I have ever been to.I spent 5 full days there and I only scratched the surface.I especially liked its Baroque architectural grandeur and James Cox'awesome peacock creation.There were so many great paintings by the very famous art masters of western civilization like;Leonardo Da Vinci,Raphael.Titian,Rembrandt,Rubens,Cranach the Elder,Watteau,Monet,Renoir,and Mattisse.I also appreciated great paintings by less famous painters like;Spinello Aretino,Dujam Viskovic,Domenico Caprioli,Hieronymous Francken II,Hans Thoma,and Jacques Bellange,just to cite a few.Personal favorites were;Spinello Aretino's"Saint Benedict",Domenico Caprioli's"Portrait of a Man",Rembrandt's"Danae",Paulus Potter's"Punishment of A Hunter",Monet's"Cliff of Dieppe",Pissarro's"Boulevard Montmartre,Paris",Renoir's"Woman at Stairs",Matisse's"Music",and Ferdinand Hodler's"Lake".
I ve seen better. I m not intrested in museums. Plus i ve seen better museums like the louvre ...

Simply Amazing!. First Tip - buy your ticket online, there were ques when we got there but that was December and out of season, I imagine in warmer months it gets rammed.You use ticket desk 5 with your printed ticket and there are plenty of helpful people to guide you around.Its breathaking, some of the exhibits werent my taste but the egyptian mummy and all the Monet, Matisse and Van Gough's simply stun you, to think you can stand so close to them! We originally were going to book a two day ticket, however after reading some reviews on here went for the simply one day entry ticket and this is for everything exlcuding the gold rooms but it takes so long to get around it you can barely see everything. Defo one of the best in the world, and dont forget to look up, the staircases and ornate roofs are jaw droppingly amazing and I'm 23 I dont get excited about things like this, such a rich treasure trove in one place albeit the exterior is a bit worn.There are clean toilets and gift shops downstairs which are possibly a lot cheaper than the shops outside of it for gifts.Defo go, it has something for everyone.

Must see. Must see. However, it can get really really crowded. In the morning all people from cruises rush in and it really spoils experience. Some paintings are hard to get to. Try to go later in the day.

Very impressive! Not to be missed.. Beautiful palace with gorgeous works of art. Very crowded in the summer months. Fortunately, Allatours provided early admission to the Hermitage before it was open to the general public.

Get a private guide. By hiring a private guide--bingo, no queues.Our guide was a professor who taught English, very knowledgable,certainly knew the hermitage's evry nook and cranny.Also, great for the palace and several churches.She was well worth the investment.

Amazing even for non-art lovers. I wouldn't call myself an art lover but even I had a great time here. There are so many pictures from such a variety of artists, I could've spent days looking around. I also liked seeing all of the portraits of the Tsars and the rooms where they spent their time. We spent the whole afternoon here and only saw the main bits (though that was long enough for my aching feet and back).
Impressive Museum. One of the most impressive building and art collection I`ve ever seen in my life. You can feel the history in every inch of the site.
For art lovers. Amazing amount of art from all the famous artists in the world. Be careful to book enough time for this visit!!!
Stuffed full of treasures. Two days just gets you started. Don't miss the treasure room. My fave was the art deco knick knacs. Wow.

Spend Hours and Look and Walk and Look and Walk and .... Truly awe inspiring and totally awesome! So many works of incredibly important and beautiful art -- not to mention the gorgeous palace and its stairways, rooms, halls, etc. themselves. The jewels etc. in the special Treasure Rooms are worth the extra cost to see, if you can get in, most especially if you can get the last-minute bargain deal.

Unbelievable. If you think it will take a day to see everything, allow two. Two days, allow four. It's all been said before, but the range and quality of exhibits is amazing. Being allowed to take photographs of anything is also a first. Don't understand this as at the Peterhof, an extraordinary grand palace held together by pozidrive screws, photography was not allowed.
Indulgence in art. The variety, the richness the exposure to so many great in art

Great if you are an Art and History Perason. Very Busy and you need a lot of time depending on your interests, better to go before the end of June they say, some people say they could spend days going thru it.
The Hermitage. Not only is the art world class, but you are also walking through an incredible palace with amazing architecture and beautiful floors, walls, and ceilings.
Must see. a very big collection of fine art and historic place, it's fully restored palace is a must see , you hardly find something like this anywhere else
Beautiful in and outside.. I liked the European art (there is more European than Russian art). And the buildings are beautifully painted.
very good building and collections. the museum is wonderful but the management is very bad

Wonderful museum and art gallery. Fantastic location, impressive palace rooms and amazing art. Shame that some of the art is so poorly displayed with poor lighting. Quite unusual in that photos are allowed. The extra option of visiting the royal jewellery was good but the guide's English was hard to understand and we were hurried through at too fast a pace. The authorities seem quite casual about security and people getting close to the paintings.
Amazing Hermitage!. I looked at only a section of this museum and spent 4 hours there!
Magnificent collection of art. Although major reconstructions were all around the place (square and some halls in the Ermitage), it was still a nice visit.
the most beautiful museum in the world. inside and outside. A little bit depressing that they have more dutch paintings than we have at home

Fantastic in the off season - get there early for empty rooms of Picassos. We went to St Petersburg in Early November, which was fantastic. Not too cold (5-8 degrees) and not so busy. We went to the Hermitage on a Sunday. It opens at 10:30 and we were a little slow that morning, so got there at 10:45. Queued for 10 mins and then in. Make sure you leave you coats at the free cloakroom.Also if like us and most people you are most interested in the French/Spanish 19th/20th century paintings, then my tip would be to go up the stairs to the 2nd floor, and instead of following the crowd straight on, instead turn right and right again and walk down long corridor. If you follow this route and the map you can go straight to the 3rd floor and then through to the last Picasso room. We got there at 11:15 and there was only the Babushka sitting there. We saw Picassos, Degas, Monet, Matisse all in virtually empty rooms. After 45 mins the crowds started coming through from the main route, and by then we had seen our highlights. Took a while to then find the Kandinsky but don't miss these. We then spent the next couple of hours enjoying the building and other rooms, and actually only stayed 3.5 hours. Enough for my wife and I without being too knackered. When we left the crowds were busier and queues for 30 mins plus I'd guess.This is the MUST see thing in St Petersburg

The best gallery and museum in Russia. There are no words to say how many precious things of art are kept in Hermitage. Must see. Please don’t expect you are able to see everything in one day. If you have only 2-3 of hours – just choose 1-2 topics you would like to see, e.g. Dutch art and French art 17-18 centuries. And keep 20 minutes just to walk around the building to enjoy interiors where they are saved or restored.
Not without a guide for your first trip. After a first visit with a guide, I would comee back to explore the Hermitage individually. October was a good month as there were fewer tourists
Opulant & exquiste. need a guide to get the most out your vsit, too much to see in one visit or digest, luckily as part of our tour we had an excellent rusian guide

Extraordinary art and architecture. This fabled place is almost a glut to the eye. Because there is far more than can be taken in on a canned, rushed and crowded tour, I recommend spending as many hours as possible discovering the Hermitage on one's own. Everything is very clearly labeled in English and one can avoid the crowds at the most famous paintings with just a bit of patience. The serious art buff will wish to spend most of an entire day, while others will find a full afternoon satisfactory. The guided tours are primarily for those with only a passing interest in art and architecture and limited time. But it is hard to be rushed through rooms laden with treasures while seeing only 10% of them.

One word - WOW. I had limited time in Russia and I thought I would just take a quick stroll through for an hour but ended up staying for 5 hours until we were kicked out. The conserved rooms are delightful, ornate and opulent. You can really imagine the wealth that Russian royalty flaunted in those days. The art is dwarfed by the rooms that house them and so I find myself distracted by the intricate detail of the Palace. It is a maze so I highly recommend you get a map prior to going in. You can buy them inside but they aren't very good. Expect long waiting lines to get in. If you go in a group tour, you can go in more quickly as they have a separate entrance.Photography is allowed inside in most rooms but some will have signs that clearly show you cannot. The view outside from within the Museum is very nice too if you can draw your attention away from everything else!

The Ermitage is the Ermitage!. Huge, but the map will help you a lot! Worths to get the photography ticket, evene if nobody checked it! Many art-surprises, like the section of the caucasian and siberian art, very rare objects that you usually cannot find in western museums.For improving the service they could offer free wi-fi and applications to visit the collection with iphone or smart phone.
one of the richest museum of the world. Must see!!!!!! Ich time, when you come in Hermitage, you see new detail (pictures, sculptures and other arts)

Not just for art lovers. We are not art lovers, but there was no chance we were going to miss the chance to see the Winter Palace, and also one of the most famous museums in the world. The entryway alone is worth the price of admission, and walking thorugh this museum gives you a sense of russian history. We had a spectacular engligh speaking guide who made the whole experience so much better for us. She knew the Hermitage like the back of her hand, was very passionate about art, and the works in the museum, and was able to show us around, made sure we saw the key pieces, and had a wealth of insight. We had a great visit here, and I can't imagine anyone visiting St. Petersburg, and not visiting the Hermitage Museum.

A building to match the size and grandeur of Russia.. I visited the gallery with a Russian tour company. Our excellent guide gave us a tour for jover two hours that gave a broad picture of both the history and the art contained therein. The number of paintings is so vast that a guide or very careful homework is needed to gain maximum value and pleasure from this world class attraction. My personal two favourite attractions were the peacock clock and the painting by Rembrandt, 'the prodigal son,' such a symbolic painting. a good guide will have many stories about the royal family as well. I have mobility problems and was warned that Russia was difficult for the disabled but not here. My guide organised the lift without difficult and the improvised ramps wre excellent.
Outstanding. The volume and quality of works of art on display was overwhelming

A great selection of paintings. The key to visiting the Hermitage is to have your tickets in advance. Also it is worth paying for the audio guide. It is a such a big museum that you could end up walking around aimlessly if you don't have a plan. Take time to research it in advance and get a floor plan when you arrive.
wonderfull palace. amazing palace,richness on the beach, a protected palace
Hermitage - pace yourself!. We pinpointed what we wanted to see and concentrated on those places and enjoyed them very much - to try to see everything would be impossible!
Impressive. Dont miss one of the best museums in the world!111

Magnificant city, beautiful architecture.. I would encourage anyone visiting St Petersburg to spend time in the Hermitage, especially The Winter Palace. Even if you are not interested in the art contained within it, the building itself takes your breath away, especially the sweeping marble staircase.The bookshop within is expensive so I would suggest you buy the book outside the building for less than half the price, lots of traders are available.The other highlight of our trip was The every day St Petersburg excursion, all the main sights were visited and the icing on the cake was travelling on the metro underground, the decor of the stations is very interesting. Part of the tour was a visit to a Russian orthodox church, on the day we visited there was an open coffin with the family in attendance, apparently this is a usual occurance but not something we are used to and could be quite disturbing to some visitors.
The best one !!. the marvellous work of art at the museum needs couple of visits before you can absorb it. do buy the paintings at the museum shop.

Almost overwhelming, but .... First, decide in advance what you want to see, because if you don't, you will possibly spend a whole week wandering around aimlessly, seeing plenty that you didn't know existed, some of which will be very interesting, but in the end you will miss the most interesting.Second, when you arrive, look for the monitor screen just beyond the entrance desk/ticket check. Using the monitor screen you can locate each item of interest, and add it to your personal itinerary. When finished, you can get the system to work out the route you need to follow to see your chosen items ... (drum roll) and then you can have a print-out of your itinerary, including a sheet of explanation on each item and a map to show the route you need to follow!I have visited the Hermitage many times, and this facility is the single most valuable modern addition - don't go in without it!

Crowded and overwhelming even in late October. Waited in line as tour groups got to go in ahead and saw several Russians who tried to cut the line and were incredulous that they had to go to the back of the line. And it was crowded once we got inside, so perhaps I started off with a bad attitude but I found the Hermitage too big and overwhelming. Yes, it is an amazing museum with great collections, thus the very good rating, but for a casual art fan, the Russian museum was more enjoyable, both for the art and the atmosphere.
good history. Lots of info but very large. They want to you to pay to take pictures but no one does and they still take pictures

Hermitage Museum entrance policy. The entrance ticket for the day does not allow multiple entries during the day. So, be sure to stay in the musuem until you are ready to leave. Very small cafes serve the most minimal refreshments and there are no restaurants in the museum. We made a mistake of leaving the museum to have a substantial lunch and a break but to our surprise, our ticket was good only for a one time entry. New experience for us as all the major museums we have seen in the world allow for multiple entries on the day a ticket was purchased.One of the tourists outside the museum mentioned that there is a sign stating admission policy that was in English but she agreed that it was easy to miss. For 400 rubles, I would expect more than one entry during the day.
Impressive !. Don't come too early in the morning when all tours get there.Lunch time is a better option

Immense and amazing. This was such a treat. Could have spent all day there not wearing. As it was we took in the main collection had a lovely lunch and retunred to look at the painitings. My favorites were the Matisses. WoW!

Awesome. Two days wasn't nearly enough time for this. Expect crowds around the Impressionists, enjoy the Da Vinci's on your own.Book via internet before you get there to avoid the lines. You pay extra, but life's too short.
A must. A must and don't forget to take in the additional diamond and gold tours.
too much to see in just one day. Spend lots of time in the rooms that show the early painters; the Impressionists were okay, but better in France and NYC

overwhelming collection. We had only a couple of hours in the Ermitage and really felt that it would be worthwhile to have more time at hand. A tour guide is highly recommended, otherwise one risks missing beautiful exhibits. And I don’t remember any explanatory labels in English. – Spending so much time inside, don’t forget to walk around the wonderful buildings!
Impressive. Lots to see. Make up your mind in advance what you want to see.
Museum of great arts. Rembrandt and Leonardo da Vinci's paintings were magnificent as well as French impresionest paintings.

A Crowded 10+ Site To Visit. We had a wonderful tour guide; I'd be overwhelmed trying to visit on my own. I'd get there right when it opens to avoid the later crush of tour buses, some areas - da Vinci, for example - were so packed it was impossible to see much of anything. You can't bring in large purses or coats so leave them on the bus - as warned - or you'll have to wait to check them. You don't need coats or jackets inside anyway - it's warm enough! I was hesitant as to where I would fine good amber jewelry on the trip; the Hermitage gift shop had a wonderful, unique selection at fair prices. I'm very pleased with my purchases.

#1 in the world collection by Rembrandt. Pros: This museum contains the most paintings in the world by Rembrandt. Even Rijksmuseum has fewer. Cons: Some items of the exposition lack any tags. I overheard some foreigners asking the guard what the items were about and she said the staff could not keep up with making up the tags, let alone the stories behind all the items of the exposition. Their windows need some serious repainting. It’s a major overhaul – there are a lot of windows.

One of the top in the world. It was mid October so the place wasn't crowded. We spent 6 hours there and didn't finish. A world class museum and the palace as a bonus. You can buy 1 or 2 day tickets online and not wait. There is so much art, sculpture, gold and the grandiose. Incredible!

One of the best collections in the world. We loved the extraordinary collections exposed that have the advantage of being concentrated in a single place. We hated the poor and very inefficient organisation of the tickets office and obviously did not like to pay the double of a Russian citizen for exactly the same tickets. You waste an enormous amount of time just to get into the museum in spite of paying the double of a Russian citizen.

Absolutely Wonderful Experience. I visited the place during late summer which I think the best time to visit because of lesser crowd. Although I have been to St. Petersburg many times before on cargo vessels (Which I’m employed) never really found some spare time to visit the place. Finally came my day – a day with heavy rain pouring in!! Since no cargo operations were possible, finally managed to go ashore and found my way to Baltiyskaya Metro station and got down from Nevsky Prospekt Metro station. It is the closest Metro station which the Hermitage is just a 10 minute walk from there.Arrived at winter place square around 10 am and had to wait about 20 minutes in the ticket queue. Ticket cost was 400 Roubles for the whole complex and borrowed an audio guide which the cost was 350 Roubles along with a map of the complex. From then on it’s just an amazing experience. The halls, paintings, sculptors and artifacts were simply awe inspiring and indescribable. I didn’t rush through the halls so only managed to see the ground floor of the complex and a small section of the upper floor during the whole day! I think you need at least 2 full days if you want to see it properly. Most of the museum staff was helpful although there was a language barrier. You just have to ask Davinci, Raphael or any other famous name or place –they just direct you to the place.Thanks to all reviewers I was able to plan my trip early. Overall it was a great experience. Suggest visiting the place during late summer on a weekday, and if it is raining you should be able to have the museum to yourself!!
Best art collection I've ever seen. The art collection is one of the most extensive and impressive I have ever seen.
Overwhelming!. This is a huge place. We spend an entire day here and it still wasn't enough; although we were exhausted. We also did the Gold and Diamond rooms; really liked the Diamond room.

Impressive palace.. I enjoyed this more for its architecture as a palace than for its art, which is wonderful. (You must realize, I'm from New York and have been to the MET, the Prado, the Louvre, National Gallery London, National Gallery Washington, DC, Art Institute of Chicago, etc. many times each). I don't mean to sound jaded, but after a while my eyes and brain can only concentrate on so many paintings at once. For me the standout was the building. Worth the price of admission all by itself. Would return to see it again, and probably give the art works their due.
Unforgettable. THE museum! Amazing quantity of fabulous art works from everywhere in the world and form any age. Need more than one day to visit.

Quite a museum and a MUST visit. This is a great museum and it is huge! It is worth to take a day to visit is and enjoy the views from the museum. If you are a student, don;t forget to take your student card, as it will get you there free of charge. The furniture rooms are exquisite and the crystal room as well! As not all the rooms have translations to other languages, you might as well get an audio guide.

A stunning tour. Absolutely stunning sums it up. The site is relatively quiet so you get to tour it unhindered. Provision of free cloackrooms is good given as most people have thick coats & its warm indoors, where

Buying a ticket online really helped. Just wanted to say that buying the ticket online (at the Hermitage web site) really helped. You print out a voucher. When I showed it to the woman at the information desk she cut in front of the entire line and I would up with my tickets in a few minutes. You do have to show your passport. I think it was 2 dollars more but worth it.Other than that, the only thing that I have to say is that you should allocate 2 hours a day for 2 days to really see the place and even then you'll leave feeling that you missed a lot.

Delightful!. The Hermitage is a fabulous place to spend a day while in St. Petersburg. One of the biggest museums in the world, with a great collection of painting, it is situated in Winter Palace – an ex-residence of Russian tsars. As you step on the front staircase you're surrounded by luxury. The splendour of its design is overwhelming. If you are a single visitor and dislike excursions, get a map at the entrance and choose the halls you'd like to see: Rembrandt, impressionists, Flemish painters, it’s your preference. Don’t dream of exploring the whole museum – it is huge! The collection of Italian painting alone occupies 30 rooms, not less than in the Accademia Galleries in Venice, it seems to me. The Hermitage can boast of housing renowned masterpieces: Leonardo’s Madonna Litta, Titian’s Danae, Matisse’s Dance and dozens more; so, roam around and delight in art!Tip: Before visiting the Hermitage get an idea of what it’s like on their site.
A Must. What an incredible treasure house - full of old masters etc. The restored buildings are sumptious but tinged with thoughts of their recent sad past.
Magnificent. So much to see and absorb. You need a guide or an audio guide to make the most of yor visit. Try not to see too much at once or you will be exhausted!
Amazing building and art collection. the Hermitage was everything we expected and much more! Fantastic rooms, incredible art collection.....

spectacular and beyond all expectations. Order tickets on line to avoid waiting in long lines.The Impressionist paintings were so numerous, one's head swims.Beautiful Rembrants painting.There are over 3 million exhibits. It is wise to spend at least 2 visits at the Hermitage.

Great Place. This is a world class are museum & palace, cant miss it if you are a history or/and art lover. We went on 30-Sep, there is a small queue at the ticket box but can get the ticket in 10 mins. The problem is many local people jump the queue and make it an annoying experience.We arrived at around 11am and leave when the museum close at 5pm.There are 2 cafes there sell basic sandwiches, pastries and cake. We had some pastry there and taste is nice, with normal tourist price.

Gorgeous & sweeping museum. When I travel to a city, I always try to visit various museums concering (modern) art, history, fauna, tradition, cuisine etc. In this manner, I visited several museums in different cities(I haven't seen famous Louvre yet) Hermitage is the best museum I have ever seen!

Sensory overload. To read about the Hermitage does not prepare you for the overall majesty of the building or the collections within. We just rocked up and bought a ticket with not much of a problem but suggest you go early. Coats deposited at left luggage free of charge (heavens!) and an electronic guide is available at a reasonable charge. Would suggest you take five minutes to plan the must see collections or you could end up like those Japanese soldiers lost on pacific islands such is the scale of the place, be aware also of the all seeing baboushkas who guard the rooms because daring to slump against a window sill will bring them to their feet. The exibitions are just mind blowing and a history of the world unravels before you as you progress through this building. If you go to only one museum in your life - make it this one - if you see only one Russian building in your life - make it this one, a whole nations history is writ large in the echoing corridors and the splendour of the Hermitage and its environs

Spectacular but unbelievably crowded. This museum is unlike anything I have seen in the United States. Our museums tend to have white walls to highlight the art work. At the Hermitage, the rooms of the museum are as gorgeous or more gorgeous than the art work itself. Spectacular chandeliers, golden columns, wooden art floors. Good thing the rooms are so beautiful because when we were there (on a cruise tour) it was so crowded you could never get close to much of the art work, and couldn't hesitate to look at it. The new system of 'walky talkies' so you only quietly hear your own guide is great. That helps keep the noise level manageable. Try to find a way to go on your own at some time when the tour groups are not there. Surprisingly, you can take video and photos, which is not true at some other places in St. Petersburg.

One of the world's top museums. This former palace of the tzars has around 22 miles of exhibit space and supposedly the largest collections of paintings in the world. We went with a private guide for a couple of hours to get in ahead of the long lines and to get the lay of the land. Then we continued for another four hours on our own going back to rooms and items we wanted to spend time with. The public rooms of the tzars are over-the-top in opulence, and the collection of art, begun by Catherine the Great, is overwhelming. We studied in advance what pictures and areas we wanted most to see so that when we left, we'd have something to remember beyond a blur of images. Tour groups all cluster around major paintings such as the Rembrandts, so you may want to choose some lesser ones to spend time with. Or, go early before it gets too crowded.

Off season. Go in the off season. We had most rooms to ourselves. Just us and the guard. The winter palace in winter is the only way to go. The lights were magical. No lineups, no crowds and we took in the art that was highlited on the brochure as we did not have a lot of time.
Sensory Overload. This building is a piece of art in itself. Your attention was drawn to the art, the walls, the floors, the ceilings. What to look at was mind-boggling.

A vast museum catering to all tastes that needs careful planning. The huge Hermitage lives up to it's reputation as a vast museum full of many thousands of years of exhibits all housed in the opulent winter palace - itself worth a look.A few tips:- As others have commented, plan your visit and work out what you want to see in advance. You could easily spend a whole day and still not cover it all.- Use the ticket machine outside, the queues to pay at a ticket desk, especially at weekends, can be 30+ minutes. But be warned they don't give change and if you want photo tickets with your admission ticket, you can't combine the purchase.- Some of the galleries are poorly lit, principally those rooms facing the outside, making it difficult to view some exhibits when you're fighting with bright sunshine.

Simply unrivalled anywhere. This is a spectacular site.It would takes days and days to go through so plan what you wnat to see.There were no lines when we went and the museum was not filled at all. The treasures in here really fit any interest. It is a remarkable collection and a visit to this city MUST include this site.All the positive things you ahve heard and read are true!

High Quality 2-day Shore Excursion in St Petersburg. Just a quick review to recommend Alla Tours (www.alla-tour.com) with whom we had a great experience - we were delighted with the quality and value for money they offered, and would recommend them to others with hesitation The pre-tour instructions Alla provided were timely and very accurate There was no need for Visas and the system for greeting us was smooth and swift: from leaving the ship to being on the tour minibus (about 14 people in total) took about 20 minutes of which 15 was queuing at passport control! Our guide Valentina was simply superb – excellent English, great sense of humour, encyclopaedic knowledge, with an ‘interesting’ view of Russian History - past and present Day 1 was packed and fantastic and as described on the itinerary. The Hermitage and a trip into the Underground system highlights. We also chose to go to the Marinsky Ballet as an ‘add on’ on the evening of Day 1- again arranged by Alla tours. We were the only couple to do this. Again the arrangements were faultless and smooth. In the evening a Taxi was waiting for us just beyond passport control, it took us to the Ballet where we picked up tickets and were guided to our seats and then the taxi was there immediately after the performance to take us back to the ship. The Ballet itself was simply superb – a real highlight of many highlights of St Petersburg. We would recommend it very highly as an essential ‘add on’ – so much better we understand than the ballet ‘events’ offered by cruise liners. Day 2 started with paying for the 2 day visit and the Ballet (payable by credit card or cash) and then a full itinerary as described in the brochure. Peterhof is breathtaking. Another brilliant day All in all we cannot recommend this Alla Tour programme too highly – it delivers exactly what it promises and it is excellent value for money. We hope you enjoy it as much as we did  Kate & Arthur, Notts, England

Utterly magnificent and unmissable.. This museum is simply one of, if not, THE best in the World. You could spent months here and not get bored. Last week I spent 5 incredibly pleasurable hours wandering through the palatial state rooms, the breathtaking art collections, and the fascinating lower level treasures. I've never been anywhere quite like it, and in this readers humble opinion, it eclipses the Louvre, Prado and Uffizi. If you come to St Petersburg, do not miss this ! Stunning.

most beautiful royal palace in the world. I visited all the main royal palaces in Western Europe and I can say,without hesitation,that the Winter Palace is the most beautiful and luxurious royal palace in the world. It is simply BREATHTAKING , OUT of THIS WORLD and BEYOND WORDS !

Beautiful, fascinating place - not to be missed. It was pouring with rain when we visited, but it made no difference to our enjoyment of the place. Unlike in some of the smaller palaces, we didn't feel we were being hurried through and had masses of time to enjoy the magnificent rooms and exhibits. We were also allowed to take photos in all parts of the palace. Having seen the main Classical exhibits - both paintings and sculptures - we had time to nip upstairs to glory in the fantastic collection of Impressionist paintings and to photograph them and go right up to them, unheard of in many other similar places. The shops are well stocked and not too outrageously expensive and the toilet facilities clean and modern. All in all, a marvellous experience.

Wonderful trip. Went on a Viking River Cruise from St. Petersburg to Moscow. Weather not wonderful but the trip was pure magic and would recommend all buildings etc. All fees for palaces etc. were included in our fare

Awe Inspiring. If you are only going to be in town a short time start with the 2 hour overview tour and prepare to be overwhelmed. You will learn a lot that you won't get from walking around on your own. You will walk through many richly decorated rooms. The wall decorations are magnificent created by true craftsman. There are rooms filled with art objects which you won't have time to truly take in. If you have time come back again to spend more time in one or two areas. Don't forget to look down and admire the floor, it really is inlaid wood and is withstanding the abuse of thousands of feet every day.

Stunning art, architecture and crowds. We visited the Hermitage in May, 2011 as part of a full day tour package. Spent about 4 hours at the museum which was not nearly enough time to see everything. Stunning art works and architecure along with absolutely stunning crowds. At some museums you will see one or two paintings by famous artisits (e.g. Matisse, Cezanne, Picasso) but at the Hermitage you will see rooms full of each artists works!! Very difficult to get close to many attractions due to the crowds but absollutely a must see when you are in St Petersburg. There is no air conditioning so beware in the summer time as it can be very hot due to the crowds and lack of air circulation.
Amazing. As beautyful as El Louvre in Paris. It has a huge art collection as well as works from Rembrant.

Overwhelming amount to see - a guide is essential if you have limited time. You could spend several days here and see only a fraction of it. We used a guide from spb-tours.com and she not only knew the history and story behind many of the pieces but how to circulate us to the more important ones first. She also got us directly in, bypassing the queue which went well down the street. This tour company provided more flexible options than did Denrus, and we were very happy with them. As someone else commented, I was surprised to see artwork by the masters with little or no protection around it. I liked it actually, that I could get right near a Rembrandt and examine it with nothing in between us. Hermitage is the top-rated St Petersburg site for a reason. It is that good. But all of the top 4 are excellent, and all are "must not miss" sites. If you are not into artwork, the other 3 would come higher on your list.

You need more than 1 hour to see this place. Our guide gave us the 1 hour tour of the Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace of Peter the Great. Even in that short time, we saw so many amazing and beautiful pictures and things such as Russian Icons from the 15th century, original Da Vinci of the Madonna, the Gold room where the walls are hung in gold relief; the Red Boudoir room of Catherine the great where she could receive people and lovers if she wanted to; Roman mosaics, rooms full of Greek Sculpture etc. Our guide said to fully see all the exhibits in the Winter Palace would take 7 years of walking it daily.

A Must See while in St. Petersburg. Order tickets on-line. Go tot he kiosk right inside the Hermitage gates to print your ticket. Bypass the long queue to the right as ticket holders don't stand in line. Arrive early to beat the tour group crowd. Don't start in room 1 as the cattle follow the herd, take a right at the top of the stairs and begin in another section you will be glad you did.

Overwhelming. I expected the Hermitage to be huge but was not prepared for the sheer size of the place. So much to see but not enough time and too many people. Very stern attendants in every room. They haven't quite figured out how to manouver all the visitors through this magnificent museum. There are people coming from all sides. By now a lot of places have figured out a one way system for navigating through museums, huge art exhibits etc. so maybe it will happen here also. Some fantastic artwork, a privilege to see it. Buy small souvenirs inside the museum as opposed to the outrageously expensive souvenir shops the guides bring you to.

Great Tour in St. Petersburg. We were on a cruise ship visiting St. Petersburg for two days. We looked into the cost of the ship's tours and decided to use the services of "www.Denrus.RU" We were a party of four, and customized their standard Family Tour. We had a wonderful guide and driver. When we got to any attraction, our guide would take a look at where most of the people were headed and she would take us in the other direction. We were able to see a lot more than some of our fellow travelers but saw all the same things they did, just in a different order. The vehicle we traaveled in was clean and the driver courteous and helpful. Outr guide was able to recommend restaurants to stop at and souvenir shops that also had spotless restrooms. We would use this tour company, without any doubt.
Everything I expected. Incredible art. Was a bit shocked by lack of security and humidity/lighting/climate controls. However, a must-see and does not disappoint.
Outstanding. Visited Heritage. It was as great as promised. You need to allow as much time as possible for your visit.

Complete opulance throughout. After traveling to many destinations the past few years we have come to expect some rather interesting things to see on our vacations-St. Petersburg did not disappoint in this regards. . The palaces were incredible to visit and more than captivated everyone but once you step back and actually think about the way people must have been treated to get to this, it is almost disqusting. St. Petersburg and the Hermitage Museum were off the charts ifabulous, as were the other palaces we visited, as well as some of the churches-highly recommend this trip to everyone. BUT-be prepared for some stunning revalations about the Tsars and their wealth and their disregard for human dignity. The city of St. Petersburg was one of the best places we have been to yet it is also a place to appreciate what you have earned on your own. A dicotomy of terms, if you will. Go if you get the chance, the Hermitage is an eye opening experience for all.

Comparable to the Louvre.. Breathtakingly beautiful museum on the banks of the Neva River in beautiful St. Petersburg, Russia. Best to go in Summer, but you can expect long lines to enter, unless you're willing to surreptitiously tip a guard for a quick entrance. If lines are too long for your liking then The Russian Museum is an excellent second choice, never a line to enter. If you go to The Russian Museum stop by the Lazy Dog Cafe, a five minute walk from the museum, a basement restaurant and outdoor cafe, good food, drinks, atmosphere.

Amazing........it doesn't get better than this.. It's worth walking in after lunch.....no queues. A perfect time for a first look around. To do justice to the Hermitage you really need a few days but for a short trip, concentrate on what most interests you, perhaps the main state rooms and, say, the stunning modern art. Don't forget that other palace where Rasputin had his last ever meal....also a must, as is the ballet.

Breathtaking..... From the entrance you will be with your mouth open...So much gold,treαsures all over, paintings from the most world famous painters and so much more...You will need days to see them all.The usual touristic round is about 3-4 hours. If you dont go to this museum you haved see enything....

Amazing experience. The Hermitage is truly a spectacular art collection, in a former incredible and beautiful palace. This is the second time I have visited this museum and it still was an amazing experience and it was the same way I felt when I first visited here 37 years ago. I was so impressed the first time I was here, I have always wanted to return and experience it again. When I was here 37 years ago, St Petersburg(Leningrad at the time) was a very different place and a very interesting experience. Things have changed and it was very nice this time that one can take more time to visit this museum and do it at your own pace. On this visit we got to the museum when the doors opened in the morning and had the place to our selves for a couple of hours before to got crowed. Many of the other TA reviews give a lot of good insight about this museum without me repeating things. So if you ever get a change to visit St Petersburg, the Hermitage is not to be missed.

Worth seeing but don't go in the tourist season. Worth seeing. As a foreigner in Russia you will pay more than Russians. You can buy tickets online as we did but when we got there we were sent from one ticket window to another when we thought having pre bought tickets would be faster than waiting in line. It was total chaos with many Chinese tourists and many tour groups. You could not enjoy looking around the museum as it was packed and very unpleasant with too many people. There are only toilets on the ground floor and one slow lift. In Russia the tourist experience is a hit and miss affair and often badly organized. However do see the Hermitage off season it is beautiful as is St Petersburg.

The Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace 2-Day Combination Tour. Trip to The State Hermitage Museum was an amazing experience. Since we anticipated that one day is not enough so we purchased a 2-Day combination ticket on-line. The advantage you don't need to queue outside particularly when its raining there is no roof. What we were not aware is that the combination ticket will allow you to visit the Hermitage Museum only in Day-1 and in Day-2 it is for the Peter the Great's Winter Palace (next to Hermitage) very small and nothing interesting to see except his dinning room + Menshsinkov Palace (long walk) but there are few interesting things to see (also a small area) and a porcelain factory (which is far away) that we did not bother to visit. Lucky during our vacation the State Hermitage is open to public for free every first Thursday of a month. So we went back and completed all the remaining galleries that we missed in Day-1. At least it was a consolation for what we paid for day-2 that we think is not worth-it.

Simply Excellent.. What can I say by way of praise that has not been already said here? Tremendous art museum with probably the finest collection of old masters I have seen anywhere in the world. Personally I like the religious paintings and the portraiture not so much the impressionists as the previous reviewer mentions but they are there also. Our guide was excellent and this is really an essential thing to have to avoid as many queues as possible, although when you are talking about seeing the big names, Rembrandt, Da Vinci, Rubens and so on, queues are a little inevitable. They say to do about 2 hours in one go here and that's a good idea, anymore and you stop really looking. Please bear in mind it's going to get really warm in here, theres no AC and a lot of people, and it's a good idea to buy a guidebook, if for nothing else than they have decent pictures of some of the main paintings as you cannot photograph these. Make sure you go here if your in the city.

The Impressionists paintings are not to be missed! ...and other notes. I was pleased to see in a review below that the Impressionist painting are still there. I saw them in 1995ish shortly after they were discovered or at least taken out of crates and put on view. The colors the Impressionists used were exquisite. To see them fresh as they were painted was one of the great treats of all my travels. I realize that we are now 15 years out and I seriously doubt that they are being taken care of as well as they deserve, but if you are in St. Petersburg and don't visit, your soul has lost a chance to soar. They are breathtaking.Search for a small restaurant behind the circular parade grounds behind the Hermitage and Palace. Ask around for the restaurant the Alexander Pushkin had his last supper/lunch? in before he went to his death in a senseless duel.Third note: It's worth the effort to try to make your trip during the Silver or White Nights--around the Summer Solstice in July. It's a big thing for the citizens and they stroll along the Neva and wait for the bridges to all be opened. It's been going on a long time and they are quite proud of their traditions and their city. Many of those who suffered during the seige of Leningrad are gone, but you'll see some who remember it well as children. I hope you meet some.

One of the Outstanding Museums of the World. This is truly one of the greatest collections out there in the world. It is worth visiting St. Petersburg just for this.
Because the place is so huge, I recommend taking at least 2-3 half-days. Also try to visit the separate gold and diamond collection rooms.

Prob a must, if you've come this far. If you're an experienced traveler who enjoys museums as just a part of the itineray you'll find this to be subpar when it comes to a city's/nation's pre-eminent museum. No comparison to top-flight options elsewhere in the world. If you're hardcore about your museums or Russian history, you'll like think it great. That said, you're here so you've got to take a stroll thru. Just don't expect it to be the Louve, Met, etc

Palace and square - breathtaking. The Museum is large...very large...the largest!And the square in front of it is stunningly breathtaking, specially if you arrive early (or late) when it's practically empty. And you walk and walk and walk until you finally get to the entrance. Inside it's a maze, could spend a week in there. No picture taking mostly...

A must!. The Hermitage itself is worth a trip to Sankt Petersburg. The palace is beautiful with its characteristic green facade, and the collection is breathtaking! They should organize the pictures better, but the intrinsic value of the collection is anyway extraordinary.It is worth the long queue you have to face!

Visiting The Hermitage. Visiting the Hermitage can be daunting. It contains enough art work that it would take you ten years to see everything, if you looked at each piece of art for one minute. The lines are long, the museum is crowded beyond belief, the art, for the most part, is poorly displayed. That said, it is the most beautiful museum in the world, with one of the best collections.Buying tickets at the museum is a bad idea. For a little bit extra, you can buy tickets on line at the museum’s web site. More on that later. To buy tickets on site, you have two choices, queuing up for a manned ticket window or buying the tickets from the machine just as you enter. The latter is the best choice here. You need to have 400 rubles in 100 ruble bills to use the machine. The line here is much shorter.If you buy tickets on line there are a few things you should know. You can buy one or two day tickets. Two day tickets must be used on consecutive days. If you are buying tickets for someone other than yourself—you must place a separate order as you must show ID that matches your voucher. You take the voucher to a special ticket window. You queue up in a very short line to the right of the long line. You present your voucher and then you get your ticket(s). You can use a copy of your passport as an ID. It sounds easy but in Russia, nothing is easy.Firstly, if you buy more than one two day ticket, it can confuse them. I purchased two, two day tickets. When I arrived at the counter, the ticket seller was flummoxed. She couldn’t understand that I wanted two, two day tickets. I also made the mistake of asking for my wife’s one, two day ticket package. This whole Abbott and Costello routine took almost thirty minutes to sort out. I was told that I could only get one pair of tickets. She took my voucher and gave me two tickets. However, the voucher listed two, two day tickets. If I hadn’t printed out a spare voucher, I would have been out of luck. By the time I got upstairs, in the Renaissance rooms, it was packed. More on that later.I went two days in a row, took off a day to see Peterhof, and returned with wife in tow for my second two day sojourn through the museum. After showing my voucher, to the very same ticket seller, I was told that I had already picked up all the tickets. Through my broken Russian I explained that she herself told me that I could not pick up all the tickets. I watched her play with her computer for about twenty minutes and she led me to a ticket counter where they printed out all my tickets, including the ones I had already used. Since we headed to the third floor that day, the museum was not overly crowded. Keep in mind that if you use a two day voucher it may take some time to get in on the first day, but on the second day, you have your ticket in hand and can run up the Jordan Staircase at 10:30 AM when the museum opens. This is what I did on the second day. More on that later. I had planned four, four hour trips to the Hermitage. To try to see this museum in one day is ill advised for a true art aficionado. If you just want to see the State Rooms, The Davinicis, and a few other highlights, one day is fine. This just wouldn’t work for me and I didn’t want to spend eight hours in the museum as I had done in The Louvre, two summers before. I ended up only going for three days, about four hours each day. Luckily my hotel, The Pushka Inn, was two minutes from the Hermitage. It’s a hotel that is perfectly located, has a great restaurant, and the most helpful staff I have ever encountered. Naturally, I had to see the Davincis and the Michelangelo as soon as I got in. You make a left at the top of the Jordan Staircase and hang a left. Then you will have to ask as the rooms are poorly marked, if at all. Simply ask one of the friendly guards: G’dere Davinci or Raphael Loggia. Try to learn the words for left and right. Knowing a few Russian phrases will save you much time in Russia. Once in the Renaissance rooms I saw a sea of people queuing up to see the Davincis. They just brushed past the Della Robias, The Fra Angelicos, and Botticelli’s, to snap a picture of the Davincis. Every painting in The Hermitage is covered in glass. Most of the lighting is through the window. Not only are you fighting the glare, your eyes are fighting the reflections of passers bye. If you are looking at a painting of note, you will see a constant barrage of flashes, infra-red focusing lights, etc. I shot a video of one of the Davincis and it looked like a fireworks display. It looked pretty but it wasn’t the pretty that I had in mind. I then visited the Michelangelo and the Raphael Loggia and continued through the ages: The Renaissance, The Baroque, Dutch art (especially Rembrandt), Spanish art, and French art, up until the English art. This is the majority of the second floor, which, is the majority of the museum. You can get from the 200’s to room 300. To do more than this in one visit will test the bounds of your patience and your feet. Taking this route will give you the opportunity to see all the State Rooms. Don’t plan for them as you can’t miss them. On the second day, I had my ticket in hand. I was let in at about 10:20, and darted up the stairs to my first destination. Bliss. I had the Davincis, the Michelangelo, and the Raphael Loggia to myself. I shot a little video and then the crowds came. I bid adieu to the second floor and spent the rest of the day touring the ancient art galleries on the first floor. It was deserted and undeservingly so. This has one of the finest collections of Egyptian, Greek and Roman art in the world. There is also a fair amount of ancient Russian art, called Scythian art. This is a solid three hour tour, with a little time left over for the treasures upstairs.On the third day, we were slowed down by the ticket lady so we went straight to the third floor. Here you will see French art of the 18th and 19th century, the Impressionists and modern art. This floor, coupled with the “recovered” art taken from the Nazi’s in World War II must have more Renoirs than any museum outside the Barnes Collection. It has a vast array of Impressionist art and a slew of Picassos and Matisses. The latter is especially well represented. After two hours we descended to the second floor where we re-visited the Renaissance galleries, the Rembrandts, and the aforementioned “Recovered” art. There was also a special exhibition of Annie Liebovitz and a special exhibition of Giorgione’s “The Tempest.” Also, his “Judith” is not to be missed—nor should any Giorgione.To sum up, you can probably see this museum in two four hour visits, but be warned, you may not get to see everything you want to see. I missed some things I wanted to see but had little regret spending three, four hour days at The Hermitage. Don’t miss the Russian Museum for half of the world’s Russian art. The other half is at The Tretyakov Gallery in Moscow. Also in Moscow is The Pushkin State Museum, which is an encyclopedic museum like the Hermitage, just nowhere near as large. Its Impressionist annex is especially captivating. I wouldn’t miss it.One last thing. Finding a bathroom on the second floor is impossible. There is a restroom at the bottom of The Jordan Staircase and one on the third floor.

Fabulous- not to be missed!. Do not miss this on your visit. It is a spectacular palace, some of which has been converted to a museum.Plan to spend at least a day here. The only problem is that because it is a major tourist attraction, it gets really busy and uncomfortably crowded.You have to pay extra if you want to take photos.

Wow a must see if you go to St. Petersburg, Russia. The opulence of the rich was unbelievable to see. After going to this city, I can say I have never seen such a display of wealth in stark contrast to poor. I even think Russian wealth surpased Versailles, France. This is all part of that era, and it is amazing. They also found hundreds of impressionist paintings by the masters in the basement, which had been hidden away for 33 years to avoid being destroyed in the war, all beautifully maintained. I would venture to say there is more here than the world realizes yet. It really isn't a good idea to go by yourself, so join a tour. Be prepared, though: We went on a Holland America 2 day St. Petersburg tour and paid a large amount...BOTH days 3.5 hours of our trip were spent being driven to a souviner shop and a mall for fast food at a food court. with KFC and McDonalds..very upsetting....we came clear across the world to do that? I think not..but it is a new country in terms of tourism, so perhaps they didnt' realize we wanted authentic food and not have our time driving to an out of the way souviner shop when they were everywhere, including right outside our ship. The tour was very rushed, and we were hustled through the rooms, not being able to really see and appreciate the Monets, the Picassos...and all the other masterpieces, so be ready for that if you attach this tour to another. The traffic in this city was the worst in the world we have seen so far..more tour buses than I have seen anywhere in the world. It's bursting with people wanting to see it. The museum is a must see..skip the subway tours and such and spend the time seeing this and the other palaces.

A Classic Beauty. Our visit was with a guide furnished through our Princess cruise ship. Princess provided a Russian visa or else we would have to applied to the Russian embassy which takes quite a bit of time and money as I understand it.The Hermitage is huge, crowded and hot in summer, but it is worth it. The master paintings, the sculptures, the thrones, the ceramics, the marble all are one of a kind and exquisite. But I was most impressed with the decorations of the rooms themselves. Everywhere you see gold, precious stones, mirrors and furniture that is simply amazing. I have seen the Louvre and Versailles and the palaces of Vienna and Wurtzburg, Germany, but the Hermitage is the most eloquent in my opinion. Check it out for yourself. It is huge. You just cannot see it all. Takes AT LEAST three hours. TIP: Ask for a map in English of the museum when you enter.

A must in St. Pertersburg..........but so much to see!. The place is huge and the artifacts truly remarkable, however getting in requires the assistance of a tour guide otherwise you are lining up for up to 2 hours!Spend just 1 minute looking at all on display would take you 11 YEARS!Our guide was exceptional with an amazing knowledge base, full of antidotal stories laced with history.The space is large although it is JAMMED with people,watch you wallet, camera's are permitted in most areas, stairs are easy to climb.Its is very warm inside so leave your jacket /sweater in the bus/car.The Hermitage is a world class, one of a kind; treasure housing art which covers every Gendre. We enjoyed the visit and were very pleased we had a english speaking guide to explain what we were viewing.Saw the high spots a nd moved on!

Amazing - but plan your visit carefully. I spent 5 days in a row taking in the beauty of the Hermitage, and felt like I got to know it pretty well. In order to avoid the crowds, it is worthwile to carefully plan your visit. - It is not possible to avoid the crowds by going early, the tour groups will be earlier, since they are allowed in earlier and will head straight to the masterpieces. It is better to visit those around closing time, if you're lucky, you will be able to be alone, surrounded by Rembrandts. - There is much and much more to see than just the highlights, the Hermitage has a stunning archeological collection which is hardly visited by anyone. It is all the more interesting since it features many excavations from the caucasus, and these are not easily to be seen in other archeological museums. I would focus on what is unique for the Hermitage, in my opinion, all the Egyptian and Greek artifacts can be seen in many other museums, but the Siberian art is quite unique. It is pretty amazing to have all these big rooms just for yourself, hardly anyone visits these. - Use the toilets near the group entrance, they are quite clean compared to the toilets in the main entrance. Or even better, use the toilets between rooms 68 & 61, since they are in the area of the archeological artifacts described above and not nearly as much used as the other toilets. - If you take pictures, it is helpful to take a picture of the accompanying text. This way, you will remember who actually painted that particular work of art. - For those from the Netherlands: Become a friend of the Dutch Hermitage, earning you free entrance to St. Petersburg Hermitage. You are able to enter through the group entrance, even before official opening time. This way, you will be able to leave the Hermitage and come back later during the day, not possible on a normal ticket.

Astonishing works of art but very bad welcome & service. The place is huge and full of astonishing masterpieces and you need at least 4-5 hours to visit at least the basic works of art. As in most monuments in town, no Russians pay much higher tickets than Russians (at Hermitage you will pay 4 times more than a Russian to get in). I found, here and almost everywhere else in St. Peterburg, extremely rude and hostile guardians and receptionists. Most Russians, despite their job as front desk and ticket offices, refuse to speak any other language but Russian, including English. Also beware as most tours and signs are in Russian only. In brief, it is definitely worth a visit and I would suggest to swallow hard on service and concentrate on the masterpieces.

Very, very impressive. We loved our visit - but are not art buffs, so having a guide made all the difference. She could take us quickly to the "must-sees". Also got full value then for the history of the buildings and rooms.

St. Petersburg is unforgettable !. On August 4th & 5th 2011 we arrived in St. Petersburg on The Jewels of the Seas. We had arranged a two day tour with TJ Travels and they were at the port, waiting for us. Alla Semenova was the tour guide and Anton Ivanov the driver for our two day adventure. They were outstanding in their knowledge and friendliness. We saw The State Hermitage Museum, with Alla's guide and we were exhausted, but felt we got the best ! They were two days filled with knowledge, pictures, sites, boat ride, underground train. We felt that we got our moneys worth and then some ! At the end of the tour we felt like Alla and Anton were part of our family. When in St. Petersburg, TJ Travel is the way to see the most. If you have the chance to book with Alla Semenova, even better !!!

I'll be back in November. We visited the gallery during a boat trip from Moskwa to Pietari (as the Finns say). The Russian guide tried to bring us in thru the wrong entrance, so we lsot 20 min. Then she showed us a lot of historical objects, e.g. tools Peter I. used personalls as a craftsman. Since we had a time budget of of some 150 min for the gallery this resulted in an kind of fast forward mode thru the really important paintings of Italy, France, germany ("We go to the next romm, but before leaving just look back at the legendary painting by Duerer, which plenty of people are admiring just now.Avoid Ermitage in top season, except you get it free in ypour sightseeing package ! Just come back for a quiet, pleasant visit in November, when you might have the key rooms (almost) for yourself ...The variety of objects presented here and the weatlthof the paintings is, however, really overwhalming.

What amazing!!. Beautifull and magnificient Palace. It is very well conservated and restaured.The collection is amazing of course, is a rich collection is not only the the collection that we must see, we need to look to palace that is magnificient.It is incredible the way the workers that are in the rooms they speak to peaple very unpleasents. They should at least speak english. We are speaking about Hermitage not about a museum of a litle village.I was surprise to notice the fragile security of the museum.

Went with Riviera Travel: Excellent Guided Tour - it's amazing!. Get a local guide or failing that an audio guide. You'll not be disappointed! Also do a boat trip as you'll see it from the Neva - it's amazing!So much to see!

Truly breathtaking. The rooms at the Winter Palace were just magnificent - attention to detail and wealth of decorations could leave you over-awed. The collection at the Hermitage numbers some 3 million pieces and only small proportion of those are displayed. Yet whatever there is it will leave you occupied for days on end - time stops still in this place.Try to get there as early as possible - queues are long and groups have priority. Once inside start with the third floor that will be relatively empty at this time as groups are herded to the mandatory attractions - da Vinci and Rubens painting, and then make your way down.

buy tickets early, stay late. You can skip the long lines by purchasing tickets in advance from their online site. Also, the tour groups race through during the day, elbowing you away from the most popular art. So wander the less visited sections until about 3 when they all leave -- then you'll have a quiet and cool museum to yourself until it closes around 7.

Best museum I've ever been to.. The Hermitage is humongous. Every time I stepped into the palace, I was overwhelmed by not only the size, but the beauty of the architecture. What I liked best was the Egyptian and photography exhibit. I have always had an interest in Ancient Egypt, and I was gladly surprised to see their huge exhibit on ancient artifacts. Also, when I went, they had a special exhibit on Annie Lebowitz, the famous photographer. I had never really enjoyed photography exhibits, but this was definitely worth going to. The only thing that I didn't like about the Hermitage was how long it took to get in. The first time, I stood in line for over half an hour (on a Tuesday!). However, the next time I went, I found that when you enter the courtyard, the line on the left always moves faster. I completely bypassed the line! But believe me, it's totally worth it.Definitely bring your walking shoes. Also, if you plan on going in the summer, bring a fan (you can buy one from most of the street vendors before you enter)! It can get very hot, and there's no air conditioning. Only bring a camera if you really want to. You must buy a special pass to be able to take pictures. I did not, but I think that just looking at the beauty was enough for me. Going to the Hermitage is definitely a long visit event. My friends and I would go for three hours at a time. Personally, I visited twice, but a few of my friends went upwards of five times. I wish I would have gone more, but I saw the most important things that I wanted.Oh, and definitely find one of the information desks and ask for a map! It will help to plan out where you want to go in the museum. Whether you like Renaissance artwork, French Impressionism, or modern art, the Hermitage literally has all you could wish for!

Best Tour Guide Ever!. We arrived in St. Petersburg without a tour guide wondering what we were going to do, decided it wasn't that big of a deal....We will do this on our own! Ugh. What a mistake, the city doesn't have normal north, south, east, streets. Everything is manuvered by canals and rivers. We were lost in the first 15 minutes.A friend of a friend referred us to Alyona Malyutina, northvenice@hotmail.com Born & raised in St. Petersburg, she opened her schedule for us, arrived 15 minutes early, had a clean car & proceeded to show us St. Petersburg top to bottom. What a refreshing bit of Russia she is!!! We couldn't be more thankful for the vast amount of information & knowledge she shared with us in only one day. She is fair in price & vast in knowledge. Thanks Alyona.

Put this on your bucket list if you are an art lover!. Wear comfortable clothes and sneakers as this is going to be a long visit. We had a private guide who showed us the highlights in many of the rooms. The art collection is spectacular as is the Winter Palace. Our guide was very knowledgeable and gave us background information about the history of the palace and specfic objects in the rooms which greatly enriched our visit. I reccomend that you get a private guide if possible. Bring a camera as you are going to want to take many pictures. If you want to avoid lines our guide recommended going in Sept - Oct. The weather will be cooler but many of the people will be gone. My husband and myself would like to return to see more of The Hermitage in the future.

Must Go!!!!!. If you go during peak season, better book the tickets online and avoid the queue.I were there queuing up for more than 1 hour >"< It's no much more expensive than purchase in person. But, it takes 3 days or more to send the tickets to you. Also, the ticket machine is in Russian ONLY and give NO change!!! you have to purchase permit to take photos. And the machine doesn't allow you to buy entrance tickets and permit at once, which means you have to purchase separately -_-" There is someone to assist u in buying the tickets but can only speak RUSSIAN, which is pretty helpless. Also, go very early in the morning. I spent a whole day there. And there is no necessary of joining any tour. Just get books like frommers with you and take your time browsing all the beautiful and impressive paints

The Vatican, Louvre and Versailles - all in one. Visited this place with a private shore excursion with a company which organize group tours on one of its off days - Wednesdays. Strongly recommend that you join one of those tour company to visit on one of these off days if you can as there is no horde of people and you really have the time and space to enjoy the beauty, majesty and magnificent decor and exhibit that The Hermitage has to offer.The facility has the greatness and splendor of a king's/czar castle like what you see in Versailles in France. Then grandness and richness of elite noble living is so evident everywhere.Then they have a good collection of paintings from Leonardo, Michelangelo, Renoir, Picasso, Van Gogh and many other famous painters. The beauty is that on such off-days, we had all the time to study up close and personal such exquisite arts and appreciate every moment of it. The last time we went to the Louvre, we could not approach in the crowd even within 10 feet to see Leonardo's Mona Lisa and even at that has a fleeting 10 seconds view of it before force to move along in the crowd. The Hermitage is Grand and has a wide selection of paintings by these famous painters.Then walking along many corridors, the ceilings and walls are filled with beautiful paintings and murals similar to that you see in the Vatican. The experience we have in the Hermitage is tons better than those we had experience in the Louvre, Vatican and the Versailles. If you enjoy any of these sites, you will definitely enjoy. the experience that The Hermitage has to offer.

Bether than Louvre and Prado. Forget the crowd. Take a day, take patience, take a guide, take extra batteries, and enjoy from the ceiling to the floor everything is beautiful. Better than Louvre and Prado, you can go as close the master pieces and take pictures as you want.

Fantastic museum unfortunately in bad condition. Unfortunately Hermitage needs improvements. i've seen valous pictures exposed to the sun. The building was crowded, the rooms are hot - air conditioning is bad condition. They should sell one Van Gogh (that is under the sun, with many defects in it) and reform the building.

Of course the review is great, but just bear in mind the hordes of people. What can you say about one of the world's best art collections? It's of course amazing, but just bear in mind the lack of oxygen, the hordes of people, etc. Apparently it is much better to go in the low season (winter).

azamara journey shore excursion. I have reviewed my rather bad experience with azamara journey baltic cruise elsewhere. This is just THEIR specific 3 day St.Petersburgh. My advice: dont go. The excursion is hectic and very poorly organized. Have your seen the movie "if it is tuesday, it must be belgium?" Make it, "if it is tuesday, it must be belgium, rome and Paris all in one day".I had hope that this would be the highlight of my azamara baltic experience. It was not. It is so much cheaper and with a little effort, easier to see this wonderful complex and enjoy St.Petersburg, minus the cruise shore excursion

A real eye opener - never knew that such opulence could exist!. As part of our Baltic Cruise we enjoyed a visit to the Hermitage Museum and Winter Palace. This enormous attraction can only be viewed in small bits - it would take 12 years if you were to view every icon and painting properly. Our guide gave us a tour of the highlights. We were fortunate to go on an early tour organised by Alla Tours that allowed us entrance to the museum before the crowds came in. This meant that we were not jostled by the many thousands who throng to this attraction each day.Be aware that there are many steps to climb and that the rooms are spread over a vast area with very few seats to be had to rest your weary legs.I would not recommend that anyone considers undertaking this visit on your own - a guide is essential to enjoy the vast array of exhibits and beautiful rooms.An absolute must for anyone visiting St Petersburg.

Great collection and buildings, but over-crowded. I went to the Hermitage over the weekend, as I had purchased an online ticket valid for 2 consecutive days. First the plus side: everything is very beautiful. The buildings of the Winter Palace, the old and new Hermitage, are very impressive. The rooms are still decorated as they were in older times, and it really adds something to the visit. The collection is also excellent, offering art pieces from all times and places in the world. I had a great time there!The down side is that this museum is extremely crowded. Way too crowded. So crowded that at some point, you just want to leave (and that's what I did on the 2nd day, when room after room I encountered hordes of guided tour groups, up to 30 people in each group! That's just too much!).Do buy your ticket online before your visit. Print the voucher, and just walk through the gate on Palace Square. Ignore the line if there is one. Cross the interior court of the Winter Palace all the way to the end. Don't be scared by the huge lines of people waiting, they are waiting to buy a ticket.
