At some point you will finally see a line indicated for people with tickets. Enter the hall. Do not wait at one of the booths for tickets. Just walk around the main hall to the information desk, and that's where they will exchange your printed voucher for the actual tickets. Nothing is indicated properly there, and one might think he has to wait in the line with all other people, just don't. Walk straight to the information point which is located behind the ticket booths. That should avoid you loosing more than 1/2 hr as I did (luckily I did see that I didn't have to wait in the line outside, but I didn't know I didn't need to wait inside to exchange the voucher).Right next to the information point, you'll see stairs leading you down to the free cloakroom, which is apreciable.Another down point are people using flash to take photos. I'm sure that Da Vinci's paintings, which are more than 500 years old, appreciate that very much. The worse is that there are signs everywhere showing "no flash", but nobody seems to care.And finally, i hope that they will start cleaning the toilets more often. I rarely suffered from such a horrible smell in any museum toilets.

Clear your schedule and spend all day!. This is one of the best museums in the world. I was shocked by how massive and diverse their collection is, They have everything from a DaVinci and Michelangelo to Egyptian mummies and Roman statues. Truly mind blowing.

MARVELLOUS. I booked a two day ticket directly at Hermitage´s site and it was quite a good action , in order to avoid terible queues.As i had previously watched that amazing movie "the Russian Arch" I immediately recognized lots of those magnific rooms. Studying the map of the expositions at the site is also a good idea.What a labyrynth! My focus was Middle East , Caucasus and Central Asia expositions , but I think I have a look in much more than this. What a complete museum , dont miss it!

Online Tickets Are Actually Off-line, But.. Huge and Very Impressive Collection, Yet.. Too Many Visitors. We bought so called online tickets on Friday evening, but then we noticed that the tickets were not sold online, they needed another "approval" before being emailed to us and since the approving officers don't work on weekends, we had to buy the tickets again from the ticket boot, because we were there for Sat-Sun-Mon and the museum was closed on monday, it would be too late if we waited for the tickets to be approved and arrived. Anyway, we cancelled the online tickets with some part of it non-refunded :( The Collection is huge, if you have half a day, like we had; my personal recommendation is to start from the top floor (more recent artists of 20th-21st century) and go down (reverse of chronological order). The collections of older times are vast in number, pick the collections or milestone paintings you aim to see, and see those, as you may not have time to see all in half day (also even walking in the corridors takes time!)Very many visitors, something expected, the officers in each room are very helpful even if they don't speak English :) In summary, a MUST SEE in St. Petersburg but PLAN AHEAD your tickets (not online if it's a Thursday or Friday) and things to see inside (the website is helpful on that).

Excellent Tour of St Petersburg. We cruised to St Petersburg and had booked a 2 day tour with Alla Tours of St Petersburg on the internet prior to sailing. We had an excellent guide and extensive tour of the city, metro and palaces which had been well planned and included 2 lunches. There was so much to absorb but our guide explained the history and development of St Petersburg and Russia very thoroughly. She led us through an extremely busy Hermitage Museum and still had the original 14 of our party at the end! It is a beautiful city with so much to see, another visit is essential.J Gambold.

Huge Museum With a Smorgus Board of Historcal Items. Depending on where you are traveling from to visit here, ( Me being the United States) you may have already noticed the culture difference. It is different than getting greeted in a warmly manner, and showing you aroung the museum. They will come across as rude and unconcerned about your visit there.Therefore aside from the culture and the way customer service is represented, it was an impressive structure as well as museum. Well worth visiting at the very least to say I was in this well known magnificent structure.

Five hours is enough. It is true that will take twenty years if one has to view all the three million exhibits in the Hermitage. But I feel that five hours is enough for casual visitors like me. The initial euphoria while climbing the Jordan stair case of the Hermitage lasts for one hour and then the repetitive and monotony sets in. Even for a connoisseur, apart from his interest in a particular area, the others too would be monotonous.Most of the tourists, stay on an average for three days, so it would not be worth to put in more than five hours, when there are other places of interest and equally beautiful. I would advise to buy one day ticket online as it would save considerable time, while standing in the queue for tickets.

The Collection is Mind-Boggling. The Hermitage bears many commonalities with the Louvre. It had an amazing mix of depth and breadth in a palatial setting. For me, the deep and high-quality collection of French impressionist paintings were the highlight. There would be an entire room of works by a brand-name artist, and then, whoa! Another whole room of nothing but that artist’s work. Of the many other cool items there, the peacock clock stood out the most.Notes if you go: you have to check your bags, and they charge extra (200 rubles, over $7) for the right to take photographs. One sour note: many of the paintings were visibly damaged (such as significant cracks in the paint), perhaps from being hidden from the Nazis and perhaps from mismanagement. The Hermitage doesn’t seem that careful about managing climate control in the rooms.

Go with a personal guide. My husband and I have just returned from a cruise which included a two day stop in St Petersburg. I took the advise from other people's comments and booked private tours with Marina Wilson Tours. This was the best decision we could have made - no need to get Visas, we had the benefit of our own driver/guide, advantage of bespoke trips and, best of all, we didn't have to wait to get into any of the sites. Our guide was Sergey Shiskin who, it appears, also works independently www.petersburgm.com There was no requirement to pay in advance, nor pay a deposit.

Allocate a full day or more!. Please get an e-ticket else be prepared to stand in line for hours! For students with international student pass, admission is free (so do not stand in line). Do get an audio guide as it explains not only the artwork but also give some background of the notable artists and helps you appreciate the artwork more. Do not pass up on the Hermitage gift shop as well! They have a good collection of books and prints/postcards of the more popular paintings, most of which are not available outside of the Hermitage. I was there from 12 till closing and only managed to cover the 2nd floor (they had a special exhibit by Anna Lebowitz, amazing!) and part of the 3rd floor. Didnt get a chance to go on the excursion to the gold room tho. A re-visit is very much in order! Do note that I've not been to the lourve so this was my maiden musuem experience, wonder if musuems regulars would find this collection as amazing as I do!

Great art, terrible crowds. We visited the Hermitage as part of a cruise excursion which had the dual benefits of a guide and no waiting for entrance plus we did not have to get an expensive visa. It was crowded but the art collection is one of the best in the world. We were also struck by the beauty of the architecture itself. The Hermitage is a must see for anyone who considers themselves a world traveller. My regret is that we only had four hours; four days is a more appropriate length of time to savor the museum.

Magnificent!. A visit to the Hermitage transports you back to the days of Czars and Czarina's in Russia. The architecture of the palace itself is astounding; the rooms magnificent; and the displays of Russian artwork and period pieces rival the Louvre and Versailles. The Room of Chinese Art is amazing. I love the way they have rooms dedicated to a specific artist (Monet, Van Gogh, Renoir) or Russian region (Tibetan art, Mongolian art, Byzantium art). Russia is such a large country with a multitude of cultures and thousands of years of history. Take at least 2 days to tour the Hermitage. Better yet, take 3! It's so beautiful and the art will leave you marveling at the expanse of the Russian collection.

Museum of a different kind - truly fascinating. There are several 'must go' museums in the world - like the British Museum in London, Louvre in Paris, Cairo Museum in Egypt..then in Russia, it is the Hermitage. I have seen all the rest of the museums mentioned but none is as splendid and glamorous as the Hermitage. There is always something to entertain you or to attract your attention even if you do not know anything about art or the artist. Each chamber has its own distinctive character and style of architecture and it is never boring. You have to look at not only the paintings or sculptures but also the ceilings, walls and the floors that revealed the stories of the history (look at my photos). There are so many chambers and corridors that you will easily get lost if you did not prepare your trip well in advance or have no guides with you. If affordable, spend a little time at the souvenir shop on the G/F before you enter or after you left the exhibition chambers. There are some good quality canvas paintings (copies) of the famous art works with different sizes. As a layman, I took a look at those paintings before I entered so that I would know what to appreciate when I got inside and see the 'real thing'. I spent 500 rubles and brought home a piece of great memory. I am not a museum fan but this one is really fanscinating. I would definitely like to return when I have a chance.

Experience of a Lifetime. Not to be missed - but expect it to be crowded in "tourist" season. There is more to see than it is possible to take in - but I was thrilled to see two DaVinci's and the architecture of the place is worth the visit. The opulence of these buildings is beyond description. Truly a must see!!

Set aside a whole day... at the very least. Hermitage is probably the most beautiful museum ever, and it is enormous. To view all the art, beautiful interiors and artifacts in less than a day is simply impossible. If you don't have the time, see as much as you possibly can, making sure not to miss the Russian culture and Western European art collections, and the Winter Palace. It's a truly breathtaking place to visit.

Top 5. This is one of the top 5 musea in the world. You can reed about the museum on their website but be sure to check out the Rembrandts for sure. Tip buy a ticket and walk to the entrace, skipping the line to the ticket box altogether

Treasures were amazing, but so were the museum guards.. The treasures of the Hermitage in St. Petersburg are decadent beyond belief. It was amazing to see the gold and Amber and beautiful furniture, tiles, jewelry, art work....but alas I forgot to take some pictures there. What sticks in my mind are the men and women guarding these treasure. They were treasures themselves. Really. I'm so sorry I didn't take photos of each and every soul I saw sitting in the rooms,room after room it was their job. I wondered at the time how it felt to watch the trail of tourists tramping through the palaces of Russia. Most of them never ever smiled either. It was like a hit upside the head when I got back to our ship. I missed taking pictures of the best part. The unsmiling people of Russia. Our guide told us many were Russian widows who live on very small pensions. Yet they grabbed the brass ring, and were willing to watch and guard the treasures of Russia. Many looked like real Babushkas, and others were classy dames, with great hair and make up...some looked like really nice little ladies, wearing their best clothes, hair and make-up. It was amazing, and most of the guards are women.

Hermitage, get lost in History. The Hermitage is a must for every person visiting Saint Petersburg. Such a must that you have to be ready for a long queue to get in.The Palace is immense, and you better chose what interests you the most otherwise you might easily get lost and waste time.The visit requires several hours and can be conducted alone or with a guide.We focused on the Second Floor with the most of Russian history but some very powerful international work too.The palace interiors are impressive, Peter the First wanted to keep is name in centuries and he definitely did.A Must do but don't get nervous if you get out of it tired, your brain will thank you ;)

Awesome but pick your favorites before you go or get a guide. This museum is beyond words in terms of depth and quality, but be warned, this much depth means you can not possibly see it all in a few hours, a day, or likely even several days. Your best bet is to hire a guide that will get you by entry lines and lead you to the highlites in 3 or 4 hours and then you can revisit your favorite parts. If you decide not to go this way, spend some real time on line planning out your time there. Expect large crowds and to spend some time in line to see some of the more famous exhibits. The museum itself is in a great location near other not to be be missed sights in St Petersburg right on the Neva River.

Do not miss, but plan well. As most reviewers agree, this is a not-to-be-missed sight in St. Petersburg, a world-class (if not world's-best) museum. There isn't any one piece that is so much better than the others, but the collection as a whole is almost overwhelming. The museum is so huge (spanning four different buildings now, and seemingly expanding all the time) that without a good plan (or a good guide who knows what you are interested in) it can be a daunting task to even go inside. And, of course, the buildings themselves are of great interest. The state rooms of the Winter Palace are lovely even without the art, and the history of the palaces, their restoration, their inclusion into the museum is fascinating. I've heard that it would take 9 years to see everything in the Hermitage, and it certainly feels as if it is true, after a long day walking through the various rooms. It is definitely worth having a clear plan of what you want to see and the best route to see it, as even in June the museum was crowded with large tour groups with headsets and waving tour guides, making it hard to just wander and look at the art. Or, bypass the major stops on every tour (impressionists, Rembrandt, etc) and opt for the lesser known or less important periods and artists for a more sedate and art-museum-ish sort of experience. I love Dutch realists, for example, and the two rooms of paintings were nearly deserted, giving me time to really appreciate the various artists and pieces in the collection. You cannot go to St Petersburg and miss the Hermitage, but you should also make sure you know what you want to see and how to get there -- or you'll be frustrated by the crowds and the labrynthine corridors. Do some research up front on the collection.

Not To Be Missed, Seriously!!!. By the time I left this museum, my head was spinning with everything I saw. I don't understand why people think this is only an art museum. Yes, there's a lot of beautiful art here, cause that's what Catherine The Great (reason for the construction of this museum) wanted, but now its also very large collection of sculptures, artifacts, relics, riches and etc. from ancient civilizations/cultures all over the world. Upon entering, we walked into the Egyptian room and the first thing I saw were 2-large granite sarcophagus's on the floor and from there it just kept on getting more and more amazing. If the art, artifacts or sculptures weren't impressive enough, the architecture and ornately detailed rooms became mind-boggling in themself. You gotta remember, this building was orignally intended for royality and distinguished guests, so because of this nearly each room is a story in itself. I'm a huge history buff and no where else in the world, do I know of, can you see such a vast collection of the world's history in one place. Do get there early (no later then 10 AM) to avoid the long lines and hopefully some of the large tour groups. Also, if possible avoid taking any coats or bags with you cause this all needs to be check-in and its just another chaotic line. You really need a full day to truly appreciate and see everything there is in this very large museum, but in my opinion it more then worth it and maybe you'll leave as blown away as I was.

Important Helpful Hints. This mammoth museum is probably the largest in the world in terms of number of paintings, but that doesn't make it the greatest. Most of the paintings are by lesser artists, and some important schools are very sketchily represented. Be that as it may, here are some tips. If you are someone not that familiar with art but want to say you've been there, the usual three-hour guided tour will satisfy you. However, if you want to make sure you see certain pictures, figure out how to see the museum on your own and plan to spend most of the day there.Under no circumstances take anything that has to be checked, i.e., coats or similar items. On our visit, the coatroom became a mob scene because of a total lack of crowd control, and nothing convinces me that anyone was going to correct this situation any time soon.

Unbelievable. We loved this museum. I would have been impressed even without the exhibits, the building is wonderful. With the exhibits both my husband and myself, who each have our own individual approach and appreciation to museums, agree this one is the best we have ever seen. We bought our tickets on line and proceeded through the entry process very quickly as promised. No need for a tour guide, this is one of those places you need time to yourself.

Very impressive, full of history and arts. It was my second visit to the Hermitage. Things haven't changed significantly in years. The golden carriage is missing. I only spent a one full day at the museum - that was more than enough for me but not nearly enough to see all the sculptures, paintings and other. Each room (ceiling, floor, walls) is a masterpiece itself and on top of it there is a lot of really well preserved exponats.An important tip - buy your ticket online through http://www.hermitagemuseum.org/ and avoid a long long line to the ticket office. There is a separate ticket office (number 5) that deals with internet tickets only - this got us inside the building in about 3 minutes compared to some people who had to wait for over an hour in a line!Also, I wouldn't hire a guide but rather use an audioguide - each exposition has a number and if you are interested in a particular exhibit, you can just punch it into the device and hear all about it through the headphones. This way you can do Hermitage in your own pace and see what you really like and skip what you are less interested in.Hermitage is a must do while in St. Petersburg, even if you are not a huge fan of museums - this is far more than yet another boring museum.

Great Artwork and Magnificent Collection. There is so much to cover and we could not cover all that we wanted to on our cruise tour. The architecture, restoration of artwork, and the amazing story/history makes this the prize stop for our Baltic Cruise.While our cruise tour allowed us to move quickly into the palace, we did have to move quickly as there were numerous other tour groups as well as individuals. The history of the Palace, and indeed St Petersburg, will give you an entirely enriched perspective of Russia's Imperial history.

Stunning, but busy.... This is one of the places you have to visit before you die... It is just stunning! Even if you are not the biggest art lover you would enjoy. Beautiful interiors, decorations, furniture, exhibitions, paintings and pieces of art are countless... Be sure that you'll have few hours to see that (quickly). The best would be to have two days ticket (remember that Monday is closed). I have booked tickets through their website www.hermitagemuseum.org - it takes two days to deliver your vouchers. Then you need to skip queue and go to cashier no. 5 (don't worry, I couldn't find it as well, it's really well hidden - ask staff for help). When you enter museum be sure that you will not leave even for toilet (use these inside) because this is only 1 entry on your ticket per day (even if they tell you that you can come back in 5 minutes...). You can take photos almost everywhere, but flash is often forbidden. It is not cheap museum to visit, but definitely worth it. Absolutely great. Unfortuantely I forgot about Monday closure and I haven't seen treasury (extra fee). That must be amazing. Anyway, have a look and definitely reserve some time for the Great Hermitage. I was guest of Renaissance Baltic Hotel and their key cards allows you to skip the queue - priority entry. There is nice cafe inside with reasonable priced sandwiches and canapes as well as coffee, refreshments & mmmmmmniamy pastries...Near main entrance I have seen guy with... small young bear! Yes, bear. I thought it is not allowed even in Russia... I was wrong...

Avoid the queues - go in March. We went mid-week in March, and from joining the ticket queue around opening time to getting inside took around 20 minutes. We left when the staff were vacuuming around our feet at closing time.It isn't as "state of the art" as some western European galleries, but is truly unmissable, even for philistines like me who went to St Petersburg for the railway museum. The main hazard seemed to be the risk of getting run over by tour groups as they are marched through the galleries at high speed; far better to go at your own pace, but wear comfy shoes and accept that there is no way you'll get round it all in a day. Then go to the Russian Museum another day! The extra fees for photography were not being enforced.
Breathtaking. I ran out of words! Beautiful! I'm sorry that I did not spent all 7 days in the museum!

Overwhelming.... The best advice I could give is to plan your visit before arriving. I had not read up on the displays nor did I realize the size of the exhibits before coming to the Hermitage. I was in St. Petersburg for work and was able to get in to the Hermitage one afternoon after breaking off from my group. The museum very much reminded me of Versailles on the outside, but was very different from any other museum I have ever been in...and I work across the street from the Smithsonian museums. The fee was nominal, certainly for all there is to see. I liked the requirement to have your coat checked, was much easier to get around without the bulky winter coat (was snowing a lot outside). Outside the museum there were a set of Catherine and Peter impersonators, which seemed ubiqutous the more I got around town, as well as some guys trying to sell black market cavier (black, Beluga).I wandered the museum, which was probably not the best way to view things as I was not focused and spent a lot of time backtracking. Budget 5 hours, minimum. There are places to eat and plenty of souviners to be bought once inside.

Getting into the Hermitqge. After all my numerous visits to the Hermitage I would recommend to come in November-April - excluding school vacations (November 1-7, January 1-10, March 24-31), preferably - on weekdays. No lines for tickets - only checkrooms might be an obstacle (mainly on weekends). Remember, that first Thursday of each month is a day for entrance with free tickets obtained from the box office.During the season it is better to use the Internet ticket sale - $18 one day, $26 two consecutive days per person. Otherwise - it is better to come an hour before the official opening (by 9.30) to the entrence from Palace square to get to the courtyard from where you enter the vestibule. Those with vouchers purchased in advance - go ahead of line showing the papers to the guards.If you want to get to the Treasury (2 departments available - Golden and Diamond rooms) - it is better to find a way to do in advance. These areas are non-available for regular visitors and can be visited with special groups with the obligatory attendance of Hermitage guides. During the season, in Summer they organise tours in English - one group of 15 persons a day to each room with tickets sold only on the day of the tour, no advance purchase. Advance arrangement can be done via an agent in Russia only. This particular visit might be a highlight (like for the majority) or a failure. Please think if a big collection of jewellery produced between 4th millenium BC and early 20 century AD is of interest for youand do not believe immediately to somebody telling it is all junk.

It is overwhelming, but you will be wise to plan your visit in advance. The Hermitage is by far the most frequently visited museum in St Petersburg so if you come to visit it during the high season, make sure you book your entrance tickets in advance via their website or ask the hotel where you are staying to book the tickets for you (some hotels provide this service for a fee even if you do not book a guided tour) or, if you are determined to buy the tickets on the spot, come at least half an hour before the opening time, which is 10:30, or expect to spend up to an hour and a half lining up to the booking office.The entrance for individual visitors is from the side of Palace Square (there is another entrance from the riverside, but it is only used by organized tours). The booking offices only accept Russian rubles – no credit cards! You can either buy a regular ticket that is valid for a day and lets you see the main collection located in the Winter Palace and the three adjoining buildings, or, if you want to visit the Treasury (the gold and jewelry collection) also known as the Gold Room or the Diamond Room, there is a tickets that includes a visit to the Treasury. Important: the Treasury is a guided tour with a Hermitage tour guide, so you have to be at the meeting point at exactly the time indicated on your ticket (or, better still, 5 minutes before). There are normally just one or two English-speaking tours of the Treasury a day (and a group can be no more than 15 people), so if you do not manage to get on one of these, you will have to join a Russian-speaking tour – better than nothing if you mostly want to see things (and there are some captions with general information in English). Make sure you sign up for the right kind of Treasury, however: there are actually two of them – one (which is more popular), known as the Diamond Room, is a display of gold, silver and precious stones dating from 1000 B.C. to the early 20th century, and the other, known as “Treasury No.2”, is a display of ancient Greek and Oriental gold and jewelry. Overcoats and bigger-sized bags are not allowed inside – check them in the cloakroom downstairs (the cloakroom is free). The ticket checkpoint is equipped with turnstiles – press the bar code on your entrance ticket to the barcode reader on the turnstile, and when the green arrow shows up, push the turnstile and walk through. Remember that you can only use your ticket once, - it will not work again if you decide to walk out of the museum and then re-enter it, even on the same day.Some people are confused about the Winter Palace and the Hermitage, thinking that these are two separate sights. In fact, the Winter Palace is part of the Hermitage, and when you enter the Hermitage, you actually enter the Winter Palace. Besides the palace, there are four more buildings of the Hermitage, all joined together by roofed passages – three house the collections, and the fourth one, the Hermitage Theater, is used for performances. To find your way in the Hermitage is not as easy as you might imagine – the place is like a maze, so get a plan for free at the Information Desk next to the booking office (make sure it is in English not in Russian) or hire an audio guide in the lobby (after you have passed through the ticket checkpoint). If you do lose your way, ask the museum attendants (there is one in every room – they are mostly elderly ladies but they will speak some basic English and will send you in the right direction).If you want to use your camera inside, buy a camera permit at the same booking office where you buy your entrance ticket (no pictures are allowed in the Treasuries, though) but remember you cannot use flash for paintings. There are lots of kiosks and small museum stores that sell books of the Hermitage all over the place, but the main gift shops with the biggest choice are downstairs on the main level of the Winter Palace. The gift shops also have a big selection of souvenirs specially made for the Hermitage. The guys that walk around the Hermitage offering you books mainly sell outdated editions, so it is safer to buy the books at the official museum stores.There are a few toilets around the place (one in each Hermitage building and one at the cloakroom in the basement), but they are all downstairs on the main level. There are only two elevators (both are not very easy to find), so most people walk upstairs. The main staircase has very shallow steps and is fairly easy to climb.Generally, the Hermitage is a huge place with about three million exhibits, so if you are an art lover, leave a whole day for your visit. You can lunch at one of the two cafeterias downstairs on the main level of the Winter Palace – none of them accepts credit cards, but one (the internet café) will normally take dollars and euros. There are some ATM machines inside the museum at the entrance that you can use before you go through the ticket checkpoint.The Hermitage works until 6 o’clock p.m. on weekdays and Saturdays, and until 5 o’clock p.m. on Sundays. Monday is the regular day off.

Fabulous Museum. On a recent trip to St. Petersburg (and Moscow) I visited the Hermitage. This museum is fabulous but its size is overwhelming. The Russians have done a wonderful job in restoring the Winter Palace to its former glory. I saw the museum as part of of tour and barely made a "dent". To anyone wanting to see the splendours of this museum I highly recommend that they take their time and visit the museum on their own. If time is limited another suggestion would be to concentrate on any section of particular interest only. The Hermitage is certainly an attraction not to be missed when in St. Petersburg.

This is a must whilst in St.Petersburgh. The Hermitage Museum is certainly one of the best Museums in the world. The Art Collection alone is amazing just by itself. Then we found many rooms FULL of treasures from the four corners of the world.We booked with a tour group from our Baltic cruise and managed to arrive early in the morning. This tour was prepaid and so no hassels with finding our way around. Being September, the weather was cool and comfortable. BE AWARE that NO coats or jackets are allowed and have to be checked into the cloak room.Our tour ended at lunchtime leaving us wanting more as we really have had only a small taste of what The Hermitage has to offer.

Pure Magic. All your troubles will disappear while you wonder through this incredible museum.All the over used adjectives are bang on correct to describe this spectacular building..."awesome, breathtaking, magical" and that's just the exterior! Wait until you're inside.You'll marvel at the endless rooms of lavish spectacle. After visiting the Louvre, thisplace blows it away! Honestly need several days to explore and view the treasures.Hate to be critical but cafeteria and gift shops are a HUGE let down. Have a hearty mealoutside before spending the day inside. Enough of that... PLEASE make sure you paythe extra fee and visit the "Diamond room". Beyond belief!

An obvious must-see.. We were lucky to book the tickets online, as in June the queue to the ticket offices was about 3 hours long. This workaround has two catches, though: first, the tickets voucher is e-mailed to you not immadiately, but after 2 or 3 days, so don't wait till the last moment. Second, it's fun to fetch the tickets while you are there: you go in through the exit, waving the voucher to the security person, go to informations desk, they call some clerk in some office, you go there, they take you t yet another desk, there they take your voucher, go to the ticket office and return with your tickets. It's not very streamlined but it gets the ticket in only about 10 minutes.Inside... Well, there's lots to see, as it can be expected. Most people seem to be visiting the painting galleries (Leonardo, Rembrandt...), but there are some corners with really exotic stuff like the caucasian archaeology section. One day may not be enough to see all what's in here, so it may be sensible to buy a two-day ticket and spend both days in the Winter Palace.And if you're looking for more Russian artwork, don't miss the State Russian Museum which is not that far away.

Brilliantly beautiful! But some things to note..... Skip the audio guide. Get there early to avoid ques or buy online. Don't bother doing gold room tour - waste of money. Afternoon gets very busy.... So see what you want to early. Don't bother with ticket to take photos as no one checks it so another waste of money. Fantastics rooms - out of this world . A must see place!

The worst museum ever. Today (11th August 2010) I went to the Hermitage musem, and I must say that it is the most disorganized museum I've ever been to.First of all, at least in theory, the entrance from Palace square should be reserved to individuals, but I saw groups entering from there too, so, if one hour before the opening of the museum there is already in place a very long queue, after the opening of the museum, differently from what you would expect, the situation becomes worse and worse.It is made even worse by the fact that there are only four ticket windows, incredibly few for such a busy museum, also considering this is high season, so the result is an even longer queue.Moreover, the disposition of the ticket windows itself is completely nonsense: the initial queue is split in two and each sent to a different couple of ticket windows, but then they all get mixed up, causing a big big big mess!It would be much better to have one queue for all windows and when one of the employees is free the next one in the queue could be served. This way, if one of the employees is new or one of the terminals has some problems, there wouldn't be one queue much more slower than the others.Some of the employees can't speak English, nor they can understand the kind and number of tickets you are asking for: considering that the Hermitage is not Wal Mart and that they sell a limited number of "items" this issue should not exist at all!Besides of that, the queue is shared with Russian people, which, in order to obtain their discounts, have to show their ID, making the queue unreasonably slower.It is true that maybe most or all of these problems can be avoided by buying tickets online from their web site, but the procedure itself is not easy at all it if must be done when you are already on vacation (a receipt it sent after three days, it must be printed and taken to the "manager" or whoever it is, ...).Opening time are just ridiculous: with only seven hours and half per day, and the ticket allowing the entrance for just one day, which is the point of having 24 Km of exposition if visitors can't humanly see them? If I had chosen to stop visiting in order to eat something/going to the toilet, I would have had even less time! If one (OR MORE) room(S) is (ARE) under maintenance, they should move the most interesting masterpieces in another open room, it is completely unacceptable to lose the chance to see them! A defined clear route though the musuem does not exist: in order to see everything you must turn back over and over, because the way the maps depict the museum is quite different from the reality (close doors, stuff only access... etc).Reaching other floors is an obstacle course: expecially the third floor, because of massive restoration works currently underway, so massive that they have almost completely made invisible the main stairway (see the attached picture).There is a fee in order to be allowed to take pictures, but the majority of the most architectonally spectacular rooms are used for temporary exhibitions, so pictures are not allowed at all, and in some cases pictures are not allowed even for the permanent exhibition.The value of the collections is not at issue, but I would have expected something more, at least comparable to the other museums I have visited so far, from the organizational point of view, by one of the most famous museum in the world.

Very good - but book tickets online to avoid very long queue. A bit of a replicate of other Italian museums at times but overall, its very impressive and definitely something to see while in St. Petersburg. Only recommendation would be to definitely book your tickets online and avoid the ridiculous queues getting into the museum.

The Hermitage is so good that I travelled 20,000 kms twice to see it. The main reason I returned to St Petersburg was to see The Hermitage again. I loved it, not only the exhibits, but the beauty of the building. It is a definite must do for anyone.Tips 1.Get in line one hour before it opens in the hope that you won't have to wait over two hours like we did in the hot summer sun. There are multitudes of people and it can be noisy in some parts of The Hermitage due to the number of people there.2. Find a good Russian guide who will take you in a very small group to discover the best of the place. There are large groups everywhere and the leader usually has a flag leading everyone about, not ideal imo. (We did it on our own, but it is interesting to have a guide.)3.Entry cost 400 roubles plus 200 roubles to take photographs (a must do).4. You cannot go to the toilet after you are in The Hermitage, neither can you take your own food and eat it there, you leave your large bags in the cloakroom on arrival.5. Go to the cafe for a quick meal.6. If you get stuck in a line for a long time like us then look out for two food stalls inside the courtyard where you can buy a beer, coffee, drink and snack but you will need someone to mind your place in the line if you do this.And yes the Russian Museum only a short walk away is terrific but nothing surpasses The Hermitage.Give yourself a maximum of three days in St Petersburg, get a 4 or 5 star hotel near The Hermitage and organise a guide ahead of time to see The Hermitage, The Church of the Spilled Blood, Russian Museum, Peterhoff Palace and Catherine Palace.Enjoy.

watch out for stampedes. I visited with my family the Hermitage in mid June.Rather than comment on the art I'll just say that you can take all the pictures you like and don't need a ticket for the camera.There are thousands of visitors every day...the little old ladies can not be bothered checking every one,I think they gave up long time ago!You can buy tickets for the Gold and Treasury exhibits the same morning that you visit the museum,no problems!.But watch out for the tour stampedes,mostly Chinese,they'll storm in and out of a room with lighting speed,then you can resume quietly with your viewing.

This place makes other museums look unimportant. I have always thought that opulence that was something reserved for Indian palaces, but the 'Hermitage' is in another league for museums. As practical as 'Te Papa' in Wellington or the 'Natural History Museum' in London, but with the added interest that the building itself is a work of art. By world standards it's reasonably priced for entry.The art collections alone occupy over a hundred rooms in this vast complex, with works by almost every artist imaginable, the treasury and Faberge collections are out of this world, and then there's room after room of the more usual museum 'stuff'; mummies, bronze age axes, flint arrow heads, Bazantine pottery it just goes on and on. Unfortunately, like all large museums it's impossible to see it all, or even a large part of it, in one visit. "Museum Fatigue" eventually sets in, not tired of wandering around but the brain gets over-loaded! Certainly a reason to return to St.Petersburg. But I have no idea when the best time to visit is, early May was busy, guides said that it was actually fairly quiet - I suspect it's all a matter of luck, extra tickets for the treasury etc need to be booked well in advance.

Wow!!!. Words will not do it justice. An absolutely amazing place to visit (free to children and students!) . Packed full of culture, exhibits and paintings from all the great masters. This really is a must if you are visiting St Petersburg.

Don't miss the Hermitage!!. This is a MUST SEE in St. Petersburg. Their collection is amazing!! You are allowed to take photos in the Hermitage if you pay for a photo pass. It was very crowded the day I was there but still worth the trip! They have art from all the classical artists - Michelangelo, Monet and Renoir, just to name a few!!

Russian Museum, not Hermitage, should be your #1 priority. Hermitage is fantastic, but it's full of Western art, artists you've seen time and again in museums all over the world.Now the Russian Museum is a different story altogether. There you will find stunning artists you've possibly never heard of. And that's what you travelled to Russia for - to explore and encounter Russia. So far from disaparaging the Hermitage, I urge you to reverse your priorities, and make the Russian Museum - also conveniently located, and with much smaller crowds - your number 1 priority. Enjoy...

The Gold Room, Hermitage. My daughter and two grand-kids signed up for a St Petersburg city tour through a tour operator located in the US who then made our advance reservation for the Gold Room (required 60 days in advance) of our trip. It would honestly take five years just to see all that the Hermitage offers and I understand that only 5% of their collection is on display. The Hermitage has over a 1000 rooms and has at least 24 rembrandts, 40 Rubenes! TheHermitage was the Winter Palace of almost every tzar and tzarina to rule Russia since Catherine the Great.We were very pleased with the second floor which has a fine collection of Italian Renaissance if you wish to see lovely Leonardo da Vinci works and sculputure. There are also Picasso and Matisse pieces on the 1st floor. The patterned parquet flooring and inlaid marquetry through out the Hermitage is breathtaking! Our tour of the Gold Room was scheduled for 2pm and there were only the four of us with our Gold Room guide. As this was a private tour we were able to ask questions and received detailed answers and learned more than the guide books.Living in Florida myself, and my daughter living on Long Island we were hesitant to book our St Petersburg & Novgorod city tours directly through Russia for we did run into problems when we booked other tours directly in the Czech Republic and Hungary. We found Red October USA online and phoned to see exactly what and how they operated. We were pleased that the owner is a Russian and operates a USA based business which made it so convenient for setting up exactly what we wished to see. We have now toured in Russia several times but on this trip we arrived on a cruise ship and wanted the best city tour we could book. Being past European, Med. and Carribean cruisers we know enough NOT to book the tours offered by the cruise lines unless that is you want to be treated like cattle and herded around! We always book PRIVATE tours so we don't need to see what we don't want to see - we are alway specific as to what and where we want to go. We asked Red October to give us several hours in the Hermitage so we could see not only the main museum but also the riding stable and other apart;ments. It takes many trips to St Petersburg to see WELL all of the wonderful sites, but if this is your first and maybe only trip to St. Petersburg - take a private tour and spend MORE time in the Hermitage and Winter Palace.

Unbelievable. Diamond Rooms a must if you can get tickets. The palace is so grand and breath taking it makes if difficult to cocentrate on the art. We found a Dela robia there that was as good as anything in the Ufitzi.The Peacock clock is amazing.

attractive for western culture fans. For me it is a little bit disppointed as Hermitage is not as good as Louvre and British museum in Ancient Mesopotamis civilization.for its gallery on this side,Hermitage has few convincing displays,and this also applies for Egypt gallery.but for western culture Hermitage is really big treat.and one more thing!for student it is free!
Must see. Takes about a week if you like to see it all there. Definitely worth seeing, feeling, and experiencing.

One of the great museums of the world. We toured the Hermitage without a guide which was fun even if a little confusing. We signed up for both the gold and diamond tours when we bought our entrance tickets. Unfortunately once you enter the Hermitage you can't exit and re-enter. However the gold tour is outside of the Hermitage! We had to beg and plead with the guards to get back into the Hermitage without buying another ticket. The diamond tour which is inside the Hermitage had many of the same exhibits as the gold tour so my advice would be to just buy the diamond tour. Otherwise we enjoyed wondering the museum which is so huge that you never knew what room would be next - an elaborate palace room, Renaissance art or Greek statues. We eventually saw all of the art that we really wanted to see and ran into many other interesting exhibits. You do have to pace yourself so be sure to drop into the cafe for coffee and pastry sometimes.

Don't miss the State Hermitage Museum!. If you want to fully take in the museum, allow at least 2 days. The place is enormous and one day doesn't do it justice. Also, the audio guide is worth the extra expense. Wear comfortable shoes as there aren't many places to sit and rest. We were there from opening to closing and didn't even cover half the place.

Amazing!. Believe everything you read about the Hermitage - it is amazing, both the building itself and the art. It is absolutely huge - so do a bit of research before you go and plan out what you wnat to see. I read somewhere that if you spent 1 minute before each picec of art - it would take 15 years to get around - so a bit of planning would be time well spent.We booked out tickets online - highly recomended. So skip the queue and enter in the door on the left as you cross the courtyard - we only saw signs that this was for groups or disabled but I had read to do this and we were let straight in by the guard. then you have to battle your way to the ticket window to exchange your voucher for actual tickets. Also book for your tour of The Diamond or Gold rooms at this time - we paid for photography (the right to take pictures) when we were booking our tickets - but no-one ever asked us to show our tickets to see if we had paid this extra fee. Gold Rooms - very interesting - guide had good English. Look our for the IBM kiosks for information dotted around the museum- you can key in what you're looking for and print off a map etc. very handy.

Must see, but buy tickets in advance. We didn't and we wish we would have! Seeing how long the line was the day before, we got up early the next day and were in line before 10AM. We didn't actually have a ticket in hand until maybe 11:30. This is because things are done 'Russian Style,' which basically means 'lines are for suckers'. Seriously, with each group that were let into the ticket office, I'd say half are people who just snuck in during the rush or people who claimed that they were with somebody else already inside. What a joke!But those shenanigans aside, the Hermitage and Winter Palace are a must see and well worth seeing. We spent pretty much all day there and still didn't see everything, but were starting to get burnt out. One amazing room after another. It just keeps going and going and going. Truly remarkable. Beyond my expectations.Just do yourself the favor and get your ticket in advance so you get to see it sooner than the those poor souls waiting in line.

Hermitage, buy in advance. My husband and I took the June 2009 Celebrity Cruise line (Constellation) on their 14 day Baltic Cruise. St. Petersburg was one of our favorite cities on the cruise. It is important to note that if you do not get a Russian visa prior to going, you will not be able to get off the ship unless you book the tour excursions through the cruise line. We obtained our Visa from Visa Express in Houston, TX and it cost about $200 per person. Which was actually well worth it since the cruise line excursions were expensive. Celebrity Constellation was docked about a 10 minute cab ride from the main sites. It cost about $12 each way. However, if you walk about half a mile you can take the local #7 bus to the main attractions for about $1. Once you are by the Hermitage, you can easily walk to all the other sites. I would recommend getting rubles in advance if you are doing independent touring.I HIGHLY recommend buying your Hermitage tickets in advance from their website. The lines are VERY long and by buying them in advance, you go straight in, no wait. This saved us atleast 2 hours in line.We took a canal cruise, great photo opportunity. We read on one of these posts that Anglo Tours did English speaking tours. They were good and covered a lot of history. Their English was great. They were located off Nevsky Prospect and their first cruise was at 11am (so don't rush down there at 8am like we did).In terms of safety, we were careful. We stayed in the main areas and around people. To be honest, we felt pretty comfortable overall. People were helpful but I do have to warn you that very few people spoke English and there were no signs in English so get a good guide book with good maps. It was very easy city to get around once you are in the main area (by the Hermitage). Peter and Paul fortess was nice, reminded us a little of Tower of London. The political history museum was interesting but we preferred the ones in Budapest and Prague more. Russia's had a lot of great displays but reading the captions for all the photos and items was just a little too much. You would need a lot of time to really cover it. The Hermitage was wonderful (I am not a huge fan of art museums but this one is amazing and the building itself is worth the visit). The Church on Spilled Blood was interesting but a little expensive, if you have seen a lot of other churches, you might save your money. If you like tile mosiacs, you would appreciate the church.
Wonderful. This museum is a very great reason to visit Russia. It is a wonderful building with an incredible art collection. I think shoud be the of the purpose to visit St Petersburg.

wow. The Hermitage is one of the best museums in the world and by itself worth the visit to St Petersburg. We were told that during the summer there are huge lines, but now in April is the best time to go. Although the museum itself completely differs from other museums in the world, its the collection that matters. Hopefully they will eventually make the place have decent air conditioning.

Mind-blowing!. We visited SPB during Xmas week (ours, not theirs!) 2008. There was plenty of snow, it was quite cold but the city was not crowded with tourists. It was a great time to visit.Although there were plenty of visitors, we didn't experience any crowds or queues at the Hermitage - other than when picking up our coats at the cloakroom at closing time. The pre-exit toilet stop was a bit hectic too! We had lunch at one of the cafe areas on the ground floor before spending the rest of the day there. As previous reviewers have mentioned, we could have spent 2 days there - easily.Obviously it's a 'must-see' place - but be prepared to be blown away. Nothing I'd seen prior to the trip had quite prepared me for the scale of things. And now I have to go back to finish what I started........... Do - Check your coats etc at the cloakroomEnsure you have enough battery power in your camera and plenty of space on memory cardsPace yourself, don't rushSurrender to the majesty of it and suspend disbelief! (& pledge to remove 'OMG' from your vocab for the day)Visit the web-site before you go - preparation is the keyDon't - Try to 'do' the museum in 2hrs - you'll kick yourself laterTry to see it all - you can't & you'll get 'museum burn-out'Wear high-heeled shoes (they will issue you with hessian over-shoe/sandal things to protect their precious floors)

How We 'Did' The Hermitage in Five Hours. On Tuesday we went to THE HERMITAGE. We had purposely not walked in that direction since our arrival so as to maintain an element of anticipation! It was only a short walk from our hotel (but long enough for our daughter’s hair to freeze – she had not finished drying it before leaving!) and our first view was a classic image of the building across a snowy park. As you would expect from a world famous museum, all the facilities – ticket office, cloackroom, toilets, café, etc are very accessible and user-friendly. In February there are no queues, no crowds – we often found we had entire state rooms to ourselves. The floor plan/map provided by the museum (in English) is good, although it is still easy to get completely lost. Note that they refer to the ground floor as ‘the first floor’, the first floor as ‘the second floor’, and so on. We spent 4 or 5 hours in the museum and concentrated on the STATE ROOMS of the WINTER PALACE (marked as ‘Palace Interiors’on the plan) and 19th & 20th Century European Art. The State Rooms are all on the ‘second floor’ and while you are on this floor it is also worth seeking out two other exhibitions : tucked away in Rooms 143-146 is a collection of TROPHY ART appropriated from the Nazis at the end of WWII. It includes works by Renoir, Van Gogh, Gaugin, Degas, Manet, Monet & Cézanne. This is clearly still a very sensitive issue – the collection is not referred to on the museum plan and, unlike elsewhere in the museum, photography is not allowed. Also on this floor, in Rooms 175-187, is an EXHIBITION OF RUSSIAN INTERIORS– it consists of a series of rooms (smoking room, library, study, nursery, etc) re-creating the style of each decade from the early 1800s to the Revolution. Originally opened as a temporary exhibition in the 1980s, it proved so popular that is has remained ever since.On the ‘third floor’, in Rooms 314-350, you will find the collection of MODERN EUROPEAN ART from the 19th & 20th Centuries. It is a breathtaking collection, with a stunning range of works by Picasso, Matisse, Gauguin, the Impressionists and many others.A tip: If you can, watch RUSSIAN ARK, a film by Alexander Sokurov before your trip. Watching this film before a visit to the Hermitage really gives an added dimension and depth to your visit. Made in 2002, this film was shot on location in the Hermitage in a single, unedited take. It takes the viewer on a journey through 300 years of Russian art & history. It received rave reviews, among them, the Guardian, “Breathtaking … a cinematic love letter to the Hermitage”. Our teenage daughter particularly appreciated having seen the film – it really did enhance her visit to state rooms in the Winter Palace.

Almost overwhelming!. An incredible collection! Buy your ticket on-line at the Hermitage Museum website and avoid the lines. On line tickets also allow you to take photographs (which you can turn into the best screen saver ever!) Review the floorplans at the website to make the most of your time there. Wear comfy shoes and check coats and bags downstairs. Rent the audio tour (bring an unimportant piece of ID along, you'll need to leave something as security- I used my frequent flier miles card.) Make sure you pick up a map and take advantge of the little computerized "You are here, where do you want to go" kiosks scattered throughout the Museum. (We didn't notice them until well into our third hour and they came in quite handy for finding specific works of art) Pace yourself as best you can and have a cup of tea before you head upstairs to the Impressionists on the top floor, where I guarantee you will be amazed at the scope of the collection!

book early. This museum is an absolute must see however it gets so busy with tour groups. The museum hasn't quite figured out how to get the queues down and I was watching one tour guide who had to get twenty tickets individually for her group as she couldn't get the tickets all at once. People must have been stood for over two hours in the queue. We booked on line which allowed us to skip the queue however we still had to fight at the ticket office as there are no orderly lines! Go to the museum however ensure that you book on line will save you so much time!

No.1 reason to visit Russia!. What more can be said for this magnificent museum and its unbelievable art treasures? Simply one of the best experiences anyone can have. Here are some practical tips:- Book your tickets online! This will save you A LOT of waiting. Two-day tickets are best, as they allow you entrance to other branches of the museum as well.- Don't visit on weekends. Although we booked our tickets online, we had to wait 45 mins to exchange our voucher with the actual tickets, as the crowds were incredible ( I really wonder why they don't open more counters, people often have to wait in line for more than two hours...)- Don't visit as part of a group. You'll only see a very small percentage of the exhibits, you'll be rushed through rooms and you'll miss most of what your guide tells you.- Go prepared. It's impossible to see everything. Get a good guidebook beforehand and organize your visit before you travel according to your personal taste.Hermitage is one of the things that anyone should see in his/her lifetime.

Amazing museum!. We weren't aware of the buying tickets beforehand scheme other reviewers have mentioned, so we queued. We arrived just before opening time (which is 10.30am) and the queue was already quite long. It was 45 minutes before we actually had bought our tickets and got into the museum to start looking around, but later on in the day the queue does get longer! We were lucky as the time of day meant we could queue in the shade rather than the direct heat of the sun (it must have been at least 27C there). Once inside the museum is amazing. We went more for the architecture than the art works. We weren't disappointed either. The rooms are just amazing! A lot of them have various works of art on display, and up on the 3rd floor are rooms that feel more like art gallery rooms - plain rooms with art on the walls. There were Picassos, Monets and others in those. We were there for over 2 hours and managed to get museum fatigue as well as getting hungry. The museum cafe is very good (great cakes!).We got round the museum quite quickly really. We didn't see everything, even a whole day wouldn't do the place justice, but we were only in St. Petersburg 2 days so we wanted to see as much of other attractions as we could as well.

Scythian Gold - Don't Miss It!. First, as another reviewer has already said, buy your tickets online at the Hermitage Shop. Buy two day tickets, because it takes a day to get oriented and establish your priorities. The long line is to buy tickets. So if you already have your voucher you do not have to wait in line - at all. Move past all those people directly to a ticket counter and exchange your voucher for a ticket.When you exchange your voucher for a ticket, also buy a ticket to the gold treasure. Even though you will be rushed through much too fast and cannot take any photos, this is incredibly lovely stuff and includes the stag in mid-leap that is the logo of the museum. And on the way to the gold treasure room, be sure to see the ancient Russian exhibits on the first floor.

The highlight of our visit to St Petersburg. We were able to spend a full day at The Hermitage which we needed to see the wonderful state rooms, The Raphael Loggia and the fabulous paintings, tapestries and sculptures. We went with Russian Gateway and our guide Maria got us into the Hermitage without having to queque and took us straight to the french Impressionist gallery which we wanted to see first. We had arranged to stay after Maria had given us a 3 hour guided tour and it was good to have the flexibility to stay as long as we wanted after this. We had two breaks for food and drink at the cafe there which wasn't crowded and the tales of dreadful toilets there proved to be unfounded.

Every room is a work of art. We went on a tour of the Hermitage with Royal Caribbean which included the Gold Room. Our tour of the museum itself was very rushed, it was also very crowded. The only time we were able take our time and see everything at our own pace was in the Gold Room in which we spent about a half an hour. It is filled with treasures, including a ring once owned by "Francis Drake, a pirate". Don't know if it was worth about $33 pp more than the regular tour, however, it was nice not to be rushed through one exhibit hall anyway. I don't know how you could go to St. Petersburg and not see the Hermitage, but with the crowds it is tough to see even a fraction of the art there. If you can plan your visit around the crowds, you would experience a lot more of the museum than the rushed four hour shore excursion I went on.

Worth a visit but be warned. While a visit to St. Petersburg is not complete without a visit to the Hermitage and Winter Palace, be warned you will find more than just an impressive art collection. For my wife and I, the bad attitude and poor treatment by the employees unfortunately overshadowed our visit. In all our worldwide travels, we have never seen such dismal, rude people. They were rude, pushy, and surly. Our tour group and ourselves were yelled at and pushed several times by the museum staff. We were either standing in the wrong place or not moving fast enough for them. Our Russian tour guide got into several yelling arguments with the staff. Not what we expected in a world famous art museum.While we still encourage you to go see one of the treasures of the world, just be prepared for the people you will find there.
you want like to go to any other museums afterwards. it just has everything you have ever wanted to see!

dont stand in a queue. We went to St Petersburg to see the sights but mainly to go to The Hermitage.If you dont want to stand in line for 2 or 3 or more hours, go online to The Hermitage Shop before you leave and buy a 1 or 2 day pass (would reccommend 2 day)costs US$24 each, just print out your copy and bypass the queue.Walk past the queue (go about 10-11am and you will avoid most of the coach groups).Show your paperwork to the guard on the door, but dont go to the first counter you see, carry on a few more steps and take a rh turn.Since this counter is hidden away you get issued with your tickets in minutes.If you want to see THE TREASURES Room, book you spot as soon as possible.We didn't know and missed out.Fortunately we had seen the Moscow Faberge exhibit .It might cost you extra but when you have gone all that distance!!.Don't take anything bigger than a handbag, you will have to go through the traumas of finding the left luggage room.If you decide to do the audio tour you have to leave ID, try and find something with you name on that is not your licence, passport or credit card. We used our airline membership cards.Also there is a massive internet area near the cafe.

One of the greatest museums in the world. Anyone who has even the slightest appreciation for art will treasure this museum. I've been to the Hermitage a half dozen times, but it never ceases to impress me. The building itself is as much an artistic treasure as the masterpieces hanging on its walls. The main staircase is the most impressive entrance. It leads up to the royal chambers, many of which are still decked out in royal finery. If you've seen "Russian Ark," you'll recognize many of these spaces. Intertwined with the royal rooms are collections of great Russian and European art. You of course have to catch a glimpse of the Hermitage's most famous works in these rooms, like Michelangelo's Madonna or Catherine the Great's enormous gold mechanical clock. Usually the crowds start the thin out by the time you get to Italian sculpture or modern European art. It's easy to get tired out by such a large museum, which is a shame, 'cause there's still a tremendous amount left to see! I especially enjoyed the armor room, the ancient Roman sculpture, the Ancient Egyptian art, and the dark twisty hallways packed with artifacts from ancient Siberia and central Asia.A few tips: Although the entrance fee is rather expensive, admission is free with a student ID, and once a month there is a free admission day (although that day is also much more crowded than usual!). The museum has a nice ATM machine as well a post office that never has a queue (that's a rarity in Russia!). Don't eat at the museum cafe unless you're starving--it's overpriced and the food is terrible.

Wow. Beautiful beyond belief.. I read somewhere that the Hermitage is one of the two great art galleries in the world, and you can pick the other one yourself. I support this sentiment 100%.No trip to St Petersburg would be complete without a visit to this institution. The art collection rivals any in the world and to my mind beats the rest hands down. What amazed me is the range of works covered. One minute you can be walking through gallery after gallery of ancient sculpture, and then you find yourself face to face with 28 Picassos, then a dozen Monets, a room full of Rembrandts, a Gainsborough Lady, more Cezanne's than you could shake a stick at, a Michelangelo, a handful of Da Vincis, a wall of Raphaels, a room of Van Goghs that I never knew existed. The list goes on. It would be impossible to see everything in a day, or even two, but whatever you see you are guaranteed a delight. That the collection has this impact with no "signature" pieces (ie. there is no Mona Lisa or Birth of Venus) is testament to the quality of what is there.Of course, the greatest piece of art is the Winter Palace itself. As a gallery it is unmatched. The rooms are amazing and walking from room to room can literally take your breath away. It's also amazing to think that you are wandering around the palace that was home to the Russian Tzars for over 200 years. We were there in March and so the heat was not a problem. However, I would suggest you go early. We arrived at 11am and there was no queue, but we looked out of a window at about 2pm and people were queuing around the block.

meh,. It was a really fancy place, but I went in the summer and it was so hot (no AC inside) and crowded to the max.Some of the doors and statues inside were fantastic. Make sure you go in the morning when there are less people.
